title: Y.& R. Executive Shifts Agencies and Accounts
description: Dan O'Donnell, global account managing director for the Citibank portion of the Citigroup account at Young & Rubicam Advertising in New York, has left to become executive vice president and global business director for the Merrill Lynch account at J. Walter Thompson in New York, part of WPP Group P.L.C. Mr. O'Donnell, 42, succeeds Tom Cotton, 46, who was named to the new post of executive vice president and global business director for the Qwest Communications account.

title: What Right to Bear Arms?
description: To the Editor:

title: For Election Day, Ho-Hum Races, but a Rare Bit of Hope for Nassau Democrats
description: For the first time in a generation, Democratic candidates in Nassau County are looking forward to Election Day with gusto.

title: A Long-Absent Spanish Warrior Resurfaces at Last
description: In his multiple role as artistic director, occasional conductor and vocal drawing card at the Washington Opera, Placido Domingo has assembled a varied season that is unusually laden with novelties. The first is ''Le Cid,'' Massenet's spectacularly scored and vocally demanding opera, which opened tonight at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. In a week the company is adding Carlisle Floyd's ''Susannah'' to its fall repertory, and later in the season it will offer Bellini's ''Puritani'' and Handel's ''Julius Caesar.'' These last three are from that netherworld where operas dwell when they are no longer true rarities but not yet repertory staples.

title: Relieving Road Congestion Again on Colorado Ballot
description: As one of the fastest-growing states in the country, Colorado has the traffic problems to prove it. On any given day, almost any given hour, highways are clogged and tempers are frayed. Arriving late has become a way of life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUTTERPERL, MURIEL
description: MUTTERPERL-Muriel. On October 31, 1999, after a long illness at the age of 79. Beloved wife of the late Martin; devoted mother of Donald and Nancy Mutterperl, and William and Nancy Mutterperl; adoring grandmother of John and Heather, Jeffrey, Matthew and Emily, and Adam; great-grandmother of Noah; dear sister to Shirley Jacobs and the late Janice Nick; devoted friend and companion of Harvey Silverstein. A woman of great strength and courage with boundless love for those whose lives she touched. Family will receive friends Monday, 7-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Funeral service at Frank E. Campbell, Tuesday at 9:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to your favorite charity would be appreciated.

title: Tennessee's Quick Start Sends Rams to First Defeat
description: In the final seconds the unbeaten St. Louis Rams had the ball and the Tennessee Titans' defense was on the field mixing its strategy, trying to protect a 3-point lead. The other Titans stalked up and down the sideline, back and forth. They had twisted faces, scary looks. Another desperate Titans finish was unfolding.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Friday about House approval of an across-the-board spending cut misidentified the Democratic representative from Kentucky who voted for it. He is Ken Lucas. A correction in this space on Saturday misstated the party affiliation of the representative who was named erroneously in his place. That representative, Frank D. Lucas of Oklahoma, is a Republican.

title: Norwegian Diplomat, Vital to '93 Oslo Pact, Tries for Encore
description: For the last week, Terje Roed-Larsen, a Norwegian diplomat known for enduring patience and a passion for finding peace in the Middle East, has juggled appointments in Gaza, Tel Aviv and Jerusalem, testing the mood.

title: EGYPTIAN JET, CARRYING 217, PLUNGES INTO THE ATLANTIC; CAUSE OF CRASH IS UNKNOWN
description: An Egyptian jetliner bound from New York to Cairo overnight with 217 people aboard plunged suddenly into the Atlantic southeast of Nantucket Island 33 minutes after takeoff early yesterday. One body and some debris but no survivors were found in an exhaustive daylong search, and the disaster's cause was not immediately known.

title: Apres Superstars, First Race Of the Season Is Ho-Hum
description: The World Cup skiing season had an early start over the weekend on a glacier in the French Alps. It kicked off a season that will lack major competitions and some of the sport's biggest names.

title: For Muresan, the Joy Is Just Being Able to Play
description: The 6-foot-10-inch 14-year-old picked up the orange ball and glared at the rim. The concept of tossing the basketball into the cylinder intrigued him, and since his height put him so close to the hoop, he thought making a basket would be easy.

title: Behind a Grisly Confession, the Torn Lives of Colombian Children
description: Now that Luis Alfredo Garavito has confessed, the Colombian police and news media reports are describing him as a cunning serial killer, a glib predator and a ''solitary sadist.'' But it is also clear that, whatever his personality traits, Colombia's deepening social disintegration provided the perfect environment for such crimes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHBERG, IRVING
description: HOCHBERG-Irving. Devoted husband of Ellyn Seifert. Loving father of Diane Greer and Beth Hochberg. Dearest brother of Harriet Kushins and Barbara Resnicoff. Cherished grandfather of Ian and Samantha Greer. Services 11:15 AM, Monday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: A Plan to Rebuild Bridges Widens Gap on Aid to Serbs
description: Over strong American and British opposition, France and Germany are backing a European Union plan to aid Yugoslavia by building a temporary bridge over the Danube and clearing the wrecks of the bridges bombed by NATO earlier this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTINEZ, JULIO
description: MARTINEZ-Julio. By his life, Julio Martinez has set an example for all of us of how to advocate for the poor, the addicted and the disenfranchised. His voice may be silent, but his example will never be forgotten. Sincere condolences to his wife Judy and to the Martinez family. Father Coleman Costello Executive Director, Walk the Walk

title: Microsoft's Lobbying Abuses
description: For at least four years, Microsoft has deployed a legal team to battle the Justice Department's antitrust investigation and lawsuit. The company has also waged a lavish public relations campaign to persuade Americans that it is being unfairly targeted and punished for its success in producing software that consumers want. These are standard practices for businesses under attack. But this year the software giant overstepped the boundaries of legitimate opposition by lobbying Congress to reduce the proposed budget of the Justice Department's antitrust division, a step tantamount to punishing the department for pressing the antitrust case. Congress should not go along.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, ABE
description: GOLD-Abe. We will miss our dear Uncle and send condolences to his beloved Honey. Marilyn Farber Jacobs Alan Farber Janice and Stash Jacobs Tami, Michael and Scott Farber

title: The Fast Growth of a Very Slow Movement
description: The universal symbol of running has always been the winged foot, an embodiment of the pursuit of speed.

title: For Bush, an Adjustable Speech Of Tested Themes and Phrases
description: If you happened to be at the Holiday Inn here on this prematurely wintry morning, you heard Gov. George W. Bush of Texas make the self-effacing observation that his decision to marry his wife, Laura, was probably wiser than her decision to marry him. (Cue the laughter.)

title: As if by Decree, Woods Wraps Up Yet Another Title
description: Through the sadness and the symbolism, the extraordinary run of Tiger Woods continued today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUSTMAN, MARIANNE DELANEY
description: BRUSTMAN-Marianne Delaney. Of Stuart, FL, and Mamaroneck, NY, and former longtime resident of Larchmont, NY, died Saturday, October 30. She was 61. She is survived by her husband Leonard W. Brustman Jr. and by her daughters Suzanne Montanaro (Dr. Joseph) of Wyndham, NH, Joanne Brustman of NYC, Kathleen Rasor (Richard) of Larchmont, NY, and Karen Brustman of Red Hook, NY. Daughter of the late T. Ronald Delaney and Julia Coye Delaney. Mrs. Brustman is also survived by her brothers T. Gerald Delaney of Santa Fe, NM, and Michael C. Delaney (Charlotte) of Tequesta, FL, and sisters Sharon D. O'Connell (John) of Atlanta, GA, and Susan D. Cline (John) of Scottsdale, AZ. She was predeceased by her sister Sheila D. Griffin (Dr. William) of Lincoln, NE. Five grandchildren also survive, Zachary, Emily, and Paige Montanaro, and Drew and Ryan Rasor. Visiting will be Monday, 7-9 PM, and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY. Mass Wednesday, 10 AM, at St. Augustine Church in Larchmont.

title: Don't Give Us Little Wizards, The Anti-Potter Parents Cry
description: Whenever Margaret Cusack opens ''Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone,'' her fifth-grade class at Ledgeview Elementary School in this Buffalo suburb breaks into cheers. As the teacher pauses at chapter's end, the students beg for more. If the bell rings, they refuse to budge.

title: Four Leaders Of Movement Are Charged By Beijing
description: The Chinese government today formally charged four of the top leaders of the banned Falun Gong movement, immediately using new sections of the country's criminal law approved by legislators on Saturday.

title: Offerings of Equity Set for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHEAR, PETER JOHN
description: SHEAR-Peter John. Memorial service Wednesday, November 3, 5:30 PM, at The Unitarian Church of All Souls Chapel, Lexington Ave. between 79th and 80th.

title: Cartoon Bodies With Real Talking Heads
description: In the timeless tradition of ''Rocky and Bullwinkle,'' HBO's ''Happily Ever After'' series of animated fairy tales zooms over the heads of children, gleefully playing to their parents with tongue-in-cheek casting. Tomorrow brings the series' highlight: a wickedly funny election saga that updates ''Chicken Little,'' with enough real-life political voices to make the bookers of ''Meet the Press'' faint with envy. Some are cast so close to type that the roles seem like sly cameos.

title: Trying to Reach a Lover With a Telephone as Enemy
description: In prospect the double bill of operas to librettos by Jean Cocteau presented by L'Opera Francais de New York on Wednesday evening at the Kaye Playhouse seemed welcome especially for the rare opportunity to see Darius Milhaud's miniature three-act work ''Le Pauvre Matelot'' (''The Poor Sailor''). But as fine as that experience turned out to be, Jennifer Ringo's performance in ''La Voix Humaine'' (''The Human Voice''), a more familiar work by Poulenc, proved more memorable.

title: Congress Oversteps
description: To the Editor:

title: Citibank, Breaking Barrier, Will Open Branch in Israel
description: Breaking into a long-protected local market, Citibank today became the first international bank authorized to set up a full-service branch in Israel.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Signatures on Cyberspace's Dotted Line
description: What began as a seemingly simple attempt to stimulate electronic commerce by giving so-called digital signatures the legal weight of their ink-and-paper counterparts has erupted into a partisan political battle in Congress that opponents fear could wipe out some basic consumer protections.

title: An Aircraft With a Good Record, but a Carrier With Security Failures in Its Past
description: The Egyptair Boeing 767 that crashed this morning was a relatively new model with a good safety record, operated by an airline with extensive international experience and relatively few operational problems, although some horrible security failures.

title: Cyprus Company Buys 9% Stake in Lukoil
description: A 9 percent stake in Lukoil, Russia's largest oil company, was sold on Friday to an offshore company thought to have close ties to Lukoil management.

title: Peter Deflects Opposition
description: Deflecting passes and blocking kicks has become something of a specialty for Giants defensive tackle Christian Peter, who deflected the Philadelphia pass that teammate Michael Strahan intercepted and returned for the winning touchdown in the Giants' 23-17 overtime victory over the Eagles yesterday.

title: Protecting Patient Privacy
description: With Congress deadlocked on how to protect medical privacy, the Clinton administration has taken an important but incomplete first step in addressing the problem by proposing new federal regulations. Under the 1996 Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, Congress was supposed to pass a medical privacy law by August 1999. Because Congress failed to meet that deadline, the administration is required to develop regulations. The issuing of administrative rules, however, does not diminish the need for Congress to pass comprehensive legislation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, MARSHALL
description: LEVIN-Marshall. On October 25, 1999. Age 72. A cherished friend whose spirit will live in our hearts forever.

title: Family Values, Applied
description: To the Editor:

title: Hussein's Worst Enemies Meet, But With Little Meeting of Minds
description: Even in exile, Iraq's fractious opposition groups have spent more time divided against one another than uniting against their common enemy, Saddam Hussein. But with the United States acting as midwife, more than 300 of their representatives converged on New York City over the weekend to try to forge a credible alternative to the present dictatorship in Baghdad.

title: Motorola to Offer a Chip That Can Support a Variety of Cell-Phone Standards
description: With an eye toward the convergence of the Internet and next-generation digital cellular networks, Motorola plans to announce a new chip design on Monday that is meant to support a wide range of cellular telephone standards while offering more computer-like features.

title: Oppression of Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SIMON, BERNARD E., M.D.
description: SIMON-Bernard E., M.D. Mount Sinai School of Medicine and The Mount Sinai Hospital of Mount Sinai NYU Health will hold a memorial service to mark the passing in August of our dear friend and esteemed colleague Bernard E. Simon, M.D., Clinical Professor of Surgery Emeritus and internationally-renowned plastic surgeon who was associated with Mount Sinai for more than 60 years, and one of three physicians who donated their services to a group of severely disfigured atomic bomb survivors known as the Hiroshima Maidens, who underwent reconstructive surgery at Mount Sinai. Family, Trustees, faculty, staff, students, friends and admirers are invited to attend at 5PM Wednesday, November 3, in the Hatch Auditorium, Guggenheim Pavillion, Fifth Avenue at 100th Street.

title: Pimco to Sell A 70% Stake To Allianz
description: Allianz A.G., the European insurance giant, agreed today to buy 70 percent of Pimco Advisors Holdings for $3.3 billion, making it one of the world's 10 biggest money managers and giving it a platform for further expansion.

title: Science Makes News
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Bush's Campaign Speech
description: Following are excerpts from a speech that Gov. George W. Bush of Texas delivered in Fargo, N.D., last Thursday. Its basic language and themes are repeated in most of his campaign speeches.

title: Editors' Note
description: Starting today, close readers will notice a few changes in The Times's spelling, capitalization, abbreviation and punctuation practices. Most noticeably, official titles are lowercase except when they directly precede names (''the secretary of defense,'' for example, no longer ''the Secretary of Defense''). In other changes, ''a.m.'' and ''p.m.'' are no longer capitalized in clock times; ''federal'' and ''government'' are also lowercase when they occur outside organization names.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHLACHTER, HELEN
description: SCHLACHTER - Helen. Darling Mom, five years gone but with us constantly in love and spirit. Susan and Kare

title: Turning Up the Volume on AIDS; Agency's Shock Tactics Bring Results, and Criticism
description: In a warehouse basement with low ceilings and exposed, wheezing pipes that made it the perfect place to plot subversion, the leaders of Housing Works mapped out the group's next act of civil disobedience. Seated around a square conference table, smiling at the delight of playing naughty, they set the ambush for a Friday in November and timed it to disrupt Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's weekly cabinet meeting.

title: House Panel Says It Will Release F.B.I. Notes in Fund-Raising Case
description: A House committee whose chairman, a Republican, has accused the Justice Department of ignoring questions of illegality in connection with the Democratic Party's fund-raising efforts is expected on Tuesday to release the F.B.I.'s notes of its interrogation of John Huang, a major figure in the 1996 campaign finance scandal.

title: Seeing Anew In a World Of Light And Darkness
description: Henry Grunwald can hardly see the fragile little horse (circa 400 B.C.) from southern Italy on an end table in his Park Avenue apartment. He can barely discern the delicate Klimt line drawings kept in the hallway out of direct light. He can still enjoy the shards of ancient pottery laid out on a gleaming table, by touching them, and the inlaid glass eye from ancient Egypt.

title: Accounts
description: * Sxsportsmed.com, Westport, Conn., an online sports medicine content and e-commerce company, to McCann-Erickson Consumer Health, New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., to handle its first account.

title: Ewing Takes a Step Toward His Return, With Many to Go
description: Allan Houston was shooting at one end of the court and Latrell Sprewell was working on his free throws at the other end, the last two Knicks working out, when Patrick Ewing rushed through. He pulled his jacket on as he strode for the exit, his eyes fixed on door, oblivious to the players on the floor and the reporters trailing him.

title: Hillary Clinton vs. Giuliani: Poll Finds Few Undecided
description: One year before the election for United States Senate, a remarkably small number of New Yorkers say they are undecided in a contest between Rudolph W. Giuliani and Hillary Rodham Clinton, suggesting the advertisements, speeches and assaults that are being readied will be aimed at a scant few hundred thousand voters, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: On Test Ban Treaty, Reopen the Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: One Hope for Nigeria
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEDER, PAULA (PEPE)
description: FEDER-Paula (Pepe). On October 28, 1999 at age 92. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Loving mother of Jay and Ellen Feder. Cherished grandmother of Robert, Michele, Maddy, Noelle, Harold, David & Stephane. Adoring great-grandmother of Stephen, Aaron, Jackson and Jessica. Private services and interment were held. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale, 5901 Palisade Avenue, Riverdale, NY 10471.

title: Suffolk Republicans Scarred, But Not Humbled, by Scandal
description: Against a backdrop of scandal, Felix J. Grucci Jr., the supervisor of Brookhaven, is facing a tough challenge from a former New York City police sergeant, Thomas Oberle, a Democrat who promises to end decades of one-party rule.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMBROS, LAMBROS J.
description: LAMBROS-Lambros J. On October 29, 1999, at age 64. Loving father of John F. Lambros and Olivia W. Lambros. Devoted son of Niki and the late John Lambros. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, 5-7 PM, and Wednesday, 10 AM-12 noon. Funeral services at the Greek Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74 St., Wednesday, 2 PM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to Norfolk Library, PO Box 605, Norfolk, CT 06058.

title: Congress Oversteps
description: To the Editor:

title: This time it's Interpublic doing an internal merger to add another giant to Madison Avenue.
description: FOR the second time in less than two months, a big merger reshaping Madison Avenue is a result of an internal realignment rather than an acquisition or takeover.

title: 5 People Are Shot to Death In 2nd Weekend of Violence
description: Five people were slain during a particularly violent 14-hour stretch of the Halloween weekend, including the owner of an auto repair shop who was shot to death when he tried to stop a robbery at a Brooklyn grocery store where he regularly shopped.

title: New Things to Fear From an Old Type of Madman
description: DESTROYING THE WORLD TO SAVE IT

title: A Prize for Brilliant Play For an Australian Master
description: One of the world's great player-writers died on Wednesday. Dick Cummings of Sydney, Australia, was 67, and had been battling pulmonary fibrosis. His compatriots considered him the greatest Australian-born player of all time, just behind Tim Seres, his Hungarian-born partner, and his bridge columns in The Sydney Herald were lively, intelligent and popular. He served the game with distinction in many ways.

title: Cyclone May Have Killed Thousands on India's East Coast
description: More than two days after a cyclone of monstrous power churned across the Bay of Bengal into India's east coast, as many as a million and a half people are homeless, hundreds of villages in one of the country's poorest states have been washed away and tens of thousands of survivors are camping along roadways without adequate food or water. The death toll is unknown, but officials are guessing it is in the thousands.

title: MORE  ON  THE  CRASH
description: FOR NOW, A MYSTERY -- Moments after the jet was lost, the hunt for debris and answers began. Page A18.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELAN, HILIA D.
description: ELAN-Hilia D. Age 85, of Floral Park, died October 29. BA University of Michigan, MA Columbia Teachers College. Talented painter, musician, gardener, family historian. She loved to argue politics. We will miss you always. Memorial Sunday at 3 PM, at home. Your Daughters Susan and Nancy Grandchildren Ryan and Emily

title: What Right to Bear Arms?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, JULIUS, M.D.
description: LEVINE-Julius, M.D. October 30, 1999. Husband of Maisie (nee Gordon) of Cherry Hill, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Father of Dr. Stephen (Rhea) Levine. Grandfather of Elizabeth Levine (Robert) Kennedy, Dr. Michael (Melissa) Levine and Dr. Zachary (Jennifer) Levine. Great-grandfather of Zoe Kennedy and Benjamin Levine. Private graveside services were held Sunday. The family will be at the late residence. For further information contact Platt Memorial Chapels, Inc., Cherry Hill, NJ.

title: Cutting Ethical Corners in the Name of Science, Then and Now
description: ''Where is it all leading?'' asks the out-of-work English lecturer played by the sterling Daniel Gerroll in Shelagh Stephenson's engrossing and beautifully mounted ''Experiment With an Air Pump.''

title: Compressed Data; Revamped Britannica Site Is Swamped by Demand
description: The maiden voyage of the free Internet-based version of Encyclopaedia Britannica is shaping up like the Encyclopaedia Titanica.

title: Essay; Running Huge Risks
description: Americans are unaware that Congress and the president have just agreed to put us all at extraordinary financial and personal risk.

title: Judge Decides Against Forcing Reporter to Disclose Materials
description: A judge has declined to order a reporter to provide prosecutors and defense lawyers with notes and tape recordings of an interview with a defendant in a racially charged murder trial.

title: A Blind Pop Tenor Takes On the Operatic Stage
description: There were crestfallen faces throughout the audience at the Detroit Opera House on Friday night as Andrea Bocelli made his North American opera debut in the title role of Massenet's ''Werther'' with the Michigan Opera Theater.

title: Treasury Sales for Week Involve Only Bills
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: On Test Ban Treaty, Reopen the Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: City Shaken by Reports of School Shooting Plot
description: Carl M. Henderson and his girlfriend had been looking forward to their first high school homecoming on Friday, but their plans were dashed when city officials accused some of their classmates of planning a violent act at the school.

title: Mahanambrata Brahmachari Is Dead at 95
description: Mahanambrata Brahmachari, a soft-spoken Hindu scholar who offered early and important intellectual encouragement to the Roman Catholic monk and writer Thomas Merton, died in Calcutta on Oct. 18. He was 95.

title: Media Talk; Comings and Goings At Conde Nast Raise In-House Questions
description: Imagine that the gleaming new Conde Nast building in Times Square is a giant cocktail shaker, and rumors and speculation are the ingredients. Put it this way: S. I. Newhouse Jr., the chairman of Conde Nast and its parent, Advance Publications, is mixing one mean martini.

title: Bargain Basement Is a No-Win Deal
description: The season ticket-holder, an endangered species at tatty Nassau Coliseum, requested anonymity. What with the starless roster, the reviled ownership and the inevitable specter of a sixth straight season in playoff Siberia, being an Islander fan from nearby Lynbrook, N.Y., is nothing to brag about.

title: Overpriced Medications
description: To the Editor:

title: East Timorese Celebrate in Their Newly Freed Capital
description: East Timor began its rebirth today with a huge and solemn religious procession down the waterfront road where just hours before tanks had escorted the last departing Indonesian soldiers to their ships.

title: Coke's New Pricing
description: To the Editor:

title: One Dictator At a Time
description: The efforts in Spain and Britain to bring Gen. Augusto Pinochet to trial for human rights crimes in Chile should be hailed not only by the millions around the world who have been persecuted for their ideas, but all who refuse to accept that democratic customs and culture are the exclusive province of a few select countries. There are those who question Spain's decision to charge General Pinochet in its own courts, as well as Britain's cooperation in holding him for extradition. But their arguments do not stand up to serious scrutiny.

title: Victor Van Bourg, 68, Defender Of Organized Labor in Court
description: Victor Van Bourg, who has been called the West Coast king of union-side labor law, died on Tuesday at San Francisco International Airport. He was 68 and lived in Berkeley, Calif.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: The New Right in Europe
description: Last month saw election surges for anti-immigrant far-right fringe parties in Austria and Switzerland. The Swiss People's Party, led by the industrialist Christoph Blocher, will now have the second largest parliamentary bloc in Switzerland's lower house of Parliament. It can now change the shape of Switzerland's governing coalition. In Austria, the Freedom Party, led by the more dangerous and charismatic Jorg Haider, took second place in parliamentary elections and may become part of the government.

title: E-Commerce Report; All that some retailers want before Christmas is a functional site.
description: THE e-commerce train is about to leave the station for the second meaningful Internet shopping season, and when it does, plenty of disappointed retailers will still be standing on the platform.

title: INSIDE
description: High Toll in India Cyclone

title: Little Solace for Families United by Loss
description: Hatem Ayad said the Muslim prayers with his father-in-law at Kennedy International Airport early Sunday morning before putting him on the Egyptair flight for Cairo. Then he went home and went to sleep, content that their first visit in three years ended on such an intimate note.

title: Fearlessly Taking a Fresh Look at Revered Artists
description: Most of us cultivate all the ways and means we can to prove that our tastes and opinions are genuinely distinctive. One of the best ways for a critic to do this is by writing about the lesser lights in a field -- the minor, the overlooked, the underappreciated. You have the pleasure of saying something fresh if only by default; since almost no one has written about that artist, whatever you say sounds original.

title: Coaxing the Smile That Sells; Baby Wranglers in Demand in Marketing for Children
description: A typical day for Melanie Sawyer involves singing ''Itsy Bitsy Spider'' a dozen times, wiping away drool from wet chins and chasing after the occasional toddler who has had enough. Sally Nachamkin has a full repertory of routines, and always brings her puppets and props -- so many that when her son was a child he thought his mother worked as a clown.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RIKER, JOHN L.
description: RIKER-John L. To commemorate the first anniversary of his death, there will be a memorial service Wednesday, November 3, 1999, 4:30 PM, St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 84 St. & Park Ave., NYC.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Motorola Chip to Support Many Cell-Phone Standards

title: Kaplan Thaler Group Gains Insurance Client
description: The American Family Life Assurance Company in Columbus, Ga., known as Aflac, has awarded the creative and strategic parts of its account, with billings estimated at $30 million to $40 million, to Kaplan Thaler Group in New York, a unit of MacManus Group.

title: Reseeding Ivy: Columbia on Comeback Trail From Troubles
description: Columbia University is on a roll.

title: William Wilson, 51, Co-Author Of Witty Primer for College Grads
description: William Wilson, an editor and a co-author of ''An Incomplete Education,'' a general reference book addressed to college graduates who felt their education was inadequate, died at his home in Greenwich Village on Oct. 18. He was 51.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERGER, PAUL
description: GOLDBERGER-Paul. Of Jericho, NY, on October 30, 1999, at age 77. Beloved husband of Anita. Loving father of Irene, Diane and Fred. Devoted grandfather of Ana, Jeremy, Andy and Robbie.

title: College Freshman Lifts His Sport Into the Era of the Quad
description: Can five revolutions be far behind? Not with Timothy Goebel, the first man to land three quadruple jumps in official competition, on the hunt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBSON, ROBERT
description: GIBSON-Robert. On October 28, 1999. Beloved husband of Maria. Loving father of Alexis Minder and Robert M. Gibson. Adoring grandfather of Alexander Robert Minder, Andrew C. Minder and Tristan C. Gibson. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, 10 AM, at Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church in Larchmont, NY.

title: Parties Closer Than They Seem In Budget Fight
description: As President Clinton and the Republican-controlled Congress begin final budget negotiations this week, the combative debate and expected vetoes obscure a fundamental reality: the two sides have only modest differences over how much to spend.

title: Why Three Never Works, Anywhere
description: To the Editor:

title: Compressed Data; Chap Stick Chat And Other Connections
description: Got the shakes for some lip balm? Try the Chap Stick Addicts support group on sixdegrees.com.

title: Mexican Runs on Both Change and Stability
description: After a recent campaign speech, Francisco Labastida Ochoa slid behind the wheel of a Chevrolet Suburban, roared onto a two-lane highway and accelerated to 100 miles per hour.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RULNICK, DORIS
description: RULNICK-Doris. November 1, 1992. In loving memory always. Your dear daughter, Joyce

title: Corrections
description: An article by Allen Barra in the Week in Review on Oct. 17 about the origin of the Four Horsemen metaphor in Notre Dame football carried an incomplete credit. It was excerpted from the book ''American Greats,'' edited by Robert A. Wilson and Stanley Marcus, being published this month by PublicAffairs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGER, CHARLES
description: HAGER-Charles. Partner at Dewey Ballantine. Past Chairman, New York Lawyers for the Public Interest. Vice President, Downtown Athletic Club. Vice President, North Shore Committee Against Thermal and Nuclear Pollution. Greatly missed by wife Nancy; sons Eric, Tim, Jonathan, Wayne, Craig; daughter Anne; brother Bo; and grandsons Charles, Winslow and Thomas. Donations to Nature Conservancy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, MICHAEL LEWIS
description: ALLEN-Michael Lewis. Age 61, on Saturday, October 30, after a short illness. Devoted husband of Beverly; adored father of Nancy Markhoff, Richard, and Jeffrey; and father in-law of Michael Markhoff, and Mari Korper Allen; beloved grandfather of Adam and Abigail Markhoff. Brother of Leonore Schwartz. Memorial service to be held on Monday, November 1, 11:30 AM at the Clinton Inn, 145 Dean Dr., Tenafly, NJ, 201871-3200. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in his memory to Council for a Liveable World, 110 Maryland Ave., N.E., Washington, DC 20002 or the Calvary Fund, c/o Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Rd., Bronx, NY 10461.

title: CD Software Said to Gather Data on Users
description: RealNetworks' popular RealJukebox software for playing CD's on computers surreptitiously monitors the listening habits and certain other activities of people who use it and continually reports this information, along with the user's identity, to RealNetworks, said a security expert who intercepted and examined data generated by the program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAGORIN, SIDNEY N.
description: ZAGORIN-Sidney N. 84. Of Monroe Twp., NJ, on October 30, 1999. Husband of 60 years of Sylvia R. Kifferstein Zagorin. Father of Audrey and Ira Whitman and Howard and Marilyn Zagorin. Grandfather of Lynne and Dan Solender; Eden and Andrew Whitman, Randy and Jodi Zagorin. Great-grandfather of Ethan and Hazel Solender. Service 11:45 AM Monday, Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, Cranbury Rd. at Evergreen Boulevard, East Brunswick. Memorials to Alzheimers Assn., 299 Cherry Hill Rd., Suite 305, Parsippany, NJ 07054 or Temple B'Nai Shalom, PO Box 957, East Brunswick, NJ 08816.

title: Schwab to Offer Rich Clients Access to Private Offerings
description: Now that anybody with an online trading account has a shot at those coveted first-time stock offerings, what do brokerage firms have left to offer exclusively to the rich?

title: Freehold, the Sequel
description: To the Editor:

title: The Big City; Cut Taxes? Not So Fast, Locals Warn
description: COULD you use $10,496? That's what the average household in New York State would get back through the tax cuts approved by Congress, according to the Tax Foundation, a research group in Washington. Because so many New Yorkers, including middle-class ones, are in high tax brackets, the average windfall in New York would be $3,000 higher than in the rest of America.

title: Information, Please
description: A Message to Our Users:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIDDELL, DONALD MACY
description: LIDDELL-Donald Macy. The Memorial Service for Donald Macy Liddell will be held at 12 noon Wednesday, November 3, at Saint James Church, Madison Avenue at 71st Street.

title: Odessa Journal; An Aged Beauty Gets a Face Lift From a Geologist
description: He was just a geologist. She was a grande dame, the celebrated epicenter of cultural life in a beautiful, if faded, seaport. As he entered his prime, she was leaving hers, a web of crow's-feet splintering her lovely face and her graceful frame slowly settling southward.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGNER, ELEANOR (NEE LANGER)
description: WAGNER-Eleanor (nee Langer). Devoted mother, grandmother, wife. Died October 31, 1999. Services Temple B'nai Israel of Elmont, Elmont NY, 2 PM Monday, November 1. We will miss her.

title: 2 Big U.S. Law Firms Announce Merger
description: The law firms of Rudnick & Wolfe and Piper & Marbury agreed to merge over the weekend, broadening their areas of specialization and geographic reach.

title: Fields Hold Answers, Not the Many Polls
description: There were no major upsets. Every team in the top 10 that was supposed to win did so. The nicest thing to come out of this college football weekend was the resurrection of one of the most memorable names in sports: Sonny Sixkiller.

title: Outside the G.O.P.'s Big Tent, Hoping He's Let Back In
description: SENATOR ROBERT C. SMITH, newly returned from the campaign trail, sat in his spacious office the other day and reflected on the importance of not being a thin-skinned grudge-holder.

title: Rangers' Offense Continues To Sputter
description: It took a tour de force from Brian Leetch for the Rangers to earn their first point in five games on Saturday night. Now if they can muster a little production from some of their high-priced forwards, they might be able to win a game again.

title: On TV Soon, Look for Latinos; Nickelodeon Discovers a Large New World to Portray
description: In a working-class New York City neighborhood, a 14-year-old girl faces a dilemma. As a student at a performing arts school, she has just won an audition to join a singing group, but this means going on tour, away from family and friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, LOIS
description: SIEGEL-Lois. Beloved daughter of the late Julius and Beth; devoted sister of Charles. Services 9:45 AM Tuesday, ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Adviser Pushes Gore to Be Leader of the Pack
description: Vice President Al Gore has been paying Naomi Wolf, the feminist author, thousands of dollars a month to help him figure out how to become the top dog.

title: Media Talk; Marital Woes Threaten Radio Star's Image
description: If Howard Stern could fulfill his fantasies, would he still be, well, Howard Stern?

title: After Protracted Talks, a Disneyland Will Rise in Hong Kong
description: In a deal that will bring Main Street, U.S.A. to the doorstep of mainland China, the Walt Disney Company has reached an agreement to build a theme park in Hong Kong, a government official close to the negotiations said early today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHILLER, BERTA
description: SHILLER-Berta. Beloved wife of Milton. Devoted mother of Joel and Leonard and mother-in-law of Barbara and Elyse, and loving grandmother of Louise, Eric and Renee. Cherished sister of Blossom Shelton. Services at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, Monday, 10 AM. Interment to follow at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: Young and Old, Set for Adventure
description: They were drawn across the Atlantic by curiosity about another culture or dedication to their professions. Some were retirees savoring their freedom, or grandparents relishing their grandchildren. Others were students, exploring another part of the world. Some were businessmen. Some were crew members, for whom the flight between America and Egypt was business.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: In America; Blueprint For Tragedy
description: The lives of the homeless, in the view of the mayor, are not wretched enough. So here comes the threat to drive them out of the shelters and into the streets if they don't shape up and go to work, and the terrifying threat to snatch children from their mothers and dump them into foster care, and so forth and so on.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's really fun reading books that take you into a different world. Video games really don't. It's just like, 'Oh, I won again.' ''

title: First Steps of the Inquiry Follow a Pattern Made Familiar by Recent Airplane Crashes
description: Moments after Egyptair Flight 990 suddenly, mysteriously dropped from the sky at about 1:52 yesterday morning, the complex but by now familiar search for a plane in ocean water and the investigation into why it went down were under way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIN, SAMUEL WOLF
description: FEIN-Samuel Wolf. Born May 13, 1912. Died October 27, 1999. Beloved husband of 60 years of the late Evelyn Leibowitz, loving father of Michael, Cynthia and Eric. Cherished grandfather of Lara and Karen Stolman. Loving brother of Sofie and Evelyn and the late Harry, Bella and Sally. Caring uncle to many nieces and nephews. A sweet, kind and gentle man who loved to sing. Services were held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, on Friday, October 29, 1999. He was loved dearly and will be greatly missed. The angels in heaven will sing more sweetly now.

title: After a News-Ad Clash, A 'Wall' May Go Up Again At The Los Angeles Times
description: On Mondays, Kathryn M. Downing, the publisher of The Los Angeles Times, spends perhaps half the day closeted with her top management team: seven business executives, the general counsel and the newspaper's editor, Michael Parks.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Sports of The Times; From Halftime to Overtime, Coaches Inspire
description: THE Giants trailed the hapless Philadelphia Eagles by two touchdowns at halftime yesterday, and the locker room was in chaos. Players were arguing with each other. Defensive linemen scolded defensive backs for missing tackles. Offensive players were embarrassed that they had scored only 3 points.

title: Campaign Trailblazers
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, ROBERT C.
description: JONES-Robert C. Died October 30, age 84. Former National Director of the Episcopal Church Army and Administrator and Verger of St. Thomas Church, NYC. Survived by wife Barbara, brother Philip, children Constance, Kathleen, Michael, Christopher, Timothy and Lisa, grandchildren Cherie, Brian, Hannah and Ryan. For information, 718-832-3358.

title: Taking It Easy for Now, With Works Short and Sweet
description: The New York Philharmonic, taking a hands-on approach to the millennium, has been grappling with a lot of big new works (not to mention big ideas) this season, undoubtedly putting a strain on both time and nerves in rehearsal. The need for occasional respite is understandable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIHER, FLORENCE MCCAFFREY
description: LEIHER-Florence McCaffrey. On October 28, 1999, in New York City. She was a 1927 graduate of New Paltz SUNY University. Retired teacher, Our Lady of Assumption School, Bronx, NY. Active member for many years with the Ladies of Charity. Beloved wife of the late Frank M., who was the former Resident Manager of Peter Cooper Village and Stuyvesant Town, New York City. Loving mother of Gregory, James and Robert (Chip). Dear mother-in-law of Diane and Nancy. Devoted grandmother of Suzanne, Kathryn and Rebecca. Dear sister-in-law of Anna and Dorothy. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Ladies of Charity, care of the Archdiocese of New York, 1011 First Avenue, New York, NY 10022. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue, 20th Street, New York, NY, Monday, 2-5 and 79 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Church of the Epiphany, Tuesday, 11 AM. Interment St. Mary's Cemetery, Port Jervis, NY.

title: School a Rare Luxury for Rural Chinese Girls
description: At first glance, Hong Mei, a willowy 12-year-old in a long floral skirt and hoop earrings, seems a beacon of color and sophistication in this poor mountain village where the streets, the mud homes, even the crops are the same drab dusty brown.

title: Charges Unravel Drug-Use Scholar's Career
description: For a quarter-century, Dr. Ansley Hamid was a creative researcher and trailblazing anthropologist, discovering and documenting trends in urban drug use that were closely watched and, in some cases, celebrated by academics and drug-use experts nationwide.

title: Max Patkin, 79, Clown Prince of Baseball
description: Max Patkin, who made more consecutive appearances on the diamond than Cal Ripken and was thrown out of more games than Earl Weaver in half a century of slapstick as the Clown Prince of Baseball, died Saturday at a hospital in Paoli, Pa. Patkin, who lived in Exton, Pa., was 79.

title: People
description: * Dennis Eastham, president and chief operating officer at the Brann North American Agencies, Bethesda, Md., part of Snyder Communications , was named to the new position of president and chief operating officer at Brann Worldwide .

title: Playfulness and Virtuosity Upstage Drama
description: There are choreographers who know how to work with the special gifts of the dancers at hand and Robert Hill, in American Ballet Theater's new ''Baroque Game,'' is clearly one of these creative spirits.

title: Monday Morning Quarterback
description: Highlights and lowlights from the weekend.

title: More Stations Back Revised DTV Standard
description: Almost half of the nation's 1,600 television stations have now expressed support for the Sinclair Broadcast Group's campaign to revise the nation's standard for digital television broadcasts. Among the supporters are 350 public television stations.

title: Patents; A system of curtains adapted from theater and film sets may help in controlling forest fires.
description: BRENT LEE FARLEY is a stagehand currently working on the Baltimore set of the new John Waters film, ''Cecil B. Demented.'' Like the director, Mr. Farley could be said to take a quirky view of life, and has earned patents for sled pants, a hand-shaped hair dryer and an inflatable shower curtain.

title: Computer Scientists Are Poised For Revolution on a Tiny Scale
description: Scientists at a variety of elite laboratories around the country are sharing a growing sense that they are on the brink of a new era in digital electronics. It will usher in a world of circuits no more than a few atoms wide, with a potential impact on computing, in terms of speed and memory, that may be too profound to fathom.

title: Russian Museum Plans A Satellite for London
description: A year ago, the Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia, announced that it was transforming a home for the elderly in Amsterdam into a satellite museum. Now it is carrying the same idea to London, where it plans to open a permanent exhibition space at Somerset House, a late-18th-century mansion on The Strand.

title: Baffert Holds a Hand With Nothing but Aces
description: For a man who paid $700 million for a professional football team that won't even take the field until the year 2002, it was probably no big deal to shell out $875,000 for a 2-year-old filly who had never run a race. But Bob Baffert, the trainer who scouted the filly and recommended that Robert McNair of Houston buy her, it was an investment made in heaven.

title: Procter & Gamble Adds Deutsch to Its Roster
description: Deutsch Inc. in New York is joining the agency roster of Procter & Gamble, the world's largest advertiser.

title: In Brooklyn, Neighbors Balk at a Baseball Plan
description: The idea was to turn a sandlot near Prospect Park in Brooklyn into a site fit for minor league baseball, to bring professional ball back to the borough 43 years after the Dodgers left.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the Library of Congress's acquisition of the papers of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. misspelled the given name of a history professor at Stanford who defended the King family's financial demand. He is Clayborne Carson Jr., not Clayburn.

title: Abandoned Newborn In Critical Condition
description: A newborn baby girl remained hospitalized in critical condition yesterday, two days after being abandoned in a city park.

title: Awaiting Verdict, Microsoft Starts Lobbying Campaign
description: The first part of the verdict in the Microsoft trial is due out soon, perhaps as soon as Friday. But the Microsoft Corporation is already looking past the legal case and lobbying the government to pass laws that would protect the company in areas where it is being challenged in court.

title: France Shocks New Zealand to Advance
description: The World Cup semifinal at Twickenham Stadium tonight ended as nearly every rugby expert on either side of the Channel and the Equator expected it would end: in a convincing victory for a team with great speed, great ball skills and great presence.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Freeze Frame: Sparkling Plays Define Giants
description: Football games are won in focal moments, sequences almost stolen from the game's routine -- the stab of hand on ball, a bull-rush to block a kick, a deflected pass that leads to a catch-and-run and touchdown.

title: Compressed Data; Decor Flexibility Through Fine Art
description: So the corporate digs need spiffing up and you think some original art sure would be nice over the reception desk, or in the conference room. True, you could get some by-the-numbers original oils, or an old master print -- but you want something with a bit more class.

title: Patient Confidentiality
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULLERJAHN, EDUARD H.
description: BULLERJAHN-Eduard H. October 29, 1999, age 79, of Little Compton, RI. Husband of Julianna Sweetser Bullerjahn. Father of Stephen Riddle Bullerjahn, John teSelle Bullerjahn, and George Shepley Bullerjahn. Stepfather of William Daniel Grant IV. Brother of the late Hazel Dwyer. A celebration of his life will be held on Tuesday, November 2, 1999, at 2 PM in The Stone House Club, Little Compton, RI. Relatives and friends are invited. Memorial contributions may be made to The Little Compton Visiting Nurses Association, P.O. Box 545, Little Compton, RI, 02837. For information, contact the Cherry Place Home of Waring-Sullivan, Ashton, Coughlin and Driscoll.

title: Jury in Subway Slaying Deliberates for a 3rd Day
description: A Manhattan jury deliberated for a third full day yesterday without reaching a verdict in the murder trial of Andrew Goldstein, the schizophrenic man accused of pushing a woman in front of a subway train.

title: A Program Of Protest And Tribute
description: The American Composers Orchestra concert, conducted by Dennis Russell Davies on Sunday at Carnegie Hall, was a strange and disappointing occasion. ''Protest'' was the theme, which might have explained the presence of some weak pieces, except that those same pieces were ineffective in voicing any kind of protest. The mildness of most of the music and the silliness of the last piece subverted the point of the program, to suggest that protest through music is unnecessary or impossible, or that nobody is protesting, neither of which is the case.

title: Some Jeep Wranglers to Get New Plastic Roofs
description: Taking a big step forward in the development of automobiles with plastic bodies, DaimlerChrysler announced today that it would equip 5,000 of its Jeep Wranglers each year with lightweight, low-cost roofs made from a new kind of specially hardened plastic, starting in the 2001 model year.

title: Football Remembers Payton, the Ultimate Player
description: Late yesterday afternoon each National Football League team received an e-mail message from the Chicago Bears. Many executives knew what it said before they read it: Walter Payton, one of the best ever to play running back, had died.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The dollar rose against the euro as a report suggested further strength in United States manufacturing without inflationary pressure. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0506, down from $1.0542 on Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREVOR, MILDRED
description: KREVOR-Mildred. Of Glen Cove L.I. on October 31, 1999. Beloved wife of Julius. Mother of Michael and Brad. Grandmother of Michael Spenser. Sister of George Seaman. Service at Dodge-Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove, Wednesday at 12 noon.

title: Alaska Suspends BP Amoco Talks
description: Gov. Tony Knowles of Alaska called on the Federal Trade Commission yesterday to block BP Amoco's acquisition of ARCO, at least temporarily.

title: Russian Class Struggle in Louisiana
description: The characters in the New Group's production of Dmitry Lipkin's ''Cranes'' at the Theater at St. Clement's are so disturbingly amusing that it is only toward the end you realize they haven't done much and have revealed little that you could not anticipate in the first few minutes.

title: U.S. Backs European Effort To Send Heating Oil to Serbs
description: The Clinton administration, worried that it could be blamed if Serbs freeze to death in the winter, has decided to support a European-run pilot program to send millions of dollars worth of heating oil to Serbia, senior administration officials said today.

title: Walter Payton, Extraordinary Running Back for Chicago Bears, Dies at 45
description: Walter Payton, the Chicago Bears' running back whose single-minded aggressiveness and singular combination of power and speed made him the leading ground gainer in pro football history, died yesterday at his home in Barrington, Ill., a Chicago suburb. He was 45.

title: Across the World, Families And Friends Sift Memories
description: Robert T. Fitzpatrick had lived on Long Island's North Fork for only three years, but to his neighbors on Old Wood Path in Southold, he may as well have been a lifelong resident.

title: New Clues to Why We Dream
description: To Sigmund Freud, whose classic book, ''The Interpretation of Dreams,'' arrived in the bookstores of Vienna 100 years ago this month, dreams were filled with latent meaning, their bizarre imagery and peculiar narratives concealing deep-seated, instinctual motives and desires.

title: Louima Assailant Seeks Leniency, Saying an Error Enraged Him
description: After pleading guilty to brutalizing Abner Louima in a police station, Justin A. Volpe told a psychologist that he lost control because he believed Mr. Louima had punched him in a street brawl and then had cursed him at the station.

title: Bush's Campaign Script
description: To the Editor:

title: Q & A
description: Spiders' Life Spans

title: EUROPE MAY RAISE RATES
description: European Central Bank policy makers are leaning more to raising interest rates as money supply growth quickens, the central bank president, Wim Duisenberg, said. ''Our inclination for higher interest rates has certainly risen somewhat'' since July, Mr. Duisenberg told the daily business newspaper Handelsblatt. His comments underpin expectations that the bank, which sets rates for the 11 countries using the euro, will raise borrowing costs on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, LOIS
description: SIEGEL-Lois. Beloved daughter of the late Julius and Beth; devoted sister of Charles. Services 9:45 AM Tuesday, ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Lizzie, With Ax and Whacks
description: American Ballet Theater closed a season rich in diversity on Sunday at City Center with additional and major debuts. Sandra Brown, girlish and touching, did excellently in her first stab, no pun intended, as the accused ax murderer Lizzie Borden on Sunday afternoon in Agnes de Mille's ''Fall River Legend.'' Marcelo Gomes and Gillian Murphy were the new leads on Saturday afternoon in Robert Hill's ''Baroque Game.''

title: Ukraine's President Wins Spot in Nov. 14 Runoff
description: Leonid Kuchma overcame his own lackluster record as leader of Ukraine for the last five years to win a commanding first place in a preliminary round of presidential elections on Sunday.

title: ADAPTEC LOOKS TO STRENGTHEN DATA-STORAGE LINE
description: Adaptec Inc., the No. 1 designer of electronic cards that speed computer communications, agreed yesterday to buy Distributed Processing Technology for about $235 million to bolster its data-storage product line. Adaptec will pay about $190 million in cash and $45 million to assume Distributed Processing's employee stock-option plan. Closely held Distributed Processing, based in Maitland, Fla., makes data-storage devices. Through the purchase, Adaptec, based in Milpitas, Calif., said it hoped to strengthen its so-called redundant array of independent disks technology, which allows computer servers to retrieve information stored on other network servers.

title: LUCENT TO ELIMINATE 1,680 JOBS, OR 1% OF ITS WORK FORCE
description: Lucent Technologies, the phone-equipment maker, said yesterday that it planned to cut 1,680 jobs, or about 1 percent of its work force, to reduce expenses at the unit responsible for sales to businesses. The cuts are being made in the Business Communications Systems unit. Lucent plans to cut 1,200 jobs by asking employees to resign and to eliminate 200 managers responsible for them. It is dismissing 280 people at offices in Tucson and Silver Spring, Md. Fiscal fourth-quarter sales in the Business Communications Systems unit, which supplies companies with office-phone equipment and software, were unchanged from the period a year earlier, at $2.47 billion.

title: Novel Ways To Counter Destruction Of Arteries
description: Two studies offer hope of improved treatments for some half a million heart patients whose blood vessels have deteriorated to the point of requiring bypass surgery.

title: Astronomers Zooming In on Baffling Cosmic Jets
description: They are among the greatest frustrations in astronomy: colossal outpourings of energy driven by engines that remain a mystery because they are too far away for astronomers to resolve their details with even the largest telescopes.

title: DUTCH CABLE BID
description: Europe's second-largest cable TV company, United Pan-Europe Communications N.V., said it bid ''in the region of'' 1.4 billion guilders, or $672 million, for the Dutch cable company Eneco KabelTV and Telecom. France Telecom's Casema unit, which has 1.1 million customers in the Netherlands, is also in talks with Eneco, according to a spokesman, who declined to say if Casema had bid. Eneco had 585,000 TV subscribers in 1998. U.P.C. is already the Netherlands' largest cable TV company.

title: Soft, Wet Grass a Problem for the European Horses
description: Eleven of Europe's best race horses flew into South Florida today for the Breeders' Cup, but, while the weather seemed suitable for flying, racing officials were bedeviled by an old problem: was it suitable for racing?

title: BAA'S PROFIT FALLS
description: The world's largest airport operator, BAA P.L.C., said the end of duty-free shopping within the European Union had contributed to a 17 percent drop in its second-quarter profit. The company, which operates Heathrow and Gatwick airports in London, said its profit fell to 108 million, or $178 million, in the second quarter, down from 30 million [pounds], or $213 million, a year earlier. BAA had warned of a profit slowdown earlier this fall, after duty-free shopping at airport shops in the European Union was halted on July 1.

title: 4 Agencies Honored At Echo Awards
description: Four agencies have taken top honors at the 1999 International Echo Awards competition sponsored by the Direct Marketing Association.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE RISES. Coffee jumped 10 percent, as dry weather threatened to reduce next year's harvest in Brazil, the world's top grower. In New York, coffee for December delivery rose 10.15 cents, to $1.1035 a pound.

title: Halfway Into Season, Giants Are Half a Team
description: Before Jim Fassel even got out of bed this morning, he was smiling as he recalled Sunday's rousing victory over the Philadelphia Eagles. When he got to his Giants Stadium office at 6 a.m., Fassel watched the tape of the game, pleased to have a 5-3 record at the season's midpoint with a bye week ahead. Over coffee, he then talked with a few of his coaches, each marveling at the resolve of a Giants defense that willed itself to victory.

title: Election Day Choices in New York City
description: The off-year general election is being held today, with polls open between 6 a.m. and 9 p.m. in New York City. Ballots for the city boroughs cover several judicial, Council and district attorney races, plus two proposals, one on the judiciary, the other on charter revision. Here are our recommendations:

title: To Sleep, Perchance to Dream
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Does a Tip About a Gun Justify a Stop and Frisk?
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the police may stop and frisk someone solely on the basis of an anonymous, uncorroborated tip that the person is carrying a gun.

title: On Call at Sea
description: To the Editor:

title: As He Steps In for Ewing, Camby Steps Up for Knicks
description: It was only 19 seconds, about the time it takes to tie a pair of shoelaces or twist off a childproof cap. A forgettable and frivolous fraction of time to almost anyone but Marcus Camby.

title: On Hopeful Soil, Arafat and Barak Chase an Old Dream
description: In the birthplace of the Israeli-Palestinian peace effort, President Clinton presided today over a kind of multinational homage to the original dream of a permanent peace as both sides prepared for the thorny final round of negotiations.

title: Fresh Gains Are Reported in Manufacturing
description: Manufacturing expanded in October for the ninth consecutive month, a survey of business executives showed today.

title: Judge Sees Fallacies in the Arguments of the Mayor
description: Excerpts from the ruling by Judge Nina Gershon of Federal District Court in Brooklyn on the city's lawsuit seeking to cut financing to the Brooklyn Museum of Art:

title: A Birth-Defect Danger
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALLAWAY, DOROTHY HARDING
description: CALLAWAY-Dorothy Harding. Of Southbury, CT, formerly of Cold Spring Harbor, LI. Beloved wife of the late Samuel R. Callaway, died peacefully on Sunday, October 31, 1999 at Danbury Hospital, Danbury, CT. She was 84 years old. She is survived by two daughters, Joan C. Pratt of Brentwood, NH, and Dorothy C. Munson of Richmond, MA; a son, Samuel R. Callaway, Jr. of Redding, CT; seven grandchildren, two step grandchildren and four great grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at the United Church of Christ, Southbury, CT, on Sunday, November 21 at 2:00 PM. A memorial service followed by interment will be held at a later time at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, LI 11754, where contributions in Mrs. Callaway's memory may also be made.

title: Alpha and Beta Guys
description: To the Editor:

title: World Bank Begins Task Of Rebuilding In East Timor
description: Even before the recent violence that destroyed most of East Timor's buildings, the creation of a newly independent society and economy here presented a harsh case study in development from the ground up.

title: 30-Year Yield 6.18%, Amid Hopes of Only One Rate Rise
description: Yields of Treasury securities held near their four-week lows yesterday amid hopes that the Federal Reserve would not need to raise interest rates more than once in coming months to check inflation.

title: Bronx Officers Are Suspended After Shooting
description: Three off-duty police officers who attended a party in the Bronx at which two men were shot early Sunday have been suspended without pay, police officials said yesterday.

title: Dow Falls in Mixed Trading As Nasdaq Hits a New High
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday as traders and investors took some profits after the big run-up in market gauges over the last two weeks.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about WMS Industries' closing of its pinball machine division misidentified the inventor of the game's first drop-down targets. He is Steve Kordek, not Harry Williams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEICH, ELIZABETH JUNE FERGUSON
description: TEICH-Elizabeth June Ferguson. Of West End, NJ, and Lake Worth, FL. Died on October 31, 1999. June was Britain's gift to America. She was an elegant lady with a vibrant personality and sense of humor (British). She was strong, warm, and a very good friend. June had excellent classic taste in things and people. She will be greatly missed by her loving husband, Seymour J. (Cy), a son Mark H.T. Ferguson, and his wife Jan of Maui, Hawaii, two daughters, Barbara Teich-Vali and Liz Graham Missett, both of NJ; also two grandsons, three granddaughters and two great grandsons. At June's request, there will be no service and no flowers. If you choose, you may contribute to American Lung Association, 917 North Maine St., Tom's River, NJ 08753

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEITZMAN, MARY C.
description: WEITZMAN-Mary C. of New York City, 85, died Sunday, October 31, 1999 at Mt. Sinai Hospital. Former wife of the late J. Daniel Weitzman. Loving mother of David M. Weitzman of Orinda, CA. and Donald C. Weitzman of Brookline, MA. Sister of Frances Pasmanick of Washington, D.C., Harold Cohen of Arlington, VA, and Norman Cohen of Venice, CA. Grandmother of Katherine, Martin, Gwendolyn, Laura, and Lillian. Civil Rights activist; member of Southern Conference for Human Welfare in the 1940's. Opened first desegregated movie theater in Washington, D.C. in 1948. BA and MA, George Washington University, Phi Beta Kappa and Sigma Xi; Ph.D. Columbia University and Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Faculty, Department of Anatomy and Structural Biology, Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Memorial Service 6:00 pm Wednesday at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue

title: Across the World, Families And Friends Sift Memories
description: They were a foursome: a quartet of women in Orange County, Calif., who were brought together by the card game Pan.

title: Executive to Raise at Least $1.2 Billion to Aid ICO
description: Craig O. McCaw, the cellular telephone pioneer, said yesterday that he had agreed to raise at least $1.2 billion to take ICO Global Communications Ltd. out of Chapter 11.

title: After a Crash, Fear Overtakes Logic
description: Trans World Airlines Flight 800 crashed off Long Island in 1996. Swissair Flight 111 crashed off Nova Scotia last year. John F. Kennedy Jr.'s plane crashed off Martha's Vineyard last summer. And now Egyptair Flight 990 crashes off Nantucket. Four recent flights ending in tragedy off the Eastern Seaboard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, DOROTHEA ACKERMANN
description: HECHT-Dorothea Ackermann. Died suddenly on October 30 in New York City at age 85. Widow of the late George A. Hecht. She was a volunteer at the Lincoln Center Library for the Performing Arts and the Museum of the City of New York Theater Collection and she was formerly staff assistant at Foreign Affairs magazine. Beloved mother of Karen Hecht and Dorothea Hecht and cherished grandmother of Garitt A. Kono, Jr., Meredith Anne Schlow and Sarah Rallings Schlow, adored greatgrandmother of Anna Katherine Feldberg and Chloe Elizabeth Feldberg. Dear sister of Jean Marie Ackermann of Pacific Grove, CA. Lifelong friend of Jane Adler Light. Private interment at Trinity Church Cemetery, N.Y.C. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Lincoln Center Library for the Performing Arts.

title: McCain's Rise in New Hampshire Surprises Bush
description: Gov. George W. Bush's advisers, acknowledging that they had been caught off guard by how quickly Senator John McCain has risen in New Hampshire polls, say they are bracing for a hard-fought contest in the state that holds the first presidential primary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CREAVEN, BRIDGET (NEE MCNAMARA)
description: CREAVEN-Bridget (nee McNamara). On October 31, 1999. Native of County Mayo, Ireland. Beloved wife of the late Michael, devoted mother of Patrick J., Mary B. Kelly, Kathleen M., Loretta A. O'Reilly and the late Rev. William F. Also survived by 14 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Funeral from the Riverdale on Hudson F.H., 6110 Riverdale Ave, Bronx, New York on Wednesday, 9:30 AM. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Margarets Church, at 10 AM. Interment at St. John's Cemetery. Visiting hours 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Reading Ancient Skulls
description: To the Editor:

title: A Single Girl Takes On the California Frontier
description: DAUGHTER OF FORTUNE

title: TARMAC TALKS END
description: The South African mining company Anglo American P.L.C. said negotiations to acquire Tarmac P.L.C., Britain's largest maker of asphalt, had halted after Tarmac rejected its offer of 1.13 billion [pounds], or $1.85 billion. In a possibly related twist, Rugby Group P.L.C., a cement company, said it had received an offer but refused to name the bidder, leading to speculation that Anglo American had selected it as a consolation prize.

title: Sports of The Times; From College In Mississippi To Champion
description: THE news that Walter Payton died yesterday at his home in a suburb of Chicago came not so much as a shock but as a sorrowful, piercing spike. We were prepared last February by the shock of seeing the once robust Payton looking gaunt and frail as he announced that he suffered from a rare liver disease. Now we mourn a family's loss of a father and husband, and the industry's loss of a great athlete. I mourn the loss of a shared past, life petals that peel away each time someone contemporary dies.

title: Rudy Burckhardt Tribute
description: A memorial for Rudy Burckhardt, the filmmaker and painter, is to be held tonight at 7:30 in the Great Hall at Cooper Union, 7 East Seventh Street, at Third Avenue, in the East Village. Participants are to include the poet John Ashbery, the composer Elliott Carter, the dancer Douglas Dunn and the artists Red Grooms, Alex Katz and Yvonne Jacquette, who was Mr. Burckhardt's wife. Mr. Burckhardt died on Aug. 1 at 85.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARON, HENRY EDWARD
description: ARON-Henry Edward. Devoted husband of Sylvia. Cherished father of Jeff and Gene. Adored grandfather of Eve and Jake. Beloved teacher. He will be deeply missed by his family, his friends and his students. He will be remembered as an inspirational teacher and a courageous fighter for social justice. Services Wednesday, November 3, 12 Noon, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: IMPROVEMENT AT FUNERAL OPERATOR
description: Bankruptcy protection enabled Loewen Group, a funeral chain based in Vancouver, British Columbia, to earn $1.9 million in the third quarter, compared with a loss of $32.4 million a year earlier. The results partly reflected a suspension of interest payments. The chairman, John Lacey, said a revised business plan, which will include restructuring $2.2 billion of debt, should be completed before the end of the year.

title: Settlement Approved in Wyndham Suit
description: Wyndham International, the fourth-largest hotel company in the United States, won a approval today of a $300 million settlement of shareholders' suits over a $1 billion stock sale.

title: VITAL SIGNS: EXCHANGES; Anonymous Patient, Irate, Goes Public
description: It's a standard of medical journals: a letter outlining the unusual case of an anonymous patient. But in an unusual twist, a Michigan man has thrown aside anonymity to take issue with the description of his cases and to remind doctors of the consequences journal submissions can have.

title: AT&T Fights Push to Open Cable Lines To Its Rivals
description: Seeking to stamp out a growing political brush fire that started here, the AT&T Corporation argued before a federal appeals court today that the city exceeded its authority last year when it sought to force AT&T to open its cable lines to rival Internet service providers.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Circuits on Thursday with an article about renting videotapes and DVD's online misstated the number of movies available at the DVD Overnite site. It is 1,200, not 12,000.

title: New Efforts to Uncover The Dangers of Mercury
description: Most people think of mercury as the shiny liquid metal in thermometers. But it has other forms, and it is a less visible, and very toxic, kind -- methylmercury -- that is troubling scientists, environmentalists and government officials.

title: Clinton Seeks China Deal On Trade by Month's End
description: After a series of secret exchanges with Beijing over the last two weeks, the White House is hoping to close a deal by the end of this month that could pave China's way into the World Trade Organization, even if Congress cannot pass judgment on the agreement until next year.

title: Russian Businessman Under Investigation Is Detained in Hungary
description: One of Russia's most prominent businessmen has been detained in Hungary at the request of Russian law enforcement officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRATTO, DONATO
description: FRATTO-Donato, ''Danny''-entered into rest on Saturday, October 30, 1999 at home, Newburgh, NY. He was 54. Loving wife, Julie Mazzotti-Fratto. DiDonato-Brooks Funeral Home (914) 561-8300.

title: Scotland's Technology Nexus; Silicon Glen Blend: Equal Parts Theory and Practice
description: John Dunlop might very well have the look and manner of an archetypal academic or a midlevel bureaucrat, aloof from the high-technology revolution sweeping the globe. In reality, though, rather like a digital Braveheart, he is very much part of his country's updated assault on the electronic barricades.

title: When Too Much Water Hurts a Runner
description: Sports bottles of water have become indispensable accessories in gym bags and symbols of good health. But sports doctors are warning people not to drink too much water during endurance events like the New York City Marathon, which takes place on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRETT, ELEANOR C.
description: BRETT-Eleanor C. Of Lakehurst, NJ, on November 1, 1999. Wife of the late Edward. Mother of Mary, Suzanne, Edward, John, Gerard and Timothy. Sister of Donald Haney. Grandmother of eight. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY, 2-4:00 and 7-9:00 PM Wednesday. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main St., Tuckahoe, NY 10707.

title: For a Therapist, the Return of a Gritty, Freewheeling Past
description: Like his wife, the fashion photographer Lillian Bassman, Paul Himmel isn't much interested in the past.

title: Web Retailers Empty Wallets On Advertising
description: Send.com is buying its 15 minutes of fame right now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLIGERMAN, HOWARD
description: KLIGERMAN-Howard. November 1, 1999. Beloved husband of Carole (nee Wolff). Devoted father of daughters Vicki Kligerman and Wendy Stober and son-in-law Clifford. Cherished brother-in-law of Gerry and Richard Wolff and Miralyn Kligerman. Dear brother of the late Alan Kligerman. Services Tuesday, November 2, 10AM at Plaza Funeral Home, 91 Street & Amsterdam Avenue, New York.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review last Tuesday about the Boston Ballet production of Christopher Wheeldon's ''Firebird'' misidentified the performer in the role of the Enchanted Princess. She was Tara Hench, not Larissa Ponomarenko.

title: A Small-Screen Feast of Verite Born of a Hunger for Impact
description: Charlie Tabesh, the vice president of Turner Classic Movies, a cable television channel devoted to classic movies, knew that despite being a confessed ''film fanatic,'' he had a significant gap in film knowledge, one that corresponded to a gap in his channel's programming.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: LIBERTY TO BUY FOUR MEDIA FOR $252 MILLION IN STOCK
description: The Liberty Media Corporation, a unit of the AT&T Corporation,agreed yesterday to acquire a television services concern, the Four Media Company, for about $252 million in stock. Liberty Media will exchange 6.35 million of its shares for the 19.7 million Four Media shares outstanding. Based on Liberty Media's closing price on Friday, each Four Media share is valued at $12.80. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Four Media soared 77 percent, rising $4.6875 each, to $10.75. Liberty Media's stock was down $1.312, to $38.375. Four Media, based in Burbank, Calif., provides technical and creative services to owners, producers and distributors of television programming.

title: A New Frontier Aboard the Mars Direct
description: Dr. Robert Zubrin, 47, an astronautical engineer and founder of the Mars Society, a group advocating travel there, was having coffee in Manhattan on a recent morning.

title: Will Sale of Blass Lead to a New Image?
description: A Bill Blass wardrobe for Madonna? Suits for Sting?

title: Rodeo and Racing Take 2 Athletes' Lives
description: Their names did not engender the public familiarity afforded professional athletes like the golfer Payne Stewart, who died last week in a plane crash.

title: Conde Nast Officials Get New Positions
description: Conde Nast Publications said yesterday that it had promoted three top executives.

title: Aid to the Arts: Who Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: Setback for Bell Atlantic In Drive for Long Distance
description: Raising a speed bump in the Bell Atlantic Corporation's path toward offering long-distance communications services, the Justice Department said yesterday that the company had come close to fully opening its local networks in New York to competitors, but had not quite made it.

title: Walter Payton Dies
description: The Chicago Bears back, 45, who ran for the most yards in N.F.L. history, died of complications from liver disease. Obituary, Page C23.

title: For the Musical Alchemist, a New Tack: Cryogenics
description: It was a chance meeting. Dr. Joseph Markoff, a Philadelphia ophthalmologist and a classically trained trumpet player, was entertaining at a family party when one of the guests made a startling proposition: would Dr. Markoff consider having his trumpet frozen?

title: How MTV Came to Be James Bond's Latest Ally
description: DURING the next three weeks, MTV viewers might feel as if they have stumbled into one of those James Bond movie marathons -- only this one will be celebrating just one film.

title: Hours of Polling Places in Region
description: There will be several elections today in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey. Polling places will be open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. in New York, from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. in Connecticut, and from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. in New Jersey.

title: The Pleasures of Unpredictability
description: Rock started out chasing the unexpected, with artists pushing their voices and instruments until they made new sounds. Now, though, rock and pop are at their most rehearsed, with dancers and other diversions overshadowing music's ability to surprise.

title: Judge Rejects 'Gay Panic' As Defense in Murder Case
description: A District Court judge in Laramie, Wyo., ruled today that lawyers for a man accused of murdering a gay college student last year may not use a ''gay panic'' defense to justify the actions of their client.
