title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: No Charges Against Officers in Fatal Brooklyn Shooting
description: A Brooklyn grand jury has decided not to bring any charges against four police officers involved in the fatal shooting of a mentally disturbed, hammer-wielding man, District Attorney Charles J. Hynes announced yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: Court to Weigh Police Tips

title: There Goes the Airspace? Clintons Close on a House
description: President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton closed on their $1.7 million house here today without attending the closing, but their presence was felt in the neighborhood long before they signed the papers and wrote the checks.

title: The Politics of Imperfection
description: Life would be simple for presidential candidates if they did not have advisers. Vice President Gore is the latest to discover this, thanks to the amusing report in Time magazine that he is being urged to quit behaving like a ''beta male,'' to wear earth-toned suits and to look for opportunities to bash President Clinton, whose alpha maleness Mr. Gore has to conquer. It is, as we have been saying, going to be a great campaign year.

title: 30 Egyptian Officers Aboard;Crash Cause Baffles Probers : Hope Abandoned For 217 on Plane
description: WASHINGTON  An intensive search continued Monday in the waters off Massachusetts where EgyptAir Flight 990 crashed Sunday, but authorities said they had given up hope of finding survivors and they were still baffled about the cause of the crash.

title: N.H.L. Suspends Devils' McKay
description: The penalty Randy McKay had feared materialized yesterday when the National Hockey League suspended him for three games for his infraction against Ulf Samuelsson of the Flyers on Saturday night.

title: Kosovo Aid Groups Fall Short as Winter Nears
description: A damp, heavy fog already envelops Kosovo daily, and with winter just a few weeks away, the United Nations and myriad relief organizations are failing to meet the expectations of the hundreds of thousands of homeless Albanians.

title: Across the World, Families And Friends Sift Memories
description: More resolute than bereft, Patricia Rose is making a memorial journal of the final two weeks in the life of Walla Zeid, a 19-year-old student from Luxor, Egypt.

title: When TV Changed American Politics
description: On a sidewalk in the shopping district of a small Wisconsin town, Hubert H. Humphrey stops passers-by and hands out business cards. ''Good to meet you,'' he says over and over. ''I hope you'll be at the election booth tomorrow, April 5. Let me give you one of my cards.'' Those cards might as well say ''Willy Loman for President.'' With his baggy overcoat and his hat at an angle that should look jaunty but only manages to seem sad, Humphrey looks desperately old-fashioned compared with the competition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTOCK, JACK
description: WEINSTOCK-Jack. Beloved husband of Florence, devoted father of Susan, Amy and Gwen, loving grandfather of Ariel and Gregory, dear brother of Gloria and Selma. Services and interment were held.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILDER, EDYTHE FISHER
description: GILDER-Edythe Fisher. Age 88, widow of Arthur Gilder, aunt of Jon, Robert and Laurie Greer, dear family friend of Lois Hahn and Charles Maier. On October 28 after a brave struggle with long illness. There will be no funeral, but friends can contact Charles Maier at 617-868-2281 or Lois Hahn at 914428-4102 for information about a later memorial gathering.

title: New Voice Against the Cuban Embargo
description: Pope John Paul II last year deplored the United States' embargo against Cuba for the suffering it has caused and the way it isolates ordinary Cubans from outside ideas. A similar judgment has now been reached by the conservative Republican governor of Illinois, George Ryan, who visited Havana last week, the first American governor to do so in 40 years. His visit was rooted as much in commerce -- Illinois farmers could benefit from selling food to Cuba -- as in foreign policy.

title: Charter Reform, Pro and Con
description: To the Editor:

title: Richard Tullis, 86, Ex-Chairman of Harris Corp.
description: Richard B. Tullis, who guided the Harris Corporation from a small printing press company to an electronic communications equipment giant, died on Sunday at his home in Vero Beach, Fla., the company said. He was 86.

title: Waking Up To Gumbel, Served in A New Blend
description: During yesterday's premiere of ''The Early Show,'' CBS's entry into the morning-show wars, Bryant Gumbel's smartest move was his first. He announced that he and his co-anchor, the virtually unknown Jane Clayson, had had their ''enthusiasm tempered enormously by a major tragedy,'' the Egyptian airliner crash on Sunday.

title: TEXTRON ACQUIRES INTESYS TECHNOLOGIES
description: Textron Inc., maker of Bell helicopters and Cessna business jets, said yesterday that it had bought InteSys Technologies to strengthen its assemblies business, which makes casings for auto parts and wireless phones. Textron, based in Providence, R.I., acquired closely held InteSys for an undisclosed price from its management, institutional shareholders and Berkshire Partners, a Boston-based investment firm. InteSys, based in Gilbert, Ariz., makes assemblies for the automobile, computer, telecommunications and medical industries. Shares in Textron, which had $9.6 billion in 1998 sales, fell $3.6875, to $73.50.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: XETA CORP., Tulsa, Okla., a provider of telecommunications systems and services to the lodging industry, agreed to buy closely held U.S. Technologies Systems, St. Louis, for $26 million in cash and 150,000 Xeta shares.

title: Saving an Island
description: To the Editor:

title: VITAL SIGNS: REMEDIES; Catching Headache Pain on the Rebound
description: A 33-year-old woman who consulted a Houston neurologist about her persistent migraines was relieved when a brain scan showed her fears of a tumor or aneurysm were unfounded. But she was skeptical when her doctor told her the cause was much simpler: her headache pills.

title: Cyclone-Ravaged Indian State Still Mostly Cut Off After 4 Days
description: The eastern state of Orissa remained largely cut off from the rest of India today, four days after the most ferocious cyclone in recent memory tore through coastal areas with 160-mile-per-hour winds.

title: S. Thondaman of Sri Lanka, a Tamil Leader
description: Savumiamoorthy Thondaman, a Sri Lankan trade unionist and political figure who was a leader of the minority Tamils of Indian origin, died on Saturday in a hospital in the Colombo area. He was reported to be 86 or 87.

title: Across the World, Families And Friends Sift Memories
description: To their neighbors in Ridgefield, Conn., they were Natalie and Martin Greenberg. To each other, they were ''sweetheart'' and ''doll.''

title: Atmel to Buy Chip Plant
description: The AtmelCorporation plans to buy a plant in Irving, Tex., from Hitachi Semiconductor AmericaInc. for an undisclosed price to increase its production of advanced chips. The purchase of the 650,000-square-foot plant does not include equipment. Atmel plans to install equipment in time for production by the end of 2000. Atmel, whose shares have more than tripled in the last year, said it was experiencing strong demand for its products. Atmel chips are used in telecommunications products, computers, consumer and auto electronics and other products.

title: Leading Tabloid Publisher to Buy a Big Competitor
description: In an era when Congress worries about multibillion-dollar megamergers and corporate chiefs with creased, sweaty brows testify before Congressional subcommittees about the threat of monopolization, one question has yet to rear its head: what happens if one media company starts to corner the market on tabloid gossip?

title: Saving the Nurse
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Urges Supreme Court to Uphold the Miranda Decision
description: The Clinton administration came strongly to the defense of the Miranda decision in a brief filed with the Supreme Court tonight, urging the justices to take up a legal challenge to the 33-year-old legal landmark and to reaffirm a decision that ''has come to play a unique and important role in the nation's conception of our criminal justice system.''

title: VITAL SIGNS: SIDE EFFECTS; Hope for Reversing Damage From Drugs
description: Even in low doses and even for a relatively short time, amphetamine use leads to diminished capacity to learn in monkeys, a Yale study has found.

title: Saving the Planet
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The first time I saw Walter Payton in the locker room, I thought God must have taken a chisel and said, 'I'm going to make me a halfback.' ''

title: A Top Executive To Quit Seagram
description: Seagram said today that its vice chairman, Robert W. Matschullat, would leave in June after more than four years during which the company changed from a beverage maker to one of the world's biggest entertainment companies.

title: Speed It Up, but Watch Those Elbows
description: After various Knicks had been whistled for holding, grabbing and chucking with their forearms, the referees conducting a clinic on the new rules during training camp last month asked whether the players had any more questions regarding what the league expected of them from now on.

title: Harry Potter's 'Magic'
description: To the Editor:

title: In Major Test, New Israeli Missile Destroys an 'Incoming' Rocket
description: Passing its first major antiballistic missile test, the new Arrow II missile successfully intercepted and destroyed a dummy incoming rocket over the Mediterranean today, the Israeli Air Force reported.

title: Business Support Declines in Britain for Adoption of the Euro
description: In a remarkable decline in support for adopting the European single currency, British businesses are evenly split on whether to abandon the pound sterling, a survey showed today -- a sharp contrast to strongly favorable sentiment about the euro a year ago.

title: Public Interests; Uncontested Contests
description: Happy Election Day, America!

title: No Timetable to Restore Pakistani Democracy
description: Pakistan's new military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, refused today to be pinned down on when he would restore democracy as he faced more than an hour of questions at his first news conference since he seized power in a coup three weeks ago.

title: Private Acres in Public Parks Fuel Battles on Development
description: Nestled in the San Juan National Forest here in southwestern Colorado are a small rectangle of mountains and a valley that straddles the meandering East Fork of the San Juan River.

title: Prison Schools Measure Is Called Discriminatory
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People urged residents yesterday to vote against a proposed amendment to the New Jersey Constitution to ban the use of lottery money for prison education.

title: Saving the Tiger
description: To the Editor:

title: RealNetworks to Stop Collecting User Data
description: Responding to privacy concerns about its RealJukebox software, RealNetworks executives announced yesterday that they had released a patch on their Web site that would prevent the program from relaying personal information about users to RealNetworks or to any third party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAYER, DORIS L.
description: DRAYER-Doris L. Devoted wife of Frank, beloved mother of Michelle Rubens, and the late Steven Drayer, dear sister of Allan Feuer, cherished grandmother of Emily, William, and Caroline. Services were held November 1, 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHBERG, IRVING
description: HOCHBERG-Irving. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Lexington School for the Deaf/Lexington Center for the Deaf mourn the passing of our long time trustee, supporter and friend. We will miss Dr. Hochberg's counsel and wisdom which have contributed enormously to Lexington's providing quality services to deaf and hard of hearing persons throughout the New York metropolitan area. Philip Bravin, President Oscar P. Cohen, Superintendent/CEO

title: Syracuse Players Among Three Still in Hospital After Stabbings
description: Two Syracuse University football players and another man remained hospitalized yesterday with stab wounds following a melee outside a downtown Syracuse bar early Sunday morning.

title: Vast Potential For Answers In Black Box
description: The Egyptair Boeing 767 that crashed Sunday was equipped with an unusually sophisticated black box, one that recorded three times as many categories of data as the standard required in the United States, Boeing said today.

title: Finding Fame Wittily, With Coward as Guide
description: One evening in March 1961, Noel Coward had dinner with Elaine Stritch, who was to star in his forthcoming Broadway musical, ''Sail Away.'' Coward, the author, composer, lyricist and director of the show, wrote in his diary that Ms. Stritch was ''wildly enthusiastic and very funny'' and would be wonderful in the role of the cruise director on a British ship. He had also heard that she was a woman with problems, and added: ''However, I think I shall be able to manage her. If I can, all will be fine and dandy, if not ze scenes will be terribile. I must engage an expert understudy.''

title: People
description: * Jeffrey Schur and Paul Hosea were named to the new positions of senior vice presidents and executive account directors at Designory/ Pinkhaus, Long Beach, Calif., and New York. Mr. Schur, who will open the agency's first New York office, had most recently been a principal at Doig Elliott Schur, New York. Mr. Hosea had been senior director at the George P. Johnson Co., Torrance, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEAD, HENRIETTA MILLS
description: MEAD-Henrietta Mills. Cherished wife of Robert H. Mead. Beloved mother of Robert, Slade & Winter; grandmother of six small children, and sister of Edward and Slade Mills. A graduate of Westover School and Phi Beta Kappa from Vassar College Class of 1976; member of the faculty of Salisbury School for more than 20 years, and a Commissioner of the State Gaming Commission of the State of Connecticut, appointed by Gov. Lowell Weicker. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Norfolk Library, P.O. Box 605, Norfolk, CT 06058. A memorial service will be held at Norfolk Congregational Church at 1:00 P.M., on Saturday, November 6, 1999.

title: Of Cameras and Consequences at a Women's Prison
description: In the course of a somewhat strained exchange with the chief medical officer at the Valley State Prison for Women in central California, Ted Koppel announces that for the moment he is acting as an advocate for the prisoners who have been complaining to him about their medical care.

title: With Eye on Charter, Mayor Refuses to Sign a Gun Bill
description: In a political maneuver aimed at encouraging voters to approve changes to the City Charter in today's ballot referendum, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani refused yesterday to sign City Council legislation that would require gun owners in New York City to use safety-locking devices even though he believes the devices are important tools in preventing accidental shootings.

title: Baylor and Manuel Step Into Helms
description: On the day that Don Baylor rejoined the managerial ranks from which he was inexplicably evicted a year ago, other black and Latino candidates did not fare so well yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABERNETHY, MARY
description: ABERNETHY-Mary. On October 30 at age 96. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Devoted mother of Patricia Suppa, Michael Abernethy, Maureen Gerhard and Eileen Connolly. Also survived by nineteen grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. A graduate of St. John's University with a Masters in Education. She retired from the NYC Board of Education after 42 years. Funeral from the McManus Funeral Home, 2001 Flatbush Avenue, Wednesday 9:45am. Funeral mass 10:30am our Lady Help of Christian Church. Interment Holy Cross cemetery. Visiting 2-5pm and 7-9pm.

title: Artist's Pen Mightier Than the Nazi Sword
description: IF you don't want to read this story, Morris Wyszogrod will understand. There were long periods during which he tried not to tell it himself, when he would go to somebody's house for dinner and start answering questions and the lady of the house would ask him to step into the kitchen and say, ''Morris, if you keep telling these stories, my husband will become sick.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, STANLEY
description: BARNETT-Stanley. On November 1, 1999, most beloved husband of Elaine. Devoted father of Richard and Sharon. Cherished grandfather of Michael & Adam. Loving father-in-law of Todd. The most wonderful and loved man that God ever created. Graveside service Wednesday 11 A.M. at Union Fields Cemetery.

title: Training Mission Turns Into a Grim Lesson on Disaster for Cadets
description: At 2:30 a.m. on Sunday, a terse alert crackled from the radio of the Kings Pointer as the training ship steamed across the Atlantic south of Cape Cod: a Boeing 767, Egyptair Flight 990, had apparently gone down south of Nantucket. Ships in the area were urgently needed to help search for it.

title: Across the World, Families And Friends Sift Memories
description: The joke around the radiology department at the Veterans Affairs Hospital in Chillicothe, Ohio, was that when Dr. Adel Elkousy, the department's chief, and Milly New, his administrative assistant, both retired in a few years, they would have to go to the courthouse for a divorce.

title: United States Women Hit Their Stride at 40
description: Jean Chodnicki of Manhattan ran her fastest marathon, 2 hours 43 minutes, in 1980. She was 21. Now at 40 she hopes to run close to that performance in Sunday's New York City Marathon and join a growing number of women in their 40's in what was once considered a young runner's pursuit: the Olympic marathon trials.

title: Abroad at Home; The Price of Harshness
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service took Cyrus Atefi into custody one year ago for deportation to Iran. I wrote about his case in February, thinking that he would surely be free soon. But he remains locked up: a testament to the harshness of the 1996 Immigration Act.

title: Andersen Consulting's Chief Makes E-Commerce New Goal
description: Andersen Consulting said yesterday that Joe W. Forehand, a high-ranking partner with 27 years of experience at the firm, would be its new chief executive. Mr. Forehand said in an interview that he planned to make e-commerce the central part of the consulting firm and that the company intended to take stakes in clients more frequently.

title: Rangers Call Up Daigle, But It's Just for Practice
description: When Alexandre Daigle got the call from the Rangers' general manager, Neil Smith, to report for practice today, he did not ask for and wasn't getting any promises that his time with the team would last for more than two days of workouts. But after a humbling period of a once very promising career, two days of practice with the Rangers was still preferable to the grind of minor league hockey.

title: Help With Weight Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: A Brutal Turn in Stock Frauds; Killings Accent Violence in a Wall Street Subculture
description: When two stock promoters were found shot to death in an affluent New Jersey suburb last week, the headlines may have conjured up an image of well-tailored suits and polished wingtips, a carpeted blue-chip world where violence is usually a stranger.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Study Finds Lapses on Medical Guidelines
description: It is hard to imagine the wizards of ''E.R.'' stopping to consult the latest practice guidelines before rushing to deliver a baby or cracking open a dying patient's chest. But for real-life practitioners, staying up to date with medical science increasingly means staying abreast of such guidelines.

title: Cigna Earnings Rise in Quarter
description: Cigna, the nation's third-largest health insurer, said today that its third-quarter earnings rose 21 percent after the company raised employer premiums and added new members as it held down administrative costs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: White House Seeks Deal To Allow China Into W.T.O.

title: VITAL SIGNS: TESTING; Slowing the Heart, Extending the Life
description: Cardiac patients whose hearts take longer than normal to recover after exercise are far more likely to die of heart disease, according to a study at the Cleveland Clinic.

title: Clavijo's Services In Demand
description: The MetroStars find themselves in competition with the New England Revolution for the services of Fernando Clavijo, who staged his first practice with the MetroStars yesterday as their interim coach after the departure of Bora Milutinovic.

title: Charter Reform, Pro and Con
description: To the Editor:

title: President Bradley Would Earn Far Less Than Citizen Bradley
description: Bill Bradley, author, lecturer and consultant, would have to take a substantial pay cut if the American people accepted his offer and elected him president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMBROS, LAMBROS J.
description: LAMBROS-Lambros J. On October 29, 1999, at age 64. Loving father of John F. Lambros and Olivia W. Lambros. Devoted son of Niki and the late John Lambros. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, 5-7 PM, and Wednesday, 10 AM-12 noon. Funeral services at the Greek Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74 St., Wednesday, 2 PM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to Norfolk Library, PO Box 605, Norfolk, CT 06058.

title: An Interloper in the Canyon of Heroes
description: As a longtime Boston Red Sox fan, I have an admission to make. Last Friday I found myself in the parade honoring the New York Yankees -- sitting in the back seat (red cushions) of a vintage MG. I am still somewhat puzzled as to how I ended up in this weird situation.

title: Cape Town Journal; For Red Light District's Best Brothels, Gold Stars
description: This city's brothels, the unwanted stepchildren in the venerable roster of tourist attractions here, would like nothing more than to be brought into the family. And an idea floated by the tourism chief may finally give the ''good'' ones the very imprimatur of legitimacy they crave.

title: Bush Slightly Hurt During Jog When a Truck Spills Debris
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas was slightly injured today while jogging in Austin, Tex., when a truck trailer overturned, scattering debris across a foot path, and Mr. Bush was forced to dive out of the way.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption in the Westchester section on Sunday about mayoral races in the county reversed the given names of the Democratic candidate in Yonkers. She is Margaret Mary Mulrooney, not Mary Margaret.

title: Boston Battles Cancer With a Citywide Mailing
description: Cities often undertake campaigns to fight crime or litter.

title: Hershiser Files as Free Agent
description: Orel Hershiser, who is 41 years old and just completed his 16th season pitching in the major leagues, filed for free agency yesterday, the first sign that he hopes to follow up on a season in which he went 13-12 with a 4.58 earned run average and achieved his 200th career victory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUTTERPERL, MURIEL
description: MUTTERPERL - Muriel. Her many friends and business associates offer deep and sincere condolences to the family on the passing of a wonderful person. She will be sorely missed by all who knew her. Tucker Anthony, Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, MILDRED
description: FISHER-Mildred. Suddenly at home on October 31, 1999. Loving and cherished wife of Arthur Irving. Beloved mother of Faith Einhorn (Robert), Arlene Davis (Charles), and Fred Fisher (Patti). Adored grandmother to Hayley, Heather, Sam, Eric, Ian, Mara, Glenn, and Gregg. Dear sister of Morton and Maxwell Fox. Her boundless love and devotion to family will be an inspiration to us all. We will carry her spirit in our hearts forever.

title: A Verdict on 'Sensation'
description: Delivering a ringing endorsement of the First Amendment as well as a stinging rebuke to Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, Federal Judge Nina Gershon ruled yesterday that Mr. Giuliani's efforts to punish the Brooklyn Museum of Art for mounting a controversial display of modern art had violated the Constitution. ''There is no federal constitutional issue more grave,'' she wrote, ''than the effort by government officials to censor works of expression and to threaten the vitality of a major cultural institution as punishment for failing to abide by governmental demands for orthodoxy.'' She then ordered the mayor to resume city payments to the museum and end his campaign to evict the museum from city land and to fire its board of trustees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSHING, DOROTHY HEDGES
description: CUSHING-Dorothy Hedges of West Orange, NJ formerly of Short Hills, on Sunday, October 31, 1999. Wife of the late Robert Lee Cushing. Mother of Mrs. J. Robert Campbell, Jr., Mrs. Henry M. Hulshizer and Candace W. Cushing. Also survived by five grandchildren and one great grandchild. Funeral service will be private.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Chase Manhattan must cut its revenue after discovering some nonexistent trading profits.
description: THE Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's third-largest bank, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter trading revenue would be reduced by $60 million after the bank found it had booked nonexistent trading profits. The bank has dismissed a currency trader involved in the matter.

title: Yanks Start Off-Season Appraisals
description: The Anaheim Angels have asked for permission to interview the Yankee coaches Willie Randolph and Chris Chambliss for their managerial opening -- though, technically, the Angels do not need approval, because the Yankees' contracts with Randolph, Chambliss and the rest of the coaching staff expired yesterday.

title: Charter Reform, Pro and Con
description: To the Editor:

title: Across the World, Families And Friends Sift Memories
description: Kurt Schwenk, the 39-year-old manager of business development at the Palm Computing division of 3Com Corporation in Santa Clara, Calif., was following one of his several passions when he took off on vacation with his girlfriend, her parents, his mother, Erica Schwenk of Hilton, N.Y., and his sister and brother-in-law, Mitzie Schwenk and Will Jackson of Scotch Plains, N.J.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BAYER A.G., Leverkusen, Germany, named David R. Ebsworth head of worldwide pharmaceuticals, succeeding Horst Meyer, who is retiring. Mr. Ebsworth had been president of the North American pharmaceutical division and vice president of Bayer Corp., Pittsburgh.

title: Daewoo Founder and 12 Other Executives Offer to Resign
description: Disgraced by the collapse of the business empire he founded 32 years ago, the chairman of Daewoo Group submitted his resignation today to the domestic creditors who are overseeing the sale of the South Korean conglomerate's vast array of heavily indebted businesses.

title: Officers Not Charged In Brooklyn Shooting
description: A grand jury has decided not to bring charges against four police officers in the fatal shooting of a mentally disturbed, hammer-wielding man on Aug. 30, the Brooklyn district attorney announced.

title: Ewing Making Small Strides
description: If Patrick Ewing continues to make the small strides, he may beat the January prediction for his return. Today, he shot with the Knicks for the third time and did some light running on the court.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Impact of Climate Change

title: 100 Years Ago, a Book Ignited the Study of the Mind
description: It was not the overnight success its author had hoped for.

description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Rescue Squad Comes to Aid of Florida Panther
description: With its Roman nose, gray-tinted coat and lethal jaws, the Florida panther was once a figure of mythological power that roamed throughout the southeastern United States.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGER, CHARLES
description: HAGER-Charles The Board of Directors of The Legal Aid Society mourns the death of Charles Hager, distinguished former member Stuart Meiklejohn, Chairman Daniel Greenberg, President

title: Lobbyists Plead Guilty, Ending Inquiry Into a Lawmaker
description: Two lobbyists pleaded guilty today in Boston to relatively minor charges arising from a huge construction project in Boston, thereby ending an investigation that had seemed to threaten the chairman of the House transportation committee.

title: Leading Black New Yorkers Meet Privately With Gore
description: Two months after Bill Bradley delivered a speech on race relations at a public hall in Harlem, Vice President Al Gore met privately yesterday with two dozen prominent black New Yorkers, some of whom urged him to begin campaigning in black communities across the state.

title: TRADE ENVOY OPTIMISTIC
description: Expressing confidence that World Trade Organization negotiators will succeed at the Seattle meeting that begins late this month, the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, said member nations were making progress toward an agenda. Ms. Barshefsky said there was an ''emerging convergence of views in some very big areas,'' including agriculture and services; sticking points, she acknowledged, include the question of whether negotiations will cover competition and antidumping policies.

title: A Soaring Spirit Trapped in the Rococo
description: The New York City Opera has added another new production to its staple repertory, this time ''The Abduction From the Seraglio,'' which opened on Sunday afternoon. The set is simple: two sheer walls that retreat and converge to form a triangle. The colors -- blues, aquas, reds and purples -- are striking; the costumes reflect turn-of-the-20th-century England and its influence on Ottoman dress.

title: In Fight Against Tuberculosis, Experts Look for Private Help
description: International public health officials and scientists are trying to enlist leading American philanthropists in plans to create a trust fund of $500 million to $600 million to help stop the spread of tuberculosis.

title: Civic Duty Calls, but It's A Sales Pitch
description: TECHNICALLY -- and you would do well to italicize that word -- neither the Council nor the charter commission tells people how to vote. Mailings at public expense are supposed to be purely ''informational'' (a requirement that does not apply to Mr. Giuliani's phone calls because they are paid by his political action committee with private money).

title: Giuliani Campaigns Upstate for Local Candidates
description: Traveling in a Gulfstream jet with the state Republican chairman, Bill Powers, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani made two speedy campaign appearances upstate today for the kind of local Republican candidates that he has rarely, if ever, endorsed, but who are now important to him as he prepares to run for the United States Senate against Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Metro Business; NextWave Seeks Price Cut
description: NextWave Telecom Inc. told a federal appeals court in Manhattan yesterday that a bankruptcy judge was right to reduce the price the company must pay for wireless telephone licenses because their market value declined in the months after a 1996 government auction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOHNEN, ISABELLE ALEXANDRINE
description: BOHNEN-Isabelle Alexandrine. Of Bronxville, NY, on October 30, 1999. Wife of the late Theodore. Mother of Mary and Theodore. Sister of Blanche Prinkey, Elizabeth Beall, and the late William Quinlan. Grandmother of Ashley M. Bohnen and Lacey A. Bohnen. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY, 2-4:00 and 7-9:00 PM Thursday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, NY on Friday, November 5, at 10:00 AM.

title: DISNEY DEAL DONE
description: Hong Kong confirmed that it had concluded negotiations with the Walt Disney Company to build a theme park there. Hong Kong's chief executive, Tung Chee-hwa, will announce the project today, along with executives from Disney's theme park unit. The government declined to discuss the deal, though officials briefed about it said Hong Kong would put up most of the cost, estimated at more than $2.7 billion.

title: Across the World, Families And Friends Sift Memories
description: They found each other late in life, after long careers in science and social work. They had raised eight children between them, and lost their first spouses to cancer.

title: GIULIANI ORDERED TO RESTORE FUNDS FOR ART MUSEUM
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani violated the First Amendment when he cut city financing and began eviction proceedings against the Brooklyn Museum of Art for mounting an exhibition that the mayor deemed offensive and sacrilegious.

title: Lord Jakobovits, Outspoken Chief Rabbi In Britain for 24 Years, Is Dead at 78
description: Lord Jakobovits, outspoken former chief rabbi of Britain whose views on individual responsibility endeared him to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, died on Sunday morning at his home here. He was 78.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, MAXINE P.
description: FREEDMAN-Maxine P. Dearest sister of Phyllis F. and Mike Seelig and the late Alan J. and Doris C. Freedman. A most committed and loving aunt to Kenny, Patty, Karen, Nina and Susie. A devoted great-aunt of ten. She willingly gave of her time to others with a clear mind and an open heart. Services Tuesday, November 2, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue,

title: Inspired Barkley Hopes To Be St. John's Leader
description: Some people wear their hearts on their sleeves, but Erick Barkley did not have much sleeve on his basketball shirt. So he wore at least two aspects of his expressive personality on his bare arms yesterday at Alumni Hall after his St. John's team finished practice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, DR. ABRAHAM J.
description: BRENNER-Dr. Abraham J. Devoted husband of the late Esther, beloved father of Lois, dear grandfather of Stephanie. Services 11:30 Wednesday at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

description: To the Editor:

title: Kelly Smith's 90 Minutes of Fame Yet to Come
description: Kelly Smith of Seton Hall scores a lot of goals, but there is more to her game than mere statistics. When she touches the soccer ball with the outside of the foot while running and surveying the field for the best option, it is clear she is a complete player.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, ESTHER
description: ROTH-Esther. We deeply mourn the passing of Esther Roth, sister of Fred Lafer, Chairman of the Board of Directors and Co-Chair of the Executive Committee of American Friends of the Hebrew University. On behalf of AFHU, we extend our deepest condolences to Fred and all the family. American Friends of The Hebrew University Keith L. Sachs, President Adam B. Kahan, Exec. Vice Pres.

title: For 4th Day, Jury Weighs Insanity in Subway Shoving Case
description: A Manhattan jury deliberated for a fourth full day yesterday without reaching a verdict in the trial of a schizophrenic man accused of killing a woman by shoving her in front of a speeding subway train.

title: Front Row
description: Fashion Ads in National Geographic

title: An Outspoken Church Defender
description: William A. Donohue refuses to lunch with the rich and powerful even though, he says, they come courting. He hardly ever takes phone calls -- unless, of course, it is from people like Cardinal John O'Connor -- and he never lets anyone tell him what to do.

title: Digital-Contract Bill Fails in House Vote
description: The House today turned back a proposal that would have given digital contracts the legal weight of ink and paper. The outcome essentially killed the bill's chance of passage this year.

title: How to Cut Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Prosecutor Teaching At an Elementary School
description: The former Essex County prosecutor, Patricia A. Hurt, who resigned Aug. 20 amid questions about her office's spending and handling of an investigation into the killing of an Orange police officer, is now an elementary school teacher in East Orange.

title: How Good Can Mammograms Be? Suits Seek to Set a Standard
description: Recently, a jury in Hawaii awarded $1.32 million to a 57-year-old woman who said her breast cancer diagnosis had been delayed for 17 months because a radiologist had not found it on a mammogram. In New York, a 37-year-old woman won a $2.5 million malpractice suit against a radiologist who she said had failed to find her breast cancer on a mammogram done seven months earlier. In Florida, a jury awarded $3.35 million to a 56-year-old woman who claimed that her breast cancer diagnosis was delayed for six months because her cancer had been missed on a mammogram.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAKOBOVITS, LORD IMMANUEL
description: JAKOBOVITS-Lord Immanuel. The officers, trustees and staff of the Memorial Foundation for Jewish Culture deeply mourn the passing of its esteemed past president, Lord Immanuel Jakobovits, former Chief Rabbi of Great Britain and the Commonwealth and a renowned leader of world Jewry. As president from 1988-1994, he advanced the Memorial Foundation's sacred mission of revitalizing Jewish cultural life throughout the world after the Shoah. To all the members of his family we extend our heartfelt condolences. Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler, President Dr. Jerry Hochbaum, Executive Vice President

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in the Metro Business column on Friday about plans by the French food company Fauchon to open its first American branch in New York referred incorrectly to a $3 million sales projection for next year. It is for the United States, not worldwide.

title: Beneath Cooper Union, the a Cappella Sounds of the Sistine Chapel
description: Renaissance polyphony from our vantage point floats freely in the air, describing an ethereal geometry of shape and density. In its time, however, the music of Josquin Desprez, Adrian Willaert and their colleagues was just as much about the places in which it was performed, the most familiar surviving example of this being Gabrieli's antiphonal brass calling back and forth across the interior of St. Mark's Church in Venice.

title: Hachette Partnership With Phase 2 Media
description: Hachette Filipacchi Media in New York, owned by Lagardere Group, said yesterday that it had acquired an equity interest in Phase 2 Media in New York, an online advertising and marketing company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: New York Sets Out Standards, Grade by Grade
description: In an effort to help parents hold schools accountable for what children learn -- or don't learn -- the New York City school system has produced a series of guides to what every child should know from kindergarten through 12th grade.

title: Cruise Line Account Goes to Arnold
description: Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines in Miami, part of Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd., said yesterday that it had awarded its integrated marketing account to Arnold Communications in Boston. Billings were estimated at more than $50 million.

title: Coast Guard Gives Up Search for Crash Survivors
description: The Coast Guard abandoned the search for survivors of Egyptair Flight 990 in waters off Nantucket Island yesterday, but recovered a large piece of the plane and detected submerged pinging signals, apparently from one of the black boxes, whose retrieval could explain the jetliner's mysterious plunge into the sea.

title: Assembly Races Draw Big Money and Little Interest
description: Tuesday's election for New Jersey's 80 State Assembly seats is expected to earn the unenviable distinction of having both the highest cost and the lowest voter turnout of any State Legislature elections in New Jersey history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, LOUIS
description: ROSNER-Louis. Died October 31, four days shy of his 95th birthday. Cherished husband of the late Mary, loving father of Audrey and Harriet, loving father-in-law of Irwin, loving grandfather of Gari and Guido, Caryn and Paul, Martin and Ruth and Claire, loving greatgrandfather of Meryl, Drew, Sarah & Jason. Graduated City College, CPA #

title: Accounts
description: * Petstore.com, Emeryville, Calif., a Web-based pet products retailer and advice company, to Black Rocket, San Francisco, to handle its first account. Billings were estimated at more than $15 million.

title: After a Lowly Season, Nets' Spirits Are High
description: The Nets have brushed off last season as if it were a mirage, as if the routine beatings they endured had nothing to do with their lack of skill and competitiveness and everything to do with the coach who was fired, the players who were traded and the injuries that were sustained.

title: Diet Change May Avert Need for Ritalin
description: My sister-in-law Cindy Brody thought that large amounts of sugary foods turned Sam, her otherwise normally active son, into a wild and aggressive animal, though well-designed studies have repeatedly failed to find a relationship between sugar per se and hyperactivity.

title: Canada Files Complaint Against YBM Offering
description: Canada's top securities regulator filed a complaint today against YBM Magnex International and its senior managers and directors, including former Premier David Peterson of Ontario, accusing them of failing to disclose negative information about the industrial magnet maker's business in a share offering prospectus in 1997.

title: AT&T CREATES LATIN UNIT
description: Seeking to strengthen its services to corporate clients, the AT&T Corporation said it would merge Netstream, its Brazilian telecommunications company, with the FirstCom Corporation, which is based in Florida. AT&T will control the company, to be called AT&T Latin America, and will inject $70 million into it together with Promon Tecnologia, a Brazilian partner.

title: Corrections
description: A highlight caption in the Television section on Sunday, for Thursday's programs, misstated the day for the show ''Sessions at West 54th.'' It will be seen on Channel 13 at midnight on Friday, not Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, A.
description: MILLER-A. Anthony of West Hempstead on October 31, 1999. Beloved husband of Nannette Connors. Devoted son of Frieda and Julius. Loving father of Kevin, Brian and Kara Miller. Dearest grandfather of Matthew Miller. Also survived by step children James, William, Julie and Thomas Connors. Reposing at the Krauss Funeral Home, Inc. 1097 Hempstead Turnpike, Franklin Square. Funeral Mass Friday 9:45 am at St. Thomas the Apostle RC Church, West Hempstead. Interment following at St. Charles Cemetery. Visiting hours Wednesday and Thursday 2-5 and 7-10 PM.

title: Across the World, Families And Friends Sift Memories
description: Imilda Kolander, 66, who traveled the world with her husband and on her own, was not quite fearless, but almost, said her husband, Harry. On a trip up Mount Ararat in Turkey, she was taken hostage by Kurdish rebels.

title: Like Old Times, Holmgren Wins in Green Bay
description: There is a street near Lambeau Field called Mike Holmgren Way. It was named after Holmgren for his seven years of service as the Green Bay head coach in which he won a Super Bowl and helped restore the Packers' legend and luster.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: ASIA

title: VITAL SIGNS: PATTERNS; How the Eyes Help Watch the Weight
description: Anyone who doubts the intimate connection between the eyes and the stomach should consider these observations.

title: G.M. Director Who Led '92 Management Shake-Up Sets Retirement
description: John G. Smale, the director who led a rare management coup at General Motors seven years ago this month, plans to retire in May, a G.M. spokesman said today.

title: Yacht Designers Put Theories to the Test
description: Years of planning, design and fixation on the tiniest details have finally come to this: catching a light breeze in its sails, a mighty yacht heaves its sleek form through the chilly New Zealand waters with sailors straining to understand every nuance of its performance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELOVER, VICTOR R.
description: SELOVER-Victor R. On October 29, 1999, of Garden City. Beloved husband of Donna, loving father of Russell, dear grandfather of Victoria. Funeral service private. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Cathedral of the Incarnation Memorial and Endowment Fund, 50 Cathedral Avenue, Garden City, New York 11530 appreciated.

title: Even Interview Is Now Over 30
description: The last thing the photographer David LaChapelle wanted to be associated with was a party where, as he put it, ''Miuccia Prada would be staring at Helmut Lang.'' Those two were indeed at Interview magazine's 30th anniversary party last Thursday night at the Kit Kat Club. And so were Calvin Klein, Fran Lebowitz, Barry Diller, Diane Von Furstenberg, Jon Bon Jovi, Tom Ford, Puff Daddy and Elizabeth Hurley.

title: U.S. Gives Its Backing, and Cash, to Anti-Hussein Groups
description: The Clinton administration made clear yesterday that its support for Iraqi dissidents would be channeled through the Iraqi National Congress, a diverse and shaky coalition of Iraqi opposition groups that have so far shown little in common beyond their hostility to President Saddam Hussein.

title: Frenchmen, Not Alike, Yet in Tune
description: The French violinist Renaud Capucon gave a confident debut recital at Weill Recital Hall on Friday evening, accompanied by his compatriot Frank Braley. They proved, in some essentials, unalike. Mr. Capucon plays with his rhythmic feet firmly on the ground: his phrasing is solid and molded much less by rubato than by careful choices from across a wide range of color and dynamic nuances around a decisiveness at the center of his tone. Mr. Braley is an excellent musician too and a master of color, but his personality is gentler and his rhythmic sense more pliable. But the differences only added to the robust strength and the collegiality of their partnership.

title: Couple Are Found Slain In Their New Apartment
description: A man and a woman were found shot to death in their new apartment on Sunday in what the Monmouth County prosecutor said was a murder-suicide.

title: NORTH AMERICAN VACCINE TALKS WITH POTENTIAL BUYER
description: North American Vaccine Inc. said yesterday that it was negotiating with a potential buyer after having two setbacks last month with distribution agreements for its first United States-approved product, a vaccine called Certiva. The undisclosed bidder is making a stock offer in line with the company's recent trading price, it said. North American's stock has dropped as much as 33 percent since Oct. 4, the day before Abbott Laboratories ended a United States Certiva marketing agreement. North American, based in Columbia, Md., rose 18.75 cents, to $5.50, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Women's Tennis Close to New Sponsorship Deal
description: It appears that the women's professional tennis circuit, which found its first title sponsor 29 years ago in Virginia Slims cigarettes, will again be sponsored by a women's product.

title: Front Line In Meningitis Campaign: Freshmen
description: Of all the infectious diseases that afflict Americans, meningitis ranks nowhere near the top. But meningococci, the bacteria that are a cause of both meningitis and other serious health problems, bring chaos disproportionate to the low case numbers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WHEELER, FRANK
description: WHEELER-Frank. 11/03/89. Remembering the fun and love we had with you. 10 years-hard to believe. Sis and The Kids

title: A Hint of a Fire Problem Halts Boeing Jet Delivery
description: The Boeing Company has halted delivery of 34 planes, and is discussing with the Federal Aviation Administration whether it will have to repair several hundred already delivered, after discovering that too much glue was used to put together a cockpit part, the company said today.

title: DANA SELLING WARNER ELECTRIC HOLDINGS TO COLFAX
description: The Dana Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its Warner Electric Industrial Products Group and most of its Warner Electric Industrial Motors and Controls Group to the privately held Colfax Corporation. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Warner Electric Industrial makes industrial clutches and brakes, while Warner Electric Industrial Motors makes a wide range of electric motors. Combined, the businesses had sales of $360 million in 1998. They employ 3,000 people at 22 manufacturing plants worldwide. Colfax, based in Richmond, Va., makes fluid handling and industrial positioning products. Dana, based in Toledo, Ohio, makes and sells components to vehicle manufacturers and related companies

description: BASEBALL

description: WEITZMAN-Mary C., Ph.D. The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns the passing of our distinguished associate professor emeritus of anatomy and structural biology. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the Weitzman family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D., Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine

description: To the Editor:

title: Badillo's Sound Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, LLOYD HILTON
description: SMITH-Lloyd Hilton. A resident of Southampton, NY, and Palm Beach, FL, died Wednesday October 27, 1999, in Palm Beach, FL. Mr. Smith often quoted the Mark Twain exclamation, ''If I cannot smoke cigars in Heaven, then I won't go,'' was 94. Born in Pittsburgh, PA, the deceased was a member of The Yale Class of 1929 where he was Editor of The Daily News. Following graduation he pursued a career in finance in New York City, and was a founder of Argus Research Corporation and Laird Inc. During World War II, he served in the U.S. Navy, achieving the rank of Lt. Commander, and seeing action in the Pacific, on the legendary aircraft carriers, The Hornet and The Wasp. Following the war, Mr. Smith was active as an independent oil and gas producer and was Chairman of Paraffine Oil Company in Houston, TX. He served on numerous corporate boards, including Curtis-Wright Corporation, Information Storage Systems, and Falcon-Seaboard Inc. He was also a Director of The Michael DeBakey Medical Foundation, and The Museum of Fine Arts in Houston. The deceased was well known as a staunch supporter of The Republican Party. He was a Founding Director of The National Review Magazine, and along with Paul Nitze, The Committee On The Present Danger. He was also a major benefactor of The American Spectator Magazine and The Heritage Foundation. Mr. Smith had been a Member of The National Golf Links of America, The Brook, The Southampton Club, The Meadow Club, and The Racquet and Tennis Club in New York, and The Everglades and The Bath and Tennis Clubs in Palm Beach. Mr. Smith was predeceased by his wife, Elizabeth Keith Wiess, and his sister, Elizabeth Smith Hamilton. He is survived by four daughters, Camilla Clay Smith, Sandra Isabel Lloyd, and husband Douglass Smith, Sharon Keller, and husband David, and Sydney MacPherson, and husband Barry, grandchildren, Robert Livingston Gerry IV, Lloyd Harriman Gerry, Christopher Schaefer Keller, Michael Roland Keller, Elizabeth Cairns MacPherson, Ian Barry MacPherson, Megan Keith MacPherson, and great grand daughter Katherine Lloyd Keller. Funeral services were held Friday October 29, 1999, at 3 P.M. at The Episcopal Church of Bethesda By The Sea, in Palm Beach. Interment was on Monday November 1, 1999, at The Southampton Cemetery. The family has requested memorial contributions be made to the donors' favorite charities.L

title: The Doctor Is Mum
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, IRWIN
description: KATZ-Irwin. Of Rockville Centre, L.I. Died peacefully on October 28, 1999. Age 91. Son of the late Samuel and Rose Katz. Loving uncle of Alice Goldstein, Richard Katz and the late Arthur Katz, together with numerous grand nieces and nephews.

title: AMERISERVE FOOD TAKES STEPS TO CUT ITS COSTS
description: AmeriServe Food Distribution said yesterday that it would eliminate 1,500 jobs, or about 15 percent of its work force, as one of several measures meant to cut costs and bolster cash reserves. The Addison, Tex., company, which distributes food to national restaurant chains like Pizza Hut, Red Lobster and Taco Bell, also plans to raise as much as $140 million through asset sales and inventory reductions, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. AmeriServe, which is privately held, described the moves in a letter it is sending to suppliers. The letter seeks to allay concerns about the company's financial condition, particularly its payment of outstanding bills and the costs of an ongoing restructuring

title: A Policy Shift On Serbia Tied To a Free Vote
description: The Clinton administration, trying to strengthen the opposition to President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, has agreed to end its economic sanctions on Serbia as soon as there is a free election there, senior administration officials said today.

title: Yankees Decide to Keep O'Neill and Strawberry
description: The Yankees retained outfielder Paul O'Neill and designated hitter Darryl Strawberry for next season, exercising contractual options, as expected. O'Neill will receive $6.5 million, Strawberry $750,000.

title: Small Change for Voters By Mail: 55 Cents Lost
description: For years, absentee voters in New York City enjoyed a little bonus: their ballots were prepaid by the City Board of Elections.

title: Earnings for Marks & Spencer Slide 43%
description: Marks & Spencer, the troubled British retailer that owns the Brooks Brothers chain in the United States, reported a 43 percent drop in first-half earnings today and announced a major restructuring that includes property sales and use of cheaper overseas suppliers.

title: Mickey and Minnie Go to Hong Kong; A Proposed Disney Park Raises Queries on Tourism and Cost
description: On Aug. 23, 1998, a delegation from the Walt Disney Company arrived at the office of Hong Kong's chief executive to pitch the idea of building a Disneyland here. That summer day, Hong Kong was far from the happiest place on earth.

title: Critic's Notebook; In the End, the 'Sensation' Is Less the Art Than the Money
description: No one should have been surprised by a court's decision on Monday in favor of the Brooklyn Museum of Art and against New York City and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, since the ruling was predictable, but museums across the country must have been relieved anyway.

title: Democrats Win Seats in Three Districts, Narrowing Republicans' Majority
description: Democrats picked up three seats in elections for New Jersey's 80 State Assembly districts today, narrowing the Republicans' majority in the lower house of the Legislature to 45-to-35.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, WOLCOTT
description: JONES-Wolcott ''Bud''. Age 71. Of Southbury, CT. On November 2, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Iris Hathoway Jones. Loving father of Jeff Jones of Coventry, CT. and Amy Hamilton of Pearl River, N.Y. Memorial Mass November 13, 11AM, Church of the Epiphany, 262 N. Main St, Southbury, CT.

title: JETS
description: Initial bids for the Jets range between $475 million and $510 million, according to people involved with the sale process. The lower offer has been made by Charles F. Dolan, the Cablevision chairman, and the higher bid by Sam Grossman, a Phoenix-based real estate developer.

title: Parcells Taps Mirer, And Points Finger, Too
description: With a virtual demand from Bill Parcells that he had better produce, Rick Mirer received his coach's less-than-wholehearted endorsement at quarterback today over a still gimpy Ray Lucas as the Jets began the work of trying to salvage the season.

title: MARRIOTT TO HALT 35 SENIOR-LIVING COMMUNITIES
description: Citing what it termed ''supply pressures in some markets,'' Marriott International said yesterday that it would cancel up to 35 senior-living communities that are in early stages of development. The Washington-based hotel company, which currently operates 139 senior-living centers and is building an additional 15, also said slow sales at newly opened centers were expected to reduce earnings by 5 cents a share in the fourth quarter. The projects to be canceled represent about half of the senior-living projects in the company's development pipeline, Marriott said

title: After Union Leader's Death, Discovery of $2 Million Raises Questions
description: For two years, Stanley Israel headed one of the city's lesser known labor unions, the Correction Officers' Benevolent Association. After losing a bitterly contested union election in 1995, Mr. Israel, described by some associates as a man of simple tastes, retired.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about research breakthroughs in molecular electronics misstated the academic specialty of Mark Reed at Yale University. He is the chairman of the electrical engineering department, not a chemist. The article also misstated the given name of a researcher at the Mitre Corporation. He is James C. Ellenbogen, not John.

title: Sills Said Don't Do It, And Dislikes the Sound
description: When Paul Kellogg, the artistic director of the New York City Opera, visited Beverly Sills, the chairwoman of Lincoln Center, to tell her he was installing a new sound system at the New York State Theater, ''I advised him not to,'' Ms. Sills said. ''If I was in that job, I wouldn't.''

title: Gonzalez Is Traded and Griffey Awaits His Turn
description: With teams already trying to position themselves for the incredible class of free agents next fall, the Texas Rangers swapped the star slugger Juan Gonzalez to the Detroit Tigers in a nine-player deal, and the Seattle Mariners announced that Ken Griffey Jr. has requested a trade and that they will try to comply with the demand of the center fielder, who seems destined to break Henry Aaron's career home run record.

title: Judging Teachers In Consumer Era
description: A WOMAN who lives on an island needs to join her fiance on the mainland so they can marry. The boatman, seeing she is desperate, doubles the charge for the trip. She does not have the money, but a stranger offers to pay the fare if she sleeps with him. The deal is consummated. The woman and her fiance marry. Three years later, a friend of the fiance, now the husband, learns of the deal and tells him. The outraged husband divorces the woman.

title: No Breathing Required
description: THERE was a time each year, soon after Alexis Lichine had returned to New York from the harvest at Prieure-Lichine, his chateau in Bordeaux, when we would drive up to Westchester to have lunch with Alfred A. Knopf.

title: Maybe 'the Best Manager in America,' Clearly a Model for Other Executives
description: When John F. Welch Jr. resigns from General Electric in April 2001, he will actually leave two vacancies: those of G.E.'s chief executive and corporate America's most-admired manager.

title: Sampras Struggles In His Comeback
description: With his game showing rust and his timing lacking in his first match in more than two months, Pete Sampras had to save three match points to beat Francisco Clavet of Spain, 4-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-4) at the Paris Open last night.

title: Talks on Ulster Stop to Let Mediator Seek Counsel
description: George J. Mitchell today suspended his nine-week-old mission to unblock the deadlocked Northern Ireland peace accord, saying he needed to brief President Clinton and the British and Irish prime ministers, Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern, before reconvening talks in Belfast on Monday.

title: A Happy Accident: A Pretzel With More Snap
description: I WAS drinking a beer and eating pretzels and, at first, paying little attention to either. But something about the pretzels had me reaching in the bag again and again.

title: Prosecuters Say Colonel's Wife Sent Heroin From Columbia
description: An American Army colonel's wife who has charged with mailing illegal drugs from the United States Embassy in Colombia to New York City smuggled heroin, and not, as originally thought, cocaine, according to Federal prosecutors.

title: Republican Defeats Incumbent In Race for County Executive
description: Joel Giambra, the Republican candidate for Erie County executive who was endorsed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, defeated the Democratic incumbent, Dennis Gorski, who quickly conceded last night.

title: EURO DISNEY PROFIT FALLS
description: Europe's largest theme-park operator, Euro Disney, said its profit in the second half of the fiscal year fell 8.7 percent after it began paying royalties to the Walt Disney Company, its biggest shareholder. Net income for the company, the operator of Disneyland Paris, fell to 68.9 million euros, or $72.6 million, in the six months that ended on Sept. 30. Royalties and higher financing costs pushed down earnings after a five-year waiver on payments to Walt Disney came to an end.

title: New M.T.A. Spending Plan Badly Flawed, McCall Says
description: A fiercely contested proposal by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to spend $17.5 billion on repairs and expansion of its subway, bus and commuter train service is based on unclear and flawed financial assumptions, according to a report issued yesterday by State Comptroller H. Carl McCall.

title: Man Opens Fire in Xerox Office, Killing 7
description: An apparently disgruntled service worker for the Xerox Corporation in Honolulu drove to his company's offices early yesterday morning and, with murderous precision, shot and killed seven co-workers, the police said.

title: Japan Drafts Bill to Control Some Cults By Year's End
description: The government approved a bill today that is intended to restrict the expanding activities of the Aum Shinrikyo doomsday cult, the group behind the fatal nerve gas attack in the Tokyo subway system in 1995 and other terrorist acts.

title: It's Johnson Standing in the Knicks' Spotlight
description: In the middle of a team trying to live up to its introduction as the defending Eastern Conference champion last night, there was Larry Johnson, bending and turning and pivoting in the paint as if he were a kid again, playing a game of Twister.

title: Indonesia Releases Bank Audit, Hastening I.M.F. Help
description: Indonesia's Parliament published a long-awaited report today on a banking scandal that had helped bring down the administration of former President B. J. Habibie, and the International Monetary Fund said the move cleared the way for it to resume a $43 billion economic rescue package by the middle of next month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORMAN, JOSEPH
description: FORMAN-Joseph. It is with profound sorrow that Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center/Rutland Nursing Home, its Board of Trustees, Medical/Dental Staff, and all personnel mourn the passing of Joseph Forman, esteemed Board Member. Sincere sympathies to his wife, Jean, and family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. David Minkin, President Emeritus Stanley Mandel, Chairman Of The Board Linda Brady, M.D., President and CEO

title: Prodigal Smith Named Chairman of Senate Environment Panel
description: Senator Robert C. Smith, a New Hampshire conservative who recently forsook the Republican Party, and then rejoined it, was elected chairman of the important Environment and Public Works Committee today, a move that could profoundly reshape environmental policy.

title: As Years Increase, Her Times Get Faster
description: If there were still an East Germany, 38-year-old Katrin Dorre-Heinig says she would be a doctor specializing in cancer research. Instead, in a unified and democratic Germany that allows her to do what she wants, she has become history's fastest female marathon runner over age 35 and a favorite in Sunday's New York City Marathon.

title: Packard Bell NEC Plans Layoffs Of Up to 88% of Its Work Force
description: Packard Bell NEC Inc., the struggling personal-computer maker controlled by the NEC Corporation, said today that it would lay off as much as 88 percent of its work force in the United States. The company also said that its chief executive would resign and that it would stop selling the Packard Bell brand in the United States.

title: CLAIRE'S STORES TO BUY RIVAL CHAIN AFTERTHOUGHTS
description: Claire's Stores Inc., a retailer of accessories and jewelry for teenagers, agreed yesterday to buy a rival chain Afterthoughts from Venator Group for $250 million. Afterthoughts operates 768 mall stores that sell costume jewelry, handbags and other items to 14- to 19-year-olds. It had sales of about $194.6 million last year. Claire's 2,200 stores sell similar items mainly to younger people, age 8 to 14 years. New York-based Venator, the former Woolworth Corporation, has been selling or closing smaller chains to focus on its athletic-shoe stores Champs and Foot Locker. Venator expects a gain of about $87 million, or 64 cents a share, from the Afterthoughts sale

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOONEY, DONALD F.
description: MOONEY-Donald F., Esq. Born July 9, 1926. Died November 1, 1999. Beloved father of Kathleen, Mark, Donald, Joanne, Jacqueline, Matthew and Paul. Husband to Florence, grandfather to Michael, Megan, Nicole, Annabelle and Kevin. Survived by sister Pat and brother to deceased, Jack and Margaret. Alumnus of Regis High School, Fordham University, St. John's Law School and member of the International Maritime Association. Wake services, Wednesday & Thursday 2-4 & 7-9 PM at Lincoln Park Funeral Home, 625 McLean Avenue, Yonkers, NY (914-963-1550). Mass, Friday 10:30 AM at St. Anthony's R.C. Church, Nepera-Park, Yonkers, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Sisters of Charity, c/o Sister Elizabeth Vermaelen, Mt. St. Vincent on Hudson, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, NY 10471 apppreciated.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Shelf Life for Spices

title: NEW YORK VOTERS STRONGLY REJECT CHARTER REVISION
description: New York voters resoundingly rejected revisions to the City Charter yesterday in a defeat for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who had campaigned for the changes as a referendum on his policies. The vote was a victory for Mark Green, the Public Advocate, and other Democratic politicians, who had criticized the revisions as a mayoral power grab.

title: New York Authority Negotiating to Sell 2 Nuclear Plants
description: The New York State Power Authority said today that it was negotiating to sell its two nuclear power plants, which would be one of the largest asset sales ever by the state, and signals the continuing, rapid evolution of the electric power industry.

title: Poll Worker Killed on Way To Help Out With Election
description: Barbara Blanchard wanted to celebrate her 46th birthday yesterday, a day early, at the Bronx polling site where she helped people to vote because she saw that as her civic duty. But she never got a chance to rejoice in either the birthday or her duty.

title: New Publishers For 2 Magazines
description: Two magazines have named publishers.

title: DAEWOO INVESTIGATION THREATENED
description: Lee Hun Jai, chairman of South Korea's Financial Supervisory Commission, said he would seek investigations into possible negligence of duties by top Daewoo Group management officials. Mr. Lee said that inquiries may begin as soon as debt-workout programs put core Daewoo affiliates back on the track toward recovery. Accounting firms responsible for auditing Daewoo's books may also face investigation, he said.

title: Man Dies After His Cigar Sets His Car on Fire
description: A lighted cigar that a man tossed from the window of his car on Monday was blown into the back seat, igniting papers and debris and ultimately setting the entire car on fire, fatally injuring the man.

title: Ship Locates Data Recorders, but Storm Complicates Search and Recovery Efforts
description: Navy searchers said yesterday that they had definitively determined the watery location of both the flight data recorder and the cockpit voice recorder belonging to Egypt Air Flight 990, an essential discovery in the quest to learn why the Boeing 767 plummeted into the Atlantic Ocean off New England early Sunday morning, killing all 217 people aboard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNAHUM, MICHAEL
description: BENNAHUM-Michael. On November 1, Michael Bennahum, 58, died of cancer at home surrounded by his family. He is survived by his soulmate and wife Leslie, his children David and Samantha who gave him so much joy, his aunt Stella whom he loved dearly, and his brother David whose care and love were constant. Though taken so soon, we were blessed with every moment Michael shared with us. His generosity extended to his work as an investment banker, film producer, and Democratic social activist. His greatest gift was the gift of inspiration, especially to the young where he gave them the confidence and clarity to extend themselves in pursuits that seemed beyond their reach. His legacy will live on through all the lives he inspired. In the words of the poet R.M. Rilke, ''I live my life in circles/that reach out across the world./I may not complete the last one,/but I give myself to it.'' Burial in Binyamina, Israel. Memorial service Tuesday, November 9, 2:30 p.m. Beir Chapel, Central Synagogue, 123 E. 55th St. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan.

title: Revlon Replaces Its President With an Executive From a Rival
description: Financially troubled Revlon said yesterday that it had hired a former manager of a key competitor to replace its president and chief executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PISKIN, MAY
description: PISKIN-May. On Tuesday, November 2. Devoted wife of Oscar, loving mother of Pauline Sherman, cherished grandmother of Jonathan and Jennifer Sherman, mother-in-law of Milton Sherman, and great grandmother of Alexander Westley-Sherman. We will miss you very much and remember you always for your giving and inspirational strength. Funeral services will be private.

title: Audience Reaction Is More Ho-Hum Than Outrage
description: Surtitles! Microphones! Few things in opera arouse more opposition than change. For the serious operagoer, the human voice is a sacred instrument and nothing must stand between it and the audience, even if it clarifies a work. And the trained human voice in its pure form, unencumbered by amplification or alteration, has an almost religious significance. Opera singers are the sum total of all their training, of their physiognomy, the size of their palate and voice box, the configuration of their teeth, their lung capacity. And to the purist, any attempt to interfere with them is fundamentally a lie.

title: East Timor Leaders Oppose a Malaysian-Led Force
description: SINGAPORE  The East Timorese leadership has effectively vetoed a proposal by Malaysia, which prides itself as a champion of Third World causes, to take command of the United Nations-sanctioned force that will help prepare the territory for independence within three years, diplomats said Tuesday.

title: Kenneth L. Schnitzer, 70, Dies; Innovative Houston Developer
description: Kenneth L. Schnitzer, a visionary Texas real estate developer and civic leader whose 30 commercial buildings form much of the Houston skyline, died on Monday after a six-month battle with lung cancer. He was 70.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPLIN, VIRGINIA T.
description: CHAPLIN-Virginia T. The National Board of the YWCA of the U.S.A. is deeply saddened by the tragic loss of Virginia T. Chaplin, National Board member from 1970 to 1982 and one of its Vice Presidents, a member of the World Service Council from 1982 to the present and President of the YWCA of Lewiston - Auburn, Maine from 1958 to 1962. She will be remembered for her commitment and dedication to the improvement of the quality of life of the women, girls and their families both nationally and globally. The YWCA of the U.S.A., National Board and staff extend their heartfelt condolences to her family. She shall be missed. Alexine Clement Jackson, National President Prema Mathai-Davis, CEO

title: Irish Trainer Tries Dirt With 3-Race Challenge
description: Aidan O'Brien of Ireland, 30 years old and loaded with wit and charm, landed in Florida the other day with eight of his horses and a growing reputation as the brightest young trainer in Europe. He sized up the humid weather and the enormity of outrunning the best horses in America in the Breeders' Cup, and said: ''They all traveled very well. Now is when the problems start.''

title: Holmgren Is at Home On Road in Wisconsin
description: Little surprise that Mike Holmgren prepared his Seattle Seahawks for their visit to Green Bay on Monday night in his hammer-like style, head on, candidly and decisively. He told them that this was a special game. He told them that the crowd at Lambeau Field was even more special. He imparted his insights on the Green Bay players that he had coached for the previous seven seasons.

title: Privacy in Financial Dealings
description: The financial services bill that will overhaul the nation's banking laws is a good deal for financial institutions but a bad deal for consumer privacy. The bill would allow banks, brokerage houses and insurance companies to merge into financial conglomerates, a long-overdue reform. The banking industry stands to gain from the right to expand into other businesses, and consumers could benefit from the ease of one-stop shopping and the creation of new financial services. But protecting consumers' financial privacy should also be central to financial modernization. This bill is weak on that score.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLIGERMAN, HOWARD
description: KLIGERMAN - Howard. We mourn the loss of our exceptional friend, a dedicated father and loving husband who will be dearly missed by all. Our heartfelt condolences to the family. The Mehler Family

title: What Justice For Dictators?
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Affairs; Social Safety Net
description: Estimates are that by 2005 one billion portable Internet connections will be deployed around the world -- be it through cell phones, pagers or Palm Pilots. And by 2010 there'll be about three billion -- so many in fact that 100 million toasters should be online by then. Why not? Finland is already putting phones in Coke machines -- you can charge your drink to your home number -- and the company DigiScents plans to deliver smells over the Internet by sending data to a ''Snortal'' attached to your PC, which would on command mix different chemicals to recreate various scents. Look around: anything with electricity is being reinvented to carry software and become networked. That's the future. Even for your toaster.

title: Senate Panel Approves Bill on Patent Revisions
description: Legislation that would revamp the United States patent system and bring it closer in line with European and Japanese practices is moving quickly through Congress.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about rising violence among people involved in stock fraud misstated the crimes admitted in 1997 by Barclay Davis, a New York stock promoter. He pleaded guilty to money laundering and conspiracy to commit securities and bank fraud; he did not admit to prosecutors' allegations that he tried to have an accountant and a stock speculator harmed.

title: Leo Group Plans to Acquire MacManus
description: Leo Group, the advertising concern that created the Jolly Green Giant and the Marlboro Man, is acquiring MacManus Group, the creative team behind Bounce fabric softener and Pampers. It also plans to take the new combined group public next year, company executives said yesterday.

title: Rubin May Leave as State Dept. Spokesman
description: James P. Rubin, chief spokesman of the State Department and one of Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's closest and most powerful advisers, has suggested to Dr. Albright that he may resign in the spring, administration officials and friends of Mr. Rubin said today.

title: In Search of a Chinese Trade Deal
description: President Clinton's new efforts to salvage a trade deal with China enabling it to join the World Trade Organization come as welcome news. The initiative, begun with a phone call last month from Mr. Clinton to President Jiang Zemin, seeks to repair what administration officials now concede was a policy blunder in April when Washington rejected market-opening terms offered by Prime Minister Zhu Rongji on his visit to the United States. Worse yet, publication of the Chinese terms by the administration triggered opposition by opponents of Mr. Zhu's reforms inside China, making any deal more difficult to achieve.

title: Gathering and Waiting for Results of Grim Search
description: Sayed Gabr emerged into the cold late afternoon fog clutching a batch of color photographs.

title: National News Briefs; Unions Win Pledge At Gulf Coast Shipyard
description: After six years of trying to unionize 4,000 workers at the Avondale shipyard near New Orleans, a coalition of 11 labor unions won a partial victory yesterday. Avondale's new owner, Litton Industries, agreed with the New Orleans Metal Trades Council not to fight unionization and promised to recognize the unions if a majority of the shipyard's workers signed cards saying they wanted union representation.

title: Eating Your Way to Wisdom and Harmony
description: ET tu, Ben and Jerry?

title: Biogen Halts Remaining Trials on Drug
description: Biogen said today that it had halted the remaining trials of its experimental Antova compound, two weeks after suspending most studies of the drug because of signs that it was triggering blood clotting problems.

title: For Queens College Lab, Fanfare Turns to Whispers of Doubt
description: Two years ago, Queens College announced with great fanfare that it had snared Dr. Luc Montagnier, co-discoverer of the AIDS virus, to become a professor and the linchpin of a big new AIDS research center on the Flushing campus.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Public Lives column on Oct. 21 about Paige Rense, editor in chief of Architectural Digest, misstated her observation about the results of the initial public offering of Martha Stewart's Omnimedia. Ms. Rense said, ''As you know, Martha Stewart just became a billionaire'' (not ''millionaire'').

title: 3 Deaths Loom Large In Norfolk
description: In this pristine slice of small-town New England, where the village green nearly resembles what it looked like two centuries ago, the modern intrusions of jet crashes and long-distance grief seem particularly jarring.

title: New Air-Bag Rules Would Again Require Vehicle Crash Tests
description: Federal safety regulators said today that auto makers should be required to install frontal air bags that deploy fast enough to protect adult men who are not wearing their seat belts, and they proposed stringent rules that would take effect in the 2003 model year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENKINS, MURIEL GERLI
