description: JENKINS-Muriel Gerli. Of North Palm Beach Florida on November 2nd in New York City. Beloved mother of Dorinda Howard and Diana Squibb; stepmother of Farish and Edgar Jenkins; grandmother of Timothy and Christopher Yates, Wendy Howard and Andrew Squibb; sister of John and David Gerli. A funeral service will be held on Friday November 5th at 11:00 AM at Christ Church, Rectory Street Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Breher Park Zoo, 1361 Summit Ave, West Palm Beach, Fl 33405

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAVA, ALYSSA CLAIRE
description: PAVA-Alyssa Claire. Suddenly, in Santa Fe, N.M. on October 27, 1999. Beloved daughter of Dr. Yale and Freda Pava. Cherished niece of Evelyn Schwartz, Judy Cohen and Pearl Lesser. Beloved cousin to many. Services Thursday, 1PM at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: In Barcelona, Savoring Eroticism and Its Painters
description: At the entrance to a large exhibition of erotic art in an 18th-century palace in central Barcelona, a discreet sign written in Catalan, Spanish and English warns that ''Garden of Eros,'' as the show is called, is for ''adult audiences'' and that unaccompanied minors will not be admitted. The advisory also cautions visitors who might wander into the palace unprepared that ''they may find works on show offensive.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEDER, MAX
description: FEDER-Max. Of Sunrise, FL, and former longtime resident of Brooklyn and Forest Hills, NY, on October 29 at age 90. Son of Philip and Ida. Beloved husband of 59 years of the late and deeply missed Rose. Devoted father of Michael. Loving grandfather of Jonathan. Caring brother of Shirley and the late Irving, Betty, Mary and Ebby. Private services and interment were held. Contributions in his memory may be made to The United Lubavitcher Yeshivoth, 841-853 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, NY 11230. He was a man of faith and humor-and an independent spirit who will live in our hearts forever.

title: Drug Maker Accepts a Fine Over Test Kits
description: Abbott Laboratories, the nation's largest maker of medical diagnostic devices, agreed today to pay $100 million to settle accusations that the company failed to meet federal quality standards when it made hundreds of varieties of medical test kits.

title: Isles: Rebuild and Win?
description: Mike Milbury, discussing the outlook for the Islanders in what promises to be another tough season, said yesterday that while a youth movement will proceed, he is concerned with winning games right away.

title: Simple and Sweet From a Master Baker
description: AS I paged through ''Room for Dessert'' by David Lebovitz, I immediately began baking and tasting -- in my head. I wondered if the ginger cake, made with fresh ginger, would be much different from one made with dried ginger. Or if the black and white cookies would be crisp and bittersweet, like a cocoa cookie I once made from a recipe in a newspaper clipping. I wanted to make the nocino custard simply because I had never heard of it before.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Abbott Laboratories to Pay $100 Million Over Test Kits

title: Meeting in Oslo on a Mideast Settlement in a 'Last Sprint'
description: President Clinton today began what he described as a ''last sprint'' with Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, to devise a peace settlement.

title: Clinton Tells Russian of Concern Over Chechnya Bombing
description: At a meeting here today with Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, President Clinton expressed strong concern over the Russian air and artillery bombing of Chechnya and the suffering of civilians in the breakaway region, a senior administration official said.

title: Unsettling Moments for Devils
description: Even though they are in first place in their division and have a winning record (6-4-1), an aura of unhappiness is starting to develop around the Devils. There seem to be too many players who feel uncertain about their role on the team. There have been so many changes in roles and line combinations by Coach Robbie Ftorek and his staff that players are starting to look over their shoulder. They play with such nervousness that they commit mistakes in their zone and hold the stick tight when in scoring position.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, ESTA
description: EPSTEIN-Esta (nee Reichman). At age 82 on November 1, 1999. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Marilyn Berger and Judy Wacht. Loving mother-in-law of Albert Berger and Harvey Wacht. Cherished grandmother (Granny) of Lauren, Dorian and Michael. Dear sister of Fay Silverman and Shirley Glaser. Funeral services private.

title: Valentine Must Wait; So Must Phillips
description: Mets General Manager Steve Phillips confirmed yesterday that neither he nor Manager Bobby Valentine will have their contracts extended beyond next season, the final year on both of their deals. At the end of next season, Phillips added, his contract situation will be addressed before Valentine's, because Valentine reports to Phillips.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, SAMSON D.
description: PRICE-Samson D. Died November 2, 1999 in Greenville, SC. He was 96 years old. He is survived by his wife, Ruth; his sons, Kenneth, Edward and Arthur; his grandchildren Giselle, Andrew and Stephen; and his daughters-in law, Graciela, Patricia and Sandra. He was a pioneer of the frozen fruit industry. He was a founder of Chill-Ripe Fruit, Inc., Frosted Fruit Products, Inc., Mid-Valley Products, Inc, and Empacadora Santa Clara, S.A. He was devoted to his family, his church and his industry.

title: In 'New' Mexican Politics, Some Old Tricks
description: Mexico's governing party pledged to turn over a new leaf this year by making its first presidential primary open, clean and fair. But since Francisco Labastida Ochoa seems to be the president's choice, many old guard party leaders are backing him with the dirty electoral tricks that have kept the party in power for 70 years.

title: Once Common, but Now Exotic
description: QUINCE, a stepchild in the orchard and a princess in the fruit bowl, makes its annual appearance at the greengrocer's this time of year, though hardly in great abundance. Not a fruit for eating out of hand, quince has a sour, astringent taste uncooked. But with cooking, quinces acquire a mellow yet piquant flavor, somewhat like that of a spicy pear. Once it has been tasted, the quince becomes as much a part of autumn's favorite flavors as pumpkin.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The gospel according to Greenspan: rising home prices.
description: ALAN GREENSPAN, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that in some ways surging home prices give a greater kick to the economy than rising stock prices do.

title: With Little to Pique Interest, Most Voters Yawn
description: The expansive gym was quiet. There were no lines. No one was in a hurry. More than a dozen election monitors -- most of them elderly women -- waited for voters at their tables under the white backboards and bright fluorescent lights at Public School 199 in Sunnyside, Queens.

title: Column Begins Today
description: Starting today, Fred Andrews will write a column every other week. The first topic is Prof. Clayton M. Christensen of Harvard. Management, Page C10.

title: Our Towns; A 'Hero' Gone, Accusations Divide Town
description: New Jersey has contributed two signifi cant and contrasting -- chapters to the nation's law and lore of sex crimes: community notification of sex offenders under Megan's Law, and community shielding of sexual predators in the notorious Glen Ridge gang-rape case of the late 1980's.

title: Hilary Tjader Harris, 69, Sculptor and Experimental Filmmaker
description: Hilary Tjader Harris, an experimental and documentary filmmaker and kinetic sculptor, died on Oct. 26 at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 69.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, LEONARD DAVID
description: JACOBS-Leonard David. On Monday November 1, 1999 of South Orange, NJ. Beloved Husband of Marlene (Nee Holwitz). Devoted Father of Jeffrey B. Jacobs, Adam S. Jacobs, and Ann S. Jacobs. Dear Brother of Jerome Jacobs. Adored Father-in-law of Marilynn Jacobs and Zohar Kirshenboim. Loving Grandfather of Rebecca Leigh Jacobs, Mia Alexandra Jacobs, Daniel Philip Jacobs, and Lee Jacobs Kirshenboim. Cherished Cousin of Marilyn Linden. Loved by Many. Funeral Services conducted from Congregation Beth El, 222 Irvington Avenue, South Orange, NJ on Wednesday, November 3, 1999 at 1:00 PM. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery Woodbridge, NJ. In Lieu of Flowers donations may be made to The Cultural Arts Committee of Congregation Beth El, 222 Irvington Avenue, South Orange, NJ 07079. Information: The Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBLICH, MANETTE
description: LIEBLICH-Manette. The Board of Governors and members of Elberon Bathing Club mourn the untimely passing of our dear friend and longtime member, Manette Lieblich. On behalf of all our members, we express our deepest condolences to her family. Robert Fagenson, Pres. Jane Guadagno, Secy.

title: Phillips's Tenure Is at Stake as Umpires Vote on the Fate of Their Union
description: Preparing for an election that will determine their collective bargaining future, 52 umpires met today in an all-day session that was clearly aimed at abolishing the power of Richie Phillips as the umpires' labor leader.

title: In Jet Crash Inquiry, Learning From Past Missteps
description: Mysteries still dominate the investigation into what caused EgyptAir Flight 990 to plunge suddenly into the sea as it headed from New York City toward Cairo early Sunday. No cause has been determined. Little evidence has been recovered.

title: Giuliani Expected to Begin TV Ads in Upstate New York
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is expected to begin broadcasting his first television advertisements in upstate New York promoting his likely candidacy for the United States Senate, starting as early as today.

title: A Passion for Community
description: I spent seven years as an outdoor leadership instructor, starting at age 19. I took people through storms, over passes, up technical rock climbs. I once climbed 70 feet with no rope protection to get a rappel rope that was snagged on a little piece of rock. In Yellowstone, I rescued two people with frostbite; I had to get them out before their feet thawed, because when that happens you're in screaming pain.

title: Though Heavily Outspent by Opponent, Democrat Wins Easily in East Side Race
description: Eva S. Moskowitz, a 35-year-old former college instructor, won a lopsided victory yesterday in a City Council race representing the East Side of Manhattan. Ms. Moskowitz, a Democrat, won despite being heavily outspent in one of the costliest and hardest-fought campaigns the city has seen for a Council seat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUNSDORF, PAULINE
description: RUNSDORF-Pauline. Died November 1, 1999 at 92. Widow of Theodore Runsdorf. Mother of Sissy Greenberg, Lee and Lucette Runsdorf. Grandmother to Fran and Alan Hirmes, Jeffrey and Jodi Greenberg, Elise and Brian Napack, Jim and Nina Runsdorf, and the late Warren Greenberg. Great grandmother of Justin, Kimberly, Alexa, Katie, Evan and Georgi. Services at 10 AM, Boulevard Park West Chapel, 1415 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCALPIN, KATHLEEN
description: MCALPIN-Kathleen Middleton. On October 31, 1999 Kathleen M. McAlpin beloved mother of Frank Vinton Lawrence III, sister of Nora Kidwell, grandmother of Jennifer R. Pieters. Widow of the late Frank V. Lawrence, Jr. and William Rockefeller McAlpin. Memorial Services will be held on Friday, November 5, 1999 at 2:00 PM at St. Pauls Episcopal Church in Chestertown, MD. A memorial service in Norfolk, CT will be held at a later date. Information: Fellows, Helfenbein, and Newnam Funeral Home Chestertown, MD.

title: BANK PROFIT RISES
description: Spain's largest bank, Banco Santander Central Hispano S.A., said its third-quarter profit rose 29 percent. The bank, formed in an April merger of the biggest and third-biggest Spanish banks, said profit rose to 408.3 million euros, or $429 million, from 316.4 million euros had the banks been combined a year earlier. Santander has closed branches and shed staff in pursuit of 25 percent earnings growth this year.

title: Dull Promotion for Holyfield-Lewis
description: The promoters of the Evander Holyfield-Lennox Lewis heavyweight unification rematch reasoned that if they could get the two fighters together on a conference call yesterday they could ignite some excitement for the bout, which is less than two weeks away.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: You Can Quote Him on That

title: Corrections
description: A dance review yesterday about a performance of Agnes de Mille's ''Fall River Legend'' by American Ballet Theater at City Center on Sunday misstated the given name of a dancer who portrayed one of the town sweethearts. She is Rosalie O'Connor, not Rosemary.

title: Defending the Operatic Voice From Technology's Wiles
description: Blaring amplification systems that destroy spatial relationships among performers onstage and turn a musical score into just one element of a high-tech spectacle have been major components of Broadway musicals for at least 20 years.

title: Russians Balk at Opening Nuclear Sites to U.S. Eyes
description: This was supposed to be a banner day for American-Russian cooperation. The American ambassador was scheduled to cut the ribbon at a gala opening of a United States-financed business center in one of Russia's closed nuclear cities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCONNON, B. RAY
description: McCONNON-B. Ray, Jr. On Monday, November 1, 1999 at Reston Hospital. Husband of Karon McConnon, father of B. Ray McConnon, III, Catherine Simons, Caron Fritz and Kerry McConnon, grandfather of Brittany Catherine Schott and Devin Patrick Simons. Friends may call at at Everly-Wheatley Funeral Home, 1500 West Braddock Road, Alexandria, VA, Wednesday, November 3rd and Thursday November 4th, 6-8PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at 11AM, Friday, November 5th from St. Rita's Catholic Church, 3815 Russell Rd, Alexandria, VA. Interment Quantico National Cemetery.

title: Animal May Have Seen Tractor as Sexual Rival : Hippo Kills Zoo Director
description: PARIS  A male hippopotamus in rut, an annual state of sexual excitement, apparently mistook a tractor for a rival  or a female hippopotamus  and trampled the director of a zoo near Bordeaux, officials there said Tuesday.

title: Accounts
description: Top of the World Trade Center Observatory, New York, part of Ogden Entertainment, to Kovant & Brodsky, New York, to handle its account, which had been at Barker Campbell Farley Mansfield Advertising, Virginia Beach, Va. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: With Friends Like These . . . The Story of Kinski and Herzog
description: When the actor Klaus Kinski wrote his autobiography, he referred to Werner Herzog as ''the vermin,'' ''this blowhard'' and ''a miserable, hateful, malevolent, avaricious, money-hungry, nasty, sadistic, treacherous, cowardly creep.'' And those were some of the nicer things he had to say. Now Mr. Herzog has a chance to return the favor with ''My Best Fiend: Klaus Kinski,'' an account of their unbelievably turbulent collaboration and how each man tormented and goaded the other into doing his best work.

title: I Was a 60-Something Gap Girl
description: wanted to be a salesgirl at the Gap. Never mind that I was 60 years old and the last time I worked a cash register had been nearly half a century earlier in a Chicago clothing store for women.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, MAXINE
description: FREEDMAN-Maxine. The Brotherhood Synagogue mourns the passing of our Honorary Trustee, supporter of Israel and devoted Jew. Condolences to her loving family.

title: Subway Jury Deadlocks; Mistrial Ruled
description: A mistrial was declared yesterday in the trial of Andrew Goldstein, the schizophrenic who pushed a woman he had never met to her death in front of a subway train in January, after a hospital worker and a former social worker on the jury said they could not convict him of second-degree murder because they believed Mr. Goldstein was insane at the time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, STEPHEN J.
description: KING-Stephen J. The employees of the New York City Department of Environmental Protection mourn the passing of our esteemed Director of Police. We will truly miss this dedicated and trustworthy public servant. To his wife, Tina, and to all his family, we extend our deepest condolences.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: The Rarest of Treats: Just Hold the Meat

title: As Season Starts, So Does a Quest For a Go-To Guy
description: Latrell Sprewell signed a new contract yesterday before the season opener, one of those deals (five years, $61.8 million) that ensures he will not have to spend another night at a two-star White Plains lodge. ''I can't live there forever,'' he said with a half-smile. Allan Houston received his financial security in 1996, $56 million and change.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHELPERT, JOHN W.
description: SCHELPERT-John W., MD. It is with deep and profound regret that James R. Jones, MD, Professor and Chairman, and the faculty of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology of New York Medical College acknowledge the tragic death on board Egyptair Flight 990, Sunday, October 31,1999, of Dr. John Schelpert, and his wife, Joanne. Dr. Schelpert was much respected and loved by his colleagues, residents, medical students and patients. He joined the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology of New York Medical College in 1989 and retired to Maryland in 1994. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his daughters Jane, Ann, Susan and Elizabeth. Dr. Schelpert and Joanne will be sorely missed by all, and are in our thoughts and prayers.

title: Liberties; The Alpha-Beta Macarena
description: I will say this in Naomi Wolf's favor: You've got to respect a woman who gets a vice president to pay her a salary higher than his own.

title: Raiding Memory Lane
description: Somehow, a local promoter named Jon Weiss managed to coax three seminal but semiobscure 60's bands out of retirement this weekend for his annual Cavestomp festival of garage rock, Friday through Sunday at the Westbeth Theater Center in the West Village. They are the Standells (playing Sunday night), the Chocolate Watchband (Saturday), and the Monks (Friday and Saturday). With the exception of a show or two, these bands have not performed in more than 30 years. Their members have become astronomers, restaurateurs, truck drivers and producers of children's audiotapes. But this weekend they will be rock stars again, with their shows recorded by Mr. Weiss for release as live CD's.

title: Fox Film Group Names a New President
description: Fox Entertainment Group said today that Tom Rothman had been promoted to president of 20th Century Fox Film Group, giving him oversight of the studio's two main movie divisions: 20th Century Fox and Fox 2000 Pictures. Mr. Rothman had been president for production at the 20th Century Fox division.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA FALLS. Cocoa fell as shippers in the Ivory Coast, the world's largest supplier, begin exporting newly harvested beans at a time of weak demand. In New York, cocoa for December delivery fell $38, to $840 a metric ton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JESSON, CHESTER S.
description: JESSON-Chester S. of Rutherford, NJ, died Saturday October 30, 1999. Mr. Jesson was born in Bayonne, NJ. He was a retired linotype operator for the New York Times. Mr. Jesson was a Staff Sergeant in the Army Air Corps. Serving in Guam during WW II. He was a parishoner of St. Mary R.C. Church, Rutherford, NJ where he sang in the choir. Mr. Jesson was a member of the Old Guard of Rutherford. Mr. Jesson was predeceased by his wife Helen (nee Dembowski). He is survived by his son Paul, and daughter-in-law Eileen of Shelton, CT. his grandson Paul Charles of Baltimore, MD, and two sisters Florence Martinsen, of Red Bank, NJ, and Hattie Symanski of Bayonne, NJ. Funeral from the Collins-Calhoun Funeral Home, 19 Lincoln Ave., Rutherford, NJ. on Wednesday at 9 AM. Funeral mass at St. Mary's R.C. Church, Rutherford, NJ at 9:30 AM. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, N. Arlington, NJ. Friends will be received Tuesday 2-4 & 7-9 PM.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about United States support for Iraqi opposition groups referred incorrectly to what the United States says it is giving. While the opposition coalition received backing, the State Department said it would not get cash until it had incorporated itself as a legal entity with a transparent bookkeeping system.

title: Fassel Readies Offense's Plan B
description: There are people who listen to Giants Coach Jim Fassel talk about his team and its anemic offense and think he's delusional. What in the name of Pollyannaism is all this ''the glass is half full'' nonsense?

title: AIR CANADA SWEETENS OFFER
description: Raising the ante in a takeover fight, Air Canada sweetened the cash component of its proposal to shareholders in an effort to thwart an unwanted bid from the Onex Corporation. Air Canada said it would pay 16 Canadian dollars, about $10.90, a share for 36 percent of its stock, up from 12 dollars. Onex has proposed buying Air Canada and Canadian Airlines and merging them into a single airline. Air Canada wants to acquire Canadian and run it as a separate unit. Timothy Pritchard

title: MACERICH SELLS SHOPPING MALLS TO JOINT VENTURE
description: Macerich Inc. sold three of its California shopping malls yesterday to a joint venture it formed with Ontario Teachers Pension Plan Board for about $535 million, cutting its debt load. Separately, the company, a real estate investment trust based in Santa Monica, Calif., bought the 560,000-square-foot Santa Monica Place shopping center for $130 million in cash and assumed debt. The seller was the Rouse Company. The three malls Macerich is selling are Lakewood Mall, Stonewood Mall and Los Cerritos Center, all in Los Angeles County. Macerich and Ontario Teachers formed their joint venture in February. Macerich owns a 51 percent stake in the venture, and Ontario Teachers has 49 percent. Macerich said the venture would assume $322 million of debt on the malls.

title: What Justice For Dictators?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YUNKER, ROSE ELIZABETH
description: YUNKER-Rose Elizabeth (nee O'Rourke). Of Point Lookout, L.I. On October 31, 1999. Loving wife of the late Howard. Beloved mother of Susan Yunker and Michael Yunker. Cherished grandmother of Beth, Jenni and Sean. Dear sister of Ann O'Rourke, Grace Bartnett and Patricia Morrison. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated on November 4, 1999, 11am at Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal R.C. Church, Point Lookout, Long Island.

title: BACK IN JAPAN'S CARD MARKET
description: The largest United States financial services company, Citigroup, will buy the credit card company Diners Club Japan, marking a return to the Japanese card market. Citigroup agreed to purchase a 60 percent stake in Diners Club Japan owned by Fuji Bank, the country's sixth-largest lender, and the 40 percent owned by the travel agency Japan Travel Bureau for an undisclosed sum. The acquisition returns Citigroup to a credit card market it exited in 1990, when it sold the stake in Diners Club Japan it originally owned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBLICH, MANNETTE
description: LIEBLICH-Mannette. The Officers, Trustees, and Members of The Hollywood Golf Club note with sorrow the passing of their long time friend and member, Mrs. Mannette Lieblich. We offer our heartfelt condolences to her family. Bernard D. Karasic, President Charles Weissman, Secretary

title: Bush Emphasizes Morals in Prescription for Education
description: Lamenting that classrooms had ceased to be safe places where students are taught moral values, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas said today that schools should allow more religious expression, that teachers should be freer to punish unruly students and that the government should more aggressively prosecute children who carried guns.

title: Danger at the Crossroads
description: When President Clinton met yesterday with Vladimir Putin, the Russian Prime Minister, to convey concerns about the 200,000 refugees fleeing Russia's attack on Chechnya, he was addressing a part of the world where there is a wider American interest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHICKELE, DAVID
description: SCHICKELE-David. Film maker, violist and composer, 62, died of Cancer on October 31st in his San Francisco home. He is survived by his wife Gail, son Graham Spencer Nighttrain, daughter Laura Bissonette and brother Peter. His gifts touched many lives. Donations may be made to Commonweal, Box 316, Bolinas, CA 94924.

title: Red Sox Fan's Treachery
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Speech on Education
description: Following are excerpts from a speech today by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas on the importance of teaching morality in schools:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, JAROLD
description: FREEMAN-Jarold and Barbara. The Board of Directors, Scientific Advisory Committee, Postdoctoral Fellows and employees of The Irvington Institute for Immunological Research note with great sadness the tragic and untimely deaths of Jarold Freeman and his wife Barbara Freeman on Egyptair Flight 990. Our deepest sympathies are with Jarold's daughter, Gail Freeman, our esteemed Executive Director. Mrs. John J. Veronis, Chairman Joshua S. Rubenstein, President

title: Despite U.S. Protests, U.N. Relief Aide in Baghdad Is to Stay On
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan has asked the United Nations relief coordinator for Iraq to stay for another year, despite pressure from the United States and Britain to dismiss him.

title: Sports of The Times; It's Camby To Rescue At Garden
description: ON behalf of the New York news media, and in the spirit of the new basketball season and the coming holiday season, I am extending the following offer to Jeff Van Gundy: If the coach promises not to burden us with daily forecasts of doom, we hereby agree to not overreact to any Knicks defeat until we can quantify its impact relative to postseason math.

title: Crab Cakes That Let The Crab Stand Out
description: GETTING the most out of crab cakes often means putting the least into them. Since crab has the best texture and subtlest flavor of all crustaceans, the best crab cakes are those that showcase the crab, not another ingredient. When you load crab cakes up with white bread, corn or curry and top them with a fussy sauce, you might be making them different, but not better.

title: Senate Backs Lower Import Tax On Africa and Caribbean Goods
description: A popular package of trade bills for African and Caribbean nations escaped a procedural thicket in the Senate today and advanced toward final approval when the senators voted to limit debate and consider amendments to the far-reaching legislation.

title: Commercial Real Estate; M.T.A. Starts Big Move Downtown
description: Some of the city's transportation agencies have been on the move over the last three weeks, the start of a long-term relocation of most operations of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to Lower Manhattan.

title: A Necklace Of Jewels By Ellington
description: Bobby McFerrin genially stole the show at ''Love You Madly,'' the fourth annual gala concert for Jazz at Lincoln Center, which raised more than $1.2 million. Like most institutional galas, it offered the easygoing, well-known side of the repertory. Continuing the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra's yearlong celebration of the centennial of Duke Ellington's birth, it was a concert of miniatures: ''three-minute masterpieces,'' as Wynton Marsalis put it, that slipped Ellington's inventiveness into tunes that became pop standards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSUNA, MARY ANN
description: OSUNA-Mary Ann. Also known as Sydney Sloane. Beloved wife of Jess. Devoted mother of Tracy. Loving grandmother of Sean. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, NYC. Funeral Mass Friday 9:30am Our Lady of Pompei Church. Interment Calvary cemetery. Visiting Wednesday 7-9:30pm and Thursday 2-5pm and 7-9:30pm.

title: Foreign Nameplate Autos Are Sales Favorites in U.S.
description: Buyers snapped up cars and trucks with foreign nameplates last month, forsaking some of their past favorites -- American-made sport utility vehicles.

title: A Primer on Weathering Technology's Storms
description: IN ROUND 1, the giants of the old bricks-and-mortar economy took their lumps from their new Internet rivals on several notable fronts: books, toys, stock trading. Now, in Round 2, they are fighting back with their own incursions into the Internet, most prominently the online services established by the big Wall Street firms.

title: Heavy Winds Leave 100,000 Homes in Dark
description: Wild winds of more than 65 miles per hour toppled trees and power lines throughout the region last night, plunging more than 100,000 homes into darkness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBLICH, MANNETTE NEUMAN
description: LIEBLICH - Mannette Neuman. Lover of family and nature, especially flowers and animals. Devoted wife of Daniel Parke Lieblich. Loving mother of Nancy Bracken Garson and Lynn Jeffery. Unforgetable grandmother to Genevieve and Emily Bracken; Todd Daniel, Diana, and Carolyn Jeffery. Loving sister of Emanuel Neuman. Memorial service 2PM Thursday at Temple Beth Miriam, Elberon, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Monmouth County, NJ S.P.C.A., Planned Parenthood, or the Mannette Neuman Lieblich-Beautification Fund of Deal, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRITZER, LEO
description: KRITZER-Leo. Beloved husband of the late Ruth Vogel Kritzer. Adored father of Lester and Laurie Kritzer and Arthur. Cherished grandfather of Amy Ruth and Andrew Herbert Kritzer. Loving brother of Jesse and the late Herbert. Services at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York, 12:30PM Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSTERIS, MARIA
description: FOSTERIS-Maria (nee Dinescu). October 31, 1999. Mother and wife. She kept her family together for 70 years. Burial Thursday in Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: F.B.I. Notes Shed More Light On Political Donor's Case
description: A Democratic fund-raiser who emerged as a central figure in the long-running investigations of Democratic fund-raising told the F.B.I. in an interview that Bill Clinton reacted with ''surprise'' when a wealthy Indonesian businessman told him he wanted to raise a million dollars for Mr. Clinton's first presidential campaign.

title: REDESIGNING NATURE: A special report.; Squash With Altered Genes Raises Fears of 'Superweeds'
description: For most of the 30 years Bernie Thiel has been growing squash, he has battled an invisible but potent adversary: viruses that can turn his neat rows of sunny-yellow vegetables into a mottled, sickly green harvest.

title: Supreme Court Considers Police Reaction to Unprovoked Flight
description: There was general agreement during a Supreme Court argument today that there might be reason to be suspicious of a person who runs away at the mere sight of a police officer. But the question before the justices went beyond that everyday observation to whether unprovoked flight, by itself, is so inherently suggestive of wrongdoing as to turn a person into a potential suspect who can be chased, stopped, questioned and frisked by the police.

title: Nassau County Halts a Century Of G.O.P. Rule
description: A century of one-party rule in Nassau County reached a crashing end Tuesday as voters across this wealthy county, furious over a last-minute property tax increase and embarrassed by the county's fiscal crisis and by a wave of government scandals, gave Democrats legislative control for the first time ever.

title: Rising Star in French Cabinet Falls in a Corruption Inquiry
description: Prime Minister Lionel Jospin's government suffered a major blow today when one of its rising stars, Finance Minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn, resigned in the face of growing accusations of corruption.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a tentative agreement allowing the Library of Congress to buy personal papers of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. misstated the initial amount requested by the King family. A family spokesman said the request was for $20 million, not $30 million.

title: Born Anew Every Day To Be Abused And Baffled
description: Since at least that famous time when Dante got lost in a dark forest six centuries ago and felt an urgent need for explanations, people have been waking up at halfway points in their existences and wondering what on earth they're doing there. Where, after all, would American literature be without the midlife crisis?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAHN, WILLIAM FREDERICK
description: HAHN-William Frederick, Jr. On November 2, 1999, of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL, formerly of Garden City, and Centerport, NY. Was for many years a leading worldwide figure in the moving and storage industry as President of Hahn Brothers. Beloved husband of the late Muriel Gucker Hahn, devoted father of Muriel Losee and Danelle Kensbock, loving granfather of Thomas P. Losee III, and Kendall Losee Graebner, and loving great grandfather of Clark E. Graebner III, and Lars Thomas Losee. Memorial services to be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Cathedral of the Incarnation Memorial and Endowment Fund, 50 Cathedral Avenue, Garden City, NY 11530, would be appreciated.

title: Book Revives Issue of Pius XII and Holocaust
description: The debate over the conduct of Pope Pius XII during World War II has lasted far longer than either the war or his 19-year papacy.

title: Rewriting the Resume Rules of the Road
description: It is a tenet of the job search, passed down to college graduates for decades: Keep your resume short, ideally no more than one page. A single sheet is more likely to hold an employer's attention and make an applicant look organized, not arrogant.

title: China's Future Is in Girls
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO GAINS. The euro rose against the dollar on speculation that the European Central Bank would raise interest rates on Thursday. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0515, up from $1.0506 on Monday.

title: MacLean Is Left Dangling on Fourth Line
description: Because he is a goal scorer who cannot score goals, John MacLean finds himself in an unusual position: skating on the Rangers' fourth line.

title: Some Italian Sparkle at a Brooklyn Diner
description: FIRST came Diner, an authentic but decrepit old diner on the south end of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, that was cleaned up and turned into a glowing little neighborhood bistro. Now comes Miss Williamsburg Diner -- once the greasiest of spoons -- scrubbed until gleaming inside and serving dishes of pasta rather than burgers and fries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARP, SAMUEL
description: KARP-Samuel, on November 2. Beloved husband of Helen. Dear father of Bruce and Stephanie, Iris and Louis, and the late Walter J. Cherished grandfather of Stacy, Walter, Jennifer, Jessica and David. Dear brother of Louis and Martin Karp and Gerry Lapayover. Service today, 1PM, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn (near Avenue V).

title: Tempest-Tossed
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Civil Rights Crusader Takes On the World
description: THE REV. LEON H. SULLIVAN, the Philadelphia civil rights legend, anti-apartheid warrior and grandmaster corporate guilt-tripper, set down in New York briefly this week to address the world.

title: Movado Expands AG Relationship
description: Movado Group in Lyndhurst, N.J., expanded a relationship with AG Worldwide in New York, formerly Arnell Group Brand Consulting, by awarding AG its Movado brand, which had previously been handled in-house. Billings are estimated at $12 million. AG already handles creative duties for the Movado Concord and ESQ Swiss watch brands.

title: C.I.A.'s Gaffe? A Male Failing
description: One of the unwritten rules for cabinet members testifying in Congress is not to be too candid about how your colleagues stumbled into really big mistakes. Apparently, no one conveyed that to the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky.

title: Segundo Show Delayed
description: Tonight's performance by the Cuban singer Compay Segundo at Town Hall in Manhattan has been postponed until next Wednesday at 8 p.m. Tickets for tonight's concert will be honored. Refunds are available at the point of purchase. Information: the Town Hall box office, (212) 840-2824.

title: Dangerous Curves: The New Banquettes
description: THE deep, curved banquette at Union Pacific is the most alluring table in the room: plush and cozy, dimly lighted. And if you are lucky enough to get it, you nestle into your own little pod, protected yet part of the passing scene, and feel smugly content. You know you have snagged the best table.

title: Roommate Is Charged After a Headless Body Is Found on a Corner in Queens
description: A 25-year-old Queens man was charged yesterday with murder, accused of strangling and then decapitating his companion, whose naked body was found on a street corner near their apartment in Corona early Monday morning, the police said.

title: Fat-Free but Fattening
description: To the Editor:

title: Harry Potter's Readers
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrat Wins Close Race for Mayor in Philadelphia
description: Holding off a spirited Republican challenge, the former City Council president, John F. Street, was elected mayor of this Democratic bastion on Tuesday, prevailing with a late electioneering surge that marshaled the party faithful from President Clinton to the ward captains of the city's proud Democratic machine.

title: Art, Speech and a Sad Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: As Joyous as It Is Macabre; A Mexican Holiday Ensures the Dead Have Their Day
description: As bloody ghouls and wart-specked witches scurried along the sidewalk on Sunday night, Eduardo Fuentes and his siblings watched from inside their house in the Norwood section of the Bronx, obliging the demands of trick-or-treaters but remaining coolly detached from the masquerade going on outside. ''It's fun to see,'' Eduardo, 16, said. ''But it has nothing to do with us.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COUGHLIN, ELIZABETH
description: COUGHLIN-Elizabeth (Aunt Liz) On November 1, 1999. Loving sister of Francis, the late Daniel and Augustine (Uncle Brother). Loving, helpful and caring aunt to ten nieces and nephews and 21 grand nieces and grand nephews. Former Chief Archivist of American Mental Climax, past President of Soropotimist International of New York. Long time resident of St. Francis DeSales Parish, Manhattan. Member of the famous Brefni Court Association in Rockaway. Reposing at Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave.(81 St.)N.Y. Visiting 7-9pm November 3rd; 2-5pm & 7-9pm on Thursday, November 4th. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Francis DeSales Church, 135 E. 96 St. Manhattan, Friday, November 5th, 1999 at 10am. Burial in Calvary Cemetery Friday. Donations in lieu of flowers to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, N.Y. 10461 in her memory would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, ROBERT E.
description: GOODMAN-Robert E. On Monday, November 1, in Amagansett, NY, after a short illness. Bob was married to Eleanor and had five children, John, George, Peter and Jim Goodman and Leslie Cayce. In lieu of flowers please send gifts to East End Hospice in Westhampton, NY.

title: Mike Wallace Getting Over It
description: Mike Wallace says he still has not seen the movie ''The Insider,'' Michael's Mann's re-creation of the most turbulent moments of Mr. Wallace's professional life as a correspondent for CBS's ''60 Minutes.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, THOMAS
description: JOHNSON-Thomas ''Mac''. Of Greenwich Ct. On October 31, 1999 at age 73. He had a long and distinguished career in the advertising business at Better Homes & Gardens, Sports Illustrated, Hockaday Associates, DeGarmo, AC&R, and R. Gesell & Co., producers of fine watches for NFL Properties. Greatly missed by wife, Carol, daughter, Lisa Kane, son, Chris (Monika), and sister Judi (Charles) Thompson. Services 11:30 AM, Saturday, at St Paul's Episcopal Church, Riverside, Ct.

title: Abidjan Journal; Political Woman Goes From Ivory Tower to Street
description: The often told story about Henriette Diabate went like this: the woman with the impeccably proper upbringing once lost an election because instead of making sure that the ballots were being counted properly after a long day, she daintily went home to take a bath.

title: Gaffney Wins Re-election To 3rd Term
description: The Suffolk County executive, Robert J. Gaffney, easily won re-election today to a third four-year term, defeating his Democratic opponent, Sheriff Patrick A. Mahoney, according to unofficial returns.

title: THE CHEF
description: PAIN AU CHOCOLAT, the French after-school treat, and its Italian cousin, bread slathered with Nutella, inspired me to create these chocolate rolls. I wanted a bread that wasn't too sweet but wouldn't need butter or jam. A bread that would be rich and, in its own way, decadent. Something that would be perfect for breakfast or as an afternoon pick-me-up.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Ruggerio Thinks East

title: G.E.'s Chief Sets a Date To Step Down
description: Everyone knew it was coming, but now they know when: John F. Welch Jr., the chairman of General Electric, will retire after the company's annual meeting in April 2001.

title: Korea Refracted Through a SoHo Lens
description: THERE are few tricks more difficult than picking up a raw scallop with chopsticks. At Woo Lae Oak, the waiter was trying to move a dozen onto the gas-fired grill on our table, and for an American, he was showing a deft hand. Still, by scallop No. 10, the strain began to show.

title: NEW HEAD FOR I.B.M. IN ASIA
description: Kakutaro Kitashiro, general manager of IBM Japan, was promoted to general manager of I.B.M.'s Asia-Pacific operations. He will be the first Asian executive to head the company's sprawling operations in the region, which include 35,000 employees in 19 countries, and the highest-ranking Japanese executive ever at I.B.M. His elevation is testament to the successes IBM Japan has had in a market dominated by domestic rivals. Stephanie Strom

title: Congressional Panel Approves Banking Bill
description: A committee of lawmakers from the House and Senate approved legislation today repealing Depression-era laws that had restricted the banking, securities and insurance industries from entering one another's businesses.

title: From The Heart Of the City, Real Ragu
description: IT'S a simple dish yet, minor variations in ingredients and technique can provoke passionate arguments. Its origins are most likely noble; yet, its heights were reached after years of peasant refinement. It's the epitome of home cooking, yet can be the pride of a restaurant.

title: WINN-DIXIE AGREES TO SELL SOME STORES TO KROGER
description: Winn-Dixie Stores agreed yesterday to sell its 74 stores in Texas and Oklahoma to the Kroger Company, for an undisclosed amount of cash to focus on the Southeast. Winn-Dixie will sell 69 stores and a dairy in Texas and 5 stores in Oklahoma to Kroger. That will leave Winn-Dixie, which is based in Jacksonville, Fla., with 1,114 stores in 12 states. The purchase will strengthen Kroger's position in the Dallas-Fort Worth area and help it expand in other markets, Kroger said. It already has 171 stores in Texas and Oklahoma. Cincinnati-based Kroger has 2,192 supermarkets and other stores in 31 states

title: Acquisition by Cooper
description: Cooper Industries, the maker of Crescent wrenches and Halo lighting fixtures, has agreed to acquire the closely held Crompton Lighting for an undisclosed price to increase its customers in Europe. Terms were not disclosed. Cooper is based in Houston; Crompton, a maker of lighting fixtures and specialty lamps, is based in Guiseley, England.

title: Diplomacy in Oslo
description: The hard bargaining lies ahead. But the important players in the Mideast peace talks did their best yesterday to convert the good will surrounding a memorial service in Oslo for the pioneering Israeli peacemaker Yitzhak Rabin into renewed efforts to reach a final agreement between Arabs and Israelis by the end of next year. Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, proclaimed their willingness to take the courageous decisions that will be necessary to achieve this ambitious timetable, beginning with a framework agreement by mid-February. For his part, President Clinton pledged to do whatever he could to help, including possibly a Camp David-style summit meeting early next year.

title: Newbridge Warns Again About Its Earnings
description: Shares of the Newbridge Networks Corporation fell 25 percent today after the Canadian maker of communications switches warned of unexpectedly weak fiscal second-quarter results, mainly because of sluggish sales in the United States. Hoping to regain momentum and investor confidence, the company replaced its president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEW, JOHN
description: LEW-John. On October 31, 1999 after a long battle with lung cancer. Survived by his wife, Harriet King, two sons Andrew and Christopher, his parents, a sister and a brother. Memorial service November 4 at St. Michael's Church, 225 W. 99th St., 10:30-11:30 a.m. In lieu of flowers donations to Gilda's Club, 195 W. Houston St, NY 10004.

title: Smith Has National Record in Sight
description: GETTYSBURGH

title: For Research, Students Now Head to Barnes & Noble
description: When Sarah Schissel, 10, a savvy public school student on the Upper West Side, needed to research the materials certain American pioneers used to build their homes, one of her first stops was not her local library but a Barnes & Noble Booksellers.

title: As Hours Lengthen, Workers Gain Freedom to Set Them
description: Americans are putting in longer hours than ever, but at least they have more say today than in years past about when they work them.

title: Art, Speech and a Sad Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: A Budget Cut of 1% Is Passed by Senate; Clinton Dismisses It
description: The final battle of this year's budget war was joined today, as President Clinton rejected as ''blind'' and ''mindless'' an across-the-board budget cut passed by Congress and his negotiators hunkered down with congressional chairmen to shape the federal budget behind closed doors.

title: Publisher Drops Holocaust Book
description: Schocken Books suspended publication yesterday of ''Fragments,'' a memoir about a Latvian Jewish orphan's early life in a Nazi camp. The publisher cited evidence that the account was no more than a vivid fantasy.

title: Suicide Law Is Humane
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Travel; At least one airline is bucking the trend toward further restrictions for carry-on luggage.
description: SHORT of war and high school, there are few times when as much general antipathy prevails as those moments when several hundred people, fumbling with clunky carry-on bags, squeeze onto a fully booked airplane.

title: Readin', Writin' and Earthquake Drills
description: At 11:14 on a recent Friday, as students in Irma Mendoza's fifth-grade class at Victory Boulevard School in the North Hollywood section were receiving handouts, a timer went off, sending everyone under their desks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZPATRICK, ROBERT
description: FITZPATRICK-Robert & Sharon. Of Southold, Long Island, NY. Formerly of Port Washington, NY. Died in the October 31st crash of Egyptair Flight 990. Robert was 69 years old, Sharon was 67. Beloved parents of Tara, Scott, Sean, and Maura; loving grandparents of Cassidy, Jameson, Rory, and Shea. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, November 13 at 1:00 p.m. at St. Patrick's Church, Main Rd., (Route 25), Southold, NY. In lieu of flowers the famiily requests that contributions be made to the Leukemia Society of America, 600 3rd Ave, NY, NY or to Island Harvest, 199 Second St., Mineola, New York 11501.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAU, RAYMOND
description: BLAU-Raymond, 89, died on October 30, 1999 of South Orange, New Jersey and Longboat Key, Florida. President of Max Blau & Sons, Inc. Loving husband of the late Hope Blau. He is survived by his loving daughters Maxine Blau and Adele Blau Cass, and grandsons David and Gregory. Friends and family may pay their respects Saturday and Sunday from 1-8 p.m. at the home of Adele Blau Cass, 168 Glenview Road, South Orange, NJ. For more information call (973) 642-4900.

title: So Saucy, in Her Life and Her Work
description: SECRETS OF THE FLESH

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: A Crew Aide Weighs Leaving

title: New Jersey's Sloppy Start Is Too Much to Overcome
description: Don Casey's first regular-season game as the Nets' head coach (without the ''interim'' attached to his title) started horribly.

title: Mayor Says Judge Rushed Decision in Museum Case
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani accused a federal judge yesterday of rushing to issue her ruling in the Brooklyn Museum of Art case to block city lawyers from fully investigating the finances of the museum's ''Sensation'' exhibition.

title: Art, Speech and a Sad Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: Seven People Killed In a Honolulu Office
description: A Xerox employee killed seven co-workers yesterday at the company's Honolulu office, the police said.

title: Alan Heimert, 70, Professor And Expert on Early America
description: Alan Heimert, a longtime Harvard professor whose scholarship about 18th-century America was influential and controversial, died on Monday in Washington. He was 70 and lived in Winchester, Mass.

title: Oxford Health Plans Posts Its First Profit in Two Years
description: Breaking a 21-month streak of losses, Oxford Health Plans, the big New York-area insurer, posted its first profitable quarter in two years yesterday.

title: Internet Door Is Wide Open to Blacks
description: To the Editor:

title: Masters of Their Fate: A Holocaust Fantasy
description: The fact that for many people a Holocaust comedy is oxymoronic hasn't prevented filmmakers from Ernst Lubitsch to Mel Brooks to Roberto Begnini from finding antic humor in the ultimate 20th-century horror. Whether that humor strikes us as funny or appalling depends on our personal responses to the unthinkable. That's why some who watch ''Train of Life,'' Radu Mahaileanu's fable about a Jewish village somewhere in Central Europe that beats the Nazis by building its own deportation train and riding it to freedom, may have the queasy feeling of seeing history trivialized. Others will find a redemptive warmth in its fantasy of self-deliverance accomplished through the ultimate pseudo-assimilation of Jews posing as Nazis.

title: Rite Aid Restates 2 Quarters' Results
description: Rite Aid, the No. 3 United States drugstore chain, said today that it had a second-quarter loss that was not as wide as it forecast, and it restated financial results for two quarters.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Here's someone who has everything in life: a husband, children, grandchildren, money, diplomas, honors. But she's here with us, in the middle of all of us who have nothing and who are fighting to get something.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMBROS, LAMBROS J.
description: LAMBROS-Lambros J. On October 29, 1999, at age 64. Loving father of John F. Lambros and Olivia W. Lambros. Devoted son of Niki and the late John Lambros. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, 5-7 PM, and Wednesday, 10 AM-12 noon. Funeral services at the Greek Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74 St., Wednesday, 2 PM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to Norfolk Library, PO Box 605, Norfolk, CT 06058.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROSBY, COL. HENRY ASHTON
description: CROSBY-Col. Henry Ashton. Aged 87, died November 1st. of a heart attack in Franconia, NH. Beloved husband of Letitia Elise. Father of Henry Ashton, John Player, Sheldon Bedloe, Eleanor Latrobe Hall, Letitia Elise Haynes and George de Forest Crosby and 14 grandchildren and one sister, Rosalie Crosby Gevers.

title: When Biotechnology Crops and Their Wild Cousins Mingle
description: Since genetically engineered crops came on the American agricultural scene in 1992, farmers have enthusiastically adopted these plants, last year harvesting genetically altered corn, soybeans and cotton from 50 million acres -- an area one and a half times the size of New York State. Meanwhile, several studies have been published pointing toward ecological risks from genetically modified plants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGNER, ELEANOR
description: WAGNER-Eleanor. The Administration and Board of Directors of the Rodeph Sholom School mourns the loss of Eleanor Wagner, beloved mother of Board member Claudia Wagner. May her blessed memory be a consolation to Claudia, her husband, Don Lebowitz, and to their children, Zev and Ezra. David N. Roberts, Chairman, Board of Directors Rodeph Sholom School Irwin Shlachter, Headmaster

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMERANTZ, GERTA
description: POMERANTZ-Gerta. On November 2, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Freddy Pomerantz. Dear mother of Leslie Fay Pomerantz and John and Laura Pomerantz. Adored grandmother of Andrew and Lynn Gross, Frederick (Ricky) Coff, Andrea and Matthew Lustig, Susan and Kevin Davis, and Marnie. Great-grandmother of Kristen, Matthew, Nicholas, Michael, Anna and Zachary. You were the matriarch of our family, and now that you are gone, a part of who we are and from where we have come, leaves us, too. You are in our hearts. Rest in peace. Services Thursday, 9:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Harry Potter's Readers
description: To the Editor:

title: Calendar
description: Spices in India: A Report on Broadway

title: 3 Democratic Incumbents Handily Rebuff Challengers
description: In races for district attorney in the Bronx and Queens and on Staten Island, three longtime Democratic incumbents won re-election yesterday, easily shaking off their little-known challengers.

title: Myth, Women And Power
description: Michiyo Sato, a Japanese-born choreographer based in New York, delighted in retelling myths and devising archetypal figures in the program ''Michiyo Sato and Dancers,'' presented on Saturday night at the Mulberry Street Theater.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SOLECTRON CORP., Milpitas, Calif., a manufacturing-services company, bought two plants from Ericsson AB, Stockholm, the world's third-largest maker of cellular phones, to raise its manufacturing capacity.

title: Penny-Wise Classes In Cooking
description: ENROLLING in a New York cooking school, or even just attending a workshop with a celebrity chef, can leave you on a noodles-only food budget for the rest of the year. But with a little resourcefulness -- and in some situations, elbow grease -- you can pursue your fantasy of becoming the next Julia Child (or just a better cook) at little cost, and sometimes at no cost at all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAFRAN, CLARA
description: SCHAFRAN-Clara. 102 years old. Beloved wife of the late Max. Devoted mother of Beatrice and Rodolpho, Teresa and Abe. Cherished grandmother and greatgrandmother. Graveside service 1PM Thursday, Nov. 4th, at Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, NY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROONEY, CATHERINE T.
description: ROONEY-Catherine T. November 1, 1999. Beloved mother of Edward K. Flaherty, loving daughter of the late Thomas and Mary Rooney, dear sister of Julia, Eileen, Thomas, Stephen, Martin and the late Margaret, Patricia, Marie and John. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Reposing at John J. Barrett Funeral Home, 424 W. 51 St, NYC 7 to 9 PM Thursday and 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM Friday. Funeral mass 9:45 AM Saturday Sacred Heart RC Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Shooting Kills 2 and Injures 2 in Seattle
description: A gunman dressed in camouflage, sunglasses and a brown hat opened fire this morning at a shipyard building near Lake Union here, killing two people and wounding two others, the police said. The man then fled, leading to a huge manhunt through north Seattle during which police advised residents to stay in their homes and kept children at 20 schools locked inside their buildings for part of the school day.

title: Clinton Vetoes Budget Cut, but Seeks Accord on Foreign Aid Bill
description: President Clinton today vetoed another of the spending bills passed by Congress, but after speaking with the two top Republican leaders, he said he was ready to work around the clock to settle the standoff over the federal budget.

title: Castles and Courage
description: To the Editor:

title: Online Fans of 'X-Files' Know It's the Clothes That Make the Show
description: FORGET the aliens and the sinister government conspiracy. Now that the heart of the extraterrestrial plot has been revealed on ''The X-Files,'' fans are chatting online less about the show's intricate story lines and subtle details and more about what the two lead characters are wearing.

title: A Device That Soaks Up All the White Board Can Hold
description: If the words ''white board'' conjure images of long meetings and fingers cramped from note-taking, the Mimio might have a market. The $499 device, by Boston-based Virtual Ink (www.mimio.com), captures meeting notes, brainstorms and brilliant doodlings as fast as they are rendered and saves them to a computer. The signals are received by a two-foot-long Mimio bar, which attaches to the average white board and is connected to a computer. It picks up ultrasonic and infrared signals sent by a wireless holder that slips onto a regular dry-erase marker that is used for writing. The sketches can be exported into programs like Word and shared with others. Imagine what college students could do if their teachers used the Mimeo?

title: Tie Is Fitting for Teams That Forgot How to Win
description: For the Rangers, some ties are better than others. But not last night's.

title: PNC BANK TO SELL SHARES IN INVESTMENT SERVICING UNIT
description: The PNC Bank Corporation, the largest bank based in Pennsylvania, plans to sell shares of its investment servicing unit in a year or more, to create a currency to buy other servicing businesses, Tom O'Brien, PNC's chairman and chief executive, said in an interview. Pittsburgh-based PNC agreed to buy the First Data Corporation's mutual-fund servicing unit in July for $1.1 billion in cash, becoming the second-biggest provider of fund accounting services to mutual funds and the largest in transfer agent services. The State Street Corporation is the No. 1 provider of fund accounting services to mutual funds.

title: Open Space for All
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; Breathing While Black
description: A federal appeals court says it's all right, but it's not all right.

title: SIEMENS PROFIT JUMPS
description: The German manufacturing giant, Siemens A.G., said its fourth-quarter net income rose 79 percent, helped by rising profit in its semiconductor and mobile phone divisions. Profit in the period ending on Sept. 30 rose to 1.56 billion marks, or $835.4 million. Siemens is starting to reap the rewards of a reorganization that has included shedding lackluster units accounting for 15 percent of sales.

title: Tight Governor's Race Will Be Decided by Mississippi House of Representatives
description: More than 740,000 people went to the polls in Mississippi on Tuesday to choose a new governor. But it appears the race will be decided by the 122 members of the state's House of Representatives.

title: Laws That Can't Stop a Bullet
description: In the past two days, back-to-back attacks in Honolulu and Seattle have added new episodes to an ongoing American drama: everyday scenes of work or leisure suddenly transformed into carnage by killers who open fire with handguns. We recoil in horror and search for explanations, but we never face up to the obvious preventive measure: a ban on the handy killing machines that make the crimes so easy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, SAMUEL
description: FISHER-Samuel. We extend heartfelt condolences to Betty Fisher and son, Jerome on the passing of their beloved husband and father. As Silver Founders and generous supporters of the Medical Center, Samuel & Betty and Jerome & Shirley have devoted their lives to Tzedakah and Chesed and have helped to fulfill the Hospital's mission to heal the sick and ease the pain of the afflicted. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. for Shaare Zedek Med. Ctr. in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, Pres.

title: Growing Australian Battle Cry:God Save the Queen!
description: SYDNEY  With about 70 percent of its trade now done in the Asia-Pacific region and the non-British component of its population up sharply in recent years, Australia seems ripe to cut its last remaining constitutional ties to Britain and become a republic.

title: Chiapas Bishop Follows Rule, Reluctantly, to Submit Resignation
description: Bishop Samuel Ruiz Garcia, the embattled prelate who championed the cause of the Indians in Chiapas State and tried to make peace between the government and the Zapatista rebels, turned 75 today and offered his resignation, obediently but reluctantly, to Pope John Paul II.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGER, CHARLES
description: HAGER-Charles. The Board and Staff of New York Lawyers for the Public Interest mourn the passing of Charles Hager, a generous colleague and distinguished former Board Chair.

title: Clinton Will Field Questions on Internet in Bid for Big Audience
description: President Clinton will field questions from the public over the Internet for an hour and a half next Monday, using an advanced technology that will allow 50,000 people to see and hear him.

title: Dusting Off an Enchanted Land and Adding Some Dragons
description: Before there was Disneyland, there was Children's Fairyland, a 10-acre park in Oakland, Calif., near Lake Merritt. Since 1950, children have entered through the Old Lady's Shoe and ambled from Mary Had a Little Lamb to the Three Little Pigs, where they can play with live animals. But over the last 30 years, attendance has decreased and paint has flaked. Now Fairyland is fighting back.

title: Members Are Suing PacifiCare H.M.O.
description: PacifiCare Health Systems Inc., the No. 1 operator of Medicare health maintenance organizations, is being sued by its members, who accuse it of using false advertising and unfair business practices.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil rose on signs that OPEC kept close to its production limits last month as it sought to trim world inventories. In New York, crude oil for December delivery rose 17 cents, to $22.56 a barrel.

title: B. F. GOODRICH BROADENS AEROSPACE PRODUCT LINE
description: B. F. Goodrich, the No. 1 United States maker of aircraft landing gear, said it bought Boeing's ejection-seat business to broaden its range of safety-related aerospace products. Terms were not disclosed. The ACES II ejection seats are used in the F-15 and F-16 fighter jets and other aircraft, Goodrich said. About 7,000 have been produced for the United States Air Force and foreign military customers. The United States Air Force's new F-22 aircraft will use the seat. Goodrich also makes evacuation slides for commercial aircraft and propellants for other escape systems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFFER, ROBERT L.
description: SCHIFFER-Robert L. We honor the remarkable achievements of a just man. His funeral will be held at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in his memory may be made to Planned Parenthood International and the American Society for Yad Vashem. Selma Schiffer, Suzi & Franklin, Wendy & Michael, Madeline & Alexander

title: INSIDE
description: Crackdown Rattles China

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNAHUM, MICHAEL
description: BENNAHUM-Michael. The principals and staff of ING Captial Advisors deeply mourn the passing of their friend and colleague, Michael Bennahum. His wit and wisdom will be missed by us all.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Guide column of the Long Island section on Sunday referred incorrectly to the Long Island Baroque Ensemble, which is to perform on Saturday at 8 p.m. at St. Andrew's Lutheran Church on Brookside Drive in Smithtown and on Sunday at 3 at Christ Episcopal Church on East Main Street in Oyster Bay. It is a chamber music group, not a dance troupe. Information: (516) 724-7386.

title: Van Gogh Print Or Original Oil: The Web Has It
description: CHRISTINE BOURRON will not call what she is doing revenge against the art world, but just two years ago, she visited dozens of galleries in both Boston and New York with a simple mission: to buy an original work of art as a birthday gift for her mother. She had a clear idea of what she wanted -- a painting of flowers by any American artist. She was willing to spend about $4,000.

title: BROWSER
description: An eclectic selection of Web sites and events.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMAHON, KEVIN DANIEL
description: MCMAHON-Kevin Daniel, 38. Of New York City and Los Angeles, CA, passed away on October 31, 1999. He attended Parsons Art School and The School of Visual Arts, and led a successful career as a producer of popular television shows and documentaries. He is survived by his eight sisters and brothers and his parents. A Memorial Mass will be held on Saturday November 6, 1999 at 7:30 P.M. at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Clifton, New Jersey.

title: A Challenge to Yugoslavia
description: The Clinton administration has signaled an important and welcome change in its policy on economic sanctions against Serbia. Hoping to strengthen the democratic opposition to Yugoslavia's president, Slobodan Milosevic, Washington now says it will ease its restrictions on commerce and travel as soon as Mr. Milosevic submits himself to free and fair elections. Previously the administration said these sanctions would continue as long as Mr. Milosevic remained in power.

title: Metro Business; Planners Support Giving Pier to MGM
description: Atlantic City took a step yesterday toward turning over the old Garden Pier to MGM Grand and allowing the company to build a 1,500-room hotel and casino complex between the Boardwalk and Pacific Avenue.

title: Queens Museum Seeks Fame, but Not Notoriety
description: The people who run the Queens Museum of Art insist they do not envy their counterparts in Brooklyn. Oh, they wouldn't mind having lines around the block and a world-famous permanent collection. And perhaps they would prefer a greater claim to fame than the 10,000-square-foot wood and plastic model of New York City from the 1964 World's Fair -- a big hit with school groups, but hardly the stuff of high art.

title: Man Is Convicted in Killing of Gay Student
description: A jury in Laramie, Wyo., today found a man guilty of second-degree murder in the killing of a gay University of Wyoming student last year. By also finding him guilty of robbery and kidnapping, the jury enabled prosecutors to seek a death penalty.

title: Girls' Soccer Disrupted
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Accuses Seven Utilities Of Violating Clean-Air Law

title: People
description: * Edward S. Lehman was named vice president and manging director at Western Initiative Media Worldwide, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Cos., succeeding John McNamara, who left. Mr. Lehman had been director for Internet relationship marketing at Earthweb, New York. Also, Annie Moore, vice president for client services, relocated to New York from Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COUTSOUVELIS, ANN M. (NEE DUFFY)
description: COUTSOUVELIS-Ann M. (nee Duffy). On November 3, 1999. Beloved wife of the late George. Survived by Eleni Kalergis; her sister, Patricia Hurley, and her brother, Edward Duffy. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue (at 20th Street), New York City, Sunday, November 7, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, November 8, at 10 A.M., at The Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: Vietnamese P.O.W.'s Set Up as Spies, Book Says
description: A secret American program was created during the Vietnam War to portray enemy prisoners as spies and then send them back to North Vietnam, where they would face possible execution, according to a new history of covert action during the conflict.

title: Investigators Focus on a Device That Caused a '91 Crash in Which 223 Died
description: On Sunday, only the second Boeing 767 ever to fall out of the sky -- EgyptAir Flight 990 -- smashed into the sea under mysterious circumstances. The first 767 to crash, in May 1991, in Thailand, did so because a thrust reverser, a device meant to slow a plane on the runway, somehow activated in the sky. In that crash, 223 people died.

title: Nets Make Too Many Mistakes by the Lake
description: Starting sluggishly, then rallying to make the game competitive has merits against Eastern Conference powers like the Indiana Pacers. But when that is your pattern against the Cleveland Cavaliers, an inexperienced and injury-plagued team with only slightly legitimate playoff chances, pats on the back are not in order.

title: Rodriguez, Not Griffey, May Be Leader in Offers
description: While Ken Griffey Jr. ranks among the game's greatest players and may break Hank Aaron's career home run record -- he needs 2 to reach 400, 358 to surpass Aaron -- the market for his services could be surprisingly thin, affected by his apparent intention to test free agency after the 2000 season and the glut of star players available for trade this off-season.

title: Alone at Sea, When a Terrible Roar Shook the Night
description: Far offshore, in waters shrouded by darkness and a light haze, the crew of the fishing vessel Hedy Brenna worked through the night last Saturday and into Sunday morning, hauling lobster pots from the deep water south of Nantucket. The seas were nearly flat calm. The air was unseasonably warm. A routine trip had just begun.

title: A Computer's 911 Call
description: To the Editor:

title: An Author In Limbo
description: The writer Pat Jordan could be the poster boy for all the mindless and sometimes cruel whacks that book publishing can inflict on authors. Here's his story, but first there are certain things about that world to be understood. For instance, an author's nearly primordial need is for a strong editor who not only edits the book but as its publication date arrives also hounds and prods and seduces the publisher and sales force into winning the book a good ride from the booksellers.

title: Gallaher of Britain Considers Bid for French Tobacco Rival
description: The British cigarette maker Gallaher Group said today it might bid for the French tobacco maker Seita, a move that could scuttle the proposed merger of Seita and Tabacalera of Spain.

title: Waging War on Obesity
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Have-Nots May Yet Have a Day
description: AS soon as the Seattle Mariners announced that Ken Griffey Jr. wanted to be traded to a team closer to his Orlando, Fla., home, the gloom-and-doom set in baseball pounced on the development as another blow to low-revenue teams. Griffey, they instantly assumed, would wind up with one of those high-revenue teams with seemingly unlimited payrolls.

title: 30-Year Treasury Yield Declines to 6.13%
description: Spurred by investor optimism that the Federal Reserve will not have to raise short-term interest rates more than once in the near future, prices of Treasury securities rose slightly yesterday after rebounding from early weakness.

title: Visitors' Hall of Dreams Is Village's Nightmare; Take the Bats and Balls and Go Home, Some in Cooperstown Say to Tourists
description: Too much baseball?

title: One Curriculum For New York
description: New York City Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has issued a series of guides to what every child should know, from kindergarten through the eighth grade. It will be easy to cavil at these informal standards. But their symbolic value is immense: the guides implicitly establish a common curriculum where one is desperately needed.

title: EXECUTIVE GETS SUSPENDED SENTENCE
description: The chairman of South Korea's biggest brokerage firm, the Hyundai Securities Company, received a three-year suspended jail sentence and the firm was fined 7 billion won, or $6 million, for rigging stock prices in a case that exposed fraud at a top conglomerate. Prosecutors said that Lee Ik Chi, who had been hailed as a national hero earlier this year as assets of the brokerage firm's ''Buy Korea Fund'' swelled to $10 billion, used 223.4 billion won from Hyundai's shipping units to prop up the stock price of its electronics business.

title: M.T.A. Chief Won't Rule Out Higher Fare to Pay for Expansion Plan
description: Leaving the door open for fare increases, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority told state legislators yesterday that large new sources of money would be needed if the authority goes ahead with plans to expand its subway, bus and commuter rail systems.

title: Bacteria Cases in Denmark Cause Antibiotics Concerns in U.S.
description: An outbreak of severe, drug-resistant salmonella infections in 27 people in Denmark, traced to meat from infected pigs, is being described by American scientists as a warning on what can happen in the United States unless steps are taken to limit the use of antibiotics in farm animals.

title: LIBERTY CORPORATION UNIT BUYS TV STATION IN TEXAS
description: A unit of the Liberty Corporation agreed yesterday to buy an NBC affiliate television station in Lubbock, Tex., from the closely held Holsum Inc. for $59.8 million in cash. The purchase of KCBD-TV by the Cosmos Broadcasting Corporation would increase the number of television stations Liberty owns to 12. The company last year bought a CBS affiliate in Harlingen, Texas. Liberty also owns single stations in Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, Indiana, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, Ohio and South Carolina.

title: Textures of Childhood In an 8-Year-Old's Grief
description: THE TINY ONE

title: ONE EUROPE, 10 YEARS -- Gloom in the Castle.; Havel Finds His Role Turning From Czech Hero to Has-Been
description: Vaclav Havel, the ironic dissident who articulated the power of the powerless and helped bring down the Berlin Wall, still serves, like a prisoner, as president of the Czech Republic.

title: Election Day Apathy
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Without striving for it, I became a character in a story, in a fairy tale. I was awarded honorary degrees at universities around the world and at every one of those ceremonies I had to listen to the story of my life. And those biographies were always the same fairy tale.''

title: 3 Cultural Officials Defend Actions of Brooklyn Museum
description: In a joint letter yesterday, three executives of cultural institutions in the city defended the Brooklyn Museum of Art's decision to finance its controversial ''Sensation'' exhibition in part by soliciting substantial donations from companies and individuals with a direct commercial interest in the artwork on display.

title: Tyco Changes Its Strategy And Plans Stock Buyback
description: Tyco International, whose share price has declined in recent weeks over concern about its accounting practices, is likely to refrain from all-stock acquisitions that use pooling-of-interests accounting, Tyco said today.

title: Democrat Is Elected Under Voting Method She Fought
description: It was startling enough, here in the nerve center of the Nassau County Republican Party, to see two Democrats elected Tuesday to the Town Board -- the first since 1917.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROEBUCK, WALDEMAR A.
description: ROEBUCK-Waldemar A. On November 1, 1999. He was the first and former president of the Board of Directors of Strycker's Bay Apartment, Inc. He was president of the Franciscan Lay Apostolate in the U.S. & Canada. He also held several community posts. Reposing at Walter B. Cooke-Kennedy Funeral Home, 117 West 72 Street, Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass, St. Francis of Assisi Church, on Friday at 10 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDNICK, PEARL
description: RUDNICK-Pearl. On November 2, 1999. Dear mother of Arthur Rudnick and mother-in-law of Patricia Rudnick. Beloved grandmother of Jeff & Stephanie Rudnick. Loving sister to Esther Kalkut. Services Thursday 12PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAU, RAYMOND
description: BLAU-Raymond, 89. Died on October 30, 1999 of South Orange, New Jersey and Longboat Key, Florida. President of Max Blau & Sons, Inc. Loving husband of the late Hope Blau. He is survived by his loving daughters Maxine Blau and Adele Blau Cass, and grandsons David and Gregory. Friends and family may pay their respects Saturday and Sunday from 1-8 P.M. at the home of Adele Blau Cass, 168 Glenview Road, South Orange, NJ. For more information call (973) 642-4900.

title: Democrats, Stunned Victors, Face Nassau's Budget Crisis
description: The morning after the most remarkable electoral upset here in 100 years, Nassau Democrats straggled into county offices today like zombies, awestruck at the stunning victory they had just won over the supposedly all-powerful Republican machine, and nearly overwhelmed by what lay before them.

title: 'Gay Panic': A Specious Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: You Want a Whole House?
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants, in Middle of Bye Week, Will Not Let Sehorn Practice
description: A groin injury kept Giants cornerback Jason Sehorn from practicing today, a move that the team, in the middle of a bye week, called a precautionary measure.

title: The New Super Sheds The Old Mr. Fix-It Image
description: JOHN HEALY owns three computers, has a constantly ringing cellular telephone and oversees 33 employees. His workday starts at 7 a.m. sharp, firing off e-mail messages to his staff, clients and board members. Sounds like a typical executive climbing the corporate ladder, but in this case the corporation is the San Remo apartment building on Central Park West, and the ladder Mr. Healy is climbing leads not to a corner office but to a suite -- where he works as the building's superintendent.

title: Jet Climbed Sharply Before Falling to Sea
