description: New radar data released by the National Transportation Safety Board shows that EgyptAir Flight 990 fell steeply in its final minutes, then climbed more than a mile before plunging once more and apparently breaking up in mid-air.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, ELIZABETH
description: WHITE-Elizabeth. On November 1, 1999. Eponymous retired NYC restaurant owner. Survived by daughters, Joan Ehrgott & Susan Ghio, and five grandchildren. Private mass will be held.

title: Woods Could Become First $6 Million Man
description: After winning his past three starts, Tiger Woods hopes to continue his streak in Spain. Returning to the site of the 1997 Ryder Cup, Woods heads a world-class field competing in this week's American Express Championship, the final official event of the 1999 golf season.

title: Handspring Finds More Fits, Fewer Starts in Visor Delivery
description: HUNDREDS of people who were among the first to order the new handheld Visor, a Palm Pilot-like digital assistant, are still waiting for the U.P.S. truck.

title: At the Movies, but Nary a 'Shhhhhhh' Will Be Heard
description: Now you never have to leave the house: the worlds of home video and chat are colliding. The makers of the film ''The Matrix'' are holding an online screening and inviting owners of DVD-ROM copies to chat with the filmmakers, Andy and Larry Wachowski.

title: Giuliani's Upstate TV Spots
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Senate exploratory committee began broadcasting a new 30-second television commercial on Monday in upstate New York.

title: Making the Kitchen Easy on the Cooks, and on the Senses
description: THE kitchen of the past was designed for one sex: female, whether hired cook or lady of the house. Social changes, however, have ensured that today, everyone is in the kitchen, and happy to be: teenagers, children, men, the elderly and, yes, women.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, MARTY
description: LEVINE-Marty. 71. Beloved husband of Dorrie. Loving father of Robin and David. Cherished grandfather of Michael, Matthew, Jeremy and Josh. Memorial services to be held Friday, November 5, 1999, 11:00 AM at The Village Temple, 33 East 12th St, NYC.

title: QUALCOMM SETS 4-FOR-1 SPLIT AS PROFIT QUADRUPLES
description: Shares of Qualcomm, which is leading the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index this year, rose 16 percent yesterday to a record after the company said profit more than quadrupled and it set a 4-for-1 stock split. Qualcomm rose $29.06875 a share, to $260.75. The stock has surged more than tenfold this year, giving the company, which developed the world's second-most popular cell-phone technology, a market value of $42 billion. Qualcomm expects royalties from its code-division multiple access, or CDMA, technology to climb after doubling in the recent quarter. The date for the stock split will be set after Qualcomm holds a stockholders meeting, which is expected around Dec. 20.

title: G.M. to Offer a New Reason To Keep the Cell Phone On
description: For drivers not already talking on their cellular phones, the General Motors Corporation plans to introduce a new service sometime next year, one that will let them surf the Internet from a car.

title: Iraq Rules Out New Monitoring Tied to Suspension of Sanctions
description: Iraq's foreign minister said today that his government would reject any United Nations move to suspend economic sanctions in return for Iraq's cooperation with a new weapons-monitoring program.

title: The Old Scars Have Healed, Brown Says
description: The demons are behind him, Dave Brown announced today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORMAN, JOSEPH
description: FORMAN-Joseph. Beloved husband of Jean. Loving grandfather to Scott, Stacey, Jeffrey, Wendy and Stephanie Nagel. Cherished great-grandfather to Keith, Greg, Allison, Daniel, Jesse, Naomi and Dana. Poppa Joe's endless devotion to family and Judaism will continue to be an inspiration to all of us. We will carry his spirit in our hearts and souls forever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIREMARK, SAMUEL
description: FIREMARK - Samuel. Devoted husband of the late Ida, loving father of Teri Firemark and the late Hugh Firemark, cherished grandfather of Gordon Firemark, Rachel Firemark, Alison Firemark and Aurora Baletti, great-grandfather of Nicholaus Bates. Beloved brother of Lena Tannenbaum, Ida Barr, Ethel Breitboard, Yetta Firemark, Pearl Shapiro, Goldie Street and the late Gus Firemark. His generosity and kindness will be remembered by the many people he served as owner of Rael Pharmacy in Laurelton, Queens, and as director of Jade Winds Condominium in North Miami Beach, FL. Funeral services today, 12:30, at I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich St, Hempstead, New York. Interment to follow at the New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WUNDER, GEORGE W.
description: WUNDER-George W., age 86, of Port Washington, L.I. November 1, 1999. Beloved husband of Frances. Devoted father of William, Carolyn and Robert. Adoring grandfather of four, great grandfather of two. A Memorial Service will be held Saturday, November 13th at 10 A.M. at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, 9 Carlton Avenue, Port Washington. Memorial contributions may be made in his name to: The Colorado School of Mines Foundation, 1600 Arapahoe, Golden, Colorado 80401

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, ELLEN RUTH
description: HALPERN-Ellen Ruth. Beloved wife of Sidney Arthur. Loving mother of Nancy Halpern, Paul & Nancy Halpern and Debra & Aron Yagoda. Funeral Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY, 10AM Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REITER, HILDE KAUFMANN
description: REITER-Hilde Kaufmann. Nov. 2, 1999. Mother of Peter Reiter and Joan Goldfarb. Grandmother of Suzanne and David Reiter, Tara Ceccini and Jesse Goldfarb. Sister of Lottie Frazer and Anneliese Goldberg. Wife of late Gerhard Reiter, M.D. Funeral November 5, 11 A.M. at Ballard Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, New York.

title: Boxed In: The Television V-Chip Puts Up Electronic Fences
description: EVERYONE has opinions about television sex and violence, and opinions about the technology to block it, the V-chip, run equally strong. To the Clinton administration, the V-chip is a triumph of technology that allows parents to keep material that runs contrary to their tastes or beliefs from being viewed by their children. To critics of the V-chip, it is government interference that falls only slightly short of censorship.

title: The Might Behind the Women's Rights Movement
description: Susan B. Anthony was a teetotaler spinster, raised in a strict Quaker home in which toys were not allowed. In photograph after photograph she displays the stern features and cranky expression of a woman who never had fun. Elizabeth Cady Stanton had a life, and she enjoyed it. She loved food and clothes, and in her photographs, as she changes from a dark-haired young mother to a plump white-haired matron, she usually has a headful of curls.

title: Sniffing Out New Ways To Uncover Land Mines
description: FOR decades, the United States military and international relief organizations have been searching for low-cost, effective ways to rid the world of land mines. There are more than 100 million mines buried in 70 countries, and they kill or maim more than 2,000 people per month, according to United Nations estimates.

title: A Chicago Exchange Considers Share Sale
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the nation's No. 2 derivatives exchange, said this week that it might abandon its 80-year-old membership structure and become a for-profit company before the middle of next year.

title: Indonesian Bank Agency Is Ready to Confront Big Debtors
description: Paralyzed for three months by a scandal that still threatens its chairman, the agency in charge of rescuing Indonesia's ravaged financial industries is preparing a comeback.

title: Bill to Combat Drug Traffic Caught in Lobbying Battle
description: Efforts by the Republican chairman of the Senate intelligence committee to soften a bill that would expand economic sanctions against drug traffickers and the businesses that work with them have touched off a furious dispute on Capitol Hill.

title: A Word or Two on Words
description: To The Editor:

title: U.S. Spending Limits Set in '97 Now Are Largely Ignored
description: As Congress and the Clinton administration head into the final stages of their negotiations over the federal budget, both sides say they are determined to avoid spending any portion of the money that flows to the government through the Social Security system.

title: The Don Cossacks, Stamping Brightly and Fiercely
description: The Don Cossacks of Rostov were impressive to behold as they gathered onstage at the start of the program on Sunday at Lehman Center for the Performing Arts. The men were in uniforms. The women wore long, brightly colored and richly embroidered gowns. This Russian company, directed by Anatoly Kvasov, pleased the ear as well as the eye in theatricalized versions of folk songs and dances reflecting the traditions of the Cossack warriors who once dominated the Don River.

title: Charter Reform Loses
description: Only sheer determination propelled voters from New York City and Nassau County out into the wind and rain Tuesday to send their unmistakable messages. In New York they defeated Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's misguided attempts to revise the City Charter, to leave what he called a ''shadow'' of his strong personality behind in the structure of city government. In Nassau, voters ended a century of one-party rule and gave Democrats their first turn at fixing that suburban county's humiliating fiscal crisis in an era of personal and governmental plenty.

title: Congressional Memo; Not Quite Business as Usual In House on Managed Care
description: Here is how the textbooks say a bill becomes law: The Senate passes the bill. Then the House of Representatives passes its own version. Then a conference committee is formed, where senior senators defend their bill and senior representatives defend their bill, with both sides striking compromises to resolve the differences.

title: Can a Strong-Willed Chief Share Power in Merger?
description: The planned merger between American Home Products and Warner-Lambert once again raises the question of whether John R. Stafford, American Home's famously strong-willed chairman and chief executive, is capable of sharing and, perhaps more important, letting go of power.

title: For Late Library Hours
description: To the Editor:

title: Bokonbayeva Journal; God of Birds, but Scourge of Foxes and Badgers
description: The fiercest and most successful hunter in these parts, heir to a tradition that stretches back many centuries, does not use a rifle or a bow and arrow. His weapon is a magnificent golden eagle who is also his intimate friend.

title: Philip Morris Gifts to a Pataki Sponsor are Investigated
description: The New York State Ethics Commission has opened an investigation into whether two trips by Gov. George E. Pataki to Hungary were illegally financed by companies with extensive interests before the governor, including Philip Morris.

title: School Board Gives Crew a Report Card
description: The Board of Education released an evaluation of Chancellor Rudy Crew yesterday that was less enthusiastic than past reviews, with unusually detailed recommendations on how he could improve his management style and take a more hands-on approach to running the city's schools.

title: In a Tent, Derring-Do And Skill
description: Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center has taken on its fall coloration: the Big Apple Circus, with stars of red, green, yellow and orange adorning the deep blue ceiling of its intimate tent, has set up shop among the trees.

title: Milan Sends a Gift 'Leonardo' Horse Out to Pasture
description: Italy knows what to do with a gift horse: Look it in the mouth and send it to the racetrack.

title: College Textbook Stores Sue Internet Competitor
description: Another legal battle has erupted between traditional bookstores and online booksellers -- this time among textbook shops. The National Association of College Stores, which represents 3,000 stores, is suing VarsityBooks.com, an online textbook store, for what the association says is false and misleading advertising concerning discounts.

title: Folding Chairs That Sacrifice Neither Style Nor Comfort
description: SOME folding chairs are just too nice to put away. And now there are so many models to choose from -- both vintage and new -- that you can hold out for both comfort and good design. You can invest in a 1940's French button-tufted antique or a 1999 design that bears an uncanny resemblance (from behind) to E.T. And most are so comfortable, you will linger long past dessert.

title: Wise Advice on Bell Atlantic
description: The Department of Justice exercised good judgment and political courage this week when it formally advised the Federal Communications Commission to reject Bell Atlantic's bid to enter long-distance phone service in New York State. The rejection surprised many participants in this application because it came only days after the New York Public Service Commission gave Bell Atlantic's application its blessing.

title: Residential Resales
description: MANHATTAN

title: MURDOCH LOOKS TO GERMANY
description: At the News Corporation's meeting in Adelaide, Australia, Rupert Murdoch said that British Sky Broadcasting, the pay-TV company in which the News Corporation owns a 40 percent stake, is in talks to buy a 25 percent stake in Premiere World, a German pay-TV company controlled by Kirch Group.

title: A Week for $10,000? Rents for Y2K Fizzle
description: THE advertisements are popping up in practically every periodical with a classified section -- and especially on the Internet: ''Bye Bye 1999, Hello 2000!'' ''Y2K New York Style.'' ''Great Millennium Rentals.'' One-bedroom ''fully furnished apartment, East Side 20's close to everything,'' boasts another ad. The price? Ten thousand dollars, from Dec. 28 to Jan. 2.

title: The Big City; Just Reading The News Is Dangerous
description: IN the investigation of the crash of EgyptAir Flight 990 this week, there is one question not being considered by the National Transportation Safety Board: how many people will be killed and maimed as a result of the news coverage? But maybe a lawyer somewhere is pondering it.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: THE AMERICAS

title: The Shepard Case Verdict
description: The killing of Matthew Shepard, a gay college student in Wyoming who in 1998 was beaten, lashed to a fence and left to die, shocked Americans by lifting homophobia to a new level of savagery. A jury has now convicted Aaron McKinney of murder, kidnapping and robbery in the case, and he could face the death penalty. The other defendant, Russell Henderson, pleaded guilty to murder and kidnapping earlier, and is serving two life sentences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAURIER, BRIAN DOUGLAS
description: LAURIER-Brian Douglas, 43. Of Brooklyn, New York. Died October 29, 1999. He was an artist and sold his paintings privately. He was preceded in death by his mother, Margaret Lee Laurier. Survivors include his daughter Margueritte, father Maurice, sister Karen, brother David and special friend Vanessa. A celebration of Brian's life will be held at 11AM Saturday, November 6, 1999 at Elm Grove Cemetery, Mystic, CT, conducted by Justin Osterman of All Souls Unitarian Congregation. In Brian's memory, contributions may be made to a trust account for his daughter C/O Karen L. Morisato, 4305 Poplar Forest Crt, Chantilly, VA. 20151.

title: Fall of a Mighty Suburban Party Machine in Nassau County
description: It played a crucial role in choosing a president, sent one of its own to the United States Senate, and wielded great power in Albany for decades. But the hallmark of the Nassau County Republican Party, perhaps the last great party machine left in the country, has been its century-long vise grip on local government.

title: In New Hampshire, Bush Is the Image of Scrappiness
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas today wrapped up a feverishly busy visit to New Hampshire that saw him log hundreds of road miles, lunge for every hand in his path and, above all, look less like a carefree front-runner than a scrappy contender who had indeed broken a sweat.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Regal Pace At a Mobbed Show

title: Design Notebook; This Is Your Life (It's Also Their Art)
description: IN the more than 25 years they've been married, Steven and Judith O'Connor have moved 18 times. They have lived in a small nondescript apartment in Iran with a Turkish toilet and in a heavily shuttered home in Athens, shortly after the collapse of the military regime. Then there was the cedar-paneled house overlooking a sound in Bermuda, the tile-roofed hacienda in Phoenix and the Provencal-suburban manor in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: No Consensus on Effect of Genetically Altered Corn on Butterflies
description: An unusual scientific symposium organized and financed by a biotech trade group ended today with conflicting assertions about the risks that genetically engineered corn might pose to the monarch butterfly.

title: China Takes Permits of 5 Western Reporters
description: The police called in at least five Western reporters on Wednesday for questioning about a clandestine Falun Gong news conference that they attended on Oct. 28 and seized the reporters' accreditation cards and residence permits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZPATRICK, ROBERT
description: FITZPATRICK-Robert. The management and staff of Paul Stuart, Inc. offers its condolences to the family of our former employee Bob Fitzpatrick and his wife, Sharon lost to us all on EgyptAir Flight 990. They will be missed.

title: U.S. Cites Criminals' Raids On Medicare and Medicaid
description: Organized criminal groups have infiltrated Medicare and Medicaid, and are skimming hundreds of millions of dollars a year from the programs, federal investigators said today.

title: $1.1 Billion To Settle Suit On Vitamins
description: Seven of the world's largest drug companies agreed yesterday to pay more than $1.1 billion to settle a class-action lawsuit that sought damages as a result of an international conspiracy to fix vitamin prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBLICH, MANNETTE NEUMAN
description: LIEBLICH - Mannette Neuman. Lover of family and nature, especially flowers and animals. Devoted wife of Daniel Parke Lieblich. Loving mother of Nancy Bracken Garson and Lynn Jeffery. Unforgettable grandmother to Genevieve and Emily Bracken; Todd Daniel, Diana, & Carolyn Jeffery. Loving sister of Emanuel Neuman. Memorial service 2 P.M., Thursday at Temple Beth Miriam, Elberon, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Monmouth County, NJ S.P.C.A., Planned Parenthood, or the Mannette Neuman Lieblich-Beautification Fund of Deal, New Jersey.

title: A Chilly Welcome For Digital Wallets
description: YOU have hunted through countless Web sites, found the perfect gift at the best price. Now all that is left is to fill out an order form the length of a corporate tax return.

title: A Liberal Democrat Wins in Salt Lake City
description: Within the vast bastion of Republican conservatism around Utah, Ross Anderson struck a blow on Tuesday for liberal Democrats, winning election easily to become the next mayor of Salt Lake City.

title: San Francisco Mayor Is Forced Into Runoff
description: After a long, hard-fought campaign, Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr. will have six more weeks to convince voters he should still be mayor.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: African Is Among 4 Named Trade Group Deputy Chiefs
description: The World Trade Organization's director general, Mike Moore, named four new deputies today, including the first African to hold such a high-level post, to help him run the 134-nation trade regulatory group.

title: A Bad Rap on Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: President's Visit to Hartford Will Focus on Redevelopment
description: President Clinton is expected to announce nearly $200 million in private investments in this slowly rebounding city on Thursday during a tour of inner city areas that have not felt the full effects of the current economic boom. He will also visit Newark on Thursday and Chicago and Hermitage, Ark., on Friday as part of his ''new markets'' tour.

title: Lectures, Exhibitions, Sales and a Walking Tour
description: Gehry on Gehry

title: Myway.com Awards Account to Arnold
description: Myway.com in Andover, Mass., part of CMGI, an Internet portal and custom portal solutions company, has awarded its first branding account to Arnold Communications in Boston, part of Snyder Communications. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: Books for the Blind
description: To the Editor:

title: Lalique, the Sequel
description: To get original 1920's and 30's Lalique crystal -- patterns designed by Rene Lalique -- people must comb through offerings at auction houses and antique shops. But if shoppers want contemporary Lalique crystal, made in the same French factory as the originals, they can find them at 712 Madison Avenue (63rd Street), below, where America's largest Lalique boutique opened last week. Mme. Odette Boulenger (top), with Lalique for 54 years, directed the shop's decor. The store sells crystal stemware, barware and decorative pieces, and the new Atlantic Furniture Line, based on Rene Lalique's furniture at the 1925 exhibition of Modern Decorative and Industrial Arts in Paris. The furniture is mahogany with satin-finished crystal inlays. Prices range from $9,000 for a console to $31,000 for a wall unit. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Collapsing Crane Severs Arm of Operator in Lower Manhattan
description: A 60-foot crane collapsed in St. Andrew's Plaza in lower Manhattan yesterday evening, severing the arm of one construction worker after a cable snapped, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, GLORIA D. (NEE KRUGER)
description: COLLINS-Gloria D. (nee Kruger). On November 2, 1999, of Timonium, Md., formerly of Douglaston, N.Y. Beloved wife of Peter C. Collins. Devoted mother of Peter K. Collins and his wife-Caroline of W. Newbury, Ma., and Stacy Collins O'Coner and her husbandSean of Phoenix, Md. Loving grandmother of Dylan, Abigail, Patrick, Ryan and Kevin. Interment private. The family will receive friends in the Lemmon Funeral Home of Dulaney Valley, Inc., 10 W. Padonia Road at York Road, Timonium-Cockeysville, Md on Friday from 2-4 & 7-9pm. A Memorial Service will be held in the Timonium Presbyterian Church (303 W. Timonium Road)on Saturday, November 6th at 11AM. Reception to follow. Expression of sympathy may be directed in Gloria's name to three selected charities-please contact the funeral Home (410) 252-6000.

title: ABC Executive Will Head CNN's Financial Network
description: CNNfn, the financial news cable channel operated by the Cable News Network, yesterday named Shelby Coffey III, the former editor of The Los Angeles Times and current executive vice president of ABC News, as its new president, ending a long effort to fill the position.

title: McDonald Stays in Step With a Lifetime Dream
description: It took a life-threatening fall from a horse to chart the course that has not only made Debbie McDonald a champion in dressage, that horse-and-rider partnership in a sort of equine step dance, but also has her fulfilling her dream of riding at Madison Square Garden in the National Horse Show.

title: Sponsor Dropout Ends Plan For TV and Film Soundstages
description: An ambitious plan to build a television and movie soundstage complex on top of a Manhattan office building has been abandoned, becoming the latest in a series of heavily promoted ''Hollywood-on-the Hudson'' proposals to fall apart, city officials confirmed yesterday.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Blazing Hot and Highly Volatile
description: THE Nasdaq composite index began in February 1971, an attempt to get attention for the small stocks that traded in the then-new Nasdaq market of what had been known as over-the-counter stocks. The index, set at 100 when it was introduced, took 12 years to triple to 300.

title: Talks With China Near, Clinton Says
description: President Clinton confirmed reports today that he was seeking to re-start negotiations with China over its entry into the World Trade Organization, and said that if he struck a deal in coming weeks, he believed Congress would approve it.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the coming retirement of John F. Welch Jr., chairman of General Electric, misstated the title of David L. Calhoun, a possible successor. He is chief executive of the Employers Reinsurance Corporation, the largest unit of the GE Capital Services Corporation; Dennis Dammerman is chief executive of GE Capital itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAILIN, BEN
description: BAILIN-Ben, on November 3, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Rose. Devoted father of Howard and Myra. Loving grandfather of David and Jeffrey. Cherished greatgrandfather of 3. Services Friday, November 5, 11AM, King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, New Jersey.

title: 7 UTILITIES SUED BY U.S. ON CHARGES OF POLLUTING AIR
description: In what federal officials called one of the biggest enforcement actions in the nation's history, the government sued seven giant electric companies in the Midwest and the South today, accusing the utilities of defying anti-pollution regulations and illegally contaminating the air breathed by millions of Americans.

title: Johannes van Paradijs, 53; Helped Explain Gamma Rays
description: Dr. Johannes van Paradijs, whose observations of the most powerful explosions in the cosmos led to an understanding of their nature, died Tuesday in Amsterdam. He was 53.

title: Wordless Singers and Other Sendups
description: Meredith Monk calls her ''Magic Frequencies'' a science-fiction chamber opera, but as is the case with many of her works, it might as easily be described as a ballet, given that there is more dance and movement in it than singing. A collection of theatrical sketches may be a still more accurate description. But why quibble over terminology? By now, Ms. Monk's name affixed to a work conveys ample information about what a listener can expect to see and hear, even if the specifics change from piece to piece.

title: Where Death Got a Head Start, Indians Struggle
description: Dead bodies, some washed up from the bay like driftwood, others bobbing like corks in the river, have become so plentiful in this port city that the authorities simply collect what they can and lay them out in tight bunches on the beach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, LILLIAN
description: LEVINE-Lillian. The family of the late Lillian Haft Shulman Levine mourn the loss of a beloved wife, mother, grandmother, greatgrandmother and sister. Her vitality, generosity, humor and love will be deeply missed. We will cherish her memory always. Services will be private.

title: Democrat Wins in a Squeaker Election for Mayor of Philadelphia
description: After a harrowing election night vigil in which he finally beat back his opponent by a hairbreadth margin, John F. Street wearily faced his city early this morning and claimed the mayoral prize with a humble plea: ''Give us a chance.''

title: Fed Survey Raises Hopes That Rates Will Stay Steady
description: The economy remains strong with some evidence of slower growth, the Federal Reserve said today in reporting the results of its latest regional economic survey. The findings suggested that Fed policy makers might not be in a rush to raise interest rates when they meet on Nov. 16.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAKOBOVITS, IMMANUEL, LORD
description: JAKOBOVITS-Immanuel, Lord. Emunah of America mourns the passing of a world Jewish leader of outstanding dignity and personality whose reputation resounded throughout the world. Our condolences go to his wife, Amelie, our good friend, and to the entire family. Dr. Sylvia Schonfeld National President

title: The Computer as Post Office
description: I WAS getting along fine at the post office until digital stamps came along.

title: Danny Glover Says Cabbies Discriminated Against Him
description: The actor Danny Glover, of the ''Lethal Weapon'' series, ''Beloved,'' and other films, filed a complaint yesterday with the City Taxi and Limousine Commission, charging a cabdriver with discrimination on Oct. 9 for refusing to allow him to ride in the front passenger seat.

title: Buying Groceries Online? Forget About Lamb Shanks
description: IF MY expectations for online grocery shopping were high, it was because I had heard many wondrous stories: of delivery ''ambassadors'' in Chicago who arrived at the door anxious whether the bananas were exactly ripe, of customers in Boston with refrigerators in their garages to accommodate round-the-clock ice cream delivery, of lucky mothers in Seattle who had not been inside a supermarket with a screaming child in months.

title: A Bittersweet Farewell As Time Goes By
description: In ''Danzon'' Pina Bausch has choreographed a 20th-century dance of life, as opposed to a medieval dance of death. The journey onstage at the Brooklyn Academy of Music suggests the inevitable end that claims all. But as dirt is thrown across the floor at this universal funeral, there is no rancor, no terror.

title: The V-Chip Arrives With a Thud
description: WITH KENNY dying a violent death in almost every ''South Park'' episode, wrestlers on cable channels engaging in round-the-clock head-banging and plenty of bare skin showing in prime time, it is not surprising that many parents find a lot of what is on television unfit for their children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMERANTZ, GERTA
description: POMERANTZ-Gerta. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns with profound sorrow the passing of Gerta Pomerantz, a Chai Founder and wife of our cherished friend and benefactor, the late Fred P. Pomerantz, a founding member of Boys Town's Board of Directors. Fred was a pioneering leader in his service to Israel and the Jewish People. His commitment to the welfare of his fellow man motivated many others to follow his example. Inspired by his father's magnanimous philanthropy and desire to assist disadvantaged Israeli youth, his son, John J., established the Fred P. Pomerantz Center for Technological Education at Boys Town, which enabled the school to emerge as a premier institution for high-tech education in Israel. The individual and collective achievements of Boys Town students will endure as a living and lasting tribute to the memory of Fred and Gerta Pomerantz. We extend heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Josh S. Weston, Chairman Michael J. Scharf, President Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Rabbi Ronald L. Gray, Executive Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, MAX
description: WEINSTEIN-Max. Beloved husband of the late Claire. Devoted father of Arlene and Michael Slater. Loving grandfather and great grandfather of Karen and Mark, Lauren, Rebecca, Matthew and Michele. Graveside services Friday, 11 AM at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island.

title: Investors See Room for Profit In the Demand for Education
description: When Arthur Levine, president of Teachers College at Columbia University, met last year with Michael Milken, the ''fallen junk bond king turned education entrepreneur,'' it was more than a case of the old school meeting the new.

title: Finder's Fee Pulls Out Amid Final Planning
description: When it got down to the hard realities of the Breeders' Cup today, Finder's Fee was withdrawn from the juvenile races, Mossflower skipped the Distaff and was booked into the new Filly and Mare Turf race and Chilukki at 8-5 was named the lowest-priced favorite of all 102 horses entered Saturday in the $13 million championships.

title: Mets Are Eyeing Griffey And Braves From Afar
description: While remaining circumspect about the Mets' interest in Ken Griffey Jr. because he fears a tampering charge, General Manager Steve Phillips said yesterday that, should the Atlanta Braves acquire Griffey, it would affect the Mets' plans.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TEXAS UTILITIES CO., Dallas, said it plans to buy back more than $800 million of its common stock next year. The buyback will involve approximately 7.5 percent of its 276.4 million shares outstanding.

title: Reprising 'Huey' and Waiting to Connect
description: Roger Guenveur Smith, who is in New York to reprise his acclaimed theatrical reincarnation of Huey Newton, has delved into a cornucopia of tics, accents and colloquialisms to play a startling range of characters. His film roles include a disabled peddler in Spike Lee's ''Do the Right Thing,'' a jive-talking hustler in Mr. Lee's ''He Got Game'' and a cuckolded husband in ''Eve's Bayou.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERSON, CARL HOSHIN
description: PETERSON-Carl Hoshin, of Yonkers, NY, died on November 2, 1999. He is the loving husband of Lucille Lohmeier Peterson. Cherished son of Doris Dorn Peterson and the late Carl Peterson. Dear cousin of Philip Peterson. Brother of Doris Rubasch. A memorial service will be held at 4 PM Saturday, December 4, 1999, at Empty Hand Zendo, at The Meeting House, 624 Milton Rd, Rye, NY 10573. Friends who wish may contribute to The Empty Hand Zendo in his memory. For more information, contact Westchester Funeral Home, 914337-4585.

title: Ayatollah Rebukes Iran Liberals and U.S.
description: Iran's supreme religious leader today marked the 20th anniversary of the seizure of the American Embassy here with a fiery speech denouncing Iranian reformers who have called for reconciliation with the United States as ''either simpletons or traitors.''

title: Ian Bannen, 71, Whose Career Spanned O'Neill and 'Ned Devine'
description: Ian Bannen, who scored a film triumph late in his career as a charming con man in the 1998 hit comedy ''Waking Ned Devine,'' died yesterday in a car crash in his native Scotland. He was 71.

description: Q. When you buy something online, how do they make sure credit card information is safe from computer hackers?

description: Psychologists have long puzzled over what is known as cognitive dissonance, the ability of one person to calmly hold two seemingly paradoxical ideas, like opposing cruelty to animals but relishing kielbasa.

title: Floyd Claims the Mayor In Flood-Ravaged Town
description: Two months after it destroyed hundreds of homes and businesses in Bound Brook, N.J., a community on the banks of the Raritan River, Tropical Storm Floyd has claimed another victim there: the political career of Mayor Frank J. Gilly, who lost his re-election bid on Tuesday.

title: Mrs. Clinton Prepares for Residency and Campaigning
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said today that she had cleared her schedule of most first lady obligations after Jan. 1 so she could spend the ''majority of my time'' campaigning for the Senate next year. Her new house now officially in hand, Mrs. Clinton said she would establish herself as a New York resident as soon as possible.

description: THE ability to recognize patterns -- the way noses tend to appear in the middle of faces, how words like ''throw'' are often associated with ''curve ball'' and ''touchdown pass'' -- has always been linked with human intelligence. Not necessarily high intelligence, but something that machines have a hard time with.

title: Does Al Gore Need a Makeover?
description: To the Editor:

title: City Sites For Year 2000: A Mixed Bag
description: PERHAPS it is just another sign of growing confidence that the nation will sail into next year with few serious computer date problems. Maybe the money is needed elsewhere. Or could it be old-fashioned incompetence?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELSON, HELEN RUTH, (NEE GOTTESMAN)
description: ADELSON-Helen Ruth, (nee Gottesman) on November 3, 1999. Devoted mother of Mark (Margaret) and Sarah Phoebe. Cherished sister of Judith Friedman, Sarah Lubin and Michael Gottesman. Services are today, November 4, 10:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Two U.S. Drug Giants Planning to Merge in a $70 Billion Deal
description: American Home Products and Warner-Lambert said early today that they had agreed to merge in a deal that would form the world's largest drug company.

title: OTIS TO INVEST IN LG
description: A South Korean conglomerate, LG Group, agreed to form a joint venture with the Otis Elevator Company, a unit of the United Technologies Corporation. The venture will acquire the building-facilities business of the LG Industrial Systems Company, which makes elevators, escalators, parking systems and industrial motors. Otis Elevator will invest around $500 million in the venture.

title: Stars on the Walls, And in Sellers' Eyes; Hopes of a Boom Drive Fall Auctions
description: Just as analysts on Wall Street try to predict cycles in the stock market, collectors and dealers try to track peaks and valleys in the art market. So the fact that this month's important auctions of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art will include many works owned by individuals hoping to cash in on the recent strong prices has insiders wondering whether this season's sales can top the 80's boom.

title: Winter Bringing Fears for Afghan Refugees
description: Thousands of refugees face disaster this winter unless Afghanistan's battling factions allow the creation of a safe corridor within the next few weeks to deliver food, fuel and shelter supplies to the country's north, the United Nations relief coordinator for Afghanistan said today.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The dollar rose against the euro, as investors avoided big bets on the euro to await clearer signals from Europe on interest rates. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0485, down from $1.0515 on Tuesday.

title: Children in Shelters
description: To the Editor:

title: A Major Importer Is Convicted Of Smuggling Caviar Into U.S.
description: A major caviar importer who supplies restaurants and retailers across the United States was convicted yesterday of smuggling thousands of pounds of the delicacy into the country to avoid new restrictions that seek to protect dwindling sturgeon supplies.

title: Video Fishing Game Means No Slimy Bait
description: THE PROMOTIONAL materials for Sega's new Bass Fishing game for Dreamcast promise ''the sensation of sport fishing in an expansive 3-D virtual lake -- one minute you're sitting on your couch waiting patiently for a tug at your lure, then BAM! You're standing on the edge of your boat with a bass tugging madly on your hook! To make things even more realistic, the fish are hyper-intuitive. Sunlight reflections bounce perfectly off ripples in the lake, as realistically rendered wiggling fish, complete with blank stares and moving gills, swim about in the lake's murky depths, testing your ability to 'lure' them in.''

title: Sprewell Puts His Game Face On
description: It seemed as if Latrell Sprewell slipped into something more comfortable when he ducked into the locker room at halftime tonight and emerged with a look more suited for his personality.

title: Latin Markets Surge, With Mexico's Up 5.73%
description: Inestors bought heavily into Mexican stocks today, reacting to polls predicting a stable outcome in the nation's first presidential primary election and to signs that Telefonos de Mexico is becoming an important Internet competitor.

title: Women Make Rapid Gains in the Chase for Doctoral Degrees
description: The annual total of women receiving Ph.D.'s has increased by more than 50 percent in a decade, growing at over twice the rate of the number of men getting those degrees, a new study has found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHATFIELD TAYLOR, MAROCHKA
description: CHATFIELD TAYLOR-Marochka age 93 died of a stroke following a fall, in Mystic, CT, November 2, 1999, at Pendleton Rehabilitation Center. She was born in St. Petersburg, Russia July 24, 1906. Her father was the well-known Russian artist, Boris Anisfeld, who designed sets and costumes for the Russian theater and opera before the 1917 Russia revolution and later for the Metropolitan Opera in New York. Ms. Chatfield-Taylor emigrated to the United States with her father and mother at the height of the Russian revolution. She arrived in New York in 1918, when her father's paintings, transported from Russia, were exhibited in a major show at the Brooklyn Museum. Later, her father was employed by the Metropolitan Opera Company from 1918-1927. She was educated at the Ethical Culture Society School in Manhattan. The family moved to Chicago in 1929, where her father became professor of advanced painting at the Chicago Art Institute. While attending the Art Institute as a student, Ms. Anisfeld produced exhibitions of her own work of drawings and paintings. She also created murals for cafes and bars in Chicago and designed high-fashion clothing. In 1936, she married journalist Otis Chatfield-Taylor, from a prominent Chicago family. The ceremony was conducted in her father's art studio in Chicago. They lived in Croton-on-Hudson, New York. Mr. Chatfield-Taylor owned and edited the local newspaper. Following his death in 1948, Ms. Chatfield-Taylor moved to Manhattan and created a company called Maggie Taylor gowns, which produced her own original clothing designs. In 1954, Ms. Chatfield-Taylor moved to Washington, D.C., where she worked for many years as a real estate agent and antique dealer. In 1970 she moved to Stonington, CT. Following her father's death in 1973, she devoted her energies to promoting her father's reputation in the world of Russian and American art. She is survived by one son, Charles Chatfield-Taylor of San Francisco, CA and Stonington, CT and by two granddaughters, Jessica Chatfield-Taylor of San Francisco, and Mercedes Flett of Lotus, CA. No memorial service is planned. Donations in memory of Marochka Chatfield-Taylor may be made to The Art Institute of Chicago, 111 South Michigan Ave, Chicago, IL 60603-6110.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIETRICH, KURT
description: DIETRICH-Kurt. Died at home on November 1st. A quiet, caring, creative man whose friendship was cherished by many. Kurt was the ever supportive and devoted husband of Susanne, the much loved and loving father of Gregg, Mark, and Allison Demetros. Affectionate brother of Greta Bussman. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: The Healer of Injured and Ailing Hospitals
description: DR. LUIS R. MARCOS loves the little ironies in life.

title: ESSAY; Like Athletes, Workers Need Conditioning for Computer Jobs
description: ALMOST every day now, I see one or two patients with pain in their upper limbs that they attribute to their use of computers at work. These patients are usually young and quite healthy, but they have a look of apprehension, some fear of the unknown and an overly gentle handshake, as if I might damage them further with a simple greeting. But since they are often on their ever-more-truncated lunch hours, they waste no time beginning their story -- a story I am hearing with an alarmingly increasing frequency.

title: Embargo on Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Publisher Assails Paper In Los Angeles
description: Otis Chandler, the former publisher of The Los Angeles Times and the former chairman of Times Mirror, its parent company, last night offered a sweeping denunciation of the newspaper's current management for its ''unrealistic and impossible'' circulation goals, its ''unbelievably stupid and unprofessional'' agreement to share profits with the management of a downtown arena, and its contribution to the decline in morale among the newspaper's staff.

title: A Quiet Roar: China's Leadership Feels Threatened by a Sect Seeking Peace
description: Has it come to this: that the Chinese Communist Party is terrified of retirees in tennis shoes who follow a spiritual master in Queens?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINHAUS, GERALD I.
description: STEINHAUS-Gerald I. Fifty-two, died suddenly on Monday, November 1st having been stricken at his home in New Canaan, (CT). Born in Brooklyn, New York, October 30, 1947, graduated from New York University with a degree in mathematics & German literature, Mr. Steinhaus received his Juris Doctor from Northern Illinois University School of Law and was in private practice in New York for over twenty years. Son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Jack (Julia) Steinhaus of Lido Beach (NY) and predeceased by his sister, Sharon and a brother, Paul, Mr. Steinhaus is survived by his wife of twenty-five years, Karen Steinhaus and their three children, Joshua, 23, Jeremy, 20, and Johanna, 19. Mr. Steinhaus is also survived by his sister, Maxine, four nieces and a grand nephew. Services will be 2PM Friday, November 5th at Hoyt Funeral Home in New Canaan followed by interment at Lakeview Cemetery.

title: Of Toxic Waste, a Dog And a Mysterious Bag Lady
description: Swiss modern-dance choreographers have grown introspective in recent years. So it seemed, at least, from the mini-festival of work by Swiss modern-dance choreographers presented on Friday and Saturday nights at the Swiss Institute in SoHo in conjunction with New Europe '99.

title: Colombia Rebels Add Journalists to List of Prospective Hostages
description: As the focus of Colombia's civil conflict shifts from the battlefield to the negotiating table, left-wing guerrillas are withdrawing the immunity they once granted to the press and have begun kidnapping journalists attempting to cover their activities.

title: Sprint to Take On Bell Atlantic With $35-a-Month Local Calling
description: The Sprint Corporation, the nation's third-largest long-distance telephone company, will seek to loosen Bell Atlantic's grip on the regional telecommunications market by offering unlimited local calls for a monthly rate of $35, officials of the company said yesterday.

title: Technology Issues Lead Nasdaq to 5th Consecutive Rise
description: Technology stocks propelled the Nasdaq composite index to a fifth consecutive advance and its first close at more than 3,000 points yesterday, extending a gain that in slightly more than two weeks totals 12.7 percent. It was the market's fourth-busiest session on record.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FROMHARTZ, MARY
description: FROMHARTZ-Mary. Wife of the late Phillip. Loving mother of Zeporah Geller, Diane Fromhartz, & the late Susan Granett. Devoted grandmother & great grandmother. Graveside services Friday, Nov. 5, 10:30 AM at United Hebrew Cemetery, Staten Island.

title: BREEDERS CUP; An Edge With Every Breath They Take
description: In Kentucky, Burrito found the wire and paid 33-1 wearing it. In California, racing stewards would not let Zante out of the paddock sporting one. Rip! Off came the latest piece of equipment for race horses, and Zante's trainer, Bobby Frankel, is still upset. He knows what his horse's nose needs: a nasal strip.

title: 2nd Teacher Kills Self After Sex Abuse Charge
description: For the second time in two weeks, a Bergen County educator charged with sexually abusing female students has committed suicide, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Coalition of Democrats Helped Doom Mayor's Charter Plan
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's huge defeat on the City Charter on Tuesday was engineered by a classic, sometimes stealthlike coalition of labor unions, Democratic officials and political clubs that targeted 20 key neighborhoods around the city and then deployed 1,500 people to knock on doors and bring voters to the polls on Nov. 2. Even Mr. Giuliani acknowledged yesterday that his opponents ''did a much better job of pulling the vote.''

title: Devils' Double: A Victory, And a Hero From Their Past
description: Claude Lemieux, the most valuable player in the Devils' Stanley Cup championship in 1995, is back in New Jersey.

title: Hold the Needle and Thread
description: Barbara Barran, a professor of English at the New York School of Interior Design, had always dreamed of using quilt motifs in an innovative, decorative way -- without sewing. (She fondly recalls Amish quilts from growing up in rural Pennsylvania.) To her delight, Ms. Barran has found a manufacturer who can make quilt-patterned area rugs and runners from laser-cut broadloom that is hand-assembled to look like Amish patchworks. Her rugs come in eight styles and many colors, with ready-made sizes in nylon pile; Wild Goose Chase, above, 36 by 54 inches, is $495. A 28-by-96-inch runner in the same pattern is $895. Special orders in nylon or wool are 40 percent more. Information: www.classicrug.com or (888) 334-0063. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Robert Van Kampen, Investor And Bible Collector, Dies at 60
description: Robert D. Van Kampen, a millionaire investor who built one of the world's largest private collections of biblical manuscripts and early printed Bibles, died on Friday at Loyola University Medical Center outside of Chicago while awaiting a heart transplant. He was 60.

title: Pataki Asks Changes in Law to Speed Budgets
description: Taking on one of the most contentious issues in state government, Gov. George E. Pataki and his Republicans allies in the Legislature today proposed extensive changes in state law intended to speed up New York's notoriously tardy budget-making process.

title: MICROMUSE WILL BUY CALVIN ALEXANDER NETWORKING
description: Micromuse Inc., a maker of networking software, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Calvin Alexander Networking Inc. for about $42 million in stock to gain software that finds and identifies problems in computer networks. Calvin Alexander's technology will be integrated into Micromuse software products that manage computer networks. New York-based Calvin Alexander whose eight employees will be retained, was founded by Michael Wood about two years ago. Mr. Wood will be a senior vice president at Micromuse.

title: Nazi Slave Labor Talks Halt Over Payments
description: Faced by growing differences over compensating Nazi-era slave laborers, German and American negotiators have abandoned plans to meet this month in Bonn.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Oct. 26 about the acquisition of Blue mountain.com by Excite@Home misstated the stake held by AT&T in Excite. It is 26 percent; AT&T is not the majority owner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHER, VIOLA (VICKI)
description: SCHER-Viola (Vicki). On October 25, 1999, in Boca Point, Florida. Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Dear mother of Ellyn Fine, Sally Weiss Greenspan and David Scher. Adored grandmother and great-grandmother. You were the matriarch of our family, you will always be in our hearts.

title: Jet Plunged, Then Climbed 7,000 Feet Before Crashing
description: After EgyptAir Flight 990 fell steeply in its final minutes, approaching or even reaching the speed of sound, the plane slowed its decline and then climbed more than a mile before plunging once more and apparently breaking up in midair, according to radar data released here tonight.

title: Wheelchair Racers Seek Equality With Runners
description: Carlos Guzman will never forget last year's New York marathon, when he and dozens of other athletes in wheelchairs felt deeply humiliated after being stopped for nearly half an hour at the Queensboro Bridge to let the lead elite runners pass.

title: Free Software Sounds Alerts On Sites' Use of Personal Data
description: Amazon.com may have attracted 13 million shoppers, but how many of them really know what the company plans to do with their personal information? That is the question asked by Enonymous.com, a new company that wants to give Web surfers a more complete picture of exactly how sites plan to use their names, e-mail addresses and any other information they collect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERRMANN, RICHARD A., M.D.
description: HERRMANN-Richard A., M.D. On November 3, 1999. Beloved husband of Marilyn, devoted father of Rachel & Amy. Services Sunday, November 7th, 1:45 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made to the Student and Teaching Fund of the Weill Cornell Medical College, 1300 York Ave, Box 123, New York City, New York 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHELPERT, JOHN W., M.D.
description: SCHELPERT-John W., M.D. The Executive Commmittee of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG), District II, mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague and his loving wife Joann, who lost their lives tragically aboard the EgyptAir Flight 990. Dr. Schelpert enthusiastically dedicated over 18 years to ACOG. He was Chairman of District II from 1987-1990. During his tenure Dr. Schelpert established the joint ACOG/DOH C-Section Task Force; completed the Maturity Information Booklet and guided the Prenatal Care Act of 1987. In his honor, ACOG NYS, will present the John and Joann Schelpert, M.D., Memorial Lecture at the ADM. Contributions may be made to ACOG, 152 Washington Avenue, Albany, New York 12210.

title: FLETCHER CHALLENGE DEAL REJECTED
description: Minority shareholders of Fletcher Challenge Canada Ltd., a Vancouver-based pulp and paper manufacturer, rejected a plan by its New Zealand parent that would have combined it with other international forest-product businesses to create a company with $3.5 billion in assets. Fletcher Challenge Ltd. owns 51 percent of the Canadian company, but its proposal required approval by most of the minority shareholders. Only 9 percent voted in favor.

title: GROUP MAINTENANCE TO ACQUIRE BUILDING ONE
description: Group Maintenance America agreed yesterday to acquire the Building One Services Corporation for $370 million in cash and stock. It will also assume debt of $570 million. The companies specialize in janitorial and heating services for commercial-property owners. Building One's stockholders will receive 1.25 Group Maintenance shares for each share. Apollo Management IV, an investment firm controlled by the New York investor Leon Black, will buy $150 million in new debt issued by Group Maintenance as part of the acquisition. Shares of Building One, based in Minneapolis, were up 43.75 cents, to $11.7625, while Group Maintenance of Houston was up 25 cents to $10.25.

title: New Offerings Are Strong For Thomson And Be Free
description: The initial public offerings of Thomson Multimedia, the French maker of RCA televisions, and Be Free, an American provider of Internet marketing services for online merchants, were strong performers yesterday.

title: A Death Puts Gene Therapy Under Increasing Scrutiny
description: Six weeks after an 18-year-old Arizona man died unexpectedly in a gene therapy experiment, the field's safety record is coming under increasing scrutiny, and new information is coming to light about patients who may have been harmed in other clinical trials.

title: Few Clues to Gunman's Rage in Hawaii Killings
description: He lived on Easy Street, a one-block dead end in the green hills above town. He raised prize carp and goldfish in homemade tanks and built fine furniture by hand. And he also collected weapons, as many as 19 by official count: a dozen handguns, 5 rifles and 2 shotguns, each apparently registered as required by law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIE, GLORIA J.
description: RIE-Gloria J. on November 3, 1999 after a long illness. Beloved wife of John. Mother of Christopher, Dr. Jonathan and Jennifer Van der Linden. Grandmother of nine. Houston St, NYC 10014 or The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, Inc, 1 Penn Plaza, NYC 10019.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASEDO, ADINA STITZEL
description: ASEDO-Adina Stitzel, at 93, of Manhattan, died on Wednesday, November 3, 1999, at home. Born in London, England, in 1906, she came to the U.S. in 1912. She lived on the Lower East Side where she taught Hebrew before sailing to Palestine. In Jerusalem she met and married Dr. Jeroham Asedo, who died in 1992, after 62 years of marriage. She was active in many Zionist organizations and founded Oron, a Hebrew braille magazine. She is survived by two daughters, Yael Freedman of New York, Tamar Sherman of Northport; a son, Ethan Asedo of Marlboro, New Jersey, and nine grandchildren. Graveside services will be held at 11 AM today at Beth Israel Cemetery in Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: Accounts
description: * The Tennessee Valley Authority, Knoxville, Tenn., to Fitzgerald & Co., Atlanta, part of the Interpublic Group of Cos., to continue handling the account, which had been placed in review. Billings were estimated at $6 million.

title: Auditors Toughen Rules on Conflicts
description: The accounting profession has adopted requirements to strengthen compliance with a rule that forbids auditors from having a financial interest in the companies they are supposed to be keeping honest.

title: Drug Giants to Merge In a $70 Billion Deal
description: American Home Products and Warner-Lambert, the pharmaceutical giants, announced early today that they had agreed to merge in a deal that would form the world's largest drug company.

title: Furniture, From B.C. to A.D.
description: Necessity is the mother of furniture; its design has many fathers. ''The design of furniture is influenced by painting, architecture, sculpture and interior decoration,'' said John Morley, author of the comprehensive ''History of Furniture: 25 Centuries of Style and Design in the Western Tradition'' (Bulfinch Press, $75). Mr. Morley was keeper of furniture and interior design at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London. He draws erudite connections between a Biedermeier dressing table and a 20th-century cocktail cabinet. The 16th-century traveling bed below has Moresques -- interlacing tendrils and vines -- inlaid in ebony, ivory and purplewood. The bed was made in Germany; the motifs are Islamic.

title: Puzzle of 767 Crash:Thrust Reversers
description: WASHINGTON  With a blustery storm bringing a temporary halt to recovery operations in waters off Massachusetts, EgyptAir and other aviation officials sought to quell speculation Wednesday that a thrust reverser on Flight 990 might accidentally have deployed, sending the plane into an irrecoverable dive.

description: PITKIN-Lily. Devoted wife of the late Irving. Beloved aunt, great-aunt and great-great aunt. Services are on Friday, at 12 noon, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

description: CARRIER CORP., Hartford, part of United Technologies, named Jonathan W. Ayers president, succeeding John Lord, who is retiring.
