title: A Word or Two on Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Plan Set for Retail Complex On State Land in Harlem
description: After a dispute with the city and a nine-month delay, Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday that Harlem Center, an $85 million retail, office and hotel complex, would be built on state-owned land at the crossroads of Harlem.

title: Getting a Load Off Your Feet, From the Sleek to the Sensual
description: All chairs and couches are essentially descendants of something the Egyptians created nearly 5,000 years ago. Four varied offspring are being shown in Manhattan.

title: Finding the Right Slam By Avoiding a Splinter Bid
description: One four-four fit is as good as another, and one five-four fit is as good as another. Those statements are broadly true, but there are interesting exceptions. Assuming that they are both major suits, it is usually right to play in the stronger suit: Losers in the weak suit may be avoidable if it is not trumps.

title: Rejecting Some Taxes And Limits On Growth
description: In wide-ranging referendums around the United States, voters on Tuesday rejected the strictest antigrowth measures in the country, approved the nation's most sweeping antitax proposals, rejected proposals to allow murder convictions based on nonunanimous jury votes and to ban a type of late-term abortion and prohibited banks from imposing surcharges on automated teller machines.

title: Nike's enthusiastic new campaign draws some criticism from New York Marathon officials.
description: WITH what could best be described as evangelical zeal, Nike is in the middle of an advertising campaign this week in New York City that tries to capitalize on that proud urban tradition of preaching from street corners to promote the company's products during the 30th running of the New York City Marathon, which will take place on Sunday.

title: Republicans Maintain Their Solid Majority
description: A healthy economy and foul weather on Election Day allowed Republicans to retain their solid majority in New Jersey's 80 General Assembly races, leaders of both parties said today.

title: Vertigo at Floor Level
description: The marble roundel, five feet in diameter, looks as if it is whirling around: Cosma is one of five designs from Paris Ceramics inspired by the floors of the Basilica of San Marco in Venice. (It's worth just looking, but anything more will set you back $11,700.) The roundels are made of hand-carved marble veneer attached to three-quarter-inch marble. Polished sandstone parquet, $55 a square foot, above, is also available. Paris Ceramics, to the trade, 150 East 58th Street; (212) 644-2782.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Metro Business; Power Plant to Be Built
description: Calpine Corporation, a power plant developer with projects in 15 states, said Tuesday that it would build a 500-megawatt power plant in Oxford, Conn., for $250 million to boost electricity sales in New England.

title: Juror Who Rejected Guilty Vote in Subway Killing Had Just Been Convicted
description: A holdout juror whose refusal to convict caused a mistrial in the case of a schizophrenic man accused of shoving a stranger to her death in the subway was convicted of harassment and resisting arrest three weeks before he became a juror, a fact that probably would have disqualified him.

title: Senate Passes Trade Bills For Caribbean And Africa
description: The Senate today approved a far-ranging package of trade bills for African and Caribbean nations intended to help flagging economies in those regions by opening new markets.

title: Television CensorChip
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Corrections
description: A list of television program credits on Page E11 today with the review of the two-part documentary ''Not for Ourselves Alone: The Story of Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Susan B. Anthony'' misstates its broadcast time. It is to be shown on PBS stations on Sunday and Monday at 8 p.m., not 11:30.

title: National News Briefs; F.B.I. Deputy Director Resigns for Private Sector
description: The deputy director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation will retire at the end of the month after 31 years with the F.B.I., officials announced today.

title: Alzheimer's, With Tears On the Side
description: SHE ought to start carrying tissues wherever she goes, the young New York woman was saying between sniffles. The tears seem to flow all the time these days.

title: A Bear Stearns Banking Fund
description: Bear Stearns plans to raise at least $1 billion for its first merchant banking fund as the concern, the sixth-biggest United States securities firm, expands its business of investing in companies.

title: U.N. Says Yugoslav Poverty Is Soaring
description: Poverty in Yugoslavia has nearly doubled since the Kosovo conflict, with almost two-thirds of the population, predominantly Serbian, living at or below the poverty line, the senior United Nations relief official there reported today.

title: Of Houdini In Essence But Not Quite All About Him
description: ''Houdini the Great,'' presented at the Miller Theater on Saturday evening as part of the current Danish festival, is an unpretentious little musical comedy, with words by Erik Clausen and music by Andy Pape. It had little to do with Houdini's life, which was rather a pity, because that life was interesting and full of music-theater possibilities and because the central character, if given a chance by the score, could have sung out the artistry of escape. Houdini put his life at risk, night after night, for the sake of a virtuoso feat. He represented, if somewhat in caricature, the flamboyant daring of a great singer.

title: COMPUTER LEARNING CENTERS HIRES INVESTMENT BANK
description: Computer Learning Centers said yesterday that it had hired U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray to help it explore options, including a possible sale. The company, based in Fairfax, Va., provides computer education and training at 28 centers in the United States and Canada. It reported revenue of $68.8 million and a loss of $3 million for the six months ended July 31. Computer Learning rose 43.75 cents, to $3.25, giving the company a market value of about $59 million.

title: Morality Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: PacifiCare Picks New Chairman
description: PacifiCare Health Systems Inc., one of California's biggest health insurers, said today that it might seek a buyer and that it had named a new chairman in a series of moves intended to help raise its flagging share price.

title: South Korea Announces Plan to Stabilize Financial Markets
description: The government announced a $2.5 billion plan today aimed at stabilizing South Korea's financial markets by rescuing the country's investment trust companies, swamped with bonds bought from the crumbling Daewoo Group conglomerate.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: Panel to Focus On U.S. Bank And Deposits By Africans
description: Citigroup's handling of bank accounts controlled by prominent African leaders and their relatives is expected to come under scrutiny in Congressional hearings that begin on Tuesday, according to people involved in the inquiry.

title: China Set to End Suspension of Military Relationship With U.S.
description: China and the United States have agreed to resume military relations suspended by Beijing last May when NATO bombed the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen said today.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Vienna never looked so good. In a decorating frenzy, David Bouley has summoned up a time and place -- the Hapsburg Empire circa 1900 -- that shimmer in a seductive golden haze. He has created a fevered dream of a restaurant, with dense fabrics, opulent colors, lacquered woodwork and jeweled, gilded walls decorated in Klimt's most flamboyant manner. The perfume of romance hovers thickly in this stunning evocation of a city that, a century ago, was a factory of civilized magic.

title: Racing for Equality
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: People
description: * Bob Needleman was named to the new position of senior vice president and co-creative director at Ryan Drossman/Marc, New York, part of Marc USA. He had been creative director at Needleman Pilla Advertising, New York.

title: Former Terrorist Now Fights for Parole
description: Susan L. Rosenberg, a former member of the Weather Underground, was arrested in New Jersey in 1984 after she and a companion were found unloading 740 pounds of dynamite and weapons, including a submachine gun, from their car. Ms. Rosenberg, who had planned to supply others with explosives for bombings, was tried, convicted and sentenced to 58 years in prison.

title: Rodriguez and Green Cause Teams to Quiver
description: Alex Rodriguez, his agent and the Seattle Mariners' brain trust were in the same room in the same city for a while yesterday, while Shawn Green and his agent and the Toronto Blue Jays' general manager were in the same state only 20 minutes apart. But both groups really were in the same state -- a state of uncertainty.

title: The Parent Behind a Landmark Schools Suit
description: TO illustrate an anecdote, Robert Jackson tore off a piece of paper, popped it in his mouth, and chewed. As an 8-year-old in Harlem, he worked for a newsstand owner who punished him thus if he returned from his route with newspapers that were unsold. ''She taught us not to bite off more than we could chew,'' he said.

title: Nuclear Power's Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Rally in Tehran Pays Lip Service To the Revolutionary Zeal of '79
description: For Islamic revolutionaries, it's a red-letter day, a day to raise old banners, shout old slogans, burn a few flags, renew the old fervor -- savor the days when Iran, in its dealings with America, had the sense that at last it was calling the shots.

title: New Jersey Area Codes to Multiply
description: In a simpler time, less than a decade ago, New Jersey's telephone system had two area codes: 201 and 609. Now it has five, with a sixth -- 856 -- going into service on Nov. 13 in four southern counties.

title: BP AMOCO TO ADJUST PENSIONS
description: The multinational oil giant BP Amoco plans to adjust the way it calculates pensions for its British retirees. The new formula will significantly increase most of its 35,000 retirees' income and cost the company $:600 million, or $977 million, which will be covered by the current surplus in the company's pension fund. The new calculation goes into effect on May 1, 2000.

title: Hungry To Snap Up Modernism
description: November may prove to be a true test of American madness for modernism. This month's fairs, sales and online auctions are full of late 19th- and 20th-century decorative arts, and Americans seem to be acquiring them as fast as they can.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COTT CORP., Toronto, the No. 4 soft-drink company, agreed to let Thomas H. Lee Co., Boston, buy an additional 5 percent stake in the company, giving the investment firm a 35 percent stake.

title: Mark Lombardi -- Vicious Circles'
description: Deven Golden

title: Opportunity Re-Knocks at Avon; Passed Over Before, a Woman Is Named Chief Executive
description: Slightly more than a month after warning investors to expect disappointing financial results soon, Avon Products said yesterday it was replacing its chief executive with the ultimate Avon lady.

title: Treasury Prices Keep Rising; 30-Year's Yield Slips to 6.10%
description: Treasury bond prices gained for the third consecutive session yesterday on optimism that the Federal Reserve might not raise short-term interest rates again this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLINS, JOSEPH
description: WOLINS-Joseph, on November 3, 1999, devoted husband of the late Selma, adored father of the late Sarah of Sag Harbor, New York, survived by sons John of Philadelphia, PA, Richard Lazaar of Tarrytown, NY and David Lazaar of the Bronx, NY, beloved brother of Louise Page of Barstow, CA, five grandchildren, one great-grandchild and numerous cousins. Mr. Wolins was an accomplished artist and was represented in the permanent collections of numerous museums worldwide. His warmth, wit and unique personality will be sorely missed. No memorial service is planned. Donations in his memory may be made to the Epilepsy Society, 257 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10017.

title: Seat-of-the Pants Director: Lights! Camera! Gumption!
description: Meet Mark Borchardt, the funny, garrulous subject of the not-to-be-missed documentary ''American Movie.'' He's someone you won't soon forget. He has dedicated himself to making a no-budget black-and-white horror film that features homemade scarecrows and primitive acting, one that's not about to rival ''The Blair Witch Project'' in anything but the expletive department. But that doesn't matter. The point is that Mr. Borchardt cobbles together this project as if his life depended on it, because it does. Insightfully and stirringly, not to mention hilariously, ''American Movie'' shows why.

title: Looking Back, Perlman Bows To the Start Of a Century
description: Itzhak Perlman tipped his hat to the coming 21st century by looking back to the turn of the 20th. His program, offered as part of the Great Performers series at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday evening, was in the style and spirit of the programs that violinists like Mischa Elman, Fritz Kreisler and the young Jascha Heifetz typically played in the first few decades of the century.

title: A High-Stakes Show in Las Vegas
description: WHEN Charlie Van Cleve attended her first trade show for car accessory manufacturers in the mid-1970's, about 100 companies displayed their wares. ''There couldn't have been more than 500 people,'' said Ms. Van Cleve, who was then doing sales for the performance car company owned by Carroll Shelby, the racecar driver.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHELPERT, JOHN WILLIAM
description: SCHELPERT-John William, III, M.D. and Joann Appleyard, of Chestertown, MD and former longtime residents of Bronxville, NY, died Sunday, October 31, 1999. John was a retired obstetrician/ gynecologist with New Rochelle Medical Center. He was a graduate of Yale University, 1950 and Jefferson Medical College, 1955. He held several Board positions with the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, District II from 1973 to 1987, concluding as Chairman from 1987 to 1990. He remained active in ACOG until 1994. Joann, a 1951 Connecticut College graduate, active member of numerous community organizations including the Junior League, the Bartow Pell Mansion and Boulder Ledge Garden Clubs, is survived by her mother, Kathryn Appleyard, sister Jeanne Pontius, brother Joseph Appleyard, Jr. all of Lancaster, PA, and sister Gail Heilbut of New York, NY. Together, they are survived by their four daughters, Susan Murray of Radnor, PA, Ann Francis of Glastonbury, CT, Jane Duffin of Fort Lauderdale, FL and Elizabeth Potter of Winchester, MA. Also surviving are seven loving grandchildren. A memorial service is scheduled for Thursday, November 11, 1999, 2:00 P.M. at Christ Episcopal Church, Bronxville, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to the Chesapeake Bay Foundation, 162 Prince George Street, Annapolis, MD, 21401 or Emmanuel Episcopal Church, Preservation Trust Fund, P.O. Box 875, Chestertown, MD. 21620.

title: To What Great Lengths True Love Will Travel
description: When Kevin meets Nora, she's still a virgin. So when she says she has slept with another man, she means exactly that: slept.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Oct. 25 described the appointment of Adrienne Clarkson as Canada's governor general, the personal representative of Queen Elizabeth II. Ms. Clarkson, a Chinese-Canadian television personality, is the country's first immigrant governor general.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday, about the Nasdaq composite index, in which five companies account for one-third of the value, misidentified the fifth-largest company. It is Dell Computer, not Qualcomm.

title: Morris Louis
description: Ameringer/Howard

title: Executive Urges Central Market
description: The chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, Henry M. Paulson Jr., urged United States securities firms and exchange executives to create a central electronic stock-trading system so United States markets are not left behind European rivals.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: No 'Gay Panic' Excuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARESCA, ANTHONY
description: MARESCA-Anthony. November 3, 1999. Beloved husband of Eileen. Fond brother-in-law of Mary Boyes. Also survived by five nieces & nephews. Visiting Friday, 2-5 & 7-9 PM. McLaughlin Funeral Home, Third Avenue at 97 St. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 9:30AM, at St. Patrick's Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCAVUZZO, JULIUS J.
description: SCAVUZZO-Julius J. On November 4, 1999, age 67, of Mill Neck Estates, Oyster Bay, Long Island. Beloved husband of Patricia A. Loving father of Steven (Laurie) and Paula. Dear step-father of Frank Ruggiere (Alison), Kathleen DeParis (Lawrence), Bart Ruggiere, and Mark Ruggiere. Cherished grandfather of Kathryn and Sophia Julia. Also survived by five loving step-grandchildren. Dear brother of Angela Altimari and Vincent Scala. Visiting Oyster Bay Funeral Home, 261 South Street, Oyster Bay, LI, Sunday 3-5 & 7-9 P.M. Memorial Mass St. Gertrude RC Church, Bayville, LI, Monday 10 A.M. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Hospice Care Network or American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: Stopping Blacks: A Chilling Decision
description: To the Editor:

title: Plymouth Becomes a Ghost Ship
description: PLYMOUTH is about to sail into the sunset. DaimlerChrysler announced on Wednesday that it would phase out the brand at the end of the 2001 model year.

title: Games Are Still Popular, Study Shows
description: The International Olympic Committee, battered for the last year by corruption and doping scandals, released a survey yesterday suggesting that the popularity of the Games had not suffered.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: A Crocodile That's Cuddly

title: Advocates for Blind, in Suit, Say AOL Impedes Access to Internet
description: Arguing that virtual spaces must be as accessible to people with disabilities as are physical spaces, a major organization representing the blind filed suit against America Online yesterday, saying the online service is almost impossible for blind people to use.

title: CONGRESS PASSES WIDE-RANGING BILL EASING BANK LAWS
description: Congress approved landmark legislation today that opens the door for a new era on Wall Street in which commercial banks, securities houses and insurers will find it easier and cheaper to enter one another's businesses.

title: Accounts
description: * Space.com, New York, a Web-based company dedicated to space-related news, information, education and entertainment, to Wolf Group, New York, to handle its first account. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million.

title: Police End Detail to Lure Fugitives With MetroCards
description: The Police Department yesterday canceled an operation intended to catch violent criminals by mailing them free MetroCards, after the plan drew criticism from police unions and civil libertarians.

title: Looking Backward Toward the Future
description: BUILDING A BRIDGE TO THE 18TH CENTURY

title: Education Commissioner Suggests Limiting Remedial Classes at CUNY
description: The New York State Education Commissioner recommended today that the City University of New York be allowed to proceed with its plan to remove remedial classes and remedial students from its four-year colleges, provided the university and the state closely monitor what happens to students under the policy.

title: F.B.I. Warns Criminals That It's Year 2000 Ready
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation turned the clock forward to Jan. 11, 2000, on its main crime-fighting computer today, in a test that indicated fugitives would not slip through the cracks because of glitches caused by the new millennium.

title: Passenger Stabs Driver Of City Bus
description: The first sign that there was something amiss on the city bus in Brooklyn yesterday morning was the passenger banging on a window and yelling for help.

title: Should City Dictate Curriculums?
description: To the Editor:

title: OIL PROFITS DOUBLE
description: The British-Dutch oil giant Royal Dutch/Shell Group said its profits more than doubled to $1.81 billion in its third quarter from $841 million in the comparable period a year earlier as rising oil prices increased the company's profit margins. The company attributed its strong profits in part to a cost-reduction program aimed at cutting $2.5 billion a year by 2001. The company's results, which were in line with analysts' expectations, reflect the recent upswing in earnings for the oil industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRETT, JULIA
description: BRETT-Julia (Hornung) of Sharon, MA, formerly of Long Beach, N.Y. on November 4, 1999. Longtime teacher in the Long Beach NY School System. Beloved wife of the late attorney Karl C. Brett. Devoted mother of Karen and Douglas McKown of Salem, NH and Susan Brett Myerson of Sharon, MA. Loving sister of Ethel Korman of California. Cherished grandmother of Kira and Brett Myerson. Graveside services at The Mount Eden Cemetery, 20 Commerce St, Hawthorne, NY on Friday, November 5 at 2PM. Memorial observance will be held on Sunday at the Myerson residence in Sharon, MA. Remembrances may be made to The American Cancer Society. For information, Brezniak Rodman Funeral Directors, Newton, MA, 1-800-554-2199.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MARION
description: COHEN-Marion. November 4, 1999. Beloved wife of Nathaniel. Loving mother of Hank and Maya. Adoring grandmother of Alex and Jenny. She will be deeply missed.

title: Tampering Ruling Imminent
description: The Mets should find out shortly if their tampering charge against the Seattle Mariners involving John Olerud had any merit.

title: In Artists' Prints, Work and Play
description: ALTHOUGH the big destination for print lovers this weekend is the ninth annual Print Fair, sponsored by the International Fine Print Dealers Association, there is no shortage of opportunities to see the fine art of the printmaker elsewhere. Besides the fair at the Seventh Regiment Armory, quite a few galleries are mounting shows of their own that will last longer than the three-day event on Park Avenue. Occurring uptown and down, they range from the work of established modern masters to that of up-and-coming artists whose names do not yet ring a bell.

title: An F.A.A. Study Shows Few Gains In Improving Security at Airports
description: After Trans World Airlines Flight 800 exploded off Long Island in July 1996, initial fears that the jumbo jet had been brought down by a terrorist bomb prompted the Clinton Administration and Congress to demand that security at the nation's airports be improved.

title: N.F.L. Matchups Week 9
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POKART, BILLIE
description: POKART-Billie. Always in my thoughts. Love, Joe.

title: Signposts as Soapboxes
description: There was the fury against apartheid that turned East 44th Street and Second Avenue into Nelson and Winnie Mandela Corner and the support for Israeli sovereignty that turned a portion of East 70th Street into United Jerusalem Place. And lighter occasions have produced street signs honoring Barbie dolls and Broadway shows, the stand-up comic Jackie Mason and the cellist Yo-Yo Ma.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: A Taxi Ride To Torture Provokes A Chase
description: Since movies keep pushing the envelope of the acceptably gruesome, even the nastiest sights glimpsed in Phillip Noyce's preposterous thriller ''Bone Collector'' should strike jaded moviegoers (those who relished ''Seven,'' for instance) as ho-hum shocks.

title: Gypsies and Others Said to Draw Kosovar Fury
description: Kosovo Albanians have become increasingly aggressive in attacking not only Serbs in this battered province, but also Gypsies and other ethnic minorities, according to foreign officials in charge of restoring peaceful administration in Kosovo.

title: 88 Keys Are Not Enough, So the Strings Are Plucked
description: Margaret Leng Tan has made a specialty of playing unconventional music on unconventional pianos, with the tinkly timbres of toy pianos her current fascination. She returned to a full-size concert grand for her recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday evening, but characteristically she devoted her program to music -- the two books of ''Makrokosmos,'' composed in 1972 and 1973 by George Crumb -- that demanded some modification of the instrument and an expansion of the techniques used to play it.

title: Peter Takes Quiet Ride Into Lineup For Giants
description: Most of the Giants were rushing through the locker room, hurrying to get dressed and to the airport for a flight out of town, trying to take advantage of every moment of the three-day vacation the bye week was providing. But Christian Peter was taking his time, sifting through his mail and then heading into the weight room.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERRMANN, RICHARD A.
description: HERRMANN-Richard A., M.D. On November 3, 1999. Beloved husband of Marilyn, devoted father of Rachel & Amy. Services Sunday, November 7th, 1:45 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made to the Student and Teaching Fund of the Weill Cornell Medical College, 1300 York Ave, Box 123, New York City, New York 10021.

title: Christian Churches Plan a Joint Protest of Nazareth Mosque
description: With a bitter blast at Israel, Roman Catholic and Orthodox Christian leaders here said today that they would close their churches for two days to protest a government decision to permit construction of a mosque on state land next to the Church of the Annunciation in Nazareth.

title: Meeting Handel's Demands And Exulting in Her Own
description: Lorraine Hunt Lieberson is a singer whose voice always sounds utterly secure, and yet after every song she seems to be laughing in pleasure and surprise that it worked again. On Tuesday night it worked again five times over as she went through a selection of demanding Handel arias -- every one a show stopper -- with Orpheus at Carnegie Hall.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Confirmation 'Courtesy' Not a Given for Ex-Senator
description: Once during a committee meeting, Senator Carol Moseley-Braun, the first black woman elected to the Senate, leaned toward a colleague and whispered, ''I am stunned about how often and how much race comes up in conversation and debate in this general assembly.''

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL CLIMBS. Crude oil rose on speculation that high demand in Europe for North Sea supplies would limit exports to the United States. In New York, crude oil for December delivery rose 58 cents, to $23.14 a barrel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, SYLVIA
description: BERMAN-Sylvia. Beloved wife of Sol Berman, of 41 years and the late Ben Rosenstein. Devoted mother of Arthur Rosenstein, Barbara and Mickey Weinburg and Gail & Alan Levenstein. Cherished grandmother of Bonnie and Scott Rogoff, Susie and Adam Hurwitz, Miranda, Jessica & Tony Levenstein. Adored great-grandmother of Jonathan, Andie, Jennifer, Brian and Melissa. Loving sister of Gertrude Kurshan. Services at 11:30 AM Friday at ''BoulevardRiverside Chapel'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

title: Insiders Believe Charges Could Benefit the Sport
description: Reeling from questionable decisions by judges and recent poor performances by fighters in major matches, boxing took another hit yesterday when a federal grand jury in Newark indicted four officials of the International Boxing Federation, one of the three major organizations that sanction world championship bouts, on charges of bribery and racketeering.

title: Classic May Decide Who Wins Horse of Year
description: Two days before the race of his life, Behrens was relaxing far from the battlefield today in the citrus groves of Payson Park, the serene oasis 90 miles north of Gulfstream Park, where 102 horses will race on Saturday for eight championships and $13 million in prize money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAJI, KEIZO
description: SAJI-Keizo. The Rockefeller University community deeply mourns the passing of our beloved friend, Keizo Saji, a cherished member of the Rockefeller University Council for over fifteen years. His commitment to the University's mission of biomedical research and education will be greatly missed. Our deepest condolences are sent to his wife, Keiko, and the entire Saji family. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Richard B. Fisher, Chairman Arnold J. Levine, President Torsten N. Wiesel, President Emeritus Richard M. Furlaud, Chairman, Rockefeller University Council

title: A Long-Distance Tether to Home; New Technology Binds College Students and Parents
description: Sachiko Brown and her mother, Alscess Lewis-Brown, speak to each other every day, sometimes more than once, spanning the distance between Seton Hall University and the island of St. Croix any way they can.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBLICH, MANNETTE
description: LIEBLICH - Mannette. Dystonia Medical Research Foundation NY Chapter notes with sorrow the passing of Manette Lieblich, mother of Nancy Garson, wife of our President, Tom Garson. Deepest condolences to the family. Board of Directors Dystonia Medical Research Fndn

title: Is $2 Billion Fair Payment for a Fiancee Left at the Altar?
description: REMEMBER when people sued for ''alienation of affection?'' The idea was that if someone came in and stole the love of your erstwhile sweetheart, he should be forced to pay for the pain he inflicted on you.

title: Metro Business; 250 Jobs to Be Cut By Summit Bancorp
description: Summit Bancorp, New Jersey's largest bank, said yesterday that it was firing 250 people, or 2.6 percent of its staff, to cut costs.

title: Gunmen Kill Son of Kaunda, Former President of Zambia
description: The 47-year-old son of Kenneth D. Kaunda, the former president of Zambia, was fatally shot Wednesday night in the driveway of his home in the Zambian capital, Lusaka.

title: Kagwe Has Priorities: Victory, Then History
description: In the 30-year history of the New York City Marathon, only Grete Waitz, Bill Rodgers and Alberto Salazar have won three or more years in a row. On Sunday, John Kagwe, who won the marathon here in 1997 and 1998, can join them.

title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: MARCUS ROBERTS: ''In Honor of Duke'' (Columbia/Sony). First of all: despite the pious title, it's not an album of Ellington music. Mr. Roberts, on piano, emphasizes in his liner notes that the record is not a tribute: ''a tribute,'' he declares, ''implies that the value of what you're paying tribute to has little current or future relevance.'' Strong words, but he's right. It's not Ellington or Armstrong or Parker that makes people treat jazz condescendingly; it's the insistence of record and concert producers on hollowly honoring them with repertory rather than with something deeper.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: SPARE TIMES
description: Museums and Sites

title: Signs Seem To Suggest Clemens Will Stay
description: With six days remaining before the deadline for Roger Clemens to demand a trade from the Yankees, numerous baseball executives believe that George Steinbrenner has probably reached an oral contract agreement with the pitcher already.

title: Cybersegregation?
description: To the Editor:

title: For Workers at the Prospective Partners, Healthy Doses of Uncertainty
description: It was a day like any other today outside the world headquarters of Warner-Lambert. Some employees hurried to lunch, others jogged and limousine drivers waited outside the yellow brick, glass-lined buildings to whisk executives away to out-of-town assignments.

title: 'Building Histories'
description: Apex Art

title: Mournful Echoes of a Whistle-Blower
description: Late in ''The Insider'' the tobacco industry whistle-blower Jeffrey Wigand sits despondently in a hotel room and contemplates the steep price of what he has done. The setting is somber except for the bright pastoral mural on the wall behind him, looking like a window onto an unsullied, unattainable world. Then the image begins to roil and morph, and it turns into a vision of the home and family that Mr. Wigand has lost. This is a flashy visual effect, but it's also one that piercingly captures the man's state of mind. And although Michael Mann is a filmmaker whose stylistic brio has a way of overpowering his subject matter, this time he strikes a balance, and he gets it right.

title: The Servants of Both Science and Beauty
description: The New York Public Library has smartly titled its exhibition of 700 years' worth of glorious scientific illustrations ''Seeing Is Believing'' just when digitization has raised doubts about believing your eyes.

title: Singh's 67 Leads by 1 at Valderrama As Woods Starts Slowly With a 71
description: Asked to give his assessment of Valderrama Golf Club, Vijay Singh was honest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPELL, MEYER
description: KOPELL-Meyer. Of New Rochelle, New York. Died November 4, 1999 at the age of 95 years. Meyer is survived by his wife Frieda Ginsberg Kopell. He is also survived by his daughters Linda Levine and Nancy Kopell. His sons-in-law Mark Levine and Gabriel Stolzenberg also survived Meyer. His sister Sylvia Layton and his brothers Sidney and Manny Kopell survived him. Also, his grandchildren Robert (Laurie) Levine and David (Susan) Levine. Funeral service Friday (today) 10:00 A.M. at Bet Am Shalom Temple, Soundview Avenue, White Plains, New York. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a letter in Science Times on Tuesday about the status of the tiger in the wild misstated the affiliation of the writer, Dr. Peter Jackson. He is with the World Conservation Union, not the Wildlife Conservation Union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REITER, HILDE
description: REITER-Hilde. Manhattan Guild sadly records the passing of its esteemed member Hilde Reiter. Her devotion to the Guild and Chaim Sheba Medical Center, Israel was boundless. Deepest sympathies are extended to her family.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: DELL COMPUTER, Round Rock, Tex., named Goran Malm senior vice president for the Asia-Pacific region, Singapore. He had been senior vice president for the Asia-Pacific division at G.E.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: What a Review Has Wrought

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBIAN, GEORGE
description: GIBIAN-George. The Department of Russian Literature and the Russian Language Program at Cornell University are deeply saddened by the unexpected death, on October 24, 1999, of Goldwin Smith Professor of Russian and Comparative Literature George Gibian. He founded the Department and has been a beloved teacher and major scholarly presence for nearly fifty years, 38 at Cornell. He was teaching and writing until his death. We will miss our dear friend. Nancy Pollak, Chair

title: Ernesto Pujol
description: Linda Kirkland Gallery

title: New York Opening of Exhibition on Nazi Atrocities Is Delayed
description: The planned opening in New York next month of an exhibition linking ordinary German soldiers to Nazi war crimes has been postponed as a result of a dispute over whether some of the photographs may be misleading.

title: $500 Million Teligent Stake Seen for Microsoft-Led Group
description: Giving a vote of confidence to the concept of delivering advanced data communications services using wireless links, a group including Microsoft and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, the investment firm, is close to a deal to invest $500 million in Teligent Inc., people close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Rebound in City Murder Rate Puzzling New York Officials
description: For several years, New Yorkers have talked about crime like veterans recalling a vanquished enemy from an old war.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the quality of medical care on cruise ships misstated the salary of a doctor for Carnival Cruise Lines. The doctor, Mauro Neri, was hired by Carnival in 1996 for $1,057 a week, not $1,057 a month.

title: Gore Calls on Republicans To Pass a Gun Control Bill
description: Seizing on the mass shootings in Seattle and Honolulu this week, Vice President Al Gore angrily challenged the Republican-controlled Congress today to approve far-reaching gun control legislation before lawmakers adjourned for the year.

title: Self-Centered, Stylish Parisians in Pursuit of Amour
description: If there is a single characteristic shared by the circle of friends and acquaintances who are the focus of ''Portraits Chinois,'' it is near-total self-absorption.

title: Pressed by a Reporter, Bush Falls Short in World Affairs Quiz
description: Gov. George W. Bush could not name several foreign leaders when he was hit with a pop quiz by a television reporter, according to a report by the television station on Wednesday night.

title: Boy Critically Injured In Elevator Shaft Fall
description: A 4-year-old boy was in critical condition last night after falling five stories in an elevator shaft in a city housing project, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERIC, FRANCOISE
description: ERIC-Francoise. (Mrs. Seward). On November 4, 1999, peacefully at home. Survived by her nephew, Pierre de Moreuil, and her great niece, Claire de Moreuil. Private burial in Remsenburg. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, NYC, Friday, November 12, 1999 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, a donation to the Dr. Stuart Kuan Fellowship at Memorial-Sloan Kettering Hospital, 1275 York Ave, New York, N.Y. 10021 would be appreciated.

title: Internet Companies Set Policies to Help Protect Consumer Privacy
description: To address online privacy concerns, a group of leading Internet advertising and data-profiling companies have agreed to adopt policies that allow consumers to find out what information is collected by the marketers and to turn off the data-gathering technology.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I would like nothing better than to see you die, Mr. McKinney. However, this is the time to begin the healing process, to show mercy to someone who refused to show any mercy.''

title: Nasdaq Is Planning to Compete in Europe
description: The Nasdaq stock market, the largest electronic exchange in the United States, plans to open an Internet-based exchange that will list shares of companies based in Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, ABRAHAM H.
description: STERN-Abraham H., Rabbi. Beloved husband of Gloria and of the late Hilda Scharf Stern. Devoted father of Miriam and Howard Sarnoff, Ilana and Bernard Kabak, Rochelle Stern and Tom Warrick. Cherished grandfather of Diane Sarnoff and Jason Kanefsky, Aileen and Eric Gellman, Gabriel Kabak and Elizabeth Warrick and great-grandfather of Jordan, Amanda, Emily & Alison. Shiva information call 516-292-0123.

title: INSIDE
description: Clinton Visits Northeast

title: A Shareholder, And a Citizen
description: Soon, possibly tonight, a federal judge will rule on the Justice Department's antitrust case against Microsoft. But whatever the decision, it's only the first round in this and related litigation.

title: The Devil And More
description: Samuel Ramey, right, in the title role in Arrigo Boito's ''Mefistofele,'' which opens tonight at the Metropolitan Opera, has made a specialty of performing operatic versions of the Devil. But his repertory is not limited to pieces involving Beelzebub; it ranges widely, from Baroque opera to 20th-century works.

title: On My Mind; Please Read This Column!
description: On Jan. 6, 1987, when The New York Times printed my first column, the headline I had written was: ''Please Read This Column!'' It was not just one journalist's message of the day, but every writer's prayer -- come know me.

title: Report Faults Care of Man Who Pushed Woman Onto Tracks
description: A new state investigation into Andrew Goldstein's psychiatric history concludes that the mental health system spent nearly $100,000 a year to treat him through repeated short-term hospital stays when he really needed a far less costly combination of supervised housing and daily visits from a case manager to ensure that he took his medication.

title: Should City Dictate Curriculums?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sending a Musical Into the World
description: ARMED with stacks of Playbills, the ushers stand at the top of the stairs in their black cardigans and white collars, guarding the entrance to the still-empty theater like sentries.

title: National News Briefs; Head of Finance Inquiry Is Stepping Down
description: Attorney General Janet Reno said today that the head of the Justice Department's long-running campaign finance inquiry was stepping down and would be replaced by a former career federal prosecutor.

title: 4 Boxing Officials Charged in Bribery
description: The founder of the International Boxing Federation -- one of the three major international ranking groups -- and three other top officials of the organization were indicted on charges of receiving payments for manipulating the rankings to allow boxers to qualify for lucrative fights as top contenders.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 16.

title: McCann-Erickson And Boston Beer Part
description: The Boston Beer Company, maker of Samuel Adams beers, and McCann-Erickson in New York said yesterday that they had mutually agreed to part ways. The account, which had billings last year estimated at $11.9 million, had been with McCann-Erickson since August 1998.

title: Excerpts From Statement by Father
description: Following are excerpts from the statement yesterday by Dennis Shepard, the father of Matthew Shepard, at the sentencing of Aaron J. McKinney, who was convicted of second-degree murder on Wednesday in the death of the younger Mr. Shepard, as recorded by the Albany County Attorney's Office in Laramie, Wyo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGMAN, GEORGE S.
description: BERGMAN-George S. On November 3, 1999, in his 102nd year. Former Mayor of Sands Point, N.Y., WWI Marine Corp Veteran. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Dear father of Susan Meehan and John Bergman. Grandfather of Eric, Laura and Jeanne Bergman and Christopher and Alisoun Meehan. Uncle of Patricia Meyer, Jay Edwards and Judy Williams. Services today 2pm at North Country Reform Temple, Crescent Beach Rd., Glen Cove, N.Y.

title: Sports of The Times; Nets Making Right Moves Off the Court
description: THE Nets didn't have to win a championship or even a game to get an audience yesterday with the president, who came to their home, or at least to the city they say will someday be home.

title: Sprewell Takes the Fans' Bait
description: In a section of Chicago's United Center reserved for those with platinum cards or connections, a middle-aged man in a gray sweater stood up like a citizen vowing to fight city hall -- except his beef was with the anti-establishment, Latrell Sprewell.

title: Discriminatory Searches
description: When law enforcement officials resort to tactics that discriminate against law-abiding citizens, it is the job of the courts to demand firm adherence to the Constitution. Sadly, a federal appeals court in Manhattan failed in that duty last week in a case growing out of a notorious 1992 incident in upstate New York.

title: Stopping Blacks: A Chilling Decision
description: To the Editor:

title: ITALIAN INSURANCE MERGER
description: One of Italy's biggest insurers, Istituto Nazionale delle Assicurazioni, accepted a $12.5 billion bid after Assicurazioni Generali, the nation's No. 1 insurer, gave I.N.A.'s management a role in the combined company and sweetened its offer. The acquisition would bolster Generali's position as Europe's third-biggest insurer after Axa of France and Allianz of Germany, with combined premiums of more than 70 trillion lire ($38 billion). The company would have a 26 percent share of the Italian insurance market and be Europe's biggest life insurer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBOVITS, RABBI LORD
description: JACOBOVITS-Rabbi Lord Immanuel. Esteemed member of Board of Directors of Medical Research Foundation of Israel. We will miss his support, advice and leadership. He was a shining light of morality in a confused world. A man of peace. A master of communication. He followed the lead of our forefathers, opened his house in Dublin, New York and London to welcome congregants and strangers. A moralist in medicine and in life. A penchant to act against the unjust. Our condolences to his dear wife Amalie. He spiritually enriched our lives. Derek Enlander, President Lawrence Friedland, Vice Pres. George Dallal, Treasurer

title: Albany Grant For Nassau Is Jeopardized
description: A $10 million grant that the Republican-controlled Nassau County Legislature said had been promised by Gov. George E. Pataki to help balance the county's budget in 2000 may not be coming after all, now that Democrats have won control of the County Legislature, officials with both parties said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, LILLIAN
description: LEVINE-Lillian. The family of the late Lillian Haft Shulman Levine mourn the loss of a beloved wife, mother, grandmother, greatgrandmother and sister. Her vitality, generosity, humor and love will be deeply missed. We will cherish her memory always. Services will be private.

title: Restaurant Scheme Invokes a Fastidious Mayor
description: After his efforts to clear New York City's streets of crime, the homeless, hot dog vendors, jaywalkers, squeegee men, double-parkers and cars that block intersections, it might be easy to believe that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had handed down yet another edict -- this one banning unlocked cans of garbage on city sidewalks.

title: Should City Dictate Curriculums?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bradley, in East Harlem, Pushes Health Care
description: Bill Bradley, whose $65 billion health care plan has been attacked by Vice President Al Gore as ill conceived and too expensive, went on the offensive in East Harlem yesterday before some of the people most lacking in adequate health care.

title: Frederick B. Gleason Jr., Retired Business Executive, 91
description: Frederick Brockway Gleason Jr., 91, a retired business executive, died on Tuesday at his home in Portland, Me. A former New Yorker, he had lived in Maine since 1971.

title: Public Interests; Air Rudy
description: No sooner had the polling booth curtains stopped twitching in New York this week than Rudolph Giuliani took to the air upstate, with the first commercial of the 2000 U.S. Senate campaign. (The race still has no official entrants. But Mr. Giuliani has bought TV time and Hillary Clinton has bought a $1.7 million house, either of which is as good as an announcement as far as I'm concerned.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINNEGAN, J. RICHARD
description: FINNEGAN-J. Richard (Dick). Born January 20, 1925, New York City, passed away November 3, 1999 on Maui. Beloved husband of Lindy, loving father of Mrs. Katie (Gary) Darnell, Ann and Jim Finnegan and Mrs. Stacey (Kevin) Foster. Dick, a graduate of Phillips Academy '43 and Yale University '49, enjoyed a career in banking that spanned 40 years. He served in WWII in the 82nd Airborne and was awarded the Purple Heart. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to The Salvation Army or American Lung Association.

title: Philip Services Gets Bankruptcy Protection
description: The Philip Services Corporation, a Canadian metal and industrial waste company controlled by Carl C. Icahn, the New York financier, won approval this week for a bankruptcy reorganization plan to help wipe out more than $1 billion in debt.

title: FRUIT OF THE LOOM PLANS TO PARE ITS PRODUCT LINE
description: Fruit of the Loom Ltd., one of the largest United States makers of underwear and T-shirts, said yesterday that it would discontinue some products and might close some plants in an effort to return to profitability. The company plans to eliminate about 1,000 products, representing a total of less than 2 percent of sales, it said. The company also is considering closing some sewing plants. Fruit of the Loom said it had a third-quarter loss of $166.4 million, or $2.49 a share, compared with net income of $50.4 million, or 70 cents, a year earlier. It had been expected to have a loss of 34 cents.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Freight Strike a Test of Hoffa's Mettle
description: At daybreak today, Ernie Soehl, a gruff-voiced fireplug of a man, was already yelling orders to the picket line of teamsters just north of Giants Stadium.

title: Bergen Brunswig Profit Dives; Chief Ousted
description: The drug wholesaler Bergen Brunswig dismissed its president and chief executive, Donald R. Roden, today and put Robert E. Martini, its chairman and former chief, in charge of the troubled company. At the same time, it said fiscal fourth-quarter profit fell 85 percent.

title: Thwarting Patients' Rights
description: House Speaker Dennis Hastert suffered an embarrassing defeat last month when 68 Republicans defied his leadership and voted with the Democrats to approve a strong patients' rights bill. Now he is trying to undo that vote through parliamentary maneuvers.

title: Groggy Defender Lifts Isles
description: ISLANDERS 2, CANADIENS 1, OT

title: While Defending Crackdown, China Admits Appeal of Sect
description: The government continued to lash out at the Falun Gong spiritual movement today, comparing it to ''organized crime'' and predicting it would soon ''vanish.''

title: Hey, Baby, Want to Marry A Guy Worth $100 Million?
description: Unmarried men are like wild mustangs charging lustily through life in a continual search for new varieties of sweet, succulent grasses, announces Jimmy (Chris O'Donnell), the smirking narrator of ''The Bachelor,'' a crude, frantic farce satirizing yuppie mating rituals in the age of the cigar bar.

title: A Dolan Agrees to Purchase the Indians for $320 Million
description: Larry Dolan was crestfallen last year when his $525 million bid to acquire the expansion Cleveland Browns team failed, but yesterday he agreed to buy the Cleveland Indians from Richard Jacobs for $320 million for his sporting thrill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAU, RAYMOND
description: BLAU-Raymond, 89. Died on October 30, 1999 of South Orange, New Jersey and Longboat Key, Florida. President of Max Blau & Sons, Inc. Loving husband of the late Hope Blau. He is survived by his loving daughters Maxine Blau and Adele Blau Cass, and grandsons David and Gregory. Friends and family may pay their respects Saturday and Sunday from 1-8 P.M. at the home of Adele Blau Cass, 168 Glenview Road, South Orange, NJ. For more information call (973) 642-4900.

title: A. M. Rosenthal of The New York Times
description: The departure of a valued colleague from The New York Times is not, as a rule, occasion for editorial comment. But the appearance today of A. M. Rosenthal's last column on the Op-Ed page requires an exception. Mr. Rosenthal's life and that of this newspaper have been braided together over a remarkable span -- from World War II to the turning of the millennium. His talent and passionate ambition carried him on a personal journey from City College correspondent to executive editor, and his equally passionate devotion to quality journalism made him one of the principal architects of the modern New York Times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURAK, MANUEL
description: BURAK-Manuel. Beloved father of Anne and Gene; father-in-law to Lee and Mary Ann; brother Ben grandfather of Sheri, Elyse, Adam, and great-grandfather of Kyler. Services are today at the Hebrew Institute of White Plains. Donations can be made to the Hebrew Institute, 20 Greenridge Avenue White Plains, New York 10605.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Cuomo Book, And Easy to Read

title: A Menu Featuring Divorce And Fear
description: A marriage crumbles in ''Dinner With Friends,'' but it would be difficult to forge a more harmonious union of cast, director and script than the one created at the Variety Arts Theater, where Daniel Sullivan's unflinching production of Donald Margulies's rueful play opened last night.

title: Stranded in the City. On Doomsday to Boot.
description: The teasing question that is the hook of Don McKellar's somber thumbsucker of a film, ''Last Night,'' is one that most of us have probably asked ourselves: What would you do if you knew for certain that tonight was your last night on earth?

title: Zvi Griliches, 69, an Authority On Analysis of Economic Data
description: Zvi Griliches, who spent part of his youth hiding from the Nazis in his native Lithuania, survived Dachau, taught himself English in seven months at a British internment camp and went on to become one of the world's leading authorities on the statistical analysis of economic data, died yesterday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 69.

title: Giving In on Foreign Aid Bill, G.O.P. Finds an Election Issue
description: The White House and Congress agreed tonight to cut a deal on a foreign aid bill, adding $799 million more than Republicans wanted to spend, Congressional aides said.

title: Daisy Bates, Civil Rights Leader, Dies at 84
description: Daisy Bates, a civil rights leader who in 1957 led the fight to admit nine black students to Central High School in Little Rock, Ark., died yesterday at a hospital there. She was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIETRICH, KURT
description: DIETRICH-Kurt. The Saltaire community has lost a unique spirit and devoted friend with Kurt's passing. Artist, wit, proud and loving husband, father and neighbor, Kurt leaves us with fond rememberances of his kindness, grace and humor. Our deepest sympathies to Susanne and their children, Gregg, Mark and Allison. Martin M. Berger, Mayor

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDD, OLIVER WORSHAM
description: RUDD-Oliver Worsham, Jr. November 2, 1999. Husband of Julia Meade Rudd. Father of Caroline Rudd and Alice Rudd Elder. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Memorial service Monday, November 8, at 3:00 PM, Fifth Ave. Presbyterian Church, 7 West 55 St., NYC.

title: Seattle Journal; No Joy: Mighty Griffey Has Cut Out
description: Baseball fans here used to say their town had the game's very best player and its very worst stadium. Then that player, Ken Griffey Jr., led the team on a memorable playoff run in 1995 that was a huge factor in the city's decision to forsake the tomb-like Kingdome and build the state-of-the-art Safeco Field, a baseball Xanadu that opened in July and is the most expensive ballpark in major league history.

title: WARNER-LAMBERT GETS PFIZER OFFER FOR $82.4 BILLION
description: Hours after executives of the American Home Products Corporation and the Warner-Lambert Company announced a $70 billion merger agreement yesterday, Pfizer Inc. tried to break up the deal with an $82.4 billion hostile bid for Warner-Lambert.

title: Sushi for All
description: Sushi bars continue to proliferate, in every part of town and in every price range. Here are a dozen that particularly stand out. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: MCN ENERGY TO SELL 95% STAKE IN 4 PLANTS TO DTE ENERGY
description: MCN Energy Group, owner of Michigan's second-largest natural-gas utility, agreed yesterday to sell its 95 percent stake in four coal-briquettes plants to DTE Energy for as much as $152 million. The plants compress waste from coal mining into briquettes used for fuel. DTE will initially pay $45 million, which will be adjusted up to $152 million or down to zero based on the results of a 36-month test. MCN said it expected to complete the sale in December. The transaction is separate from the Detroit-based companies' planned merger. DTE, owner of Michigan's biggest utility, said last month that it would buy MCN for more than $4 billion in cash, stock and assumed debt.

title: In Newark and Hartford, Clinton Says Cities Are Untapped Markets
description: As President Clinton toured a struggling Newark high school and a slowly recovering Hartford neighborhood to announce a series of corporate investments in impoverished cities, the White House and the speaker of the House, J. Dennis Hastert, reached a bipartisan agreement to merge their anti-poverty programs.

title: Study Links Perfect Pitch to Tonal Language
description: Most native speakers of languages that use tones to convey meaning may have a form of perfect pitch, according to new research. The results may suggest that many or even most babies are born with perfect pitch but lose it if they do not learn a tonal language or undergo early musical training.

title: European Central Bankers Raise Key Rate a Half-Point
description: Declaring that Europe's economic outlook had turned ''far more favorable,'' the European Central Bank reversed course today and raised interest rates for the first time in its short history.

title: Infant Found in Trash Can Is Buried With Police Pomp
description: Detectives who decided that no life, however brief, should go unrecognized arranged an elaborate funeral at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday for a newborn baby whose body was found last month in a street-corner trash can.

title: New Video Releases
description: Besieged

title: Sexual-Assault Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: October Data Disappointing For Retailers
description: After six months of robust increases, the growth in retail sales eased in October, indicating a potential slowdown in consumer buying as the all-important holiday shopping season approaches.

title: Season Is New But the Struggles Seem the Same
description: In the New York area, hockey season usually sneaks in through the side door, while baseball and football occupy October's front porch and backyard. But November's chilly winds bring a return to the ice rinks, and what do we see through their thick glass? The wealthy Rangers struggling, the frugal Devils dealing and the same old bargain-basement Islanders in their same old arena, hoping to do new business in Long Island's changing political atmosphere.

title: HIGHER BID FOR TARMAC
description: Britain's largest producer of road surface material, Tarmac, said it had revived talks to be taken over by Anglo American, the world's largest mining company, after it raised its bid for a second time to about $:1.2 billion ($1.97 billion). Anglo American raised its bid to 585 pence a share from 550 pence, an offer Tarmac had rejected on Monday. The company originally bid 535 pence a share for Tarmac.

title: At Annual Print Fair, A Multitude of Styles
description: If you have never been to the Print Fair, the ninth annual installment of which is on view at the Seventh Regiment Armory, do yourself a favor this year and go.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Drug Giants' Merger Deal Prompts Offer From Pfizer

title: Art Financing, at Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Balthus
description: Beadleston Gallery

title: AUSTRALIAN TELECOMMUNICATIONS DEAL
description: Australia's No. 2 telecommunications carrier, Cable and Wireless Optus, said it would sell its 10.6 percent stake in AAPT Ltd. to the Telecom Corporation of New Zealand, giving that company a foothold in the nation's telecommunications market, valued at 25 billion Australian dollars, or $16 billion. Optus, which is based in Sydney, said it would accept Telecom's offer of 5.10 Australian dollars a share after its own bid for AAPT was blocked by Australia's antitrust regulator earlier this year. The sale increases Telecom's stake in AAPT to about 43 percent.

title: 60-Something Gap Girl
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE ART
description: Pivotal Vermeer Making a Visit

title: On Italian Minimalism, And Much, Much More
description: ''Minimalia: An Italian Vision in 20th-Century Art'' at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center is a good show -- maybe even two or more -- in a bad show's body. The main attraction in this messy 10-decade pastiche is an exhibition about Italian art of the 1950's, 60's and 70's. But to get to it, you have to dig, sort and categorize; and the confusion is made worse by stuffing so many works (142 by 54 artists) into the circuitous galleries of P.S. 1's third floor: if the painting fits, hang it.

title: 2 Navy Ships Head to Site Of Wreckage
description: Two United States Navy ships on a mission to recover the data recorders from EgyptAir Flight 990 steamed out of port and into rough, wind-swept seas today, hoping to reach the sunken wreckage in time to take advantage of a brief respite of calm seas forecast for Friday.

title: After 55 Years at Times, Rosenthal Is Packing Up
description: After 55 years as a reporter, foreign correspondent, editor and columnist, A. M. Rosenthal spent his last working day at The New York Times yesterday packing up his memories the only way he knew how: by writing about them.

title: The Rites of Soccer
description: The Buttercups eked out victory over the Emeralds on a recent Saturday when No. 3, dark, shiny ponytail bobbing, slid a soccer ball a few sizes smaller than Mia Hamm's into the orange net goal. The whistle blew. The crowd roared. No. 3's father scooped her into his arms and carried her off the field upside down. An Emerald and a Buttercup went off together with the lineswoman to play for the rest of the autumn afternoon.

title: Naomi Wolf, Feminist Consultant to Gore, Clarifies Her Campaign Role
description: Naomi Wolf, the feminist writer turned feminist campaign consultant, disputes the notion that she has been giving Al Gore secret lessons in how to bare his teeth, growl and get elected leader of the pack.

title: RICE TAX SOUGHT
description: Indonesia said it would ask the International Monetary Fund to let it tax imported rice at up to 35 percent to protect its farmers. The I.M.F., which has oversight over such changes because of its $43 billion economic aid package to Indonesia, pressured the country to open its market to rice imports last year. As Indonesia's currency strengthened, however, import prices fell and rice flooded the market.

title: Rebels Say Congo Is Violating Cease-Fire by Bombing Towns
description: A three-month-old cease-fire in Congo has grown increasingly fragile in recent days, possibly threatening the agreement to end a war that has drawn in half a dozen African nations.

title: Risks of China Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Puppets of Polling
description: To the Editor:

title: Four Boxing Officials Are Charged With Bribery
description: The founder of the International Boxing Federation and three others in the powerful sanctioning organization were indicted today on federal racketeering and bribery charges, accused of soliciting bribes from fighters and their promoters in exchange for advancing them in the organization's rankings.

title: Tallyho! A Chase After the (Usually) Elusive Rabbit
description: The calendar did not yet say winter, but it might as well have. I was being soaked by a decidedly cold, gusty rain as I crashed through the brambles of a thick woods accompanied by baying hounds and a party of humans fanning out through the trees. It's the world of beagling.

title: 2 Phone Companies Set Up Senior Management Team
description: When Bell Atlantic announced its $53 billion agreement to acquire GTE in July 1998, the companies did just about everything but offer free phone calls to convince the world that their deal represented a true merger of equals.

title: A Letter From an Old Hand Agitates a New Newspaper
description: Otis Chandler, whose bust stands above the marble floor of the main entrance to The Los Angeles Times, was riding his motorcycle to work through the Ojai Valley on Wednesday when he decided that the time had finally come to protest the way the newspaper he made had been remade.

title: For Devils, Lemieux's Return Isn't Enough
description: Claude Lemieux, who was playing for the Colorado Avalanche until traded to New Jersey on Wednesday, took his pregame nap on the plane from Denver to Boston this afternoon. When he arrived at the airport here for tonight's game against the Bruins, he was rubbing his eyes after finding that the man who sent him packing from the Devils four years ago was waiting for him.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: The Subject Was 'Roses'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARYLES, AVI
description: MARYLES-Avi. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community, beloved husband of Daisy and brother of our dear friend Matthew J. Maryles, member of the Board of Directors of Yeshiva College. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Maryles family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLAND, DR. BEATRICE L.
description: FRIEDLAND-Dr. Beatrice L. The Yeshiva University family expresses profound sorrow on the passing of a longtime friend whose dedicated service to our Stern College for Women spanned five decades. As its first professor of biology; chair, biology department for 23 years; and, more recently, member, Board of Directors, she played a pivotal role in the College's creation and development. The University recognized her unique contributions by naming her professor emerita in 1978 and awarding her an honorary degree last year. The Beatrice Lashin Friedland Endowed Scholarship Fund was established at SCW in her honor by her son and daughter-in-law, Robert and Sheila Friedland. We extend our heartfelt condolences to children, Robert (and Sheila) Friedland, and Kenneth (and Jane) Friedland; grandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees Lea Eisenberg, Chairman SCW Board of Directors

title: Temperament Issue Poses Test for McCain
description: Ever since he began his run for the Republican presidential nomination, John McCain has built his candidacy around his character, presenting himself as a battling maverick whose inner strength was forged during his five and a half years as a prisoner of Hanoi.

title: Jets' Green Must Put Friendship On Hold
description: They became Jets together. They are godparents to each other's children. They speak three or four times a week, and they even got certified in scuba diving together while on vacation last summer.

description: Theater

description: PLASTRIK-Simone. A service will be held at Riverside Chapel, 76th St & Amsterdam Ave. Wednesday, November 10 at 6PM.

title: Madden and Little Grab the Spotlight
description: The U.S. Equestrian Team rider Beezie Madden and 17-year-old Marilyn Little, who is just starting her career in the Grand Prix ranks of show jumping, shared top honors on the opening night of the 116th National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.

title: Residential Real Estate; Co-op City Hires Outside Managers
description: For the first time in Co-op City's 31-year history, its board of directors has hired an outside management company, with the goals of cutting operating costs while increasing revenue and making improvements at the 15,372-apartment Bronx development.

title: Sydney Journal; And Elizabeth Windsor Is Still the Strong Favorite
description: God save the queen! Here it is, the end of the 20th century, and a mature, developed nation appears to be on the verge of voting this weekend to retain a foreign monarch as its figurehead rather than to become a republic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERON, BOBBIE SCOTT
description: HERON-Bobbie Scott. October 31, 1999. Beloved mother of Gil Scott Heron, loving sister of the late Gloria Flynn Scott and the late William H. Scott, both of Jackson, TN. Service Saturday, November 6, 9:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave (at 81st Street).

title: Water Main Break Halts Subway Line in Bronx
description: A large water main broke in the Bronx yesterday, flooding a subway tunnel and interrupting service on the No. 6 line at six stops in the South Bronx during the evening rush hour.

title: 'Milton Avery Revisited' -- Works From the Louis and Annette Kaufman Collection
description: Syracuse University Lubin House

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PITKIN, LILY
description: PITKIN-Lily. Devoted wife of the late Irving. Beloved aunt, great-aunt and great-great aunt. Services are on Friday, at 12 noon, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: No Cynicism? Yeow! We're All Shook Up!
description: You'll hear a little authentic 1950's rock in ''Shake, Rattle and Roll.'' But while most of the music is synthetic, this package is trimmed with some real 50's sensibility. Four hours of network television with nary a hint of postmodern cynicism? Good golly, Miss Molly!

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   RUSS, BEN
description: RUSS-Ben 26th yahrzeit. Eternally my soul mate. Mario

title: COSTAR GROUP TO BUY COMPS.COM FOR $102 MILLION
description: CoStar Group agreed yesterday to buy Comps.com Inc. for about $51 million in cash and another $51 million in stock. It will also assume about $5 million in debt. The acquisition will enable CoStar, based in Bethesda, Md., to become the leading Internet-based provider of information on commercial properties. It will exchange 0.31496 share, or $7.44, for each Comps.com share. Investors can also choose to receive $7.50 in cash. Comps.com, based in San Diego, has 20,000 customers and a database of more than 400,000 commercial real estate transactions. CoStar's database compiles listings of commercial properties for sale or rent. The company's Internet database tracks more than 314,000 buildings in 40 United States markets.

title: Corrections
description: An article in House & Home yesterday about an architect-designed loft in TriBeCa misstated the surname of the couple who own it. Their given names are Steven and Judith; for privacy, they required that their surname be withheld. (O'Connor is the woman's maiden name.)

title: Parents of Gay Obtain Mercy For His Killer
description: With a call for mercy from the parents of the gay student he beat and left for dead on a prairie fence, Aaron J. McKinney was spared the death penalty today in a courtroom in Laramie, Wyo.

title: Mexican Candidate Plays the Bad Boy
description: Roberto Madrazo Pintado, who is running an unexpectedly strong race in the governing party's presidential primary, delights in playing the bad boy.

title: City Bus Kills Woman After She Falls in Street
description: A 38-year-old New Hampshire woman was killed by a city bus in Downtown Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Disney Posts 71% Decline In 4th-Quarter Earnings
description: Walt Disney said today that profits for its fourth quarter and full year fell sharply, hurt by slumping sales of home videos and Disney merchandise and by a reorganization charge caused by cost-cutting.

title: Nasdaq Gains 27.44, Continuing Into Record Territory
description: The technology-dominated Nasdaq market pushed further into record territory yesterday but stocks generally pulled back from sizable early-session gains as Wall Street braced for the Labor Department's report this morning on October's job market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASAREZ, MARION
description: CASAREZ-Marion, on November 2nd, (formerly NYC). Survived by family and friends. For info: ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800-322-0533.

title: Benigni's Film, In Two Versions
description: These days movies seem to move from theaters to video more quickly -- except, of course, when it's more slowly. Roberto Benigni's ''Life Is Beautiful'' will be released on Tuesday, not exactly a swift passage for a film that opened in theaters in October 1998. Most movies take about six months. ''Shouldn't have been delayed! Fans want sub not dub!'' reads the comment in The Movie Monitor, a tip sheet that advises video retailers about releases.

title: Police Study Death Of Man in Village
description: The bruised body of a man was found in the hallway of a Greenwich Village apartment building yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMERANTZ, GERTA
description: POMERANTZ-Gerta. The Board of Governors of the Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member and dear friend, Gerta Pomerantz and offers its heartfelt sympathy to her family and friends. David L. Rudnick, Pres. Marshall L. Hess, Secretary

title: Yoshitomo Nara
description: Marianne Boesky

title: Artest Makes A Productive N.B.A. Debut
description: Ron Artest, the former St. John's star, racked up the first 14 points and 4 rebounds of his pro career against his beloved Knicks, the team he pulled for when he was growing up in Queens yet the same team that passed him by in last spring's college draft.

title: Ignoring Bodyguards, Barak Steps Forward at Memorial
description: Defying his own secret service officers, Prime Minister Ehud Barak made a surprise last-minute appearance at a rally in Tel Aviv tonight to commemorate the fourth anniversary of the assassination of his mentor, Yitzhak Rabin.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about an unusual heroin detoxification treatment referred incorrectly to the role and family ties of Dr. Andre Waismann of Israel. While he was a pioneer in using the treatment, Dr. Waismann had no role in CITA Americas, a company that patented the treatment and performed it at hospitals in the United States. Dr. Waismann is not related to the company's co-founder, David Yerushalmi.

title: DEMAND FOR HONG KONG FUND
description: Hong Kong residents applied for units in an index tracking fund worth 25 billion Hong Kong dollars, or $3.2 billion, more than the double the amount the government had sought, indicating success in its first sale of the shares that it bought last year. The strong turnout means it may be easier for the government to sell more of its stock portfolio, valued at 203.9 billion Hong Kong dollars, which was bought during the last two weeks of August 1998. It also suggests less will be available for institutional investors.

title: Montoya Admits Feeling the Pressure
description: Juan Montoya says that the most pressure he felt during his 20-race pursuit of the CART FedEx series championship was trying not to be the driver who failed to keep the Target/Chip Ganassi Racing Team's winning streak intact.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in New York City.

title: Privacy in Banking
description: To the Editor:

title: Russia Opens Chechen Border to Flood of Refugees Fleeing Bombs
description: Busloads of desperate refugees poured out of Chechnya today, as Russia opened the border after Western criticism that it was needlessly endangering civilians.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KAPLAN, MARLENE
description: KAPLAN-Marlene. Happy Birthday, ''Marl''. Forever in our hearts. Ricki, Al, Marc, and Nicki

description: The highest court in Massachusetts faced a case today that called for the wisdom of King Solomon:
