title: GIANT CEMENT ACCEPTS $276 MILLION OFFER FROM RIVAL
description: Giant Cement Holding agreed to be acquired by a Spanish rival, Cementos Portland, for $31 a share in cash, a total of about $276 million. Cementos Portland will also assume $67.4 million in debt. Cementos Portland already owns 65 percent of CDN-USA Inc., which sells cement in the northeastern United States, and the acquisition of Giant Cement will help it capture a greater market share and increase production. Giant Cement, based in Summerville, S.C., is the 15th-largest United States cement producer. Shares of Giant Cement soared 48 percent, jumping $9.875 each, to $30.4375.

title: Many Theories On Final Climb Of Doomed Jet
description: Now that crash investigators have used radar data to lay out a picture of a Boeing 767 on a wild roller coaster ride in the last few minutes of EgyptAir Flight 990, people familiar with the airplane are busy trying to concoct a chain of events that would match the data.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SABAT, CHARLES
description: SABAT-Charles. Of New York on Thursday, November 4th, 1999. Beloved husband of Marilyn (nee Hartman) cherished father of Robert (Jessica) Sabat and James Sabat. Adored Grandfather of Nathaniel and Olivia Sabat. Graveside services at B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, New Jersey on Sunday November 7, 1999 at 1:30 PM. For information call Menorah Chapels at Millburn 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, NJ.

title: HealthGate Web Deal
description: Snap.com and Xoom.com, two Web sites, agreed today to pay the HealthGate Data Corporation $75 million over three years to provide health and medical information for the Internet company they will form with NBC, a unit of General Electric. Cnet, which owns Snap.com, and Xoom.com, a Web-based direct-marketing company, have agreed to be acquired by G.E. to form NBC Internet Inc., or NBCi.

title: CBS is pulling out all the stops to promote its mini-series 'Shake, Rattle and Roll.'
description: TO PUBLICIZE ''Shake, Rattle and Roll,'' a mini-series about a fictional band's rise in the early days of rock 'n' roll, CBS is beginning a promotional effort worthy of a worldwide arena tour.

title: Internet Group Approves Domain Registration Rules
description: The Internet's governing board today approved terms for opening the network's address registration businesses to full-scale competition, ending the six-year monopoly that enriched Network Solutions Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLITZER, FLORENCE KAIDEN
description: BLITZER-Florence Kaiden. On November 3, 1999. Beloved wife of Arnold. Loving aunt, great aunt and dear sister-in-law. Florence was a master reading teacher for the New York City Board of Education and for Hunter College. She will be profoundly missed. Service Friday, 10AM at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: An Aw Shucks Manner, but Don't Be Fooled: He's an Absolute Devil
description: The bass Samuel Ramey comes from Colby, Kan., a farm town of 5,000. The population was 5,000 when Mr. Ramey was born there 57 years ago. The population is still 5,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, MAY M.
description: SULLIVAN-May M. Age 96. Died November 3rd, 1999. Much loved retired New York City school teacher. Survived by her niece Jule A. Hale. Grandnieces Helen Marino, Virginia Dowicz, Claire Hernandez, Catherine Dougall and Elizabeth Hale-Shames, grandnephews Joseph, Robert, Matthew Ross and Dr. John M. Hale, eight great-grandnieces and six great-grandnephews. Reposing Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232 Street, Bronx, Friday, November 5 from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Our Lady of Angels R.C. Church, (Sedgwick Ave.), Bronx, N.Y., Saturday, Nov. 6 at 11:30AM.

title: Parcells Rules Out Role in Jets' Ownership
description: With added emphasis, Coach Bill Parcells removed himself today from any possibility of being part of the new Jets ownership.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERRMANN, RICHARD, M.D.
description: HERRMANN-Richard, M.D. The Association of Practicing Physicians of the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center deeply regrets the passing of Dr. Herrmann, a respected colleague, teacher, and physician. We offer our condolences to his wife Marilyn and his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DVOREN, GILDA
description: DVOREN-Gilda. Died November 4th, 1999 at age 86. Exceptionally intelligent, articulate, funny, warm, and loving, she was a wonderful aunt, as was her beloved husband, Robert (Ruby) Dvoren, a wonderful uncle. Jon Tanner and Shari Stack

title: The Magic Takes Longer But the Wand Seems Intact
description: Being dry and salty, as opposed to dewy and sweet, clearly has major preservative qualities. Case in point: the tall, droll and handsome Elaine Stritch, an actress who was never, ever what you would call an ingenue. The evidence that this is a blessing, at least in the long run, is currently on display in Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Microsoft has demonstrated that it will use its prodigious market power and immense profits to harm any firm that insists on pursuing initiatives that could intensify competition against one of Microsoft's core products.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLAS, PETER, M.D.
description: NICHOLAS-Peter, M.D. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and The Mount Sinai Hospital of Mount Sinai NYU Health deeply mourn the passing of our dear friend and distinguished colleague, Peter Nicholas, M.D., Associate Dean for Graduate Medical Education and Associate Professor in the Samuel Bronfman Department of Medicine, who was associated with Mount Sinai for more than three decades. After receiving his medical degree from Yale University, Dr. Nicholas joined Mount Sinai as an intern in 1968 and subsequently held numerous positions at The Mount Sinai Hospital, Elmhurst Hospital Center, and Mount Sinai School of Medicine, including fifteen years as Associate Dean for Students, Clinical Years. A respected authoritiy on infectious diseases, Dr. Nicholas published extensively and played a pivotal role in Mount Sinai's AIDS Clinical Trials Group and in research on tuberculosis. Greatly admired as both teacher and clinician for his exceptional dedication to students and patients, he will be remembered most fondly, and he will be sorely missed. We extend our sincere sympathy to his wife Joan, to his sons Peter and Matthew, and to the entire family. Helene L. Kaplan, Chair, Mount Sinai School of Medicine Stephen M. Peck, Chair, Mount Sinai NYU Health Arthur H. Rubenstein, MBBCh, Dean, Mount Sinai School of Medicine John W. Rowe, M.D., President Mount Sinai NYU Health Barry R. Freedman, President The Mount Sinai Hospital Joel J. Bauer, M.D., President Medical Board

title: U.S. JUDGE DECLARES MICROSOFT IS A MARKET-STIFLING MONOPOLY; GATES RETAINS DEFIANT STANCE
description: The judge in the government's antitrust trial against the Microsoft Corporation issued a broad denunciation of the software giant this evening as the first part of his verdict in the landmark case.

description: BASEBALL

description: Judge Contends Microsoft Stifled Tech Innovation

title: John Evans, 90, Ex-Director Of National Solar Observatory
description: John W. Evans, an astrophysicist who was the first director of the National Solar Observatory in Sunspot, N.M., and his wife, Betty, died on Sunday at their home in a suburb of Santa Fe, N.M., in what the local police described as an apparent murder-suicide. Dr. Evans was 90 and his wife was 89.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Los Angeles Chooses Cortines To Be Interim Head of Schools
description: After weeks of paralyzing struggles and with a series of tough decisions looming, the Los Angeles Board of Education announced today that its embattled superintendent had abandoned his fight to stay on in return for a rich severance package, and that Ramon C. Cortines Jr. would become his interim replacement.

title: INFLATION IN BRAZIL
description: In a sign that Brazil's central bank may have greater leeway to cut interest rates, inflation in the nation's largest city showed signs of slowing. Sao Paulo inflation rose 1.13 percent in the month ended Oct. 29, compared with a 1.18 percent increase in the previous four weeks, the Institute for Economic Research said. Higher transportation costs, mainly in the price of imported oil, kept price increases from slowing further.

title: Wife Argues Coach Didn't Kill Himself
description: The death of a girls' basketball coach last month in Garfield, N.J., just hours after he was charged with molesting a player, was eventually ruled a suicide by the Bergen County medical examiner. But the coach's widow is disputing that ruling, saying the death may have resulted from his diabetes, her lawyer said today.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The euro fell against the dollar after the government's jobs report showed the American economy continuing to grow with little sign of inflation. In New York the euro slipped to $1.0377 from 1.0419 on Thursday.

title: A Setback on Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROWE, COLIN F.
description: ROWE-Colin F. 1920-1999. Renowned architectural theorist, urban designer, architect, author and Professor Emeritus at Cornell University. He had an indelible influence on architectural education and practice in the U.S. and Europe over the last 40 years. He will be dearly missed by all those who learned from, taught with, and loved him. With deepfelt condolences to his family and friends. Blake Middleton Martha Eddy

title: Jobless Rate Drops to 4.1% As Wages Rise By 1 cents an Hour
description: The American economy demonstrated once again last month its remarkable ability to absorb nearly all the people seeking jobs and yet not pay more to hire them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENDAL, SEYMOUR
description: GENDAL-Seymour. 73. Of colon cancer. Life partner of Phyllis for 47 years. Loving father of David and Ellen Gendal, Boca Raton, FL., and Leslie & Mark Lederman of Scottsdale, Arizona and the late Keith Barry. Adoring grandfather of Drew and Jocelyn Lederman & Eric and Alex Gendal. Services Sunday, November 7 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue at 12 P.M. Please, no flowers.

title: SPEEDWAY MOTOR DOWN 38% AFTER WARNING ON RESULTS
description: The shares of Speedway Motorsports fell about 38 percent yesterday after the company said that it would have a loss in the third quarter and an unexpectedly low fourth-quarter profit. After a delayed opening, the stock closed down $17.4375, at $28.50. Speedway said third-quarter net earnings would be about $6 million below expectations. And while the company expects a profitable nine-month period and fourth quarter, it said fourth-quarter earnings would probably be $3 million below analysts' expectations. Speedway, a promoter and marketer of motor sporting events that is based in Concord, N.C., blamed lower-than-expected attendance at races, a delay in selling an industrial park acquired with the Las Vegas Motor Speedway in December and expenses for a start-up venture.

title: Schumer Joins Runner's Citizenship Plea
description: The fastest marathoner in the world has a new running partner: a United States senator.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, WILLIAM
description: HALPERN-William. The office and staff of Silk and Halpern Realty Associates Inc., and Richard T. Halpern Ltd. mourn the passing of their mentor and founder, William Halpern. He is survived by his sons, James and Richard, and two grandchildren, Dyer and Hilliary Halpern. Shiva will be Monday, from 5-9 at Silk And Halpern 6 east 45th Street suite 1305 NY.

title: HILTON GROUP TO SELL GOLDEN GATE FIELDS RACETRACK
description: Hilton Group said yesterday that its Ladbroke Racing unit had agreed to sell the Golden Gate Fields racetrack in the San Francisco area to the M I Entertainment Corporation for $77 million in cash, notes and stock. M I Entertainment is a unit of the Canadian auto parts maker Magna International and an investment vehicle for Magna's chairman, Frank Stronach, a prominent owner of thoroughbreds. Hilton, a hotel and casino operator based in London, said the sale was part of its plans to dispose of its non-European betting and gaming interests. Ladbroke has owned Golden Gate Fields for about a decade.

title: Walter Skees, 64, Chief Vocalist for the Army
description: Walter Francis Skees, who as the United States Army's chief vocalist sang for seven presidents and millions of people around the world, died on Oct. 23 at his home in Carmel, Calif. He was 64.

title: The Soul of the Next New Machine: Humans; How the Wedding of Brain and Computer Could Change the Universe
description: When Ray Kurzweil discusses human destiny, it is not always clear whether he's talking about technology or theology.

title: Tribute for Art Farmer
description: A concert in celebration of the life of Art Farmer, the bebop trumpet and fluegelhorn player, is to be held tomorrow at 7:30 p.m. at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in the Citicorp Center at 54th Street and Lexington Avenue. Mr. Farmer died on Oct. 4.

title: City Drivers Are Shaken By Parking Ticket Blitz
description: In Manhattan's traffic hell, there is always a lower depth.

title: Mental Health Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: TARMAC ACCEPTS NEW BID
description: Four days after Tarmac P.L.C., Britain's largest maker of asphalt, rejected an offer of $:1.13 billion, or $1.85 billion, to be acquired by Anglo American, the mining company, Tarmac said it had agreed to a sweetened offer of $:1.2 billion from Anglo American. It was the second increased offer Anglo American made for Tarmac since it first bid for the company on Oct. 29.

title: Mets Can Make Strong Statement by Giving Valentine His Due
description: Steve Phillips does not say anything about the Mets without carefully considering every syllable. Phillips, the team's general manager, is cautious. Very cautious. Extremely cautious.

title: On Their Minds: A. M. Rosenthal
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. VERSUS MICROSOFT: THE JUDGE -- Man in the News; Finding Fault With Microsoft -- In His Biggest Trial, a Judge Makes His Opinions Clear
description: Thomas Penfield Jackson seems a natural as a judge. He's a big man, white haired, avuncular. But he did not seem a clear natural for the Microsoft trial.

title: FRENCH COMPANIES IN PACT
description: The French telecommunications equipment supplier Alcatel increased its holding in the military electronics company Thomson-CSF. Alcatel will raise its stake in Thomson-CSF to 25.3 percent from 15.8 percent through a two-pronged transaction with the French state that will allow it to cut its stake in the nuclear engineering company Framatome to below 10 percent, from 44 percent. Alcatel's chairman, Serge Tchuruk, said the agreement was ''an elegant and simple way to implement synergies between civil and military technology.''

title: Pace of U.S. Consumer Borrowing Slows
description: United States consumers slowed their pace of borrowing in September, ringing up credit-card debt at less than half the pace they did in the previous month, Federal Reserve figures showed today.

title: By the Way, a Mayor-Elect Is Gay
description: The winning platform was what you might expect from a man eager to be mayor of Plattsburgh, a small, once-industrial border town upstate: more police officers, after-school programs, and a plan to revitalize the economy by drawing tourists to the town's War of 1812 battle sites. (A diorama of the war, he likes to point out, is inside City Hall.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHABER, DAVID
description: SHABER-David, on November 4, 1999. Beloved husband of Alice. Loving father of Samantha and Remy. Dear brother of Dr. Gary Shaber of Philadelphia, PA. Devoted uncle of Steven Shaber, Ruth Hung, Amanda, Sarah and Liza Ward. Memorial service Sunday, 2:30pm at ''The Riverside'', 76 St & Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory to The Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60 St, NY, NY 10022, or The Roxbury Land Trust, 7 South St, Roxbury, CT 06783.

title: Nasdaq Aims To Export A Hot Market Around Globe
description: LONDON  The Nasdaq stock exchange is hoping to spread the entrepreneurial fever sweeping America's technology industries to the Old World, detailing plans Friday for a pan-European electronic stock exchange next year.

title: Pope Pius's Silence in War: Why?
description: To the Editor:

title: Davenport May Face Stevenson
description: Alexandra Stevenson gets another chance to prove that Wimbledon was no fluke.

title: State Warns Not to Eat 3 Types of Fish Products
description: State officials issued a warning yesterday about three fish products that have been found to contain an organism that can cause flu-like symptoms, as well as serious complications for pregnant women and people with compromised immune systems.

title: U.S. Seeks Missile System Despite Treaty Risk
description: The administration said today that it might go ahead with a national missile defense system, even if it meant withdrawing from the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty over Russian objections.

title: An Oratorio Evokes Kristallnacht but Also Hope
description: The curious career of Michael Tippett, composer, continued posthumously on Thursday night with the New York Philharmonic's first-ever performance of ''A Child of Our Time'' at Avery Fisher Hall. Lionized by the British musical establishment as one of the century's geniuses, Tippett has indeed attracted admirers outside his own territory. Yet when his pieces do find their way into international concert programs or recording catalogs, it is almost always at the hands of British performers. Not so with Tippett's contemporary, Benjamin Britten, whose music has been taken up by the entire world, or with the young Thomas Ades, who is beginning to enjoy a similar embrace.

title: Not Tomorrow, Now: A Real Annie
description: It's hard to decide which star to praise first in ABC's joyous new film of the Broadway musical ''Annie.'' Who knew Kathy Bates could sing and dance? (Like a dream.) And is there any performer with a more radiant combination of face and voice than Audra McDonald? Is there any fabulously sleazy character that Alan Cumming can't make thrilling, even when he has to tone it down for a G rating? And God bless 12-year-old Alicia Morton, who plays Annie: when she sings ''Tomorrow'' (that harrowing ghost tune of little girl auditions past), strolling through the melting-snow streets of Manhattan with her new dog, Sandy, she really does seem to be thinking about tomorrow -- rather than how precious she is.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAU, RAYMOND
description: BLAU-Raymond, 89, president of Max Blau & Sons, Inc. Friends and family are invited to pay their respects between 1 and 8 PM on Saturday and Sunday at the home of Adele Blau Cass, 168 Glenview Road, South Orange, NJ. For more information, call 973-642-4900. Mr. Blau died Saturday, October 30, 1999 at his vacation home in Florida. He was an owner and served as president of Max Blau & Sons, Incorporated. He joined his father's business in 1929. Consequently, the name of the company was changed to Max Blau & Sons, Inc. Raymond shall forever be remembered as a legend and leader in the Office Furniture Industry. He was instrumental in the development and success of Max Blau & Sons, Inc., a company that is now run by the third and fourth generations of his family. He brought a certain charisma and charm to everything he did. Raymond, often remembered for his trademark short sleeve suit jackets worn with a bolo, was always willing to help, learn and develop new relationships. His favorite section of the newspaper was the ''Bids Wanted'' in the legal advertising section. Raymond was always willing to take on any project or bid, and successfully brought in business from all over the world. He was a wealth of knowledge to all who knew him, and a mentor to many people. His kindness and gentle nature will not be forgotten. He was a dedicated and loving family man. There was nothing that he would not do for his family. Raymond was the loving husband of the late Hope Blau for over 59 years. He is survived by his loving daughters Maxine Blau and Adele Blau Cass and grandsons David and Gregory Cass. Raymond and Hope will forever be remembered in our hearts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, JANE S.
description: HART-Jane S. November 1, 1999, age 86. Long time resident of New Rochelle, NY. Graduate of Juilliard School and Teachers College. Musician, teacher and composer. Predeceased by her husband Leslie A. Hart. Survived by children Sara and Richard Olson, David Hart and Diane Bentley, grandchildren Daniel and Elizabeth Olson, Alex and Lily Hart, sister Amelia Taylor, brother Lewis Smith. A long and healthy life filled with music, loving friends and family. Memorial service Sunday November 14th, 3pm at Community Unitarian Church, 468 Rosedale Ave, White Plains, New York.

title: Trying to Heal Old Hatred in Ruins on Danube
description: The road north from Budapest ends abruptly at a pale green fence here in Esztergom, on the banks of the Danube. And a good thing, too: the bridge is out. Spans of pale green steel reach to the first pilings in the river from both the Hungarian and Slovak sides, but the three middle supports stand alone. It has been thus for 54 years, since the bridge was blown up by retreating Nazis.

title: The Microsoft Findings
description: Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's long-awaited conclusions in the Microsoft antitrust case were labeled as simple ''findings of fact.'' But by declaring that the software giant built by Bill Gates had ruthlessly stifled competition and harmed consumers, Judge Jackson went further than most experts expected in declaring Microsoft guilty of misconduct as a monopoly. Mr. Gates and his stunned aides indicated that they intended to appeal the decision. But the sweeping nature of the finding suggests that Judge Jackson wants to provoke settlement talks between Microsoft and the government on possible remedies. A settlement would let the court avoid ordering a breakup of a company that has helped drive the growth of the American economy.

title: Nets Continue to Reel As Raptors Enjoy a Rout
description: Toronto's Vince Carter and Kevin Willis had just simultaneously dunked an offensive rebound while the nearby Nets stayed planted on the floor. After witnessing this display of dominance, Tracy McGrady, who two years ago was competing against high school players, jogged down the court lazily, staring and smiling at the Nets' bench.

title: House Passes Compromise Bill for $13.5 Billion in Foreign Aid
description: The House overwhelmingly approved a compromise foreign aid bill today, but some allied governments and international aid workers expressed disappointment at the debt relief for poor countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTTER, RALPH FRED
description: POTTER-Ralph Fred, died after a brief illness on November 3, 1999, in a hospital near his home in Ormond Beach, Fla. Earlier he had owned his own independent insurance agency in Palmer, Mass. He is survived by his wife of 57 years, Helen Mansfield Potter; three sons, Frederick, Thomas and Ralph, and two grandchildren, Stephen and Philip. His family will miss him greatly and appreciates all of his many contributions.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLAND, BEATRICE, PH.D.
description: FRIEDLAND-Beatrice, Ph.D. Died on Wednesday, November 3rd. Beloved wife of the late Arthur Friedland. Adored mother of Robert & Sheila Friedland and Kenneth & Jane Friedland. Loving grandmother of Jason, Benjamin, Daniel, Michael & Ari.

title: Aetna H.M.O. Loses Contract With Hospital
description: In a dispute over reimbursement rates and terms, central New Jersey's largest regional hospital, Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital, has decided that it will no longer accept patients seeking elective treatment who are covered by Aetna U.S. Healthcare, the state's largest managed care company.

title: Stanton Gives Approval To Three-Year Contract
description: Even though the Yankees are expected to announce soon that they have reached an agreement on a new three-year contract with Mike Stanton, the reliever yesterday went through the formality of filing for free agency.

title: Internet for Research?
description: To the Editor:

title: Appeals Court Hands Intel A Key Antitrust Victory
description: A federal appeals court today handed Intel a key victory in its antitrust battles, lifting an order that required the world's largest computer chip maker to share patented microprocessor technology with another company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORKOW, ROSLYN L.
description: BORKOW-Roslyn L. On November 5, 1999. Adored and cherished sister of Annette Leibowitz. Beloved wife of the late George K. Loving and admired mother of Evan and Sam Borkow. Graveside services Sunday 1:00 P.M. at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. ''The Riverside'', 212-362-6600.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTNER, SYLVIA
description: Rotner-Sylvia. On November 4, 1999. Beloved wife of Jack for 55 years. Cherished mother of Kenneth and the late Ronald, and dear mother-in-law to Carol. Loving sister of the late Dr. Herbert Harris. Adoring grandmother of Annie. She will be deeply missed by family and friends. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: Doorman Critically Hurt In Fire in Chelsea
description: The doorman of a Chelsea apartment building was critically injured last night in a fire that began after a candle was accidentally knocked over in a tenant's apartment, the authorities said.

title: Tennessee Debates Governor's Appeal for an Income Tax
description: In these flush economic times when many states have budget surpluses, Gov. Don Sundquist has had to grapple with revenue problems so severe that he has proposed the first income tax in Tennessee history, despite a lack of support from many of his Republican colleagues.

title: Grief Is Everyone's
description: To the Editor:

title: Pope Pius's Silence in War: Why?
description: To the Editor:

title: Colorado Dominates With Its Power Play
description: The Colorado Avalanche make it look easy. The Rangers just don't get it.

title: Fighting Poverty, President and Speaker Find a Moment of Unity
description: Near the end of a bitterly partisan Congressional session, President Clinton and Speaker J. Dennis Hastert appeared together here tonight to celebrate a rare moment of accord: a pledge to merge their plans to alleviate inner-city and rural poverty.

title: Pierce Advances To the Semifinals
description: Top-seeded Mary Pierce of France, seeking her second consecutive title on the WTA Tour, defeated the former Wimbledon champion Conchita Martinez of Spain, 6-2, 6-2, yesterday to reach the semifinals of the Sparkassen Cup in Leipzig, Germany.

title: NASA Seeking to Avoid Year 2000 Trouble on Shuttle Mission
description: To avoid Year 2000 computer problems, NASA is taking steps to make sure the shuttle Discovery completes its mission to repair the Hubble Space Telescope before the new year, even if it means flying over the Christmas holiday, a space agency official said today.

title: Waves Above and Darkness Below Slow Search for Recorders
description: Searching water so deep and murky that no sunlight reached the sea floor, operators of Deep Drone, a remote-controlled submarine tethered to a Navy salvage ship, closed in today on two pinging sounds they hope will lead them to the two flight recorders from EgyptAir Flight 990.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: MOST 8TH GRADERS IN NEW YORK CITY FAIL STATE TESTS
description: A large majority of New York City eighth graders have failed to meet tough new state standards on tests in mathematics and English, raising questions about the quality and content of the curriculum in middle schools.

title: Daily News Error: $100,000 Dreams Turn to Nightmare
description: Mary Ann Ronga's heart began to pound as she rubbed the boxes on The Daily News ''Scratch 'N' Match'' game yesterday. One, two, then three boxes matched, indicating that the Staten Island housewife had won $100,000. ''I sat there looking at it for 25 minutes,'' she recalled. ''I couldn't believe my eyes.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARPF, SEYMOUR
description: KARPF-Seymour. On November 5 in Pompano Beach, FL. Loving husband of Shirley (Kanarek), after 60 years of marriage. Mourned by son, David; grandchildren and brother, Horace. Services Sunday, November 7 at 9:30AM, Frank E. Campbell, 81st St. and Madison.

title: On Second Thought, Loroupe Might Enter Race
description: On Sept. 26, Tegla Loroupe won the Berlin Marathon in 2 hours 20 minutes 43 seconds. That was the fastest time in history by a woman, 4 seconds faster than her previous world best and enough to earn at least a few months off from racing.

title: Budget Skirmishes
description: As Congress lurches toward adjournment, the road is littered with dead bills, messy compromises and tactics dictated by future campaign ads. Popular initiatives to tighten gun laws, raise the minimum wage and regulate health maintenance organizations are in danger because Republican leaders are more loyal to their own agenda than to that of the majority of lawmakers. But nowhere have the leaders' perverse priorities been more clear than in the handling of a foreign aid bill to provide a paltry $370 million to 41 of the world's poorest nations.

title: Making Children Smile for Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Muslim Service Softens Despair Over Loss
description: It is called the Salat al-Ghaib, and it is the Muslim prayer for the dead whose bodies are absent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APAT, ADELINE
description: APAT-Adeline. On November 5, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Herman. Loving mother of Klara and Larry. Adoring grandmother of Sharon and Annette, Roger and Liana, and Lisa. Great-grandmother of Rachel, Robby, Ariel, Cory, Zachary and Joshua. Services Tuesday, 11:15am at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZPATRICK, WILLIAM J.
description: FITZPATRICK-William J. Of Staten Island on November 4, 1999. Beloved husband of Agnes (nee Carlier). Loving father of William, Sean, Kevin, Brendan, and Brian Fitzpatrick, Patricia Garrity and Mary Valenti. Also survived by nine grandchildren. Funeral from Casey Funeral Home, 350 Slosson Avenue, S.I., NY. on Monday. Mass of Christian Burial Blessed Sacrament Church 11 AM. Private committal. Friends will be received Saturday 7-9P.M. & Sunday 2-4 & 7-9 P.M. In lieu of flowers contributions to S.I. unit of the American Cancer Society would be greatly appreciated.

title: Sick on the High Seas
description: To the Editor:

title: I.B.F.'s Lee Has Faced Problems Before
description: Robert W. Lee Sr. created the International Boxing Federation in 1983, pledging that it would objectively rank the world's top fighters, legitimize championship titles and generally help clean up a sport long sullied by suspicion and scandal.

title: A Bold Investment Yields Paltry Returns; Lone Bank in Poor Neighborhood Fails to Attract Customers
description: Just before 1 p.m. on a recent Monday, Donald Heglar strode into the Red Hook branch of Independence Community Bank and walked right up to the tellers' window.

title: Going by the Book, Then Smashing It
description: Matthew Sweet

title: Keizo Saji, 80, Who Headed Beverage Conglomerate, Dies
description: Keizo Saji, the chairman of Suntory Ltd., one of the world's largest alcoholic beverage companies, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Osaka, Japan. He was 80.

title: Woman Is Found Guilty of Assaulting a Teacher
description: A Brooklyn woman was convicted yesterday of assaulting a sixth-grade teacher who gave her daughter grades of unsatisfactory on her report card in June.

title: In a Contest of Conflicting Facts, It Finally Came Down to Whom the Judge Believed
description: It was a case in which 26 witnesses put forth a bewildering number of contradictory viewpoints as fact, in which a videotape sullied the legendary brilliance of the world's wealthiest man, in which two million pages of documents included thousands of e-mail messages that at times made various figures in the case look greedy, ruthless, egomaniacal or just plain dishonest.

title: Buchanan Visits Art Exhibit In Brooklyn and Doesn't Like It
description: Patrick J. Buchanan used the controversy over the ''Sensation'' exhibit to rally his troops at a Manhattan restaurant yesterday, saying that he had gone to the Brooklyn Museum of Art to see ''the so-called exhibit'' and that he was not impressed.

title: STARWOOD TO SELL KANSAS CITY HOTEL FOR $61 MILLION
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide, the world's largest hotel owner, said yesterday that it had sold the Ritz Carlton Kansas City Hotel to the private investment group Maritz, Wolff & Company for $61 million and will use the proceeds to reduce debt or buy back stock. Starwood's chief executive, Barry S. Sternlicht, is trying to improve profits by selling some assets and renovating others after a series of acquisitions. In September, the company said that it planned to sell hotels valued at about $500 million by July 2000.

title: INSIDE
description: New School Job for Cortines

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOTO, EFRAIN, DEACON
description: SOTO-Efrain, Deacon. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the deacon of Our Lady of Lourdes Church, 92-96 220th Street, Queens Village, on November 4, 1999. Reposing in Stutzmann Funeral Home, 224-39 Jamaica Avenue, Saturday, November 6, from 2 to 5 and 7 to 10 P.M., and Sunday, November 7, from 2 to 5 and 7 to 10 P.M. Funeral Mass on Monday, November 8, at our Lady of Lourdes Church, at 10:30 A.M. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Soldier Killed, 19 Hurt When Truck Overturns
description: A soldier driving a truck was killed and 19 others were injured when the vehicle rolled over on the way to a routine training session yesterday.

title: Drug Maker's Suitors Affirm Bidding Plans
description: While it remains the highest offer, Pfizer Inc.'s bid for the Warner-Lambert Company lost some of its appeal yesterday.

title: Ex-Officials Allege Fraud At City Union
description: Two former officials of District Council 37, the giant union for New York City municipal employees, have accused its benefits fund of illegally diverting fund money toward the union's political activities and fraudulently obtaining large overpayments in contributions from the city.

title: COMPASS BANCSHARES TO ACQUIRE MEGABANK FINANCIAL
description: Compass Bancshares Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the MegaBank Financial Corporation for stock valued at $96 million. In the transaction, Compass will exchange 3.45 million of its shares for MegaBank's outstanding stock. Compass said the acquisition gave it entry to Colorado through MegaBank's nine full-service offices in metropolitan Denver and its Empire Title and Escrow Corporation unit, which operates six offices in the Denver area and Fort Collins. MegaBank, based in the Denver suburb of Englewood, has $298 million in assets. Its stock slipped 25 cents, to $11.125. Compass, based in Birmingham, Ala., is a bank holding company with assets of $17.7 billion. It has 195 offices in Alabama, Arizona, Florida and Texas. Its shares rose 25 cents, to $28.

title: Political Clubs Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DETAR, VERNON
description: deTAR-Vernon. Organist and Choirmaster, the Church of the Ascension 1939-1981. Memorial service Sunday, November 14, 4 PM, at the church, 5th Ave. at 10th St

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Teamsters strike against the Overnite Transportation Company misstated the affiliation of John Schulz, who commented on the effect on James P. Hoffa's reputation. Mr. Schulz is associate editor of Traffic World magazine, not Trucking World.

title: INVESTCORP IS IN $303 MILLION DEAL FOR SYNTHETIC
description: Synthetic Industries agreed yesterday to be acquired by Investcorp, a global buyout concern based in Bahrain, for $33 a share in cash, a total of about $303.6 million. In addition, Investcorp will assume $230 million in debt. Synthetic, based in Chickamauga, Ga., makes polypropylene fabrics and fibers used for carpet backing, concrete reinforcement and other applications. It is among the largest makers of carpet backing in the United States and a major maker of fibermesh, a stabilizer used in concrete and asphalt underlay and in landfills. In May, it hired Beacon Group Capital Services as its financial adviser to search for a buyer. Synthetic shares rose $3.375, to $37.4375.

title: Overseas Money Flows In, Lifting Latin Stock Markets
description: Buoyed by fresh inflows of overseas investment money, stock markets in Latin America are staging a rally that could presage a return to economic growth in many of the region's countries next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARYLES, AVI
description: MARYLES-Avi. The Yeshivah of Flatbush deeply mourns the passing of Avi Maryles, beloved husband of Daisy, father of Miriam, beloved brother of Honorary President & Board of Trustees Member Matthew J. Maryles, & Jesse, Norman, & Josh Maryles. Heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire Maryles family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Paul Kopyt, President Dennis M. Eisenberg, Executive Director

title: On Their Minds: A. M. Rosenthal
description: To the Editor:

title: SBC In Wireless Purchase
description: SBC Communications, the No. 1 United States local phone company, has agreed to buy the closely held Radiofone Inc., adding 200,000 wireless-telephone customers in Louisiana and Michigan. Terms were not disclosed. Wireless companies in the United States are consolidating to gain coast-to-coast coverage and lower their costs.

title: Republican Leaders Engage President in Budget Talks
description: Eager to adjourn with a spending deal that allows them to claim a partial political victory, Republican leaders in Congress are bargaining directly with President Clinton, White House and Congressional officials said today.

title: Toughen Up the Rules of the Sky
description: The events were depressingly familiar. After the crash of Egyptair Flight 990, the National Transportation Safety Board rushed into action, marshaling people and equipment and spending millions of dollars to recover as much of the airplane as possible in order to find out the cause of the crash.

title: Iggy Pop's Lust for Life After All These Years
description: Iggy Pop practices the comedy of cruelty, turning avant-garde theatrics into a Borscht Belt routine by way of a Midwestern football halftime show. This 52-year-old rock provocateur is exploring introspection these days, but on Thursday at Irving Plaza he showed what he has found inside: more lust, more fury, more hunger to annihilate himself within the cleansing acid bath of rock 'n' roll.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWOFFORD, HUGH G.
description: SWOFFORD-Hugh G. Mentor, wonderful friend and partner in Swofford and Scharff. Possessed of many talents. We will miss him. Monroe B. Scharff

title: Pope Lands in India Amid Rise in Anti-Christian Violence
description: John Paul II arrived in India today to meet with the Roman Catholic bishops of Asia at a time when anti-Christian sentiment and violence among Hindu fundamentalists is at its highest in decades.

title: Political Memo; The Education of George W. Bush, and the Voter
description: One afternoon last week, flying high above northern Texas, Gov. George W. Bush eagerly displayed the tome he was reading, ''Titan,'' a 774-page biography of John D. Rockefeller.

title: Now China Suggests Fate of Nation Depends on Defeating Sect
description: Just when it seemed that official invective against Falun Gong could grow no harsher, today's issue of the People's Daily has suggested that the very fate of China hangs on the struggle against the banned spiritual movement.

title: Beijing Is Expected to Counter U.S. Anti-Missile Defense Plan : Chinese Nuclear Buildup Predicted
description: PARIS  Western specialists are increasingly convinced that the strongest moves to counter the new U.S. emphasis on anti-missile defenses will come not from Russia, as widely forecast, but from China.

title: Conceding Nothing, Gates Sees Finding As Only One Step
description: Smiling stiffly, conceding no predatory behavior whatsoever and insisting that Microsoft's actions had in fact ''brought tremendous benefits to millions of consumers,'' William H. Gates defiantly took issue this evening with a federal judge's finding that the company had engaged in monopolistic behavior.

title: Pope Pius's Silence in War: Why?
description: To the Editor:

title: Alexandria Journal; Ancient World's Great Database to Get a Successor
description: This city is trying hard to recapture the luster it lost 2,000 years ago.

title: Malcolm Marshall, 41, Cricket Player and Coach
description: Malcolm Marshall, who despite his small stature became one of cricket's greatest fast bowlers, died Thursday at Queen Elizabeth Hospital in his hometown, Bridgetown, Barbados. He was 41.

title: HYUNDAI DELAYS NORTH KOREA TRIP
description: For the second time, South Korea's largest business conglomerate, Hyundai Group, delayed a plan to dispatch a team to North Korea to survey sites for an industrial complex because North Korea had not yet approved the visit. While the South Korean business group hopes to build a complex near Haeju, on the southwestern coast of North Korea, Pyongyang wants to build it farther north.

title: Chancellor Crew's Report Card
description: When Rudy Crew was named New York City's schools chancellor in 1995, he declared that he had no interest in ''tinkering at the edges'' and would work toward revolutionary change. This week's yearly evaluation by the board of education offers what is on balance a favorable view of Dr. Crew's progress. Although the board applauds the chancellor for championing the system and generating important new policies, it also criticizes him for paying too little attention to the administrative details that are vital to making those policies work. The evaluation seems essentially on target, and leads us to hope that Dr. Crew will stay on and drive his policies to fruition.

title: Believing Mrs. Clinton
description: To the Editor:

title: How a Venerable Bassist Keeps His Trio Up to Date
description: Ray Brown Trio

title: Sports of The Times; When Losing Is Familiar But Different
description: TWO months ago, Keyshawn Johnson stood in the Jets' locker room, anticipating the beginning of a triumphant season. This was Sept. 11, as the Jets prepared for their season opener against New England.

title: Help Wanted, Meaning Help Can Be Fussy
description: Not so long ago, most people were wary of leaving a job. Whatever its faults, they had too much at risk, like their seniority, security and benefits. But these times of prosperity and low unemployment have changed all that. Now, for the most part, people do not lose jobs. Jobs lose them.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about former Senator Carol Moseley-Braun's nomination as ambassador to New Zealand misstated the date of the photograph. It was Tuesday, not Thursday.

title: On Houston's Big Night, Give Sprewell a Save
description: It was late in the fourth quarter when Latrell Sprewell ducked his head into the tense moments of Allan Houston's revival at the Palace and made sure the night ended with a boisterous ''Hallelujah!''

title: Sound the Alert: Herron Gains a Share of the Lead
description: It is dangerous to underestimate Tim Herron's game.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GROUP 1 AUTOMOTIVE INC., Houston, the sixth-largest United States automobile retailer, plans to buy dealerships that have about $1 billion in revenue next year as it tries to further consolidate the fragmented industry.

title: C.I.A. Chief Slips In to Study Police Department Program
description: Cloaked in a befitting amount of secrecy, George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, was quickly shuttled into police headquarters in Lower Manhattan yesterday morning to see the nerve center of the city's war on crime.

title: CANADIAN JOBLESSNESS FALLS
description: Canada's unemployment rate fell three-tenths of a percentage point to 7.2 percent in October, its lowest level since March 1990, Statistics Canada reported. In the last two months, more new jobs have been created than in the first eight months of 1999. In the last year, total employment has increased by 2.5 percent, with manufacturing showing the strongest growth at 9.6 percent. Marc Levesque, an economist at Toronto Dominion Bank, said excess labor and production capacity was rapidly dwindling.

title: A DECADE LATER
description: Ten years after the revolution, Solidarity's main strategist is friends with his old enemies and enemies with his old friends. No one said post-Communism was going to be easy. A report by Roger Cohen in The Times Magazine.

title: Favorable News on Jobs and Inflation Lifts Equity Prices
description: Financial markets applauded a government report released yesterday that portrayed a slowing economy with no discernible increase in inflationary pressure.

title: MOTOROLA STOCK RISES 7%, REACHING A RECORD HIGH
description: The shares of Motorola Inc. rose 7 percent yesterday to a record after the company, the world's No. 3 semiconductor maker, told analysts that it was controlling production costs and expected to exceed industry growth forecasts. Motorola climbed $7.8125 a share, to $114.3125. The shares have gained 18 percent this week and are up 88 percent so far this year. The company told analysts that growth in its semiconductor business would outpace the 19 percent rate it projects for the chip industry in 2000, said Brian Modoff, a Deutsche Banc Alex Brown analyst. Motorola also increased production of the G4 chips that Apple Computer needs to power its newest machines, after failing to meet earlier demand.

title: Government Lawyers Say Facts, Not Strategy, Proved Case
description: Justice Department lawyers savored a resounding victory this evening in their case against Microsoft, a victory that one official attributed not to any brilliant strategy but to the simple truth.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, ALICE
description: KATZ-Alice. West End Temple, Neponsit, NY, mourns the death of a very dear member and extends to her husband Louis and family deepest sympathy.

title: Union's Fate? It's in the Mail
description: The ballot is in the mail. The arbitration is in abeyance.

title: Looking for the Senator From All of New York
description: In a New York Times/CBS News poll reported this week, 4 out of 10 New Yorkers said they didn't think Hillary Rodham Clinton knew New York well enough to represent it effectively. But if Mrs. Clinton comes to the Senate race as a carpetbagger, can her likely opponent claim that his career in New York City makes him any more representative of a state that isn't all skyscrapers and investment bankers? From upstate, Rudolph Giuliani looks like a carpetbagger, too.

title: Leonardo Captures Power and Speed
description: Leonardo, a horse rejected twice by his trainer and rider Jimmy Torano, and Marco, a horse that helped the United States equestrian team win Nations' Cup competitions in Sweden and Hungary last summer, each jumped clear rounds to win open jumper stake classes at last night's session of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.

title: Pope Pius's Silence in War: Why?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pop Quiz for Mr. Bush
description: A presidential campaign is a time of testing. Few candidates, however, face an embarrassment like the one endured this week by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. The Republican front-runner was asked by a Boston television reporter to name the leaders in four world hot spots -- Chechnya, Taiwan, Pakistan and India. Although Mr. Bush has not been very forthcoming on his international policies, this kind of quiz-show questioning offers little chance for illumination. Mr. Bush, whose alpha-male instincts clearly made him consider throttling the reporter, probably fared no better than most ordinary Americans would have. He called up part of one name, ''Lee,'' for Taiwan's president, Lee Teng-hui.

title: Peekskill Artists Spawn a Political Revolt
description: For nearly 10 years, the all-Republican City Council here tried to spark a downtown renaissance by luring artists to settle in the large empty storefronts along its once busy main streets.

title: Officer Who Guarded Safir Fatally Shoots Self at Home
description: A highly decorated sergeant on Police Commissioner Howard Safir's security detail shot himself to death yesterday morning, officials said.

title: Moseley-Braun Deflects Criticism at Confirmation Hearing
description: In an atmosphere of conviviality, Carol Moseley-Braun, the former senator from Illinois, appeared before a Senate committee today in her quest to become ambassador to New Zealand and helped push aside accusations of impropriety that have shadowed her for years.

title: World Trade Group's Leader Says Discord Threatens Talks
description: Frustrated by the World Trade Organization's apparent inability to agree on an agenda for its meeting barely three weeks away, the leader of the group has warned the 134 member countries that the meeting could end in failure.

title: Bush on Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Cooperstown Attitude
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMERCE ONE BUYS COMMERCEBID FOR STOCK AND CASH
description: Commerce One, a leading maker of business-to-business software, agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held CommerceBid.com for $4.5 million and 785,000 new shares of Commerce One. This week, General Motors chose Commerce One, based in Walnut Creek, Calif., as its partner to create an Internet marketplace through which G.M. will buy about $87 billion of materials and parts annually. News of that partnership drove Commerce One shares up $46.9375 on Wednesday. The company issued its initial shares in July at $21 each. Yesterday, Commerce One's shares gained $38.875, to $289.875, in Nasdaq trading. CommerceBid.com is based in Santa Clara, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENSEN, PAUL M.
description: DENSEN-Paul M. The Lautenberg Research Center of The Hebrew University of Jerusalem mourns with profound sorrow the passing of Paul M. Densen, Chairman of the Lautenberg Research Center Endowment Committee. Paul was the pioneering and outstanding leader on a daily basis for over 20 years in his service to the Lautenberg Center. His service to the Jewish people and to all of humanity had no peer. His commitment to ''Tikun Olam,'' repairing the world, and to the welfare of his fellow human beings motivated many others to follow his example, and his contributions to the eradication of cancer and other immunological diseases will be noted for generations to come. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife, Sarah Jane; his sons, Mark and Robert, and his entire family. The Lautenberg Research Center U.S. Senator Frank R. Lautenberg Founding Patron Dr. David Weiss Founding Chairman, Jerusalem Dr. Eitan Yefenof Chairman, Jerusalem Eleanore Popeck-Rigolosi Co-Chair, Executive Committee Milton Spielman Co-Chair, Executive Committee Paul Einhorn, Chairman Research Associates Society Carmi Schwartz Executive Vice Chairman

title: TENNECO AUTO AND PACKAGING UNITS BECOME INDEPENDENT
description: Tenneco Inc. separated its final two businesses, as Tenneco Automotive, the maker of Monroe shock absorbers and Walker mufflers, and the Pactiv Corporation, a packaging company that makes Hefty bags, became independent companies. Shareholders got one-fifth of a share of Tenneco Automotive and one Pactiv share for each Tenneco share. Tenneco Automotive fell 37.5 cents, to $8.125, and Pactiv fell $1, to $13.125. The combined value of the two new stocks was $14.75, down from Tenneco's $16 close on Thursday. The separation completes a dismantling that began in 1992. Both companies are based in Lake Forest, Ill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUSS, MITCHELL
description: KRAUSS-Mitchell. 68 of Westfield, NJ. Mr. Krauss was the co-owner of NJ's oldest advertising agency, J.M. Kesslinger & Assoc. of Union, NJ, and an active leader in the advertising industry in the state. He is survived by his wife Joy, son Bill (Stephanie Voss), daughters Susan and Caroline (John) Bogart, brother Harold and sisters Hannah Walitsky and Sylvia Friedman. Services at Temple Emanu-El Westfield, NJ on Sunday, November 7 at 1:30pm. For information, call Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd., Union, NJ

title: From Fences to Fast Getaways, the All-Time All-American Greats
description: What is an American Great? Drive-in theaters? Ice cream cones? The Rockettes? Everyone may have a different home-grown idea. Here are some suggestions from ''American Greats,'' edited by Robert A. Wilson and Stanley Marcus and published by PublicAffairs. This sampling was compiled by Joyce Jensen.

title: BUSINESS SENTIMENT IMPROVES
description: Japan's index of economic sentiment at businesses rose to its highest in more than two years as companies cut inventories and excess production capacity. The economic conditions index rose to a seasonally adjusted 10 in the July-September quarter, up from minus 7 the previous quarter, the Economic Planning Agency said. That is the first positive index since January-March 1997.

title: KOREA GAS TO OFFER SHARES
description: State-owned Korea Gas will begin its initial public offering of 30 million new shares on Nov. 22 and 23, according to Daishin Securities, a lead manager in the offering. The company will offer 40 percent of the shares to the public, 30 percent to financial institutions and 20 percent to the company's workers. The remaining 10 percent will go into a new investment fund. Seoul currently holds a 51 percent stake in Korea Gas. The company has a monopoly on importing liquefied natural gas into South Korea.

title: Clear Finding in Blunt Language
description: With a 207-page legal document, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson has fashioned a club and wielded it against the Microsoft Corporation.

title: Bitterness Stalks Show On Role of the Wehrmacht
description: The decision to postpone the United States debut of ''The German Army and Genocide'' exhibition puts a spotlight not just on the difficulty of using archival photographs as historical evidence but a keen sensitivity within Germany about questions of national honor as well.

title: Justices Restore Cleveland's School Voucher Program for Now
description: A sharply divided Supreme Court issued an unusual order today permitting Cleveland to operate its disputed school voucher program at full strength until a federal appeals court rules on the program's constitutionality.

title: Albany Studies Impact of Ruling Restoring Thousands of Bias Cases
description: The administration of Gov. George E. Pataki is wrestling with the impact of a recent federal court ruling requiring the state to reinstate thousands of discrimination complaints, even as it already faces an enormous backlog of such cases.

title: Mary Weitzman, 85, Humanist Researcher in Endocrinology
description: Mary C. Weitzman, who was a chorus girl as a teenager, a college freshman at 35, later a professor and finally a respected medical researcher, died on Saturday at a Manhattan hospital. She was 85 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Between Baffert and Lukas, a Race for Dominance
description: Buoyed by increasingly cooperative weather, thoroughbred racing was busily gearing up today for its annual rite of revival, the Breeders' Cup.

title: Proof That Spanish Dance Is More Than Castanets
description: American Bolero Dance Company

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REMCH, MARY D.
description: REMCH-Mary D. Of Ridgewood, Queens, formerly of Bushwick, Brooklyn, New York. Survived by her loving children Peter, Patricia, Geraldine Shea, Henry, and Mary Youkon; adoring grandchildren Kristen, Michael, Molly, Johnathan, Deshon and Nicholas; loving sister Anne Ruoff; loving in-laws Florence Rubenfeld, Andrew Porat, Joseph Shea, Diala Toure Remch and Michael Youkon. Viewing Sunday 2:00-4:30 and 7-9:00 PM at Koch Funeral Home, 68-59 Fresh Pond Road, Ridgewood, NY. Mass of Christian burial Monday at 9:45 AM at Miraculous Medal RC Church. Interment Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, NY. In lieu of flowers donations in the name of Mary Remch to St. Francis Breadline, 135 West 31st Street, New York, NY 10001.

title: Religion Journal; Armenian Church Gets a New Worldwide Leader
description: On the wall above the entrance to the Armenian Orthodox cathedral on Second Avenue near 34th Street in Manhattan is a large bas-relief of St. Vartan, a fifth-century warrior prince whose leadership in a long struggle against a conquering Persian army helped preserve Christianity as the faith of his people.

title: Onex Bows Out of Fight for Air Canada After Adverse Ruling
description: The Onex Corporation scrapped its hostile takeover bid for Air Canada late today after a Quebec judge ruled that the conglomerate's proposal would violate ownership limits on the country's dominant airline.

title: New Bergen Book Tackles Pesky Rebidding Problems
description: Good books for intermediate players, covering bidding and play, are few and far between. Marty Bergen's ''Points Schmoints'' was popular three years ago, and the sequel, ''More Points Schmoints'' is likely to be equally successful. It is available for $19.95, including mailing, from the author, at (800) 386-7432.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about the bass Samuel Ramey misidentified his management company. It is Columbia Artists Management; Vincent & Farrell Associates is his publicist.

title: Bronx School Is Closed Because of Fears of Elevated Lead Levels
description: A Bronx elementary school was closed yesterday because of concerns that lead in the air from a nearby construction site might have penetrated the building. But preliminary tests conducted by school workers showed the air in the building was safe, school officials said late yesterday.

title: Why Russia Falls Short of I.M.F. Criteria
description: Buoyed by high world oil prices and a boost from a currency devaluation last year, the Russian economy is looking better than it has in years.

title: Webvan Stock Price Closes 65% Above Initial Offering
description: Webvan Group, an online grocer that has overcome several financial and regulatory obstacles, rolled ahead in its first day of public trading today to achieve a market value of $7.9 billion.

title: Odds Favor a Sprinter Who's Had an Odd Year
description: He is a hefty 1,200-plus pounds and is named for Artax, a flying horse in the children's book ''The Neverending Story.'' The name is pretty fitting: twice this year, he has barreled home all alone in times that have shattered track records.

title: In Crashes, First Ideas Are Often the First to Go
description: When an almost new Boeing 737 plunged to the earth on the Indonesian island of Sumatra in December 1997, the cause seemed to jump out of its wreckage: rivets that should have held the plane's metal skin to the skeleton were missing.

title: Serbs Reject U.S. Plan Linking End of Sanctions to Free Vote
description: The Yugoslav government has dismissed a new American proposal for a partial suspension of sanctions in return for early elections. It says the offer would not be honored if the government of President Slobodan Milosevic is re-elected.

title: Journal; Has Jerry Falwell Seen the Light?
description: By chance, the verdict in the Matthew Shepard murder trial was announced in Laramie, Wyo., on Wednesday just before my interview with the Rev. Jerry Falwell. He hadn't heard the news, so I told him of Aaron McKinney's conviction and asked his response. Mr. Falwell's reply was instantaneous. After saying that the ''horrific crime'' deserved ''the severest of punishments allowed by law,'' he volunteered: ''I could never accept 'gay panic' or any other excuse as grounds for what he did.''

title: TEMPLE-INLAND PLANS TO BUY BACK UP TO 11% OF ITS STOCK
description: Temple-Inland, a Texas lumber and paper products company, said yesterday that it would buy back up to six million shares of its stock. The buyback, which will take place over an unspecified time, represents about 11 percent of Temple-Inland's 55.8 million outstanding shares. Companies use buybacks to increase per-share earnings by reducing shares outstanding. Temple-Inland, based in Diboll, Tex., reported revenue of $2.7 billion for the first nine months of this year. The company's shares price rose $1.4375, to $63.125.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SILVER FALLS. Silver prices fell after the October jobs report showed that wage growth was slower than expected, a sign that inflation remained under control. December silver fell 13.7 cents, to $5.085 an ounce.

title: Filings, Hearings and Decisions: Next Phase of the Case
description: The publication of Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's findings of fact yesterday began a rolling series of filings, hearings and decisions that could bring the case to a close by early next year.

title: Karl Waage, 83, Paleontologist Who Ran a Yale Museum, Dies
description: Karl M. Waage, a paleontologist and former director of the Peabody Museum of Natural History at Yale University, died on Oct. 18 at Connecticut Hospice in Branford, Conn. He was 83.

title: For Daewoo Group, Eastern Europe Remains Mostly in the Red
description: YOU could hear a linchpin drop in the vast production hall at the Daewoo Group's Avia truck factory on an old airfield at the edge of this city. In one portion of the hall, a few dozen workers slowly bolted together updated 1960's-model three-ton trucks. The rest lies empty, awaiting the arrival of an assembly line to build the new Daewoo-designed model on which the factory's future -- if it has one -- depends.

title: Time to Check Weatherstripping
description: WEATHERSTRIPPING is designed to close the gaps around the perimeter of doors and windows so the warm interior air cannot escape to the outside. Weatherstripping around doors, particularly around the entry door, has a short life span because the doors are used every day. Opening and closing a door wears the weatherstripping until it no longer forms an effective seal.

title: Part I: Relax the Inner Child
description: California livin' is not necessarily stress-free. Tim Healey, a physical therapist in Santa Ana, says that stress-related behavior and learning problems have dominated his practice over the last five years. Having researched the physiological effects of stress on infants with Dr. T. Berry Brazelton, a professor emeritus of pediatrics at Harvard University Medical School, Mr. Healey holds about 50 seminars a year, mostly in California, on how elementary school teachers can reduce stress in the classroom. He believes that exasperating student behavior like averting the eyes, slouching and twirling hair repetitively can often be attributed to an overstimulating environment.

title: Road Settlement
description: Under an agreement that ends a longstanding border feud, Greenburgh has opened an access road leading to a large shopping center in Yonkers, Supervisor Paul J. Feiner of the Town of Greenburgh said.

title: Latin Quarters
description: Dressed in the bohemian look of the moment, the author Lisa St. Aubin de Teran and her eccentric clan invite you inside the Villa Quarata.

title: And Not a Penny More
description: The New York Stock Exchange is weighing the benefits of pinching a penny when the securities industry converts stock prices to decimals from fractions next year.

title: Landscapes by the Carload: Art or Kitsch?
description: THOMAS KINKADE's 100,000-square-foot headquarters here is hardly a typical artist's atelier. But then Mr. Kinkade, arguably the most commercially successful painter of the 1990's, is hardly a typical artist.

title: Fire Ruins the Watery World of an Aquarium
description: IN May 1998, when the Cape May County Zoo burned to the ground and 200 animals were killed, the Ocean City Aquarium took in some of the surviving animals. Now some of the aquarium reptiles are being housed at the reopened zoo, after a fire Oct. 30 damaged the aquarium.

title: Fighting Addiction By Documenting Its Wretchedness
description: THE young woman's image is blurred and unsteady as it tracks across the screen. She shifts back and forth in front of a gritty sink, absently tending to a gaping wound that runs the length of her forearm, which is bloated to twice its normal size from her addiction to intravenous heroin and cocaine. Her boyfriend, John, ''wants to get a job,'' she explains. ''He wants to get off it. He wants to get clean. We both do.''

title: Life on the Outside
description: WALKIN' THE DOG

title: Shades Of Freya: A Memory Trip
description: SYRIA has always seemed to me an extraordinary country. Marked by the footprints of empire since the Hittites and Egyptians first clashed at Kadesh at the end of the 13th century B.C., Syria thrived under the Romans, argued under the Byzantines, bowed before the Umayyads, bled under the Crusaders, the Mongols and the Mamelukes, and finally rested for 400 years in quiet obscurity under the Ottoman Turks. Then World War I shattered that peace and the country was awarded as a mandate to the French, to gain independence only in 1945.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Mrs. Grundy Meets Miss November
description: The Century of Sex

title: Newark Flight Experiment Is Deemed a Failure
description: An experiment last year that took some planes departing from Newark International Airport over an industrial portion of Carteret and Rahway has been declared a failure by the Federal Aviation Administration. The standard patterns, which sends planes over Elizabeth, Linden and Staten Island, will remain in effect for now, despite complaints from residents about noise.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: COURTROOMS, prisons, police stations and officers of the law in many shapes and forms fill the screen with color, conflict and, thank goodness, a little comedy this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBIN, HARRY
description: DUBIN-Harry. On November 5, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Juliette. Loving father of Ronald Dubin and Jane Cates. Adored grandfather of David, Danielle, Denise, Colin, Melissa, Jonathan, David and Gilbert and greatgrandfather of Julia, Harrison, Evan, Leah and Reilly. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday 7-9PM with service Wednesday 9:30AM. Interment private

title: India Staggered by Cyclone
description: In the aftermath of one of the mightiest cyclones in India's history, the government tried -- fitfully and often futilely -- to provide relief to 10 million people affected by the Oct. 29 storm in the eastern state of Orissa.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Page 12 of the Arts & Leisure section today about the Atlantic Theater Company misstates the surname of an actor being directed by David Mamet, a founder of the company. He is Robert Bella, not Stella.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Purveyor of Puns

title: Grieve for Them
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALTENBACHER, RICHARD S.
description: KALTENBACHER - Richard S. Age 85, of Highland Beach, FL, and Martha's Vineyard, MA. Beloved husband of 61 years of Polly. Adored by his family, revered by his friends, and respected by his colleagues in the leather manufacturing industry. Survived by: Carol and Philip Mehler, Amanda and Mark Tamis, Isabella Bea Tamis, Philip Richard Mehler, Nancy and Edward Strauss, Arthur and Libby Jacobson and Zoe, Samuel, Grace and Rachel Simone Jacobson, Thomas and Traci Jacobson and Chloe Jacobson. Elizabeth and David Kaufman, Willa and Oliver Kaufman, Joseph and Gail Kaltenbacher, Jason and Eric Kaltenbacher. Survived by sister Carolyn K. Meier; predeceased by brother Jose C. Kaltenbacher. Services Monday, November 8, 1999, 3:30 PM, at Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton, FL; 1800-992-9262.

title: The Me Millennium
description: Andrew J. Cherlin's article ''I'm O.K., You're Selfish'' suggests that ''being responsible for your own actions'' is at odds with ''being involved in your community.''

title: Saving a Piece of the Architectural Past in Indiana
description: IN a move to save a significant piece of the state's urban and architectural history, the Historic Landmarks Foundation of Indiana is taking on the role of developer.

title: Weighing the Value of Bugs in a World of Pesticides
description: MANY gardeners in the New York area felt helpless and confused in September as helicopters and trucks sprayed their neighborhoods with malathion or pyrethroids to try to kill mosquitoes carrying the West Nile virus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, PERCY J.
description: MORRIS-Percy J. Age 90, who retired as Administrative Director of the European Division of Vicks Chemical Company in 1971, died in New Smyrna Beach, FL, on October 27, 1999. Survivors include four daughters Susan Gill, New Smyrna Beach, Katherine Allan, Seoul, Korea, Marylou Bruno, Longwood, FL, and Elizabeth Baglietto, Lake Worth, FL; eight grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; An Exhibition of Women
description: The photographer Annie Leibovitz combines portraits of both famous and unknown subjects in WOMEN (Random House, $75). She evidently means to celebrate changes that have been wrought by the feminist movement. Turn the page with a photograph of Madeleine K. Albright and discover two bull riders from an ''all-girl rodeo.'' On the flip side of a photo of three female soldiers is a picture of Louise Bourgeois. With her always penetrating and frequently ironic eye, Leibovitz has taken a haunting image of Joni Mitchell beside a fountain in an eerie garden setting and a shot of a haunted Nicole Kidman who looks like she has just seen Stanley Kubrick's ghost. There is a shot of Hillary Rodham Clinton so fastidiously posed she could be a waxwork. A tribute to Cindy Sherman -- herself a photographer and famous for creating different characters from her own image -- becomes a delicious joke when it unfurls six Sherman look-alikes as so many cutout paper dolls. Although Susan Sontag gave Leibovitz the idea for this exquisite collection, her introductory essay amounts to a feminist diatribe that offers none of the insights she brought to ''On Photography'' 22 years ago. Her outmoded polemic perpetrates some of the very offenses it rails against, as when Sontag writes, ''It's still common to begrudge a woman who has both beauty and intellectual brilliance.'' A good many of these photographs honor women who obviously enjoy displaying both -- including the striking one of Sontag herself.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Taking Shelter
description: The Clinton Administration says corporate tax shelters are spreading out of control. It wants a law to force companies to disclose shelters, instead of leaving the task of ferreting them out to the shrinking ranks of Internal Revenue Service auditors. Congressional Republicans and many companies say such a requirement would be excessive and unworkable.

title: Efforts to Keep Innovations Amid Standards
description: ''SO, soldier, what is courage?'' Janet Matthews asked of a student who entered a classroom at Westlake High School here one recent morning.

title: Leslie Morris and Jonathan Bari
description: Leslie Susan Morris, the daughter of Gail and Howard S. Morris of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married yesterday evening to Jonathan H. Bari, the son of Joan and Sidney Bari of Philadelphia. Rabbi Gerald I. Wolpe officiated at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUSS, MITCHELL
description: KRAUSS-Mitchell. A most warm and wonderful colleague. He was a pleasure to work with and to be associated with. Our deepest sympathy to his wife and family. Nat and Ernie Roth

title: The Me Millennium
description: Don't you think you're being just a little bit Eurocentric?

title: Little Ambassadors With Hearts In Need of Repair
description: TWO Siberian toddlers have arrived in the United States on an adult-size mission: to serve as emissaries of Russia and symbols of an effort to improve relations between the two countries.

title: The Man Who Heard the Soundtrack of the Mind
description: IT has been more than five years since Dennis Potter died of pancreatic cancer. In that time Potter, the iconoclastic British writer of ''The Singing Detective'' and ''Pennies From Heaven,'' has been the subject of at least three books, including an exhaustive biography by Humphrey Carpenter, and several homages, the most recent being the Alain Resnais film ''Same Old Song,'' in which characters lip-sync old standards, a Potter signature. Potter's wish was granted when ''Karaoke'' and ''Cold Lazarus,'' teleplays that he raced to complete in his last days, were produced and televised after his death. And his earlier dramas are periodically brought out; a seven-week showing of ''Pennies From Heaven'' at the Museum of Television and Radio concludes today. Potter's works, then, continue to be a source of fascination.

title: Millennial Hope With a Tincture Of Hopelessness
description: KURT MASUR is an unabashed idealist, a man who turns all misty in the face of big, life-affirming sentiments. His idealism is not just talk. During his prominent tenure as the music director of the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra, he spoke out against the repressive Communist government in East Germany and became a political hero in his homeland.

title: A Black Eye for Boxing
description: The founder of the International Boxing Federation and three other top officials were indicted on charges of receiving bribes from fighters and their promoters in exchange for manipulating the federation's rankings to allow boxers to qualify for lucrative fights. A prosecutor cited the ''culture of corruption'' in the organization, one of three major international ranking groups for boxing.

title: OPINION; A G.O.P. Loss in Perspective
description: BEFORE anyone throws a sheet over Nassau County Republicans, let's look at their Election Night losses in context.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APAT, ADELINE
description: APAT-Adeline. On November 5, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Herman. Loving mother of Klara and Larry. Adoring grandmother of Sharon and Annette, Roger and Liana, and Lisa. Great-grandmother of Rachel, Robby, Ariel, Cory, Zachary and Joshua. Services Tuesday, 11:15am at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Ruling Against Giuliani
description: A federal judge held that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani violated the First Amendment when he cut public funding to the Brooklyn Museum of Art for refusing to cancel an exhibition he considers offensive.

title: Tough Love for a Tough Girl
description: ''ROSETTA,'' the artful, gritty Belgian film that won top prize at Cannes this year, opens with a harrowing scene of a young woman being chased like a rabbit. The hounds are security guards at the factory where she has just been told, without explanation, that she's not getting a job she has been trying out for. Instead of going quietly, she abruptly takes off -- deep into the factory. The guards finally run her to ground in a changing room, where she has locked herself in, hunched down and gasping, clutching herself as if to keep anyone from taking the white smock and shower cap that are her work uniform.

title: Morning Becomes Bryant Gumbel
description: Is this part of the kinder, gentler Bryant II -- still going after Katie Couric's throat?

title: 7 Utilities in Pollution Suit
description: Spending $60 million for five new furnaces does not qualify as ''routine maintenance.'' So said the Justice Department and Environmental Protection Agency as they sued seven big electric utilities in the Midwest and South, accusing them of polluting the air by revamping old coal-burning power plants under the guise of normal upkeep.

title: An Offering to the Ghosts of Wildness Past
description: THERE are sparking synapses all through ''Bringing Out the Dead.'' You're wondering whether you're bored stiff or flatlining when, like a match in film noir, the screen flares into life. Nicolas Cage and Patricia Arquette sit down together and a riff in the editing makes her look like the head on an Etruscan coin. It's a glimpse of Godardian eternity in the rowdy Manhattan night. Or take the jittery progress of the ambulance, with the street turning 90 degrees, so that the wash of sunset looks like light at the end of a tunnel.

title: A Man of Letters, and Now a Doctor
description: Robert Giroux of the publishers Farrar, Straus & Giroux, who has edited some of the greatest writers of modern times in his 50-year career, will receive an honorary doctor of humane letters degree today at Seton Hall University in South Orange.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Bech at Bay: A Quasi-Novel

title: A Stylish Merlot
description: On Monday night, the '97 Wolffer merlot from Sagpond Vineyards in Sagaponack was opened to accompany a meat dish, which it did, as usual, very well.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Next to Mom and Dad; It's a Hard Life (or Not)
description: MONEY doesn't buy happiness -- and among teenagers, it may actually make life feel harder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERIC, FRANCOISE. (MRS. SEWARD)
description: ERIC-Francoise. (Mrs. Seward). On November 4, 1999, peacefully at home. Survived by her nephew, Pierre de Moreuil, and her great niece, Claire de Moreuil. Private burial in Remsenburg. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, NYC, Friday, November 12, 1999 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, a donation to the Dr. Stuart Quan Fellowship at Memorial-Sloan Kettering Hospital, 1275 York Ave, New York, N.Y. 10021 would be appreciated.

title: Lemieux Returns, Only to Be Upstaged by a Rookie
description: Claude Lemieux was greeted by cheering Devils fans tonight in his return to New Jersey after a bitter departure four years ago, and he rewarded the Continental Arena crowd of 15,402 with two goals.

title: The Me Millennium
description: Your writers have got it all figured out -- a century of thought pulled together in a bunch of essays all focusing on our collective selfishness.

title: Staying Afloat
description: PASSAGE TO JUNEAU

title: The Fossil Wars
description: The Bonehunters' Revenge

title: The Me Millennium
description: I was employed by a major New Jersey company that started using the psychological tests for career development that Margaret Talbot discussed in ''The Rorschach Chronicles.'' However, when the test posed such questions as ''Have you ever hit anyone as an adult?'' I opted out, claiming an invasion of my privacy.

title: Horse and Rider Are Exploring New Heights
