description: Until last week, Jimmy Torano, a lifelong horseman who at 34 has finally put himself in the driver's seat of an equine vehicle with a legitimate chance to make the United States Olympic team, had managed to avoid any personal confrontations with 7-foot Puissance walls.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GASTON, VICTOR HOWARD, SR.
description: GASTON-Victor Howard, Sr. Memorial service and musical reception, Sunday, November 14, 5 PM, Riverdale Presbyterian Church, 4763 Henry Hudson Parkway West, Bronx, New York. All friends invited to pay tribute.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: Hummingbird House

title: Chile's Right Is Being Led In a Change Of Direction
description: Joaquin Lavin, the presidential candidate of the Chilean right, flashed a wide grin and laughed triumphantly as a throng of dockworkers, unemployed coal miners and students cheered wildly in response to his every promise.

title: Barbie's Guru Stumbles; Critics Say Chief's Flaws Weigh Heavily on Mattel
description: A CHIEF executive's ultimate test is how he or she copes in a crisis.

title: How Microsoft Sought Friends In Washington
description: Twenty months ago, Representative Billy Tauzin walked into the office of William H. Gates 3rd, chairman of Microsoft, bearing a 10 inch by 10 inch white box and a warning.

title: The Typist
description: Selected Letters

title: The View From/Purchase; Volunteers' Mission Behind the Scenes
description: TO the casual observer, the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College here is a fait accompli, a huge, self-contained institution with four state-of-the-art theaters, a cafe and an intriguing gift shop. It offers everything from folk music to opera and, in its sleek, professional ambience, seems almost to run itself.

title: From Portugal, Macho but Urbane
description: Sorting through low-priced Portuguese reds for a jewel can be a chore. Far too many cuff the palate. Then you discover the 1996 Duas Quintas from Ramos Pinto, a macho blend, and the quest is rewarded.

title: It's No Longer Just the Economy, Stupid
description: THE median size of a new house in the United States just passed 2,000 square feet, 25 percent bigger than two decades ago. Ford's new Excursion, a $37,000 behemoth of a sport utility vehicle, is selling out as soon as it reaches dealers. Half of all households now invest in the stock market. Unemployment is at a nearly 30-year low.

title: Pets and Poverty
description: Your letter writer suggests that Americans ought to give up pets in order to ''forge deeper relationships with other humans.'' That's an admirable goal, but a grossly misguided means to accomplish it. There is one behavior of animals that most humans cannot duplicate: the nonjudgmental attitude that an animal brings to every human being it meets. Not skin color or physical infirmity or any of a myriad of prejudices can influence an animal's response.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTNER, SYLVIA
description: Rotner-Sylvia. On November 4, 1999. Beloved wife of Jack for 55 years. Cherished mother of Kenneth and the late Ronald, and dear mother-in-law to Carol. Loving sister of the late Dr. Herbert Harris. Adoring grandmother of Annie. She will be deeply missed by family and friends. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: The Anti-Elitist Club Party: Ready or Not
description: CAN you open a club in New York with no velvet ropes, no V.I.P. lists and no snooty attitude? That's what New Yorkers -- and I don't care whether you are Prince, Lauren Hutton or Derek Jeter, we've all been snubbed by a Praetorian Guard at a nightclub door -- say we'd like to see. Do we?

title: Today, The Musical Dies
description: At the start of his article, Albert Innaurato (Sept. 26) reminds the reader that ''the finest musical theater is, after all, a direct descendant of tacky operettas and vaudeville.'' Yet later, he proceeds to skewer the musical-theater art form for essentially retreating to its original format. It is true, as he points out, that the great musicals (''Carousel,'' ''South Pacific,'' ''West Side Story'') have given today's musical theater a lot to live up to.

title: For Garth Fagan, Home Is Where The Focus Clears
description: ON a recent bright, crisp morning, the 12 members of Garth Fagan Dance arrived at company headquarters in downtown Rochester excited that they would be learning a new Fagan work later in the day. The piece, ''Woza,'' which can mean ''Come'' in Zulu, set to a commissioned score by the South African composer Lebo M, will have its world premiere during the company's two-week engagement at the Joyce Theater, beginning on Tuesday. The program also includes last season's hit ''Two Pieces of One: Green,'' set to 16th-century chants and a jazz composition by Tony Williams, as well as revivals of ''Postscript Posthumous: Ellington'' (1983) and ''Oatka Trail'' (1979), danced to Dvorak's Cello Concerto in B minor and inspired by a wilderness refuge near Rochester.

title: Judith Shulevitz, Nicholas Lemann
description: Judith Anne Shulevitz and Nicholas Lemann, writers in New York, are to be married today by Rabbi Marion R. Shulevitz, the bride's mother, at the University Club in New York.

title: Commercial Property /The Market; Office Space Is Scarce, and Getting More Expensive
description: WE are already seeing triple-digit rents at the upper end of the midtown market,'' said an ebullient Steven Swerdlow, the senior managing director of CB Richard Ellis's New York office, referring to the $100 a square foot annual rents reported for the buildings at 712 and 767 Fifth Avenue.

title: The Typical Image
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RENNICK, MARY ANN
description: RENNICK-Mary Ann. A service will be held on Sunday, November 14th at Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square South, NYC at 3PM to celebrate the life of Mary Ann Rennick. A reception will follow at Gene's Restaurant, 73 W 11th St for family and friends.

title: Of Fish and Family
description: THE NIGHT GARDENER

title: Soft Words, Tough Words
description: There is a soft side and a hard side to Richard L. Huber, Aetna's chief executive, both recently in evidence.

title: One of L.I.'s Most Varied Mexican Spots
description: ''I'M waiting for the bullfight to start,'' was one diner's comment shortly after entering the new Blue Tequila Bar and Grill, at 135 Old Country Road, in Carle Place (516-248-4500). Her reaction was understandable because this colorful Mexican hangout, with its mariachi music, sombreros, terra-cotta walls, strings of garlic, baskets, urns, wagon wheels, steer heads, tequila posters and lively neon-lined bar is as much a fiesta or celebration as it is a restaurant. Waiters wear kerchiefs and straw cowboy hats, a guacamole lady in a vividly colored flowing dress moves from table to table where bright serape-style covers hold many a mammoth pitcher of sangria. Hanging plants, gourds and pumpkins are everywhere, dishes arrive with tiny Mexican flags sticking out of them, Happy Birthday is sung to a rapid Latino hand-clapping rhythm and to the smiling South of the Border staff, everyone is an instant ''amigo.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAWLOWSKI, ANTON
description: PAWLOWSKI-Anton, 54, noted classical guitarist and teacher. Memorial service Sunday, November 14, at 11:00 A.M. at Greenwich House's Recital Hall, 46 Barrow Street, Manhattan.

title: For Meat and Poultry, Pure Maple Syrup
description: MOST people use maple syrup -- which is now prominently on display with the pumpkins and apples in farm stands -- on their breakfast pancakes. But it also makes a wonderful glaze for meat and poultry. I like to combine it with hot spices and use it as a marinade for a butterflied leg of lamb, which can be grilled or broiled -- or even cooked in the fireplace. The marinade caramelizes over the heat and gives the lamb a delicious crust. Of course, use only pure maple syrup. Blends may contain as much as 80 percent corn syrup, which does nothing for the taste.

title: Australians Leave No Room for Debate Over Who's Best
description: On the day that Australians voted to keep Queen Elizabeth II as their constitutional, if merely symbolic, head of state, the Queen handed the most important trophy in rugby to an Australian who voted against her.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARTER, KATHLEEN ARNEY
description: CARTER-Kathleen Arney. Memorial service Saturday, Nov. 13, 4PM, at Fourth Universalist Society, 160 Central Park West at 76 St.

title: Conservatives Backing Bush's Abortion Strategy
description: Fearful that Gov. George W. Bush's stand on abortion could cost him crucial support, prominent conservative leaders are working aggressively behind the scenes to persuade their followers to put aside misgivings and rally behind the Texas governor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEE, PETER ROGERS
description: DEE-Peter Rogers. October 30; born in Winchester, MA 1939. Graduated from Boston College, and The American Academy of Dramatic Arts, NY. He served in the U.S. Navy. His love and dedication to the theater lead him to act, write plays and poetry and direct. Mr. Dee was awarded the International Directors Medal. His most recently performed play, ''Amber Patches'' was performed at Saranac Lake, NY starring Julie Harris. Survivors are his partner G.E.B. Shelton, of NY, two brothers, Thomas P. Dee, W.Virginia; Stephen C. Dee, CA; two sisters, Cathy C. Tebo and Maureen C. Smith, both of Cape Cod, MA. Uncle of five nephews, one niece, and three grandnephews. A memorial will take place at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center Chapel, NY, Monday, December 13 at 2:00 PM with an additional memorial on Cape Cod, April 15, 2000. In lieu of flowers please call 212-265-0252 or 212-582-7394 to ascertain Mr. Dee's favorite charities.

title: Up From the Rank and File, She Conquers the Under-21's
description: Nineteen-year-old Maria Kouvatsou of Greece won the Girls Under 21 World Championship in Yerevan, Armenia, Sept. 30. She led from the start, then lost her last two games, but still had an 8 1/2-4 1/2 score, enough to put her into a four-way tie for first place, after which tiebreak coefficients gave her the title.

title: Youth Center Deal
description: The Peekskill Housing Authority, a an agency independent of the city, and the city of Peekskill have unveiled a $4.2 million collaborative effort to improve the Bohlmann-Kiley complex and nearby neighborhood in its downtown.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Raising a Glass, Raising a Curtain
description: The black tie is common enough in fund-raising for cultural groups. For the State Theater in New Brunswick, add red wine and white wine. These are not events, but labels: State Theater 1997 California Chardonnay and State Theater 1997 California Red Zinfandel, from Ehlers Grove Winery in the Napa Valley. But the proceeds nurture New Jersey, subsidizing ticket prices at the State Theater and aiding its education and community outreach activities. With the help of Stage Left restaurant just down Livingston Avenue, a selection committee tasted a dozen choices and settled on the two bottles. The theater's literature describes the chardonnay as ''dry, full-bodied, well balanced'' and the red zinfandel as ''deliciously spicy,'' which might also make a good review for a production there. The wines, $12.72 a bottle or $152.64 a case, may be ordered by calling (732) 247-7200, extension 541, or e-mailing cdiaz@statetheatre.com

title: Technology Too High? And Now Microsoft
description: WHAT a week it was for true believers in technology stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average almost doubled its weighting in technology shares last Monday when it added Microsoft, Intel and SBC Communications to its 30-company list. And on Wednesday, white-hot technology shares propelled the Nasdaq composite above the 3,000 mark for the first time. At Friday's close, the Nasdaq composite was up a blazing 41.48 percent this year.

title: Giuliani Senate Bid Could Give Unions Negotiating Leverage
description: Labor unions overwhelmingly backed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's re-election in 1997, but now they are not only tilting strongly toward his likely Senate opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton, but also hoping to use the Senate race to squeeze more out of the mayor in contract talks next year.

title: NATO Was Closer to Ground War in Kosovo Than Is Widely Realized
description: In early June, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, the most outspoken advocate of a ground invasion of Kosovo, had ordered the preparation of 30,000 letters calling up Britain's army reserves. Typed and addressed, they were about to go into the mail, making possible the commitment of up to 50,000 British troops -- half the standing army -- to go into Kosovo.

title: France Presses For a Power Independent Of the U.S.
description: In a Europe that is increasingly concerned about unilateralism and resurgent isolationism in the United States, France seized the moment this week to urge the European allies to develop a more independent defense and foreign policy.

title: That Reminds Me . . .
description: When J.W. Marriott Jr., as in Marriott Hotels, recently received a 1999 Albert Schweitzer Leadership Award at a dinner to benefit the Hugh O'Brian Youth Foundation, he started by saying, ''Thank you for those kind words.'' Which reminded him of an old story, one touching on his concern with service:

title: Progress Seen in Search For Clues to EgyptAir Crash
description: An EgyptAir flight bound for Cairo fell from a moonlit sky early last Sunday morning, plunging into the Atlantic south of Nantucket Island and killing all 217 people aboard. So began a painful and familiar ritual.

title: New Listings Almost Daily
description: Well, if the truth-in-advertising laws got tougher, this could be how Mr. Sternlicht would have to search for new executives. The resignation of Mr. Bartels last week has been only one of several high-level departures this year. Jim Gallagher, a spokesman, said that the company's performance is improving and that none of the departures, save Mr. Nanula's, reflected any rancor. ''I don't want you to think this is a troubled company with people only going out the door,'' he said. ''Nothing could be further from the truth.''

title: An Uneven Syracuse Is Still Too Much for Temple
description: At times, the Syracuse players looked as if they were not on the same page as the coaches; at times, they executed their plays with aplomb. But on an afternoon when many of them were fully concentrating on football for the first time this week, the Orangemen scored 10 points in the last 1 minute 34 seconds and beat a hapless Temple team by 27-10 in a Big East Conference game before 43,970 at the Carrier Dome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, REV. THOMAS E.
description: DAVIS-Rev. Thomas E., Pastor Emeritus of Ascension R.C. Church, New Milford, New Jersey on November 4, 1999. Devoted son of the late Edward S. and Cecilia Fitzsimmons Davis. Beloved brother of Robert of Purchase, New York and the late Edward and Jack Davis. Brother-in-law of Anne Hogan Davis. Also survived by 6 nieces and nephews and 12 great nieces and nephews. Archbishop Theodore E. McCarrick, Archbishop of Newark will concelebrate a funeral Mass Tuesday, Nov. 9, 1999, 7:30 PM in Ascension R.C. Church, 256 Azalea Drive, New Milford, N.J. Rev. Davis will lie in state at the church Tuesday from 3:30 P.M. to 7:30 P.M. It is requested that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to Fr. John's Foundation for the Handicapped and Poor, C/O Fr. John Hourihan, 5 Johnson Street, Monmouth Beach, N.J. 07750. A memorial Service for Fr. Davis will be held at Booth Bay Harbor Maine in June 2000. For information Boulevard Funeral Home, New Milford, N.J.

title: Development In Chelsea
description: To the Editor:

title: Bunk
description: LIES ACROSS AMERICA

title: Robert L. Schiffer, 79, Speechwriter at U.N.
description: Robert L. Schiffer, who was a speechwriter for United States delegates to the United Nations, including Adlai E. Stevenson and Arthur J. Goldberg, and who was also an international affairs consultant and an author, died on Tuesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York City. He was 79 and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Frat Party Is:; a) Milk and Cookies; b) Beer Pong
description: It's called beer pong, and at Dartmouth College a place where traditions die hard -- it has been part of fraternity life for at least 40 years, as hallowed as rush or Winter Carnival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELMAN, ABBE J.
description: SELMAN-Abbe J. The Board of Directors of the New York County Dental Society is saddened by the passing of our distinguished past President. Dr. Selman served in 1974 as a standard bearer for our profession. His guidance and wisdom wil be missed. Our deepest sympathies to Edy, Josh and Richard. Memorial Services to be announced. Elliott Moskowitz, President Mark A. Mintzer, President Elect Donna Rumberger, Vice President Jack Hirsch, Secretary Robert Raiber, Treasurer

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-07-99: The Ethicist; Brother's Keeper
description: My brother is in prison for a nonviolent offense, and I could help him gain early release. However, he is H.I.V. positive and has infected his girlfriend and two or three others, a result of broken condoms, he claims. I don't want him to die in jail, but there is no doubt in my mind that lives will be saved if he stays in. Should I place the needs of society over those of my own flesh and blood? -- C. F., New York

title: Julie Roberts and Francis Fleming
description: Julie Nell Roberts, the daughter of Joanna B. Roberts of Fair Haven, N.J., and Lawrence W. Roberts of Red Bank, N.J., was married yesterday to Francis Gerard Fleming III, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fleming Jr. of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. John Monroe performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of Red Bank. The Rev. Peter Colapietro, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the service.

title: Red Flags Were Flying With Leaf
description: In the spring of 1998, Ryan Leaf gave the San Diego Chargers the first hint that their franchise quarterback was not exactly a leader. Leaf was the only player to walk out of the rookie symposium the National Football League holds for its first-year players, leaving several days early.

title: AAA Bond Rating
description: Westchester County's AAA credit rating was reaffirmed as the county sold $55.48 million in municipal bonds on Nov. 1. All three major rating agencies -- Moody's Investors Service, Standard & Poor's Corporation and Fitch IECA -- confirmed Westchester's top credit rating.

title: Sarah Kotler, Douglas Kotlove
description: Sarah Beth Kotler, a daughter of Sheila Kotler and Dr. Stuart Kotler of Holmdel, N.J., was married last evening to Douglas Alan Kotlove, a son of Adrienne and Irwin Kotlove of Coral Springs, Fla. Rabbi Jay Stein performed the ceremony at Congregation Magen David in Ocean, N.J.

title: BLACKBOARD: Q.&A.
description: Can adults learn as easily as children? Do learning ability and memory retention diminish with age? With the number of college students over age 30 doubling since 1970, the questions seem particularly relevant. Two experts were consulted on the subject -- Elizabeth Gould, a neurobiologist in the department of psychology at Princeton University, and Andrew Lerner, a psychologist in the New York City public school system who also teaches ''Adult Learning,'' a class that explores how adults learn, for the continuing education department at the New School for Social Research.

title: The Me Millennium
description: I teach medieval history, so I was delighted to find that the Middle Ages are still relevant to the way we frame current debates. But I was frustrated to see all those hoary myths about the medieval ''flat earth'' belief and the subordination of the self to church and king. It's all straight out of Mark Twain. Every educated person before 1500 knew that the world was spherical.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, RUTH
description: MURRAY-Ruth. 89, formerly of Parkchester, Bronx, NY, died October 29. She is survived by her brother Morris Kronenfeld, nieces and nephews. She was a secretary at the Bronx Music School, and later Tishman Realty and Construction Company for many years. For information ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' 800-522-0588.

title: Suffolk Voters Tell County: Watch LIPA
description: BY a margin that surprised even supporters, voters in Suffolk County approved a ballot proposition on Tuesday that compels the county to act as a watchdog over the Long Island Power Authority.

title: The Me Millennium
description: The fact that Margaret Talbot could critically discuss personality tests and their use in the workplace and not even raise the issue of whether such testing is an unacceptable invasion of the privacy of employees and job applicants indicates something very unsettling about American society on the eve of the millennium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLAS, PETER, DR.
description: NICHOLAS-Peter, Dr. The faculty & staff of the Division of Infectious Diseases & the Samuel Bronfman Department of Medicine of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and Mount Sinai NYU Health mourn the loss of our beloved colleague, Dr. Peter Nicholas. A graduate of Yale University School of Medicine, Dr. Nicholas trained in internal medicine and infectious diseases at Mount Sinai. For more than 25 years as a faculty member of Mount Sinai and attending physician at Elmhurst Hospital Center, Dr. Nicholas touched the lives of hundreds of physicians-in-training as Associate Dean of Graduate Medical Education, Director of the medical student clerkships and the Infectious Diseases Fellowship, and enthusiastic medical school lecturer. His commitment to excellence in clinical care was reflected in his role as Chairman of the Infection Control Committee, a program he started at Elmhurst Hospital Center in 1975. Dr. Nicholas will be remembered as a superb, dedicated physician and educator, a tireless patient advocate and warm friend to all of his colleagues. His compassion, kindness, honesty, and integrity were truly inspirational. We extend our condolences to his wife, Joan, and his entire family. Mary Klotman, MD Chief, Division of Infectious Diseases Barry S. Coller, MD Chairman

title: In an Upset, Actors Guild Elects Novice As President
description: The Screen Actors Guild has elected William Daniels, an award-winning television star, as its president in an upset victory over the incumbent, Richard Masur.

title: Field of Ruins In the Sand
description: IT was my traveling companion, Leyla, who persuaded me that I had to see Sergiopolis (modern Resafe), a Byzantine holy city stranded in the desert wastes of northern Syria, about 120 miles southeast of Aleppo. To me it seemed too far, and it was May; I was convinced that the drive would be hot, tiring and dull. But Leyla is not easily thwarted. We were going to see Sergiopolis whether I liked it or not, and of course she knew I would love it.

title: Mmmm, a Little Warm Pizza to Start
description: THE old stone house off U.S. 1 in Greenwich may have more ghosts of restaurants past than any other building in Fairfield County. You'd never know it, though, by the lively, exuberant atmosphere at Moreno Ristorante, the new occupant of this attractive, two-story space.

title: Conflicting Voices From Iran
description: Iran's conservative clerics tried to use Thursday's 20th anniversary of the seizure of American hostages in Teheran to whip up renewed hostility toward America, to discredit Iran's political reformers and to mock the vision of a more tolerant Islam advocated by President Mohammad Khatami. They did not succeed.

title: PATAKI TO IMPOSE STRICT NEW LIMITS ON AUTO EMISSIONS
description: Gov. George E. Pataki will impose new state vehicle emissions standards that are more stringent than federal requirements, a step that is expected to help push the entire auto industry to develop lower-pollution cars, trucks and vans.

title: Beyond Watercolors: Possibilities of Paper
description: IN the last 20 years, artists have been using a variety of techniques to create impressive works on paper surfaces. This direction in contemporary art allows an arts center with limited staff and physical space to organize an exciting exhibition without having to contend with heavy sculptures or large canvases.

title: Skip the Mulch; Let Trees Breathe
description: THERE is a planting technique appearing these days that should be corrected. This technique is the tendency to make mounds of mulch around the bases of newly planted trees. These mounds are not just a few inches, in some cases but more like a foot or more high.

title: The Verdict: Microsoft Is a Monopoly
description: In the first part of his verdict in the government's landmark antitrust case against the Microsoft Corporation, the presiding judge in the trial said that the company used its monopoly power to stifle innovation, reduce competition and hurt consumers. Next, he will rule on whether the company actually violated the law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVANS, DEANE MANN
description: EVANS-Deane Mann, of Darien, CT on Nov. 4. Survived by his wife Sue Ann Milliken Evans, sons Deane Mann Evans Jr. and James Milliken Evans, grandchildren Samivel and Georgia, and sister Paula Evans Foley. President of Louis Watjen, Inc. of New York City. A memorial service will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, CT at 3:30 PM Saturday, November 13. Memorials to Visiting Nurse and Hospice Care of Southwestern Connecticut, 1029 East Main St., Stamford, CT 06902 or the Carl & Dorothy Bennett Cancer Center, P.O. Box 9317, Stamford, CT. 06904.

title: Marla Nierenberg, Michael Hanan
description: Marla Sue Nierenberg, a daughter of Claire Nierenberg and Dr. Aaron Nierenberg of South Orange, N.J., is to be married today to Michael Scott Hanan, a son of Linda A. Hanan of Parsippany, N.J., and Nathaniel Hanan of Cliffside Park, N.J. Rabbi Jehiel Orenstein will perform the ceremony at Congregation Beth El in South Orange.

title: VIEW; Life on the High-Fat Bandwagon
description: THEY say there are no sure bets in this world, but I disagree. I'd stake my life on the fact that right now, somewhere in America, a man is telling a woman he's going on a diet.

title: Summerhill Revisited
description: IN A DAMP AND WINDY CORNER OF EASTERN England, a large run-down Victorian mansion stands as an unlikely monument to a revolutionary idea in education. It was here in the 1920's that a Scottish teacher founded Summerhill as the first modern ''free school,'' where classes were not compulsory and key decisions were made by an assembly of pupils and teachers. The objective was even more unorthodox: that children should be happy at school.

title: Habitats/1349 Lexington Avenue; After 53 Years, a Move In the Same Building
description: FOR everyone, moving is traumatic. But for pack rats it may actually be a good thing, providing the necessary pressure to slim down, throw out, clean up. To begin anew.

title: The Me Millennium
description: It is interesting, and more than a little sad, that not one of the writers you asked to explore the problem of ''me'' had any use for the concept of ''Him.'' Even in ''The Saintly Boss,'' Mary Gordon's thumbnail biography of Ignatius of Loyola, neither the word ''God'' nor the name ''Jesus'' appears. Gordon writes: ''The modern executive could learn a lot from Ignatius, but I fully understand that this is not a realistic possibility. His way requires periods of private contemplation and public revision.'' Well, yes, but before even that, it requires knowing that someone is there: There is another Me beside me.

title: Report Cites Medicare Fraud
description: For several years, administration officials have boasted of success in their effort to curtail Medicare fraud. But a report to Congress from the General Accounting Office suggests that those claims may be premature.

title: Cradle of Ships
description: THE YARD Building a Destroyer at the Bath Iron Works. By Michael S. Sanders. Illustrated. 253 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $26.

title: After Thomas Loses His Temper, Depleted Knicks Lose to Cavaliers
description: The reality of the situation was unfolding painfully for a Knicks team that was beginning to fizzle on the floor while Larry Johnson leaned stiffly against the baseline table and Kurt Thomas was still huffing like a steam whistle in an empty locker room.

title: Katherine Calihan, Duncan Kennedy
description: Katherine Roth Calihan, a daughter of Brenda S. Calihan and Joseph L. Calihan Jr. of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to Duncan Robb Kennedy, a son of Louisa L. Kennedy and Moorhead C. Kennedy of Mount Desert Island, Me. The Rev. Kenneth Westray performed the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in San Francisco.

title: Crime
description: The tall cliffs of the Cornish coast cast long shadows over THE LAMORNA WINK (Viking, $22.95), another atmospheric entry in an elegantly styled series by Martha Grimes. Melrose Plant, the congenial aristocrat who picks up the slack for Richard Jury when that Scotland Yard detective is otherwise engaged, takes a trip to Cornwall and impulsively rents a house by the sea where two children were mysteriously drowned. Although he makes allowances for a certain brooding presence (''This was Daphne du Maurier territory, Manderley-in-flames country''), one look around pubs like the Drowned Man and the Die Is Cast makes him wonder if ''this penchant for names of ill omen'' bodes ill.

title: Jeanne Choi, Nelson Rosen
description: Dr. Jeanne Susan Choi, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Myong S. Choi of Manhattan, is to be married today to Dr. Nelson Garrett Rosen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Rosen of Philadelphia. Rabbi Joel S. Goor is to perform the ceremony at Oheka, the Otto Kahn house in Cold Spring Hills, N.Y. A traditional Korean cultural ceremony was performed yesterday at Kum Gam Sung, a restaurant in Flushing, Queens.

title: Staten Island Fills a Hole in the Sky
description: In recent years, Staten Islanders have seen a hole in the skyline where a six-sided steeple once soared over the treetops of St. George. It had topped the Brighton Heights Reformed Church, an 1863 landmark destroyed by fire (left) in 1996. Parishioners concluded a $2.8 million rebuilding effort on Oct. 30 by capping its new brick church with a 70-foot steel-fiberglass steeple (right). ''That beautiful, old-fashioned, white Gothic church gave St. George the feeling of a town,'' said Theo Dorian, president of the St. George Civic Association.

title: The Power of Stripping Down to Nothingness
description: WHEN Sankai Juku first performed at City Center in 1984, audiences were transfixed by its brutal images, its haunting beauty. It grabbed something fearful and nightmarish from inside us and reflected it back with a new intensity. Four men, covered only with white powder, dangled upside down from high above, tied at the ankles like pieces of meat. They descended slowly, backs arching, arms coiling, flaunting their closeness to death. (The next year, one dancer did fall to his death during an outdoor performance.)

title: Reid Shane and Laura Berland
description: Laura Berland, a film executive, and Reid Shane, a television executive, were married in New York last evening. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the New York Palace Hotel.

title: Keeping Buildings Fraud-Free
description: IF there is one thing that has been proved by the indictments in Manhattan of more than 200 construction-industry and management companies and individuals over the last six years, it is that as long as there are cookies on the counter, there will always be new hands creeping toward the cookie jar.

title: The Gnomes of Santa Fe
description: THE PREDICTORS

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-07-99: On Language; Pushing It
description: 'Allergies, I am told, don't flare up the first time you come in contact with the offending agent,'' writes Tom Wolfe, author of the novels ''Bonfire of the Vanities'' and ''A Man in Full.'' ''The allergens build up gradually over time until one day you can't take it anymore.''

title: The Me Millennium
description: A psychologist and long-time Prozac user, Lauren Slater writes that she doesn't mind sickness, which she says ''can be an escape'' (''Prozac Mother and Child'').

title: A Maple Glaze for Poultry
description: MOST people use maple syrup -- which is now prominently on display with the pumpkins and apples in farm stands -- on their breakfast pancakes. But it also makes a wonderful glaze for meat and poultry. Of course, use only pure maple syrup. Blends may contain as much as 80 percent corn syrup, which does nothing for the taste.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORNAN, PETER
description: DORNAN-Peter. Age 76. Retired researcher and chief of the Samizdat Archives Department at Radio Liberty in Munich, died November 1, 1999 in suburban Philadelphia, Pa. where he made his home with his sister, Joan Dornan Katz, having moved there recently from Asbury Park, New Jersey.

title: Star-Crossed Lovers' Long Night in Verona
description: IN the beginning, the one-man chorus (played by Paul Niebanck) traverses the tragic journey from ''ancient grudge'' to ''new mutiny,'' presaging ''the two hours' traffic of our stage.''

title: Honolulu Journal; Pockmark on Paradise's Landscape
description: It juts into the ocean at the eastern end of Waikiki Beach like some ghostly barge, its concrete arches crumbling, its curving windows broken, its 100-meter saltwater swimming pool stagnant and its 2,500 bleacher seats empty and forlorn. For 20 years, the War Memorial Natatorium has been a shuttered scar on this famous stretch of shoreline, a victim of municipal neglect and political deadlock.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Suffolk to Auction Off Tax-Defaulted Houses
description: THE five-bedroom, two-bath Cape Cod at 4 Straw Lane is a bedraggled sight on a street of neatly kept homes just south of the Long Island Expressway.

title: A Hole in the Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-07-99; A League of His Own
description: Of the major sports, I have always found football the most difficult to love. I do follow the game (in part because my job requires it), and I have a nominal hometown rooting interest in the Jets. And though I know it only from grainy highlight reels, I have a certain affection for the old N.F.L. -- those guys with multi-consonant surnames, one foot out of the slaughterhouse or coal mine, waging war in the driving snow. The televised glare of the modern game has none of that romance.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BUTNERS, FRICIS EVALDS
description: BUTNERS-Fricis Evalds. October, 1903-October, 1979. Put vejini Dzen laivinu Aizdzen mani kurzeme Tu esi ar mums tagad un muzigi Milestiba tava gimene

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAPALDO, LOUIS A.
description: CAPALDO-Louis A. 29 years ago November 8, 1970 Louis passed away. Memories of love and devotion never die. Always alive in my heart. Susan Capaldo

title: BEST SELLERS: November 7, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Corporate Contributions And the Asbestos Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Bookend; Charge!
description: ''All men who feel any power of joy in battle,'' runs the most memorable sentence in Theodore Roosevelt's ''Rough Riders,'' ''know what it is like when the wolf rises in the heart.'' Through most of his 40 years he had managed to control this prowling aggression. Big-game hunting and a variety of strenuous sports relieved most of the physical pressure, while politics and writing served as outlets for his need to wage ideological warfare. He boasted that he was primarily a ''literary feller,'' but an analysis of the books he wrote before 1898 shows that every one of them dealt with ways to establish mastery.

title: Angst, Bravado and a 90-Word Title
description: FIONA APPLE showed up late for an interview with her excuse on a makeshift leash. It was a black-and-white wire-haired mongrel that had been abandoned in the New York subway. Ms. Apple and her manager, Andrew Slater, were walking through Central Park when they came across some policemen offering the dog to passers-by as an alternative to the city pound.

title: The Me Millennium
description: Slater's article hit a post-modern nerve: the idea that the mind (or personality, or whatever else we choose to call that elusive creature of consciousness) may be nothing more than the twinkling of electrical charges inside a sack of biochemicals. The notion is about as appealing as the prospect of one's own death, but quite possibly just as irrefutable. Doctors were recently reported to have inadvertently sent a woman into deep (but, thankfully, temporary) depression by applying an electrode to a specific area of the brain previously thought unconnected with emotion. Just as in the 1950's and 1960's, when humankind came face to face with the prospect that the species could self-destruct in a nuclear instant, today we confront intimations of some sort of reductive physical absolute. Perhaps this insight was at the core of the abiding ''horror'' experienced by Kurtz in Conrad's ''Heart of Darkness.''

title: Q & A
description: Grand Canyon From Above

title: Reluctantly, Australians Keep a Bond To the Queen
description: A mismatched coalition of political opposites soundly defeated a move to end the symbolic rule of the British monarchy here today, even though that is clearly what most Australians want.

title: MacArthur Reports Doubling in Passengers
description: Less than eight months after Southwest Airlines started discount flights from MacArthur Airport in Islip, the number of passengers using the airport has more than doubled.

title: Stalwart Fans, Braving the Weather, Bearing Signs
description: At age 18, Lin Boyette would race through Rockefeller Center on his way to Broadway shows, hoping to catch a glimpse of the celebrities he watched so often on NBC.

title: Uncovering The Belle Epoque In Paris
description: ON my second night in Paris, an unseasonably hot evening in May, I find myself transported to a male bordello where Marcel Proust, perched on a wobbly chair, is spying on a fellow patron. I hadn't planned to spend time in this Place de Clichy cineplex, where ''Time Regained'' is playing alongside the latest American blockbusters. But I'm locked out of my friend's Montmartre apartment, and this is one place I can await her return in air-conditioned comfort. Besides, entering Proust's world jibes perfectly with my own voyeuristic purposes. To research a novel, I've come to peer through the keyhole of the present-day and discover the past of the Belle Epoque. I want to experience Paris as my fictional characters might have experienced it in 1910. But can I really recapture that lost time in a mere 10 days, or is my quest as shaky as Proust's chair?

title: Don't Call Them Workaholics
description: Once a workaholic, always a workaholic, right? Well, some of the prime candidates don't seem to think so.

title: Altered Itineraries As the World Heats Up
description: IT probably isn't necessary to cancel or change vacation plans just yet, but global warming -- if it develops as forecast -- promises in time to revise travelers' lists of preferred destinations.

title: Blossoming in a Barren Landscape
description: I'M what they call suggestible, so when two of the dice on my clock from the Westward Ho casino fell off, and the hands got stuck, I knew it was time for a trip to Las Vegas. But that was just an excuse for a trip through the desert. After all, that's where time stops; the desert is just there, waiting, ever-changing, ever-not, a wind-swept museum of hope, a weird bakery of the impossible, the only place where I feel at home.

title: The Dissidents: Lech Walesa/Poland; Victorious but Not Necessarily Content
description: The Berlin Wall fell 10 years ago this week, making public heroes of the dissidents who led the resistance to Communism in central Europe. In the following pages, several of them talk candidly about their secret pasts and the world they helped create - and show they haven't lost any of their moral skepticism.

title: Mostly Dead Poets Society
description: LIVES OF THE POETS

title: Setback for a Software Giant: Key Sections of Judge's Findings of Fact
description: PRESSURING OEMs TO PROMOTE INTERNET EXPLORER AND TO NOT PRE-INSTALL OR PROMOTE NAVIGATOR

title: Q. & A.
description: Documents Needed in Co-op Sale

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-17

title: One Man's Trash Is Another's Museum
description: SIX year-old Ian Foulk stood on the 125-foot-long enclosed skywalk with his faced pressed to the glass and watched intently as the small bulldozers down below crushed hundreds of cans and plastic bottles into colorful, 20-foot high trash mountains.

title: Heisman Battle's a Draw, But Wisconsin Triumphs
description: The stakes were high. Brees vs. Dayne. The Heisman Trophy possibly on the line. When the out-of-town scores were announced before the opening kickoff, a roar erupted from the nearly 70,000 fans jammed into Ross-Ade Stadium.

title: Marbury Keeps Shooting As the Nets Keep Losing
description: As recently as last season, Stephon Marbury played like a true point guard, deftly running the Nets' offense and setting up his teammates with dozens of open shots. He put it up a lot, to be sure, attempting more field goals than anyone else on the team, but his distribution of the ball was excellent and undeniable.

title: Skip Mounds of Mulch; Let Trees Breathe
description: THERE is a planting technique appearing these days that should be corrected. This technique is the tendency to make mounds of mulch around the bases of newly planted trees. These mounds are not just a few inches, in some cases but more like a foot or more high.

title: Museum Volunteers Lovingly Restore Planes
description: IT was the early aviation version of a Ferrari, an amphibian built for the sportsman to fly off land or water. With its wheels up, it was also a boat.

title: After the Fall; The Former Enemy
description: Jerzy Urban/Poland

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday on movies about Joan of Arc misstated the title of one by Carl Theodor Dreyer. It is ''The Passion of Joan of Arc,'' not ''The Passion of Saint Joan.''

title: The Easy Way
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: By Millions, Colombians Take to Streets Against War
description: With startling swiftness and a sense of civic commitment rarely seen in this country, an organized mass peace movement is suddenly becoming an important new force in efforts to negotiate an end to civil conflict after 35 years.

title: Making Alterations For the New Dow 30
description: An overhaul of the Dow Jones industrial average was completed last week, but it caused barely a murmur in the mutual fund universe. After all, very few funds explicitly track that venerable benchmark, which on Monday dropped four issues -- Union Carbide, Goodyear, Chevron and Sears, Roebuck -- while adding four standard-bearers of the new economy -- Microsoft, Intel, Home Depot and SBC Communications.

title: On New State Standards Tests, City Students Struggle
description: The New York State Education Department released the results of new tests last week, and the smiles were scattered at best. Students across the state, especially in New York City and other urban areas, were failing to meet new higher standards and graduation requirements set out by the state.

title: Miss Cleveland, Mr. Sanzenbacher
description: Kathryn Sullivan Cleveland, a daughter of Barbara and C. E. Thomas Cleveland of Briarcliff, N.Y., was married yesterday to Alan George Sanzenbacher, a son of Joan Sanzenbacher of Waterville, Me., and Dr. Karl E. Sanzenbacher of Skowhegan, Me. Msgr. James K. Vaughey performed the ceremony at St. Theresa's Church in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOTWIN, ROSEMARIE
description: LOTWIN - Rosemarie. Dearest mother. Remembering you on your birthday and always. Love, Sean, Kelle, Dakota, and Autumn Rose

title: Bad for the Jews
description: A PEOPLE APART

title: Cryptanalyze This
description: THE CODE BOOK

title: Demetrio Lakas, 74, Panama Leader Who Had Role in Shaping Canal Pacts
description: Demetrio B. Lakas, president of Panama from 1972 to 1978 during the government of Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, died on Tuesday in a hospital in Panama City. He was 74.

title: Voters Give Incumbents Reasons to Cheer
description: THE people who are in elected office now in Westchester will, for the most part, still be in elected office in January, since Westchester voters gave Democrats another two years to control the Board of Legislators -- and control reapportionment of legislative seats -- and re-elected incumbent mayors in Yonkers, Mount Vernon and New Rochelle.

title: SOAPBOX; The N.B.A. in a Gym
description: AS the new season gets under way for the National Basketball Association, I've been hearing speculation about whether the New Jersey Nets will be a winning team this year. But rather than look ahead, I'm drawn back, to the late 70's and the brief love affair I had with the team, and the time.

title: The View From/Middletown; For State's Hindus, a New Place to Worship
description: HALF a century ago, immigrants from India were nearly unknown in Connecticut. The 1950 federal census listed their number at 333. Since then, however, the figure has grown to 11,755 in the last census count in 1990.

title: Japanese Family Values: I Choose You, Pikachu!
description: FOR those parents frantically beating the pavements to find yet another pack of $5.99 Pokemon cards, take heart: your children are unwittingly demanding a healthy dose of Japanese values.

title: John Nuveen & Company
description: WHO'S in charge of the stock market? The little guy, says Eugene E. Peroni Jr., director of equity research for defined portfolios at John Nuveen & Company, the money management firm based in Chicago.

title: Missed Opportunity On Lymphoma
description: Re ''A Doctor at Yale Spends a Lifetime Fighting Cancer'' (Sept. 19): The interview with Dr. Vincent T. Devita Jr., director of the Yale Cancer Center, seems to imply that all lymphoma is curable. As a recent patient at the Yale Cancer Center, I know from experience that this is not the case and the article was a missed opportunity to inform the public about lymphoma. To make my point I will quote directly from an article written by R. Daniel Foster in the April 1999 issue of ''Lymphoma Update,'' published by the Lymphoma Research Foundation of America. Mr. Foster writes, ''Progress in the treatment of low-grade non-Hodgkin's lymphoma has been slow, and the disease remains incurable.''

title: Setback for a Software Giant: Key Sections of Judge's Findings of Fact
description: Inducing ICPs to Enhance Internet Explorer's Usage Share at Navigator's Expense

title: Not All Are Equal
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Dissidents: Zbigniew Bujak/Poland; Victorious but Not Necessarily Content
description: The Berlin Wall fell 10 years ago this week, making public heroes of the dissidents who led the resistance to Communism in central Europe. In the following pages, several of them talk candidly about their secret pasts and the world they helped create - and show they haven't lost any of their moral skepticism.

title: Families Get Painful Look At Airplane Wreckage
description: Seven buses full of mourners pulled into an isolated Air National Guard base here today to view some of the shattered pieces of the airplane that carried their friends and relatives to their deaths nearly a week ago.

title: A Bit of Revelry for Art's Sake
description: VINCENT VAN GOGH made a scene. Matisse's five red dancers slowly contorted off the stage. Picasso was a bit stiff.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Chrysler's Sparkle

title: IN BRIEF; Cohan House Nearer To Landmark Status
description: After carefully weighing public testimony at a hearing on Oct. 27, the five-member Landmarks Preservation Commission of the Village of Kings Point unanimously adopted a resolution to recommend landmark status for the George M. Cohan house, at 99-100 Kings Point Road.

title: A Ruling on Race: A Blight on the Dream
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DODGE, GUY
description: DODGE-Guy. Died October 21. Professor Emeritus Brown Univ. Brown faculty 1941-76 & former Chair Political Sci Dept 1950-62

title: Morning Becomes Bryant Gumbel
description: I never changed channels while Bryant Gumbel was host of ''Today,'' and I welled up with tears when he said farewell.

title: Political Briefing; The G.O.P. Takes Pen to Paper
description: Democrats have always been in charge of redrawing Congressional districts in Virginia after each census, simply because Republicans have never been in charge of the Virginia legislature. But the Republicans finally snatched majority control in the elections on Tuesday, and now there's a heavy whiff of gerrymandering revenge in the air.

title: The Me Millennium
description: Slater complains that ''Prozac has made of me a simpleton.'' But as anyone who has experienced the relief it offers from the acute psychical agony of major depression knows, Prozac doesn't make you any way at all: it lets you be who you are.

title: POSTINGS: Owner Names New Hotel After His Favorite Animal; A 12-Story Giraffe at 26th St.
description: Henry Kallan has decided to name the 12-story, European-style hotel being completed at the northeast corner of Park Avenue South and 26th Street after his favorite animal -- the giraffe.

title: It's Not Chic, Not 212 and Sometimes Not Working
description: Joelle Delbourgo, a literary agent, is not amused when clients ask whether her Fifth Avenue office is in Utah. ''I say 646 is my area code and they think it's a big joke,'' she said.

title: Correction
description: A Critic's Notebook article on Oct. 24 about the George Street Playhouse production of ''Do I Hear a Waltz?'' referred incorrectly to Stephen Sondheim's 1964 musical ''Anyone Can Whistle.'' It was the third musical for which he wrote both music and lyrics, not the first. It followed ''Saturday Night'' (1954), which was not produced until 1997, and ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum'' (1962).

title: An Apple for Oprah
description: She's the queen of daytime television and one of the country's most influential readers, but now you can also call her ''Professor.'' Oprah Winfrey and her companion, Stedman Graham, an author and president of a management, marketing and consulting firm, are both dazzling students at Northwestern University this fall. They join a long line of celebrity teachers, a few even more famous than Oprah. Test your knowledge of those who have imparted theirs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENSEN, PAUL M.
description: DENSEN-Paul M. The Lautenberg Research Center of The Hebrew University of Jerusalem mourns with profound sorrow the passing of Paul M. Densen, Chairman of the Lautenberg Research Center Endowment Committee. Paul was the pioneering and outstanding leader on a daily basis for over 20 years in his service to the Lautenberg Center. His service to the Jewish people and to all of humanity had no peer. His commitment to ''Tikun Olam,'' repairing the world, and to the welfare of his fellow human beings motivated many others to follow his example, and his contributions to the eradication of cancer and other immunological diseases will be noted for generations to come. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife, Sarah Jane; his sons, Mark and Robert, and his entire family. The Lautenberg Research Center U.S. Senator Frank R. Lautenberg Founding Patron Dr. David Weiss Founding Chairman, Jerusalem Dr. Eitan Yefenof Chairman, Jerusalem Eleanore Popeck-Rigolosi Co-Chair, Executive Committee Milton Spielman Co-Chair, Executive Committee Paul Einhorn, Chairman Research Associates Society Carmi Schwartz Executive Vice Chairman

title: Setback for a Software Giant: Key Sections of Judge's Findings of Fact
description: Excluding Navigator From the IAP Channel

title: Calfskin Masquerades
description: The graphic appeal of animal patterns is never far from the mind of fashion. This fall, it's on accessories, stenciled on calf and pony skin. A new idea is the calfskin zebra-stripe bracelet, above, sometimes with matching bag and shoes. Other markings are Dalmatian and calf patterns on boots, jackets, bags and shoes. There are also status patterns, bottom left, for nonanimal enthusiasts.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If you want to work, I don't give a damn, you find work. But Germans are sheep. Why should my brother think for himself if money is being thrown at him?''

title: London
description: London in winter is lighted from within, with its own special delights. This is a Christmas city, brimming with festivities, seasonal events and holiday shopping, and even people who don't much like Christmas may find themselves carried along by the celebratory air.

title: Nancy Browne, Charles Chadwell
description: Nancy Diane Browne and Charles Kendrid Chadwell were married yesterday at St. Paul United Church of Christ in Staunton, Ill. The Rev. Richard Feyen performed the ceremony.

title: Police Chief Reassigned After Parade Dispute
description: A high-ranking police official was transferred to a lesser post after ignoring an order from a member of the Police Department's City Hall security detail during the rally for the New York Yankees at City Hall Park last month, officials said yesterday.

title: Gun Control Laws Aren't Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Bidding War To Uncork Drug Stocks
description: REDD FOXX, the comedian, once observed that health nuts were going to feel stupid someday, lying in the hospital dying of nothing.

title: Integration Anxiety
description: 'How many of you who are white think about being white all the time?'' asks Michelle Fine, speaking to a racially integrated class of seventh graders last spring at Renaissance Middle School in Montclair, N.J. Fine, a white woman and Montclair resident, is a nationally regarded social psychologist who specializes in education issues. Today she's wrapping up an oral history course she has volunteered to teach along with the school's principal, Bernadette Anand.

title: Last Stand in Defense Of a Hollow's History
description: Jim Weekley, the last litigious man in Pigeon Roost hollow, warily awaited word from Washington about how the politicians were trying to get around his big court victory, which has put this state's coal mining industry and government establishment in a state of shock.

title: Beyond Pork Buns At a Chinese Bakery
description: After nine years in the bakery business in New York, Fay Da Bakery opened its eighth location in September, this one at 83-85 Mott Street, between Canal and Bayard Streets. The company has two other locations in Chinatown, three in Flushing, Queens, one in Elmhurst, Queens, and one in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report on Oct. 24 with an article about the Atlantis resort in the Bahamas misstated privileges available to nonguests for $25 a day. The fee is for a guided tour of the resort's marine habitats; it does not allow the use of the resort's facilities.

title: It's High Time to Be Stylish and Funny
description: With her headmistress mien and plummy Queen's English, Dame Diana Rigg has served as the pitch-perfect host of PBS's ''Mystery'' series for the last decade. No one, however, would accuse this British star of putting herself on the shelf. Not with a 40-year career that ranges from the Royal Shakespeare Company to the popular television series ''The Avengers'' and back again.

title: BLACKBOARD: COPING PARTS I and II; Part II: Whisper
description: Monty Roberts, the author of the best-selling memoir ''The Man Who Listens to Horses,'' has spent five decades working with wild, unruly steeds. Now he is applying his methods to other hard-to-control charges: schoolchildren.

title: The Only Otello
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Rush to Make A Mideast Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Pink Triangles And Politics
description: As a former teacher at Brookfield High School, I have closely followed the four-year-old libel lawsuit of another teacher, Veronica Berrill, against the couple who accused her of being a homosexual recruiter. That and other absurd accusations were based on the fact that Mrs. Berrill participated in the high school's safe zones program, which simply affirmed the equality and humanity of homosexual students and shielded them from threats or derision in her classroom.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: SUNNYSIDE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRUCHTER, ISRAEL
description: FRUCHTER - Israel. Lincoln Square Synagogue records with sorrow the passing of Israel Fruchter, beloved father of our devoted Board member Steven Fruchter. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Adam Mintz, Rabbi Ken Cappell, President

title: Life, Art, Honor and Dishonor
description: ''THE entire cast acts as chorus.'' That's only a stage direction in Lanford Wilson's ''Book of Days,'' and it comes after the identification of 12 characters. But let it be a summation of the all too often forgotten concept of ensemble to which the Hartford Stage cast is giving living assurance.

title: Why We Write
description: To the Editor:

title: EgyptAir Crash May Revive Question of Universal Rules
description: Few industries have more need for a single set of rules worldwide than aviation, since airlines fly similar equipment through shared skies, over the homes and offices of unprotected civilians. The problem, as planes from 185 nations fly overhead, is who should inspect and enforce the rules.

title: Rocking the Foundations Of American Life
description: LITTLE STEVEN VAN ZANDT has always been ''a band kind of guy.'' Having said that for the first time many years ago, he left his role as a guitarist in Bruce Springsteen's E Street Band, which many fans consider one of the best rock-and-roll bands in the world, to start a solo career in 1984.

title: State to Disperse $80 Million to Victims of Flood
description: Some North Jersey residents who were victims of Hurricane Floyd's floods will start receiving checks in the mail this week, said Ed Rogan, a spokesman for the Department of Human Services. The department is overseeing the disbursement of $80 million in emergency disaster relief approved by the Legislature and the governor last month.

title: An Important Fish Becomes Scarce
description: SINCE Squanto taught the Pilgrims to fertilize their crops with menhaden, the abundance of the oily, pungent fish has been taken for granted along the Northeast coast. But during the last 10 years, adult menhaden, generally known as bunkers, have become scarce in the Northeast, affecting the food chain and causing a debate about the regulation of the menhaden fishing industry.

title: An Actor and a Director Whose Bond Was, Well, Mad
description: THE film opens with a man in the spotlight clutching a microphone. He points at the audience and shouts with ferocity, ''First, cast the beam out of thine own eye, and then the mote from mine!'' This man is not merely quoting Scripture; he is also speaking as Jesus Christ himself: ''I am not the Jesus of the official Church, whom the police, bankers, judges, hangmen, officers, church bosses, politicians and other powerful people tolerate. I am not your Superstar.'' Is he out of his mind? Is he part of some crazy cult? With the same ferocity he pushes aside an audience member who climbs onstage and tries to speak. When another spectator grabs the microphone and talks about Jesus' tolerance, the man who speaks as Jesus invokes His anger and furiously walks off.

title: Iguanas Are Mellow Pets Though Not for Everyone
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Basics and Esoterica at Hunter; Co-op Conference With 60 Workshops
description: Everything from nuts-and-bolts concerns such as avoiding renovation disasters to esoteric matters such as living with landmarking will be on the menu when the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums holds its 19th annual conference next Sunday.

title: Stand-Up Comedy, About as Subtle as a Mob Hit
description: NO one will ever accuse the world of stand-up comedy as highbrow entertainment.

title: Foreign Affairs; George W.'s Makeup Exam
description: A Boston TV reporter surprised Republican presidential front-runner George W. Bush last week with a pop quiz on foreign policy that the governor pretty much flunked. He was asked to name the leaders of Taiwan, India, Pakistan and Chechnya, and got only Taiwan right. What was scary about the interview was not that George W. didn't know all the names. It was the Quayle-in-the-headlights look on his face when he was asked for them. If I were the Democrats, I would run commercials over and over again just showing that look on his face. And the voice-over would say: ''Here's how George W. looked when he was asked to name the leaders of Taiwan, India, Pakistan and Chechnya. Imagine how he would look if he were asked what to do about them.''

title: Lawmakers Put Campaign Cash to Work in the Market
description: Campaign contributions are, by nature, risky investments, given the unpredictability of election outcomes.

title: The Role of President
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Farm, Pick Your Own Metaphors
description: EVEN before I lived in New Jersey, William Carlos Williams was my favorite poet, and not just because we have the same birthday. I always admired Rutherford's man of letters because, among other things, he knew where to find a good metaphor. Consider his 16-word poem, ''The Red Wheelbarrow'':

title: Sports of The Times; Farewell to an Old Friend and Faithful Reader
description: THE day after Pee Wee Reese died, my friend Bob Fitzpatrick called and said I had to write something.

title: Second-Home Buyers Are Going Longer Distances
description: SYLVIA POLLACK, a psychologist, travels to her pondside ski chalet in Madison, N.H., about every six weeks. She and her husband, Lee, live in Madison, N.J. (the towns' names are just a coincidence, she said). ''We had no choice about the distance because we wanted to be in the mountains,'' she said. To help pass the time while traveling, she has taken up knitting -- ''and we listen to books on tape.''

title: Nothing Behind The Wall
description: When the Berlin Wall came down 10 years ago this week, it made a lot of very smart people look very foolish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDAUER, ESTELLE SIMON
description: LINDAUER-Estelle Simon. Of Whiting, NJ, on October 31, 1999. Wife of the late Milton Lindauer. Survived by daughter Anita Weintraub, son-in-law Dr. Howard Weintraub, grandson and his wife, Marc and Jeanne Weintraub and grandson Seth Weintraub.

title: Curmudgeons on Cue
description: SEVERAL years ago, when I bought a bicycle that cost more than my first year of college, I realized that I was firmly in the throes of middle age. I look back on that purchase as an important sign.

title: Sensing Room for Growth, Home Depot Thinks Small
description: Elizabeth Bacorn was in a hurry. After selecting paint to touch up the fireplace in her Old Bridge home, Ms. Bacorn scoured the aisles of the new Villager's Hardware here for her next purchase.

title: Q&A/Tarin M. Byrne; After an Illness, Triplets Fulfill a Dream
description: AS a child, Tarin M. Byrne was convinced she had a twin who had perhaps died at birth. Her childhood imagination evolved into a long-lasting fantasy -- and the family joke -- that she would ultimately give birth to twins. But when as a teenager she was told she had leukemia, it became questionable whether she would be able to have children at all, let alone twins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DVOREN, GILDA
description: DVOREN-Gilda. Died November 4th, 1999 at age 86. Exceptionally intelligent, articulate, funny, warm, and loving, she was a wonderful aunt, as was her beloved husband, Robert (Ruby) Dvoren, a wonderful uncle. Jon Tanner and Shari Stack

title: Back by Popular Demand
description: After Baby Jane Dexter's wall-shaking interpretations of ''I Put A Spell on You'' and ''Until the Real Thing Comes Along'' at the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's fund-raiser last spring, her listeners reacted as they do not after ''Macbeth'': they stood; they stomped; they screamed.

title: A Dying Neighborhood Has Many Executioners
description: To the Editor:

title: Manhattan Morning Through the TV Looking Glass
description: Watching the morning shows, viewers share the insiders' perspective of the anchors: looking out through the windows at the crowd, occasionally stepping outdoors to join them. What image of New York City is projected through those obligatory windows? Though all the studios are clustered in midtown, like the city itself the neighborhoods and views change drastically from block to block.

title: Adventures In Expenses Accounts
description: Viewed dispassionately, expense accounts shouldn't be troublesome. In theory, someone who spends money while conducting company business simply accounts for the expense and is reimbursed. But decades of excessive creativity have bred understandable suspicion. Still, truth is sometimes stranger than fiction, and once in a while, there's a pot of gold (or at least a few dollars) at the end of the rainbow.

title: Editorial Observer; The Long Search for a Civilized Way to Kill
description: It was in 1923, just eight years before Hollywood made ''Frankenstein,'' about the use of giant blasts of electricity to jolt life from the dead, that the state of Florida began to electrocute people who had been tried and sentenced to death. Residents of rural areas like the countryside around the state prison, in north-central Florida, had yet to receive electric power. But from Florida oak, inmates at the prison made a chair, fitted with cables and electrodes, leather cuffs and straps and a metal hat. Wired to a generator, it delivered 2,300 volts, at high amperage, directly to the brain when the executioner pulled a switch on the control panel. The executioners were hooded white men, paid volunteers. The first five electrocutions were all of black men, and so were five of the next six.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUECK, BERNARD C.
description: GLUECK-Bernard C. and his wife of sixty-five years, Marie Louise Glueck (nee Howard) died recently. Both were eighty-four. They had run Stony Lodge in Ossining, New York together. He had been the Hartford Institute of Living's Director of Research and Psychiatrist at Sing Sing Prison, professor, and prolific author.

title: Albany Plan to End Parole Raises Dispute
description: FELIPE RODRIGUEZ walked into the visitor's meeting room here at the Sing-Sing Correctional Facility. His long black hair was tied back in a neat ponytail, his mustache groomed and a tie adorning his green prison uniform. A barbed-wire fence and the Hudson River glimmered in the afternoon sun outside as other inmates at the maximum-security prison talked and held hands with girlfriends and wives.

title: Amy Kusel, Steven Epner
description: Dr. Amy Beth Kusel, a clinical psychologist, and Dr. Steven Lloyd Epner, a neuroradiologist, are to be married today by Rabbi David Holtz at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Atlantic Page, M. C. McClellan
description: Atlantic French Page, the daughter of Garril Goss Page of San Anselmo, Calif., and Charles Hall Page of San Francisco, was married yesterday to Maxwell Couper McClellan, a son of Elizabeth B. Powers of Weston, Vt., and James O. McClellan of Hilton Head, S.C. The Rev. James H. Billington Jr. performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Cathedral in San Francisco. The Rev. Gordon S. McClellan, a Presbyterian minister and the bridegroom's brother, took part in the service.

title: New Tack to Fight Underage Alcohol Sales
description: INSPECTOR TONY ROCCO, commander of the Nassau County Police Department's first precinct, sees the Metro gas station and convenience store on Merrick Road in Baldwin almost every day. After all, it's only two blocks from the station house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNTFEST, IRVING JAMES, PH.D.
description: GRUNTFEST-Irving James, Ph.D. November 1, 1999, in West Palm Beach, FL, age 82. Mourned by special friend Lillian Baker of West Palm Beach, son David of Arlington, VA, daughter Eve Gruntfest of Fort Collins, CO, sister Lillian Cote of West Lafayette, IN. He was a research chemist. Contributions may be sent to Brown University Annual Fund, Providence, RI 02912.

title: Chicagoans Bid Payton Fond Farewell At Soldier Field
description: The city said goodbye today to one its greatest heroes at a public memorial service for the football star Walter Payton.

title: Abstract Objects And Realistic People
description: David Slater Mike Solomon

title: THEATER; For Some, All the Web's a Stage
description: AUDIENCES filing into the Manhattan Theater Club production of Arthur Kopit's new cyberthriller, ''Y2K,'' will undoubtedly receive a by-now-familiar set of instructions: turn off your cell phones, disengage beepers, defuse Palm Pilots and alarm watches -- in short, unwire yourself. Normally a ripple of happy sighs flows over the crowd at such moments, the patrons eager to comply with the quaint notion that the theatrical temple, if nothing else, should remain technology-free.

title: Next Move for Bogle: Boardroom to Classroom
description: John C. Bogle, founder of Vanguard Group, has always been fond of the bully pulpit. His new one is in Greenwich Village.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Milla Jovovich; She Has a Fan in Mick
description: IT was no limo. It wasn't even a car. But Milla Jovovich, the fledgling rock star, seemed not to mind perching on a wobbly amplifier in the back of a rented van crammed full of music equipment.

title: ROBERT A. LUTZ
description: ROBERT A. LUTZ, the quintessential car guy who retired as president of Chrysler and now runs the Exide Corporation, the battery maker, doesn't have room in his garage in Ann Arbor, Mich., for all his cars. Just 12 can be parked inside; the rest brave the elements.

title: For Gym Rats, A Cozy Hole
description: Gyms, Rich Barretta thinks, are either ''too fluffy or too hard-core.'' Mr. Barretta, a former Mr. America and Equinox fitness instructor, has spent his life working and working out at other people's gyms. Now, he's opened his own: Duomo, a sort of gym and social club at 11 East 26th Street. ''Fitness is our core, but members come here just to shoot pool on their lunch hour,'' he said. Mr. Barretta's 23,000-square-foot space offers sweeping views of Madison Square Park, an old-fashioned jukebox stocked with hip-hop and Frank Sinatra, one pool table, an art gallery and 20 personal trainers. Odell Lambroza, 35, an investment banker and Duomo patron, likes its nongym-gym feel enough to commute from the Upper West Side. ''I like walking into a pretty environment,'' he said. ''I never feel like a trapped rat.'' Memberships cost $1,500 a year, and a day pass is $26. KAREN ROBINOVITZ

title: Setback for a Software Giant: Key Sections of Judge's Findings of Fact
description: Giving Internet Explorer Away and Rewarding Firms That Helped

title: Can G.M. Return to the Passing Lane?
description: A JOKE making the rounds of car dealers offers this solution to America's drug problem: ''Turn the marketing over to G.M. and demand will go away.''

title: Time to Check Weatherstripping
description: WEATHERSTRIPPING is designed to close the gaps around the perimeter of doors and windows so the warm interior air cannot escape to the outside. Weatherstripping around doors, particularly around the entry door, has a short life span because the doors are used every day. Opening and closing a door wears the weatherstripping until it no longer forms an effective seal.

title: Minimalist Shoreham Adds 90 Rooms
description: The Shoreham, a hotel in midtown Manhattan that has become popular in the fashion industry for its location and chic minimalist decor, has doubled in size. The hotel, at 33 West 55th Street off Fifth Avenue, bought an office building next door and created 90 rooms and 2 suites, giving it a total of 176 rooms and suites.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; The Garbage Collector Admires His Body
description: The Irish poet Paul Durcan is quite the flirt: his best poems are long, loose and loopy, and though they demand a certain readerly cooperation, in most cases the reader will be glad to oblige. In a typical poem, the poet discovers that a waitress has written ''I love you'' on his check, though when he discloses a stanza later that she loves everybody, one takes from the page a pleasure more lasting than the momentary reward of the merely sexual. Throughout GREETINGS TO OUR FRIENDS IN BRAZIL: One Hundred Poems (Harvill, $23), there is a mateyness in Durcan's work that is never presumptuous; his speakers come across as gentle and intelligent, from a garbage collector describing pridefully his own body (''my nipples could jump over a government minister'') to a musician meditating on his strangely happy isolation as he drives home at night, ''my audience all couples canoodling behind in the village.'' Durcan, who has written for (and performed with) Van Morrison, includes many autobiographical poems here, and eventually a portrait emerges of someone who sees himself as, paradoxically, both central and marginal to his culture: following a reading in Ireland's National Gallery, a shy middle-aged couple give him a tea cozy with the words ''crazy about Paul'' stitched into it, yet earlier a man had interrupted the performance to ask, ''Where is the toilet?'' Mainly, though, this is a book of sly pleasures -- of, for example, Durcan and a friend reading lazily in a Dublin bookstore: ''Oh yes! Behind the bookshelves! / Like two haymakers siesta-ing / Behind a haycock in Provence.'' David Kirby

title: Life on the Other Side of I.B.M.
description: IS there life after leaving I.B.M.? Four former executives who voluntarily although reluctantly took early retirement from International Business Machines Corporation a decade or so ago weighed that question recently.

title: OFF BROADWAY; Finding the Right Real Estate Can Be a Dramatic Experience
description: ONE measure of the New York theater's relative prosperity these days is the number of producers looking for Off Broadway houses in which to transfer plays or present new ones.

title: Streetscapes/The 1893 Cable Building, Broadway and Houston Street; Built for New Technology by McKim, Mead & White
description: THE 1893 Cable Building marked the sudden advent of a new technology, with giant basement rollers drawing cable cars along Broadway from the Battery to 36th Street -- a $12 million investment that became obsolete less than a decade later. Now the building at Broadway and Houston Street, designed by McKim, Mead & White, is on the line that divides SoHo and NoHo, as a new rush of technology allows the owner to return the building to its cable-era elegance.

title: Those Were the Good Old Days, and So Are These
description: THOUGHTS about Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway in its early years from five people who were present (and active) at the creation in the 1950's and 60's, and a look at working there today by four members of the younger theatrical generation.

title: Disney's Great Leap Forward
description: The Walt Disney Company said it would open its third international theme park in Hong Kong in 2005. Not since China took back the former British colony in 1997 has there been so much fuss about a new arrival.

title: Assisi Church, Shattered by '97 Quake, to Reopen
description: On Nov. 28, a commemorative mass will reopen the Upper Church of the Basilica of St. Francis in Assisi, which was badly damaged in an earthquake just over two years ago.

title: No Clear Favorite Among Elite Runners
description: Of the 30,000 men and women who have entered today's New York City marathon, only 8 to 10 men and perhaps 5 women have a realistic chance to win. But even those favorites cannot agree on which of them have the best shots.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, LEO
description: COHN-Leo. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the father of its member, Yehudah Cohn. May his entire family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President

title: Going to School on Saturday, to Learn Things Hungarian
description: On a beautiful fall Saturday recently, most youngsters were enjoying the last of the good weather with their friends. But 61 young people traveled to New Brunswick, as they do every Saturday during the school year, to attend classes at the Szechenyi Hungarian Saturday School and Kindergarten.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the Hunter Group, a consulting firm that advises teaching hospitals on financial problems, quoted incorrectly from remarks by Dr. Warren Gold, chairman of the medical school faculty association of the University of California at San Francisco, about cost-cutting proposals for the merged medical centers of that university and Stanford. Dr. Gold said the Hunter Group had recommended ''a major cutback in physician practice support payments'' -- that is, subsidies given by the medical center to faculty members who provide primary care to patients there. He did not say ''a major cutback in payments from professional fees'' to finance teaching and research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHABER, DAVID
description: SHABER-David, on November 4, 1999. Beloved husband of Alice. Loving father of Samantha and Remy. Dear brother of Dr. Gary Shaber of Philadelphia, PA. Devoted uncle of Steven Shaber, Ruth Hung, Amanda, Sarah and Liza Ward. Memorial service Sunday, 2:30pm at ''The Riverside'', 76 St & Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory to The Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60 St, NY, NY 10022, or The Roxbury Land Trust, 7 South St, Roxbury, CT 06783.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.
