description: HILF-Herman. Devoted husband of Jacqueline. Beloved father of Phyllis and Diane. Cherished grandfather of Rachel, Danielle, Emily, Aaron and Rebecca. Proud father-in-law of Jerry and Elliot. He lived his life with courage and dignity-from fighting for his life in WWII to fighting cancer. His loving and generous soul is always with us. Services today 1 PM at Norman Jeffers, Ft. Hamilton Pkwy.

title: Slow Runners Strive In Fast Company
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Corporate Contributions And the Asbestos Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: The Me Millennium
description: When reading Michael Kimmelman's article ''The Lost Art of Immortality,'' I anticipated his thought that ''talent is not necessarily an issue'' with contemporary celebrity. I suppose that many of us may have contemplated this dumbing-down of our culture. It is revealing that the level of fame of a giant figure like Byron is now enjoyed by comparative nobodies like O.J. and Monica. The temptation is great to blame a dysfunctional society, yet the Regency of Byron's time was probably as trivial and decadent as our own. The only difference may be that our age readily trades the notion of community and group for individual recognition, however specious. We know more, and sadly, seem to care more about the lives of Diana and John Kennedy Jr. than about our neighbor next door who has cancer or a family member who has lost his job.

title: For Those With AIDS, a Shortage of Buddies
description: As AIDS service groups face dwindling donations, another resource that came to symbolize the gay community's compassionate response to the disease is also proving scarce: buddies.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: QUICK SHOTS OF FALSE HOPE

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: LOUIS ARMSTRONG,

title: A Purist Plies His Trade In the Heart of Bohemia
description: SHEPARD SOBEL has some truly radical notions about the theater, and if they start getting around, there's going to be trouble. ''I think the most interesting take on Chekhov is Chekhov's take,'' he says. ''I'm not going to improve on that. My basic thing is, trust the playwright and the text.''

title: Coaching Entrepreneurs for Profit
description: IN his years in Congress and in his career as a professional football player, Jack Kemp gained fame but little fortune. Now, Washington's champion of entrepreneurship and the free market is turning his preaching into practice, embracing capitalism in a more personal way: He owns high-technology stocks worth millions, he's on the boards of nine public companies, he's an adviser to two Silicon Valley venture capital firms and he's raised capital for fledgling Internet ventures.

title: Pets and Poverty
description: Having read the letter suggesting that people give up their pets and donate the money saved thereby to the poor, I have no difficulty in seeing why so many people prefer the relationship with a pet to that with certain humans.

title: Our Towns; Turnpike: Doing What It Does Best?
description: EVERY car owner eventually meets that one road in life with a personality that must be confronted or avoided, cajoled or negotiated on a daily basis. The Long Island Expressway is like the customer service representative who is supposed to help but always manages to tie you up in knots. The Cross County Parkway is like that sweet neighbor who suddenly turns ugly, then sweet again, without explanation. The Cross Bronx Expressway is simply the Soup Nazi of roads -- without the soup.

title: Vast Arizona Caves Will Open to the Public
description: In 1974, two spelunkers, Randy Tufts and Gary Tenen, set out in search of undiscovered caves in southern Arizona. After wriggling through a crawl space that was about 10 inches high and 2 feet across, the men discovered what today is known as Kartchner Caverns, a seven-acre cave system in the Whetstone Mountains, 40 miles southeast of Tucson. The caverns include two galleries the size of football fields, each with 100-foot ceilings and 26 smaller chambers.

title: Political Briefing; The Governor Speaks, And Some Jaws Drop
description: The week's prize for bluntness -- some might say insensitivity -- goes to Gov. Jim Geringer of Wyoming, a conservative Republican.

title: Ms. Martinez And Mr. Garner
description: Suzanne Beth Martinez, a daughter of Helen and Joseph Martinez of Blauvelt, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christopher Daniel Garner, a son of Theresa and Richard C. Garner of College Park, Md. The Rev. Christopher Wyvill, a great-uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title: Juror and Court System Assailed in Mistrial
description: Saying he was so angered by the outcome of the Andrew Goldstein trial that he wanted to publicly apologize, the jury foreman has lashed out at a fellow juror and at New York's court system.

title: Blocked Punts Help Columbia Get First Ivy Victory
description: Quentin Unsworth blocked two punts, leading directly to Columbia touchdowns, and the Lions held on for their first Ivy League victory of the season, 21-14, over Dartmouth yesterday at Wien Stadium.

title: Judge Reilly, Mr. McNamara
description: Judge Margaret Catherine Reilly and Vincent De Paul McNamara, a lawyer, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Patrick in Glen Cove, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas C. Costa performed the ceremony.

title: Morning Becomes Bryant Gumbel
description: Say what you will about Bryant Gumbel's arrogance and dislike of women, he's awfully good at what he does. I have missed the edge he brought to morning television. His presence is likely to shake out some of the fluff that has become a part of the format of all three networks.

title: OFF BROADWAY; Tilting Artfully: An Off Off Broadway Manifesto
description: IT'S no secret: serious new drama has left Broadway, and these days the natural home for someone doing a traditional straight play, or even a traditional musical, is Off Broadway. So what's Off Off Broadway for?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRAMER, LILO
description: CRAMER-Lilo, age 77, born in Amsterdam, Holland, died on October 22, 1999 in Boston, MA. Daughter of Ernst and Grete Laqueur, and sister of Gerda, Peter, Hein and Renata; she married Hans Cramer, moved to NY in 1947 and raised three children. She was a leader in the promotion of natural childbirth in Westchester County and an artist. Five years ago, Lilo moved to Massachusetts & found new paths and friends for living a full expressive life. She leaves Irene Cramer in Newton, MA., Sandra Cramer in Milton, MA., David Cramer in Ardmore, PA., and five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on December 5, 1999 at 1:30 P.M., at Orchard Cove, 1 Del Pond Drive, Canton, MA. 02021 with an open house the prior day at the home of Irene Cramer in Newton. Contributions may be made in Lilo's name to The Community School, PO Box 555, Camden, Maine, 04843.

title: Debra Freedberg, Jeffrey Baker
description: Debra Lynn Freedberg, the daughter of Judge and Mrs. Robert A. Freedberg of Easton, Pa., was married there last evening to Jeffrey Bruce Baker, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Michael A. Baker of Toronto. Rabbi Mark L. Shrager officiated at the Northampton Country Club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVINE, PAUL T.
description: LAVINE-Paul T. Of Fort Lee, N.J. Beloved husband of Bernice. Devoted father of Janice Bishop. Loving grandfather of Rori, Scott and Adam. Services ''Wien & Wien'', Hackensack, N.J. Sunday 9:30AM. (1-800-378-1892).

title: Marathoners Linked To the Internet
description: For marathon runners, timing is everything. Participants in the New York City Marathon today, more than 30,000 of them, will be wearing ChampionChips, tiny computer chips that keep track of their times. Issued by the New York Road Runners Club, the bright yellow plastic chips, which are the size of a quarter, attach to a sneaker's laces. As runners pass over rubber mats laid at five points in the race (the starting line, the 10-kilometer mark, the halfway point, the 20-mile mark and the finish line), antennas in the mats will pick up the signals from the chips, and the times will be computed instantly, in much the way E-ZPass works. ChampionChips have been used in marathons in Berlin, Boston and Los Angeles. In today's race, the times of the runners will be posted every 20 minutes on the World Wide Web at nycmarathon.msn.com. Race organizers predict that someday Internet users will be able to track the progress of each runner moment by moment. At the race's end, runners may either return the chips or buy them for $30 (for use in other races). And after running 26.2 miles, what's better than a good impulse buy?

title: Word for Word: Chief Executive Anger; Hell From the Chief: Hot Tempers And Presidential Timber
description: AS if presidential candidates don't already have enough tests of character to worry about -- financial impropriety, drug use, adultery -- now it seems they have to make nice as well. The Arizona Republic ran an editorial last week criticizing Senator John McCain for his ''volcanic'' temper, claiming that temperament is a legitimate campaign issue. The Republican responded by accusing the campaign of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas of helping to plant the charges against him, which first appeared in The New York Times. ''Do I insult anybody or fly off the handle or anything like that?'' Mr. McCain asked. ''No, I don't.''

title: Wisps of an Empire That Time Forgot
description: ASIANS, not knowing who or what these strangers were, called them barbarians. The intruders were Europeans with ruddy faces, insatiable curiosities and a certain amount of greed who wandered into the mysterious East in the late Middle Ages. A lot of them were Portuguese -- pious priests who first penetrated high Himalayan valleys or the byways of Japan, and storm-hardened seafarers washed ashore on the steamy beaches of South India, Ceylon, Malaya and the spice islands of Indonesia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, SYLVIA L.
description: ROBINSON-Sylvia L. On November 5, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Sol M. Robinson. Dear mother of Irwin Robinson and Carol Perlman. Cherished grandmother of Nancy, David, Sharon, Jeremy and great grandmother and aunt. Adored daughter of the late Reuben and Rebecca Lester, and sister of the late Leslie, Mildred and Cecilia. Services private.

title: The Me Millennium
description: Last names for people in much of the Western world may have come about mostly in the 18th century. However, the Celts (now Scots, Welsh, Irish and some French and Spanish) have had last-name identity for a much longer time. Names like Kennedy were not invented in the 18th century but were handed down for thousands of years by a people whose social system centered on the clan and their very personal ''me'' identity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLIWISE, RUTH (NEE OFFENKRANTZ)
description: BLIWISE-Ruth (nee Offenkrantz). Friday, November 5, 1999, of Mountainside, NJ. Beloved wife of Daniel Bliwise. Devoted mother of Donald Bliwise. Loving sister of William Offenkrantz. Dear grandmother of one. Funeral services from Temple Emanuel, 756 East Broad St., Westfield, NJ, on Monday, Novmeber 8, 1999, at 9:30 AM. Interment Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ. For information call Menorah Chapels at Millburn.

title: Liberties; Name That General!
description: There's a wonderful old Calvin Trillin essay about how he and his wife, Alice, would give each other global hot spots for Christmas.

description: THE TINY ONE

title: Even the Mayor Is Not Immune
description: Mayor Sara Bost had not repaired the wall where car thieves had slammed into her house on Eastern Parkway when it was riddled with bullets from a drive-by shooting.

description: LANTERNS

title: Gulfstream Rides Show Chavez Has Arrived
description: He was a street kid growing up in Callao, Peru. He earned nickels where he could -- at a bakery for 50 cents a day, collecting bus fares, washing cars. One day a friend took Jorge Chavez to a race track and told him he should try riding horses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOLPE, JEAN
description: FOLPE-Jean. On Thursday, November 4, 1999. Beloved wife of Morris Folpe. Beloved mother and mother-in-law of Herbert K. and Emily Folpe. Predeceased by loving son Lawrence. Beloved sister of Mary Gritz, the late Dorothy Markson and the late William Isaacson. Beloved sister-in-law of Dr. Victor Markson, Mrs. William Isaacson and Eleanor Shankman. Loving grandmother of Dr. Andrew and Anastasia Folpe and Jane Folpe. Services at Ralph Schugar Chapel, 5509 Centre Ave., Shadyside, Pittsburgh, PA, on Sunday at 2 PM. Visitation half hour prior to service (1:30-2 PM). Interment Beth Shalom Cemetery. Shiva will be observed at the home of Herbert Folpe, 2 Fifth Ave., NYC, Monday evening through Thursday. Contributions may be made to a charity of the donor's choice.

title: Blackmail Questions
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating whether contractors working on downtown renewal projects in New Rochelle were pressured into hiring minority workers, city Detective Lieut. Robert DeLeno said.

title: The Problem Of Not Being A Milestone
description: KAROL SZYMANOWSKI'S ''King Roger'' is a beautiful opera with qualities that work against its survival. Think first about the practical matters of putting any opera on. At 80 minutes, this one is too short for a full evening, and finding a suitable partner for a double bill is not easy. ''King Roger,'' if the composer's elaborate directions are followed, is complicated to stage, this coupled with the fact that in terms of theater, very little happens in it.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHANZER, BEN
description: SCHANZER-Ben. 11/2/84. In loving memory of our dear husband, father and grandfather

title: On Politics; Making Headway, Democrats Look Toward Two Big Ones
description: For years, Hamilton has been Reagan country, the home of the Republican-voting Democrats who lived in this old, inner-suburb of Trenton, worked in factories and small businesses and embodied the state Democratic Party's inability to get its point across to its own people.

title: COVER STORY; Aye, a Bit of a Donnybrook Among the Wee People
description: It took just one word to sell NBC on the idea for the two-part mini-series that begins tonight at 9: ''Leprechauns!'' Of course, its being uttered by one of the most prolific and successful mini-series producers, Robert Halmi Sr., may have helped.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, MADELEINE A. (BOBBIE)
description: THOMAS-Madeleine A. (Bobbie). On November 4, 1999. Beloved wife of William H. Thomas (Bill). Funeral Mass at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave. at 66th St, Friday, Nov. 12th, 10 AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Beyond Horror
description: To the Editor:

title: The Role of President
description: To the Editor:

title: Margarita Camacho and Lee Winter
description: GETTING in touch with Dr. Margarita Ticzon Camacho, a cardiothoracic surgeon, and Dr. Lee Howard Winter, a cardiothoracic anesthesiologist, is almost as impossible as making reservations for the millennium on St. Bart's.

title: Diva of the Difficult Song
description: Innumerable stories beneath Lincoln Center, below its stages, its dressing rooms and even its garage, Audra McDonald is at work in a vast concrete bunker, doing something that involves ancient passions, modern technology and the overarching threat of a bomb. She is singing new music, for a new Broadway show.

title: Martin a High Hopper Amid the Bad Bounces
description: If it had been snowing and windy and cold instead of fine weather every game they have played this season, perhaps the Jets would not be 1-6. They do, after all, have their cold-weather game going well behind Curtis Martin's running.

title: I Hear America Sighing
description: THE REAL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLAND, BEATRICE, PH.D.
description: FRIEDLAND-Beatrice, Ph.D. Died on Wednesday, November 3rd. Beloved wife of the late Arthur Friedland. Adored mother of Robert & Sheila Friedland and Kenneth & Jane Friedland. Loving grandmother of Jason, Benjamin, Daniel, Michael & Ari.

title: That Old Crescent Moon
description: The approach of the new millennium has made for some strange bedfellows, one of the strangest being people surfing the Internet in search of outhouses to adorn their suburban gardens.

title: Shoe Store Hoists Anchor At the South Street Seaport
description: The only things that are left at the Enzo Angiolini on 205 Front Street in the Museum Block Building of South Street Seaport are full-length mirrors, two couches back to back, and wooden shelves with a smattering of marked-down women's shoes and handbags. The store is to close Nov. 27.

title: Setback for a Software Giant: Key Sections of Judge's Findings of Fact
description: The Change in the Usage Shares of Internet Explorer and Navigator

title: Morning Becomes Bryant Gumbel
description: If Bryant Gumbel (Bill Carter, Oct. 24)wants to bring more of an edge to CBS's morning show, you can be sure that he will succeed in disenfranchising more viewers. Gumbel has always come off as cold and arrogant. If he were white, would he be getting the same opportunities over and over again? I think not!

title: THE WORLD: Toppling Dictators; Guns Don't Scare Them? Try Campaign Spending.
description: DIPLOMACY. Sanctions. Bombs. There isn't much the Clinton administration hasn't tried to rid itself of Saddam Hussein and Slobodan Milosevic. Now, suddenly, Congress is handing the administration tens of millions of dollars and demanding that it to do more.

title: Hookless Fly-Fishing Is a Humane Advance
description: The brown trout rose languidly, to an emerging mayfly barely larger than the head of a straight pin. The dorsal fin of the trout made a tiny wake on the smooth, flat surface of the West Branch of the Delaware River, a stream that had turned olive since those languid June days when the orchard grass and timothy stood pale green and waist-high in the meadows.

title: Verdict in Gay Man's Death
description: After a brief trial and 10 hours of deliberation, a Wyoming jury found Aaron J. McKinney guilty in the 1998 murder of Matthew Shepard, a gay college student who was found beaten to death and tied to a prairie fence. The verdict was hailed as a major victory by gay and lesbian groups because the judge would not allow Mr. McKinney's lawyers to use the so-called gay-panic defense to maintain that sexual abuse he suffered as a child triggered a violent reaction against Mr. Shepard.

title: Office Tower Is Planned, Without Leases Set
description: Jerry I. Speyer, the developer who owns Rockefeller Center and the Chrysler Building, wants to accomplish the real estate equivalent of reviving an endangered species: he plans to build a speculative office tower.

title: Bursting Schools Go on a Building Spree
description: AN unprecedented spurt of public school construction is under way in Connecticut. State records show that the total cost of construction projects approved by local districts in 1999 is three times what it averaged in previous years.

title: Dragging in the Mud
description: FITZCARRALDO

title: Where the Mud and the Bugs Are
description: ''HOW many of you like . . . mud?'' Anne Jaffe asked a second-grade class at Thornwood's Columbus School. A strong majority shot up their hands. ''How about bugs?'' prompted a smaller but nonetheless healthy response. Ms. Jaffe, one of the 75 volunteer educators in the County Parks, Recreation and Conservation Department's Volunteers in the Parks program, was warming up the students for a field trip two days later at the Marshlands Conservancy in Rye.

title: The Mentally Ill Emerge From the Shadows
description: A LOW point was the night a few years ago when Isaac Brown was picked up by a city ambulance after he got down on his knees somewhere in the Bronx and starting talking to a military statue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, WILLIAM
description: HALPERN-William. The office and staff of Silk and Halpern Realty Associates Inc., and Richard T. Halpern Ltd. mourn the passing of their mentor and founder, William Halpern. He is survived by his sons, James and Richard, and two grandchildren, Dyer and Hilliary Halpern. Shiva will be Monday, from 5-9 at Silk And Halpern 6 east 45th Street suite 1305 NY.

title: Toner Goes From Tragedy to Triumph
description: As Soaring Softly capped a winning comeback today in the new $1 million Breeders' Cup Filly and Mare Turf race, the trainer James Toner turned to the horse's owner and said with the relief of a man who has suffered enough, ''They can't take it away from us now.''

title: A Mutual Fund Rival on the Trading Floor
description: ANEMIC cash flows. Competition from electronic brokers. Flagging share prices for asset management firms. All in all, it is not a happy time for the mutual fund industry.

title: From Meatpacking to Candy for the Body
description: THE SETTING -- A new boutique, Jeffrey New York, on West 14th Street between Ninth and 10th Avenues. Last Tuesday night, sedans with drivers idled outside the store in a steady rain, while inside shoppers wandered through the 12,000-square-foot loftlike space. Some listened to jazz records spun by a D.J., Peter W. Suznovich. Others watched an employee watering patches of moss that ringed a cast-iron fountain.

title: Usually Silent, the Military Urges Hard Line on Chechnya
description: As Western leaders urge Moscow to move quickly to a political solution to the war in the breakaway region of Chechnya, Russian generals are pressing for an all-out military victory against the Chechen rebels, and in unusually strident fashion warning Russian politicians to get out of the way.

title: Just Wild About Horatio
description: Losing Nelson

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE LIGHTHOUSE STEVENSONS

title: U.S. Leader Urges Global Red Cross to Admit Israeli Aid Group
description: The new president of the American Red Cross, Bernadine Healy, has opened the long-simmering issue of whether to admit Israel's related aid group, which uses a red star of David as its emblem, as part of the international organization.

title: A Lesson In History
description: The article, ''Popular Images of Washington'' (Oct. 17), urges readers to visit the Senate Chamber of the Old State House to view Gilbert Stuart's majestic full-length life portrait, commissioned by the Connecticut state legislature. Visitors to the Virginia state capitol at Richmond may wish to compare it with the famous Jean-Antoine Houdon full-length statue commissioned by that legislature.

title: The Dissidents: Ilona Kiss/Hungary; Victorious but Not Necessarily Content
description: The Berlin Wall fell 10 years ago this week, making public heroes of the dissidents who led the resistance to Communism in central Europe. In the following pages, several of them talk candidly about their secret pasts and the world they helped create - and show they haven't lost any of their moral skepticism.

title: The Young Mozart's Initiation in Italian Opera
description: IN March 1770, when the governor general of Lombardy, an Italian province then under Austrian control, announced that the 14-year-old Mozart had been invited to compose an opera for one of the country's most renowned opera houses, the Teatro Regio Ducale in Milan, there was an uproar among the personnel and patrons of the theater.

title: Style; Where There's a Villa, There's a Way
description: I grew up dreaming of Italy. I reconstructed its landscape from the letters of Byron, Goethe and Stendhal, superimposed with scenes from Fellini, Giotto and men in dark suits. When my first husband asked me to marry him, I was reluctant until he added the lure of living in Italy. Despite being 16, I accepted and went off to Bologna. The two years that I spent in this ragged boot as a child bride left me longing to return.

title: Corporate Contributions And the Asbestos Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, ROSS
description: LEVIN-Ross, 84. Died November 2, 1999. Beloved husband of Helen, loving father of Martin & Wendy, cherished grandfather of Erica, Rachel, Matthew, Aaron, Michelle, Daniel, Mallory & Melanie. Devoted brother of Horty. He will be missed by all. Services today, 2:15PM, Star of David Funeral Chapel, North Lauderdale, FL.

title: A TV Quiz Show That Can Stop Traffic
description: Last Sunday, on a traffic island on Seventh Avenue, there was a sight to stop passers-by even in media-heavy midtown: a 1992 Toyota pickup covered with 53 working television sets and 400 television remote controls.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Film Screenings

title: The Teachings of Carl Jung
description: IS PART OF A WORKSHOP ON PERSONALITY DIFferences, Cheryl Oberkircher, a school psychologist in suburban Dallas-Fort Worth, gives students a personality test and then divides them into two groups. She hands each a brown paper bag and asks the children to come up with descriptions of the contents. For a recent workshop with fourth graders, the bags held terrier-shaped salt and pepper shakers. One group saw two ears, two eyes, wavy fur and holes on top. The other described wet noses, barks and a ''house pet that wasn't a cat.''

title: The Me Millennium
description: In your interesting special issue (Oct. 17), you claim that with the Renaissance came ''the rise of individual self-consciousness.'' In ''How 'I' Moved Heaven and Earth,'' Richard Russo argues that ''to the medieval mind, the individual hadn't much importance except as a tiny (albeit significant) cog in the great wheel.''

title: The Me Millennium
description: Jaded is much too mild a word for such views as were expressed in ''The Me Millennium.'' I don't know what world your writers inhabit, but let me assure these hopeless folks that there is indeed plenty of altruism, selflessness, concern for collective humankind and, dare I say, optimism for the next century.

title: Philadelphia Democrat Wins
description: As the vote tally clicked past midnight, Philadelphia came closer to ending a half-century of Democratic rule in City Hall. But finally, by dint of the party machine, former City Council President John F. Street emerged as the people's choice, just barely, with 50.2 percent of the vote.

title: Medicine Speeds Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Today's Waiter, Tomorrow's Star
description: CHEZ JOSEPHINE **

title: Single Travelers Are Being Heard
description: TOUR companies say they hear clients voice an increasing distaste for the single supplement, the additional fee for those occupying a room alone.

title: Cheryl Markus, James Lebenthal
description: Cheryl Lynn Markus, a daughter of Carol Markus of Lake Orion, Mich., and Joseph Markus of Upperville, Va., was married yesterday to James Beymer Lebenthal, the son of Jacqueline and James Lebenthal of New York. The Rev. Petero A. S. Sabune performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. Rabbi Joseph Gelberman took part in the service.

title: Charlotte Perriand, Designer, Is Dead at 96
description: Charlotte Perriand, the French designer who created furniture with Le Corbusier in the 1920's and 30's and was rediscovered as a modernist legend in her own right in the 1980's and 90's, died at her home in Paris on Oct. 27. She was 96.

title: Gore's Staff Is Finding Good 'Vibes' in Nashville
description: It is not yet clear if moving Vice President Al Gore's campaign from K Street in Washington to Charlotte Avenue here will make it ''closer to the American people,'' as he promised, or make him more likely to win the presidency, as he hoped.

title: For Employers, Pitfalls in Treating Workplace Depression
description: ASK an experienced manager about the ''reasonable accommodation'' that employers must provide under the Americans With Disabilities Act, and you are likely to hear about wheelchair ramps, Braille signs in the elevator and other physical changes to assist workers with physical handicaps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, SIGMUND
description: DIAMOND - Sigmund. Teacher, scholar, mentor, loyal friend, and man of uncompromising integrity. You were my role model of what a scholar should be. Thank you for believing in me and so many others. In sorrow and love, Astrida and your other students Vieglas smiltis

title: In the Library With: Judy Kweskin Greenfield; Passing Along to Children a Love of Books
description: IN her 25 years as children's librarian at the Rye Free Reading Room, Judy Kweskin Greenfield has seen a lot of changes in libraries and life styles. But one thing has not changed: the children.

title: In Hindsight, Mets Made the Best and Worst Trades of Last Off Season
description: The off-season had hardly begun when the Texas Rangers traded Juan Gonzalez to the Detroit Tigers. Last off-season only one player of that magnitude, Roger Clemens, was traded. The Gonzalez deal last week could be the harbinger of a whole string of swaps involving major players.

title: Hilary Nislick, Matthew Selig
description: Hilary Dara Nislick, the daughter of Paulette Resnick of Millburn, N.J., and Stephen Nislick of New York, was married last evening to Matthew Scott Selig, a son of Rochelle Levine of Rye Brook, N.Y., and Michael Selig of Cliffside Park, N.J. Rabbi Bruce Block officiated at the Plaza in New York.

title: Learning Guaranteed, Or Your Money Back
description: Nobody is talking about giving away toasters or cell phones yet, but some community colleges seem headed in that direction. A number of them are issuing guarantees that their diplomas are worth more than the paper they're printed on, offering to retrain graduates whom companies find lacking in job skills, or providing tuition-free classes if a four-year college refuses credits for certain courses. The trend has taken hold in the last 10 years at dozens of colleges, including the entire 48-campus Illinois community college system, said David Pierce, the executive director of the American Association of Community Colleges, who finds no harm in guarantees as long as colleges follow through.

title: Routed Once, Edgemont Gets Revenge and Title
description: Before last night's game, the Edgemont High School players and coaches were reminding themselves of the task at hand and the result the last time they had met Westlake. In the second week of the season, Edgemont, the defending New York State Class C champion, had been humbled by the Wildcats, 41-7, and in case anyone might have forgotten, Pete Buongiorno, an Edgemont assistant coach, had the numbers written in bold print on his baseball cap.

title: Tasty French Dressing For Babies and Children
description: Tartine et Chocolat, an elegant French children's clothing and accessories store, opened its first New York location on Oct. 30, after two years of searching for the perfect spot. ''Some were too small,'' Alvaro Roche said. ''Others didn't have enough windows.'' Mr. Roche is one of three owners of Tartine et Chocolat's American division.

title: Artax Leaves No Doubt In Record-Tying Victory
description: This time, the instructions were crystal clear for Jorge Chavez as he got set for his ride aboard Artax: ''If anyone ran on the track, run them over,'' said the horse's owner, Ernie Paragallo.

title: INSIDE
description: Australians Save the Queen

title: Ghosts
description: DONA INES VS. OBLIVION

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IZZO, FRED A.
description: IZZO-Fred A. On November 5, 1999, of Great Neck, NY. A motion picture industry pioneer. Beloved husband of Ann, dear father of Dorothy, Kathy, Karen, and Fred Jr. Adored grandfather and greatgrandfather. Visiting 3-5 and 7-9 PM today, at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, LI. Funeral Mass Monday, 9:45 AM, at the Church of St. Mary, Manhasset, NY.

title: Congress Eases Bank Laws
description: After decades of trying, Congress finally repealed Depression-era laws that limited the ability of banks to enter the securities and insurance industries. President Clinton is expected to sign the legislation shortly, ushering in a new era on Wall Street as leading institutions seek partners to become financial supermarkets.

title: Kristen Sauer, Harry Sandick
description: Kristen Katharine Sauer and Harry Sandick were married yesterday at Xavier's restaurant in Garrison, N.Y. Dr. Judith D. Wallach, the president of the Manhattan branch of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, officiated.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-07-99: Questions for Karenna Gore Schiff; The Golden Child
description: Q: When you were growing up, what music did you listen to?

title: Expand Phone Numbers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, SYLVIA
description: BERMAN-Sylvia. On behalf of the entire NYU Medical Center community, we note with great sorrow the passing of Sylvia Berman, who served as an Associate Trustee of the NYU Medical Center Board of Trustees since 1969. In 1998, she became an Associate Trustee of the Board of Trustees of Mount Sinai NYU Health. She was the President of the Lila Motley Cancer Foundation, which has generously supported cancer research at NYU School of Medicine. Mrs. Berman was a good friend and we will miss her deeply. We offer our sincere condolences to her husband, Sol Berman; her daughter, Barbara Weinburg; her son, Arthur Rosenstein; her sister, Gertrude Kurshan; and her grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Stephen M. Peck, Chairman, Board of Trustees, Mount Sinai NYU Health Robert M. Glickman, MD, Dean, NYU School of Medicine Theresa A. Bischoff, President, NYU Hospitals Center, Executive Vice President, Clinical Operations, Mount Sinai NYU Health

title: What's So Funny About New Jersey?
description: GOT discovered by an agent, got a couple of breaks. Now he's so big he performs -- where else? -- in New Jersey. They give him a hot meal. And if he survives that, they actually pay him decent money.

title: Out of Leonia, A First Novel
description: WORKING in a room of her own a few years ago, Linda D. Cirino wrote a tragic love story set in Nazi Germany even though she had been to Germany exactly once in her life: to change planes.

title: The Accommodations of Adam Michnik
description: It is a question of cabbage. Not an everyday demand at the trendy Tokyo restaurant, where Poland's nouveaux riches purr into their mobile phones as they gaze at the raw fish. But Adam Michnik, enfant terrible of the revolution that brought democracy to central Europe and sushi and the beautiful set to downtown Warsaw, wants the vegetable. In what form, however, is unclear, and as Michnik seeks to define the cabbage dish, he is transformed into a dervish. Wide-eyed, a Japanese waitress watches as a whirlwind of gesticulation and stuttering utterances -- interrupted only by long draws on a cigarette and a gulp of sake -- at last communicates the desired thing: a spicy Korean cabbage appetizer, kimchi.

title: An Art Deco Master Who Turned Iron Into Licorice
description: EDGAR BRANDT, the French Art Deco blacksmith, rarely seems to have forged an iron rod into anything but spirals, judging from the decorative and architectural metalwork he produced from 1901 to 1942. And currently there is much to see of his spiral-embellished work that once sold widely in the United States, especially in New York.

title: John McCain's Message
description: Much of the recent coverage of Senator John McCain has focused on his gains against Gov. George W. Bush and on the question of his temperament. Both subjects deserve attention, but they should not obscure another part of the McCain story. One reason his candidacy has traction is that voters seem to be responding to his old-fashioned outrage about a campaign fund-raising system that is simply legalized influence-peddling. In this sense, Mr. McCain is moving his campaign forward with an issue that, according to the barons of conventional wisdom, holds no interest for voters.

title: Latitude Adjustment
description: The Search for the

title: Lawrenceville Firm Beams Virtual Ads to 'Early Show'
description: The new ''Early Show'' on CBS has not defaced the Plaza Hotel with a scrolling advertisement. Nor has it plastered its logo on dozens of other Manhattan sites. That's the job of Princeton Video Imaging of Lawrenceville.

title: Defining Free Speech
description: Re ''A Teacher's Lawsuit: Free Speech or Libel?'' (page 2, Oct. 10): I don't get it. Why is this the question? My two children each went through four years at Brookfield High School, and on several occasions I found myself disagreeing vigorously with school policies. I had my own battles with the school authorities. But I never ever thought that having a difference of opinion about what was best for my kids meant I had a license to tell outrageous lies or make disgusting accusations about a teacher or administrator. Since when is malicious abuse of another human being ''free speech?''

title: Will Lawsuits Alone Stop Acid Rain?
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH SCHOOLS: American Soccer Odyssey; Two Promising Players From Africa Find Hope
description: The search for Bishop Dike, according to his coach, would be a simple rescue operation: drive to Philadelphia, find the sweet, freckle-faced African dreamer and persuade him to let go of his shame, return to New York to finish high school and then apply to a junior college that needed a soccer star.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: The Fall of the Year

title: Murder Is Hate
description: To the Editor:

title: A Cabbie on a Mission For Overlooked Veterans
description: When most people think of Duffy Square these days, they think of bargain theater tickets at the TKTS booth, not the army chaplain for whom the intersection was named.

title: Michielle Spector, Jason Kupferberg
description: Michielle Barbara Spector and Jason Alan Kupferberg were married last evening by Rabbi Joseph Maza at Temple Beth Ahm in Springfield, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, SHIRLEY (NEE IMMERMAN)
description: FRIEDMAN-Shirley (nee Immerman). Widow of the late Benny Friedman. Beloved sister of Janice Fox and Muriel Martin.

title: Small Firms Resisting Nasdaq Conversion Plan
description: The Nasdaq stock market's plan to become a for-profit concern is encountering some opposition from small brokerage firms worried that their interests would be overlooked in the conversion.

title: Chinatown, His Chinatown: One Artist, Two Heritages
description: JOSHUA CHUANG'S photography mirrors his exploration of ''what it means to be Chinese in America, the struggle to balance oneself between two worlds and find a sense of self.'' The photographer understands the issue: He was born in 1976 in New York City and raised in suburban Holmdel, N.J.

title: Food; Shell Game
description: Ray Tanner, the quintessential nut man of Rensselaerville, N.Y., a small village southwest of Albany, is running against the squirrels.

title: Corrections
description: An automobile review last Sunday about the new Ford Focus station wagon referred incorrectly to its engines. The car is available not only with 110 horsepower but also with 130.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Percentage of Poor Found Lower Than U.S. Average
description: The percentage of adults and children living in poverty in New Jersey is lower than the national average, ranking fifth from the bottom, according to a federal Census Bureau report released last week.

title: White Post Farm Is a Magical Place
description: I have visited White Post Farm several times. For a very small fee, it is a magic place to bring a child and one of the few places with character remaining on Long Island. It is also extremely clean.

title: Out of Hawaiian Pop, Into the Classics
description: WHEN the Wallingford Symphony celebrates its 25th anniversary next Saturday evening at 8, the audience at the Paul Mellon Arts Center will be party to an unusual event: the world premiere of what may be the only Concerto for Ukulele and Symphony Orchestra.

title: As Mexican Primary Vote Nears, Angry Recriminations
description: The governing party's first presidential primary campaign began months back as a smiling affair, with the four candidates holding their hands aloft in a kickoff ceremony, projecting comradeship and party unity.

title: Diary of a Mad Progressive
description: WAKING IN THE MORNING, BLANKETS CLUTCHED AROUND ME TO KEEP out the chill drafts - Summerhill School had no central heating in the 1950's - I would contemplate whether to go to lessons or spend the morning swinging on the rope that hung from a gigantic beech tree on the overgrown grounds. Or would I experiment with the vivid poster paints and huge sheets of paper in the art room? Sometimes I just sat in my room eating Cadbury's chocolate-cream eggs and reading.

title: Between a Comma and A Period
description: MEMORANDUM

title: Fans Should Hold Off Judging New Rules
description: Two years ago, Jeff Van Gundy was nearly fined by the National Basketball Association for saying, among other things, ''Unfortunately in the N.B.A. now, we're making up rules to hide deficiencies of players.'' The assessment did not go over well with the people entrusted with putting more panache in the game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDD, OLIVER WORSHAM, JR.
description: RUDD-Oliver Worsham, Jr. November 2, 1999. Husband of Julia Meade Rudd. Father of Caroline Rudd and Alice Rudd Elder. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Memorial service Monday, November 8, at 3:00 PM, Fifth Ave. Presbyterian Church, 7 West 55 St., NYC.

title: A Depot Is Saved, A Museum Born
description: Science City, a 55,000-square-foot science museum, will open on Nov. 20 inside the recently restored and expanded Union Station in Kansas City, Mo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARYLES, AVI
description: MARYLES-Avi. The Jewish Community Relations Council of New York extends heartfelt condolences to our esteemed Vice President Matthew Maryles on the passing of his beloved brother. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Gedale B. Horowitz, President Michael S. Miller, Executive VP

title: Geometric Composition Celebrated in Black and White
description: BRETT WESTON (1911-1993) came by his photographic ability naturally, perhaps inevitably, as the son of the early modernist photographer Edward Weston.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-07-99: Word & Image; Too Much Art
description: The mayor of New York, Rudolph W. Giuliani, has driven many of my friends to pay a dutifully supportive visit to the Brooklyn Museum to honor its right to display assorted works of schlock and shock that he deems vile and unworthy of public subsidy. Their pilgrimage has driven me to pay a grateful visit to Barnes & Noble, to locate the wise and witty words of Prof. Jacques Barzun, a former teacher who has long argued that support for the arts in the modern era has become ''an insoluble problem.''

title: Mary, Quite Contrary
description: MARY DALY RECLINED ON THE LAWN of her lakeside condominium and pondered what a tree might reveal about ''radical elemental feminism.'' Professor Daly, a 70-year-old pioneer of the women's movement, was explaining how that term, which appears in the subtitle of her seventh and most recent book, ''Quintessence,'' differs from ''essentialism,'' the label critics have long used to describe what they view as simple-minded woman worship.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-07-99; What They Were Thinking
description: Lisa Stipp, Durango, Colo., July 3, 1999

title: Control Antibiotic Use
description: To the Editor:

title: Andrea Gottsegen, Jeremy Asnes
description: Dr. Andrea Lee Gottsegen and Dr. Jeremy David Asnes were married last evening by Rabbi David Goldstein at the Audubon Zoological Garden in New Orleans.

title: Microsoft Insists It Did Nothing Wrong
description: Playing down prospects for any settlement in his company's titanic antitrust battle with the government, the Microsoft Corporation's president, Steven A. Ballmer, today explained Microsoft's fight-on strategy by invoking the wisdom of his 7-year-old son, Sam.

title: 'Stiffed'
description: To the Editor:

title: Amy Schoenberg, Michael Steinberg
description: Amy Michelle Schoenberg, the daughter of Roberta and Leonard Schoenberg of Livingston, N.J., was married last evening in Short Hills, N.J., to Michael Steinberg, the son of Fran and Burt Steinberg of New City, N.Y. Rabbi Peter E. Kasdan officiated at Short Hills Caterers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIANCAVILLA, JOSEPHINE
description: BIANCAVILLA - Josephine and James. Married 50 years, now united together in heaven. Loving daughter, Louise

title: Chicago's New Fare: French, Mexican, Flamboyant
description: IN a thriving local economy punctuated by the clamor of new construction near the Loop, Chicago is enjoying a surge in fine restaurants. French food or cuisine with strong French underpinnings is in the vanguard. In neighborhoods where Italian trattorias have long been as regularly spaced as mailboxes, everyday-priced bistros now also dot the landscape.

title: Last-Second Field Goal Dashes Lions' Title Hopes
description: Young athletes can make mistakes under pressure, and so can veteran coaches. In his 400th game as coach of Penn State today, Joe Paterno made a difficult decision that might have cost his team a chance for a national championship.

title: Brown Tide Is Found Toxic in Low Amounts
description: The brown-tide algae that has devastated scallops in the Peconic Bays of eastern Long Island may be toxic to shellfish in far lower concentrations than was previously believed, new research shows.

title: PERSONAL BUSINESS; M.B.A. Classes Casting Their Aspirations Abroad
description: FOR M.B.A. candidates at several universities, the essential new tool is no longer the latest business calculator or the fastest laptop. It's a passport.

title: A Ruling on Race: A Blight on the Dream
description: To the Editor:

title: Behind Syria's Stony Facade
description: SEEN from the outside, Syria has a rough veneer. Few Americans think of it as a tourist destination, scared off, perhaps, by its less than savory image: for years, Syria has been a member of the State Department's terrorism list. But pass through its doors, wander its souks, explore its back roads, and Syria turns out to be something very different.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, MILDRED (NEE NIERENBERG)
description: GOLDMAN-Mildred (nee Nierenberg). On November 4th, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Irving Tut Goldman (owner of Brittany Chemists). Loving mother of Stephen (Jeanine) and Seth. Devoted grandmother of Cherie and Todd. Dear sister of Ben Nierenberg and the late Clara Wolf. Aunt and great-aunt to many nieces and nephews.

title: Allies Were Nearing Kosovo Ground War
description: The United States came much closer to a ground war in Europe than is commonly understood, officials of several governments say.

title: Appeals Panel Revives Suit On Use of Dr. King Speech
description: Reversing a lower court's decision, a federal appellate court has revived a lawsuit by heirs of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. who claim that CBS violated copyright laws by broadcasting portions of his ''I Have a Dream'' speech without permission.

title: Maker of Drug Kits Fined
description: After six years of warning Abbott Laboratories about deficiencies in the manufacture of its medical test kits, the Food and Drug Administration put new restraints on the sale of products that help detect everything from the virus that causes AIDS to hepatitis in donated blood. Abbott also agreed to pay a record $100 million to settle accusations that the company failed to meet federal quality standards when it made a wide variety of test kits. DAVID BARBOZA

title: In the Region/Connecticut; 4 Finalists Vie for Coveted Site in Casino Country
description: IN 1991, when the Connecticut Department of Mental Health announced it would close Norwich Hospital, there were fears that the 70 mostly turn-of-the-century buildings on a 430-acre campus off Route 12 would sit idle for many years.

title: Queens of the Stage, One Playing a Third
description: TWO grand ladies of the theater opened on the very same night. Who said life is not beautiful? One, Julie Harris, is, thank heaven, often with us. ''I love to work,'' she says in a perfect summary of an extraordinary life in the theater.

title: Financial Aid for the Bourgeoisie
description: CHRIS CORNISH has a solid annual income of $140,000 from his own software business. He and his wife, Sandra, own three cars, including a Jeep Grand Cherokee, and live in a four-bedroom house in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRYER, RICHARD
description: BRYER-Richard. 34 years without you, my adored Richie. My heart, my love are yours till the end of time. Mom

title: They Do Everything But Take the Test for You
description: DON'T beat yourself up,'' Stuart Servetar said as he consoled the teenager in his office. He picked up a plastic squeeze ball with a tongue sticking out of the eye socket and jiggled it in front of the boy. ''You tried really hard.''

title: Batten Roses and Plant Hardy Shrubs
description: Wayward rose canes that are long enough to whip around in the wind may break or rock the shrub and weaken its hold in the ground: trim longest canes by a third or tie to fences and arbors. Cut out dead wood, but save major rose pruning for spring.

title: Lucent to Cut 1,700 Workers, Technicians and Repair People
description: Lucent Technologies of Murray Hill has urged 150 technicians and repair workers in the state to take retirement packages as part of a plan to pare down the company's work force by 1,700 jobs, or 1 percent of its employees.

title: Gun Control Laws Aren't Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Scarves Dipped In Nature's Paints
description: When Akihiko Izukura, a textile designer in Kyoto, Japan, chooses colors for his gossamer silk scarves and other accessories, he leaves no root or leaf unturned. He extracts an orange yellow from onions and a maroon from chestnuts; uses lac, a deep red insect secretion; and fixes the colors with alum or iron compounds. His palette also includes a soft beige from mugwort, a reddish brown from betel palm and a rose red from madder. These are the dyes that Hinaya, Mr. Izukura's family's company, has used since the early 1800's, when it wove silk for kimonos and obis. ''It was traditional to make kimonos and obis, and sell them to the royal family in Japan,'' said Kae Yoshino, Hinaya's American representative. Since the 1970's, Mr. Izukura, 56, has designed modern products from naturally dyed silk. Last month, he introduced scarves ($225 to $300), gloves ($20), rugs ($3,200 to $4,200) and obis ($980 to $2,800) at Dimson Homma, 20 East 67th Street; (212) 439-7950. ELAINE LOUIE

title: BENEFITS
description: A Century Onstage

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NORWICK, DOUGLAS J.
description: NORWICK-Douglas J. Your star shines brightly and your spirit dances on. Always love. Herbert J. Baker

title: Pets and Poverty
description: I was stunned by the letter (Oct. 3) submitted by Rita Delapa of San Diego in response to the Sept. 5 article ''The Singer Solution to World Poverty.''

title: Sin of Omission
description: To the Editor:

title: If You Look Real Carefully, You'll Spy 'I Spy' in Winsted
description: IGNORE the battered steam roller, chain link fence and potholed parking lot that lead to the unlikely scene of one of the more surprising success stories in American publishing. From a defunct knitting mill in Winsted, the photographer Walter Wick has created the ''I Spy'' series of photographic picture riddle books for children that have them and their parents searching for clues embedded in one elaborate scene after another.

title: Beneath the Lawns, Seeds of Discontent
description: SOME shows stick in the mind. For example, ''World War II and the American Dream,'' an exhibition presented in 1994 at the National Building Museum in Washington, strongly influenced my view of suburban development. The show documented in detail how wartime industry was retooled to create the economic infrastructure of the post-war consumer society. Talk about the ghost in the machine! Beneath the malls, the lawns, the garages lay this subterranean realm of bombers, explosives and tanks. I thought about the show earlier this year on reading news reports of violence at high schools in suburban Littleton, Colo., and Conyers, Ga. Could it be that this militaristic past had come back to haunt the American dreamland superimposed atop it?

title: Leaving the Farm for the Other Real World
description: TO Scott Halley, there was never any question that he was meant to be a farmer, his life forever set to the rhythms of planting and harvesting wheat.

title: The Waiter in the Dinette
description: Intimate dinner parties have become a bit less intimate this season as the sight of hired waiters has become more common, even for gatherings of two or four people. ''Whether I'm entertaining one couple or 25 couples, there's an element of pressure,'' said Liz Lange, a maternity clothing designer whose time is consumed just now with opening a Madison Avenue store in February and caring for her year-old son. ''Hiring a waiter means that I can come home, spend time with my baby and not rush around in a panic. These days, it's fairly standard to see waiters at small gatherings. It's not pretentious, just practical.'' Aaron Armijo, owner of Waiters on the Run, a company that provides household workers, says customers are often surprised by how affordable a waiter can be. (He charges $21.50 an hour for each waiter for cocktail parties, and $25 for sit-down dinners.) And they are willing to spend money if it buys them time. ''It used to be that mom cooked all day for dad's clients or friends,'' said Mr. Armijo, whose waiters have served working women like Katie Ford, chief executive of Ford Models, and Yue-Sai Kan, who has a line of cosmetics in China. ''But now,'' he added, ''mom works, and often, the clients are hers.''

title: The Dissidents: Laszlo Rajk/Hungary; Victorious but Not Necessarily Content
description: The Berlin Wall fell 10 years ago this week, making public heroes of the dissidents who led the resistance to Communism in central Europe. In the following pages, several of them talk candidly about their secret pasts and the world they helped create - and show they haven't lost any of their moral skepticism.

title: Skipper Is Seeking America's Cup and Popular Appeal
description: Paul Cayard's vision for the future of the America's Cup is simple: he wants it to play in the heartland. With his high school hoops background and a thorough grasp of the sporting spectrum, he believes, ''If some guy in Topeka, Kan., is channel surfing and finds an American team racing a Japanese team in a windy, neck-and-neck battle in some scenic location, he's going to get into it even if sailing isn't his thing.''

title: Marathon's First Finisher, Ever
description: Gary Muhrcke won the first New York Marathon on a hot day in September 1970. Only a few hundred people lined the route, which was then entirely within Central Park. Just 127 runners answered the starter's gun, with 55 still running at the end. Nina Kuscik, the sole female entrant, dropped out before reaching the finish line, but was the top woman in 1972 and 1973.

title: Casting New Light On the Most Visible Of Playwrights
description: LIVING-ARTIST retrospectives are as rare as small egos in the theater, but as it happens, New Yorkers are enjoying two this year. The unique Signature Theater Company, which dedicates its season to a single playwright every year, is focusing exclusively on Maria Irene Fornes. And the Atlantic Theater Company has devoted its entire season to the works of its co-founder David Mamet.

title: Siblings' Lives Trace a U.S.-German Divide
description: On March 15, 1960, an 18-year-old German girl and her younger brother boarded a train here to escape East German Communism for the West. But the police were patrolling and the girl, convinced they could not make it together, pushed the boy off the train as it started to move.

title: Today, The Musical Dies
description: Clearly, Innaurato has become so enraged with the current state of musical theater that a rebuttal feels like a deeply futile exercise. I can only say that I'm glad I didn't read his article when I was a boy falling in love with the theater. I'm even more grateful that, reading it as an adult, I'm armed with the clarity to realize that what he writes is utter nonsense. It's one thing to lament the commercialization of an art form. It's another to dance on its grave.

title: Lives; Off the Books
description: My decision to leave the corporate world and sell books on Sixth Avenue in Greenwich Village was incomprehensible to my family and friends. Early on, a former co-worker spotted me standing behind my book table one evening and asked in a tone of comic disbelief, ''So this is what you're doing now?'' ''No,'' I replied, embarrassed. ''I'm just watching the stuff for a friend of mine. He went to the bathroom.''

title: Warhol: The Herald Of Sampling
description: MENTION Andy Warhol's relationship to pop music, and the first name to crop up will be that of the Velvet Underground, the band Warhol championed in the mid-60's. In fact, Warhol's art and ideas didn't find musical expression until the Velvet Underground was long defunct. The arts don't evolve in temporal lock step, and it wasn't until the mid-80's, largely because of advances in technology, that pop music began to explore the territory Warhol had opened up long before. Today, the connections between Warhol's ideas and pop music -- especially electronica and hip-hop -- have only deepened, offering one more strand of evidence that Warhol, far from being the poseur and opportunist many still consider him, was an artist and thinker of uncanny prescience.

title: Julie Armour, Thomas Jones
description: Julie Hume Armour, a daughter of Karen and James Armour of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Thomas Calvin Jones, a son of Peggy Jane Jones of Pitman, N.J., and the late Harry E. Jones. The Rev. Laura J. Ahrens, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the St. Luke's Parish in Darien. The Rev. Dr. Philip M. Jones, the bridegroom's brother and a Presbyterian minister, took part in the service.

title: Dividends Are Fading As Market Signals, Too
description: OF all the market-timing models that failed to anticipate the extraordinary stock bull market of this decade, the most spectacular failure has been the one that is based on dividend yields.

title: Op-Art; 1999 New York Marathon Advertising Opportunities!
Los Angeles Drug Case Bars Medical Marijuana Defense
description: In a July 1997 raid, police officers and federal agents here found more than 4,000 marijuana plants in a Bel-Air mansion known as the castle, near the home of Ronald Reagan, whose administration created the ''zero tolerance'' approach to illegal drugs.

title: About the Creation Of 'Book of Days'
description: THE playwright and the director have independent identities, each having achieved distinction without the other. Yet they go together. It is hard to think of the director Marshall W. Mason without play after play by Lanford Wilson leaping to mind.

title: For Employers, Boom Economy Puts Odds in Job Seekers' Hands
description: LISTEN to some employers complain and you'd never believe that happy days continue to bless Long Island's economy.

title: Gun Control Laws Aren't Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Predictions And a Nice Profit Too
description: ASTROLOGY, divination, and things metaphysical have been around since the dawn of civilization, but interest in finding answers to the mysteries of life -- either from the movement of stars or from a psychic hot line -- has increased dramatically in recent decades. Still, to run a business selling aids to those seeking such guidance -- and to make money from it -- may be as startling as the revelations the sellers promise their customers.

title: Broadway Doesn't Live There Anymore
description: FOR one brief, shining moment, and it really wasn't much more than that, there flourished on the island of Manhattan a bold and glittering realm of theaters, or so legend has it. It was called Broadway, in reference to the arterial avenue that ran through it. And those who are old enough to remember swear that there was a time when this neighborhood comprising 40 square blocks held up the most scintillating of all cultural mirrors to the urgency, energy and impudence that was New York.

title: Labor Wields Leverage in a Giuliani-Clinton Senate Race
description: Labor unions overwhelmingly backed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's re-election in 1997, but now they are not only tilting strongly toward his likely Senate opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton, but also hoping to use the Senate race to squeeze more out of the mayor in contract talks next year.

title: A Most Unlikely Murder Scene
description: Two more workplace shootings left seven people dead in Honolulu and two in Seattle. The killings, coming so soon after nine people were shot to death in two stock trading firms in Atlanta in July, left many Americans feeling slightly numbed, even as the victims' families and the communities involved struggled to recover from the seemingly inexplicable crimes.

title: Made in the U's of A: Designs for Real Life
description: Last spring, Allen Taflove, who teaches in the Engineering, Design and Communication Program at Northwestern University, posed this problem to his students: You're alone in the desert, you break a leg and you can't get any reception on your cell phone. So what do you do? The freshmen responded by designing an antenna that boosts reception in remote places.

title: But Does It Work?
description: We run from one fad to another in education, from phonics to whole language and back to phonics, from subject-based to holistic learning, from curriculum-based to child-centered learning, from neighborhood to magnet to charter schools, from old to new to whole math, from English-only to bilingual education to language immersion.

title: Sit, Roll Over, Strike a Pose: The Dog as Fashion Plate
description: IT was just after 2 p.m. last Tuesday, and William Calvert, a 30-year-old designer of the kind of clean-looking evening dresses that fashion editors invariably call modern, was waiting for his next fitting. An assistant to the designer sat hunched over a phone, rolling her eyes. Seems there was a problem with the security guard downstairs. A little matter of building policy: no dogs allowed.

title: Finding Words to Rate the Eats and the Eater
description: EVERY time I eat a restaurant meal, I want to be a restaurant critic. Dining out on Long Island is always such a unique and, if one survives, memorable experience that it seems a shame not to share it with a wider audience. Critics also get better service. Here's a little trick I have learned. Place a small notebook on the table and write a few lines from time to time, frowning over the wine, or looking censoriously around for your long-vanished waiter. If the management is actually present and awake, the service may improve 100 percent, although there may not be much they can do about the food.

title: Woods Near Leaders In Pursuit of 4th Straight
description: He did it with typical Tiger Woods flair, making birdie putts on each of his final two holes. Suddenly, Woods was just one stroke off the lead. Suddenly, the possibility increased that Woods might win his fourth consecutive tournament, something that has not been done on the PGA Tour in 46 years.

title: Gun Control Laws Aren't Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Urging Hair To Grow
description: Gone are the days of bingeing on Knox Gelatin to grow thicker, shinier hair. Now, two new French imports are selling hope to the hair-impaired with products that claim to enhance eyelash, eyebrow and hair growth. Talika, the French cosmetics line, has arrived at Saks Fifth Avenue stores with Eyebrow Lipocils ($30 for seven milliliters) and Eyelash Lipocils ($35 for 10 milliliters). They are ''conditioning gels'' made of plant extracts that the company says were originally used to treat burn victims and found to stimulate hair growth. Talika says the products will make eyelashes and eyebrows grow 0.5 to 2.5 millimeters longer, or 0.002 to 0.01 of an inch, within a month. Also new to the American market is Viviscal, a French ''hair pill'' popular with European models and fashion editors. Made of fish protein and vitamin C, the pills are supposed to make hair longer and smoother in six months. A one-month supply of 60 tablets is $79 at Clyde Chemists, at Madison Avenue and 74th Street, or from (800) 318-3934. ''Nothing's been scientifically proven to make hair grow longer,'' said Dr. Fred Brandt, a dermatologist in Manhattan and Coral Gables, Fla. ''But there are some natural ingredients, such as vitamin C, keratin, that are healthy for hair growth. And whatever length it is, healthy hair is better-looking hair.''

title: Thirsty? Not So Fast.
description: The New York City Marathon has been a fixture so long that all runners know the drill. They do their 20-mile training runs, eat their pasta, explain to acquaintances that no, really, they're not crazy, and tell friends exactly where to stand today for that inspirational wave and holler.

title: Penguins Hailed
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE WORLD: The Ascent of Man; What's It All About, Alpha?
description: ALPHA males dominate wolf packs, boss baboon troupes and lord it over harems of elephant seals. Like other mammals, human groups also foster alpha males. But though the leadership abilities are valued, many societies are uncomfortable with other alpha traits, like aggressiveness, temper tantrums and indiscreet expression of the drive that spurs the pursuit of alphadom in the first place -- sexual access to plenty of women.

title: Anne Hutchins and James Orsi
description: Anne Robbins Hutchins, a daughter of Waldo Hutchins III of Glen Head, N.Y., and the late Marion Joan Adams Hutchins, was married last evening to James Monell Orsi, the son of Joyce B. Orsi of Granville, Mass., and C. James Orsi of Waterford, Conn. The Rev. Gwen W. Sears, an Episcopal deacon, performed the ceremony at the Meeting House, a former church in New Marlborough, Mass.

title: A Snapshot of World Faith; On One Queens Block, Many Prayers Are Spoken
description: It is an ordinary Sunday morning on Bowne Street.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-07-99: Salient Facts; Suite Dreams
description: WHERE DID LUXURY BOXES COME FROM?The so-called Eighth Wonder of the World -- better known as the Houston Astrodome -- introduced the luxury-box concept in 1965. These first boxes were located so high above the field that even nosebleed aficionados might object, and were quite spartanly appointed too. In the years since, as team owners have got hooked on luxury-box revenues, accommodations have become much more lavish. It won't be uncommon to see hardwood floors, Oriental rugs and marble bars. But, strangely, a private toilet is no longer de rigueur. ''Some people think that it's not private enough to go into the toilet with everyone right there,'' explains Bernardo Fort-Brescia, of Arquitectonica, the design firm that collaborated with architects from HOK Sport on Miami's new American Airlines Arena and on Philips Arena, in Atlanta. So in Miami, luxury-box patrons commune in a shared restroom down the hall.

title: An Artist's Own Race to the Finish
description: A lone figure amid a whir of runners and cyclists, Adam Kaufman sat on Park Drive at West 67th Street, brushing yellow strokes of paint on the asphalt. The eight-foot Police Department badge he was painting was one of seven emblems that will adorn the finish line today at the New York City Marathon.

title: In One Stop, Kmart and Health Insurance
description: On the day before Halloween, Miguelina Vasquez went to the Kmart here to find costumes for her two children. On the way over to the aisle with the vampire masks, she stopped to sign up the children for government-financed health insurance.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: In Nassau, the Millennium Comes Early; The Budget Triggered One Voter Revolt, and There May be More in Store
description: THE key to the revolution that took place in Nassau County's voting booths last week -- and the key to much of the political maneuvering likely to captivate county government for the next two years -- can be found at a storefront office a couple doors away from the Dunkin Donuts on Merrick Road in Bellmore.

title: Farms Where Turkeys Are Raised to Be Gobbled
description: ''HELP WANTED'' reads the sign hanging outside Ronny Lee's farm market in Hightstown. This is the time of year when Mr. Lee anxiously seeks extra hands to help him perform an unsavory but necessary seasonal chore. ''We hang the sign up, but we don't say what it's for,'' he said. ''People come in and inquire, and then we'll break it to them.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENDAL, SEYMOUR
description: GENDAL-Seymour. 73. Of colon cancer. Life partner of Phyllis for 47 years. Loving father of David and Ellen Gendal, Boca Raton, FL., and Leslie & Mark Lederman of Scottsdale, Arizona and the late Keith Barry. Adoring grandfather of Drew and Jocelyn Lederman & Eric and Alex Gendal. Services Sunday, November 7 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue at 12 P.M. Please, no flowers.

title: A Few Waves of the Deal-Making Wand
description: Deal announcements were flying like rabbits out of deal makers' hats last week. Or perhaps it was just an illusion; after all, it has been a few months since there was such a cluster of activity.

title: Uncovering Beauty in Ordinary Noise
description: IT is a sultry, sticky afternoon, but in the quiet corner of the trendy Third Arrondissement where the Finnish composer Kaija Saariaho makes her home, her thoughts drift toward snow, the sea and lofty ideas: natural, perhaps, for a daughter of the Nordic lands.

title: Where Even The Flops Have Zest
description: THIS month is an anniversary of sorts: the beginning of the seventh year I have been covering theater as a regular beat. Not the least of the discoveries for a man who had been made numb after decades of total immersion in films: that Off Broadway (including Off Off Broadway) is not just an alternative New York theater, but virtually the entire New York theater. Colleagues, of course, have been announcing this for years. Yet that realization came to me with the kind of shock you're supposed to experience only while watching a fiery, 12-car pile-up in a $70 million Mel Gibson movie.

title: Body of Child Missing 20 Years Is Found in Mother's Home
description: A 60-year-old woman who neighbors said often complained of hearing the phantom cries of a baby at night was arrested yesterday after the police discovered her young daughter's body in her Brooklyn apartment, wrapped in plastic and hidden in a footlocker. The woman was charged with murdering the girl, who disappeared 20 years ago.

title: The -------- That Changed My Life
description: Consultants charge up to $300 an hour to help prepare and polish it, and $60 for a quick appraisal. Prep schools offer a weekly class throughout the fall to conceive, draft, rewrite, revise and edit it. Parents ghostwrite it and get secretaries to type the final version, spell-checked and grammatically correct, on 24-pound bond paper. Students who write it without assistance experience what William Hiss, the former dean of admissions at Bates College, calls myopic paranoia: ''I don't know why they are asking that question, but I know they are out to get me.''

title: A Place for Big Appetites in Tarrytown
description: THINK of Ruth's Chris Steak House and think big: worldwide franchise, capacious dining hall, extensive bar and roomy lounge, mighty cuts of meat, colossal lobsters, lofty prices. Food here is not delicate, but then this is not the place for delicate appetites, which must be big as well.

title: After Killings, Denver Streets Strike Fear In Homeless
description: His muscles tightened as he talked about life on the streets. He admitted he was afraid. ''You have to look around every corner now,'' Tom Hollis said. ''Especially when it is getting dark.''

title: Film at 11
description: REPUBLIC OF DENIAL Press, Politics, and Public Life. By Michael Janeway. 216 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $22.50.

title: Sallie Judd and Justin Abelow
description: Sallie Matthews Judd, a daughter of Ruina W. Judd and Ardon B. Judd of Albany, Tex., was married in Washington last evening to Justin Douglas Abelow, a son of Angela P. Abelow of New York and Herbert B. Abelow of New Marlborough, Mass. The Rev. Margaret M. Graham performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Georgetown.

title: The Dissidents: Jirina Siklova/Czech Republic; Victorious but Not Necessarily Content
description: The Berlin Wall fell 10 years ago this week, making public heroes of the dissidents who led the resistance to Communism in central Europe. In the following pages, several of them talk candidly about their secret pasts and the world they helped create - and show they haven't lost any of their moral skepticism.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the mayoral race in Peekskill misstated the number of years since the city has had a Democratic mayor. It was 18, not 38; Fred J. Bianco, a Democrat, served three terms as mayor, from 1976 through 1981.

title: Political Briefing; First in the Heart Of Governor Bush
description: Whether or not Senator McCain competes in the Iowa caucuses, Governor Bush says he is not competing in Louisiana's caucuses. No way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASUS, EDWARD
description: LASUS-Edward. 90 years old. Died October 29, 1999. Beloved husband of Helen & sons Robert, Richard & Howard & sister Clara Dorn Perrotti. A man with a sense of purpose, a smile and a helping hand for his fellow man.

title: In Convertibles, a Path To Technology Stocks
description: TECHNOLOGY has been the undisputed champ of the bull market. But investors seeking a slightly less risky way to jump into the sector may want to consider convertible bonds.

title: I'll Cut My Throat Another Day
description: SELECTED LETTERS

title: After Complaints by Actor, Group Will Sue Taxi Panel
description: Three days after the actor Danny Glover protested that he had been passed by and treated rudely by New York City cabdrivers, State Senator David Paterson and the Rev. Al Sharpton said yesterday that they were organizing a class-action lawsuit charging the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission with racial discrimination.

title: Setback for a Software Giant: Key Sections of Judge's Findings of Fact
description: Following are excerpts from the findings of fact issued Friday by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson in the Microsoft antitrust case:

title: The Quality Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The table of contents on Oct. 24 misspelled the surname of the author of an article about the designer Donna Karan. She is Pilar Viladas, not Viladis.

title: Order in the Court! A Revolution Is on Trial.
description: HIGH on the slopes of the Alborz Mountains above the smog-choked heart of Tehran, million-dollar townhouses and condominiums have sprung up just below the sprawling estate that housed the shah's winter palace. Here, in the suburbs, is the Beverly Hills of Iran, an area of high, white walls that give onto homes with magnificent panoramas, lush gardens and swimming pools. It is a surreal setting, the kind Antonioni might have chosen for a film, encoded with messages about the very strange society Iran has become after 20 years of Islamic rule.

title: Setback for a Software Giant: Key Sections of Judge's Findings of Fact
description: Excluding Navigator From the OEM Channel

title: Microsoft's Horizon
description: For more than a year, the Microsoft Corporation has been untarnished on Wall Street and on Main Street from the government's relentless antitrust assault on the company. But suddenly, it may begin feeling some pain as investors and the computer industry consider the likely impact of the blow delivered on Friday evening by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson.

title: On Tense Visit To India, Pope Tells Bishops To Evangelize
description: After blessing the memorial at Gandhi's cremation site, Pope John Paul II today told Roman Catholic bishops in Asia to respect other religions, but not to lose sight of their ''call to conversion'' in the next millennium.

title: Group to Retrieve Gear Near Crash Site
description: The National Transportation Safety Board settled a potential dispute on Friday with a group of New England lobster fishermen whose members have been barred from retrieving their gear since last Sunday, when EgyptAir Flight 990 crashed.

title: Cat Thief Wins the Classic and Wreaks Havoc
description: On a day when records fell, winning and losing streaks ended and long shots reigned, the 16th Breeders' Cup ended with one final surprise today when Cat Thief won the $4 million Classic at odds of 19-1 and threw the race for Horse of the Year into total confusion.

title: Renaissance for a 'Lightweight'
description: WHO was the most popular American artist of the century? Norman Rockwell, obviously.

title: DEALS AND DISCOUNTS
description: EARLY TO CRUISE -- The Delta Queen Steamboat Company has an early booking discount of $800 a couple for next year's trips on its newest riverboat, the 161-passenger Columbia Queen, which is scheduled to make its debut March 31 in the Pacific Northwest. The offer applies to cruises throughout 2000 booked with a deposit six months or more in advance. The Columbia Queen will make seven-night cruises on the Columbia, Snake and Willamette Rivers traveling from Portland, Ore., to Astoria, Ore., and then eastward to Lewiston, Idaho. Rates range from $1,985 to $2,985 a person, double occupancy, before the discount, and include many shore excursions and a night's hotel stay in Portland, but not port charges and taxes. Air fare is extra. Information: (800) 297-3960. On the Internet: www .columbiaqueen.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSEN, CHARLES A.
description: JOHNSEN-Charles A. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Charles A. Johnsen, associated with The Times from 1973 until retiring in 1980.

title: Governor Will Sign Bill To Aid Gettysburg Monuments
description: Thirteen monuments dedicated to the New Jersey soldiers who fought at Gettysburg, which are beginning to show wear after years of marking historic spots on the battlefield, are to be refurbished with $55,335 in state money.

title: Treasures of Maharajah In San Francisco
description: A comprehensive international exhibition examining the artistic traditions of the Punjab under Sikh rule is on view at the Asian Art Museum of San Francisco until Jan. 9. ''The Arts of the Sikh Kingdoms'' features more than 160 rarely seen objects drawn from 19 public and private collections in India, Pakistan, North America and Europe.
