title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARPF, SEYMOUR
description: KARPF-Seymour. On November 5 in Pompano Beach, FL. Loving husband of Shirley (Kanarek), after 60 years of marriage. Mourned by son, David; grandchildren and brother, Horace. Services Sunday, November 7 at 9:30AM, Frank E. Campbell, 81st St. and Madison.

title: Joey's Sidekick, Kathie Lee's Pal, Man of the Hour
description: HERE'S the question: Now that Regis Philbin has a prime time hit all his own, is he beginning to contemplate life without Kathie Lee Gifford?

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-07-99: Counter Culture; The Assault on Good News
description: I was gamely sitting through the second bone-crunching, blood-gushing hour of ''Fight Club'' the other night when I found myself involuntarily wondering how much damage the movie was doing to society. For most Beltway types, this is a sadly automatic spasm. A similar thought tends to flit through my mind when watching a late night rerun of Jerry Springer, or the latex melodrama of cable wrestling. After Tipper Gore and Bill Bennett, watching mindless violence just isn't any fun anymore.

title: Political Briefing; Is McCain Doing Double Take at Iowa?
description: Given the way his poll numbers keep inching up, is Senator John McCain having second thoughts and now considering a leap into the Iowa caucuses? Mr. McCain has said for months that he will not compete in Iowa, having only limited resources and having made few friends in the state with his opposition to some subsidies that benefit its corn farmers.

title: The Dissidents: Jens Reich/Germany; Victorious but Not Necessarily Content
description: The Berlin Wall fell 10 years ago this week, making public heroes of the dissidents who led the resistance to Communism in central Europe. In the following pages, several of them talk candidly about their secret pasts and the world they helped create - and show they haven't lost any of their moral skepticism.

title: Go Form a Company, Mamet Said, So They Did
description: HOW does a nonprofit Off Broadway company measure its success? In the case of the Atlantic Theater Company, the answer may go back to the Stoics. ''We measure what we do against our larger guiding principles,'' says the group's artistic director, Neil Pepe. ''We talk about the Stoics believing in 'Do your job. Treat the endeavor with respect.' These principles are what we return to, even after all our recent perceived major successes.''

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: The Musical (and the Clothes) That Refused to Die
description: LET us now honor New York's multicultural roots, kosher-style. The immigrants from Russia, Poland, Latvia, who got off the boats on Ellis Island in 1910 expected to find streets paved with gold, it has been said. What is not said, but presumably understood, is that there was no gold. Sometimes there were not even streets, and the immigrants were expected to pave them. And they were always expected to do it right.

title: A Summer at Sea
description: THE VOYAGE

title: When New York Is on the End of the Line
description: WENDY FORSEEN had breezed through the training classes on diction and questioning techniques and was about to earn her headset as a pollster at Teleforce Research Group, a national telephone polling company in Fargo, N.D. But there was one last trial in her two-week training session.

title: THE NATION: No Fare; New York's Cabbies Show How Multi-Colored Racism Can Be
description: IT may be the most blatant form of racism in New York City: a cab driver refusing to pick up someone who is black.

title: Joined at the Stoop: Neighbors Till the End
description: Mornings begin on West Hagert Street at 7, when Dorsha Mason, 80, crippled and bent by phlebitis and arthritis, rises from bed in the row house of the North Philadelphia neighborhood where she has lived for more than half a century, inches her way across her living room with her walker and opens her front door.

title: Rutgers Misses Shot At a Victory
description: Brian Madden darted past the lunging Rutgers defenders early in the first quarter today. And as Madden, a sophomore quarterback, slid into the end zone, the Scarlet Knights' hopes of winning this season slipped further away.

title: Ms. Bradbury And Mr. Pape
description: Barbara King Bradbury, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Bradbury Jr. of Pinehurst, N.C., was married yesterday to William Bolton Pape II, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Pape II of Woodbury, Conn. The Rev. Steven McGuigan performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Stockbridge, Mass.

title: A Paris Arts Festival That Looks Outward
description: INTERNATIONAL arts festivals usually offer eclectic programs of music, dance and theater meant to squeeze maximum excitement into a few weeks. Thus, if Salzburg, Edinburgh or Lincoln Center in New York is any guide, festivals often become ends in themselves: they, rather than their host cities, are the stars. And at least in Europe, which is home to hundreds of arts festivals today, they busily compete with one another for attention and acclaim.

title: A Study in Contrast: Photos and Sculpture
description: WHAT does a retired designer and a politician concerned with the environment have in common? They are both having one-man exhibitions at the Garrison Art Center here.

title: The Me Millennium
description: The photograph accompanying Lauren Slater's article ''Prozac Mother and Child'' was a devastating indictment of the Prozac culture: a rigid mother holding her infant up for inspection like an object, without the slightest hint of any emotional connection!

title: Gell-Mann at Yale
description: To the Editor:

title: The Me Millennium
description: David Samuels's extraordinary essay ''In the Age of Radical Selfishness'' movingly captured the philosophical ennui of my generation. Those of us with expensive educations and high-paying jobs seem to live in a kind of aimless emotional universe. I have often wondered why my friends and I work so hard. To afford a co-op? To eat in restaurants every night? To buy Prada coats and Kate Spade bags? All these things to buy and nothing to talk about but ourselves and what we want. Solipsism at its best. And depressing as hell. If individual gratification is the only goal, then we are left with nothing but ourselves -- and a very lonely planet.

title: Germans and Jews Look to Future
description: WITH skepticism, curiosity and at least one case of sweaty palms, about 100 Jews -- including some whose parents were Holocaust survivors -- came to dinner here Wednesday night to exchange thoughts and feelings with 27 high-ranking German officers, some of whom said they had never been in a Jewish home before.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAYER, DORIS L.
description: DRAYER-Doris L. On October 31, 1999, my wife, sweetheart and best friend for 49 years departed. Mother of Michelle and the late Steven J. Drayer, grandmother of Emily, William, Caroline; sister of Allan Feuer. I have not the ability to express in words my sorrow and love of this extraordinary lady I was married to. Rest well, my darling. Sonny

title: Microsoft's Friends Rue the Findings, Its Foes Relish Them
description: James L. Barksdale, the former president of the Netscape Communications Corporation, was the first witness to take the stand in the Microsoft case. In fact, it was his company's complaints about Microsoft's behavior that captured the Justice Department's attention and touched off the investigation and trial that is now coming to a close.

title: In the Region /New Jersey; For Newark's Central Ward, 206 Town Houses
description: BY next summer 206 town houses for low- and moderate-income families are expected to be completed on two 6.5-acre sites on either side of Irvine Turner Boulevard between West Kinney and Prince Streets in Newark's Central Ward. The sites are a block from where the 1967 racial riots erupted, pushing the city into decline.

title: Resistance to Ikea
description: A proposal by Ikea, the Swedish furniture chain, to build a 270,000-square-foot store that would employ 500 people and provide $2.5 million in sales tax for New Rochelle might be good for the city but not for the neighboring town of Mamaroneck, Marmaroneck's Administrator said.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: The Edna Webster Collection

title: The Evolution of Shop
description: Decades ago, high school students who wanted to learn a marketable skill went the Fonz route: take shop, become a mechanic. No more. Today, high schools are integrating work-related classes into traditional curriculums, giving students the chance to fulfill college entrance requirements while developing job expertise.

title: All That Jazz And More
description: Celebrations for literature, music, a hospital and landmarks.

title: Look to Social Class
description: To the Editor:

title: Silicon Island, Wired but Underpopulated
description: FAYYAZ YOUNAS, a 26-year-old software engineer and SUNY Stony Brook graduate, was explaining how his penchant for risk had taken him from Long Island to Northern California's Silicon Valley when, as if on cue, an earthquake shook his Palo Alto, Calif., office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JESSON, CHESTER S.
description: JESSON-Chester S. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Chester S. Jesson, associated with The Times from 1967 until retiring in 1978.

title: For Chechnya's Civilians, Broken Bodies and Lives
description: Late on a sunny morning, the seven women lying shoulder-to-shoulder in Ward 1 of the Sunzhenskaya District Hospital grew quiet, turned inward, as doctors tended to the little girl in the corner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, FRANCES K.
description: SINGER-Frances K. On November 5, 1999. Cherished wife of Dr. Benjamin A. Singer. Loving mother of Pamela Singer and son-inlaw Robert M. Unger. Adoring grandmother of Samuel. Dearest sister of Sarah Fisher, Martha Zelman and the late Roberta Feldman. Devoted friend and teacher. Adored aunt and great-aunt. Her zest for life, unique style and elegance are her legacy to us all. Service Monday, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. Lisa St. Aubin de Teran has lived the life most of us dream about. She has had three husbands -- a Venezuelan landowner whom she wed at age 16, a Scottish poet and a Scottish artist -- and reared three children in some of the most romantic spots on earth: a Venezuelan plantation, a Norfolk castle and the Villa Quarata in Morra, a tiny Umbrian hamlet. In her memoir, ''A Valley in Italy'' (HarperPerennial, $13), de Teran, 46, whose most recent novel is ''The Palace'' (Ecco Press, $23.95), graphically describes the joys and hazards of renovating her palazzo, which sat empty for 90 years, occupied only by local animals, until she bought it in 1988. Most horrific moment? Sleeping in bedrooms without windowpanes and waiting for nocturnal visits from bats, who swooped so close they almost nested in her hair.

title: Q&A/Charles Atkins; Exploring The Mind In Office And Word
description: BY day, Charles Atkins is the director of psychiatry at Waterbury Hospital. In his free time, he writes novels called psychological thrillers, which are filled with real information about serious mental disorders.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MEMORIAL TRIBUTE
description: MEMORIAL TRIBUTE. The students of the Rabbi Joseph H. Lookstein Upper School of Ramaz offer their condolences to the bereaved families on their loss in the crash of Egyptian Air flight 990. We pray that in the fullness of time God will grant them comfort and peace. May it be of solace to the families to know that their sadness is shared by many others. Student Government Organization Saul Safdieh, President

title: Work Is in Dispute, but Cropsey's Home Is Open
description: WHILE a State Supreme Court justice decides who owns ''View at Hastings-on-Hudson,'' the Jasper F. Cropsey painting now back on display at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, those curious about the artist can visit his homestead overlooking the river here. The yellow Gothic Revival cottage, which is on the National Register of Historic Places, was also the place where Cropsey's great-granddaughter, Barbara Newington, grew up. Her father, William Steinschneider, served as a mayor of Hastings.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 7, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Serving Up Italian With Deft Touches
description: FANS of Caffe Laguna in Long Beach have been waiting impatiently for its latest venture, Cafe Grappa, to open in East Meadow. Many of the same mouth-watering dishes that put Caffe Laguna on the map are offered at the new restaurant. That splendid food is the good news.

title: Sweet Rents May Be Over At a Former Candy Factory
description: The tenants of a converted candy factory at 20 Henry Street are panicked because their landlord has decided to buy its way out of the state's Mitchell-Lama housing program, which they say has kept rents there affordable since 1975. The landlord could then charge market rate rents in a building where tenants pay $600 to $1,300 for loft-style apartments with exposed beams and views.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JALET, CRUZ, FRANCES
description: JALET - CRUZ - Frances. Brave and right-minded. Tireless and true. Love, Tuckerman, Jacqueline, Vanessa, Roberta & Francie

title: Mimi Laver and Andrew Freedman
description: Mimi Rise Laver, the daughter of Nita and Steve Laver of Philadelphia, was married there last evening to Dr. Andrew Nathan Freedman, the son of Susan and Irving Freedman of Amherst, N.Y. Rabbi Barry Schwartz officiated at the Society Hill Sheraton.

title: You've Seen the Park, Now the Opera
description: RINGED by a wall of skyscrapers, apartment buildings, churches, synagogues and museums with a web of side streets leading to it, Central Park is the city's communal courtyard, a green respite where streams of people take the air from early morning until late evening, and even overnight. Occasionally, overheard conversations suggest larger dramas. And to observe patiently from a bench anywhere in the park is to be rewarded with a narrative, interpreted usually through the onlooker's own imagination.

title: At a Testimonial for a Revolutionary, Pride and Grief
description: It was just short of a farewell.

title: A Woman Caged
description: To the Editor:

title: State Test Results for Fourth Graders and Eighth Graders
description: Schools in New York, and even in Westchester, have a long way to go to meet new higher performance standards set by the state. The latest evidence for this is included in test scores in math and English for eighth-grade students that were released last week. Six of 10 students across the state and 5 of 10 in Westchester failed to meet the state's standards in math.

title: Challenging That Cheeseburger
description: IMAGINE that you're a trial lawyer. You've noticed that Americans are getting fatter, and that the government blames obesity and inactivity for more than 300,000 premature deaths every year. You've also noticed that scientists believe fatty foods kill people, and that fast-food outlets are selling cheeseburgers with both hands.

title: Political Briefing; A Race Even Tougher Than It Looked
description: The outcome of the race for governor of Mississippi could hardly be more in doubt.

title: The Company's Strategy
description: There was no evidence of any olive branch as Microsoft's president, Steven A. Ballmer, discussed the company's strategy and played down prospects for any settlement in its antitrust battle. Page 33A.

title: A Teacher Who Inspires
description: Veronica Berrill is an inspiration to all of humanity, particularly to educators, in her quest to establish safe zones for gay and bisexual students at Brookfield High School. The Houde family's crusade to see the safe-zone program discontinued, along with their lawyer, Joseph Secola's remark that safe zones have no place in school are ludicrous and ignorant. Congratulations to Mrs. Berrill for reminding people to think twice before trying to inflict their unfortunate agendas upon others.

title: Preserved in Oil; Society portraits, many in a formal style worthy of Sargent, are in vogue again.
description: HER spine buttressed by a pillow, her coppery hair set off by the russet shawl draped behind her, Elena Patterson sat for Hilary Cooper, a New York portrait painter, a picture of comely repose.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In /Dix Hills; A Sprawling, Affluent Suffolk Hamlet
description: A STREET map tells much about Dix Hills, a sprawling, affluent hamlet in western Suffolk County whose standout schools draw younger families.

title: Diabetes Is Expensive Disease
description: Re ''Dealing with Diabetes in School'' (Oct. 10): This article is a vivid demonstration that diabetes is a difficult disease to control and that an increase in federal funds for diabetes research is long overdue.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DAVIS, DR. HAZEL GRUBBS
description: DAVIS-Dr. Hazel Grubbs. A memorial service for Dr. Hazel Grubbs Davis will be held on Saturday, November 13, at 2 PM, National Cemetery Chapel, Farmingdale, NY. Officiating at the Service will be Rev. Maggie Morrison. She was promoted to glory at the age of 85. She will long be remembered as a college professor at Slippery Rock University, PA; Oneonta, NY; University of Arizona; Hofstra University and CUNY. She served for over 50 years on the White House Committee for Early Child Development, International Early Childhood, etc. Reception will follow the service at Syosset, NY. Further information: 724-224-4159

title: Finding Weight Bias Across the Workplace
description: The next time you're turned down for a pay raise or a new job, and you don't know why, you might step on a scale.

title: Mary Quinlan, John Mumford
description: Mary Megan Quinlan and John David Mumford were married in a Quaker ceremony yesterday at the Friends Meeting House in Washington. Carol Bechtel of the Meeting signed the marriage certificate.

title: Are the Rangers Sliding Toward Major Changes?
description: The Rangers' most glaring need coming into this season was supposed to be a second-line center. But what they have really lacked is someone to center the first line.

title: To a Hospital's Neighbors, Its Bridge Is a Disconnect
description: For 20 years, a bridge connecting two medical buildings near Stuyvesant Square has divided neighbors and the hospital that built the walkway. Now the hospital, Beth Israel Medical Center, is planning to renovate the covered bridge, which spans 17th Street near First Avenue. But neighbors who consider it an eyesore want the hospital to tear it down.

title: Sports of The Times; March Madness Can Wait; Autumn Is Gaining Its Own Stature
description: MAURY HANKS'S travel agent booked him and his basketball team on a flight that did not exist this week. The perfect itinerary, months of meticulous planning, evaporated into a mad dash for Tuscaloosa, Ala., through Cincinnati, slowing down in Birmingham for a few hours sleep.

title: Shopping on the Net: To Kick the Tires, You Click the Mouse
description: ARMED with consumer information from the Internet, Duane Walton walked into car dealerships in the Orlando, Fla., area expecting to negotiate a great deal on a minivan.

title: A New Zone For Housing? Some Worry
description: The City Planning Commission has proposed opening up a 15-block area to new housing. The area, now zoned for manufacturing, is on the border of Bedford-Stuyvesant and Williamsburg. Some local civic leaders fear that many residents and businesses will be pushed out under the plan.

title: Dowling Shakeup Highlights School's Woes
description: THE longtime president of Dowling College, Victor P. Meskill, has been forced to step down by trustees worried about finances and his lagging fund-raising efforts. The change came as Dowling struggles to redefine its place in a regional higher education market that has grown increasingly competitive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'AMICO, GRACE M.
description: D'AMICO-Grace M. Executive secretary for the New York Times. Services were held for Grace M. D'Amico, 74, of Pompton Plains, New Jersey. Grace died on Monday, October 25, 1999, in Biloxi, Mississippi. Born and lived in New York City for 65 years, she lived in Pompton Plains, New Jersey, since 1991. Miss D'Amico was an executive secretary for the New York Times for 28 years until her retirement in 1991. The Journal American previously employed her. Miss D'Amico is survived by four brothers, Salvatore, Joseph, Anthony and Richard, two sisters, Annette Scifo and Barbara Gambino (Buttercup), 21 nephews and nieces, 26 great-nephews and nieces, and one great-great-niece. Her sister Gloria Petino predeceased her.

title: Greenspan Cranes His Neck Over Stock and Home Prices
description: THE Federal Reserve, as everyone knows, is always trying to keep inflation down without sacrificing too much economic growth. The public debate that accompanies this process focuses on the behavior of the real economy. The booming stock market has stretched that focus, of course. But even so, the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, is expressing greater concern lately about the dangers of a high stock market and rising home prices.

title: Just Imagine
description: Over the past century, business has given us the car, the radio, the television, the personal computer, the jet, the trash compactor and shampoo combined with conditioner. Imagine that you could ask for one equally huge innovation in the coming century, to improve your own lot or that of all mankind. What would you ask for? Send your ideas to Outlook 2000, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to Outlook-2000@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Don't Define Child by Disease
description: I recently finished yearlong speciality training in diabetes care and management at the Yale School of Nursing, and I am currently working on a grant position providing education and medical management to women with diabetes. In reference to the article ''Dealing With Diabetes in School,'' it is no longer considered appropriate to refer to a person with diabetes as a ''diabetic.''

title: Swan Song for Swing
description: The cool cats and swinging dudes who have been jitterbugging at the Leopard Lounge in Sayreville for the last year will have to find a new place to jive.

title: A Great Feat
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Why Long Island City Hasn't Happened; Once, the Neighborhood Was Hailed as the Next SoHo. But Can You Build a Bohemia From Scratch.
description: ONE Saturday morning last month, Ann Schaumburger and eight other artists tidied up their studios above a Long Island City furniture factory, hung their paintings and collages, chilled bottles of white wine and set out platters of Brie and grapes.

title: Altered Crops Cause Mischief
description: To the Editor:

title: German Army's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Agencies Make Acquisitions
description: Western Initiative Media Worldwide in New York has signed a letter of intent to acquire Botway Group in New York, a media agency. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Chiapas Bishop Exits
description: To the Editor:

title: The Monks' Moment, Recaptured
description: Jubilation greeted the American debut of the Monks, who played their first show since 1967 on Friday night. The reunited band still had the ornery ferocity that has made its 1966 album, ''Black Monk Time,'' a touchstone of contentious, aberrant rock.

title: Tougher Robot Joining Search At Crash Site
description: It uses sonar for ears and video cameras for eyes. Its titanium arms have joints in seven places, its wrists can spin 360 degrees and it can dive more than a mile and a half in rough seas to grasp things from the ocean floor.

title: Mourners Seek Solace In the Rituals of Faith
description: The roses drifted seaward shortly before sunset today, pushed away from the rocky shoreline by a crisp northerly wind. ''Allahu akbar,'' the mourners wailed in Arabic. ''God is great.'' Another voice, that of a woman crying in English, carried out over the stones and surf. ''My baby, my baby, my baby,'' she screamed, as Red Cross workers nearby wept.

title: E-Commerce Report; Web site publishers and advertising agencies square off on ownership of data on customers.
description: ON the Internet, where information is king, some of the most valuable information is data about user or customer behavior. Of this, one of the most closely followed measurements is so-called click data, which focuses on who has clicked on an advertising banner or some other particular link. Web site publishers, advertising agencies and companies that buy those ads have relied heavily on that data to build their businesses, and until now they have been generous about sharing it freely with each other.

title: Throw Away That Cell Phone
description: WE may live in a disposable society, but is the world ready for throw-away cell phones? Randice-Lisa Altschul thinks so.

title: In Opera, Technology Can't Improve Voice
description: To the Editor:

title: Now Putting A Big Stamp On the Era Of the Internet; Pitney Bowes Is Updating The Business of Business Mail
description: The three phrases flash in rapid succession on the United Illuminating Company's Web site: No stamps. No checks. No fees.

title: What Really Scares Microsoft
description: A federal judge has made it official: Microsoft is a monopoly, a two-ton bully that squashes competitors and cheats consumers. Still, no matter how much the government lawyers crow or Bill Gates complains, the fact is that the real future of the software industry is already being decided entirely outside the court system -- in a technological marketplace too fast-moving and too accepting of good new ideas to be artificially held in check.

title: Treasury to Auction New Five-Year Note
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills as well as the quarterly refunding made up of a new five-year note and the reopening of the April 10-year note due 2009.

title: Media Talk; A Biographer in Search of a New Publisher
description: If the literary agent Richard Curtis has his way, there will be one more chapter written in the hand-wringing saga of St. Martin's Press and its canceled biography of Governor George W. Bush of Texas.

title: As New York City Immigration Thrives, Diversity Broadens
description: New York City is ending the century as it began -- oxygenated by immigrants -- with the new arrivals coming from an increasingly diverse set of nations and settling over a broader swath of the city than ever before, according to a study by the Department of City Planning to be released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWEIBACHER, EDWARD
description: SCHWEIBACHER-Edward. November 6, 1999. Beloved husband of Margaret. Father of Edward, John, and Anne and Larry Brown. Grandfather of Karolyn, Lydia, Nathanael, Janice, Jeremiah, Micaiah, Hope and Jedediah.

title: Visit by Son Leads to Woman's Arrest
description: Madeline Carmichael could not bear to look at her granddaughter.

title: State Aquarium To Select an Agency
description: The New Jersey State Aquarium in Camden, N.J., and Winning Strategies Advertising in Mount Laurel, N.J., have agreed to part ways as of Dec. 31. The agency has handled the aquarium's account since 1996. The aquarium's marketing budget was estimated at $1 million.

title: In Westchester, Trouble on the Menu; As Hispanic Clientele Grows, a Restaurant Loses Its Lease
description: The Guatemalan day laborers who mow the lawns, paint the houses and detail the cars in Westchester's wealthy northern suburbs have found an unlikely haven: a hole-in-the-wall Chinese takeout here that now serves tortillas and salty pork along with dumplings and shrimp lo mein.

title: A Pioneer in Consulting Is Leaving Yankee Group
description: There are a lot of people out there trying to make their livings as experts and consultants in the technology and communications businesses. Almost all owe something to Howard Anderson, who practically invented the technology consulting industry when he founded Yankee Group Research in 1970.

title: Editorial Observer; Tinkering at the Margins of Anti-Gay Bigotry
description: The integration of the American military stands as this country's most striking transformation of the century. Harry Truman issued the executive order ending segregation in 1948, and by 1956, white recruits from the most bigoted reaches of the South were being ordered around by black drill sergeants at boot camp. Under the edict, known racists were no longer allowed to hold positions of authority and were eventually weeded out. Within a few decades, the military had more black managers by far than the civilian sector, which still has not caught up. As the military sociologist Charles Moskos wrote: ''Today, one is more likely to hear racial jokes at the university faculty club than in the officers' club. And in the officers' club, one will surely see more blacks.''

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
Paid Notice: Deaths  MARIUS, RICHARD C.
description: MARIUS-Richard C.. Of Belmont, MA, November 5. Beloved husband of Lanier Smythe. Dear and devoted father of Richard Henri Marius of Murfreesboro, TN; Frederick Stewart Marius of Winchester and John Bartlett Marius of NYC. Brother of John Marius of Lenoir City, TN. Loving grandfather of Ellen Patricia Marius and Henri Richard Marius. A memorial service will be held at a later date. For further information contact the Short, Williamson & Diamond Funeral Home, Belmont.

title: Stench of Horror Lingers In a Prison in Kosovo
description: The high, red brick walls of Dubrava prison tell little. Like the modern police buildings outside, they bear signs of bomb damage from NATO attacks in May this year, but that is only half the story.

title: Altered Crops Cause Mischief
description: To the Editor:

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
When a TV Network Is Your Chef
description: The ESPN Inc. sports empire exists seemingly to propagate wildly. It has spawned six domestic cable television networks and 20 more networks worldwide, a magazine, an Internet service, books, videos, games, a radio network, music, pagers and pay-per-view programming.

title: It Isn't Really Nostalgic, Just Intoxicating Ballroom Dancing
description: ''Ballroom Fever'' swept into City Center on Saturday night looking bound for Broadway. The two-hour show, which featured champion competitive ballroom-dancing couples and a delightful comedy duo, certainly looked as if it belonged there. With almost no advance publicity or marketing, ''Ballroom Fever'' had a large and exuberant audience.

title: Internet Utopia
description: To the Editor:

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
Paid Notice: Deaths  SABERSKI, NORMA LILLIAN (NEE BERNSTEIN)
description: SABERSKI-Norma Lillian (nee Bernstein). Loving wife of Eugene for 60 years. Mother of Jean Rosen, Neda Birbrower, Lloyd Saberski, Jay Rosen, Barry Birbrower, Dale Saberski. Grandmother of nine. Great-grandmother of two. We will miss you. Services Monday, 10 AM, Temple Beth Abraham, Tarrytown.

title: Inspiring Without Saying a Word
description: David Fishman sits by his father's hospital bed and talks to him. He tells his father, Stewart, the progress he has made running, about his training for the marathon and how it is all for him. He knows that his father understands, even though he has no proof beyond sometimes seeing small facial gestures, a short emission of sound, or a slight nod.

title: George V. Higgins, 59, Author of Crime Novels
description: George V. Higgins, a crime novelist best known for his first published work, the best seller ''Friends of Eddie Coyle,'' was found dead on Saturday at his home in Milton, Mass. He was 59. He apparently died of natural causes, The Associated Press reported.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, MARGARET LENNON
description: KENNEDY - Margaret Lennon. Age 83. Graduate of College of Mt. St. Vincent. Worked for the NY Pulic Library. Volunteer for Lighthouse International. Survived by host of loving cousins. For information, Frank Barone Funeral Home, 718-629-2047. Mass St. Teresa's Church, 10 AM, Tuesday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Microsoft probably does have a monopoly, but I'm not going to lose any sleep over it.''

title: Enjoying a Winning Streak Lasting Half a Century
description: Very few of the world's greatest players maintain their skill and enthusiasm for half a century or more. One of the few exceptions is Tim Seres of Australia, who on three occasions led national teams that came close to winning a world title. Now 74, he continues to win national titles and make brilliant plays. On the diagramed deal, played last year in his club in Sydney, he arrived in six clubs as shown.

title: Health Care Brings Out Contrast in Candidates
description: The debate over health policy being waged in the Democratic presidential primary is not simply about cost estimates, political positioning and appeals to Democratic constituencies. Health policy experts say Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley have very different visions about how to deal with the nation's 44.3 million uninsured.

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
Bush on Sex Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay; The Skillful Envoy
description: If an inability to recall the name of the new strongman in Pakistan is proof of George Bush's lightweightedness, then we are all lightweights.

title: Special Team, Special Play
description: Chris Hayes was feeling sorry for himself on the Jets' sideline in the fourth quarter yesterday. ''I was asking myself, 'What can I do to make the big play?' '' he said.

title: Warner-Lambert's Chief Defends Decision to Ignore Pfizer's Bid
description: The chief executive of the Warner-Lambert Company described the drug maker's rationale yesterday for proceeding with its proposed $72 billion merger with the American Home Products Corporation and spurning a hostile, though more lucrative, overture by Pfizer Inc.

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
Soaring Seattle Comes Abruptly Down to Earth
description: Three of the world's richest men, their wealth derived from the Microsoft Corporation, live in the Seattle area. The company's market valuation alone is nearly half a trillion dollars, and its presence is a huge reason that 2,500 other high-technology companies are congregated here.

title: William Goodhart, 74, Author of Hit Play
description: William Malcolm Goodhart, whose first effort at play writing became a Broadway hit, died on Oct. 20 at his home on Shelter Island, N.Y. He was 74. The cause was heart disease, his family said.

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
People
description: * Eric Keshin, executive vice president and chief operating officer at McCann-Erickson New York, part of the McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising unit of the McCann-Erickson World Group, owned by the Interpublic Group of Cos., was named to the new position of general manager and chief operating officer.

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
Paid Notice: Deaths  KALTENBACHER, RICHARD S.
description: KALTENBACHER - Richard S.. Age 85, of Highland Beach, FL, and Martha's Vineyard, MA. Beloved husband of 61 years of Polly. Adored by his family, revered by his friends, and respected by his colleagues in the leather manufacturing industry. Survived by: Carol and Philip Mehler, Amanda and Mark Tamis, Isabella Bea Tamis, Philip Richard Mehler, Nancy and Edward Strauss, Arthur and Libby Jacobson and Zoe, Samuel, Grace and Rachel Simone Jacobson, Thomas and Traci Jacobson and Chloe Jacobson. Elizabeth and David Kaufman, Willa and Oliver Kaufman, Joseph and Gail Kaltenbacher, Jason and Eric Kaltenbacher. Survived by sister Carolyn K. Meier; predeceased by brother Joseph C. Kaltenbacher. Services Monday, November 8, 1999, 3:30 PM, at Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton, FL; 1800-992-9262.

title: Taxis and Racism
description: To the Editor:

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
Breaking Out of the Routine With Mozart and Beethoven
description: The Orchestra of St. Luke's, coming off a season devoted entirely to Haydn, is this year leaving special causes to others, to judge from its opening program of standards on Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall. And with so many other organizations indeed embarked on strenuous millennial missions, there may be something appealing about the modesty here.

title: At 116, the National Is Showing Its Age
description: The National Horse Show, if this year's dismal attendance at Madison Square Garden provides any clues, may be flirting with obsolescence for lack of the Broadway curb appeal that once made it a sellout. But the National, though ailing at the box office in its 116th year, has never lacked for spectacles, and it served up a classic last evening to close a four-day run cluttered with grand prix jumpers, hunters, trick roping and riding, trick dogs and dressage exhibitions.

title: In New Hampshire, the Fight for Independents
description: Michael O'Leary spent his Saturday knocking on doors for Bill Bradley, the former senator who is running for the Democratic presidential nomination. Yet Mr. O'Leary says he is considering voting for another candidate in New Hampshire's first-in-the-nation primary in February: Senator John McCain, the maverick Republican from Arizona.

title: COMPUTER WORRIES FUEL WITHDRAWAL OF U.S. DIPLOMATS
description: The State Department is planning to withdraw hundreds of government employees and family members from Russia and three other former Soviet republics before Jan. 1 because of concerns over the Year 2000 computer problem.

title: In a Must-Win Predicament, Jets Do What They Must
description: Despite Curtis Martin's rushing, the defense's domination and the special teams' big play, the Jets' offense looked beaten and incompetent as it trudged deep into the fourth quarter today, desperately seeking to end the first half of their season with a victory over the Arizona Cardinals. If not, Monday's second-guessers, and perhaps the Jets themselves, would be conjuring memories of a 1-15 record of another era.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Microsoft Findings Leave Some Feeling Ambivalent

title: St. Peter's Journal; Ha! Taking the Wind Out of Leif Ericsson's Sails
description: In a grand North Atlantic arc, from Washington to Newfoundland to Norway, Scandinavians and their New World descendants are gearing up for a series of lavish museum exhibits next spring, designed to celebrate the 1,000th anniversary of the arrival of the first Europeans in North America.

title: Buyer Plans for St. Moritz To Be Ritz-Carlton Flagship
description: The St. Moritz, the faded old dowager on Central Park South, is the hotel that every tycoon wants but none has been able to keep.

title: Media; The need to build revenue has led many newspapers to 'experiment' with their products.
description: WHEN Jane E. Kirtley moved into her new home in Minneapolis in September, she found on her doorstep a free weekly supplement to The Minneapolis Star Tribune. Called The Buyer's Edge, it contained articles about things like buying a car online, and advertisements for things like car dealerships.

title: A Singer Who Goes To the Devil, Devilishly
description: The reason for Boito's ''Mefistofele'' at the Metropolitan Opera on Friday night could be found at the top of the cast list. Samuel Ramey has made a minor career of the title role, and this production -- questionable in its taste as well as its state of repair -- has been following him around the world since its birth at the Grand Theatre de Geneve 12 years ago.

title: A Rough Patch of Volatility Is Seen for a Fast-Rising Stock
description: Microsoft has long been, in the words of one analyst, ''an institutional investor's dream.'' Since going public in March 1986, its market value has soared to $470 billion, making it the world's most highly valued company.

title: Media Talk; Advertising Cover Tests Standards of Magazine Industry
description: Why would Smart Money, the financial magazine published jointly by Hearst Magazines and Dow Jones, feature a photograph of the actor Jerry Orbach on the cover, smiling benignly as he steps out of a taxi?

title: Pope Tells India His Church Has a Right to Evangelize
description: Summoning all his moral authority, Pope John Paul II tried today to persuade leaders of other religions here that interfaith understanding should lead them to recognize the Roman Catholic Church's right to evangelize.

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
Old-Time Democrat Tries to Weave a Budget Tapestry
description: WHEN Jack Lew, the White House budget director, came to power, he took down an oil painting of a yachting regatta left on the office wall by a Republican predecessor and replaced it with scenes of working-class life.

title: Despite a Tough Stance or Two, White House Is Still Consolidation Friendly
description: The Clinton administration may have rattled the house of Bill Gates with its aggressive antitrust case against Microsoft, but it is in the process of winking at some of the older economic empires that in an earlier age dominated American commerce.

title: Expansion of Arts Center Touches a Nerve in Princeton
description: When the colleagues of the architect Michael Graves strolled out of their first planning board meeting here last December, they thought they had reason to be pleased.

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARYLES, AVI
description: MARYLES-Avi. The Board of Directors of the Zamir Choral Foundation expresses its heartfelt sorrow upon the untimely passing of Avi Maryles, beloved brother of its members Matthew J. Maryles and Jesse Maryles. Expressions of condolence to his beloved wife Daisy, their cherished daughter Miriam, dear brothers Norman and Josh Maryles, and the entire family, which mourns so profoundly the loss of this unique man. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Matthew Lazar Founder and Director Marsha Bryan Edelman President

title: Bombs Hurt 14 in Israel on Eve of Peace Talks
description: Three makeshift pipe bombs exploded in the Israeli coastal town of Netanya today, wounding 14 people, on the day before the planned start of Israeli-Palestinian negotiations on a permanent peace.

title: Canal Plan May Create 17,000 Jobs, Study Says
description: A federal program to help revitalize communities along the Erie Canal could create 17,000 jobs, almost twice as many as originally forecast, a Cornell University study has found.

title: It's Simple: Woods Is Too Good, Too Soon
description: Tiger Woods was simply too good. Too good to be daunted by a controversial triple-bogey on the 17th hole. Too good to be rattled when fans cheered against him. Too good to be beaten by a field featuring most of the world's best players. Too good to be intimidated by a diabolical golf course that frustrated many of his opponents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHMAN, THOMAS C.
description: LEHMAN-Thomas C.., Sr. Of West Orange, NJ. Beloved husband of the late Louise (Spitz). Cherished father of Karen & Eric Gurwin, Cathy & Robert Gursha, Thomas C. & Suzy Lehman, Jr., Judy & David Weiniger. Special loving grandfather of Jeffrey, Jason, Michael, Jaclyn, Daniel, Lauren, Julie, Brian, Douglas, Kacey, Rachel. Brother of John & David Lehman. Funeral service at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, South Orange Ave, Short Hills, today, 11 AM.

title: Compressed Data; OfficeClick Offers Aides A Clique of Their Own
description: Now that e-commerce companies are categorizing people every conceivable way -- by sexual preference, foot size, lactose intolerance -- and giving them a portal, it seems only right to award a portal to administrative assistants.

title: Inspired by Selena, They Seek Her Role; Singer's Spell Lives On in Stage Auditions
description: In a studio in the theater district this weekend, close to 200 girls and young women auditioned for a new musical. But this was no ordinary open casting call, for the role being cast was that of Selena, the Tejano singing star whose murder in 1995 at age 23 horrified millions of fans, particularly the young Hispanic women who saw themselves in her.

title: Capriati's Comeback Continues in Quebec
description: Jennifer Capriati continued her comeback yesterday by defeating Chanda Rubin, 4-6, 6-1, 6-2, in the final of the Bell Challenge in Quebec.

title: Chiapas Bishop Exits
description: To the Editor:

title: Letting Nothing Stop the Streak
description: Multiple sclerosis cannot slow Zoe Koplowitz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PESARESI, CONSTANTINE V.
description: PESARESI-Constantine V.., Rev. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the pastor emeritus of Our Lady of Sorrows Church, 104-11 37th Avenue, Corona, on November 6, 1999. Reposing at Buen Pastor Funeral Home, 3720 104th Street, Corona, on Monday, Novemeber 8, from 2 to 5 PM. Mass of Transferral in Our Lady of Sorrows Church at 7:30 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday, November 9, at 10:30 AM. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Preists' Pugatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZAR, ARTHUR
description: LAZAR-Arthur. The Congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its longtime and founding member, and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Marjorie Miller, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Kenneth M. Chasen, Asst. Rabbi Stephen Merkel, Cantor Jack Stern Jr., Rabbi Emeritus

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
In Opera, Technology Can't Improve Voice
description: To the Editor:

title: Guns Will Still Flow
description: To the Editor:

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
Knicks' Johnson May Miss Game
description: Larry Johnson gingerly left the locker room at Gund Arena in Cleveland Saturday night after sitting out the Knicks' loss to the Cavaliers with back spasms. There is no guarantee that his chronically bad back will loosen up in time to play the undefeated Milwaukee Bucks tonight.

title: Newspaper War With a Twist in Hawaii
description: Hawaii is no stranger to monopolies. This former island kingdom is still a place where a handful of landlords own vast tracts, where entrenched business interests dominate civic affairs and where the Democratic Party, which has held sway since statehood, controls the governorship, the entire Congressional delegation and roughly 80 percent of the Legislature.

title: The Mystery of Winning at the Meadowlands? It's Elementary
description: The uninitiated players and coaches who enter Giants Stadium on a blustery day have to watch the swirl of the plastic grocery bags and the dips and dives of the white paper napkins to get a read on the tricky winds. To those who have played here before, it is merely a matter of searching the memory bank.

title: Big Fire Closes 3rd Ave. Bridge, Snarling Traffic From the Bronx
description: A fire raged for more than two hours last night beneath the Third Avenue Bridge, which carries traffic from the Bronx to Manhattan, closing the bridge and threatening to badly disrupt this morning's rush hour.

title: Forget Jingles. Viewers Prefer Familiar Tunes in Commercials.
description: THE advertising industry may be playing your song -- in commercials, that is.

title: A Changing South Revisits Its Unsolved Racial Killings
description: In Alabama, a federal grand jury has been hearing evidence for more than a year in a 1963 racist bombing that killed four black girls in a downtown Birmingham church.

title: Guns Will Still Flow
description: To the Editor:

title: Goofing Off While The Muse Recharges
description: Sometime in the middle of June I sat down to a ritual that, as much as any other, has typified my writing life: At the end of a very lengthy period during which I did basically nothing whatsoever of any good to man nor beast, I got back to work. That is, I started writing again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGENBERG, GLORIA
description: WAGENBERG-Gloria. On November 6, 1999. Beloved wife of Jerry. Adoring mother of Mitchell, Nina, Eric, Risa and Caryn. Loving grandmother of Jordanah, Zachary, Jacob, Scout, Chase, Lana, Maxson and Cole. Greatest aunt of Robin and Donna. She was our gift and we loved her deeply. We will miss you everyday. Services Monday, 12 noon, at Gutterman's, in Woodbury.

title: A Debut With Signs Of the Future
description: The annual Alice Tully Vocal Arts Debut Recital has become a much-anticipated event in New York's concert life. For three years this program has enabled a singer from Juilliard, chosen by the faculty, to give a major debut recital at the hall bearing Tully's name. This year's choice is Mariana Karpatova, a mezzo-soprano from Bulgaria, who gave her debut recital on Thursday night with the pianist Speranza Scappucci. Ms. Karpatova is already an experienced artist, having graduated from the Music Academy in Sofia and spent recent years with the Juilliard Opera Theater. At 33 she seems poised for a fine career.

title: Pasta Party Helps Fuel Runners
description: Saturday night, thousands of marathon entrants had eaten at the free, mammoth Ronzoni pasta party in a tent at Tavern on the Green. But other groups gathered all over the city for more intimate prerace celebrations.

title: Correction
description: A brief report by Bloomberg News in Business Day on Friday about a deal involving the HealthGate Data Corporation and the Web sites Snap .com and Xoom.com misstated details of the agreement. HealthGate will pay $75 million to appear on the Web sites and in some of the sites' television advertising; Snap.com and Xoom.com will not pay HealthGate. In addition, the General Electric Company will combine some of the Internet holdings of its NBC network with Snap.com and Xoom.com to form a publicly traded company called NBC Internet Inc.; it is not acquiring the Web sites or Cnet Inc., which is a partial owner of Snap .com.

title: Sports of The Times; A Once Hot Ticket Is Now Cold to the Touch
description: LET'S say that last summer you won tickets to yesterday's game between the Arizona Cardinals and the Jets at Giants Stadium. Wow! The Jets breezed to the American Football Conference championship game a year ago and the Cardinals relished a sweet playoff victory at Dallas.

title: Altered Crops Cause Mischief
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Media Talk; Just Facts (Mostly) From National Journal
description: Pundits, aweigh!

title: Silicon Valley Cites Concern Amid Glee on Microsoft Case
description: In Silicon Valley, the nation's high-technology capital, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's powerful findings in the Microsoft antitrust case have been received with a sense of vindication but also ambivalence.

title: Myths and Reality With an Impish Grin
description: ''I'm not much of a talker,'' Brendan Perry murmured after the first song of his set on Wednesday night at the Bowery Ballroom. ''I'll do my best.''

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
Live and Tape Sounds Mix, Not Match
description: Sonic Boom, the new-music series happening this year at the Cooper Union, opened on Wednesday night with a lively, varied and strongly played concert given by the New York New Music Ensemble. Three pieces for the group, by Rand Steiger, Julia Wolfe and Steven Mackey, were interleaved with two spectacular solos: Mario Davidovsky's ''Synchronisms No. 3'' for cello and Michael Lowenstern's ''Spasm'' for bass clarinet. Everything, except Mr. Mackey's new work, involved electronics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, BETYE
description: WASSERMAN - Betye. Betye (Baum) Wasserman of Spring Valley, NY, passed away at her home after battling a long illness. She was 59. Mrs. Wasserman was born on February 25, 1940, in Bronx, NY, to Mae and Al Baum. She graduated from New Rochelle High School and then Lesley College where she received a degree in elementary education. Betye was an active member of Pomona Jewish Center where she founded a youth group for young children, was the editor of the synagogue newsletter and held various officer positions within the synagogue Board, as well as the President of its Sisterhood. Additionally, she was honored as ''Congregant of the Year,'' in 1993. Other organizations that Mrs. Wasserman was affiliated with included Hadassah and Women's ORT. She is survived by her husband and soulmate Alan, her daughter Roberta Ginsberg of Pine Brook, NJ, and her husband Larry, her son Andrew of Plantation, FL, and his wife Lisa, grandchildren Scott and Kimberly Ginsberg, and her brother Stanley Baum and his wife Louise of Dunwoody, GA. Mrs. Wasserman leaves behind a legacy of volunteerism, selflessness and literally hundreds and hundreds of friends. Services were held on Sunday, November 7, at Pomona Jewish Center, Pomona, NY. Memorial donations may be made to Pomona Jewish Center, PO Box 400-D, Pomona, NY 10970. For further information please call Hellman Memorial Chapels, 914356-8600.

title: Kagwe Fades to 5th As Boston Winner Completes a Double
description: A 36-year-old former Portuguese track star intruded on Kenya's annual dominance of the New York City Marathon yesterday, but only until he was inside Central Park, less than two miles from the finish. From there it was all uphill.

title: An Early Charge By the '98 Winner Gets Brushed Aside
description: Franca Fiacconi felt the only way she could win yesterday's New York City Marathon was to attack from the start. Adriana Fernandez felt if she stayed with Fiacconi, she could break her.

title: Primo Nebiolo Is Dead at 76; Led World Track Federation
description: Primo Nebiolo, a powerful and controversial figure in international sports who brought track and field out of the amateur ranks as president of its world governing body for almost two decades, died yesterday at a hospital in Rome. He was 76.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, FRANCES K.
description: SINGER-Frances K.. On November 5, 1999. Cherished wife of Dr. Benjamin A. Singer. Loving mother of Pamela Singer and son-inlaw Robert M. Unger. Adoring grandmother of Samuel. Dearest sister of Sarah Fisher, Martha Zelman and the late Roberta Feldman. Devoted friend and teacher. Adored aunt and great-aunt. Her zest for life, unique style and elegance are her legacy to us all. Service Monday, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Acoustic Music, Live From the Living Room
description: In more than 30 years of touring, the Texas singer Ray Wylie Hubbard had seen far more professional-looking spaces than the one he performed at on Wednesday evening. The stage lighting consisted of a single black desk lamp clamped to the top of a chipped window frame. And the backstage area was a small bedroom where guitars rested against the wall next to a vacuum cleaner.

title: Scottish Bank and Santander Reportedly in Talks
description: The Royal Bank of Scotland is negotiating with the Spanish bank Banco Santander Central Hispano about possibly making a joint bid for National Westminster Bank, executives close to the talks said tonight.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Compressed Data; In a World of Chips, A Man for All Modems
description: The nation reacted with surprise upon learning late last month that the Coca-Cola Company has been testing a new kind of vending machine that can be instructed to raise prices when the weather is hot. But for companies like Eicon Technology, a Canadian maker of wireless and cable modems that enable machines of all kinds to follow orders, that was old news.

title: Suspect in Rapes is Stabbed During Break-In
description: A man suspected of being a serial rapist broke into a 12-year-old girl's bedroom in Queens while she was sleeping Saturday morning, but was stopped when the girl's uncle stabbed him, the police said yesterday.

title: Altered Crops Cause Mischief
description: To the Editor:

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
Paid Notice: Memorials  KNOPF, MARILYN
description: KNOPF-Marilyn. Lovingly remembered for nine years. Emmer, Yellin and Knopf Familie

title: The Lions Solve the Rams and Continue Their Run
description: The St. Louis Rams have amazed, even terrified, the National Football League with their powerful and versatile offense. But fear only lasts so long. It takes just a short time for the rest of the league, full of innovative men, to put a team like the Rams under a microscope and pick it apart, like a scientist breaking down a virus.

title: Penn State's Prospects Plummet
description: It seems disrespectful to think of a grand old game like the Rose Bowl as a consolation prize, but that's what it will amount to for Penn State. And that is only if the Nittany Lions can qualify to play the Pac-10 champion in Pasadena, no sure thing now. Ranked No. 2 last week, Penn State fell to No. 6 in the Associated Press poll, No. 8 in the USA Today/ESPN poll and No. 9 in the New York Times computer ranking this week after losing by 24-23 to Minnesota in Happy Valley on Saturday. The Nittany Lions (9-1 over all, 5-1 in the Big Ten) have little chance now to play in the Sugar Bowl in the national championship game between the two top-ranked schools as judged by a consensus of ratings in the Bowl Championship Series.

title: Internet Utopia
description: To the Editor:

title: Monday Morning Quarterback
description: Highlights and lowlights from the weekend, by JOE LAPOINTE

title: RMC in Negotiations to Buy Rugby Group
description: RMC Group, the world's largest maker of ready-mix concrete, is negotiating to acquire Rugby Group, a British cement company, for $:800 million, or $1.3 billion, executives close to the talks said today.

title: John Hadfield, 92, Whose Book on British Life Became a TV Series
description: John Hadfield, an editor of literary anthologies and the author of ''Love on a Branch Line,'' a fanciful tale of British rural life in 1950's East Anglia that became a successful television series, died the last week of October, The Daily Telegraph of London reported. He was 92 and lived in Woodbridge in the English county of Suffolk.

title: Bush on Sex Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Thelonious Monk's Many Incarnations
description: The Carnegie Hall Jazz Band's program of Thelonious Monk music on Thursday night wasn't a failure, but there was a long distance between its high points and low points, and the whole evening left a listener wondering what the band wanted to do with Monk in the first place.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: U. of Cambridge and M.I.T. In Joint Research Venture
description: Seeking to import a measure of New World innovation and technology to the Old World, the British government will announce a $108 million investment today in a joint venture that will link research and educational programs at the University of Cambridge in England with those at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
Blue Jays May Deal Green For the Dodgers' Mondesi
description: The engine that the Texas Rangers stoked last week with the trade of Juan Gonzalez roared into this tiny resort town on the Pacific Ocean this weekend and fired up a contingency deal that has Shawn Green moving from Toronto to Los Angeles for Raul Mondesi in a four-player swap. The completion of the deal depends on the Dodgers' ability to negotiate a contract with Green by midnight Monday.

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
A Chip On Their Sneakers
description: For the first time, technology allowed friends, relatives and anyone with computer access to learn how runners fared in the New York City Marathon within about 15 minutes of them crossing the finish line. The quick results were thanks to the Internet, the Microsoft Network and a computer chip embedded in a small yellow plastic disc that entrants wore on their sneakers.

title: Colin Rowe, Architecture Professor, Dies at 79
description: Colin Rowe, a historian and teacher whose ideas helped to shape the thinking of some of today's most prominent American architects, died on Friday in Arlington, Va. He was 79.

title: New Technology Investment Fund Says It Has Raised $600 Million
description: Redpoint Ventures, a technology-focused venture capital firm created in August through the combination of Brentwood Venture Capital and Institutional Venture Partners, plans to announce on Monday that it has raised $600 million in its first fund -- an amount thought to be the largest effort for a first-time technology fund.

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
Pepi Deutsch, 101, Holocaust Survivor With Remarkable Tale
description: Pepi Deutsch, a resilient, resourceful woman whose endurance of the brutalities of the Nazis with her teenage daughter at her side was one of the most affecting stories of survival to emerge from the Holocaust, died on Friday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. She was 101 years old and lived at her daughter's home in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: German Army's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Better Pay for Librarians
description: To the Editor:

title: TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce; The future of online commerce must be built on credibility. And yet, companies continue to squander the public's trust.
description: IF dot-com companies are really trying to inspire consumer confidence as they embark upon what could well be their make-or-break holiday season, they must be taking oxymoron pills. Under the hot light of recent scrutiny, their increasingly questionable business practices are becoming public, casting long overdue doubt on the credibility of much of the commercial Internet.

title: Assessing the Impact of the Gift-Giver of Nazareth
description: DESIRE OF THE EVERLASTING HILLS

title: Web Audio Network Plans New Delivery System Today
description: RealNetworks Inc., the multimedia Internet company, plans today to announce a new network delivery service and a new version of its media player, called RealPlayer 7.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALAYA, MARIO SALVATORE
description: ALAYA-Mario Salvatore. November 4, 1999, in Huntington Beach, CA. Beloved father, grandfather, great-grandfather, age 100 years. Born February 6, 1899, in Sperone, Italy. A decorated officer in the Italian Army in WW I. Arrived in the U.S. in 1921, he began a career in food importing and marketing, and married Maria Spagnola of New York City in 1929. A naturalized citizen, fluent in several languages, Mario began a second career teaching in the New York Public Schools, earning his BA at City College at age 68, and retired to Temecula, CA, in 1975. He is survived by their four children (Louis Alaia, Carlo Alaia, Flavia Alaya, and Ann Alaia Woods), two sisters (Clementina Alaia and Michelina Casler), nine grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren. Services November 9, in Huntington Beach. Donations may be made in his memory to the Maria Alaya Scholarship Fund of the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan.

title: No Stop Signs on the Course; Also, No Prizes at the End of It
description: For the second time in two years, Miguel Such was the first to roll across the finish line in the New York City Marathon's wheelchair event yesterday, and he thrust his fists in the air and savored victory.

title: Republicans Plan to Offer A Party Line To the Internet
description: In an effort to raise money, embrace supporters and bypass the news media, the Republican National Committee plans to begin offering subscriptions in January to a ''family friendly'' Internet service that will deliver the party's messages directly to supporters.

title: Generations Apart But Racing Together
description: Edward Leitch, 72, traveled over 5,000 miles from Cairns, Australia, to New York City to run 26.2 miles with his youngest son, Andrew, 38.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
With Mixed Emotions, Grunfeld Returns
description: He plans to speak and sign autographs at the NBA Store in midtown Manhattan this afternoon. He may have time for a few friends before heading over to Madison Square Garden to watch the game between the Knicks and the Milwaukee Bucks. By then, Ernie Grunfeld is unsure of what he will do or how he will feel.

title: The Big City; How Vouchers Can Shift The Balance
description: ADVOCATES of school vouchers believe that public schools will improve if they're forced to compete for students, but what if that's wishful thinking? What if a voucher system merely allows the better students to escape, leaving the rest trapped in the same bad schools?

title: Some Software Users Wary of Judge's Findings
description: As the Justice Department and some in the technology industry celebrated a federal judge's finding this weekend that Microsoft had hurt consumers by abusing its Windows monopoly, Bob Mirell was browsing the software aisles at CompUSA in Midtown Manhattan feeling decidedly unwounded.

title: Charles Sweet, 81; Oversaw Trials in Labor Killing
description: Judge Charles G. Sweet, who helped supervise the trials of several of the nine people charged in the killing of the labor leader Joseph A. Yablonski and his wife and daughter 30 years ago, died on Oct. 31 at a nursing home in Tampa, Fla. He was 81.

title: A Positive Approach To An Incurable Disease
description: Jean Angell began falling down. Strolling outside on the street, or inside her Manhattan brownstone, her feet would suddenly turn clumsy and she would trip. But she looked fine and felt fine, and so when she and her husband told their three children in the summer of 1998 that she had contracted amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (Lou Gehrig's disease), her daughter Margaret was stunned.

title: The Picture Is Muddled On Turn To Derby
description: The colts and fillies had barely been sponged off after the biggest race of their 2-year-old lives, and their owners were already thinking about the first Saturday in May. In the barn of the Breeders' Cup Juvenile winner Anees, the trainer Alex Hassinger already had Kentucky -- as in Derby -- on his mind.

title: Omnicom Merges 2 Agency Units
description: Two Omnicom Group agencies, Merkley Newman Harty and Consumer Healthworks, both in New York, have merged. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Clean Air Counterattack
description: There were two important and potentially far-reaching victories for clean air advocates last week. On Wednesday, the federal government announced legal action aimed at forcing 32 coal-fired power plants in the Midwest and South to install modern anti-pollution controls or risk severe monetary damages. Two days later, Gov. George Pataki of New York disclosed that he would shortly impose new emissions standards on cars and some other vehicles sold in New York in an effort to force the automobile manufacturers to produce much cleaner cars on a faster timetable than required by federal law.

title: Dispute Over Plan To Use Jobless Aid For Parental Leave
description: A bitter struggle has erupted over a plan by President Clinton to allow states to pay unemployment benefits to workers who take time off to care for newborn infants.

title: Prague's Path: Euphoria to Anxiety
description: To the Editor:

title: Protest in Williamsburg
description: Running with friends and bodyguards in the middle of the pack, the controversial Austrian politico Jorg Haider slipped past the 10-mile mark apparently unnoticed by a group of Austrian students protesting his hard-line policies.

title: Taxis and Racism
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWEET, LAURA
description: SWEET-Laura. On November 7, 1999. Wife of the late Samuel. Beloved mother of Joan and Richard Jankel, Linda Sweet. Cherished grandmother of Alice and Jess Shatkin and Peter Jankel, and proud great-grandmother of Parker Tillie Shatkin. Graveside services Monday, 1 PM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont.

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
Hearings Offer View Into Private Banking
description: In 1997, federal bank examiners were pressing executives at Citibank Private Bank to explain the source of more than $50 million deposited into a secret account controlled by the president of Gabon, Omar Bongo, bank and Senate documents show.

title: LOCKDOWN -- A special report.; An Iron Hand at Rikers Island Drastically Reduces Violence
description: Just five years after city officials braced for riots on Rikers Island, where inmates routinely slit one another with razors, gangs were a menace and guards brawled with inmates in a perpetual fight for control, violence inside the sprawling complex of city jails has been brought to extraordinary lows.

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
Prague's Path: Euphoria to Anxiety
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Bassinine Error' Mars Tournament
description: Fox Sports's broadcast of the richest bass-fishing tournament ever ended yesterday with a glaring misstatement at the weigh-in that gave the impression that the $600,000 winner's check went to the wrong angler.

title: Equity Market Offerings Set For This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: In America; Marathon Man
description: Al Gore seemed to be enjoying himself. The instant reviews were coming in and they were quite favorable. The vice president had just finished a two-hour open meeting with 125 mostly independent voters in Plymouth, N.H. He answered every question they came up with, including one from a man who was convinced that the search for a cure for cancer should be financed by a steep dedicated tax on beer and ''every bottle of booze'' sold in America.

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
Dolphins Dominate On Defense
description: Steve McNair is not likely to doubt the Miami Dolphins' standing as one of the National Football League's stingiest defenses.

title: Pulling No Punches in the Dream Factory
description: In his 45 years as an agent and manager, stretching from the era of Catskill comedy to ''Saturday Night Live,'' Bernie Brillstein has never been accused of mincing words.

title: Image Is Poor, But Hartford Looks Good To Developers
description: Hartford had a bittersweet moment in the national spotlight last Thursday, when President Clinton came to town to announce that local companies were investing nearly $200 million to redevelop the city. It was good news, of course, but any temptation to bask in civic pride was probably tempered by the occasion for the visit: Hartford was a featured stop on Mr. Clinton's poverty tour, sharing billing with the Mississippi Delta, Newark and Appalachia.

title: INSIDE
description: Senate Inquiry on Citibank

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
THE ELITE'S CHOICE WINS HUGE VICTORY IN MEXICO PRIMARY
description: Franciso Labastida Ochoa, the candidate of the establishment in Mexico's governing party, won a decisive victory today in the party's first presidential primary election, rapid vote counts and early official returns showed. But his main opponent moved to open a battle over the results.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELSEY, FRANCES VOORHEES
description: KELSEY-Frances Voorhees. Age 83, died peacefully on November 6, 1999, at her residence in Meadow Lakes, Hightstown, NJ, as a result of a stroke which occurred on October 22. At her bedside were her loving husband of 58 years, H. Burr Kelsey, and her three devoted and loving children, Patricia Kelsey Schultz of Richmond, VA, Peter B. Kelsey of Fairfax, VA, and Marjorie Kelsey White of Annandale, VA. She is also survived by eight grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the First Presbyterian Church of Hightstown, Thursday, November 11, 1999, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Garden Club of America, 14 East 60th St, New York, NY 10022, or to a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Horse of the Year by Elimination
description: After all the upsets and long shots, the dreams won and lost in the Breeders' Cup, who is the Horse of the Year?

title: Out Like a Lion, and No Returning Like a Lamb
description: Erica Scheier, 26, a veterinarian from Hoboken, N.J., running yesterday's New York City Marathon, has never been a patient runner, and has never been inclined to wait for anything in life. She knew she was fast and wore a ''Go, Erica!'' T-shirt to gain crowd support.

title: I.B.M. to Offer PC's in Color, With Brand Name, Next Year
description: I.B.M. will introduce business personal computers with new designs and a new brand in the first half of 2000 to try to revive its money-losing PC unit, the company said here today.

title: Better Pay for Librarians
description: To the Editor:

title: Altered Crops Cause Mischief
description: To the Editor:

title: After a Jolt, Woman Now Runs for Two
description: At 1:50 p.m. yesterday, with 10 miles to go, Beth Griffin bounded down First Avenue, her blond hair bobbing in ponytails. Making it to the 16th mile and to the finish line of the New York City Marathon was no small feat for Griffin, 37, whose daily runs had turned into trips to the drug dealer 12 years ago when she was addicted to heroin.

title: A Top Government Lawyer Puts a Breakup on the Table
description: The Justice Department's top antitrust enforcer said for the first time yesterday that a breakup of Microsoft was within a range of remedies being considered in the government's antitrust suit against the software giant.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: The Nets' New Plan Brings a New Result
description: The Nets spoke about the motion offense that they had instituted on Saturday as if it were a magic potion, as if the cutting and passing it demanded would cure all that has afflicted them. They said that it would improve their shooting, their chemistry and their defense, and put an end to the surprising season-opening slide that had them confused and beleaguered heading into tonight's game against the Washington Wizards.

title: Accounts
description: * Glaxo Wellcome Inc., Research Triangle Park, N.C., part of Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C., to Ogilvy Healthcare, New York, part the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of WPP Group, to handle the first account for Advair, an asthma drug. Billings were estimated at $30 million.

title: Sports of The Times; When the Wall Is Internal and the Course Is in the Head
description: LISA BUSTER did not run one mile yesterday. But the gamut of highs and lows she experienced were an emotional marathon that left her drained at the end of the day. She watched one client surge toward history, then fade, then surge again, then fade to fifth. She saw another surge, fade and finish second.

title: Altered Crops Cause Mischief
description: To the Editor:

title: They Came, They Ran, They Conquered
The Truth According to Otis Chandler
description: The startling letter that Otis Chandler wrote last week to the staff of the newspaper run by his family for over a century may be remembered as a striking moment in the effort to protect journalistic integrity from the commercial pressures of a new age in media economics. Before retiring as publisher of The Los Angeles Times in 1980, Mr. Chandler turned an uneven, provincial daily into a newspaper with ambitious news coverage and a national reputation for quality. But it is also one of many American papers that have struggled in ensuing years to maintain growth and profitability.

title: Being Too Hard on Microsoft?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Rangers Win for the First Time in Three Weeks
description: The strategy seemed foolproof: keep the Rangers on the power play and they would not score.

title: An Economy British Air Can't Afford
description: Sipping coffee in his office, Robert J. Ayling seemed relaxed for a chief executive whose job is in peril, if you believe the reports in the British press and the whispering around water coolers in London's financial district.

title: Bradley Denounces Gore Over Health Care
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley issued his strongest criticism yet of Vice President Al Gore today, asserting that Mr. Gore had fallen prey to an incremental mentality of Washington and betrayed a ''fundamental Democratic principle'' by not pushing for universal health care as a candidate for president.

title: Martha's Back, Vulnerable, Vicious and 80
description: When Uta Hagen played Martha in the original Broadway production of Edward Albee's ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' in 1962, she placed her galvanic imprint on the role and helped to define the play. Something similar occurred at least twice in plays by Tennessee Williams, with Laurette Taylor's performance in ''The Glass Menagerie'' and Marlon Brando's in ''A Streetcar Named Desire.'' Ms. Hagen has occasionally returned to other roles, but after closing in ''Virginia Woolf'' in London in 1964 and making an original cast recording, she has never again appeared in this play -- until now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOBBS, EDWARD ROBERT, D.D.S.
description: HOBBS-Edward Robert, D.D.S. On Nov. 7, 1999. Loving husband of Diane Cucchi, adored father of Andrew. Dear brother of Robert and Barbara Hobbs. Devoted son-inlaw of Mr. & Mrs. Anthony Cucchi, brother-in-law Mark Cucchi and Lisa Kaelin and Alyce Hobbs. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Thursday, November 11, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Memorial Service at St. Hilda's-St. Hugh's, 619 West 114 Street on Friday, November 12th at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory to St. Hilda's-St.Hugh's.

title: Judge Who Said What? Technology Shares Continue Their Surge
description: Technology stocks yesterday shrugged off the stinging judicial rebuke delivered to Microsoft last Friday and surged to a seventh consecutive record.

title: Acquisition Of 2 Banks To Proceed
description: A prolonged delay in HSBC Holdings $9.9 billion acquisition of the Republic New York Corporation and Safra Republic Holdings ended today after Edmond J. Safra, who founded both banks, agreed to accept $450 million less for his stakes.

title: RMC MAKES OFFER FOR RUGBY
description: As expected, the RMC Group, the largest maker of ready-mix concrete, will acquire the Rugby Group, the British cement maker, for $:896 million, or $1.45 billion. Last week, Rugby said it had received an unsolicited offer, but did not identify the suitor, leading to speculation that Anglo American P.L.C. had bid after its offer for Tarmac had been rebuffed, though that bid was later accepted.

title: Education Is a Sticking Point in Negotiations on Spending Bills
