description: Congress and the White House argued late into tonight on the year's long-overdue spending bills but remained deadlocked over billions of dollars and crucial paragraphs of legislative language.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEITZ, BROTHER CARL JOHN, S.J.
description: SEITZ-Brother Carl John, S.J. Beloved brother of Rev. Paul Seitz, Kenneth Seitz, Dorothy Schrilla and Sr. Marie Seitz, D.C. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray-Weigel Hall, 515 E. Fordham Road, Bronx. Visitation today 3-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 11:30 AM, at Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel. For information, contact Farenga Bros., Inc. 718-654-0500.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOCKMAN, EUGENE J.
description: BOCKMAN-Eugene J. After a long illness. Nov. 8th, 1999, at Beth Israel Hospital in New York at the age of 76. Beloved husband of Miriam, cherished father of Peter, Claudia and Andrea, and adored grandfather of Maria, Bianca, Kate, Trevor and Kyle. He was proud of his 41 years of public service in the City of New York, his nationwide reputation as an Archivist & Librarian, his service record as a decorated veteran of WW II, and most of all his family. Services Wednesday, 10:45 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Visiting hours Tuesday 68PM. In lieu of flowers, friends may donate to The American Parkinson's Disease Association, The Parkinson's Disease Foundation, or the Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Hospital.

title: Pope Meets Georgian Orthodox, at a Religious Distance
description: Pope John Paul II met with the patriarch of the Georgian Orthodox Church today in an encounter that visibly illustrated the lingering obstacles to the pope's longtime dream of reconciling the Roman Catholic Church and Eastern Orthodoxy.

title: A Coming-Together of Foes To Assess Internet's Impact
description: Over the weekend, Robert J. Herbold, the chief operating officer of Microsoft, and James L. Barksdale, the former president of Netscape Communications, appeared on television, radio and in newspapers, commenting from opposite sides of the Microsoft antitrust case.

title: So Sue Me
description: To the Editor:

title: New Answers to an Old Question: Who Got Here First?
description: For most of the 20th century, the solution to the mystery of the original Americans -- where did they come from, when and how? -- seemed as clear as the geography of the Bering Strait, the climate of the last ice age and the ubiquity of finely wrought stone hunting weapons known as Clovis points.

title: Too Easy on Emissions
description: To the Editor:

title: With Offense Floundering, Parcells Is Not Optimistic
description: No, the Jets did not lose on Sunday. But Coach Bill Parcells has never sounded as pessimistic about his offense -- and in particular his quarterback, Rick Mirer -- as he did today.

title: Investors Shrug Off Finding on Microsoft
description: Microsoft stock fell $1.625 a share yesterday, to $90, but ended the day higher than the $87 a share reached in after-hours trading on Friday. That was the day a federal judge found that the government had proved that the company had a monopoly and had used it to stifle competition. Investors seem to have decided that even the harshest of all possible remedies for Microsoft -- a breakup of the software giant -- would not be a disaster for the company or the stock market.

title: Turning Up the Amps, and Kicking Those Legs High
description: Before Fushitsusha's performance at Tonic on Saturday night, the band prepared and so did the audience.

title: Museum to Display Times Capsule on Dec. 4
description: This year editors of The New York Times Magazine invited 48 designers, architects and engineers to submit proposals for The New York Times Capsule, a vessel to preserve artifacts from this century for the next 1,000 years. The winning design is to be announced on Dec. 4, and it will be displayed, along with a sampling of the items considered essential for understanding the 20th century, beginning that day at the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Hospital to Form Venture With Consultants
description: The First Consulting Group, a health care consulting firm, plans to form a venture with New York Presbyterian Hospital to run the hospital's information-technology and telecommunications departments, executives said yesterday.

title: Runner-Up in Mexican Primary Says He Won't Protest Results
description: Roberto Madrazo Pintado, the candidate who finished second in the governing party's first presidential primary after a rancorous campaign that had seemed to threaten a party rupture, acknowledged his defeat today. He said he would not protest the results of Sunday's balloting, or leave the party.

title: Arts Abroad; Celebrating the Capture Of Another Glorious Space
description: The refined perils listed on the day's shooting schedule were a good clue that the filmmakers lurking about on a dewy morning in Suffolk might be James Ivory and Ismail Merchant.

title: Whitman and Forbes, Separated Now by Political Ideology
description: Steve Forbes brought his Republican presidential campaign into New Jersey's capital today, speaking on the steps of a war memorial a block from the office of his childhood pal, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGEL, RUTH. (NEE EPSTEIN)
description: VOGEL-Ruth. (nee Epstein). Died peacefully November 7, 1999 at the age of 82 at her home in Boynton Beach, FL. Formerly of New York City, Chatham, N.Y. and Freeport, L.I. Beloved wife of Dr. George for 56 years. Devoted mother of Dr. Robert and Ronald. Loving grandmother of Daria, Evan, Geoffrey and Alec. Dedicated volunteer of the Jewish Board of Social Children's Services. Graveside service to be held 11AM, Wednesday at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, N.Y. Donations in Ruth's name may be made to the Fund for Blood and Cancer Research, Weill Medical College of Cornell University, C/O Dr. Mark Pasmantier, 407 East 70 Street, N.Y., N.Y. 10021.

title: Leon Stukelj, 100, Medalist in Gymnastics in 3 Olympics
description: Leon Stukelj of Slovenia, a gymnast who was born only two years after the first modern Olympics and became the oldest living Olympic gold medalist, died yesterday in Ljubljana, Slovenia. He was four days short of his 101st birthday.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: John G. Bonomi, 76, Lawyer Who Sought to Disbar Nixon
description: John G. Bonomi, a lawyer who investigated the role of organized crime in professional boxing and later successfully sought the disbarment of President Richard M. Nixon, died on Saturday at his home in Irvington, N.Y. He was 76.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Dining section on Wednesday about inexpensive cooking classes in New York misstated the telephone number for Williams-Sonoma, which is offering evening classes on holiday entertaining. It is (212) 689-6832.

title: Of Spouses, Sex, Sleep and Snoring
description: If there were ever any doubts that there are a lot of snorers out there, and an equal number of long-suffering spouses, a new study puts them to rest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, RITA
description: COHEN-Rita. Temple Sinai records with profound sorrow the passing of its charter member, beloved wife of the late Murray Cohen, devoted mother of Deborah Shah, Justin Cohen and Jennifer Cohen and grandmother of Lauren Shah. Heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire family. Rabbi Bruce S. Block Jane Koch Gellman, Pres.

title: OFFER FOR EXPLOSIVES MAKER
description: The Scandinavian buyout firm, Industri Kapital, plans to offer 5.3 billion kroner, or $670 million, for Dyno A.S.A., the world's second-largest maker of explosives. Industri Kapital plans to bid 206 kroner for each Dyno share after a review of the company. Shares of Dyno, a Norwegian company, climbed 10.5 kroner, to 194.5 kroner, bringing its market value to 5.0 billion kroner. A purchase of Dyno, which also makes specialty chemicals like adhesives, would be Industri Kapital's second investment in chemicals after it acquired Neste Chemicals for $540 million last month.

title: NORTEL NETWORKS FORMS AN ALLIANCE WITH MICROSOFT
description: The Nortel Networks Corporation plans to announce today an alliance with the Microsoft Corporation that will make much of Nortel's networking code available to outside developers, executives close to the deal said yesterday. Nortel also intends to announce price cuts of as much as 50 percent for many of the data networking products that it has developed with Bay Networks Inc., which Nortel acquired for $9.1 billion in 1998, the executives said. The announcements could be made as soon as today. Nortel declined to comment on the report. Nortel, which is locked in an intense battle in the communications equipment industry has taken market share from many telecommunications equipment companies as it has linked its fortunes to the Internet.

title: AIDS Virus Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Richard Martin, 52, Curator of the Costume Institute
description: Richard Martin, who infused the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art with his deep knowledge of popular culture and art history, died yesterday at his apartment in New York. He was 52.

title: Drugs, Safe and Not Safe, in Pregnancy
description: The thalidomide tragedy of the 1960's touched off intense concern and a vast amount of research about the safety of drugs taken during pregnancy. Many drugs (and druglike substances, including coffee, alcohol and tobacco) were tested in laboratory animals or studied in pregnant women. Some were found to be potential hazards to developing fetuses, usually only at the beginning of pregnancy but in some cases only near the time of birth and in others throughout gestation.

title: Doctors Are Reminded, 'Wash Up!'
description: March 27 was John Allen's last good day. He had been semicomatose in the days leading up to his heart transplant surgery, but now the transplant was working well and he was alert and communicative. ''He was his old self,'' recalled his wife, Sandy, a psychiatric nurse, who lives in Manhattan.

title: George V. Higgins, 59, Author Of Dialogue-Rich Crime Novels
description: George V. Higgins, who turned a prosecutor's knowledge of lowlife crooks into gritty Boston crime novels that unfolded in the gamy dialect of the city's hoodlums and cops, was found dead on Saturday at his home in Milton, Mass. He was 59.

title: INSIDE
description: China vs. Sect: 111 Arrests

title: Total Immersion in Schumann's Complex Imagination
description: It is not easy to make an interesting program out of one composer's works, especially a past master. But the all-Schumann program of chamber works and songs presented at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday night was conceived and executed in a way that helped listeners hear this master's music in fresh ways. The event was part of a series organized by the cellist Robert Martin called ''Music for Mischa,'' which commemorates the more than 50 concerts that Mischa Schneider, the legendary cellist and longtime member of the Budapest String Quartet, gave at the museum.

title: A Mirage of Amazonian Size; Delusions of Economic Grandeur Deep in Brazil's Interior
description: Two decades ago, the American billionaire Daniel K. Ludwig took a bold but very expensive gamble here. After buying a piece of the Amazon jungle larger than the state of Connecticut, the shipping magnate spent a large chunk of his fortune building an industrial, mining and agricultural complex that he imagined would prosper as a result of the world's growing appetite for products like paper, aluminum, porcelain, rice, beef and pork.

title: U.S. vs. Microsoft: Trouble for the Software King
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite appearances, dot-com companies try to spend advertising dollars effectively.
description: IT often seems these days as if dot-com companies are peddling their wares by buying up every moment of commercial time and every inch of advertising space everywhere from matchbooks to cyberspace to the Super Bowl.

title: Low Profile for F.B.I. in Crash Inquiry
description: Shortly after 4:30 a.m. on Oct. 31, Lewis D. Schiliro, the top F.B.I. official in New York, was awakened by a call from one of his deputies with the news that EgyptAir Flight 990 had crashed.

title: Return to the Basics: Single-Speed Bikes
description: At this year's international bike show, manufacturers introduced new bikes made of ultralight aerospace materials like titanium, aluminum and other metals. Many come equipped with front-suspension forks, rear suspension, hydraulic disc brakes and 27 gears.

title: New Rules for Viewing Executions of Murderers
description: Family members of murder victims would be allowed to witness the killer's execution, under a bill released yesterday by the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: CUT IN JAPANESE GROWTH
description: Japan's economy grew more slowly than previously indicated between April and June, suggesting that large amounts of government spending are still needed to keep the recovery alive. Japan's economy expanded one-tenth of 1 percent in the quarter, less than the two-tenths of 1 percent initially reported two months ago, the Economic Planning Agency said. It was the second consecutive quarter of growth after 15 months of contraction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEHADI, RUTH LAMBERT
description: SHEHADI-Ruth Lambert. Age 76, born in Saint Louis, MO, graduate of Washington University, long time Greenwich resident. Beloved mother and wife, devoted advocate for the mentally ill. Her peace, love and sense of humor will be sorely missed. Services Thursday 11 A.M. at First Presbyterian Church, 18 Lafayette Place, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The National Alliance for the Mentally Ill, 200 North Glebe Road, Suite 1015, Arlington, VA 22203, would be appreciated.

title: Man Is Charged in Home-Repair Fraud in Queens
description: A Florida man suspected in a nationwide home-repair fraud scheme has been charged with stealing more than $130,000 from an 81-year-old Queens man, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAMSON, HOWARD
description: BRAMSON-Howard. Young Israel of Flatbush mourns the passing of our beloved member and supporter Howard Bramson. Kenneth Auman, Rabbi Mark Goldstein, Pres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERRLICH, MARION M.
description: HERRLICH-Marion M., late of Grafton, VT, on October 26 in Ambler, PA at the age of 93. She was the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Watson E. Morgan of Bristol and then Burlington, VT and the wife of the predeceased William E. Herrlich. Before moving to Grafton in 1967, Mr. and Mrs. Herrlich lived for the greater part of 35 years in New York and Bronxville, NY. She is survived by her children, Elisabeth H. Harper, William M. and Katherine H. Wahlert, and by seven grandchildren. A woman of great grace and kindness, she personnified the strength and will of traditional Vermonters. A graveside service of burial will be held in Grafton on November 20 at 1:30 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Office of Annual Giving at Middlebury College.

title: $22.5 Million Monet Leads Fall's First Big Auction
description: No one in the audience at Christie's last night flinched when a Monet ''Waterlilies'' sold for $22.5 million. Or when a Pissarro cityscape fetched more than twice its estimate. Or when a London dealer snapped up five paintings, presumably for stock, paying well above the high estimate on every lot.

title: Incomplete Dream Study
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE RECORD: Governor Bush and the Environment; Bush Approach to Pollution: Preference for Self-Policing
description: Early this summer, with political pressure mounting to address his state's severe air pollution problems, Gov. George W. Bush signed a law he regards as the gold star of his green resume: A program to regulate outdated industrial plants that are among the heaviest polluters in Texas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, CEIL (NEE NOVISON)
description: LEVY-Ceil (nee Novison). May 11, 1914 to November 7, 1999, surrounded by many loving people to ease her passage into the next phase of the journey. Her time on earth was only the beginning. Her spirit, courage, intelligence and love of learning leave a legacy to her family and friends now and forever. Among the survivors are brother Hyman; daughters Rodelle, Sheryl and Suelle; son-in-laws Irwin and David; grandchildren Patti and Scott, Robin, Stacey and Gregg; and great grandchildren Max, Lindsey and Mitchell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZAR, ARTHUR
description: LAZAR-Arthur. Age 87. Passed away peacefully on November 6, 1999 at his home. Beloved husband of the late Rosa Lazar for 57 years. Loving father and father-inlaw of Mattie and David Schlang and the late Laurence Lazar. Cherished grandfather of Lisa and Julie Schlang, loving brother of Lil Hollander and the late Jack and Marty Lazar. Beloved brother-inlaw, uncle and great uncle. Arthur had an insatiable zest for life. His kind heart, wisdom and generous nature will be deeply missed.

title: Senator Delays Vote to Confirm Admiral as Envoy to China
description: A Republican senator has blocked the confirmation of retired Adm. Joseph W. Prueher to be the next Ambassador to China, saying he is worried that the admiral is too friendly to China.

title: When Foods Do Harm
description: To the Editor:

title: Heard the One About Bass Tourney on Fox?
description: Five points about Fox's broadcast of the the first Ranger Millennium M1 Bass Tournament on Sunday:

title: Oiling the Gears for the Body's Clock
description: Older people may find it hard to miss that they are the targets of yet another aggressive advertising campaign, this one for products containing melatonin.

title: Front Row
description: To Have and to Hold

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELSEY, FRANCES VOORHEES
description: KELSEY-Frances Voorhees. Age 83, died peacefully on November 6, 1999, at her residence in Meadow Lakes, Hightstown, NJ, as a result of a stroke which occurred on October 22. At her bedside were her loving husband of 58 years, H. Burr Kelsey, and her three devoted and loving children, Patricia Kelsey Schultz of Richmond, VA, Peter B. Kelsey of Fairfax, VA, and Marjorie Kelsey White of Annandale, VA. She is also survived by eight grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the First Presbyterian Church of Hightstown, Thursday, November 11, 1999, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Garden Club of America, 14 East 60th St, New York, New York 10022, or to a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: After Fire, 3rd Avenue Bridge Is Closed for the Morning Rush
description: An overnight fire on the Third Avenue Bridge stalled commuters traveling from the Bronx to Manhattan yesterday morning but caused no serious damage to the bridge, which was reopened just after rush hour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNNINGHAM, PHILIP TRACY (USN, COMMANDER, RET.)
description: CUNNINGHAM - Philip Tracy (USN, Commander, Ret.) Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Microdyne Corporation of Alexandria, Virginia died suddenly on November 6, 1999 at his home in Alexandria, Virginia. Mr. Cunningham was the son of the late Daniel T. Cunningham and Hilda Bedingham Cunningham. Born in Washington, D.C. and raised in New Jersey, he was a graduate of Holy Cross (BS) in 1959 and Harvard (MBA) in 1968. In the last years of his life, he spent his summers in his Watch Hill, Rhode Island home where he was active in community affairs, a member of the Watch Hill Yacht Club and the Lighthouse Keepers Association. He is survived by his wife, Lizanne Stahnke Cunningham, their twin children, Daniel and Jacqueline, his first wife, Mary Lou Riggio Cunningham and their four children, Elizabeth Cunningham of Clinton, NJ, Maura Cunningham Spaeth of Cos Cob, CT., Katharine Cunningham of Fairfax, VA and Sheila Cunningham Donaldson of Fairfax, VA., two grandsons, Joseph Morano and Noah Spaeth of CT. and a sister, Mrs. Matthew Kelley of PA. Friends may call at the Demaine Funeral Home, 520 South Washington Street, Alexandria, Virginia on Tuesday, November 9, 1999 from 7 until 8:30PM. A funeral service will be held at St. Mary's Catholic Church, 310 South Royal Street, Alexandria, Virginia on Wednesday, November 10, 1999 at 10:00AM. Private interment in Arlington National Cemetery on November 19, 1999. In lieu of flowers, the family requires contributions be made to the Campagna Center, 418 South Washington Street, Alexandria, Virginia 22314.

title: Flu Shows Up Early in Brooklyn and Bronx
description: Like an inconsiderate house guest, the flu has arrived in New York City more than two weeks before anyone expected it. The season's first influenza outbreaks have been reported in Brooklyn and the Bronx, the city's health commissioner said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Education Life section on Sunday about Mary Daly, a feminist professor at Boston College, misspelled the surname of a Boston Globe columnist who criticized her. He is Adrian Walker, not Walter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGAND, E. VICTOR AND CONSTANCE
description: MARGAND-E. Victor and Constance. Beloved parents, longtime residents of New Rochelle, NY. Suddenly in Florida. Graveside gathering, 2 PM, Sunday, November 14, 1999, at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. For more information, call Riverside Mount Vernon, 914-664-6800. In lieu of flowers, contributions to a charity or organization of your choice in their honor would be appreciated.

title: Sports of The Times; N.F.L. Takes A Timeout For Grieving
description: PRO football coaches often lament that it is nearly impossible to acquire the complete attention of their players for more than a reasonable stretch. We stress reasonable. Four or five hours of work a day and, hey, after that, in many circles, coaches lose players' eyes, ears and brains, no matter how creative the snatch.

title: Political Memo; Pataki Tests The Winds With Moves On Emissions
description: Last summer, as environmentalists called for air pollution controls on New York's oldest power plants, Gov. George E. Pataki showed no interest, declining to include them in a related bill. Then, his administration briefly backed away from its demand that plants in other states cut their emissions, before reversing itself under intense criticism.

title: Third Republican Will Seek Lautenberg's Seat in Senate
description: A Congressman from New Jersey, Bob Franks, yesterday became the third Republican to announce his candidacy for the United States Senate seat being vacated by Frank R. Lautenberg, a Democrat.

title: Diagnosis Was Malaria, but Experts Disagreed on the Source
description: A 106-degree fever with teeth-clenching chills would frighten anyone, and when the cause cannot be identified quickly, such symptoms are even more alarming.

title: Satellite TV Bill Advances in Congress
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed today on legislation aimed at giving satellite television companies like Hughes Electronics' DirecTV assistance in competing with cable TV.

title: Priceline Will Add Phone Calls to Its Menu
description: Priceline.com said today that it would soon add long-distance telephone calls to its plane ticket, hotel room, car and mortgage services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, RICHARD
description: MARTIN-Richard. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art are profoundly saddened by the untimely loss of the curator of our Costume Institute, Richard Martin. In his six immensely productive and influential years at the Museum, Richard brought an extraordinary intelligence, an unfailing eye, and a mesmerizing style to The Costume Institute, emerging not only as the most acclaimed curator in his field, but deservedly as one of the nation's leading spokesmen on all aspects of the history of fashion. At the Met, he challenged all of us to broaden our concept of costume, and it is no small tribute to his vision and zeal that both professionals and the public responded so enthusiastically to his exhibition program. His bravery and commitment will not soon be forgotten. We will miss him greatly. Philippe de Montebello, Director

title: Four Advertisers Turn to Suissa Miller
description: Suissa Miller in Los Angeles, seeking to rebound from the loss of the $150 million Acura account last summer, has been named to handle assignments for four advertisers with combined billings estimated at $55 million to $65 million.

title: Restaurants Could Use Table Manners
description: HERE'S one that we all should probably have seen coming. Manhattan now has what is being described as the city's first restaurant with a ''cell phone zone,'' a special area to which compulsive yakkers are exiled when the urge to tele-gab becomes irresistible.

title: When Foods Do Harm
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Sends Envoys to Try to Close a Deal on Opening Chinese Markets to the U.S.
description: After a long telephone call with President Jiang Zemin of China on Saturday night, President Clinton sent his trade representative and his top economic adviser to Beijing today. They will try to close a deal to bring China into the World Trade Organization in return for a broad opening of its markets to American-made goods.

title: Sorry, Wrong Number
description: To the Editor:

title: N.T.T. SHARES PRICED
description: Japan's Finance Ministry priced its sale of 952,000 shares in the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, the world's largest phone company, at 1.66 million yen each, raising up to 1.56 trillion yen, or $14.7 billion. Investors offered to buy more than seven times the amount of N.T.T. shares available for sale. The ministry, whose stake in the former government monopoly will fall to 53 percent from 59 percent, is selling this fifth block of N.T.T. shares to help finance the government's bank-bailout program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAY, HELEN F.
description: MAY-Helen F. Of West Islip, L.I. On November 7, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Leo. Loving mother of Edward and the late Patsy Ann Sorrentino. Cherished grandmother of four, dear sister of Evelyn Wilson. Friends may visit at the Claude R. Boyd-Spencer Funeral Home, 448 West Main Street, Babylon, L.I. today 24:30pm and 7-9:30pm

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRULETZ, ROSALIND
description: STRULETZ-Rosalind. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons notes with sadness the passing of Rosalind Struletz, beloved sister of Morton Olshan, our Honorary Trustee Co-Chairman. We extend condolences to Mort, Carole and his family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Cantor Debra Stein-Davidson Donald Zucker, President

title: Indonesia's Students Pledge To Press Democratic Agenda
description: ''Welcome, Gus,'' read a big white banner the other day, using a nickname for Indonesia's new president. ''We are the students and we will be your opposition.''

title: Israel and Palestinians Start Major Talks
description: Israeli and Palestinian teams sat down here today to begin negotiating a permanent settlement of their century-old conflict, staking out opposing positions but promising to work faithfully to reach an accord.

title: Giants Make a Move Into a First-Place Tie by Standing Still
description: When the Giants went away for the weekend, they were just another hopeful, but imperfect, National Football League team. When they came back to work Monday morning, they reconvened as a first-place team.

title: After 40 Years, New York-Havana Flights Will Resume
description: Almost 40 years after the last Havana-bound commercial airplane took off from a New York City airport, flights between the two cities will resume next month, fulfilling one of the key elements of the Clinton administration's more relaxed policy toward Cuba.

title: Sprewell Adds Spark To Knicks' Victory
description: Ernie Grunfeld flew to Milwaukee four days after Michael Jordan retired last January to gauge whether Latrell Sprewell could resuscitate his own career and an aging Knicks into the post-Jordan era.

title: Court's Refusal to Hear Cases Preserves Delays on Death Row
description: The question, as framed for the Supreme Court by lawyers for death row inmates in Florida and Nebraska, was whether -- all other arguments about the death penalty aside -- a decades-long wait for a death sentence to be carried out is itself so ''cruel and unusual'' as to be unconstitutional.

title: Financial Times Picks BBDO New York
description: BBDO New York, part of the BBDO Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, has been chosen as the agency to handle the American introduction of ft.com, the Web site of The Financial Times newspaper. Though billings were not disclosed, they were estimated by Adweek at $40 million.

title: National News Briefs; M.I.T. to Get $100 Million
description: Kenan E. Sahin, a Turkish immigrant who studied management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and went on to found a software company, has said he will give $100 million to the university. The gift came as M.I.T. began a $1.5 billion capital campaign.

title: Havel Is a Hero
description: To the Editor:

title: More Than 300 Nurses Strike At a Hospital on Long Island
description: More than 300 registered nurses went on strike yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Plainview, N.Y., as the two sides remained deadlocked over the nurses' demands for strict rules on the ratio of nurses to patients.

title: Ancient Resonance in Twinkling Syncopations
description: Cosmas Magaya spent a few moments dissecting one of the pieces performed by the Mbira Masters of Zimbabwe on Friday night at the Washington Square Church. It had four phrases, he explained, plinking simple pairs of notes on his mbira, the African thumb piano with a buzzing gourd resonator. But a second, interlocking part, with rhythms staggered against the first, instantly transformed the rudimentary phrases into a twinkling lattice of syncopation and harmony, ready for vocals to thread through and around it. With percussion, voices and the orderly plinking of the mbiras, the music layered on syncopations until it seemed to multiply the number of musicians onstage.

title: First Seat on School Bus Proves Hardest to Fill
description: A national shortage of school bus drivers, caused by the roaring economy and a rise in the school-age population, is making students wait up to an hour for a ride, delaying and canceling field trips and athletic events, and forcing mechanics, transportation supervisors and even some teachers to get behind the wheel.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAASS, IRVING B.
description: HAASS-Irving B., on October 18, 1999, in Boca Raton, Florida at age 82. He was a longtime resident of Valley Stream and Roslyn, NY. Married for 51 years to the late Marcella Rosenthal Haass, he is survived by his sister, Miriam Mayer; his children, Barbara Haass Barshay and Richard; and by his grandchildren Jill, Blythe, Allyson, Courtney, Samuel, and Francesca. A graduate of Brooklyn College, a veteran of WW II, he was a distinguished securities analyst on Wall Street, where for decades he was a partner with David J. Greene & Co. Devoted to family and work, he will be sorely missed. Memorial donations may be made to the Salvation Army.

title: Gay Response to Falwell
description: To the Editor:

title: Coalition of Jews Protests Southern Baptist Conversion Tactics
description: The Southern Baptist Convention, the nation's largest Protestant denomination, has always proclaimed it has a mission to reach out to people worldwide to urge them to a belief in Jesus Christ as the Messiah. But new efforts it has undertaken, aimed at converting Jews and Hindus, have generated a backlash from members of those faiths.

title: Trying to Balance Legal Sanity and Sense
description: TALK about the law with H. Richard Uviller, a Columbia Law School professor and veteran court buff, and he will lean forward, his eyes sparkling, his deep voice lifting itself from its gravel bed. Talk about his life, and it seems as if he is referring to a second cousin, someone he liked but didn't know very well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFARB, FRIEDA
description: GOLDFARB-Frieda The Board of Governors and membership of Edgewood Country Club record with deep sorrow the death of Mrs. Frieda Goldfarb, an esteemed member, and extend to her family its deepest sympathy. Arthur I. Frankel, President Saul Friedland, Secretary

title: On Top of the World, the Cantor's Musical Son
description: Did you miss ''The Jazz Singer'' when it opened with George Jessel as its star at the old Fulton Theater in 1925? Or when it returned in 1927 as the primitive but trailblazing Warner Brothers-Vitaphone talking film with Al Jolson thrilling the audience at the Capitol Theater when he said: ''Wait a minute; wait a minute. You ain't heard nothing yet''?

title: Thanking Freud
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RIGG, TREVOR MARK ANTHONY
description: RIGG-Trevor Mark Anthony, Esq. In loving memory of our dear ''Bunney'' who passed away on November 9, 1990. Sadly missed by mother, brothers and sisters, nephews, nieces, in-laws and friends.

title: U.S. vs. Microsoft: Trouble for the Software King
description: To the Editor:

title: BP Amoco Quarterly Profit Jumps 72%
description: Bolstered by higher oil prices and deep reductions in costs, BP Amoco today announced a 72 percent rise in third quarter profits and forecast higher gains next year from its planned $33.6 billion purchase of ARCO.

title: Bradley Bluntly Attacks Gore
description: Bill Bradley said the vice president had betrayed a ''fundamental Democratic principle'' by not backing universal health care. Page A23.

title: Interbrand Group Starting Foundation
description: The Interbrand Group in New York, a brand and corporate identity consulting company owned by the Omnicom Group, is starting a foundation to help charitable and social welfare organizations raise their public profiles and improve their fund-raising.

title: Treasury Report Faults Comptroller
description: A regulatory agency has been lax in monitoring banks for possible money laundering, according to a preliminary, and still confidential, report by the inspector general's office of the Treasury Department.

title: Toll Records Provide Trail In Audit of Prison Workers
description: For nearly a year and a half, state authorities say, dozens of prison employees spent their workdays tending to personal affairs and then falsified time sheets to cover their tracks. The scheme might never have been uncovered, the authorities say, had the employees not committed one minor blunder: using their state-issued E-ZPasses and cellular phones wherever they went.

title: GALLAHER WON'T MAKE OFFER
description: Less than a week after acknowledging that it had approached the French tobacco maker Seita about a possible bid, the Gallaher Group, a British cigarette maker, said it would not make an offer. A bid could have scuttled Seita's proposed merger with Tabacalera of Spain, but Gallaher said it could not reach an agreement with Sieta after five days of negotiations. Seita and Tabacalera are now set to complete their planned merger at the end of the month.

title: Rescuing Balenciaga, With a Glance at the Past
description: In his long, puritanical career as a dressmaker, Cristobal Balenciaga never gave an interview and seldom saw a client. He was a recluse deluxe, driving to work in his blue Jaguar, dining with his friend Coco Chanel, visiting his homes in his native Spain, but always comfortably cloistered. When a client asked if she might bring a friend to see his show, one of the couturier's minions replied, ''Curious women are not welcome here.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, LAUSON HARVEY
description: STONE-Lauson Harvey. Beloved husband of Jane Hunter Stone, loving father of Harlan Fiske Stone II, and Peter Hunter Stone. Loving father-in-law of Helen Galatan Stone and Paola Malanotte Stone. Devoted grandfather of Christopher Harlan Stone and Emily Palmer Stone. Family will receive friends Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9 at Jere J. Cronin Funeral Home, 115 Atlantic Ave, Brooklyn Heights, N.Y.

title: When Fire Consumes a Sense of Smell
description: Several years ago, doctors at the Smell and Taste Treatment and Research Foundation noticed something odd: within a two-month period, six firefighters came in for treatment and were found to have lost the sense of smell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUTILLO, EDITH
description: CUTILLO-Edith, 88, of Flushing, on November 6. Born in Manhattan, Ms. Cutillo was a graduate of Hunter College who joined the Red Cross as a social worker in 1944 and by 1947 was promoted to Casework Supervisor. After securing a Master's Degree in social work from Columbia University, she became Senior Intake Casework Supervisor in 1963. Meanwhile at home, she tended her aging parents with the aid of her sister Emily and, for several years, helped take care of her sister Lucille's three children, Thomas, Kathleen and Robert Murphy, and then became a surrogate mother to her sister Lena's three sons, John, Edward and Ronald Butscher. In 1966, disappointed and outraged by the glass ceiling in place at the Red Cross, she left the organization to take a position as Senior Social Worker at Elmhurst City Hospital, retiring from there in 1974. Edith Cutillo's adult life was dedicated to the health and happiness of others.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Managed-Care Company To Let Doctors Have Say

title: Rangers Approach $60 Million, Power Play Not Included
description: For the Rangers, this season's power play has provided no advantage at all. A disadvantage is much more like it.

title: U.S. vs. Microsoft: Trouble for the Software King
description: To the Editor:

title: ARCH COMMUNICATIONS TO TAKE OVER PAGING NETWORK
description: The Arch Communications Group, the No. 2 paging-services company, agreed yesterday to buy a larger rival Paging Network Inc. for about $1.36 billion in stock and assumed bank debt to keep competitive with wireless phone companies. As part of the transaction, the companies want to convert about $1.6 billion debt and preferred shares into common stock of the combined company. Arch Communications will exchange 0.1247 share for each share of Paging Network, also known as PageNet, or about 85 cents. That is 12 percent below Friday's closing price. Dallas-based PageNet warned that it might file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection if enough investors do not agree to the debt conversion.

title: Successor To DiCicco Is Sought
description: UNITED STATES WOMEN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPIN, DOROTHY S.
description: LAPIN-Dorothy S. On Nov. 6. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving sister of Jacob and Mortimer. Sisters-in-law Betty Silverman and Evelyn Goodstein. Cherished friends Evelyn Denker, Beatrice Vare, Ruth Denker and loving godmother of Samuel Denker. Also survived by nieces and nephews. Services today 1PM at Mt. Hebron cemetery, Flushing, New York.

title: Etcheverry Promoting Education and Soccer
description: As American soccer fans know, few images can match the beauty of Marco Antonio Etcheverry at the controls of a D.C. United attack in full flight -- engine purring, ball zipping from player to player as if each were taking orders from an all-knowing master.

title: John A. Puelicher, 78, Chairman Of a Bank Holding Company
description: John A. Puelicher, retired chairman of the board of the Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, a bank holding company, died on Oct. 30 at his home in Milwaukee. He was 78.

title: U.S. vs. Microsoft: Trouble for the Software King
description: To the Editor:

title: Paris Journal; A Fouled City Puts Its Foot Down, but Carefully
description: The young woman in the White Sox cap would give her name only as Sophie. Her golden lab would go by Mellis. No last names, please.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I did not free Europe, or release my people, or any of that nonsense. It was that crowd in front of me, and the hopeless confusion of my leadership, that opened those gates.''

title: Abroad at Home; Hypocrites in Power
description: There have been contemptible Congresses before, and historians can argue about which was worst. But I remember none in modern times as dismal as the one now sitting, the 106th Congress. It has set new records in cynicism and hypocrisy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, WILLIAM
description: HALPERN-William. The principals and staff of Diamond, Wohl, Fried, Roth & Co., CPAs, are deeply saddened by the death of their longtime friend and client and extend their sympathy to Richard and James and the entire family.

title: For Youth, Silence in a Cloud of Smoke
description: Researchers at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston were dismayed to learn in a new study that few American doctors counsel young patients about the dangers of smoking. In fact, the study found, the number of doctors who do so actually seems to be on the decline, even though most people who start smoking do so when they're teenagers.

title: Former Leader of National Auto Regains Control of the Company
description: The former chairman of National Auto Credit Inc., who quit after the company's auditors resigned and the integrity of the company's financial statements was challenged, has won a court fight in Delaware allowing him to regain control of the company, which specializes in lending to customers with poor credit records.

title: Not So Fast, Merrymakers
description: Physicists have calculated that the arrival of the year 2000 will be delayed on Dec. 31, thanks to one of NASA's planetary probes.

title: TV Ad Focuses on Health Care, Jobs and Education
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that the New York State Democratic Committee will begin broadcasting today in upstate New York in support of Hillary Rodham Clinton's potential Senate campaign.

title: Court Upholds Maine Campaign Law
description: In a victory for advocates of an overhaul of how campaigns are financed, a federal judge has upheld Maine's groundbreaking Clean Election Law, ruling that the incentives it offers to candidates to take public money instead of private contributions are constitutional.

title: Black Executive's Departure to Complicate Coke's Diversity Drive
description: When Coca-Cola shuffled its senior management last month, Carl H. Ware, a senior vice president responsible for African business, was told he would no longer report to M. Douglas Ivester, the chairman and chief executive.

title: Report by House Republicans Says Clemency for Puerto Ricans Was Campaign Move
description: A report by House Republicans asserts that President Clinton's grant of clemency to a group of Puerto Rican nationalists followed discussions in the White House that such a move would provide political help to some Democratic members of Congress and Vice President Al Gore.

title: Clinton Tips the Scales
description: The ongoing confrontation between Congress and the president on education spending is not only about class size and local control of schools. It also provides the opportunity for Congress to reassert its constitutional prerogative to control the country's purse strings.

title: We, the First People
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Ignoring State Curriculum Caused Poor Scores, Experts Say
description: When New York State announced the poor results of its tough new fourth- and eighth-grade math tests on Friday, the dismay was not confined, as so often in the past, to New York City and other big cities. Many parents, teachers and administrators in the state's wealthiest areas -- where people buy expensive homes thinking that they are also buying outstanding public schools -- were in shock, too.

title: Conservationists Write a Seafood Menu to Save Fish
description: As overfishing depletes the seas of prized species like cod, tuna and swordfish, conservation groups are urging consumers to make dining choices they say will help damaged ecosystems recover and support sustainable fisheries. Their lists recommend seafoods to eat and avoid.

title: Accounts
description: * Marketshopper.com, New York, an on-line gift shopping Web site, to CMGCommunications, New York, as the first agency of record to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Cowboys Lose Smith, Aikman and the Game
description: It took less than a minute for Emmitt Smith to show a national television audience that he is not ready to ease into retirement. Two dazzling touchdown runs, back to back, gave the Dallas Cowboys a seemingly sturdy 17-0 second-quarter lead over Minnesota. Then, a tiny bone in the running back's hand did something that the Vikings' defense could not: stop Smith.

title: Suffolk Executive Plans Talks to Settle Bill for Shoreham
description: Less than a week after easily winning re-election to a third term, County Executive Robert J. Gaffney has taken on a far more daunting task: negotiating a settlement in the bitter two-year battle between the Long Island Power Authority and the county Legislature over taxes on the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Cigarette Company Considers Libel Suit
description: The Brown & Williamson tobacco company is conducting a poll of people who watched the film ''The Insider'' to help decide whether to file a libel suit against the film's distributor, the Walt Disney Company, a spokesman said.

title: Out of the Pit and Into the Spotlight
description: One of James Levine's goals in starting a series of concerts for the Met Orchestra at Carnegie Hall was to showcase his superb musicians in repertory that they would not get to perform otherwise. So what was the point, one might have asked, of beginning Sunday afternoon's concert with the Prelude to Wagner's ''Meistersinger,'' an opera the orchestra has played splendidly in recent seasons at the Met?

title: Crackdown on Sect Yields 111 Arrests, Beijing Announces
description: Chinese officials today offered the first official tally of the government crackdown on the banned Falun Gong spiritual movement, saying 111 people had been formally arrested on a variety of criminal charges, from disrupting state security to stealing state secrets.

title: $200 Million Boondoggle?
description: To the Editor:

title: Q & A
description: Scorpion Venom

title: New Contract for Green Completes Mondesi Deal
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers finished a distant third in their division this year, but they are 1-2 in the player salary standing.

title: Mothers for a Moment, Then Cloistered Forever
description: Here's what used to happen in Ireland to a young unmarried woman who found herself pregnant, at least if her family decided to throw her out: she'd be forced to give up her baby, which would be put up for adoption or placed in an orphanage, and she wouldn't be allowed to visit. Then she'd be essentially held captive by the Roman Catholic Church, forced to live in a cloister and work in its laundry for the rest of her life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APAT, ADELINE
description: APAT-Adeline. The Board of Directors, faculty and staff of CLALThe National Jewish Center for Learning and Leadership extend deepest condolences to Klara Silverstein, our esteemed Board member, her husband Larry and the entire family on the passing of Klara's beloved mother, Adeline Apat. May her inspiration enhance the life of her family and may they be comforted by her loving memory. Barbara B. Friedman, Chairman Rabbi Irwin Kula, President Donna M. Rosenthal, Executive Vice Chairman

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DELL COMPUTER CORP., Round Rock, Tex., announced plans to build a second manufacturing operation in the Nashville area, adding about 650 jobs.

title: Questioning Guidelines
description: To the Editor:

title: What the Pop Quiz Said About Bush's World
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURTIN, JOHN F.
description: CURTIN-John F. On November 7th, 1999 of Dumont, New Jersey. Devoted husband of Regina (nee Hess). Beloved father of Loretta Maiorano, Rosemary Dujnic, Kathleen Maged and John Curtin. Dear brother of Gerard Curtin, Dorothy O'Leary and Regina O'Brian. Also survived by ten grandchildren. Funeral Mass on Wednesday at 9:30 A.M., at Saint Mary's R.C. Church, Dumont. Interment in Maryrest Cemetery. The family will receive friends on Tuesday 3-5 & 7-9PM at the Frech Funeral Home, 161 Washington Avenue, Dumont, New Jersey, and request that in lieu of flowers donations be made to the Multiple Sclerosis Association.

title: Money Manager Settles Charges
description: The former California money manager Jay Goldinger will pay at least $6 million to settle government charges that he juggled customers' profits and losses on Treasury bond futures trades.

title: After the Wall
description: What began in 1961 as a crude expanse of cinder blocks and barbed wire became in time a 113-mile stretch of fortified concrete and steel, imprisoning West Berlin. It was both a physical and psychic barrier, for 28 years the most powerful symbol of the cold war, dividing not just Berlin and Germany and Europe but East from West. Then, 10 years ago, on the evening of Nov. 9, 1989, the Berlin Wall came down, its collapse a dramatic expression of the larger failure of a Soviet empire brought down by economic decay, the cynicism of its citizens and the historic decision of its leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, not to use the force needed to hold it together. In fact, by allowing the wall to be breached without military response, Mr. Gorbachev did exactly what President Reagan, on a visit to Berlin two years before, had demanded: ''Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall!''

title: Yes, the Regents Mean Business
description: New York's Education Commissioner, Richard C. Mills, crisscrossed the state for three years urging school districts to upgrade their curriculums to meet the challenging new standards and tests that the state Board of Regents began to phase in this year. But new statewide test scores show that even some suburban school districts turned in disappointing scores and may have failed to beef up course offerings.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The euro fell against the dollar as economic reports diminished optimism about growth in the 11-nation euro region. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0386, down from $1.0419 on Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBOWSKY, AARON A. D.D.S.
description: DUBOWSKY-Aaron A. D.D.S. Of Bayonne, New Jersey. On November 7, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Pearl and survived by June Slutsky (nee Gross). Devoted father of Dr. Scott and daughterin-law, Carol, loving grandfather of Eric, Jonathan and Adam. The memorial period will be observed at the family residence, Monday through Thursday evening. Should friends desire, contributions may be made to a charity of their choice. For information, call Wien & Wien, 1-800-322-0533.

title: FIRST CHARTER ADDING CAROLINA FIRST BANCSHARES
description: The First Charter Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Carolina First BancShares for stock valued at $260 million, in a deal that strengthens First Charter's banking presence in the Charlotte, N.C., area. The transaction, values Carolina First shares at $42.50 each, based on First Charter's closing stock price on Friday. First Charter, based in Concord, N.C., is the holding company for Citizens National Bank, which has assets of $1.8 billion and 33 offices. Carolina First, based in Lincolnton, N.C., owns Lincoln Bank of North Carolina, Cabarrus Bank of North Carolina and Community Bank and Trust. The subsidiaries have assets of $774 million and 31 offices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLAND, BEATRICE, DR.
description: FRIEDLAND-Beatrice, Dr. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Sisterhood mourn the passing of their devoted member and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, President

title: The Unbreakable Code Broken in World War II
description: If the Battle of Waterloo was won on the playing fields of Eton, then the Battle of Britain can be said to have been won in the warrens of Bletchley Park, a mansion 50 miles north of London. There early in World War II, when the German blitzkrieg was sweeping through Europe, a team of British crossword puzzle whizzes, chess masters, mathematicians, paleontologists and other brilliant eccentrics contributed to Allied victory by breaking a seemingly unbreakable German code.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAREY, FRANK E.
description: CAREY-Frank E. On Friday, November 5, 1999, of Arlington, Virginia, husband of the late Anna G. Carey, father of Barbara Hayes, New Rochelle, New York; Eleanor Kroeger, Springfield, VA; and Susan Fulmer, Bristol, TN, eight grandchildren and six great grandchildren. Friends may call at the Murphy Funeral Home of Arlington, 4510 Wilson Boulevard, on Thursday, November 11, from 4 to 8 PM. The Mass of Christian burial will be offered Friday, November 12 at 10 AM at St. Thomas More Cathedral, Arlington, Virginia with interment at Fairfax Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions to Catholic Charities or the Alzheimer's Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENWALD, HAROLD
description: GREENWALD-Harold. The Partners, Counsel, Associates and Staff of Bangser Klein Rocca & Blum are deeply saddened by the death of our dear friend, counsel, and former partner. He was a soft spoken, unfailingly courteous man. We will sorely miss his intellect, integrity and ethical standards. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his family.

title: To Polish His Image, Bradley Has Worked With Madison Avenue for 16 Months
description: Bill Bradley has met quietly for more than 16 months with Madison Avenue advertising executives who are polishing his sometimes ponderous image by creating television commercials and slogans to sharpen his insurgent presidential campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPKIN, GEORGE L., M.D.
description: POPKIN-George L., M.D. The faculty, alumni, residents and staff of the Ronald O. Perelman Department of Dermatology, New York University, record with a deep sense of loss the sudden death of Dr. George L. Popkin, who had been associated with the Department for over fifty years. George trained at Skin & Cancer and rose through our faculty ranks, serving for the last thirty years, as Clinical Professor of Dermatology. He epitomized the very best among our clinical voluntary faculty members. One of the founders of the sub-specialty of Dermatologic Surgery, Dr. Popkin served as Head of our Skin Surgery Section and our Monday Service for many years. George was truly a sweet human being; a dedicated, gifted physician, an exemplary teacher and a loyal friend to all of us. We offer our condolences to his wife Sally and all of his family and friends. Irwin M. Freedberg, M.D. George Miller MacKee, Professor and Chairman

title: Atmosphere, Naturally, In an All-Sibelius Program
description: It always takes reminding that Sibelius, who wrote so little music after the 1920's, lived until 1957. So the Lahti Symphony Orchestra of Finland, which was founded in 1949, is a belated contemporary as well as a compatriot of the composer.

title: PRODIGY TO BUY RIVAL FLASHNET COMMUNICATIONS
description: The Prodigy Communications Corporation, an Internet-service provider, agreed yesterday to buy the rival FlashNet Communications for about $124 million in stock. Prodigy, based in White Plains, will exchange 0.35 share for each FlashNet share outstanding, or $8.66, based on Prodigy's price on Friday. The offer is 13 percent less than FlashNet's closing price on Friday. The purchase is Prodigy's third since it first sold shares to the public in February. Its subscriber base will expand to more than 1.5 million with the addition of the Fort Worth-based FlashNet's 244,000 customers.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Wiser Veteran Passes Up a Quiz

title: Judge Says Yugoslavia Impedes Work of War Crimes Tribunal
description: The president of the tribunal examining war crimes in the Balkan states that were once part of a larger Yugoslavia told the General Assembly today that the Yugoslav government has continued to obstruct the court's work and suggested that the Security Council lacks the will to force it to comply.

title: How to Rebuild Serbia
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINSKY, HERBERT A.
description: LINSKY-Herbert A. Of Fort Lee, N.J. Devoted father of Brian and Douglas. Beloved brother of Bette Gordon. Services ''Wien & Wien'' Hackensack, N.J. Thursday, 6pm. (1-800-378-1892)

title: Brookhaven Finds High Levels Of Tritium in Monitoring Well
description: In an unexpected finding, officials at Brookhaven National Laboratory said today that they had detected tritium, a radioactive substance, in a monitoring well at levels twice the federal standard for drinking water. But they said the contamination, found near a building housing a particle accelerator experiment, posed no health threat.

title: Taking What's Rightfully His
description: There is not any place Lennox Lewis goes that people do not tell him that he defeated Evander Holyfield during their heavyweight unification bout in March.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHEL, ROSE F.
description: FISHEL-Rose F. On Saturday, November 6, 1999, in St. Louis, MO, at the age of 99. She is survived by her great-granddaughters Lillian and Miriam Mindich. Rose was a lifelong resident of Park Slope. A memorial service will be held Thursday, December 16, 3 PM, 3rd St. entrance of Prospect Park.

title: Cruel and Unusual
description: NEW HAVEN

title: History Is Made by an Old-Fashioned chief.gov
description: Already the master of the rope line and televised town meeting, President Clinton took a technological leap into the computer age tonight by becoming the first president to participate in a live Internet chat.

title: Kittles Is Recovering, but Williams Has a Way to Go
description: On one end of the court at the Champion Center today, Keith Van Horn and Stephon Marbury mugged for the camera, striking poses for a magazine cover.

title: From the Candidates, a Deafening Silence
description: A Federal judge's finding last week that Microsoft is a monopoly that has stifled competition has left this season's crop of presidential candidates speechless.

title: New York City Campaigns To Attract New Teachers
description: With New York City facing an acute shortage of licensed teachers, officials have begun an intensive campaign to attract more people to the profession.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTROW, ANNE
description: OSTROW-Anne. Young Israel of Oceanside expresses heartfelt condolences to our member, Bruce Ostrow and family on the loss of his beloved mother. May the family be comforted among those who mourn for Tzion and Yerushalayim. Evan Torczyner, Pres. Jay Yaacov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: Namesake as Spoils of War; North vs. South, With a Battleship to the Victor
description: Call it the battle for the battleship, or the north versus the south.

title: Naomi Wolf's Critics
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGENLANDER, RUTH
description: MORGENLANDER - Ruth. Be loved wife of the late Abraham. Loving mother of Marilyn and Howard. Cherished grandmother of Jennifer, Stephen, David, Rachel, Elliot, Jeffrey, Tracy, Lucy and Christi. Services to be held today, 12 Noon, at the Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Ave (corner of M).

title: A Minimum Wage Bill for the Well Off
description: The Senate will vote today on a Republican-sponsored amendment to raise the minimum wage by $1, to $6.15 an hour, over three years. Though the Democrats propose the same hike spread over only two years, the basic proposal is uncontroversial. Both parties recognize the popularity and wisdom of raising wages of low-paid workers when unemployment rates are at their lowest levels in 30 years and workers, therefore, face no threat of mass layoffs.

title: Verdict in Berlin Wall Deaths Is Upheld
description: An appeals court upheld a manslaughter conviction today against the last Communist leader of East Germany for his role in the shootings of people who were trying to escape to the West.

title: INQUIRY AT HANJIN GROUP
description: South Korean prosecutors began investigating accusations of illegal overseas money transfers and tax evasion by the Hanjin Group transportation conglomerate, questioning Hanjin Shipping's president, Cho Soo Ho, about company transactions. Cho Choong Hoon, the group's founder and honorary chairman, and Cho Yang Ho, his son and the chairman of Korean Air, are scheduled for questioning on Tuesday. Cho Soo Ho, who is said to have denied all charges, is suspected of using 3.8 billion won, or $3.2 million, in company funds since 1996 and failing to report 2.9 billion won in corporate taxes.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: 100 Eyes, One Insect

title: BETTING ON A TURNAROUND
description: Carlos Ghosn, the chief operating officer of the Nissan Motor Company, said the company's executive committee, including Mr. Ghosn himself, would resign if Nissan failed to post a profit in the year ending in March 2001. Under Nissan's business plan, which was announced Oct. 18, the auto maker said it would close four plants in Japan and eliminate 21,000 jobs as it tries to return to profit by 2001.

title: Danger but No Joy on Dark Urban Streets
description: ''The Next Image'' was the name the Wellspring Project gave to its program of dances on Sunday afternoon at the Theater of the Riverside Church. The organization is made up of dancers inspired by the technique and esthetic of the modern-dance teacher and choreographer Erick Hawkins. And one of Hawkins's policies that they admirably maintain is that of having performances accompanied by live music.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Sale of Shares Reaps Triple the Goal Set by Hong Kong
description: In another boost to this economically resurgent city, Hong Kong's government has raised far more money than expected from an offering of shares it bought last year in a costly market intervention.

title: Stock Plunges as Providian Faces Connecticut Inquiry
description: Shares of the Providian Financial Corporation, the credit card company, fell about 23 percent today after the company said that the Connecticut attorney general was investigating the way it issues cards and bills customers.

title: First Lady Sees No Senate Tie to Israel Trip
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said yesterday that her trip this week to Israel was an official visit and should not be viewed in the context of her run for the United States Senate. Her remarks came as the White House disclosed more details of the First Lady's 36-hour itinerary, including a visit to the Western Wall in Jerusalem.

title: When Foods Do Harm
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOLPE, JEAN
description: FOLPE-Jean. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Jean Folpe, mother of Herbert Folpe. We extend our deepest condolences to Herbert and his family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Cantor Debra Stein-Davidson Donald Zucker, President

title: FERRELLGAS PARTNERS TO GET UNIT OF WILLIAMS ENERGY
description: Ferrellgas Partners agreed yesterday to buy the Thermogas Company from Williams Energy Services for $432.5 million. The deal will create one of the largest retailers of propane gas. Ferrellgas said it would pay $257.5 million in cash and $175 million in senior Ferrellgas common units, which it said Williams intended to convert to cash in a separate deal. Thermogas sells propane to 300,000 customers through 180 outlets in 18 states, primarily in the Midwest. Williams Energy is a unit of the Williams, a Tulsa, Okla., holding company with interests in natural gas and communications. Ferrellgas, based in Liberty, Mo., sells propane to 800,000 customers in 45 states.

title: ALLIED WASTE PLANS TO SELL SOME PROPERTIES
description: Allied Waste Industries said yesterday that it planned to sell some of its solid-waste properties to Superior Services for about $209 million in cash. The Allied assets include three landfill operations, six transfer stations and some small-container commercial hauling operations. Superior Services, a waste-collection company, is based in West Allis, Wis. Allied, a waste-management company based in Scottsdale, Ariz., noted that its planned divestiture represents partial compliance with a consent decree negotiated with the Justice Department. The decree stemmed from the company's acquisition of Browning-Ferris Industries. That acquisition, valued at $9.4 billion, closed in early August and created the second-largest waste services company in the United States.

title: BIG H.M.O. TO GIVE DECISIONS ON CARE BACK TO DOCTORS
description: The United Health Group said yesterday that it was returning decision-making power over patient care to physicians, breaking with a longstanding element of managed care that has infuriated many doctors and frustrated their patients.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANOFF, RUTH
description: DANOFF-Ruth. Beloved wife of the late Alfred, loving mother of Dr. Dudley Danoff and Myrna Weinstein, dear sister Faye Schaffer and Beverly Gans. Cherished grandmother of Sherry, Dana, Aurelle and Doran. Adored greatgrandmother of Marissa and Darin. Services today 12 noon at ''Gutterman's Inc,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Afghan 'Lion' Fights Taliban With Rifle and Fax Machine
description: The Lion of the Panjshir is not a big man, especially so for someone thought to be Afghanistan's greatest guerrilla fighter. With his beret cocked and his brow in a pensive wrinkle, he has the look of a Beat Generation poet, more at home in a basement coffee house than in high-altitude combat.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS FALLS. Natural gas fell as unusually high temperatures in parts of the United States kept heating demand in check. In New York, natural gas for December delivery fell 21.9 cents, to $2.665 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: MIDCOAST ENERGY SETS DEAL TO ADD KANSAS PIPELINE
description: Midcoast Energy Resources agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Kansas Pipeline Company for about $190 million in cash, giving it pipelines that deliver natural gas to Wichita and Kansas City, Kan. The price includes the repayment of $68.4 million in Kansas Pipeline debt. Midcoast said it expects to take a fourth-quarter charge for an $8.5 million penalty for early payoff. Kansas Pipeline's 1,120-mile interstate pipeline transports gas from Oklahoma and Western Kansas. It is one of three systems capable of delivering to the Kansas City area. Houston-based Midcoast, which had 1998 sales of $234.1 million, said the purchase would bolster its pipeline mileage by 41 percent and create opportunities for growth in the Midwest and Gulf Coast.

title: BANK EXPRESSES INTEREST
description: The Royal Bank of Scotland filed a formal merger notice with British regulators stating that it was considering making a bid for National Westminster Bank P.L.C., potentially creating a bidding war with the Bank of Scotland. Last week, Britain's Takeover Panel ruled that the Royal Bank of Scotland would have to disclose its position concerning NatWest by Dec. 3.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing of the Media Business page on Thursday about the selection of an advertising agency by Myway.com misidentified the parent company of one finalist and omitted the parent for another. Merkley Newman Harty is part of Omnicom Group, not BDM, the new holding company made up of Leo Group and the MacManus Group. Another finalist, Bartle Bogle Hegarty, is part of BDM.

title: AUTOCAM IN BUYOUT LED BY AURORA CAPITAL GROUP
description: The Autocam Corporation agreed yesterday to be taken private in a buyout led by the Aurora Capital Group that values the company at $18.75 a share, a total of about $121 million. Autocam, based in Kentwood, Mich., makes precision-machined components for the automotive and electronics industry. It earned $6.3 million on sales of $180 million in the year ended June 30. Aurora is a Los Angeles-based private investment firm. In the transaction, Aurora will also refinance Autocam's $109 million of debt.

title: Dr. Freud, I Think Fido Is Obsessive-Compulsive
description: When Neiko Fischbein watched television she got ''overcranked.'' No matter what, she could not sit still. ''She just seemed to be attracted, or distracted, by everything in constant fashion,'' said Dr. Ellen Fischbein, a psychiatrist who lives outside of New Haven. ''I'm kind of a high-energy person, but she exhausted me.''

title: Mexico's Political Experiment
description: Mexico took a step toward greater democracy on Sunday when the party that has supplied all its presidents for the past 70 years held a competitive primary to choose next year's presidential nominee. The primary was an important but not flawless exercise in free political choice.

title: Civilized Killing?
description: To the Editor:

title: RealNetworks Is Target of Suit In California Over Privacy Issue
description: A California lawyer has filed a $500 million class-action lawsuit against RealNetworks, a leading maker of Internet multimedia software, charging that the company violated that state's unfair business practices law by distributing software that secretly gathered data about users and transmitted it back to the company on the Internet.

title: From One Marathon to Another for Victors
description: Joseph Chebet was so relieved after winning the New York City Marathon on Sunday that he slept soundly that night. Adriana Fernandez was so hyped up after winning the women's title that she could not sleep.

title: People
description: * David Harris was named to the new position of senior partner and multicultural media director at Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, New York, a unit of the WPP Group, working on the account of the Office of National Drug Control Policy. He had been senior vice president and management representative at Bates USA, New York, part of the Bates Worldwide unit of the Cordiant Communications Group.

title: Will Science Come to Aid of Galapagos Bachelor? Tune In
description: Scientists think they now know why Lonesome George, the Galapagos Islands' most eligible bachelor, can't seem to have a meaningful relationship.

title: Feeding Russian Fears
description: To the Editor:

title: Archaeology and Ancestry Clash Over Skeleton
description: Not all the conflicts in the search for the earliest Americans center on rival scientists with sharply different interpretations of the bones and artifacts they are finding. Emboldened by a 1990 federal law, American Indians have joined the fight with forceful claims that it is, after all, their past that all the fuss is over.

title: At Berlin Wall: The Crumbling, Then and Now
description: Having guarded the ramparts of East German Communism for 28 years, Harald Jaeger knew his business at the Berlin Wall. So the statement by the Politburo member on television on that night -- Nov. 9, 1989 -- struck him as lunacy.

title: Hamilton's Surgery For Knee and Toe
description: Darryl Hamilton, the Mets' center fielder, underwent surgery yesterday to remove scar tissue from the patella tendon in his left knee, and to remove loose fragments and spurs from his left big toe. Both procedures lasted an hour and a half and were performed by Dr. David Altchek at the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Breakup of Microsoft? Possibly, but Investors Shrug It Off
description: A BREAKUP of the Microsoft Corporation -- the world's most valuable company -- appeared somewhat more plausible yesterday, after the release on Friday of a Federal judge's finding that the government had proved that the company had a monopoly and had used it to stifle competition.

title: Show Business Embraces Web, But Cautiously
description: Regis and Kathie Lee, watch out. The hosts of a new talk show are none other than the Lord and Satan themselves. In ''The God & Devil Show,'' they interview guests like John Wayne -- one needn't be alive to be a guest on this show -- and viewers then vote whether to send the guest to heaven or hell.

title: A Case for Some Well-Toned Tissue
description: Working to develop engineered tissue that may one day be used to repair or replace damaged human body parts or organs, researchers at the University of Michigan came face to face with a problem: the tissue from the lab was not as strong as that made by the body.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SIMMONS, HELEN E.
description: SIMMONS-Helen E. Loved and remembered always. Deirdre, Maud and Charle

title: No Refuge in the Home of Childhood
description: There was an odd discrepancy between what one saw and what was promised in ''Objects No Longer Present,'' which Gina Gibney Dance performed on Saturday night as an attraction in the Danspace Project's City/Dans series at St. Mark's Church.

title: U.S. vs. Microsoft: Trouble for the Software King
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Education Life section on Sunday about changes in fraternity culture misidentified the Ivy League college that was the last to go coeducational. It was Columbia, in 1983, not Dartmouth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWAB, LOIS F.
description: SCHWAB-Lois F. Of Roosevelt Island and Gardiner, NY, died on November 8. She was 76 years old. Born in New York City to Sidney and Nathalie Goetter Feibleman, she grew up in Great Neck, NY and New Orleans, was married in 1947 to Armand Schwab Jr. and moved north. The couple lived in Mamaroneck, NY, for 25 years, where she raised three children, worked with husband in local politics and was a member and the president of the Larchmont-Mamaroneck Motion Picture Council. Determined to resume her education, she earned a BA in art history at Manhattanville College in 1979 and an MS in library and information science at Pratt Institute in 1982, after which she volunteered for many years as the children's reference librarian and a cataloguer at the Roosevelt Island Community Library. She is survived by her husband of 52 years, her sons and daughters-in-law Tony and Deborah of Teaneck, NJ, John and Robin of Seattle, and Matthew and Valerie of Stone Ridge, NY, and six grandchildren: Andrew and Madeleine, Peter and Rachel, and Hallie and Nicholas. She was admired and will be remembered as a good wife, mother, grandmother and librarian. A memorial service is planned for December.

title: The Earliest Americans
description: A growing body of evidence contradicts longstanding theories about the original Americans. The old notion that hunters crossed the Bering Strait from Siberia is being challenged by new theories of earlier migrations that may have originated in Australia or Europe.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Scientists Studying Deep Ocean Currents for Clues to Climates
description: El Nino and La Nina, the warmer and colder phases of a perpetual oscillation in the surface temperature of the tropical Pacific Ocean that drastically affects weather around the world, have in recent years become familiar agents of short-term climate change.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, MADELEINE A. (BOBBIE)
description: THOMAS-Madeleine A. (Bobbie). On November 4, 1999. Beloved wife of William H. Thomas (Bill). Funeral Mass at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave. at 66th St, Friday, Nov. 12th, 10 AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Off-Duty Officer Shoots Man Confronting Him
description: An off-duty police officer shot a Brooklyn man yesterday morning on a street corner at the crowded Fulton Street Mall after the man tried to rob him, the police said. The officer, Varlos Brathwaite of the 88th Precinct in Fort Greene, was shopping when he was approached by Tobia J. Evans, 22, of Flatbush, who pulled out a knife and asked for his valuables around 11:15 a.m., said Officer Joseph Cavatolio, a police spokesman.

title: Chirac's Attack on Congress Has a Bigger Target
description: PARIS  In an unusual public berating of the U.S. Congress, President Jacques Chirac of France has laid bare  and perhaps sought to exploit  an undercurrent of resentment in his country against U.S. power and prosperity.

title: What the Pop Quiz Said About Bush's World
description: To the Editor:

title: Extra Oxygen for Anesthesia's Hangover
description: Patients often wake up from general anesthesia with nausea and vomiting, but researchers say they can sharply reduce the incidence of these symptoms with a relatively simple step: increasing the amount of oxygen given to surgery patients.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, MONROE SCHUYLER
description: SINGER-Monroe Schuyler, 72. A lifelong New Yorker, Monty graduated from Harvard College in 1947 and Yale Law School in 1950. He began his career at Shearman & Sterling, became a partner at Berlack, Israels & Liberman, and then spent over thirty years as Assistant Secretary and Vice President of Interpublic Group of Companies. He was a founder and vice president of the West Brooklyn Independent Democrats. An indefatigable traveler and railroad buff, he rode trains on every continent. He was the beloved father of Andrew Benjamin and former husband of Ann Singer. There will be a memorial gathering of friends and relatives on Sunday, November 21.

title: Public Interests; A Millennial Hit Parade
description: Less than eight weeks until the turn of the millennium, and somehow things don't seem ready. All those books, magazines, TV specials and Y2K conferences, and still it doesn't feel as if the whole thing has sunk into the popular culture.

title: With a Nod to Predecessors, Clinton Sets Out New Goals in Europe
description: President Clinton celebrated the 10th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall today with a speech outlining the major challenges he believes Europe faces and a warning that any hope of bringing stability to the Balkans will require pushing President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia from power.

title: Treating Exile as a Separate Country
description: THE MUSEUM OF UNCONDITIONAL SURRENDER

title: Despite Boom, Flea Markets Buzz
description: Darryl Haun has discovered yet another opportunity in the great American tradition of making a buck. Mr. Haun is a machinist during the workweek, but at amusement parks he has become an ace thrower of objects at targets, like rings around bottles and quarters on plates. ''After you figure it out,'' he explained, ''it's not total chance.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about the possibility of physically linking the human brain to computers misstated the medical condition of Ray Kurzweil, the author of a book on the subject. He wrote a previous book about nutrition because his family has a history of heart disease; it is not he who has congenital heart disease.

title: Giant Hopes for Tiny Satellites
description: The concept of less being more will take on new meaning in space next month when the Air Force launches a fleet of tiny experimental satellites made of miniature components -- diminutive machines that could one day work together in groups to replace or supplement larger spacecraft.
