title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, ARTHUR B.
description: BROWN-Arthur B. 94, of Floral Park, NY, on Nov. 8, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Ruth Levison Brown, devoted father of Alan R. Brown. Also survived by 6 nieces. Retired professor of mathematics at Queens College and past president of the Metropolitan Section of the Mathematical Association of America. His helpfulness will be missed by all whom he touched. Services 11:30 AM, Thursday, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARMFLASH, HERBERT
description: WARMFLASH-Herbert, of Boca Raton, Florida. Devoted father of Rabbi Andrew and Barbara, beloved brother of Howard, and grandfather of 3. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, NJ on November 10, 1999 at 2:15 PM.

title: Greedy Is Good: A New Resistance To Sharing
description: JULIA CHILD was lunching at Oceana a couple of weeks ago, and as it came time to order, she insisted that everyone at her table have the same thing. Because it was Julia Child, they obeyed, and went on to enjoy a rare meal with no ''Oh, can I try one of your Florida stone crab claws?'' or ''Here, have some pan-seared dorade!'' And absolutely no plate-passing.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Keeping It Simple

title: CALENDAR
description: Food Education at Columbia

title: 'Single Use' Medical Devices Are Often Used Several Times
description: When patients come to the University of Virginia Health System to have an abnormal heart rhythm diagnosed or treated, they are told that doctors will be threading thin wires through their veins directly into their heart. They learn that they run a slight risk of infection, or of damage to the heart, lungs or blood vessels from the very nature of the invasive procedure.

title: Letting the Doctors Decide
description: To the Editor:

title: Has the Wall Truly Tumbled Down?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Celebritystores Awards Its First Account
description: Celebritystores.com in Boca Raton, Fla., an on-line celebrity news and merchandise company, said yesterday that it had awarded its first account to Beber Silverstein & Partners in Miami. Billings were estimated at $4 million.

title: Restorer Who Found a 16th-Century Painting Is Charged
description: When a Long Island furniture restorer, Frank J. Vaccaro, picked up a piece of wood in his shop and started to remove an old print that was glued to its side, he made an unusual discovery: He saw a pair of eyes looking back at him, covered in black paint.

title: Board Blocks Student Access To Web Sites
description: The Board of Education has installed a filter on its computer system that blocks students in New York City schools from gaining access to any Web sites that include categories like news and sex education, including those of major news outlets, policy groups and scientific and medical organizations, officials acknowledged yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGEL, RUTHE
description: VOGEL-Ruthe. Our beloved sister, you will be deeply missed. Irma Stecher Gerald Epstein

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil rose after the International Energy Agency said production cuts by big exporters were eroding global inventories. In New York, crude oil for December delivery rose 76 cents, to $24.03 a barrel.

title: A Mother's Love
description: To the Editor:

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON TO BUY INNOVASIVE DEVICES
description: Johnson & Johnson, the health care products giant, has agreed to acquire Innovasive Devices Inc. for $85 million in stock. Innovasive Devices, based in Marlborough, Mass., makes and sells sports medicine devices used in the surgical repair of soft tissue in the knees and shoulders. It had revenue of $12.6 million in the nine months ended Sept. 30. In the transaction, Innovasive Devices stockholders will exchange each of their shares for Johnson & Johnson stock worth $8.25, the companies said late on Monday. Shares of Innovasive Devices changed hands at $7.9375, down 53.125 cents.

title: Four Agencies Make Deals in Health Care
description: Four agencies are making acquisitions in the booming field of health care communications.

title: Liberties; The Pals and Palettes of Al
description: So Al and I are dishing about clothes.

title: Letting the Doctors Decide
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITISH MIDLAND STAKE SOLD
description: Challenging the troubled British Airways on its home turf, Deutsche Lufthansa said it would pay $148 million for half of Scandinavian Airline System's 40 percent stake in British Midland Airways, Britain's second-largest carrier. British Midland will also join the Star alliance of airlines, which includes Lufthansa and United Airlines. The purchase will increase the alliance's share of the slots at Heathrow to 27 percent, compared with 48 percent controlled by British Airways and its partners in the Oneworld group. Sir Michael Bishop, founder and chairman of British Midland, will maintain a 60 percent stake in the airline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEATHERS, VIRGINIA
description: LEATHERS-Virginia. Nov. 7, in Freehold, NJ. Beloved wife of the late L. Hudson Leathers. Survived by son, John, & her grandchildren, Joanna & Jonathan of Manhattan. Born in Columbia, SC, longtime New Jersey resident. Known for her Southern charm & stylish hats. Burial will be in South Carolina.

title: America Discovers The Turkish Mosaic
description: SHISH kebab from a street vendor in Istanbul had a powerful effect on Laurent Gras, the French chef at Peacock Alley in the Waldorf-Astoria. The small cubes of lamb had been marinated overnight in pomegranate juice and grilled on a skewer over aromatic charcoal. It was street food, but refined -- the vendor was obviously concerned with every detail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEBER, ARTHUR A.
description: FRIEBER-Arthur A., 78. Died at home on November 6, 1999 in San Rafael, CA. after a long illness. Devoted husband of Carolyn, loving father of Laury and Christopher. Contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society, 19 W. 56 Street, NYC 10019 or to the Marin Humane Society, 171 Bel Marin Keys Blvd, Novato, CA. 94949.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LADO, HENRIETTA JEAN
description: LADO-Henrietta Jean. On Nov. 8, 1999 in San Francisco. Beloved wife of the late Michael, cherished aunt of Stanley & Melvin Roboff, great-aunt of Gary, Sari, Annie, Katherine & Julia Roboff. Services Friday, 9:45 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Prosecutors Seeking to Break The Grip of Windows System
description: The state and federal officials prosecuting the Microsoft antitrust case now say that their goal in any settlement, or court-imposed remedy, will be to break the company's monopoly in personal computer operating systems, or limit its ability to wield such monopoly power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FROHLICH, ANNE
description: FROHLICH-Anne, 92, died Nov. 8. Wife of the late Jack Frohlich, mother and mother-in-law to Sam & Angela Frohlich, Harriet and Howard Herzog, grandmother to Jamie Vandervelden, Jennifer Rodier and husbands James & Brian. Her great grandchildren are Justin Vandervelden & Sara Rodier. Rose Rosenblatt is her sister. Service at Schwartz Bros. Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, noon, Thursday, November 11.

title: Saks Fifth Avenue Selects New Chief
description: Saks Inc. named Christina Johnson president and chief executive of its Saks Fifth Avenue department-stores division today, replacing Philip Miller, who will continue as chairman of the retail chain.

title: Former Xerox Officer Gets Top Avis Job
description: When Addison Barry Rand walked away from a 31-year career with Xerox last year, he promised himself two things: one, that he would take his wife, Donna, and their two children on some long-overdue vacations, and two, that he would land a job heading a Fortune 500 company.

title: HONDA EARNINGS FALL
description: The big Japanese car maker Honda Motor reported sharply lower earnings for the second quarter. Although unit sales of cars, engines and generators were higher, the strong yen eroded profits, which fell 20.7 percent, to 63.5 billion yen, from the corresponding period last year. Almost 80 percent of Honda's operating profits come from its sales in the United States, making it especially sensitive to exchange rates.

title: Iran Hard-Liners Try Cleric, Who Tries Them
description: After the first 10 days of a trial that has transfixed Iran, a prominent Muslim cleric who is accused of betraying the Islamic Revolution has infuriated the ruling hierarchy by using the courtroom as a pulpit to promote the democratic principles that caused him to be put on trial in the first place.

title: Juicy Bird, No Mess
description: IF you want to keep a boneless chicken breast juicy inside a flavorful exterior, all you have to do is coat it with flour or cornmeal or a batter and cook it quickly in a fair amount of fat. But there is a much lighter alternative, a combination of sauteing and steaming.

title: U.P.S. INITIAL PUBLIC OFFERING RAISES $5.47 BILLION
description: United Parcel Service, the package delivery service, raised a record $5.47 billion in an initial public stock offering that was priced late yesterday. Led by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, underwriters priced 109.4 million U.P.S. class B shares at $50 a share, $1 above the top end of a prepricing target range of $47 to $49 a share. The sale represents a 9 percent stake in U.P.S., which was founded 92 years ago and is based in Atlanta. The $50 price gives the company a market value of more than $60 billion. The company, which has roughly $2 billion in cash, will use the proceeds from the stock sale to buy back roughly 8 percent, or about 93.7 million shares, of its class A voting stock at an offering price of $54 a share.

title: The Kitchen Workhorse (It's Not a Cuisinart)
description: WHEN you are served carrot puree at Eleven Madison Park, you remember it. It tastes lovely, but there's also something beguiling about the texture. It's as smooth as velvet, as decadent as cream. Kerry Heffernan, the chef, uses great ingredients, of course, but that's not his secret.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUNYON, CHARLES III
description: RUNYON-Charles III, 85, of Ocracoke, N.C. died November 3, 1999. Charles is beloved and missed by his family and by his many wonderful friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHMAN, DAVID
description: REICHMAN-David, age 84, of Monroe Township, New Jersey (formerly of Queens) November 9th, 1999. Devoted husband of Marjorie Ulrich Reichman. Beloved father of Donald and Jerold, & father-in-law of Jill and Cynthia. Cherished grandfather of five. Services on Wednesday 9:45 A.M., at Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, East Brunswick, New Jersey.

title: PATAKI PROPOSES CURB ON RELEASES FOR MENTALLY ILL
description: Gov. George E. Pataki announced today a plan to stop the decades-old practice of emptying the state's huge psychiatric hospitals and called for spending an additional $125 million for supervised housing and other community-based services for the mentally ill.

title: Seeking a Hit, Sometimes Without His Bat
description: AN argument could be made that Steve Friedman has mellowed. It was already 7:20 a.m. and he had downed only his second Diet Coke. He had left his favorite prop, a baseball bat, at the office, rather than lugging it into the control room of his latest network morning show.

title: For Job Stress, Erect Fire Walls
description: ''How was your day?'' my husband, Bruce, asks me every night when he is finally home from the hospital. On my bad days -- ones that involve deadlines, or spats with editors, or sources who won't cooperate -- I grumble and grouse in reply.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, SAUL
description: JOHNSON-Saul He was the master of his fate; the captain of his soul. Beloved father of Peter and Ira and grandfather of Russell, Tara, Stacey and Lindsey. Also survived by sister Helyne. His love and counsel will be cherished.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTZLINE, WALTER F.
description: PORTZLINE-Walter F. On November 8, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Muriel. Devoted father of Thomas Portzline, M.D. Loving brother of Ralph, Donelle and Jack. Fond father-in-Law of Mary Beaudet. Friends may call on Wednesday 7-9:30 PM & Thursday 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Avenue, Floral Park, NY (At R.R. Plaza). Funeral, Friday 9:30 AM. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the National Audubon Society would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELISH, MARY JANE (DIETZ)
description: MELISH-Mary Jane (Dietz). Born December 3, 1913, died November 4, 1999. Memorial service at St. Ann's & the Holy Trinity (corner of Clinton & Montague Sts), Brooklyn Heights, NY, Sunday, November 14th, at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to the Stained Glass Restoration, St. Ann's Center, 157 Montague Street, Brooklyn, New York 11201.

title: Amazon Further Expands Its Retail Reach
description: Feeding its audacious ambition to be the general store of the Internet, Amazon.com said yesterday that starting today, it would begin selling tools, video games and software.

title: Business of Education
description: To the Editor:

title: With 500 Miners as a Chorus, Byrd Attacks Court Ruling
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd rallied more than 500 coal miners outside the Capitol today, complaining that the White House had reneged on support of his attempt to roll back a judicial decision against the strip mining of mountaintops in West Virginia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OKUN, IRWIN L., DR.
description: OKUN-Irwin L., Dr., on November 9. Beloved husband of Lola, loving father of Beth and Todd, adoring grandfather of Elissa, Brooke, Sarah and Joshua, devoted brother of Beatrice and Arthur. Graveside service Thursday at New Montifiore Cemetery in W. Babylon.

title: ADVANTICA TO SELL EL POLLO LOCO UNIT FOR $114 MILLION
description: Advantica Restaurant Group Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its El Pollo Loco fast-food unit to an affiliate of American Securities Capital Partners for $114 million. The transaction also calls for the buyer to assume $14 million in debt. Advantica, based in Spartanburg, S.C., operates about 2,600 restaurants across the United States, including Denny's, Coco's and Carrows. El Pollo Loco had sales of $38.5 million in the third quarter. American Securities Capital is a private investment firm based in New York.

title: A Better Way to Test a Candidate's Mettle
description: The presidential character issue is back (it never seems to be gone for long). Does John McCain's terrific anger tell us something terrible about him? Does Al Gore's putative beta-ness on the Greek alphabet scale -- or the attempt by Naomi Wolf, feminist and political adviser, to push him to alpha-ness -- mean that he does not have the virility to rule? The questions are typical of the slippery way ''character'' is invoked as an indicator of electability.

title: When Inmates Leave Rikers Island
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Use Vouchers
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIGHTER BRITISH FORECAST
description: Offering a bright assessment of Britain's economic prospects, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown, increased his growth forecasts to 1.75 percent for this year -- from a previous 1 percent to 1.5 percent -- and up to 3 percent for next year, compared with his earlier forecasts of 2.25 percent to 2.75 percent. The figures reflect a marked turnaround from the situation one year ago, when some forecasters were predicting a slowdown or even a recession. Mr. Brown said that the government's aim was ''a Britain of stability and steady growth.''

title: Learning at Mayor's Knee, Mayor La Guardia's Knee
description: I was his aide for a year and a half. It was a $1-a-year proposition. I did a variety of things for him, like traveling with him in his big car when he visited a dedication of a big school or Department of Sanitation garages. He also gave me a number of special assignments, which included finding ways to get to La Guardia Airport and how they could increase their revenue by having shops and things like that.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWEITZER, DR. NANCY J.
description: SCHWEITZER-Dr. Nancy J. 11/10/ 49-11/12/86. Today is the anniversary of your 50th birthday. I am grateful to God to have had you for 37 years, my darling daughter. My love is eternal. Your Mo

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRUCHTER, ISRAEL
description: FRUCHTER-Israel. Manhattan Day School/Yeshiva Ohr Torah records with profound sorrow the passing of Israel Fruchter, father of our esteemed board member, Steven Fruchter. May the entire family be comforted in this hour of their untimely loss. Manhattan Day School/ Yeshiva Ohr Torah Rabbi Mordechai Besser, Principal George Karasick, President Elliott Gibber, Chairman of the Board

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Disco Music, Big Band Dispute

title: Stricter Ground Water Limit For Gasoline Additive Is Set
description: Addressing growing concerns that drinking water is being polluted by a gasoline additive, Gov. George E. Pataki ordered today that New York adopt the nation's toughest ground water limit for the chemical.

title: Budget Remains Prickly Issue For Nassau County Legislature
description: There was the promise of something new in Nassau County when the newly elected members of the first-ever Democratic majority in the County Legislature announced today that they had chosen Judith A. Jacobs, their former minority leader, to be their majority leader.

title: Madrigals Sung as Minidramas
description: La Venexiana, an Italian vocal quintet formed in the early 1990's, took its name from an anonymous Renaissance comedy that was a precursor of the commedia dell'arte. And although it may seem peculiar for a musical group to take its name from a theater work, the reason became evident during the second half of the quintet's all-Monteverdi concert on Monday evening at the Ethical Culture Society. Perhaps because Monteverdi's language is their own and alive to them, they sang his madrigals as though they were miniature dramas, or in some cases -- ''Gira il nemico insidioso amore'' and ''Bel pastor,'' for example -- lively comedies.

title: MANAGEMENT: Soothing Savage Structures; A Leaderless Orchestra Offers Lessons for Business
description: It seemed to be magic. Music burst forth from two dozen string and wind instruments in perfect synchronization, without a conductor to summon it.

title: Bush, Stumping in Carolina, Urges Better Veterans' Care
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas said today that American military veterans were getting less than they deserved from the country they had served and should be given better health care and relief from a tangled, tortuous bureaucracy.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: A Seasoning That Seems Too Precious to Eat

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Army Says Strained Resources Leave Troops Unprepared for War
description: The Army has described two of its 10 divisions as ill prepared for war because of shortages of troops, equipment or training in a report that may set the stage for a political battle over whether the service should get more money.

title: Haiti's Paralysis Spreads as U.S. Troops Pack Up
description: Five years after an American-led force of 20,000 troops invaded this island and restored constitutional rule, the Haitian people are entering a new and uncertain era.

title: 3-Way Bidding Battle Sends a Picasso Soaring
description: It takes only two big spenders to push the price of an artwork to stratospheric levels, but three determined telephone bidders declared war last night at Christie's sale of 20th-century art. So eager were they to take home Picasso's ''Nude on a Black Armchair'' that they were still fighting it out at $36 million. In the end, the winner paid $45.1 million, nicely above Christie's high estimate of $40 million. So tense was the bidding that the salesroom burst into applause when the winner was finally declared.

title: Decision on Clemency for 16 Did Not Involve Gore, He Says
description: Vice President Al Gore said today that he did not know whether the White House gave any consideration to his political standing with Puerto Ricans when President Clinton granted clemency in August to 16 Puerto Rican prisoners but that in any case he had nothing to do with the decision.

title: Oversight of Derivatives Said to Be Adequate
description: Despite the collapse of a giant hedge fund last year that required a rescue arranged by the Federal Reserve, top government regulators have concluded that they do not need to supervise the use of complex financial contracts by hedge funds or other institutions.

title: Student Stole to Pay Tuition, Police Say
description: A student at a Princeton college has been arrested after admitting that he stole from the bursar's office to pay his tuition, the police said yesterday.

title: Citing Reserve, Firm Improves Credit Rating For the State
description: Citing New York State's reserve fund of nearly $3 billion, a major Wall Street firm raised the state's credit rating a notch today, although the rating remains among the lowest for the states.

title: The Defense Is Still Thriving in Division I-AA
description: Joe Del Gais, the St. John's defensive coordinator, has been spoiled by continuity. Since assuming the post in 1997, Del Gais has lost just two starters a year to graduation, and every season the defense has improved.

title: Where Profits Stay in the Bottle for 17 Years
description: A FEW of the original investors in Sonoma-Cutrer, the prominent California winery, probably wish they had taken their profits in old croquet balls. Or had consumed their money's worth. In the first 17 years that it made wine, Sonoma-Cutrer produced some good and extremely popular wines. And it was the host of spectacular croquet matches played on its two international-class croquet lawns. But profits? There really weren't any.

title: Legalized Murder
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; New Jersey Builders Predict 18% Growth
description: A construction industry trade group in New Jersey yesterday projected an 18.4 percent increase in the value of nonresidential building projects for the 2000-2001 two-year cycle.

title: Charizard Beats Psyduck, But Pikachu's the Cutest
description: In the year 2015 or so, it's going to be embarrassing. Young novelists and reporters will probably be using terms like Charizard-like or Squirtle-like in their work and insisting to their much older editors that everyone knows what they mean, everyone who ate and slept Pokemon as a child, anyway, which will be the vast majority of young adults.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, RICHARD
description: MARTIN-Richard. Parsons School of Design's faculty, students and administration mourn the passing of our beloved faculty member and cherished colleague, Richard Martin. His visionary intelligence, collaborative skills, and sincere humanity helped to make him a leader in curriculum development and academic programming. In addition, his recent gift of several thousand books to Parsons' library ensures his lasting legacy at an institution where he will be much missed.

title: Longtime I.M.F. Director Resigns in Midterm
description: Michel Camdessus resigned today in the middle of his third term as managing director of the International Monetary Fund, setting off a behind-the-scenes struggle involving the Clinton administration and European nations over who will head the agency that is in effect dictating national economic policy from Russia to Indonesia and Africa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOBBS, EDWARD ROBERT, D.D.S.
description: HOBBS-Edward Robert, D.D.S. On Nov. 7, 1999. Loving husband of Diane Cucchi, adored father of Andrew. Dear brother of Robert and Barbara Hobbs. Devoted son-inlaw of Mr. & Mrs. Anthony Cucchi, brother-in-law Mark Cucchi and Lisa Kaelin and Alyce Hobbs. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Thursday, November 11, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Memorial Service at St. Hilda's-St. Hugh's, 619 West 114 Street on Friday, November 12th at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory to St. Hilda's-St.Hugh's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNETTE, GEORGE GILBERT
description: BENNETTE-George Gilbert. 70, on November 8, at his home in Fairlee, VT. Husband of Shirley Hersom, father of Stephen Page and Matthew Gilbert, and brother of Elizabeth Shackelford. Concert pianist and longtime Director of Arts and Leisure Education at the Lighthouse International, Manhattan. Memorial donations may be made to Guiding Eyes for the Blind, 611 Granite Springs Road, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, or to a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINE, VERNA
description: FINE-Verna. We mourn the passing of a devoted colleague, courageous woman, and cherished friend. Verna's spirited presence and ready wit will endure in the hearts and memories of those whose lives she touched. Our condolences to her loving family. Boosey & Hawkes Linda S. Golding, President

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is the government's problem. The water is deep and I did not see how big the hole was. The road is stuck. The country is stuck.''

title: Why Bush Stumbled
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Travel; The latest surcharge at many hotels intends to make guests pay for using phone lines too long.
description: TO keep guests from plugging in their laptops for hours and tying up trunk lines, a growing number of hotels are imposing new fees on extended use of local and toll-free telephone numbers.

title: Matthaus Is the Latest MetroStars Savior
description: In signing Germany's Lothar Matthaus, the MetroStars and Major League Soccer gained a star of the first light. And at his first news conference as a member of the MetroStars in midtown Manhattan yesterday, everyone seemed to bask in his glow. His introduction resembled the fanfare generated by Pele and Franz Beckenbauer of the Cosmos two decades ago. Television cameramen and still photographers jostled for position, a crush of reporters asked questions in several languages and even the food was up to Cosmos' vintage.

title: Corrections
description: A brief art review in Weekend on Friday about an exhibition of Milton Avery's paintings through Nov. 20 at Lubin House of Syracuse University, 11 East 61st Street in Manhattan, misidentified the works' owner. They are owned by Annette Kaufman, a friend of the artist, not by Syracuse University.

title: MODIS ISSUES FOURTH-QUARTER EARNINGS WARNING
description: Modis Professional Services Inc., a provider of staffing and consulting services, warned yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings would miss expectations as it considers spinning off its largest division. Fourth-quarter earnings will be 15 cents to 18 cents a share because of expenses for the Year 2000 computer problem and the cost of exploring the spinoff. The company, based in Jacksonville, Fla., had been expected to earn 33 cents by analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. Shares of Modis fell $1.9375 each, to $11.5625. Modis said it might give investors shares in Modis Inc., its information-technology services division, with $1.35 billion in estimated 1999 revenue.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE ENTERPRISE BUYS STAKE IN PRISMA
description: Public Service Enterprise Group, which owns New Jersey's largest utility, said yesterday that it had acquired a 70 percent stake in the Italian power-plant developer Prisma 2000 S.p.A. for about $80 million. The investment is Public Service's first in Europe. It bought half of Prisma from Barguzin Holding Danmark and 20 percent from Societe Financiere Cremonaise S.A., which retains 30 percent. Prisma, based in Cremona, Italy, plans to build power plants in Italy that can generate 550 megawatts of electricity, enough to light 550,000 homes in the United States. The Newark-based Public Service owns the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, a utility with 2.2 million electricity

title: U.S. Honors 9 Civil Rights Heroes, and Memory of 10th
description: An air of joyful mourning, if such a thing can be, permeated the White House today as the nation both honored the nine black students who desegregated Central High School in Little Rock, Ark., in 1957 and paid homage to the civil rights leader Daisy Bates, who died last week.

title: Trump Proposes Clearing Nation's Debt at Expense of the Rich
description: Preparing to embark on his first trip as a prospective candidate for president, Donald J. Trump yesterday presented a plan that he said would pay off the national debt, bolster Social Security and slash taxes by billions of dollars. Mr. Trump promised to accomplish all this at no cost to ordinary Americans, by forcing the rich to pay for it.

title: Selling Wine With Frills, Often the Edible Kind
description: WHEN the Morrell Cafe and Wine Bar opened in tandem with the new Morrell & Company wine shop in Rockefeller Center, the surprise was how the restaurant and retail operation had come so close in a state that has traditionally kept the two completely separate.

title: Sondheim's 'Marry Me,' This Time With Men
description: A brief note buried in the program of the theater production here of ''Marry Me a Little,'' with songs by Stephen Sondheim, says, ''Permission to change gender for the production of 'Marry Me a Little' has been made with the author's prior and express written consent.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIMONA, JOE
description: DIMONA-Joe, It is with profound sorrow that we mark the passing of our great friend and associate Joe DiMona, a wonderful author and quintessential New Yorker. We will miss his high spirits and intellect greatly, but take solace in the fact that his remarkable body of work, ''Prime Minister of the Underworld'', ''Last Man At Arlington'', ''To the Eagles Nest'' and many others will live forever. Martin Nirschel Chris O'Neill

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; $558 Million Ordered Repaid In Stock Grants
description: FOR want of a clause, a fortune was lost.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RECANT, PEARL W.
description: RECANT-Pearl W. Cherished mother of Dr. Robin S. Recant, Judge Donna G. Recant, and Dr. Jane F. Recant. Former wife of Dr. Benjamin Recant. You will always be in our hearts and memories. We love you. Private services for family only. Memorial observance at the home of Dr. Jane Recant 5-8PM, today and Thursday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Seeks Way to Open Operating-System Market

title: New York Trails in Race to Lure Biotechnology, Comptroller Says
description: Despite its vast resources in medical research, New York State has ''missed the boat'' on biotechnology, a promising new industry that has pumped billions of dollars into other states' economies, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall said yesterday.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Scratching the Popular Itch to Switch Jobs
description: Sally Poliak will never forget her political victories. She also never wants to relive them.

title: Backup Plan Proves to Be Wrong One
description: They read like a Who's Who in Football when the Jets acquired them in the off-season, bolstering a roster that already looked imposing. Now, considering the club's 2-6 start, these same acquisitions and the team could be renamed ''What Could Have Been.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLUB, ALBERT
description: GOLUB-Albert. Our beloved husband, father and grandfather passed in peace on November 8, 1999. His wife Ann, family and friends remember his gentle ways with eternal love. Services at Riverside Chapel in Great Neck today, November 10, at 1:15PM.

title: Israeli Soldiers Begin Clearing a West Bank Settlement
description: In the dark before dawn today, Israeli soldiers and the police began forcibly removing people from an illegal outpost in the West Bank where some 200 militant Jewish settlers had gathered to protect a makeshift community of about four families.

title: H.M.O.'s Shift May Please Patients, but Raise Costs
description: As recently as a week ago, Dr. Elihu Sussman in New York would have an office assistant call a nurse at the UnitedHealth Group, one of the health maintenance organizations that he deals with, to request approval to send a patient for a magnetic imaging scan. The assistant would wait on the line, endure 20 minutes of elevator music, typically get the approval and send the patient on his or her way.

title: Europeans Find Their Fear of Unleashing an Ogre Was Misplaced : Mistrust of Unified Germany Fades
description: PARIS  Ten years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, reunited Germany has hardly turned out to be the economic subjugator and tiger shark of European politics France and Britain so feared at first.

title: HOLIDAY TOMORROW: Veterans Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Shrill, Fast and Pounding (With a Debt to Stravinsky)
description: Riccardo Chailly's passion for the music of Edgar Varese, fully evident in his recent recordings of that composer's complete output, was again unmistakable on Monday night at Carnegie Hall as he spoke freely and ebulliently on the subject, with the entire Philadelphia Orchestra on the platform behind him waiting to begin. Happily, his enthusiasm continued into the performance of ''Arcana.'' And happily, so did the orchestra's.

title: LUCENT SAYS IT HAS NEW SWITCHING TECHNOLOGY
description: Trying to position itself as a leader in optical networking technology, Lucent Technologies said yesterday that it had developed a product that can route streams of digital information among different optical fibers using microscopic mirrors. For at least a decade, fiber optic technology has been the dominant way to transmit data, but switches, which tell individual messages where to go, have remained electrical. Now, companies are racing to develop ways to both switch and transmit data optically. Perhaps the leading company in optical switching, Sycamore Networks Inc., recently offered shares to the public and now has a market value of more than $18 billion. Lucent says that in one second, its new product can switch 10 times the amount of data carried by the entire Internet.

title: Alberto-Culver Adds An Agency to Its Roster
description: The Alberto-Culver Company in Melrose Park, Ill., has added Euro RSCG Tatham in Chicago to its agency roster to handle the creative duties for brands including Tresemme hair-care products, Consort men's hair spray and Mrs. Dash seasonings. Billings were estimated at $25 million to $30 million.

title: China Sentences 4 Leaders of Banned Party
description: Four founders of the outlawed China Democracy Party were declared guilty of subversion today and given prison sentences ranging up to 11 years.

title: Medical Journal Cites Misleading Drug Research
description: Reports of research on drugs tend to exaggerate the drugs' benefits, making them sound better than they really are, according to an article and editorial being published today in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENWALD, HAROLD
description: GREENWALD-Harold. The Zionist Organization of America mourns the passing of its esteemed leader and Honorary Chairman of the Finance Committee. He served the cause of Israel and Zionism with integrity and distinction and will be sorely missed. May his family find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Morton A. Klein, Nat'l Pres

title: On Iranians' Minds
description: To the Editor:

title: Long Live the Semicolon
description: To the Editor:

title: How Dances Defied Death In Cambodia
description: Given the legions of scholars, intellectuals and artists who were killed during the Khmer Rouge's genocidal rule of Cambodia between 1975 and 1979, it is hard to argue that classical dancers were singled out for murder. Seemingly any association with enlightenment, independent thought or tradition sufficed to merit a death sentence.

title: Cafe Dining, With a Touch of Cheek
description: MOST restaurants have a personality. Some have moods. Nicole's has both, and they run to extremes. In fact, the extremes are so extreme that Nicole's could be the restaurant version of ''I Led Two Lives.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARQUIS, PHILLIP E., D.D.S.
description: MARQUIS-Phillip E., D.D.S. July 4, 1911-November 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Florence. Father of Ronny and Eden. Grandfather of Joshua, Jonathan, Ashley and Alix.

title: The Ties That Bind: Don't Blame Mom
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; It's Time To Ponder A Camby Era
description: HE was gone for 46 seconds. A sprained ankle kept Marcus Camby, the former vanishing No. 2 draft pick, on the Knicks' bench for under a minute on Monday night against the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: COMPANY BRIEF
description: EMMIS COMMUNICATIONS CORP., Indianapolis, a radio, television and print-media company, bought two radio stations in Buenos Aires for $15 million in its first foray into Latin America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZAR, IMRE
description: LAZAR-Imre. It saddens our hearts to learn of the passing of Mr. Imre Lazar, father-in-law of Jack Rudman, father of Miriam and grandfather of Zvi, Jenny and Aliza. May they and all of Israel be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. A Family Friend

title: Choreographer Viola Farber Is Remembered by the French
description: For all their touchiness about the predominance of American popular culture here, the French have never been shy about acknowledging their debt to American contemporary dance. That helps to explain why French choreographers, dancers and cultural officials gathered here on Monday evening to pay tribute to Viola Farber, the American choreographer who died at 67 in New York last December.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, EVELYN
description: ROSE-Evelyn on November 8, 1999, of New York City. Devoted wife of the late Murray Rose. Beloved mother of David Rose. Adoring grandmother of Michael and Melissa, dear sister of Arthur Greenfield and Rose Hochberg. Graveside services Wednesday 1pm at Cedar Park Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to the Osteoperosis Foundation.

title: McMurtrie Godley, 82, Envoy To Laos During Vietnam War
description: G. McMurtrie Godley, a United States ambassador to Laos during the Vietnam War who played a central role in American efforts to defeat Communist forces there, died on Sunday in Fox Hospital in Oneonta, N.Y. He was 82.

title: Justices Hear Students' Case On the Withholding of Fees
description: At the heart of a Supreme Court argument today on student speech on public university campuses was a debate over the right not to speak.

title: Cisco Systems's Sales Surge And Profit Meets Forecasts
description: Cisco Systems reported a 49 percent gain in sales for its first quarter as the company remained a top beneficiary of the buildup of the Internet. Excluding acquisition-related charges, its earnings exceeded analysts' estimates by a penny but fell a penny short of the ''whisper number.''

title: About-Face and Continuity in Brooklyn
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music's 17th annual Next Wave Festival began with the usual bold mixture of experimental theater, music and dance. There were visits from such academy favorites as Laurie Anderson, Pina Bausch and Philip Glass and the debuts of several international companies. A hip-hop celebration featuring Vernon Reid and the Roots will bring the festival to a close on Dec. 11.

title: Restaurant's Added Gratuity Leads to Discrimination Claim
description: Charles Thompson was so angry about the automatic 15 percent tip added to his dinner of sizzling fish and spring rolls that he called 911.

title: School Reopens After Lead Dust Scare, but Many Stay Away
description: Public School 37 in the Bronx was reopened yesterday after a two-day shutdown because of concerns about lead dust in the building, but more than 25 percent of the students stayed away despite assurances that the school was safe.

title: Unable to Settle Budget, Congress Is Ready to Work Overtime
description: Congress cannot settle its financial and political scores with the White House and today abandoned hope of completing its budget and adjourning this week, Republican leaders said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOROWITZ, MAX
description: HOROWITZ-Max. November 10, 1972. I miss you Daddy.

title: Europeans Have Deferred to U.S. in Microsoft Litigation
description: It is almost impossible to walk into an office in Europe and not bump into desktop computers that run Windows 95 and other Microsoft programs like Word and Excel. So it was hardly surprising that the scathing appraisal issued in the Microsoft case by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson last Friday has been front-page news across the Continent.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GODLEY, G. MCMURTRIE
description: GODLEY-G. McMurtrie. The Board of Trustees, artists, and staff of Glimmerglass Opera deeply mourn the passing of our Chairman Emeritus and express our heartfelt gratitude for his years of leadership, devotion, and generosity. We extend our condolences and regards to his wife, Betty, and to the Godley family. Peter Duchin, President Board of Trustees Esther Nelson, General Director Paul Kellogg, Artistic Director

title: EgyptAir Data Recorder Is Pulled From the Ocean
description: A submarine operated by remote control retrieved a flight data recorder from the depths of the ocean south of Nantucket today, bringing to the surface a crucial piece of evidence that investigators hope will reveal why EgyptAir Flight 990 crashed into the sea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, LAUSON HARVEY
description: STONE-Lauson Harvey. Beloved husband of Jane Hunter Stone, loving father of Harlan Fiske Stone II, and Peter Hunter Stone. Loving father-in-law of Helen Galatan Stone and Paola Malanotte Stone. Devoted grandfather of Christopher Harlan Stone and Emily Palmer Stone. Family will receive friends Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9 at Jere J. Cronin Funeral Home, 115 Atlantic Ave, Brooklyn Heights, N.Y.

title: House Votes to Let Satellite TV Carry Local Station Programs
description: The House overwhelmingly passed a bill today that would allow satellite television companies to compete better with the cable industry by permitting them to carry local television channels for the first time.

title: Helping City Schools Bring a Taste of the Arts to Students
description: After a long morning of drills in reading, third graders at Public School 156 in Brownsville, Brooklyn, spent an hour last Friday dancing to the urgent flutter of flamenco music. Their small hands spiraled and their sneakers thumped as a professional dancer, Andrea Del Conte, guided them through stomps and whirls in a classroom with mirrored walls and glossy floors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, IRVING
description: DAVIS-Irving. On November 9, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Estelle (Dickman) and of Sylvia. Dearest father of Leslie Davis and Helen Kolins. Devoted grandfather of six.

title: Kudos for Kebabs: Istanbul in New York
description: TURKISH restaurants in New York used to be disappointing, churning out assembly-line appetizers and dried-out kebabs. But capitalizing on the American appreciation for all things Mediterranean, they have improved significantly in the last few years. Here are some favorites.

title: Arsonist-for-Hire Suspect Accused in '97 Bronx Apartment Fire
description: A Bronx man was charged yesterday with setting fire to an apartment on orders from a drug dealer who had been beaten by a resident of the apartment, law enforcement officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGOLIES, DANIEL
description: MARGOLIES-Daniel. 89. Nuremberg prosecuting attorney, died of heart failure in Denver, CO November 6. After graduating from Harvard, 1931 and Harvard Law School 1936 he began his career as co-counsel for the LaFollette Senate Committee on unfair labor practices. During World War II he worked for the OSS in London and Germany. He and his wife were prosecuting attornies at the Nuremberg trials. After the trials he joined the State Dept. and later the Foreign Service, retiring in 1970. He was born in Cleveland, OH and married Harriet Zetterberg (deceased 1986) in London, 1945. He is survived by two children, Mary Margolies DeForest and David Margolies. A memorial service will be held Thursday, December 2, at Washington Hebrew Congregation, 10:30 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Shalom Park, 14800 East Belleview, Aurora, CO 80015.

title: 7 Students Charged in a Brawl That Divides Decatur, Ill.
description: It started as a melee among high school students in the bleachers at a football game in the small Illinois city of Decatur. But it has grown into a bitter debate over race and rules, drawing the likes of the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Gov. George Ryan. And it has closed high schools for two consecutive days and resulted in charges against some of the students.

title: Shares Are Lower as Rally in Technology Issues Fizzles
description: Stock prices fell, led by Intel and Microsoft, as the rally in technology shares that drove the Nasdaq composite index to seven consecutive records ended.

title: How to Get Paid Not to Work
description: Naturally government and employers want to help Americans balance their family lives and their jobs. But the Clinton administration's plan to let states use unemployment insurance money to pay employees on leave after the birth of children is shortsighted, misguided and politically motivated.

title: Why Bush Stumbled
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Safety First With Bamboo

title: Sports of The Times; Dollar Bill Comes Home to the Garden
description: He knows the back corridors of the Garden as well as he knew the intricacies of the backdoor play.

title: Drug Studies Said To Magnify Benefit
description: Research on drugs tends to exaggerate their benefits, according to an article and editorial in The Journal of the American Medical Association. The journal said positive results tended to be published more often than negative ones, researchers sometimes published a study more than once and journals sometimes failed to properly screen out poor studies.

title: Giuliani Stresses Republican Ideals to Nation's Conservatives
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was the featured speaker at a benefit dinner here tonight for The American Spectator magazine, whose 400 guests represented the nation's conservative establishment.

title: Citigroup Head Concedes Laundering Controls Were Poor
description: The co-chairman of Citigroup testified before a Senate subcommittee today that his bank had been slow to correct years of weak controls over wealthy private accounts, and he lent support to a proposal that would prohibit American banks from accepting corrupt deposits from abroad.

title: Metro Business; Deal for AT&T Building
description: AT&T Corp. has signed a contract to sell its New York headquarters building at 32 Avenue of the Americas to three members of the Rudin family.

title: House Votes to Bolster a Drug-Trafficking Bill
description: After a bitter fight involving some of Washington's most powerful lobbying firms, Congress is dropping legal protections sought by international companies that feared becoming targets of new laws against drug traffickers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTLE, FANNIE A.
description: LITTLE-Fannie A. Of Ridgefield, CT. At the age of 87. Formerly of Ardsley and Somers, New York. Fifty-two year employee with DuArt Film Laboratories in New York City. Mother of Charlotte E. Donigi and her husband, Don, and Frank G. Little, Jr. Grandmother of 5, great grandmother of six. Funeral Mass Friday at 10AM at St. Mary's Church, Ridgefield, CT. Interment Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY. Contributions to the charity of one's choice.

title: It Was a Problem School But Now It's a War Zone
description: In the guise of being sociologically sensitive and highly hip, ''Light It Up'' turns out to be a pretentiously righteous drama that drowns any claim to serious attention in a sea of superficial characters.

title: PANCANADIAN WILL BUY NORTH SEA STAKE FROM BP AMOCO
description: PanCanadian Petroleum Ltd. said yesterday that it planned to acquire the central North Sea interests of BP Amoco Exploration. The holdings, which are off the British coast, include the Scott and Telford oil fields. PanCanadian, based in Calgary, Alberta, said the purchase price would be $211 million. PanCanadian is one of Canada's largest producers of crude oil, natural gas and natural gas liquids. It said the agreement covers BP Amoco's 13.5 percent interest in Scott, its 20.2 percent of Telford and associated production operations. PanCanadian said it was also acquiring a 26 percent interest in an adjacent block. The acquisition is subject to British government approval.

title: Environmental Sneak Attack
description: This is the time of year when members of Congress scramble to promote pet projects even if it means delaying adjournment. One new roadblock standing in the way of completing the federal budget is a last-minute effort by Senator Robert Byrd to attach a rider to one of the final spending bills that would favor strip mining in his home state of West Virginia. The White House, which has vowed to veto anti-environmental measures pushed by Republicans, has merely frowned on the Byrd rider. President Clinton should make clear that the administration does not have two standards, one for Republicans and one for powerful Democrats like Mr. Byrd, and that it will veto any bill to which the Byrd measure is attached.

title: Mr. Gorbachev's Role
description: The Berlin Wall was bound to fall eventually. But that it came down as bloodlessly as it did 10 years ago this week is largely a tribute to one leader. Today Mikhail Gorbachev is a political pariah in Russia and increasingly forgotten in the West. But history will remember him generously for his crucial role in ending the cold war and pulling back the Iron Curtain that Stalin drew across Europe in 1945.

title: Look out, Bell Atlantic -- here come challengers to your dominance of Manhattan's yellow pages.
description: THREE companies, including the nation's largest independent publisher of yellow pages directories, are looking to challenge Bell Atlantic's long dominance in yellow pages in the Manhattan market.

title: FEWER JOBLESS GERMANS
description: German joblessness dropped slightly in October, but the gap between western and eastern Germany continued to widen, according to statistics released by the Federal Labor Office. On a seasonally adjusted basis, the number of unemployed workers declined 11,000 in October, the first decline in three months. The overall unemployment rate remained unchanged at 10.5 percent, but the rate increased slightly, to 18.3 percent, in the east and declined slightly, to 8.6 percent, in the west.

title: In Baseball, October Goes To the Highest Of the Bidders
description: General managers and their aides carried large, blue hard-cover notebooks out of their daily business session today. The notebooks were actually heavier than they looked. They were filled with dollar signs, large dollar signs. They contained the payroll information from the 1999 season. To the general managers, that made the notebooks more frightening than a Stephen King novel.

title: CANADIAN PORT DISPUTE
description: Most shipments through the port of Vancouver, British Columbia, which handles one-quarter of Canada's maritime cargo, have been halted for three days by a lockout of 2,200 members of the dockworkers' union. The value of stalled traffic is put at about $52 million a day, including imports of consumer goods and exports of forest products. Grain is being shipped because of special legislation.

title: Out of Six, He Has No Left Feet
description: Even those without a child may want to beg or borrow one as a pretext for making their way to the New Victory Theater in Times Square before Tomas Kubinek ends his latest engagement there on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GENSER, RUTH
description: GENSER-Ruth. November 10, 1998. Take care of Daddy, I miss you. Love Barbara

title: THE CHEF
description: I HAVE always loved transferring the primitive, soulful character of Southern food to something that is delicate and refined. It's how I maintain a sense of place in my cooking, what the French call cuisine terroir, here in back-country Virginia. For the next eight weeks, I'll be bringing you some of the flavors of my region, combined in unusual ways and presented in dishes where you wouldn't expect to find them.

title: Mets' Talks On Griffey Are Called Productive
description: The Mets met with the Seattle Mariners for a second time on Ken Griffey Jr. today. They expect to meet again.

title: Cineplex Bringing Back The Movies to 42nd St.
description: The movies are coming back to 42nd Street, with the opening of a 13-screen Loews Cineplex on Friday signaling a revival of the western end of the block between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, which has been undergoing demolition and construction for several years.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the resumption of direct flights from New York to Havana misstated the views of the U.S.-Cuba Trade and Economic Council on the American trade embargo on Cuba. The council takes no position; it does not advocate lifting the embargo. The article also misstated the council's statistics on United States citizens who travel to Cuba. The council's president, John S. Kavulich II, estimated that 140,000 U.S. citizens would travel to Cuba this year; he did not say that 140,000 U.S. citizens travel there every year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MISEIK, SHIHAB, MD.
description: MISEIK-Shihab, MD. The Department of Medicine at New York Methodist Hospital sadly announces the death of our colleague, Dr. Shihab Miseik. He was a knowledgeable and peaceful young doctor who will be deeply missed. Dr. Miseik graduated from the University of Khartoum in 1991 and was a member of the Sudanese Medical Association. He was a volunteer for the African Relief Agency establishing mobile clinics and delivering food to refugee camps. In July, 1999, he started his residency in Internal Medicine at New York Methodist Hospital. He is survived by his parents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, RABBI LEIB
description: KRAMER-Rabbi Leib. Of Montreal, on Shabbos 27 Cheshvan 5760, November 6, 1999. Mourned by his dear wife Chaya Zelda; beloved children Michel, Sara, Yosef, Esther, Shmuel; grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Memory can be honored thru ''Rabbi Leib Kramer Scholarship Fund,'' c/o 4706 Kent Ave, Montreal, CA 43W1H1.

title: After Boat Collapse, Questions Linger but Race Goes On
description: When it comes to America's Cup yacht design and construction, there is a fine line between too light and just right.

title: Williams and Brosius Win Gold Gloves
description: On a day when Yankee center fielder Bernie Williams won his third consecutive Gold Glove, and a teammate, third baseman Scott Brosius, won his first, a significant question during a conference call with both players yesterday was whether Williams would indeed undergo surgery on his ailing left shoulder.

title: Bermuda Exchange Idled
description: Trading on the Bermuda Stock Exchange was shut down today because of a computer problem as technicians upgraded the operating system software. There was no trading on the relatively thinly traded electronic offshore securities exchange, which provides a market for 248 equities, funds, debt issues and depository securities, an exchange executive said. The BEST, or Bermuda Electronic Securities Trading system, was introduced at the end of last year. The disruption was the second since last December, but the exchange said trading should resume on Wednesday.

title: I.M.F. Director Quits, Prompting a Struggle
description: Michel Camdessus, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, resigned in the middle of his third term, citing personal reasons. The move set off a behind-the-scenes struggle between the Clinton administration and European nations over who will head the agency that is dictating economic policy from Russia to Indonesia.

title: 'Walkers' Make a Tentative Stand; African Deliverymen Complain, Gently, of a Tough Job
description: As pickets go, the labor protest outside an Upper West Side supermarket two weeks ago was oddly subdued. There were no accusatory shouts from the dozens of strikers, nor were there any of the fiery union slogans one might expect from a group of disgruntled employees.

title: What Prosperity Means
description: To the Editor:

title: A Clamorous Trattoria, With Food to Match
description: ANY restaurant that opened next door to Tomoe Sushi in Greenwich Village always seemed a little forlorn. The people standing in line in front of it have always been waiting for a table at Tomoe.

title: Yashin in Ranger Blue? Do Not Count on It
description: The player who could help the Rangers the most this season will not appear with his team when it plays tonight at Madison Square Garden. Center Aleksei Yashin of Ottawa, one of the bright, young stars of the National Hockey League, was suspended yesterday by the Senators for refusing to honor his contract.

title: Theodore Hall, Prodigy and Atomic Spy, Dies at 74
description: Theodore Alvin Hall, who was the youngest physicist to work on the atomic bomb project at Los Alamos during World War II and was later identified as a Soviet spy, died on Nov. 1 in Cambridge, England, where he had become a leading, if diffident, pioneer in biological research. He was 74.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times yesterday about veterinarians' growing use of psychology and psychiatric drugs omitted the full identity of an expert who was quoted on the links between human and animal psychology. She is Dr. Bonnie Beaver, a professor at Texas A&M University who is on the executive board of the American Veterinary Medicine Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROUT, BETTY LEA
description: BROUT-Betty Lea. On November 8, 1999. Dear sister of Judith Friedman and Robert Brout. Sister-inlaw of Sandor Friedman. Betty was a social worker and writer; she dedicated her life to the principles of humanism and ethical culture. She has served on the Boards of the New York Ethical Culture Society and the American Humanist Association. We all remember her for her goodness of heart. Service Thursday 12:00 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Turning Up Emotions, Turning Off The Suds
description: Karen Mason, more than most New York cabaret performers, embodies the kind of Midwestern woman who would unblushingly accept Oscar Hammerstein's description of Mary Martin's character in ''South Pacific'': ''as corny as Kansas in August'' and ''as normal as blueberry pie.'' But if Ms. Mason, who remembers ''slinging pasta'' in Chicago at a restaurant called Lawrence of Oreganos, is the personification of an urbanized true grit, beneath her hearty affability churn the same romantic preoccupations that drive more overtly sophisticated performers into cabaret.

title: SEOUL TO ISSUE BONDS
description: The South Korean government will issue up to five trillion won ($4.22 billion) of won-denominated government bonds to keep the local currency from rising too fast against the dollar, the Ministry of Finance and Economy said. The ministry said it was working to reduce an oversupply of dollars caused by the recent influx of foreign investment funds, particularly into the local stock exchange. The inflow of foreign direct and portfolio investment funds has been surging.

title: Unrest in Aceh Forces Wahid To Shorten Trip
description: SINGAPORE  President Abdurrahman Wahid of Indonesia cut short on Tuesday his first overseas trip since taking office, returning home to deal with an intensifying separatist movement in Aceh Province and calls for immediate action by the government.

title: So Celestial, So Rippling, So French
description: Why this French love affair with the harp? Sunday afternoon's Chamber Music Society concert at Alice Tully Hall began with pieces by composers of successive generations -- Saint-Saens, Debussy and Andre Jolivet -- all using the harp prominently. Then came Faure's C minor Piano Quintet, in which the rippling piano part, beautifully and unpretentiously played by Lee Luvisi, gives the impression the instrument is trying to gently shake off its keys and hammers.

title: Devils Show How to Kill Penalties and Win Games
description: The Devils can thank their penalty killers, especially Scott Stevens, Scott Niedermayer and Ken Daneyko, while the Flyers can blame their power-play units, which entered the game between the division rivals ranked first in the league in efficiency.

title: For the Wall's Fall, East Germans Are Given Their Due
description: At a ceremony marking the 10th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder made very clear today which Germans deserve special praise, saying, ''The wall fell from east to west, pushed down by brave and fearless East Germans.''

title: Haskel Frankel, 73, Author and Theater Critic
description: Haskel Frankel, a prolific author and theater critic, died last Wednesday in Chester, Conn. He was 73.

title: ITALIAN GAS UTILITY IN BRAZIL
description: Brazil's hopes of increasing natural gas consumption were lifted after Eni S.p.A. of Italy agreed to pay $143 million for a concession to build a natural gas grid in the country's industrialized southeast. Eni outbid CMS Energy, the Enron Corporation of Houston and Gas Natural S.A. of Spain for the right to construct a gas distribution network in the interior of Sao Paulo state. Eni will use gas from the recently completed Bolivia-to-Brazil gas pipeline.

title: Merrill Lynch Has Trouble Processing Trading Orders
description: Just three weeks before its scheduled introduction of an advanced online stock-trading system, Merrill Lynch & Company is struggling to handle customers' trades the old-fashioned way.

title: A Young Match for the Turkey
description: Gallo Sonoma Frei Ranch Zinfandel, 1995, California. About $18.

title: Tropical-Storm Victims Get Checks From State
description: Nearly two months after Tropical Storm Floyd swept through New Jersey, the first checks were handed out yesterday from a $50 million fund that state lawmakers approved on Oct. 25 to aid victims of severe flooding.

title: 'Annie' Makes November Sing for ABC
description: Sunday's spectacular ratings performance by ABC's new version of the musical ''Annie'' has opened the door for an annual November musical event on the network. And if ABC manages to fulfill its pie-in-the-sky wish, next November's production will be a new version of the musical ''Mame'' starring Barbra Streisand.

title: Pfizer's Drug Merger Bid Alarms Rivals in Europe
description: Executives from three of Europe's largest drug companies are predicting that Pfizer will not only win the battle for Warner-Lambert but that the combination of the two companies could touch off a series of huge mergers, creating the industry's first super companies.

title: $1 Increase in the Minimum Wage Wins Senate Approval but Faces a Clinton Veto
description: Split along party lines, the Senate today approved a Republican plan to raise the federal minimum wage by $1 an hour over three years, to $6.15, and provide a variety of tax breaks mostly to the owners of small businesses.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR FALLS. The dollar was little changed as traders awaited a report today on United States producer prices. In New York, the dollar settled at 104.94 yen, down from 105.19; the euro traded at $1.0407, up from $1.0386.

title: PALESTINIAN-BRITISH GAS DEAL
description: The Palestinian Authority is following Israel in contracting with BG P.L.C., a British gas company, to search for natural gas off their shared Mediterranean coast, signing a 25-year exploration and distribution deal with BG in London. Last week a BG joint venture in Israel announced what it said might be a commercially viable offshore gas find near the Israel-Gaza border. Under the new Palestinian agreement, at least two exploration wells are to be drilled off Gaza within 18 months.

title: Political Life Adapts Itself To Private One
description: THIS provincial city, locked between the deep waters of Lake Champlain and the High Peaks of the Adirondacks, is an unlikely place to have elected the state's first openly gay mayor.

title: The Aristocrat of Meats Does Stew Duty
description: VEAL is the prima donna of meat. Pale and delicate, with a European heritage and a high price, it is more often associated with expensive restaurants than with the corner supermarket. Even the more robust cuts like the shank that have become popular recently appear only infrequently on home dinner tables in this country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, LILLIAN
description: STERN-Lillian. Manhattan Day School/Yeshiva Ohr Torah records with profound sorrow the passing of Lillian Stern, mother of Shera Goldman, wife of our esteemed board member, Martin Goldman. May the entire family be comforted in this hour of their untimely loss. Manhattan Day School/ Yeshiva Ohr Torah Rabbi Mordecai Besser, Principal George Karasick, President Elliot Gibber, Chairman of the Board

title: Russia Blockades Chechnya to Isolate Rebels
description: Russia sought today to cut off Chechnya from the outside world by banning foreign trade with the breakaway republic and suspending international flights to the region.

title: Tales Like Persian Carpets On Screen
description: There is a reason many people consider Iranian movies to be the most artistically adventurous being made anywhere today, and it has to do with the intensity with which that country's filmmakers probe the basic elements of the moviegoing experience. Among the recurrent themes are the relationships of actors to nonactors and of nonactors to fictional characters, the shadowy lines between fiction and documentary, and the ability of film to convey a firsthand experience of the physical world.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Price
description: For those who have spent the past decades tracking the Arab-Israeli peace process, this is indeed an auspicious week. Finally, finally, finally, we are really at the final negotiations, which began Monday in Ramallah.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRULETZ, ROSALIND
description: STRULETZ-Rosalind. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York note with deep sadness the death of Rosalind O. Struletz of LaGrange, Georgia, beloved sister of Morton Olshan, a longtime leader in our Real Estate Division. She will always be remembered by her local Jewish community as a force for progress and harmony. We convey our deepest sympathy to her children, Howard & Donna, and Allan and Lori, as well as to Mort, his wife Carole, his children Andrea and Michael, and all the members of the family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Andrew J. Singer, Chair, Real Estate and Allied Trades Div John S. Ruskay, Acting Exec VP

title: Cosmic Puzzle: Are They Out There? Will We Hear?
description: Don't conclude from Timothy Ferris's skepticism about unverifiable sightings of unidentified flying objects that he harbors many doubts about the existence of other forms of life in the cosmos. Quite the contrary. ''Life Beyond Earth,'' his new two-hour PBS program, makes a cogent case for the existence of extraterrestrial intelligences even as it concedes the difficulty of identifying them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, BURT
description: EPSTEIN-Burt. On November 8, 1999, age 43. Beloved husband of Donna Esbensen. Cherished son of Seymour and Lenore. Devoted father of Warin, Jessica and Amanda. Fond grandson of Irene Ganz. Dear brother of the late Carol Epstein. Services on Thursday, 2 P.M., at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: No. 1 UConn Grows Taller for New Season
description: Check the rings carefully and note the rotund point guard. It is about all that will seem familiar about the Connecticut Huskies, who begin the defense of their first national championship Thursday at Madison Square Garden in the first round of the Coaches vs. Cancer/Ikon Classic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOMNITZ, ERIC
description: LOMNITZ-Eric. The Managing Directors and staff of American Express Tax & Business Services are saddened by the death of a friend to many of us. We offer our heartfelt condolences to Barbara, sons Robert and David, daughters-inlaw Michele and Olga, grandson Daniel, and to his friends and associates at Continental Resources.

title: Giants vs. Colts: It's Put-Up Time for Contending Teams
description: The wind was whipping across the practice field next to Giants Stadium Monday afternoon and players tugged the turtlenecks beneath their pads up over their mouths as a last seal against the cold.

title: Manning Is Already The New Colt Hero
description: Two years ago, in the weeks before the National Football League draft, Bill Polian found himself immersed in a great debate: Who was the better quarterback, Peyton Manning or Ryan Leaf? Now the choice seems laughable, but at the time N.F.L. executives argued the point ferociously. In the offices of the Indianapolis Colts, something about Leaf's lack of seasoning compared to Manning's maturity struck the master architect Polian. Manning became his choice, and Leaf went to San Diego.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROEHRICH, JOHN DENNIS
description: ROEHRICH-John Dennis. On November 6, 1999. Partner of Wheels Sattelite, Inc. A Memorial Mass will be offered Saturday, November 13th, 1PM at Saint Francis of Assisi R.C. Church, 135 W. 31 St, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE SELLS SHAMPOO UNIT TO PRESTIGE
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, the largest United States maker of household products, sold its slow-growing Prell shampoo business on Nov. 1 to Prestige Brands International Inc. for an undisclosed price. Prestige Brands, a newly formed consumer-products company, said the Prell purchase was part of a strategy to buy more well-known brands. The sale comes as P.& G., the biggest United States shampoo company, seeks to strengthen its higher-volume hair-care lines including Pantene, Pert Plus and Vidal Sassoon. Prell, once one of Procter & Gamble's top products, had less than $50 million in annual sales and accounted for less than 1 percent of P.& G.'s $7.1 billion in beauty-care sales for the year ended June 30.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Greek Protests Against U.S. Could Shorten Clinton's Trip
description: White House officials said today that President Clinton's visit to Greece this weekend will probably be shortened or rearranged because a rash of anti-American demonstrations and attacks there have raised security concerns.

title: Vanya Moves to West Virginia but Still Despairs
description: The guitar was Chekhov's idea; it is in the opening stage directions for ''Uncle Vanya.'' So what's better than hearing the inspired guitar playing of Steve Bargonetti and his wife, Diane Gioia, before a word is spoken in the Worth Street Theater Company's ''Uncle Jack,'' derived from the Chekhov play by Jeff Cohen, who also directs the production?

title: BOND REDEMPTIONS TO BE MONITORED
description: South Korea's Financial Supervisory Service formed a quick-response team to deal with a potential run on investment trust companies with exposure to bonds issued by the sinking Daewoo Group. As of yesterday, investors can redeem 80 percent of their money invested in Daewoo bonds, up from 50 percent, raising fears that a possible liquidity squeeze at investment trusts might cause another financial crisis.

title: INSIDE
description: Resonant German Date

title: Big Three Injured
description: DALLAS

title: Letting the Doctors Decide
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISMAN, JOSEPH, DR.
description: WEISMAN-Joseph, Dr. November 8, age 91. Dentist, retired Professor of Periodontics NYU Dental College. Son of Bella and Louis, husband of Helen (nee Freedman), father of the late Phyllis Falk & the late Edward Weisman, grandfather of Caryn Christianson, Deborah Davidowitz, Susan Wickes, Andrea Riddle and Mark Weisman. Great-grandfather of Kenneth Madison and Phyllicia Christianson, Emily Davidowitz, Daniel & Bryan Wickes, Michelle & Emily Riddle, Matthew Weisman-very dearly loved by all. Funeral at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, Thursday, Novemeber 11 at 11 A.M., 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers. Interment at Westchester Hills Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BONHAM, WILLIAM R.
description: BONHAM-William R. 1921-1987. Twelve years ago the unthinkable happened. My soulmate you are still with me every day. Mo

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, PERLA
description: BLOOM-Perla. Beloved mother, sister and friend. Services November 10, 1999, 12 noon at Manhattan Sephardic Congregation, 325 East 75th Street. Interment to follow at Mt. Judah Cemetery, Ridgewood, NY. Any donations to Cancer Care or the American Cancer Society.

title: Does Social Class Matter in School?
description: A DANGEROUS myth was once conventional -- that disadvantaged children could not learn. So poor children were assigned to tracks and taught less challenging lessons. Educators took little responsibility for low achievement, blaming children's poverty and home lives.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Urban League Wins Contract to Train Parents

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a protest planned by Christians in Israel misstated the history of papal visits there. If Pope John Paul II goes next year, he will not be the first Pope to do so. In 1964, Pope Paul VI made a one-day visit to Israel, although it was not considered an official visit because the Vatican had not yet extended diplomatic recognition.

title: A Writer's Down Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Action-Packed Outing: Marbury and Kidd
description: A month ago, before the Nets' first public intrasquad scrimmage, John Nash introduced Stephon Marbury as ''the best point guard in the National Basketball Association.'' Receiving his cue, a smiling Marbury jogged onto the court, no doubt believing his general manager's description to be correct.

title: Waste Management Names Chief Executive
description: Waste Management Inc., the nation's largest trash hauler, said yesterday that it had named A. Maurice Myers, the chairman of the Yellow Corporation, as its chief executive to try to fix its accounting system and lift its stock.

title: Australia Shoe Offering
description: The Venator Group, the biggest United States athletic shoe retailer, is selling shares of its Colorado Group unit in Australia to the public so that it can focus on its Foot Locker, Champs and other chains. Venator, formerly the Woolworth Corportation, expects to raise about $75 million from the offering. The Colorado Group is Australia's largest specialty footwear retailer, with more than 300 stores.

title: At Papal Mass in Caucasus, a High-Profile Orthodox Christian
description: Ten years to the day after the collapse of the Berlin Wall, President Eduard Shevardnadze of Georgia did something that was unthinkable 10 years ago, when he was foreign minister of the Soviet Union: He sat in the audience at a Mass celebrated by Pope John Paul II before 7,000 people and jumped out of his seat and warmly kissed the pope on the cheek.

title: A Shift in the H.M.O. Revolution
description: The UnitedHealth Group's decision to let doctors decide -- without the approval of the insurance company -- what care a patient should receive could signal a major change of course in the managed-care revolution. When the managed-care concept first burst upon the American health scene a decade or so ago it was touted as the best way to control runaway medical costs and to assure that all patients received the care they needed but not unnecessary care. As one key element of ''managing'' costs, insurance plan administrators were given the power to approve, in advance, any costly procedures and hospitalizations recommended by doctors participating in the plan. Whatever merit this approach had as a management tool, it was despised by both patients and doctors.

title: Investigation of State Development Agency Focuses on L.I. Land Deal
description: Nearly two dozen developers eagerly set their sights on the old Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center in 1997 when the state offered to sell the property -- the largest tract of undeveloped land on Long Island.

title: Gore Takes His Turn at the Name Game
description: Let no one accuse Vice President Al Gore of not knowing his Uzbeks from his Moldovans.

title: Crack a Communique, Shatter an Assumption
description: THE CODE BOOK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONAS, PAULINE LEVY
description: MONAS - Pauline Levy. The trustees and staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services mourn the passing of Pauline Levy Monas, the beloved mother of Martin Monas, the JBFCS board member whose generosity established Levy-Monas House on Long Island. Mrs. Monas played a role in creating and supporting Levy-Monas House, an adolescent-group home named for her parents and in-laws. She also created the tradition of philanthropy carried on by her son and other members of her family. Funeral services for Mrs. Monas will be held Thursday, November 11, at noon at the Norman L. Jeffer Community Chapel, 4620 Fort Hamilton Parkway in Brooklyn. The family will sit shiva at the home of Martin Monas in Manhattan. We express our deepest sympathy to her son, Martin; her daughter, Barbara Herman; her sisters, Frieda Spiegel and Edna Ginsberg; her brother, Abe Levy; her grandchildren, Shari and Lowell Frey and Barry Herman; and her great-grandchildren, Allison and Sam Frey. Joseph S. Kaplan, President Seymour R. Askin, Jr., Chairman of the Board Alan B. Siskind, Ph.D, Executive Vice President Paul Levine, CSW, Associate Executive Vice President Rosemary Sanchez, Director, Levy-Monas House

title: Panini, Fresh Off the Grill
description: IT would be nice to say that I have been searching for grilled panini in New York ever since I tried them in Italy several years ago. But the truth is that I have been looking for these grilled Italian sandwiches ever since I tried them 10 years ago in Seattle, at Botticelli Cafe, a renowned espresso bar.

title: Poll Finds Greater Confidence in Democrats
description: A year before the election, Democrats enjoy public confidence on most critical election issues, from health care to education to Social Security, and more voters say they will vote for Democrats than Republicans in the the House of Representatives, the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows.

title: Robert Kennedy Says Mayor Plays Politics With Water
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. inserted himself into the race for the Senate yesterday by accusing Mayor Rudolph W.
