Giuliani of jeopardizing the city's water supply to ''court political favor'' with upstate Republican leaders and developers crucial to Mr. Giuliani's unannounced campaign. Last month, Mr. Kennedy met privately for more than an hour with Mr. Giuliani's all-but-certain opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the design competition for the Times Capsule, commissioned by The New York Times to preserve artifacts from the 20th century and scheduled for display at the American Museum of Natural History starting Dec. 4, misstated the name of a finalist. It is Antenna Design New York Inc., not the Antenna Group.

title: Fashion Police, Federal Division; A Presidential T-Shirt Brings Trouble in Chappaqua
description: It was the most successful fund-raiser that a college scholarship group here had ever seen.

title: Why Live Music Sounds Better at Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Medical-Device Reuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Israelis Clear Settlement of Holdouts
description: Clutching an olive branch and draped in a prayer shawl, Yehoshafat Tor, the leader of this militant outpost of Jewish settlers, lay handcuffed on the ground this morning, ringed by Israeli soldiers and police officers after he had been dragged from his home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEE, DR. TIMOTHY
description: GEE-Dr. Timothy. A man of respect, tolerance, the love and caring of a good friend. May you be remembered as a great healer, friend and example to all humanity. Our condolences to Carol and the family. Rose Blumenthal and Family

title: I.R.S. Rewards Workers Who Told of Abuses
description: The Internal Revenue Service is paying money, and in some cases giving promotions, to employees who testified about abuses of taxpayers during 1997 and 1998 Senate Finance Committee hearings that led to a major overhaul of the tax agency.

title: . . . And Committing to His Decorator
description: ON the day that Jerry Seinfeld was announcing his engagement to Jessica Sklar, a Tommy Hilfiger publicist, her former husband, Eric Nederlander, was closing on his new Lafayette Street loft and contemplating his future -- with a decorator.

title: JAPAN'S SURPLUS FALLS
description: Japan's current account surplus shrank 27.8 percent in September, its biggest drop in 18 months, as companies brought home less profit from abroad and exports fell. The surplus shrank to a six-month low of 811.7 billion yen, or $7.7 billion, seasonally adjusted, Ministry of Finance figures showed. The surplus had been expected to widen to 1.27 trillion yen. From a year earlier, the surplus fell 40 percent. The unexpected decline may signal that the rise in the yen, which is up more than 8 percent this year, is starting to take a toll on exports.

title: The Ragged March to Markets
description: Ten years ago, at about the time the Berlin Wall fell, the government-controlled economies of Eastern and Central Europe began a long and uncertain trek to market-based economies. They had no blueprints. Economists had given little thought to creating capitalism out of socialism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, LILYAN
description: FELDMAN-Lilyan. November 9, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Feldman. Loving mother of Barbara Gogel. Cherished grandmother of Kenneth Gogel & Lynn Oxfeld & great grandmother of five. Service at 10AM Friday, November 12, 1999 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, ADELE
description: WILSON-Adele. Beloved wife of the late Meyer. Loving mother of Ira and Lynne. Dear sister Naomi Dvorkin. Cherished grandmother of Michael, Matthew and Amy, and great-grandmother of seven. Service today, 10 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mount Vernon, NY.

title: BRITISH TELECOM CUTS RATES
description: Moving closer to offering flat-rate pricing for Internet calls, British Telecommunications P.L.C. said it would again cut the cost of Internet calls. The cuts will let Internet-access providers charge its clients a flat rate for access to the Internet by January. Industry experts say that Internet use in Britain and throughout Europe has been stifled because most local phone calls are metered by the minute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'ROURKE, MARGARET M.
description: O'ROURKE-Margaret M. On November 9, 1999 of Jackson Heights, NY. The Saint Patrick's Day Parade Committee offers their deepest sympathy to the family of our distinguished OfficerDirector. The Committee will meet at Conway Funeral Home, 82-19 Northern Boulevard, Jackson Heights, NY, Friday, November 12, at 7 P.M. to pay our respects to an outstanding lady. John T. Dunleavy, Chairman

title: People
description: * Debra Brown was named to the new post of president for the custom product and licensing unit at Cyrk Inc., New York. She had been president at Thompson Connect, New York, part of the J. Walter Thompson unit of thecobiWPP Group.

title: The Rangers Flirt With Victory But Embrace Another Defeat
description: For more than 30 minutes last night, the Rangers dominated the best team in the Eastern Conference. But over the final 20 minutes, when it counted most, the Rangers found themselves back in the familiar position of being dominated.

title: Paris's Filthy Streets
description: To the Editor:

title: Seattle and Griffey Suitors Far Apart
description: The pursuit of Ken Griffey Jr., one of the most attractive players ever available in baseball's trade mart, seems likely to continue until one side, the Seattle Mariners, or the other, the teams they're talking to, blinks.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR SLIPS. The dollar fell as a report on producer prices raised concern about inflation. In New York, the dollar settled at 104.65 Japanese yen, down from 104.94 on Tuesday; the euro traded at $1.0437, up from $1.0407.

title: A White Steel Sconce With a Moderne Grace
description: The fixture is heavy (no plastic parts), the effect is light. The Safir wall sconce from Luxo is made entirely of steel. Though it was conceived for commercial spaces, it has begun turning up in homes. The Safir, about 15 1/2 inches tall and about 8 inches wide, takes two halogen bulbs. It weighs seven pounds and costs $465. The Safir can be ordered from Standard Lighting, 16 East 38th Street; (212) 679-6388. LINDA LEE

title: Essay; Drama At 301 Congress
description: Every dramatist knows that before the plot can thicken, a mix of characters must be stirred in. In the roman a clef to be written about the Bush campaign, if it wins, here are the real people on whom to base the cast:

title: Goldman Lifts Ban on Stock Sales for Charities
description: In what may become an early holiday gift to schools, hospitals and other nonprofit groups, Goldman Sachs Group, the investment bank that became a public company earlier this year, has lifted some restrictions on its stock to allow partners to donate as much as $500 million to charity.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: ASIA

title: Honors
description: * The Association of Independent Commercial Producers, Los Angeles and New York, named presidents for regional chapters: Brian Donnelly, partner and executive producer at Onesuch Films, Los Angeles, West; Bob Fisher, president and executive producer at Celsius Films, New York, East, and Alan Sadler, executive producer atBig Deahl Productions, Chicago, Midwest.

title: 'Cybersquatting' Measure Attached to Satellite-TV Bill
description: Hoping to fend off a threatened veto of a controversial bill to outlaw speculating in Internet addresses, or ''cybersquatting,'' Congressional leaders have attached it to a bill on satellitetelevision that has already passed the House and is awaiting a vote in the Senate.

title: Nigerian Fraud Syndicates Set Up Shop in South Africa
description: The unsolved killing of one foreign businessman here and the mysterious disappearance of another has local and international law enforcement agents warning overseas executives and entrepreneurs to be wary of West African criminal syndicates that in recent years have made this, the continent's financial capital, their second home.

title: Nominee Logjam Loosens
description: Former Senator Carol Mosely-Braun was confirmed as an ambassador as senators reached an agreement to approve dozens of nominees as envoys and judges. Page A16.

title: A Slow Start For Bradley, Who Recovers To Win a Fan
description: Delivering the same stump speech over and over, presidential candidates sometimes develop a clipped delivery, omitting important words. The problem proved particularly acute today for former Senator Bill Bradley, who was known for a terse, almost telegraphic style of speech even before he began campaigning for the Democratic nomination.

title: New Web Service Offers Portable Bookmark Lists
description: For regular Web users, browser lists of bookmarks or favorites are personal bibliographies. Unlike lists on paper, unfortunately, browser lists of Web addresses cannot easily be transferred between computers, at the home and the office, for example.

title: INSIDE
description: New Plan for Diversity

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANAUER, LILO
description: HANAUER-Lilo (nee Growald). Died peacefully after a long illness, November 10th, 1999 at the age of 87 in her home in New York City. Beloved wife of Bernard Hanauer for 53 years. Sadly missed by daughters Elaine Hanauer Ravich and Linda Hanauer, son-in-law William Ravich and grandaughters Madeline Ravich & Emily Ravich. Beloved nursery school teacher at Stern Kindergarten for over 25 years. Services Thursday, November 11, 1:00 PM at Louis Hirsch & Sons, 1225 Jerome Avenue, Bronx.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, CHRISTINE
description: MAYER-Christine. Passed away peacefully November 9, 1999 after a long illness. Cherished daughter of Nomy Mayer. Adored sister of Robert & devoted niece of Elaine Johnson. She will be remembered and loved for her great courage and kindness and an inspiration to her friends and family. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory to The Unitarian Church of All Souls, 1157 Lexington Avenue, New York, New York 10021. There will be a memorial service at All Souls Unitarian Church, Sunday, December 5 at 1:30 P.M.

title: New York Senate Panel Urges Changes in Boxing
description: A New York State Senate committee investigating corruption in the boxing industry recommended sweeping changes to the sport yesterday, including the abolishment of sanctioning organizations that rank boxers and the creation of a national governing body to regulate fights in the United States.

title: The Playwright's Nightmare, Wearing a Butcher's Apron
description: The Oedipal urge, as perhaps only a playwright might experience it, courses through ''The Heart of Art,'' a saucy bit of character assassination by Michael Weller. In this amusing, theater insidery satire, a megalomaniacal father figure of a producer named Arthur Dick takes a novice dramatist under his wing and wrings every last ounce of idealism from his soul.

title: Deal by United Dominion
description: United Dominion Industries, a maker of pumps, valves, compactors and other equipment, has agreed to buy the Kelley Company, a maker of dock accessories and vehicle restraints. The financial terms were not disclosed. Kelley is expected to have sales this year of $70 million. It is based in Milwaukee and operates factories in Wisconsin and Ontario. United Dominion is based in Charlotte.

title: Bank One Again Warns About Profits
description: Citing continuing weakness in its huge credit card division, the Bank One Corporation issued its second profit warning in three months today, saying that fourth-quarter earnings forecasts would have to be reduced by as much as 16 percent.

title: Web Search Group Loses Grant
description: THE SCOUT REPORT, a highly regarded publication that monitors the Internet for new and useful research resources, is facing a loss of financing when its three-year grant from the National Science Foundation runs out next spring.

title: Of Knots and Wrinkles
description: MARCEL WANDERS, clad in black and baring a mouthful of braces, is one of the designers of Droog, the Dutch brigade known for its conceptual high jinks (and jammed debut parties). Of them, he manages the most crossover appeal. While the rubbery sinks and stack of drawers belted together by fellow Droogies haven't spread much beyond avant-garde design magazines, Mr. Wanders's macrame rope chair, stiffened in a dip of epoxy, is already in production at Cappellini, where his seven-foot ''cloud'' lamps made of cotton stretched on wire frames are best-sellers among the loft set.

title: Deal Is Struck On Restoring Medicare Aid
description: Congressional negotiators and Clinton administration officials announced tonight that they had reached a tentative agreement on legislation to restore some of the money cut from Medicare in 1997.

title: For Bush, the News Is Mixed: He's Liked, by People Who Aren't Always Sure Why
description: Derrell Kinley had a good enough feeling about George W. Bush not only to show up for his speech at the civic center in nearby Anderson on Tuesday night but also to stick around another hour just to shake his hand.

title: J. Crew Web Goof Results in Discount
description: Want a cashmere sweater from J. Crew for $18? For several hours this week, J. Crew's Web site, www.jcrew.com, inadvertently listed a $218 cashmere sweater for $18, leading several hundred e-shoppers to quickly add the item to their digital shopping carts in hopes that the pricing glitch would go unnoticed. J. Crew officials soon discovered the mistake on the site and removed the item. But did the sly surfers who ordered the $18 sweater really get away with a $200 discount?

title: Wholesale Grocer Job Cuts
description: The Fleming Companies, the second-largest American grocery wholesaler, plans to cut 194 jobs -- about half of 1 percent of its work force -- as it closes a San Antonio distribution center. A spokeswoman said this week that Fleming, which employs 39,000 people, would eliminate 90 clerical and management positions and 104 production jobs. It will shut the San Antonio center in March after transferring work in January to a larger distribution center in Garland, Tex.

title: Vivid Documents of Human Atrocities
description: THERE is no glitter at www .witness.org. There is death and anguish. Bodies are being stacked like cordwood. Women shriek at the loss of a relative to prison, or to a killing squad. The heavy metal comes in the form of bars and razor wire, and the soundtrack is rock-hard, not hard rock. Come equipped with RealPlayer, QuickTime and a strong stomach.

title: Two Gold Gloves for Mets
description: The cornerstone of the 1999 Mets team was its immaculate infield and yesterday it was duly rewarded with two Gold Gloves, the first time the Mets have received more than one Gold Glove in their 37-year history.

title: Television Bureau Names President
description: Christopher Rohrs has been named president of the Television Bureau of Advertising in New York, a trade organization for local television broadcasters. He succeeds Ave Butensky, 66, who is retiring after eight years as president and will serve as a consultant. Mr. Rohrs, 50, is vice president for sales and marketing at Post-Newsweek Stations in Hartford, part of the Washington Post Company.

title: A Case of Open and Closed
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEITNER, SYLVIA
description: LEITNER-Sylvia (Tzippy). In 1940, I was blessed with a beautiful bride. Children and grandchildren made us thrive, then in 1989 came the accident and you did not survive. In 1999, precious memories are all that remain, like an antidote for the loss and the pain. With Love, Na

title: On the Outside, Looking In: Most Are Stuck In the Slow Lane
description: WHEN it comes to the current availability of bandwidth, there are vastly more have-nots than haves. I should know. Despite seven months of promises, I learned recently that there would be no high-speed digital subscriber line in my home.

title: 5 Passengers Are Slashed On a D Train
description: In what witnesses described as several minutes of pandemonium, a teenager wielding a box cutter terrorized scores of passengers on a Manhattan-bound D train last night, slashing five people before being subdued and beaten by other riders, the authorities said. Three other passengers were injured during the chaos, none seriously.

title: Colts' Bratzke Shedding Overachiever Label
description: The more Chad Bratzke heard the term, the more it began to grate on him.

title: Disney Changes Video Releases
description: The Walt Disney Company, trying to revive its lagging home video sales, said today that it would release all future titles on DVD at the same time as on videocassette and would revamp the schedule for releasing its animated films into video stores. Slower sales in home video have been one factor behind Disney's slump in earnings.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Now I'm going to have to get a broker.''

title: Olympus Focuses On Digital Cameras
description: TOKYO  In a battle for supremacy among some of the world's best-known brands, the slimmest of leads may be enough to propel one company to domination.

title: For the Young And the Hip, And Only On the Web
description: I AM looking over some notes I jotted down the other day while visiting a new Web site called Troublewear.com. ''It's really pimp,'' I wrote. ''This is tite, I'm ready for a killer whack. Click and buy, dude. Just do it.''

title: On Pollution, Bush Ignores Texas Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERSTEIN, IAN JACOB
description: WASSERSTEIN-Ian Jacob. On November 9, 1999 died at home. Lived life as fully as possible with optimism and enthusiasm. Died of cancer, a patient at Memorial Sloan Kettering-Cancer Center, NYC. which was part of his extened family. Son of Sara Frischer and Stephen Wasserstein. Brother of Robby. He opened our eyes to the things before us which we would not have noticed if he weren't there. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to The Aubrey Fund for Pediatric Cancer Research, MSKCC, 633 3rd Ave, NY, NY 10017. The family will be sitting shiva at home for the week.

title: The Grand and the Humble: Behind St. Petersburg Walls
description: ''Everyone harps on about the Romanovs and their palaces, but I wanted to show that the city is much more intriguing than a mere facade for balls and revolutions,'' said Katya Galitzine, the author of ''St. Petersburg: The Hidden Interiors'' (Vendome Press, $50). An English-born descendant of Catherine the Great, Ms. Galitzine first visited in 1985, when it was still Leningrad. Her book -- crammed with surprising room scapes and an informative, anecdotal text -- offers glimpses of the city's glories and privations, from its creation in 1703 by Peter the Great to its successive eras of imperial splendors and dachas (below), industrialization and revolution (bottom, Communist Party Headquarters). CHRISTOPHER MASON

title: Judge Halts Drug Tests of Welfare Applicants
description: A federal judge today temporarily halted Michigan's unusual program to test welfare applicants for drug use.

title: Pokemon Movie vs. School? For Young Fans, That's a No-Brainer
description: Between the mayor and movie executives, why go to school at all?

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Computer Associates to Appeal Ruling on 3 Executives' Stock
description: Computer Associates International said yesterday that it would appeal a judge's ruling that its top three executives must return more than half a billion dollars worth of stock from a large executive payout that infuriated shareholders.

title: U.S. May Bar Illicit Funds In Deposits By Foreigners
description: The Clinton administration, as well as some senators, presented legislation today to make it illegal for American banks to handle the proceeds of official corruption abroad.

title: A French Paradox at Work; 35-Hour Week May Turn Out to Be Best for Employers
description: Last year, the Beyer family, which owns a small jam and fruit preserves plant here near the Swiss border, made a proposal to their 18 employees: Would they like a 35-hour workweek and continue to be paid for working 39 hours?

title: Indonesians Warn Against Aceh Referendum
description: SINGAPORE  Indonesia's two most senior legislative officials joined the military Wednesday in warning President Abdurrahman Wahid that the country will disintegrate if the government fails to defuse separatist demands in the province of Aceh.

title: Death Penalty Is Error-Prone; Cruel and Unusual
description: To the Editor:

title: A Prohibited Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOMNITZ, ERIC
description: LOMNITZ-Eric. On November 9, 1999, at his home in London, England. Beloved husband, devoted father and cherished friend to so many. He will be greatly missed. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St., Friday, November 12, at 11:AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Nets' Game Is Mostly Just Talk
description: The most heated moments of tonight's meeting between the Nets and the Phoenix Suns came after the final buzzer sounded. That's when Penny Hardaway, who led the Suns to a resounding 104-89 victory with 25 points, began mocking the frustrated and furious Stephon Marbury.

title: David Schickele, 62, Filmmaker And, With Brother, a Parodist
description: David Schickele, a film director and musician, died on Oct. 31 at his home in San Francisco. He was 62.

title: NEW VIRUS
description: A new e-mail worm virus is loose, security experts warn, and it can operate without the opening of an attachment. A patch for the new virus, called Bubbleboy, was posted by Network Associates, a computer security company, on Monday (www.networkassociates.com).

title: Clinton Optimistic About Year 2000
description: In his first detailed remarks on the subject since late last year, President Clinton predicted today that the Year 2000 computer problem would not disrupt the federal government or critical companies in the private sector, including those providing most of the nation's financial services, power, phones and transportation.

title: Joseph DiMona, 76, Writer; Co-Author of Haldeman Memoir
description: Joseph DiMona, a professional author and screen and stage writer who collaborated on the Watergate memoir of the imprisoned former White House chief of staff, H. R. Haldeman, died on Saturday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 76.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSIER, JOAN
description: WEINSIER-Joan (nee Tuby). On November 10, 1999. Loving daughter of Evelyn Tuby and the late Dr. Robert Tuby. Beloved wife of Philip. Adored and treasured mother of Michael and Wendy and mother-in-law of Marcy. Cherished grandmother of Matthew. Devoted sister of Suellen Globus and loving aunt to three nieces. Her extraordinary compassion, kindness, honesty, warmth, beauty, style and elegance are her legacy to us all. She will be deeply missed by all whose lives she touched. She graduated from Finch College, enjoyed a successful modelling career and studied drama with Lee Strasberg and Claudia Frank. In later years, she enjoyed a successful career in real estate sales and most recently, art sales. Services will be held at Temple Beth-El, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, New York, Friday, November 12, 1999 at 11 AM. For further information call Schwartz Brothers, 718-263-7600.

title: A Way to Check E-Mail Without Logging On
description: Can't get enough e-mail? Tired of having to fire up the old PC and modem every couple of hours at home just to check for new messages? Notify Technology, based in San Jose, Calif., has developed a device that lets you check for e-mail at a glance, without logging on.

title: Its Initial Run Over, 'View' Hopes to Join List of Operas That Endure
description: ''Good night,'' the bass baritone Timothy Nolen sang at the Civic Opera House here on Friday night, in the melancholy concluding notes of ''A View From the Bridge,'' William Bolcom's operatic adaptation of the Arthur Miller play.

title: Internet Filter Infiltration
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Forget Futuristic Dreams, Think Sweet Love and Peace
description: The reunited Eurythmics performed at Madison Square Garden on Monday night dressed in camouflage outfits, a hint that they were up to something. Ten years after Annie Lennox and Dave Stewart released their last album together as the Eurythmics, they were back not only to introduce a few new songs but also to camouflage their early songs in more recent guise.

title: Picking the Right Data Superhighway
description: THE key to happiness in the Internet age is bandwidth. Bandwidth, bandwidth, bandwidth. Fat pipes, capable of sucking down Web pages, music files, video clips, e-mail and other forms of digital information and entertainment from the Internet in the blink of an eye. A data spigot that is always open, without busy signals and without the kinds of delays and service interruptions that drive most computer users mad.

title: Do You Know Who's Watching You? Do You Care?
description: CALL L. L. Bean, the clothing and outdoor gear company, don't identify yourself in any way, place your order, and see what happens. If you have shopped there before and you're calling from your home telephone number, the folks there know it -- even if you've blocked Caller ID. They know where you live. And they have your credit card number.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Ford Is Getting Its Ducks in a Row for Divestiture of Its Parts Unit
description: Ford Motor recently overcame its most contentious union negotiations in decades by finessing an agreement over the future of workers at its giant auto parts unit.

title: Kitchen Designs Where Nothing Is Wasted
description: There's a fresh slice of modernist history at Bulthaup Kuchensysteme, a new kitchen showroom in SoHo.

title: A Year 2000 Launching?
description: To the Editor:

title: DOWNTIME; Technology Puts the Recording Studio on a Hard Drive
description: LIKE many featherweight chart-toppers of summers past, Ricky Martin's ''Livin' la Vida Loca'' may soon be blown into the remainder bin. But the song is assured of at least a small place in technological history. On May 15, ''Livin' la Vida Loca'' became Billboard's first No. 1 single to have been recorded and mixed entirely using a computer.

title: But Wait! You Mean There's More?
description: TIM SAMUELSON lives the role of the eminent architectural historian he is, in a Mies van der Rohe lake-front apartment embellished with original ornaments by Louis Sullivan and Frank Lloyd Wright.

title: Bush Supports A 2-Year Budget
description: Weighing in on the predictably intense budget battle still under way in Congress, Gov. George W. Bush said today that it was time to change the federal budget process from an annual review to one that occurs every other year, as in Texas.

title: Drug Treating Blood Pressure Cuts Heart Risk
description: A drug that has been marketed for eight years to combat high blood pressure turns out to substantially lower the risk of heart attack, stroke, bypass surgery and diabetes and its complications in those who have heart disease, scientists reported yesterday.

title: A Web Page Kit Full of Tools for Beginners
description: COMPLETE WEB STUDIO 2.0

title: Abortion Discord Holds Up U.N. Dues and U.S. Budget
description: The white-hot domestic issue of abortion is holding up a deal to pay nearly $1 billion the United States owes the United Nations, which in turn is one of the main sticking points blocking a budget agreement between Congress and the White House.

title: Personal Web Art Curator
description: To the Editor:

title: Plot Twist: Me! Me! Me! Meets Girl
description: FOUR years ago, during a pilgrimage to the ''Seinfeld'' set, I sat in the famous coffee shop meditating with Jerry Seinfeld on the mysterious reluctance of New Yorkers to marry. He blamed the temptations of their environment: the endless new possibilities that a single New Yorker passes on the sidewalk every day.

title: Ex-Madam Is Sentenced For Prostitution
description: A woman who admitted she ran a brothel in Morris Township was sentenced to nearly nine months in jail yesterday, after pleading guilty to violating her probation by engaging in prostitution herself at a motel in Hanover.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, SHERWOOD MELVIN
description: WEINER-Sherwood Melvin, 73, died on October 29, 1999 following a long illness in Delray Beach, FL. Mr. Weiner was born in Mount Vernon, NY on October 23, 1926. He was the son of the late Barnett T. Weiner and Anne C. (Birnbaum) Weiner. A private memorial is planned. Donations in Mr. Weiner's name may be made to the Guggenheim Museum in New York City. For information Scobee - Combs - Bowden Funeral Home, Boynton Beach, Florida.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO CURB ISRAELI ARMS SALE TO CHINA AIR FORCE
description: Israel's sale of a sophisticated $250 million airborne radar system to China has raised serious concerns at the Pentagon, and the Clinton administration has quietly urged Israeli officials to cancel delivery of additional radar planes and to curb other weapons sales to the Chinese military, administration and Defense Department officials said today.

title: Allstate Poised to Sell Insurance Over Telephone and Internet
description: In a major shift in sales strategy, the Allstate Corporation said yesterday it would begin selling auto and homeowners' insurance and other coverage over the telephone and the Internet.

title: KOREAN AIR CHAIRMAN TO BE CHARGED
description: South Korean prosecutors said they would seek an arrest warrant for the Korean Air Lines chairman, Cho Yang Ho, on charges of evading taxes and embezzlement. Prosecutors said they had confirmed most allegations levelled against Mr. Cho, including the evasion of 67.3 billion won in taxes and the creation of a 168.5 billion won slush fund. His brother Cho Soo Ho, president of the Hanjin Shipping Company, will be indicted without detention, as will their father, Cho Choong Hoon, Hanjin Group's founder and honorary chairman, prosecutors said.

title: Liwang Journal; There's No Place Like It: The Very Humble Cave
description: Two years ago, Ma Xiuhua's family finally gave up on the parched fields of their poor mountain village and moved to this town to try their hand at buying and selling vegetables. Tired of fighting years of drought, they said goodbye to the small mud-brick house -- home to Ms. Ma, her husband, their two children and her in-laws -- and set out to find an in-town apartment to rent.

title: In Wartime Letters Home, Eloquence of Common Men
description: At first, they poured into the Post Office at a rate of about 1,000 a day, as if they were patriots rushing to answer a call to arms. Letters from the front, letters from home, they had been written in wartime and had survived in attics and at the bottom of drawers, the buried testimony of men and women who had known war too well. Now veterans were mailing them in; wives, children and descendants of soldiers and sailors were mailing them in. They were becoming a great massing of American voices of war, arriving from all directions, rising out of the past.

title: Safety Issue Is Stressed By Cabbies in Bias Effort
description: The city's move to punish cabdrivers who bypass minority passengers poses an ethical quandary perhaps best described yesterday by Paul Frietz, a native of Haiti who has been driving New York City taxis for 15 years. He recalled being robbed, assaulted and having his hand broken in 1997 by two passengers, both young black men.

title: Clinton Plans a Kosovo Visit, And the Serbs Are Surprised
description: President Clinton may add a brief stop in Kosovo to his trip this month through southern Europe to highlight the importance of the peacekeeping mission there and to address tensions between Serbs and Albanians, administration officials said today.

title: The Web Without Microsoft
description: OCCASIONALLY a new product can be annoying and delightful at the same time. Rarely, however, does a delightful product become annoying without any help whatsoever from the Microsoft Corporation, the notorious monopolist.

title: XL CAPITAL SAYS IT WON'T MAKE A NEW OFFER FOR CAPITAL RE
description: XL Capital Ltd. said yesterday that it would not make a counteroffer for the Capital Re Corporation, the bond insurer, to top a $511 million cash and stock bid from Ace Ltd. XL Capital gave no reason for its decision to withdraw from the bidding that it began early last month with an unsolicited offer for Capital Re, which had agreed in May to merge with Ace in an all-stock transaction. XL Capital and Ace, both based in Hamilton, Bermuda, viewed the purchase of Capital Re, which is based in New York, as a way to expand into bond insurance and other financial guaranties. The competition for Capital Re began after Ace's shares lost about half of their value in the four months after the Ace-Capital Re merger plan was announced.

title: Millennial High Notes
description: To the Editor:

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HARRIS, SYLVIA BAKER
description: HARRIS-Sylvia Baker. May 15, 1906 to November 11, 1966. Dearest loving wife of Joseph, dearest loving mother of J. Robert and James B., dearest loving grandmother and great-grandmother. God bless you, Mom. You're the greatest ever. We all dearly love you and miss you so very much. All our love forever. Your loving and devoted sons, Bob and Jim

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONSON, RUDOLPH
description: ARONSON-Rudolph. On Nov. 9, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Julia. Devoted father of Raymond and father-in-law of Linda. Cherished grandfather of Philip and Deborah, Deborah, Suzanne and Sarah. Dearest great-grandfather of Ethan and Julia. Rudolph was a graduate of the Cooper Union, Class of '29 of which he remained an active alumnus. He was also a founder, director, officer and shareholder of Walter Balfour and Co., Inc. and an original member of the Hollis Hills Jewish Center. Services Thursday, 9:30 AM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York. Interment at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the Cooper Union, 30 Cooper Square, 8th Floor, New York City 10003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, LILLIAN
description: BLUM-Lillian, on October 25, 1999, beloved wife of Louis D. Blum, cherished sister of Belle Grohs, and devoted mother to Elizabeth, Margaret, and Charles Busch. Both fragile and indomitable, she was the port in the storm for everyone she loved. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Planned Parenthood Federation of America, Development Dept., 810 Seventh Ave., NY, NY 10019.

title: F.B.I. Said Freeing Prisoner Would Aid Arab Status
description: A newly declassified court document shows the F.B.I. argued against freeing an Egyptian man who has been jailed for more than three years on secret evidence because it would improve his credibility among Arabs and people ''would be more inclined to listen to him.''

title: NORTEL TO CUT AS MANY AS 1,000 JOBS NEXT YEAR
description: The Nortel Networks Corporation, North America's No. 2 phone-equipment maker after Cisco Systems Inc., will cut as many as 1,000 jobs, or about 1.5 percent of its work force, next year to reduce overlap and contract out more business, its chief executive, John Roth, said. The reductions will be made largely in administrative positions like payroll and information systems. By the end of the year Nortel plans to provide details on some of the cuts, which add to 11,500 other cuts announced in the last 14 months. Nortel is looking for ways to improve profitability as it faces competition on equipment prices from Lucent Technologies and Cisco. On Tuesday, it slashed prices on routers to half that of comparable products from Cisco.

title: DECLINE AT CABLE AND WIRELESS
description: Increased spending to upgrade its networks and more competition in Hong Kong contributed to a 42 percent drop in first-half profit for Cable and Wireless P.L.C., a British telecommunications company with interests around the world. Net income fell to 205 million [pounds), or $332.6 million, from 356 million [pounds] a year earlier. Cable and Wireless is transforming itself, focusing on business and data markets and shifting from its former consumer businesses.

title: BEA SYSTEMS TO BUY THEORY CENTER FOR $100 MILLION
description: BEA Systems Inc., the largest developer of so-called middleware software, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Theory Center of Boston for $100 million in stock and cash. It will absorb Theory Center's 42 employees. BEA Systems, which is based in San Jose, Calif., said the acquisition would help it create e-commerce software to help its customers conduct business over the Internet. It said the move complemented its acquisition last year of the closely held Web Logic Inc. BEA Systems shares rose $4.875, to $66.25. The news was announced after the close of United States markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTZLINE, WALTER F.
description: PORTZLINE-Walter F. On November 8, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Muriel. Devoted father of Thomas Portzline, M.D. Loving brother of Ralph, Donelle and Jack. Fond father-in-Law of Mary Beaudet. Friends may call on Wednesday 7-9:30 PM & Thursday 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Avenue, Floral Park, NY (At R.R. Plaza). Funeral, Friday 9:30 AM. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the National Audubon Society would be appreciated.

title: Veterans Day
description: NEW YORK

title: KOREAN SALES DROP
description: Sales at South Korea's top manufacturing companies fell 3.4 percent from a year earlier during the first half of this year, the Bank of Korea said, the first decline since the central bank began preparing the report in 1970. The bank attributed the slide to a drop in the dollar versus the won, as well as a fall in export prices. First-half exports at the companies declined 18.7 percent, while domestic sales rose 9.4 percent.

title: A Humane Burial
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONAS, PAULINE
description: MONAS - Pauline Levy. The trustees and staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services mourn the passing of Pauline Levy Monas, the beloved mother of Martin Monas, the JBFCS board member whose generosity established Levy-Monas House on Long Island. Mrs. Monas played a role in creating and supporting Levy-Monas House, an adolescent-group home named for her parents and in-laws. She also created the tradition of philanthropy carried on by her son and other members of her family. Funeral services for Mrs. Monas will be held Thursday, November 11, at noon at the Norman L. Jeffer Community Chapel, 4620 Fort Hamilton Parkway in Brooklyn. The family will sit shiva at the home of Martin Monas in Manhattan. We express our deepest sympathy to her son, Martin; her daughter, Barbara Herman; her sisters, Frieda Spiegel and Edna Ginsberg; her brother, Abe Levy; her grandchildren, Shari and Lowell Frey and Barry Herman; and her great-grandchildren, Allison and Sam Frey. Joseph S. Kaplan, President Seymour R. Askin, Jr., Chairman of the Board Alan B. Siskind, Ph.D, Executive Vice President Paul Levine, CSW, Associate Executive Vice President Rosemary Sanchez, Director, Levy-Monas House

title: They Terrorized Haiti: Will the U.S. Act?
description: To the Editor:

title: Online Journalists Keep Their Eyes on Daily Numbers
description: OLD-media journalists measure their mettle in scoops and Pulitzers. New-media reporters and editors have another gauge of success or failure: hits.

title: Death Penalty Is Error-Prone
description: To the Editor:

title: On Israel Trip, Mrs. Clinton Talks Youth, Not Politics
description: It looked like an expertly managed election campaign. Hillary Rodham Clinton swept through Israel today, shaking hands, embracing children and posing cooperatively for the mob of photographers who dogged her every step.

title: STRONG DEMAND FOR THUS
description: The telephone division of Scottish Power, Thus P.L.C., raised up to $1.8 billion in an initial public offering of 303.6 million shares priced at 310 pence. The company said the demand from fund managers and employees was nine times the shares offered, and shares rose by as much as 25 percent before settling back to 335 pence.

title: AVID TECHNOLOGY TO CUT 200 JOBS FOR $20 MILLION A YEAR
description: Avid Technology Inc. said yesterday that it would eliminate 200 jobs, or 11 percent of its work force, in a cutback intended to save the software company $20 million a year. The cuts will primarily involve workers at company headquarters in Tewksbury, Mass., and sales and marketing staff in the United States and Europe. Avid Technology said it expected to record a charge of $9 million to $10 million in the fourth quarter. Three weeks ago, its chairman and chief executive, William J. Miller, and its president and chief operating officer, Clifford A. Jenks, resigned. Successors have not been named. Avid Technology provides digital video and audio tools for information and entertainment applications.

title: Art and Antiques Shows
description: Folk Art as Reflection

title: A Brooklyn Headmistress, 53, Admits Selling Cocaine at School
description: Delores Hill ran an acclaimed private school in Brooklyn that gave working class families an alternative to poorly performing public schools. She operated a soup kitchen at the school, and she spoke out about the danger of drugs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNETTE, GEORGE
description: BENNETTE-George. The Board and staff of Lighthouse International are saddened by the death of George Bennette. During his 32 years at the Lighthouse he served as Director of the Lighthouse Music School and retired in 1989. His accomplishments left a lasting impact on the Music School and its past and present students. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Shirley, and other members of his family. William B. Follett, Chairman, Board of Directors Barbara Silverstone, President & CEO

title: Queens Woman Found Dead In Her Ransacked Apartment
description: A Queens woman who was known as a neighborhood activist and who served as a poll watcher in last week's election was found dead Tuesday night under a pile of bloody clothing in her ransacked apartment, her throat slashed and two stab wounds in her back, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TELFER, WINIFRED
description: TELFER-Winifred. The Board of Trustees of the Reece School express their heartfelt sympathy to fellow board member Dean Telfer on the death of his beloved mother Winifred Telfer. We extend our condolences to the entire Telfer family.

title: China and U.S. Resume Talks On Trade in a Hopeful Spirit
description: With both sides expressing cautious hope, senior American and Chinese trade officials met today in renewed negotiations over China's entry into the World Trade Organization.

title: Name That Chief: Gore Loses Round
description: Whoops. Vice President Al Gore had a good laugh on Tuesday, making fun of Gov. George W. Bush's unfamiliarity with various world leaders. But it turns out that Mr. Gore was not totally up to the minute himself on foreign affairs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMABILE, ALIDA MARIA
description: AMABILE-Alida Maria, 48, of Santa Monica, CA. November 8, 1999. Beloved sister of Maryellen and husband John D. Ryan, cherished aunt of Christine Marie and Andrew John Ryan. She was predeceased by her parents Arthur V. and Marie L. Amabile. Resting, Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY where family will receive friends Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 11 A.M., Holy Innocents Church. Entombment Ferncliff Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, JUDITH A.
description: SULLIVAN-Judith A. Of Ancramdale, NY on November 8. Artist, teacher, contractor, visionary and adored friend of many worldwide, Judy wanted to use her experience as a Peace Corps volunteer in Bulgaria to help build international business partnership. Visitation at home today from 4-8 PM, Gathering Friday at 10:30 AM. For information contact Peck & Peck Funeral Home at 518-329-2121.

title: Political Briefing; Republican Voters Cringe at Choice
description: Last week's mayoral election in San Francisco left Republicans in a political quandary.

title: 19th Century Gets Back At an American Nemesis
description: The Oslo Philharmonic saved its best for first at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night. One had the impression, valid or not, that this attractive orchestra from Norway had stored up its energy for a week and let it all out in one burst of excitement. The piece was Verdi's Overture to ''I Vespri Siciliani''; its broad, distinct outlines made a perfect advertisement for the orchestra's best qualities: namely, a dark, true string sound, an excellent brass section and meticulous preparation by its music director, Mariss Jansons. Mr. Jansons tends toward micromanagement, but the controls imposed on phrase, pause and accent made sense. Even if they hadn't, the sheer exuberance of his players in the Verdi piece would have overridden excessive dwelling on detail.

title: On Pollution, Bush Ignores Texas Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: Trustees Vote Not to Raise SUNY Tuition
description: The trustees of the State University of New York said yesterday that they planned to freeze tuition next year, despite a deficit of about $77 million at its three teaching hospitals.

title: Denver Papers Log Big Gains In Circulation
description: A bitter newspaper war in Denver, with penny-a-day special offers, generated startling circulation gains in the last six months. The Denver Rocky Mountain News recorded a 19.3 percent gain, and its total daily circulation of 396,114 vaulted it ahead of its archrival, The Denver Post, which reported a daily circulation of 376,549, an increase of 10.4 percent.

title: MATSUSHITA TO COMBINE UNITS
description: The world's largest consumer electronics maker, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, plans to meld the broadcasting systems businesses of its companies as part of a push to become the biggest maker of broadcast equipment by 2003. Matsushita and its cellular phone subsidiary will merge their broadcast businesses in April to cut costs and improve sales. If Matsushita succeeds, it would unseat Sony as the biggest seller of broadcast equipment. Stephanie Strom

title: Accounts
description: * Concentric Network Corp., San Jose, Calif., a provider of electronic- commerce services, to Gardner, Geary, Coll & Young Advertising, San Francisco, to handle its account, which had been handled on a project basis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLEMAN, JEANNE
description: ADLEMAN-Jeanne. In San Francisco, on November 6, after a long illness. Therapist, Author, Educator, and Feminist and Anti-Racist Activist. Survived by her loving children, Martha and Donald Mahoney of Miami, Stepdaughters, Judith Mahoney Pasternak of New York and Joan Mahoney of Detroit, and thirteen grandchildren and step-grandchildren. No flowers, please (for health reasons); donations may be made in Jeanne's memory to either Gay and Lesbian Outreach to Elders in San Francisco or The San Francisco Women's Building.

title: '50 Attack in Korea Remembered
description: In a solemn encounter, three United States Army veterans and four South Korean civilians who stood at opposite ends of a chaotic incident half a century ago met here today to pray in a service of remembrance of that event, which the Koreans described as a massacre by American forces.

title: Grief for 19 Bonds Uruguay, Muting an Election's Clamor
description: With just over two weeks to go before Uruguayans choose their next president, what had been a lively campaign suddenly turned funereal when a bus plunged off a bridge.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: Traveler, 29, Is Charged in Fight That Broke Airline Clerk's Neck
description: A Virginia man accused in an attack at Newark International Airport that left a ticket agent with a broken neck was indicted yesterday on charges of aggravated assault.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, LAUSON HARVEY
description: STONE-Lauson Harvey. Beloved husband of Jane Hunter Stone, loving father of Harlan Fiske Stone II, and Peter Hunter Stone. Loving father-in-law of Helen Galatan Stone and Paola Malanotte Stone. Devoted grandfather of Christopher Harlan Stone and Emily Palmer Stone. Family will receive friends Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9 at Jere J. Cronin Funeral Home, 115 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn Heights, New York.

title: Political Briefing; 'Jaded' Old Firebrand Will Take a Breather
description: Another of California's voluble, seemingly unsinkable liberals, Tom Hayden, is withdrawing from the political fray.

title: Long Ago, Modern Actually Meant New
description: November is the month to set clocks back -- to about 1950. The annual MODERNISM -- fair runs through Sunday at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street; $12, (212) 777-5218 (above left, 1904 table). The TRIPLE PIER EXPO -- is Nov. 13, 14, 20 and 21 at 12th Avenue from 48th to 55th Streets (Pier 88 for Modernism); $12 for one day, $14 for two, (212) 255-0020. The 20TH-CENTURY ART AND DESIGN AUCTION -- at William Doyle Galleries is next Wednesday at 10 a.m.; 175 East 87th Street, (212) 427-2730 (below, Lea Halpern pottery). The same day, the 20TH-CENTURY DESIGN AUCTION -- at Tepper Galleries starts at 2 p.m; 110 East 25th Street, (212) 677-5300. The 20TH-CENTURY MODERN AUCTION -- at David Rago Auctions, is next weekend at 333 North Main Street, Lambertville, N.J.; (609) 397-9374 or www.amazon.livebid.com. An INTERNATIONAL 20TH-CENTURY ARTS FAIR -- will be at Seventh Regiment Armory Nov. 27 to Dec. 1; (212) 642-8572 (top, Italian lamp). Christie's East's IMPORTANT 20TH-CENTURY DESIGN AUCTION -- is Nov. 27 at 10 a.m.; 219 East 67th Street, (212) 606-0400. WILLIAM L. HAMILTON

title: Treason Charge For Pakistan's Ousted Premier
description: Almost a month after he was ousted from power in a swift bloodless coup, Pakistan's deposed prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, has been accused of hijacking and kidnapping for what military officials say was his treasonous refusal to allow a plane carrying the army chief to land at an airport in the port city of Karachi.

title: 'Modernism' Pieces to Be Sold Online
description: FOR collectors who are yearning for a 1920's Jean Dunand bronze bowl or a 1930's French lacquered desk lamp but who can't get to the ''Modernism'' show, which opens today at the Seventh Regiment Armory, pieces from the show will be auctioned on the Web at www.icon20 .com. The auction began yesterday and will end on Sunday at 3 p.m.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, LAUSON
description: STONE-Lauson. The entire Long Island College Hospital family mourns the passing of Lauson Stone, our esteemed friend, colleague and benefactor. Mr. Stone was a member of the LICH Board of Regents for over 30 years, serving as Co-Chair of the Board of Regents Nominating Committee, as well as serving as a Vice President for Legal Affairs. He was also a generous supporter of the hospital, whose contributions helped expand and improved patient care services. In recognition of his philanthropic commitment to LICH, the Amity Street entrance to the hospital is named in his honor. His support and friendship will always be remembered. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family and all who loved him. John Wren, Chairman Board of Regents Allan Gibofsky, MD, JD President & CEO Jagdish Gupta, MD, President, Medical Board

title: Vick Has Hokies No. 1 in Highlights
description: Like most 14-year-olds aspiring to be college football stars, Michael Vick thought ''big time'' meant Florida State, Penn State or Notre Dame. So one afternoon, sunk into his couch and racing through television channels with the remote control, he barely paused when he came across the maroon-and-white uniforms of a team called the Hokies.

title: Car-Bomb Killing in Turkey Revives Battle Over Islamic Politics
description: The assassination of a leading secularist intellectual has revived the battle over Islamic politics that has polarized Turkey over the last few years.

title: Home Leave for Y2K
description: Traveling around the world as an employee of the State Department has an adventurous sound to it -- the intrepid American facing daunting challenges abroad. That is why the news about Y2K furloughs from our embassies in the former Soviet Union sounds like such a faint-hearted idea. At American outposts in Russia, Ukraine, Belarus and Moldova, non-essential employees have been told that they can go to Washington over the New Year's holidays if they are nervous about what mischief foreign computers will cause as their time mechanisms shift from 1999 to the year 2000. The cost of sending American employees to the nation's capital on Y2K leave, according to estimates given to Michael Gordon of The Times, ranges from $1.25 million to $8 million, depending on how many of the 800 authorized to go actually decide to take advantage of the offer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRISTENSEN, RONALD JULIUS
description: CHRISTENSEN-Ronald Julius, a celebrated artist and member of the National Arts Club, New York City, died in Naples, Florida, on November 5, 1999. He was 76. During his career, Mr. Christensen had 75 one-man exhibitions. His work is included in many museums and hundreds of private collections. Donations in his memory may be made to the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South, New York, NY 10003.

title: Political Briefing; A Reluctant Kennedy Turns Back on Suitors
description: Given the opportunity, Kennedys usually jump into a political contest.

title: FLIGHT RECORDER SAID TO INDICATE CONTROL AT FIRST
description: The first unusual event in the flight of EgyptAir 990 on Oct. 31 was the autopilot's disconnecting and then, about eight seconds later, what appeared at first to be ''a controlled descent'' that was smooth and straight, investigators at the National Transportation Safety Board said this evening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELDIN, BENJAMIN
description: ZELDIN-Benjamin. Of Great Neck, L.I. Died November 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Beverly. Devoted father of Michael, Randy and Andrew, and father-in-law of Amy, Zehava and Robin. Cherished grandfather of Rebecca, Alexander, Natalie, Jordan, Evan and Steven. Loving brother of Beatrice Felsenfeld. Service Thursday, at 1 PM at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Technology Shares Resume Surge as Demand for New Issues Offsets Inflation Report
description: Stocks resumed a mostly upward course yesterday as enthusiasm for technology issues overcame some early nervousness about the government's latest figures on inflation.

title: Florida Governor Offers Plan for Diversity
description: Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, in a move that could head off a possible statewide vote on whether to ban affirmative action, has offered his own plan to change race-based college admissions and stop minority set-asides in state contracts.

title: Cabbies Who Bypass Blacks Will Lose Cars, Giuliani Says
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced an undercover sting operation yesterday that will take away the cabs of drivers who refuse to pick up minority passengers. His decision came less than a week after the actor Danny Glover complained that several New York taxi drivers had refused to pick him up because he is black.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Share the Wealth
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOBBS, ED
description: HOBBS-Ed. New York City and Haworth NJ. Leigh and Charles Merinoff and their children Leslie and Andrew are deeply saddened by the loss of their dear friend, Ed Hobbs. We remember him with affection. Our love & our prayers are with Diane & her son Andrew during this difficult time.

title: OIL DEAL CANCELED FOR LACK OF FINANCING
description: Tuboscope Inc., an oil field services company in Houston, said yesterday that it had canceled its agreement to buy Newpark Resources Inc., which disposes of oil field waste, after difficulties in obtaining financing. Tuboscope, which removes waste from fluids used in drilling, said in June that it would buy Newpark for stock then worth $638 million. The companies plan to continue to work together through an alliance, and Tuboscope agreed to buy the assets of Newpark's business that removes waste from oil field fluids. Tuboscope shares rose $1.1875, to $13.875. Newpark, which is based in Metairie, La., rose 18.75 cents, to $5.4375.

title: Police Trial Opens for Officer Who Shot Squeegee Man
description: In a case that focuses attention on how the New York Police Department disciplines its members, a police officer who shot an unarmed squeegee man went on trial yesterday in a disciplinary proceeding that will determine whether he keeps his job.

title: The Songs Must Go On, A Recitalist Determines
description: A musical performer has to be, among many other things, a trouper, a lesson that Stephen Salters, a young baritone, has evidently learned early and well. At the end of his recital on Monday evening at Alice Tully Hall, presented by the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation, Mr. Salters, speaking from the stage, noted in passing that he was fighting a cold.

title: Picasso Tops Himself, Dominating Sotheby's Sale
description: In what became a one-painting sale last night at Sotheby's, Picasso's ''Seated Woman in a Garden'' sold for $49.5 million, the second highest price ever paid for a Picasso.

title: In Westchester, 1.7 Percent Tax Cut Is Proposed
description: The Westchester County executive, Andrew J. Spano, proposed a $1.16 billion budget today that includes the largest tax decrease -- 1.7 percent -- proposed in 25 years.

title: CD-ROM Drive Maker Strives for a Quick Burn
description: One of the hottest must-have devices turning up in personal computers is the recordable CD drive, or in the parlance of PC mavens, a CD burner.

title: Uncloistering the Tapestry
description: Tired of unicorns, but love the feel of tapestry? Here is good news: Sally Sirkin Lewis, president of J. Robert Scott, has designed seven new tapestry-weave fabrics whose patterns are reminiscent of the 1950's instead of the Middle Ages. ''Skating'' (above) suggests random lines, loops and curves made on the ice by figure skaters. The palette includes red, green, yellow, black, tan or ivory; $120 a yard at J. Robert Scott (to the trade), 979 Third Avenue (58th Street); (877) 207-5130. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZONINO, JAMES DAY
description: ZONINO-James Day. Of Tarrytown, NY on November 9, 1999. Husband of Carolyn and father & father-in-law of Lisa Day Zonino and William Woodworth, Carolyn Ann Zonino and Jennette Zonino. Visiting Friday 2-4 and 7-9PM at Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford (Saw Mill exit 17), Dobbs Ferry, New York. Funeral 11:30AM, Saturday at the Scarborough Presbyterian Church, Route 9, Scarborough, NY. Memorials to the Phelps Hospice or Memorial Sloan-Kettering preferred.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARCH, SEYMOUR
description: KARCH-Seymour. Of Lauderhill, FL. (formerly Englewood Cliffs, NJ). Beloved husband of the late Beatrice. Devoted father of Roy Karch, Randi (Michael) Subarsky. Loving grandfather of Zachary and Molly. Services ''Wien & Wien'', Hackensack, New Jersey, Thursday, 1:30PM (1-800-378-1892). We will love you forever.

title: Fox and NBC Acquire the Rights to Nascar's Races
description: Nascar's television landscape flip-flopped yesterday when the stock car racing organization sold six-year packages of broadcast and cable rights worth $400 million a year to Fox, NBC and their cable partners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORSON, CLIFFORD ROY
description: DORSON-Clifford Roy, on November 4, 1999. Beloved son of Marianna Dorson Reid and Edward Dorson, cherished brother of Edward, William and Corey Dorson. Memorial services at Marble Collegiate Church, 3 West 29 St., 3:30PM Monday, Nov. 15. In lieu of flowers, a donation to NAMIFACT, 632 Broadway, Suite 302, NYC 10012, would be appreciated.

title: Pen Pen, That Big Rock Candy Video Game
description: REMEMBER Candyland? First published by Milton Bradley in 1949, Candyland is a board game in which players race through a psychedelic landscape filled with gumdrop mountains, gingerbread houses and other illustrated bonbons. For anyone under 10, Candyland is more than a mere rainy day pastime. It is the sugar-coated paradise where you would live if such a thing were possible. It is a visual proxy for heaven.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAKSYMOWICZ, ZENON
description: MAKSYMOWICZ-Zenon. Age 87 on June 13, 1999 in Brooklyn. In WW II fought with Polish 13th Horse Artillery Regiment; wounded in action; captured at last battle of 1939 campaign at Kock. Remained a POW in Germany until end of war. May he rest in peace.

title: Batch Grocery Orders Online
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, RICHARD
description: MARTIN-Richard. The Docents of the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum want to express our deep sadness at the enormous loss of our curator. He gave unstintingly of his knowledge, time and humor to prepare us for our tours. We will miss him.

title: Why Editors Become Agents
description: Does the world really need another literary agent? Well, ready or not, here they come, tumbling out of publishing houses into author representation like loose change from a torn pocket. There is, it would seem, an immense difference between saying yes or no to a book proposal and hearing that yes or no. Nonetheless the move from editor or publishing executive to agent is almost becoming a trend. Or so it appears.

title: TV's New Odd Couple: A Bachelor and His Stylish Pad
description: IT'S a man's, man's, man's, man's world of interiors.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Climbing prices for heating oil and gasoline caused by shrinking inventories pulled crude oil prices higher. In New York, crude oil for December delivery rose 44 cents, or 1.8 percent, to $24.47 a barrel.

title: Working With Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: Detectives Arrest Suspect In Nine-Year-Old Murder
description: Detectives have arrested a suspect in the nine-year-old murder of a Manhattan building superintendent, police officials said yesterday.

title: Asian Telecommunications Venture Formed
description: Hong Kong's main telephone company, Cable and Wireless HKT, and Asia's leading satellite-television company, Star TV, said today they would form a company to deliver entertainment and information services to subscribers in Hong Kong and elsewhere in Asia.

title: Security Fears Rise at Clinics For Abortions In Canada
description: This is the season when doctors who perform abortions consider going on vacation.

title: Mahathir Calls Early Election In Malaysia
description: SINGAPORE  Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad of Malaysia called early general elections Wednesday, saying that his governing coalition was "very confident" it would retain its two-thirds majority in Parliament.

title: Saying Goodbye To the Monthly Heap
description: MAGAZINES, too good to toss but not good enough to keep forever, often end up in their own never-never land, stacked under a coffee table or beside a couch. The solution is to think big, think modular and think about more than one rack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RINDNER, ADELE
description: RINDNER-Adele. Peacefully and with dignity on November 10, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Devoted mother of Sandy, Lenore Heller, Michele Barer, Barbara Glassman and Robin Tedesco. Loving mother-in-law of Peter and Harvey. Cherished grandmother of Susan, Josh, Jeffrey, Sarah and Michael. Graveside services will be held Friday 11am at Wellwood cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. Donations can be made to The Girl Scouts of America.

title: Sports of The Times; N.H.L. Offers A World Beat On Skates
description: THE collision knocked the helmet off Scott Gomez's head, but it could not remove the smile from his face. It was initiated by Ulf Samuelsson, Philadelphia's veteran ruffian from Sweden. As he checked the Devil rookie Tuesday night, Samuelsson's stick gave Gomez a big welt over his left eye. While Gomez replaced his headgear and cleared his thought process, experienced teammates gave him sympathetic pats on the back.

title: A Cloak for Shoppers' Web Dollars
description: DAVID CHAUM is at it again. Mr. Chaum, a master cryptographer who made his name creating techniques for preserving a person's anonymity on the Net, is now developing a new generation of tools for protecting the privacy of online shoppers.

title: Tired of being a villain, Philip Morris works on its image.
description: A GIANT marketer is seeking to ingratiate itself with consumers at a time when its principal product is being excoriated more relentlessly than ever.

title: A Scanner's Color Depth
description: Q. I want to buy a scanner but don't understand all of that 24-bit and 36-bit color business that's always mentioned in scanner advertisements. What does it mean?

title: Teenager To Spend Life in Prison For Shootings
description: Seventeen-year-old Kip Kinkel was sentenced to spend the rest of his life in prison today, shortly after the Oregon teenager read an apology for the shooting rampage he went on last year that left his parents and two fellow high school students dead and nearly two dozen people injured.

title: Workers Ready to Cash In as U.P.S. Goes Public
description: It has been in business for 92 years and delivers more than 12 million packages each business day, but until yesterday nobody really knew what United Parcel Service was worth.

title: Lester Bowie Is Dead at 58; Innovative Jazz Trumpeter
description: The trumpeter, band leader and composer Lester Bowie, an icon of the experimental movement in jazz from the mid-1960's on who was also known for his comic shows and jazz-based treatments of pop music, died on Monday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 58.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, SANDOR B.
description: ROSENBERG-Sandor B. of Tenafly, NJ on November 9, 1999. Devoted and beloved husband of Shelly. Father of Allison, Andrew and Melissa. Brother of Paul. Senior partner of Rosenberg & Coder, LLP. He lived life to the fullest until the very end. We all love you and miss you more than you will ever know. Thanks for the memories. Services today at ''Gutterman-Musicant'', Hackensack, NJ, 12 noon. Should friends desire, contributions to the American Cancer Society would be appreciated. For information call the funeral home 1-800-522-0588.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the Microsoft Corporation antitrust trial referred incorrectly in some copies to the state for which James E. Doyle is attorney general. It is Wisconsin, not Illinois.

title: Treasuries Fall After Release of Price Report
description: Treasury prices fell yesterday for the second consecutive day after a report showed that the core rate of producer prices in October rose more than expected. The strong data raised speculation again that the Federal Reserve would increase short-term interest rates to keep inflation from accelerating.

title: Much Ado About Nothing, Part II, on Stage?
description: To be drawn to the Evander Holyfield-Lennox Lewis fight for the undisputed heavyweight championship at the Thomas & Mack Arena on Saturday night, boxing fans must have a short memory and deep pockets.

title: Between the Cackles, Alienation and Apocalypse
description: Mr. Bungle's music comes straight from the head. It's about dexterity and juxtaposition: setting up collisions among various styles and keeping track of the resulting debris. ''Truth is a ruin,'' Mike Patton sang when Mr. Bungle performed at Irving Plaza on Monday night. In its two sets, Mr. Bungle dipped into rockabilly, thrash, bossa nova, heavy-metal pomp, jazz, klezmer, delicate Beach Boys pop and improvised clangor, for starters. Mr. Patton, formerly of Faith No More, seems determined to use every one of his vocal styles -- croons, howls, sneers, operatic melodrama, punk-rock barking -- and to challenge the idea that any one of them should pass for sincere.

title: NEWBRIDGE REVISES TERMS OF STANFORD TELECOM DEAL
description: The Newbridge Networks Corporation, the Canadian phone-equipment maker, revised its agreement to buy Stanford Telecommunications Inc. after a drop in its share price caused the original bid to fall through. Newbridge, which is based in Ottawa, will now pay $34.22 a share in cash for Stanford, in Sunnyvale, Calif. It offered to pay as much as $490 million in stock when the agreement was announced on June 22, but its shares have fallen 33 percent since then. Newbridge is struggling to increase sales in the face of competition from Lucent Technologies. Stanford would give the company the radio technology it needs to make wireless equipment, a business Newbridge hopes will generate $1 billion in sales in the next three years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETRAKOS, RUTH BARNETT
description: PETRAKOS-Ruth Barnett. Loving mother of Marina Joy and Avra Petrakos. Devoted daughter of Louis M. Barnett; dear sister of Barbara J. Barnett. A Graveside service 2 PM, Friday, at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, N.Y.

title: A Global Gallery Shows Reflections In a Roving Eye
description: Mary Vinson scours the world for fabrics and other treasures for her Royal Hut line of home furnishings. Her sophisticated offerings include throw pillows (inset, $168 to $290) covered in brilliantly hued wools and silks from places like Madagascar, Niger and India; she has them made in a New York workshop that will also make custom lamp shades. Colorful wastebaskets (left, $78), woven for her in Zimbabwe, are made of telephone wire in a choice of six colors. She also has a line of luxurious silk ikat and Indian gauze bedcoverings, hand-painted dinnerware and a hand-carved four-poster bed from the West Indies. By appointment, at 401 Lafayette Street (Fourth Street); (877) 684-6766. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARRUTHERS, TONY
description: CARRUTHERS - Tony, artist, teacher, bon vivant. On October 19, 1999. Much loved by friends, colleagues, collaborators and extended family, Tony is survived by his cat Wenckebach and countless absurd and inspirational moments. He taught and worked in the USA, England and Europe; most recently at Bennington College in Vermont, where he was in midst of a multimedia course on the social physicalization of death. A memento mori with photos, drawings and videotapes will be open on Friday evening November 12 thru Sunday, November 14th at 537 Broadway in Manhattan, and a celebration of his life and work will be held in Bennington, Vermont on December 11th, 1999. More information on these events is available at (212) 539-3537. His own bio is perhaps his best epitaph-Tony Carruthers: Once worked in a brewery. He makes video; designs performances and watches TV, but he also watches the light outside his windows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, LAURA
description: WEISS-Laura. On November 9, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Dr. David Weiss. Loving mother of Drs. Robert and Michael Weiss. Cherished grandmother of Dr. Edward, Andrea, Erik, and Dana Weiss. Services Thursday, 11:30AM, at ''Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel,'' 114-03 Queens Blvd at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Killer of New Jersey Officers Faces at Least 4 1/2 More Years
description: A 61-year-old convict imprisoned for nearly 36 years for the 1963 murders of two police officers in Lodi, N.J., must serve at least another 4 1/2 years, the state parole board ruled today.

title: Nassau Leader Vetoes a Few Budget Items; Legislators Won't Try to Override
description: The Nassau County executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, vetoed several changes today that the Republican-controlled County Legislature had made in the $2.2 billion budget he submitted a month ago. He also modified several proposals the legislators had passed, but the legislative leaders seemed willing to go along with the requests.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Speaking to the Blind
description: To the Editor:

title: Snippets to Remember: The Fall of the Wall
description: Here's something the Internet didn't have a role in: the fall of the Berlin Wall. But making up for lost time, the Web has an abundance of sites that pay homage to the event, which occurred 10 years ago this week.

title: Death Penalty Is Error-Prone; Chair as Reminder
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Retailers Post Increases In Earnings
description: Kmart and Federated Department Stores said yesterday that third-quarter profits rose as high consumer confidence and low unemployment helped increase sales, led by clothing and housewares.

title: GARDEN Q. & A.
description: Passionflowers: What Now?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZ, MARJORIE
description: SCHWARZ-Marjorie, 86, died peacefully on November 9, at her home in San Francisco. Beloved sister of Barbara French, Eleanor Stock and Dorothy Hines. She was also a cherished aunt and great aunt and will be sorely missed. Any contributions in her memory can be made to Audubon Canyon Ranch, Stinson Beach, CA 94970.

title: Man Indicted in Dumping Of Oil-Tainted Water
description: A Bronx man was indicted in New Jersey yesterday on charges he dumped 5,700 gallons of water tainted with oil from a Jersey City truck repair shop into the Hackensack River.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HAGER, CHUCK
description: HAGER-Chuck. I miss you and will gladly meet you in this new life with our new identities. Carol

title: In a Favorite Hand, Beating An 11-Card Trump Holding
description: If you were to interview 26 of the world's best players, including veterans who have won many world titles and juniors who are likely to reach those heights soon, you could make a fascinating book. That was the thought that occurred to Marc Smith of England, and the result proves that he was right, although two photographs are misidentified. ''World Class'' is available for $20.95, including shipping, from Baron Barclay Bridge Supplies (800 274-2221).

title: Iron John Is Buying Throw Pillows . . .
description: IF you accept the rule of thumb that anything three inches above the floor constitutes furniture, then Charlie Himmelberg, who is single and lives in a four-room apartment on the Upper West Side, owns six pieces: a futon, a bookshelf, a television stand with a television, a coffee table, a folding canvas patio chair and a pressed-wood kitchen table that a girlfriend gave him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APAT, ADELINE
description: APAT-Adeline. The Trustees and staff of the Hunter College Foundation extend heartfelt condolences to Klara Silverstein, our trustee, her husband Larry, and their family on the death of Klara's beloved mother, Adeline. Like Klara, a daughter of Hunter College, Adeline also shared a devotion to life and to family. Our thoughts are with all the family at this time of loss and sadness. The Hunter College Foundation Allan H. Kurtzman, Chair, Floria V. Lasky, Co-Chair Timothy B. Harwood, Exec. Dir. Sandra Radinsky, Deputy Dir.

title: F.D.A. Approves Arthritis Drug
description: Johnson & Johnson won approval to market its drug Remicade as a treatment for rheumatoid arthritis, clearing it to compete with Enbrel, a drug sold by the Immunex Corporation and its parent, the American Home Products Corporation.

title: Lifetimes of Memories Preserved on CD-ROM's
description: A new Internet company is betting its existence on a truism: People like to talk about themselves.

title: Microsoft Shareholders, Mostly, Support Their Chairman
description: He got a prolonged standing ovation on the way to the podium, and he was mobbed by autograph seekers on the way out.

title: FREEMAN SPOGLI TO BUY STAKE IN MEDICAL ARTS PRESS
description: Freeman Spogli & Company, a closely held investment firm in Los Angeles, agreed yesterday to acquire a majority 70 percent stake in Medical Arts Press in a buyout with management valued at $277 million. Medical Arts executives will own the rest. Medical Arts, which is based in Minneapolis, makes, distributes and sells office products and supplies to health-care professionals through catalogs and targeted mailing. It had $118 million in sales in the 12 months ended in September and will continue to expand its Internet presence.

title: Compromise on Education Brings Budget Deal Closer
description: Congress and the White House came closer to striking a budget deal tonight, reaching a tentative agreement on spending for education, but still arguing over the environment, abortion and back dues the United States owes the United Nations.

title: GARDEN NOTEBOOK; There's Something Burning in the Garden
description: BACK 350,000 years or so, when the local volcano began belching flames, it's a good bet that no one stuck around saying, ''Get the marshmallows.''

title: States' Rights Adherents on Top Court Appear to Be Given Pause
description: The five Supreme Court justices who have been leading the court's drive to expand states' rights at the expense of federal authority peered into the future today and just maybe -- momentarily and almost imperceptibly -- blinked.

title: J. C. Penney Delays Drugstore Offering
description: The J. C. Penney Company, the second-biggest United States department-store operator, said today that it would delay plans to sell 20 percent of its Eckerd drugstore chain to the public until the first half of next year.

title: HEALTHIER OUTLOOK FOR BRAZIL
description: Citing the government's progress in controlling spending, the Standard & Poor's Corporation changed its outlook on Brazil's credit rating to stable from negative. The move came after Brazil exceeded goals set with the International Monetary Fund to create a budget surplus before interest is paid on government bonds. Even so, S.& P. still said it considered Brazil a ''speculative grade'' investment, which prevents many United States investment funds from buying its debt securities.

title: McCain Enlisting Fellow Veterans to Back His Campaign
description: Presidential candidates often have made appeals to veterans. But John McCain, the Arizona senator whose singular biography includes his five and a half years as a prisoner of war, is making a full-scale effort to mobilize them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLEXSAK, ANDREW S.
description: OLEXSAK-Andrew S. Jr. Of Union City, New Jersey on Tuesday, November 9, 1999. Companion of Michele French. Son of Andrew S. Olexsak, Sr. Father of Patricia, Jennifer, Danielle and Andrew. Brother of John, Ronald Olexsak and Katherine Pinyan. Uncle of many nieces and nephews. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend the funeral services on Saturday at 9:30 AM at the Leber Funeral Home, Kennedy Boulevard at 20th Street, Union City, NJ.
