Thence to St. John's Episcopal UC where at 10:30 AM a Funeral Service will be offered. Interment at Holy Cross Cemetery, Callicoon, New York. The family will receive friends on Friday from 2-4 and 7-9. For those desiring, donations may be sent to charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINER, SOPHIE
description: REINER-Sophie. (nee Anderman). November 9, 1999. 92 years old. Wife of the late Albert Reiner. Mother of Diana Falick Waill and Leona Schonberg. Grandmother of Jeffrey and Melanie Falick and Roy Schonberg. Great grandmother of Benjamin Whipple. Sister of Sylvia Chotin, Bernard Anderman and the late Ethel Guterweil.

title: Getting Personal in Prime Time; Creators of TV Shows Tap Their Lives
description: Two years ago Betsy Thomas, a television writer, checked into the Chateau Marmont hotel in West Hollywood in the aftermath of a divorce. On her first evening there she called room service for a bottle of wine when friends visited. The waiter, an unemployed actor, arrived with the tray.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Swinger, a Miss And an Injury

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: RAYTHEON CO., Lexington, Mass., the military contractor, received a $1.1 billion contract to build two power plants in Massachusetts for Sithe Energies Inc., New York.

title: Rite Aid Calls Earnings Forecast Inaccurate
description: The Rite Aid Corporation, the nation's No. 3 drugstore chain, told analysts and investors today not to rely on forecasts for profit and cash flow made last month. The statement sent the company's stock down by a third.

title: Early Count Hints at Fewer Kosovo Deaths
description: In five months of investigation and exhumation of the dead in Kosovo, war crimes investigators have found 2,108 bodies in grave sites throughout the province, the chief prosecutor announced today.

title: McKeon Is Named Manager Of Year
description: Almost unappreciated in his own domain, Jack McKeon was honored for his and his team's unexpected performance this year by being named National League manager of the year today.

title: Caught in Shifting Values (and Plot)
description: DISGRACE

title: In Bulgaria, 10 Years of Misery
description: We here in Bulgaria have had democracy since 1989. What has happened during these last 10 years?

title: A Canal Worth a Trip
description: On Nov. 9, 1906, the battleship Louisiana steamed out of Norfolk, Va., bound for the Caribbean, with President Theodore Roosevelt on board -- the first time in history a president had left the country while in office. Roosevelt wanted to see for himself what he called ''the biggest thing that's ever been done,'' the building of the Panama Canal.

title: Water Main Bursts Near City Hall, Complicating Commute Home
description: A big, 129-year-old cast-iron water main burst in downtown Manhattan yesterday afternoon, shutting down traffic on Broadway and the N and R subway lines below, and frustrating homebound commuters.

title: School Officials Defend Web Site Filtering
description: As more teachers came forward yesterday with new accounts of students doing research being blocked from Internet access, New York City school officials yesterday defended their use of a computer program that filters out sites with references to weapons and breasts, even if the sites were about medieval weapons and breast cancer.

title: Miscellany
description: * Opus Marketing, Richmond, Va., a creative marketing agency, was renamed Play.

title: In America; Dismantling Medicaid
description: Ambivalence.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BURNS, JAMES TERRY
description: BURNS-James Terry. In loving memory of our brother Jim, who died 20 years ago today at the age of 22. We miss him still. Harborfields, '75, Colgate , '79. Brothers: Peter Martin, Stephen Geoffrey & Richard Dale Burns

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASNER, BENJAMIN
description: KASNER-Benjamin. Beloved husband of Cecile and the late Mollie. Loving father of Victor Kasner and the late Arlene Russin. Dear grandfather and great grandfather. Dear brother of Mollie Gartenstein. Services at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn (at Avenue L) today at 11 A.M.

title: Ward and Childs Aim to Improve Reputations on the Court
description: It would be difficult for Charlie Ward and Chris Childs of the Knicks to be unaware of the criticism they often face in print or on talk radio.

title: Ex-Senator Is Confirmed as a Logjam Over Nominees Is Broken
description: Former Senator Carol Moseley-Braun and Adm. Joseph W. Prueher won Senate confirmation as ambassadors tonight as Democrats and Republicans in the Senate reached an accord that cleared the way for approval of dozens of envoys and federal judges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEE, TIMOTHY S.
description: GEE-Timothy S., M.D. The Saint Vincent's Comprehensive Cancer Center records with a deep sense of loss the sudden death of Dr. Timothy S. Gee. Dr. Gee was Chief Neoplastic Hematopoietic Services at Saint Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center. Dr. Gee's special interest included his focus on patient care, the leadership of a support group for his patients, and his role as an internationally recognized researcher in the development of new treatments for Leukemias, Lymphomas, and Myelomas. Dr. Gee was truly a dedicated, gifted physician, an exemplary teacher, and a loyal friend to all of us. We offer our profound condolences to his wife, Carol, his children, and all of his extended family and friends. John S. Macdonald, M.D. Medical Director & Chief of the Gastrointestinal Oncology Division of the Saint Vincent's Comprehensive Cancer Center

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRUSSELL, RAY
description: TRUSSELL-Ray, Dr. A memorial service for Dr. Ray Trussell, General Director of Beth Israel Medical Center from 1968 to 1978, New York City Commissioner of Hospitals from 1961 to 1965, and former Director of the Columbia University School of Public Health, will be held at 10:30 A.M. Friday, November 12th at the Podell Auditorium of Beth Israel Medical Center, accessible through the hospital entrance at First Avenue and 16th Street in Manhattan.

title: Clinton Cites Harley-Davidson in Pushing His Trade Policy
description: President Clinton today saluted a much-exported American icon, the Harley-Davidson motorcycle, in an effort to prepare the political ground for two high-stakes trade negotiations that are already touching off raucous debate in Washington and around the country.

title: 2 Wrongs in South Beach
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinic Chain Plans to Shed 53 Outlets
description: Charter Behavioral Health Systems, the largest operator of privately run psychiatric hospitals and clinics, said yesterday that it planned to sell 53 of the 96 centers it operates.

title: Webb and Inkster Teeing Off in a Duel
description: The battle between Karrie Webb and Juli Inkster for player of the year of the Ladies Professional Golf Association will be settled this weekend.

title: On a Slave Ship, Humanity's Power
description: The genius is in the detail. If any choreographer knows how to make one part of a dancer's body move in rhythmic counterpoint to another, it is Garth Fagan. Teaming up again with the South African composer known as Lebo M, one of his collaborators in ''The Lion King,'' Mr. Fagan has come up with a dazzling piece: from finger to toe, everything dances in ''Woza,'' which had its premiere on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: A Holiday Spectacle In New Finery
description: Radio City Music Hall isn't alone in undergoing a refurbishing this year. So has its ''Christmas Spectacular.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LADO, HENRIETTA JEAN
description: LADO-Henrietta Jean. On Nov. 8, 1999 in San Francisco. Beloved wife of the late Michael, cherished aunt of Stanley & Melvin Roboff, great-aunt of Gary, Sari, Annie, Katherine & Julia Roboff. Services Friday, 9:45 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Parcells Replaces Mirer With Lucas
description: Even winning was not enough to keep Rick Mirer as the Jets' starting quarterback.

title: A Day Late, but Still a Victor in Marathon
description: WHILE you were no doubt sleeping in your cozy bed Sunday night, Zoe Koplowitz, 51, was in the streets for her 12th New York City Marathon, in which, as usual, she finished last.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article yesterday about a plane crash in Mexico that killed 18 people misstated the type of plane in some copies. It was a DC-9, made by McDonnell Douglas, not a Boeing 727.

title: U.S. Military Acted Outside NATO Framework During Kosovo Conflict, France Says
description: France drew up a list of lessons today that it had learned from the allied bombing of Yugoslavia last spring. One of them was that some missions were not really allied at all, but 100 percent American.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HARE, AMELIA T.
description: O'HARE-Amelia T., 91, formerly of Jackson Heights, NY, died November 9, 1999. Retired Director of Fundraising Operations for the Children's Aid Society in New York City. Wife of the late Joseph James O'Hare. Services Friday at 8:00 AM at the M.J. Murphy Funeral Home, 616 Ridge Road, Monmouth Junction, New Jersey. Funeral liturgy will be 10:00 A.M., at St. Augustine of Canterbury, Kendal Park, NJ. Burial in Calvary Cemetery, Long Island City, NY. Contributions in lieu of flowers to the Children's Aid Society, 105 East 22 Street, New York, NY 10010.

title: Subway Juror Wasn't Asked if He Had a Police Record
description: A court transcript made available yesterday shows that a holdout juror who caused a mistrial in the case of a schizophrenic man accused of killing a stranger in the subway was never asked about his own criminal background during jury selection.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Campaign Ads
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton took her undeclared candidacy for the United States Senate in a truly unfortunate direction this week. A year before the election, the New York State Democratic Party started running television commercials for Mrs. Clinton, paid for in part by unregulated ''soft money'' raised by the national party in Washington from corporations, unions and rich individuals. The ads recall one of the worst fund-raising abuses practiced by President Clinton in his own 1996 re-election campaign. Mrs. Clinton should withdraw them or pay for them entirely with money raised under the federal election law ceilings, as Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has done with his first ads.

title: New State Park of 153 Acres Is Created on L.I.
description: In a major victory for environmentalists, Gov. George E. Pataki announced today that more than 80 percent of a former psychiatric center near Long Island Sound would be preserved as a wooded nature sanctuary and a new state park.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Increase in Shares of U.P.S. Pushes Value to $81 Billion

title: Diana Rigg as a Detective Armed With One-Liners
description: ''Speedy Death'' has everything a comfortable British mystery should have: Chayning Court, a country estate with an Upstairs and Downstairs abounding in suspects or victims with Woodhousian names like Alistair Bing, Bertie Philipson, Everard Mountjoy and Baxter the Butler; weddings and funerals as required and lines like ''Have you taken leave of your senses, boy?''; motives, financial and romantic; weapons, including a gun, a knife and a bathtub; prowlings in the night; shattered glass; eavesdropping, and a worldly sleuth (abetted by an upwardly mobile chauffeur) who sees everything and can tell a clue from a herring: ''The door unlocked and the window opened?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GATHERAL, MALCOLM
description: GATHERAL-Malcolm. Of Falmouth, November 9, beloved husband of the late Ruth (Hennessey) Gatheral. Uncle of Sabina G. O'Hara of Larchmont, New York, Margaret G. McGarrahan of Cotuit, MA., Elizabeth McAlpine of Atlanta, GA, James Gatheral of Pitlochry, Scotland, Marcus Gatheral of Lochwinnoch, Scotland and many great and grand nieces and nephews. Funeral service will be private. For information, call Chapman, Cole & Gleason Funeral Home, Falmouth, MA.

title: Muhammad's Place Is Secure
description: Indianapolis Colts Coach Jim Mora said yesterday that he would not be reluctant to bring back the rookie defensive back Steve Muhammad, whose pregnant wife, Nichole, died last Sunday, several days after Muhammad was charged with domestic battery.

title: New Pullout for West Bank
description: The Israeli government approved a further withdrawal in the West Bank today, moving to carry out another part of its latest accord with the Palestinians.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARSON, BROOKE
description: CARSON-Brooke. November 11, 1946-September 9, 1996. For Brookie, as on every day you are greatly loved and greatly missed on your birthday. Much love from, Mother, Ian, and Devereaux

title: Gap Says 3rd-Quarter Profit Jumped Thanks to Old Navy
description: The Gap said today that its third-quarter profit rose 32 percent as its Old Navy chain drew back-to-school shoppers with low-priced cargo pants and fleece vests.

title: New Beachhead For Videodiscs
description: With the release last week of ''Saving Private Ryan,'' digital videodiscs made headway in a vital genre: the Steven Spielberg movie. Though the director never said so, it was thought that he was holding his films from DVD until it was clear that the format would succeed. Spielberg films are about as important to DVD as Disney classics, and on this disc, which has behind-the-scenes clips and other features, he does not contribute a director's commentary but does talk at the end of the film about the Normandy invasion and about the National D-Day Museum, which is to open in New Orleans in June.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Life Returns to a Fouled Creek; Newtown, Less Classy Than the Gowanus, Has Allies
description: Up in the wheelhouse of the Bullet II, a 65-foot party boat out of Sheepshead Bay, Capt. Eddie Shaw chomped his frayed cigar, checked his sonar screen and cut the wheel hard to starboard, heading into unfamiliar waters and leaving the East River behind.

title: Gore Commercial on His Health Care Plans for Children
description: This 30-second commercial is the fourth from Vice President Al Gore. It discusses health care for children and is being broadcast in the early-voting states of Iowa and New Hampshire.

title: Update on Berlin Since the Wall
description: The last New York roundup of contemporary art from the eternally under-construction city of Berlin was at the Museum of Modern Art in 1987; it was all about neo-Expressionist painting. Now comes an update titled ''Children of Berlin: Cultural Developments 1989-1999'' at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, and there isn't a painting in sight.

title: With Ingenuity, Officers Rescue 2 From River
description: Using a makeshift lifeline and no small measure of ingenuity, two police detectives who saw a man strip off his clothes and jump into the East River yesterday rescued him and a woman that he was trying to save from drowning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITTENSTEIN, ROBERT
description: WITTENSTEIN-Robert., age 69, of Westport, CT and Boca Raton, FL, died Wednesday, November 10, 1999 following a long illness. Mr. Wittenstein was a former Senior Vice President, Investments at Paine Webber, Inc. Mr. Wittenstein was predeceased by his sister, Arlene Stuart, & is survived by his wife of 46 years, Sari Katz Wittenstein; 3 children, Ira, Andrew and Victoria; two brothers, Frederick & Leon Wittenstein; sister, Judith & his four grandchildren. Services Friday, November 12, 1:00 PM from Temple Israel, 14 Coleytown Rd., Westport, CT, with interment following at Temple Israel Cemetery in Norwalk, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to the charity of one's choice. For information: Abraham L. Green & Son Funeral Home, Fairfield, CT.

title: BRITISH TELECOM SHARES SOAR
description: Buoyed by forecasts of unparalleled growth in the data, wireless and Internet industries, shares in British Telecommunications soared to all-time highs after the company reported a 21 percent leap in second-quarter sales, to 5.3 billion [pounds] ($8.75 billion). The company said pretax profits, excluding one-time items and good will, rose 3 percent, to $:832 million ($1.37 billion), despite surging costs from the company's expansion.

title: Holyfield Is Older and Wiser, but Don't Dare to Mutter 'Aging'
description: Questions have circled Evander Holyfield's career like birds of prey poised to swoop down for the kill, but he has always managed to survive.

title: Children's Story: A Day in the Life of Forrest's Dad
description: Spalding Gray's captivating new monologue, ''Morning, Noon and Night'' is absolute confirmation of the liberating power of devotion to a child. Mr. Gray may have gained renown for his obsessive contemplation of his own navel, but during 95 lovestruck minutes at the Vivian Beaumont Theater he begins to shed his myriad neuroses as if they were the strands of a suffocating chrysalis.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about planned job cuts at Nortel Networks misidentified the No. 1 maker of telephone equipment in North America. It is Lucent Technologies, not Cisco Systems.

title: The Public Servant Behind the Public Kennedy
description: EDWARD M. KENNEDY

title: ALBRIGHT OFFERING TO TAKE CRITICISM FOR A DEAL ON U.N.
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright has volunteered to be the lightning rod for criticism from abortion rights groups if President Clinton compromises with Congress on a deal to free nearly $1 billion the United States owes the United Nations, senior administration officials said today.

title: MAYTAG TO BUY BACK AS MANY AS 10 MILLION SHARES
description: The Maytag Corporation, the No. 3 United States appliance maker, said yesterday that it planned to buy back as many as 10 million shares, extending its repurchase plan to increase the value of its stock. Based on yesterday's close of $45.625, a gain of 87.5 cents, the buyback is valued at about $456.25 million. The buyback would represent about 8.4 percent of the 83.9 million shares outstanding.

title: Little Stories in a New York Earthquake
description: Lots of people would pay big bucks to see New York City get blown apart. But you can watch the big event free if you don't mind settling for a fake catastrophe in a fake New York. That's what you'll get on Sunday and Tuesday nights in the CBS mini-epic ''Aftershock: Earthquake in New York.''

title: Experts Say Microsoft Has Some Points for Appeal
description: Although mostly solid, the findings of Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson in the Microsoft antitrust trial may have been so sweeping as to leave the company room to chip away at them on appeal, some leading antitrust experts say.

title: Judean Foothills Journal; Stealing Millennial Loot, From 2 Millenniums Ago
description: ''Come, climb into the grave,'' said Amir Ganor, an archaeologist-cop, his hand reaching out from an underground hole. ''See what the robbers have done.''

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Joan, Medieval Warrior Princess
description: The Hundred Years War feels twice that long in ''The Messenger: The Story of Joan of Arc,'' Luc Besson's shrill, overheated portrait of the teenage warrior, cross-dresser and martyr. Saving France from English clutches this time is Milla Jovovich, bringing hearty cries of ''C'mon! C'mon!'' to a story usually associated with spirituality and magnificent understatement. Though Ms. Jovovich's performance dominates the film, she remains pedestrian and underwhelming, with leadership abilities that are noticeably dubious. As presented here, the real miracle about Joan of Arc is that France's favorite dish is not fish and chips.

title: Retaining the Student Fees
description: One of the roles of higher education is to provide a place where ideas and beliefs can collide, where students can learn to tolerate even points of view they find obnoxious. For decades, radical movements and countermovements in America have used the campus as a place to form and grow, to articulate ideas and promote goals. That has been true of the black civil rights movement in the 1950's and 60's, the Vietnam War opposition and the feminist movement of the 1960's and 70's, the gay rights movement of the 1970's and the conservative Christian movement of the 1980's and 90's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPERLING, DAVID E.
description: SPERLING-David E.. 81, of Sherman, Ct., and formerly White Plains, NY, passed away November 9, 1999. Husband of Phyllis H. for 58 years, father of Margaret, Alice, David L., Sharon, Louise; grandfather of Daniel, Sarah, Gideon and David J. He remained a lifelong learner and natural teacher. Much beloved by friends and family for his quiet dignity, humor and quality friendship. He was a wonderful man. A Spring Memorial Service is planned in Sherman, Ct.

title: Residential Real Estate; From a Nut Factory to Luxury Rentals
description: Once used as a factory to process nuts, the 19th-century building at 21 Jay Street has been converted into 10 luxury rental lofts, departing from the trend of the last two years of converting old industrial buildings in TriBeCa to condominiums.

title: WINDFALL SCANDAL IN SPAIN
description: Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar of Spain fended off sharp criticism in Parliament over $190 million in stock option earnings for 100 top executives of Telefonica, whose chairman, Juan Villalonga, was appointed by Mr. Aznar's government before the telecommunications giant was privatized in 1997. Joaquin Almunia, leader of the opposition Socialist Party, has seized on the issue as elections must be held by April. Al Goodman

title: While Mrs. Clinton Looks On, Palestinian Officials Criticize Israel
description: In a return visit to Palestinian territory today, Hillary Rodham Clinton was acclaimed anew as a champion of Palestinian nationhood, and then listened with visible discomfort as her hosts at a health care function here excoriated Israel for its alleged toxic contamination of Palestinian air and water.

title: Talks on China Trade Deal In Peril, the U.S. Side Says
description: American officials expressed a sudden pessimism today about the prospects for a long-sought deal to get China into the World Trade Organization.

title: Public Interests; George W., Helmsman
description: George W. Bush must be feeling at least a tiny bit of heat from John McCain, since he's felt compelled to come up with a reason that he would make a better president than the senator from Arizona.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNCH, RUSSELL VINCENT
description: LYNCH-Russell Vincent., November 14, 1922 to November 10, 1999. Born in New York, NY; raised in Greenwich, CT. Attended Phillips Exeter Academy. He served in the Pacific on the aircraft carriers U.S.S. Ticonderoga and the U.S.S. Hancock. Upon release from the Navy in 1945 as a decorated Naval Aviator, Mr. Lynch returned to Yale University and graduated in the Class of 1947. Upon graduation, Mr. Lynch was employed by Chance Vought Aircraft of Dallas as a test pilot. In 1974 he started R.V. Lynch and Company, an oil and gas concern. He is survived by a sister, Helen Barrett (Rogie) Dickie of Devon, PA., his brothers David Barrett Lynch of Gladwyn, PA., and William R. Lynch of Greenwich, CT. He had six children: Rose Peabody Lynch, of New York, R. Vincent Lynch Jr., of London, Alexander P. Lynch, of Greenwich, C. Burton Lynch, Peter F. Lynch and Joseph B. O. Lynch, all of Dallas, Texas, along with fourteen grandchildren. The funeral will be in Dallas, on Saturday, November 12.

title: For Bradley, a Strategic Love of the Game
description: After Bill Bradley retired from the Knicks, he stopped following basketball, or any other sport, for that matter.

title: Design for Memorial to Flight 800 Is Unveiled on Long Island
description: The design for a memorial commemorating the 230 people killed when Trans World Airlines Flight 800 exploded was unveiled yesterday on Long Island, not far from where the airliner went down. But an organizer said the group planning the project still needed hundreds of thousands of dollars to turn the design into a reality.

title: Day in the Life of a Dad
description: Spalding Gray, above, may be best known for monologues that delve into his own neuroses. But in ''Morning, Noon and Night,'' which he is performing at the Beaumont, he explores the new sense of purpose he has found through raising his children, in a work that is unscathed by sentimentality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLKE, DOROTHY C.
description: WOLKE-Dorothy C.. Retired NYCPD of the Bronx, November 10, 1999. Sister of Margaret E. Stevens & Patricia Wolke, aunt of Christopher Stevens and Michelle Bordonaro. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY between the hours of 2-4 & 7-9PM Friday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Saturday, November 13 at 9:45 AM.

title: Daring to Open a Crack in the Door to Cuba
description: FEW 25-year-old junior travel executives are likely to be worried about the potential security risks associated with having their picture appear in a newspaper.

title: John Currin
description: Andrea Rosen Gallery

title: Modern Visions
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Dell Has Quarterly Earnings That Meet Revised Estimates
description: After warning last month of an earnings squeeze because of rising memory chip prices, the Dell Computer Corporation reported third-quarter earnings yesterday that met analysts' revised estimates. But the company's unit shipments grew at more than twice the industry rate as Dell continues to gain market share from other personal computer manufacturers.

title: Banco Santander of Spain Will Acquire 2 Portuguese Banks
description: Banco Santander Central Hispano, the largest Spanish bank, said today that it would buy two banks in the Champalimaud Group of Portugal but would not achieve its earlier bid for 40 percent of the group because of stiff opposition from the Portuguese government.

title: Giuliani Assails Hillary Clinton Tactic
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani denounced Hillary Rodham Clinton yesterday for authorizing a New York television advertising campaign that promoted her expected Senate candidacy, and which was largely financed with unregulated corporate and labor contributions. Mr. Giuliani described it as another example of campaign finance abuse by the Clintons.

title: Jacobo Timerman, 76, the Torture Victim Who Documented Argentina's Shame, Dies
description: Jacobo Timerman, the distinguished Argentine journalist whose imprisonment and torture by his country's military forces in the 1970's created an international human rights furor, died yesterday at his home in Buenos Aires. He was 76.

title: NATWEST ISSUES DEFENSE
description: A war of words continued as National Westminster Bank defended itself in a letter to shareholders as it tries to thwart the Bank of Scotland's hostile bid. Sir David Rowland, chairman of Natwest, wrote, ''Bank of Scotland's plans reveal a dangerous blend of hubris and parochialism.'' He added that his suitor's savings plan ''would require something akin to divine intervention to succeed -- which Bank of Scotland has sought in the past, without success.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BOEING CO., Seattle, said it was investing $250 million to build a launching complex at Cape Canaveral Air Station, Fla., for rockets capable of sending commercial satellites with expanded payloads into orbit.

title: Biagio DiLieto, 76, Mayor Of New Haven for a Decade
description: Biagio DiLieto, a former New Haven mayor and police chief who helped breathe new life into the city during his 10 years in office, died Monday at a hospice in Branford, Conn. He was 76.

title: Subtle Spins In an Old Tale
description: Did you hear the one about the old maid and the traveling salesman? Groan if you will, but there was a time when the question summed up not only a whole species of smutty jokes but also a gentler genre of romantic comedies. You know the formula, which was given its most popular incarnation in ''The Music Man'': flashy con artist meets buttoned-up spinster; sparks fly; she makes him honest, he makes her fun.

title: Rangers Force Overtime and Win
description: The Rangers were 19 seconds away from another devastating defeat tonight and the start of the Muckler watch.

title: Boars, Brides and Violinists In Significant Numbers
description: Princess Mononoke

title: Authenticity of Famed Photographer's Prints Scrutinized
description: For years, collectors and dealers of high-quality art photographs have been surprised by a proliferation of first-rate prints by Lewis W. Hine, the important documentary photographer best known for his early- to mid-century images of labor, poverty, immigration and the construction of the Empire State Building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SATTINGER, ETHEL
description: SATTINGER-Ethel. Age 99, on November 11, 1999, formerly of Kew Garden Hills. Beloved wife of the late Max. Devoted mother of Sam and Gilda Sattinger, Shirley and Seymour Rubin. Adored grandmother of Lisa and Lee Einbinder, David and Tori Sattinger, Richard and Beth Rubin. Cherished greatgrandmother of James, Russell, Willa and Jackson. Services today, 2PM, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Chicago Hiltons Select Bozell
description: Three large Chicago hotels that are part of the Hilton Hotels Corporation have awarded their regional account to the Chicago office of Bozell. Billings were estimated at $1 million to $3 million.

title: Mexico's Fair Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: Apologize to Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Salutes the Last World War II Veteran on Active Duty
description: President Clinton honored the last World War II veteran serving on active duty at Veterans Day ceremonies today, but Capt. Earl R. Fox did not feel like a hero.

title: SHOPNOW.COM TO ACQUIRE SPEEDYCLICK FOR $50 MILLION
description: ShopNow.com Inc., an online marketplace, agreed yesterday to pay $50 million in stock and cash to buy the SpeedyClick Corporation, an Internet site aimed at women. ShopNow.com, based in Seattle, said it would pay $47 million in stock and $3 million in cash for the closely held company. SpeedyClick, which offers contests, games, chat rooms and other services online, has about 1 million registered users and 3 million visitors monthly, according to ShopNow.com.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: For Microsoft, the Time May Have Come to Cut a Deal
description: WITH the facts in, here is the Microsoft debate:

title: DYNAMICWEB TO ACQUIRE EB2B FOR 25 MILLION SHARES
description: DynamicWeb Enterprises Inc., which helps companies do business over the Internet, agreed to buy the closely held eB2B Commerce Inc. for 25 million shares, worth $118.8 million at Thursday's closing price, and a $15 million investment from eB2B. EB2B runs commerce networks between manufacturers and retailers. DynamicWeb gains eB2B's business-to-business technology, while eB2B gets DynamicWeb's customer base. The new company, to be called eB2B Commerce Inc., will have 30 million shares outstanding. EB2B's president and chief executive, Peter J. Fiorillo, will retain those roles. DynamicWeb's president and chief executive, Steve Vanechanos, will become chief technology officer.

title: John Wonnacott
description: Hirschl & Adler

title: Judge Dismisses Incest Case Against Swiss Boy of 11
description: GENEVA  A judge in Colorado has dismissed charges against an 11-year-old Swiss boy accused of molesting his sister, ending a dispute over differences in the way the United States and Switzerland handle possible juvenile offenders.

title: Houdini Turns Kidnapper, and the Battle of Wits Begins
description: As long as ''Oxygen'' sticks literally to its guns, then this little thriller about a race to save a woman snatched from a Manhattan street in broad daylight and buried alive by a kidnapper has its merits.

title: Bush Courts Veterans' Vote in Michigan
description: About 200 people turned out at a historic cemetery here today to see Gov. George W. Bush of Texas commemorate Veterans Day. But he should not count on winning their votes just yet.

title: Health Care Puzzle
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Plan Would End Race-Based Admissions
description: Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, in a move that could head off a possible statewide vote on whether to ban affirmative action, has offered his own plan to change race-based college admissions and stop minority set-asides in state contracts.

title: CISCO SYSTEMS TO ACQUIRE V-BITS FOR $128 MILLION
description: Cisco Systems Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire V-Bits Inc., a privately held maker of video processing systems for cable television providers, for $128 million in stock. V-Bits' products let cable companies offer digital video services over cable television networks. The company, which is based in San Jose, Calif., has 30 employees. Cisco, the computer networking giant, which is also based in San Jose, said the acquisition had been approved by the boards of both companies and should close before the end of the year. Its shares rose $4.3125 each, to $83.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Jitish Kallat -- 'Private Limited-I'
description: Bose Pacia Modern

title: Paid Parental Leave: Who Gains?
description: To the Editor:

title: Family Saw Youth Change Before Attack On Subway
description: Damien Purrier began to lose control of his life two months before the police arrested him on charges that he slashed commuters on a Manhattan-bound subway train, his family members said yesterday.

title: Way Too Trusting Of Kindly Strangers
description: ''Felicia's Journey'' was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 9. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: Metro Business; Hospital and H.M.O. Agree on Cutoff Date
description: Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital and Aetna U. S. Healthcare said yesterday that the hospital would treat the health plan's members until April 30.

title: Cadillac is redesigning its image before its retooled cars appear.
description: CADILLAC has worked through an identity crisis and come up with a sharpened brand image and radical designs for the cars in its future. But years before any of the futuristic cars have rolled out of factories, the flagship division of General Motors plans an ad campaign promoting its new image.

title: Bristol-Myers Squibb In Development Deal
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, the world's No. 1 maker of cancer drugs, said yesterday that it would pay $32 million to a unit of Millennium Pharmaceuticals Inc. over five years in a partnership to develop cancer treatments linked to genetic information.

title: Statehouse Journal; Past Haunts a Mississippi Election
description: The past is always palpable in Mississippi, but rarely does it unsettle the present as powerfully as it has in the last week, reaching forward from an unburied century to prevent the voters of the state from choosing their own governor.

title: Cool Dudes in a Cosmological Mood
description: ''Dogma'' was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 4. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: Baby's Body Is Found In Bag at Recycling Plant
description: A newborn girl was found dead late Wednesday in a bag on a running conveyor belt at a trash recycling plant in Brooklyn, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIFFERT, LEE
description: SEIFFERT-Lee. At the age of 92. Survided by her brothers and sisters Peggy Rothstein, Max Tabachnick, Susan Weinstein and Emanuel Tabachnick. Services are private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINCHAS, MARCIA COOPER
description: PINCHAS-Marcia Cooper. on November 11, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Raphael, devoted mother of Daniel and David, loving grandmother of Marisa. She was a United Nations staff member for 35 years. She will be deeply missed by all whose lives she touched. Service today at 9:30AM at the ''Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Leukemia Society of America.

title: Taxi Discrimination
description: In the movie ''The Pelican Brief,'' the African-American actor Denzel Washington plays an undercover reporter who tries to follow a suspect by hailing a cab -- but gets left in the lurch when the cabby sees that he is black and roars away. The humiliating experience of being passed up by taxis, some of which then pick up white passengers a short distance away, has become almost a rite of passage for black men in New York City, where comedians have turned the experience into a gag that audiences find quite funny.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE RISES. Coffee prices rose on speculation that Brazil would not get enough rain to avoid further drought damage to the world's largest crop. In New York, coffee for March delivery rose 4.5 cents, to $1.1995 a pound.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen slipped against the dollar after Japan announced its latest stimulus plan, which is worth about $171.4 billion. In New York, the dollar settled at 104.91 yen, up from 104.65 on Wednesday.

title: Knockouts Helping The Colts Flourish
description: For a team that won only three games last season, the Indianapolis Colts have made themselves felt this year, and not only with their precocious offense. In their last five games, the Colts have knocked out all five starting quarterbacks.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Berlin's Art Since the Wall
description: Since the wall came down 10 years ago, Berlin has blossomed with a new generation of artists in their 20's and 30's. Their work -- often raw, at times dysfunctional but oddly delicate -- is on display in Queens in a group show at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City. ''Children of Berlin: Cultural Developments 1989-1999'' is fueled by wit and energy. Video, sculpture and installation, often combined, predominate. Architecture, theater and fashion are very much in the picture, as is the world of club culture, including a re-creation of Cookie's Bar in Berlin, above, at the P.S. 1 cafe.

title: F.D.A. Issues a Health Warning on a Weight-Loss Supplement
description: In another round of its escalating battle with the dietary supplement industry, the Food and Drug Administration issued a health warning today about a weight-loss product that is being marketed as a natural remedy but that the agency deems ''an unapproved new drug.''

title: Groups Offer Way to Teach Bible in Class
description: After years of arguing over whether the Bible ought to be taught in public schools, 20 national organizations from across the ideological spectrum have joined to produce a booklet that spells out how to do so without breaching the wall between church and state.

title: Composers' Guild Honors Its Founder in a Concert
description: The Guild of Composers gave a 25th-anniversary concert at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday evening in honor of the association's founder, Jacques-Louis Monod, offering a circuit of his interests or, better, a squiggle of his interests, since they are too numerous and too broad to be covered in one program. As a conductor, organizer and moral supporter, Mr. Monod has been a great friend of American composers, and the first half of the concert consisted of American instrumental pieces from the half-century of his professional life. Then came chamber music: Bartok's Third Quartet, Maurice Delage's ''Quatre Poemes Hindous'' for voice and mixed ensemble, and Ravel's ''Trois Poemes de Stephane Mallarme'' for a similar grouping.

title: City Unions Shift Strategy On Bargaining
description: Unhappy with their current contracts, leaders of New York City's municipal unions said yesterday that they would use new bargaining tactics that they hoped would help them overcome the Giuliani administration's past success in holding down wage increases.

title: ONE EUROPE, 10 YEARS: Surprising Strengths; In East German Soil, Some Companies Thrive
description: When the Berlin Wall collapsed 10 years ago, Stephan Schambach was 18 and had never set foot in a capitalist country.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: 'Real Thing' Returns. Really.

title: Richard Artschwager
description: Lehmann Maupin

title: New Video Releases
description: Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me

title: For a City Driven By a Dream
description: NEW YORK is a city defined by its chaos, its glittering promise that life here will never be dull. In recent decades alone, a visitor might have bumped into Holly Golightly, Travis Bickle, Jerry Seinfeld (or their prototypes). Such mind-spinning differences suggest that 10 hours might not be enough to cover more than 300 years of the city's unwieldly history.

title: Edgar Degas
description: Barbara Mathes

title: News of Possibly Breaking Even Ignites Advanced Micro Shares
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc., the biggest rival of Intel in the computer chip market, said today that it might break even in the fourth quarter, news that sent its shares up 23 percent.

title: Corrections
description: The State of the Art column in Circuits yesterday misstated the Web address of the NetPliance company, maker of the i-Opener computer. It is: www.netpliance.net.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Biotechnology Companies Defend Use of Genetic Crops

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, RICHARD
description: MARTIN-Richard. The faculty, staff, students and alumni of the Department of Art and Art Professions, New York University/School of Education deeply mourn the passing of our extraordinary colleague with whom we have worked for more than 20 years. His inspirational teaching, astonishing positive energy and creative vigor will be sorely missed. Carlo Lamagna Chairperson

title: 3 Masterworks Stolen in '78 Are Mysteriously Returned
description: On Christmas Eve 21 years ago, thieves dropped through a skylight into a San Francisco museum and made off with four 17th-century paintings, including one attributed to Rembrandt valued at $1 million.

title: A Holiday Offers Good News for McCain
description: Cautiously buoyed by new poll results and increasingly swarmed by reporters and supporters, Senator John McCain swept through a half-dozen Veterans Day observances in New Hampshire today, taking full advantage of a holiday that played directly to his military credentials.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Staking Out Tony At Ben Vereen's

title: In Courtroom, Kosovo Doctor Denies Charge Of Terrorism
description: The most prominent Kosovo Albanian in Serbian custody went on trial here today, facing charges of terrorism and separatism.

title: Clemens Stays a Yank as Mets End Bid for Wells
description: Roger Clemens and David Wells will be forever linked for last spring's blockbuster trade, but they won't share New York City any time soon. Clemens, officially giving up his right to demand a trade yesterday, will apparently remain with the Yankees, and the Mets' trade talks with Toronto regarding Wells and the slugger Carlos Delgado have collapsed.

title: Agreement on Plan to Revamp Organ Distribution
description: After a last-minute plea by Donna E. Shalala, the secretary of health and human services, members of Congress have cleared the way for the Clinton administration to enact a long-delayed regulation that will revamp the nation's system for distributing donated organs.

title: Wahid's Move on Trade Stirs Up Nationalism Among Muslims : Opening to Israel Vexes Indonesians
description: SINGAPORE  President Abdurrahman Wahid of Indonesia, a reformist Muslim, left Jakarta on Thursday for the United States, leaving behind a country deeply troubled by his decision to open trade ties with Israel and permit a vote on independence in the province of Aceh, an Islamic stronghold.

title: A Budget Too Flush To Fight About
description: The United States political system, arguably the most effective in the world, has an uncanny penchant for making its successes look like failures. The wrangling now going on in Washington over the federal budget is an ugly, confusing spectacle -- long on finger-pointing and gotcha moves, short on conciliation and statesmanship. As the vetoes, gimmickry and accusations of ''raiding Social Security'' fly up and down Pennsylvania Avenue, it is hard to remember that the battle is over marginal adjustments in an increasingly responsible fiscal policy.

title: Nascar Switches Drivers And Rakes In a Fortune
description: Nascar started planning its assault on network wallets a year ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSIER, JOAN (NEE TUBY)
description: WEINSIER-Joan (nee Tuby). On November 10, 1999. Loving daughter of Evelyn Tuby and the late Dr. Robert Tuby. Beloved wife of Philip. Adored and treasured mother of Michael and Wendy and mother-in-law of Marcy. Cherished grandmother of Matthew. Devoted sister of Suellen Globus and loving aunt to three nieces. Her extraordinary compassion, kindness, honesty, warmth, beauty, style and elegance are her legacy to us all. She will be deeply missed by all whose lives she touched. She graduated from Finch College, enjoyed a successful modelling career and studied drama with Lee Strasberg and Claudia Frank. In later years, she enjoyed a successful career in real estate sales and most recently, art sales. Services will be held at Temple Beth-El, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, New York, Friday, November 12, 1999 at 11 AM. For further information call Schwartz Brothers, 718-263-7600.

title: N.F.L. Matchups -- Week 10
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: In Presidents, Character Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, SHERWOOD MELVIN
description: WEINER-Sherwood Melvin., 73, died on October 29, 1999 following a long illness in Delray Beach, FL. Mr. Weiner was born in Mount Vernon, NY on October 23, 1926. He was the son of the late Barnett T. Weiner and Anne C. (Birnbaum) Weiner. He is survived by a son Albert Weiner and two daughters Deborah Weiner and Bernadette Anne Weiner. A private memorial is planned. Donations in Mr. Weiner's name may be made to the Guggenheim Museum in New York City. For information Scobee - Combs - Bowden Funeral Home, Boynton Beach, Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENWALD, HAROLD
description: GREENWALD-Harold., age 92, born in Yonkers, NY, on April 2, 1907, died on November 6, 1999, at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York, after a short illness. Son of the late Rose and Louis Greenwald, he was a highly respected attorney, generous supporter of many philanthropic organizations, ardent Zionist and lover of the State of Israel, caring friend to many, and loving, devoted family member. He leaves behind many whose lives he touched and who will deeply miss him. A remarkable man. Now he will be reunited with his beloved Dot.

title: QUEST SOFTWARE TO BUY FOGLIGHT FOR $83.4 MILLION
description: Quest Software Inc., a maker of database software, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Foglight Software for about $83.4 million in stock to add a monitoring system for its electronic-commerce software. Shareholders of Foglight, based in Pleasanton, Calif., will get 1.3 million shares of Quest stock. Quest, based in Irvine, Calif., makes software that permits electronic gathering and distribution of data through computer systems and the Internet. With this acquisition, it will get Foglight's Real-Time Application Performance System, which monitors applications and automatically corrects any problems or alerts system managers. The stock rose $2.25 a share yesterday, to $66.375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: L. H. Stone, 94, Defender of 8 In '42 Trial For Sabotage
description: Lauson Harvey Stone, a lawyer and civic leader who was assigned by the War Department to be a defense lawyer for eight Nazi saboteurs who were tried in Washington in 1942, died on Sunday at a Brooklyn hospital. He was 94 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Modigliani Sells High, But Auction Falls Short
description: Auction fatigue set in at Sotheby's last night on the week's fourth consecutive evening auction. The atmosphere in the York Avenue salesroom reflected tired buyers' determination to control the proceedings and not get carried away.

title: Gore, Rebuking Congress, Rejects Policy of Isolation
description: Vice President Al Gore chastised the Republican Congress today for what he cast as its isolationist stance, calling for an emphasis on diplomacy in foreign policy as an invaluable tool to stop the spread of nuclear weapons and stabilize the world.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Nov. 3 about Kenneth L. Schnitzer, a Houston real estate developer, omitted a reference to two former wives, who survive him. They are Pam Duke and Kathryn Schnitzer Freeman.

title: Americorps Lives
description: Americorps, President Clinton's national service program, has survived the budget warfare in Washington. An appropriations measure already signed by Mr. Clinton earmarks $438.5 million for the valuable five-year-old program -- roughly the same amount as last year.

title: Ban Tipping
description: To the Editor:

title: French Pieces With Bronze Accents
description: Among connoisseurs of 18th-century European furniture, the gold standard has always been French pieces, especially one-of-a-kind works signed by the top cabinetmakers.

title: A Woman's Struggle For Dignity
description: This year's dark-horse winner of the Palme d'Or at the Cannes International Film Festival was ''Rosetta,'' a wrenching work of social realism from the Belgian brothers Luc and Jean-Pierre Dardenne. Even more bluntly than they did in ''La Promesse,'' these filmmakers assess the moral toll taken by deprivation and economic struggle. Their camera closely observes the title character, a teenage girl who ekes out a living for herself and her boozy, troublesome mother. This young woman's life is so harsh that she spends much of the story fighting for a job at a waffle stand, and hides a pair of rubber work boots as if they were buried treasure.

title: 'Modernism'
description: Seventh Regiment Armory

title: Why There's No Place Like Home
description: Tripping exultantly through the restored Beaux-Arts jewel of a City Hall, City Councilman Jack Evans took measure today of this local government's nearly stepping back toward its sorry past as a political plantation.

title: SHARES OF INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS DROP NEARLY 19%
description: Shares of the International Multifoods Corporation, the leading distributor of snacks and other items to the United States food vending industry, dropped nearly 19 percent yesterday after the company warned that its third-quarter profit would fall well short of Wall Street estimates. Citing a decline in cheese prices and higher distribution costs, the company said earnings for the quarter that will end on Nov. 30 will total 42 cents to 45 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial had expected the company to earn 58 cents a share. International Multifoods' shares fell $3.75, to $16.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Popular New King Has a Goal: A Modern Morocco
description: King Mohammed VI succeeded to the throne in July when his father, Hassan II, died after reigning for 38 years. As crown prince, Mohammed had been dismissed by some as a bachelor playboy.

title: Harvesting a Bumper Crop of Antiques in Amish Country
description: It was nearly 5 p.m. on a Sunday, and action at the giant antiques markets in Adamstown, Pa., was wrapping up. My wife, Jane, and I were at Weavers, one of the many multiple-dealer markets that dot the villages and country roads north of Amish country in Pennsylvania. We had picked out several things, but if we took the time to pay, we might miss the chance to grab a lamp at Adams Antiques, about five minutes away.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the beginning of an article yesterday about Gov. Jeb Bush's plan for changing race-based college admissions in Florida was omitted from some copies. The article is reprinted today on page A22.

title: Many Riders See Nuances in Bias by Cabbies
description: When Solomon Rasheed dons his white shirt, dark blue tie and dark blue slacks, he assumes a gentlemanly air as a doorman for a tony building on East 81st Street in Manhattan. A coil of good cheer and polite manners, he zestily performs the small things for the building's residents: providing a welcoming voice on many a dull day, doing his utmost to hail a taxi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIPKIN, FRANCES
description: ZIPKIN-Frances. Beloved wife of the late Jack Zipkin. Loving sister and sister-in-law. Dear aunt to her many nieces and nephews, grand nieces and grand nephews and good friends. Funeral services are on Sunday 12 noon Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALLEN, FRANCINE
description: ALLEN-Francine. With a smile on your face and a song in your heart... forever my rose, forever my heart. I miss you Mama.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWIMMER, MOLLIE (NEE APPELSTEIN)
description: SCHWIMMER-Mollie (nee Appelstein). On November 10, 1999. Beloved wife of the late George. Devoted mother of Lois and Marty Eisenberg. Cherished grandmother of Elyse Eisenberg. Graveside services Friday, 1PM at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York.

title: In E-Politics, Clinton's Former Adviser Still Plays by Own Rules
description: One of the best-known veterans of old-fashioned hard-ball politics, Dick Morris, has turned to the Internet and shaken up e-politics.

title: An Unlikely Home For Economic Boom
description: Ten years after the Berlin Wall came down, economic buoyancy seems wildly at odds with eastern Germany's enduring image of shuttered factories and stagnant growth. Eastern joblessness is still 18 percent, twice as high as in the west.

title: Biotech Companies Take On Critics of Gene-Altered Food
description: Worried about growing resistance to genetically modified foods, some of the world's biggest biotechnology companies are mounting a huge lobbying and marketing campaign to counter their critics and combat what they call a rising wave of anti-biotech hysteria.

title: SOLUTIA TO BUY VIANOVA RESINS FOR $640 MILLION
description: Solutia Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the German chemical company Vianova Resins for about $640 million. Solutia, a chemical company that was spun off from the Monsanto Company in 1997, said the acquisition would more than double its sales in Europe. Vianova, formerly owned by Hoechst A.G., produces resins and additives for coatings and technical applications. The company was acquired from Morgan Grenfell Private Equity Ltd., part of Deutsche Bank A.G. Solutia, based in St. Louis, plans to combine its existing coatings performance materials business with Vianova. The transaction is expected to be completed later this year, subject to European Union approval and agreements with minority shareholders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, RABBI JOSEPH
description: GOLDBERG-Rabbi Joseph. Lincoln Square Synagogue records with sorrow the passing of Rabbi Joseph Goldberg, beloved father of our devoted member, Batya Goffin and beloved father-in-law of our Cantor, Sherwood Goffin. A gentle man of Jewish scholarship and knowledge. May the families be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Adam Mintz, Rabbi Shlomo Riskin, Founding Rabbi Herschel Cohen, Assoc. Rabbi Ken Cappell, President

title: Port Authority Chairman Will Skip Senate Race
description: The chairman of the Port Authority, Lewis M. Eisenberg, announced today that he would not run for the United States Senate from New Jersey next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNITZER, JESHAIA
description: SCHNITZER-Jeshaia., Rabbi, of Montclair, on Thursday, November 11, 1999. Distinguished leader of the Jewish community for over half a century. Beloved husband of the late Hilde Maier Schnitzer. Cherished father of Rabbi Jonathan A. and Beverly Schnitzer of Rockville, Maryland, and Lisa J. and Rabbi Richard Plavin of Manchester, Connecticut. Adored ''Opa'' of Aviva (Plavin) and Cory Lebson, Ariel and Ilana Plavin, Shira and David Schnitzer. Dear brother of Charles Schnitzer, Rose Harad, Claire Fleisher and Selma Winson. Funeral services conducted at noon on Friday, November 12, 1999, at Congregation Shomrei Emunah, 67 Park Street, Montclair, New Jersey. Interment at Menorah Cemetery, Delawanna, New Jersey.

title: Driving and Talking Do Mix
description: Check out that guy in the car that's weaving wildly. With a phone glued to his ear, he seems like a prime example of why drivers should be banned from using cellular telephones. Indeed, from Victoria, Australia, to Brooklyn, Ohio, legislatures and local governments have decided that driving and talking on the phone are not to be done at the same time. In New York City, a decree of this sort applies to cabbies. In England, Singapore and Brazil, drivers must use hands-free attachments on their phones. New York, Nevada and Maryland have recently considered bans.

title: BRAZILIAN INFLATIONARY PRESSURE
description: Brazil's benchmark inflation rate climbed 1.2 percent in October, its largest increase in more than three years, as retailers took advantage of a small advance in economic activity to pass on price increases to consumers. Fears about inflation, now expected to end 1999 at 8.8 percent, contributed to the central bank's decision late on Wednesday to halt a succession of interest-rate reductions that have put the main lending rate at 19 percent.

title: KOREAN RATING IS UPGRADED
description: Standard & Poor's raised South Korea's sovereign rating to BBB from the lowest investment grade of BBB-. The agency also upgraded South Korea's long-term foreign currency rating to A from A-. S.& P. said the South Korean economy was recovering briskly enough to absorb a current round of corporate restructuring, while the possibility of another exchange crisis was low because of sufficient foreign currency reserves of $67 billion.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about newspapers' latest performance as reported by the Audit Bureau of Circulations misstated the daily figure for USA Today. Its average circulation Monday through Friday is 1,758,447; the Monday-through-Thursday number is 1,671,539.

title: Developer Raises Stake in Mall of America
description: The Simon Property Group said this week it had raised its stake in the biggest United States shopping mall, the Mall of America, outside Minneapolis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEE, TIMOTHY S., M.D.
description: GEE-Timothy S., M.D.. He was our good and compassionate friend and doctor-for our daughter, Lauri; for our dear friend, Herman Kannatt, and as chairman of the Medical Board of our Foundation. Tim, you will be missed. To Carol and family, we mourn our mutual loss and express our deep sympathy. Evelyn and Herb Strauss and all of the Lauri Strauss Leukemia Foundation Members

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HAAS, RHODA WILLNER
description: HAAS-Rhoda Willner. We think of you always with love. Stella, Abbie, Jane and Jay

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, FRED
description: STEIN-Fred., on November 10, 1999. Beloved husband of Arlene. Dear father of Ivi. Brother of Robert and George. Funeral Services I.J. Morris, Inc., 1895 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, Friday, 10 AM. Interment at New Montefiore Cemetery. Family requests donations to be made in memory of Fred to Cancer Research and Treatment Fund Inc., 1440 York Ave., NYC 10021.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Come, climb into the grave. See what the robbers have done.''

title: Mannesmann Arms Itself Against Any Offer by Vodafone
description: Mannesmann A.G. is shoring up its defenses as it prepares for what could be a takeover battle on a huge scale with Vodafone Airtouch P.L.C. of Britain.

title: Lead Detected In Rifle Range Brings Closing Of L.I. School
description: For 37 years, without creating much of a stir, the school district here operated a shooting range in the Marion Street Elementary School for its high school rifle teams. But as gun violence broke out in schools around the country in recent months, the range began to concern some parents.

title: Small Firm Offers to Process Tax Returns Free on Internet
description: A small Texas money management company says it will let anyone prepare and file an income tax return free next year on its Web site, no matter how much the filer makes or how complicated the tax return.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about efforts to revitalize Hartford misidentified the owner of the Civic Center Mall. The owner is Aetna; the Northland Investment Corporation has signed a memo of intent to buy the mall.

title: Accounts
description: * Concentric Network Corp., San Jose, Calif., a provider of electronic-commerce services, to Gardner, Geary, Coll & Young Advertising, San Francisco, to handle its account, which had been handled on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $25 million.

title: Judge Overturns Verdict in 1980 Murder
description: When Carlos Figueroa was questioned by the police after the killing of a gas station owner in the Bronx in 1980, he admitted that he was at the scene that night, but he said that as soon as he heard gunfire, he darted out and hid.

title: Kittles Urged to Speed Up Return, but He's Not Rushing
description: Kerry Kittles was speaking to reporters today, providing inconclusive answers to questions about his status, when Jayson Williams walked by and said, ''He's playing.'' Kittles chuckled as if it were a joke, but Williams was not laughing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHMAN, NAOMI, DR.
description: FISCHMAN-Naomi, Dr.. Wife of the late Lewis. Beloved mother of Dr. Ronald (Cora) Fischman and Dr. Daniel (Marlene) Fischman. Dear sister of Zeev Lurie. Also survived by four grandchildren: Michael, Leslie, Nicole, and Leah. She received her Ph.D. from New York University and taught Hebraic Studies at both Hofstra University and C.W. Post College. Religious services will be held at 1PM Friday (today) in Groman-Eden Chapel with internment to follow in Eden Memorial Park, Mission Hills, California. For information contact Groman-Eden Mortuary Directors, 800-522-4875.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHNEID, HOWARD
description: SCHNEID-Howard. November 12, 1997. We're finally being painted. Love forever, Anita and Flam

title: Berlin's Brief Dawn, Before the Darkness
description: ''BERLIN METROPOLIS: Jews and the New Culture, 1890-1918,'' a show that opens on Sunday at the Jewish Museum, should be a required course in every New Yorker's education. Without an appreciation of the German capital's past, our city's history remains incomprehensible. Our glass skyscrapers, our cosmopolitan tradition, our appetite for novelty and change spring partly from seeds that were planted a century ago in Berlin's swampy soil. Civics class doesn't come better than this deeply intelligent homage to our cultural forebears.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Parental Leave: Who Gains?
description: To the Editor:

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Channel Surfing Across the Seas

title: Offense Awaits Elias and Morrison
description: Patrik Elias and Brendan Morrison have distinctly different views of what it means to miss all of training camp with the Devils. Elias believes he missed nothing, while Morrison says he is still trying to catch up.

title: The Big D Now Means Deterioration
description: The Dallas Cowboys will forever remember this month as the one in which their slow decline into mediocrity began gathering steam, and now resembles a boulder rolling down a mountain slope. This proud organization is in trouble. Worse. The Cowboys, as we know them, are dead.

title: Japan Moves To Stimulate Its Economy
description: Fearful that Japan's tenuous recovery from its worst postwar recession could collapse in an election year, the government announced a package of economic stimulants today worth 18 trillion yen, or about $171.4 billion, almost twice the amount that had been expected just a few weeks ago.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A Departure For Ang Lee

title: AIRLINE'S HEAD IS ARRESTED
description: Prosecutors arrested the head of South Korea's flagship airline on charges of evading taxes and embezzling company funds. Cho Yang Ho, the chairman of Korean Air Lines, has been charged with evading 62.9 billion won, or $53 million, in taxes from a 109.5 billion won rebate he received from a United States engine company between January 1994 and December last year. The prosecution is also tracing the bank accounts of Mr. Cho and his company to determine whether portions of a purported slush fund were spent for lobbying.

title: Nasdaq Continues Its Run Of Record-Setting Sessions
description: The Nasdaq composite index rose to its ninth record in 10 sessions amid optimism that Dell Computer would beat forecasts when it reported profits after exchanges closed.

title: East Meets West Where Music Meets Poetry
description: There was some linguistic cross-dressing in the concert the Washington Square Contemporary Music Society gave on Tuesday night at Merkin Hall. Most of the music was American; most of the words were not -- except in the one piece not by an American, ''Whitman Settings,'' by the British composer Oliver Knussen. The two Americans providing vocal music, David McMullin and Morris Rosenzweig, went a long way off, choosing texts from the eighth-century Chinese poet Li Bai (or Li Po) and from medieval Hebrew poets, respectively.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOMNITZ, ERIC
description: LOMNITZ-Eric.All his friends and associates in the AIMCOR companies in the U.S., U.K., Luxembourg, Holland and Germany for whom he was a founding father of our current businesses, will miss his humor, enthusiasm, advice and example. So much of what we are today as individuals and as a business we have learned from Eric. We share the grief of his family as our own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLITZ, SIDNEY
description: BLITZ-Sidney. Former principal of P.S. 158 in Manhattan, died on November 4, 1999 in Somerset, NJ. Mr. Blitz served for over 40 years in the New York City school system as a teacher of merchandising at Thomas Jefferson High School, assistant principal and principal. He was the co-founder of the well-known Altman-Blitz course for aspiring school secretaries and teachers, an adjunct professor of Business at Long Island University, and the author of several articles on merchandising. He received his B.S. from CCNY and his M.A. from NYU. His wife of 58 years, Mildred Algaze Blitz, died on October 19, 1999. They are survived by their son Mark of Upland, CA, daughter Andrea Rosenberg of East Brunswick, NJ, and five grandchildren.

title: And Mom, Another Thing: When Will You Grow Up?
description: The mother and daughter in Mona Simpson's widely praised novel ''Anywhere but Here'' spend an awful lot of time driving around and going out for conciliatory ice cream cones after they fight. That would not bode well for a movie version, but the film happens to have a knowing, well-distilled screenplay by Alvin Sargent and the same incisive, affectionate direction that Wayne Wang brought to ''The Joy Luck Club.'' Mr. Wang once again works splendidly with actresses, and boy, does he have a lot to work with this time.

title: Foodborne Illness Sickens Eight
description: An outbreak of the foodborne illness listeriosis has sickened eight people in southern Westchester County in recent weeks, health officials said yesterday. Two of the people died, but they both had many other medical problems and officials do not know to what extent listeriosis caused their deaths.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Novartis Plans No Bid for American Home
description: The chairman of Novartis A.G. of Switzerland said today that he now had no intention of making a hostile bid for American Home Products, but added that the fate of the New Jersey company was far from decided despite its pending agreement to merge with Warner-Lambert.

title: Visiting Nature at Her Pied-a-Terre
description: Nature and the city are not two things that usually go together. But one place they intersect -- and with a vengeance -- is the Greenbelt. A 2,800-acre swath of natural parkland preserved in the middle of Staten Island, the Greenbelt is crisscrossed by 32 miles of little-known hiking trails. Despite the nearness of city streets, it is possible, by sticking to the trails, to walk in the Greenbelt for hours without seeing another human being.

title: Jets' Lucas Deals With Slight Case Of Nerves
description: The Jets' Ray Lucas has struggled the last few days to keep his composure: he will be starting at quarterback before a national television audience Monday night.

title: Pakistan on Trial
description: After seizing power in Pakistan last month, Gen. Pervez Musharraf has been disturbingly slow in presenting his timetable for a restoration of democracy. This week his military government took an alarming step backward by filing charges of treason, hijacking and kidnapping against the ousted prime minister, Nawaz Sharif. A conviction could lead to a death sentence. Executing Mr. Sharif would undercut the chances for progress in Pakistan and poison relations with the United States and other countries.

title: WORLD BRIEFINGS
description: EUROPE

title: INSIDE ART
description: A New Museum For Modernism

title: Pak, Unruffled, Takes 1-Shot Lead
description: Important tournaments often bring out the best in Se Ri Pak. And today at the PageNet Tour Championship, in an elite 30-player field featuring the year's top money winners, Pak picked another timely occasion to play superb golf.

title: Felix Galimir, 89, a Violinist Who Taught Generations, Dies
description: Felix Galimir, a violinist who was one of the last links to the vital musical world of prewar Vienna, and a chamber music player who was revered by several generations of instrumentalists as a demanding and inspiring coach, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89 and had continued to teach and advise young musicians until his health began to fail in recent weeks.

title: End Talk of Conversion
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft and Tandy in Internet Agreement
description: The Microsoft Corporation announced a strategic agreement with the Tandy Corporation yesterday to spotlight Microsoft's Internet products and services within Tandy's Radio Shack stores.

title: April No Longer: UConn Opens With a Thud
description: Jim Calhoun's face was crimson as he bolted out of his seat to scream at a player last night. The honeymoon has ended for the defending national champion Connecticut Huskies on the first night of the new season about as abruptly as if the bride had woken up and smacked the groom across the face.

title: Bill Owens -- 'Suburban Folk Tales'
description: Howard Greenberg Gallery

title: Quiz All Candidates On Foreign Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Terror Hovers Above a Circle That Binds Life to Death
description: A man, head shaved and body chalk-white, lies on a sand-filled stage with arms and legs raised. He is both infant open to discovery and expiring figure. Ushio Amagatsu, director and choreographer of the Japanese Butoh dance troupe Sankai Juku, uses this double image to distill his cyclical theme in ''Hiyomeki (Within a Gentle Vibration and Agitation).''

title: At Least 14 Die as Apartment Building Collapses in Italy
description: At least 14 people died early today when a six-story apartment building collapsed in Foggia, a city in southern Italy. The toll was expected to rise sharply as rescue workers continued to dig with shovels and their bare hands in the search for survivors.

title: A Slightly Kinder and Gentler Era for Hostile Takeovers
description: Could it be that hostile takeovers have become just a little friendlier?

title: Hesitating Beside A Shallow Labor Pool; Will Fed Take Plunge and Raise Rates?
description: Frank Ciotola, a restaurant owner in Columbus, Ohio, is paying dishwashers $8 an hour nowadays, up from $6 two years ago. And he is spending more money placing help-wanted ads than he is promoting the restaurant itself.

title: Strip Mining and Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROEHRICH, JOHN DENNIS
description: ROEHRICH-John Dennis. On November 6, 1999. Partner of Wheels Sattelite, Inc. A Memorial Mass will be offered Saturday, November 13th, 1PM at Saint Francis of Assisi R.C. Church, 135 W. 31 St, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: 'Fin de Siecle Rituals' -- Contemporary Taiwanese Art
description: Taipei Gallery

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: U.S. Will Play Iran in World Cup Rematch
description: In its first game of the new year, the American soccer team will play the Iranian national team at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif., Sunday, Jan. 16, the United States Soccer Federation announced yesterday.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 9.

title: Posters Too Nice for the Dorm Room
description: CAR posters are a cheap decorating mainstay of bachelor apartments, like shelves on concrete blocks. But their predecessors -- original automotive posters from the early 1900's -- can be worth lots of money. An auction of 680 rare posters in New York City on Sunday will include about 50 vintage car posters, all of them rare survivors.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Is it possible for the new Russian Tea Room to be louder, gaudier and redder than the old? The answer is yes, yes and yes, with an exclamation point.

title: Election Panel Clears a Use Of Web Sites By Campaigns
description: Federal regulators said on Wednesday that Web sites created by independent supporters of a candidate do not count as campaign contributions, partly clearing a murky area of election law.

title: In I.R.A. Message for Negotiators, a Hint That Accord Isn't Dead
description: The Irish Republican Army, having submitted a long-awaited message to peace negotiators, has raised a slim, last-minute hope that former Senator George J. Mitchell's rescue mission might still succeed in moving forward the stalemated Northern Ireland peace agreement.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Garnett Wins Last-Minute Duel With Camby
description: For most of the night, the Knicks' Marcus Camby and the Timberwolves' Kevin Garnett had kept their distance. But in the crush of the moment, they were one-on-one, two young stars so spindly and sturdy, you could run a flag up their frames, two neophytes under pressure so intense one was bound to emerge with a defining moment.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GARSON, EUGENE
description: GARSON-Eugene. 11/12/98 An everlasting bond of love and devotion can never be broken. Gloria

title: Education Deal a Victory In Politics, If Not Yet Schools
description: President Clinton and Republicans in Congress today hailed their compromise on Mr. Clinton's program to hire 100,000 teachers and reduce class sizes in public schools. But it remains to be seen how much their political victory will benefit the children it aims to help.

title: Album of the Week
description: HOBEX: ''Back in the 90's'' (Slash/London Records). Few listeners will first hear Hobex the way this critic did: in an enjoyably squalid bar in Columbia, S.C., in 1996, on the rowdy college circuit below the Mason-Dixon line. Playing to drunken fraternity boys, the Chapel Hill-based trio of alternative-pop veterans delivered oven-fried soul far better than it should have been. Since that night I've wondered whether a band so fine in its context could go beyond it.

title: INSIDE
description: Dozens Feared Dead in Italy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALIMIR, FELIX
description: GALIMIR-Felix. On November 10, 1999. Violinist and teacher. Beloved husband of the late Suzanne. Brother of the late Marguerite, Renee and Adrienne. Cherished uncle of Elsa Miller, Richard Hurtig, Naomi Krasner, Viola Morse & the late Vien Krasner. Services Friday, 10AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Encourage Tipping
description: To the Editor:

title: Pirates Recruit Top Prospects
description: It took Seton Hall's basketball coach, Tommy Amaker, only to the midpoint of his opening statement to slow the expectations that were surrounding this day, noting that perspective will be a word that needs to be used around his team for the next few years. With that, he announced yesterday that the Pirates had received official letters of intent from what has been heralded as the best recruiting class in the nation. Seton Hall got written commitments from Andre Barrett, Eddie Griffin, Marcus Tony-El and Damion Fray on Wednesday, the first day of the early signing period.

title: CELLTECH MAKES PURCHASE
description: Britain's largest biotechnology company, Celltech Chiroscience, will acquire Medeva, another British pharmaceutical concern, for $:658 million, or $1.07 billion, hoping to leverage its research and development operations with Medeva's profitable line of drugs. Analysts said the purchase gives Celltech, which does not now have any drugs on the market, a stable of drugs and a sales force to sell its own drugs when they are ready. Celltech will begin selling Chirocaine, an anesthetic, in the United States next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACIFICO, RICHARD GLENN
description: PACIFICO-Richard Glenn. On November 9, 1999.
