He is survived by his wife Natalie, children Stephanie and Richard Jr., parents Salvatore and Lydia Miranda, sisters and brothers Grisel, Lynn and Duff, grandmother Ramona and nieces, nephews, cousins, aunts and uncles. Friends may call on Friday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Forest Park Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills. Services will be Saturday, 11 AM, at the chapel.

title: FOOD RETAILER TO SELL STORES
description: Acknowledging that its 1998 acquisition of Kwik Save stores had been disappointing, Somerfield, a major British food retailer, announced that it would sell much of its Kwik Save division along with its biggest supermarket outlets. The move reflected competitive turmoil caused by price-cutting after Wal-Mart Stores' acquisition in June of the Asda Group, Britain's No. 3 food retailer. Somerfield's stock, the most sluggish in the European food retailing business, fell 10 percent and hit a record low. Alan Cowell

title: A Witness to History, From War's Generals To Poverty's Victims
description: Best known for his photograph of Gen. Douglas MacArthur confidently treading water in the Philippines in 1945, Carl Mydans has been a storyteller with a camera since the 1920's. At 92, Mr. Mydans has slowed down. Instead of traveling almost every day from his home in Larchmont, N.Y., to his office at Time magazine, where he is a contract photographer, he now does it about twice a week. But he has never stopped taking photographs. Even when he doesn't have a camera with him, he says, he is taking photographs in his mind.

title: An Advancing Cuisine
description: Korean restaurants, largely concentrated in Korean neighborhoods near the garment district and in Flushing, Queens, are steadily reaching out to a new audience of New Yorkers, who are slowly discovering this bold, healthful cuisine. Here are a dozen worth trying. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHTOB, ABRAHAM
description: SHTOB-Abraham. The entire National Lawyers Guild family embrace our Dotty, her children Terry and Eric, grandchildren Danny and Nicky, and great grandson Hugo as they mourn Abe, labor educator and life-long fighter for social justice. Dotty derives so much of her devotion to us from her partnership with Abe. Heartfelt love.

title: Just Enough Color in a World of White
description: The watercolors of Paul Cezanne rank high among the wonders of Western European art. For this reason, the chance of seeing 46 of them at the Acquavella Galleries is not to be missed.

title: Sports of The Times; Krzyzewski's Logic Runs Into Realities
description: THE new kid running the famously erudite Duke offense has sizzle to his game and a mouth to match, and a heart that has guided him into a soup kitchen to volunteer. The third coming of Jason Williams sounds something like an amalgam of the previous two.

title: No Painless Execution
description: To the Editor:

title: Rubin Is Named to Ford's Board
description: The Ford Motor Company appointed Robert E. Rubin, the former treasury secretary, to its board as the automaker tries to improve its credibility with investors.

title: As Braves Learn, Price for Griffey Is Steep
description: One insight into why Ken Griffey Jr. was not traded during the general managers' meetings in Dana Point, Calif., this week comes from examining the asking price: the Seattle Mariners, the moving party, asked the Atlanta Braves for Andruw Jones, Kevin Millwood and Ryan Klesko, an executive of another club said yesterday. He said the Braves, who had been the favorite before the meetings to win the Griffey sweepstakes, replied with a polite no, thank you, pronounced themselves out of it and went about their business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOWIE, LESTER
description: BOWIE-Lester. The staff and board of the Brooklyn Academy of Music mourn the passing of Lester Bowie, a great musician, who gave so much to his community. We extend sympathy to his wife, Deborah, a BAM employee, and her family. Karen Hopkins President Joseph Mellilo Executive Producer

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Collecting; The Real Chitty: It Does Bang Bang
description: In 1921, Count Elliot Zborowski, a wealthy English sportsman, set out to build a fast racecar with a Mercedes chassis that predated World War I, powered by a war-surplus Benz airplane engine. Years later, his creation inspired a whimsical Ian Fleming children's book, ''Chitty Chitty Bang Bang,'' and a popular movie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCADAMS, JOHN V. SR.
description: McADAMS-John V. Sr.., 82, of Kirland Village, Bethlehem, PA. formerly of Rancho Sante Fe, CA., and Monclair, NJ on Wednesday, November 10, 1999. A member of the Essex Fells Country Club, New Jersey, the Players Club of New York, The Bankers Club of New York and also former member of the Mary Star of the Sea Church, La Jolla, Ca.A mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at Saturday, November 20, 1999 at 10:30AM at imaculate Conception Church, Montclair, NJ. No calling hours. Memorial contributions to Alzheimers Disease & Related Disorders 325 Chestnut St., Phil, PA Survivors are wife Anne McAdams of CA., sons John V. Jr. of Pittson, NJ, Michael X. of Sommertown, TN., Bruce E. of Park City Utah, Scott T. of Melbourne Florida, Gregg of Waretown, NJ. Helen Radcliffe of Bath, PA.

title: U.N. Tribunal Wrong to Free Top Suspect, Rwanda Says
description: The decision of a United Nations tribunal to drop its case against a former official in Rwanda accused of helping to organize the 1994 genocide there has angered the Rwandan government and threatens to unravel efforts to bring the most prominent suspects to justice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERRY, PRINCE, ARLENE
description: PERRY-PRINCE-Arlene. A beautiful loving and giving lady has left us. We are better for her grace and poorer by her passing. Goodbye, Arlene Iris. The Orenstein, Goeringer and Spokojny Families

title: Bob Beamon Recounts Career
description: Sometimes it seems as if life began for Bob Beamon on Oct. 18, 1968, the day of his world record-shattering long jump of 29 feet 2 inches at the Mexico City Olympics. Before that, few knew the athlete from Jamaica High School in Queens, whose world record stood for 23 years.

title: EX-INDONESIA CHIEF GETS PARDON VOW
description: The new president of Indonesia said here tonight that he had decided to pardon the nation's former leader, President Suharto, if Mr. Suharto is convicted of crimes as a result of an investigation into whether he and his family stole billions of dollars from the government.

title: Rowland Proposes Stadium Two Miles Outside Hartford
description: For six years, state officials have been pushing for a downtown football stadium. But today, Gov. John G. Rowland announced a proposal to build the stadium about two miles away in East Hartford, on a former airfield that United Technologies Corporation has offered to donate.

title: The Case for 'the General'
description: George W. Bush has rightly been given a pass for failing a pop quiz on the names of world leaders, a piece of journalistic gaming that would have stumped most full-time pundits. Instead, Vice President Al Gore and others have said Mr. Bush's real error was his suggestion that ''the general'' now leading Pakistan, Pervez Musharraf, might be better for stability in the Indian subcontinent and its neighboring region than was the corrupt and incompetent civilian government that the military ran off.

title: Mexican Airline Accused of Lapses in Upkeep
description: Mexico's third-largest airline, already facing financial and legal pressure, is now defending itself against assertions by a labor union that its maintenance procedures are dangerous and deceptive.

title: 4-Wheeled Guests At the Waldorf
description: ARE motorcars began to find their way off the street and into elegant hotels in the early 1900's, when the makers of Duesenbergs, Packards and Rolls-Royces unveiled new models in elegant ballrooms. On Nov. 27, a modern version of those auto showcases will take place at the Auto Salon and Auction at the Waldorf-Astoria in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONAS, PAULINE LEVY
description: MONAS - Pauline Levy. The Board, staff and volunteers of DOROT, Inc. extend deepest condolences to our longtime supporter and Honorary Board member, Martin Monas, on the passing of his beloved mother. Her belief in community involvement and devotion to family were evident in Mr. Monas' dedication of gifts to DOROT in honor and memory of family members, including ''Sonny's Garden'' in memory of his uncle, Solomon Levy, o.b.m. We mourn the loss of Mrs. Monas, a precious and inspiring presence, and express heartfelt sympathy to her son, Martin; her daughter, Barbara Herman; her brother, Abe Levy; her sisters, Frieda Spiegel and Edna Ginsberg; her grandchildren, Shari and Lowell Frey and Barry Herman; and her greatgrandchildren, Allison and Sam Frey. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Anne E. Heyman, President Renee Adler Ascher, Board Chair Marilyn Katz, Hon. Board Chair Vivian Fenster Ehrlich, Exec Dir

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADEN, RENEE F. HALIFAX
description: RADEN-Renee F. Halifax., NS, Canada. 80. Died October 15, after a long illness. Daughter of Meyer and Minnie Freedman, Albany. Survivers: son, Joel (Odette) Raden, NYC; daughter, Lesley (Steven) Brown, Halifax. Also, sister, Estelle Freedman, Albany; brother, William (Susan) Freedman, Albany; and 5 grandchildren. Memorial services were held in Halifax.

title: U.S. Troops in Haiti
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONIAK, MICHAEL R., DDS
description: KONIAK-Michael R., DDS., of Middletown, NY died November 10, 1999. He was fifty-three years old. Dr. Koniak was a dentist in Orange County for twenty-five years maintaining an office in Goshen, NY for most of such time. Locally he was an active member of Rotary and a director of ARC of Orange County. He is survived by his two sons, Aaron of Reno, Nevada and Ian of Los Angeles, California and his sister and brother-in-law Gail K. Posnack and Stan Posnack of Airmont, New York. Funeral services will be held Friday, November 12th at 11 AM at Temple Beth-El, Spring Valley, NY with burial to follow services. A period of mourning will be held at the home of Dr. Koniak's sister, Gail Posnack in Airmont, NY until Tuesday, November 16th. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to ARC of Orange County. For further information, call Hellman Memorial Chapels, 914-356-8600.

title: In Presidents, Character Matters
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMABILE, ALIDA MARIA
description: AMABILE-Alida Maria., 48, of Santa Monica, CA. November 8, 1999. Beloved sister of Maryellen and husband John D. Ryan, cherished aunt of Christine Marie and Andrew John Ryan. She was predeceased by her parents Arthur V. and Marie L. Amabile. Resting, Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY where family will receive friends Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 11 A.M., Holy Innocents Church. Entombment Ferncliff Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEALY, HENRY THORNTON
description: SEALY-Henry Thornton. On November 10, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Nellie Mayer. Devoted father, grandfather, great-grandfather. Burial private at Cedar Lawn Cemetery, East Hampton, New York, Saturday November 13.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Shaky Congo Peace Pact Grows More So
description: The peace deal in Congo, never hardy even at birth, is not dead yet, or so almost everyone involved says. But it has been badly bruised in recent days, and both the government of President Laurent Kabila and the rebels say it will not take much for the fighting to flare once again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIPPS, SAMUEL (AKA SEYMOUR M.)
description: RIPPS-Samuel (aka Seymour M.). Passed away on Wednesday, November 10 in St Petersburg Fl. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. Interment at Mt Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, N.Y. on Sunday, November 14 at 11 A.M. Under the direction of Temple Memorial, Flushing, N.Y.

title: Two Kinds Of Veterans, And Wars
description: ON Veterans Day, a veteran glances back.

title: Engines Switched Off On EgyptAir Flight
description: Information from the flight data recorder of the EgyptAir flight that crashed showed that the plane's wild final maneuvers included a free fall and a shutdown of both engines, the chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board said.

title: Excerpts From Speech on Security Concerns in Asia
description: Following are excerpts from the prepared text of a speech that Steve Forbes made yesterday on United States policy toward China. The address was given at the Richard Nixon Library in Yorba Linda, Calif.

title: Run Defense Might Suffer if Widmer Cannot Extend His Streak
description: As they prepared to face one of the National Football League's most explosive offenses, the Giants practiced today without one of their principal defenders against the run. Corey Widmer, the middle linebacker, did not participate in the team's final extended workout because of severe back spasms.

title: All Groups in Indonesian Province See Referendum as Secession : In Aceh, It's Independence or Nothing
description: BANDA ACEH, Indonesia  The rallying cry of "Referendum!" is painted in block letters throughout this restive province of rice paddies, coffee plantations and overt poverty. But for the leaders of the movement calling for a vote on Aceh's future, "referendum" means secession from Indonesia.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's just cool. ''

title: Robert Kramer, 60, a Director Of Films With a Political Edge
description: Robert Kramer, an American movie director whose portrayals of militants caught up in the antiwar movement of the late 1960's and early 1970's earned him a prominent place in modern political cinema, died on Wednesday in a hospital in Rouen, France, at the age of 60. Friends gave the cause of death as meningitis.

title: Budget Fight Pits Business Against Environmentalists
description: The most explosive issues remaining in the budget battle are legislative land mines pitting business interests against environmental groups.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the number of bodies found by war crimes investigators in Kosovo referred incorrectly to a State Department briefing on April 19. The department did not say that up to 500,000 Kosovar Albanians were missing and feared dead. Its spokesman, James P. Rubin, said that 100,000 men were unaccounted for and that ''based on past practice, it is chilling to think where those 100,000 men are.'' He said, ''We know that civilian casualties are the objective of President Milosevic's policy.''

title: Mets Are Preparing Their Best Pitch for Griffey
description: The Yankees have all but completed a new contract with Jim Leyritz, while the Mets have made a small trade and continue to explore the long-shot possibility of trading for Seattle's Ken Griffey Jr.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Senate confirmation of Faith Hochberg of New Jersey to be a federal judge misstated her position. She is the current United States attorney for New Jersey, not a former one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEE, TIMOTHY, M.D.
description: GEE-Timothy, M.D. The SASS Foundation extends its deep sympathy for the loss of a dear friend, colleague and board member. His contributions and presence will be missed, but his fight against cancer will long live on in all of us. Francis P. Arena, M.D. Barbara and Martin Sass

title: PLACER DOME TO BUY 50% OF CHILEAN COPPER MINE
description: Placer Dome Inc. agreed to buy the 50 percent of a Chilean copper mine that it does not own from its Finnish venture partner Outokumpu Oy for $251 million, its first acquisition under its new president, Jay Taylor. The agreement comes nine months after the Canadian miner Aur Resources Inc. withdrew its $265 million bid for the stake, partly because of low copper prices. Copper has since risen about 19 percent. Placer Dome, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, is the world's No. 5 gold producer. It said that taking control of the Zaldivar mine did not mean it was shifting its focus from gold. Mr. Taylor said last month that the company was ready to resume making acquisitions after two big purchases in the United States and South Africa earlier this year.

title: Governor, Executioner
description: To the Editor:

title: Mental-Health Bias
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NBTY INC., Bohemia, N.Y., which makes and sells nutritional supplements, agreed to buy closely held Nutrition Warehouse Inc., Mineola, N.Y., and its affiliates for about $29.5 million in cash and stock.

title: TODAY'S KEY GAMES
description: NO. 13 MIAMI (5-3) at NO. 4 VIRGINIA TECH (8-0)

title: Ferrari in Deal to Buy Rest of Maserati
description: Ferrari S.p.A. said today that it had acquired the 50 percent of Maserati that it did not already own, as Ferrari, Italy's top maker of high-performance sports cars, prepares for Maserati's return to the United States market in the coming year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMMUL, OSCAR ROGER
description: SAMMUL-Oscar Roger, from a heart attack in his Alexandria, Virginia, apartment on October 13, 1999, the eve of his 86th birthday. A native New Yorker, Mr. Sammul obtained a Bachelor's Degree in chemistry from C.C.N.Y. and a Master's Degree in education from Columbia University. He then worked for the New York City Board of Education until World War II interrupted his employment. He served with distinction as an Army captain in the European theatre until war's end in 1945. After the war, he returned to his major field, teaching science at Thiel College in Greenville, PA. He next accepted a research position with the old Army Chemical Corps in Denver, CO. This led to his final career position as a pharmaceutical chemist with the Food and Drug Administration in Washington, DC, where he retired with a commendable record. He remained in the northern Virginia area and gave a greater emphasis to his hobbies and avocations. Favorites included gardening, antiques, the stock market and keeping abreast of developments in scientific fields of interest. Some of these activities were curtailed when his wife, Phyllis, died in 1992. Oscar Roger Sammul leaves behind as closest kin his beloved cousin, Dorothy Jeisi, of Whiting, NJ. Family members, colleagues and friends already miss Oscar, but take comfort in cherished memories of a quiet, gentle, unobtrusive and modest man, much admired and respected in both professional and social circles.

title: Pokemon Is Catching, and Keeping, Them
description: Anthony Ruiz was celebrating his 8th birthday at the Cineplex Beverly Center here, joining the hundreds of children and parents taking in ''Pokemon: The First Movie'' on four screens at the center, one of 3,000 theaters that presented this animated film on its opening day, Wednesday, and haven't had a quiet moment since.

title: 'A Sand County Almanac' at 50
description: Fifty years ago, Aldo Leopold's ecological testament, ''A Sand County Almanac,'' was published. It was a posthumous book, appearing a year and a half after Leopold died of a heart attack in April 1948 at the age of 61. A graduate of the Yale Forestry School and a 17-year veteran of the United States Forest Service, Leopold had his greatest influence, during his lifetime, as a professor of game management at the University of Wisconsin. But it is the ''Almanac,'' his meditations on a Wisconsin River farm and an unequivocal statement of conscience, that will carry his influence and his good name down the generations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNCH, R. VINCENT
description: LYNCH-R. Vincent, November 14, 1922 to November 10, 1999. Born in New York, NY; raised in Greenwich, CT. Attended Phillips Exeter Academy. He served in the Pacific on the aircraft carriers U.S.S. Ticonderoga and the U.S.S. Hancock. Upon release from the Navy in 1945 as a decorated Naval Aviator, Mr. Lynch returned to Yale University and graduated in the Class of 1947. Upon graduation, Mr. Lynch was employed by Chance Vought Aircraft of Dallas as a test pilot. In 1974 he started R.V. Lynch and Company, an oil and gas concern. He is survived by a sister, Helen Barrett (Rogie) Dickie of Devon, PA., his brothers David Barrett Lynch of Gladwyn, PA., and William R. Lynch of Greenwich, CT. He had six children: Rose Peabody Lynch, of New York, R. Vincent Lynch Jr., of London, Alexander P. Lynch, of Greenwich, C. Burton Lynch, Peter F. Lynch and Joseph B. O. Lynch, all of Dallas, Texas, along with fourteen grandchildren. The funeral will be in Dallas, on Saturday, November 12.

title: Rocket Attack on U.S. and U.N. Offices in Pakistan Fails
description: Several rockets were fired at American diplomatic and United Nations buildings here today in an apparently coordinated attack, but they missed their targets. One person was reported injured.

title: ANTI-BRITISH PROTEST AT BANK BALI
description: Indonesia's Bank Restructuring Agency has asked Standard Chartered Bank of Britain to recall some of the foreign staff it dispatched to run Bank Bali as some local employees have staged protests accusing the management of arrogance. Standard Chartered began running Bank Bali in July under an agreement to buy a 20 percent stake in the Indonesian commercial bank, which had just been nationalized. The British bank's review of the bank's records helped uncover a financial scandal that helped bring down Indonesia's president.

title: Big Increases In Productivity By Workers
description: The most debated economics issue in America today is whether workers are becoming ever more efficient, thanks to computers and the Internet. And the Labor Department, in the most comprehensive review of the data to date, says there has indeed been an improvement in this decade, mainly in the last four years.

title: When Schoolchildren Take to the Road
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARENWALD, WALTER PHILLIPS
description: ARENWALD-Walter Phillips On November 12, 1999. Beloved husband of Helen, father of Elaine and Joanne, loving father-in-law and grandfather. Funeral services on Sunday, November 14, at 12:15 PM, Waterbury & Kelly, Briarcliff Manor, New York.

title: Christie's Rules Out Joining Mass-Market Web Ventures
description: Christie's said yesterday that it had decided against joining forces with an online giant like eBay or the Walt Disney Company's Go.com to offer its auctions online and that it had merged its six-month-old Internet unit into its marketing department.

title: At First, Nixon Spurned Idea Of a Pardon, Lawyer Says
description: Herbert J. Miller, Richard M. Nixon's criminal defense lawyer, said today that the former president had at first spurned a pardon from President Gerald R. Ford in 1974, saying he wanted to fight any charges that might be brought against him by the Watergate special prosecutor.

title: Is the Dollar Leaving Canada Feeling Drained?; Capital Is Fleeing to the South As U.S. Companies Look North
description: Twenty years ago, when an outside company tried to buy MacMillan Bloedel, British Columbia's largest timber company, the provincial premier reacted angrily, saying: ''B.C. is not for sale.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALIMIR, FELIX
description: GALIMIR-Felix. The Board of Trustees and Staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the passing of Felix Galimir. A musician's musician who appeared on the Carnegie Stage more than a dozen times, he had a central role in the training of generations of some of America's finest musicians. The entire Carnegie Hall family feels his loss. He inspired a legacy that will endure for generations. Isaac Stern, President Sanford I. Weill, Chairman Franz Xaver Ohnesorg, Executive and Artistic Director

title: G.M. to Take Quarterly Charge
description: General Motors, the world's largest automaker, will take a $444 million fourth-quarter charge to reflect the increased retiree pension costs of the contract it reached with the United Automobile Workers in September.

title: Global Trade Harmony? Yeah, Right
description: The World Trade Organization was meant to usher in a glorious new era of global trade harmony, but in the five years since its creation, the trade body increasingly has become more of an international agreement to disagree.

title: On Rudeness, in the Abstract and in the Audience
description: If anything justified Kurt Masur's decision to present five of the ''Messages for the Millennium'' commissioned for this season by the New York Philharmonic in a single program, it was the fact that they were all so different, not only in style but also in the way each chose to grapple with the stated issue. Or chose not to.

title: U.N. Plane With 24 Aboard Crashes in Kosovo
description: A United Nations airplane with 24 people on board crashed today in northern Kosovo during a flight headed here from Rome.

title: Rangers Lose Free-Agent Wing to Bruins and Feel Jilted
description: Joe Murphy, the Rangers hardly knew you.

title: NEFF AGREES TO SELL MACHINERY DIVISION TO NORTRAX
description: The Neff Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its Neff Machinery Inc. unit to Nortrax for about $91 million. Neff Machinery, a construction and equipment dealership business, had 1998 revenue of about $103 million, Neff said. Nortrax is a joint venture formed by the John Deere Construction Equipment Company and Credit Suisse First Boston Equity Partners to run Deere's construction equipment dealers. Neff, a Miami-based equipment rental company, expects to close the sale before the end of the year. It had revenue of $298.5 million in the nine months ended Sept. 30. John Deere Construction is a unit of farm equipment manufacturer Deere & Company, based in Moline, Ill.

title: In Celebration of Viking Ancestors
description: Here's a programming concept that requires a map and a flow chart: Gudmundur Emilsson, an American-trained, Icelandic conductor who recently became the music director of the Baltic Philharmonic in Riga, Latvia, brought a chamber version of his orchestra to the Miller Theater on Wednesday evening, and for the occasion he commissioned new works from half a dozen American and Icelandic composers. The program, which he called ''Voyages,'' was meant to celebrate the 1,000th anniversary of the Viking landing in North America.

title: Despite Warning, Some Cabdrivers Are Snared
description: By the time Mohammed Faruque settled into his cab just after dawn yesterday, the radio of his yellow cab had already started crackling with exchanges of advice: Take extra care today -- pick up anyone flagging down a cab, no matter the color of his skin.

title: A Cold War Turning Point on Tape
description: Until now, there have been only memories of Nikita S. Khrushchev's furious tongue-lashing of the famous Russian poet Andrei Voznesensky during a Kremlin meeting on March 7, 1963. But in a newly uncovered audio tape, the scornful voice of the Soviet leader -- the man who first launched the cultural thaw ending the Stalin era and then tried to crush it -- can be heard in a landmark confrontation that signaled a clampdown on artistic and intellectual freedom.

title: Don't Shoot That Declarer, He's Doing the Best He Can
description: In the Depression years it was common for a husband and wife to play a social game, for a small stake, against a neighboring couple. One such game, indeed, led to the celebrated Bennett murder case, in which a wife shot her husband to death after he failed to make a four spade bid. She was acquitted by an impressionable jury, but had trouble thereafter finding bridge partners.

title: PRESIDENT GETTING BETTER OF BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET
description: As the Congressional session sputters to a close, Republicans are quietly ceding ground to President Clinton in budget talks, determined to avoid even a hint of the kind of ideological conflagration that led to a government shutdown four years ago.

title: New Quake Hits Turkey, Leaving More Than 100 Dead
description: Scores of people were killed Friday night and hundreds more were injured in a strong earthquake that shook northwestern Turkey.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR RISES. The dollar rose against the euro as Germany reported the biggest drop in retail sales in two years. The dollar settled at 1.0313 euro in New York, compared with 1.0413 euro on Thursday.

title: Financial Companies Lead in a Broad Advance of Prices
description: Stocks rose yesterday, led by financial shares including American Express and Citigroup, after a government report on productivity eased investors' concerns that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates for a third time this year when policy makers meet on Tuesday.

title: Tapping Out a Code for Warmly Witty
description: Herbin (Tamango) Van Cayseele is one of the great tap artists performing today, a dancer of astonishing speed and lightness whose feet produce a rippling, richly complex cannonade of tap beats. The surprise of his new show, ''Urban Tap,'' which opened on Thursday night at the Kitchen, is not his dancing but his expertise as a finder of talent and a producer.

title: Vernon de Tar Memorial
description: A memorial service for Vernon de Tar, the organist and choirmaster, will be held tomorrow at the Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue at 10th Street, Greenwich Village, at 4 p.m. Performers will include the Church of the Ascension Choir, conducted by Dennis Keene, and the organists Jon Gillock and Harvey Burgett. Mr. de Tar died on Oct. 7 at the age of 94.

title: Columbine Killers, on Tape, Thanked 2 for Gun
description: In the weeks before the massacre at Columbine High School, the two teenage killers made a videotape in which they chillingly described the act they were about to commit and assured future viewers that they were acting alone and that no one knew what they were planning.

title: Justice in Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: BURNHAM PURSUING 'STRATEGIC ALTERNATIVES'
description: Four months after rejecting a $1.2 billion buyout offer, enduring an 18 percent drop in its stock price since then and reporting third-quarter results below expectations, Burnham Pacific Properties Inc. said yesterday that it was exploring ''a full range of strategic alternatives.'' The San Diego-based company, which is the largest real estate investment trust owning strip shopping center on the West Coast, did not say what the alternatives might be. Burnham owns about 80 properties, mainly in California, with 13 million square feet of space. In July, Burnham Pacific, on the advice of Goldman, Sachs & Company, rejected a buyout offer from the retailer and property investor Jay Schottenstein that valued the company at $13.50 a share, or $1.2 billion.

title: Pak Displays Top Form, Leaving Competition to Play a Weekend of Catch-Up
description: There are 30 players in the PageNet Tour Championship, but Se Ri Pak has been in a class by herself.

title: SIGNPOSTS OF IDENTITY
description: You may be what you wear, but often the clothes are as complex as the person you're revealing (or aspiring to be, or hiding underneath). A special issue of The Times Magazine.

title: CORDANT TECHNOLOGIES SEEKS THE REST OF HOWMET
description: Cordant Technologies offered yesterday to acquire the 15.4 percent of Howmet International Inc. it did not already own for $17 a share, or $261 million. After the announcement of the offer, shares of Howmet rose more than 26 percent, or $3.6875, to $17.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. Howmet has 100 million shares outstanding. Cordant, based in Salt Lake City, makes high-performance fasteners through its Huck International unit and solid propulsion systems through its Thiokol division. Howmet, based in Greenwich, Conn., makes precision castings of super alloy, titanium and aluminum allows for aircraft and industrial gas turbine engines.

title: BRITISH INQUIRY ON PUB DRINKS
description: British drinking establishments may be heading for trouble over soft-drink sales. The Department of Trade and Industry, which rules on antitrust issues, called for an inquiry into bar prices for soft drinks, saying they were more than triple the price in supermarkets. The margin is even greater than that for beer, which costs an average twice as much in pubs as in supermarkets. The department also ordered pub and bar-keepers to make drink costs more visible.

title: Death Toll Rises in Italy
description: With 30 people dead and 27 others missing, rescue workers at a collapsed apartment building in southern Italy continued digging through debris today, in what officials fear may be the worst such accident in 40 years.

title: Bradley and Medicaid
description: To the Editor:

title: Teenager Who Killed Boy Defends Molester as Good 'Role Model'
description: Samuel Manzie, a teenager serving a 70-year sentence for the murder of an 11-year-old boy, appeared in court today to defend the man who pleaded guilty to molesting him before the slaying.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 25 about the transplant of frozen ovarian tissue misstated the occupation of an Arizona woman who underwent it. An annual report newly received from New York Methodist Hospital, in Brooklyn, shows her as a belly dancer, not a ballet dancer; the word was misunderstood by telephone interviewers.

title: Stanford Wins, And a Rematch Is Just a Yawner
description: An apathetic chant went up last night midway through the first half of the most anticipated matchup of the Coaches vs. Cancer Ikon Classic, a short burst of murmuring exhorting the Connecticut men's basketball team. Sure, this was the Huskies versus the Duke Blue Devils, a rematch of the schools involved in an epic national championship game seven months ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIELS, IRWIN H.
description: DANIELS-Irwin H. On November 12, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia, loving father of Arleen D. Auerbach. Dear father-in-law of Robert Auerbach. Cherished grandfather of Steven and Laura. Adoring great-grandfather of Anya and Alex. He will be deeply missed. Service Sunday 11:15am at the Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Suddenly, After 800 Years, Lords Depart With Dignity
description: For more than a century, reform-minded British politicians tried to remove the country's hereditary peers from the House of Lords, an effort so tortuous and ineffectual that, in 1963, Lord Samuel said he felt as if he had spent the previous 50 years watching ''a slow-motion film of a prima ballerina, marked by an exhibition of almost languid deliberation.''

title: Charges Fly in Race at U.N. Hunger Agency
description: The Food and Agriculture Organization, a United Nations agency headquartered in a marble and glass palace commissioned by Mussolini, is not normally the subject of intense discussion outside the building.

title: Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, 87, Is Dead; Horseman From an Aristocratic Family
description: Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, the elegant symbol of the sportsman in high society when he was the impresario of horse racing and the pillar of one of the most aristocratic families in America, died yesterday at his home in Mill Neck, N.Y. He was 87.

title: Sports of The Times; Checkmate In a Squared Circle
description: ON the eve of a big fight, perhaps the last significant heavyweight fight of the millennium, Emanuel Steward, the trainer who put Thomas (Hit Man) Hearns on the map, is in a clinch, simultaneously excited and frustrated. With a victory over Evander Holyfield tonight, his client, Lennox Lewis, the World Boxing Council champion, will become the undisputed heavyweight champion of the world.

title: BRAZIL EUROBOND SALE
description: In a move that will provide the central bank with foreign currency to help prevent a weakening of the real, Brazil's currency, the government sold 600 million euros, or about $620 million, worth of two-year bonds in international markets. Although emerging market debt securities are rallying, the offering is expensive for Brazil. The yield will be 4.5 percentage points higher than comparable securities issued by Germany. Simon Romero

title: What's the Opposite of a Tree? Ask Mensa's Testers
description: There is a special club for those who don't make it into Mensa, the high I.Q. society. It is called Densa (really). And I have discovered a secret route in. Here is the admission test: Your editor asks you to take the Mensa test and to write about it in the newspaper. What do you do? If you agree, you don't have to wait for your Mensa score. You are already a member of the American order of idiots.

title: Gore Goes From Supporting Clinton to Staking Own Claim on Presidency
description: After nearly eight years of touting himself as the most influential vice president in history, Al Gore has apparently had enough: He now thinks that his elected position as second-in-command is secondary to his run for the presidency.

title: Mayan Carving in Brooklyn Thought to Be Stolen Ruin
description: Acting on an anonymous tip, detectives made an unlikely discovery yesterday in the garage of a home in Brooklyn: a 2,000-year-old Mayan carving they believe was looted from a ruin in Guatemala and then illegally carried across the border.

title: Will a New Cab Policy End Bias?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANSELL, EDMONA LYMAN
description: MANSELL-Edmona Lyman, age 70, of Jupiter Island, Fl and East Hampton, NY, died on November 11, 1999. A native of San Francisco, CA, she resided in New York City for many years. She is survived by her husband, Frank L. Mansell; four sons, Robert L. Miller of Los Angeles, CA, Charles B. Miller of Twin Bridges, MT, Christian F. Miller of Hamilton, MT, and Gordon L. Miller of Sante Fe, NM; two daughters, Devon Mansell Laycox of Sherborn, MA, and Jessica Mansell Ambrose of East Hampton, NY; twelve grandchildren; and a sister, Princess Genevieve di San Faustino of San Francisco, CA. A memorial service is planned for Monday, November 15, 1999 at 5 PM at Christ Memorial Chapel, Jupiter Island, FL. Contributions may be made to The Freedom Institute, 515 Madison Avenue, NY, NY 10022.

title: From Shared Experience, An Offer of Comfort; A Support Group Helps to Repair Lives Shattered by Plane Crashes
description: In the days and weeks after Swissair Flight 111 plunged into the frigid waters off Nova Scotia, Michele Librett said she turned to family and friends, neighbors and an airline support team to make it through a period marked by shock and denial, grinding physical pain and the grim sensation that life couldn't possibly go on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, RUTH
description: FRIED-Ruth. Age 69. Of Remsenburg, N.Y. and Boca Raton, FL. On November 11, 1999. In this limited space and at this time, it is impossible to adequately convey our warmth and love for Ruth. Our mother and wife was so many things: a businesswoman; a writer; a political activist; a loving spouce and parent. Ruthie was smart, outspoken and consistently exceptional. No one who met her ever forgot her. Ruth inspired and challenged us to excel in the world, and will continue to do so forever. A rare person, she will truly be missed. The loves of Ruthie's life include daughters Debra and Jacqueline and son Andrew, with devoted husband Alfred atop the list. Six loving grandchildren (Rachel; Alex; Orly; Benjamin; Ethan; Erel), aunt Florence Rogol and brother Eugene Zuch also survive. Services shall be held at Gutterman's Chapel, Boca Raton, FL. at 11AM Sunday, November 14. Memorial contributions may be made to the Washington Institute for Jewish Leadership and Values, 6101 Montrose Road, Rockville, MD. 20852. Telephone 301-770-5070.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLISH, SYLVESTER
description: BLISH-Sylvester, age 82, died Thursday, November 11, 1999 at Stamford Hospital. Born October 1, 1917, he was predeceased by his wife Marite Orteig Blish, and survived by his children Marguerite Coffey of Bridgwater, CT, Suzanne Sclafani and Sharon LaGreca of Darien, CT, Cindy Philpott of Holmdel, NJ, Paul Blish of Norwark and Nanette Blish of Rowayton, CT, 14 grandchildren, a greatgrandson, and sisters Kathrene Blish Houlihan and Elizabeth Blish. A Lt. Commander in the U.S. Navy during WWII, he was retired from Domtar Inc. Mass of Christian burial today 10:00 at St. Leo's Church, Stamford, CT. Information: Leo P. Gallagher and Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St., Stamford, CT.

title: Death of Coach Motivates C.W. Post
description: Just two weeks ago, Bob Blitz, the coach of the C. W. Post women's soccer team, drove his car to the campus field to watch his playoff-bound club defeat Philadelphia University, 3-0. Weakened by pancreatic cancer that had spread to his liver, Blitz occasionally rolled down the window to yell instructions, but he saved most of his talking for after the game.

title: F.D.A. Calls For Listing 'Stealth Fat' On Labels
description: Faced with mounting evidence that a type of fat often found in margarine and baked goods raises the risk of heart disease, the Food and Drug Administration today announced plans to require food manufacturers to include specific information about these fats on nutrition labels.

title: GERMAN RETAIL DECLINE
description: German retail sales unexpectedly declined in September, providing further evidence that growth in Europe's largest economy is lagging behind that of other countries in the 11-nation euro region. Sales fell 4.5 percent in the month, the second decline in three months, and 2.7 percent from a year earlier, the biggest fall in almost two years, the Federal Statistics Office said. German manufacturers scaled back production in September as orders fell. Business confidence, which had revived in recent months, also stalled.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: AFRICA

title: U.S. Negotiators Extend Trade Talks in Beijing for 4th Day
description: In a last-ditch effort to reach an agreement on China's entry into the World Trade Organization, American negotiators decided overnight to stay here a fourth day for at least one more meeting.

title: INSIDE
description: Another Quake Hits Turkey

title: Year 2000 Insurance Is Hot on Wall St., but Not as a Sign of Fear
description: Year 2000 insurance has been the hottest-selling item on Wall Street recently. And its popularity is one reason investors are less concerned than they were a few months ago about possible disruptions in business and trading when computers make the internal change to the new year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSGROVE, HENRY J., MSGR.
description: COSGROVE-Henry J., Msgr. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of a former presiding Judge of the Tribunal of the Diocese of Brooklyn, on Nov. 11. Reposing in Fairfield Funeral Home, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Sunday, Nov. 14, from 3 to 5 and 7 to 9 pm. Funeral Mass at the Immaculate Conception Center, 7200 Douglaston Parkway, Douglaston, Monday, Nov. 15, at 10:30am. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: How to Be Both an Outsider and an Insider; 'The Czar of Latino Literature and Culture' Finds Himself Under Attack
description: Ilan Stavchansky Slomianski has come a long way from the secluded, middle-class Jewish enclave of Mexico City where he grew up. There Ilan, the son of a popular Mexican soap opera star, attended Yiddish day school and celebrated the high holidays in synagogue. Other kids called him El Guerito (Little Blondie).

title: Six Students End Hunger Strike After Fairfield Drops Contractor
description: Six Fairfield University students and a professor ended a hunger strike yesterday after the institution announced it would drop a contracting company that the students said was anti-union and paid janitors poorly.

title: The Nothing That Time Forgot
description: As those of us in the unwashed masses prepare to celebrate the new millennium this coming New Year's Eve, well-scrubbed critics are bemoaning our lack of sophistication, insisting that the new century and the new millennium do not begin until 2001. We have examined this controversy from mathematical, historical, cultural, and political perspectives and have come to this conclusion: Party on.

title: In New York, A Record Fine Over Lobbying
description: Philip Morris has agreed to pay a $75,000 fine, the largest ever imposed by state lobbying regulators, for underreporting the amount of money it spent to lobby New York lawmakers on tobacco legislation, officials announced today.

title: TRIPOINT GLOBAL TO ACQUIRE VERTEX COMMUNICATIONS
description: In a deal that combines two makers of satellite communications products, TriPoint Global Communications agreed yesterday to acquire the Vertex Communications Corporation for $22 a share, a total of $118.7 million. Vertex's shares jumped 42 percent, gaining $6.4375, to $21.0625, on the Big Board. TriPoint, based in Gastonia, N.C., supplies satellite and wireless communications products and services. It is a privately held company composed of RSI, Prodelin and CSA Wireless Communications. Vertex, based in Kilgore, Tex., makes satellite communications earth station products.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday about the flight data recorder from EgyptAir 990 misstated the surnames of two investigators displaying it. The man at the left was Vernon Ellingstad, not Ellington; the other was Bernard Loeb, not Lobe.

title: Off the Page and Onto the Screen: An Encyclopedic Mirror of What?
description: In the early years of this fading millennium, two words often appeared in encyclopedia titles: ''speculum'' (mirror) and ''imago'' (image). Encyclopedias were meant to reflect the world while also giving it shape. And what enormous mirrors they were! One Chinese encyclopedia from the 13th century filled 240 volumes. The German-language General Encyclopedia (1818-89) reached volume 167 and was never even completed.

title: A Portrait of Jesus as a Handsome Revolutionary
description: At the end of the NBC film ''Mary, Mother of Jesus,'' Pernilla August as the title character is asked by her son's disciples what they should do now that Jesus is gone. That's simple, she says, with an attempt at a beatific smile, they should ''try to teach as he taught, live as he lived and love as he loved.''

title: Web Site Gives Up NJTransit Domain Name
description: A New Jersey Web page publisher averted a legal battle yesterday when it agreed to relinquish ownership of its Web domain -- NJTransit.com -- to the state's mass transit and bus operating agency.

title: Will a New Cab Policy End Bias?
description: To the Editor:

title: Harlem's Pathmark Anchors a Commercial Revival on 125th Street
description: When a Pathmark store opened on 125th Street and Lexington Avenue in April, becoming the first full-service supermarket in Harlem in three decades, a few things needed to be adjusted. In response to feedback from customers, products from local bakeries were added, for example, and steps were taken to ease the delivery truck traffic that was clogging 124th Street.

title: Mississippi Memories
description: For all its progress since those ugly days when only whites could vote, Mississippi now faces an embarrassing reminder of its worst old instincts. That embarrassment comes in the form of the gubernatorial race that is still officially undecided 11 days after the election. The Democratic candidate, Lt. Gov. Ronnie Musgrove, received the most votes, 6,600 more than the Republican candidate, Mike Parker, a former congressman. If this would seem to settle matters elsewhere in the union, it does not in Mississippi.

title: A JOINT BID FOR NIPPON CREDIT
description: Four major Japanese companies -- Ito-Yokado, Softbank, Orix and Tokio Marine and Fire Insurance -- are jointly bidding for the failed Nippon Credit Bank. But spokesmen declined to provide details of the bid structure and declined to say if the group will make a separate bid for the trust bank unit, Nippon Credit Trust Bank, if the planned purchase of the parent fails. The leading Japanese financial newspaper, Nihon Keizai Shimbun, reported Softbank would contribute some 50 percent of the planned acquisition. The companies are also inviting major regional banks to join the group, it said.

title: A Farewell To Irony: Grief Gets A Chance
description: Mourning doesn't get any more stylish than the songs of the Pet Shop Boys, who gave their first New York concert since 1992 at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Thursday night. Their grief comes with an ebullient disco beat, electronic zingers and choruses that can be shouted from the dance floor. Onstage, the Pet Shop Boys -- Neil Tennant on vocals and Chris Lowe on keyboards -- wore sunglasses and gravity-defying blond wigs for the first half of the show. But there's sadness not far below the glittering surfaces; the songs are elegies for lost friends, lost lovers, and lost trust.

title: Another Loss, But Nets See A Ray of Hope
description: Who could blame onetime believers if they abandoned the current collection of Nets in flocks, questioning their talent and their heart while entertaining ideas of trades and firings that might energize this often drab ball club. But the atmosphere of gloom has not shaken the Nets' faith in themselves.

title: First Lady's New Campaign Worries
description: Among many Democrats yesterday, the question was not why Hillary Rodham Clinton had sat silently in Ramallah as the wife of Yasir Arafat seemingly accused Israelis of poisoning Palestinian women and children. The question was why Mrs. Clinton had agreed to go to the West Bank in the first place -- and then why it took her 12 hours to offer even a tentative response to Suha Arafat's remarks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAFT, EVE F.
description: KRAFT-Eve F. The entire New York Junior Tennis League family mourns the passing of our dear friend Eve, who inspired and guided our mission to grow the sport of tennis for NYC youngsters. We will miss her untiring passion, creativity and brillance in developing community tennis programs in schools and public parks. She truly transformed the sport of tennis. Our heartfelt condolences to Ken, Rob and the rest of her family.

title: In Expanding Platform, Forbes Attacks China
description: Steve Forbes, the wealthy magazine publisher and candidate for the Republican presidential nomination, came to the shrine dedicated to the president who opened modern diplomatic relations with China today and launched a bitter attack on the Chinese government, saying he would militarily contain the country and deny it trade relations if it did not moderate its behavior.

title: EgyptAir Data Shows Engine Shutdown
description: The wild final maneuvers of the EgyptAir flight that crashed on Oct. 31 included a free fall and an engine shutdown, the chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: Governor, Executioner
description: To the Editor:

title: Wanted: 24-Hour Care for the Mentally Ill
description: In October, for the first time in more than six years, my brother, Robert, was living outside a state mental hospital, and the two of us were having dinner together in a Chinese restaurant on Ninth Avenue in Manhattan. The restaurant was around the corner from Robert's new home on West 48th Street -- Project Renewal, a residence for 57 men and women who, like Robert, suffer from long-term serious and persistent mental illness.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, PHYLLIS
description: FRIEDMAN-Phyllis. Of New York City, formerly of South Orange, N.J. On Thursday, November 11, 1999. Dear sister of Donald Friedman. Services at Bernheim Apter Goldsticker, Surburban Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, N.J. Sunday, 2 P.M. Contributions to Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease Foundation, Inc., POB 611625, North Miami, FL. 33261 would be appreciated.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Expands War on Gun Industry
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said yesterday that it had broadened its attack against the gun industry for shootings with illegally obtained handguns by filing suit in Federal District Court in Brooklyn against several hundred gun wholesalers. In July, the group filed a similar suit against nearly 100 manufacturers.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS RISES. Natural gas rose on forecasts of colder weather over the weekend in the Midwest and the Northeast. In New York, natural gas for December delivery rose 12.7 cents, to $2.649 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Will a New Cab Policy End Bias?
description: To the Editor:

title: TRAINMAKER CUTS JOBS
description: Europe's biggest industrial company, DaimlerChrysler A.G., will cut 16 percent of the work force at its Adtranz unit, halving production capacity, in yet another effort to turn around the unit, which is the world's biggest train maker. The company will take a charge of 190 million euros ($197 million) against earnings this year to carry out the plan, the third in three years. The latest is aimed at saving 300 million euros a year by closing six manufacturing sites in Germany, Switzerland, Norway, Portugal and the United States. Adtranz, which has lost money every year since 1996, will eliminate 3,000 jobs: 1,000 in production, 1,400 in administration and 600 in engineering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARDER, LEWIS B.
description: HARDER-Lewis B., 81. Of Katonah, NY. Died on November 11. Husband of Dorothy. Father of Deirdre Harder Laveran and Diana Harder Terrell. Grandfather of seven, great-grandfather of five. Also survived by two brothers and three sisters. A memorial mass will be at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Bedford, NY, on Tuesday at 12 noon. Interment will be private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Northern Westchester Hospital Center, Mount Kisco, New York.

title: Korean Atrocity Survivors at Pentagon
description: Survivors of a killing of South Korean civilians by United States troops in 1950 told their stories to military officials today and received assurances that a thorough review would be conducted ''as a tribute to the shared sacrifices of the Korean and American people during the Korean War.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISELIN, BETTY BING
description: ISELIN-Betty Bing. Of Long Branch, New Jersey, and New York City on November 11, 1999. Wife of the late Philip H. Iselin, President of the New York Jets and Monmouth Jockey Club. She was the creator and Chairman of the Monmouth Park Charity Ball, which funded Monmouth County charitable organizations for more than fifty years. She served as a gubernatorial appointee to the New Jersey Board of Institutions and Agencies in the 1950's and 60's. She was the beloved mother of Kay Iselin Gilman Ahlstrom and Jimmy Iselin, the devoted motherin-law of Ruthanne T. Iselin and the enthusiastic and involved grandmother of Emmett Nicholas & Mark Gilman, Robin and Jamie Iselin and the great-grandmother of Ryan Gilman. A graveside service will be held on Sunday, November 14 at 11 A.M., at the Woodbine Cemetery, Eatontown Boulevard, Oceanport, NJ followed by a memorial luncheon at the Hollywood Golf Club, Roseld Avenue Deal at 12 noon. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Monmouth Park Charity Fund, PO Box MP, Oceanport, NJ 07757 or the New York Service for the Handicapped, 853 Broadway, NY, NY 10003 would be deeply appreciated. For further information, please call Kay Gilman at 212-371-7017 or Ruthanne Iselin at 212-289-9375.

title: Concisely, With Swoops
description: All of a sudden singers are the hottest commodity in the jazz record business, thanks to the success of Cassandra Wilson and Diana Krall. But they can come from strange places. Sometimes they're not exposed to jazz concertgoers all over the nation before they hazard a solo career, like so many instrumentalists; they can seem to come out of nowhere.

title: Discovering That Sleuths Can Have Fun
description: Two young filmmakers who bombed out with their first documentary (''Watering the Apple,'' a three-hour-plus salute to New York's drinking water) decide to do their second on a Los Angeles private eye. Things get complicated, though, when the cheating wife they're shadowing for a client turns out to be sleeping with the private eye's partner. Soon the partner, who flees to Mexico with $40,000, turns up dead.

title: Will a New Cab Policy End Bias?
description: To the Editor:

title: Growing Up With No Margin for Error
description: Our perception of adolescence has, in recent years, become muddled. Are teenagers still emotionally maturing children, or are they miniature versions of fully formed adults?

title: NEW CHIEF AT ABN AMRO
description: The largest bank in the Netherlands, ABN Amro Holding, named Rijkman Groenink as its new chairman and chief executive, replacing Jan Kalff, who will retire in May. Mr. Groenink, 50, has been a member of the management board since the bank was formed in the 1990 merger of Algemene Bank Nederland and Amro Bank. ''He's the youngest and most aggressive person on the board,'' said Benoit Vincenzi, an analyst at Fox-Pitt, Kelton Ltd., ''and ABN Amro is probably going to be a bit more daring in the next phase of expansion.''

title: Corrections
description: A pop music review on Thursday about a concert by the Eurythmics at Madison Square Garden misstated the night of the performance. It was Tuesday, not Monday.

title: Kingpins and the Constitution
description: The target of a new anti-drug initiative now speeding toward final Congressional approval is a worthy one -- big international drug traffickers. But as too often happens when Congress collaborates with the Clinton administration to toughen law enforcement policies, civil liberties stand to suffer.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADEN, RENEE F.
description: RADEN-Renee F. Halifax, NS, Canada. 80. Died October 15, after a long illness. Daughter of Meyer and Minnie Freedman, Albany. Survivers: son, Joel (Odette) Raden, NYC; daughter, Lesley (Steven) Brown, Halifax. Also, sister, Estelle Freedman, Albany; brother, William (Susan) Freedman, Albany; and 5 grandchildren. Memorial services were held in Halifax.

title: 'Single Use' Devices
description: To the Editor:

title: The Devils Give A Rookie Goalie A Rude Welcome
description: It took just a few short turns on the ice tonight for the Devils to uncover the main weakness of the expansion Atlanta Thrashers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASMOWITZ, DOROTHY (NEE BAER)
description: PASMOWITZ-Dorothy (nee Baer) 89, of East Brunswick, NJ (formerly of Brooklyn) on November 12, 1999. Wife of the late Joseph. Beloved mother of Ronald Pasmowitz & Iris Pianko. Grandmother of four and great grandmother of four. Services Sunday 11:45 AM Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, East Brunswick, New Jersey.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITTEMORE, RICHARD D.
description: WHITTEMORE-Richard D. Age 80 of Port Washington, LI on November 11, 1999. Beloved husband of Wilda. Devoted father of Richard of Brule, NE, Reed of Port Washington, LI, Cynthia Kaestner of Fairfield, CT and Elizabeth Ford of Littleton, CO. Adoring grandfather of 9 grandchildren and 4 great grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday December 4th at 1pm at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church. Memorial contributions may be made in his name to: The Port Washington Public Library, 1 Library Drive, Port Washington, NY or to St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, 9 Carlton Ave., Port Washington, NY or to the charity of your choice.

title: Clinton Sees Indonesian Leader and Offers Talks on Military Ties
description: President Clinton met today with Indonesia's new president, Abdurrahman Wahid, and said the United States was willing to open talks aimed at resuming military ties between the two nations that were broken off by Washington several weeks ago.

title: Gros Morne Journal; Town Struggles to Keep From Being Washed Away
description: The sound of raindrops heralds fear and sleepless nights for Nicolas Tertilus and his neighbors. They live atop a cliff overlooking the Mancelle River, which they watch swell with torrents of water flowing down the treeless mountain slopes. They hear the currents rush past the cliff, gouging chunks of dirt from the base and making the earth tremble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIONDATO, DEVINO (MR. NINO)
description: RIONDATO-Devino (Mr. Nino) on November 11, 1999. Loving brother of Luisa and Argia Piazzetta. Beloved brother of Agurino. Lifelong companion of James Nolan. Friends may call Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Funeral 1PM Monday.

title: Both Sides Reminded of Stakes In 11th-Hour Effort in Ulster
description: With his mission to salvage the Northern Ireland peace settlement at a crisis point, George J. Mitchell abruptly adjourned talks this morning and urged negotiators to spend the weekend focusing on ''the gravity of what is at stake.''

title: Eight Arrested at Rally File Suit, Saying City Violated Their Rights
description: Timothy Bryant expected a solemn evening when he arrived outside the Plaza Hotel on 59th Street last year for a vigil for Matthew Shepard, the gay college student who had been killed in Wyoming days before. Instead, Mr. Bryant said yesterday, the gathering on Oct. 19, 1998, turned into bedlam as police arrested him and dozens of others ''to scare us into never doing this ever again.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HACK, PAULA
description: HACK-Paula. Mother to Jonathan, Daniel and daughter-in-law Cindy. Grandmother to Rachel and Andrew. Sister of Lois and aunt to three nieces. Beautiful, gifted Paula, you may never have known how admired, respected and loved you were. The Family Descended from grandparents Jenny and Louis B. Shapiro

title: More Immigrants Are Deported As Officials' Power Increases
description: Equipped with new powers to turn away immigrants at the borders, and with more jail space available for those people they arrest inside the country, immigration officials in New York City have deported more than 4,000 people in the last year, an increase of 12 percent over the previous year.

title: South Carolina Argues Future of a Rebel Flag
description: Carrying the battle flag of the Confederacy through this birthplace of the Civil War, the hundreds of men parading in their gray uniforms and the women in their black widow's weeds knew exactly what was at stake in their struggle over the memory of an earlier era.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, ELLEN C.
description: NEWMAN-Ellen C., on November 12, 1999. Beloved daughter of the late Herman and Meta Zoberman. Cherished sister of Martin (Carole) Zoberman. Loving aunt of Rachel and David. Dear cousin of Marvin Cooper. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Keep Cabbies Safe, and Passengers' Rights Will Follow
description: It is tempting to be cynical about the latest skirmish between Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and New York City taxicab drivers.

title: ACQUISITION FACES INQUIRY
description: British regulators are investigating NTL Inc.'s planned acquisition of the cable, television and Internet businesses of Cable and Wireless Communications for 8.2 billion [pounds] ($13.2 billion). The Secretary of State for Trade and Industry, Stephen Byers, said the acquisition raises ''sufficient concerns'' about the delivery of pay-TV services to warrant a competition investigation. Regulators will issue a report by Feb. 25. NTL, Britain's largest cable company, competes with the satellite broadcaster British Sky Broadcasting Group. Nevertheless, analysts expect the acquisition to be approved.

title: African Deliverymen
description: To the Editor:

title: Preserving Area Codes
description: To the Editor:

title: Guards Learn From a Wily Veteran
description: If things were different if the Jets were 6-2 instead of 2-6 -- the team would be approaching the second half of the season admired for having accomplished something truly unusual: starting two guards in every game who had never played the position in the National Football League. But a couple of untested players seldom get a private mentor, in this case the former veteran guard and tackle, William Roberts.

title: No New Cases of Listeriosis In Westchester
description: Health officials in Westchester County said yesterday that they had not received any additional reports of people falling ill from an outbreak of the food-borne sickness listeriosis. But, they added, several residents have called in the last 24 hours with concerns about the disease.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   NARDELLI, CAMILLO
description: NARDELLI-Camillo November 13, 1987 Always remembered with love Kay

title: Church Council Meets Amid Financial Crisis
description: In the 49 years since its founding, the National Council of Churches has distinguished itself by strongly supporting civil rights legislation, helping resettle many thousands of refugees in the United States and sponsoring two influential Bible translations that have sold nearly 70 million copies.

title: THE MAYOR LOSES FREE SPEECH CASE
description: In another First Amendment defeat for the Giuliani administration, a federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that city officials had improperly retaliated against an AIDS service organization that had been critical of the mayor by moving to make it ineligible for millions of dollars in federal money.

title: Police Officer Is Shot In the Leg in Queens
description: A police officer was shot in the leg last night while responding to reports of an assault in Queens, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a referendum on ending the symbolic role of the British monarchy in Australia referred incorrectly to the results. Five of Australia's six states, not five territories, voted against the measure. Of the two Australian regions classified as territories, one voted for it and one voted against it.

title: Bush Grasps the Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: Labels Must Display Data on Type of Fat
description: The Food and Drug Administration has announced plans to require food companies to include on nutrition labels specific information about a type of fat often found in margarine and baked goods because of mounting evidence that these fats raise the risk of heart disease.

title: Three men, with three styles, in three venues, deliver three messages. Just perhaps, there is one very important common thread.
description: On the surface, the three events were completely different -- and even more so the three individuals at the center of them. A small lunch, a private interview, a public lecture. An Italian Roman Catholic cardinal steeped in years of Vatican diplomacy; a Jordanian prince claiming direct descent, over 42 generations, from the prophet Muhammad; a Canadian philosopher known for his explorations of liberalism, ethics and the nature of modernity.

title: Vodafone Said to Draft a Giant Bid for Mannesmann-Orange
description: Vodafone Airtouch P.L.C., the world's leading mobile phone operator, is expected to announce as early as Monday a hostile bid that could be worth more than $117 billion for Mannesmann A.G., the German telecommunications conglomerate, and Orange P.L.C., the British phone company that Mannesmann has committed itself to buy, executives close to the talks said here tonight.

title: In Search of the Revered Truffle
description: It turns out that the squirrels of Central Park, jaw-stuffing masters of the eat-and-run lifestyle, do not devour everything they uncover. They do not trifle with truffles.

title: A Soft Start That Ends In a Howl
description: Sonic Boom is the catchy title of the nomadic contemporary music series that has now settled into the Great Hall at Cooper Union. But with one exception, ''boom'' is not the word to describe the sonics of the four pieces, all from the 1990's, performed on Wednesday night by ModernWorks!, a dynamic new music ensemble founded in 1997 and directed by the cellist Madeleine Shapiro.

title: Mentally Ill Need Permanent Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SATTINGER, ETHEL
description: SATTINGER-Ethel. The Officers, Directors, Administration and Staff of the Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center extend their heartfelt sympathy to Shirley Rubin, pastAuxiliary Honoree, and her husband Seymour, member of the Gurwin Housing Board, on the passing of Ethel Sattinger, a longtime resident at Gurwin Center. Joseph Gurwin, President Alfred W. Levy, Chairman Martin Eglow, Vice President Herbert H. Friedman, Executive Vice President

title: Fight Fans Are Split Between Sentiment and Sense
description: The heavyweight championship unification rematch between Lennox Lewis and Evander Holyfield at the Thomas and Mack Center on Saturday night is forcing boxing fans to choose between their heads and their hearts.

title: State Decides To Start Over In Disputed L.I. Land Sale
description: Nearly a year after selecting a buyer for the largest tract of undeveloped land on Long Island, the Pataki administration abruptly reversed course yesterday, announcing that it would put the 560-acre property up for sale again, because of questions surrounding a bidding process that riled potential buyers.

title: Amid the Controversy, UConn's El-Amin Continues to Play
description: The story surrounding Khalid El-Amin and his use of a sport utility vehicle continued to shadow the Connecticut Huskies yesterday.

title: A Day Later, Mrs. Clinton Rebukes Arafat's Wife and Explains Herself
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton rebuked the wife of Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, today for accusing Israel on Thursday of causing cancer among Palestinians through the use of toxic gas, calling her statements inflammatory rhetoric that harmed peace efforts.

title: Cost-Effective Farming
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOUCHARD, ALBERT J.
description: BOUCHARD-Albert J. On November 12, 1999. Retired V.P. at Dean Witter Reynolds. Loving husband of Laurette. Devoted father of John Paul, Dr. Martha Bouchard Cann and Rachelle Hendele. Dear grandfather of eight. Beloved brother of Emily Bouchard and Christine Garamella. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue (at 20th Street), NYC, Sunday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM. Funeral Mass at Church of the Epiphany, Monday, 11AM.

title: Russia Says Its Forces Have Seized Chechen City
description: Russian officials said today that they had largely driven Islamic rebels from Gudermes, the second-largest city in Chechnya, and in an unmistakable sign of their intention to retake complete control of the separatist republic, proposed to move the capital there from Grozny.

title: First Lady Is Assailed By Giuliani on Mideast
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani sharply criticized Hillary Rodham Clinton yesterday for ''embracing and kissing'' Suha Arafat, the wife of the Palestinian Authority president, after listening to Mrs. Arafat excoriate Israel for using what she said were carcinogenic crowd-control gases in Gaza and the West Bank.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: DATEK ONLINE HOLDINGS CORP., Iselin, N.J., named John Grifonetti president and chief operating officer, succeeding Edward J. Nicoll, who became chairman and chief executive last month. Mr. Grifonetti will remain chief financial officer.

title: Camby Is Hurt as Knicks Succumb to Exhaustion
description: By the grueling end, their blue jerseys were untucked, their mental edge was rumpled and Marcus Camby was as sedentary as Patrick Ewing while he watched the misery unfold with his knee packed in ice.

title: Judge Denies Custody to Mother of Switched Baby
description: A woman whose baby was switched at birth with another infant was denied custody of her child today, but the judge in the case granted the mother's request for visitation rights.

title: Parents of Boy Who Choked to Death on Pokemon Ball File Suit
description: The parents of a Yonkers boy who choked to death on a Pokemon ball filed a federal lawsuit against the toy's maker and distributor yesterday, two days after the opening of a movie about the popular game.

title: Delicate Bargaining on U.N. Dues
description: The Clinton administration is right to try to negotiate a deal with House Republicans that would allow payment of nearly $1 billion in back American dues to the United Nations. But it must make clear that its willingness to compromise has limits. Even though Secretary of State Madeleine Albright has offered to defend any deal the administration makes from feminist criticism, President Clinton should not accept legislation that could be used to penalize family planning organizations when they use their own money to advocate more humane abortion laws. That is too consequential and lasting a change in American policy to sign on to simply because Dr. Albright has volunteered to serve as the administration's flak-catcher.

title: Manager Jailed After Robbery At Movie House
description: A theater manager was charged with conspiracy in an armed robbery of a multiplex cinema here today, accused of collaborating with a man who was arrested after a crash in the Lincoln Tunnel, the authorities said.

title: CHRIS-CRAFT IN TALKS ON TV STATION OWNERSHIPS
description: Chris-Craft Industries, owner of 10 television stations in the United States, said yesterday that it was in talks about possible transactions after rules governing the ownership of multiple stations in large cities were relaxed. The company, which has a market value of $2.43 billion, said it had hired the New York-based investment bank Allen & Company as an adviser. Chris-Craft said it had held talks with several parties it would not identify. Chris-Craft owns TV stations in cities including New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco, all highly sought-after markets for rival station groups. A Federal Communications Commission decision on Aug. 5 will allow one owner to have two TV stations in some large United States cities.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nasdaq Sets Its 10th High In Last 11 Trading Sessions

title: An Actress Who Seems Fragile Only if She's Acting
description: JUDGING from her cinematic repertory, one might think that the actress Emily Watson would be tiny, vulnerable, an imperiled sprite of a woman.

title: Yale Nips Princeton as Missed Extra Points Decide
description: Yale, led by quarterback Joe Walland's 263 yards of total offense, beat Princeton, 23-21, today in a tense contest ultimately decided by two missed extra-point attempts.

title: At Museums, Admit One and a Shopping List; A Fish Puzzle That's a Keeper
description: When it's too cold to go ''down the shore,'' kids can still dream about the beach and play with beach toys.

title: 26.2 Miles Of Smiles
description: There were some crowd-pleasers at last week's marathon festivities. On Saturday, there was a four-mile International Breakfast Run for Fun. Some 12,000 participants also took part in Sunday's 26.2-mile marathon of 30,000 runners. Below, the breakfast runners, many wearing or waving national colors; top left, two Dutch runners rocked along with rounds of cheese.

title: Century in Eloquent Objects
description: WITH only about six weeks left in what it calls the New York Century, the Museum of the City of New York has collected 100 objects to tell the story of those years. The items include a bronze bust of Martha Graham, the formal conducting wear of Leonard Bernstein, a hat from the finale of ''A Chorus Line'' and a collection of invitations for Studio 54 and the Limelight. There are photographs, too, like Lewis Hine's shot of the Empire State Building under construction in 1930.

title: Putting Tax-Delinquent Properties Into New Hands
description: AT some point in the not too distant future 47 tax-delinquent properties in the Bronx, 20 of them parcels of vacant land, will complete a transfer to new ownership that has been initiated by city government -- even though city government itself will never take title.

title: Caroline Moody, Nicolas De Lancie
description: Caroline Leisenring Moody and Nicolas De Lancie were married yesterday by the Rev. Arthur C. Lipton, an interfaith minister, at the Forest Hill Clubhouse in San Francisco.

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about the Cable Building, misstated the position of Ken Follett at Apple Restoration, the concern that restored the facade. He is the executive vice president, not the company's head.

title: The Past and Its Power: Why I Wrote 'The Price'
description: THE sources of a play are both obvious and mysterious. ''The Price'' is first of all about a group of people recollected, as it were, in tranquillity. The central figures, the New York cop Victor Franz and his elder brother, Walter, are not precise portraits of people I knew long, long ago, but close enough, and Gregory Solomon, the old furniture dealer, is as close as I could get to reproducing a dealer's Russian-Yiddish accent that still tickles me whenever I hear it in memory.

title: The Me Millennium
description: Studying the results of The Times's personal- values poll (''I'm O.K., You're Selfish,'' by Andrew J. Cherlin, Oct. 17), I couldn't help wondering if the chart pictured is a mirror image of the true results. The top-ranked personal value is ''being responsible for your own actions.'' And this in a society where the first reaction to a personal mistake or oversight is to consult a lawyer to see if anyone can be sued?

title: HOLIDAY FILMS: PERSONAL VISION; A Twitchy Take on a Tale of Terror
description: DRESSED in a black suit, black-and-white striped socks and windshield-size black sunglasses, his hair a nest of gravity-defying tendrils, Tim Burton looks as if he has been sewn together by a very chic Dr. Frankenstein.

title: Getting Personal, for the Books; In Haddonfield, The Owners Read My Mind
description: I can't find whatever I want in my favorite bookstore, but that is one of its main attractions.

title: Sanctuary
description: Mosquito By Gayl Jones. 616 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $28.50.

title: Don't Store the Hose; Reach for a Rake
description: Keep watering container plants and newly planted trees and shrubs. Even after they shed their leaves, woody plants continue to grow roots until they can't take up water through frozen soil.

title: Memories Make for His Many Ideas
description: TOMIE DEPAOLA, who has illustrated 205 children's books and written about 100 of those, says that despite his prolificacy he doubts he will ever run out of ideas.

title: Endpaper; In the Closet
description: Nina Griscom

title: Capturing a World of Pettiness and Perfection
description: SINCE my childhood days watching ''The Million Dollar Movie'' on afternoon television, I can think of nothing more satisfying on a rainy day than randomly coming across a backstage biopic reinventing the life story of a musical genius like Cole Porter or George Gershwin. The best part, inevitably, is when the composer sits down at the piano and stares into space with a furrowed brow for a second. Then pow! Out pours ''Night and Day'' or ''Rhapsody in Blue.''

title: Man Is Accused of Shooting Officer During Queens Scuffle
