description: A 27-year-old Queens man was arrested on attempted murder charges after getting into a scuffle that ended with a police officer's being shot in the leg with his own service weapon on Friday night, police officials said.

title: HOLIDAY FILMS: The Ghosts of Hollywood Past Continue to Cast Their Spell; Remember: Life Is Not Always So Wonderful
description: WHO doesn't love the holiday movies? Who can watch ''It's a Wonderful Life'' and not feel a surge of exultation when the friends of the desperate George Bailey pour into his home, and we see all the good he has done in his life abundantly repaid? Such moments leave us all aglow, reassured that in a world of tribulation, it is possible to find good will among men.

title: What Do Children Want?
description: Ready or Not

title: Galleries That Make a Showing
description: MILES from the Hamptons, despite odds that make survival tricky, the art of selling art is alive and relatively well west of the Shinnecock Canal. A few suburban galleries, mostly on the North Shore, have managed to find an audience for works by accomplished, if relatively unknown, local artists.

title: Abusing Medical Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: Generous Donor
description: To the Editor: The article ''The Other Side of Muir Woods'' (Oct. 10) reminded me of my visit. In a glass case near the office was a series of letters between President Theodore Roosevelt and William Kent, the donor. He wished to have the property named Muir Woods. The president preferred naming it for Mr. Kent.

title: Here's the Dirt on Baseballs
description: THE best mud in New Jersey may be the best in baseball.

title: Please Recycle, City Asks, Just Not Every Week
description: Bronx politicians and community leaders have been denouncing City Hall, saying the borough should not be the only one in the city in which some areas lack weekly curbside recycling pickups. Of the 59 community districts in the city, 49 have weekly collections, borough officials said, and the 10 that do not are all in the Bronx. In those districts, recyclables are picked up every other week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARDER, LEWIS B.
description: HARDER-Lewis B., 81. Of Katonah, NY. Died on November 11. Husband of Dorothy. Father of Deirdre Harder Laveran and Diana Harder Terrell. Grandfather of seven, great-grandfather of five. Also survived by two brothers and three sisters. A memorial mass will be at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Bedford, NY, on Tuesday at 12 noon. Interment will be private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Northern Westchester Hospital Center, Mount Kisco, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINEBURGH, JOEL T.
description: WINEBURGH-Joel T. Age 58, of New City, NY, passed away November 11, 1999. Loving husband of Marjorie, father of Steven and Diana, Susan, and Amy, adoring grandfather of Henry, devoted son of Edith and the late Samuel Wineburgh, brother of Michael and Melinda, and cherished friend. He graduated from Syracuse University and Thunderbird AGSIM, and served as a 1st Lieutenant in the U.S. Army. He was a Senior Vice President of Cometals, Inc. Funeral services today, Hellman Memorial Chapel, Spring Valley, NY, at 1 PM. Memorial contributions may be made to Hadassah. Joel's energy and enthusiasm will be missed by family and friends around the world

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, GORDON H.
description: MOORE-Gordon H., physician and resident of Houston, Texas, died Friday, November 5, 1999, at the age of 50 from complications related to the HIV virus. Dr. Moore began his profession in the practice of pediatric medicine and later held the position of Medical Director of the McGregor Clinics. His personal life included extensive travel throughout the world and devoted service to Trinity Episcopal Church in Houston. While family and friends knew of his dedicated service to others, most were unaware of the extent to which he lived this vocation-the establishment of charitable organizations, actual service within those organizations, and most profoundly in the way he quietly touched the lives of those he knew. ''Gordon Moore was the most selfless person I have ever known. He was a warm, caring individual and I have lost a great friend,'' said a friend and colleague. Dr. Moore was a Founding Director of the Episcopal Medical Missions Board and served on a mission to the Dominican Republic, providing medical services to the poor. He was also a founder of the Emergency Aid Coalition and volunteered many hours of service in inner city clinics. Ever faithful to the church's life and mission, Dr. Moore served on the Vestry of Trinity Episcopal Church, where he shared his vision of the church as an open, diverse community for all people. An outstanding teacher and scholar, he was noted for his Bethel Bible instruction at both Trinity and Palmer Episcopal churches. ''He found great joy in sharing. He saw Christ in all people,'' remarked a student and fellow parishioner. Dr. Moore is survived by his partner of 20 years, Kevin Stevens; his parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Moore; his brothers, Scott Moore and Jerry Moore, and their families. Memorials may be sent to the Episcopal Medical Missions Board, c/o St. Francis Episcopal Church, 345 Piney Point, Houston, Texas 77024.

title: Sarina Green, Gordon Ogden
description: Sarina Green, a daughter of Ellen and Edmund T. Green of Cambridge, N.Y., was married yesterday to Gordon Stuart Ogden, a son of Mary and Elliott M. Ogden of Wainscott, N.Y. The Rev. Milton Crocker Williams performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel at Trinity Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Friends, Indeed: Stories From the Heart; If It's Tuesday, It Must Be The Gathering of the Lunch Bunch
description: TELL us about your best friends, we said. And you did.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DACHS, SIDNEY
description: DACHS-Sidney, on October 27th, 1999 in Walnut Creek, CA at age 87. Formerly of New York and Huntington, NY. Beloved husband of Martha Selz Dachs. Devoted father of Alan (Laurie) and David (Tracy). Adored Opa of Eric, Abby, Emily and Michael. Private services were held in California.

title: Hokies Seize Their Opening To Secure a Title Game Bid
description: When the third quarter ended, the Virginia Tech tuba section crept into the north end zone and led a limb-jangling rendition of a wedding reception classic: the Hokie Pokey.

title: The Gathering Storm Over Prescription Drugs
description: THE pharmaceutical industry represents the greatest strengths of American capitalism. And also the weaknesses.

title: The Street Talk, He Says, Is a Bum Rap
description: DR. DRE, who has sold more than 20 million albums as a rapper and producer, feels like an underdog again. ''For the last couple of years, there's been a lot of talk out on the streets about whether or not I can still hold my own, whether or not I'm still good at producing,'' he said. ''That was the ultimate motivation for me. Magazines, word of mouth and rap tabloids were saying I didn't have it any more. What more do I need to do? How many platinum records have I made? O.K., here's the album -- now what do you have to say?''

title: Big Plans for Powder
description: SOMETIMES your whole morning can turn around on a doughnut hole. I had come to The Canyons, a sprawling new ski area in the blustery northern fringes of Park City, Utah, expecting to find what every Canyons' brochure kept promising was ''the most exciting story in mountain resorts.'' Instead, what I discovered last January as I drove up the unfinished gravel access road past tractors, trailers, towering cranes and ''Pardon Our Dust'' signs was a story that had a beginning, but clearly no end in sight. When I heard I'd have to put my rented S.U.V. in a ''temporary'' remote parking lot and wait for the shuttle bus, I gritted my teeth and seriously considered heading over to that deluxe skiers' paradise, Deer Valley.

title: At Heaven's Gate, In Silicon Valley
description: I DON'T want to gloat, but I have pretty good news for close friends, family and anyone else to whom I may owe money. I will be a billionaire within the hour.

title: Sometimes, an Outside Director is Comfortable in the Chief's Chair
description: THE board of the Thermo Electron Corporation, the scientific, medical and industrial instrument maker based in Waltham, Mass., did not look far when it hired a new president and chief executive last spring. He was one of its own: Richard F. Syron, a Thermo Electron director since 1997 and the president of the American Stock Exchange.

title: The Small but Sure Steps Taken To Turn Their Lives Around
description: Never give up. That's the message of five Long Islanders who, despite the odds, turned their lives around and realized their wildest dreams. From a museum president once labeled as lazy and stupid, a successful businesswoman beaten down by an abusive spouse, a college professor who was once a welfare mother and a young woman saddled by unfortunate family circumstances, they prove that obstacles can be overcome at any point in life. Not only have the people we have chosen to spotlight conquered stumbling blocks, met challenges and realized their own self-worth, after changing their lives they have also become role models, inspiring others and making a difference.

title: Donny and Marie Go Wild
description: You'd be hard pressed to recognize them, but the glam rocker in the black leather pants and mirrored ''stripper hat'' is Donny Osmond, and the blonde in the five-inch red heels is Marie. But they're still the wholesome, hard-working Mormon brother-and-sister act they've always been. For the sake of a style experiment, the two agreed to adopt new personas and take them for a walk.

title: 'Secrets of the Flesh'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Supreme Court on Privacy
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments last week on one of several important federalism cases that will go a long way toward defining this session of the court. The case involved a constitutional challenge to the 1994 Driver's Privacy Protection Act and, more broadly, to Congress's authority to legislate national solutions to problems that are truly national in scope.

title: Streetscapes/39 East 79th Street; A Co-op Built by and for the Social Register Crowd
description: THE sidewalk shed at 39 East 79th Street is soft gray with a simple white stripe, like the canopy of a private club on Park Avenue. That's fitting, because the 14-story 1926 building, at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue, was built like a club, a Social Register co-op put up by a small circle of friends from Tuxedo Park, N.Y. -- and headed by Emily Post, the patrician author of books on etiquette.

title: HOLIDAY FILMS; A Valley Boy Who Found a Home Not Far From Home
description: I AM from the San Fernando Valley. For many years, I was ashamed of this fact, thinking that if I was not from the big city of New York or the farm fields of Iowa I had nothing to say.

title: Finding Black Boxes, Retrieving the Dead; Lost at Sea Isn't What It Used to Be
description: ON April 3, 1945, a Navy Hellcat accelerated down a runway in Rhode Island and climbed out over the Atlantic Ocean. A short while later, the pilot, Ensign Vincent A. Frankwitz, radioed the tower to say the fighter's engine was losing oil pressure. Too far from shore to make it back, he was going to ditch.

title: Neglected, of Course
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE HARSH STEPPES, HOSPITABLE PEOPLE
description: JOLT. The railway car shuddered. I sleepily opened an eye. It was 1 o'clock in the morning. We were at the border between China and Mongolia on the Trans-Siberian Railway heading north. China and Mongolia have different railway gauges, so at the border each railway car is rolled into a shed and hoisted into the air while the wheels are changed. When the train arrives at the border, the cognoscenti race off to shop for the three-and-a-half-hour process.

title: Rise in Claims Of Wife Abuse Against Police
description: The number of complaints of domestic abuse committed by New York City police officers has continued to climb in the year since Officer Patrick J. Fitzgerald killed his wife, his children and himself in a rampage that drew attention to the often unspoken problem of domestic violence within police households, according to city statistics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYKES, DOROTHY MILLANG
description: SYKES-Dorothy Millang. Age 92. Died peacefully at her home in East Hampton on November 12. Devoted wife of the late James. Loving mother of Cordelia Menges, James Sykes Jr. and Martha Murray. Adored grandmother of Dorothy, Jake, Stuart, Ben, Matthew, Sam, Andrew and David. Cherished great-grandmother of Gardner, Serena, Martha, Sophie and Alice. A memorial service will be held Saturday, November 20, at 11 AM, at St. Luke's Church in East Hampton. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the East Hampton Library.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-14-99; What They Were Thinking
description: Cindy Siquerios, 24, May 12, 1999, White Memorial Medical Center, East Los Angeles

title: Coming Home
description: MY GRANDFATHER'S HOUSE A Genealogy of Doubt and Faith. By Robert Clark. 288 pp. New York: Picador USA. $24.

title: What Your Clothes Make of You
description: Fashion trends are about one thing: a collective yearning. A Calvin Klein senses the frustration of clutter in our lives and gives us minimalism. A Tom Ford feels our repressed sexuality and gives us raunch. We respond. A trend is born.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: PLEASANT pick-me-ups for the spirit, ranging across a spectrum from frothy farce to fact-based inspiration, dot the cinematic landscape this week.

title: Battling to Pull Over Bikes From Sidewalk Highway
description: Despite Mayor Giuliani's quality-of-life campaign, some West Siders say, the city needs to curb a practice that threatens not only the quality of life, but also life itself: bicycle riding on city sidewalks.

title: Mondays With Morris
description: Max Frankel's witty article on Edmund Morris was marvelous (Word & Image, Oct. 24).

title: Kim Huey, Norman Steiner
description: Kim E. Huey and Norman Steiner are to be married today at the Water's Edge, a restaurant in Long Island City, Queens. Justice Sheila Abdus-Salaam of State Supreme Court in Manhattan is to officiate.

title: The Chip Stampede May Be Hitting a Wall
description: THE Nasdaq Composite Index is no longer simply a stock index; it's a phenomenon. The index is up an astonishing 46.9 percent this year; in 10 of the last 11 trading days, it has closed at record highs.

title: The Battle Of the Binge
description: Jack Hitt (The Way We Live Now, Oct. 24) expresses what I have long felt: that the ''either/or'' ethic of enforced abstinence is at the heart of the binge phenomenon. In prohibiting the moderate use of alcohol and refusing to give it a place in the induction of the young into the adult culture, these policies have prevented college students from learning to use alcohol in a pleasant and sensible way in adult company. I, too, remember sherry hours with faculty members and occasional dinners accompanied by a glass of wine or two in professors' homes in a family setting, to name only two such occasions. What was the harm in that? The real harm is in marginalizing social drinking. We have only to glance at other cultures, like the French or the Italian, where wine and beer are integrated into normal life, to see how extreme our policies are.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDIN, ABE R.
description: GOLDIN-Abe R. Raconteur, oenophile, lover of life, guardian of family and religious traditions, World War II veteran, passed onto his next journey November 12, 1999 after a courageous 10 year battle with cancer. The loss of this loving and distinguished man will be felt by his wife Molly, daughters Holli and Jill, sons-in-law Bert and Sam. grandson Alex, sisters Ruth and Bea, nephews, nieces, friends and colleagues who knew and loved him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THALER, NATHAN
description: THALER-Nathan. Died Novemeber 12. Devoted husband of 62 years to Evelyn. Beloved father of Richard and Howard. Cherished grandfather of Karen and Lawrence.

title: PERSPECTIVE; Making Heads or Tails of It Under Ungodly Scrutiny
description: With the flip of a coin a year ago, Phil Luckett said he learned ''what the Bible meant about going through fire.'' The man who always packs his Bible along with his National Football League rule book could have used some salvation after being skewered following an infamous coin toss last Thanksgiving Day.

title: Just Imagine ...
description: Over this past century, business has given us the car, the radio, the television, the personal computer, the jet, the trash compactor and shampoo combined with conditioner. Imagine that you could ask for one equally huge innovation in the coming century, to improve your own lot or that of all mankind. What would you ask for? Send your ideas to Outlook 2000, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by e-mail to Outlook-2000@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, MAURICE AARON.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Maurice Aaron. A gentleman, a scholar, a friend without equal, a person who savored life to the fullest and shared it with family and friends; compassionate, wise and deeply involved with the community. A bon vivant, a man of style and breeding. I am lucky to have been a part of his life. I'll be seeing you, kid. Hank Meirowitz

title: Corrections
description: An art review on Oct. 17 about an exhibition of paintings by Fred Mitchell at Noel Fine Art in Bronxville misstated the order in which modern artists settled in Coenties Slip in Manhattan. Mr. Mitchell established a studio at 128 Front Street before Jasper Johns and Robert Rauschenberg, not after.

title: They Take Their Best Shots And Come Home Champions
description: AS this year's hunting season approached, hundreds of sportsmen descended on the Long Island Shooting Range in Brookhaven to shake off the summer's rust and hone their shooting skills. Al Marelli was there to direct them and point out any flaws in their form. He doesn't miss much.

title: Israel: The Revised Edition
description: THE IRON WALL

title: ANNUAL SPENDING ON MEDICARE DIPS FOR THE FIRST TIME
description: Medicare spending declined in the most recent fiscal year for the first time in the history of the program, even as private health insurance plans reported increases of 4 percent to 10 percent, new government data show.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: A Brooklyn Teenager Plays Powerfully but Falls Short
description: Fifteen-year-old Irina Krush, from Brooklyn by way of Russia, is probably the strongest young woman ever in American chess. Though she demonstrated great power in the Girls Under 21 World Championship Tournament in Yerevan, Armenia, which ended on Sept. 30, she failed to push through to victory. She equalled the tally of the winner, Maria Kouvatsou of Greece, with 8 1/2 points out of 13 rounds, but the tiebreak coefficients calculated afterward relegated her to fourth place.

title: Some Big Glitches In E-Campaigning
description: In politics, as in real life, glitches occur.

title: Counting Down To Millennium But . . . Oops!
description: TO the chagrin of the New Rochelle watch company that donated it, the Millennium Countdown Clock at the County Center in White Plains is wrong.

title: A Pip of Its Kind
description: Who said Donald J. Trump -- he of the big buildings -- doesn't have a few big ideas as well?

title: THE GUIDE
description: Holocaust and Hiroshima

title: Beauty, In the Eye Of the Beholder; The Pulaski Skyway
description: A roof. Four walls. A firm foundation. That's about all it takes to make a building.

title: Pick-Me-Ups Pick-You-Ups; Sit a Spell, Browse a Spell
description: Sometimes all it takes is a breath of pine scent that does not hang from the rearview mirror, a solid meal and a little rustic shopping to restore a day that has lost its shine.

title: The Store's the Thing: Shakespeare & Co. in Brooklyn
description: Coinciding with the Brooklyn Academy of Music's fall season, the bookstore Shakespeare & Company has opened a small performing-arts-oriented store at the academy's opera house. On the second floor beside the cafe at 30 Lafayette Avenue (between Ashland Place and St. Felix Street), the new Shakespeare & Company is the first outside Manhattan. Aimed at people interested in film, theater, dance and music, ''it's not just a Shakespeare & Company, it's also a BAM store,'' said Juan Demarchena, the manager.

title: Commercial Property/New Jersey; Y2K Concerns Help Slow Year-End Office Sales
description: THESE are roller-coaster times for the sale of office buildings in New Jersey. After six months of steady rises, sales eased in October and are expected to continue to slow in the waning weeks of 1999, then rebound in the new year.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Don't Think, Smile!

title: The Cable Guys
description: Donald Trump, like Ross Perot before him, can easily run for president because of his large personal fortune. According to your article, many supporters of the Reform Party believe that the more personal money someone has, ''the less corruptible and the more appealing he is.''

title: Baby Steps Toward Accord On Social Security
description: THE country learned one main lesson this year from the inability of President Clinton and Congress to make headway in dealing with the long-term financial shortfall in Social Security: that making even modest changes to the retirement system requires far more political trust than is present in Washington today.

title: Playing Catch-Up With Monopolies
description: WHEN President Clinton signed legislation on Friday updating the Depression-era law governing banking, insurance and Wall Street, he was doing little more than allowing Washington to catch up with the sweeping changes that have reshaped the financial services industry over the past few decades.

title: High Tech Helps Disabled Skiers
description: WITH an unsteady gait, Sam Avalos trudged toward the ski lift in Breckenridge, Colo., his crutches leaving marks outside his footprints in the soft snow. Reaching the lift line, Mr. Avalos replaced his crutches with a set of outriggers, short poles with a miniature ski on the bottom, and lowered himself into a mono-ski, a chair made of molded fiberglass, Kevlar and carbon fiber perched on a single ski. After a short ride up the ski lift, he attacked the hill, carving graceful turns on the bumpy slope.

title: For Collectors, the Joy Is in the Details
description: ONE may be the loneliest number, but then a collector would never stop there. Here's a look at some collectors who haven't stopped yet.

title: Summer's Drought May Outlast Autumn's Rains
description: DESPITE all the gloomy predictions that the summer's drought would drain the woods of color this fall, I've seen some pretty fiery sweet gums, maples and scarlet oaks. But I also watched the leaves of birches and dogwoods, both shallow-rooted trees, droop and turn brown by mid-July. Some trees, especially those on dry hills, simply toppled over.

title: A Misfit on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Chechnya War at Key Stage, Russia Says
description: As Russia continued its heavy bombing of the Chechen capital, Grozny, today, Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin told top security officials that the war in the secessionist region had reached a turning point.

title: A Chief Intent on Raising Eyebrows
description: ONE recent afternoon, Mel Karmazin, the chairman and chief executive of CBS, stormed through the office of the network's late founder, William S. Paley, on the 35th floor of Black Rock, the CBS headquarters in Midtown Manhattan, and collapsed into a chair in the adjoining conference room.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Spanking Watson

title: It Happened With One Movie: A Studio Transformed
description: ''IT HAPPENED ONE NIGHT'' almost didn't. Only days before shooting was to begin, this 1934 screwball comedy, now a classic, lacked a leading lady. Established draws like Myrna Loy, Margaret Sullavan, Miriam Hopkins and Constance Bennett had all passed on playing the role of the runaway heiress who falls for a newspaperman during a cross-country bus trip. Hopkins reportedly sniffed, ''Not if I never play another part.''

title: Rebecca Silloway, Philip Svahn
description: Rebecca Janelle Silloway, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Silloway of Atascocita, Tex., was married there yesterday to Philip Christopher Svahn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Svahn of Columbus, Ohio. The Rev. James Abernathy performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of Christ the King.

title: Silence, Please
description: To the Editor:

title: H.M.O. Mystery, Cont.
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting Together a Pleasant Meal That Spells Simplicity Itself
description: COMFORT foods push all sorts of emotional buttons. That's why my favorites will probably not be yours. Had my background been Italian, my choice might have been a plate of soft, warm polenta. Chinese? Noodles in broth, perhaps. And if I came from the South I would have wanted cheese grits.

title: The Very Best of Friends; They've Been Friends For Nine Whole Years
description: TELL us about your best friends, we said. And you did.

title: My Body
description: In her work, the conceptual artist Vanessa Beecroft, whose installation appeared last year at the Guggenheim, has often addressed how women look at themselves and are themselves looked at. For the magazine, she assembled one of her performances in a private studio by asking 21 women, from professional models to women she met on the street, to expose the naked truth beneath their clothes -- or not, for those who declined to disrobe. The models, she explains, ''provide a kind of backdrop,'' establishing the standard of beauty by which women are often judged. But in the foreground, the individuality of everyday people emerges. They are like figures in a bas-relief, their bodies not nearly so perfect, though no less beautiful.

title: Amy Newmark, William Rouhana Jr.
description: Amy Louise Newmark, a specialist in technology investments, and William Joseph Rouhana Jr., a telecommunications executive, were married last evening in Manhattan. Justice Nicholas L. Pitaro, who is retired from State Supreme Court in Queens, officiated at the Pegasus Suites at the Rainbow Room.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADEN, RENEE F.
description: RADEN-Renee F. Halifax, NS, Canada. 80. Died October 15, after a long illness. Daughter of Meyer and Minnie Freedman, Albany. Survivers: son, Joel (Odette) Raden, NYC; daughter, Lesley (Steven) Brown, Halifax. Also, sister, Estelle Freedman, Albany; brother, William (Susan) Freedman, Albany; and 5 grandchildren. Memorial services were held in Halifax.

title: Theodore Federici, Laura Henry
description: Laura Jane Henry was married yesterday to Theodore Federici. The Rev. William T. Federici, a minister of the United Church of Christ and a nephew of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Columbus Club in Manhattan.

title: RON MOTLEY
description: For a man who stands to collect tens of millions of dollars in tobacco settlement fees, Ron Motley travels light -- and without electronic gizmos.

title: Opening Doors With the Point of a Sword
description: IN 1968, when newspapers ran an article about Uriah Jones, one headline was ''Negro, 43, Fences Way to Olympics.'' That year Mr. Jones was the first black person to be on a United States Olympic fencing team; in 1971 he became the first black man to win a national fencing championship. As he kept beating his opponents, he explained, he kept ''kicking in doors.''

title: Hillary Clinton Strikes Back At Giuliani on Mideast Trip
description: Taking a jab at Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for criticizing her behavior during a West Bank visit in which Yasir Arafat's wife accused Israel of using poison gas, Hillary Rodham Clinton said today that she was in the Middle East to support peace efforts, and expected every American to do so.

title: Susan Elia and Noel MacNeal
description: FEW parents ever dream of their daughter marrying a puppeteer. It is not exactly a profession that yells money or security. An early retirement in Florida doesn't leap to mind. Nor does health insurance.

title: Janitor's Son Sends Message to Forbes
description: Gary Bauer, the son of a janitor, says that Steve Forbes, the inheritor of a family fortune, should quit the presidential race.

title: Press Gallery Named To Honor Journalist
description: FOR almost half a century, he has been reporting Westchester news. Now Milton Hoffman, most known for his coverage of government and politics for what is now The Journal News, will have a press gallery named for him.

title: Debora Cappucci, Bryan Buljat
description: Debora Ann Cappucci, the daughter of Barbara A. and Albert A. Cappucci of Ithaca, N.Y, was married yesterday to Lt. Bryan Joseph Buljat, the son of Unni and Joseph M. Buljat of Upperco, Md. The Rev. Peter Escalante performed the ceremony at St. Brigid Roman Catholic Church in San Diego.

title: Laurel Weldon, Aaron Hoffman
description: Dr. Sirje Laurel Weldon and Aaron Michael Hoffman are to be married today at St. Lawrence Hall, a historic building in Toronto. Justice Gloria R. Klowak of the Superior Court of Ontario will officiate, and Rabbi Alvin Kass is to take part in the ceremony.

title: Giants Plan to Bend, but Not Break
description: The Giants have a defensive game plan today for defeating the celebrated Indianapolis Colts and their precocious Hoosier triad, the offensive boy wonders who have liberated this year's National Football League from the numbing muddle from huddle to huddle.

title: The View From/Harrison; A Teenage Spin on the News
description: ROBERT ROGERS is the kind of guy everyone wants to meet: good looking, articulate, friendly, ambitious. He is only 13. Robert, a freshman at Harrison High School here, is a college admissions office's dream.

title: Bulgaria's Plight Isn't West's Fault
description: To the Editor:

title: Help Wanted at I.M.F.
description: For 13 years Michel Camdessus, head of the International Monetary Fund, spent billions bailing out Latin American and Asian nations and tried to prop up a corruption-ridden Russia, help convert Eastern Europe to capitalism and keep Africa from drowning in debt -- drawing criticism from Capitol Hill to the streets of Jakarta. In calling it quits, citing personal reasons, Mr. Camdessus has touching off a behind-the-scenes struggle among Europeans, the Clinton administration and the developing world over who will run the institution that runs the economic policies of much of the world. DAVID E. SANGER

title: A Stage Where Works in Progress Can Progress
description: THE carefree, pluralistic spirit of the 1960's didn't die; it possessed the body of Ellie Covan. As executive director of Dixon Place, a performance space she founded in 1986, Ms. Covan provides a venue where choreographers, actors, writers, performance artists and musicians can present works in progress. Critics are not invited.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the effect of the Americans With Disabilities Act on employees with depression misidentified the government agency that receives complaints from disabled workers about workplace accommodation. It is the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, not the Labor Department.

title: Behind The Seams
description: It's tough to say which aspect of every new season's clothes makes people more furious: the obvious planned obsolescence or the appearance of utter obliviousness to people's needs. Somehow, year after year, designer clothes have to go from being a dream on a drawing board to fitting into a real life. No designer goes to greater lengths to research the back story of her collections than Anna Sui, who creates elaborate bulletin boards illustrating her influences as she goes along. But whatever the inspirations, the real work, she says, is making her customers feel that somehow those elements say something about them when they wear the clothes. ''Fashion always has to reflect what's going on,'' Sui said. ''You can't just pull a concept out of nowhere and say this is the look of today, because it doesn't happen that way. Fashion is a reflection. That's always the challenge. You have to bring it back so that a person can walk down the street and not look like she walked out of a costume epic or a time machine. It's got to fit into how people are dressing today.'' Here, Sui walks us through the process of putting together her triumphant fall '99 collection.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Zwilling's Dream

title: The Flying Pope
description: WITNESS TO HOPE

title: Complicity in Chechnya
description: To the Editor:

title: Especially for Young Readers
description: I'TS possible that they have discovered dragons and secret passageways along the shore, or maybe it's the strong library systems, numerous bookstores and inspiring landscape. Whatever the reasons, Long Island is home to an increasingly active group of children's book writers. Through their words they have added volcanoes and waterfalls to a landscape where none existed before, and populated this new geography with fantastic creatures. Their contributions, along with those of writers nationwide, will be honored beginning tomorrow during National Children's Book Week. So grab a quilt, a child and a cup of tea. Find your eyeglasses and a good book. Read.

title: Christina Weber, Andrew Whitney
description: Christina Colket Weber, a daughter of Charlotte C. Weber of Ocala, Fla., and Dr. John C. Weber of New York, was married yesterday to Andrew Gordon Curtis Whitney, a son of Caroline H. B. Whitney of Cambridge, Mass., and Patricio G. Whitney of Buenos Aires. The Rev. Brenda G. Husson performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Touched By a Doctor
description: The most dangerous thing that patients encounter in the hospital may well be the unwashed hands of their doctors, say infectious disease specialists. Even though it was proved 150 years ago that unclean hands could transmit disease, many doctors and other hospital workers still fail to wash up as they should, before and after touching each patient. A recent study found that only 17 percent of doctors treating patients in an intensive care unit washed their hands appropriately.

title: Be Assured: He's Dead
description: To the Editor:

title: Hefty History at Reasonable Prices
description: THE autumn has brought a wonderfully rich harvest of affordable and accessible paperback books for fans of business history, a genre whose volumes usually cost a bundle and weigh a ton.

title: Widower, 69, Is Arrested After Robbery
description: Things were not going Ralph Hall's way when he walked into a Queens bank Friday morning, the police say, carrying a note saying he intended to rob the place.

title: The Cable Guys
description: I am not an advocate for Jesse Ventura, but I was disconcerted by the scowling, angry photograph of him in James Bennet's article (Oct. 24). I have seen the governor on television several times, and your picture was uncharacteristic of his appearance on those occasions, when he displayed an easygoing, cordial personality. The cover illustration was somewhat more honest but didn't undo the damage.

title: In Your Own Kitchen, Comforting Yourself and Your Guests
description: COMFORT foods push all sorts of emotional buttons. That's why my favorites will probably not be yours. Had my background been Italian, my choice might have been a plate of soft, warm polenta. Chinese? Noodles in broth, perhaps. And if I came from the South I would have wanted cheese grits.

title: Primal Scream: Teaching Tykes to Get a Grip
description: WHEN educators gather this week in New Orleans for a national conference on teaching young children, Mother Goose rhymes will make room for lessons in anger management: aggression prevention, self-regulation and emotion control.

title: Death Toll Nearing 400 in Friday's Quake in Turkey
description: The death toll in Friday's earthquake rose past 300 today as rescuers continued to search for more bodies and relief teams began arriving from abroad.

title: Baltimore, My Baltimore
description: IT'S a conversation that has come up throughout my life. It goes something like this:

title: Male Domination
description: To the Editor:

title: Lower East Side TV Crew Used Good-Neighbor Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Royal Butler On a Budget
description: CONFIDENTIALLY, I did have a little problem with Barbara Walters,'' the butler is saying on the phone from England. ''20/20. They said they needed something new -- would I be willing to discuss A, B and C? -- and of course I could not. A relationship between two people is a very special thing. It cannot be bought. I've been offered $:1 million to tell my story, and I can't do that. If I gave it away, who would I be? I wouldn't be the person she called 'my rock,' would I?''

title: Communist Push in Ukraine Runoff May Help Incumbent
description: Ukraine's Communists are rallying their red forces to support Petro Symonenko in this Sunday's runoff presidential election against the incumbent president, Leonid Kuchma. That seems to suit Mr. Kuchma just fine.

title: Beauty, In the Eye Of the Beholder; Twin Railroad Bridges
description: A roof. Four walls. A firm foundation. That's about all it takes to make a building.

title: HOLIDAY FILMS: The Ghosts of Hollywood Past Continue to Cast Their Spell; The Holiday Rituals of Make Believe
description: ALTHOUGH any picture may nominally become a holiday movie simply by being dropped by its distributor into the year-end pileup, only a few films have worked their way into the season as an integral part of the celebration. These are the true holiday movies, which have attained their status through repetition, after they have died and gone to television.

title: They Bad
description: Three years ago, a lanky 17-year-old basketball player in St. Louis saw something about himself in the tag on a pair of shorts. Something that he liked. The image was of a faceless, raceless, brawny ballplayer in midmove. ''That's me,'' the kid thought. ''A ballplayer.'' Tag in hand, he found a tattoo parlor and had the caricature etched into the skin of his upper arm, with the words ''The Law'' above it (because when he's playing defense, he's got you on lockdown) and ''Silky Smooth'' underneath.

title: Recording of 24 Minutes As Monument of History
description: ADAM ABESHOUSE walked through the forest of microphones on stage in the Recital Hall of the Performing Arts Center of Purchase College here. He raised one an inch, lowered another two inches, slid one a bit forward and moved another a bit backward. The microphones were Mr. Abeshouse's palette as he prepared to record Melinda Wagner's 1999 Pulitzer Prize-winning ''Flute Concerto'' with the Westchester Philharmonic recently. The Pelham producer and recording engineer would add his own artistry to that of all the other artists in the hall that day: Ms. Wagner, the composer; Paul Lustig Dunkel, the flute soloist; Mark Mandarano, the conductor, and the orchestra players themselves.

title: Camby Is Questionable
description: Marcus Camby was treated for tendinitis in his left knee yesterday, and whether he will play against Miami at Madison Square Garden tonight will be a game-time decision. On Friday night, Camby played just the first six minutes of the Knicks' loss to the Boston Celtics and spent the rest of the game with his knee packed in ice.

title: Bridging the Gap Between Monomania and Museum
description: IN the beginning, they were just hobbies, diversions, interesting ways to spend spare time. But somewhere along the way, what began as simple pastimes became uncommon passions: for reptiles, for chess, for steam railroads, for fretted musical instruments.

title: If 12 Hours Aren't Enough
description: Quick: After discovering New York Harbor, what became of the English explorer Henry Hudson? a) He went home to write a book. b) He discovered the real Northwest Passage. c) He returned to the harbor and drowned.

title: Keeping Poor Children Healthy
description: LAST July, Sarabeth Goslee gave birth to her daughter Makiah. If not for a program provided by the state, Makiah would not have had health insurance after her birth.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The difference between 'Millionaire' and the 50's game shows tells you where education is going in this country. In the 50's game shows you had to know the exact answer. Today we get multiple choice on a show whose title isn't even punctuated correctly.''

title: The Very Best of Friends; A Great First Impression That Has Never Changed
description: TELL us about your best friends, we said. And you did.

title: 'Top Hat' for a 'Bad Boy'?
description: As early as this week, a federal judge will decide how much more United Way of America must pay to its former president, William V. Aramony, who has been in federal prison since 1995 for embezzlement. At issue, in pension language, is whether being a bad boy should keep him from wearing a top hat.

title: SHORTS
description: TOUR

title: SPOTLIGHT; Portraying the Passion of Jesus, Mary's Son
description: When Christian Bale was approached last summer about portraying the Son of God in tonight's NBC movie, ''Mary, Mother of Jesus,'' his initial reaction was one of merriment. ''I found it very, very funny,'' said the 25-year-old British film actor, tucking into a grilled-chicken salad at a cafe in Manhattan, where he was filming an updated version of ''Shaft,'' starring Samuel L. Jackson and directed by John Singleton.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Way We Are
description: I know it's late, but I've found my Man of the Year. He is Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who just threw the book at Microsoft, handing down a stunning 207-page finding that Bill Gates & Co. had a monopoly over PC operating systems and wielded that monopoly power ''to harm any firm'' that threatened it.

title: Louder Than Words
description: SILENT STARS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTTS, JEAN
description: POTTS-Jean. At age 88, died Wednesday, November 10, 1999. Jean was the recipient of The Edgar Award for ''Go Lovely Rose'' in 1954 and went on to write 14 more mysteries and nearly 40 stories. She was a native of Saint Paul, Nebraska, where there is a permanent exhibit of her works at the Gruber House, Lower Level. The exhibit known as the Jean Potts Archives was the inspiration of the Howard County Historical Society and one board member in particular, Ron Sack. Jean will be missed by her many friends and admirers

title: Driving Into Mexico? $800 Deposit, Por Favor
description: FOR American and Canadian tourists who are dismayed over a new plan to charge deposits of up to $800 for foreign-registered cars driven into Mexico, the government has some advice.

title: New Owners For Restaurant At Terminal
description: Metrazur, the long-delayed restaurant being built for the east balcony overlooking the main concourse of Grand Central Terminal, has entered into a partnership with one of New York's most prominent chefs, and plans to open to the public in January.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-14-99: Pipeline; The Hot Phone
description: THE STANDARD: In the early 1990's, designers at Motorola became aware of a seemingly minor trend: in Japan, people were wearing electronic gadgets as fashion accessories. Motorola had invented the world's first portable phone in 1973 -- a two-pound brick with 2,000 parts -- and been working ever since to winnow it down into a more appealing size and shape. Now the company had a new idea: what about a wearable phone?

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption today on Page 3 of the special Holiday Films supplement to Arts & Leisure, with an article about setting movies in the San Fernando Valley, misstates the middle name of the author, who is a director. He is Paul Thomas Anderson, not Taylor.

title: Shakespeare And Cole Porter, Together Again
description: YOU know the tale; it's Broadway's most relentless cliche. Today this musical is on the short list of classics, but in the 1940's it was universally viewed as a doom waiting to happen: based on a play that couldn't be adapted, with a cast of nobodies and an author thought to be deep in a conclusive losing streak. The show had to beg for its capitalization, but it came in a hit, its very title soon to be a summoning term for Golden Age Musical Comedy.

title: Young Performers On Norwalk Stage
description: HUNDREDS of younger and older students are contributing mightily to the week's musical activity. The largest assembly, 8 p.m. next Saturday at the Norwalk Concert Hall, displays the collective talents of the 250-plus players in the Norwalk Youth Symphony. Actually four ensembles operate under the symphony banner: two chamber orchestras for the youngest students, the intermediate concert orchestra, and -- for the most experienced youngsters -- the principal orchestra.

title: At Last, Buildings Are the Stuff of Dreams
description: A few weeks ago, a pundit observed that the millennium was shaping up to be a major dud. No one really cared about it, no one was excited about it, the whole thing was a bore, ho-hum, zz-zz-zz-zz. What was this commentator expecting? Mass suicides, perhaps? A reversal of the earth's poles? But if there's any truth to his observation, one reason may be that for many of us now the major events of the day are internal. They are happenings in the life of the body and the mind. And if this, and much more than this, is true, then the cause for celebration came early this year. It arrived on Nov. 4 with the centennial of the publication of Freud's ''Interpretation of Dreams.''

title: Beauty, In the Eye Of the Beholder; Architects' Office
description: A roof. Four walls. A firm foundation. That's about all it takes to make a building.

title: Art With Meaning Close to Home
description: ALL politics is local, but not all art. Yet museums and other art institutions in New Jersey have shown a special knack for making the exotic, the far-flung or the arcane relevant to their patrons' daily lives.

title: Pick-Me-Ups Pick-You-Ups; Casting Off Cares
description: A fresh breeze, a jug of wine, a gaff-rigged schooner and, well, that's probably all you need.

title: The Opera Isn't Over Until the Kid Draws
description: Bradley Portela, 11, dangled his legs from a bench outside the Metropolitan Opera at Lincoln Center and recounted the tale with utter glee: ''Aida is a slave from Ethiopia, and she gets captured by the people from Memphis, and nobody knows she's actually a princess.

title: Financing Parental Leave
description: President Clinton says he has found a new tool to ''help parents balance work and family.'' He will let states pay unemployment benefits to workers who take time off to care for newborns.

title: The Tyranny Of Cool
description: In the upper-middle-class suburb of Highland Oaks in North Miami, Elana Schulman, 15, is considered a fashion radical. She is also class secretary, a candidate for homecoming princess and captain of the cheerleading squad. Younger girls who feel constrained by the strict prescriptions for clothing marvel at what they see as Elana's daring. She pretty much wears whatever she feels like putting on.

title: Latest Lure On the Web: Free Trades
description: THE price war among online brokerage firms has escalated so rapidly that the stock trade has gone from being a commodity to a come-on.

title: National Trust Offers A Guide to Winter Sites
description: Visitors to Britain have a new guide to historic sites that are accessible in winter. Out and About with the National Trust in Winter contains information about more than 100 National Trust properties that will remain open from November through March, in many cases for the first time.

title: For the Few, a Breathtaking View; The Island Has Largely Resisted High-Rise Creep. But, Oh, the Scenery...
description: NASSAU COUNTY MEDICAL CENTER opened here in 1974 as the tallest occupied structure in all of Nassau and Suffolk. The 19-floor tower commands a 360-degree view that on a clear day extends to the North Shore, Jones Beach and the distant New York City skyline.

title: Those Sultry Come-Ons at Hair Salons
description: Who are those sultry women and arrogant men pictured in hair salon windows all over the city? During the last few years, these illustrations of attractive people have proliferated in New York, so much so that in some salon-rich areas, like Avenue U in southern Brooklyn, they now appear every few blocks.

title: After-Hours Trading: Managers Aren't Thrilled
description: After-hours trading is upon us. But who will be doing the buying and selling when the Nasdaq market and New York Stock Exchange start staying open past their current closing time of 4 p.m.? Nasdaq is in the midst of the transition, and the Big Board will make the change next year.

title: Be Medicareful
description: Randy Cohen (The Ethicist, Oct. 24) offered questionable advice to the writer who asked if it was ethical to transfer her mother's assets so that she could qualify for Medicaid. It may be legal. Whether it is ethical is another matter. Transferring assets was done to impose the cost of caring for the older person on taxpayers. Cohen did not deal with that aspect of the issue. If the question had been, ''Is it ethical to benefit the children of an affluent older person at the taxpayers' expense?'' I suspect that his answer would have been different.

title: Getting Away With Murder and More
description: A DENSELY populated state breeds a fair amount of crime, and New Jersey has been no exception. In fact, the state has been the site of some of the nation's saddest and most spectacular wrongdoing: the Lindbergh kidnapping in 1932, the triple homicide in Paterson in 1966 that turned Rubin (Hurricane) Carter into a cause celebre, the 1994 murder of young Megan Kanka.

title: Is the Party Over?
description: MONEY, GREED, AND RISK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, TOBY NEVINS
description: FRIEDMAN-Toby Nevins. Of Boynton Beach, FL; formerly of Cedarhurst, NY, and White Meadow Lake, NJ; passed away November 11, 1999. Woman of valor. Beloved wife of Harold K. for 53 years. Loving mother of Lydia (Jon) Jacobs and Nancy Friedman (Steve Posner). Proud grandmother of Scott, Jolie, Jay, Melanie, Jared, and Daniel. She will always be in our thoughts and hearts.

title: Character 101
description: In a newly released 400-page guide, Pace University in White Plains is listed among the 550 colleges in the United States noted for building values. The guide, ''Colleges That Encourage Character Development,'' is published by the John Templeton Foundation, a think tank near Philadelphia that focuses on issues of moral and spiritual growth.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Books From The Times
description: ''One advantage of a collection of film reviews spanning seven decades,'' Peter M. Nichols observes in his preface to THE NEW YORK TIMES GUIDE TO THE BEST 1,000 MOVIES EVER MADE, by Vincent Canby, Janet Maslin, and the film critics of The New York Times (Times Books/Random House, paper, $25), ''is that it reflects changing times as tellingly as it explores movies.'' Nichols, the editor of the volume, points out that many a movie now on anyone's list of the best went unrecognized by the critics at its release: he cites, among others, ''Grand Illusion,'' ''The Third Man,'' ''Bonnie and Clyde'' and ''Chinatown.'' Nevertheless, this collection offers 1,000 reviews -- talkies only -- just as they were written, beginning Oct. 7, 1927 (Mordaunt Hall on ''The Jazz Singer''). Each review is accompanied by a credit box, updated to current style. Intended especially for film buffs and renters of videos, the book includes appendixes on the critics' choice of the 10 best movies of each year from 1931 to 1998 and a roster of foreign films by origin.

title: The Very Best of Friends; A Path They Never Envisioned Traveling
description: TELL us about your best friends, we said. And you did.

title: Friends, Indeed: Stories From the Heart; Close, Closer, Closest: Twinned Together
description: TELL us about your best friends, we said. And you did.

title: Testing Gap: Black, White and Gray Matter
description: TASHA PERSAUD, a high school senior from Staten Island, put it this way: ''If your doctor told you you can't run anymore, would you try to go out and run? If someone says again and again that you can't achieve, you don't even try.''

title: A Victory, However Late, Is Still a Victory
description: November has been both the cruelest and sweetest month for Carol Moseley-Braun. A year ago, she lost her re-election bid after serving one term as Illinois's Democratic senator. This month, she was confirmed as ambassador to New Zealand despite the opposition of Senator Jesse Helms, who heads the Foreign Relations Committee. Mr. Helms and Senator Peter Fitzgerald, the Illinois Republican who defeated Ms. Moseley-Braun, the only black woman to serve in the Senate, were the only lawmakers to vote against her. DAVID STOUT

title: Elizabeth Suhocki And Jon Maass
description: Elizabeth Mary Suhocki, a daughter of Elaine and Vincent P. Suhocki of Mendham, N.J., was married last evening to Jon Anthony Maass, a son of Delores and Herman A. Maass of Poland, Ohio. The Rev. Edmund Nixon performed the ceremony at Epiphany Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-14-99: The Evolution of Embellished Denim; Jeanealogy
description: According to the lore of the fashion industry, style starts on the runway and trickles down from there. But in the late 20th century, that process has been thrown into disarray. It's almost impossible to determine where and when a trend starts. In the case of embellished jeans, an enduring favorite thanks to the nostalgia of baby boomers everywhere, the relationship between catwalk and Kmart has been hopelessly complex.

title: F.D.R. Memorial
description: To the Editor: I was surprised to see that Cynthia Hacinli, in ''What's Doing in Washington'' (Oct. 31), did not mention the new Franklin D. Roosevelt memorial, nor was it marked on your map. If someone follows the route around the Tidal Basin suggested by Ms. Hacinli for biking, as I did recently on foot, it would be hard to miss the memorial.

title: An Organ-Sharing System
description: With 4,000 Americans dying each year for lack of a human organ, distributing them is tricky business. Donna E. Shalala, secretary of health and human services, learned that in February 1998, when she said she would require that organs be shared across broad regional lines and go to the sickest patients first. Her plan has been held up by Congress, but under a deal it will finally go into effect, possibly as soon as the end of the year. SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

title: 'Black Box' Voice Recorder from EgyptAir Crash Is Recovered
description: A robot submarine late Saturday night recovered the long-sought cockpit voice recorder from Egyptair 990, the Boeing 767 that crashed 60 miles south of Nantucket two weeks ago.

title: Thick-Skinned and All the Better for It
description: NOW that all the pumpkin hoopla has passed, attention can be made to the other winter squashes that are so prevalent in produce markets. These colorful vegetables are true North American native plants and have been cultured for many centuries.

title: Bulgaria's Plight Isn't West's Fault
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: LOWER MANHATTAN

title: THE GUIDE
description: Stamford's Loft Studios

title: Beauty, In the Eye Of the Beholder; Mutual Benefit Life
description: A roof. Four walls. A firm foundation. That's about all it takes to make a building.

title: Friendly Feathers
description: Now that there's been a backlash against socialites' wearing shahtoosh, derived from the wool of the endangered Tibetan antelope, luxury seekers are swathing themselves in more environmentally friendly coverups. A year and a half ago, Larissa Schutt, an American designer in Hong Kong whose label is called Wild by Schutt, started making boas and shawls with feathers that are either naturally shed or the byproducts of birds farmed for food. ''The idea is to do something for the environment and conservation,'' she said. ''It's a way of bringing the outdoors into fashion in an unconventional way.''

title: In Evening Dress or Karate Gear, a Champion
description: JENNIFER GIACOBBE stretched out her bare feet with their painted pink toenails. She watched as her mother, Mary Ann, teased and sprayed her straight blond hair into a glamorous upsweep for a very special occasion: the last father-daughter banquet she would attend at the Ursuline School here, where she is a senior. Jennifer, a slender and soft-spoken 17-year-old who was recently crowned Miss New York American Teen, looked as traditionally feminine as the next girl when she stepped out in her long black velvet evening dress with her father, John. But when she competes for the national title of Miss American Teen for the Year 2000 at Disney World on Thanksgiving weekend, she will not be wearing satin ballet slippers or shiny tap shoes. She will be barefoot, her painted toenails gleaming, as she demonstrates the expert karate kicks that helped win her the state title.

title: Beauty, In the Eye Of the Beholder; Sacred Heart Cathedral
description: A roof. Four walls. A firm foundation. That's about all it takes to make a building.

title: It Takes a (Bigger, Better) Village
description: SKIING may not have grown much in the last several years, but North American ski areas have exploded with development. According to the National Ski Areas Association, last season there were 52 million skier and snowboarder visits, down about 4 percent from the previous year. The number of skier-snowboarder visits has hovered between 52 million and 54 million for the past five years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRADY, SHIRLEY J.
description: GRADY-Shirley J. Of Chatham Township, NJ, on November 11, 1999. Beloved wife of William J. Grady. Mother of Trisha Grady and her husband, Richard Lieberman, of Sunnyside, NY; Kathy Grady and her husband, Alan Godchaux, of New Orleans, LA; and Mike Grady and his wife, Margaret, of Chatham, NJ. Sister of Jill Hatmaker of Powell, WY, and Carl Hups of Denver, CO. Also survived by her grandchildren Sara and Madeleine Godchaux, Morgan Lieberman, and Zachary, Nicole and Samuel Grady. Friends and family are invited to gather for a time of remembering at the Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main St. (Rt. 124), Chatham, NJ, on Sunday, November 14, at 2 PM. Those who wish may contribute in her memory to the Atlantic Homecare Hospice, 33 Bleeker St, Millburn, NJ 07041.

title: Developing a Site On West 23rd Street
description: To the Editor:

title: PERSPECTIVE; From Tragedy To Triumph: O'Hara Event Is a Beacon
description: What is it about sports that soothes the soul during the worst of times? The perfect move in time and space that embodies the grace of life itself? Or maybe the reassurance that we are alive to watch this game and to hope one more time for victory.

title: Be Medicareful
description: As an administrator of the Medicaid program, I have heard many stories and seen many justifications for transferring funds and ''giving gifts.'' What it comes down to is that relatives do not like to see money they regard as their inheritance paid to a nursing home.

title: Mining Her Memories To Play a Troubled Soul
description: IN the pantheon of film actresses, Winona Ryder is becoming almost as well known for her eyes as Bette Davis. Ms. Ryder's, of course, are brown, not blue. On screen, they appear black, enormous and extraordinarily expressive, bearing a striking similarity to those of the cartoon character Princess Mononoke in the Japanimation feature of the same name. Off screen, they look large, but less unreal.

title: H.M.O. Mystery, Cont.
description: To the Editor:

title: Cross-Country at Lake Tahoe
description: THE first snow to whiten the Sierra,'' wrote the 19th-century naturalist John Muir, ''usually falls about the end of October or early in November to a depth of a few inches.'' That snow usually melts, he noted, but then, ''with intervals of splendid sunshine, storm succeeds storm, heaping snow on snow, until 30 to 50 feet has fallen.''

title: Teachers of the Year
description: Two northern Westchester teachers have been recognized for their efforts.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: A Sense of Place

title: Vinyl or CD, Where Sounds Abound
description: RECORD stores'' can't be called record stores anymore. To do so dates a person as having grown up before the era of compact discs, back when the only things replacing vinyl albums were reel-to-reel tapes or eight-tracks.

title: Best of Three Worlds?
description: To the Editor:

title: Beauty, In the Eye Of the Beholder; A Old Factory
description: A roof. Four walls. A firm foundation. That's about all it takes to make a building.

title: Friends, Indeed: Stories From the Heart; The Women's Movement And Two Women Who Moved
description: TELL us about your best friends, we said. And you did.

title: Lower East Side TV Crew Used Good-Neighbor Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Airport Lounges
description: To to Editor: Apropos of the mention of airport lounges in the Practical Traveler (''Mix and Match Frills on Flights,'' Oct. 31), some more information may be useful.

title: Hard Landing
description: The ousted prime minister of Pakistan, Nawaz Sharif, was accused of conspiring to hijack a commercial aircraft carrying his dismissed army chief, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, now Pakistan's military ruler. Mr. Sharif is charged with refusing to let the plane land. It was only because the armed forces seized the airport in Karachi -- and control of the country -- that the plane was able to land with seven minutes to spare. If convicted, Mr. Sharif could be executed. CELIA W. DUGGER

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Love Undetectable: Notes on Friendship, Sex, and Survival

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUCHMAN, SAM
description: SCHUCHMAN-Sam. Of Fort Lee, NJ. Beloved husband of the late Nadia. Devoted father of Leonard Schuchman and Dorothy Kaplan. Loving grandfather of Nancy, Ted, Benjamin, Abe, Michelle, David, and great grandfather of Jason, Katie, Kyla, Matthew, Adam, Mason, Lauren. Services were held ''Wien & Wien'', (1-800-378-1892).

title: The Rockets May Be Better Off Without Barkley
description: After his fracas with Shaquille O'Neal last Wednesday night, Charles Barkley walked briskly down a corridor of the Compaq Center in Houston. He had just been thrown out of a game the Rockets would go on to lose to the Lakers, dropping Houston to 0-5 for the first time since 1982.

title: Pick-Me-Ups Pick-You-Ups; A Pause That Civilizes
description: Little sandwiches of cucumber, water-cress or herring, followed by a salad of fresh mozzarella, tomato and basil. A mini brioche with smoked salmon and creme fraiche. The tea of your choice and mini pastries that are almost too pretty to eat.

title: Conspiracy Theorist
description: DENMARK VESEY

title: 'E.R.' Is Back on Its Feet After Major Surgery
description: THE blood on the floor on the set of ''E.R.'' at Warner Brothers looks perfectly real. The freshly painted lime-green walls have that hospital look. The nurses' desk is covered with medical records and stethoscopes. ''Nothing's really changed,'' said Anthony Edwards, whose role as Dr. Mark Greene on the top-rated drama for the last five years is even more powerful this season. ''And maybe everything's changed.''

title: Affirmative Action in Florida
description: When Ward Connerly, a key figure in overturning affirmative action programs in California, began collecting signatures to get a similar referendum placed on the ballot in Florida, Republican strategists had reason to worry. The last thing they need now is a nasty fight over affirmative action that would boost turnout among African-Americans and other Democratic constituencies. That would only make it tougher for Republicans seeking election to Congress from Florida, as well as for the presidential campaign of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, who considers Florida a pivotal state.

title: The Struggle to Stay on the Trail; Kicked Off Land by New Owners, Hiking Routes Are Redrawn, Sometimes Onto Roads
description: FOR those who have taken to the woods this season to see the fall foliage, a walk along the 700-mile Blue-Blazed Hiking Trail System may seem like a peaceful respite.

title: Here Lies Ichabod Crane, But You'd Hardly Know It
description: The gravestone of Col. Ichabod B. Crane, who may have lent his name to the schoolteacher pursued by the Headless Horseman in Washington Irving's story ''The Legend of Sleepy Hollow,'' lies vandalized in the corner of a graveyard on Richmond Avenue.

title: Foes Object to Seagoing Flagpoles at Landlocked Parks
description: The removal of several flagpoles from parks throughout the city has met with a mixed reception.

title: Muni Offering on Web Pays Off
description: Pittsburgh officials said last week that they had received twice as many bidders as expected for the city's sale of $55 million of general obligation bonds, offered directly to investors online.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Q & A
description: Classes in Cuba

title: In the Alps, Precautions Against Avalanches
description: After avalanches last February killed dozens of skiers and villagers in Switzerland, Austria and France, authorities in those countries have strengthened precautions against such disasters.

title: Pick-Me-Ups Pick-You-Ups; By Land, by Sea And By River
description: Sharks at the office got you on the run? Take a breather and get some perspective with a visit to the real toothy predators of the undersea world at the New Jersey State Aquarium in Camden.

title: As the Stock Rally Broadens, The Role of the Fed Grows
description: HERE'S some good news ahead of the meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers on Tuesday: The stock market rally is broadening. More stocks are doing better -- or at least not as poorly as they once were -- compared with the Standard & Poor's 500 Index.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Home Ice Still a Disadvantage for the Rangers
description: Perhaps it is fortunate for the Rangers that their next five games are away from Madison Square Garden.

title: L.I.'s Biggest Export? Try Standup Comedy
description: JERRY SEINFELD of Massapequa. Billy Crystal of Long Beach. Rosie O'Donnell of Commack. Eddie Murphy of Roosevelt. A disproportionate number of the hottest stars in comedy -- stars who are so big they get to be called entertainers, for god's sake -- come from Long Island. Why?

title: Elizabeth Wydler, James Golden
description: Elizabeth Ann Wydler, a daughter of Brenda E. Wydler of Garden City, N.Y., and the late Representative John W. Wydler, was married yesterday to James Drew Golden, a son of Virginia and Matthew Golden of Garden City. The Rev. Brian J. McNamara performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church there.

title: The Other Stuff
description: JOHN GLENN

title: Habitats/Roosevelt Island; An Apartment in the City, But a Little Bit Out of It
description: ROOSEVELT ISLAND doesn't feel like any other part of the city. Walking down its main street, just a few minutes by subway from midtown Manhattan, it's easy to imagine that this is a postwar suburb of some European city, with its harsh, concrete storefronts suddenly softened by the sight of the river, and some autumn-flowering bushes.

title: Acrostics
description: I was dismayed when I turned to the acrostic puzzle a few Sundays ago and saw that it hadn't been composed by Thomas Middleton. What has happened to him?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEE, TIMOTHY, M.D.
description: GEE-Timothy, M.D. The Medical Staff of St. Vincent's Hospital notes with sorrow the passing of an esteemed colleague and friend. Dr. Gee, an international authority in the treatment of leukemia, will be remembered for his warmth and compassion. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Joseph M. Jabbour, M.D. President of the Medical Staff St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York

title: In Pay Dispute at Radio City, Orchestra Authorizes a Strike
description: The Radio City Orchestra, a mainstay of the 67-year-old music hall and its Christmas Spectacular, has voted to authorize a strike if current negotiations with the hall's management fail, union officials said last night.

title: Caution With Dryer's Exhaust Vent
description: IT is not difficult to attach an exhaust vent to a clothes dryer, but the hookup must be done properly to avoid the possibility of fire. According to the National Fire Protection Association, almost 14,000 fires each year are caused by improper venting of the dryer or careless maintenance procedures.

title: Israeli Sale Raises Fears
description: For years, the Clinton administration has voiced its disapproval of Israel's arms sales to China. But the latest deal -- the sale of a sophisticated $250 million airborne radar system known as Phalcon -- stirred greater than usual concerns, especially regarding American technology and the threat to Taiwan. At week's end, Israel assured Washington that the system contained no American technology. STEVEN LEE MYERS

title: Running Time: 17,356,680 Minutes
description: MATINEE IDYLLS

title: Morning Becomes Bryant Gumbel
description: As I read Bill Carter's article (Oct. 24), I thought I might have stumbled onto a late entry to the issue ''The Me Millennium.'' Bryant Gumbel certainly came across as self-serving, self-pitying and catty.

title: Corruption in Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Goodbye Broadway, Hello 42nd Street
description: HMV, the music and video chain, closed its prominent location at 2081 Broadway, at 72nd Street, last Sunday. Mark Anthony, a security officer, said ''the rent's too high,'' and that the store was moving to 234 West 42nd Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. HMV will open there on Saturday, but Ken Feldman, director of marketing in the United States, said: ''It's actually not a direct move. It's more a matter of coincidence that the move is happening at the same time.''

title: A Land Where Death Is a Fact of Life
description: THE long, sad list of casualties from this country's internecine slaughter continues to lengthen -- most recently with the deaths of eight people last week in a car-bombing in Bogota. To the toll of those killed by paramilitary groups and guerrillas in the region's longest-running civil conflict must be added those murdered by drug cartels and criminal gangs, as well as a new set of victims: the 140 young boys kidnapped, tortured, raped and butchered by a serial killer who confessed his five-year killing spree to the police late last month.

title: Thousands Relive the Horror As New Disaster Hits Region
description: When the ground beneath her home began to sway on Friday evening, Leman Ongor thought she was living through just another aftershock from the devastating earthquake that shook this region three months ago.

title: In the Region/Westchester; Sales Picking Up the Pace in the Co-op Market
description: SOMETHING has happened to the county's co-op market that would have seemed inconceivable just a few years ago: Some real estate agents are complaining that they have few apartments to sell. ''My brokers are just starting to farm for inventory,'' said Liz Lindsey, who owns a real estate agency in Mount Vernon that bears her name.

title: The Very Best of Friends; Lots of Differences, and a Whole Lot in Common
description: TELL us about your best friends, we said. And you did.

title: Remnants of a War Hidden in the Soil
description: AN archaeology teacher at Joel Barlow High School in Redding is leading a group of students and volunteers on an excavation of Israel Putnam Memorial State Park, work that is proving a hunch he and other historians have had for years: What was believed to be a cemetery for 25 Continental Army soldiers is actually the site of a field officer's quarters during the 1778-79 army encampment in Connecticut.

title: Clothes Unmake The Man
description: I once had a girlfriend who bought me clothes. At first this made me extremely happy, but then something changed, and these gifts, which had seemed such a pure expression of love, began to seem like little apologies.

title: Pick-Me-Ups, Pick-You-Ups; LLAMA MAMAS AND MORE
description: Baby pigs suckle in the farrowing house. Goats, sheep, geese, ducks, rabbits, horses, ponies and dairy and beef cattle graze in their pens. Though it's not a petty zoo, all the animals at the Suffolk County Cornell Cooperative Extension's 220-acre farm and education center in Yaphank can be petted and hand-fed. For suburbanities, this is a good as it gets. But for a real treat, save the sliced carrots ($1 per bag in the gift shop) for the alternative livestocks: 21 llamas and an alpaca named Steeley Dan. ''We try to stay within a working farm, but not necessarily a Long Island farm,'' aid Tabitha Haubold, an extension education and animal science program manager. Hence, the three-year-old active breeding program for South American llamas. One stud llama will father all the babies due next spring; the gestation period for llamas is 350 days.

title: Cooking Up Meals for Holidays
description: HOLIDAYS and home-cooked meals used to be synonymous. In some parts of the country, going to a restaurant on Thanksgiving or Christmas would be unthinkable.

title: The Shadow Designer
description: Even without the Michael Kors ''cashgora'' poncho in pumpkin that was draped over her shoulders, June Horne would have stood out at the breast-cancer benefit held in late September at the flagship store of Saks Fifth Avenue. As she roamed around the Kors shop within Saks, chatting ebulliently with the designer, embracing old friends and glad-handing customers, her wattage surged to a fuse-blowing level. Horne is in her mid-40's, with a beautiful milk-chocolate complexion, brilliantined hair la Josephine Baker and a full-bodied figure. She looks not like a waif who models designer clothes but like a customer who actually buys and wears them.

title: Apartment For Use by Landlord
description: Q. I am a landlord of a rent stabilized building. When one of our stabilized apartments was vacated, we completely renovated it. We then approached a tenant who has an apartment next to the one we live in and asked if they would consider moving into the renovated unit so we could expand our own space. The square footage of both apartments is the same, but the rent on the renovated apartment is more than the rent on the tenant's current apartment and the apartment is one flight higher. The tenant, who has been in the building for 20 years, refused. What are my chances of getting this space in an eviction from an apartment based on owner occupancy? . . . Thomas Wittschen, Brooklyn.

title: Scorched Earth
description: THE SOUL OF BATTLE

title: Joseph Colaprico, Katia Latsinik
description: Ekaterina Alexandra Latsinik, the daughter of Albina and Alexander Latsinik of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Joseph Stephen Colaprico, the son of Mary Jane Colaprico of Little Neck, Queens, and Joseph P. Colaprico of Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. Samuel Morgen, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Thanksgiving Cobblers That Are as Easy as Pie but Lighter
description: ASSUMING the planning for Thanksgiving is already under way, imagine the holiday meal without pie. Well, not exactly. Consider Thanksgiving with a cobbler instead. And with good reason.

title: At Museums, Admit One and a Shopping List; A Zeolite to Call Your Own
description: Young rock collectors can add to their stash at the Trailside Nature and Science Center gift shop. The shop has a collection of minerals for sale, including green and purple zeolites found in a Somerset County quarry and fluorescent minerals from the Patterson area. Minerals from other areas around the country are also sold. Prices range from 50 cents to $4.

title: Taps Play at a Legion Hall For the Veterans Days of Old
description: THE SETTING -- The wood-paneled bar at Canarsie Post 573, a brick American Legion Hall built in 1928. Outside, floodlights illuminated a granite obelisk with the inscription, ''Dedicated to the residents of Canarsie who gave their lives in defense of this country.'' Two plastic floral wreaths left over from Memorial Day flanked the monument. Nearby, an American and a P.O.W. flag grudgingly rose to the attention of a pesky breeze on an otherwise mild Veterans Day.

title: Boulez Gets a Chance To Make Converts
description: PIERRE BOULEZ will probably never shake off the reputation he earned in his 20's as a fearsome polemicist on behalf of the most complex contemporary music, including his own. He emerged from Europe in the 1950's as the leading advocate of the post-Webern school of serialism, or 12-tone music, or -- to use the term Mr. Boulez preferred in his theoretical writings -- dodecaphonic music. In one essay, published in Paris in 1952, he unequivocally declared that any musician who has not felt ''the necessity of the dodecaphonic language is of no use.'' So much for Stravinsky, who was still producing Neo-Classical masterpieces at the time, as well as such essentially tonal composers as Britten and Shostakovich, who were then in their creative primes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGER, OSCAR
description: UNGER-Oscar. On November 13, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Gertrude; loving father of Robert and Arthur and father in-law of Susan and Lois; dear grandfather of Jonathan, Kenneth, Brian, Adam and Peter.

title: Up From Flea Markets, With Vintage Rags for Sale
description: There isn't an awning yet at Rags-a-GoGo at 218 West 14th Street (between Seventh and Eighth Avenues), but there is a white dry-erase board advertising shirts and sweaters for $12, pants and jeans for $18, dresses and jean jackets for $20, and leather, suede, wool, corduroy and plush coats for $28. The clothes at the store, which opened in September, are vintage.

title: Correspondence/Sino-Sayings; Not-so-Ancient Chinese Proverb: Glib Truisms Gloss Over Reality
description: A few years ago, when I took a visiting editor out to the Chinese countryside for a taste of rural life, I had an opportunity to show off my proficiency in Chinese -- or thought I did. We came upon a peasant working a field 50 miles outside Shanghai, and struck up a conversation. The farmer spoke of how things had changed in his village thanks to the arrival of television and, more recently, a video store. His thick rural accent proved no problem: I proudly translated for my boss.

title: If Your Mom Were a Restaurant Chef . . .
