description: TO me, comfort food has an association both with comfort and an ability to comfort. In its more common and recognizable form, comfort food is warm, smooth, straightforward and reminiscent of home.

title: A Growing Market for Mansions of the Sea
description: AS he prepared for the Fort Lauderdale International Boat Show two weeks ago, where a half-billion dollars would change hands over the next four days, Mike Kelsey Sr., a 40-year veteran of the boat-building industry, repeated his prayer of gratitude: ''Thank God there are rich people who love the water and will pay us to do what we do.''

title: Savoring Inspiration Amid the Mundane
description: A SANCTUARY for the soul. An endless source of inspiration.

title: The Battle Of the Binge
description: Hitt's suggestion that the solution to campus binge drinking is to teach ''the obvious pleasure of drinking . . . by example'' is both illogical and inaccurate. In one paragraph, he extols the good old days of the 1970's, during which he, on the one hand, survived his own drinking career, describing how he was surrounded by responsible (?) adults while doing his drinking, and, on the other, mentioning at least one episode he is unwilling to recount in a family newspaper. Is this the method he recommends to teach students responsible alcohol consumption?

title: Returns to Senders; Snail Mail: It's Alive! And It's Mutating!
description: THE United Parcel Service, with its fleet of unfashionable brown trucks and brown-uniformed drivers, picks up big boxes, moves them around the world and then drops them off. Founded in 1907, the company is in many ways a quintessential bricks-and-mortar business, the kind that the new economy of the Internet was supposed to overshadow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIBELLINO, ROBERT M.
description: RIBELLINO-Robert M. On November 12, 1999. Beloved father of Marisa Kidwell and grandfather of Darien. Devoted son of James V. Jr. and Ingrid (nee Kvamli). Loving brother of James V. III, Bruce, and Dan and Craig Olsen. Funeral Tuesday, 9 AM, from the Andrew Torregrossa and Sons Funeral Home, 1305 79 St, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial 9:30 AM, Saint Bernadette Church. Entombment Moravian Cemetery. Visiting Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-10 PM.

title: Heather Simpson, David Wilson
description: Heather Ann Simpson, the daughter of Ellie Hatcher Simpson of Corona del Mar, Calif., and the late John D. Simpson, was married yesterday to David Matthew Wilson, a son of Eileen and Thomas W. Wilson of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. Thomas Morette, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. John and St. Mary in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: The Father Hunt
description: EDDIE'S BASTARD By William Kowalski. 367 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $24.

title: Beauty, In the Eye Of the Beholder; A Barn Near Lambertville
description: A roof. Four walls. A firm foundation. That's about all it takes to make a building.

title: Britain Goes Modern; Black Rod and the Day Boys? No, It's Not a Rock Group.
description: WHO liked the House of Lords when it was packed full of aristocrats with inherited titles? Not Walter Bagehot, the 19th century writer, who said that ''the cure for admiring the House of Lords is to go and look at it.''

title: A Million Reasons The TV Quiz Show Has Struck It Rich
description: For more than 40 years, the prime-time network quiz show was considered a hopelessly dead television format, killed off at the peak of its popularity in the 1950's by the self-inflicted wounds of rigged questions and answers, phony champions and fake drama.

title: Riders Sitting High in the Saddle
description: SOME of Westchester County's finest riders and horses jumped to the head of their classes last weekend when they joined the country's top equestrian competitors at Madison Square Garden for the 116th National Horse Show. Even to qualify for the premier equestrian event in the United States is an honor -- the show includes Olympic and world championship competitors -- and Westchester riders and horses not only participated. In many cases they also won.

title: Best Buys: $1 and Elbow Grease Give Old Buildings New Lives
description: TWO years ago, Bruce A. Blakeman, presiding officer of the Nassau County Legislature, posed an intriguing question to Geri Barish, a breast cancer survivor and the president of 1 in 9: The Long Island Breast Cancer Action Coalition:

title: SOUTH KOREA SEEN TRYING TO EXTEND RANGE OF MISSILES
description: United States intelligence analysts have discovered evidence that South Korea is trying to develop longer-range ballistic missiles while keeping some of the program's key aims secret from Washington, American officials say.

title: POSTINGS: A $175 Million Gift, a $100 Million Upgrading; 2 New Buildings for Polytechnic U. in Brooklyn
description: With the benefit of a $175 million gift from a former professor of chemical engineering, Donald F. Othmer, Polytechnic University is planning a $100 million investment to upgrade its main campus in downtown Brooklyn. The improvements include the campus's first residence hall and a new academic building with an athletic facility, also a first for the university.

title: Fears Grow Over the De Facto Partition of Kosovo
description: Senior Western and United Nations officials say they are increasingly worried about a de facto partition of Kosovo, and they fear that President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia may be using the north of the province to undermine international efforts to bring Kosovo peace and normality.

title: Taking a Holiday From the Traditional Fare
description: FOR diners who are anti-turkey, anti-stuffing and anti-cranberry sauce, Thanksgiving looms as a very glum day. Few restaurants are open, other than those celebrating the holiday full throttle. But there are alternatives that have their own charm. Ethnic Indian restaurants, for example, tend to stay open on Thanksgiving, and there are other possibilities as well. Following is a sampling of places to have a festive meal. All take reservations and credit cards, unless otherwise noted.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 14, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Fashionistas Have Fun, Too
description: Executives at Mattel and Hasbro are getting some unexpected competition from Seventh Avenue this toy-buying season. It started last fall when Miuccia Prada introduced her signature backgammon set ($670), but now as the much-hyped 1999 holidays approach, Ms. Prada is releasing a handful of toys and games packaged in nylon carrying cases in a line called Millennium Gifts. They include tarot cards ($92), a stainless-steel tick-tack-toe set ($350) and a shiny red metal yo-yo (right, $184). The novelty items, in stores before Thanksgiving, are meant to be exotic, over-the-top presents for the last round of 20th-century revelry.

title: From Here to Eternity: Choice Burial Sites
description: FOR sale: rolling hills, natural landscaping and water views in historic East End neighborhood, $750. It sounds too good to be true, but it is true. And yes, people are dying to get in.

title: The Pope Perseveres
description: It was not all that surprising that John Paul II was snubbed by hard-line Hindu religious leaders in India. He preached interfaith tolerance but also insisted on the right of Roman Catholics to evangelize in a country where Christian missionaries are increasingly attacked by Hindu fundamentalists.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-14-99: The Ethicist; Knit Picking
description: My sister was going to buy some colorful sweaters to use in a family picture and then return them. When I chided her about this, she said it was the same as when I went to Barnes & Noble and looked up phone numbers for European restaurants in the Michelin guide without buying the book. What do you think? M.L., Vermont

title: The Cable Guys
description: The Reform Party behaves like a deform party. Politics gets shabbier and shabbier, turning now to what amounts to circus clowns. All these wannabes have to offer is a slogan or the attitude that ''I can do it better than the next guy.''

title: A Disappearing Act With Wires
description: FOR most New York City residents, the information highway is as much eyesore as access route: a tangle of wires bursting from the backs of computers, fax machines, telephones, television sets and home entertainment systems to snake their way around the apartment and into the ultimate scar upon a latex paint landscape -- a drill hole, outlet or jack. Not even hallways are exempt; witness the ever-yellowing plastic molding that graces many a ceiling -- a sure sign that cable installers were here.

title: The View From/Stony Creek; Library Exhibit Shows The Tale of Quarries That Dominated a Town
description: TODAY, most people think of Stony Creek as a pleasant residential enclave, the gateway to the picturesque Thimble Islands. Yet for 150 years this waterfront village of 1,200, part of the town of Branford, was famous for the quarries that produced vast quantities of granite used in construction.

title: BENEFITS
description: Autumn Ball

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Woodside, Queens; A Polyglot Enclave, At First, 'Irishtown'
description: WITH several subway lines -- including one, the No. 7, with 61st Street as the first rush-hour express stop in Queens out of Manhattan, service by three bus companies and a Long Island Rail Road stop -- Woodside is a place where people don't need a car, even though it's easy to have one.

title: There's Writing and There's Screenwriting
description: ''THE Cider House Rules'' was published in 1985. That same year I began work on the screenplay, which I continued for 13 years, until the Swedish director Lasse Hallstrom shot the film in the fall of last year. Miramax will release the movie on Dec. 10.

title: The Very Best of Friends; Seventy-Five Years Later, and Still Going Strong
description: TELL us about your best friends, we said. And you did.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-14-99: On Language; N.Y.T. Style
description: On Nov. 1, the president of the United States lost his capital.

title: Vanity Goes to the Doctor; Today's dermatologists are remaking themselves as beauty gurus and even opening spas.
description: DR. SETH MATARASSO'S patients often book an entire morning or afternoon for treatments. ''We'll start from the bottom with the leg veins and work our way to the top, with the liver spots on the hands and back,'' said Dr. Matarasso, a dermatologist in San Francisco. ''Then, we do their Botox, collagen and Derma-Peel. We may even do a micro-liposuction underneath the neck and around the knees.''

title: Concerns Over New Station in Westport
description: THOMAS PAPAN seems to understand the habits of Metro North train commuters better than most people, a talent he says has grown while tending his coffee shop business at Railroad Place in Westport for the past 25 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAFT, EVE F.
description: KRAFT-Eve F. The entire New York Junior Tennis League family mourns the passing of our dear friend Eve, who inspired and guided our mission to grow the sport of tennis for NYC youngsters. We will miss her untiring passion, creativity and brillance in developing community tennis programs in schools and public parks. She truly transformed the sport of tennis. Our heartfelt condolences to Ken, Rob and the rest of her family.

title: Morning Becomes Bryant Gumbel
description: I remember an episode on the ''Today'' show many years ago. The film ''Tap,'' starring Sammy Davis Jr. and Gregory Hines, was being promoted. Gumbel's guest was an old hoofer, Sandman Sims, or one of his contemporaries who had also appeared in the movie. He presented Gumbel with a pair of autographed tap shoes from the cast and asked that Gumbel put them on. Gumbel refused several times although the dancer practically pleaded with him to do so. It made for an uncomfortable viewing experience. Gumbel would not try them on even out of respect for the elderly dancer. He would not try those shoes on for the charm of the moment. He would not try them on to be a ''sport.'' Bryant Gumbel lost me as a viewer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARDS, CARMELA
description: RICHARDS-Carmela. On November 12, 1999. Beloved wife of Jeremiah Richards; sister of Peter and the late Raymond Pirozzi; aunt of Peter Jr. and Gay Pirozzi. Daughter of the late Joseph and Betena Pirozzi. Friends may call at The Abbey, 1076 Madison Ave, 81 St, Sunday and Monday. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Jean Baptiste Church, Lexington Ave at 76 St, Tuesday 11 AM. Interment to follow at Mt. Calvary Cemetery, White Plains, NY.

title: Corrections
description: A Q & A answer on Page 16 of the Travel section today, about traveling to Kobarid, Slovenia, omits a word in some copies. The affected passage should read: ''From the Venice airport, take a bus to Mestre and get off at the train station. From there, trains to Gorizia, on the Italian-Slovenian border, leave every hour or two at 53 minutes past the hour.''

title: Clean Plates, Clean Ties
description: Wearing a napkin like a bib was once a practice reserved for little kids and for your embarrassing uncle. But now, at Tropica, a seafood restaurant in the MetLife Building, power-lunching executives can be seen sporting their napkins at their necks through a specially tailored buttonhole that allows them to attach the napkins below the collars of their starched shirts.

title: A Life Goes On
description: Whether it was direct or indirect, Philip Workman had a role in the police officer's death. That fact isn't in dispute. Workman made a choice and he must face the consequences. For the past 17 years, the officer's family has lived with its loss. Your article pulled my heartstrings not for Workman but for the officer's loved ones.

title: The Invisible Population, The Gays Next Door; At Work, Home and School, a Minority Often Under Attack
description: ''EITHER our neighbors have figured it out, and they're still friendly to us -- or they think we're just sisters,'' Karen Carr, a lesbian living with her companion in a suburban neighborhood of this city, said last week.

title: The Rival Preserver Of Balanchine's Flame
description: YOU see her yield completely, fainting with a soft abandon in a supported deep back bend, and before you see the recovery, she is already standing apart, mild and free, as if in thought.''

title: THE WORLD: A Literature of Fear; After Apartheid, White Anxiety
description: THE old order has vanished and the new world disorients, dislocates, unsettles. Television sets hum with the unintelligible clicks of Zulu and Xhosa. White men beg on street corners. Black judges rule from the bench. And the violence once banished to the townships spills uncontrollably beyond their borders, destabilizing the safe zones, the white zones.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: How a Pair of Plays Gain Longer Lives
description: FOR everybody's good, not to mention the whole world of theater, Doug Hughes and David Saint not only believe that regional theaters should work together, but also are making it happen, once again, with two new works: ''Syncopation,'' by Allan Knee, and ''Down the Garden Paths,'' by Anne Meara.

title: Bordeaux-Style Reds Make Presence Known
description: BORDEAUX-STYLE red blends, widely found in California, have not yet fully gripped the imaginations of all East End winegrowers. Only about 10 are currently on the market, from the East End's 24 producers, with two more in barrel and bottle awaiting release. But at a fairly high price level, they are a potentially important feature of producers' individual portfolios and thus the overall Long Island scene.

title: Deborah Lewis, Russell Kern
description: Deborah Ann Lewis, a daughter of Phoebe and Robert Lewis of Kings Point, N.Y., was married last evening to Russell Arlen Kern, a son of Madeleine and Jack Kern, also of Kings Point. Rabbi Myron Fenster performed the ceremony at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, N.Y.

title: Who Pays for Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: Masterpieces Returned
description: Cat burglars dropped through the skylight of a San Francisco museum in 1978 and stole four 17th-century Dutch Masters, one of them attributed to Rembrandt. Now three of the paintings have mysteriously surfaced, left in a box at Manhattan's William Doyle galleries. The bad news: the paintings were in sad shape. JOHN KIFNER

title: My High-School Muse
description: Deirdre LaPenna didn't dress like anybody else for school. It was the early 70's in our plain Long Island suburb, and with a grace that seemed both childlike and cosmopolitan, she appeared in high school, day after day, in outfits -- from Donna Reed dresses to brocade-trimmed suits -- that intrigued the ranks of us conformist kids in straight-leg jeans and corduroys. She was not the fashion-addicted yenta of ''Clueless'' or the smoldering vixen of ''American Beauty.'' She was the artsy and talented blonde with a naughty streak -- beautiful and askew -- who was liked by everyone, even the vice principal, who busted her for smoking.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Page 28 of the Long Island section today with an article about local Web sites misidentifies a man pictured with the home page of Long Island Globalink. He is Richard Arfin, owner and creator of the Globalink site and its parent company, Long Island Online Services Inc., of Hauppauge; he is not Michael Watt, director of the search engine LongIsland.com.

title: The Past Is Another Country
description: PAST FORGETTING

title: Why the Berlin Wall Came Down
description: To the Editor:

title: London's Example
description: To the Editor: At a time when New York seems more clogged than ever with unnecessary vehicles, how refreshing to read that some cities are able to buck the dead end that is auto dependency (''London Bans Cars on Some Soho Streets,'' Travel Advisory, Oct. 3).

title: Jacob Glick, 73, Violist, Coach And Champion of New Music
description: Jacob Glick, a violist admired for his championship of new music and his performances on the Baroque viola d'amore, died on Nov. 1 at the Southwestern Vermont Medical Center in Bennington. He was 73 and lived in New York and Bennington.

title: Sudan's Slaves and War Get a Second Look
description: WHAT'S an ambitious senator to do? Get re-elected or awaken the world to slavery in faraway Sudan? That was the crux of a recent episode of ''Touched by an Angel.'' Oversimplified and a mite soppy, the show presented one character who reflected American attitudes toward Sudan (and most African countries for that matter).

title: After the Fire
description: FOR most of her 20 years at the Manhasset, an ornate century-old building at Broadway and 109th Street, Hilary Schlessiger worked at home, writing children's books in the study of her spacious two-bedroom apartment. When her work lagged or her thoughts grew stale, the lanky, wiry-haired writer would reinspire herself by strolling the hallways and listening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISELIN, BETTY BING
description: ISELIN-Betty Bing. Of Long Branch, New Jersey, and New York City on November 11, 1999. Wife of the late Philip H. Iselin, President of the New York Jets and Monmouth Jockey Club. She was the creator and Chairman of the Monmouth Park Charity Ball, which funded Monmouth County charitable organizations for more than fifty years. She served as a gubernatorial appointee to the New Jersey Board of Institutions and Agencies in the 1950's and 60's. She was the beloved mother of Kay Iselin Gilman Ahlstrom and Jimmy Iselin, the devoted motherin-law of Ruthanne T. Iselin and the enthusiastic and involved grandmother of Emmett Nicholas & Mark Gilman, Robin and Jamie Iselin and the great-grandmother of Ryan Gilman. A graveside service will be held on Sunday, November 14 at 11 A.M., at the Woodbine Cemetery, Eatontown Boulevard, Oceanport, NJ followed by a memorial luncheon at the Hollywood Golf Club, Roseld Avenue Deal at 12 noon. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Monmouth Park Charity Fund, PO Box MP, Oceanport, NJ 07757 or the New York Service for the Handicapped, 853 Broadway, NY, NY 10003 would be deeply appreciated. For further information, please call Kay Gilman at 212-371-7017 or Ruthanne Iselin at 212-289-9375.

title: Soldier Presidents
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIELS, IRWIN H.
description: DANIELS-Irwin H. On November 12, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia, loving father of Arleen D. Auerbach. Dear father-in-law of Robert Auerbach. Cherished grandfather of Steven and Laura. Adoring great-grandfather of Anya and Alex. He will be deeply missed. Service Sunday 11:15am at the Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: America Style for Thanksgiving
description: The Champagne region and its people, the Champenois, argue accurately that Champagne at dinner can go with everything. All the more reason at Thanksgiving to serve the best low-priced American sparkling wine, made in -- seriously -- Albuquerque, N.M.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Scary on the Outside
description: Wendell Mayo's beguiling B. HORROR: And Other Stories (Livingston, paper, $11) contains, as the title suggests, narratives that are often loosely based on the plots and themes of cheap horror films. ''Mary Magdalena Versus Godzilla'' tracks a man's lifelong attempts to entertain (and later, in a way, to save) his sister through his obsession with Godzilla; ''B. Horror'' contrasts the terror a young actor tries to evoke in his stage performances, in which he re-enacts scenes from B movies, with the terror he sees in reality; and ''Robert's Bride'' is ''Bride of Frankenstein'' retold with depth and sophistication, cataloging a man's confused attraction to his friend's inscrutable fiancee. But Mayo, in his third book, demonstrates that ''horror'' can mean something as simple as fear and apprehension, and in patient, sharp prose, he pushes his characters into small psychic duels, where people come close to understanding each other but can't -- or won't -- get there. The results can be as funny as ''Going Long,'' where a man's obsession with football makes him blind to his estrangement from his wife, or in ''Who Made You,'' where a couple's arguments over a refrigerator, Greenpeace and the Baltimore Catechism make the distance between them all too clear. Mayo can also be a surprisingly poignant writer; ''Woman Without Arms'' is a painterly meditation on a lover's body, prosthetic limbs and all, that raises questions about the nature of physical attraction. There's no need for standard B movie tropes -- Roger Corman's buckets of blood, Ed Wood's bad lighting -- to shock the reader here. In Mayo's world, each character already wears a cheap, unconvincing mask; that these disguises hew so close to reality is terrifying enough. Mark Athitakis

title: Q&A/Dr. Christopher M. Bellitto; Taking Church History Beyond the Pews
description: DR. Christopher M. Bellitto would like to do for Roman Catholic Church history what Ken Burns and Doris Kearns Goodwin have done for American history -- give it mass appeal without demeaning it.

title: Flat Tax Goes From 'Snake Oil' to G.O.P. Tonic
description: Four years ago, when Steve Forbes first promoted the idea of a flat tax, he was ridiculed by his fellow Republicans. ''A truly nutty idea,'' said Lamar Alexander. Others, like Bob Dole and Newt Gingrich, heaped scorn, calling it everything from ''snake oil'' to ''voodoo.''

title: Pick-Me-Ups, Pick-You-Ups; BUBBLE THERAPY

At first bite, the peppermint, basil and eucalyptus combination of essential oils in Peace of Mind gumballs burst with a tingly coolness.

title: Looking at Ancient Egypt, Seeing Modern America

title: Heading Into the New, Gazing Back at the Past
description: IT just wouldn't be a holiday season without devils, robots, talking mice and headless horsemen, all of which are represented in the films opening in the weeks ahead. But distance seems to be the common denominator this year. Most of the lovers are from times past and lands far away (Sweden, Russia, Australia, several from England), and filmmakers seem to be looking to the past. Tim Robbins and Woody Allen chose the 1930's, Barry Levinson and Anthony Minghella the 50's, Mike Leigh and Ang Lee the 19th century, Tim Burton the end of the 18th and Chen Kaige the 3rd. That's one way to deal with the millennium approaching: avoidance. As always, opening dates are liable to change.

title: A Drug for the Heart Helps With Other Serious Ills

Added to standard therapy for heart disease, it lowered risks by about 25 percent. LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

title: Getting Mr. Scaffold on the Line

On a tree trunk near my block in Greenwich Village, a civic-minded neighbor had posted a sign urging passers-by to register complaints about the scaffolding surrounding the church on the corner.

As if the original Philadelphia house where Thomas Jefferson drafted the Declaration of Independence still existed. Or as if historians were able to stand on the actual platform at the exact spot where President Lincoln delivered the Gettysburg Address.

title: They Don't Grow On Trees
description: Fall foliage may be past its peak in the country, but along Madison Avenue it's in full bloom. Fashion designers and home accessories buyers are holding fast to the leaf motif. Prada's hemlines are appliqued with piles of leaves this season, and Fendi is selling handbags decorated with -- what else? -- beaded leaves. Alexis Bittar, a Manhattan jewelry designer, worked all summer carving Lucite pins in the shape of maple and oak leaves in brilliant, gold-tinged hues (left, at Saks Fifth Avenue, $110 to $120 each).

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about alpha male behavior misstated the affiliation of Bobbi S. Low, author of the forthcoming book ''Why Sex Matters.'' She is a professor at the University of Michigan, not Princeton.

title: 'Scent of the Roses' in Nyack
description: ETHEREAL, luminous, luminescent, divine. Julie Harris has evoked just such reverence for almost 50 years. Her sublime performances in a parade of plays must be finite only because we are still counting. And Ms. Harris has put her own magical spin on reality in ways we think of as innumerable ever since she was 24, playing 12-year-old Frankie Addams (''Twelve and three-quarters,'' she will say, never settling for the imprecise.) That was in ''The Member of the Wedding,'' in 1950.

title: Watching While Time the Sculptor Shapes the Self
description: TWO films I directed are opening this week: the new James Bond and ''42 Up.'' Coincidentally, they are the longest-running franchises in the history of their genres -- it's the 19th Bond movie, and the 35th year of a series that has followed the lives of 14 British people every seven years from age 7 to the present day. Any similarities pretty much end there, as ''The World Is Not Enough'' (opening Friday) cost 240 times more to make than ''42 Up'' (opening Wednesday at the Film Forum).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HURNEY, ROSE
description: HURNEY-Rose. Age 81, of Baldwin, NY, died November 2, 1999. Dearest Mom, we will mourn you and miss you all the days of our lives. Love, Eileen, Joe, Mary, Michael and Teresa.

title: Wheelchair Policy
description: To the Editor: I was pleased to read ''Airlines Face Scrutiny Over Wheelchair Policies'' (Correspondent's Report, Sept. 26). I have registered a complaint with the Department of Transportation against American Airlines. After writing to the airline, senators, representatives and various government agencies, I have pursued this as a matter of principle. The airline never said that its actions were wrong, although it did say it was sorry for the inconvenience.

title: For G.O.P., Sure Bet Turns Very Doubtful
description: When George E. Brown Jr., a 79-year-old Democrat representing California's 42nd Congressional District, died last July, Republicans figured they finally had a good shot at capturing the seat that Mr. Brown had held for 27 years. Though Mr. Brown had won 14 straight elections, Republican candidates had been steadily nibbling away at his winning margins as the district, centered on San Bernardino, just east of Los Angeles, grew more and more conservative and Mr. Brown remained steadfastly, unabashedly liberal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIONDATO, DEVINO (MR. NINO)
description: RIONDATO-Devino (Mr. Nino) on November 11, 1999. Loving brother of Luisa and Argia Piazzetta. Beloved brother of Agurino. Lifelong companion of James Nolan. Friends may call Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Funeral 1PM Monday.

title: Vivian Fuchs, Polar Explorer Of the Old School, Dies at 91
description: Sir Vivian Fuchs, the British leader of an international expedition that in 1957 and 1958 made the first surface crossing of Antarctica -- a journey then regarded as the last great challenge of exploration -- died on Thursday in his home in Cambridge, England, his family said Friday. He was 91.

title: New Doctors Step Into a Turbulent World
description: The hospital seemed to her to be full of mystery and concentrated energy. At dawn, there was already a surge of sounds. Doctors' names crackled over the loudspeakers, were repeated, then repeated again. Nurses glided down the hallways, their crepe-soled shoes squeaking, attaching intravenous drips and taking care of little things. A pushy patient bleated for his breakfast. Another, presumably void of hope, chanted, ''Die, why don't I just die?''

title: Corrections

But for 16 years, Simsbury Public Schools have had Superintendent Joseph Townsley, who has a doctorate in education administration, as their leader.

description: MONEY was always a struggle for my family. We had limited means and lived in a community thought to be affluent, which only added to my feeling of being economically deprived while growing up on the western edge of Philadelphia at the end of the Depression and during World War II.

Decompression begins on a velvet-covered featherbed in a dimly lighted room. Slip between the sheets for an hourlong massage that ends with hot, wet towels draped across your back. Then dip into the 360-jet whirlpool bath.

title: With a Huff And a Puff

Rich Barretta, a personal trainer who charges $150 an hour to inspire Manhattan's office-bound bodies, recently opened Duomo at 11 East 26th Street. ''Stepping is pretty much dead,'' he proclaimed, touting instead the latest trend in workouts: aerobic versions of battle, namely capoiera (pronounced ca-PWHERE-ah), which is Brazilian martial arts, and krav maga (pronounced krav ma-GAH), which is Israeli hand-to-hand combat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANSELL, EDMONA LYMAN

She is survived by her husband, Frank L. Mansell; four sons, Robert L. Miller of Los Angeles, CA, Charles B. Miller of Twin Bridges, MT, Christian F. Miller of Hamilton, MT, and Gordon E. Miller of Sante Fe, NM; two daughters, Devon Mansell Laycox of Sherborn, MA, and Jessica Mansell Ambrose of East Hampton, NY; twelve grandchildren; and a sister, Princess Genevieve di San Faustino of San Francisco, CA. A memorial service is planned for Monday, November 15, 1999 at 5 PM at Christ Memorial Chapel, Jupiter Island, FL. Contributions may be made to The Freedom Institute, 515 Madison Avenue, NY, NY 10022.

title: PRIVATE SECTOR; In New Jersey Politics, No Goldman Rematch

Eisenberg, chairman of the Port Authority, announced last week that he would not seek a Senate seat from New Jersey, forgoing a rerun of an old Wall Street grudge match. Mr. Eisenberg, 57, would have been fighting for the Republican nomination and a possible match against Jon S. Corzine, 52, a leading contender on the Democratic side. Both men are natives of Illinois who earned considerable fortunes at Goldman Sachs Group. Both became players in New Jersey politics after their Goldman careers were cut short.

title: The Dresser
description: It begins with a vision -- of myself draped in some undulating material that is the sartorial equivalent of gold dust, living every inch up to the discerning inner shopper I carry around with me as I traipse bewilderedly through the department stores, looking for something perfect to wear -- and it ends in one of those dubious epiphanies where reality comes and finds you out as the person you really are, despite the pair of Robert Clergeries or Walter Steigers on your feet, gleaming as Dorothy's red shoes. Not to mention the piles and piles of returned clothes, all those humiliating trips back to an emporium that once looked on you with such hope only to regard you now with such irritation-cum-suspicion, as you arrive at its door to return a large portion of your carefully selected purchases, an arsenal of explanations and excuses at the ready. This is the story, in other words, of me and my personal shopper.

And it's usually more humbling than self-aggrandizing to realize that things considered particular to one's own era came into being much earlier.

We assembled six experts: Jane Rinzler Buckingham, president of Youth Intelligence, a trend-spotting firm; Ginny Hilfiger, a senior vice president of Tommy Hilfiger; Kal Ruttenstein, a senior vice president of Bloomingdale's; Valerie Steele, chief curator at the Fashion Institute of Technology; Cathy Horyn, a fashion reporter for The Times; and Bill Blass, the designer. Then we asked them to decipher 15 human Rorschach blots: people photographed in whatever they happened to be wearing. Finally, we provide the real answers. The results begin here.

title: Giving Swordfish a Breather
description: The world's fisheries are in generally poor shape. Highly mechanized fishing fleets, huge government subsidies for the fishing industry, spotty international regulation, the debasement of wetlands, coral reefs and other important breeding grounds -- these and other factors have combined to put many of the world's fishing stocks at risk. In American waters alone, according to a Federal report released last week, over 40 percent of known fish stocks are now ''overfished,'' which means the fish are being caught faster than the stock can replenish itself.

The village spent $1.8 million to renovate the 70-year-old building and comply with federal regulations governing public access for the disabled.

title: A Grand Idea That Went Badly Awry

Both have operated small businesses and received loans from the Los Angeles Community Development Bank, an unusually ambitious, federally financed effort to bring a measure of prosperity to depressed areas of this city.

title: Construction Stocks Poised for Resurgence
description: WALL STREET is never wrong, according to the common wisdom, just early in making its investment recommendations. Analysts were wildly ahead of themselves in 1998, when Congress passed a giant transportation spending bill; many decided to recommend the shares of engineering and heavy-construction companies.

title: Food; Sage Advice
description: Once a shaman purified my house with smoke from a bundle of slow-burning sage. For weeks, the place smelled as though it were winding down from a pot party -- at least, that's what I thought at the time. The shaman, who called his ritual ''smudging,'' insisted that the peculiar aroma, probably from the cremated leaves, was the residue of bad energy. In any case, the smell was not Thanksgiving, which had, until this point, been my primary association with sage. Usually deployed in a dried state, the herb was an ingredient that we used to stuff our holiday bird.

description: Marcus Coleman again started at right cornerback in practice today as the Jets went through their final tuneup for what once would have been a pivotal game: Monday night at New England.

One round there shows why: whatever handicap a golfer plays to, he or she will be challenged but not overwhelmed. And the course's condition, natural setting and customer service draw praise in golfer surveys -- even with greens fees peaking at around $250.

description: NEISSER-Eric. The staff, the board, and the members of the American Civil Liberties Union mourn the passing of Eric Neisser, dean and president of Franklin Pierce Law Center and longtime friend and colleague of the ACLU. Eric devoted his entire professional life to defending the rights of the most vulnerable among us. He was a formidable litigator, a brilliant constitutional scholar, and a kind and generous mentor. We will miss him sorely.

title: Pick-Me-Ups, Pick-You-Ups; PERSONAL PLUNGER
description: Premium coffee are like fine wines. ''The warm Pacific sun, rich volcanic earth and abundant rain create the ideal conditions for growing,'' said Anita Messina of Classy Coffee in Port Washington. ''That's what makes them so delicious.'' Her premium Hawaiian Kona coffee beans ($34.95 by the pound) or Jamaican Blue Mountain ($44.95) a pound) taste even better in a French press. Ground fresh, they're put into a plunger pot. Hot water is poured on top and the coffee filter brews table side for full-bodied flavor, like a perk system without the overexposure.

title: For a Treat, Go Fry An Oreo
description: I COULDN'T imagine anything worse than deep-fried Oreos.

title: Young Entrepreneurs
description: Greenburgh is sponsoring a program to help low-income youths start their own businesses.

title: Making a God More Human
description: LOUIS XIV was a mere parvenu in the Sun King business. The first Sun King was the Egyptian pharaoh Ikhnaton, who lived some 30 centuries before Louis and built on this spot an opulent royal city that was the Versailles of its day. He called the city Ikhtaton, Horizon of the Sun, in honor of the sun god Aton, whose name was incorporated in his own, meaning Servant of the Sun. From his new capital on the Nile, roughly midway between Memphis and Thebes, Ikhnaton and his celebrated wife, Nefertiti, governed Egypt for 12 of the 17 years of his rule, from 1353 to 1336 B.C., and established a one-god (Aton) religion to supplant the polytheistic system that had obtained for centuries.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WYNTON MARSALIS

title: Getting Personal, for the Books; In Ridgewood, a Place to Meet an Author and Make a Friend
description: I used to bump into Edward I. Koch, when he was mayor of New York, at some civic conclave. Or at a reception at Gracie Mansion.

title: Primary Surprise
description: Mexicans were surprised by the yawning margin by which Francisco Labastida Ochoa, the candidate who promised gradual change, won the first presidential primary of the governing party. Mr. Labastida took 273 districts while his closest rival, Roberto Madrazo Pintado, won 21. The real surprise was the peacable concession by Mr. Madrazo, who had campaigned as a rebel. JULIA PRESTON

title: The Battle Of the Binge
description: I found it pleasantly ironic that Hitt's article appeared on homecoming weekend at Sewanee. I am a member of the graduating class of 1999, the first one not to have experienced ''legal'' kegs. Having attended my first homecoming weekend at which I was doing the actual homecoming, I must give my support to Hitt. As the tolerance for social drinking has decreased, the number of drunken students has gone up. I look at people who graduated years ago and were not regulated by rules that turn social drinking into mortal sin; they seem to be productive members of society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, SHIRLEY BLUM.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Shirley Blum. On November 13, 1999. Beloved wife of Albert; devoted mother of Howard and Richard; loving grandmother of Lindsey and Annie; cherished sister of Dr. Bertram Blum. She will be deeply missed. Services will be held Sunday at 2 PM, at I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich St, Hempstead, NY; 516-486-2500. Contributions may be made in her honor to Sloan-Kettering Memorial Hospital in NYC.

title: A City Shaped by Upheaval and Chutzpah
description: IF it is indeed true that there are eight million stories in the naked city, as a long-departed television crime show used to assert, then the six-part public broadcasting documentary on the history of New York, a special presentation of ''The American Experience,'' that starts tonight on Channel 13, has set itself a herculean task.

title: INSIDE
description: Toll Rises in Turkey Quake

title: His Cigar Is Just a Cigar
description: GORE VIDAL

title: Leigh Fisher and Avi Savar
description: Leigh Stacey Fisher, a daughter of Enid and Alexander Fisher of Bridgewater, Conn., was married last evening to Avi Albert Savar, the son of Robina Shapiro of Gainesville, Fla., and Isaac Savar of Istanbul. Rabbi David Lincoln officiated at the Plaza in New York.

title: U.S.-Based Challenge Is on Blyth's Horizon
description: In 1971, a brash Scottish paratrooper with a chip on his shoulder and named Chay Blyth gained fame when he sailed round the world alone, via the Southern Ocean, upwind against the prevailing westerly winds and currents. For this, he earned the nickname Wrong Way Chay.

title: Cohen's Top Feat May Be Monetary, Not Military
description: Of all the offensives he has mounted as secretary of defense, William S. Cohen, a Republican, might be remembered less for the military operations than for persuading a reluctant Democratic president to sign this year's $17 billion spending increase for the Pentagon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUNICE, EMANUEL
description: MUNICE-Emanuel. Loving husband of Bonnie. Beloved father of Amy and Ted. Adored grandfather of Laura and Justin. Former principal of East NY High School; former president of the Council of Supervisors and Administrators. Memorial service November 21, 11A.M. Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, White Plains.

title: At Museums, Admit One and a Shopping List; An Ocean Of Options For Gifts
description: You won't find the colorful clown fish swimming in the waters of New Jersey, but you can find them in a tank at the New Jersey State Aquarium and you can find bright T-shirts with their likeness in the Treasures Gift Shop atthe aquarium. The fish are part of the Aquarium's WOW Exhibit, which stands for weird or wonderful in the underwater world. Clown fish, which make a great shirt design, live in the warm waters of the Caribbean and get their name from the patterns around their faces that make them look as if they are right out of the circus. The shirts are $15.99 for children and $21.99 for adults.

title: The Best? Who's Asking
description: The best? It all depends on who you are asking, and about what. Here are assorted answers to that question:

title: Theater Steps In As an Antidote To the Jar Jars
description: AT moments of crisis, the movies have traditionally turned to their older brother for help. And by and large, the theater has answered the call.

title: Scrumptious Scrubbers
description: Mark and Mo Constantin, the brothers behind Peppermint Foot Lotion and other products from the Body Shop, now have their own company. Taking the all-natural philosophy to another level, the company, Lush, offers skin, hair and bath products, using fresh ingredients like strawberries, butternut squash and Belgian chocolate. Crush (about $3.40 to $5.50), a shower gel, contains fresh-squeezed orange juice; Scrumptious Smoothie (about $6.90), a body scrub, has blueberries, walnuts, oranges and bananas. Lush has stores in places like Britain, Canada, Australia and Sweden, but the products are also available through www.lushcanada.com and by catalog (888-733-5874). Employees called compounders make the products by hand, with their names and the expiration dates on them. ''I've had people who love a particular product say, for example, 'I like Lee's batches better than Leslie's,' '' said Graham Brown, a partner in Lush's Canadian operation. Lush's Ultra Fresh Fridge face and body masks are too perishable to ship. Made of rice, grapes, eggs and tomatoes, they are stored in iced stainless-steel bowls in Lush shops and can last for four weeks in a refrigerator. ANNA HOLMES

title: I Sing of America's Mongrel Culture
description: WHY would anyone care about what state the American musical is in? For one thing, it's a reflection of our culture. Without much debate, the American musical is considered one of our great artistic contributions to the world in this century, along with the skyscraper, Hollywood film, Pop Art and (here's where I get into trouble) the television sitcom. What is on Broadway right now is representative of our culture. Just as much as the laser-and-white-tiger shows of Las Vegas and the Top 10 countdown on AM radio, or the Metropolitan Opera's newest production, or the Cleveland Orchestra's fall schedule represent aesthetically who and what we are -- and want -- as a society, the American musical and its artists do, too.

title: Andrew Schwartzberg, Jaime Krat
description: Jaime Beth Krat, the daughter of Leslie Krat of Oyster Bay, N.Y., and Gary Krat of Boca Raton, Fla., was married last evening to Andrew Nathan Schwartzberg, a son of Marjorie and Martin Schwartzberg of Rockville, Md. Rabbi Bruce Lustig performed the ceremony in a party space at 55 Wall Street in New York.

title: In Stamford, Art and Artifacts That Tell a Story of Women
description: THE exhibition ''Of Significant Influence: Women of Stamford, Past and Present,'' which is on view at the Stamford Historical Society through Saturday, began with the idea of focusing on seven Stamford women who became well known locally or nationally for their accomplishments: the comedian Gilda Radner, the singer Libby Holman, the philanthropist Helen Altschul, the political activist Louise Seeley, the urban renewal proponent Edith Sherman, the educator Sarah Francis Smith and the physician Dr. Joyce Yerwood.

title: Correction
description: The What's Doing column on Nov. 7, about London, misstated the telephone number for tickets to the Millennium Dome. It is (44-870) 606-2000.

title: Dayne Over Top In His Last Shot At Rushing Mark
description: Before this afternoon's game against Iowa, Ron Dayne, the Wisconsin tailback, wrote the name of his 2-year-old daughter, Jada, on the tape on his wrist, as he does every Saturday. ''I put it there to motivate me a little more,'' he said.

title: The Axis Of Austerity
description: In 1899, the economist Thorstein Veblen proffered a theory about high fashion that would hold true for most of the next century. In fact, it would provide an answer to the question so often asked by ordinary people when they come into contact with clothes that cost more than sofas: ''Why would anyone ever buy that?'' The point of stylish outfits, Veblen maintained, was not simply to show the world that you were rich but to prove, in the most envy-making sense, that you had little to do but get dressed. A neat, expensive garment carries with it ''an exemption from personal contact with industrial processes of any kind,'' he wrote. It argues that the person wearing it ''consumes without producing.''

title: When the Charisma of the City Steals the Limelight
description: IT'S home sweet home this movie season for some, but not all, directors who have their eyes fixed on city life. In ''Bringing Out the Dead,'' Martin Scorsese depicts Manhattan as an update on Pandaemonium -- the capital of hell in Milton's ''Paradise Lost'' -- as he did in ''Taxi Driver.'' In one bravura nighttime shot, filmed from the perspective of an ambulance driver (Nicolas Cage) losing his grip on reality, Mr. Scorsese turned the camera over to give the impression of what it's like to career sideways down Ninth Avenue, ''unbalanced'' being the requisite point of view.

title: Traits That Link Children's Book Writers
description: WESTCHESTER seems to be a natural incubator for children's book authors.

title: The New Extreme Sport: Bike Travel in Manhattan
description: Several weeks ago, Rob Weisbrod, a 34-year-old bike messenger, was racing up 10th Avenue in Chelsea when he spotted several steel construction plates ahead. He swerved to avoid them, he said, but then was headed for a construction ditch. He veered again, he said, only to smash into a taxi door as it opened, leaving ''major bruises up and down'' his body.

title: Beer or Wine, Without the Alcohol
description: FINALLY, after what has seemed like a hundred years of hype, the dawn of the new millennium is at hand. Before turning the calendar page there is just one final hurdle to clear: the New Year's Party.

title: Gore Dueling With Bradley On Health Care
description: Vice President Al Gore broadened his criticism of former Senator Bill Bradley's plan for universal health insurance today, saying that the program would leave millions of African-Americans and Latinos with inadequate coverage.

title: Colleges Make Reputation in Polls, but the Game Is Politics
description: The scripts used by the student pollsters have pronunciation guides for Pa-TACK-ee, ROD-ham, and Ju-lee-AN-ee, but not for their college, which sponsors the poll: QUIN-i-pee-ack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHTOB, ABE
description: SHTOB-Abe. 87. Educator, scholar, electrician, comrade died November 10. His first passionate love was his wife Dorothy, and beloved children and grandchildren Eric, Terry, Sonia, Nicholas, Daniel, Amy, Callie, great-grandson Hugo, sister Jessie. His family and cherished friends mourn the passing of this beloved, special person.

title: Furor Rises In Canada Over Hunt For Grizzly
description: Harry McCowan, a grizzly-bear hunting guide, looked harassed.

title: The Necessary War?
description: To the Editor:

title: Where to Reserve Thanksgiving Meal
description: ALTHOUGH technology keeps everyone in touch these days, it is hard to play tug-of-war with a wishbone over the wires. But in the modern world, where dinner hosts and guests might live hours -- even time zones -- apart, just contemplating the logistics required for a Norman Rockwell Thanksgiving scene is enough to make one look for cheap holiday air fares to somewhere else. Gathering in some convenient central spot would therefore seem the smart thing to do.

title: Ready to Roll Out An $18,000 Barrel
description: How far can tequila, the rough-and-tumble party animal of distilled spirits, take its image upmarket for the millennium? One manufacturer is aiming pretty high.

title: Aspen
description: For almost 20 years, Colorado reigned as the nation's leading ski-vacation state. But last season, visits statewide fell for a second year in a row, dipping low enough to allow California to claim supremacy for the first time since the early 1980's.

title: Federal Funds for Teachers Reveal Surprising Hurdles
description: Most school districts applauded last week's Congressional agreement to set aside more than $1 billion for the hiring of additional teachers to reduce class sizes next year. But their experience this fall spending a similar federal windfall has shown that it takes more than money to put an effective teacher in front of a classroom.

title: Good Question
description: What Are Journalists For?

title: A Sect's Political Rise Creates Uneasiness in Japan
description: Forgoing anything so formal as a temple or church, four middle-aged women meet each month in Kumiko Hashimoto's small dining room here to discuss Buddhist principles and to review the latest teachings of their spiritual master.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACE, HARRY R., M.D.
description: PACE-Harry R., M.D. Of Boynton Beach, Florida, age 85, died November 12, 1999. He practiced obstetrics and gynecology at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn, New York, for over thirty years and delivered three generations of babies. He was the first resident in obstetrics and gynecology at Maimonides (Israel Zion) Hospital. Dr. Pace taught at Downstate Medical School and was in active practice with Doctors Merriam, Schantz and Blumen. He is survived by his wife, Toby, of 57 years; his son, Randy, and three granddaughters: Meredith, Kimberly and Allison. Graveside services will be 10:30 AM, Monday, November 15, 1999, at New Montefiore Cemetery, Wellwood, New York.

title: Bookend; The Dog Wrote It
description: A llegations are swirling around the Scottish author James Mackay, maintaining that he may not have written every single word of his biographies of John Paul Jones, Andrew Carnegie and Mary, Queen of Scots all by himself -- indeed, that significant portions of these works had appeared in earlier works, under different authors' names.

title: Finds in Egypt Date Alphabet In Earlier Era
description: On the track of an ancient road in the desert west of the Nile, where soldiers, couriers and traders once traveled from Thebes to Abydos, Egyptologists have found limestone inscriptions that they say are the earliest known examples of alphabetic writing.

title: Sights Unseen From a Bus Top: Marilyn's Grate And Gay Harlem
description: ''I DON'T give tours,'' said the man in the blue Giants cap and sunglasses. ''I live 'em.''

title: Lewis Unifies Title by Seizing Holyfield's Two Crowns
description: In a sometimes thrilling slugfest, Lennox Lewis won a 12-round unanimous decision over Evander Holyfield at the Thomas and Mack Center tonight, defeating an aggressive, hard-punching Holyfield, who displayed the kind of heart, determination and grit that have made him one of the toughest heavyweight champions in the business.

title: The Mensa Test as Confidence-Builder
description: Louis Valanzola says he fears success. John Leyman cannot get work as an actor. Laurie says her friends call her an ''airhead.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, PAULINE
description: ROTH-Pauline. Age 89, died on November 6. Beloved wife of the late Joel Roth. Survived by loving family, Doris and Elliot Rosenblatt, Dr. William and Francine Kohlberg, and Dr. Stephen Roth. She will be missed by grandchildren Lauren, Marnie, Jeffrey, David, Edward, Diana, Mark & Jason.

title: Pick-Me-Ups, Pick-You-Ups; SUITED TO A TEE
description: Do you have the desire - but not the energy - for an infusion of golf? At the Heartland Golf Park in Edgewood, you don't have to shlep a bucket of balls or even bend down to put a ball on the tee. All you have to do is swing.

title: Serving Up the Vast City In Bite-Size Pieces
description: IT'S a big, unwieldy city, but three recent books serve it up in more manageable pieces. David Masello, New York correspondent for Art & Antiques magazine, takes the reader on a virtual walk that covers 50 notable public artworks. Carol J. Binkowski, staff organist at the Church Center for the United Nations, traces the history of music in the city from Colonial times to the present and describes the sites where that history was made. And Jane Mushabac and Angela Wigan tell the city's story in nearly 1,500 entries on a fast-paced time line.

title: Guns in Hand, Targets in Jeopardy
description: THEY have guns and will travel -- quite often to a marksmanship competition that end will with them taking home trophy. Here is a look at some of the best shots in New Jersey.

title: Oliver Stone Goes to War Again, With Cleats On
description: BEFORE the 1972 Super Bowl, President Richard Nixon drew up a pass play for the Miami Dolphins and gave it to the team's coach, Don Shula. Nixon had lately been directing the retreat of American forces from Vietnam but was sure he had a winner this time. The Dolphins waited only eight plays to run the pattern against the Dallas Cowboys, resulting in an incomplete pass and contributing to a humiliating 24-3 loss. Two and a half years later, Nixon resigned from office in disgrace.

title: For These Fishermen, Surf and Enthusiasm Roar
description: I AM balancing in rubber waders anchored with spiked Frankenstein boots on a slippery rock somewhere along the Montauk shoreline. Angry gray waves are smacking me in the chest. Rain is pelting down and I am trying to fling a bucktail into raging surf.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACSON, RUTH
description: ISAACSON-Ruth. Of Manhattan, on November 12. Beloved mother of Donna and Lynn, sister of Blanche and Alvin Smith, aunt of Susan, Carol, and Laura, and grandmother of Hanna Frankel. She comes to this greatest of journeys well prepared, for she was a gallant and resourceful world traveler, always questing, curious, eager, and fascinated.

title: From Wine Clubs, Choices to Quaff and to Keep
description: DURING the three decades I have been a chef and a restaurant owner, a constant refrain I heard from the wine-loving public was: how can I learn more about wine?

title: Predicting Sunny Days For Latin Stocks
description: THOSE analysts who last year consigned Latin America to a long convalescence after the economic crises in Asia and Russia and the near collapse of Long Term Capital Management might want to think again.

title: Aaron F. Goldstein, 90, Justice On Supreme Court in New York
description: Aaron F. Goldstein, a former New York State Supreme Court justice and a former state assemblyman from Brooklyn, died Oct. 27 at a hospital in Westwood, Calif. He was 90.

title: Complete Menu Provides a Race For Every Taste
description: EXPECTING runners to agree on the best races in New Jersey is like expecting New Yorkers to agree on the city's best restaurants.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the first line of an article by John Irving today, on Page 35 of the special Holiday Films supplement to Arts & Leisure, is obscured. The article, about bringing Mr. Irving's novel ''The Cider House Rules'' to the screen, should begin: ''Manchester, Vt. -- 'The Cider House Rules' was published in 1985.''

title: It's Over, but the 'The End' Is Still Nowhere In Sight
description: MOVIES used to end. Audiences knew the end was near when two lovers walked into a sunset, a cowpoke rode off into a sunset, or Gloria Swanson descended the stairs in her mansion on Sunset Boulevard. For those who couldn't take a hint, filmmakers invariably flashed the phrase ''THE END.'' Like a bartender flipping the lights on after last call, ''THE END'' told moviegoers to beat it, pal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTZ, SAMUEL
description: SALTZ-Samuel. Died peacefully after a long illness, November 11, 1999 at the age of 86. Devoted husband of the late Deborah Saltz, beloved brother of Julian Saltz (brother-in law of Nicky Saltz), Adele Vexler, Helen Jacobson, and the late Elizabeth Saltz. Sadly missed by his nieces and nephews: Betty Thalheimer, Carol Lesser, Joyce Agress; Roslyn, George, Drew, & Abby Uzupis; Paul, Sonya, Eleven, & Jessica Vexler; Norman, Anne, Talya and Luke Vexler; Marian, Jason, Laura, and Noah Teoerski; Juliette, Jane, and Denise Saltz; Peter and Jovana Jacobson; Janet, David, Kira and Lani Johnson. A member of the Englewood Cliffs Planning Board, he was a leading builder in New Jersey, having built Acquacknonk Village in Haledon and hundreds of homes. A veteran of World War II, he served overseas in Europe. He was a major contributor to ORT. Contributions may be made to B'nai Brith or ORT. Services ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle Street, Englewood, New Jersey on Sunday at 12 noon. For further information: 1-800-322-0533.

title: Leaving Heathcliff and Cathy Behind
description: MY British visa said ''student,'' but I knew better: I was a pilgrim. Under the spell of Thomas Hardy and the Brontes, I was on the track of the rustic life -- the true old-fashioned England. It turned out to be a path worth losing.

title: Backers of Amateur Arena See Ballpark Plan as Lever
description: Supporters of an amateur athletic arena in Coney Island are hoping their opposition to a minor-league ballpark may help to improve their own plan's chances.

title: The Haunted Wardrobe
description: I met Helen Hollins on Memorial Day weekend this past June. She was dead. At first, of course, I didn't know it was Mrs. Hollins -- it was just another Sunday and my sister and I, as we have done nearly every Sunday for years, went to the flea market in search of something great. My entire wardrobe (except for undergarments, pants and shoes) is vintage, all culled pretty much from a 20 year span, circa 1958 to 1975. Most of my free time is spent in an endless quest for the perfect bag or coat or dress. Shopping at fleas and vintage stores is, for me, a sort of mental panacea -- simultaneously distracting, calming and engaging. The flea is never predictable in the way a store usually is, and after years of training, I've become expert at sensing, often from a great distance, a promising collection. Dealers are consistent: if there's one good piece, there are often others, and on that broiling Sunday last summer, one booth held at least 50 great pieces. And they all once belonged to Helen Hollins.

title: He Shot Down the Heat, And He Has Stayed Hot
description: It was just a normal summer day when Allan Houston stopped his workout in midchurn, stepped off the stationary bike and ducked into a film room at the Knicks' practice facility.

title: 2nd 'Black Box' Found
description: A robot submarine recovered the cockpit voice recorder from EgyptAir Flight 990 last night. The device was to be flown to Washington today.

title: The Spotlight Shifts to the Ring
description: A HARD wind was whipping around Columbus Circle, the last remnants of Hurricane Floyd, bending trees, swatting away umbrellas, splattering buildings with raindrops the size of peanut M&M's. Inside the glass-enclosed restaurant Jean Georges, at the circle's northern perimeter, everything was calm and dry, a cool yellow light and low murmurs merging with the herbal vapors.

title: A Confirmed Iconoclast, Still Looking for Targets
description: IN the symphony of famous comic voices, Stan Freberg's is a Stradivarius. To see his rubber mouth, off-center jaw and wild eyes in person -- and hear that sonorous, ever-shifting voice -- is to remember hours and years of laughter that began in his head and went straight to your ear, and belly.

title: Below the Desert, a Majestic Cavern Is Unveiled
description: The Chihuahuan Desert yields no clues to the majesty below the vast expanse of ocotillos, agaves, prickly pear cactus and mesquite trees here in dusty southeastern Arizona. Nor do the Whetstone Mountains that rise imposingly over the desert.

title: In the Region/Long Island; For George Cohan's Kings Point Villa, It's Not Over
description: OF the 380 listings in the National Register of Historic Places for Nassau and Suffolk Counties, including 42 historic districts, just eight have been designated National Historic Landmarks, a distinction that marks them as being of special national importance.

title: Little Rock Nine, 1999
description: In 1957, civil rights leaders in Little Rock, Ark., carefully chose nine students to desegregate Central High School. They wanted children who would do well academically in class and, just as import, be able to withstand threats and taunts without resorting to violence.

title: Naomi Wolf's Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: Budget Plan Shows Cut in Tax Levy
description: WITH the help of money from the settlement of lawsuits against the country's tobacco companies, County Executive Andrew J. Spano has proposed a Westchester budget that he says has the largest decrease in funds raised by the property tax in 25 years.

title: INVESTING WITH: Gordon Grender; GAMerica Capital Fund
description: AS a fund manager, Gordon Grender doesn't seem to mind doing things that might be regarded as a little odd. For example, he runs a United States stock fund, the $58.5 million GAMerica Capital fund, from an office overlooking Westminster Cathedral in London.

title: Getting Personal, for the Books; In Montclair, A Trove Of Treasures
description: I HAVE always thought that books, even in hardcover, constitute a good entertainment value -- if you divide the price by the hours of enjoyment.

title: Islanders Make Effort, but Blues' Demitra Makes Difference
description: They went from the best of hockey to the worst of hockey to somewhere in between. But it added up to another loss for the Islanders, who fell to St. Louis, 5-3, tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: A Life Goes On
description: Your Lives column (photographs by Gigi Cohen and text by Jrgen Schaefer, Oct. 24) humanized a murderer and his family but provided no photographs of the murder victim or of the victim's family. Indeed, the victim's name was not even given.

title: Pataki Orders PCB Cleanup Near Hudson
description: The Pataki administration ordered General Electric today to clean 700,000 cubic feet of soil contaminated by PCB's at an old factory that dumped the chemicals in the Hudson River, a move that environmentalists lauded as a good, though limited, step.

title: Williamses Are Buckled In And Rolling, at a Safe Pace
description: Public servants for the day, Venus and Serena Williams were busy skipping school, as well as tennis practice, for their dual debut in the year-end Chase Championships, which start tomorrow at Madison Square Garden. But all for a good cause, and gratis: filming a commercial in West Palm Beach, Fla., last week for the federal Department of Transportation's ''Buckle Up'' campaign.

title: Cheetah Club Draws Big Crowds, and Often a Siren's Song
description: When Eric Miller opened his nightclub almost three years ago, he never imagined he would see officers in blue mixing it up with revelers in black.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROSS, ROSE
description: BROSS-Rose. 87. Beloved wife of the late Edward, mother of Marilyn Teitel and Elaine Schwartz, grandmother, great-grandmother, sister, aunt.

title: Abbey Gardner and Patrick Dolan
description: Abbey Marks Gardner and Patrick Sean Dolan were married yesterday at the Bath Club in Miami Beach by Judge Ursula Ungaro-Benages of Federal District Court in Miami.

title: The Cable Guys
description: Jest if you will about Donald Trump's aversion to shaking hands. Although the man has a bundle of faults, we might be wise to emulate his cleanliness regime.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-14-99; Looking Young Is Getting Old
description: As the 1960's and I both close in on our 40th birthdays, I've come to the conclusion that looking young is getting old. American women have been imitating teenagers since the miniskirted and Velcroed Youth Quake of the late 1950's and early 1960's, a mutiny against couturiers that has itself become a fashion cliche. Designers once got their ideas from high society; now they take them from teens, tweens, even toddlers -- remember pacifiers and pigtails, a few years ago? Our mothers may have warned us that we would look ridiculous if we tried to look 20 when we were 12, but that's nothing compared with the shame of trying to look 12 when we're 35.

title: Namesakes, for Better or Worse
description: IS it fine to be Best? Is it better to be Good? Indeed, is it good to be Fine?

title: At Museums, Admit One and a Shopping List; Toy From a Simpler Time
description: Children did pass the time playing before soccer leagues, video games and Pokemon cards. The small gift shop in the Georgian-style William Trent House sells the toys that 18th-century children enjoyed and probably even traded with their friends. Toys include marbles, jacks and the ball and cup with which you shoot the ball and try to catch it in the cup. Easier said than done. Prices range from less than $1 to $2.50.

title: An Agency Comes Into Trenton, And It's an Award-Winning Move
description: FOR years, some state agencies have only pretended to be in the capital.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-14-99: Questions for Emily Woods; Crew Control
description: Q: Are there ways in which you and J. Crew diverge in style?

title: Riding Telluride's New Age Spirit
description: ALMOST 9,000 feet up in the San Juan mountains in southern Colorado, set in a U-shaped, red-rock canyon, Telluride is a remote place with a history.

title: Financial Stocks Bask in the Limelight
description: Financial stocks are looking for a little respect, but that's asking a lot, given investors' love of all things technology of late.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE SOUND BITE SOCIETY

title: Return of the Munchkins
description: Nobody can accuse Brian Brille, an investment banker, of forgetting the little people. He invited some of them to his annual Halloween party -- as part of his costume.

title: Jay Berland and Doris Garcia
description: Dr. Doris Josephine Garcia, an internist, and Dr. Jay Steven Berland, a fellow in critical care pulmonology, were married last evening. Rabbi Adele Agin officiated at Chateau Briand, a caterer in Carle Place, N.Y. The Rev. Peter Brennan, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the service.

title: Settlement House Is Gone, But Christodora Endures
description: To the Editor:

title: Michigan's Rally Lowers Penn State's Sights Even More
description: Last week's last-second defeat cost Penn State a chance at a national championship. This week's late defeat cost the Nittany Lions a chance for a Big Ten championship and a trip to the Rose Bowl. They have only a faint chance for the Fiesta Bowl or the Orange Bowl or any place in the Bowl Championship Series for top teams. How far can they fall, how low can they go, now that they have lost in devastating fashion to Minnesota and Michigan in consecutive home games?

title: Student Fees Unfair
description: To the Editor:

title: Martin Schwarz, Patricia Connell
description: Patricia Ann Connell, a lawyer, and Dr. Martin Alan Schwarz, an immunologist, are to be married this afternoon. Rabbi Philip E. Schechter will perform the ceremony at the Highlawn Pavilion, a restaurant in West Orange, N.J.

title: Package Tourists
description: HOMESICKNESS

description: I was disappointed that Hitt's article on campus binge drinking stopped at describing this behavior as ''a socialized phenomenon'' like ''table manners or sexual behavior.'' There is another epidemic among college kids: suicide. Could there be a relationship between binge drinking and suicide among young adults?

title: Experts Say State Mental Health System Defies Easy Repair
description: Gov. George E. Pataki gave advocates for the mentally ill welcome news on Tuesday, when he said New York State would spend $125 million more on housing and other community-based services for psychiatric patients and temporarily suspend the decades-old policy of closing down state hospital beds once their occupants are discharged.

Our heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire Hidary family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Paul Kopyt, President Dennis M. Eisenberg, Executive Director

title: Neighbors Are Not Fans Of Morning-Show Studios

At issue are the studios for ABC's ''Good Morning America,'' which opened in September at Broadway and 44th Street, and for CBS's ''Early Show,'' which opened two weeks ago at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street.

The silk scarf, which is 42 by 42 inches, has brilliant shades of blue, red, green and gold and sells for $45.

title: Talk of Collaboration on Decoding of the Genome
description: Talk of collaboration has flared among rivals pursuing one of biology's highest goals, the decoding of the human genome. Scientists close to Celera, a private company, and its competitor, a worldwide public consortium of academic centers, are discussing pooling their efforts, senior officials of the rival efforts said.

title: Don't You Sass Me, Mr. Micro-Smartypants!
description: IN its endless search for further efficiencies, our federal government may wish to consider subcontracting certain of its traditional functions to those modern technologies and individuals better equipped to handle them. The judiciary for example -- long a ponderous, frustrating apparatus -- might be the perfect candidate for this kind of streamlining.

title: Appreciating Qualities Of Winter Squash
description: NOW that all the pumpkin hoopla has passed, attention can be made to the other winter squashes that are so prevalent in produce markets. These colorful vegetables are true North American native plants and have been cultured for many centuries.

title: Are We There Yet?
description: AROUND THE WORLD

title: Rutgers Shocks Syracuse, And Breaks Losing Streak
description: Spiraling into football oblivion with an 0-9 record and an 11-game losing streak dating from last season, injury-plagued Rutgers upset Syracuse, 24-21, in overtime today.

title: Renewed Life In Trade Talks With Chinese
description: Chinese and American trade officials talked deep into the night in a renewed push for agreement on China's entry into the World Trade Organization. But this morning officials gave no indication of whether this latest round had brought the two sides any closer to the long-sought breakthrough.

title: Our Towns; Gotta Trade 'Em All!
description: BY 3:30 in the afternoon, in another shopping center off another highway, about two dozen kids are gathered in the games area of Wizard World, eating pizza, swilling Sprite and sharing an obsession. A cell of card-crazed kids, they have already been at the toy store for hours, dropped off by parents and baby sitters on Veterans Day, and they will be here for hours more in a universe all their own.

title: Carrying Coals to Newcastle, or Seaweed to Long Island
description: SEAWEED, seaweed everywhere, and not a bite to eat.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-14-99: Tastes; Secrets and Ties
description: The necktie is the most useless piece of clothing ever contrived by man. It has no practical worth, costs too much and is accident prone.

title: Friends, Indeed: Stories From the Heart; Man's Best Friend, or in This Case, Woman's
description: TELL us about your best friends, we said. And you did.

title: Beefcake for the Masses
description: We are all staring at Jeff Aquilon's rear end. The time is the late 1970's; the place a fashion spread in GQ magazine. Jeff is shown from behind as he lifts himself out of a pool. The back is broad, the tan is perfect, the glutes are firm. He is modeling a pair of Speedo briefs. A photo credit informs us that Jeff was captain of the water polo team at Pepperdine University, in Malibu, California. None of us have heard of Pepperdine University, but it doesn't matter. We've written our own caption for this shot, anyhow. It goes something like: Rip 'em off!

title: Sports of The Times; Lewis Wasn't the Only Winner
description: TWO days before last night's championship fight, Evander Holyfield offered an insight into the art of his business, and the business of his business, that was both philosophic and prophetic.

title: Pick-Me-Ups, Pick-You-Ups; EXERT AND CONQUER
description: It's fun twist on a traditional martial arts. After an hour of exercise, plus some resistance training with dumbbells at the end, the basic punches, kicks and blocks in the musically driven kick boxing clas at Southwest Fitness Club in Woodmere leave even diehard gym rates sweating and panting. And raring to go.

title: Tenants Protest Y.M.C.A. Sale and Loss of a Chelsea Home
description: They moved in when furnished rooms were plentiful and cheap in Chelsea, and they stayed through the real estate boom and the housing crunch. Now, many of the longtime residents of the McBurney Y.M.C.A. say they cannot afford to move elsewhere -- and they would not want to move even if they could.

title: Teaching the Ear New Dialects of Sound
description: ALTHOUGH computers are now so entrenched in our daily existence that life is nearly unthinkable without them, they have yet to play a major role in the arts. What use should art, the perfect marriage of emotion and intellect, have for computers, all brain and no heart?

title: Drinking Buddy
description: STRINGS ATTACHED

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Lions Discover Life After Sanders
description: Joe Louis Arena in Detroit was packed last month with more than 17,000 people waiting excitedly for the boxer Prince Naseem Hamed to enter the ring. Before Hamed did, the announcer introduced two hometown guys, one of them Barry Sanders.

title: Helpers, Unpaid but Highly Rewarded
description: FOR the last three years, Bridgit Sandford of Smithtown has volunteered to help train puppies to become aide dogs for the disabled, a task that has had a profound impact on her 2 1/2-year-old son, Rob.
