description: TELL us about your best friends, we said. And you did.

title: Richard Marius, 66, Novelist And Historian of Reformation
description: Richard Marius, a scholar of the Reformation, novelist and speechwriter who ran the Harvard Expository Writing Program for 16 years, died Nov. 5 at his home in Belmont, Mass. He was 66.

title: Artistic Themes With Appealing Variations
description: JUST reading the title on the announcement card, ''Hot and Cool: The Iconography of Abstraction,'' filled me with enthusiasm. Surely this would be an exhibition geared to comparing surface configurations, pigments and brush strokes to gauge a painting's emotional temperature. Theme shows, frequently mounted by Long Island's museums and galleries, tend to generate rather specific expectations.

title: The Most Innovative Figure in Silicon Valley? Maybe This Labor Organizer
description: With a Prada bag and the air of an entrepreneur, Amy Dean is an unlikely labor trailblazer.

title: Still Tough, Still Authentic. Still Relevant?
description: ANDRE YOUNG, better known as Dr. Dre, hasn't exactly been silent since he released his first solo album, ''The Chronic,'' in 1992. He produced Snoop Doggy Dogg's debut album, Tupac Shakur's ''All Eyez on Me,'' and Eminem's ''The Slim Shady LP,'' all multimillion sellers, while rapping on their albums and co-starring in their video clips. But on his new album, ''Dr. Dre 2001'' (Interscope 069490486), Dr. Dre sounds defensive, as if he's worried that hip-hop considers him a has-been. ''Now we got a new era of gangstas, hustlers and youngsters living amongst us, looking at us now, calling us busters,'' he admits in ''The Watcher,'' adding, ''It's funny how time flies.''

title: Friends, Indeed: Stories From the Heart; Born Sisters, They Grew Up to Be Friends And Soul Mates at Solstice Time
description: TELL us about your best friends, we said. And you did.

title: Devils and Brodeur Stumble Against the Capitals' Kolzig
description: Olie Kolzig of the Washington Capitals was better than Martin Brodeur of the Devils tonight. Kolzig came up with 32 saves and helped the Capitals to a 4-2 victory over the Devils, who may be starting a trend in contrast to last season's.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Byrds Out, Chippewas In
description: Stephen Ambrose and Douglas Brinkley's handsome edition of WITNESS TO AMERICA: An Illustrated Documentary History of the United States From the Revolution to Today (Lou Reda/HarperCollins, $35), an anthology of first-person accounts from American history, is an updating of Henry Steele Commager and Allan Nevins's ''Heritage of America'' (1939, revised in 1949). To accommodate the momentous events and social changes of these past 50 years, Ambrose and Brinkley begin with the Boston Tea Party and the American Revolution, eliminating entirely European settlement and colonial life. Gone are the Puritans of Salem, the Byrds of Virginia, Montcalm and Wolfe on the Plains of Abraham. Probably nobody will miss ''A Yankee Approves of Slavery.'' But it is a little startling to see the Progressive era reduced to two articles, World War I to three. Even World War II, in 1949 the longest section with 16 articles, is now down to six; longest in this edition, not surprisingly, is ''The Individual Rights Revolution,'' with 13 selections ranging from ''The March on Washington'' to ''A Chippewa Remembers the Birth of A.I.M.'' Will all these names be as important 50 years from now, for the next edition? Will the cold war still merit as many selections as the Blue and the Gray? Will we still want to read Colin Powell's reflections on the gulf war and Michael Kinsley's on the Clinton impeachment? Will there be room once again for ''Forever Young in Aspen''? Or will these, too, like the Bonhomme Richard, La Follette and the Bonus Army pass into the vales of history? David Walton

title: Surfing the Island, on the Web
description: THE Internet connects users with the world. But sometimes the best place to surf is in your own backyard.

title: Precision Marks Show of Mostly Black and White Drawings
description: IN these days of ever-splashier exhibitions, an austere one is sure to stand out. At the Gallery on the Hudson here, a show of mostly black and white drawings with some purposeful hints of color is absorbing because it has layers. A wealth of possible visual experiences emerges if the viewer spends time with the drawings.

title: Visiting Pilgrims and Paul Revere
description: IN early October, with the leaves in Central Park just beginning to turn, a New England weekend beckoned as insistently as the beach in summer. My wife, Carole, and I quickly settled on the Boston area. Thanksgiving was approaching, and our children, Maggie, 9, and Jack, 7, knew little of their Colonial roots. We'd introduce them to Pilgrims and minutemen while squeezing in a some leaf peeping -- without breaking the bank, we hoped.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANDERPUTTEN, HERBERT JOSEPH
description: VANDERPUTTEN - Herbert Joseph. Of New York City, formerly of Westbury, LI. On November 12, 1999. Beloved husband of Ruth, his wife of 59 years. Devoted father of Peter (deceased), Thomas, Gary and James. Loving father-inlaw of Joan, Jan and Jill. Cherished grandfather of Christine, Michael, Bryan, Joy, Victoria, Christopher and Chelsea. Funeral Mass of Christian Burial at St. Agnes R.C. Church, 43rd Street at 3rd and Lexington Avenues. Interment of Ashes immediately following at Greenwood Cemetery in Brooklyn. Family will receive friends at the home of Gary Vanderputten after interment. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to God's Love We Deliver or Maryknoll Missionaries.

Oberlander of Ardsley, N.Y., is to be married today to Gary David Drevitch, a son of Adeline and Milton Drevitch of Brookline, Mass. Rabbi Jack Stern is to officiate at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Purity of Sport, Caught in a Fight in Las Vegas
description: THE greatest fight hardly anyone ever saw took place in Las Vegas in 1965, and hardly anyone can remember who won. Apparently, nobody even remembers the fighters' names. ''Their first names were Lupe and Carlos, I think,'' said Bill Caplan, head of a public relations company whose No. 1 client is Bob Arum, the boxing promoter and No. 1 rival to Don King. ''I can't remember their last names.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONRON, MICHAEL A.
description: CONRON-Michael A. Aviator and Aviation Executive of Greenville, Delaware, Tolouse, France and Lyme, Connecticut, October 29, 1999. AB, Political Science, Brown University; MA, American History, University of Massachusetts, Amherst; MThil, American History, Columbia University. After Brown, he served as a US Naval Aviator and there after was on the faculty of The Institute of Aviation of the University of Illinois, Champaign. He was with Pan American World Airways for 22 years in various capacities as a pilot and executive in New York, Africa and Europe. In 1990, he joined Airbus Industrie where he was a member of the Flight Test Department, and most recently, Director of Flight Operations Development. He is survived by his wife, Shana Rimel Conron, and his daughter, Rachel Meyer Conron. A memorial service will be held at 4PM, Friday, December 10 at The Wings Club, 52 Vanderbilt Avenue, NY, NY 10017. Contributions may be made to the Michael A. Conron Fund at Brown University, established to further the understanding in the U.S. of the history of Southeast Asia and the U.S. involvement in Vietnam.

description: Opera has spent almost 400 years trying to balance music and words and doesn't often get it right. The earliest examples are poetry floated on tones. Music so dominated the last century that audiences have had to take librettos on faith, either knowing them beforehand or reading along by virtue of projected titles. Given the quality of most texts, incomprehensibility can be a blessing.

title: Why Trade Will Win
description: Many Americans seem to think it is vital that we find a way to get China into the World Trade Organization. The United States trade deficit with China, likely to reach $60 billion for 1999, is already the worst case of imbalance in all of our foreign trade -- imports from China are now about five times higher than our exports there. If China can't be drawn into the disciplined framework of the W.T.O., the alarmist thinking goes, the United States may never be able to sell widely in the huge Chinese market.

title: After a Playoff, Pak and Webb Savor Different Victories
description: The final L.P.G.A. event of the year was one of the most exciting. And for both Se Ri Pak and Karrie Webb, it had a happy ending.

title: DEAL IS REACHED ON DUES OWED U.N., BREAKING IMPASSE
description: White House and Republican negotiators in the House reached a tentative agreement late tonight in a dispute over abortion rights that would pave the way for the United States to pay nearly $1 billion it owes the United Nations, officials familiar with the deal said.

title: Robert C. Belloni, 80, Judge Who Upheld Indian Fishing Rights
description: Robert C. Belloni, a former chief judge of the United States District Court for Oregon who upheld American Indian fishing rights in the Pacific Northwest, died on Nov. 3 at a retirement home in San Mateo, Calif. He was 80 and formerly lived in Portland.

description: In the latest disputes over public access to the steps of City Hall, police officers briefly refused to allow a city councilwoman and the public advocate to hold separate news conferences yesterday on the steps.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Monday about the growing popularity of house concerts, at which musicians perform in private homes rather than clubs, referred incompletely to the authorship of ''House Concerts: A Guide for Musicians and Hosts.'' Kimberli Ransom's co-author is Douglas McLeod.

Three veterans who captured 9 of the last 12 Chase titles will be absent, two of them permanently, and the top 16 singles players contending for the world championship will include four first-time entrants, including the Williams sisters.

description: To the Editor:

description: Rabbi Jeshaia Schnitzer, a pioneer in integrating Jewish pastoral care and family therapy, died on Thursday while staying at his daughter's home in Manchester, Conn. He was 81 and lived in Montclair, N.J.

description: Perhaps the Nets' 1-5 record puts them in good position to face the Seattle Supersonics tonight at Continental Arena. After all, the Sonics' two losses have been to the Philadelphia 76ers, who entered their game with an 0-4 record, and to a Detroit Pistons team that had a 1-5 mark.

description: ELECTRONIC-COMMERCE companies have long been accused of wishful thinking. Now they're selling it.

title: Jarrett Adds Third Winston Cup to Family Trophy Case
description: With 10 laps to go, Dale Jarrett was in fifth place and quite content. After all, ninth place would be good enough to win the $2 million Winston Cup championship.

Beloved husband to Suellen, loving father to Bill and John, father-in-law to Diane and stepfather to Jonathan and Greg, proud grandfather to Ryan, Jamie and Sydney, cherished son to David, dear brother to Paul and Jill, uncle and great-uncle to many. He will always be in our thoughts and hearts.

title: Riley Has the Heat Off and Running
description: Tim Hardaway never thought he would orchestrate the highest-scoring offense in the National Basketball Association again. When he left the Western Conference five years ago to join Pat Riley's militia in Miami, the author of the killer crossover dribble was suddenly forced to slow it down and make do in a plundering halfcourt game.

title: In Kansas City, Few Trains, but New Life in the Station
description: It required new laws in two states, sales-tax elections in five counties and an act of Congress, as well as a major corporate giving campaign, but Kansas City's monumental Union Station has finally been restored to the grandeur it once enjoyed as a centerpiece of the nation's passenger rail network.

title: If It's Monday, This Must Be Turkey
description: As a candidate in 1992, Bill Clinton criticized President George Bush for excessive globe-trotting. But in his nearly seven years in office, Mr. Clinton has taken more foreign trips, spent more time overseas and assembled larger and costlier entourages than any president before.

description: BERNSTEIN-Howard A. Lovingly remembering you on your birthday. In our hearts forever. Our Family

title: The Governor in Overdrive
description: Suddenly out of the miasma that overtakes Albany in the legislative off-season, a positively energetic Gov. George Pataki has surfaced. Every day, it seems, he is out there, announcing new policies, facing live cameras, earning headlines.

title: Reality Catches Up to a Utopian Legacy; A New Jersey Oasis Debates High Taxes and Suburban Growth
description: This is a town that boasts of Albert Einstein as a founding father. Its first citizens were immigrant garment workers fleeing Manhattan tenements during the Depression. Their goal was to create a community around a cooperative farm and factory. Since then, this feisty little town of 900 in the center of the state has cherished a history of happy isolationism.

title: Lewis Wins Bout, But I.B.F. Refuses To Give Him Belt
description: Even before Lennox Lewis could win the undisputed world heavyweight championship with a 12-round unanimous decision over Evander Holyfield on Saturday night at the Thomas and Mack Center, it was under dispute.

title: Sports of The Times; Thrills Inside Ring; Muck Outside It
description: BOXING is the last frontier of mainstream sports; the unregulated Wild West, a primal encounter between opponents who settle disputes in the most ancient of ways.

title: To Get a Surplus
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: No Sign of Crime on Plane

title: Collages Move and Inventively Change Their Stripes in Surprising Ways
description: Garth Fagan makes dances resemble collages. Just as collage artists place shapes of different sizes, colors and textures next to one another on a surface, so, in choreographing for his company, Garth Fagan Dance, Mr. Fagan fills the stage with sequences of varying lengths and rhythms. He often follows sustained phrases with abrupt ones, and lets smoothly lyrical passages explode into twitches and shivers.

title: Max Hunter, Ozark Folklorist Of Tunes and Tales, Dies at 78
description: The way his widow tells it, Max Hunter realized early in his travels as a salesman in Missouri that the hill people of the Ozarks had songs, stories and expressions that were uniquely theirs. And so he decided to collect as many as he could before they vanished into time.

title: London Journal; They're at It Again: Barbs Fly Across the Channel
description: No Briton has ever actually shouted ''Non!'' at Martine Mercier when she tried to serve French food, as The Daily Mail is currently proposing with its snappy ''Just say 'Non!' '' campaign. But, said Mrs. Mercier, that might be because most Britons don't speak French.

title: Shaking Hands, and Looking for Checks in Them
description: Corporate jets will be parked practically wing to wing today at the municipal airport in Austin, Tex., as Gov. George W. Bush's 300 most important fund-raisers arrive for a two-day meeting.

title: Single-Minded Crusader Who Is Blocking Dues to U.N.
description: ASK members of Congress to name their political heroes, and the answer is usually drawn from a predictable lineup that includes Abraham Lincoln, Franklin D. Roosevelt and Ronald Reagan.

title: Debt Offerings Are Planned For This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Jack Hooke, 83, Manager of Pop Musicians
description: Jack Hooke, who managed some of the biggest names in jazz, rock 'n' roll and Latin music during 51 years in entertainment, died on Saturday at North Shore University Medical Center in Queens. He lived in Bayside, Queens, and was 83.

title: In the Car, Drive, Don't Phone
description: To the Editor:

title: Three giant advertising agencies take actions to accommodate their growth in the global market.
description: THOUGH the increasing globalization of advertising and the concurrent consolidation of Madison Avenue are significant trends, they often seem abstract, even ethereal. But they assumed tangible form late last week as three agency giants took steps that ranged from the resignation of a large account to an acquisition to a reorganization of the executive suite after a merger.

title: Green, as in G.O.P.
description: Now that Robert C. Smith of New Hampshire, once again a Republican, has been selected to succeed John Chafee as chairman of the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee, the void left by Senator Chafee's death may quickly become obvious.

title: Compressed Data; A Debit Card for Students, With Oversight for Parents
description: A new type of Visa card allows students to shop until their parents say drop. Called the PocketCard, it carries the Visa label and is used like any other credit card. But it is technically a debit card, financed and guaranteed by a sponsor, like a parent, through an account set up on the Internet. The account must be tied to a checking or savings account, which allows the card to be almost instantly replenished over the telephone or with the click of a mouse. Transactions can also be monitored as soon as they are made.

title: A Cuban, at 91, Links Memories to Song
description: In Cuban music there's an honored place for what might seem to be a beta male's role: singing low harmony. Francisco Repilado, the 91-year-old singer and songwriter who performed on Wednesday night at Town Hall, has made it his career since the 1930's. With his amiable, resonant baritone, he has sung the second part behind leading Cuban singers including Beny More, and he has been known since the 1940's as Compay Segundo (compadre second). His appearance on the ''Buena Vista Social Club'' album, which starts with his song ''Chan Chan,'' spread Compay Segundo's reputation around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYKES, DOROTHY MILLANG
description: SYKES-Dorothy Millang. Age 92. Died peacefully at her home in East Hampton on November 12. Devoted wife of the late James. Loving mother of Cordelia Menges, James Sykes Jr. and Martha Murray. Adored grandmother of Dorothy, Jake, Stuart, Ben, Matthew, Sam, Andrew and David. Cherished great-grandmother of Gardner, Serena, Martha, Sophie and Alice. A memorial service will be held Saturday, November 20, at 11 AM, at St. Luke's Church in East Hampton. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the East Hampton Library.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANSELL, EDMONA LYMAN
description: MANSELL-Edmona Lyman, age 70, of Jupiter Island, Fl and East Hampton, NY, died on November 11, 1999. A native of San Francisco, CA, she resided in New York City for many years. She is survived by her husband, Frank L. Mansell; four sons, Robert L. Miller of Los Angeles, CA, Charles B. Miller of Twin Bridges, MT, Christian F. Miller of Hamilton, MT, and Gordon E. Miller of Sante Fe, NM; two daughters, Devon Mansell Laycox of Sherborn, MA, and Jessica Mansell Ambrose of East Hampton, NY; twelve grandchildren; and a sister, Princess Genevieve di San Faustino of San Francisco, CA. A memorial service is planned for Monday, November 15, 1999 at 5 PM at Christ Memorial Chapel, Jupiter Island, FL. Contributions may be made to The Freedom Institute, 515 Madison Avenue, NY, NY 10022.

title: Pfizer Polling Shareholders On Bid for Warner-Lambert
description: Executives for Pfizer Inc., the drug giant, fine-tuned their presentation over the weekend as the company prepared to defend its $80 billion hostile takeover bid for Warner-Lambert at a shareholders' meeting tomorrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEATY, JOHN THURSTON, M.D.
description: BEATY-John Thurston, M.D. 82. On Friday, November 12, 1999, in Waynesville, NC. He was formerly of Rye, NY, and Greenwich, CT, and was a current resident of Waynesville, NC. He was educated at Princeton University and Columbia Medical School. He specialized in the practice of alternative medicine in Greenwich, CT, for 47 years. He is survived by his wife, Catherine Randall Beaty, one daughter, three sons, one grandson, three step-children, five stepgrandchildren, one sister and two brothers. A memorial service will be held in Waynesville, NC. Memorials may be made to ''Survival Until A Cure'' (ALS), 980 Post Road East, Suite 2, Westport, CT 06880. For further information contact Wells Funeral Home in Waynesville, NC.

title: Some Leave the Tournaments To Search for Fun and Profit
description: Many young players make their mark in the game then disappear from the scene. This is usually because the demands of work and family take precedence, but there is another possibility. They may decide that the comfort of social bridge in a club setting, where they can profit from their acquired skill, is preferable to the challenges of tournament play, which are expensive and time-consuming.

title: Shell to Invest in Iranian Oil, Risking U.S. Penalty
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group agreed today to spend $800 million to develop two Iranian offshore oil fields.

title: Book Lets Bush Explain His Life and His Politics
description: He agonized privately over his decision not to grant a stay of execution for Karla Faye Tucker and felt ''like a huge piece of concrete was crushing me'' during the minutes leading up to her death by lethal injection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, DONALD A., M.D.
description: DAVIS-Donald A., M.D. 91, of Southbury, CT, died at Danbury (CT) Hospital on November 12. He was born in Danbury and was loving husband for 71 years of Jean Parks Davis, also from Danbury who, survived him. Dr. Davis attended Brown University and graduated from Columbia University where he also obtained his Doctor's degree from the College of Physicians and Surgeons. As well as his private practice, he was Professor of Clinical Surgery at NY School of Medicine. He was Chief of Pediatric Surgery at that school and also at Bellevue Hospital. Dr. Davis was a member of the American Medical Association, a Fellow of the American College of Surgeons, a Fellow of the American Academy of Pediatrics, a member and Past President of the New York Surgical Society and a member of the Pan Pacific Surgical Association. During World War II, Dr. Davis served for four years as a Lieutenant Colonel in AUS Medical Corps with the 368th Fighter Group in Europe. There will be calling hours on Tuesday evening, November 16, 6-8 PM, at the Hull Funeral home on Division Street in Danbury. Funeral service is scheduled on Wednesday, November 17, at 2 PM at St. James Episcopal Church on West Street in Danbury, CT.

title: A Microsoft Remedy: Antitrust Experts Offer Prescriptions

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOOJAMRA, JOHN L., PH.D.
description: BOOJAMRA-John L., Ph.D. Of Demarest, New Jersey, died at age 57, on November 11, 1999. Dr. Boojamra was the Director of Christian Education of the Antiochian Orthodox Archdiocese, Executive Secretary of the Orthodox Christian Education Commission for all of the Orthodox Christian Churches of America and Professor of Church History and Christian Education at St. Vladimir's Seminary. Dr. Boojamra has also taught Byzantine and Church history at Fordham University where he had obtained both his Masters of Arts and Doctor of Philosophy degrees. Author of many books and articles, amongst which are ''Church Reform in the Late Byzantine Empire,'' ''Foundations in Christian Education and the Church'' and ''Social Reform in the Late Byzantine Empire,'' Dr. Boojamra was a nationally recognized and respected Orthodox Christian theologian, scholar and educator. For more than two decades, John Boojamra taught chemistry at Brooklyn Technical High School. His beloved wife, Stellie Ann Boojamra, predeceased Dr. Boojamra, who is survived by his devoted children, Dr. Constantine G. Boojamra and Nicole A. Boojamra, mother, Angela Ferris Boojamra and sister, Louise Boojamra. Reposing at Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, New Jersey. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, November 16, 1999, at 12 noon at St. Mary's Antiochian Orthodox Church, 8100 Ridge Blvd., Brooklyn, NY. Interment to follow at Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. His family, students, friends and the Church, to whom he faithfully devoted his life, will sorely miss him.

title: With Smith Leading the Charge, Bills' Defense Pummels Dolphins
description: Bruce Smith is in his 15th National Football League season, and as other veteran stars of Smith's age slowly fade away, the hulking defensive end remains a valuable part of his team. Quarterback Doug Flutie may get all the attention, but against the Dolphins this afternoon, Smith was the key part of a Buffalo defense that shut down a solid Miami offense.

title: Labels Change, Carrying Different Emotional Baggage
description: Warning: What follows neither prescribes nor prohibits. There is too much of that wherever racial facts and fictions are found. It is part confession, part justification, part proposal: a modest proposal to revive the word ''Negro,'' not as an exclusive term but as one that does justice to a group whose histories and bloodlines are too varied and contradictory for any one, all-encompassing definition.

title: Seoul's Secret Missile Research Worries U.S. as Talks Open
description: SEOUL  Amid concern in Washington that South Korea is trying to develop longer-range ballistic missiles while keeping some of the program's key aims secret from the United States, a senior U.S. official arrives here this week to negotiate South Korea's demands for increased missile capability

And yet today's presidential election represented a landmark in the often authoritarian and violent politics in the countries of the former Yugoslavia, because Macedonia is the first to have a president step down and make way for new politicians.

The entire New York Junior Tennis League family mourns the passing of our dear friend Eve, who inspired and guided our mission to grow the sport of tennis for NYC youngsters. We will miss her untiring passion, creativity and brillance in developing community tennis programs in schools and public parks. She truly transformed the sport of tennis. title: Scandal Rocks a Conservative Campus

Roche III has been president of tiny Hillsdale College here, and both he and the college have built national reputations as citadels of conservative family values. Now that his son has publicly accused him of having an affair with his wife, it appears Mr. Roche may have failed to practice what he so often preached.

title: Seattle, a City Of Opportunity
description: To the Editor:

title: Alberto Bolet, 94, Orchestra Musical Director
description: Alberto Bolet, a cosmopolitan, Cuban-born orchestra conductor, died on Wednesday while visiting his daughter in Teaneck, N.J. He was 94 and lived in Long Beach, Calif.

title: 'Japanese Only' Policy Takes Body Blow in Court
description: After Ana Bortz arrived from Brazil six years ago, she like many foreigners who live here -- grew used to the countless means employed by the Japanese to enforce distinctions between themselves and others.

title: Father Held in Death Of Brain-Injured Son
description: The father of a 2-year-old boy who spent most of his life in a hospital has been charged with murder after the brain-injured boy died.

title: Tight Labor Supply Creates Jobs for the Mentally Disabled
description: A bit fretful about joining the work force, Virginia Andrajewski, 56, turned to a fellow employee on her new job at the Crowne Plaza Hotel and whispered, ''Am I doing all right?''

title: For Three Interns, Fatigue And Healing at Top Speed
description: The interns felt they had to watch ''E.R.,'' because it was about them. Or it was about them spiced with a lot more melodrama. Sometimes it was silly. Sometimes it was maudlin. Sometimes it was all too real.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISER, ANNE N.
description: KRISER-Anne N. On November 14, 1999. Beloved wife of Sidney. Devoted mother of Judy Feldstein. Dear mother-in-law of Richard Feldstein. Cherished grandmother of Elizabeth and Christopher Rile and Julie and Mark Kessler. Adoring great-grandmother of Jessica and Lily. She will be deeply missed. Memorial service Tuesday, November 16, 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation-NY Chapter, 381 Park Ave South, NYC.

title: Fair Use of Databases
description: The House of Representatives is considering legislation designed to protect databases, or collections of facts or data, from misappropriation. The issue is increasingly important because electronic databases have become integral to all kinds of commercial and educational activities on the Internet. Many database owners want a federal law to ensure that their data collections are not duplicated and sold by others trying to get a free ride on what they spent time and money to compile. But in protecting the labors of database owners, Congress must be careful not to limit the use of facts that should remain in the public domain, a restriction that could be far worse than any problem the legislation is seeking to cure.

title: Ruling Leaves Giants Empty
description: At the start of the fourth quarter, in an attempt to corral a Giants kickoff, Indianapolis kick returner Terrence Wilkins batted the football into the end zone, where he gathered it and knelt for a touchback.

title: The Big City; A Town Without Pity? Look Again
description: NEW YORKERS had a special opportunity on Friday night to loathe themselves. It was the City Opera's premiere of ''Central Park,'' a trilogy of operas set in the park. The last one, ''The Food of Love,'' is a story by Terrence McNally about a homeless woman who stands at the zoo desperately asking strangers to take her hungry baby.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about an appearance by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas at a Veterans Day ceremony at a Michigan cemetery misspelled the name of the county he visited. It is Macomb, not McComb.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You spend the whole day in the emergency room giving. When you get home, you wonder, when do you get to take?''

title: In Russian Campaign, Candidates Crowd the Low Road
description: In a broadside that typifies the tone of the campaign before Russia's parliamentary elections next month, a billboard advertisement appeared in central Moscow in the middle of the night recently congratulating Yevgeny M. Primakov, the former prime minister, on his 70th birthday: it showed a wheelchair.

title: Newcomer Is Making Inroads in Toronto
description: When the media baron Conrad M. Black, whose company Hollinger International, started The National Post a year ago, an old-fashioned newspaper war erupted here. It has been fought mainly in Canada's largest urban center, Toronto, where three daily papers had been thriving, and to a lesser extent in other cities across the country.

title: After 'Insult' And 'Agony,' David Hare Fires Back
description: The British playwright David Hare kept silent last spring when the three productions he had brought to Broadway in one season were passed over for Tony Award nominations: ''The Blue Room,'' featuring a scantily clad Nicole Kidman; ''Amy's View,'' which brought Dame Judi Dench back to Broadway after 40 years; and ''Via Dolorosa,'' in which Mr. Hare acted onstage in his own work for the first time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUSS, MICHAEL E.
description: ZUSS-Michael E. Beloved husband, father, and educator died November 7, age 82. Dr. Zuss received his Ph.D. in philosophy at the Graduate Center, CUNY, at the age of 70, and was a member of the Phi Beta Kappa Society. An active scholar of religious and classical philosophy, he was devoted to the advancement of knowledge and his many students. He is survived by his wife, Ruth and his sons, Robert and Mark.

title: Patents; Reversible sterilization for women; a monitor for hand washing; call waiting for computer users.
description: EVERY year, several hundred thousand women in the United States choose tubal ligation as a form of birth control. The procedure is a type of sterilization in which the fallopian tubes are blocked so a woman's eggs cannot pass from her ovaries to her uterus and sperm cannot reach the eggs. While the technique for men, vasectomy, can sometimes be reversed, tubal ligation is considered permanent.

title: Granddaddy of Computer Trade Shows Is Remaking Its Global Gigs
description: Comdex, the Las Vegas exhibition that is the king of computer trade shows and the jewel in the crown of its sponsor, ZD Events, opens today for the 20th consecutive year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARQUETTE, WILLIAM
description: MARQUETTE-William. On November 12, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Shirley. Devoted father of Michael Marquette. Also survived by many other loving family and friends. Visitation at Hubbard Funeral Home, Inc., 4107 Wilkens Ave., Baltimore, MD, Monday and Tuesday, 7-9 PM, with funeral service Wednesday, 11 AM. Interment Oak Lawn Cemetery.

title: Sports of The Times; Colts' Young Stars Play Catch in Public
description: THEY met in training camp. What else do a quarterback and a receiver do but go out and play catch? Then the Indianapolis coaches gave them a set of plays, and the season was upon them.

title: Lord Group Names A New President
description: Roger Chiocchi has been named president and chief operating officer at the Lord Group in New York, assuming duties from Jim Hood, who had been chief executive for the last four years.

title: EgyptAir Voice Recorder Offers No Evidence of Crime
description: A preliminary review of the information from EgyptAir Flight 990's cockpit voice recorder, which was recovered this weekend, offered no indication of criminal activity in the cockpit of the Boeing 767, which plunged into the sea near Nantucket Island two weeks ago with 217 people aboard, government officials said tonight.

title: Vertical Transistor Holds Promise for Computing Advance
description: Promising an era of mobile computers that consume less power, researchers at Lucent Technologies' Bell Laboratories have developed a radically new alternative to the so-called planar transistor, the workhorse of the semiconductor industry the last 35 years.

title: Ornery in the Court: Judge Judy Rules
description: What are the appeals of Judge Judy that have made her the presiding queen of afternoon television? They begin with tabloid reality: courtroom quarrels over domestic disarray and financial finaglings, wrecked romances and workplace wranglings, doggy doings and neighborhood nastiness.

title: Giants' Offense Is a Collection, Not a Unit
description: After another raw, stumbling, slippery-fingered performance by the Giants yesterday in a 27-19 loss to the Indianapolis Colts, the onus fell, once again, where it has throughout the Giants' season: on their offense.

title: Editorial Observer; The Vegas Take on Architecture
description: In Las Vegas, history seems to be collapsing into a single moment. The sage-gray desert lurks nearby -- always a source of apocalyptic feelings -- and so do the nuclear test sites not many miles to the northwest. But it is really architectural history that is collapsing in Las Vegas, and especially on Las Vegas Boulevard, the Strip. Ecologists often speak of climax forests. The Strip is a boulevard of climax architecture, which, when it ceases to be new, soon turns into the architecture of tristesse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEGACY, MARGARET M. KING (NEE LANE)
description: LEGACY-Margaret M. King (nee Lane). Of Towaco, NJ. On November 11, 1999. A financial advisor with the Zesiger Capitol Group, LLC. Formerly of B.E.A. Investment Company. Loving wife of Bernard A. Legacy. Beloved stepmother of Mary Carmody, Bernard Jr., Julia Messineo, and Dorothy Rinda. Also cherished by three granddaughters. Private funeral services were conducted by the Keri Memorial Home, Lincoln Park, NJ (973-694-1582). In lieu of flowers, kindly support one of the following charities in Margaret's memory: the A.S.P.C.A. of New York, the American Heart Association, the American Lung Association, Disabled American Veterans, Guiding Eyes for the Blind or the World Wild Life Fund.

title: Monday Morning Quarterback
description: Weekend highlights and lowlights.

title: Border Backup Leaves Miles of Aid Waiting Idly Outside Kosovo
description: Trucks are backed up for miles on either side of this narrow border post, blocked in a chaotic jam that is choking the main gateway into Kosovo for vital supplies of aid. The situation is a growing concern for United Nations officials and aid workers who want to feed and shelter thousands of homeless residents of the province this winter.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Giants: Pretenders, Not Contenders
description: This was supposed to be the game that clarified some things about the Giants. With a skilled and confident opponent like the Indianapolis Colts coming to Giants Stadium, it was a good time to learn how good the Giants were.

title: Reflecting on a Writer's Life, and a Balanced Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Central Banker, An Inflation Foe, Resigns in Israel
description: Israel's long-serving central bank chief announced tonight that he would be stepping down in January, an unexpected move that could give Prime Minister Ehud Barak an opportunity to cut the steep interest rates the bank's critics say have unnecessarily slowed Israel's economic growth.

title: Fixing Year 2000 Computer Problems May Be as Simple as Counting to 16
description: Yawns might have seemed the likely response last week when a small Silicon Valley start-up, Y2K-OK L.L.C., introduced a new tool for diagnosing and fixing Year 2000 computer problems on popular I.B.M. mainframe and midrange computers.

title: Russia Is Wrong on Chechnya
description: To the Editor:

title: Rhodes Draws Interest
description: The Yankees have interest in signing the left-handed reliever Arthur Rhodes, but Rhodes might want more than they want to spend. The Yankees already are about to complete a three-year agreement with the left-hander Mike Stanton, and Rhodes's representatives are seeking a four-year deal for Rhodes, for about $4 million per season, according to a major league official. Rhodes is a power pitcher and can dominate hitters, but this past season, he went 3-4 with a 5.43 earned run average for Baltimore.

title: The I.B.F. Will Give Its Heavyweight Title Belt to Lewis
description: The lawyers for Lennox Lewis and the International Boxing Federation worked out an agreement yesterday that would allow Lewis to keep the organization's heavyweight world championship belt and maintain a unified title.

title: Metro Business; Lawsuit Says Qwest Intercepted Accounts
description: The State of Connecticut has filed suit against Qwest Communications International, the nation's fourth-largest long-distance phone company, claiming it had switched customers to its service without permission, an illegal practice known in the industry as ''slamming.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERBER, JANE O.
description: GERBER-Jane O. On November 15, 1999 of Garden City, NY. Beloved wife of Roger. Loving mother of Suzanne. Devoted grandmother of Alexandra Nicole. Loving mother-in-law of Wayne Muller. Also, survived by her sister Ethel Ursprung and brother Ralph Rodman Oborne. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel 1570 Northern Boulvard, Manhasset, Wednesday 7:00-9:00 pm. Funeral service Thursday 10:00 am at Trinity Church, Roslyn. Interment All Saints Cemetery, Great Neck. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn, In loving memory of Jane O. Gerber.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANTMAN, CATHERINE T.
description: HANTMAN-Catherine T. Of White Plains, New York, on November 14. Beloved wife of the late Sidney T. Hantman. Dear mother of Nancy T. Hantman. Funeral service Wednesday, 1:30 PM at BallardDurand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave., White Plains, NY. Interment Ferncliff Cemetery. Friends may call at the funeral home Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions to Alzheimer's Association, Westchester Chapter, 785 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, New York 10605 will be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, BESS
description: BERKOWITZ-Bess. The HewlettEast Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member Bess Berkowitz, and extends heartfelt sympathy to her husband, Nat, and the entire family. Rabbi Stanley Platek Dr. Norman Doctor, President

title: Public Interests; A Knick Reborn
description: ''Let's hear it for the athlete as president!'' said John McEnroe to the Bill Bradley rally at Madison Square Garden.

title: When dot-coms want to build up their images, they hitch their Web sites to a star.
description: REMEMBER Carl Sagan's sing-song declarations about space being filled with billions and billions of stars. Cyberspace is now becoming filled with stars, too, as a lengthening list of dot-com marketers center their ads on celebrities.

title: New Sanctions Incite Attacks By Afghans At U.N. Sites
description: With international sanctions imposed on Afghanistan on Sunday because of the Taliban's refusal to turn over a Saudi-born Islamic militant to the United States, mobs in several Afghan cities have stepped up attacks and protests directed at the United Nations, organization officials said today.

title: Recorded Music Gets Dose of Reality
description: When Thomas Edison first demonstrated his phonograph to packed houses in the 1870's, the feat seemed so remarkable that listeners occasionally fainted. Digital recordings and stereophonic sound have created a much less impressionable listening public, but Dr. William M. Hartmann, a physicist at Michigan State University, recaptured a little of the old magic when he played a radically new type of recording for a jammed conference room during a meeting of the Acoustical Society of America two weeks ago.

title: Sweetness and Drama in a Parade of Opera Stars
description: Opera loves a parade, so it invented the gala. Singers march on and off the stage, stopping to perform snippets from their favorite roles. Sweetness and harmony are the watchwords of such evenings, but competition for attention lurks under the surface or else speaks its name outright. That curious customer -- the lover of the operatic voice for its own sake -- partakes as if at an orgy. It helps too if the gala in question is for a worthwhile cause.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBY, JACOB ALLEN
description: TOBY-Jacob Allen, age 59, suddenly on November 13. Beloved husband of Anne Fribourg. Devoted brother of Ronald Toby, Martha Gooze and Nancy Grube; uncle of five nieces and nephews. Dear friend to many. Services Tuesday, 12 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in lieu of flowers to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation or a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SANTINO, RICHARD
description: SANTINO - Richard. 1946 - 1994. Forever in the hearts of his twinbrother, his niece, his comradeBob, Liza, Dick

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MERINGOFF, LEO
description: MERINGOFF-Leo. In loving memory of our dear husband, father, grandfather and brother.

title: Budget Talks Gain
description: Congressional Republicans agreed to drop a series of pro-business amendments in the last spending bills, moving closer to a final budget deal with the White House.

title: An Uphill Fight to Build Schools; In Suburbs, Opposition Is Often Just as Strong as Need
description: When school officials here proposed building a new school on the 58-acre high school campus to accommodate a ballooning student population, they expected nods of approval. After all, Chappaqua residents treasure their public schools: the district is considered one of the best in Westchester County, its sprawling high school likened to a fine New England academy.

title: Hazard Tests Urged at School Rifle Ranges
description: The Marion Street Elementary School, which was closed for three days for a cleanup last week after toxic levels of airborne lead were found in a basement rifle range, reopened again today after school officials said the school was safe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, SEYMOUR
description: KATZ-Seymour. The Katz and Schindler families mourn his death on November 11. Loving companion, father, grandfather.

title: Breaking the Mold Despite Tattered Apparel
description: Elke Rindfleisch and Dancers

title: Ode to Lonesome George
description: To the Editor:

title: Orioles Want Cone to Ask First
description: The Baltimore Orioles' executives met Saturday, and according to a club official, the Orioles continue to have an interest in signing pitcher David Cone. But the Orioles intend to wait for Cone to come to them and demonstrate a serious interest in signing with Baltimore before offering him a contract; like other teams, the Orioles are aware of how much Cone has liked playing in New York and suspect he will sign with the Yankees or the Mets. ''We'd love to have him on board,'' said a Baltimore executive.''

title: Gates Advocates Competition, but He Has His Doubters
description: As William H. Gates opened his annual speech at the Comdex technology conference, he tried to portray Microsoft as a company that wanted to give consumers choices in how they use computers and get on line. But many of those attending expressed doubts about whether Microsoft was truly embracing the idea of competition.

title: Jets and Lucas Outrun and Outwit Patriots
description: It seems that no matter how good New England gets, how much it dominates its division, or how many Pro Bowl players adorn its roster like Christmas ornaments, when Bill Parcells comes knocking on the door, the Patriots run into the basement and hide. To them, Parcells is the bogyman.

title: A Therapist for Fido
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Look to Stir Offense, And Petitgout May Sit Out
description: An irritated Jim Fassel indicated today that he planned to bench the rookie left guard, Luke Petitgout, and also make more use of the spread hurry-up offense that has been productive late in games when the Giants are desperately trying to rally.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing of Business Day yesterday about the appointment of Peter Rae as a creative director misspelled part of the name of his advertising agency and misstated its ownership. The agency is Siegel & Gale, not Siegal. It is now independent, no longer owned by Saatchi & Saatchi.

title: Spheres of Influence Grow in Washington; Once the Enclave of a Few Old Hands, Lobbying Is Corporate and Fast-Merging
description: When lobbying first became a serious profession a few decades ago, the ground rules were pretty basic. About two dozen members of Congress decreed the way most issues were decided, and an effective lobbyist had to cultivate a personal relationship with at least one of them to have any real influence.

title: Suffragists' Site
description: To the Editor:

title: A Crossover Dribble By ESPN's Roberts
description: Bill Bradley's presidential fund-raiser Sunday at Madison Square Garden brought together Bradley's former Knick teammates like Willis Reed and Walt Frazier with other former stars like Bill Russell and Julius Erving.

title: Eve Kraft, 73, Tennis Coach And Author
description: Eve F. Kraft, a tennis teacher, coach, author and the founder and former executive director of the Education and Research Committee of the United States Tennis Association, died Thursday at Princeton Hospital.

title: Border War Over City's Garbage Heats Up
description: Making good on their promise to try to stop New York City from shipping Staten Island's residential garbage to a pair of transfer stations here, officials in Elizabeth posted police officers near the state line today to issue tickets to an expected armada of New York City sanitation trucks.

title: SEARCH FOR ISRAELI CENTRAL BANKER
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel said his preferred candidate for the soon-to-be-vacated post of central bank governor is Elhanan Helpman, an economist now teaching at Harvard. Reached by telephone, Mr. Helpman declined to comment on the job offer. Mr. Helpman is seen in Israel as a supporter of the strict inflation-fighting policies of Jacob Frenkel, above, the current central bank governor, who announced on Sunday that he would resign in January after eight and a half years.

title: F.B.I. MAY BE ASKED TO TAKE OVER CASE OF EGYPTAIR CRASH
description: Government officials said this evening that the National Transportation Safety Board was considering asking the F.B.I. to take over the case of EgyptAir Flight 990 because of suspicions raised by a review of the plane's cockpit voice recorder.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: No Picture, And No TV Show

title: THE TRADE DEAL: Woman in the News -- Charlene Barshefsky; Making a Career of Digging to China
description: The first time Charlene Barshefsky found herself sitting in the waiting room outside the office of China's president, Jiang Zemin, her mind was suddenly flooded by an image from a different time and a different place: Chicago in the 1950's.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: Helmut Newton's New Book, With Its Own Coffee Table
description: He calls her Junie and she calls him Helmie, and they think nothing of photographing each other in the nude. But after 50 years of marriage and countless examples of their uniquely homey intimacy -- he soaking in the family tub, she opening her blouse for a postprandial peek -- June Newton says there's really no secret to her union with her photographer husband, Helmut.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: China to Open Its Economy Under Landmark Trade Deal

title: Serfs of the Service Economy
description: We hear endless stories about our wonderful economy -- budget surpluses, a soaring stock market, record low unemployment and, for some workers, rising wages. Yet amid the celebration, consider the plight of those who deliver groceries for supermarkets in New York City. Most of them immigrants from Africa, they are paid low wages, work long hours and receive no benefits.

title: Semistaged Works Are Fully Realized
description: How many semistaged performances of semi-operas does it take to add up to a satisfying whole? In the case of the presentation of Purcell's ''King Arthur'' by William Christie and Les Arts Florissants on Friday evening at Alice Tully Hall, one was sufficient. And although the same cannot be said of Lully's ''Bourgeois Gentilhomme,'' which was added on Saturday evening, that production made for a pleasant bonus.

title: Fraschilla, Brooklyn Guy, Takes On Albuquerque
description: He has yet to coach the University of New Mexico men in a regular-season game, but Fran Fraschilla, a Brooklyn native, is already a celebrity in this basketball-crazed state.

title: VITAL SIGNS: NUTRITION; Craving Kale? A Study Explains Why
description: Here's another benefit of getting older: vegetables taste better.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, DAVID TREDWAY
description: GRAHAM-David Tredway. Internist and educator, died in Newark, Delaware on Saturday, November 13, 1999 at age 82. He was a pioneer in the development of psychosomatic medicine whose research demonstrated a relationship between particular diseases and associated attitudes toward life events. His research has been published widely in scientific journals. Dr. Graham was born in Mason City, Iowa, son of Drs. Evarts A. and Helen T. Graham, distinguished faculty at Washington University's School of Medicine in St. Louis, and brother of Evarts A. Graham Jr., former Managing Editor of the St. Louis Post-Dispatch. He graduated from Princeton Univeristy (1938), received an M.A. degree in Psychology from Yale University (1941), and the M.D. degree from Washington University (1943). After serving as 1st Lieutenant and Captain in the Army Medical Corp in Africa and Germany during World War II he completed residency training at Washington University and was a research fellow with the late Dr. Harold G. Wolff at the Cornell Medical School in New York City from 1948 to 1951. Following six years on the faculty of the Department of Medicine of Washington University Medical School, Dr. Graham taught for 29 years at the Medical School of the University of Wisconsin-Madison as Associate Professor, Professor, and Chair (1971-1980) of the Department of Medicine. After retiring in 1986, he served as Adjunct Professor in the Department of Psychology of the University of Delaware. Dr. Graham was editor of Clinical Research Proceedings from 1954-1959, President of the Society for Psychophysiological Research in 1970, and President of the Psychosomatic Society in 1979. He was a Fellow of the American College of Physicians and a Diplomate of the American Board of Internal Medicine. Dr. Graham is survived by Frances Keesler Graham, his wife of 58 years; two daughters, Norma Graham of New York City and Mary Graham of Wilmington DE; a son, Andrew Graham of Midland, MI; and eight grandchildren. For Information: Robert T. Jones & Foard Funeral Home, Newark De, 302-731-4627.

title: A Deal That America Just Couldn't Refuse
description: In the end, the deal struck today between the United States and China was one that President Clinton had little choice but to seal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, EMANUEL M.
description: PARKER-Emanuel M. Beloved husband of Shirley, devoted father of Inez Sharp, Dr. Leslie Parker and Paul T. (Ruth) Parker. Loving grandfather of Charles, Jillian, Rebecca and Marcus. Services Wednesday, 1 PM, ''Weinstein-West End Funeral Chapel'', 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Former Agent's New Clients: Companies Seeking Web Sites
description: The vortex of investment banking and entertainment has interested Mark Patricof for a long time, ever since he came to the conclusion after graduating from film school that he did not have the talent to make major movies himself.

title: Bradley Wins Endorsement Of a Clinton Labor Secretary
description: Robert B. Reich, the former secretary of labor in the Clinton administration, broke ranks with his old boss today and endorsed former Senator Bill Bradley over Vice President Al Gore in their race for the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: INTERNET CONCERN AGREES TO BUY NET EFFECT SYSTEMS
description: Ask Jeeves Inc., an Internet search provider, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Net Effect Systems Inc. for $288.1 million in stock, adding a live-help service for searching the World Wide Web. Ask Jeeves will exchange 1.835 million shares for Net Effect, based in North Hollywood, Calif. Net Effect investors will own 5.5 percent of Ask Jeeves. Ask Jeeves's service allows users to find information on the Web by phrasing queries in conversational English. It said the acquisition of Net Effect would enable it to link customers to live experts who can answer questions either by E-mail or telephone. Shares of Ask Jeeves, based in Emeryville, Calif., rose $8.75 each, to $167.75, after soaring to $184.375 earlier in the day.

title: Sprewell Hits the Road With His Slump in Tow
description: Latrell Sprewell is unsure exactly where the problem lies. Maybe he is not driving to the goal enough. Maybe he is not following through on his shot each time he releases the basketball.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, ROBERT M.
description: STEIN-Robert M. age 72, of Newbury, MA, formerly of Huntington, NY., on November 14, 1999. Practicing attorney for 40 years on Long Island. Graduate of Purdue University and New York Law. Survived by spouse Patricia G. Stein, four children: Irene Amsbary of Sugar Hill, NH., Warren Stein of Waterford, VA., Elizabeth Stehm of Arlington, VA., and Joseph Stein of Marshfield, MA., six grandchildren and a brother, Anthony Stein of Chesapeake, VA. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to: Rare Blood Disease Center, Dartmouth/Hitchcock Hospital, One Medical Center Drive, Lebanon, New Hampshire 03756. Services will be private.

title: Six Men Accused of Plot Against Castro Go on Trial
description: The six defendants, aging Cuban exiles in sport coats and suits, sat quietly in a federal courtroom here looking more like a faction from the local Rotary Club than a counterrevolutionary cabal.

title: 22 Democrats in the Assembly Endorse Corzine's Senate Bid
description: The top Democrat in the New Jersey Assembly and 21 of his colleagues endorsed Jon S. Corzine yesterday for the United States Senate seat being vacated by Frank R. Lautenberg.

title: VITAL SIGNS: BEHAVIOR; When Patrons Have a Few Too Many
description: How can a staggering drunk get a bartender to keep serving him? Usually he just asks, say researchers looking for ways to limit alcohol-related injuries and deaths.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GROSS, DR. EZEKIEL
description: GROSS-Dr. Ezekiel. November 16, 1899-June 1, 1963. Our Dad, forever in our hearts and minds, with love and kisses. Ilka Giges and Dr. Morton Gross

title: ARTS ABROAD: An American Dares to Film Islam's Story; Making a PBS Series in Iran, a U.S. Crew Breaches the 'Wall of Distrust'
description: As an Emmy-winning documentary film director, Rob Gardner has called ''Cut!'' in many far-flung locations, from Egypt to Antarctica. But none of his previous ventures have called for quite the tact and daring required for his current project, as the first American filmmaker to be allowed to work in Iran since the Islamic revolution in 1979.

title: Vastogirardi Journal; Blissful Bachelorhood and the Shrinking Village
description: At the Bar Sport, the cafe that serves as this village's bachelor clubhouse, a government notice promising financial aid to families with children is posted on the wall -- more as an inside joke than as a community news bulletin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANDERBILT, ALFRED GWYNNE
description: VANDERBILT-Alfred Gwynne. A memorial service will be announced in the near future. In lieu of flowers, the family gratefully suggests donations in the name of the deceased to: Disabled Jockeys' Fund, c/o The Jockeys' Guild, PO Box 250, Lexington, KY 40588; the Thoroughbred Retirement Foundation, PO Box 153, Albertson, NY 11507; and the National Museum of Racing, Union Ave., Saratoga Springs, NY 12866.

title: Employees From Microsoft Give Gore an Icy Reception
description: Vice President Al Gore stepped into the lion's den today, facing down hundreds of Microsoft employees smarting from the judicial finding that their company had bullied its rivals and stifled competition. And he told them just what they did not want to hear: that competition is fundamentally a good thing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPPARD, WILLIAM FREEMAN
description: SHEPPARD-William Freeman. Of Los Angeles, formerly of NYC and Auburn, NY. Died November 10, 1999. Valiant veteran of the Battle of the Bulge. Tireless volunteer at Project Angel Food of Los Angeles. Beloved cousin of Syd Silverman, Marie Silverman Marich, Michael, Mark, Matthew Silverman. Arrangements pending. Please call the McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Ave, White Plains, NY, 914-949-7777, for information.

title: White House and Business Groups To Push Congress on China Pact
description: The Clinton administration and business groups prepared an intense campaign today to win approval in Congress for China's entry into the World Trade Organization, facing opposition from conservatives who object to almost any dealings with China and liberals who say the trade pact would be bad for workers.

title: Trump and His Portfolio Tour Miami
description: With a Slovenian supermodel on his arm, and claiming that he could outspend anyone, including George W. Bush, in a three-way race for the presidency, Donald J. Trump visited Miami today and reached out to the common man.

title: Northern Ireland Talks Get Push Forward
description: George J. Mitchell's mission to rescue the Northern Ireland peace settlement, staggered last week by the refusal of the province's largest party to endorse a blueprint worked out over 10 weeks of grinding talks, recovered significant forward motion today.

title: 49ers Suspend Phillips and Plan to Waive Him
description: Lawrence Phillips, the running back who has been suspended, will not play for the San Francisco 49ers again, Coach Steve Mariucci said yesterday. Phillips will be waived as soon as the team finds out from the National Football League how the move will affect its salary cap.

title: SOUTHERN UNION TO ACQUIRE PROVIDENCE ENERGY
description: The Southern Union Company agreed yesterday to acquire the Providence Energy Corporation for $259 million. It will also assume debt of about $140 million. Providence Energy, based in Providence, R.I., provides natural gas to 181,000 customers in Rhode Island and southeastern Massachusetts. Southern, based in Austin, Tex., supplies natural gas to 1.2 million customers in five states. In the transaction, Providence Energy shareholders will receive $42.50 for each of their shares. Shares of Providence Energy changed hands at $37.75, up 14 percent, or $4.875. Last month, Southern Union said it had agreed to buy the Fall River Gas Company for $75 million in a deal that adds 48,000 natural gas customers in southeastern Massachusetts.

title: A Chairman Is Selected By Rite Aid
description: The Rite Aid Corporation said today that it had named Leonard Green its chairman in hopes he could revive the company, the nation's No. 3 drugstore chain.

title: Women on Submarines
description: To the Editor:

title: Johnson Fails Another Test
description: The Canadian sprinter Ben Johnson has failed a drug test administered by the Canadian Center for Ethics in Sport, the third time he has tested positive for a banned substance.

title: Metro Business; A Utility Goes Global
description: Public Service Enterprise Group, the owner of New Jersey's largest utility, announced yesterday in Newark that it planned to build a $320 million coal-fired power plant in Poland. It was the second European investment the company had announced in a week.

title: German Company Standing Firm Against Vodafone
description: As chairman of Mannesmann A.G., Klaus Esser is hardly a stranger to take-no-prisoners pragmatism.

title: Simple Adjustments for a Fit Pregnancy
description: Not so long ago, pregnant women were almost universally warned to avoid strenuous activity. Running, cycling, skiing, horseback riding, singles tennis -- all were off limits. Only walking had widespread approval, and even that was to be limited to about a mile a day, preferably broken up into several short sessions.

title: Chinese Stocks Surge 9% On the Hong Kong Market
description: Shares of Chinese and China-related companies surged here today as investors concluded that a landmark trade agreement between the United States and China -- and the competition it promises -- would help Chinese companies more than it would hurt them.

title: Head of Fox TV Studio Gets New Network Post
description: Fox Inc. named Sandy Grushow, already president of its television production studio, to the newly created position of chairman of the Fox Television Entertainment Group yesterday.

title: Reasonable Concerns in an Age of Angels and Aliens
description: SLEEPING WITH EXTRA-TERRESTRIALS

title: Many Steps to Go Before China Can Become a Full Member
description: While welcoming the accord clearing the way for China's entry into the World Trade Organization, Mike Moore, the director general, cautioned today that several steps remained before the country could become a full member.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about ''A Charge to Keep,'' an autobiography by George W. Bush, misidentified the owner of its publisher, William Morrow & Company. Morrow is an imprint of HarperCollins, not part of the Hearst Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEULANDER, HAROLD R.
description: NEULANDER-Harold R. November 13, 1999. Beloved husband of Lucille. Devoted father of Bill and revered uncle of Dr. Jerome Wolff. Funeral will be held at graveside.

title: New Battles Erupt In A.T.M. Fee War As Banks Retaliate
description: Lashawanda McCullom, a 30-year-old nurse, put her credit union's cash card into a Bank of America automated teller machine here, punched in her secret code and requested a withdrawal. The machine spit out her card and flashed a message: ''Due to a recent vote by the Santa Monica City Council, the convenience of this A.T.M. is now available to Bank of America cardholders only.''

title: Physicist And Rebel Is Bruised, Not Beaten
description: Raw optimism is a trait not usually associated with longtime makers of atom bombs, advisers of presidents and heralds of doom.

title: Jackal's Day Has Passed: Forsyth Tails The Phantom
description: For a writer who has donned the cloaks and wielded the daggers of assassins and spies, mercenaries and hoodlums for some 30 years, Frederick Forsyth seems almost to be running scared.

title: Drugs in Pregnancy
description: To the Editor:

title: Smoke-Filled Albany
description: The rules for lobbying in Albany are so abysmally loose that only occasionally does the outside world get a glimpse of how New York State's Legislature can market its influence. Such a moment arrived this year when the tobacco industry was forced to open its files in state litigation around the country. The documents listed how much money companies like Philip Morris had spent trying to secure protection in places like Albany.

title: Tempestuous Goings-On, Mysteriously Scripted
description: Akim Funk Buddha and Dha-Fuzion

title: Authorities Seek Identity Of Body Found in Woods
description: Ocean County authorities are trying to identify a well-dressed man, believed to be from Turkey, whose body was dumped in a wooded area of Barnegat just off the Garden State Parkway. He had been shot four times in the back and the head.

title: Borders Names a New Chief From Outside Book Industry
description: The Borders Group, the nation's second-largest bookseller, reached outside the book industry yesterday for a new chief executive, appointing Greg Josefowicz, a food and drugstore executive, to preside over its chain of nearly 300 bookstores and its electronic outlet, Borders.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPNER, IRVING
description: KAPNER-Irving. On Monday, November 15, 1999. Beloved husband of Doris. Loving father of Mark, Carol and Judy. Cherished grandfather of Jocelyn, Oliver and Isabel. Dear brother of Sydney. Services will be at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue at 1:45pm, Tuesday, November 16. Memorial contributions may be made to NY Section, National Council of Jewish Women or your favorite charity.

title: Opening China's Markets
description: The Clinton administration appears to have salvaged the trade agreement with China that it could have concluded in April if President Clinton had not rejected it. The new agreement, announced yesterday in Beijing, paves the way for China to join the World Trade Organization, committing it to obey rules that apply to all other major trading partners.

title: Many Winners and Some Losers in Trade Accord With China
description: For American International Group, the giant insurer, the new trade agreement with China is a long-awaited go-ahead to sell insurance everywhere in China, not in just a few cities. AT&T sees the door open to provide Internet services in China. But Milliken & Company, the big textile manufacturer -- forecasting doom -- says that President Clinton's negotiators have signed a death warrant for textile makers in America.

title: Pierce Gets A Workout; Schett Romps
description: Blond and blonder, fit and fitter, Mary Pierce and Anna Kournikova, two tennis glamour girls who don't mind flexing their muscles while they flaunt their feminine physiques, treated the rubberized blue carpet underfoot like a wrestling mat as the $2 million Chase Championships, the final event on the women's tennis calendar, got under way last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Russia Is Wrong on Chechnya
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PARADNY, ROBERT, M.D.
description: PARADNY-Robert, M.D. Dear Bob/Dad, You are with us always and our love for you remains as alive as ever. Forever, Adelle, Robin, Andrea and Stewart

title: BUYOUT COMPANY ACQUIRES MARIE CALLENDER'S CHAIN
description: Castle Harlan Inc., a merchant bank, said yesterday that it had bought Marie Callender's Restaurant and Bakery from the investment firm Saunders, Karp & Megrue L.P. for $140 million in cash, adding 166 family restaurants in 12 states. The closely held Castle Harlan, based in New York, also assumed $10 million in lease debt. Marie Callender's, based in Orange, Calif., known for its fresh pies, has restaurants mainly in the West and Southwest United States. It employs about 10,000 people and had 1998 revenue of almost $230 million. Castle Harlan, which specializes in leveraged buyouts, owns two other restaurant chains: Charlie Brown's, based in Mountainside, N.J., and Luther's Bar-B-Q, based in Houston. Saunders, Karp & Megrue is a closely held investment firm based in New York.

title: Didn't Win A Lottery? Time to Sue
description: CAUTION: Parts of this column may annoy, dismay or anger some readers. Anyone prone to frequent bouts of mental anguish or emotional distress is advised to turn the page immediately.

title: A 0.4% Jump In Inventories For September
description: The nation's businesses stockpiled goods in September at the fastest pace in six months, led by wholesalers counting on increased holiday sales, Commerce Department figures showed today.

title: FOREIGN STOCK LISTINGS CONSIDERED
description: South Korea is considering allowing foreign companies to list their shares directly on the Seoul stock market, the Financial Supervisory Service said. Currently, foreign companies can issue depositary receipts in South Korea, but cannot list their shares directly on the local stock market. ''The listing under consideration is part of the government's efforts to give local investors wider opportunities for stock investments,'' an official at the service said.

title: Anger in Preschoolers
description: To the Editor:

title: Rebel Flag: Symbol of Shame
description: To the Editor:

title: Unsanitary Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Priceline.com to Test Ford Web Link
description: Priceline.com Inc. said today that it would test a service in Florida that lets consumers name their price for a new car or truck when they visit the Ford Motor Company's Internet site.

title: The Mayor and the First Amendment
description: On matters large and small, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani seems deaf to free-speech concerns. For more than a year, the mayor has imposed tight restrictions on the use of New York's City Hall steps for public demonstrations, ostensibly for security reasons. On Sunday, Councilwoman Christine Quinn was told by police guards that she could not hold a press conference on the steps, even though she was there with fewer than a dozen community members to draw attention to the killing of a young gay man in his apartment in Harlem. Only after she called Council Speaker Peter Vallone to intervene was she allowed to hold the press conference.

title: Germany Adds $555 Million To Offer in Nazi Slave Cases
description: An improved offer from the German government and the agreement of new companies to make payments have revived talks on compensating Nazi-era slave laborers, opening the way for a round of potentially decisive negotiations in Bonn that begins on Tuesday.

title: Infogrames Gets Control of GT Interactive
description: Infogrames Entertainment S.A., Europe's No. 1 maker of video-game software, said today that it had bought a controlling stake in the GT Interactive Software Corporation for $135 million in cash and notes.

title: Batons and Business
description: To the Editor:

title: An Eye on the Heart for a Better Workout
description: Subhash Mandal used to finish up his daily five-mile run feeling either exhausted or as if he had barely broken a sweat. ''I could never get a sense of how hard to push myself,'' said Mr. Mandal, 29, an actor who lives in Queens. Then, a personal trainer recommended that he try running with a heart-rate monitor strapped to his chest. Mr. Mandal says his runs are now more effective because he has an easy and accurate way to gauge his workout intensity.

title: VITAL SIGNS: AT RISK; In Heated Heroin, a Dangerous Dragon
description: Heroin users trying to avoid infected needles have turned in increasing numbers in recent years to ''chasing the dragon'': heating the drug and inhaling its fumes. But that method can cause a rare brain disorder that can in turn cause paralysis and even death, according to Columbia University neurologists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAITON, H. KENNETH, COL.
description: PAITON-H. Kenneth, Col. The New York Chapter of The Military Order of the World Wars records with sorrow the death of our esteemed companion and Treasurer for many years. He will be remembered for his patriotic leadership and selfless devotion. He will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his many friends and family. LCDR Ned Stuhr, USN (Ret) Chapter Commander

title: City's Teachers Perform Poorly On State Exams
description: Not only does New York City have a disproportionate number of uncertified teachers, but those who do pass the state certification exams tend to score much lower than their counterparts in the suburbs and upstate, according to state data that is to be placed into evidence today in a landmark school-financing case.

title: Forecast Tomorrow: Showers Of Meteors
description: Like a slugger given a second chance after a disappointing season, the Leonid meteor shower is back again this week, ready to take another swat at Earth.

title: U.N. Details Its Failure to Stop '95 Bosnia Massacre
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan laid out in a somber, self-critical report today the tragic story of how the United Nations allowed the Bosnian Muslim ''safe area'' of Srebrenica to be overrun in July 1995 by Bosnian Serbs, who then systematically killed thousands of the town's men and boys.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUMMER, ELLA BACHE
description: BRUMMER-Ella Bache. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted member Ella Bache Brummer, beloved aunt of Dr. John Laszlo and great aunt of Rebecca, Jennifer and Daniel Walter Laszlo. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREED WUHL, ROSE
description: FREED WUHL-Rose. On November 13, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Loving sister of Sharon W. Krebs, Jeanne Offen and the late Ida Forman, Irving Wuhl and Samuel Wuhl. Cherished aunt and great-aunt. Services were held.

title: Ghost of Parcells Hovers Over Patriots
description: Up and down the New England Patriots' locker room, there were always differing views of Bill Parcells when he worked here from the 1993 through the 1996 seasons. Some Patriots adored him. Others abhorred him.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Johnson Beats Hampton to Win Cy Young Award
description: In a year in which one pitcher won 22 games, it took an extraordinary season for another pitcher to win the Cy Young award. Yesterday, Arizona's Randy Johnson, who finished with a 17-9 record but had 364 strikeouts in 271 2/3 innings, beat out Houston's Mike Hampton -- who went 22-4 -- for the National League Cy Young award.

title: Monsanto and Novartis Settle Seed Suits
description: The Monsanto Company said today that it had settled several lawsuits with Novartis A.G. over patents for genetically engineered insect-resistant corn seeds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREINES, JAMES R.
description: KREINES-James R. On November 15, 1999. Beloved husband of Barbara E. (nee Tietje). Loving father of Elise and Charles and Rosanne. Fond grandfather of Fabiana and Silvana. Visitation on Tuesday, from 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at McLaughlin & Sons Funeral Home, 3rd Avenue at 97th Street, Brooklyn. Interment Wednesday morning, Greenwood Cemetery.

title: Arts Coverage Falls Behind A Cultural Boom, Study Says
description: While a flush economy has fueled an artistic boom around the country, arts coverage in local newspapers has often failed to keep pace with the new range of art exhibitions, symphony performances, film festivals, dance troupes and television shows, a new study has found.

title: HOLZMANN APPEALS TO CREDITORS
description: Germany's biggest construction company, Philipp Holzmann A.G., said it would ask Deutsche Bank A.G. and other creditors to help shoulder a charge of 2.4 billion marks ($1.3 billion) so it can stay in business. The company said it would dismiss more than 3,000 employees, or 10 percent of its work force, to save money and help meet the charge, which stems from real estate investments in Cologne and in eastern Germany. It is the second time since 1996 that Frankfurt-based Holzmann has asked creditors for a bailout.

title: After Med School, the A B C's of Insurance
description: The investigators came late last January, on a Thursday. They were deliberately cryptic. All they would tell St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center was that they were looking into a possible violation of the federal ''anti-dumping'' law, which prohibits hospitals from refusing to at least examine and stabilize patients who cannot pay. It was serious business. Only a handful of cases were investigated each year. Not until the investigators left did the hospital learn what it was all about.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORTIZ, RITA A.
description: ORTIZ-Rita A. November 15, 1999. Beloved friend, colleague, sister of Loyda & Percida, aunt of Charles, George, Debbie & Linda. Visiting hours 2 to 5 and 7 to 9, Tuesday, at Walter B. Cooke, 117 West 72 St. Funeral service Riverside Church, Wednesday, 2 PM. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to Augustin Gonzalez Scholarship Fund, Columbia University School of Social Work.

title: United States May Yet Lose Its Vote in U.N. General Assembly
description: Appropriating nearly $1 billion in back dues and assessments to the United Nations might not be enough to prevent the United States from losing its vote in the General Assembly next year, United Nations officials say.

title: Gucci Purchases Control Of Yves Saint Laurent
description: In the latest step in the growing consolidation of the European fashion and luxury-goods industries, the Gucci Group N.V. said today that it would buy Sanofi Beaute from the French billionaire Francois Pinault for about $700 million in cash to gain control of Yves Saint Laurent.

title: Reformers' Comeback: New Power Against Opponents of Open Markets
description: Although the immediate effects of China's landmark trade agreement with the United States may be mixed, the deal is a major victory for Prime Minister Zhu Rongji, an advocate of reform who has been under fire from conservative opponents in recent months.
