title: Unsanitary Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Evening Hours column of Sunday Styles this week about a French Institute dinner at the Pierre Hotel in New York misstated the given name of the event's chairwoman. She is Lucile Peyrelongue, not Lisette.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, DORIS (NEE EDELMAN)
description: WEINSTEIN-Doris (nee Edelman). Loving wife and best friend of Ira J. for 47 years. Mother of Peter & Andrea, Robert and Mary. Grandmother of Brianna, Brooke, and Alexandria. Sister of Gerald, & Maxine Edelman, Janet Edelman, Shirley and George Weinstein. Good friend of Emma Lee. Loved by many nieces and nephews. She was a master teacher of science, the consummate dealer in antique jewelry and a compassionate philanthropist. Her loss will be felt by many. Let us celebrate her life and remember her always. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Temple Beth El or North Shore Child and Family Guidance Assn. Services Wednesday 11 A.M. at Temple Beth El, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck.

title: Two Companies In Consolidations
description: Two agencies said yesterday that they had made acquisitions for undisclosed terms.

title: Smoke Two After Dinner and Call Me in the Morning
description: When I headed into the waiting room at 2:19 the other afternoon, my 2:20 patient had disappeared. I knew he would be back in a minute or two, windblown and smelling of cigarette smoke, sheepishly tossing a crumpled pack into the trash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEFFEN, NATALIE (NEE DUCAS)
description: STEFFEN-Natalie (nee Ducas), of Old Saybrook, Connecticut, on Friday, November 12, 1999, at the age of 86. Beloved wife of the late Ernest, devoted mother of James and Elizabeth, loving mother-inlaw to Joanne and grandmother to Michael. The family requests you join with them as they host an open house celebrating Natalie's life on Sunday, November 21, 1999, at 2:00 P.M. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions to the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation, P.O. Box 1776, Williamsburg, Virginia 23187 or your favorite charity.

title: Yankees Want Griffey Or Beltre in Pinstripes
description: George Steinbrenner dares to dream, which is why his Yankees executives have spent time considering ways to acquire Ken Griffey Jr., even when they know it is probably a long shot to work out a deal. The Yankees will probably spend some time dreaming of Adrian Beltre, the Dodgers' third baseman, if he becomes a free agent, as many believe he will.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: The Pill, for Crustaceans

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACE, HARRY R., M.D.
description: PACE-Harry R., M.D. The Hampton Synagogue mourns the passing of the beloved father of our dedicated and devoted Benefactor, Randolph Pace. Our heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Marc Schneier Michael B. Weisbrod, Pres. Seymour G. Siegel, Treasurer

title: Council Seeks to Ban A.T.M. Fees for Noncustomers
description: The City Council is planning legislation to prohibit banks from charging fees to noncustomers who use their automated teller machines. The bill, like measures passed in San Francisco and Santa Monica, Calif., would affect consumers who are now often charged two fees for doing business at banks where they do not maintain accounts, Council officials said yesterday.

title: VITAL SIGNS: IN THE LAB; Treadmill Regimen Yields Smarter Mice
description: Salk Institute researchers have found that, at least in mice, what the body does can shape the brain's development and enhance memory and learning.

title: Heirlooms as a Playing Field for Sibling Rivalry
description: Who is that crafty old codger with the borscht belt patter, the one who has the audience in stitches at the Royale Theater? No, it's not Jackie Mason (good guess, though), whose one-man show begins previews tonight at the Golden Theater next door. The kosher-salted crowd pleaser at the Royale is an 89-year-old furniture dealer, played by Bob Dishy, who is also the moral conscience in a drama by the morally conscientious Arthur Miller.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILLMAN, GEORGE
description: HILLMAN-George. Beloved husband of Selma. Devoted father of Terry and Lori and father-in-law of Lorin. Loving grandfather of Jesse, Ari, & Devin. Dear brother of Ruth & brother-in-law of Morris. Cherished uncle and friend. Died peacefully November 15, 1999 at the age of 83. His life was devoted to helping others. We will miss his strength and guidance. We will always remember his kind, generous and loving spirit. Services are tomorrow, November 17th at 11:30AM at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Avenue (at 10th Street), New York, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINEBURGH, JOEL T.
description: WINEBURGH-Joel T. Joel will be greatly missed by his colleagues and friends at Cometals and Commercial Metals Company. In his 26 years as a member of the Cometals family, Joel made many special contributions. He was a unique, tireless, talented and warm individual. We extend our sympathies to Marjorie and the entire Wineburgh family. Cometals

title: CHARMING SHOPPES BUYS WOMEN'S APPAREL RETAILER
description: Charming Shoppes Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Catherines Stores Corporation for about $150 million. Charming Shoppes, based in Bensalem, Pa., a women's apparel chain with $1.1 billion of revenue in the last 12 months, said it would pay $21 a share in cash for all outstanding shares of Catherines, a retailer of large-size women's clothing based in Memphis. Catherines, which registered $302.6 million in revenue in the last 12 months, has roughly 6.8 million shares outstanding. The stock soared 60 percent, closing at $19.8125 in Nasdaq trading, up $7.4375 a share.

title: In Quest to Cure Rare Diseases, Some Get Left Out
description: If there was a defining moment, a single event that foretold the sadness to come, Eric Godek's parents do not mention it. Looking back, they say only that he was 4 months old when they began to notice things that worried them. He seemed to have lost the ability to lift his head and reach for his toys, and he had begun to choke on feedings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MURRAY
description: COHEN-Murray, 82, of Boca Raton, Florida and formerly of New York, died November 14, 1999. He was a former executive of Glenoit Mills, New York, New York. He is survived by his wife, Ruth. Graveside services at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY, at 2:00 PM, Tuesday, November 16, 1999.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Hear Case on Student-Led Prayers at School Games
description: The decades-old debate over school prayer finally cycled back to the Supreme Court today in the form of a singularly American question, one that has as much to do with culture as with either religion or law: Does it violate the Constitution for one student to lead others in prayer before a public high school football game?

title: Hartford Stadium Plan Rankles Nearby Town
description: This gritty industrial city of about 70,000 people is used to being overshadowed by Hartford, its much larger and better-known neighbor eight miles to the northeast.

title: HONG KONG INTERNET VENTURE
description: One of Hong Kong's four fixed-line telecommunications operators, Hutchison Whampoa Ltd., and Global Crossing Ltd., a Nasdaq-listed Internet service provider, said they would form a $1.2 billion venture to offer Internet-related services in Hong Kong. The new 50-50 venture, to be called Hutchison Global Crossing, will provide links to Global Crossing's global network. Global Crossing will provide Hutchison $400 million of convertible preferred shares, international telecommunications capacity rights on its global optical fiber network and other data-related cable capacity that it values at $350 million. It will also invest $50 million cash.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the State of the Art column in Circuits on Thursday, about the i-Opener computer, misstated the manufacturer's name, as did a correction of the Web address, in this space on Friday. The company is Netpliance Inc., not NetPliance.com; its Web site is www.netpliance.net/, not www .netpliance.com.

title: Joy, Worry and Indifference in Streets of Beijing
description: Many Chinese were pinching themselves this afternoon, filled with disbelief that after more than a decade of false starts, China had actually taken the plunge into the international economy, signing a landmark trade agreement with the United States.

title: An Irritated Muckler Tries to Keep Balance on Tightrope
description: RYE, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- On the ice, John Muckler did not betray a hint of anxiety, speaking sternly when needed and smiling when appropriate this morning at Rangers practice. But the smiles did little to assuage the Ranger coach's frosty mood.

title: VITAL SIGNS: UPDATE; Cardiologists Share the Latest Wisdom
description: Cardiologists got together in Atlanta last week for the annual meeting of the American Heart Association. Here's a sampling of the studies presented:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINNICK, CHARLES
description: LINNICK-Charles, 95. Of Pompano Beach, Florida, passed away on November 15, 1999. He is survived by his loving daughter, Marjorie Schlosberg, devoted daughter-inlaw, Ruth Linnick, cherished grandchildren, Karen, Jeremy, Mitchell and Cindy, loving greatgrandchildren, Daniel, Jonathan and Zachary. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, November 17, at 12 noon at the Riverside Chapel, 21 Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York, 914-664-6800.

title: John Paul Stapp, 89, Is Dead; 'The Fastest Man on Earth'
description: Col. John Paul Stapp, an Air Force medical researcher who rode a rocket-powered sled at a speed faster than a .45-caliber bullet in an experiment to test the limits of human endurance, died on Saturday at his home in Alamogordo, N.M. He was 89.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Drug Maker Discloses Data About a Pact With Pfizer
description: In what is becoming one of the drug industry's nastiest takeover battles, Warner-Lambert released some confidential details yesterday of its agreement with Pfizer to co-promote Lipitor, a successful cholesterol-lowering drug.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERES, ROBERT A.
description: BERES-Robert A. November 13, 1999. An accomplished sailor, an inspiration to many. Your wife and family and those who sailed with you will treasure the time we spent together. You made a difference.

title: MOBILE COMPANY SELLS STAKE
description: The mobile phone service affiliate of the state-run Korea Telecom Corporation, the Korea Telecom Freetel Company, agreed to sell a 9.2 percent stake to the Microsoft Corporation, Qualcomm Inc. and Capital Communications of Canada for $600 million. The South Korean company said it would sell newly issued shares and bonds with subscription warrants equivalent to a 9.2 percent stake. Under the agreement, Korea Telecom Freetel will venture into the Internet business with Microsoft and jointly develop a code division multiple access system and high-speed wireless data communications technology with Qualcomm. Korea Telecom Freetel will also cooperate with Capital Communications in overseas projects.

title: Giuliani's 'Compassion'
description: To the Editor:

title: O'Connor Sends Bishops an Implied Farewell
description: With his health uncertain and his 80th birthday approaching, Cardinal John O'Connor, the archbishop of New York, sat out an annual gathering of American bishops this week. Instead, he sent a letter of gratitude that seemed a moving farewell to his spiritual brethren.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Missteps
description: Many a candidate in New York has tripped over the hazardous emotional terrain of Israel and the Middle East peace process. Hillary Rodham Clinton faces a special problem in addressing the subject because of her confusing roles as first lady, administration defender and undeclared Senate candidate. The difficulty cropped up in a different area over the summer when she first endorsed and then opposed President Clinton's pardon of several Puerto Rican nationalists. Last week it emerged again with her handling of the subject of Israel's treatment of the Palestinians, an issue that drew fire from her presumed opponent, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. The electorate will have plenty of opportunities to weigh such political exchanges. For now, Mrs. Clinton needs to move quickly to clarify her views on Israel to voters who seem perplexed about where she stands.

title: Judges Reinstate Conviction In Extortion of Bill Cosby
description: In a highly unusual move, the Federal appeals panel that overturned the conviction of a woman accused of trying to extort $40 million from Bill Cosby reversed itself yesterday and reinstated the guilty verdict against her.

title: Front Row
description: Rehabilitating Her Image

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWANTNER, MARLENE
description: SCHWANTNER - Marlene. Be loved wife of Thomas. Devoted mother of Amy, Mindy and Matthew. Stepmother of T.R., Jamie and Timothy. Cherished daughter of Morton & Shirley Rosenbaum. Loving sister of Sheryl and Robert Orgel, Michael and Carolyn Rosenbaum, Randy Rosenbaum, and Felice Rosenbaum. Dear aunt of Fran, Scott, Adam, Samantha and Taylor. Services 12 noon Tuesday at ''Temple Emanu-El'' 455 Neptune Blvd., Long Beach, L.I. For further information contact Gutterman's 516-764-9400.

title: Hubble Telescope Shut Down Because of Faulty Gyroscope
description: The Hubble Space Telescope has temporarily ceased scientific operations because of the failure of its precision pointing system, a development that will leave the valuable observatory dormant until a space shuttle repair mission scheduled to arrive next month, NASA officials said today.

title: Historians Revisit Slaughter on the Plains
description: The wanton slaughter of millions of bison in the 19th century by white hide hunters, abetted by a military intent on subjugating Indians, is probably the most famous conservation horror story in United States history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPATZ, LEO
description: SPATZ-Leo. Passed away peacefully on November 14. Beloved brother of Theodore Spatz and Dorothy Waldman. He is also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. He will be missed by all whose lives he touched with his gentle soul.

title: Agreement Presents a Split for Republicans in Presidential Race
description: The Clinton administration's agreement to support China's membership in the World Trade Organization today laid bare the deep divisions among Republican candidates for president on the nature of relations between the United States and China.

title: Mannesmann Sues Goldman In Phone War
description: A day after rejectng a $106 billion takeover from Vodafone Airtouch P.L.C., Mannesmann A.G. of Germany moved to thwart the British company's hostile bid today by suing to remove its corporate adviser, Goldman, Sachs & Company, accusing the Wall Street investment bank of a conflict of interest.

title: Union Leaders Seek Unconditional Salary Raises
description: In their first joint statement regarding next year's contract talks, the leaders of New York City's municipal unions said yesterday that they wanted the city to give their nearly 300,000 members a wage increase significantly higher than the inflation rate.

title: A Sex Guide for Girls, Minus Homilies
description: It is a Darwinian law of nature that adults believe everything was better when they were young: music, books, movies, clothes, bagels and, of course, young people.

title: Discrimination in Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. to Permanently Close Troubled Reactor at Brookhaven
description: The federal government is planning to permanently close an aging nuclear reactor at the Brookhaven National Laboratory that has been shut since 1996 when the authorities discovered it had been leaking radioactive water into the ground, federal officials said today.

title: Shares Close Little Changed Ahead of Fed Panel Meeting
description: Stocks closed little changed yesterday as investors waited for today's Federal Open Market Committee meeting that will decide the direction of interest rates.

title: Olerud Has the Upper Hand
description: Mets General Manager Steve Phillips acknowledged yesterday that the Mets were largely at the mercy of John Olerud as they wait for the free-agent first baseman to decide whether he wants to remain in New York.

title: Squeegee Man Testifies at Trial of Officer Who Shot Him
description: A squeegee man who was shot by an off-duty police officer last year testified yesterday that he was unarmed and raising his hands when the officer fired.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, CATHERINE MULLER (PAT)
description: RYAN-Catherine Muller (Pat). On Nov. 13, 1999 of Brightwaters, L.I., Beloved wife of John F. Ryan. Daughter of the late John H. and Catherine T. Muller and sister of the late Jack Muller of Brooklyn, NY. Loving mother ofJohn F. Ryan, Jr., Patricia Armstrong, Elizabeth Torphy, Frances McKeon, Jean Casey, Robert K. Ryan and Mary Pat Ryan. Cherished grandmother of 14 and one step great grandson. Reposing at the Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Highway, (1/4 mile west of the Robert Moses Causeway). Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Bay Shore, L.I. on Wednesday 10:00 AM. Interment St. Patrick's Cemetery, Bay Shore, L.I. Visiting Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: On Visit, Clinton Nudges Turkey on Rights
description: President Clinton praised Turkey's democratic progress in a speech to its Grand National Assembly today even as he gently nudged the country to strengthen its adherence to human rights.

title: Getting a Cab to Queens
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Briefing column on Wednesday about an American who faces 10 years in prison for a car accident in the former Soviet republic of Georgia, in which his interpreter died, misstated the position of the State Department. The department says it has never maintained that the jailing of the American, Loren Wille, was a retaliation for that of a Georgian diplomat, Gueorgui Makharadze, who killed a teenager in Washington in 1997 in a drunken-driving accident.

title: INSIDE
description: Gore Speaks at Microsoft

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALINO, JOHN
description: MALINO-John. Beloved husband of Phyllis. Loving father of Joanne and Paul, Debbie and Rob, Linda & Dana. Adored grandpa of Jason and Andy. Dear son-in-law of Helen and Sydney Alter. Services Tuesday 11:30 A.M., from Temple Israel of Lawrence, 140 Central Avenue, Lawrence, New York.

title: When Nice Girls Didn't
description: There may be little common ground in the long-running debate over sex education, but people on all sides agree on this much: Until quite recently, teenage girls had little access to information about their bodies and their sexuality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTZMAN, DOROTHY (DEBBIE)
description: SALTZMAN-Dorothy (Debbie). Of Bayonne, NJ, on November 15. Loving wife of Nathan. Devoted mother of Rina, Seth and Debbie, and Donna and Sam. Cherished grandmother of Yitzchak, Zvi Hersch, Benyamin, Sara and Jared. Services Tuesday, 10:00 AM at Temple Emanu-El, 29th St. and Kennedy Blvd., Bayonne, NJ. Shiva at 700 Ave. A, Bayonne, from Tuesday evening to Sunday evening. Those who wish may make donations to Jewish Family Services 201-436-1299; or Comprehensive Wound Healing Center at St. Francis Hospital 201-418-2089. For info ''Wien & Wien'' 800-322-0533

title: Republicans in Congress Ease Impasse Over Budget
description: Congressional Republicans agreed tonight to eliminate or change a series of pro-business amendments in the year's last spending bills, even though the measures had been sponsored by their own senators, effectively sweeping away the next-to-last barrier to a final budget deal.

title: U.S. REACHES AN ACCORD TO OPEN CHINA ECONOMY AS WORLDWIDE MARKET
description: American and Chinese negotiators reached a landmark agreement today that would open the economy of China, the world's most populous nation, to foreign competitors and would also make it a full partner in the world's trading system.

title: Rebel Flag: Symbol of Shame
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Clinton Failed as Mrs. Arafat Criticized Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: First Direct Observation Of an Extrasolar Planet
description: A dark shadow like an ink spot drifting across the face of a star 153 light-years away has given astronomers the first direct observations that they said confirmed the existence of planets around stars outside Earth's solar system.

title: Crude Oil Closes Above $25, The Highest Level in 3 Years
description: The price of crude oil rose above $25 a barrel yesterday, the highest level in almost three years, amid expectations that rising demand, outstripping production, would eliminate a global surplus.

title: U.P.S. to Buy Rollins Unit
description: United Parcel Service Inc., the world's largest package-delivery company, agreed today to buy a fleet-management unit from the Rollins Truck Leasing Corporation for an undisclosed sum. The transaction will allow U.P.S. to oversee shipments for an additional 100 companies. The unit has annual revenue of about $125 million and will become part of U.P.S. Logistics, which manages shipping, warehousing and inventories for businesses. U.P.S. also agreed to sell to Rollins for an undisclosed amount a truck leasing and maintenance unit that has 4,000 customers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEE, TIMOTHY S., DR.
description: GEE-Timothy S., Dr., The Leukemia Service at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center deeply regrets the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Dr. Timothy S. Gee. A distinguished clinician, academician, and valued member of our group for more than 25 years, Dr. Gee trained numerous young physicians in our Fellowship Program. He was an exemplary role model: a fervent advocate for excellence in patient care, devoted to the compassionate treatment of patients and their families, and a pioneer in patient education. He was a much respected colleague and mentor to all involved in the treatment of leukemia. His presence within our medical community will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to Carol, Vicky, Matthew, Christopher and Stephanie. Leukemia Service, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center

title: Poetry as the Setting for Meditations on a Child's Death
description: Sequitur, now in its fourth season, seems more like a collective of musicians interested in new music than a distinct ensemble. But then new-music groups are often organized in unusual ways, and however Sequitur works, its two directors, Harold Meltzer and Sara Laimon, have proved to be inventive programmers with broad stylistic tastes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, FANNE
description: GREENBERG - Fanne. Loving wife of the late Murry, devoted mother and best friend of Sheila and Saul Tarter, loving grandmother of Peri, Miles and Marguerite, cherished great-grandmother of Madison and Zoe. Graveside funeral services Wednesday, 12:30 PM, at the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. For information call I.J. Morris 516-486-2500.

title: Ex-Nurse Sentenced to 360 Years in Killings
description: Orville Lynn Majors will spend the rest of his life in prison for the murders of six patients at a rural hospital in Indiana where he had been a licensed practical nurse. Mr. Majors, suspected of killing as many as 100 patients by lethal injection, was sentenced today to six terms of 60 years each. He will not be eligible for parole for at least 180 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESEROWITZ, NATHANIEL
description: LESEROWITZ-Nathaniel. The Society of Practitioners of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center extends their heartfelt sympathy to our Vice President, Dr. Freya Schnabel, Associate Attending Department of Surgery and her children Yoni and Talia upon the death of Nathaniel Leserowitz, husband and father. We are deeply saddened by your loss. May you be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Moshe Rubin, MD, President

title: Ranjabati Sircar, 36, Indian Choreographer
description: Ranjabati Sircar, a dancer and choreographer who fused India's classical and folk dance traditions with experimental forms from the West, died in Bombay on Oct. 23. She was 36 and lived in Calcutta.

title: MORE ON THE ACCORD
description: PACT DIVIDES REPUBLICANS

title: DEAL ON U.N. DUES BREAKS AN IMPASSE AND DRAWS CRITICS
description: A fragile deal between the White House and House Republicans to end a fight over abortion and United Nations dues drew scathing criticism today from abortion rights advocates and cutting reviews from Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIDARY, MARY
description: HIDARY-Mary. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York note with sadness the passing of Mary Hidary, beloved mother of our dear friend and former member of our board of directors, David Hidary. Mrs. Hidary was the matriarch of a prominent philanthropic family whose generosity is admired throughout the Jewish community. We extend our sincerest condolences to her sons, David, Abraham, Isaac, & Benjamin; to her daughter, Ann Shamah; to her grandchildren; & the entire family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Suit Says I.N.S. Undercut Honduran Aid Effort
description: Lawyers accused the Immigration and Naturalization Service yesterday of undermining a federal program that offers work permits to Honduran immigrants so they can help relatives at home recover from the devastation of Hurricane Mitch.

title: State Sues G.E. Over Pollution In the Hudson
description: Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer sued General Electric today, the first time the state has ever taken the company to court over PCB contamination of the Hudson River, in an action that he says he hopes will open the door to many similar suits.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EIDOS P.L.C., London, Europe's largest maker of video games, bought 20 percent of Maximum Holdings Inc., Los Angeles, a privately held seller of video games online, for $55 million.

title: Osteopathy Proves Effective for Back Pain
description: One of every five Americans suffers from lower back pain, and the experience can be debilitating. Often, victims cannot drive long distances, hold their children or even walk.

title: Study Bids Good Riddance to High Heels
description: High heels are slipping out of fashion in the workplace, and that is paying health dividends, a survey has found.

title: Coca-Cola Bottler Discusses Its Price Increase
description: Insisting that there had been no fundamental shift in strategy, the Coca-Cola Company's largest bottler told investors and money managers in a rare conference call yesterday that its decision to raise retail prices earlier this year should improve the company's cash flow and profitability despite a drop in volume.

title: National News Briefs; Outside Report Criticizes Missile Defense System
description: The Pentagon will be unable to make a recommendation to President Clinton next summer on whether to deploy a national missile defense system following an outside report saying the program has serious testing and management problems, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESS, CLYDE G. JR.
description: HESS-Clyde G. Jr., 76, of New Hampshire and Florida, November 13, 1999 in New Hampshire. Family members include his wife of 41 years, Muriel (Murray), three sons; Dustin of Florida; Patrick of New Hampshire, and Timothy of Maine; a daughter, Jennifer of Massachusetts; and four grandchildren. A memorial service will be conducted Tuesday, November 16, 1999, the First Congregational Church in Manchester, New Hampshire at 3:00 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to a charity of ones choice. For information or to view an on-line memorial, go to www.phaneuf.net

title: Ignoring Tribal Lore
description: To the Editor:

title: McCall Criticizes State Push From Medicaid to H.M.O.'s
description: The State Department of Health has done a poor job of ensuring that health maintenance organizations in New York have the capacity to absorb the millions of Medicaid recipients being forced into managed care, according to an audit released today by State Comptroller H. Carl McCall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASTEN, JOHN E.
description: MASTEN-John E., 87, of Rye, N.Y. Attorney, retired Vice President of The Phelps Dodge Corporation, and public servant, died suddenly on Friday, November 12, 1999. He was husband of the late Laura Wood Masten, father of Elizabeth M. Hammill of New Castle-uponTyme, England and John H. Masten of N.Y. City, grandfather of Anthony and John Hammill and Benjamin and Andrew Masten, & brother of Barbara M. Buchanan of Falmouth, MA. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, November 21, at 1:30PM at the Rye Presbyterian Church, 882 Boston Post Road, Rye, N.Y. The family will receive guests in the parish hall after the service. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Rye Presbyterian Church and the Rye Free Reading Room.

description: Sprawling across snake-infested Louisiana woodlands, a gigantic gravity wave detector that builders hope will open a new window on the universe was inaugurated today.

description: NO more Steffi. No Monica this week either. Just when women's tennis was getting great, absent from its year-end championships are the only players who have ever been great.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption yesterday about city and state officials who were briefly blocked from holding a news conference on the steps of City Hall misstated the elected office formerly held by one of them, Catherine Abate. She was a state senator, not an assemblywoman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRISER, ANNE N.
description: KRISER-Anne N. On November 14, 1999. Beloved wife of Sidney. Devoted mother of Judy Feldstein. Dear mother-in-law of Richard Feldstein. Cherished grandmother of Elizabeth and Christopher Rile and Julie and Mark Kessler. Adoring great-grandmother of Jessica and Lily. She will be deeply missed. Memorial service Tuesday, November 16, 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation-NY Chapter, 381 Park Ave South, NYC.

title: Behind Every Great Tree, or Some, Is a Man
description: TO list all the stunts that David Murbach has pulled in order to bring moments of joy to the public would fill this space and then some, leaving no opportunity to discuss the roles that hot dogs, vodka and the Norwegian government have played in his life. So we pass the buck to the Horticultural Society of New York, which is honoring him tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, ELFRIEDE
description: McDONALD-Elfriede. Of Shelter Island, NY. On November 12, 1999. A woman of singular zeal who carried an unprecedented affection for life. She possessed an insatiable passion of our world many diverse cultures, its overwhelming and fragile beauty, and those loving beings who inhabited its terra. Ardently active in church and community, she emotionally touched, comforted and improved the lives of all. Memory of her love, kindness, generosity and indomitable spirit will serve as inspiration in our daily lives, and an everlasting solace in our times of need. Memorial services are on Tuesday, November 16, 1:30PM, Presbyterian Church, Shelter Island. Donations may be sent to (Hope for All) c/o Bank Zeal, 4001 Basel Switzerland, a relief hospital in Cambodia which was founded through the guiding love of Anni and Dieter Thurig.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKUN, JUDITH G.
description: BERKUN-Judith G. On November 14, 1999. Beloved wife of Mordecai. Devoted mother of Alicia & Geza, Edward and Joanne, Barry and Leslie, Robin and Rick, Leslie and Jose, Margarita, and the late Norman. Cherished grandmother of Alexander, Neal, Robbie, Ben, Sarah, Suzanne, Noah, Sam and Araceli. Loving sister of Annette. She lived and loved to the fullest. Services Monday, 1 PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, STANLEY ARTHUR
description: FRANKEL-Stanley Arthur. Of Scarsdale, N.Y. On November 12, 1999. Beloved husband of Irene (nee Baskin) for 53 glorious years. Loving and treasured father of Steve, Tom, and Nancy. Father-inlaw of Henry Joselson and Helen Frankel. Wholly devoted grandfather to Adam, Danielle and Arielle. Dearest brother-in-law to Newt and Joe, Mark and Amri. Uncle to the Baskin boys and Minow girls. Services will be private. Donations in his memory may be made to the Pediatric Cancer Foundation at 405 Tarrytown Rd, PMB 572, White Plains, New York. 10607-1313.

description: Astigmatism and Art

title: Nets Show Some Life, But It's A Dream
description: The Nets inspired yet more dreams of a miraculous comeback tonight at the Continental Arena, rallying from a 22-point third-quarter deficit to get the crowd of 12,474 excited and their victimizers, the Seattle SuperSonics, anxious.

title: For Voters, the 60's Never Died
description: Liberalism is back -- maybe not in name, but in spirit and in substance. Its return has been forecast several times in the 1990's, but now it is clearly in flower. From voter surveys to the floors of Congress, we see abundant evidence that Americans are embracing sensible activist government. This swing of the pendulum represents more than a correction of conservative excesses.

description: Two appliance makers are getting new agencies.

description: A brief report in arts pages yesterday about an honor for Oprah Winfrey tomorrow at the National Book Awards ceremonies at the Marriot Marquis Hotel in Manhattan misstated the information telephone number. It is (212) 685-0261.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR LITTLE CHANGED. The dollar was little changed ahead of the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates. In New York, the dollar settled at 104.84 yen, down from 105.19. The euro traded at $1.0318, up from $1.0313.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Health Care for South Africa's Poor Imperiled by Lack of Funds
description: The public hospital system in South Africa is so short of cash that it lacks enough workers, medical equipment, ambulances, linens and medicine to provide proper care to the poor, a government commission has found.

title: HOSTILE BANK BID
description: Determined to make South Africa a player in the global banking market, Nedcor, one of the country's leading banks, has begun a hostile takeover bid for a larger rival, Standard Bank. Rebuffed last month after its initial offer, Nedcor has sweetened its bid to one share for every 5.5 Standard shares and says it has already lined up nearly 50 percent of Standard's shareholders behind the merger. A combination of Nedcor, the fourth-largest bank in the country, and Standard, the second largest, would place a South African bank among the top 200 in the world.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Consumers see no reason for it. They regard it almost as a personal insult. It has evoked an emotion that is quite astonishing.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Men in Cockpit Had Solid Experience
description: As EgyptAir Flight 990 left Kennedy International Airport in New York shortly after midnight on Oct. 31, the three men in the cockpit of the Boeing 767 covered a wide spectrum, and each appeared to have solid credentials.

description: MASTEN-John E., 87, of Rye, N.Y. Attorney, retired Vice President of The Phelps Dodge Corporation, and public servant, died suddenly on Friday, November 12, 1999. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDER, JULIA L.
description: SEIDER-Julia L. in her 92nd year passed away of natural causes on November 15, 1999 at Hospice By The Sea in Boca Raton, FL. The widow of Morris Seider, she was the cherished mother of Norman Seider and Paula Seider Solomon and the beloved grandmother of Mitchell Seider, Shari Jacobson, Phillip Manketo and Jason Manketo and the great grandmother of William and Charles Seider. She was a distinguished attorney for 60 years, a true pioneer for women in the legal profession in Suffolk county, where she served as the President of the County's Bar Association. She was a brave and beautiful lady who will live in the hearts of her loved ones forever. Contributions may be made to Hospice By The Sea, 1531 West Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton, FL 33486. Service Thursday November 18, 1999 10:00 A.M. Gutterman's Inc. 8800 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY, (516-921-5757).

title: Pittsburgh Agency Chooses an Executive
description: Rodney Underwood, a longtime New York creative executive, is moving to Pittsburgh to become chief creative officer at Blattner Brunner, an agency with billings estimated at $65 million from clients like PPG Industries and Sky Bank.

title: Executive Women at the Top: Still a Very Lonely Club
description: It sounds good: the number of women who are chief executives at Fortune 500 companies has doubled the last five months. The trouble is, the number went from two, to four, and isn't likely to increase significantly soon. Such is the bittersweet highlight of the 1999 survey of female executives by Catalyst, a research group in New York.

title: At 3-6, The Jets Create Havoc
description: This was not the Ray Lucas the New England Patriots remembered. The Lucas they knew was a practice squad guy. Then a special teams player. A wannabe quarterback. Finally, a teammate who was cut.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Dream of a Place for Sharing and Celebration
description: NAME: Aniishinabe Center

title: Corrections
description: A thumbnail biography on Sept. 28 with an article about the formal start of John McCain's campaign for the Republican presidential nomination included conflicting dates for the end of his military service. (A reader's e-mail message pointed out the error this week.) Mr. McCain served in the Navy from 1958 to 1981, not 1991.

title: The Appetite Waits For No Bird
description: PROBABLY the most challenging part of cooking Thanksgiving dinner is deciding what to serve until the turkey is carved. You need some kind of diversionary starter for everyone to nibble at while the lumps are being mashed out of the potatoes and whisked out of the gravy, but it can't be anything really rich or heavy or filling, or no one will ever make it to the pumpkin pie. And it certainly can't be anything that takes more than a few ingredients and a couple of steps to assemble on a day when even the best cook feels overwhelmed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, HARRY J. JR.
description: SMITH-Harry J. Jr. On Sunday, November 14, 1999. Harry J. SmithJr., of Vero Beach, FL., and Washington, DC. Beloved husband of Norma D. Smith. Father of James A. Smith and Christine E. Greenland. Also survived by four grandchildren, Shane and Grant Magagna and Elana and Dina Greenland. Memorial contributions may be made to the Anne Cavanaugh Smith Graduate Career Center, School of Foreign Service, Georgetown University, Washington, D.C. 20007.

title: A study by McCann-Erickson finds that many consumers bristle at millennium hype.
description: AS the countdown to the millennium begins in the advertising world, one huge global agency has some surprising advice: don't hype it.

title: Prosecutors Say Tapes Prove Former G.O.P. Leader's Guilt
description: Secretly recorded conversations that federal investigators say provide clear evidence of a landfill extortion scheme were played in Federal District Court here today in the trial of John Powell, the former Suffolk County Republican leader.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Bradley's N.B.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: High School Students Learn About Freedom of the Press
description: THERE is no news at Freeport High School this fall.

title: Georgio Hofmann, 91, Owner And Breeder of Star Racehorses
description: Georgia Hofmann, an owner and breeder of thoroughbred racehorses, including the Triple Tiara winner Sky Beauty, died Sunday at her home in Bal Harbour, Fla. She was 91.

title: Liberties; Living la Vida Trumpa
description: Melania Knauss pulls up her black Calvin Klein sheath to show off her supermodel knees.

title: CSX Says Court Reduced Damage Verdict
description: The CSX Corporation, the parent company of the third-largest United States railroad, said this week that a trial court had cut a $2.5 billion punitive damage verdict to $850 million in a case involving a 1987 tank-car fire in New Orleans.

title: Nets Change the Lineup, but the Losing Stays the Same
description: While the Nets' coaches scrambled around, searching for solutions to the team's dismal 1-6 start, including changes in the starting lineup, Stephon Marbury tried to remain calm today. Marbury, who orchestrated his move to New Jersey less than a year ago, looked for a bright side, a reason to stand behind his decision to come here.

title: Closing of Brookhaven Reactor Dismays Scientists, Pleases Environmentalists
description: Scientists at Brookhaven National Laboratory were dismayed today at the Department of Energy's decision to permanently close an aging nuclear reactor that has been shut since 1996, but environmentalists praised the move.

title: Outside the Comfort Zone
description: After being eliminated from the race for chief executive, A. Barry Rand resigned as executive vice president at Xerox in January and announced his goal to run a Fortune 500 company. On Nov. 9, Mr. Rand, 55, got his wish, landing at Avis Rent A Car, a company based on Long Island that expects to make Fortune's list in April.

title: SHARE SALE POSTPONED
description: South Korea's tobacco monopoly, the Korea Tobacco and Ginseng Corporation, shelved its planned $740 million overseas share sale, citing weakness among global tobacco stocks. It is the third Korean company to do so in six weeks. The government was on its final day of meeting international investors for the sale of up to 28.7 million shares -- or 15 percent -- of the company, the world's biggest ginseng maker. The shares have fallen 7.7 percent since the sale began on Nov. 1.

title: AMERICA ONLINE IN BRAZIL
description: Moving to tap Brazil's fast-growing Internet market, America Online began its first Portuguese-language service in Brazil, Latin America's largest economy. America Online will lend its brand name and technology to the venture, while its partner in Latin America, the Cisneros Group of Venezuela, will inject $100 million of investment. America Online plans Spanish-language services in Argentina and Mexico.

title: At 42, a Point Of Reckoning For Children Of 1964
description: When Tony was 7, he was a grinning Cockney optimist from the East End of London, spouting plans to become a jockey and cavorting exuberantly at the playground. Now he can be seen as a 42-year-old who dodges sour glances from his glum-looking wife, a woman who was once filmed by Michael Apted as Tony's beaming young sweetheart. ''I must say, it's not easy being married,'' says Tony, with the boyish scrappiness and joy long gone from his face. About his life as a cabby with a fenced-in suburban backyard, he acknowledges: ''I think this must be the limitations for me now.''

title: BANK BALI TAKEN OVER
description: Indonesia's Bank Restructuring Agency took over management of Bank Bali from Standard Chartered of Britain in a dispute that bankers warn is poisoning the investment climate. Standard Chartered has been running Bank Bali since its nationalization in July as part of an earlier agreement to buy 20 percent of the troubled commercial bank. But employees protesting what they contend are efforts by Standard Chartered to oust the bank's former owner have blocked Standard Chartered executives from Bank Bali's offices. The agency, moreover, has disputed Standard Chartered's estimates of Bank Bali's bailout costs.

title: Marching Smartly to Their Own Drummer
description: IN an age of sophisticated fund-raising, when megabuck donors are giving charities sums equal to the gross domestic product of a small country, and your college is reminding you oh-so-tactfully that planned giving can reduce your estate taxes, the nation's largest charity is still collecting dimes and quarters the old-fashioned way. At least that's how most Americans perceive the Salvation Army -- as a band of quaint do-gooders in Victorian uniforms urging passers-by to drop coins in the Christmas kettles while an off-key brass band belts carols.

title: Off to the Far North in a Boat That's 'All Wrong'
description: VOYAGE TO THE NORTH STAR

title: Owners Supportive, Valentine Believes
description: With his good friend Tommy Lasorda looking on, and maybe looking ahead, Mets Manager Bobby Valentine received the New York Athletic Club's manager of the year award yesterday and said he believed he had the full support of the Mets' ownership, despite not receiving a contract extension beyond next season.

title: Schmid Named Coach of the Year
description: Sigi Schmid of the Los Angeles Galaxy was named coach of the year in Major League Soccer yesterday, even though he joined the Galaxy five games into the season after coaching at U.C.L.A. for 19 seasons.

title: Behind Every Successful Pie Stands the Right Pan
description: LIKE casserole dishes, pie pans are equipment that few cooks put much thought into choosing. Many use what was handed down to them, or they buy something pretty, or they cheap out and go for an aluminum pan from the grocery store.

title: Huskies Receive A Commitment
description: Diana Taurasi of Chino, Calif., regarded by many college coaches as the best high school player in the country, has signed a letter of intent to attend Connecticut, AnnMarie Person, a spokeswoman for the school, said yesterday.

title: CALENDAR
description: Time for Beaujolais Nouveau

title: Lending a Hand to Black Farmers in the Deep South
description: NAME: The Federation of Southern Cooperatives/Land Assistance Fund

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINSIER, JOAN B.
description: WEINSIER-Joan B. Happy birthday, Aunt Joan. We miss you and are celebrating in our hearts. All our love. Your nieces and family

title: General Is Demoted 2 Ranks And Made to Retire in Sex Case
description: For the first time in history, the Army today demoted a major general two ranks and forced him into retirement as a colonel for having adulterous affairs with the wives of his subordinates.

title: China Reassures U.N. Chief on Banned Group
description: Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, said today that China's foreign minister had given him ''a better understanding'' of the government's crackdown on the outlawed Falun Gong spiritual movement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALINO, JOHN
description: MALINO-John. The Officers and Directors of the Realty Foundation of New York are deeply saddened by the untimely passing of one of our most loyal supporters. John was a Director of the Foundation for many years, constant in his dedication of our goals and beliefs. He will be deeply missed by all of us. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Phyllis, children and grandchildren. Our throughts and prayers are with you during this very difficult time. Larry A. Silverstein, Chairman Jerry L. Cohen, President Officers and Directors

title: Bosnia Is Peaceful Now but Will It Stay That Way?
description: Peace has come to Bosnia, but is it here to stay?

title: Heated Debate on Restructuring Middle School in Riverdale
description: In a raucous public hearing last night, several dozen angry parents debated a plan that would expand a middle school in the Riverdale section of the Bronx but narrow the school's attendance to exclude many children from the nearby, poorer Marble Hill neighborhood.

title: A Billion Reasons to Be on Board
description: IT should have been Maxwell L. Anderson's night. As director of the Whitney Museum of American Art, he was presiding over a gala dinner in late September opening the second half of the museum's ''American Century'' exhibition. Dozens of top artists, patrons, museum directors and corporate contributors crowded the event.

title: E.PIPHANY AGREES TO ACQUIRE RIGHTPOINT
description: E.piphany Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire RightPoint Inc. for 3.5 million shares valued at $393.8 million, in a deal that unites two makers of e-commerce software. E.piphany, a provider of software used to analyze commerce on the Internet, said it expected to have about 275 employees after completing the transaction. The company, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., had revenue of $10.5 million in the nine months that ended on Sept. 30. The privately held RightPoint, which is based in San Mateo, Calif., supplies electronic marketing products and services. Shares of E.piphany soared 40 percent, gaining $46 each, to $157.5.

title: Business Travel; The Delta Shuttle sets the formal opening of its renovated Marine Air Terminal tomorrow.
description: SOME of the improvements have been in place almost a week, but tomorrow the Delta Shuttle will formally open its newly renovated Marine Air Terminal at La Guardia Airport in New York -- a terminal used almost exclusively by business travelers flying between New York and Boston and Washington. (The U S Airways Shuttle departs from that airline's main terminal at La Guardia.)

title: Union Leaders, Sensing Betrayal, Will Try to Block Agreement in Congress
description: Union leaders pledged yesterday to try to block Congressional approval of the Clinton administration deal for China to join the World Trade Organization, predicting that they could stop the accord the way they had blocked other administration trade initiatives.

title: The Return of Ewing May Not Be Too Far Off
description: Patrick Ewing was stretching his long limbs and craning his neck like an eavesdropper as he tuned into an interview taking place nearby. Once the questioning posed to Chris Childs reached a certain point -- How close is Ewing to being ready? -- Ewing shot a menacing look at his teammate.

title: Security Guard Dies During School Incident
description: A school security guard suffered a fatal heart attack at Franklin K. Lane High School in Queens yesterday afternoon while rushing to break up a disturbance in the schoolyard, school and police officials said.

title: The Lords Depart, and a Tradition Ends
description: To the Editor:

title: Auction Sets Records for 18 Contemporary Artists
description: Prices for artworks made in the last 30 years were so high at Christie's last night that it seemed as if a bubble were getting ready to burst. Bidders acted like spoiled children, consistently ignoring the estimates and paying whatever it took to outpace the competition, even though many works had been up for auction in the last few years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, BARRY DONALD
description: WEINSTEIN-Barry Donald. Of Coral Springs, FL. Formerly of Whitestone, NY. On November 14, 1999. Graduate of St. John's University School of Pharmacy. Through his career as a licensed pharmacist and while finishing up his doctorate in pharmacology, he was passionately proud of his profession and was the model of an ethical professional. His unexpected passing is mourned by all who knew him. He is survived by his wife Mindy, his daughter Dana, mother and father Betsey and Leonard, brother Sanford, and sister-in-law Jeannie. We will miss you all the days of our lives.

title: For an American Holiday, Anything Goes
description: ACCORDING to the earliest accounts of the first Thanksgiving, the meal included birds, corn, peas, roast venison and beer. Beer? Apparently there was not yet a decent wine shop in all of Massachusetts.

title: Plans Dropped in Congress For Expanding Milk Cartel
description: Congress has dropped, for now, plans to have New York, New Jersey and other states join a regional milk cartel that would let dairy farmers reap higher prices.

title: In Turkey, Clinton Offers Quake Relief And Comfort
description: It was a familiar scene: President Clinton consoling disaster victims, promising a swift rebuilding effort and pledging federal assistance. The difference today was that the disaster in question struck halfway around the world.

title: Gay and Lesbian Charities Look to Life Beyond AIDS
description: TIM GILL is the founder of Quark Inc., the software company that dominates the professional desktop publishing industry. He is openly gay, too, and rich -- rich enough to have incorporated his own charity, the Gill Foundation, in 1994, with an endowment he estimates at $80 million.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEGACY, MARGARET (KING)
description: LEGACY-Margaret (King). A memorial service to be held at St. Bartholemew's Chapel, 109 E. 50 St, NYC on Friday, Nov. 19 at 1PM.

title: Some W.W.F., Some N.B.A.: Sprewell vs. Warriors
description: It has been two years since Latrell Sprewell attacked Golden State Coach P. J. Carlesimo, but his lingering resentment over how the team handled the incident, and his expectations of a hostile reception has the Knick guard savoring his first return to the Arena at Oakland on Saturday.

title: Share the Table, Not the Food
description: To the Editor:

title: Desktop Discount Shopping, The Newest Perquisite
description: First came corporate day care centers. Then it was concierge services that pick up employees' dry cleaning or deliver groceries for a fee. Now comes the virtual discount mall, offering workers everything from books to car insurance at up to 10 percent off, right on their office computer screens.

title: No Civil War, but a Brotherly Indifference
description: WE would have to get to this eventually, so we might as well get it out of the way now. The sibling rivalry thing.

title: Editorial Observer; When Does a Mistake Mutate Into a Gaffe?
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has now joined a long list of politicians who must cope with nagging bloopers. Asked recently by a television journalist to name the leaders of Taiwan, Chechnya, India and Pakistan, Mr. Bush managed only one.

title: Woman on Midtown Street Is Hit by Man With a Brick
description: A 27-year-old woman returning from an office errand was smashed in the head with a brick and left critically injured on a bustling Midtown sidewalk yesterday afternoon by a man who then ran off, the police said.

title: Trade Path Is Not Clear
description: It took three United States presidents, two Chinese leaders and dozens of negotiators 13 years of sometimes dramatic brinkmanship to clear a path for China to join the World Trade Organization. Now, to listen to proponents and critics of the measure, the hard work begins.

title: A Higher Profile for the Dissidents in Cuba
description: The business card of Elizardo Sanchez, a leading dissident here, has a curious caveat next to his phone number: ''if it works.''

title: Corrections
description: A music listing in the Arts & Leisure section on Sunday for a concert this Saturday at the Ukrainian Institute of America, 2 East 79th Street in Manhattan, misstated the program and some performers. The program will consist only of the world premiere of Virko Baley's ''Treny'' for two cellos and soprano. The soprano will be Oksana Krovytska, not Olga Pasichnyk; there will be no pianist.

title: WARNING ABOUT DAEWOO DELAY
description: The domestic creditors of the South Korean conglomerate Daewoo Group sent a warning to foreign banks that unless they comply with a debt rescheduling plan announced earlier, all of Daewoo's overseas debts will be subject to a loss-sharing program. Korea First Bank, a major creditor, delivered the message to a steering committee representing Daewoo's 200 foreign creditors. Local creditors warned that foreign banks should be prepared for higher losses.

title: Gun Lobby Helps States Train Young Hunters
description: Thirty-one hunters in camouflage pants and orange vests gathered just after dawn on a recent Saturday morning at a state preserve here, sipping from steaming cups, munching doughnuts and talking about barrel gauges and bird dogs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPPARD, WILLIAM FREEMAN
description: SHEPPARD-William Freeman. Of Los Angeles, formerly of NYC and Auburn, NY. Died November 10, 1999. Valiant veteran of the Battle of the Bulge. Tireless volunteer at Project Angel Food of Los Angeles. Beloved cousin of Syd Silverman, Marie Silverman Marich, Michael, Mark, Matthew Silverman. Arrangements pending. Please call the McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Ave, White Plains, NY, 914-949-7777, for information.

title: TV NOTES
description: How to Milk A Money Cow

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFE, ROBERT E.
description: WOLFE-Robert E. 81, died November 14, 1999, in Stamford, CT. Beloved husband of Pamela A. Wolfe, father of Douglas E. Wolfe, Catherine A. Wolfe, Scott W. Wolfe. Grandfather of Six. WWII Navy Veteran. Memorial Service will be held Thursday, November 18, at Christ Church, at 1:00 P.M., 254 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to Kids in Crisis, 1 Salem Street, Cos Cob, CT 06807

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Monday illustrating one possible temporary repair for the Year 2000 computer problem misspelled the term for the counting system in which each digit carries 16 possible values rather than the customary 10, and misstated several examples. The numbering system is hexadecimal, or base 16. In it, 16 is written as 10; 17 is written as 11; and 18 is written as 12.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We felt that he knew the firearm was dangerous.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PODESTA, FREDERICK J.
description: PODESTA-Frederick J. On November 15, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Lillian (nee Daly). Fred Podesta has been associated with Madison Square Garden for more than 25 years in executive capacities as Vice President, Publicity, Advertising & Promotion Director. He was also General Manager of the New York Knickerbockers and on the Board of Governors of the National Basketball Association. Reposing at Walter B. Cooke-Kennedy Funeral Home, 117 West 72 Street, NYC, Wednesday 7-9 PM, Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass, Blessed Sacrament R.C. Church, Friday 10 AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the John V. Mara Cancer Center at St. Vincent's Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STAR, LEON D., M.D.
description: STAR-Leon D., M.D. Beloved husband, loving father and grandfather. We miss you every day, but especially today, your 86th Birthday. Your family

title: Jackson Arrested in Protest Over Expulsions of Students
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson was arrested today in a protest over the expulsion of seven students in the small Illinois city of Decatur for a melee at a football game.

title: 3 Women in the Men's Club Wield Money and Influence
description: WITH a rueful laugh, Ann Rubenstein Tisch recalled what people back home in Kansas City, Mo., used to say about rich people: If you want to know what God thinks of money, just look at the people He gave it to.

title: At the Last Hour, Down to the Last Trick, and It Worked
description: Late last Friday evening in Beijing, an angry and frustrated Charlene Barshefsky declared to the Chinese on other side of the negotiating table, ''You are wasting my time.'' Then she pulled out the oldest pressure tactic in a negotiator's bag of tricks: She demanded to see the country's prime minister, Zhu Rongji, and declared that the next morning she would head for airport.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAUM, EDITH K.
description: TRAUM-Edith K. Beloved wife of Samuel. Devoted mother of Sara Traum, Jessica Traum and Irene Gold. Cherished grandmother of Marcel Traum and David Gold. Sister of Arnold Kapnick and the late Molly Malinow. Services Thursday, 1:30 PM, at RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Inside 'Monday Night Football'; From the Truck to the Booth, a Look at ABC's No. 2 Program
description: Al Michaels is managing his frustration in the back seat of a limousine on the way to Foxboro, Mass. The ''Monday Night Football'' announcer's trip from Boston to the Jets-Patriots game on Monday is 90 minutes old and not over.

title: An Orchestral Chopin Is Given a New Hearing
description: The accepted historical view of the two piano concertos by Chopin is that they are the precocious but flawed works of a 19-year-old Polish pianist and composer who felt compelled to write concertos to gain the European public's attention. The music is elegant and deeply personal, but the orchestrations are makeshift, many assert. Soon afterward Chopin realized he had no business writing for the orchestra and stuck to piano music.

title: Text of Decision by Monetary Committee
description: Following is the text of the statement by the Federal Open Market Committee, the Federal Reserve's monetary policy panel, after its decision yesterday to raise short-term interest rates:

title: Riding Winds of Reform, Yet Mired in Orthodoxy
description: On Monday, President Jiang Zemin warmly played host to American officials at the Chinese leadership compound to celebrate the major trade agreement committing China to far-reaching economic reforms and broad international ties.

title: Lean Budget, Bloated Government
description: The closing convulsions of the budget negotiations have marked the return of a condition rarely seen in Washington these days: calm. No partisan train wreck. No government shutdown. In a sort of tacit exchange, conservatives demanded no major reductions in the scope or size of government, and liberals did not demand costly new expansions.

title: Pledges by Ulster Rivals Break the Deadlock at Talks
description: Northern Ireland's rival parties exchanged unusually conciliatory statements and pledges today, raising expectations of an imminent break in the stalemate blocking progress in their peace agreement.

title: Federal Appeals Panel Backs Reverse-Bias Suit
description: A federal appeals panel has ruled that Resorts Atlantic City hotel and casino discriminated against a white man by hiring a black man with similar qualifications as a stage technician in 1994.

title: EXPORT SUBSIDIES CRITICIZED
description: Changes in global trade of farm products are an ''extremely high priority'' of the United States government, said Dan Glickman, the secretary of agriculture. He said increasing market access and eliminating trade-distorting domestic supports and export subsidies -- which he called ''a dagger in the heart of developing nations'' -- were important American goals in the next round of negotiations by the World Trade Organization, set to begin in Seattle on Nov. 30. Mr. Glickman's speech at the organization's Geneva offices came as student protesters chained themselves to the building's main staircase while others unfurled banners on the building's roof that read, ''The W.T.O. kills people.''

title: Price of Gasoline Drops
description: The average retail price of regular gasoline in the United States dropped to $1.282 a gallon this month, the first decline since June, the American Automobile Association said. Still, prices are up 22 percent from a year earlier. The average retail price for regular gasoline fell 1.1 cents from $1.293 a gallon in October, according to the AAA's monthly Fuel Gauge Report, which was based on 60,000 credit card transactions during the last weekend. Prices are up 22.8 cents a gallon since last November, the AAA said.

title: Giving
description: In an age of sophisticated fund-raising, the Salvation Army may seem like a band of quaint do-gooders. But for almost a decade the army has been the top-rated large charity. Also: the latest in student activism, and the harried life of a grant-seeker.

title: Safe Among Seamless Shadows
description: The latest Carnegie International at the Carnegie Museum of Art here confirms what was evident at the Venice Biennale last summer: the norm for the big, international survey has become a kind of institutionalized, make-nice subversiveness, often expressed in installation-art form that catches the viewer briefly in its headlights through some combination of political correctness, environmental scale and/or dazzling technological effects. But the thrill is always finite, comprehensible and either fun or morally uplifting, digestible and quickly gone.

title: Cronos Agrees to Settle S.E.C. Charges
description: The Cronos Group, which offers marine cargo containers for lease, has agreed to settle regulators' charges that it concealed $13.6 million of payments by the company and others to its former chairman.

title: Martinez Wins A.L. Cy Young Unanimously
description: Pedro Martinez became only the third pitcher to win Cy Young awards in both leagues when he was given the American League honor unanimously yesterday. Martinez figured that would happen, after he went 23-4 with a 2.07 earned run average for the Boston Red Sox and established himself as the game's most dominant pitcher.

title: Crew Member Suspected of Crashing Jet
description: A detailed analysis of the voice and data recorders aboard EgyptAir Flight 990 indicates that a crew member, possibly a relief pilot, seized the controls of the passenger jet and forced the plane into a steep dive toward the Atlantic Ocean, government officials said today.

title: FORTUNE BRANDS PAID $100 MILLION FOR 2 ACQUISITIONS
description: Fortune Brands Inc., maker of Titleist golf balls and Jim Beam bourbon, paid about $100 million for a cabinet maker and an office products company in October, according to a regulatory filing. The amount, reported in a quarterly filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, was not disclosed when the company bought Boone International Inc. and the NHB Group. Boone makes bulletin boards, markers and other products used in presentations. It expects sales of $56 million this year. NHB is a supplier of ready-to-assemble cabinets to the Lowe's Companies and other home-improvement retailers.

title: Sports of The Times; Sometimes Character Pays Off
description: IT'S nice to see a team get one right. Bill Parcells's faith in Ray Lucas was a joy to behold Monday night. The spectacle had nothing to do with rooting for the Jets, but rather seeing a blatant case of respect and admiration pay off.

title: Congress and Treasury Agree on Minor Tax Breaks
description: The caboose on the legislative train this year is likely to be a conglomeration of minor tax breaks that, among many other items, would turn chicken droppings into a tax shelter, give Puerto Rico a rebate for the tax paid on its rum and extend a pilot program of school construction bonds.

title: Hewlett's Retiring Chairman Plans to Join a Winemaker
description: For months the speculation on Lewis E. Platt, who retires as chairman of the Hewlett-Packard Company at the end of the year, has been that he would join a venture capital firm, a medical instrument company, or perhaps an Internet start-up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, EMANUEL M.
description: PARKER-Emanuel M. Beloved husband of Shirley, devoted father of Inez Sharp, Dr. Leslie Parker and Paul T. (Ruth) Parker. Loving grandfather of Charles, Jillian, Rebecca and Marcus. Services Wednesday, 1 PM, ''Weinstein-West End Funeral Chapel'', 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY.

title: VERTICALNET TO ACQUIRE NECX EXCHANGE
description: VerticalNet Inc., a provider of business-to-business Web sites, agreed to buy the closely held Necx Exchange L.L.C. for $105 million in cash and stock. VerticalNet will pay $10 million in cash and about $95 million in stock to buy Necx, which runs an online marketplace where large businesses can buy and sell semiconductors, electronic components, computer products and networking equipment. It will also assume about $10 million in Necx debt. VerticalNet, based in Horsham, Pa., runs 53 industry-specific Web sites where companies can buy and sell goods and services. Shares of VerticalNet rose $7.50, to $100.50.

title: Pfizer Increases Its Effort To Win Warner-Lambert Bid
description: Pfizer stepped up its effort Tuesday to acquire Warner-Lambert, beginning its attempt to oust the company's board and outlining what it sees as the advantages of the hostile takeover to Wall Street analysts.

title: For a Happier Holiday
description: THANKSGIVING would not seem complete without the traditional garnishes of friction, anxiety and rivalry. Along with permission to overeat comes the opportunity to cement long-held grudges with food as a weapon. Aunt Sadie's smug look as the table chooses her yams with marshmallows over her sister-in-law's turnip surprise is simply a reaffirmation of her belief that her brother should have done better.

title: U.S. and State Officials Weigh Microsoft Remedies
description: Sometime in the next two or three months, a diverse alliance of state and federal officials -- some elected, some appointed, some Democrats, some Republicans -- must reach agreement on one of the thorniest public policy issues of the day: what to do with the Microsoft Corporation if, as expected, a federal judge finds the company guilty of violating the nation's antitrust laws.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACSHANE, FRANK SUTHERLAND
description: MacSHANE-Frank Sutherland, 72, on Nov. 15, in Gloucester, MA. Father of Nicholas M. MacShane and his wife Heather MacShane of Wellesley, MA; grandfather of Benjamin and Quincy MacShane; former husband and friend of Lynn Fry Clarke of N.Y., brother of Jean Fraser-Harris of England. Memorial service in New York City in the spring. Burial private. For information James C. Greely Funeral Home, 212 Washington Street, Gloucester, MA.

title: A Patchwork Secondary Is Still a Giants Weak Spot
description: Giants defensive end Michael Strahan was asked Monday how long it took him to get over the 50 points that the Washington Redskins scored on the Giants two months ago. ''I'm still not over it,'' Strahan said.

title: City Told to Give Homeless AIDS Patients Immediate Shelter
description: A State Supreme Court justice has ordered New York City to provide emergency housing to homeless people with AIDS on the day they request it, saying that anything less endangers their already fragile health.

title: Is Silence Golden? Givers Like It More than Getters
description: ANONYMOUS givers are the Lone Rangers of philanthropy -- fond of masks and free to ride Silver into any town they please. At Christmas they slip gold coins into Salvation Army kettles in Chicago. One of them, in Los Angeles, helped a postal worker get her house back after a swindler prayed with her in her living room, then talked her into a phony refinancing scheme. In the state of Washington, a small posse of masked donors put up about a third of the $16.5 million needed to save a 25,000-acre patch of wilderness, the Loomis Forest, from logging.

title: Two Accused Of Siphoning P.B.A. Money
description: The former longtime president of the New Jersey Policemen's Benevolent Association and his top lieutenant were indicted today on federal charges of defrauding the organization of $1 million in dues and fund-raising proceeds and using the money to buy real estate, cars and jewelry.

title: Genentech Agrees to Settle Patent Dispute
description: Genentech Inc., the nation's pioneering biotechnology company, has agreed to pay $200 million to settle its long-running patent battle with the University of California over genetically engineered human growth hormones, according to a person close to the negotiations.

title: Pay-Per-View Purchases Fall Short
description: Lennox Lewis's unanimous decision over Evander Holyfield in last Saturday's heavyweight unification bout generated 850,000 pay-per-view purchases on TVKO.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Education Pays Off Royally

title: Thinning Sea Ice Stokes Debate on Climate
description: The great ice cover that stretches across the top of the globe has become about 40 percent thinner than it was two to four decades ago, scientists have found after analyzing data collected by nuclear submarines plying the Arctic Ocean.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAFFIGAN, MICHAEL A.
description: GAFFIGAN-Michael A., 63, of Dune Acres, IN., former President of Mercantile National Bank of Indiana, died on Friday at Saint Margaret Mercy Hospital in Hammond. He continued to be active in many community organizations up until his death. All of his life he was an eloquent and passionate champion of community service. Saint Margaret Mercy Healthcare Centers recently honored Mr. Gaffigan for his outstanding support of the Healing Ministry of the Sisters of St. Francis. Mr. Gaffigan gave of his time and resources to support organizations including Hospice of the Calumet Area, Northwest Indiana Forum as well as Purdue University Calumet Chancellors Advisory Council. As past Chairman of all of these organizations, his commitment was evident in the progress made in their respective missions. In addition, in 1989 he received the Shamrock Award from the Friendly Sons of Erin for his commitment to family and faith. Mr. Gaffigan's professional career began in 1957 at Chase Manhattan Bank where he rose to Assistant Treasurer. He returned to the Midwest in 1965 to assume a position with Central National Bank of Chicago (now La Salle National Bank) and was eventually promoted to Executive Vice President. In 1976 he was appointed President and then Chief Executive Officer of Mercantile National Bank of Indiana. Under his management, Mercantile always earned more than 1% on assets and was subsequently honored by Money Magazine as one of the 100 safest banks in the United States (one of only two Indiana banks so honored). As a banker, Mr. Gaffigan was a master at balancing criticism and encouragement. ''Mike was always fair in the way he treated us and I think that is what made him the respected President he was. He really did care about the employees as much as he did the bank's clients,'' said Jeanne Cleaveringa, a former Mercantile employee. Mr. Gaffigan was born in Springfield, Illinois and matriculated at Georgetown University earning a Bachelor of Arts in Economics. He earned his Masters of Business Administration from New York University. His wife Marcia preceded Michael Gaffigan in death in 1990. He is survived by his loving wife Kathleen (Nau), his six children, three step children and six grandchildren. Mr. Gaffigan has three brothers that also survive; Jacques (Mary Ann), Joseph (Joan), and Terrence. His children are: Catherine Kulkin (Marc) of Oakland, CA; Pamela, Chicago, IL; Michael II (Laura), Miami, FL; Mitchell (Christine), Chesterton, IN; Joseph (Jane), Chicago, IL; and James, New York, New York. His stepchildren are Gary Eldridge (Lisa), San Diego, CA; Katy Eldridge, Chicago, IL; Brian Eldridge, Chicago, Illinois. His grandchildren are Ashley Gaffigan, Mitchell Gaffigan, Morgan Kulkin, Connor Gaffigan, Zachary Kulkin and Kevin Gaffigan. Visitation on Tuesday, November 16 will be from 3-8 PM at White-Love Funeral Home in Chesterton, IN. The funeral mass will be at St. Anne of the Dunes in Beverly Shores, IN at 11:00 AM, Wednesday, November 17, 1999. Donations in lieu of flowers can be made to Hospice of the Calumet Area in Munster, IN.

title: Pentagon on Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHBERG, MAX
description: HOCHBERG-Max. Died Nov. 11, 1999. He founded the Hochberg Bros. Painting Co. in 1929 and the JM Charles Painting Co. In 1967, and remained an active partner until his retirment at age 90. He was predeceased by his beloved wife Ida and daughters Alice and Beverly. He is survived by his daughter Janice Siegel and her husband Gerald in Irvington, New York, as well as 10 grandchildren, 19 great grandchildren and 2 great grandchildren. He was affectionately known to all who knew him for his indomitable spirit and devotion to family. He was lovingly cared for by Marion Benjamin throughout his long illness. Services will be held 11 AM November 18, 1999 at Temple Beth Abraham, 25 Leroy Avenue, Tarrytown, NY. Donations may be made to Temple Beth Abraham or Hospice Care in Westchester and Putnam.

title: The Bidding for Qualified Teachers
description: New York City has known for years that suburban districts were outbidding the city for the best-qualified teachers. But not until this week did city officials get a statistical portrait showing the extent of the disparity. Now that the problem is clear, Gov. George Pataki and legislative leaders need to devise carefully targeted incentives that will help New York City and other urban centers get competitive in the marketplace and provide certified teachers to the children who most need them.

title: Event Loses Star: Serena Williams Withdraws
description: All beads and bravado, she was supposed to be making a much-ballyhooed debut last night in the Chase Championships at Madison Square Garden. But by the time the paying customers arrived with their legitimate expectations of watching the 1999 United States Open champion clobber the competition in Manhattan the same way she trampled them a borough away in Queens last summer, 18-year-old Serena Williams, grounded by a bad back, was already back home in Florida sharing the living room recliner with her Jack Russell terrier.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Rates May Rise, but This Bull Is Hanging On
description: INTEREST rates may rise, the Federal Reserve may fret, but there's just no keeping a good bull market down.

title: The Fishamajig Sandwich and Other Secrets
description: ''Maybe Baby, It's You,'' which had a limited run in August at the Currican Theater in Chelsea, has reopened at the SoHo Playhouse on Vandam Street. Following are excerpts from Peter Marks's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Aug. 11.

title: Criminal Trial Under Way In 1996 Valujet 592 Crash
description: One thing became clear today, as federal prosecutors and defense lawyers made opening statements in a criminal trial that accuses a maintenance company and two employees of shoddy work and an ensuing cover-up in the handling of oxygen generators implicated in the crash of Valujet Flight 592.

title: A Home for the Baroness's Art? Yes, Next to the Baron's
description: Some people become art collectors by birth, which was certainly the case with Baron Hans Heinrich von Thyssen-Bornemisza, whose grandfather collected Rodin sculptures and whose father built up an impressive collection of Italian primitives and Renaissance oils. The Baron then added richly to what he inherited, so that the 800 paintings on permanent display at the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum here since 1992 cover the 13th to 20th centuries.

title: Walking a Tightrope From Grant to Grant to Grant
description: KATHERINE CAMACHO CARR, Ph.D., nurse-midwife and educator, is the classic entrepreneur. She is driven by an unalloyed belief in her Internet-age vision of midwifery education and her dedication to women's health. She is kept afloat by buoyant optimism. Meanwhile, she cobbles together a living on the periphery of the mainstream, confident that the ideas she and her colleagues have been developing will one day make converts of the skeptics.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
