description: AZURIX CORP., Houston, a water company formed by Enron Corporation, said it had dismissed 85 employees, or almost a third of its work force, after warning two weeks ago that fourth-quarter earnings will fall short of estimates.

title: Orson Welles Gives Them the Willies
description: Liev Schreiber is nervous, and who can blame him? This 32-year-old actor, who plays Orson Welles in the Home Box Office drama ''RKO 281,'' about the making of ''Citizen Kane,'' gained 25 pounds and spent weeks reading about Welles and watching videos of his performances and interviews. Mr. Schreiber soon began to walk and sound like him.

title: Is Liberalism Really Back?
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Encouraging Words in Ulster

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN DECLINES. The dollar rose against Japan's currency after the Federal Reserve increased interest rates but adopted a neutral stance on future rises. The dollar settled in New York at 105.88 yen, up from 104.84 Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPERMAN, IRVING
description: COOPERMAN - Irving. Beloved uncle of Janet Lehr, Judith Schreier & Robert Rosenblum. Services and interment private. In keeping with his wishes contributions to an environmental cause of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Long-Sought Pathmark Coming to Plaza in Queens
description: A 10-year quest by civic leaders to bring a major supermarket to southeast Queens is nearing fulfillment in Springfield Gardens, and no one seems more pleased than Patricia Oettinger.

title: Volunteers Log On, Help Out
description: CHRIS CARTER is not a gung-ho volunteer. Until recently, Mr. Carter, a 27-year-old senior recruiter for Microsoft in Seattle, rarely did nonprofit work. But he wanted to give something to his community, besides money. Because sports had taught him about commitment and team work, his philanthropic instincts pointed him toward a volunteer coaching job. And like any good geek, Mr. Carter turned to the Internet for guidance.

title: As E-Giving Sites Spring Up, Some Say It's Donor Beware
description: ARASH of new Internet sites is promising to make it easier to support worthy causes. Want to do a little good when you shop? Shop-for-a-cause sites like iGive.com and Greatergood.com say they will send part of the price of whatever you buy to your favorite organization. Interested in making a donation over the Internet? There are several sites like GiveForChange.com and Charitableway.com that say they will shepherd your gift to a charity, sometimes for a fee.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: The Leopard's Share
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Chicken With All Dark Meat

title: Growth in Japan Is Expected To Lift World Rate in 2000
description: The world economy is growing at an unexpectedly fast pace because of surprisingly strong expansion in Japan and South Korea, a more modest upturn in Europe and economic resilience in the United States, an organization of the world's richest nations said here today in a semiannual appraisal.

title: A New Push to Bring Scouting Where Scouts Never Went Before
description: THE stalwart youth groups that historically have played an important role in the lives of middle-class children are retooling to address the needs of the sons of Texas sharecroppers, families living in homeless shelters, immigrants and female prisoners. The result is a swelling of the ranks of Girl Scouts of the U.S.A., Boy Scouts of America and Campfire Boys and Girls at a time when adult volunteers are increasingly scarce.

title: SUNY Raises Its Salary Limit For a Chancellor to $350,000
description: The State University of New York could pay its next chancellor as much as $350,000 under a resolution its trustees passed yesterday.

title: BID FOR AEROSPACE COMPANY
description: The Swedish aerospace company Saab made a cash bid of 179 kronor a share, worth a total of about $600 million, for the military-materials company Celsius. Saab said the new company would have annual sales of around $2.8 billion, of which $1.8 billion would come from military systems. The new company would have 18,300 employees.

title: BAYER BUYS LYONDELL UNIT
description: Seeking to strengthen profits at its largest division, Bayer, one of Germany's biggest chemical makers, agreed to buy a plastic-ingredient unit from the Lyondell Chemical Company of Houston for $2.45 billion. Bayer's planned acquisition will give it access to polyols, an ingredient for the popular plastic called polyurethane, and offers Lyondell cash to reduce its debt, now at about $6.2 billion. Bayer also said its operating profit fell 18 percent, to 624 million euros ($644.5 million) in the third quarter.

title: Honors
description: * Howard Roffman, president at Lucas Licensing, part of Lucasfilm Ltd., San Rafael, Calif., and Jim Ward, vice president for marketing at Lucasfilm, were named EPM Entertainment Marketers of the Year at the 11th annual EPM Entertainment Marketing Conference in Los Angeles.

title: Sullivan & Cromwell Names New Chairman
description: H. Rodgin Cohen, an expert in banking law, has been named chairman of Sullivan & Cromwell, replacing Ricardo Mestres Jr., who will vacate the chairman's office next year.

title: Share a Forkful of Knuckle
description: To the Editor:

title: 45,000 More Wartime Accounts Found by Panel in Swiss Banks
description: A commission that is seeking Holocaust-era accounts in Swiss banks has found nearly 45,000 accounts in addition to the 5,570 already published, said a person who has read a draft of the group's report.

title: Top Jump-Shooter Who Also Leads In Making Assists
description: EACH morning Bernard McClendon coaxes himself out of the bottom bunk of his dorm room at Michigan State University, pries open eyelids that can feel like garage doors, collects his chemistry and calculus books and heads for his 8 a.m. class. No rest for mathematics majors. At night, to soothe the brain strain, he flips on the CD player in his room and finds inspiration and comfort in gospel music.

title: THE CHEF
description: MANY people think that the whole notion of preserved ancestral dishes exists only in Europe. But it exists here, too. In Virginia, the traditions can still be found in the hollows and foothills of the back country.

title: The Sage of Value and Service
description: CORPORATE America and Peter Ferdinand Drucker have fallen out of favor with each other. Dr. Drucker still has his disciples, but at the bleeding edge of business the old master's lifework is commonly seen as simplistic, portentous, off the mark, idealistic, out of date. Not for 20 years have the corporate world's heavy hitters hung on his every word.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTOCK, JOSEPH
description: WEINSTOCK - Joseph. Beloved husband of Rose. Devoted father of Carol and Steven Dikman and Robert & Jinny Weinstock. Loving grandfather of Andrew, Andrea and Sara. Services 11:30 Thursday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANDERBILT, ALFRED GWYNNE
description: VANDERBILT-Alfred Gwynne. A memorial service will be announced in the near future. In lieu of flowers, the family gratefully suggests donations in the name of the deceased to: Disabled Jockeys' Fund, c/o The Jockeys' Guild, PO Box 250, Lexington, KY 40588; the Thoroughbred Retirement Foundation, PO Box 153, Albertson, NY 11507; and the National Museum of Racing, Union Ave., Saratoga Springs, NY 12866.

title: Some Crashes Classified as Deliberate
description: It is extremely rare for an airline pilot to crash a plane deliberately. But it has happened.

title: Austin Journal; A Thrifty Rally for a Rich Campaign
description: Breakfast cost $1,000 this morning inside the Texas Ballroom at the Austin Hyatt, but the 300 or so well-tailored men and women wearing Bush for President name tags did not seem to mind.

title: Tribute to Harry Smith, Musicologist and Muse
description: The musicologist, filmmaker and painter Harry Smith, who died in 1991 at age 78, was a super-bohemian, which is to say that his life was determinedly messy, his interests determinedly scattered, his interpretation of culture determinedly oppositional.

title: Pakistan's Big Defaulters Are Unfazed by Deadline to Pay Debts
description: A deadline for some of the most wealthy deadbeats here expired on Tuesday, with only a pittance in overdue bank loans repaid and leaving the nation to wonder whether its new military government will -- as promised -- begin putting a who's who of the high and mighty behind bars.

title: Bringing Two Different Worlds Together
description: Jonathan Harvey has led a relatively quiet life in modern British music, but his reach has been considerable. Mr. Harvey was raised in the choir school tradition of his country. He acquired a certain intellectual rigor in his studies at Princeton University and a grasp of electronics and its brave, new and seemingly limitless world at the Ircam studios in Paris. Traditional instruments in combination interest him, also the world of computers. But perhaps most interesting in his music is a coming together of the two.

title: THYSSEN PLANS SALES
description: Germany's biggest steel maker, Thyssen Krupp, said it planned to sell shares in its steel division to the public and shed units with 10 billion marks ($5 billion) in annual sales to finance growth of more profitable businesses. The company said it would sell as much as 35 percent of its steel unit next year, raising about 3 billion marks. It will also sell engineering, shipbuilding and other units that generate 16 percent of sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELSOHN, LORE (HILLER)
description: MENDELSOHN-Lore (Hiller). 70, of New York City, on November 14th, 1999, after a short illness. Beloved wife of Paul and mother of Teri and Eric. Lore died in her home with her family at her side. We will miss her enthusiastic engagement with the world and the energy she brought to everything she set her hand to. In lieu of flowers, please send a donation to Learning Leaders, 352 Park Avenue South, NY, NY 10010, or Donation Department, American Cancer Society, 19 West 56 Street, New York, New York 10019-3984.

title: Racial Labels In a New Century
description: To the Editor:

title: Latin American Ties
description: To the Editor:

title: Vodafone Contemplates 2-Tier Assault
description: Brushing aside a legal challenge to its advisers and the rejection of a $106.4 billion offer over the weekend, the mobile phone giant Vodafone Airtouch P.L.C. said today that it would present a sweetened bid for Mannesmann A.G. later this week, and was prepared to make a hostile move on the German company if that failed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAMCHECK, NORMAN, M.D.
description: ZAMCHECK-Norman, M.D., age 82 of West Newton, MA died November 16, 1999. Esteemed physician and oncology researcher. Husband of Francesca, brother of Anne Spiegal and the late Irving Zamcheck. Father of Norman, Erika, Deborah and Mark. Grandfather of Ariela, Abbie, Samuel, Doria, Nicholas, Brian, Akiva and Kyle. Graveside service to be held Thursday, 11/18/99 at 1pm at the Newton Cemetery, Newton, MA. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Walland's Performance Draws Praise at Yale
description: When Jack Siedlecki arrived at Yale from Amherst in the winter of 1996-97, Joe Walland, a freshman defensive back, walked into Siedlecki's office and told the new head coach he wanted to play quarterback.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a visit by Hillary Rodham Clinton to the West Bank misidentified the Palestinian health minister, who said to Mrs. Clinton at a gathering of public health officials: ''I would like to remind you of the words that you said to Israeli and Palestinian children. Words that are inscribed in the hearts of all Palestinians, when you told them that the path to a just and real peace is the establishment of a Palestinian state.'' The minister is Dr. Riad Zanoun. (Jihad Mashal, who also spoke, is an official of a nongovernmental Palestinian health care organization.)

title: New Rules Lift the Lid on Nonprofit Pay
description: BIG compensation packages for top executives in the business world have become commonplace in the booming economy. But now, as the Internal Revenue Service completes new rules for charities and foundations, experts say it will become increasingly profitable to work for a nonprofit institution.

title: Always Divine, Now Garbage Has Made Her a Saint
description: BETTE MIDLER was onstage with Barbra Streisand and the pope, Cher and Queen Elizabeth, Tina Turner and President Clinton, all singing ''We Are the World,'' making it seem like a self-congratulatory anthem for celebrities involved in causes:

title: Steinbach Retires After 13 Seasons
description: Terry Steinbach, a catcher and designated hitter for 13 years who won the World Series in 1989 with Oakland, retired from his hometown Minnesota Twins yesterday so he could spend more time with his family.

title: Political Memo; For All-but-Candidates, Pressure to Declare
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rudolph W. Giuliani had been planning formal campaign announcements as soon as this January, complete with all the usual trappings: balloons and speeches, endorsements and a statewide flyaround.

title: Where the Space Is Small but the Taste Is Big
description: REAL estate is the great dividing line among Manhattan restaurants. You've either got a great location or you don't. You can make do with limited space or you can't. You'll pay what's necessary or you won't.

title: Austin Conner Shofner, 83; Led Escape at P.O.W. Camp
description: Brig. Gen. Austin Conner Shofner, the marine who got word to the outside world of the infamous Bataan Death March of 1942 after he engineered the first and only successful American team escape from a Japanese prisoner-of-war camp, died on Sunday at his home in Shelbyville, Tenn. He was 83.

title: Mixing Wariness and Joy, Interns Become Residents
description: Carol Lampkin was a chatty woman with a sweeping smile who needed a lot of medical attention. And she did not want it from anyone but Dr. Jennifer James.

title: A Costly Deal on U.N. Dues
description: President Clinton paid a regrettably high price to win the House Republican leadership's assent to give almost $1 billion in back American dues to the United Nations. Last weekend, White House bargainers agreed to new statutory language restricting international family planning assistance that the administration had firmly and rightly resisted in the past. Understandably, advocates for women's health and reproductive choice, even including Vice President Gore, bemoaned that damaging concession and questioned its necessity.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Adding an Associate

title: A Highway Near You Probably Needs Help
description: WHAT: Adopt-a-Highway programs.

title: SHORT-TERM RATES ARE RAISED BY FED A QUARTER-POINT
description: The Federal Reserve raised interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point today, saying that the combination of strong growth and low unemployment had left the economy vulnerable to an outbreak of inflation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Circuits on Thursday about services that offer fast Internet connections misstated the translation of A.D.S.L. It is an abbreviation for asymmetric digital subscriber line, not asynchronous.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Reaching a Goal by Staying Put
description: They sat together and laughed after it was official, drenched in Champagne and the headiness of winning the most coveted prize in the Nascar Winston Cup Series: the $2 million yearly points championship. It now seemed hard to believe that the marriage between Dale Jarrett and his team owner, Robert Yates, almost ended in an early divorce.

title: Seething, Muttering and Moaning: That's a Good Day
description: For Jonathan Davis, the leader of Korn, feeling wretched is a full-time job. In Korn's songs, he is tormented by parents, lovers, acquaintances and demonic inner voices; he contemplates suicide or seethes with fury until he irrationally lashes out. As the band's music swerves from dirge to stomp, from claustrophobic compression to power-chorded roar, Mr. Davis mutters, moans and howls. He's a self-designated sacrifice to the extremes of adolescent tumult. ''I hurt so bad inside, I wish you could see the world through my eyes,'' he sang on Monday night at the Apollo Theater.

title: Pokemon Isn't Benign
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fed Raises Interest Rates On Concern About Inflation

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Holiday Rite, Regardless of Faith

title: Foreign Affairs; Next, It's E-ducation
description: The two most telling stories about the 10th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall actually ran in the business sections of The New York Times and The Washington Post.

title: Military Trappings, Short on Status; At Merchant Marine Academy, a Sense of Being Slighted
description: The dining hall roof leaks. Decrepit plumbing makes the water undrinkable in some buildings. The temperature in the barracks fluctuates with the whims of clogged radiators.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, DORIS (NEE EDELMAN)
description: WEINSTEIN-Doris (nee Edelman). Loving wife and best friend of Ira J. for 47 years. Mother of Peter & Andrea, Robert and Mary. Grandmother of Brianna, Brooke, and Alexandria. Sister of Gerald, & Maxine Edelman, Janet Edelman, Shirley and George Weinstein. Good friend of Emma Lee. Loved by many nieces and nephews. She was a master teacher of science, the consummate dealer in antique jewelry and a compassionate philanthropist. Her loss will be felt by many. Let us celebrate her life and remember her always. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Temple Beth El or North Shore Child and Family Guidance Assn. Services Wednesday 11 A.M. at Temple Beth El, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAEHLING, DOROTHY R. (NEE SCHNEIDER) ''DOLLY''
description: STAEHLING-Dorothy R. (nee Schneider) ''Dolly'' of Bedminster formerly of Springfield on Sunday, November 14, 1999. Wife of Henry H. (Hank) Staehling. Funeral Service in Smith and Smith (Suburban) 415 Morris Ave., Springfield Thursday, November 18 at noon. Relatives and friends are invited to attend. Interment Restland Memorial Park, E. Hanover. Friends may call Thusday 10-12 Noon.

title: Forbes to File Complaint Over Group's Critical Ads
description: In a dispute that pits Steve Forbes against the Republican Leadership Council, a moderate group that includes many supporters of George W. Bush, the Forbes campaign said yesterday it would file a complaint with the Federal Election Commission over television advertisements by the council that are critical of Mr. Forbes.

title: Leading, Acting and Choosing
description: From remarks at a recent gathering of women leaders in communications businesses:

title: Taylor Leads Rangers on Ice and in Locker Room
description: With all the high-priced veterans in the Rangers' dressing room, a relative bargain has easily been their best forward this season.

title: Maybe Pigs Do Fly: This Chop Isn't Pork
description: IN the flickering candlelight at Coup in the East Village, the slab of grilled meat could have easily been a pork chop or a veal chop. It was on the bone, after all, about an inch thick, a great 15-ounce portion.

title: Gore Announces an Environmental Initiative
description: Seeking to win the active support of environmental groups that have so far failed to muster much enthusiasm for his presidential campaign, Vice President Al Gore announced today that President Clinton would sign an executive order to require environmental reviews in all new trade agreements.

title: U.S. Says an Officer Offered to Be a Guard for Drug Sales
description: A veteran New York City police officer was accused yesterday of agreeing to act as a guard for a drug dealer, federal prosecutors said.

title: Doing Good or Doing Well: It's Starting to Get Blurry
description: THERE is a new phrase in the charity lexicon, one that began as an oxymoron and quickly evolved into an accurate description: nonprofit business. A growing number of charities are creating profit-making subsidiaries, some to make money from the intellectual property they own, and others to separate customers who can afford to pay for services from those who receive those services free, or at a nominal charge.

title: Taxi Surveillance Cameras Are Auditioned for Bigger Role
description: In an experiment aimed at deterring crimes against taxi drivers, the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission said yesterday that it had installed small infrared cameras in nine cabs and livery cars and was considering the use of such cameras throughout the taxi industry.

title: Indian College For the Arts Is Facing Loss Of U.S. Money
description: As a White Earth Chippewa, now 59 years old, Catherine Ryker grew tired of minimum wage jobs and wanted to become an art teacher. So she enrolled here in the Institute for American Indian Arts, the only college of its kind in the country, where Indians teach art and culture to Indians as a way to preserve their ethnic heritage.

title: Turning Baby Internet Moguls Into Big Givers
description: LEONARD ELY, a 76-year-old real estate magnate and veteran philanthropist in Palo Alto, Calif., awaits the day in the possibly distant future when all those young whippersnappers stop obsessing about the Gaggeneau kitchen ranges, personal helipads and those charming $9-million cottages on Turkey Farm Lane in Woodside.

title: Our Towns; Newcomer Gets Attention In Newark
description: JUST a few years ago, Cory Booker seemed to face a stark choice: he could aim to own the world or save it.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: State Senate Confirms Casino Control Nominee
description: The State Senate on Monday confirmed the nomination of Michael A. Fedorko, the former acting superintendent of the State Police, to a $90,000-a-year position on the State Casino Control Commission.

title: Congress and the President On Cusp of Budget Accord
description: The White House and the Republican Congress struggled tonight to finish the long overdue budget by finding a way to pay for nearly $7 billion in new spending.

title: Giuliani at Fund-Raiser, but Not Conservative Party's
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani attended a Broadway fund-raiser for his presumptive United States Senate campaign last night, but he was left out of another event that may have even more important implications for his political future: the State Conservative Party's annual fall cocktail party, which was being held at a hotel just a few blocks away.

title: Top TV Station in San Francisco Is Sold
description: Young Broadcasting Inc., owner of KCAL-TV in Los Angeles, agreed yesterday to buy KRON-TV, the top-rated San Francisco television station, from the Chronicle Publishing Company for $823 million in cash and stock, beating several larger rivals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, VIRGINIA
description: PARKER-Virginia. The City & Country School community mourns the loss of our dedicated and beloved colleague, Virginia Parker. For over fifty years, Virginia was an energetic and loyal contributor to the C. & C. community. Honest, forthright, caring and generous, Virginia was a cherished teacher, colleague, advisor to parents, and friend. Through her teaching and her modeling of the School's values in her interactions with all, she embodied the best of our School. We can't imagine our daily lives without Virginia. We will miss her greatly. A memorial for Virginia is planned for December 12 at 2PM at the School. The City & Country School community

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAKER, JACK
description: BAKER-Jack 11/17/94. Dear Dad, forever missed, forever loved. Love Paula, Beau and Bobby

title: Racial Labels In a New Century
description: To the Editor:

title: New Boss for School Guards, Same Problems
description: Nearly a year after the Police Department took command of the guards at New York City's 1,100 public schools, many of the problems that prompted the takeover persist, including complaints of inadequate training, disputes over what constitutes serious incidents and accusations that students are too often treated as potential criminals rather than mischievous youngsters.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil rose for the sixth time in seven sessions after Kuwait said producers agreed to extend output cuts past March. In New York, crude oil for December delivery rose 57 cents, to $25.70 a barrel.

title: Cruise Ship Officer Faces Charges in Dumping Case
description: When Royal Caribbean's newest and biggest ship, Voyager of the Seas, arrived in Miami last week on its maiden voyage, the welcoming ceremony included a surprise. Agents of the Immigration and Naturalization Service boarded and arrested one of the ship's chief engineers, accusing him of ordering crew members on another vessel to dump untreated oily waste water into the Pacific Ocean and the Inside Passage of Alaska.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORTIZ, RITA A.
description: ORTIZ-Rita A. The Faculty, Advisory Council, Alumni Association, students and staff of the Columbia University School of Social Work are deeply saddened at the death of Rita Ortiz, former assistant professor and member of the Class of '47. A distinguished alumna and respected social worker and teacher for nearly half a century, she made invaluable contributions as a leader in the Puerto Rican community and in her profession. The Gonzalez Memorial Scholarship she established at the School in 1989 in memory of her brother, Agustin Gonzalez, will be a lasting tribute to their joint commitment to meet the social and educational needs of Hispanic populations. A beloved friend and esteemed colleague, she will be missed by all who knew her. Sincerest condolences are extended to her family. Ronald A. Feldman, Dean

title: Frank MacShane Dies at 72; Expert on Raymond Chandler
description: Frank MacShane, a literary biographer who specialized in applying the highest standards of criticism to popular novelists like Raymond Chandler and John O'Hara who had been ignored by other academic critics, died on Monday at a nursing home in Gloucester, Mass. He was 72.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEAL, CHARLES M.
description: DEAL-Charles M. Age 93. Died November 13, 1999, Pennswood Village, Newtown, PA. Graduated St. Lawrence University 1926, L.L.B., J.S.D. Brooklyn Law School. Resided Brooklyn Heights until retirement from A.T.&T. serving as a corporate lawyer specializing in stock transfer matters. Retired to Bronxville, New York and moved to Pennswood Village in 1980. Wife Rosiland Leale predeceased him. Survived by niece Virginia Brookins, Wayne, PA, grandnephews Christopher Brookins, Cambridge, MA, Geoffrey Brookins, New York City, grandniece Stephanie Manzella, London, England and nephew Robert Cerf of New York City.

title: The Gospel According to Tony: Help First, Preach Later
description: DRIVING around the slums of Camden and Philadelphia with the Rev. Tony Campolo is like traveling with a hybrid of Mr. Toad and St. Francis of Assisi.

title: Bush's Military Service Was Real
description: Most Americans have put the Vietnam War behind them, but when it comes to baby boomers running for national office, some people just can't seem to let go.

title: Bradley Adviser Is Linked to Tobacco Ads
description: Bill Bradley unveiled his first round of television commercials in his Presidential campaign today, but he came under immediate attack from Vice President Al Gore's advisers for relying on an advertising executive who once worked with the tobacco industry.

title: A Funny Thing's Happening in Chelsea
description: FOR a small restaurant, Vox has a lot of quirks. There's the name, to start with, a short, punchy syllable that shimmers above the door in Chrysler Building silver and an eye-catching Art Deco typeface. An allusion to ''vox populi,'' or ''the voice of the people,'' it sets up a mysterious Latin leitmotif that carries through to the wine list, which lists red wines under ''rubeo,'' white under ''albus,'' and sparkling under ''scintillo.''

title: CASUARINA CAYMAN MAKES OFFER FOR LODGING CHAIN
description: Lodgian Inc., which owns or manages more than 130 hotels in the United States and Canada, has been approached with an offer of $6.50 a share, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Casuarina Cayman Holdings Ltd., controlled by William Yung, made the offer in a letter dated yesterday to Robert S. Cole, Lodgian's president and chief executive. Casuarina holds a 9.3 percent stake in Lodgian. Its offer values Lodgian's stock at more than $181 million. Casuarina, based in Fort Mitchell, Ky., said it was the largest franchisee of full-service Marriott hotels, with 41 in operation and 4 more in construction. Most of Atlanta-based Lodgian's hotels are linked to national brands, including Holiday Inn and Marriott.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Public Lives column on Friday about a new book of photographs by Helmut Newton misstated the publisher's given name. He is Benedikt Taschen, not Bernard.

title: BANDAI PROFIT RISES
description: Japan's biggest toy maker, the Bandai Company, said its first-half profit rose a better-than-forecast 10.7 percent, helped by cost cuts and strong sales of cartoon-related merchandise. For the six months that ended in September, the company, which makes the Power Rangers toys, earned 2.66 billion yen ($25 million) before one-time items and tax, up from 2.40 billion yen a year earlier. Sales fell 8.8 percent, to 54.1 billion yen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUNSON, NICHOLAS, NVVF
description: MUNSON-Nicholas, NVVF. Born April 19, 1911 in Williamsport, PA, passed away Monday November 15, 1999. Yale Graduate Class of 1933 and veteran of World War II. Predeceased by his wife, Helen, in 1991, and one of his four sons, Edgar Munson, in 1997. Survived by sons Nicholas, William, and Thomas, daughter Monie Munson, and Sheilah Taylor, also survived by numerous grandchildren and great grandchildren. Memorial service Saturday, November 20, at 11 A.M. at The First Presbyterian Church in Allegany, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to The First Presbyterian Church or The Adirondack Presbyterian Church, Keese Mills Road, Paul Smith, New York 12970.

title: When the Slate Needs Cleaning, Generosity Does the Job
description: SURF the television channels and there he is, plugging a cookbook with recipes for the cancer-wary and promising to donate the profits to research. Flip through the newspaper and up pops his name, high on a list of America's most dedicated benefactors.

title: Georgia Trying Anxiously to Stay Out of Chechen War
description: Capped in snow, the Shatili Mountains are fabled for their rugged beauty. These days they are also one of the Caucasus' more anxious borders.

title: NATIONAL CITY ISSUES FOURTH-QUARTER PROFIT WARNING
description: The National City Corporation, the 10th-largest United States bank, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit would fall short of analysts' expectations. National City, which is based in Cleveland, said fourth-quarter earnings per share could be up to 8 percent lower -- or 2 cents to 5 cents below the current estimate of 59 cents -- as shrinking deposits and higher interest rates force the bank to pay more for the money it lends. National City shares fell $1.25 each, to $28.875.

title: Police Seek Connecticut Student After Car Is Found in Queens
description: Police officers in New York and in Connecticut are investigating the disappearance of a law student who was last seen on Friday afternoon, when she left her apartment in the town of Hamden, Conn., to meet a friend for dinner in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEADE, REVEREND GARVEY G.
description: MEADE-Reverend Garvey G. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the parochial vicar of Good Shepherd Church, 1950 Batchelder Street, Brooklyn, on November 13, 1999. Reposing in Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Road, Brooklyn, Wednesday, November 17, from 2 to 5 and 7 to 10 p.m., and Thursday, November 18, from 2 to 5 p.m. Mass of Transferral at Good Sheperd Church, on Thursday, November 18, at 7:30 p.m. Funeral Mass, Friday, November 19, at 10:30 a.m. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: 3 Big Airlines Join Others On Priceline
description: Priceline.com, the online company that lets consumers bid for everything from airline tickets to cars and groceries, has signed up three of the nation's top six airlines, in effect doubling the number of airline seats it can sell.

title: WARNACO TO BUY AUTHENTIC FITNESS FOR $426.1 MILLION
description: The apparel maker Warnaco Group said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Authentic Fitness Corporation, a swimwear maker, for $20.80 a share, or $426.1 million. Authentic Fitness is best known for its Speedo brand sportswear. The agreement, which also calls for Warnaco to assume $105 million of debt, sweetens by $6 million an offer made last month. At that time, Warnaco offered $20.50 a share. Warnaco, based in New York, makes intimate apparel and sportswear under such brand names as Warner's and Olga. It had revenue of $1.5 billion in the nine months ended Oct. 2. Authentic Fitness had sales of $410.8 million in the year ended July 3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEIGUS, ESTHER
description: NEIGUS-Esther, of Solana Beach, Ca., passed away on November 15. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Irwin Neigus, mother of Nancy and David, gradmother of Miriam and Anika, and sister of Monte Levin.

title: 13 on Staten Island Accused In Internet Sales of Illicit Drugs
description: Thirteen members of a Staten Island gang were arrested yesterday and charged with arranging sales of designer drugs like Ecstasy over the Internet, police officials said.

title: Is Liberalism Really Back?
description: To the Editor:

title: Parcells, in Praise of Lucas, Says He Gave a Good Effort
description: At 3 o'clock this morning, less than three hours after the Jets had upset the New England Patriots, 24-17, in Foxboro, Mass., their chartered plane landed at La Guardia Airport.

title: Getting on the Sweet Side of Sprouts
description: BRUSSELS sprouts have an image problem, but it's perplexing considering their assets. They are not difficult to cook. They have a long season, stretching through winter. And they are not expensive.

title: In a New Land, Support From Knowing Sources
description: TWO years ago, when Zahida Nasim moved from Pakistan to Rego Park, Queens, she quickly found that she was virtually a prisoner in a household dominated by her husband's mother, sisters and brother.

title: With Surge In 2nd Half, Knicks Stop Their Slide
description: Whether it is hecklers, losing streaks or shooting slumps, the supremely confident Latrell Sprewell has the ability to shrug off anything that could weigh him down as easily as he would an overcoat.

title: New American Traditions; In a Berkeley Kitchen, A Celebration of Simplicity
description: THE house is unremarkable, a modest gray Craftsman bungalow on a shady side street a few blocks from the University of California.

title: Dangerous Duty at Sea
description: To the Editor:

title: Share the Plenty
description: To the Editor:

title: Working the Charity Circuit Keeps This Chef's Plate Full
description: ON a Monday night in mid-October, Scott Campbell stood in a cafeteria converted into a temporary banquet hall at the Chase Manhattan Bank headquarters on Park Avenue and handed out close to 1,000 slabs of duck and foie gras terrine to a black-tie horde chewing cheek by jowl. Three assistants from his Avenue Bistro stood with him to help arrange each slice over a mound of frisee and haricots verts with a pistachio garnish. Through it all, his wife and partner, Linda, stayed close to the huge sign fully describing the dish so that she could endlessly answer the inevitable: ''What are you serving here?''

title: Women and Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACE, HARRY, M.D.
description: PACE-Harry, M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center records with sorrow the death of Dr. Harry Pace. Dr. Pace was associated with Maimonides Medical Center in the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology for over forty years. He was one of the first obstetric/gynecology residents at Maimonides. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Sincere condolences are extended to his family. David Feldman, M.D., Pres. Salvatore DeGliuomini M.D. President Elect Steven Farber, M.D., Sec'y Herbert Lehman, M.D. Treasurer

title: Jean Potts, 88, Author of Prize-Winning Mystery
description: Jean Potts, a mystery writer known for her skill at depicting personalities and provincial American life, died on Nov. 10 at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 88 and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Touch of the Lips And, Voila, a Prince
description: If an award were given to the most underappreciated wines, chenin blancs would be wearing gold. Those same bartenders who pour chardonnay in their sleep might choke at a request for chenin blanc, even if you used one of the grape's proper French names -- Vouvray, Savenni'eres or Montlouis. But chenin blanc, Sancerre, its more popular Loire sibling, chenin blanc just needs half a chance to prove its charm.

title: New Rallying Cry on Campus: Stockholder Power!
description: LIKE a grandchild who has traced the branches of his family tree, Josh Glasstetter is intimately familiar with the history of campus activism at Cornell University, where he is a junior.

title: As Industries Consolidate, New Hazards For Advisers
description: A collective shudder passed through Wall Street this week when Mannesmann A.G. sought to remove Goldman Sachs Group as the corporate adviser to Vodafone Airtouch P.L.C., the British telecommunications company that has made a hostile bid for the German concern.

title: Comcast to Purchase Lenfest Communications
description: The Comcast Corporation agreed today to buy the cable television company Lenfest Communications Inc. from AT&T and the Lenfest family for $6.71 billion in stock and debt, adding 1.25 million subscribers in the greater Philadelphia area.

title: China Denies It Bought Israeli Radar
description: A government spokesman denied today that China's military had bought an advanced airborne radar system from Israel, even though Israeli officials have privately acknowledged to the United States that the sale took place.

title: Vodafone Gets Political in Its Bid for Mannesmann
description: LONDON  The battle for dominance of mobile telephony in Europe turned political Tuesday as Vodafone AirTouch PLC claimed the support of Prime Minister Tony Blair for its bid to acquire Mannesmann AG of Germany.

title: Dr. King's Widow Testifies in a Civil Trial
description: Coretta Scott King testified today before a jury for the first time about the assassination of her husband here 31 years ago.

title: In Trade Pact With China, Human Rights Loses
description: To the Editor:

title: Strong Sales Lift Profits Of 3 Retailers In Quarter
description: Home Depot Inc., the Dayton Hudson Corporation and Limited Inc. reported better-than-expected third-quarter profits yesterday as a strong economy fueled sales of everything from tools to housewares to clothing.

title: In Retirement, Graf Honored With Ceremony
description: Steffi Graf, the living legend who collected 22 Grand Slam championships and ruled women's tennis with her iron forehand, spending a record 377 weeks at No. 1, was honored with a gala retirement ceremony last night between matches at the Chase Championships.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLTZ, STANLEY
description: SOLTZ-Stanley. At age 78. On November 15, 1999. Loving father to Robert and Fran Soltz, Nancy and Burton Sussman. Cherished grandfather to Jennifer and Julie Soltz, Stacey and Jed Golden and Glenn Sussman. Services are today at 1P.M. at Beth Moses cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

title: For the Children of Harlem, Many Different Kinds of Help
description: IN fall 1988, when David N. Dinkins was still Manhattan Borough President and she was only 6 years old, Starrene Rhett of Harlem signed a contract with an executive of the financial services giant Merrill Lynch.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Washed in Applejack

title: Mexican Pollsters Challenge Size of Turnout in the Primary
description: Several independent pollsters have challenged official results of the governing party's Nov. 7 presidential primary that showed a huge turnout of voters.

title: Officer Is Found Dead of a Gunshot Wound
description: A New York City police officer was found dead last night, apparently of a gunshot wound, the police said.

title: Kosovo Diary Update: War and Recovery
description: Last year, Robert Turner, a relief worker for the International Rescue Committee based in Pristina, Kosovo, kept a diary for the Giving special section. In this article he describes his year since. The views expressed do not necessarily reflect those of the United Nations, his new employer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIHIC, DOROTHY MARY
description: MIHIC-Dorothy Mary of Babylon, L.I. on November 15, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Hubert Louis Mihic. Loving mother of Kathryn Mihic, Dorrie & Barney Breed, Margaret & Joe Breed and Bert Mihic. Adored grandmother of Christian Breed, Joseph Breed & Buffy Breed. First woman president of Financial Advertising & Marketing Association. Member of the Catholic Daughters. Member of the Baxter Guild of Good Samaritan Hospital. Reposing at the Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Hwy. (1/4 Mile West of the Robert Moses Cswy). Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial, Thursday 9:45 A.M. at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Babylon, L.I. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I. Visiting Wednesday 2-4:30 & 7-9:30. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to Good Samaritan Hospice, 655 Deer Park Avenue, Babylon, N.Y. 11702 or The Baxter Guild of Good Samaritan Hospital, 1000 Montauk Highway, West Islip, New York. 11795

title: Accounts
description: * Piiq.com, New York, an online shopping portal that will compete against Web sites like Shopnow.com and 4Anything.com, to Earle Palmer Brown, New York, part of EPB Communications, to handle its first advertising and public relations account. Billings were estimated at as much as $50 million.

title: A Goo-Free Pecan Pie, Stripped Down to Its Crisp Essentials
description: MINIMALISM is sometimes a very good thing, especially when it comes to the pecan pie. Anne Rosenzweig's version, which she serves at the Lobster Club in Manhattan, is the perfect example: just a crisp square of puff pastry topped with a thin layer of molten caramel and toasted pecans. It's served hot, right out of the oven, with a jaunty finish -- a little cube of vanilla ice cream.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORVINGTON, SERGE
description: CORVINGTON-Serge, 88, on November 6, 1999. Born in Haiti. Great Diplomat to the United Nations and Consul General to New York. After his Master's Degree in Librarian Sciences, Columbia University he worked 20 years at New York Public Library. His greatest treasures were those of the mind and soul. He will be dearly missed. Survived by wife, Edith and sons, Robert and Serge Jr.

title: Message: I Care (More Than They Do)
description: THE night is warm, with a sliver of moon rising over the California hills, and Vice President Al Gore gazes at the people gathered outside in the dark. ''Kids are going hungry,'' Mr. Gore tells them, softly, ''and we know that's not the way it's supposed to be.'' He pauses. ''The question for America,'' says Mr. Gore, his voice almost cracking, ''is how much do we care?''

title: Rock 'n' Roll and Prejudice In Ever Misty Baltimore
description: Baltimore has been awfully good to Barry Levinson. Whenever this gifted filmmaker seems in danger of succumbing to Hollywood's schlockiest temptations, he dips back into the personal memory bank of his Baltimore boyhood and comes up with something sweet and heartfelt. In ''Liberty Heights,'' his fourth Baltimore-based film, Mr. Levinson pores over the social traumas and cultural trivia of 1950's America as reflected in his native city with the concentration of a diehard nostalgist minutely inspecting the still-visible scars of his own hypersensitive adolescence.

title: A Hollywood Agent Who Rose And Fell Fast Is Found Dead
description: Jay Moloney was one of Hollywood's golden young men.

title: A Battered Wife Runs Away, And the Detective Follows
description: ''Black and Blue,'' as blunt as its title, feels as immediate as a jab in the gut. Like the bully it portrays, it knocks you to the floor and leaves you there, stunned. You're in pain, all right, but you haven't gone very far.

title: Outdated Flight Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Make Rhodes an Offer
description: The Yankees already possess arguably the best closer in the majors in Mariano Rivera. Now they are trying to build the best middle relief corps, and have made a multiyear offer to Arthur Rhodes, a left-handed power reliever.

title: Angry Press Debate at Hofstra Over Ad Doubting Holocaust
description: A 27-page advertisement that casts doubt on the Holocaust's existence has led to angry debate at Hofstra University, where editors of the student newspaper were confronted at a crowded forum today by angered students, faculty members and leaders of campus Jewish organizations.

title: Answers From a Veteran Foundation Watcher
description: The nature of big, rich foundations is that they have many friends and few critics. Among the latter, however, is Waldemar A. Nielsen, who worked at the Ford Foundation during its early days and has remained an observer and frequent critic of the foundation world ever since. He is probably best known for his books, including ''The Big Foundations,'' ''The Golden Donors: A New Anatomy of the Great Foundations'' and ''The Endangered Sector,'' and for his often blunt columns in The Chronicle of Philanthropy, an industry newspaper. Mr. Nielsen, now 81, a tall man with a thick mane of white hair and a bushy white mustache, regards foundations with decidedly mixed feelings -- both affection and disappointment. In a recent discussion, he explained some of his views.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELAFIELD, MARGARET GADE
description: DELAFIELD-Margaret Gade. Of Vero Beach, Florida died Friday, November 12 at home. She was born in Rochester, New York in 1910 and was the widow of Lieutenant Richard Delafield USNR who died in 1945. She is survived by her children: Cecily Delafield of Vero Beach. Felicia Delafield Van Praagh of New York City, Richard Delafield of Paradise Valley, Arizona, Penelope Delafield Johnson of Haydenville, MA, Astrid Delafield of NYC, Margaret Delafield Brandt of Latham, New York, her nephew J. Dennis Delafield of NYC, 12 grandchildren, and nine great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. James Episcopal Church in St. James, NY at 11 A.M. Saturday, November 27. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to the National Multiple Sclerosis Foundation, 733 3rd Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017.

title: Metro Business; Fannie Mae Unveils Plan for New Jersey
description: Fannie Mae, the federally chartered home mortgage company, announced a plan yesterday to encourage home ownership by pledging to buy $18 billion worth of new mortgages from lenders in New Jersey during the next five years.

title: Michigan Boy Who Killed at 11 Is Convicted of Murder as Adult
description: A state jury found a boy guilty today of second-degree murder for a killing committed when he was 11. He is believed to be the youngest American ever charged and convicted of murder as an adult, in a case that has highlighted a national trend toward putting children on trial as adults.

title: Forging Links in Cuba
description: More than a dozen Cuban human rights advocates and relatives of political prisoners have held meetings with dignitaries who are in Havana for a summit meeting of Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking nations. Cuban participants said issues included multiparty democracy, open markets, freedom of expression and ending the United States embargo against Cuba.

title: How Much the Affluent Give, State by State
Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, DORIS
description: WEINSTEIN-Doris. Members of the Board of Trustees and staff of the American Red Cross in Greater New York note with sadness the loss of Doris Weinstein, trustee of the Adolph and Ruth Schnurmacher Foundation, a generous supporter of the Red Cross in New York. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mr. Ira Weinstein and the entire Weinstein family. Jonathan O'Herron, Chairman Robert M. Bender, Jr. Chief Executive Officer American Red Cross in Greater New York

title: DERIVATIVE EXECUTIVE ARRESTED
description: Shinji Yamada, the former head of the Credit Suisse Group's derivative operations in Tokyo, was arrested and charged with tampering with evidence that was part of an investigation earlier this year into the Swiss banking giant's Japanese operations. An official at the Financial Supervisory Agency said prosecutors would bring criminal charges related to the firm's sale of customized derivatives against five Credit Suisse executives.

title: INSIDE
description: Possible Clue on Aging

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; U.S. Investors Salivate Over Chinese Stocks In Pact's Wake
description: MAYBE it depends which side of the Pacific you're on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARKIN, MARK D.
description: LARKIN-Mark D., age 79, of New York City. Died on November 13, 1999, while traveling in Yazd, Iran. He was the beloved husband of Linda Hess Larkin; father of Michael Larkin of San Francisco, California, and retired partner of PriceWaterhouseCoopers. A memorial service will be held at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington at 80th St., at 4 PM, Sunday, November 21. The family will receive guests in the Community Center after the service and also from 5PM-8PM, Thursday, November 18, and Friday, November 19, at the Schapiro's, 1035 Fifth Ave., Apt. 7C. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to the Frederick Douglass Academy, Attn: Dorothy Haime, 2581 Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Blvd., New York, NY 10039.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, LAURA NADLER
description: ISRAEL-Laura Nadler. On November 16, 1999 after a valiant battle with cancer. Beloved wife for over 50 years to Theodore J. Israel Jr. Devoted mother of Michael Israel, Nancy and Steven Hannick of Highland Park, IL, and Wendy Israel of Chicago, IL. Adored grandmother of Jessica and Michael Hannick. Laura was a brave and beautiful first class lady whose infectious warmth and personality will live on forever in the hearts of her friends and family. Her zest for life will be remembered by the compendium of quilts that she handcrafted as testimony to her creative spirit. A memorial celebration will be held Saturday, November 20 at 11 AM at the family home. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Museum of American Folk Art Building Fund.

title: Cooper Union Picks Physicist as First Black President
description: Correction Appended

title: What to Ask the Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: Anti-Abortion Groups Chafe at Whitman as Advocate in Court
description: State lawyers will go to court in Hackensack on Thursday to defend a new law requiring doctors to notify a parent before performing an abortion on a girl under 18.

title: Ad Executive Cites Her Race in Airport Search
description: A black advertising executive accused United States Customs officers yesterday of subjecting her to an extensive pat-down search for drugs at Newark International Airport solely because of her race.

title: Courts Extend Federal Rule In Yonkers
description: In a surprise decision, the latest in a long legal battle, an appeals court panel has given a federal judge another opportunity to justify continuing his nearly 20-year supervision of the Yonkers school system, which includes a 1997 order that Yonkers and New York State spend $575 million to aid mainly black and Hispanic students.

title: Carlesimo Insists He Holds No Grudge
description: In an effort to soothe any lingering resentment between him and Latrell Sprewell over an incident that scarred their careers nearly two years ago, P. J. Carlesimo said he planned to speak to Sprewell if given the opportunity on Saturday night in Oakland, Calif.

title: As New Doctors Enter a Brave New World
description: To the Editor:

title: Czechs Backtrack 10 Years, to the Time of Their Life
description: This was a day for the has-beens, the have-nots, the still-haves and the never-have-hads to come together and remember the good times. And for people here, what times those were!

title: A Tax You Can Handle
description: To the Editor:

title: Up a River, Begging for Paint
description: THE limestone tablet was lying face down, a mere doorstop in the dusty remains of Thomas Cole's studio here. On a late-summer afternoon, an architectural historian visiting the cobwebby old studio in back of the house picked it up and turned it over.

title: As New Doctors Enter a Brave New World
description: To the Editor:

title: A Changing of the Guard for Giants: Rosenthal for Petitgout
description: Tuesday afternoon, Mike Rosenthal went over to the apartment of his best friend, Luke Petitgout. ''Just hanging out,'' Rosenthal said.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Talks on Compensating Nazi-Era Slaves Turn to Sour Haggling
description: A mood of exasperation gripped German industry today after an additional offer to compensate Nazi-era slave laborers failed to settle a negotiation that began with lofty moral sentiments and has descended into ugly haggling.

title: How Fast, How Much
description: AFTER nearly a quarter-century of intense research by many of the greatest technical and marketing minds on the planet, personal computers still force the average consumer to decipher an eyeball-glazing catalog of technical mumbo-jumbo like this, from a recent newspaper advertisement: ''ATX w/300 Watt PS, 48x CD Rom, 9.1 GIG LVD U2W 2MB Buffer, 128MB PC100 ECC RAM, Intel PIII 500 w/Fan, 8 MEG ATI Xpert 98 AGP, 3Com 905TX 10/100 NIC. . . . ''

title: Exploring Worlds on CD-ROM's
description: Interactive CD-ROM's have largely been ignored in the frenzy of the Internet land grab, left to collect dust on computer store shelves, but intriguing educational titles are still being released. The descriptions below are drawn from articles that appeared in Circuits this year.

title: Thalidomide Helps Some With Disease
description: Thalidomide, which was banned in the early 1960's after causing birth defects in thousands of babies whose mothers took it for morning sickness, has been found to be effective in some patients with multiple myeloma, a deadly bone marrow cancer.

title: Batteries Included
description: The Circuits Holiday Buying Guide offers suggestions and advice on high-tech gifts and online shopping, whether for personal organizers or dollhouse furniture.

title: The Ego Behind the Ego in a Trump Gamble
description: ROGER J. STONE has worked with Donald J. Trump for 19 years, a relationship longer than any of their marriages that is now reaching its blissful apotheosis with Mr. Stone as director of the Donald J. Trump Presidential Exploratory Committee.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WELLS-GARDNER ELECTRONICS CORP., Chicago, a video products company, plans to acquire the assets of American Gaming and Electronics Inc., North America's largest independent distributor of gaming parts and service. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERS, MILTON L.
description: SANDERS-Milton L. 81, beloved husband of Audrey; devoted father of Judith, Jane and Betty-Ann; caring father in-law of Michael and William; loving papa of Jonathan, Rebecca and Elizabeth; dearest brother of Beatrice. Milton was House Counsel and Treasurer of Yellow Book U.S.A.; co-founder of Sanders & Daniels, Co.; pastpresident of Woodward Mental Health Center; avid photographer, talented sculptor. He will be missed by his family and friends, upon whom he unselfishly bestowed love, solace and guidance. Loved by all for his vitality, exuberance and passion. Funeral at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, Thursday, November 18, noon. Donations may be made in his memory to the Jewish Day School, 2313 Pennsylvania St, Allentown, PA 18104, attn: Principal.

title: HORACE MANN EDUCATORS WILL NOT SEEK BUYER
description: The Horace Mann Educators Corporation, which sells insurance to teachers, said yesterday that it had decided against trying to find a buyer for the company. The company's stock fell 25 percent, or $8.1875 a share, to $21.8125 on the New York Stock Exchange. Horace Mann shares rose 27 percent in early August when the company, which is based in Springfield, Ill., said it had hired investment bankers to consider ''strategic alternatives,'' including a sale of the company. The insurer said its board had decided independence would bring shareholders the greatest returns.

title: Entrusting Medical Data To an Internet Site
description: In the realm of privacy, few things are as sacrosanct as personal medical records. So when PersonalMD.com, a Web site that began operating this summer, offered to store records on line so that in emergencies doctors anywhere could retrieve them, skeptics doubted there would be many takers.

title: Jupiter's Atmosphere Raises Questions on Planet Formation
description: A probe that plummeted into Jupiter's atmosphere late in 1995, sampling its composition for the first time, found more than twice the concentration of elements like argon and nitrogen than expected, raising questions about standard theories of how the planets formed.

title: Games to Suit Every Platform and Every Taste
description: INDUSTRY sources on Wall Street and in Silicon Valley have informed me that Santa has signed co-branded content and e-commerce agreements with Sony, Nintendo and Sega, promising to drive traffic in return for sales commissions and (most important) stock options.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the Leonid meteor shower misstated the name of an engineer at the Aerospace Corporation, which advises the Defense Department and companies on ways to protect spacecraft from meteors. He is Glenn E. Peterson, not Glenn D. Anderson.

title: Classical Music in Review; Music in Renaissance Notation From an Oxford-Born Ensemble
description: The Clerks' Group

description: Interactive CD-ROM's have largely been ignored in the frenzy of the Internet land grab, left to collect dust on computer store shelves, but intriguing educational titles are still being released. The descriptions below are drawn from articles that appeared in Circuits this year.

title: Political Briefing; Fight Gets Tougher On Louisiana Caucus
description: The fight over whether Louisiana should jump nine days ahead of Iowa and hold the nation's first presidential caucuses next year on Jan. 15 is no longer just a war of words between Gov. Mike Foster and Mike Francis, the chairman of the state's Republican Party.

title: Where the Wired Consumer Can Give as Well as Receive
description: E-COMMERCE may do many things, but wiping out world hunger won't be among them. Nonetheless, the anticipated droves of consumers heading online this holiday season may come across a proliferation of charity malls and other Web-based programs that offer opportunities to donate to a worthy cause.

title: Drug Groups and U.N. Offices Join to Develop Malaria Cures
description: Major drug companies have joined international agencies in an unusual approach to keep research in antimalarial drugs from ending because of the drugs' poor commercial potential.

title: Open Trade With Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: Benjamin Schwartz, 82, Dies; Expert on Mao's Revolution
description: Benjamin Schwartz, one of the first scholars to show that Mao Zedong developed his own brand of Communism beyond Soviet control and a professor emeritus of history and political science at Harvard University, died of cancer on Sunday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 82.

title: To See and to Be Seen, Sleekly
description: EVEN if you're displaying Aunt Tillie's teacups, a traditional curio cabinet may not be your style. Sleek, colorful alternatives, some by designers like Philippe Starck and Ron Arad, are an option for design-conscious collectors. Anything you put in them will look good.

title: Gaffes Galore
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARBANEL, HILDA H.
description: BARBANEL-Hilda H. On November 17, 1999. Beloved wife of Sidney. Devoted mother of Marsha Elser, Stephanie Simon, Geraldine Barbanel Kapchan, Samara Rosenberg and Karen BarbanelEstis. Dear sister of Esther Levine, Ruthie Lederman and Doris Plotkin. Cherished grandmother of Mindy, Mark, Michael, Sean, Benjamin, David, Daniel, Rachel, Zachary, Alex and Dani. Loving great-grandmother of Melanie, Emily and Jamie. Services on Thursday, 1 P.M. at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Sanex Sponsor For WTA Tour
description: Bart McGuire, C.E.O. of the WTA Tour, confirmed yesterday that the tour, which lacked a title sponsor for the 1999 season, has completed a five-year deal with Sanex, a subsidiary of the $20 billion Sara Lee Corporation. As of Jan. 1, 2000, the professional women's tennis tour will be known as the Sanex WTA Tour. Though neither party would confirm the amount of the contract, it is believed to be worth $35 million over the next five years.

title: Letting Footnotes Generate a Cybertrail
description: Twelve scientific and scholarly publishers this week announced an electronic reference-linking service that will allow researchers to move easily from a citation in a journal article to the content of that article with a click or two of a mouse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESEROWITZ, NATHANIEL
description: LESEROWITZ-Nathaniel. The Advisory Council of Women At Risk extends our deepest sympathies to our colleague and friend, WAR Medical Director, Dr. Freya Schnabel, and her children Yoni & Talia, upon the untimely passing of her husband, Nathaniel Leserowitz. Our thoughts and prayers are with Freya and her family. Susan Fuirst and the WAR Advisory Council

title: Digital Players Break New Ground
description: IT was only a year ago that Diamond Multimedia introduced the Rio PMP300, the world's first portable MP3 music player, and spurred an audio revolution in downloaded music.

title: Promise of Irish Peace
description: To the Editor:
