description: Interactive CD-ROM's have largely been ignored in the frenzy of the Internet land grab, left to collect dust on computer store shelves, but intriguing educational titles are still being released. The descriptions below are drawn from articles that appeared in Circuits this year.

title: Vodafone's Board To Debate an Offer
description: The board of Vodafone Airtouch P.L.C. is scheduled to meet Thursday to weigh paying as much as $125 billion in a takeover of German rival Mannesmann A.G., executives close to the British company said today.

title: An Indonesian Banker, on Trial, Finds Fame Is No Friend
description: Rudy Ramli has become the most celebrated banker in Indonesian history, though for reasons he could scarcely have imagined.

title: PEGASUS TO ACQUIRE RESERVATION SYSTEMS PROVIDER
description: Pegasus Systems Inc., a provider of electronic-commerce services for hotels, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire REZsolutions Inc. for about $250 million. REZsolutions, based in Phoenix, provides reservation systems and representation services to the hotel industry. In addition, a $20 million note will be made payable to the majority stockholder in REZsolutions, the Utell International Ltd. unit of Reed Elsevier P.L.C. Pegasus Systems, based in Dallas, said the combined company would report estimated pro-forma revenue of $180 million for 1999 and have more than 2,100 employees. Shares of Pegasus Systems fell 62.5 cents, to $47, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASS, BEATRICE
description: BASS-Beatrice (Zarkower). Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Forest Hills, NY. On November 16, 1999, peacefully after a long illness. Beloved wife of Philip for fifty years. Loving mother of Judith (and Jack) and Marcy (and Scott). Adoring grandmother of Jeffrey, Jenna and Michael. Sister of Ruth and the late Helen and Seymour. Services November 18 at 1:15 p.m. at Plaza Memorial, 91st & Amsterdam. Contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: Linux and Creator Come of Age at Comdex Show
description: LAS VEGAS  Linus Torvalds has not even finished beating up on Microsoft Corp. and already he is taking on its hardware counterpart, Intel Corp.

title: Secret Service Shirts Violate Another Law
description: A week ago, White House lawyers ordered a college scholarship group here to stop selling T-shirts bearing the presidential seal, warning that the seal's misuse was a crime punishable by up to six months in jail. Now the Secret Service says the unauthorized use of its name on the shirts violates yet another federal law.

title: Germans, Used to Consensus, Seem Unfazed by Phone Wars
description: Two years ago, Krupp ignited a political firestorm in Germany by attempting a hostile takeover of its rival in the steel industry, Thyssen A.G.

title: Exploring Worlds on CD-ROM's
description: Interactive CD-ROM's have largely been ignored in the frenzy of the Internet land grab, left to collect dust on computer store shelves, but intriguing educational titles are still being released. The descriptions below are drawn from articles that appeared in Circuits this year.

title: The Argentine Heart: Part Song, All Tango
description: When nine dancing pairs take to the stage of the Gershwin Theater for the finale of the sultry ''Tango Argentino,'' it is as if we are eavesdropping on nine intimate dialogues, each with its own subtle inflections. Severe-looking couples in formal attire with slicked-back hair and masses of jewelry entwine and unlock like lengths of magnetic rope. They create, in effect, a sultanate of suaveness.

title: Over the Summit, 2 Clouds: Chechnya and Earthquake
description: Two specters hang over the summit meeting that is bringing more than 50 world leaders to Istanbul this week.

title: As New Doctors Enter a Brave New World
description: To the Editor:

title: What to Ask the Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sights and Sales, And Exhibits Galore
description: Bidding for Toys

title: Dissecting a Man's Life to Understand His Outlook
description: His young child's illness has prompted speculation that he may have been distraught. To some, his sending of money and gifts home ahead of him seemed loaded with meaning. He was also facing retirement, although it is unclear whether he was looking forward to it or dreading it.

title: 45 Homers, .319, 110 R.B.I. Add Up to M.V.P. for Jones
description: The Baseball Writers' Association of America confirmed yesterday what Mets fans -- and certainly Mets pitchers -- have known since mid-September: that Atlanta's Chipper Jones is the National League's most valuable player.

title: A Young Life Ripped Apart, Just as It Was Coming Together
description: Things had been going Nicole Barrett's way since she moved from East Texas to New York last year.

title: Classical Music in Review; Of Maidens Like Flowers And the 'Queen of Terre Haute'
description: Susanne Mentzer, mezzo-soprano

title: Chain Will Sell 3 Jewish Funeral Homes to Lessen Control
description: The market for Jewish funeral services in Manhattan and Brooklyn is now dominated by the world's largest funeral home operator, investigators from the state attorney general's office said yesterday.

title: Army Changing Mission Of a Training Academy
description: The Army school that taught generations of Latin American soldiers to fight leftist insurgencies during the cold war -- and along the way trained officers who went on to commit human-rights abuses -- is changing its name and its mission in hopes of improving its reputation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTORINA, MARIA
description: CASTORINA-Maria Polimeni, on November 16, 1999. Beloved wife of Frank. Devoted mother of Charles and Jane Gordon. Cherished grandmother of Whitney, Kimberly and Janine. Also survived by her sisters, Margaret Polimeni and Eleyene Vomero. Mass Saturday, St. Rosalia R.C. Church, 9:30 AM. Reposing at Ralph Aievoli & Son, 1275 65 St., Brooklyn. Visiting hours 2-4:30 PM and 7-9:30 PM.

title: Oil Prices Reach Highest Level in 3 Years; Some Industrial Metals Also Gain
description: The price of oil yesterday topped $26 a barrel, the highest level in almost three years. If it climbs just a few more pennies, it will be the highest since the Persian Gulf war in 1991.

title: Political Briefing; More Encouragement For McCain's Race
description: More good polling news in New Hampshire for surging Senator John McCain.

title: For Online Shoppers, a Virtual Mall as Big as All Cyberspace
description: Here is a sampling, by no means complete, of popular places to shop online, with examples of what each sells.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREMBICKI, ELIZABETH MARTIN
description: TREMBICKI-Elizabeth Martin, 81, of Gloucester, Mass., formerly a resident of Manhasset, New York, died November 14, 1999. Mrs. Trembicki was born in Glen Rock, N.J., educated in Ridgewood, N.J. and graduated in 1940 from Smith College, magna cum laude. A resident of Long Island since 1956, she was active in the community, progressive social, educational causes, and in the North Shore Unitarian Universalist Society, Plandome, N.Y. (now the UU Congregation at Shelter Rock) from 1959 to 1993. She was a Social Worker for Nassau County Dept. of Social Services and Creedmore Psychiatric Center until her retirement in 1980. Her volunter work included a close association with Literacy Volunteers of Nassau County in the '80's and more recently with the Manhasset Public Library. Her husband, Roman Leon Trembicki, born in St. Petersburg, became a U.S. citizen in 1941, and served for 22 months in the European Theatre as a First Lieutenant in Field Artillery. He was graduated from Amherst College in 1936, and was a Systems Analyst with IBM from 1946 to 1971. He died in November, 1980, after a long illness. She is survived by her two children, Michael Leon Trembicki, Somerville, Mass., Catherine Wharton Trembicki and her partner Janet M. Corbett of Gloucester, Mass., by a sister Margaret Conant, Jamaica Plain, Mass., six nieces and nephews: Elizabeth Thomas, Mary Stack, Peter and Roberta Conant, Steven Conant, Joy Grahn, Jill Trembicki & four great nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at the Unitarian Universalist Church, Gloucester, Mass., on Saturday, November 20th at 4 PM. Burial will take place privately at Mount Auburn Cemetery, Cambridge, Mass. Contributions may be made to the Organization of your choice.

title: A Few Clues in Brooklyn
description: WHAT'S it like at the top when all your colleagues are animated and you live in a paper-cutout house? Steve is the human host of Nickelodeon's ''Blue's Clues,'' the most watched preschool television show in the United States. A man-boy who is not afraid of looking dumb, Steve towers, physically, over the Muppets, the alien Teletubbies and the pocket monsters that are the rock stars of the kiddie-entertainment circuit. If Pokemon is mythically hip, Steve is nerd transcendent.

title: Al Gore as News Breaker, Not News Maker
description: It was not uncommon in the 1970's for the children of celebrities to walk among the grizzled, bourbon-swilling veterans in the newsroom of The Tennessean, this city's once-muckraking morning newspaper. Bobby Kennedy's son David and Arthur Schlesinger's son Andrew passed through briefly, as did Judge John Sirica's son Jack, and Henry Aaron's daughter Gaile.

title: Five Who Will Dominate At Their Positions
description: POINT GUARD

title: A Russian 'Cinderella' Loses Something in Translation
description: The Moscow City Ballet arrived at Tilles Center for the Performing Arts at Long Island University in Brookville trailing clouds of potential glory. Viktor Smirnov-Golovanov, artistic director and founder of the 12-year-old troupe, had been a soloist with the Bolshoi Ballet. Several of the dancers came from well-regarded schools and small companies in Russia. But Friday evening proved a disappointment.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about discrimination against foreigners in Japan misstated the size of the award to a Brazilian woman who sued a jewelry store that refused to serve her. It was $14,000, not $47,000.

title: Pakistan's Boss: Realist, Not Diplomat
description: Gen. Pervez Musharraf was running behind schedule again today, with top posts still to fill, hundreds of the corrupt yet to arrest, back taxes to collect and policies to reconsider. His post-coup government is only five weeks old.

title: TRIGEN ENERGY SHARES FALL AFTER OFFER WITHDRAWN
description: Shares of the Trigen Energy Corporation fell 10 percent yesterday, after Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux withdrew its offer to buy the 47.3 percent of the power plant operator that it does not own for $129 million. The shares fell $2.0625, to $19.9375, on the New York Stock Exchange after falling $1.9375 on Tuesday, when Suez made its announcement. Paris-based Suez, France's second-biggest water company, said it canceled its cash offer of $22 a share because Trigen had pushed for a higher bid using ''unrealistic and aggressive'' earnings projections.

title: Star Witness Falters in Trial of Former Republican Leader
description: The star witness in the federal extortion trial of John Powell, the former leader of the Suffolk County Republican Party, faltered under cross examination today, saying he could not recall whether he was lying or telling the truth when he was interviewed by federal investigators in August 1998.

title: Exploring Worlds on CD-ROM's
description: Interactive CD-ROM's have largely been ignored in the frenzy of the Internet land grab, left to collect dust on computer store shelves, but intriguing educational titles are still being released. The descriptions below are drawn from articles that appeared in Circuits this year.

title: EGYPTIANS SEE U.S. AS RUSHING TO FIND REASON FOR CRASH
description: The Egyptian government stepped up its condemnation of American officials investigating the EgyptAir crash today, saying that by focusing suspicion on one of the pilots they were rushing to judgment about the cause. Egypt's principal spokesman said a statement attributed to a relief pilot in the cockpit was being misinterpreted and did not show he was about to commit suicide by sending the plane into the Atlantic.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a resolution by the trustees of the State University of New York on a salary increase for the next SUNY chancellor referred erroneously to a system in which about half the campuses will have operating budgets too small to cover raises for faculty and staff members. It is SUNY -- not CUNY, the City University.

title: Police Scour Shelters for Man Who Hit Woman With Brick
description: Police detectives fanned out to homeless shelters and soup kitchens in Manhattan yesterday in search of a man who hit a woman with a brick in an unprovoked attack on a busy midtown street on Tuesday.

title: Suit Accusing Shopping Mall of Racism Over Bus Policy Settled
description: A suit accusing a shopping mall in suburban Buffalo of causing a teenager's death through racist transportation practices ended abruptly yesterday with a settlement of $2.55 million.

title: Witness Says Clinton Friend Had Part in Teamster Money Scheme
description: A former Democratic official has testified that Terence McAuliffe, President Clinton's friend and chief fund-raiser, played a major role in promoting an illegal scheme in which Democratic donors were to contribute to the Teamster president's re-election campaign, and in exchange the Teamsters were to donate large sums to the Democrats.

title: An Easy Way to Expand A Laptop's Hard Drive
description: Microtech International wants to make it easy to add gigabytes of additional hard drive space to the often skimpy capacity of portable computers. Its new PortableDrive 25 is a slim box that contains a 2.5-inch IDE hard drive with connectors that plug into a laptop's U.S.B. port or PCMCIA card slot.

title: Trade Concessions Stand
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: N.T.T. Plans to Cut 21,000 Jobs in Effort to Be More Nimble
description: Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, one of the world's largest phone companies, officially confirmed today that it planned to eliminate 21,000 jobs and sharply curtail investment over the next three years in an effort to enhance its competitiveness.

title: Food in a Custom Setting
description: The English designer Johnny Grey is known for custom kitchens like the one above in an $8 million London town house. This one has an iridescent ''1960's-feeling digital-age pattern,'' he said, and a capacious drum-shaped pantry. Now, Mr. Grey is also doing pubs. His design for the latest Foxtrot Oscar restaurant (drawing, top) in Battersea is ''loosely nautical, like Nantucket.'' Nautical as in bleached blond reclaimed oak and purple rubber floors, ceilings draped with sailcloth, a pickled oak board-and-batten bar with brass cleats, and a zinc counter top. The restaurant, with a family-style menu, is scheduled to open in March. Mr. Grey recently opened an American office, in San Francisco; (415) 701-7701. For information: www.johnnygreykitchens.com.

title: Daniel Nathans, 71, Pioneer in DNA Research
description: Dr. Daniel Nathans, a Nobel Prize-winning geneticist who pioneered the use of scalpels in analyzing DNA, a technique that helped create the biotechnology industry, died on Tuesday at his home in Baltimore. He was 71 and had taught at Johns Hopkins University for 37 years.

title: More Records for Contemporary Art
description: Prices soared at Sotheby's sale of contemporary art last night, when works by blue-chip artists like Marcel Duchamp and Mark Rothko, Alexander Calder and Sam Francis sold for more than ever before.

title: Will Gift Lists Click?
description: THOSE who agonize over what to give far-flung nieces and nephews for the holidays or what to buy the friend who is a compulsive gift-returner can now instruct the would-be recipients to simplify the shopping process by setting up an online gift registry.

title: Page to Screen And Back Again
description: Now here's an astonishment to both publishing and Hollywood: this holiday season more readers are likely to be getting their literary fix from the movies than they are from books. The conjugality between Hollywood and serious novels and nonfiction is hardly new. After all, Paramount put ''Great Expectations'' on the screen in 1917, and Dickens has lingered about the front lots like a ghost ever since, along with other great writers. But for this prime period of pre-Thanksgiving through New Year's, there seems to be an extraordinary number of literary books that have made it to movie screens or are in production. More than anyone seems to remember.

title: Leading Media Companies Forming Joint Web Venture
description: An unusually broad news-sharing arrangement is bringing together some of the nation's leading media companies in a venture to share news reports on their Web sites.

title: Christmas, Hanukkah and Kwanzaa: the Virtual Traditions
description: RELIGIOUS holidays abound at this time of year, but so do holiday Web sites, which means you don't have to take a course in comparative religion to figure out what to buy for what occasion or to simply satisfy your curiosity about celebrations of Christmas, Kwanzaa and Hanukkah.

title: And the Band Plays On: A Big Stretch for MP3
description: If you can't get enough of MP3.com's free musical downloads, now maybe you can. A new MP3 player, Personal JukeBox, can carry 81 hours of high-quality digital music -- that equals about 1,200 songs, according to the manufacturer, HanGo Electronics.

title: People
description: * Kevin C. Clark was named chief executive at Screaming Media, New York, succeeding Jay Chiat, who will remain chairman. Mr. Clark had most recently been chairman and chief executive at Poppe Tyson, New York, now part of the Modem Media.Poppe Tyson unit of True North Communications.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing in the Arts & Leisure section on Sunday for a concert at 8 p.m. this Saturday by the Gregg Smith Singers misstated the location. It is St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street, not at St. Thomas Church.

title: Devils Lose Their Top Line As They Tie With Bruins
description: The Devils let a two-goal lead slip away tonight, but once again they found a way not to let a two-game losing streak take hold. They grabbed and clutched their way to a 2-2 tie with the Boston Bruins in a game that had little to excite the crowd of 14,219 until overtime.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a lawsuit filed against General Electric over PCB contamination of the Hudson River included an erroneous estimate from the State Attorney General, Eliot L. Spitzer, for the amount of the chemical dumped into the river over three decades. Mr. Spitzer, who filed the suit, said yesterday that the actual figure was 1.3 million pounds -- the amount acknowledged by G.E. -- and not a quantity exceeding 100 million pounds.

title: New Vice President Is From ABC Sports
description: The National Hockey League yesterday named Jon Litner of ABC Sports as executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Cabby Is Accused of Trying to Take 2 Women Passengers Captive
description: At a time when many cabdrivers are worried about being fined for not picking people up, one driver was arrested yesterday and charged with refusing to let his passengers go.

title: Bishops Vote for Stricter Ties With U.S. Catholic Colleges
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops voted overwhelmingly today to require theology professors at Catholic colleges and universities to obtain a certification from their bishop declaring that what they teach is ''authentic Catholic doctrine.''

title: Quick-Change Phones To Match Every Mood
description: FORGET utility, convenience and productivity. In the wireless world, style rules.

title: Beyond the Palm Pilot: New Brands and Features for P.D.A.'s
description: THANKS to personal digital assistants, ''Hey, beam me your number'' might become the most popular line in singles bars before too long. With the success of the Palm Pilot line, the era of the personal digital assistant has truly arrived. Features have increased, prices have decreased and the devices are becoming ubiquitous in certain circles. Think about how many of your friends have innocently purchased one and then become wholly engulfed by a new love and a cultlike zeal, caressing the device at frequent intervals and scouring the Web for hot new applications to download and lovingly install.

title: With Millennialism Breaking Out All Over, Some Contrarians Take a Centenary View
description: At the fin de this siecle, several exhibitions and a new movie take a look at British design at the fin de last siecle. Japonisme clearly influenced Reginald Blomfield's 1893 Arts and Crafts sideboard, lower left, recently offered by John Alexander Ltd., a Philadelphia dealer, for $48,500. The elegance of Japonisme endured in Lutyens's 1931 chair (left) from ''The Simple Life,'' a show of British Arts and Crafts at the Wolfsonian in Miami Beach through August; information, (305) 531-1001. Japonisme also influenced E. W. Godwin's 1869 Aesthetic settee (upper left): the latticework is Chinese, the spare linear order, Japanese.
To the Editor:

title: Jeopardized U.N. Status
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITISH UTILITY REORGANIZES
description: Laboring to increase profit and reverse falling stock prices, Britain's third-largest power generator, National Power P.L.C., will split into domestic and international units, shed plants worth about $1.7 billion and buy back up to 10 percent of its shares. The move came after months of deliberations at the company, which was created eight years ago in Britain's wave of privatization of state-run utilities.

title: U.C.L.A. IS OLDER, WISER AND ON THE WAY
description: Joe Drape chooses 16 teams with the weapons and the nerve to make a run at the Final Four, which will be held at the RCA Dome in Indianapolis.

title: For Parents and Stores, Anxiety Over Hot Toys
description: FOR parents who fruitlessly searched empty store aisles for last year's blockbuster electronic toy, Furby, or who braved lines that would have done the retail system of the Soviet Union proud to wait for a Tickle Me Elmo in 1996, take heart: the toy industry feels your pain.

title: Two Candidates Backed by Torricelli Gain New Judicial Posts
description: With two swift actions here on Tuesday the swearing in of a former United States attorney as the newest federal judge here and the designation of her first assistant as her replacement -- Senator Robert G. Torricelli would seemed to have won a decisive victory over his New Jersey colleague, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, with whom he has feuded over the years.

title: Making Manhattan An Island of Calm
description: ONE Sunday morning back in the 1980's, long before the art galleries invaded Chelsea, two architects were riding their bikes down the old West Side Highway. As the men, G. Phillip Smith and Douglas Thompson, turned off at 23rd Street, pedaling east, they noticed a vacant lot on the northwest corner of 10th Avenue. ''We came screeching to a halt when we saw the 'For Sale' sign,'' Mr. Smith said. ''It was love at first sight.''

title: Teacher Whose Field Trips Are an Art Is Honored
description: Donald S. Tedesco had been teaching for only about four years when he almost gave up on it. Frustrated by the conventional classroom, its stodgy textbooks and sit-at-your-desk formality, he had decided to resign, but an assistant superintendent in the Mamaroneck School District here challenged him to find a better way to teach -- and then gave him the freedom and the budget to try his ideas.

title: Digital Cameras Improve as Their Prices Fall
description: DIGITAL photography and digital video are two of the fastest-growing uses for today's personal computers. Analysts expect more than 3.5 million digital cameras to be sold this year in the United States, typically to PC owners who want to send photographs via an e-mail message, create family photo albums on personal Web pages or simply explore digital imaging as a hobby.

title: Harassment in Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: For an Eames, the Legacy Is Child's Play
description: AT 38, Eames Demetrios, grandson of the influential designers Charles and Ray Eames, recalls visits to his grandparents' house with a child's sense of adventure. Who wouldn't relish rummaging through the vast storehouse at 901 Washington Boulevard in Venice, Calif. -- the trolley factory turned studio -- with its countless totems and toys, musical contraptions, models and banks of drawers stuffed with objects from around the world?

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Spicing Austen's 1806 With Dashes of 1999
description: ''My God, this is 1806, for heaven's sake!'' a character exclaims in ''Mansfield Park,'' Patricia Rozema's smart, politically pointed screen adaptation of Jane Austen's third novel. This reminder of how every age foolishly fancies itself the most progressive and enlightened in the history of the world is drenched in irony. And it speaks to the heart of a film that is determined to invest Austen with as many prickly contemporary resonances as it can shoehorn in without appearing wildly anachronistic.

title: Huge March In Athens Protests Visit By Clinton
description: Giving a sample of the kind of resentment President Clinton can expect on Friday, more than 10,000 Greek protesters marched in front of the American Embassy today, many carrying banners branding Mr. Clinton a murderer.

title: Hewlett-Packard Results Beat Forecasts
description: After warning last month of an earnings shortfall, the Hewlett-Packard Company reported results today that beat analysts' revised estimates by 2 cents, not including charges related to the spinoff of its Agilent Technologies test and measurement business.

title: I.R.S. Workers Face More Investigations By Treasury Agents
description: Urged by Congress to get tough on abuse of taxpayers, a new team of Treasury agents plans a sharp increase in investigations of I.R.S. employees for misconduct -- anything from harassing taxpayers to theft. Indeed, the number of cases expected to be opened against I.R.S. employees will soon nearly equal the number of cases against Americans suspected of tax crimes.

title: NEWS WATCH
description: OUT OF DATE Participants in an Amazon.com online poll chose the Bible as the best book of the last 1,000 years. One problem: as Amazon pointed out, the Bible was not written in this millennium. So it was disqualified, and ''The Lord of the Rings'' (1954-56) took top honors.

title: ACCRUE TO ACQUIRE NEOVISTA FOR $140 MILLION
description: Accrue Software Inc., a maker of Internet analysis software, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held NeoVista Software Inc. for about $140.3 million in stock to move into electronic direct marketing. Accrue will pay 2.4 million shares of its common stock. The purchase will push Accrue, which is based in Fremont, Calif., into the fast-growing market for electronic direct marketing. Accrue's Insight software gathers information from data moving over the Internet and analyzes the activities of Web site visitors to see how effectively a site holds a customer's attention. Accrue's shares rose $2.3125 yesterday, to $58.4375.

title: Delaware And Hofstra Looking Up
description: America East

title: Mabel King, 66, Who Played The Wicked Witch in 'The Wiz'
description: Mabel King, an actress and singer best known for her portrayal of Evillene, the Wicked Witch of the West, in the Broadway and movie productions of ''The Wiz'' and her role as the mother in the mid-70's television comedy ''What's Happening!'' died on Nov. 9 at a hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif., where she lived. She was 66.

title: As New Doctors Enter a Brave New World
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ROSE FORSTADT
description: LEVINE-Rose Forstadt. Beloved wife of the late Jack Levine. Loving mother of Peter & Phyllis Honig, Richard & Susan Levine. Adoring grandmother of Caroline & Richard Seiden, Janice Honig, Eric & Julie Levine, Lisa & Tony Cammarota, Josh & Jeremey Davis. Beloved great-grandmother of Jack and Emily Seiden. Service Friday, 1 PM, at Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave, White Plains, NY.

title: A Lossless Fractal Algorithm? Some Other Time
description: TIMELINE

title: Lewis Looks for Big Money, Which Means Tyson
description: Forget David Tua, Michael Grant, Vladimir Klitschko, Henry Akinwande and John Ruiz. The one foe Lennox Lewis covets is Mike Tyson.

title: CONGRESS AGREES WITH WHITE HOUSE ON SPENDING CUTS
description: The White House and Republican leaders in Congress agreed on Wednesday to an across-the-board spending cut to the long-overdue federal budget, and then, after grappling all day over how to make that cut, shook hands on it this morning and made a deal.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: National News Briefs; Alcohol Found to Reduce Stroke Risk Significantly
description: As little as one glass of wine or beer per week can significantly reduce a man's risk of a stroke, the biggest study to examine the link says.

description: Interactive CD-ROM's have largely been ignored in the frenzy of the Internet land grab, left to collect dust on computer store shelves, but intriguing educational titles are still being released. The descriptions below are drawn from articles that appeared in Circuits this year.

title: Learning From Pokemon
description: Hi. My name is Lynn. I am the mother of a Pokemon addict.

title: Waste Industries Expands
description: Waste Industries, a trash company, said this week that it had acquired four companies for an undisclosed amount, in a move to expand its commercial and residential operations in the southeastern part of the United States. The company said it had purchased Southern Waste Services Inc., which operates in the coastal areas of Mississippi and Alabama; Quick-Way Salvage Inc. of Virginia; Jerry's Sanitation of North Carolina; and Matthews Sanitation Service, also of North Carolina. Waste Industries said the acquisitions gave it its sixth landfill and would add $7.4 million in annual sales.

title: Close Is Not Enough As the Nets Fall to 1-7
description: The Nets looked across the basketball court tonight and saw a vulnerable cast of underachievers not unlike themselves. A talented yet somewhat desperate club, the Detroit Pistons provided a grand opportunity for the Nets to instill life into their dying season.

title: Reporter's Notebook; In Turkey, Clinton Is, for the Moment, the Hero Adored
description: President Clinton's state visit to Turkey has featured plenty of official meetings, dinners and speeches. But it has not been all work and no play.

title: Caught Between Eras: China's Factory Workers
description: The middle-aged workers outside the aging Beijing No. 2 textile factory said today that they already knew their days of employment were numbered -- that they knew it even before China signed a landmark agreement this week to open its doors wider to global competition.

title: Metro Business; Company Will Buy 2 Lucent Divisions
description: Volt Information Sciences, a temporary-staffing company based in New York, said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase divisions of two Lucent Technologies subsidiaries.

title: The Same Old Old Faithful, With a Newfangled Twist
description: Until recently, the only way to see the country's most famous geyser, Old Faithful, in action was to trek to Yellowstone National Park in northwestern Wyoming and wait in long lines or freezing temperatures to see it spout steam high into the air.

title: I.R.A. Pledges To Help Disarm Ulster Fighters
description: The Irish Republican Army said today that it ''unequivocally'' backed the Northern Ireland peace agreement, and agreed to appoint a go-between to the panel charged with disarming the paramilitaries.

title: Each Voyage of Discovery Is One for the Books
description: Shortly into his new book, ''Passage to Juneau: A Sea and its Meanings,'' set around his solo voyage in a 35-foot ketch from Seattle to Alaska, Jonathan Raban makes an intriguing admission that grows increasingly apt as the disparate strands of this sweeping travelogue come together.

title: Exploring Worlds on CD-ROM's
description: Interactive CD-ROM's have largely been ignored in the frenzy of the Internet land grab, left to collect dust on computer store shelves, but intriguing educational titles are still being released. The descriptions below are drawn from articles that appeared in Circuits this year.

title: JAPANESE BUYOUT FUND
description: The buyout fund that is buying Japan's Long Term Credit Bank, Ripplewood Holdings L.L.C., has pulled together about $900 million for a fund to invest in Japanese manufacturing companies. It is the biggest war chest assembled so far for taking equity stakes in Japanese businesses. Investors in the fund, the RHJ Industrial Partners Fund, include Mitsubishi, Tokio Marine and Fire Insurance, Sumitomo Life Insurance, GE Capital Services, Merrill Lynch, Deutsche Bank and various affiliates of Citigroup.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAMCHECK, NORMAN
description: ZAMCHECK-Norman, M.D., age 82 of West Newton, MA died November 16, 1999. Esteemed physician and oncology researcher. Husband of Francesca, brother of Anne Spiegal and the late Irving Zamcheck. Father of Norman, Erika, Deborah and Mark. Grandfather of Ariela, Abbie, Samuel, Doria, Nicholas, Brian, Akiva and Kyle. Graveside service to be held Thursday, 11/18/99 at 1pm at the Newton Cemetery, Newton, MA. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Exploring Worlds on CD-ROM's
description: Interactive CD-ROM's have largely been ignored in the frenzy of the Internet land grab, left to collect dust on computer store shelves, but intriguing educational titles are still being released. The descriptions below are drawn from articles that appeared in Circuits this year.

title: LONE STAR TECHNOLOGIES TO BUY FINTUBE ASSETS
description: Lone Star Technologies, a Dallas-based holding company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the assets of Fintube L.P. for about $86 million. Fintube, based in Tulsa, Okla., makes finned tubes used in heat-recovery systems. Lone Star said it would pay cash and issue up to $20 million in common stock, as well as assume some of Fintube's debt. Lone Star, which has about 22.6 million shares outstanding, posted revenue of $303.9 million in the last 12 months. The Lone Star Steel Company unit of Lone Star Technologies makes oil field casing and tubing prod-

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO RISES. The euro climbed after the European Central Bank's chief economist said inflation might speed up, indicating the bank might raise interest rates. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0413, up from $1.0328.

title: BROWSER
description: An eclectic selection of Web events and sites.

title: It's Beginning to Look a Lot Like Panic
description: THIS was how my holiday shopping began this year: As we were driving home the other day, my 8-year-old middle daughter leaned forward into our car's front seat airspace, brushed her bangs from her eyes for the 10th time that hour and said: ''Dad, you're Jewish, and so are Zoe and Clementine and me. We celebrate Hanukkah. So why do we get presents on Christmas, too?''

title: Arabic Speakers Dispute Inquiry's Interpretation of Pilot's Words
description: ''I put my trust in God,'' the voice repeated on the recorder that was recently recovered from the underwater wreckage of EgyptAir's fatal Flight 990. The enigmatic prayer uttered in Arabic, ''Tawakilt ala Allah,'' has prompted some investigators to suspect that a crew member may have intentionally caused the Boeing 767 jetliner to crash into the Atlantic Ocean near Nantucket on Oct. 31.

title: New TV Software Allows Instant Language Translations
description: Just when the French have started rioting against the encroachment of American culture, new technology has arrived to enable the latest episode of ''Dawson's Creek'' to be broadcast with French subtitles in France -- at the same time it appears in the United States in English.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEMING, SISTER ELIZABETH MARIA
description: FLEMING-Sister Elizabeth Maria. Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity, in her 76th year of religious life on November 17th, 1999. Survived by her nieces & nephew. Reposing at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark Street, Yonkers, New York, on Thursday 18PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Friday 9:30AM at the convent, with interment following at St. Joseph's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, New York 10471.

title: Connecticut to Sue Coal-Fired Power Plants in Five States
description: Following similar moves by New York and federal officials, Connecticut's attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, said yesterday that he intends to sue 16 coal-burning power plants in five states to force them to reduce pollution believed to cause smog and acid rain in the Northeast.

title: Officer Says Squeegee Man Tried to Grab Gun in Fight
description: A police officer who shot a squeegee man in the Bronx last year testified yesterday that he fired his gun once after being attacked by the man, who he said was hovering over him.

title: So Easy to Buy, Such a Struggle to Return
description: WHILE hauling merchandise back to the store after the holidays is an inconvenience, digging up receipts, finding addresses and boxing up items to ship back to an Internet retailer thousands of miles away can be an off-the-charts hassle, so much so that many shoppers simply do not return items they bought online.

title: Crew Postpones Saying Whether He Will Stay as Chancellor
description: In an abrupt change of plans, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that he would not publicly announce in the coming weeks whether he wants to extend his contract and stay in New York City. Instead, Dr. Crew said, he will wait to make a joint announcement with the Board of Education sometime before New Year's Day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLAYMORE, SARAH R.
description: CLAYMORE-Sarah R. Died on November 14, 1999 at the age of 98. Daughter of the late Rose & Samuel Clayman. Beloved sister of Marjorie Cole and Jessie Rinsky and the late Anna Levine, Dr. Sigmund, Dr. Lawrence and Abraham Clayman. Devoted sister-in-law of Daniel Cole and Rita Clayman and the late Rosalind Clayman and Edna Clayman. She will be deeply missed. Services are at Riverside Funeral Home, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon on Thursday, November 18, 1999 at 1:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory can be made to the Spanish Portuguese Synagogue in New York or to a charity of your choice.

title: Essay; Pre-Selling a Speech
description: ''If the Russian government attacks innocent women and children in Chechnya,'' George W. Bush will say in his foreign policy speech tomorrow, ''it cannot expect international aid. Period.''

title: Game Shows, Greedy and Otherwise
description: ''If I won a lot of money,'' said the contestant on ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire,'' a forthright housewife with double chins, ''I'd like to lie in a bath of melted chocolate.''

title: Consumer Groups Seek Ethics Inquiry on Rubin's New Job
description: A coalition of consumer and community groups has called for a government ethics investigation into former Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin's decision to accept employment from Citigroup, the financial services conglomerate, contending the move presents an ''undeniable appearance of impropriety.''

title: As Northern Ireland Waits
description: The promises coming out of Northern Ireland this week stirred hope, once again, that 30 years of internecine warfare between Roman Catholics and Protestants could yield to what one negotiator calls simply ''a decent, democratic society.'' As the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, put it, the ordinary Northern Irish are ready to give this peace process ''a go.'' The Catholic and Protestant party leaders have also found a modest stretch of common ground where the Good Friday peace accords of 1998 could finally move into reality.

title: U.S. Thinks Iraq Is Rebuilding Ruined Military Installations
description: The Pentagon's senior intelligence officer said today that Iraq had begun to rebuild military installations the United States and Britain destroyed last December and that he could not rule out the possibility that President Saddam Hussein had resumed building chemical or biological weapons.

title: U.N. Hits Snag in Renewing 'Oil for Food' Program for Iraq
description: What the United States hoped would be a quick and painless renewal of the program under which Iraq sells limited amounts of oil to pay for goods to relieve civilian hardships turned today into complicated negotiations when Russia proposed changes favorable to Iraq.

title: State Police Modify Application Process
description: Under terms established in ongoing negotiations to increase the number of minority troopers, the state police have altered their screening process to de-emphasize test scores and make requirements more flexible, officials said.

title: Indonesia's Grocery Revolution; Urban Rich Lure Foreign Retailers and Spur a Recovery
description: In October last year, deep in the midst of Indonesia's financial breakdown, the French food retailer Carrefour set up one of its sprawling hypermarkets on the edge of Jakarta. If opening a fancy modern grocery in a shrinking third-world economy seemed risky then, it seemed foolhardy a month later, when rioting mobs came to the new Carrefour and looted it.

title: Niche Sites Offer Chance to Create or Personalize Gifts
description: ONLINE shopping may be a good way to avoid the shopping-mall parking lot, but it does not guarantee that you will avoid the homogeneity of the shopping-mall experience. In fact, the likelihood that you will give or receive The Gap's latest V-neck sweater style (boiled lamb's wool with a ribbed trim at the cuffs) is sure to increase this year, as online shoppers from even the most remote places click on trusted brands.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: National News Briefs; Michigan U. to Name School for Gerald Ford
description: The University of Michigan plans to rename its school of public policy after an alumnus who had the chance to become a professional football player but instead went on to become president: Gerald R. Ford.

title: Jungle, N.J., vs. Main Street, N.Y.; In Battle for Shoppers, Malls Emphasize Sense of Place
description: If F.T.D. and the Tupi Indians of Brazil joined forces to build a massive shopping center in the bleak, industrial strip between Newark Airport and the hulking marine docks here, it might look something like the Jersey Gardens Outlet Mall.

title: Stewart Award To Be Given Yearly
description: The PGA Tour will honor Payne Stewart by presenting an award in his memory at The Tour Championship, beginning next year.

title: ZIFF-DAVIS TO SELL UNIT TO WASSERSTEIN FOR $172 MILLION
description: Ziff-Davis Inc., the publisher of computer magazines, agreed yesterday to sell its ZD Education unit, a provider of Internet training, to the investment bank Wasserstein Perella Group Inc. for $172 million in cash. Ziff-Davis, which publishes PC Week, has been shedding businesses to improve its stock price. Wasserstein plans to use ZD Education to offer more online services to corporate customers that want to use the Internet to sell products. Ziff-Davis, which is majority owned by the Softbank Corporation of Japan, said it was not selling SmartPlanet.com, a World Wide Web site that offers courses on how to set up Internet sites.

title: Need for Computer Experts Is Making Recruiters Frantic
description: The managers at Vivid Studios, a Web site consulting firm here, are accustomed to calls from employment recruiters trying to poach their technical staff. But the day a suitor telephoned looking for Nevil was a new low.

title: Exploring Worlds on CD-ROM's
description: Interactive CD-ROM's have largely been ignored in the frenzy of the Internet land grab, left to collect dust on computer store shelves, but intriguing educational titles are still being released. The descriptions below are drawn from articles that appeared in Circuits this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARBANEL, HILDA
description: BARBANEL-Hilda. The Partners and Staff of Rosenberg & Estis are deeply saddened by the passing of Hilda Barbanel, beloved mother of Karen Barbanel and beloved mother-in-law of founding partner Warren A. Estis. Her loss will be felt by many, but she will live in the hearts of her loved ones forever. The firm wishes her family comfort during this time of loss.

title: Why Teachers Migrate
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; For Smith, The Struggle Continues
description: IAN RAFFERTY was doing just fine until Tuesday. He was living the anonymous life of a free-agent rookie lineman trying to make it in the N.F.L. Rafferty, an offensive tackle from North Carolina State, was waived in September by the Tennessee Titans and then signed to the Titans' practice squad.

title: Exploring Worlds on CD-ROM's
description: Interactive CD-ROM's have largely been ignored in the frenzy of the Internet land grab, left to collect dust on computer store shelves, but intriguing educational titles are still being released. The descriptions below are drawn from articles that appeared in Circuits this year.

title: What to Ask the Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: Club and Cone Play Waiting Game
description: The Yankees are engaged in something of a stare-down contest with David Cone, the free-agent pitcher. Both sides are waiting to see what develops, and although neither club officials nor Cone have been outspoken in outlining intentions, their reasons for waiting are apparent: the Yankees, who have engaged in steady but mostly nonconsequential talks with the pitcher, are staying in the bidding for Cone but would likely prefer to give him less than the two-year contract Cone is seeking. They are waiting to see if other teams, such as the Mets, might offer a multiyear deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARD, GLENN W.
description: HOWARD-Glenn W., of Glen Cove, LI. On November 3rd, 1999, age 93. Beloved husband of the late Thelma E. Loving father of Glenn W., Jr., Gordon E. and Katherine E. Proud grandfather of Holly, Emily and Philip, great-grandfather of Emma. Visiting DodgeThomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove, Saturday, 3-5 and 7-9. Service at First Presbyterian Church of Glen Cove, Sunday, 2 PM.

title: Investigating the Crash of EgyptAir 990
description: The cause of the crash of EgyptAir Flight 990 remains a mystery. Information from voice and flight data recorders raised suspicions that a relief pilot, Gamil al-Batouti, deliberately sent the Boeing 767 plunging into the ocean. But Egypt's government has strongly protested the view that Mr. Batouti's recorded words suggest a prayer before a suicidal act rather than a response to a problem in the cockpit. Given differing cultural interpretations of his words and the fact that much of the wreckage has not been recovered, it is too early to draw conclusions.

title: Round Pea, Meet Square Dish
description: It's hip to be square -- if you're a plate. The square plate (or ''block'') like the one at right by Laurie Gates ($18) is the traditional staging area for sushi. For store locations: (800) 680-4973. Pascale Girardin, a potter and gardener from Quebec, gives her oblong plates, top, texture with leaves, pine needles and burlap. Her plates, being used to stage architectural towers of food at Nobu, are available ($35 each) at Felissimo, 10 West 56th Street; (212) 247-5656.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: ASIA

title: Newark Tries New Runway To Decrease Flight Delays
description: In a bid to shed its ranking as the nation's leader in flight delays, Newark International Airport began using a newly lengthened runway today that will eliminate the time-consuming need to alternate arrivals and departures of some planes on a single runway.

title: The Big City; A 1911 Fire As Good TV, Bad History
description: IF you watched Ric Burns's version of New York history last night on PBS, you heard horrible stories about sweatshops and saw awful pictures of garment workers burned at the Triangle shirtwaist factory in 1911. Then, as the music turned from somber to triumphant, you saw politicians and union leaders respond with ''epoch making'' reforms that protected workers across America.

title: Time Warner To End Gifts Of 'Soft Money'
description: Time Warner announced today that it would no longer make unregulated donations to political parties, saying such ''soft money'' contributions distort the electoral process and sully the givers.

title: Glaxo Reports a 6% Increase in Sales
description: Glaxo Wellcome said today that its sales rose 6 percent in the first 10 months of this year, pushed by gains in new drugs including Seretide for asthma and migraine drugs including Imitrex.

title: Exploring Worlds on CD-ROM's
description: Interactive CD-ROM's have largely been ignored in the frenzy of the Internet land grab, left to collect dust on computer store shelves, but intriguing educational titles are still being released. The descriptions below are drawn from articles that appeared in Circuits this year.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We wind up six months after we hire an engineer having to fight off offers for that same engineer for more money. It's become a very predatory environment.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, MARY
description: WOLFF-Mary. Beloved wife of the late Murray. Cherished mother of William. Loving aunt to Maris Bluestein, Barry and Ken Werner. Dear great aunt to many. Services to be held privately.

title: McDonald's Shifts Payouts To One a Year
description: McDonald's, a company that grew rich by selling 15-cent hamburgers, is tired of sending small change to its shareholders.

title: Techie Sneakers That Measure A Child's Personal Best
description: Starting next month, there may be a new sound at recess: electronic beeps emanating from a new line of children's sneakers by Reebok.

title: Japanese Reliever Is Impressive in Workout at Shea
description: Katzuhiro Sasaki, the Japanese reliever and former most valuable player in Japan, arrived at Shea Stadium for his workout yesterday with the Mets and was surprised by the size of the outfield and the stadium. Then, because of the cold weather, Sasaki played catch and threw 13 pitches off the mound in the batting cage -- his catcher was Bobby Valentine's nephew Anthony -- to show the Mets that his right elbow, from which he had bone chips removed Aug. 9, is on its way back to health.

title: Tools That Level the Field and Ease the Ride
description: FOR the business traveler or the home-based worker, there is a wide range of useful gadgets this holiday season that can help level the competitive playing field or at least provide some fun.

title: Williams and Davenport Need Three Sets to Gain
description: All systems appeared to be go for a scintillating Chase Championships debut by Venus Williams. Her college homework was up to date, there was no threat of another sibling uprising by her younger sister, Serena, the injured and absent United States Open champion, and Venus's perforated blue tennis dress harmonized with Madison Square Garden's interior as if they had been professionally dyed to match.

title: Works on Asia Win Top Book Awards
description: Ha Jin, a veteran of the People's Liberation Army of China, has won the National Book award for fiction for his novel ''Waiting.'' Written in English and set in contemporary China, it tells the story of a man struggling with the conflicting claims of two women, one of them representing the traditional Chinese way of life and the other the new society.

title: Scandals and Standard-Bearers
description: If you go to a conservative political dinner these days you will almost certainly hear a retelling of the Tale of Triumph. Some venerable leader on the right will stand up and recount the history of the conservative ascendancy: how the movement started as a tiny, heroic band in the 1950's, cohered during the Goldwater campaign, went on to elect Reagan, defeat Communism and win the war of ideas. The story line has a lot of truth to it, but it sounds a bit odd coming at a moment when American conservatism is so flamboyantly cracking up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENDALL, ANNE MARIE
description: KENDALL-Anne Marie Kilsheimer. The Partners and staff of Kaplan, Kilsheimer & Fox, LLP join in extending our deepest sympathy and condolences to the family of Anne Marie Kilsheimer Kendall, the daughter and sister of our Partners James B. Kilsheimer III and Richard J. Kilsheimer.

title: Privacy Was a Double Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNE, D. STUART
description: BROWNE-D. Stuart, age 52, of Mayfield, East Sussex, UK, on November 11, 1999, at home. Loving husband of Kathryn Pogson, father of Daisy and April and son of Tom & Phyl. Playwright, professor of dramatic writing and author of ''Dangerous Parking.'' Funeral service at 2 PM Friday, November 19, 1999 at St. Dunstan's, Mayfield, UK. He was greatly loved and will be missed dearly, but his stories will be remembered.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOHL, DAVID L.
description: WOHL-David L. 1994-1999. ''You saw the best there was in me because you loved me.'' Unconditional love is not for this world, and so sweet boy you took it with you and it diminished the quality of my life. Love, Mommy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERNON, JOHN T.
description: VERNON-John T. Of Wilton, Connecticut. On November 15, 1999. Survived by wife Joyce Zuccaro Vernon, sons, Stephen, Michael & David, daughter Carolyn, brothers William & Peter. Memorial service on Saturday, November 20, 1999, 11 A.M., at St. Matthews Episcopal Church, New Canaan Road, Wilton, Conn. Memorial contributions to the John T. Vernon Memorial Scholarship Fund, 26 Scarlet Oak Drive, Wilton, Conn. 06897.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, PAUL P.
description: HECHT-Paul P., of Riverdale, NY, on November 16, 1999. Beloved husband of Sarah. Loving father of Delia, Amy and Liza. Devoted grandfather of John, Matthew and Elizabeth. A memorial service will be held at the Ethical Culture Society of Riverdale on Monday, November 22, 1999, at 12 Noon. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society or the ASPCA.

title: Senator Hagel's Deceptive Bill
description: In the welter of unfinished business left behind by Congress this year, campaign finance legislation again stands out. Nevertheless, progress has been achieved. The House passed a reform measure in the summer, and 55 senators backed some form of ''soft money'' ban promoted by Senators John McCain and Russell Feingold. Less noticed but also significant, five more Republican senators now say some controls on soft money are needed. Congress can build on these gains next year.

title: Cheap Digital Cameras Abandon the Ordinary
description: HERE is the holiday camera buying guide made simple: Buy the Holga 120S.

title: Sports Photos On Exhibit
description: The photograph is as recognizable as its subjects: Muhummad Ali (then Cassius Clay) in white boxing trunks standing over a prostrate Sonny Liston ordering the heavyweight champion to get up and fight.

title: Treasury Prices Fall Again on Renewed Inflation Fears
description: Treasury prices fell for the second consecutive session yesterday after the Labor Department reported that the rise in consumer prices in October met expectations. And for market participants, it left the door open for another increase in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve should inflation accelerate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALINO, JOHN
description: MALINO-John. We have lost a truly great friend and mentor and the world has lost an extraordinary human being. We already miss John's wisdom, friendship and humanity. The Mallah and Major Families

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIMER, J. SQUIER
description: REIMER-J. Squier. Of Katonah, New York. Died at his home on November 17, 1999. He was 67 years old and was born October 21, 1932 in New York, N.Y. to Otto and Ursula Squier Reimer. He attended and graduated from The Choate Rosemary Hall School and Princeton University. Mr. Reimer served in the United States Army obtaining the rank of 1st Lieutenant. He was the former Managing Director of First Boston Corp in New York, N.Y. & Vice Chairman of the Visiting Nurse Service of Hudson Valley and the Director of the Katonah Community Center. He is survived by his wife of 42 years, Donna Webster Reimer. Father of Donna Reimer Hoes and Eric Squier Reimer. Brother of Ursula Reimer Van Anda. Grandfather of Amanda and Alexander Hoes and Sayre, Peter and James Reimer. Memorial service Saturday, November 20, 11AM at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, Bedford, N.Y. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Visiting Nurse Association of Hudson Valley, 100 South Bedford Rd., Mount Kisco, New York 10549, or The Katonah Community Center.

title: In America; Cuomo's Quest
description: It was thought to be dangerous terrain, and the advice of some high-powered political advisers was blunt. Don't go there.

title: Thalidomide Found to Slow a Bone Cancer
description: In a serendipitous discovery that grew out of the pleas of a Manhattan lawyer whose young husband was dying of cancer, scientists will report on Thursday that thalidomide, the sedative that maimed thousands of babies in the 1960's, can slow the course of a deadly bone cancer. Some experts say it may become the most effective new drug for the disease in decades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARYO, ISAAC ANDRE
description: KARYO-Isaac Andre, age 92. Beloved husband of Louise for 65 years, loving father of Catherine and Stephen Shiff, of Jericho, NY. Armand & Rita Karyo, of Roslyn, NY, Richard and Arlene Karyo, of Boca Raton, FL, Michele and Lois Karyo, of Boca Raton, Fl. Adoring grandfather of Jeffrey, Natalie, Amy, Wendy, Iris, Lisa, Marc and Max. Proud great-grandfather of Rickki, Jake, Ryan, Danny, Jack and Benjamin. Caring uncle to Maurice, Alain, Reine, Bernard, Daniel, David and Lillian. Auschwitz, Dachau Holocaust survivor who always loved his family, God and Country. Shalom. Memorial services Friday 12:30 PM, at Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: OIL PROFITS
description: Higher oil and gasoline prices contributed to sharply higher third-quarter earnings at Petroleo Brasileiro S.A., Brazil's largest company, better known as Petrobras. Earnings more than tripled to 359 million reais, or $186 million, in the three-month period. Production in the quarter rose 12 percent.

title: Police Officials Ask Panel Not to Cite Officers for Lying
description: The Police Department has asked the independent panel that investigates civilian complaints of police abuse to abandon its practice of citing officers for lying, saying the department should handle such matters internally.

title: As New Doctors Enter a Brave New World
description: To the Editor:

title: House Museums Get Pushy
description: WHEN two Gustav Stickley cabinets go up for sale at Christie's on Nov. 29, as part of Barbra Streisand's Arts and Crafts collection, representatives of the Craftsman Farms, the Stickley home that the cabinets were designed for, will be there bidding.

title: BB&T TO BUY HARDWICK HOLDING FOR $138.7 MILLION
description: The BB&T Corporation, which has bank branches throughout the southeastern United States, agreed yesterday to buy the Hardwick Holding Company for $138.7 million in stock in its fourth purchase of a Georgia bank this year. Hardwick, based in Dalton, Ga., operates nine bank branches in northwest Georgia. It has assets of $518.3 million. BB&T, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., has $41.6 billion in assets and 619 branches in seven states and Washington. BB&T shares fell $1.125, to $35.5625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

description: Interactive CD-ROM's have largely been ignored in the frenzy of the Internet land grab, left to collect dust on computer store shelves, but intriguing educational titles are still being released. The descriptions below are drawn from articles that appeared in Circuits this year.

title: Work-for-Shelter Enforcement to Begin Dec. 1
description: The Giuliani administration will begin enforcing work requirements and other welfare rules on Dec. 1 as a condition of shelter for homeless families. But the first few families who fail to meet the conditions are not likely to be expelled from shelters until January, an official with the city's Department of Homeless Services told shelter operators at a meeting on Tuesday.

title: Top Executives Leaving 3 Agencies
description: Three agencies said yesterday that top executives would retire.

title: KIMBERLY-CLARK AGREES TO BUY SAFESKIN
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation, the world's biggest maker of tissue products, agreed yesterday to buy the Safeskin Corporation for about $850 million to add sales of disposable medical gloves to its expanding health care products business. Kimberly-Clark, which makes Kleenex tissues and Huggies diapers, will pay $13.31 a share in stock. The purchase includes $155 million for the assumption of debt and payment of stock options. Kimberly-Clark said the acquisition would increase sales from its health care business to $950 million next year from about $700 million this year. The announcement was made after Kimberly-Clark's shares rose $1 each, to $68.0625, while San Diego-based

title: BP Amoco and BellSouth shuffle their agency rosters to tidy up their branding accounts.
description: TWO big advertisers in two big competitive categories -- energy and telecommunications -- are making changes on their accounts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPATZ, LEO
description: SPATZ-Leo. Passed away peacefully on November 14. Beloved brother of Theodore Spatz and Dorothy Waldman, and the late Bella Kahane. He is also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. He will be missed by all whose lives he touched with his gentle soul.

title: Ruminating About Love, Perfect and Not So
description: Modesty doesn't commonly afflict million-selling rock stars. Yet Sting showed signs of it when he started his sold-out four-night stand at the Beacon Theater on Tuesday night. He bantered about his age (48), his jacket (of an unidentified shiny fabric) and the lingering sentiment that, as he joked, ''He was better with the Police.''

title: A Very Present Palette
description: A graphic designer can catch a wave, too. One such surfer of pop sensibilities is Douglas Martin, 45, a Santa Monica, Calif., art director who grew up in Flushing, Queens. His stylish colors and hard-edged graphics echo 1960's fashions and childhood streetscapes. Mr. Martin recently designed the graphics used in the movie ''American Beauty,'' posters for the Issey Miyake retrospective at the Ace Gallery (above left) and a line of calendars sold at the Museum of Modern Art (above right). The calendars are $12 (desktop) and $20 (wall size) at the museum and by e-mail from doug@loop.com.

title: Can't Beat 'Em, So Knicks Use the Losing Formula
description: Since 1992, the Knicks have resolved to leave with a victory. Innumerable players and lineups and three head coaches have failed.

title: Smucker May Shed Assets
description: The J. M. Smucker

title: KnightRidder.com Selects an Agency
description: KnightRidder.com, the new Internet business unit of Knight Ridder in San Jose, Calif., has awarded the first account for Real Cities, a network of regional Web sites, to the Salt Lake City and San Francisco offices of Euro RSCG/DSW, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: M.L.S. Is Making Changes
description: After decades of attempts by various professional leagues to Americanize the world's most popular sport, Major League Soccer announced yesterday that starting next season it would revert to virtually all the rules used throughout the world. The league also took other steps to try to attract American soccer fans, including the introduction of regular Saturday and Monday telecasts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSTEIN, DOROTHY
description: ROTHSTEIN-Dorothy. On November 16, 1999. Beloved wife of Richard H. Rothstein. Fondly remembered by her niece and nephew, Nancy and Dennis PelzPaget and her good friend Elaine Seiden and loving godchildren Leslie and Bill A. Seiden. Service Sunday, November 21, 11AM, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: A World of Finds From a Hindu Mystic
description: Walter Spalding Robbins II, known as Tucker, is a soft-spoken Hindu mystic. But he is also a furniture dealer with a foot firmly planted in the material world. His crammed warehouse has been a favorite source for style-makers like Donna Karan, Alan Wanzenburg, Juan Montoya, Clodagh and Tommy Hilfiger.

title: Classical Music in Review; An Athletic Rhythm, A Stranger to Routine
description: Deutsche Kammerphilharmonie

title: It's Point, Counterpoint In Big East Conference
description: One pops into his coach's office, and heads straight to a candy jar that Mike Jarvis keeps on a bureau. Empty. Erick Barkley has to settle for some chocolate-chip cookies.

description: To the Editor:
