description: Interactive CD-ROM's have largely been ignored in the frenzy of the Internet land grab, left to collect dust on computer store shelves, but intriguing educational titles are still being released. The descriptions below are drawn from articles that appeared in Circuits this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHBERG, MAX
description: HOCHBERG-Max. Died Nov. 11, 1999. He founded the Hochberg Bros. Painting Co. in 1929 and the JM Charles Painting Co. In 1967, and remained an active partner until his retirement at age 90. He was predeceased by his beloved wife Ida and daughters Alice and Beverly. He is survived by his daughter Janice Siegel and her husband Gerald in Irvington, New York, as well as 10 grandchildren, 19 great grandchildren and two great-great grandchildren. He was affectionately known to all who knew him for his indomitable spirit and devotion to family. He was lovingly cared for by Marion Benjamin throughout his long illness. Services will be held at 11 A.M., November 18, 1999 at Temple Beth Abraham, 25 Leroy Avenue, Tarrytown, NY. Donations may be made to Temple Beth Abraham or Hospice Care in Westchester and Putnam.

title: The Hammer That Reached All the Way to Honduras
description: John Cienki, a 29-year-old carpenter from Queens, has built expensive Manhattan kitchens and trendy bars like Idlewild on East Houston Street. But last summer his life took a different direction: he went to Guanaja, an island off Honduras, to build houses (below) for people left homeless by floods from Hurricane Mitch. Now, with the help of members of the Village Church (a congregation affiliated with Redeemer Presbyterian Church in Manhattan), Mr. Cienki has organized Southern Exposure, which he describes as ''Doctors Without Borders, but for professional carpenters.'' Volunteers will serve a year on relief projects like the one in Honduras, where they will build housing and hospitals, and ''live in tents, on beans and rice,'' Mr. Cienki said. A pass-the-hat send-off party is planned for Sunday (7 p.m. to midnight) at Torch, a supper club Mr. Cienki also helped build, 137 Ludlow Street, at Rivington Street. To contribute or volunteer: (917) 586-4121.

title: The Real You, Now on View
description: LIFE just gets curiouser and curiouser.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, EDITH
description: LEWIS-Edith. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Loving mother of Judith and Harvey Frank. Loving grandmother of David. Also survived by two great grandchildren. Services 12 noon Friday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91St and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Philip Morris Gifts to Albany Legislators Put Focus on Ethics
description: One night in March 1997, a group of New York legislators dined at a French restaurant in Albany called Nicole's Bistro, and when the bill for $1,818.20 arrived, none of them had to reach for it. The meal came courtesy of Philip Morris's chief lobbyist in New York, who has long been a popular and generous dining companion around the state capital.

title: No Choice in Chechnya
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about intentional air crashes in history misstated the name of the line involved and the number of deaths in a 1994 crash of a commuter plane. The line was Royal Air Maroc, not Air Morocco, and the deaths numbered 44, not 51. The article also misidentified the crew member responsible for a 1982 crash in Tokyo Bay. He was the pilot, not the co-pilot.

title: Pope Will Plunge Into a Bramble Bush (the Mideast) in March
description: Seeking to fulfill Pope John Paul II's longstanding desire to visit biblical sites during a Holy Year, the Vatican announced today that he will visit the Middle East next March.

title: GARDEN Q.&A.
description: Memories of a Favorite Rose

title: Inflation Still Tame but Resurging Commodity Costs Bear Watching
description: The Consumer Price Index went up just enough in October to sustain concern about rising inflation without showing much evidence of a rise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PODESTA, FREDERICK J.
description: PODESTA-Frederick J. On November 15, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Lillian (nee Daly). Fred Podesta has been associated with Madison Square Garden for more than 25 years in executive capacities as Vice President, Publicity, Advertising & Promotion Director. He was also General Manager of the New York Knickerbockers and on the Board of Governors of the National Basketball Association. Reposing at Walter B. Cooke-Kennedy Funeral Home, 117 West 72 Street, NYC, Wednesday 7-9 PM, Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass, Blessed Sacrament R.C. Church, Friday 10 AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the John V. Mara Cancer Center at St. Vincent's Hospital.

title: Florida's Messy Executions Put the Electric Chair on Trial
description: In Florida, say opponents of the death penalty, there is something worse than death. There is death in the state's electric chair.

title: Hillary Clinton's Trip
description: To the Editor:

title: Scientists Link a Single Gene to Longer Life in Mice
description: In a finding that may yield a sharp insight into the genetic reasons for death, a team of Italian scientists today reported discovery of a gene that exerts major control over the life span of mice. The effects of the corresponding gene in humans is unknown, but experts in aging called the findings a milestone that could someday lead to drugs that postpone the effects of aging.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Plans to Crack Down On I.R.S. Agent Misdeeds

title: Don't Worry? Yeah, Right
description: This week's No. 1 pop album, ''Breathe,'' by the country singer Faith Hill, extols the virtues of true love, faith in God, the smile of a stranger and the eyes of a child. Though there may be little that is recognizably country on this album of slick pop-rock ballads with a CD booklet that looks like a Victoria's Secret catalog, it does have one thing in common with the earliest commercial country successes more than 70 years ago: It is the sound of pop's rear guard marching, waving the flag of traditional values in a society complaining about their disappearance.

title: Crafts Show And Sale Of Judaica
description: CRAFTS as up to date as a titanium dreidel are the focus of ''To Life and Light: A Celebration of Judaica,'' a four-day show and sale at the American Craft Museum, 40 West 53rd Street. ''We are not showing any reproductions,'' said June Sgobbo, vice president for retailing at the museum.

title: Playboy Threatens Suit Over Playdog.com
description: Playboy says it can take a joke, but not trademark infringement, so lawyers for the magazine have threatened to sue the Milltown, N.J., man who started a Web site called Playdog.com that features pictures of dogs wearing nothing but their fur.

title: Delivering the Goods: No Simple Solution
description: E-COMMERCE is like comedy. Coming up with ideas is easy; delivery is hard.

title: German Court Overturns Pornography Ruling Against Compuserve
description: Overturning a verdict that has horrified the Internet industry in Germany for the last two years, a Bavarian court ruled today that the former top executive of Compuserve's German subsidiary is not guilty of distributing pornography.

title: Defying a Bidding Bugbear Makes the Opponents Pay
description: A few thousand enthusiasts converging on Boston today will be able to watch the final of the OKbridge world team championship between a United States team and a Russian team at the Vugraph Theater. They are the survivors of 172 teams from 33 countries that began competing seven months ago, playing throughout on individual computers.

title: Study Finds Knowledge Gap on Vouchers and Charter Schools
description: A new study suggests that a majority of Americans have little or no understanding of what a publicly financed school voucher is, or what distinguishes a charter school from other public schools -- even in Milwaukee, Cleveland and Arizona, which were among the earliest places to experiment with such options.

title: INTERNET STOCK SOARS
description: In a display of the ravenous appetite for Internet stocks, Terra Networks S. A., a unit of the Spanish telecommunications company Telefonica S.A., roared to a closing value of 10.4 billion euros ($10.7 billion) in its Madrid stock market opening, making Terra the highest-valued Internet stock in Europe. The stock closed at 37 euros ($40.32), up from 13 euros ($13.44).

title: Defaulters Are Arrested In Pakistan
description: The military government, making good on threats to jail people who have defaulted on millions of dollars in bank loans, began arresting some of the nation's wealthiest citizens today, including senior executives, politicians and a retired air marshal.

title: In Bots We Trust?
description: THE agents are ready for service. The question is, whom will they serve?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLER, PHOEBE
description: DILLER-Phoebe. Beloved mother of Marsha and Bob Kushin. Devoted sister of Jocelyn and Ralph Schuman, Bill and Doris Collins. Services 12 Noon today at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOKOLSKY, EVELYNE R.
description: SOKOLSKY-Evelyne R., 81, of Tamarac, FL. Passed away November 16, 1999. She is survived by her beloved husband Irving, her loving daughter Bette Sokolsky, dear son in-law Melvin (Regina) Minsky and her cherished grandaughter Jenifer Minsky-Frankel. Funeral services Thursday, November 18 at 1PM at Levitt-Weinstein Memorial Chapel, Tamarac FL with interment at Menorah Gardens.

title: Bush Depicted as Safe on Foreign Policy
description: This 30-second commercial, ''Dangerous World,'' was unveiled this week by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas in South Carolina, home to military bases and many veterans.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Sore Thumbs

title: Hewlett-Packard Plans Campaign
description: Hewlett-Packard is spending $200 million over the next year on advertising to increase awareness of what the company considers its record of innovation and invention.

title: Political Briefing; Special Vote Offers Few Clues for 2000
description: The Democratic victory in Tuesday's special election in California's 42nd Congressional District appears to hold few significant clues about what to expect in House races in Election 2000. But it is nevertheless a sweet victory for Democrats since it means that the district, centered on San Bernardino, just east of Los Angeles, remains under Democratic control and the Republican margin of control in the House stays at just five seats.

title: S.& P. UPGRADES HYUNDAI MOTOR
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation, the international credit rating agency, has raised the long-term corporate credit rating of Hyundai Motor from B to B+ and revised the outlook on the firm's rating to ''positive'' from ''stable.'' The agency attributed the upgrade to Hyundai's recovery in sales and finance, a faster-than-expected normalization of its affiliate Kia Motors and an improved financial structure through rights offerings. The B+ rating, however, remains a ''speculative grade.''

title: For Jets' Offensive Line, A Whirl of Inexperience
description: Just when the Jets are getting better, some things are getting worse.

title: Girl Scouts Settle Bias Claim of Girl With H.I.V.
description: The Girl Scouts settled a human rights complaint this week that accused them of excluding a 9-year-old girl from at least five troops in upstate New York because she was infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. The Scouts admitted no wrongdoing but agreed not to bar girls like her in the future.

title: When Rain Does Not Fall in Spain, the Farmers March to Protest
description: Spanish farmers often stage noisy demonstrations to demand state subsidies, but 4,000 growers who marched in Madrid last week behind a nervous brown camel and six men dressed as bedouins sought something more basic: water.

title: BT Alex. Brown Agrees to Pay $15.3 Million in Bond Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that BT Alex. Brown Inc. had agreed to pay $15.3 million to settle allegations that the brokerage firm defrauded the federal government and the state of Pennsylvania in municipal bond transactions in the early 1990's.

title: Calendars Made for Sharing, For the Online and Handheld Set
description: The Internet calendar craze has moved to handheld devices. WeSync.com not only lets you create an online calendar but lets you share it with family and friends by synching it to a Palm Pilot or any other device running the Palm Operating System. Companies have been using shared online calendars for several years, but the concept is just now moving to consumers.

title: Cocktails Can Wait; Lectures Offer Mental Refreshments
description: Recently when my husband posed the question ''How many evening lectures are you attending this week?,'' I realized that my life had undergone a subtle transition in the last few years. Like many New Yorkers I consider the brief interlude between office hours and dinner or evening entertainment to be a kind of free-for-all time. Since I rarely lunch out, preferring instead to cling to my yogurt carton, I would usually invite friends between 5:30 and 7:30 p.m. for a late tea or drinks and a leisurely visit. (In Paris this interval, called ''cinq-a-sept,'' is institutionalized as the hour of assignations, but that is another story.)

title: Corrections
description: A music review in Weekend last Friday about the Guild of Composers concert at Merkin Concert Hall in Manhattan misstated the surname of the cellist who performed Seymour Shifrin's Cello Sonata. She is Tahira Whittington, not Washington.

title: Caspian Lands Back a Pipeline Pushed by West
description: Four nations in the Caspian Sea region took a giant step today toward embracing one of President Clinton's cherished foreign policy projects, a pipeline that would assure Western control over the potentially vast oil and natural gas reserves.

title: Bishops' Vote May Have Modest Effect On Colleges
description: Leaders of the nation's Roman Catholic colleges said yesterday that there would probably be little practical effect on their campuses as a result of the new guidelines adopted by the National Conference of Catholic Bishops that seek to strengthen college ties to the church. But some officials and church experts said the policy could undermine those institutions in subtle ways.

title: Hunt Widens For Suspect In Attack With Brick
description: Detectives searching for the man who struck a 27-year-old Midtown Manhattan office worker with a brick took to the subways and knocked on doors on the East Side yesterday in an intensive effort to find anyone who could identify the assailant.

title: JAPAN CHALLENGES STEEL RESTRAINTS
description: Invoking the World Trade Organization's dispute settlement process, Japan has asked for consultations with the United States to settle the question of whether Japanese steel imports are unfairly excluded from the American market. In response to increased Japanese hot-rolled steel exports last year, the American steel industry complained that Japan was selling the products below cost or at a loss, in violation of anti-dumping laws. The United States imposed tariffs on the imports, an action that Japan says violates trade-organization rules. The two sides must begin talks within 30 days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVISON, BEATRICE M.
description: LEVISON-Beatrice M.., wife of the late Stanley D. Levison, will be remembered with the deepest love and affection by her son, Andrew, her daughter-in-law, Judith, and her two grandchildren, Tony and David, in whose lives she was a warm and loving presence. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Northside Center for Child Development, Inc., 1301 Fifth Ave., NY NY 10029, where she worked for many years.

title: Guns in the Hands of the Young
description: To the Editor:

title: Focusing on the Music, Not on Those Playing It
description: The bluegrass singer and fiddler Alison Krauss, and her band, Union Station, have sold millions of records and still aren't cool. None of the band members project much of an onstage persona other than affability; they're not the sort of glib technical wizards who appeal to string-instrument gear-heads, and they don't show discomfort with the conventions of bluegrass by playing it like giddy scholars or specter-haunted old-timers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELD, PHILIP
description: FELD-Philip., of Bay Harbor Islands, Fla., formerly of Bronx, New York, passed away Thursday, Nov. 18, 1999. He is the beloved husband of Pearl Feld. Loving father of Barbara Feld Socor, Judith Feld, and Leslie Feld. Dear brother of Bernard (Beverley) Feld. Graveside services 10:30 A.M. today at Lakeside Memorial Park, Miami, Florida by Blasberg Rubin Zilbert Memorial Chapels 305-865-2353

title: An Injured Testaverde Is Mentor For Lucas
description: Bill Parcells and Vinny Testaverde are two of the more superstitious people in the world of professional football. If they think something brings good luck, there's no way they'll discard it.

title: Submarines, Balloons and a Guy Named Bond
description: ''The World Is Not Enough'' was directed by Michael Apted, whose insightful glimpses of the maturing process can be seen in his latest documentary, ''42 Up.'' Doggone if Mr. Apted hasn't been able to make James Bond grow up a little too. In his third and most comfortable effort to model the Bond mantle, Pierce Brosnan bears noticeably more resemblance to a real human being. He shows signs of emotion, cuts back on the lame puns and makes lifelike conversation with fellow characters. Should he ever stop posing mannequinlike with left hand in trouser pocket, or engage in a clinch without appearing to be promoting his wristwatch, Mr. Brosnan's Bond will have entered the land of the living.

title: THE DRIVE TO PHILADELPHIA
description: THE LAST TEAM STANDING

title: ANTIQUES
description: Following The Trail Of Folk Art

title: Diallo's Parents Agree On Control of Estate
description: The parents of Amadou Diallo resolved their differences over the administration of his estate yesterday, reaching an agreement that officially ends the involvement of Johnnie L. Cochran Jr. and his high-profile associates in a possible civil suit against the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASADESUS, GABY
description: CASADESUS-Gaby. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sadness the passing of its beloved friend and devoted Steinway Artist Gaby Casadesus, on November 12, 1999 in Paris at the age of 98. A native of Marseille, Mme. Casadesus was first taught by her mother and continued her studies at the Paris Conservatory under Marguerite Long and Louis Diemer. After a brilliant solo career in which she championed the music of such composers as Faure, Moszkowski, and Ravel, she married the renowned pianist and composer Robert Casadesus in 1921. Their collaboration resulted in one of the most celebrated piano duos in history. An acclaimed teacher, Mme. Casadesus' master classes at the Ravel Academy in St-Jean-de-Luz, the Mozarteum in Salzburg, and the Fontainebleau School were legendary. She was a co-founder of the Robert Casadesus International Piano Competition in 1975. Mme. Casadesus' discography, including a recent reissue of live performances from 1942 to 1948 by Dante Productions, will keep her legacy alive for future generations. To her daughter Therese, son Guy, and her entire family we extend our heartfelt condolences. She was an inspiration to us all, and her loss is deeply felt. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P., Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a study that found thalidomide effective in treating a rare bone cancer misstated the affiliation of Dr. Bart Barlogie, the oncologist who led the study. He is at the University of Arkansas, not Arizona.

title: GUCCI BUYS SHOES
description: Continuing its shopping spree among luxury goods companies, Gucci Group acquired a 70 percent share in a Italian manufacturer of expensive women's shoes and leather goods, Calzaturificio Sergio Rossi S.p.A., for $96 million. The move cames only days after Gucci paid $1 billion for Sanofi Beaute, which controls Yves Saint Laurent and a collection of famous perfume brands. Sergio Rossi will continue as chief designer at the company, which expects to report pretax profit this year of $8 million on $60 million of sales, while a senior Gucci manager, Massimo Braglia, will become chief executive.

title: Facing a Wartime Memory That Rivals the Holocaust
description: Even in a great movie like ''The Best Years of Our Lives'' (1946), World War II didn't look like such a traumatizing experience. True, Dana Andrews's character couldn't get his old job at the drugstore back, and he learned that his superficial wife loved him only when he was looking handsome in uniform. But Fredric March just went back to his cushy job at the bank and into the bosom of his beautiful family. And even Harold Russell, who had lost his hands in the war, was all right once he realized that his understanding girl-next-door fiancee loved him enough to deal with that.

title: Medical Privacy, Abused
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WHITNEY HOLDING CORP., New Orleans, has made its first move into Texas by agreeing to buy the Bank of Houston for $58 million.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: A Picture of Cool at the Sotheby's Rostrum
description: IN France it is called ''esprit d'escalier,'' or staircase wit, the moment on the way out of the party when you think of that brilliant remark you should have dropped into the conversation like a silk handkerchief.

title: Fasten Your Seatbelt, Eve, And You Too, Blanche
description: ''All About My Mother'' was shown on the opening night of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 24. The film, in Spanish with English subtitles, opens today in Manhattan.

title: Radio City Musicians Reach Contract Accord
description: Audiences will not have to cross a picket line to see the Christmas Spectacular at Radio City Music Hall this year. Members of the theater's orchestra settled their dispute with the theater yesterday, averting a threatened strike that could have disrupted the hall's most popular annual event.

title: John G. Malino, 60; Executive at Loews
description: John G. Malino, an executive with the Loews Corporation in New York who oversaw all its real estate activities, died Sunday at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 60.

title: An Inquiry Finds Roe Impersonating Caviar
description: Imagine paying $75 for a one-ounce tin of Russian beluga caviar, fresh from the belly of a giant sturgeon caught in the Caspian Sea. If someone substituted roe from the prosaic American paddlefish, a habitue of the Mississippi River whose eggs go for around $10 an ounce, you would know the difference, right?

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-21

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: A Window Into a Past Of Singing and Dancing
description: It was once said that Elizabethan English lived on only in the distant valleys of Virginia and Tennessee or along the once isolated barrier islands of the Carolinas. Rural electrification and television have probably changed all that, but the principle of isolation as a kind of amber still has strength when applied to the monastic, now-dwindling sect known as the Shakers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOLAN, WILLIAM J. JR
description: NOLAN-William J. Jr. Of Irvington-on-Hudson, New York and Avon, Connecticut, died on November 17. The cause of death was prostate cancer. Mr. Nolan was born in Cambridge, Massachusetts in 1919. He was a graduate of Milton Academy (1937), Yale University (1941) and Yale Law School (1943). He spent his career as a tax lawyer and retired in 1981 as Vice President and Director of Taxes of Amax, Inc. He had leadership roles in several organizations, including the American Mining Congress and the International Chamber of Commerce. In the 1960's, Mr. Nolan was a member of the team that won the New York State Curling Championship. Mr. Nolan leaves his devoted wife of 55 years, Alice Edwards Nolan, 4 children and 2 children-in-law, William J. Nolan, III and his wife Wendy of New York City, Sally Wells Nolan of West Hartford, Connecticut, Beth Nolan of Washington DC and Lucy Pritchard Nolan and her husband Douglas Eichar of West Hartford, and 5 grandchildren, William J. Nolan IV, Anina Nolan, Nick Eichar, Andy Eichar and Chris Eichar. A memorial service will be held at the Immaculate Conception Church in Irvington at 11am on Monday, November 22. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Irvington Volunteer Ambulance Corps, P.O. Box 101, Irvington, NY 10533,or Phelps Memorial Hospital, 701 N. Broadway, Sleepy Hollow, New York 10591.

title: Jan Schoonhoven, Sherrie Levine/Joost van Oss
description: Paula Cooper Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNELLY, JOSEPHINE C.
description: CONNELLY-Josephine C.. (Nee O'Neill). 88, gracefully passed away Wednesday, November 17, 1999 at her home in Bryn Mawr, PA. Mrs. Connelly, a noted philanthropist, was the co-founder and Chairperson of the Connelly Foundation, W. Conshohocken, PA. Beloved wife of the late John F. Connelly, former Chairman and President of Crown Cork & Seal, Co., Philadelphia, PA. Loving mother of Josephine C. Mandeville, Villanova, PA, Emily C. Riley, Villanova, PA, John F. Connelly, Jr., Philadelphia, PA, Thomas S. Connelly, Gladwyne, PA, Christine C. Connelly, Columbus, NJ and the late Judith C. Delouvrier, New York City, NY. Also survived by 15 grandchildren, 5 great-grandchildren, her dear sister, Martha O'N. Wheeler, Jenkintown, PA, 4 sisters-in-law, numerous cousins, nieces and nephews. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Tuesday, November 23, 1999, at 10:00 am Cathedral Basilica of Sts. Peter and Paul, Philadelphia, PA. Her family will receive friends and relatives on Monday, November 22nd from 3 to 8 pm at the Cathedral. Interment Calvary Cemetery, W. Conshohocken, PA. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to the Josephine C. Connelly Scholarship Program, Rosemont College, 1400 Montgomery Ave., Rosemont, PA 19010. The Donohue Funeral Home, Wayne, PA (610) 989-9600

title: School Board's Approval of $300,000 for a Film Angers East Orange
description: Residents here expressed concern and some anger today over revelations that the school board in this financially strapped city approved spending $300,000 to help finance a film conceived by the district's superintendent as an educational tool.

title: Mental Refreshments
description: The enthusiastic turnouts for lecture series in New York have reached such a pitch that an hour of landscape design (or whatever) may be supplanting the cocktail hour as the way to pass that precious interlude between office and dinner. A good lecture can equal the pleasure of travel, when, under similar limits of time, one concentrates and thus learns the maximum.

title: Metro Business; New Zoning to Allow 2 Towers Is Rejected
description: The City Council Land Use Committee yesterday rejected a zoning change that had been requested by developers who had hoped to build two 13-story residential buildings on East 76th Street between York Avenue and the East River on the Upper East Side.

title: The Kinship of Macabre and Banal
description: THE TALENTED MR. RIPLEY; RIPLEY UNDER GROUND; RIPLEY'S GAME

title: U.S. Is Reconsidering Money for Russia
description: The Clinton administration is quietly reassessing whether to slow two major loan programs to Moscow as the war in Chechnya accelerates and the two leading candidates for the Republican presidential nomination call for a cutoff of aid to Russia.

title: Plan to Import New Viruses Draws Concern
description: Stressing safety and trying to debunk a cloak-and-dagger image they said was undeserved, officials of the Plum Island Animal Disease Center turned to the public Wednesday night to seek support for an expansion that would allow top-security research on viruses that are deadly to animals and humans.

title: IMASCO DRUGSTORE BUSINESS SOLD
description: An investor group led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company of New York agreed to buy Shoppers Drug Mart, Canada's largest drug retailer, for $1.7 billion from Imasco Ltd. of Montreal. The 820-store chain has been on the block since early August, when British American Tobacco P.L.C. of London made a bid for the 58 percent of Imasco it did not already own. B.A.T. wants to consolidate Imasco's tobacco subsidiary within its global tobacco business and has been selling nontobacco holdings. Timothy Pritchard

title: No Easy Labeling
description: When it comes to some prominent economic and social issues, the nation's Roman Catholic bishops can make all but the most liberal Democrats look pale.

title: Violent Acts, Clouded Judgment
description: The recent violent attacks against New Yorkers seemed as random as they were terrifying, occurring during the most mundane slices of the day -- a sleepy subway commute, a routine errand on a busy Midtown street. But in the public view, they also shared another trait -- the attackers appeared to be mentally unstable.

title: FINAL BUDGET BILL IS PASSED BY HOUSE IN BIPARTISAN VOTE
description: United by a desire to proclaim victory and leave town, Republicans and Democrats in the House joined tonight to pass the final budget bill, seven weeks after the fiscal year began.

title: There's This Newspaper Man, See, Charlie Kane . . .
description: If a film is trying to latch onto someone else's glory, it helps to jump in at the right end of the career. ''RKO 281'' depicts Orson Welles's making of ''Citizen Kane'' and William Randolph Hearst's efforts to thwart the release of the film, whose megalomaniacal newspaper tycoon was so clearly modeled on him. But while ''RKO 281'' portrays Welles in his first and most complete flash of genius, it has the glamour and artistry of those stiff, self-important commercials for cheap wine he made near the end of his life. Like so many other disappointing HBO biographical movies, including ''Dorothy Dandridge'' and ''The Rat Pack,'' this one takes a juicy idea, lines up a seductive cast, then hands them a banal script that lets everyone down.

title: City Violated Officers' Right To Free Speech, Judges Rule
description: A federal Court of Appeals panel in Manhattan said yesterday that the New York Police Department violated the First Amendment rights of the Latino Officers Association's members when it refused to allow them to march in parades wearing their uniforms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERSON, CARL
description: MERSON-Carl. November 8, 1999, three weeks before his 89th birthday. He lived a long and full life. Until his retirement, he had been a proprietor of B.A.M. Liquors in Mt. Vernon, a former liquor salesman, and a member of the Liquor Sales Union. In addition to his intellect and sincerity, he loved life and considered himself the luckiest man alive. He knew how to enjoy people, family, golf and a good piece of rye bread. He would marvel at his family and his legacies, for which he took no credit but was a major influence. He is survived by his two daughters and sons-in-law, Miriam and Larry Shapiro, Ann and Ardie Bialek; seven grandchildren and spouses, Debbie and Alan Plumer, Laura and Jacky Mizrahi, Andrew Shapiro, Michele and Todd Neufeld, David and Amy Bialek, Leah and Rachel Merson; five great-grandchildren, Trevor, Adam and Ross Plumer, Jessica Mizrahi, and Bradley Neufeld. He was predeceased by his cherished wife of sixty years, Billie, and their son, Robert. Everyone loved him. The pain of his departure is tempered by our memories of him and the knowledge that he is now at peace with his beloved wife and son.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARBANEL, HILDA H.
description: BARBANEL-Hilda H.. The Hebrew Academy of Nassau County extends its heartfelt condolences to Mr. Sidney Barbanel and the entire Barbanel family, on the passing of Hilda H. Barbanel, beloved wife, loving mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, sister, aunt and friend. Hilda Barbanel was an Aishet Chayal whose unconditional love and devotion touched the lives of all who knew her. She will live on in their memories. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Moshe Gottesman, Dean Harvey S. Liebman, President Isaac Blachor, Chairman of the Board Miriam Lieber, Administrator

title: Venus Williams Leaps Over Net and Foe
description: Call it youthful exuberance, gamesmanship, or a dollop of showboating custom made for Madison Square Garden and its partisan crowd: Venus Williams, turbo-charged at finding herself three points from her first Chase Championships semifinal, indulged a whim and leapfrogged over the net last night as she and her cowed opponent, Barbara Schett, switched sides for the first and last time in their lopsided second-set tie breaker.

title: Finding a Camera and a New Career
description: Photographic history is chock-full of people who were painters before they became photographers, but very few were in women's wear to begin with. Erwin Blumenfeld (1897-1969), a name to conjure with in fashion photography, worked in the garment trade, later owned a leather goods shop and was also an artist before he became a photographer. The camera must have come as something of a relief, for Blumenfeld had a ripe talent for photography, a minor one for painting and none whatsoever for handbags.

title: Clinton Friend Raises Money for Gore
description: Terry McAuliffe, the prodigious Democratic money man and close friend of President Clinton, was host for a $200,000 fund-raising dinner tonight at his home in McLean, Va., in honor of Tony Coelho, Vice President Al Gore's campaign chief.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE PLUMMETS. Coffee fell more than 10 percent as forecasts for rain in Brazil improved prospects for the world's biggest crop. In New York, coffee for March delivery fell 13.25 cents, or 10.2 percent, to $1.167 a pound.

title: Album of the Week
description: WILL SMITH: ''Willennium'' (Columbia). Will Smith describes himself as hip-hop's ''Mr. Clean'' and challenges other rappers to write just ''one verse without a curse.'' He's sold millions of albums doing just that; in his spare time, he's a sitcom star and a bankable action-movie hero. He has plenty to boast about, and he does, but what saves him from sounding sanctimonious or overbearing is an all-conquering affability.

title: First Lawsuit Filed In EgyptAir Crash
description: The wife and three children of a Paterson man, Ghassan Koujan, killed in the crash of EgyptAir Flight 990 have sued the airline and Boeing for $25 million each.

title: Rangers Stage a Ferocious Rally, but It's Not Enough
description: The story of the Rangers' season has been too little, too late.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, TERESA
description: HUGHES-Teresa., November 17, 1999. Beloved daughter of the late George and Catherine. Loving sister of the late George. Reposing at John J. Fox & Sons, Inc., 203 E. 201st St, Bronx, Friday, 2-5 & 79pm. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Nicholas of Tolentine Church, Saturday, 9:30am. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESEROWITZ, NATHANIEL E.
description: LESEROWITZ-Nathaniel E.. Age 47, suddenly on November 11, 1999. Survived by his stepfather and mother, Irving and Gertrude Leserowitz Wolfe, wife Dr. Freya Schnabel, daughters Yonah, Talya, brother Fred, in-laws, nieces and nephews, friend, counselor and teacher. Donations may be sent to Institute Knesset Shraga, 12 Ezrat Torah, Jerusalem, Israel

title: Isles Hoping They'll Click On the Road
description: The Islanders (4-9-2) are taking their 29 goals and going on the road. Maybe there they can get their offensive act together.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: MARSH & MCLENNAN COS., New York, named Jeffrey W. Greenberg chief executive, succeeding A.J.C. Smith, who will remain chairman. Mr. Greenberg will continue as president.

title: Key Rates
description: Percent

title: When the Body Is an Art Gallery
description: BODY ART: MARKS OF IDENTITY,'' which opens tomorrow at the American Museum of Natural History, is a transparent effort on the part of a family-style institution to heat up its image and pull in a fresh audience, one that probably couldn't care less about large, extinct reptiles with tiny brains.

title: Using the Baroque Laments To Blend Voice and Violin
description: Anne Sofie von Otter and the period-style group Musica Antiqua Koln, appearing at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday, gave their program of Baroque songs, cantatas and instrumental pieces under the title ''Lamenti,'' which might have suggested a small expressive range. But no. Composers and poets of the Baroque found it possible to lament a great many things: not enough love (Vivaldi's ''Cessate, omai, cessate'') or too much (Monteverdi's ''Con che soavita''; a death (Antonio Bertali's ''Lamento della Regina d'Inghilterra'') or imminent suicide (Dido's farewell from Purcell's ''Dido and Aeneas'').

title: Alcon Labs Awards Assignment
description: Alcon Laboratories, owned by Nestle, said yesterday that it had named FCB New York, part of the FCB Worldwide unit of True North Communications, to handle its direct-to-consumer and media planning accounts for Patanol, an eyedrop product. Billings were estimated at more than $17 million.

title: Japanese Sect's Appeal
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Seeks Trading Accounts of Murdered Stock Promoter
description: Investigators are examining whether there is a link between the deaths of two stock promoters found shot in a New Jersey home last month and an account one of the men may have had at a small Manhattan stock trading firm that recently closed its doors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIMER, J. SQUIER
description: REIMER-J. Squier. Of Katonah, New York. Died at his home on November 17, 1999. He was 67 years old and was born October 21, 1932 in New York, N.Y. to Otto and Ursula Squier Reimer. He attended and graduated from The Choate Rosemary Hall School and Princeton University. Mr. Reimer served in the United States Army obtaining the rank of 1st Lieutenant. He was a former Managing Director of First Boston Corp in New York, N.Y. & Vice Chairman of the Visiting Nurse Service of Hudson Valley and a Director of the Katonah Community Center. He is survived by his wife of 42 years, Donna Webster Reimer. Father of Donna Reimer Hoes and Eric Squier Reimer. Brother of Ursula Reimer Van Anda. Grandfather of Amanda and Alexander Hoes and Sayre, Peter and James Reimer. Memorial service Saturday, November 20, 11AM at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, Bedford, N.Y. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Visiting Nurse Association of Hudson Valley, 100 South Bedford Rd., Mount Kisco, New York 10549, or The Katonah Community Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHABER, DAVID
description: SHABER-David. We mourn the loss of an esteemed screenwriter, playwright, teacher, and lifetime member of Writers Guild of America East. The Credits Review Committee Writers Guild of America East

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO SLIDES. The dollar rose after a German report on business confidence discouraged investors who hoped to see stronger signs of growth. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0292, down from $1.0413.

title: Autobiographical Medley, From Beatles to Broadway
description: Could the Beatles' ''Here, There and Everywhere'' have been written by Jerome Kern, or Stevie Wonder's ''All in Love Is Fair'' by Harold Arlen? In her remarkable new cabaret act, Andrea Marcovicci offers such comparisons. She has performed much of the pre-rock American songbook at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel. Now she has returned with ''Marcovicci Sings Our Songs: 1965-1985,'' through Dec. 24, infusing the songs of her own generation with the same breathless fervor she has brought to the romantic ballads of Kern, Arlen, and Rodgers.

Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street, Friday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial Saturday, November 20, 10AM at St. Joseph's Church, East 87th Street, NYC. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery.

title: A $60 Million Step Forward In Rebuilding Penn Station
description: In one of the final steps toward financing the $750 million renovation of the Farley Post Office building into a new Pennsylvania Station, the United States House of Representatives approved $60 million in federal aid for the project yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINS, JAY K.
description: ROBINS-Jay K.., M.D. Died on November 13th, 1999 at age 75. Survived by dear brother Alvin L. Robins, M.D., a sister-in-law, and three loving nieces. Noted Manhattan psychiatrist. A memorial service will be held November 22, 11:30AM at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St and Amsterdam.

description: BAIN-George H.. Gone one saddened year. Always in our hearts, forever in our memories. Gladys and Family

title: LaNoue Davenport, 77, Expert In Early Music and Instruments
description: LaNoue Davenport, a pioneering figure in the revival of early music and period instruments and a former leader of the acclaimed ensemble New York Pro Musica and the American Recorder Society, died on Nov. 4 at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y. He was 77 and had been suffering from emphysema.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAFFA, LOUIS
description: YAFFA-Louis. Beloved husband of Beatrice. Loving father of Earle and Beth, Ellie and the late Michael. Cherished grandfather of Nancy, Kimberly, Charles, Jessica and Josh. Great-grandfather of Katie, Max and Gabe. Service Sunday 12 noon at Congregation B'nai Yisrael, Bedford Rd, Armonk, NY.

title: Bill Expands Health Benefits for Disabled People Who Work
description: Congress and the Clinton administration said today that they had agreed on a bill expanding Medicaid and Medicare so that people with disabilities could return to work without losing their health insurance benefits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, PAUL P.
description: HECHT-Paul P.., of Riverdale, NY, on November 16, 1999. Beloved husband of Sarah. Loving father of Delia, Amy and Liza. Devoted grandfather of John, Matthew and Elizabeth. A memorial service will be held at the Ethical Culture Society of Riverdale on Monday, November 22, 1999, at 12 Noon. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society or the ASPCA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBSTER, FRANCES BROWN
description: WEBSTER-Frances Brown. On Nov. 11 at Kendal at Hanover in Hanover, NH, of a pulmonary embolism. Beloved wife of the late Beveridge Webster, pianist and teacher at the Julliard School of Music, who died June 30, 1999. Survived by their daughter Wendy Webster Ardizzone and son Michael Webster, her sister Charlotte Wheeler, five nieces and nephews, and six grandchildren. Mrs. Webster was a cellist, pianist, violist and singer and taught piano for many years. She was principal cellist of the Westchester Symphony and participated in chamber music programs at Bennington College, VT and Mohonk, NY. Born on Jan. 24, 1915 in Riverhead, NY, Mrs. Webster received degrees from Oberlin College and the Oberlin Conservatory of Music and her Master's from Radcliffe. Her family will miss her loving and caring heart and her wonderful smile and sense of humor. They wish to express their deepest gratitude to the medical staff and caregivers at Kendal who have given Franny such loving care since her stroke on Nov. 30, 1997. A memorial service will be held at Kendal on Sunday, Dec. 12 at 3:00pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Joy of Music Program, 112 Morningside Rd., Worcester, MA 01602, a non-profit community music school founded and directed by the Websters' daughter.

title: Mall TV Network Under Development
description: The Turner Broadcasting System unit of Time Warner and the Simon Property Group, the largest United States shopping mall owner, said this week that they planned to develop a television network aimed at shoppers in Simon's malls.

title: EVERCORE PARTNERS MAKES OFFER FOR RUSS BERRIE STAKE
description: Russ Berrie & Company said yesterday that it had received a $270 million offer from Evercore Partners to buy the 48 percent of the company not owned by its chairman and chief executive, Russ Berrie. The company, which sells gifts and is based in Oakland, N.J., said it had hired Lehman Brothers and Debevoise & Plimpton to advise a special board committee on whether to act on the $27-a-share proposal. Under the proposal, Mr. Berrie would continue as chairman and chief executive of the company and would remain its largest stakeholder. The company's shares rose 15 percent yesterday, gaining $5.0625 each, to $25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Walk, Don't Run, but Do It Just as Quickly as Possible
description: This year, as the summer waned, I got my old fall feeling. It's a poignant mood, born out of my free-ranging Kentucky childhood, that comes back from time to time. My emotions react somehow when the sun is still warm but the air grows cool, the grass turns a vaguely different kind of green and the afternoon light takes on a harvesty golden glow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REGINA, JOCELYN
description: REGINA-Jocelyn. On November 17, 1999. Loving mother of Nancy Goodfellow (Jay), Marjorie Kass (Thomas) and Joanne Korman. Adoring grandmother of Sally Goodfellow, Rachel and Hannah Kass. She will be missed by her loving family and friends. Service Friday 2pm at the ''Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam. NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORD, J. COUPER
description: LORD-J. Couper., 81. Of Southampton, N.Y. On November 17, 1999. Husband of Barbara Hartley, father of J. Couper Lord, Jr, MaryLouise Lord Gillespie, Barbara Lord Edwards and the late Ruth Lord. Grandfather of Hartley and Eleanor Gillespie, Lorrie, Caroline and Courtney Edwards. Funeral service 11AM November 27 St. John's Church, Southampton. In lieu of flowers contributions to St. Andrew's Dune Church, Box 1245 or St. John's Church, Box 5068, Southampton, N.Y. 11969 would be appreciated.

title: They're Back In Circulation
description: To watch the video title shuffle, try updating a mail order catalog. ''What's interesting this year is how many movies that have been gone for years are now coming back,'' said Irv Slifkin, an editor of the 2000 catalog from Movies Unlimited, a company in Philadelphia that, along with Facets International of Chicago, is one of the most versatile mail order operations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, THOMAS F.
description: GALLAGHER-Thomas F.., 87. A retired advertising executive with Joseph E. Seagram and Sons died on November 16, 1999 at his home in New Canaan, CT. He leaves his beloved wife of 57 years, Mary Ann O'Shea and children, Paul, Joan, and Peter; and six grandchildren. A Mass will be held at 11AM, Saturday, November 20, 1999 at St. Thomas More R.C. Church, 374 Middlesex Rd., Darien, CT. Visiting hours will be 4-8pm, Friday November 19th at the Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main St., New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to The Thomas F. Gallagher, Sr. Scholarship Fund, University of Notre Dame, 1100 Grace Hall, Notre Dame, IN 46556 Attn: Carol Hennion.

title: Horst P. Horst, Photographer Of Fashionable, Dies at 93
description: Horst P. Horst, a master of light and deep shadow whose photographs of fashion and fashionable creatures like Coco Chanel, Marlene Dietrich and Noel Coward evoked the glamorous 1930's as well as his own chic circle in Paris, died yesterday at his home in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. He was 93.

description: Republican leaders in the State Senate called today for expanding a state program that subsidizes prescription drug purchases for elderly New Yorkers, proposing to more than double the number of people eligible for the coverage.

description: When Miguel Perez Carreno Hospital first opened its doors here 30 years ago, it was proudly described as the largest and most modern medical center in all of Latin America, the showcase project of a government flush with oil money and soon to become even richer.

description: KAPLAN-Lori. Hillel: The Foundation for Jewish Campus Life, mourns the passing of Lori Kaplan, beloved daughter of our dear friends, Tobee and Leonard Kaplan, a member of Hillel's International Board of Governors, and cherished sister of Lyn, Scott, and Randall, also a member of the International Board of Governors. May the Kaplan family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Edgar M. Bronfman, Chairman, International Board of Governors Chuck Newman, Chairman, Board of Directors Richard M. Joel, President & International Director

title: TOYOTA OPERATING EARNINGS FALL
description: The world's third-largest automaker, the Toyota Motor Corporation, said its first-half earnings rose 4.7 percent as accounting changes and a lower tax rate overcame the impact of a strong yen, which hurt auto profits. Toyota's net income rose to 201.66 billion yen ($1.91 billion) in the six months that ended on Sept. 30 from 193 billion yen a year earlier. Pretax profit from operations fell 1 percent, to 404.54 billion yen, however, because of a 12 percent rise in the yen.

title: U.S. Suspects Government Of Croatia In Break-Ins
description: The government of Croatia, an occasional American ally in peace efforts in the Balkans, is behind a campaign of harassment against American diplomats and others promoting democracy in Croatia, according to senior administration officials. Among the actions were break-ins last month at the homes of a diplomat and an American government contractor, they added.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a vote by the nation's Roman Catholic bishops to require theology professors at Catholic universities to teach ''authentic Catholic doctrine'' misstated the tally. It was 223 to 31, not 233.

title: House Approves Bill Helping Satellite TV
description: The House passed a hard-fought measure that would give satellite television companies the right to broadcast local channels. The legislation was part of the huge spending package now before the Senate.

title: Deal to Revamp Organ Allocation Is at Risk
description: A bitter fight over whether, and how, to restructure the nation's system for distributing donated human organs has erupted in Congress, and a deal struck last week that would have cleared the way for the Clinton administration's long-planned overhaul was on the verge of falling apart today.

title: Minimum Wages, City by City; As More Local Laws Pass, More Businesses Complain
description: What bothers Henry A. Berber most about the new ''living wage'' ordinance in Los Angeles is the picketing at his restaurant, La Luz del Dia, during a busy lunch hour. ''The way they are dressed,'' he said, ''they give the impression they are my regular customers, very dissatisfied. It hurts me personally.''

title: Decoding a Radiation-Resistant Bug
description: It thrives in deserts, medical autoclaves and food irradiation chambers. It can withstand more radiation than the Incredible Hulk. The Energy Department has used it to help clean up perpetually boiling vats of radioactive wastes. Its place of origin is a mystery, but some scientists wonder how it acquired all the hardy properties required of a space traveler.

title: Correction
description: An editorial yesterday erroneously listed Senator George Voinovich of Ohio as a co-sponsor of Senator Chuck Hagel's bill to impose limits on soft-money campaign donations, and left Slade Gorton of Washington off the list of sponsors.

title: A Sex Guide for Girls, Minus Homilies
description: It is a Darwinian law of nature that adults believe everything was better when they were young: music, books, movies, clothes, bagels and, of course, young people.

description: A State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn has been censured for sexually harassing his secretary over a 12-year period, the New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct announced yesterday.

title: Reggae Beat Keeps St. Lawrence Winning
description: They developed their swagger in Brooklyn and their ball-handling skills on the island of Jamaica and other points south. Traveling a well-worn trail, they have now transferred their talents and aspirations to New York and points north.

description: Andre Carmichael always suspected he had a twin.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We're not sure what might be holding up what, and the crew has to be meticulous at what they're doing. This is far worse than in a building collapse in that the structure twisted as it collapsed and all of the pieces are tangled together.''

title: Yanks Make Offer to Rhodes
description: The Yankees want left-hander Arthur Rhodes, but Rhodes must now decide whether he wants to leave the Baltimore Orioles. As recently as late yesterday afternoon, the Yankees had offered the left-handed reliever a four-year contract, while the Orioles had shown a willingness to give Rhodes only three years.

title: Satellite TV Compromise Passes House
description: After bowing to an objection by Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, the House passed a hard-fought measure today that would give satellite television companies the right to broadcast local channels, providing cable companies with competition.

title: New Digital Cameras Poised To Jolt World of Filmmaking
description: A digital video camera was perched like a bazooka on the shoulder of the director Mike Figgis as he carved a path through the oblivious pedestrians on Sunset Strip, following the actor Stellan Skarsgard into a swanky glass-faced office. At the same moment, not far away, three other digital cameras were following other actors as they made their way down the sidewalk, chatted on cell phones or bickered at curbside, the real world swirling all around them.

title: Editor Joining Times
description: William Norwich has joined The New York Times Magazine as editor of a new supplement, ''Style and Entertaining,'' which will make its debut Nov. 5, 2000. He will also edit Entertaining features for the weekly magazine beginning Feb. 13. Mr. Norwich, who has contributed to Fashions of The Times, was editor at large at Vogue magazine and an editor at Conde Nast House & Garden. He wrote an around-the-town column for The Daily News in New York until 1991, then wrote a column for The New York Post until 1993. His Style Diary, a report on fashion, interior design and manners, appears weekly in The New York Observer. His novel, ''Learning to Drive,'' was published by Grove/Atlantic in 1996.

title: Franco's Tough Choice: Stay or Go
description: The Baltimore Orioles are discussing whether to pursue a deal for Mets relief pitcher John Franco if Franco decides that he wants to be traded rather than remain with the Mets as a setup man to the pitcher who replaced him as the closer, Armando Benitez, a former Oriole.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVERSA, PAULINE (NEE WEINBERG)
description: AVERSA-Pauline (nee Weinberg). March 18, 1911-November 13, 1999. Cherished wife, mother, grandmother and friend. Devoted to her family, late husband Rafael; children Gina Aversa, Hugo Kierszenbaum, M.D. and Susan Wein; granchildren Heidi Wein and Samantha Kierszenbaum. Former social worker, teacher and retailer; Hunter College Class of 1931. Active in her younger years in organizations devoted to peace, civil rights and education; formidable card player. An extraordinary human being: compassionate, feisty, wise and courageous. She will be greatly missed by all.

title: Equity Case In Canada As Redress For Women
description: As an afternoon autumn light slanted across a gray tableau of railroad tracks and power plant smokestacks, a new joy infused a weather-worn trailer planted here on the edge of a potato patch.

title: SPX TO SELL BEST POWER UNIT TO INVENSYS
description: The SPX Corporation signed an agreement yesterday to sell its Best Power subsidiary, which makes power systems that protect computers, information networks and other systems from power-line disturbances, to Invensys P.L.C., the British-based electronics and engineering company. The purchase price is $240 million. SPX provides a wide range of niche products to industrial customers, ranging from auto components to data networking systems. Best Power is based in Necedah, Wis. Shares of SPX, based in Muskegon, Mich., slipped $2.125, to $79.125.

title: Kia to Replace Goldberg Moser
description: Kia Motors America said yesterday that it would soon name a replacement for Goldberg Moser O'Neill in San Francisco, which Kia dismissed after six and a half years of being the company's sole agency. Plans call for billings, estimated at $75 million to $80 million, to rise to more than $100 million by 2001.

description: Plans to knock two zeros off the yen are gaining favor here once again.

title: NEWBRIDGE TO CUT 600 JOBS
description: A Canadian phone equipment maker, the Newbridge Networks Corporation, said it would cut 600 workers, or about 10 percent of its work force, and contract with outside manufacturers and service companies. The company also confirmed an earlier warning of unexpectedly poor results, saying profit for the second quarter, which ended Oct. 31, was $14.6 million, or 8 cents a share, compared with $33 million, or 18 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Grey Replaces Managers in Brazil
description: Grey Advertising in New York said yesterday that it had replaced the top managers of its agency in Sao Paulo, Brazil, with three executives who had worked for a rival shop.

description: MARTIN-Marguerite Prewer. On Thursday, November 18, 1999 of Washington, D.C. Beloved wife of the late Williams Swift Martin, II. Loving mother of Lt. Col. Williams Swift Martin, III, Mary Vincent Martin and Ann Martin Calder. Also survived by nine grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Service will be held at Christ Church, Georgetown, 31st & O Streets, N.W., Washington, DC 20007 on Monday, November 22 at 2:00 pM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Christ Church, Georgetown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLONEY, JAY
description: MOLONEY-Jay. 35, of Los Angeles, California, died on November 16, 1999. Born on Novermber 14, 1964 in Malibu, California, Jay graduated from the University of Southern California Film School. After beginning his career in the mailroom, Jay rose to become a former Managing Partner of Creative Artists Agency. Memorial services will be held on Friday, November 19 at 11:30 AM at the Paramount Theatre, Paramount Studios, 5555 Melrose Avenue in Los Angeles. Jay is survived by his mother Carole Johnson, her husband Charles, his brothers Darren Moloney and Sean Moloney, his sister-in-law Dianna, and his nieces Sage and Violet. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to the Jay M0loney Fund c/o Creative Artists Agency.

title: CBS Will Pay $6 Billion for Men's N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: CBS Sports agreed yesterday to pay $6 billion to keep the National Collegiate Athletic Association's men's basketball tournament for 11 more years, one week after failing to retain its Nascar rights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEYMANN, HELEN LONDON
description: HEYMANN-Helen London., 81, of Hollywood, Florida, formerly of New York City, on November 16, 1999, devoted wife of the late Maxwell. She was the beloved mother of Douglas, Stuart and Roger, mother-in-law of Marcie, Nancy & Rhona Heymann respectively; grandmother of Lonn, Eric, David, Monte, Gary, Alexa, Lauren and Sean; sister of Andrew London and Sheila Abrams and sister-inlaw of Debsie London and Fred Abrams. She served as a volunteer for Hadassah, Braille Institute and Mended Hearts. Gravesite services for family will be followed by reception for family and friends. Call family for information. Contributions in her memory to Mended Hearts Program of American Heart Association or charity of choice.

title: Death, Despair And Bad Manners
description: Something is rotten in the state of Japan, and the Renaissance man who goes by the name Takeshi Kitano doesn't mind saying so.

title: Lemieux May Be Older But He Hasn't Changed
description: His face is hard and craggy, the type seen on some supporting actors in certain Martin Scorsese films. There may be a few new scars and creases earned in his days away from the Devils. His eyes are deep-set and burn in icy blue, cold as the playing surface on which he skates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, DORIS
description: WEINSTEIN-Doris. The Executive Committee and the Board of Directors of the Great Neck Arts Center express their deep sorrow at the passing of a great lady and good friend of the arts and education. Through the Schnurmacher Foundations Doris Weinstein provided dance studios, pianos, and scholarships for children in the region. Her wit, intelligence, good humor and wise counsel will be forever missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPFIELD, IRVING
description: LIPFIELD-Irving. Beloved husband of the late Ruth, devoted father, cherished grandfather, loving brother and caring companion. Funeral services on Friday, 10A.M. at the Merrick Jewish Center, 225 Fox Boulevard in Merrick.

title: Vodafone Will Sweeten Bid for Mannesmann
description: Directors of Vodafone Airtouch P.L.C., the world's leading wireless telephone carrier, decided tonight to sweeten their all-stock bid for Mannesmann A.G., Germany's engineering and telecommunications giant -- raising it as high as $125.3 billion, according to executives close to the discussions.

title: SWISSAIR IN PACT WITH AMERICAN
description: Switzerland's flag carrier, Swissair, said it had set up a 10-year partnership with American Airlines, letting the two sell seats on each other's trans-Atlantic flights and giving the Swiss airline a badly needed United States partner as airline groups, not single carriers, increasingly dominate the skies. American, Swissair and Sabena Belgian World Airways, which is 49 percent owned by Swissair, will seek antitrust immunity that would allow them to work together on setting prices and agreeing on seating capacity.

title: Tower of Logs Collapses at Texas A&M, Killing 11
description: As scores of Texas A&M University students were busy constructing a tower for the school's traditional football bonfire, the 40-foot structure buckled and collapsed early today, killing at least 11 students beneath a snarl of logs the size of telephone poles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAMIDES, EUGENE
description: CHAMIDES-Eugene. Of Chicago, formerly of Somerset NJ at age 65 after a long illness. Loving father of David (Nancy), dear brother of Steve (Helen) and Robert (Sonia). Beloved husband of the late Lucia nee Tompkins, and survived by his second wife Barbara nee Kopp of Chicago. Services Monday, 9:30AM at Gleason Funeral Home, 1360 Hamilton Street, Somerset NJ. Donations in his memory may be made to the charity of your choice. For information: The Piser Chapel 847-679-4740

title: Ellsworth's Return Is Around The Corner
description: The Giants' record, barely above .500, and their offense, anemic throughout the season, have removed some of the luster from what the team chooses to view as a big game on Sunday against the Redskins. Percy Ellsworth is among the players opting for the glass-is-half- full approach to the game in Washington, seeing it as a battle for first place and a chance to avenge the season's most embarrassing loss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUTH, EDWARD E.
description: HUTH-Edward E.. ''Ted'', 83, of Wayne, IL, former president of Aurex Corp. of Chicago. Husband of the late Mary (nee Hooker). Beloved father of Alan and Jane. Grandfather of Noah, Sarah, Henry and Kathryn. Devoted brother of Joan Collier of NYC, and the late Margaret Taylor of Winnetka, IL. Memorial service will be held at 10AM, Nov. 22, at the Little Home Church by the Wayside, Wayne, IL. In lieu of fowers, donations to the Edward Everett Huth Memorial Fund, c/o the Little Home Church, 32W128 Army Trail Rd., Wayne, IL 60184

title: Residential Real Estate; New Apartment Tower in Upper 90's
description: Work is to begin in January on a 12-story rental building on the southeast corner of 97th Street and Lexington Avenue that will be the first of three new residential buildings that its developers plan for the immediate area.

title: Antoni Milkowski -- 'Set in Steel'
description: Hunter College/Times Square Gallery

title: Corrections
description: A contents entry on Page B1 yesterday about an article reporting a sale of contemporary art misidentified the auction house that held it. It was Sotheby's, not Christie's.

title: Corrections
description: A calendar listing in House & Home yesterday misstated the site of the Fall Antiques Show, which runs through this weekend. It is at the Seventh Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and 67th Street, not the 69th Regiment Armory on Lexington Avenue.

title: Home Depot to Split Stock
description: Home Depot said today that it would split its stock three shares for two and increase its quarterly dividend. The company, which sells home improvement products, said it would distribute the shares in the form of a dividend Dec. 30 to shareholders of record Dec. 2. Home Depot also said it would increase its quarterly dividend by 50 percent, to 6 cents a presplit share from 4 cents, payable Dec. 16 to shareholders of record Dec. 2. Home Depot has about 1.5 billion shares outstanding. Its stock rose $3.0625, to $83 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. The company is based in Atlanta.

title: Bronx School Will Expand But Phase Out Poorer Area
description: After months of heated debate, a Bronx school board overwhelmingly approved a plan last night to expand Middle School 141 in the affluent neighborhood of Riverdale but narrow the school's attendance zone to phase out students from the nearby, poorer Marble Hill neighborhood.

title: Congress on Record Course for 'Pork,' With Alaska in a Class of Its Own
description: It was a throw-away line on NBC's ''West Wing,'' biting in its indictment of an inventive, sometimes outlandish bid by Congress to spend taxpayer money. There, amid a list of appropriations requests recited by a fictional White House aide, was a gem: $2 million to monitor Alaskan skies for volcanic ash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, JAMES P.
description: ROSS-James P.. 87 of Kennebunk, ME, formerly of New York, NY. Died Wednesday in Maine. Attorney for 20 years with General Dynamics in New York and St. Louis. Predeceased by his wife Rita (McDonnell) Ross. Father to Gerard, Brian, David, James, Rita Tubman, and Joanne Zelmann Ross. Brother to Thomas Ross and Helen Ross, and 6 grandchildren. Visitation 7-9pm Friday at Bibber Memorial Chapel, Kennebunk, ME. Funeral 10am Saturday, St. Martha's Church. Memorials to Maine Alzheimer's Disease Association, 163 Lancaster St., Suite 160-B, Portland, ME 04101-2406.

title: A Matter of Interpretation
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Man Accused of Making 62 Bomb Threats
description: The police have arrested a man and accused him of making 62 fake bomb threats by calling 911 from pay phones over a six-month period, officials said. The man, John Davis, 56, was charged yesterday with 62 counts of of reckless endangerment, falsely reporting a police incident and aggravated harassment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENES, SYLVIA
description: LENES-Sylvia. Of New Milford, N.J. on November 18, 1999. Beloved wife of the late William, devoted mother of Susan Palzer and Jessica Lenes, adored mother-inlaw of Bob Palzer. Dear sister of Ruth Green, loving grandmother of Benjamin. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ on Sunday 10am. Contributions to National Leukemia Society would be appreciated. For information 1-800-522-0588

title: A CAMPAIGN FOR MR. YEN
description: Japan is working hard to promote Eisuke Sakakibara, the former Finance Ministry official whose influence over currency markets earned him the nickname Mr. Yen, as the next head of the International Monetary Fund. Officials from the Ministry of Finance and influential politicians have been calling friends and allies in other nations to sing Mr. Sakakibara's praises. ''We have had positive responses from our Asian counterparts,'' one high-ranking government official said. At the top levels of government in Tokyo, there is an increasing determination to use Japan's economic might to gain a position in the global decision-making process. Stephanie Strom

title: Bush Rehearsing for a World Stage
description: On Sunday it was just a conference call, and it lasted little more than an hour.

title: Flight Data Said to Show 'Rock Steady' Plane
description: A re-examination of information from the flight data recorder on EgyptAir Flight 990, from the time of takeoff to just before the aircraft plunged toward the sea, has uncovered no sign of a mechanical malfunction, government officials said today.

title: Ex-Detectives Get 6 Months in Beating Case
description: After expressing remorse for what they called their lapses of judgment, two former New York City detectives were sentenced yesterday to six months in jail for severely beating a man who was later struck and killed by a train in a nearby subway station.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, OSCAR
description: LERNER-Oscar. Age 93. Pharmacist, activist, founding member of Local 1199. Memorial service Saturday, November 20, 11 AM at Trinity Chapel, 770 Riverside Drive (at 153rd St.).

title: COMPAQ JOINS CABLE AND WIRELESS IN SERVICES VENTURE
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation, the maker of personal computers, and Cable and Wireless P.L.C. are putting $500 million into a venture that will sell electronic-commerce services for the next five years. The agreement calls for the two companies to sell Internet services and software applications to small and medium-size businesses worldwide. Cable and Wireless, Britain's second-largest telephone company, will provide the services and support, while Houston-based Compaq will supply equipment like PC's, servers and storage devices. The two will share revenue from the venture. Compaq has expanded its services business since it acquired the Digital Equipment Corporation last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEER, FRED J.
description: BEER-Fred J.. Died on November 17, 1999 at the age of 104. Survived by his beloved nephew, Jochanan Beer and his dear relative Marion Samuels. Graveside service Sunday 11AM at New Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood New Jersey.

title: 1968 Redux: New Issues Are Hot, Value Stocks Are Not
description: It's beginning to feel a lot like 1968.

title: 2 Sides Square Off on Genetically Altered Food
description: The Food and Drug Administration, while maintaining that its policy regarding bioengineered foods is safe, opened the first of three public meetings on the subject today and was greeted with both heated criticism and staunch support of genetically engineered products.

title: A New Front in the PCB War
description: New York's attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, who has been suing big corporations right and left recently, has now charged General Electric with impeding navigation along a stretch of the Hudson River and thus preventing the river from reaching its full potential as a commercial and recreational waterway. The suit represents a novel attempt to speed a resolution of the 25-year controversy over PCB contamination in the Hudson. If successful, the suit may also establish a precedent for claims against other companies whose activities can be shown to have restricted economic development along New York's waterways.

title: CHESAPEAKE ANSWERS SUITOR WITH COUNTEROFFER
description: The Chesapeake Corporation rejected a $700 million takeover offer yesterday by the Shorewood Packaging Corporation, and it began a counteroffer to buy its would-be suitor for $480 million plus assumed debt of $260 million. The Chesapeake offer values Shorewood at $16.50 a share. Chesapeake, based in Richmond, Va., makes tissue and specialty packaging. It is nearly twice the size of Shorewood, a maker of consumer packaging which is based in New York. Shorewood said it had rejected Chesapeake's offer as inadequate and had asked Chesapeake to end provisions that make it difficult for Shorewood to present its proposal to Chesapeake stockholders. Shorewood's shares rose 87.5 cents, to $14.25. Chesapeake's shares rose $2.375 each, to $32.4375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Untangling Genet's Puzzle Of Power, Lost and Found
description: When Irma, the madam who has been queen for a day, dismisses all her prostitutes and customers at the end of the Jean Cocteau Repertory's production of ''The Balcony'' and stands alone in her house as the lights go down, a wave of sadness sweeps the theater. That is exactly the right feeling: the world has been emptied, for her and for us.

title: Profit News and Spinoff Send Hewlett Shares Up Sharply
description: Shares of Hewlett-Packard jumped nearly 21 percent today, one day after the company posted stronger-than-expected quarterly earnings, set an aggressive sales goal for next year and began spinning off its test and measurement business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANDERPUTTEN, HERBERT JOSEPH
description: VANDERPUTTEN - Herbert Joseph. Of New York City, formerly of Westbury, LI. On November 12, 1999. Beloved husband of Ruth, his wife of 59 years. Devoted father of Peter (deceased), Thomas, Gary and James. Loving father-inlaw of Joan, Jan and Jill. Cherished grandfather of Christine, Michael, Bryan, Joy, Victoria, Christopher and Chelsea. Funeral Mass of Christian Burial, 9 A.M., Saturday, at St. Agnes R.C. Church, 43rd Street between 3rd and Lexington Avenues. Interment of Ashes immediately following at Greenwood Cemetery in Brooklyn. Family will receive friends at the home of Gary Vanderputten after interment. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to God's Love We Deliver or Maryknoll Missionaries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, LAURA NADLER
description: ISRAEL-Laura Nadler. On November 16, 1999 after a valiant battle with cancer. Beloved wife for over 50 years to Theodore J. Israel Jr. Devoted mother of Michael Israel, Nancy and Steven Hannick of Highland Park, IL, and Wendy Israel of Chicago, IL. Adored grandmother of Jessica and Michael Hannick. Laura was a brave and beautiful first class lady whose infectious warmth and personality will live on forever in the hearts of her friends and family. Her zest for life will be remembered by the compendium of quilts that she handcrafted as testimony to her creative spirit. A memorial celebration will be held Saturday, November 20 at 11 AM at the family home. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Museum of American Folk Art Building Fund.

title: Boeing Agrees to Settle Case Charging Bias in Salaries
description: The Boeing Company has agreed to pay at least $4.5 million to women and minority employees who the Government says are paid less than their white male counterparts, according to people involved in the settlement, the largest ever under a Labor Department affirmative action compliance program.

title: Russia Would Gain by Losing Chechnya
description: Russian President Boris Yeltsin may have had a tempestuous debate over Chechnya with President Clinton and other Western leaders yesterday, but no one should be fooled by his show of pique. He has little reason to be upset with the compromise reached by Western and Russian negotiators at a summit meeting in Istanbul on European security.

title: Computer-Related Companies Help Lift Dow Above 11,000
description: Stocks rallied yesterday, led by computer-related companies, after Hewlett-Packard sold shares in its measurement instruments unit and reported sales that beat some analysts' estimates.

title: C.I.A. Papers Show Struggle to Keep Pace as U.S.S.R. Unraveled
description: Declassified government documents show that analysts at the Central Intelligence Agency were deeply pessimistic about the chances of success for President Mikhail Gorbachev's efforts to reform the Soviet Union's Communist system even in the final days of the cold war.

title: Steinbrenner Is Lurking . . . . . . as Nets Continue Losing
description: Last summer George Steinbrenner often deflected tough questions about the Yankees by joking that he was a basketball guy. The comments were made in jest, but as the ratification of the merger between the Yankees and the Nets draws closer, there is increasing excitement, speculation and even unrest within the Nets' organization concerning what role the principal owner of the Yankees will play in their franchise.

title: Chechnya and the West
description: President Boris Yeltsin of Russia growled this week at Western leaders meeting in Turkey that they had no right to criticize his nation's war against ''bandits and murderers'' in Chechnya. On this point, the Russian president is simply wrong. Mr. Yeltsin and his allies in Moscow need to listen to warnings by those leaders who tried during the European security conference in Istanbul to explain that using bombs and tanks would not work, militarily or diplomatically, to oust Chechen terrorists.

title: In Cabby Bias Debate, Rifts Go Beyond Skin Color
description: The Manhattan borough president, C. Virginia Fields, held a public hearing in Harlem this week in an effort to promote what she called ''constructive communication'' about the difficulties that black New Yorkers face in hailing a yellow cab.

title: Catholic Colleges, On Their Terms
description: To the Editor:

title: For Reeling Knicks, Schedule Is Compounding Their Troubles
description: Jeff Van Gundy would publicly deride the Knicks for what he believed to be a) lack of effort, b) lack of heart, c) lack of commitment, d) insert tired cliche.

title: Cairo Sends More Specialists to Aid Crash Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  A second team of Egyptian aviation specialists arrived here Thursday to join U.S. investigators in a painstaking effort to determine whether tapes that appear to point to a struggle for control in the cockpit of the doomed EgyptAir Flight 990 will support the theory that a co-pilot caused the fatal dive.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: On Budget, Everything in Moderation
description: For all of the partisanship and intense wrangling of the past 10 days, the budget agreement between President Clinton and the Republican-run Congress ended up being most remarkable for its moderation.

title: Paul Bowles, Elusive Composer and Author Known for 'Sheltering Sky,' Dies at 88
description: Paul Bowles, the novelist, composer, poet and quintessential outsider of American literature, died of a heart attack yesterday in a hospital in Tangier, Morocco. He was 88, and throughout his extraordinary career evoked a world of dark Moroccan streets and scorching deserts, a haze of hashish and drug-induced visions.

title: Food for the Future
