description: C orn that is genetically modified to include a natural insecticide, cotton that has been engineered to tolerate herbicides -- if you've been reading about such new transgenic crops, you may be asking yourself, ''Why do we need this stuff?'' After all, American farmers already turn out plenty of high-quality food at low prices.

title: Winning a Cause by Refusing to Fight
description: One of the most stunning images from Richard Attenborough's 1982 film, ''Gandhi,'' is the line upon line upon line of protesters standing up to British oppression by lying down, or allowing themselves to be knocked down. What Gandhi did was undeniably momentous. He invented and taught passive resistance based on the Hindu concept of satyagraha, the assertion of truth through firmness and patience, and as a result won India its independence. Luckily, early-20th-century movie cameras were around to record much of it.

title: YELTSIN AND WEST CLASH AT SUMMIT OVER CHECHEN WAR
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin and the West squared off over Chechnya today, as the Russian leader told a European summit meeting that the West had no right to criticize Russia for its campaign against ''bandits and murderers.''

title: Sports of The Times; Breaking The Bonds Of Innocence
description: IT was simply a deal about basketball and business, Don Nelson said. The Dallas Mavericks made a trade with the San Antonio Spurs on draft day last June. The Mavericks received the Spurs' first-round pick, the 29th and last of the first round, 19-year-old Leon Smith out of Martin Luther King High School in Chicago. There had been a conditional arrangement to have the 6-foot-11-inch Smith play one season in a developmental league.

title: Sweatshops of Yesterday
description: To the Editor:

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Mistrustful of U.S., Egyptians Are Bitter About Crash Inquiry
description: As the inquiry into the crash of EgyptAir Flight 990 moves into a delicate new phase, Egyptian and American officials face high stakes in trying to find conclusive and satisfactory answers to questions about what brought the plane crashing into the ocean late last month.

title: Deutsch hopes to reach young consumers better by forming a venture with Rush Communications.
description: MADISON AVENUE is hooking up with the hip-hop nation as the entrepreneurial principals of Deutsch Inc. and Rush Communications in New York form a joint venture agency specializing in advertising and marketing to young consumers.

title: Sports Made a Candidate
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOEVARY, THEODORE
description: KOEVARY-Theodore., peacefully on November 16. Loving husband of Lilla. Devoted father of Richard and the late George. Adored father-in-law, grandfather, brother and uncle. A pillar of strength, he dazzled us with his intellect, amused us with his stories, and inspired us with his piety and kindness. Contributions in his memory to The Elmhurst Jewish Center, 37-53 90 St, Jackson Hts, NY 11372

title: A Spirit Still True (in Its Fashion)
description: FORGET about turkey for the moment, both the kind that's eaten for Thanksgiving and the kind that closes on Broadway. It is ham that's being served, without apology and with lots of relish, in the mouthwatering new revival of ''Kiss Me, Kate,'' Cole Porter's sybarite's delight of a musical about battling egos in show business.

title: The Last Clinton Budget
description: President Clinton's ambitious domestic agenda, presented last January at the height of the impeachment struggle, always faced an uphill struggle in getting approved by a Republican Congress. The Republican counter-demand for a $792 billion tax cut was similarly destined to be blocked by Mr. Clinton's veto. After a year of posturing, the budget for this year that is heading toward enactment this week -- the last of Mr. Clinton's presidency -- is striking for its stringency. There are modest spending increases in some of the president's priority areas like education, but over all the Republican approach of spending restraint has shaped this budget.

title: SIEBEL SYSTEMS TO ACQUIRE ONTARGET FOR $259 MILLION
description: Siebel Systems Inc., a maker of software for sales automation and customer support, agreed yesterday to acquire OnTarget Inc., a provider of consulting services and training programs on sales and marketing, for about $259 million in stock. Siebel Systems said it would pay 0.3078 share for each share of the closely held OnTarget, which is based in Atlanta. Siebel said it would issue 3.7 million shares to finance the deal, valued at $259 million based on its closing stock price on Wednesday. Siebel Systems shares rose $5.75 each, to $75.8125.

title: An Advocate With an Eye for the Next Job; Mayoral Ambitions Thrust Green Into an Early Campaign Sprint
description: Mark Green, the public advocate and could-be mayor who goes out five nights a week to three events per evening -- his own happy estimate -- was having his usual terrific time at a dinner on Tuesday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Mr. Green schmoozed with the actors Billy Baldwin and Paul Newman, stuck out his hand again and again (''Hi, Mark Green!'' he said) and accepted cheery greetings from a Chatham, N.J., Episcopal priest.

title: A Lifelong Passion for the Best
description: What is there to be said about the Metropolitan Museum of Art's wonderful exhibition of treasures from the legendary collection that Calouste Gulbenkian assembled in the first half of this century and then left to the world in a museum in Lisbon, where he spent his last dozen years? See it, enjoy it, pore over its every object from beginning to end: that is, from a 17th-century Armenian illuminated Bible to a vitrine of three Japanese lacquers.

title: Suit on Song, 'Rosa Parks,' Is Rejected
description: Many of the lyrics in the song ''Rosa Parks'' by Outkast, a rap group, are not words generally associated with Mrs. Parks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAPIRO, LYNN
description: SCHAPIRO-Lynn. Loving wife of Gene for 56 years. Mom, grandma and great-grandma. Lover of life, justice and all people. Memorial Service Saturday, November 20, 10 AM at The Ethical Humanist Society of Long Island, 38 Old Country Road, Garden City, NY.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Pursuit of Stock Wealth Brings a World of Swindlers

title: CYGNUS TO SELL DRUG DELIVERY BUSINESS TO ORTHO-MCNEIL
description: Cygnus Inc. agreed yesterday to sell the bulk of its drug delivery operations to Ortho-McNeil Pharmaceutical Inc. for up to $75 million. Cygnus, based in Redwood City, Calif., said it would receive $20 million cash when the deal closed and additional money based on reaching milestones on a contraceptive patch the company is developing with the R. W. Johnson Pharmaceutical Research Institute. The institute and Ortho-McNeil are units of the health care products giant Johnson & Johnson. Shares of Cygnus rose $1.125 yesterday, to $12, in Nasdaq trading. Johnson & Johnson was down $1.25 a share, at $104.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Russia Offers To Bargain, Using Iraq As Its Bait
description: Russia has suggested for the first time that it might support a weapons inspection system for Iraq that would be acceptable to Western nations if Washington gave Moscow a free hand in Chechnya, administration officials said yesterday.

title: New Television Commercials for Giuliani Are Directed at Upstate Cities
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Senate exploratory committee released three new television commercials yesterday that specifically take aim at voters in Syracuse, Buffalo and Rochester, extending its recent effort to introduce Mr. Giuliani to upstate New Yorkers.

title: U.S. Mediator Leaves Ulster With a Plea to Save the Peace Plan
description: Former Senator George J. Mitchell ended his mediation effort today with a plea to dissident politicians not to block the plan it produced to end the deadlock stalling progress in the Northern Ireland peace agreement.

title: GLOBAL INDUSTRIES DROPS PLAN TO BUY OFFSHORE BUILDER
description: Global Industries Ltd., which builds oil pipelines and platforms, said yesterday that it had canceled its plan to buy the offshore construction unit of Groupe GTM of France for $265 million in cash because certain conditions were not met. Financing was not the problem, Global said, declining to be more specific. The acquisition of ETPM S.A. would have created the world's largest offshore builder by market value. Groupe GTM said the cancellation was a breach of the companies' purchase agreement. Groupe GTM, based in Nanterre, France, is an affiliate of Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux, the second-biggest French water company.

title: Carroll Dunham
description: Metro Pictures

title: New Video Releases
description: Entrapment

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAE, GENE G.
description: RAE-Gene G.. Of Guilford, CT who died at the age of 85 after a short illness, was born in the Ridgewood section of Queens, NY where he attended Newton High school. He graduated from the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute with a degree in electrical engineering. He went to work for the Holophane Company of New York, where he stayed for 40 years, rising to be the Vice President. In 1938 he married the former Catherine McLarney, to whom he stayed married for 61 years. In 1942 he enlisted in the U.S. Navy and an Ensign and was discharged in 1945 as a Lt. Senior Grade. Mr. and Mrs. Rae moved to Guilford in 1978 where he tutored students in mathematics and coached the math team. Besides his widow he leaves four children: David of Ridgewood, NJ, Lucy Ricciardi of Greenwich, CT, Catherine Reed of Littleton, CO and Mary Louise Rae Arnold of Fort Worth, TX.

title: A Legacy of Pride More Than Profits
description: ASTON MARTIN'S origins date to 1913, when Lionel Martin began racing souped-up Singer sports cars in amateur competitions. Success in events at Aston Hill, Hertfordshire, led to the selection of the company name.

title: Headless Horseman With Quite a Head Count
description: The year is 1799 and ''the millennium is almost upon us,'' according to the newly dashing Ichabod Crane played by Johnny Depp in Tim Burton's enthusiastically bleak new movie. And speaking of dashing, when Ichabod gallops north from New York City, he rides up the west bank of the Hudson River although the village of Sleepy Hollow is on the east. But an ornate visual fantasy of Mr. Burton's can be expected to make its own rules, and ''Sleepy Hollow'' does that with macabre gusto. His idea of a beautiful day may be somebody else's nuclear winter, but Mr. Burton eagerly brings his visions of sugarplums to the screen.

title: Postman Still Rings
description: To the Editor:

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, MARY, LOUISE SHADMAN
description: MEYER-Mary-Louise Shadman., of Camden, ME and Wellesley, MA, on October 18th, 1999. Wife of the late Norman Meyer. Mother of Wendy C. Woodfield of Jamaica Plains, MA, Bruce R. Meyer of Orange, NJ, Chris Robison of Westport, CT, Marilee B. Meyer of Cambridge, MA, and Laurel S. Meyer of Wellesley and NYC. Grandmother of six. Ms. Meyer was a teacher, educator in Early Childhood Education, writer, chaplain, historian, professional musician, and patron of the arts. Memorial service will be on November 20th, 2 PM, at the Village Congregational Church in Wellesley (Routes 16 and 135).

title: A Turkish Transvestite Just Wants Happiness
description: Osman, a proudly macho Turkish taxi driver living in Berlin, wants Murat, his gorgeous, baby-faced younger brother, to lose his virginity. Osman wants it so much that he drags Murat out of the taxi and over to a prostitute who has just agreed to a fee of 100 marks (about $50) for the assignment. Murat (Baki Davrak), however, runs away. Literally.

title: Mourning, Self-Induced, Certainly Becomes Electra
description: For nearly three hours, Sandrine Bonnaire grimly mopes through ''Secret Defense,'' the French director Jacques Rivette's dreary contemporary retelling of the Electra myth. Ms. Bonnaire is Sylvie, a dour cancer researcher who is interrupted one day in her laboratory by her emotionally distraught younger brother Paul (Gregoire Colin), who arrives toting a gun. Insisting he has evidence that their father, who ran a guided-missile factory, was murdered by his right-hand man, Walser (Jerzy Radziwilowicz), Paul announces that he intends to avenge the crime.

title: LUFTHANSA PROFIT INCREASES
description: The German airline Deutsche Lufthansa A.G. posted a 1.5 percent increase in third-quarter profit as a jump in the number of business passengers helped the airline, Europe's second biggest, overcome difficult operating conditions including too many seats on flights over the North Atlantic and elsewhere. Third-quarter implied net income was 352 million marks ($187 million), up from 347 million marks a year earlier. Lufthansa said a decline in ticket prices has begun to slow, allowing the airline to raise its forecast for full-year earnings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARKIN, MARK D.
description: LARKIN-Mark D.., age 79, of New York City. Died on November 13, 1999, while traveling in Yazd, Iran. He was the beloved husband of Linda Hess Larkin; father of Michael Larkin of San Francisco, California, and retired partner of PriceWaterhouseCoopers. A memorial service will be held at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington at 80th St., at 4 PM, Sunday, November 21. The family will receive guests in the Community Center after the service and also from 5PM-8PM, Thursday, November 18, and Friday, November 19, at the Schapiro's, 1035 Fifth Ave., Apt. 7C. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to the Frederick Douglass Academy, Attn: Dorothy Haime, 2581 Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Blvd., New York, NY 10039.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Fairy Tales With a Twist

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Missing Out On the Calories

title: Rodriguez Catches Support as Surprise M.V.P. Pick
description: Ivan Rodriguez failed to win the most valuable player award for his own team, but was named m.v.p. of the American League yesterday. Pedro Martinez received the most first-place votes for most valuable player, but finished second in part because two writers left him off their ballots.

title: Guns in the Hands of the Young
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Interests; Goose Wars
description: While Hillary Rodham Clinton was having her problems with international politics last week, the folks in her future New York neighborhood were engaged in a summit conference of their own, over one of the most explosive issues in American suburbia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSLYN, MORRIS
description: OSLYN-Morris. Warden (Retired). Survived by son Robert and daughter Roberta, four grandchildren, sisters Lillian and Billie. Memorial Service November 26, 1999, at 1 P.M. Ethical Society of Long Island, Garden City.

title: Thanksgiving Tips
description: Still trying to decide where to celebrate Thanksgiving? Here are 12 restaurants among the many that offer special holiday menus. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: Treasures of Americana, From Quilts to Portraits
description: The dazzling quilt made by Adeline Harris (1839-1931), the teenage daughter of a well-connected Rhode Island mill owner, is a specimen of quilthood like few others. Starting in 1856, this clever needlewoman sent out hundreds of diamond-shaped pieces of silk to be signed by people she saw as outstanding figures of her day: politicians, scientists, artists, educators and writers.

title: U.S. Is Reassessing 2 Loans for Russia
description: The administration is debating whether to slow two major loans to Moscow. White House officials say halting aid risks destabilizing Russia. But others involved report growing divisions over Chechnya.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Passage From India

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVIGNO, PHYLLIS
description: LIVIGNO-Phyllis. Beloved wife of the late Jack, dear sister of Richard Catalano, loving aunt of Robert Brown and Erika Weaver. Visiting Monday, 9-10, A.M., McLaughlin Funeral Home, 8225 3rd Ave, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, LAUSON HARVEY
description: STONE-Lauson Harvey. The Horace Mann Community deeply mourns the loss of our cherished friend, former student and esteemed member of Horace Mann's Board of Trustees, Lauson Harvey Stone, HM '21. A graudate of Harvard College and Columbia University Law School, Mr. Stone first served on the Horace Mann Board of Trustees in 1947, then subsequently served on the Policy and Development Committee, the Executive Committee, and the Admissions and Scholarship Committee. He was appointed both Vice Chairman and Chairman of the Joint Conference Committee and served on the Board of Trustees until 1965 when he was made Honorary Trustee. A wonderful advocate for Horace Mann, he displayed interest and pride in the work of the faculty and the students. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his widow, Jane and to his two sons, Peter and Harlan. May his memory and his work continue to inspire all of us. Michael D. Hess, HM '58 Chair, Board of Trustees

title: U.S. Trade Gap Appears to Be Stabilizing
description: The trade deficit appears to be stabilizing as foreign economic growth picks up and the voracious American demand for imported goods and services slows, Commerce Department figures showed yesterday.

title: London Company to Buy Regal Hotels in U.S.
description: A London real estate company has agreed to buy the 28 Regal hotels in the United States from Regal Hotels International of Hong Kong, paying about $253 million plus assuming $387 million in debt.

title: Where the Wall Hid a Tale of Nazi Barbarism
description: This is a country of scars. Some are evident, some lie deeply hidden, as the story of this village on the former border between East and West Germany shows.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 14.

title: Love, Alas, Not Sorcery, Was Her True Calling
description: Gluck once described his late opera ''Armide'' as ''perhaps the best of all my works.'' Yet this heroic drama in five acts, first presented in Paris in 1777, has virtually disappeared from the repertory. It was already a novelty by the time Toscanini chose it to open the Metropolitan Opera's 1910-11 season with a stellar cast topped by Olive Fremstad, Enrico Caruso and Louise Homer. That production returned to the Met the next season but has not been heard there since, or hardly anywhere else.

title: Ex-Official Is Charged With Assault
description: A former New York City health official was charged yesterday in United States District Court in Brooklyn with assaulting and intimidating Trans World Airlines crew members last year after detonating stink bombs on a flight taking off in New York and one departing from Paris.

title: Personal Touch In Budget Fight
description: In this age of computer simulation and instant global communication, some things must still be done the old-fashioned way. Getting the president's signature on a piece of paper is one of them.

title: Rite Aid Announces Inquiry By the S.E.C. Into Accounting
description: The Rite Aid Corporation, the troubled drugstore chain, said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had started a formal investigation into its accounting practices and that its former auditors resigned last week because they said they could no longer believe management.

title: Knee Injury Sidelines Top Back
description: Harvard will be without its career rushing leader, Chris Menick, when it plays at Yale tomorrow.

title: Mr. Bush's Foreign Policy
description: After a bumpy foreign policy debut on the campaign trail, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas faced the obvious task of showing that he understands international issues even though he lacks direct experience with them. In a speech yesterday at the Reagan library in California, the Republican presidential candidate placed himself solidly in his party's internationalist mainstream with warnings about isolationism and protectionism. His simplistic approach to arms control was the major flaw in a generally balanced overview of the foreign policies he would pursue if elected president.

title: Grant-Golota May Lead to Shot at Title
description: Heavyweight boxing has gone from ''The Search for the Truth,'' the title of last week's championship unification bout between Lennox Lewis and Evander Holyfield, to ''The Future Is Now,'' the label for Saturday's bout between Michael Grant and Andrew Golota here at the Trump Taj Mahal.

title: Gaby Casadesus, Pianist in Duo, Dies at 98
description: Gaby Casadesus, a pianist and teacher whose specialty was the 19th- and 20th-century French piano repertory, and who often performed in a piano duo with her husband, Robert Casadesus, died on Nov. 12 at her home in Paris. She was 98.

title: Drugs Blamed for Deaths of 2 in Motel Room
description: A New York couple whose bodies were found in a motel room last Sunday died of drug overdoses, the authorities said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANGER, ELLIOTT M. JR
description: SANGER-Elliott M. Jr. On Friday, November 19, 1999, after a long illness, at age 77. Beloved husband of Joan B. Sanger. Adored father of Elizabeth Sanger and father-inlaw of Jeffrey Trachtenberg, devoted brother of Kenneth E. Loving son of Eleanor N. Also adored grandfather of Benjamin and Joshua Trachtenberg and devoted brother-in-law of Judith and Andrew Ball and Joan S. Sanger. Funeral services Monday, November 22, at 11 AM, Temple EmanuEl, 65th St. and 5th Ave. Family will receive friends Sunday, November 21, 3-5 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Mount Sinai Oncology Care Center, Columbia College, or a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAFFA, LOUIS
description: YAFFA-Louis. Beloved husband of Beatrice. Loving father of Earle and Beth, Ellie and the late Michael. Cherished grandfather of Nancy, Kimberly, Charles, Jessica and Josh. Great-grandfather of Katie, Max and Gabe. Service Sunday 12 noon at Congregation B'nai Yisrael, Bedford Rd, Armonk, NY.

title: Far From New York, Prayers for a Victim but No Curses for the City
description: The members of the First Baptist Church here have been saying nearly continuous prayers for Nicole Barrett since Wednesday, taking turns in hourlong shifts in front of a wooden cross in a room attached to the church's gymnasium, where they sit or kneel and ask God to grant her a speedy recovery. They have been at it since word first spread through East Texas that their former neighbor had been seriously injured in Manhattan by a man who had fractured her skull with a brick.

title: Bush Questions Aid to Moscow In a Policy Talk
description: Barely 24 hours after President Clinton and other Western leaders confronted President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia at a meeting in Turkey, condemning his actions in Chechnya, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas went them one better today, calling for an end to international aid to Moscow unless the Russian government stops ''killing women and children.''

title: ROYAL BANK CUTS JOBS; EARNINGS RISE
description: Royal Bank of Canada, the nation's biggest bank, said it would cut up to 6,000 jobs over the next two years. The bank also reported that its fiscal fourth-quarter profit rose 11 percent, to 484 million Canadian dollars, or $331 million, on higher trading and underwriting revenue. For fiscal 1999, profit rose 1.7 percent, to $1.26 billion. Royal Bank also raised its quarterly dividend by 13 percent.

title: CARRIER TO ACQUIRE ELECTROLUX REFRIGERATION BUSINESS
description: The United Technologies Corporation of Hartford said yesterday that its Carrier Corporation unit had agreed to acquire the commercial refrigeration business of Electrolux of Sweden for about $145 million. Electrolux, one of the world's top producers of appliances, employs 2,300 people at 10 manufacturing sites in 8 countries and has annual revenue of $300 million. Carrier, based in Farmington, Conn., is one of the world's largest makers of air- conditioning, heating and refrigeration equipment. It has annual sales of almost $7 billion.

title: Tempers Flare in U.N. Council Over Stalemate on Iraq Issue
description: Nearly a year after arms inspectors fled Iraq in the face of imminent American bombing, tempers flared in the Security Council today over the inability of the major powers to agree on how to resume the process of disarming Saddam Hussein and lifting sanctions that have weighed on Iraqis for eight years.

title: Stagehands Authorize Strike Against 2 Owners
description: The union representing Broadway's stagehands voted last night to authorize a strike against two of Broadway's major landlords.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about a German court ruling that overturned a former CompuServe executive's 1997 conviction for distributing pornography on the Internet misstated the dollar equivalent of the 100,000-mark fine he had paid. It was about $55,550, not $180,000.

title: HYUNDAI DEAL WITH VIVENDI
description: South Korea's Hyundai Engineering & Construction Company signed a $1 billion agreement with Vivendi Water, a unit of Vivendi S.A. of France, to build waste water treatment facilities in South Korea. Samuel Len

title: THE MANIA OF A DAY TRADER
description: He sits in a spare bedroom, wearing casual clothes and keeping a watchful eye on fluctuations. Should he pile on, ride the momentum, bail out? A day at the vanguard of a revolution in stock trading. By Matthew Klam, in The Times Magazine.

title: A Star Turn for China's Cult Buster
description: The animosity between Sima Nan and the Falun Gong spiritual movement goes back a few years, ever since Mr. Sima, China's one-man cult-bashing machine, denounced the group as a fraud in 1995, and the group's leader predicted that Mr. Sima would go blind and be crippled, Mr. Sima says.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASADESUS, GABY
description: CASADESUS-Gaby. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sadness the passing of its beloved friend and devoted Steinway Artist Gaby Casadesus, on November 12, 1999 in Paris at the age of 98. A native of Marseille, Mme. Casadesus was first taught by her mother and continued her studies at the Paris Conservatory under Marguerite Long and Louis Diemer. After a brilliant solo career in which she championed the music of such composers as Faure, Moszkowski, and Ravel, she married the renowned pianist and composer Robert Casadesus in 1921. Their collaboration resulted in one of the most celebrated piano duos in history. An acclaimed teacher, Mme. Casadesus' master classes at the Ravel Academy in St-Jean-de-Luz, the Mozarteum in Salzburg, and the Fontainebleau School were legendary. She was a co-founder of the Robert Casadesus International Piano Competition in 1975. Mme. Casadesus' discography, including a recent reissue of live performances from 1942 to 1948 by Dante Productions, will keep her legacy alive for future generations. To her daughter Therese, son Guy, and her entire family we extend our heartfelt condolences. She was an inspiration to us all, and her loss is deeply felt. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P., Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: Reno Blocks Release of Egyptian Jailed on Secret Evidence
description: Attorney General Janet Reno yesterday temporarily blocked the scheduled release of an Egyptian man who had been jailed for more than three years based on secret evidence, saying she wanted to consider intervening in the case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIONDO, FRANK X., PH.D.
description: BIONDO-Frank X., Ph.D.., of Oyster Bay, NY, on November 18, 1999 at the age of 72. Beloved husband of Arlene. Devoted father of Catherine. Dear brother of Dr. Vincent (Mary) Biondo, May G. Biondo, and Josephine Rizzuti. Brother-inlaw of Arthur N. (Lynn) Boulanger. Uncle of Maryann Montalbano, and Maria Biondo. Visiting at the Francis P. DeVine Funeral Home, Inc., 293 South Street, Oyster Bay, Saturday & Sunday 3-5, 7-9 p.m. Funeral Mass Monday St. Dominic's R.C. Chapel 9:30 a.m. Interment Pinelawn Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his name to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, 8900 Van Wyck Expressway, Jamaica, NY.

title: Outstretched Arms of the Plainly Happy
description: The nicest part of ''Sarah Plain and Tall: Winter's End'' is the way Sarah (Glenn Close) reacts when she finds a grizzled man, a total stranger, in her barn. Nobody calls 911 or whatever the equivalent of that would be on the Kansas prairie in 1918. Nobody looks for the shotgun, even for protection. The children don't scream. Instead, after making sure he's not sick, Sarah takes the man, whose name is John (Jack Palance), into the warm house, feeds him and offers him a bed for the night. He turns out to be her husband's long-lost father, but she doesn't know that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORF, EDWIN L.
description: DORF-Edwin L.. 79 of Lake Worth, FL on November 18, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Florence Waxberg Dorf. Loving father of Michael, Linda and Andrea. Grand father of four. Services November 22nd at 1P.M. at Munson-Lovetere Funeral Home, Southbury, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, DORIS
description: WEINSTEIN-Doris. It is with great regret that we mark the passing of Doris Weinstein, a true Woman of Valor and a person that we should all try to emulate. Doris always looked at the bright side of everything. It was indeed difficult to tell that she was ill when you were with her. Her positive attitude about life and all it has to bring is a lesson we can all learn from. Our sincere sympathy to our dear friend Ira, the family, and all those whose life she touched. Laurie Tomchin Steve and Lenny Schnurmacher

title: Sports of The Times; The Nets Are In Dire Need Of Inspiration
description: OUTSIDE the Nets' locker room last night, Red Auerbach, the legendary Celtics coach, approached Nets Coach Don Casey and offered words of comfort. ''That was a tough loss,'' Auerbach said. ''Hang in there. You'll get there.''

title: Alexander Liberman, Conde Nast's Driving Creative Force, Is Dead at 87
description: Alexander Liberman, the dominant creative force at Conde Nast Publications for more than half a century and one of the most influential editors in America, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Miami Beach. He was 87 and had homes in Manhattan and Miami.

title: Aggies, Shaken by Accident, Cling to Pride and Tradition
description: The signs in this rural college town read ''Aggieland,'' but for the faithful of Texas A&M University, the expression is less a point on a map than a state of mind. Ask someone to explain the fierce devotion of alumni, or the school's arcane traditions, and the answer is often a smile or a shake of the head.

title: January Hearing in Drug Merger Fight
description: Pfizer will not get its chance to block the proposed $69 billion merger between Warner-Lambert and American Home Products until January. William C. Steere Jr., Pfizer's chairman, had told pharmaceutical analysts in a meeting on Tuesday that he had hoped the Delaware Chancery Court would make its ruling within four to six weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, HERMINA, M.D.
description: BENJAMIN-Hermina, M.D.. On November 19, 1999. Beloved wife of Sasha Benjamin, M.D. Dear sister of Carole Spitzer. Loving aunt of Sorin and Vlad. Wonderful friend, wonderful colleague. We will miss you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, LORI
description: KAPLAN-Lori. The Jewish Theological Seminary family records with sorrow the death of Lori Kaplan, beloved daughter of Tobee and Leonard Kaplan, passionate Conservative Jews who have put philanthrophy and love of Judaism in the center of their family life. Our hearts go out to them, Lori's sister and brothers and the entire family. May her memory be for a blessing. Ismar Schorsch, Chancellor Gershon Kekst, Chairman

title: Snag in a Deal To End Tenure For Principals
description: After finally reaching a deal to end principal tenure, the Giuliani administration and the union representing New York City's principals have hit a snag over another issue: whether the tenure changes should also apply to the city's 2,500 assistant principals.

title: Assailant Prompts Front Page Outrage
description: The front page of The Daily News got right to the point yesterday: ''Get the Violent Crazies Off Our Streets.''

title: Ousted Leader in Pakistan Appears in Public for Trial
description: The ousted prime minister of Pakistan, Nawaz Sharif, appeared in public today for the first time in five weeks and told a judge that he was not guilty of any wrongdoing.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WELLS FARGO & CO., San Francisco, agreed to acquire Napa National Bancorp for $33 million in stock, the banks said. Napa National is privately held and operates four banking offices, with assets of $160 million.

title: Hank Messick, Journalist And Author on Organized Crime
description: Hank Messick, an author and investigative journalist who wrote extensively about organized crime, died on Nov. 6 at his home in Cocoa, Fla., after a long illness.

title: An Executive's Puzzling Death Leaves Riddles At Magazines
description: Kimberly Smith Jensen was known as a tough, occasionally stubborn, boss around the offices of Mortimer B. Zuckerman's publishing empire. In August, she had been promoted to chief operating officer, overseeing three magazines. The 44-year-old executive, whose passion outside the office was rock and country music, had been with the company for 15 years, playing a crucial role in developing the business plan for Fast Company, Mr. Zuckerman's fastest-growing magazine. And she was regarded as a trustworthy manager.

title: Museum Trustees' Duty
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, OSCAR
description: LERNER-Oscar. Age 93. Pharmacist, activist, founding member of Local 1199. Memorial service Saturday, November 20, 11 AM at Trinity Chapel, 770 Riverside Drive (at 153rd St.).

title: Knicks Fall Below .500 As Outlook Gets Bleak
description: Latrell Sprewell envisions a surreal Saturday night in Oakland, where his every shot is gulped down by the net, where his every teammate links arms in his quest to humiliate the Golden State Warriors.

title: Worse Has Come to Worst for Nets, as They Tie Team Mark for Futility
description: The Nets knew tonight's game against Boston would be decided by execution and athleticism, but they were hoping that history would also play a part. Having won their last three games at the Fleet Center, including a final-second victory that ended a seven-game losing streak last March, the Nets thought that fate, luck or some other abstract force might lend them a hand.

title: Just the Right Spot; Speedy Sidewalk Masseurs, a New Urban Convenience
description: Regina Bradford had seen them a thousand -- who knew, maybe a million -- times, but she had always been something of a skeptic. ''Massage?'' she would think when she passed them in SoHo or Central Park. ''These guys? Whatever.''

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES AGAIN. Prices for crude oil continued to rally on expectations that low OPEC production would deplete supplies. In New York, crude oil for December delivery rose 76 cents, or 3 percent, to $26.56 a barrel.

title: INSIDE
description: Teamster Official Convicted

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Thursday about the appointment of a new federal judge and an interim United States attorney in New Jersey grouped the two posts incorrectly. Unlike the judgeship, the United States attorney's office is part of the executive branch.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the violinist Felix Galimir on Nov. 12 misstated Alban Berg's role in the Galimir String Quartet's 1936 recording of his Lyric Suite. While Berg coached the quartet in the work, he was not present at the recording session, having died in 1935.

title: SUMMIT IN TURKEY PLACES NEW LIMITS ON EUROPE'S ARMS
description: World leaders ended a 54-nation summit meeting on European security today with the adoption of stiff new limits on the size of conventional armaments in Europe and a new charter proclaiming that local conflicts were the legitimate concern of all European states.

title: Russia and Chechnya
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEEGER, REV. PETER J.
description: SEEGER-Rev. Peter J.. On November 18, 1999. Former Pastor of Most Holy Trinity RC Church , Willimburg, Brooklyn, NY and St. Fidelis RC Church, College Point, NY. Devoted brother of Andrew, Father Francis, Caroline, Teresa Arkins, the late Arthur, the late Robert and the late Sr. Vivian Seeger. Reposing at The Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd, Flushing , NY. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 10:30am at St. Fidelis RC Church. Interment Mount St. Mary Cemetery. Visiting Sunday 2-5, and 7-9.

title: EgyptAir Crash: Harmful Speculation; Video and Audio
description: To the Editor:

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Richard A. Posner; Wide-Ranging Legal Thinker
description: As a federal appeals court judge, Richard A. Posner has an exalted job, but one held by a few hundred others. But to a wide swath of intellectuals, he is one of the most fascinating thinkers in the nation, especially about contemporary American social issues.

title: A Gore Daughter Emerges as a Leading Adviser
description: The hotel room was packed with some of the nation's leading smart guys, all offering Senator Al Gore advice on both domestic and foreign policy in preparation for his 1988 presidential campaign. In the corner, Karenna Gore, then 15, periodically looked up from her homework. ''Dad, I don't think that's right,'' she interjected at several points.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORD, J. COUPER
description: LORD-J. Couper. The Board of Directors and membership of the Bathing Corporation express great sadness at the recent passing of our most worthy and esteemed Director of 38 years and extend our deepest sympathy to Barbara and his family.

title: ABN AMRO ADDS PITNEY BOWES MORTGAGE SERVICING UNIT
description: ABN Amro Holding, the largest Dutch bank, said yesterday that it would buy the Atlantic Mortgage Investment Corporation, the mortgage-servicing unit of the Pitney Bowes Corporation, to become one of the top 10 mortgage-servicing companies in the United States. Atlantic, which provides bill collection and processing services for residential mortgage investors like Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, will add $20 billion to ABN Amro's servicing portfolio, bringing it to a total of $90 billion. An ABN Amro spokesman declined to say how much the company would pay for Atlantic. Atlantic, based in Jacksonville, Fla., will be merged into the ABN Amro Mortgage Group, which is based in Chicago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUHRMAN, SYLVIA
description: FUHRMAN-Sylvia., 78, of Clark, NJ, formerly of Hollywood, FL and Rego Park, NY. Beloved wife of the late Hy, devoted mother of Bob and Susan Fuhrman, Phyllis and Gil Lerner, and Mark and Wendi Fuhrman, adoring grandmother of Jonathan and Serena Fuhrman, Michael and Julie Fuhrman, Jeffrey Fuhrman, Dani Beth Lerner, Todd Fuhrman and Hallie Fuhrman. Services 1:15 Sunday at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, family requests that donations be made to the Jewish Community Center of Central NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, ANNA
description: ROSNER-Anna. Beloved wife of the late Leo Rosner, died at the blessed age of 101. She will live forever in the memory of her daughters Mildred Kaplow and June Rosner; her grandchildren Stacy, Jeffrey, Wendy, Amy and Marcy, and her seven great grandchildren. Memorial service at Riverside Funeral Home, on Sunday at 10:00 AM.

title: Defending Champs Open With Victory
description: PURDUE 60, DAYTON 58

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOWLES, PAUL
description: BOWLES-Paul. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be deeply mourned.

title: Ethics Panel Head Says Clintons Misstated Ruling
description: The head of the Office of Government Ethics has complained to the White House that President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton misstated a ruling by his office in September concerning the mortgage for their purchase of a $1.7 million home in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: The B Minor Mass in Full-Voiced Romantic Style
description: Twenty years ago, the musicological debate that swirled around Bach's choral music was whether he wrote them for tiny choirs with only one or two singers on a part. In the case of the B minor Mass, the discussion was theoretical, since Bach most likely never performed it, but the argument -- based on payment records that showed that such a paltry vocal ensemble was all Bach had at the Thomaskirche in Leipzig -- was compelling to anyone who believes that the forces available to a composer are part of what determines the shape and texture of a work.

title: Congressional Agency Faults A Report on Hedge-Fund Risk
description: The General Accounting Office has criticized a White House panel's recommendations to minimize the risks posed by hedge funds to the United States financial system, saying the proposals do not go far enough to ensure safety.

title: Warring Over Goethe, Recast Now As a Political Villain
description: It was Goethe's turn this year, the 250th since his birth, to be caught in the lethal crossroads where politics and literature intersect. A scholarly dispute has developed concerning the correctness of his political behavior while a privy councilor in Weimar in the 1770's. In Germany the argument has tended to mirror the old East-West division, since Goethe was all but canonized in Communist-led East Germany, whose rulers were for decades the landlords of Weimar, the poet's adopted city.

title: Chance to Face Fraschilla Is Small Consolation for St. John's
description: The chance to play against Fran Fraschilla, their former coach, and his University of New Mexico Lobos did not seem so big a deal tonight after the St. John's men's basketball team was upset by Samford University, 68-60, in the opening game of the Cosida Classic.

title: Ex-Student Sues St. John's Over Contract For Nike Gear
description: A former graduate student at St. John's University filed a lawsuit yesterday against the university and Nike, claiming he lost his job as an assistant coach with the men's soccer team because he refused to wear team apparel with the Nike logo.

title: Eugene J. Bockman, City Archivist, 76
description: Eugene J. Bockman, a longtime archivist and librarian for the City of New York, died on Nov. 8 at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 76 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Colorado Out to Prove It's Still King of the Hill
description: The skyline of the Rockies takes on a distinctive change as Interstate 70 approaches the Copper Mountain ski resort, about 80 miles west of Denver. It is not only snowy peaks that reach skyward; so do a handful of construction cranes.

title: Delaware Library Inherits Trove of Paul Bowles Works
description: Paul Bowles, the expatriate American writer and composer who died on Thursday in Morocco at 88, transferred the bulk of his literary papers -- 50 cartons of annotated manuscripts, notebooks and correspondence -- to the University of Delaware Library, which plans a major exhibition of his work next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PODUFALY, VIRGINIA
description: PODUFALY-Virginia. The entire Long Island College Hospital acknowledges with sadness the passing of Virginia B. Podufaly, beloved mother-in-law of our esteemed friend and colleague, Joseph Broadwin, a member of our Board of Regents. To Joseph, his wife Susan, the entire Broadwin family and all who loved her, we offer our heartfelt condolences. John Wren Chairman, Board of Regents Allan Gibofsky, MD, JD President and CEO Jagdish Gupta, MD President, Medical Board

title: MINIMED TO SPEND UP TO $1.5 MILLION TO FIX INSULIN PUMPS
description: MiniMed Inc., a maker of diabetes treatment products, plans to spend as much as $1.5 million to upgrade some of its insulin pumps because of a software problem. MiniMed shares fell $5, to $80, yesterday. MiniMed, based in Sylmar, Calif., said its Model 508 insulin infusion pump, which it began distributing Oct. 4, could, when programmed in a specific way, have a software error that would result in the patient's receiving an incorrect dosage of insulin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUFFY, MICHAEL J.
description: DUFFY-Michael J.., Rev., 66, Maryknoll Missioner to Africa, died Nov. 16, 1999. He is survived by mother, Janet Duffy; brothers, Edward, John, and Daniel Duffy; and sisters, Janet Bruce, Angela Galascione, and Sharon Duffy. Wake services at Maryknoll Center, Ossining, N.Y., Sunday, 7PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Maryknoll Seminary Chapel, Monday, 11AM.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Streets do not exist in civilized societies for the purpose of people sleeping there. Bedrooms are for sleeping.''

title: With Ease, Davenport Reaches Chase Semifinals
description: It is not yet a crusade, but after six straight years of stalking a title at the Chase Championships, hanging in and hanging on until the bitter end of the endless tennis season in pursuit of her circuit's world championship, Lindsay Davenport has pronounced herself ready to improve on her record as a two-time Chase runner-up.

title: Dropping Pursuit of Merger, Ocean Spray Irks Growers
description: In a move that left many cranberry growers angry and disappointed, the board of Ocean Spray has voted against pursuing a merger with another packaged-food company, the company said yesterday.

title: A Saintly Jew Whose Spirituality Rejected Jews
description: As a brilliant but radical philosophy student in Paris in the late 1920's, she was nicknamed the Red Virgin and the Categorical Imperative in Skirts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, FANNY
description: GOLDSTEIN-Fanny., 94 years, died on November 18, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Daniel. Devoted mother of Jonathan and Geri. Cherished grandmother of Daniel, Sarah and Jason. Loving sister of Anna Kaplaw. Dearest aunt.

title: All This and Football, Too
description: Few rivalries match the fear and loathing of Florida-Florida State Week, the six-day binge before the rumble between schools located a two-hour drive apart. The outcome always reverberates the national college football landscape.

title: New Data Released on Side Effects in Gene Therapy Experiments
description: Six weeks after the Food and Drug Administration placed a hold on two gene therapy trials for liver cancer, new documents show that some patients in those experiments suffered serious side effects, including changes in liver function and blood cell counts, nausea and mental confusion. Also, a patient with a history of strokes had a minor one.

title: Pirates Start This Season Without Looking Ahead
description: The Seton Hall roster that everyone is anticipating was nowhere near the Continental Arena tonight for the Pirates' season opener. That highly heralded group of early recruits -- Andre Barrett, Eddie Griffin, Marcus Toney-El and Damion Fray -- was preparing for the high school season, still a year from officially joining the Pirates.

title: Allies Fear U.S. Project May Renew Arms Race
description: A senior State Department official flew to NATO headquarters this week to defend the administration's plans to deploy a national missile defense system in the face of growing criticism from European allies who say their security is being threatened.

title: Teacher in Brooklyn Accused of Sexually Abusing an Eighth Grader at School
description: Apparently emboldened by a group counseling session about teenage issues, a 15-year-old high-school student in Brooklyn told her counselor on Thursday that she had been sexually abused by a teacher two years ago, investigators said yesterday.

title: Army Increases Incentives for Some Who Enlist
description: Trying hard to fill its ranks in an era of prosperity and relative peace, the United States Army is offering bigger enlistment bonuses and shorter hitches for some recruits.

title: Con Ed to Pay $2 Million to Rescuers Exposed to PCB's at Fire
description: The Consolidated Edison Company has agreed to pay approximately $2 million to 270 firefighters and other emergency workers who were exposed to toxic chemicals after a fire last year at a generating plant on Staten Island, people involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Religion Journal; Jews and Baptists May Meet on Evangelism Dispute
description: Ever since late September, just after the Jewish High Holy Days, a rather pointed exchange of letters has flowed between officials of the Jewish Community Relations Council of New York and the Rev. Paige Patterson, president of the Southern Baptist Convention, the nation's largest Protestant denomination.

title: MOTIVEPOWER AND WESTINGHOUSE AIR HOLDERS BACK DEAL
description: Shareholders of MotivePower Industries and Westinghouse Air Brake Company approved a $442 million merger that creates the nation's biggest rail-equipment supplier. The plan was approved by more than 95 percent of each company's shareholders. Westinghouse Air will exchange 0.66 share of its stock for each MotivePower share and will assume $130 million in debt. The new company, called Wabtec Corporation, will be based in Wilmerding, Pa. The merger reflects consolidation among suppliers and their major railroad customers, which have spent more than $20 billion in six combinations in the last four years.

title: A Cellist With a Refined, Resonant Sound
description: Rafal Kwiatkowski, a 21-year-old Polish cellist, plays with a technical command and musical maturity that should come as no surprise, given his background. He is the son of two professional cellists and, by 14, had already won an important competition in his country. Earlier this year, Mr. Kwiatkowski took first prize in the Young Concert Artists International Auditions, which earned him a New York recital on Tuesday night with the pianist Albert Tiu at the 92nd Street Y.

title: E*TRADE GROUP IS BUYING ITS SECOND EUROPEAN AFFILIATE
description: In its second purchase of an European affiliate in three weeks, E*Trade Group acquired E*TradeNetBourse, which does business in France and five other countries. E*Trade, the Internet brokerage firm based in Menlo Park, Calif., said NetBourse also operates in Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Austria and Italy. It will become a wholly owned subsidiary. Financial terms were not disclosed. E*Trade said the purchase, and that of E*Trade Nordic, its Scandinavian affiliate, announced Oct. 25, will allow it to reduce costs because of ''strengthened management control.'' The firms will use the transaction-processing operations of Dublin-based TIR Holdings, which E*Trade acquired in September.

title: Justices to Weigh Constitutionality of Key Element of Whistle-Blower Law
description: Greatly expanding the scope of a case to be argued only 10 days from now, the Supreme Court announced today that it would decide whether the central portion of the federal whistle-blower law was constitutional.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLER, SARA C.
description: STOLER-Sara C.. Age 83, of Stowe, VT, died peacefully on November 18, 1999 at her home surrounded by her loving family. She is survived by her son Will, her daughter Ann, her grandchildren Gwenn, Tessa, Bruno and her brother William Cracken.

title: U.S. Team Defeats Russians In Internet Championship
description: The American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals, beginning here today, had an unusual curtain raiser. The final of the first Internet World Championship was played yesterday, with an American team winning by 54 imps against a Russian foursome that had come from Moscow to take part.

title: ZIFF-DAVIS IS SELLING ZDTV TO VULCAN VENTURES
description: Ziff-Davis Inc., the publisher of computer magazines, agreed yesterday to sell its 64 percent stake in the ZDTV interactive cable television channel to Vulcan Ventures for $204.8 million to help reduce debt. Ziff-Davis, a unit of the Softbank Corporation of Japan, has not made a profit since selling shares to the public in April 1998. It agreed on Wednesday to sell its ZD Education unit to Wasserstein Perella Group for $172 million. Vulcan is controlled by Paul Allen, a co-founder of Microsoft. He uses closely held Vulcan, based in Bellevue, Wash., to invest in computer, communications and cable companies. ZDTV, in which Vulcan had a 33 percent stake nine months ago, is distributed to about 14 million homes.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about the Canadian government's plan to compensate federal workers, mainly women, who received lower salaries than men who performed work ''of equal value'' misspelled the surname of one who will be compensated. She is Bev Austen, not Austin.

title: Gore Campaign Responds to Money Crunch
description: Fund-raising for Vice President Al Gore's presidential campaign is lagging, forcing Mr. Gore to add new money-raising events and slash spending, campaign officials said today.

title: COCA-COLA ORDERED TO PRODUCE DATA IN LAWSUIT
description: The Coca-Cola Company was ordered yesterday to produce ''any nonprivileged computerized or hard copy data'' concerning race and employment procedures by Dec. 16 to plaintiffs' lawyers in a racial discrimination suit brought by four former and current black employees. The order came in federal court in Atlanta, where United States Magistrate E. Clayton Scofield III was considering five motions -- four submitted by the plaintiffs and one by Coca-Cola -- concerning the discovery phase of the case. The employees are suing the company for discriminating against black employees in pay, promotions and evaluations.

title: Rhodes Is Considering Yankees' 4-Year Contract Offer
description: Arthur Rhodes is deciding among contract proposals from the Yankees and five other teams and could make up his mind by early next week, according to the pitcher's agent.

title: MORE TIME FOR NATWEST
description: Extending a deadline, Britain's Takeover Panel granted National Westminster Bank an additional two weeks to mount a defense against a $34 billion hostile bid by the Bank of Scotland. The British Office of Fair Trading requested the extension, saying it needed an extra two weeks to determine whether the bid should be referred to the Competition Commission. The extension also gives the Royal Bank of Scotland, which has said it is considering a competing bid, more time to ponder its options. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: The Bishops and the Universities
description: The National Conference of Catholic Bishops oversees matters of religious doctrine for the Roman Catholic Church in the United States. But some Catholics were alarmed when the bishops voted this week to extend their authority to the nation's Catholic colleges and universities, which educate large numbers of non-Catholics as well and historically have been independent of Rome.

title: In Bronx, a Plan for Reeling in Fish, Not Cars
description: The Bronx River -- particularly the eight-mile section that runs through the borough itself -- has been called a lot of things, including a cesspool and an open sewer.

title: Official Curbs Plan to Investigate Many in I.R.S.
description: Bowing to sharp criticism from his own investigators, a Treasury Department official last night withdrew the goals he had set under which the number of Internal Revenue Service workers to be investigated for misconduct next year would nearly equal the number of Americans who will be investigated for criminal tax fraud.

title: Millennial Meditation With a Plea For Silence
description: Kurt Masur may have made a minor miscalculation when he commissioned half a dozen composers to write works for the Philharmonic to play as ''Messages for the Millennium.'' The works were meant to be 10 to 15 minutes apiece, so all six should have fit on a single program. But composers tend to write long, particularly when presented with such an overarching idea: how, after all, can a composer be expected to offer a response to the millennium now ending or hopes for the one about to begin in 10 to 15 minutes?

title: Save Some Deductions
description: To the Editor:

title: BUFETE IN TALKS
description: One of Mexico's largest construction firms, Bufete Industrial S.A., has been courting European, Saudi and North American companies as potential partners, seeking investments that could help Bufete deal with creditors demanding payment of debts. A spokesman declined to name the companies with which Bufete has held discussions. Two Bufete creditors, Merrill Lynch and Grupo Financiero IXE S.A., have sued to recover overdue loans. Bufete, which specializes in building oil rigs and electric power stations, failed to meet a $100 million Eurobond payment in July. Sam Dillon

title: Editorial Observer; The Downside of a Social Security Promise
description: When President Clinton vowed in last year's State of the Union address to ''save Social Security first,'' he in effect vowed to scuttle any attempt by Congress to use the surplus dollars in the Social Security trust fund for government programs or for tax cuts. He pledged to use the surplus money instead to pay down the federal debt.

title: Rubin and Cincinnatus
description: To the Editor:

title: Plan to Exempt Westchester From New Area Code Fails
description: The company responsible for assigning new area codes across the country has rejected New York State's proposal to exempt Westchester County from a change to the 914 area code.

title: Rangers, Seeking Hot Hand, Shuffle Lineup and Roster
description: There were more changes at the Rangers' practice here today in the aftermath of yet another frustrating loss. Alexandre Daigle was recalled from Hartford of the American Hockey League, along with the feisty center P. J. Stock.

title: Air Safety Chief Criticizes Colleagues' Remarks on Crash
description: The federal government's top air safety investigator took a swipe at his partners in the investigation of the crash of EgyptAir Flight 990 and at the news media today, complaining that ''some unidentified sources'' were saying things about that plane's cockpit voice recording that was resulting in headlines that were ''just flat wrong.''

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day on Thursday showing the most active issues on the American Stock Exchange included one erroneously. FuelCell Energy was not one of the biggest percentage decliners in Wednesday's trading. Its shares rose $1.9375, or 8.8 percent, to $24. They did not fall $9.125. Calculations for the price omitted a 3-for-2 stock split.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: More Cabdrivers Are Cited in Part 2 of City Campaign Against Discrimination
description: For the second time in two weeks, a cadre of police officers and taxi inspectors posing as customers fanned out across the city yesterday to catch cabdrivers who discriminate.

title: Trade Pacts Must Safeguard Workers, Union Chief Says
description: Raising the stakes in labor's dispute with President Clinton over trade, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, John J. Sweeney, called on the administration today to scuttle a worldwide round of trade-liberalization talks unless negotiators first take steps toward protecting workers' rights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEDESCHI, JOHN
description: TEDESCHI-John. Died November 5, 1999 of asbestos cancer. He was an employee of The New York Times for thirty-five years. He also worked in the Brooklyn Navy Yard and served on ships in World War II and Korea. He is survived by loving wife Josephine, beloved daughters Marie Kossman (John) and Pamela Callari (John). he was the devoted grandfather of Cara Kossman & Christine & Catherine Callari; dear brother of Joseph and Michael Tedeschi and sister Ann Marro (Ray).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YELLIN, ROSLYN
description: YELLIN-Roslyn. On November 19, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Loving mother of Roberta Barron & Herbert Yellin. Adoring grandmother of Larry & Jeannie Barron. A gentle woman who loved & was loved. Service Sunday 9:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave, NYC

title: Colombia Tries, Yet Cocaine Thrives
description: Under American pressure, for most of this decade the Colombian government has been sending planes to spray herbicides on the fields of coca that flourish in areas like this. With a new, more cooperative government in power in Bogota, last year was a banner year for that joint effort, with a record 135,000 acres fumigated.

title: Disclosing Hidden Fats
description: The Food and Drug Administration cannot give Americans the willpower to resist fatty foods that promote heart disease. But it can arm people with the facts they need to make informed dietary choices. The agency is doing just that with its newly announced plans to require food manufacturers to disclose on product labels the amount of trans fatty acids, or trans fats, the product contains. The food industry does not oppose the new labeling.

title: Sex Party Allegations Surface
description: Outside the steel locker room doors, Coach Jeff Van Gundy could be heard unleashing a profane tirade on his team before a shoot-around this morning in what might have been an attempt to pierce the haze of distractions diverting the Knicks' attention.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Is This the End of the Story for Books?
description: First the scroll, then the codex and the Gutenberg Bible. And now the electronic book? Almost nothing causes more anxiety in the publishing world than the idea that books as we know them might one day be replaced by electronic or e-books. Will paper books, with their distinctive smell and touch, the special, almost trancelike intimacy they can engender between writer and reader, vanish forever? And if so, what will the experience of reading be like in the 21st century?

title: A Rising Israeli Political Star Threatens Barak's Majority
description: Eli Yishai and his seven siblings, the children of Tunisian immigrants, grew up in a lively if crowded one-room apartment in a run-down Jerusalem neighborhood. His family so typified the working poor that in the late 1960's it was featured in a newspaper expose of Israeli poverty.

title: Alfred Hassig, 78; Target of Tainted-Blood Trial
description: Dr. Alfred Hassig, who was convicted last year of letting H.I.V.-infected blood be distributed to hemophiliacs in Switzerland, died here on Sunday. He was 78.

title: Gift of Connecting: Clinton Shows Skills, From Babies to Diplomats
description: When President Clinton toured the earthquake-shattered town of Izmit this week, he said he wanted to ''do everything we can'' to help survivors. He may have made one of them rich, although the lucky victim is too young to understand his good fortune.

title: GERMAN BUILDER ON BRINK
description: The future of Germany's biggest construction company, Philipp Holzmann A.G., was uncertain after its main creditor banks disagreed about plans for a bailout. Holzmann, which has lost money for years but claimed to be in a turnaround, said on Monday that it had suddenly discovered 2.4 billion marks ($1.3 billion) in possible losses from soured real estate projects. Deutsche Bank A.G., which holds about 2.2 billion marks in Holzmann debt, is trying to organize a rescue, but other creditor banks have argued that Deutsche Bank should put up more of the money. If the banks do not agree on a plan by Sunday night, Holzmann executives say they will start bankruptcy proceedings.

title: David Shaber, 70, Screenwriter
description: David Shaber, a producer and writer for the screen and stage, died on Nov. 4 at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 70 and had homes in Manhattan and Roxbury, Conn.

title: Ex-Teamster Official Guilty In Campaign Finance Case
description: A federal jury in Manhattan convicted the former political director of the Teamsters union yesterday on fraud and conspiracy charges, concluding that he had helped divert union money to finance the re-election campaign of the union's former president, Ron Carey.

title: Corrections
description: The crossword puzzle yesterday gave an incorrect clue for 6 Down, ''Two-time N.L. M.V.P., 1954 and 1965.'' The diagram called for ''Aaron.'' But in fact the clue describes Willie Mays; Hank Aaron was voted most valuable player in 1957.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO REBOUNDS. The euro rose, rebounding from a Thursday selloff that followed a report showing German business confidence was weaker than expected. In New York, the euro was at $1.0302, up from $1.0292 Thursday.

title: Naomi Bluestone, 63, a Writer Who Guided Medical Students
description: Dr. Naomi Bluestone, a medical writer, a practitioner, a teacher and a ''Dear Abby'' to a generation of aspiring doctors, died Nov. 13 at her home in Center Barnstead, N.H. She was 63 and had moved there from Great Neck, N.Y., in 1991.

title: EgyptAir Crash: Harmful Speculation
description: To the Editor:

title: Vodafone Puts $127.7 Billion On the Table
description: Vodafone Airtouch P.L.C. today sweetened the terms of its offer for Mannesmann A.G., bidding $127.7 billion in stock in a move that if successful would vastly inflate the size of the wireless telephone company and fundamentally reshape Europe's rapidly growing telecommunications industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFER, CHARLES V. JR
description: SCHAEFER-Charles V. Jr. age 85 of Saddle River died Thursday, November 18, 1999 in Boca Raton, Florida. Born in Brooklyn, New York, he was a resident of Saddle River and formerly of Ridgewood. A graduate mechanical engineer from Stevens Institute of Technology '36, Mr. Schaefer was later awarded an honorary doctorate and founded the Schaefer School of Engineering. As an entrepreneur he owned various NJ based manufacturing businesses. He served as Chairman of the NJ Manufacturers Ins. Co., Stevens Institute of Technology, the N.J. Business and Industry Association, and the Northern New Jersey Chamber of Commerce. He was a member of the Ridgewood, Boca West, and Arcola Country Clubs and the Upper Ridgewood Tennis Club. Surviving is his wife Stephanie (nee Tactikos) Schaefer of Saddle River, a son, Charles Schaefer III of Franklin Lakes, NJ, a daughter Lynn Schaefer Bovenizer of Pennington, NJ. Also surviving are six grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Mr. Schaefer was predeceased by his first wife Lillian Meyer Schaefer in 1984. Visiting Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 at the Vander Plaat Funeral Home 257 Godwin Ave., Wyckoff, NJ. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, December 3, 1999 at 1 PM at the Wyckoff Reformed Church, 580 Wyckoff Ave., Wyckoff, New Jersey. Donations to Schaefer Fund of Excellence, Stevens Institute of Technology, Hoboken, N.J. 07030, would be appreciated.

title: In Wake of Attack, Giuliani Cracks Down on Homeless
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani declared yesterday that the homeless had no right to sleep on the streets and his police commissioner added that they could be arrested if they refused shelter. Their remarks came three days after an office worker in Midtown Manhattan was critically injured in a random attack by a man the police say may have been homeless.

title: Ad Copy That Offends
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Judge Names a Mediator To Settle Microsoft Case

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPMAN, ALFRED F.
description: CHAPMAN-Alfred F.. Retired Vice President of Sales for Shenley Liquor Company, on November 18, 1999. Loving father of Robert Chapman of New York City and Michele Bowman of East Haven, CT and brother of Elmer Chapman and John Healy. Visitation Sunday, 3-5 and 7-9PM at the Leo P. Gallagher & Sons Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St., Stamford, CT. Mass of Christian burial 10:00AM, Monday, at St. Gabriels Church, Stamford, CT. Interment St. Catherine's Cemetery, Graniteville, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIONDO, FRANCIS X., PHD.
description: BIONDO-Francis X., PhD.. The Medical staff of Jamaica Hospital Medical Center mourns the passing of Francis X. Biondo, PhD, Secretary of The Board of Trustees. His support and fervor were instrumental in achieving the remarkeable progress at our institution. We will miss our colleague. Anthony S. DiMaria, MD, President, Medical Staff

title: Corrections
description: A letter on Thursday about trade with Cuba misstated Havana's relationship with the World Trade Organization. Cuba is indeed a member; it is not making a bid to join.

title: If Your A.T.M. Fee Is Too High
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tribute to Pacino
description: Al Pacino, the intense actor who starred as Michael Corleone in the ''Godfather'' trilogy as well as in such films as ''Serpico,'' ''Dog Day Afternoon,'' ''Scarface,'' ''Sea of Love,'' ''Scent of a Woman'' and ''Donnie Brasco,'' will be the focus of the annual tribute of the Film Society of Lincoln Center at its gala on April 25 at Avery Fisher Hall. Among those honored in the past are Martin Scorsese, Sean Connery, Clint Eastwood, Bette Davis, Federico Fellini, Alfred Hitchcock, Sir Laurence Olivier and Charlie Chaplin. Information: (212) 875-5610.

title: Mitchell's Finest Game Ended on a Sour Note
description: Pete Mitchell, the Giants' tight end, had his best game and his worst game all in one afternoon last weekend against Indianapolis. Mitchell had nine receptions, as many passes as any Giant has caught in 11 years. He caught the touchdown pass that pulled the Giants within 8 points in the game. He almost single-handedly kept the Giants close to the Colts. He was the heart of a very improbable comeback.

title: Journal
description: When historians look back at America as it rang in the momentous year of 2000, what will they find? Y2K panic? An outbreak of millennial spirituality? ''Prosperity with a purpose''?

title: Jets Need Their Defense To Stand Up to the Bills
description: It took a while, Aaron Glenn said today, but the Jets' defense finally came to this understanding:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday with an article about budget talks in Congress misidentified one representative waiting to speak with reporters. The man at the far right was William M. Thornberry, Republican of Texas, not John Thune, Republican of South Dakota.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Tuesday about a Pentagon-appointed panel of outsiders studying the prospects for a national missile defense system referred incorrectly to the outlook for next steps. Defense Department officials said the Pentagon would make a recommendation to the president next summer on whether it is technically feasible to deploy the system. They did not say the Pentagon would be unable to make a recommendation.

title: SENATE APPROVES BUDGET PACKAGE, ENDING DEADLOCK
description: Congress completed work on the budget tonight, ending a year of political gridlock and breaking the spending limits that lawmakers set for themselves for the second year in a row.

title: President's Visit to Greece Yields a Toast and a Tumult
description: President Clinton raised a glass to American-Greek relations tonight in the dignified confines of Presidential Mansion as thousands of demonstrators clashed with riot-equipped policemen in an ugly but contained protest against the president's arrival.

title: Minos Volanakis, Greek Translator And Director, 74
description: Minos Volanakis, a translator and director who specialized in ancient Greek plays, died on Sunday in Athens, where he lived. He was 74.

title: As Mannesmann Fights Takeover, Construction Company Seeks Bailout : 'Consensus' In German Business Shaken Up
description: FRANKFURT  The strains in Germany's "consensus capitalism" were on full display Friday, as one of the country's corporate champions became the subject of the biggest hostile takeover bid ever and a tottering construction company clamored for an old-style bailout.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOULTON, WILLIAM
description: HOULTON-William. Died on November 18, at Mount Sinai Hospital of pneumonia. He was the adored husband of the late writer Peggy Mann and is survived by daughters Betsy and Jennifer, sonin-law Kosmo Vinyl and grandsons Jack Atticus and Charlie Paris. He was treasured by many. We will miss you ''Une''. Wake will be at Walter B. Cooke, 117 W. 72 St., Sunday, November 21 at 2:00-9:00 PM. Funeral at Holy Name Church, 96 St. and Amsterdam Ave., Monday, November 22nd. at 9:45 AM.

title: TRACK AND FIELD; Steroid Test Is Positive for Prominent Opponent of Doping
description: Dieter Baumann, a former Olympic gold medalist known for his outspoken advocacy of tough doping policies, announced today that he had tested positive for the anabolic steroid nandrolone. According to German Athletics Federation regulations, Baumann will receive an automatic two-year suspension pending a hearing.

title: CALICO BUYING CONNECTINC.COM FOR $90 MILLION IN STOCK
description: Calico Commerce said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the ConnectInc.com Company for $90 million in stock, in a deal intended to strengthen Calico's e-commerce software. In the transaction, expected to close during the winter, Calico will issue 0.081 share for each ConnectInc share. Based on Calico's Thursday closing price of $67, the agreement values each ConnectInc share at $5.43, a 27.7 percent premium over ConnectInc's closing price of $4.25 Thursday on the Nasdaq. ConnectInc, based in Mountain View, Calif., provides software and services that connect buying and selling companies via the Internet. It had revenue of $4.9 million for the nine months ended Sept. 30. Calico, in San Jose, Calif., offers software that high-technology manufacturers, telecommunications services providers and financial services companies use to sell complex products online.

title: Kreis of Dallas Is Selected M.V.P.
description: Jason Kreis of the Dallas Burn became the first American-born player voted most valuable player in Major League Soccer yesterday.

description: It's one thing for a region to produce geopolitical tensions, civil war, colorful freebooters and outrageous hyperbole. It's quite another to generate a James Bond thriller.

title: Arnolds Sturms, 87, Composer and Music Critic
description: Arnolds Sturms, a New York-based composer, flutist and music critic, died on Nov. 7 at the Isabella Geriatric Center in Washington Heights. He was 87.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Rebuilding the Path to Peace in Northern Ireland
description: Although the outcome is far from certain, Northern Ireland is now on the brink of a durable peace. The British and Irish governments are set to announce today that they have accepted a plan to transfer power quickly from the British Parliament to the new Northern Ireland Assembly and to begin the process of decommissioning the arms of the paramilitary groups.

title: Balanchine by a Different Disciple
description: As a new venture, the chamber ballet troupe formed recently by Suzanne Farrell under the auspices of the Education Department of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts is off on the right toe shoe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGILL, MADELINE E. (NEE FITZGIBBON)
description: McGILL-Madeline E. (nee Fitzgibbon). On Nov. 18, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Frank McGill. Beloved mother of Michael, Kevin and Brian. Beloved grandmother of Jane, Timothy, Patricia, Daniel, Kenneth, Matthew, David, Maura & the late Michael. Beloved sister of the late Mary Reilly. Reposing at Park Abbey Funeral Home, 1430 Unionport Road, Bronx, NY, Sunday, 2-4, 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Monday, 10 A.M., St. Helena's Church. Interment Calvary.
