title: Higher Tolls Being Proposed For Turnpike In New Jersey
description: Tolls on the New Jersey Turnpike would rise significantly for the first time in a decade, but motorists who use the E-ZPass system or avoid peak hours would receive discounts, under a proposed capital program to be announced on Tuesday.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Havana Journal; Game Produces 28 Hits, And Political Home Run
description: Tension shot through the crowd as Fidel Castro confronted his latest international standoff. He huddled with his closest advisers and watched his Venezuelan opponents flick away the Cuban projectiles.

title: Low Wages Are Relative
description: To the Editor:

title: This Time, Forbes Chooses Subtle Over Slashing in Ads
description: For months, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has braced for a multimillion-dollar onslaught of attack commercials from Steve Forbes, his wealthy rival for the Republican presidential nomination. Finally, the first commercial has arrived.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, SAMUEL
description: KAPLAN-Samuel. At age 82 on November 18, 1999. Beloved husband of Florence for 58 years. Loving father of Judy and Stan Bass and Daya Kaplan. Proud grandfather of Jeremy Bass. He will be missed by all.

title: Caterpillar Shares Battered After Warning About Profit
description: Shares of Caterpillar Inc. plummeted 12 percent today after the company warned that fourth-quarter earnings would not meet expectations.

title: Microsoft Case Gets U.S. Judge As a Mediator
description: The federal judge overseeing the Microsoft antitrust trial named a mediator today in an effort to bring about settlement talks between the Microsoft Corporation and its accusers: the Justice Department and 19 state attorneys general.

title: Edmona Mansell, 70, Alcoholism Counselor
description: Edmona Lyman Mansell, who founded the Freedom Institute in Manhattan and was one of the first alcoholism counselors in New York to promote intervention as a treatment technique, died Nov. 11 at a hospital in Jupiter, Fla. She was 70.

title: Woman Hurt by Thrown Sign, Police Say
description: A Manhattan woman walking near Lincoln Center was injured yesterday afternoon by a parking sign that the authorities say was dropped or thrown from a pedestrian overpass that spans West 65th Street.

title: Just Imagine...
description: Over this past century, business has given us the car, the radio, the television, the personal computer, the jet, the trash compactor and shampoo combined with conditioner. Imagine that you could ask for one equally huge innovation in the coming centry, to improve your own lot or that of all mankind. What would you ask for? Send your ideas to Outlook 2000, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by e-mail to Outlook-2000@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: A Firefighter's Other Life In the Cooler World of Art
description: Jim Murray, a firefighter with Ladder Company 29 in the South Bronx, is seated in a nondescript office smoking a cigarette. A rotund cat sleeps on a nearby chair. Mr. Murray, in jeans and an F.D.N.Y. T-shirt, looks like a firefighter.

description: Debra Sue Richman and Jeffrey Alan Oxman were married last evening by Rabbi Robert Orkand at the Birchwood Country Club in Westport, Conn.

title: Clinton Signs Bill Giving More Options to Students in Capital
description: President Clinton has signed legislation that would expand academic options for graduates of public or private high schools in the District of Columbia by substantially reducing their tuition at state colleges in Virginia and Maryland and by offering grants for tuition at private colleges in the area.

title: A Village Here, a Village There. But Why?; An Inventory, and Brief History, of the Village of Croton Falls
description: THE center of Croton Falls, a hamlet in North Salem that owes much of its history to the railroad, has made the railroad the focal point of its biggest renovation.

title: The Art of Museum Shopping; In Ruins
description: What is more evocative of the British Isles than a castle ruin, particularly one inspired by John Constable's ''Hadleigh Castle, The Mouth of the Thames -- Morning after a Stormy Night,'' painted in 1829? The painting is part of the permanent collection of the Yale Center for British Art and was a gift of Paul Mellon, class of '29, in 1977.

title: Deborah Caul and Matthew Siegel
description: Deborah G. Caul, a daughter of Nadine Wagner of Dix Hills, N.Y., and Arthur Caul of Douglaston, Queens, is to be married today to Matthew S. Siegel, a son of Dr. Natalie Siegel and Dr. Sheldon Siegel of Indianapolis. Rabbi Gerald Serotta officiated at Oxon Hill Manor, a historic house in Oxon Hill, Md.

title: A Dreamscape of Millennial Fears and Hopes
description: THE public impact of the millennium has so far been pretty tame: anxiety over New Year's party plans and mild speculation about whether global computers will, indeed, hit a bump when midnight strikes is about as far as it goes.

title: For a Survivor, An Empty Calculus
description: To the Editor:

title: Iona Falters in the Second Half
description: The season began promisingly enough tonight for Tariq Kirksay, the player the Iona men's basketball team will be counting on to improve last season's 16-14 record.

title: Sharing Lives, Sharing Memories; A History of Sharing, At Home and on the Road
description: Michael and I met 28 years ago in New York. A year later, in San Francisco, we made up our minds to make a home together.

title: No Name, No Known Address, but His Identity Is in His Work
description: THERE are artists who stoke their careers, or try to, by networking -- being seen at the right openings, chatting up collectors and curators, and so on. Then there are those who do just the opposite, staying close to the studio and far from the scene. Those who play hard to get sometimes end up doing better than their go-getting colleagues.

title: They're the Very Best of Friends; Using a New Language To Write of Old Friends

title: Erin Spinello, David Socolow
description: Erin Marie Spinello was married yesterday to David Jacob Socolow at Holy Family Church in Lakewood, N.J. Msgr. Thomas Madden performed the ceremony.

title: All Aboard, With Extras; At the Station: Books, Coffee, Conversation -- and, Oh Yes, Trains
description: BUSINESS suits and briefcases? Yes, you'd expect to see those on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad. And it's not unreasonable to expect a station to have a shelter to shield commuters from the rain, and maybe even a place to buy a fresh cup of coffee.

title: Ready. Aim. Enter Your PIN.
description: High technology, society's elixir of the moment, has arrived with the promise of breaking the checkmate between gun-control advocates and Second Amendment purists. Both sides tout gizmos known as ''childproof,'' ''personalized'' or ''smart gun'' technology that could -- hypothetically -- reduce the number of shooting deaths. The gadgets range from decoder rings to voice-recognition devices. All aim to do basically the same thing: prevent an unauthorized user (a criminal, of course, but also a curious child or suicidal teenager) from firing a handgun.

title: Heading for a Record Low, Unemployment Rate Drops
description: The state's unemployment rate dropped for the fourth straight month, a decline that some say is likely to continue and result in the state's lowest jobless rate in history.

title: November 14-20; U.N. Takes Some Blame
description: Four years after the fall of the Bosnian town of Srebrenica, followed by a Serbian massacre of many of its Muslim residents, the United Nations issued an exhaustive report on the debacle, taking much of the blame on itself for trying to be evenhanded in dealing with the two sides in the civil war. But the report also laid the groundwork for the tragedy at the feet of the Security Council, led by the United States, which failed to authorize enough troops to defend Srebrenica or other ''safe havens'' in Bosnia.

title: November 14-20; U.S. Decides to Pay Up
description: The White House and House Republicans struck a deal to repay nearly $1 billion the United States owes the United Nations, ending a three-year battle that had begun to jeopardize Washington's vote in the General Assembly. The dues were freed after President Clinton agreed to a Republican demand to halt federal financing to international groups that promote abortion rights overseas.

title: Pets: From Adoption To Retirement Home
description: Say Roastbeef, your beloved bulldog, stops to slurp some antifreeze on his evening walk. Or Felix, your pigeon-coveting calico, slips out a window and down the fire escape in search of a feathered meal.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Why the Market Is Neutral On Research Spending
description: STUDENTS of the stock market have long worried that it does a poor job of valuing the long-term benefits of corporate research and development.

title: They Are the Very Best of Friends; Standing by Her, a Sister and a Sister in Spirit
description: TELL us about your best friends, we said. And you did.

title: DataBank: NOVEMBER 15-NOVEMBER 19; Russia Rides Coattails of Rising Oil Prices
description: Not so long ago, Russia was in a funk. Investors, troubled by a series of negative events in early September, sent the benchmark Russian Trading System stock index into a tailspin. But since then, the index has recovered nicely.

title: Hilary O'Rourke, William Wynperle
description: Hilary Kate O'Rourke, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael S. O'Rourke of Hartsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to William John Wynperle, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Wynperle Jr. of Great Neck, N.Y. The Rev. Divya Paul performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart.

title: In Good Times, Cosmetic Surgery
description: WHAT price beauty? For Iris Grosso, 54, a divorced office manager from Great Neck, it was $20,500, which covered the cost of the face lift she had in August and the tummy tuck and liposuction she had in September on her thighs, stomach and knees. That doesn't include the cost of removing the bags under her eyes and the brow lift she had in 1993, or the nose job she had at 16.

title: Tour of Quiet Monuments to Mortality
description: ''Farewell my friends and children dear

title: Friends?
description: IN THE FAMILY WAY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, ALFRED C.
description: LEVIN-Alfred C., Doctor of Obstetrics and Gynecology, age 75, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, on November 17, 1999, after a long illness. A close friend of 73 years. We will deeply miss his love of life and wonderful sense of humor. Our profoundest sympathy to his wife Corinne and other family members. Contributions in his memory to the Helen and Harry Gray Cancer Institute at Good Samaritan Medical Center, West Palm Beach, FL, would be appreciated by the family. Arnold and Beverly Franco

title: Basses Wild!
description: Let Ed Bass sponsor over-the-top environmental projects like Biosphere II. Lee and Ramona Bass, perhaps the most private members of a very private family, support more down-to-earth, even down-home, projects like parks and a zoo.

title: The Art of Museum Shopping; Lip Service
description: Amid the bewigged forefathers, Chippendale chests and Thomas Coles, is the current exhibit entitled ''About Face: Andy Warhol Portraits,'' which ends Jan. 30. All the icons are there: ZsaZsa, Greta, Jackie, Liz and of course, Marilyn Monroe.

title: Bidding for the Auctioneer Is Right Up Their Alley
description: Haven't seen enough of Meg Whitman, the high-profile chief executive of on-line auctioneer eBay? If profiles in Business Week, Glamour and Vanity Fair left you begging for more, maybe you should consider bowling. Earlier this month, Butterfield & Butterfield, the old-time San Francisco auction house that was recently acquired by eBay, auctioned off a bowling date with Ms. Whitman and two eBay employees.

title: Miss Schneider And Mr. Horowitz
description: Meredith Adine Schneider, the daughter of Sharon Schneider and Dr. Lewis Schneider of New City, N.Y., was married last evening to David Brett Horowitz, a son of Carol and Robert Horowitz of East Northport, N.Y. Rabbi Ephraim Z. Buchwald performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, N.Y.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS; Mightier Than the Pen?
description: NOVA'S ARK Written and illustrated by David Kirk. 40 pp. New York: Callaway/Scholastic Press. $17.95. (All ages)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, MARGUERITE PREWER
description: MARTIN-Marguerite Prewer. On Thursday, November 18, 1999 of Washington, D.C. Beloved wife of the late Williams Swift Martin, II. Loving mother of Lt. Col. Williams Swift Martin, III, Mary Vincent Martin and Ann Martin Calder. Also survived by nine grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Service will be held at Christ Church, Georgetown, 31st & O Streets, N.W., Washington, DC 20007 on Monday, November 22 at 2:00 pM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Christ Church, Georgetown.

title: Tiptoeing on the Campaign Trail
description: State Senator William L. Gormley, the would-be United States Senator from the Jersey Shore, has not been too distracted by his almost-announced campaign to give his all to an intensely local issue. For almost two years the senator has lobbied, hounded and shouted, and last week he got what he wanted: a Senate vote to kill the Whitman Administration's proposed restrictions on coastal development.

title: Hidden Risk That Science Saw
description: THIS wasn't supposed to be major-earthquake country. Floods, landslides, even the occasional volcanic eruption, perhaps. But there has not been a major quake in the Pacific Northwest since European settlers first arrived here, so few people in Oregon, Washington or British Columbia ever worried about the ground shaking.

title: Parents Blaming Parents
description: Lisa Belkin's was the most profoundly disturbing article I have ever read, not because of the sympathy it generated for the parents of the slain teenagers, but because of the empathy I felt for Michael Carneal. I believe wholeheartedly that Michael's parents did not ''raise a monster,'' but that they were unable to stop their son's peer group from turning him into a monster.

title: A Breeder Recalls the Majestic Dogwood to Life
description: ABOUT 30 years ago, Dr. Elwin Orton, a plant scientist at Rutgers University, set out to develop a dogwood that would be resistant to the borers that were devastating the American dogwood, Cornus florida.

title: Getting to Know the Sights and Sounds of DVD
description: IT'S odd about DVD. With three million players in use, the digital video disc has emerged as the fastest growing format ever, and that includes the audio CD and the videocassette. Yet, according to one industry study, 40 percent of the American public doesn't know what DVD is. ''My mother doesn't,'' said Karen Stetler, a producer at the Criterion Collection, a New York company that turns out DVD special editions at the high end of a market that is filling with thousands of titles.

title: Knights-Errant
description: Timeline

title: Bad to the Bone, Formal to the Brush: Bikers Done Up in Oil
description: Soon after turning 12, Helen Garber more or less ran away from home in the Five Towns area of Long Island and began living on the Lower East Side. She hung out at bars like King Tut's Wa Wa Hut on Avenue A, where she met drag queens, heavy metal musicians, club promoters -- and bikers. She was much taken with their dramatic, often outlandish appearance. And now she is working on a series of biker portraits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, HERMINA, M.D.
description: BENJAMIN-Hermina, M.D. On November 19, 1999. Beloved wife of Sasha Benjamin, M.D. Dear sister of Carole Spitzer. Loving aunt of Sorin and Vlad. Wonderful friend, wonderful colleague. We will miss you.

title: Retail Renaissance On Thompson Street
description: Sylvia Heisel, a designer of upscale women's evening wear and lingerie, opened her first store at 131 Thompson Street (between West Houston and Spring Streets) on Wednesday. Ms. Heisel sells her designs to boutiques across the country and had been thinking about opening a store ''for a million years.''

title: A Village Here, a Village There. But Why?; In Hastings-on-Hudson, the Way Things Were Collide With the Way Things Have Come to Be
description: GETTING home too late to pick up a prescription at Greenleaf Pharmacy here? Not to worry. Peter Capuano will leave it next door with Ruth or Sharon, the waitresses at the Center Restaurant. You can pay him anytime.

title: Farm-Zoo's Neighbors Seeking Compromise
description: In response to the article 'Farm-Zoo's Neighbors Cry Foul'' [Oct. 1] and the follow-up letter ''White Post Farm Is a Magical Place'' [Nov. 7], I feel that I must clarify my position on the proposed expansion of White Post Farm. I know I speak for many of my neighbors as well.

title: A Brittany Jewel Regains Its 17th-Century Luster
description: Visitors to Rennes in western France can now tour the grand halls of that city's newly restored 17th-century Parliament of Britanny building, which has functioned as a courthouse since the French Revolution.

title: Pick-Me-Ups, Pick-You-Ups; Escaping
description: Modern life can be exhuasting. You can't escape the phone, the fax, the beeper. A vacation would be nice, but by the time you have managed work schedules, children, baby-sitters, reservations, traffic and airports, the whole getaway experience seems more stressful than relaxing. There is an alternative: in a matter of minutes and with no advance planning, you can go far away without ever leaving your living room sofa. The Lightscape Relaxation System, billed as ''the total escape,'' screens out your surroundings and crates a fantasy sea of color and music.

title: Miss Egan, Mr. Malara
description: Beth Ann Egan, a daughter of Cathy and Thomas J. Egan of Mandeville, La., was married yesterday to Anthony James Malara III, the son of Mary and Anthony Malara of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas E. Chambers performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church in New Orleans.

title: Highway Information Signs Fail to Communicate
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEDESCHI, JOHN
description: TEDESCHI-John. Died November 5, 1999 of asbestos cancer. He was an employee of The New York Times for thirty-five years. He also worked in the Brooklyn Navy Yard and served on ships in World War II and Korea. He is survived by loving wife Josephine, beloved daughters Marie Kossman (John) and Pamela Callari (John). he was the devoted grandfather of Cara Kossman & Christine & Catherine Callari; dear brother of Joseph and Michael Tedeschi and sister Ann Marro (Ray).

title: A Century of Partnering by an Art and a Medium
description: THERE could be little argument that ''A Celebration of 100 Years of American Dance on Film'' was one of the most wildly improbable dance events of 1999. But the program also suggested profound changes in the nature of dance in America, and in the relationship between dance and the electronic media.

title: Reassuming a First Love: Italian Cuisine
description: THE lovely 140-year-old Italianate mansion at 1441 Old Northern Boulevard in Roslyn village is Italian once more. The last restaurant at this location was the Corral Steakhouse. It was part of a tidal wave of red-meat emporiums that recently swept the Island. But this one lasted less than a year.

title: Overbooked Children Aren't Being Helped
description: To the Editor:

title: Thumbing His Nose
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-17

title: Corrections
description: The Food column on Page 105 of The Times Magazine today, about Thanksgiving dinner, misspells the name of a historic site where one Wampanoag attends observances. It is Plimoth Plantation, not Plymouth.

title: Looking and Wishing
description: To the Editor:

title: Massachusetts Campus Tense After Attacks on Women
description: Emerging slightly dazed from an exam into the brisk early evening air, Sarah Shumaker was approached by three fellow students who offered to accompany her to her destination at the University of Massachusetts here. The conversation took place just yards from where a series of attacks on women had occurred in recent weeks. Two reported being raped.

title: There Can Be Art In Car Parts, Too: Take Muffler Men
description: MUFFLER men are the cigar-store Indians of the late 20th century, trade figures made to stand in front of shops to advertise what is sold inside. Both are considered forms of folk art, but the skinny metal figures with shimmering muffler heads and torsos and pipe-thin legs found outside auto repair shops are wittier, more imaginative and flamboyantly painted than the stolid carved Indians of yesteryear. Today's metal icons depict cartoon characters, space creatures, robots, cowboys, bikers, boxers, guitarists, devils and pop culture images like John Lennon and Uncle Sam.

title: A Village Here, A Village There. But Why?; All Angles, Dobbs Ferry's Charms Unfold in Its Lopsided Vistas
description: AT first, it looks bleak. Approaching downtown Dobbs Ferry from the north or east, you hit a drab intersection -- two gas stations, one abandoned car dealership and an interminable traffic light. (While waiting for green, I generally catch up on correspondence or read a few chapters of ''War and Peace.'')

title: Newtown Ends King's Controversial Reign
description: Newtown High School's soccer players jumped up and down around their coach, Howie Ranzer, yesterday, not knowing whom to hug next.

title: Paranoid Enemies
description: To the Editor:

title: Seminoles Reign Supreme in the Swamp
description: Forget lining up three different quarterbacks in fancy formations. Or the snazzy inside pitches to a reversing all-everything Peter Warrick. The Florida State Seminoles are heading to New Orleans and the national title game because they have a place kicker who can kick and a punt defense that can block punts.

title: Mr. Clinton Wins on Riders
description: A heartening feature of this year's budget struggle was the collapse of the Western Republicans' annual effort to load up the appropriations bills with last-minute riders designed to aid commercial interests at the expense of the environment. A few key Democrats, an energetic conservation lobby, a stubborn band of moderate Republicans -- all deserve praise for holding fast. But most of the credit belongs to President Clinton and his associates, who showed unusual consistency in sticking to earlier threats to veto any bill containing these measures.

title: Commercial Property/Connecticut; Leases of 23 of State's 31 Former Caldor Stores Sold
description: WHEN the Norwalk-based Caldor department store chain announced it was going out of business in January, bidders lined up almost immediately to buy the unexpired leases for the 31 stores it operated in its home state. So far, 23 have been snatched up by other major chains, and many have reopened.

title: The Impresario With 100 Heads
description: WHEN he isn't seating guests, Bruce Bozzi is slapping celebrities. In the last few months, in fact, he's slapped the faces of everyone from Matt Damon and Cameron Diaz to Helen Gurley Brown onto the walls of the newest Palm steakhouse, on West 50th Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue. The faces are drawn by Bronwyn Bird, an illustrator with an old-fashioned touch, and when the old-fashioned-looking steakhouse is empty in the mornings, Mr. Bozzi, whose family owns the place, walks around -- part curator, part child playing pin the tail on the donkey -- deciding where to put them.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Cathleen Croke, John Studdiford
description: Cathleen Margaret Croke, a daughter of Honora V. Croke of Norwood, Mass., and the late John J. Croke, was married yesterday to John Paul Studdiford, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Studdiford Jr. of Jamesville, N.Y. The Rev. Ronald A. Gomes, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Church in Norwood.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-21-99; The Jurors' Dilemma
description: While the jurors tried to figure out what, if anything, was going on inside Andrew Goldstein's head when he shoved Kendra Webdale to her death, we reporters stayed busy speculating on what was in the jurors' heads. Midway through the trial, during a lunch break, half a dozen of us were sitting around the courthouse press room eating our $3.50 tuna sandwiches from Lil's when a TV reporter cut right through all the expert psychiatric testimony. ''I'd vote guilty,'' she said. ''I'd want to make sure Goldstein goes away for a long time.''

title: Putting Children on Trial as Adults
description: To the Editor:

title: Send In the Clouds
description: SECTOR 7

title: Still Mourning, Latino Group Loses 2 Treasured Murals
description: Until recently, the most visible symbols of the 21-year history of the Charas/El Bohio Cultural and Community Center at 605 East Ninth Street were two large, colorful murals on the facade of the building. One tableau, painted by Freddy Hernandez in 1991, chronicled the founding of the center. The other, painted by Chico Garcia shortly after a Charas leader, Armando Perez, was murdered last April in Queens, depicted Mr. Perez smiling and raising a clenched fist. It bore the legend, ''I will give up my life before I give up this building.''

title: Online, or Else
description: The latest advice on cyber-etiquette: unplug your old office equipment if you're dealing with people who make their living from the Web. Brewster Kahle, chief executive of Alexa Internet, which he recently sold to Amazon.com for nearly $300 million, recently told the New York Infotech Forum that he communicates with his lawyers and accountants over the Internet, thank you. ''If they fax us anything,'' he warned, ''we look for a new one.''

title: Feet vs. Wheels
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Rangers Dig Deep To Rally, Then Lose
description: The only time the Rangers seem to play well is when they are desperately behind. Tonight, their desperate play led to an unlikely comeback from three goals down. But that was about the only satisfaction the Rangers could take out of another disappointing defeat.

title: Art Every Which Way but Straight Ahead
description: IN the old days, you turned left at Cezanne's ''Bather'' and proceeded, one gallery after another, until you hit Pollock, Pop and Minimalism, and that, pretty much, was that. The Museum of Modern Art, a primary author of the First Book of Modernism, laid down this history in neatly organized movements with the high points and patriarchs all clearly indicated.

title: Don't Let Those Sticky Seeds Get Around
description: THERE is more to fall cleanup than raking or blowing leaves away. Although such effort should have top priority to allow the green grass underneath to breathe.

title: Curiouser and Curiouser
description: ALICE'S ADVENTURES

title: They Are the Very Best of Friends; From Day One, Someone to Count On
description: TELL us about your best friends, we said. And you did.

title: Episcopal Health Files for Reorganization
description: Capping months of financial distress, Episcopal Health Services declared bankruptcy last week and filed plans for reorganization under Chapter 11.

title: Casting a Cold Eye
description: THE LIFE OF W. B. YEATS A Critical Biography. By Terence Brown. Illustrated. 410 pp. Malden, Mass.: Blackwell Publishers. $39.95.

title: Turning Marriage Into a Political Issue
description: State Representative Mark Anderson of Arizona, a conservative Republican, hears a different legislative drum.

title: Riding the Mo In the Lime Green Glow
description: The stock market opens and dave goehl immediately makes a $230 profit on 500 shares of eGroup, which he bought yesterday, by accident. Dave is buying and selling securities on the Nasdaq exchange in his shorts and a T-shirt from the convenience of his spare bedroom. ''It's the neatest thing in the world,'' he says. Taped to the wall in front of him is a list of his daily reminders: to trade 12,000 shares a day, to avoid sticking with losers for too long, to choose each transaction carefully. Dave reminds me, constantly, that ''trading is 99 percent emotional,'' and since trading stocks online in real time with lots of his own money is like roasting marshmallows on the Hindenburg, he must keep his wits about him. On the wall above his desk he reads No. 1 of his ''Top 10 Habits of a Successful Trader'': ''Be Disciplined: Discipline! Discipline! Discipline! Discipline! Discipline!''

title: The Women of Bosnia
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; The Hours That Make A Student an M.D.
description: THE young doctor was reminiscing about his first year out of medical school. ''I was chronically in a terribly nervous state,'' he wrote. ''Nearly every case disclosed to me more and more plainly the depth of my ignorance, my utter unpreparedness and incompetence.''

title: District Attorneys Are Providing Mutual Aid in Death Penalty Cases
description: When Heide Mason, an assistant district attorney, walks into a courthouse to prosecute a case, the setting is normally the sprawling, 11-story State Supreme Court building in downtown Brooklyn.

title: A Season For Seedy Hitchhikers
description: THERE is more to fall garden cleanup than raking or blowing leaves away.

title: Spots Where Dogs Are King
description: PITY the poor suburban pooch.

title: N.J. LAW; Measures on Executions And on Drunken Driving
description: Lawmakers met for voting sessions here on Monday. Here are some highlights:

title: Parents Blaming Parents
description: Your chronicle of the Shoels family and their public response to the tragedy serves to underscore how hollow and moot acrimony can be. I can't help feeling that people like Geoffrey Fieger fuel the fires of our blame-centered society and offer nothing constructive in the way of healing. The inference that the Shoelses' suit is not about money is absurd. Fieger's argument that automobile manufacturers are concerned about public safety only because of the threat of litigation cheapens the lives of the Columbine victims. Applying this logic implies that the only reason parents would raise their children not to kill others is because of their concern over being sued.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Books From The Times
description: For 20 years William Safire has conducted his weekly On Language column in The New York Times Magazine, issuing the products periodically in book form. The 11th such collection now appears as SPREAD THE WORD (Times Books/Random House, $25.95). The fruits of this crop include three series of the Bloopie Awards for careless advertising copywriters (among the guilty: ads for Rolex, Hofstra University, Honda, Ford and The Times Magazine itself). Brief histories are proposed for such onetime neologisms as ''factoid'' and ''pinchbeck''; new metaphors are sought to replace ''conservative'' and ''right-wing'' for references to Communist Party factions in Russia; Safire's slur patrol examines the status of ''hocus-pocus,'' ''Jesuitical,'' ''Talmudic'' and ''Philistine''; the vocabulary of Whitewaterese is analyzed in extenso; and in a note on rare and possibly toxic adverbs, the author himself employs ''danglingly,'' then speculates that he may be the first to use it since the Oxford English Dictionary entry of 1611.

title: Is There a Butler In the House?
description: HEN Mary Ellen Keating became engaged, she decided on a do-it-yourself wedding and immediately descended into six months of detail hell. How many New Yorkers, after all, have the time to fret over seating charts and apple tarts, twice-baked crab and Aunt Rose's taxi? So when Ms. Keating turned 40 two years ago, she did what any self-respecting New Yorker with more money than time would do: She hired a consultant.

title: For Tourists, the State Capital Is a City Full of Surprises
description: FOR the people who don't live in Hartford or in one of its many sprawling suburbs east or west of the Connecticut River, the state capital is a constellation of office buildings winking from the highway en route to a ski trip up north or a parking garage that spills out to a concert or sports event at its Civic Center or the paneled rooms of the Capitol itself.

title: Museums That Make the Most Of Their Space and Settings
description: THE major museums in Westchester may not have imposing entrances and lobbies, and their their cafes and bookstores, where they exist, are modest. But more often than not, what makes visiting them a rich, satisfying experience is that their directors and curators understand what kinds of presentations best fit their buildings and grounds.

title: Hong Kong Is Hoping Disney Magic Rubs Off
description: EVER since it was handed back to China in July 1997, this former British colony has worried obsessively about what it was going to become. Now, it has an answer: Hong Kong will be the next outpost in the Disney empire.

title: A New Tristan and Isolde In a Lustrous Lineage
description: AT the first American performance of Richard Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde,'' at the Metropolitan Opera on Dec. 1, 1886, every fall of the curtain was greeted by frantic applause. The Musical Courier reported ''a genuine enthusiasm which had thus far not been equaled in the musical history of the land.'' Henry Krehbiel, in The New York Tribune, considered the ''tenseness of attention'' to be ''almost painful.''

title: The Unapologetic Tourist
description: AT some point in my life, I'm not certain when, I became a tourist. Probably I've always been a tourist, though I never liked to think of myself as one. My travel was always for purposes more important than simple pleasure; that was my conceit. I wasn't one of those people shuffling through the monastic halls of the National Gallery or the Louvre, or dickering at Indian markets in Oaxaca. No, I went here or there to do serious work; a traveler, not a tourist. As a young foreign correspondent, it was the story I was after, not diversion.

title: Brahms Without the Usual Reserve
description: BRAHMS: THE VIOLIN SONATAS

title: Corrections
description: A credit was omitted on Oct. 3 for a picture from ''Tall Tale: The Unbelievable Adventures of Pecos Bill'' in Home Design, Part 2 of the magazine. The photographer was Melinda Sue Gordon.

title: Composers for the Common Man
description: AARON COPLAND, who died in 1990, must have winced a bit when, late in life, he found himself proclaimed America's greatest composer.

title: Hey, Mickey, 'Auld Lang Syne' Already?
description: FOR those who cried ''Premature!'' when New York City department stores hauled out the Christmas holly minutes after the last trick-or-treater made it home for doughnuts and cider, consider this: At Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla., New Year's Eve began on Oct. 1. That day, Mickey Mouse's giant arm holding an equally outsize ''Sorcerer's Apprentice'' wand, and an enormous glittering ''2000'' sign, transformed the huge silver sphere known as Spaceship Earth into a millennial icon.

title: The World: Battle Line; Russia Pines for a New Savior: Victory
description: JUST for a moment, imagine the corked-up fury of life in a failed superpower, a place where the government seems impotent and scandal-scarred; where the army is demoralized by defeat and incompetence; where the economy seems to rock between inflation and depression. Then imagine that Islamic terrorists from magnifying-glass specks on the map are blowing up your citizens, seemingly with impunity. If you lived there, it might feel good to hit back, too.

title: Cut Cannas, Start Holiday Paperwhites
description: Now that foliage has been burned by cold, cut cannas to three or four inches above the ground. Lift clumps carefully without separating rhizomes, and cure in a dry spot for a few days. Keep some soil on roots to prevent desiccation, and tuck them into blankets of barely moist peat in flat, covered boxes. Store at 40 to 50 degrees. Do not let peat dry completely.

title: The Art of Museum Shopping; Compass Points
description: One can go in many directions with the Compass Rose Bowl from Mystic Seaport. With ice in its bottom and shrimp on top, strawberries heaped to the rim, a pile of paper-clips at the ready, or simply the play of sunlight on the glass, the Rose Compass Bowl is both functional and decorative.

title: Pick-Me-Ups, Pick-You-Ups; Scooting in Style
description: Remember how much energy you had as a child? Recapture that feeling with a scooter - by far the coolest one on the block.

title: Rutgers Saves Its Worst for Its Finale
description: There was no anger afterward, only resignation. The Rutgers Scarlet Knights weren't fooling themselves today about the thoroughness of this defeat.

title: November 14-20; A Campus Accident Kills 11
description: The collapse of a giant wooden tower intended for Texas A & M University's annual football bonfire left 11 students dead and much of Texas in mourning. In a university steeped in traditions, the bonfire was one of the most revered, marking the annual football game against the rival University of Texas. The school canceled this year's Thanksgiving night bonfire, and officials planned to reconsider the event. JIM YARDLEY

title: If You Can Scrape It There, You Can Scrape It Anywhere
description: PITY the urban bumper, always getting pushed around. It gets scraped by cabs jostling for a head start; it gets whacked by drivers who parallel-park not by sight, but by sound. The battle scars are everywhere.

title: ART/ARCHITECTURE
description: THERE was a total eclipse of the sun on the day in August when Shirin Neshat began shooting her new film installation, ''Soliloquy,'' in the hill town of Mardin in southeastern Turkey. There was the lethal 7.4 earthquake on Aug. 17, the day after the final wrap, when this Iranian-born New York artist and her crew arrived in Istanbul for much needed R & R. In the days between, she was shadowed by sinister plainclothesmen, whether police or military, local or national, she never knew. Some of the film crew were jailed; passports were confiscated.

title: September, October  . . . December. Please!
description: T. S. ELIOT wrote that ''April is the cruelest month,'' but then he probably wasn't depending on the public schools to baby-sit his kids to get any writing done. For those of us who are, November is certainly in the running -- if not at the top.

title: Third Women's Title Is Won By a Brooklyn Grandmaster
description: Anjelina Belakovskaia of Brooklyn, a 29-year-old women's grandmaster, won the Interplay United States Womens Championship in Salt Lake City in September. This was the third time she has triumphed in this series, having tied for the title with Sharon Burtman in 1995 and taken solo first in 1996.

title: A Metropolis Made Great By Greed; New York Has a Credo, But 'You First' Isn't It
description: Most cities have a burnished story of creation, some hoary tale of heroism and principle that swells the chests of their citizens as they strut down historic streets past Starbucks and The Gap. Take Philadelphia; founded on the premise of religious tolerance, its very name evokes fraternal love.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: ONE GIRL

title: The Bad Guy
description: MILOSEVIC

title: Watches That Come Fully Loaded
description: If an expensive watch isn't accessory enough, some watches now come with accessories of their own.

title: Winter Dreams; Antarctica
description: The seasons turn somersault in Antarctica. But if November at the bottom of the planet is technically spring, why quibble? If reckoned by its ice, it will suffice.

title: The Nation: Thanks for Sharing; Focus Groups Sometimes Emphasize the Trivial
description: IN what has become an expensive ritual of presidential politics, the Steve Forbes campaign recently assembled about a dozen potential voters around a table in Iowa so they could kibbitz about his possible television commercials.

title: Police Have Few Clues in Brick Attack
description: Detectives began showing thousands of photographs of violence-prone criminals to six witnesses yesterday in an effort to identify the man who critically injured a 27-year-old Midtown office worker with a brick.

title: The Nation; Fear of Crime Trumps the Fear of Lost Youth
description: TO look at a photograph of Nathaniel Abraham is to search for the face of a child. Nathaniel, 13, was convicted last week for planting himself on a hillside in this Detroit suburb, shooting at a stranger walking out of a convenience store and killing him -- a crime he committed at the age of 11.

title: On the Road, Sign Language Can Be Hard to Understand
description: A first-time visitor to New Jersey is driving up from the south looking for the bright lights and tourist sights of the big cities: the State House in Trenton, the New Jersey State Aquarium in Camden, the Crossroads Theater in New Brunswick or the Newark Museum.

title: Borscht Belt
description: THE RUSSIAN

title: Ruth Kaplan and John Goodwin
description: Ruth Ellen Kaplan, a retailing executive, will be married today to John Daly Goodwin, the music director of the New York Choral Society. The Rev. Susanna Macomb, an interfaith minister, will officiate at the Mark Hotel in New York.

title: Democracy in Pakistan: Can a General Be Trusted?
description: This country's elite has been notorious for corruption, with some elected officials the most voracious at the trough. So it is tempting for Pakistanis to cheer on Gen. Pervez Musharraf, who took power in a coup five weeks ago. His new government has ordered the arrest of dozens of prominent wealthy people who supposedly finagled multimillion-dollar bank loans they had no intention to repay.

title: CHOKING ON GROWTH: A special report.; In Atlanta, Suburban Comforts Thwart Plans to Limit Sprawl
description: The builders of Georgia's epic new mall, a vast savanna of shopping on 100 acres, chose a precarious moment in Atlanta's history to open their doors a few months ago.

title: Yes, Traffic Is Bad Here, But It Could Be Worse
description: Drivers in the northern part of the state spend an average of 38 hours a year stuck in traffic jams, while those in southern New Jersey get stuck in bumper-to-bumper crawls 27 hours a year. As bad as that might seem, it is not as bad as Los Angeles drivers, who face 82 hours of delays a year, the most in the nation.

title: A Leather Band? Ho-Hum
description: This season, high-end watchmakers are making wrist-size fashion statements in materials that are a far cry from classic black calf or brown croc. Van Der Bauwede is running the gamut from tough to tender with its new bulletproof Kevlar bands (1) and delicate pastel linen straps (both $175). Last week, Baume & Mercier released its Catwalk watch (2; $1,250 at Tourneau) with a rubber and steel band made from car tires. Following the current trends for pashmina and pony skin, Bell & Ross is offering cashmere bands in black, camel and charcoal gray (3; $175), while Cartier has a line of faux pony animal-print bands in giraffe, cheetah, leopard, zebra and tiger ($55).

title: C. E. Odegaard, 88, Expert on Teaching Health Sciences
description: Charles E. Odegaard, who was president of the University of Washington during years when it expanded greatly, and was a nationally prominent expert on education in the health sciences, died on Nov. 14 at his home in Seattle. He was 88.

title: Why Insurers Shrink From Earthquake Risk
description: WHEN Dan and Priscilla Sandoval moved into their sprawling new home in the steep, maple-covered hills here a few years ago, they bought the usual homeowner's insurance coverage. But they decided to skip the separate coverage for earthquakes. Their budget was tight, and they figured the risk was not that great. Everyone knew that Portland was nothing like San Francisco and Los Angeles when it came to earthquakes.

title: They Are the Very Best of Friends; I Often Wonder Why All People Can't Be Like Elyssa
description: TELL us about your best friends, we said. And you did.

title: U.S. Deal on Caspian Oil Still Faces Problems With Bottom Line
description: For both financial and political reasons, the agreement to build a pipeline to carry Caspian Sea oil across Turkey, which the Clinton administration views as a strategic victory, is far from being a reality, oil executives and administration officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENNIS, SUSAN
description: ENNIS-Susan. Adored daughter of Madeleine. Loving companion of Alan Goldstein. Cherished sister of Jane Wilk. Devoted niece of Florence Dober. Loving aunt of Steven, Meredith and Robyn. Services today, 11:15 AM, at ''Gutterman's Funeral Home'' (Parkside Building), 98-60 Queens Blvd., corner of 66th Ave., Forest Hills, NY.

title: The World; One Giant Step For Mr. Jiang's China
description: ONLY a few weeks ago, after the uninspired 50th anniversary extravaganza for the People's Republic that equated President Jiang Zemin with Mao Zedong and Deng Xiaoping, Mr. Jiang became a victim of Beijing's merciless joke circuit. In stories told in quiet tea houses and at raucous dinner parties -- the nearest thing here to Jay Leno's monologues as an index of political fortunes -- Mr. Jiang was portrayed as lacking the vision and stature that this foundering country needs.

title: Jazz Clubs Come and Go but There's Always a Gig Somewhere
description: FOR 30 years Defemio's Restaurant in Yonkers was the center of the jazz scene in Westchester, a place where amateurs and professionals played side by side for casual listeners and aficionados several nights a week. So, when Al Defemio closed the doors of his business last January to start a hard-earned retirement, many people took it badly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORD, J. COUPER
description: LORD-J. Couper, 81. Of Southampton, N.Y. On November 17, 1999. Husband of Barbara Hartley, father of J. Couper Lord, Jr, MaryLouise Lord Gillespie, Barbara Lord Edwards and the late Ruth Lord. Grandfather of Hartley and Eleanor Gillespie, Lorrie, Caroline and Courtney Edwards. Funeral service 11AM November 27 St. John's Church, Southampton. In lieu of flowers contributions to St. Andrew's Dune Church, Box 1245 or St. John's Church, Box 5068, Southampton, N.Y. 11969 would be appreciated.

title: Robert Peck and Kristin Coveny
description: Kristin Chafin Coveny, a daughter of Linda and Richard Coveny of Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Stephen Peck, the son of Barbara and Robert Peck of Manhasset, N.Y. The Rev. Terence L. Elsberry performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADER, KENNETH ''KEN''
description: RADER-Kenneth ''Ken''. Passed away November 14, 1999, of Boca Raton, Florida, formerly of Merrick, Long Island. Loving husband of Cecelia ''Cis'' to whom he was married 61 years. Adored father of Linda (Gershon) Yarmack and Roger Rader. Cherished grandfather of Robert, David, Emily and Ian. For further information, Gutterman-Warheit, Boca Raton, Florida. Toll-free 1-800-992-9262.

title: Carpentry, Asian Style: Using Japanese Handaws
description: MOST Japanese tools, planes, hammers and chisels are similar in appearance and design to their Western counterparts. Japanese handsaws, however, are different from handsaws designed and manufactured by European and American toolmakers because they cut on the pull stroke, not the push stroke.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-21-99; What They Were Thinking
description: Bronx Zoo, August 1999

title: Liberties; Nuts or Guts?
description: ''Are you the Manchurian candidate?'' I ask John McCain.

title: A Quarrel and a Prayer
description: Yosl Rakover Talks to God

title: Durable Indeed
description: When Augustus Washington was born in Trenton circa 1820, no one could have guessed that he would have a solo exhibition at the Smithsonian Institution someday. (For one thing, it didn't exist yet.) Now, he does, celebrating one of the very few black daguerreotypists whose careers have been documented.

title: Footnotes
description: 1. Happy 74th birthday to Riley B. King, Sept. 16, 1999! Not even a hurricane with its Muddy Waters and Howlin' Wolf winds could stop assorted kids and grandkids (B.B. has 15 children by 15 different women) from sampling a guitar-shaped cake ordered specially from Grandma's Secrets: (212) 740-3177. Naturally, it was named Lucille.

title: Day 1
description: OFF TO SCHOOL,

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRACT, HAROLD M.
description: TRACT-Harold M. Of blessed memory. Passed away November 18, 1991. He was a truly noble man

title: Food; The Right Stuffing
description: Some American Indians detest Thanksgiving. The holiday is predicated on a paternalistic myth of civilized colonists deigning to break bread (or share johnnycakes) with the savages. But Earl Mills Sr., the chief of the Northeastern Wampanoag tribe, is sanguine about Turkey Day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATKIN, JOHN D.
description: ATKIN-John D. Of Darien, CT on November 11, 1999 at Stamford Hospital. John was internationally acclaimed in the boating business, both as a yacht designer and yacht surveyor. He was the son of William ''Billy'' and Dorcas Atkin. His father had started on a career of designing and building boats in 1906 and John shared his gift for yacht design, having his first design published at age 15. He worked for Luders Maine Construction and Consolidated, both companies were leading designers and builders of fine yachts. After serving in the U.S. Army Transportation Corps during World War II as Navigator and First Mate, John returned to the world of boat designing. He worked along side his father at Atkin & Co. until his father's death in 1962. John then carried on the business for three decades. For several decades, John and ''Billy'' Atkin provided Motor Boating magazine with a new design each month, along with commentary on how to build. These articles were published in the Motor Boating Ideal Series and are still actively sought after in the used and rare book market. John wrote numerous other articles and books on boats and boat design. He also served as a judge at the Classic Boat gathering at the Mystic Seaport for two decades. He is survived by his wife Patricia Atkin of forty-two years and three nephews. Pat Atkin continues Atkin & Co., sending plans worldwide. A memorial services is planned for January 8, 2000 at 11:00 AM at the Noroton Presbyterian Chapel, Darien, CT. Memorial gifts may be made in Memory of John Atkin to the ''Mystic Seaport, Boat Building Shop Endowment'', P.O. Box 6000, Mystic, CT 06355.

title: Stock Option Bonanzas Vs. Stagnant Paychecks
description: THIS is a story in search of an ending. The unemployment rate has fallen as steadily as a barometer announcing a storm. Employers struggle to find workers. The Federal Reserve raises interest rates in anticipation of inflationary pressures from higher labor costs. But those costs don't show up in the standard statistics. Yet they must be out there, so the search is on.

title: Ms. Mitchell, Mr. Littleton
description: Elizabeth Ardis Mitchell and Daniel Anton Littleton, musicians, were married yesterday at the Orensanz Center for the Arts in New York. The Rev. Leslye Noyes, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEAVY, EDWARD T.
description: LEAVY-Edward T. November 21, 1979. In ever loving memory. Your children and grandchildren.

title: They're the Very Best of Friends; Using a New Language To Write of Old Friends
description: TELL us about your best friends, we said. And you did.

title: Marty Markowitz and Jamie Snow
description: Jamie Snow and State Senator Marty Markowitz are to be married today. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik is to officiate at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Pick-Me-Ups, Pick-You-Ups; Sipping
description: It's cold. Your're dragging. Do you want yoru fix by caffeine or sugar? Either way, Starbucks Coffee can take care of you.

title: For Arthur Miller, A Past Recollected Gives Life Its Form
description: ARTHUR MILLER may be his own worst publicist. Even his mildest cautionary pronouncements on the state of the American theater tend to have the moral force of something lifted from the Old Testament. At the age of 84, still tall, lean and ramrod-straight, he has both the silhouette and the rectitude of a patriarch. There he stands, ever vigilant, watching over a society that, in his lifetime, has shown an increasing affection for the flawed, the trivial, the sentimental and, in particular, anything new that is instantly disposable. Remember the past, he insists, the past. The past is the present, and if there is no past, the present is without form or meaning, a murky gray chaos.

title: Parents Blaming Parents
description: I am deeply troubled by our attachment to the notion of blame. The tragedy is not undone, but the cycle of hate leading to actions that may move us to more blame is perpetuated.

title: Nancy Trespasz, David Blair
description: Nancy Clare Trespasz, the daughter of Carolyn and Walter Trespasz of Maplewood, N.J., was married yesterday to David Reston Blair, a son of Eloise and Jack Blair of Appleton, Wisc. The Rev. Anne Marie Porter, an interfaith minister, officiated at Turtle Bay Point in the Caneel Bay resort on St. John in the Virgin Islands.

title: Schools Make a Teacher
description: To the Editor:

title: BENEFITS
description: Aiding Cancer Research

title: November 14-20; Build a Better Mouse, and . . .
description: Is death inevitable? Biologists who study aging are beginning to suspect that the final curtain may at least be postponable. The raw material of living cells is very robust. It is just that the evolutionary forces that shape it have no incentive to make a mouse, say, live forever, when hawks, cats and disease will let the luckiest mouse survive for only a year or so.

title: Pay on Delivery
description: Natural childbirth, far from being the choice of ''control-freak parents,'' is really about a willingness to surrender control to the birth process itself. Birth is not just ''getting through'' the pain.

title: A 3-Year-Old Wins Red Smith Handicap
description: Monarch's Maze became the first 3-year-old to win the Red Smith Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday when he ran down Williams News in the homestretch to score the fourth victory in his last five starts.

title: Village Where Many Cuisines Combine
description: PORT CHESTER smells.

title: Melissa Slotnick, David Fertig
description: Melissa Lynn Slotnick, a daughter of Donna A. Slotnick and Barry I. Slotnick of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening in Greenwich, Conn., to David Robert Fertig, the son of Naomi Fertig and Dr. Joseph Fertig of East Brunswick, N.J. Rabbi Jacob Rubenstein officiated at the Hyatt Regency Greenwich.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 9 about efforts by the New York City Board of Education to attract licensed teachers referred incorrectly to 50 people working toward master's degrees in education from the City University of New York. Their tuition is paid by CUNY, with support from private foundations, not by the school board.

title: North Korea Opens a Door, but Not Necessarily Its Mind-Set
description: In the two months since it agreed to freeze its long-range missile tests in exchange for the United States lifting economic sanctions, North Korea has been swamped with inquiries from foreign companies, investors and trade groups seeking to do business there.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Long Island Web sites misstated the Web address for Massapequa Park. It is: http://ci.massapequa-park.ny.us/

title: What's in a Name? Lots of Corny Jokes
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: DREAMS AND DESTINIES

title: Hingis Dispatches Venus Williams And Faces Davenport in Rematch
description: On the crowded concourse at Madison Square Garden yesterday, the sound system blasted a saccharin Spice Girls soundtrack and the beading booth did a booming business decorating heads of all hues with the hairdo Venus and Serena Williams have made famous. The place positively pulsated to an up-with-women's-tennis beat.

title: On the Trail of Feathered Friends
description: I AM a secret bird-watcher. From November through March, I count the birds that come to my feeders, and write their names on a form provided by the Cornell University Feederwatch Project. Cornell ornitholgists, with thousands of forms coming in from bird brains all over the country, can figure out what birds are living where in the United States.

title: Pick-Me-Ups, Pick-You-Ups; Indulging
description: Maybe it's the name: ''Soul Re trieval.'' This package of deliciously self-indulgent body and beauty treatments is offered by the Epidavros Day Spa, which recently opened in Mount Kisco.

title: Coast-to-Coast Fireworks
description: THE United States seems keener than most countries to celebrate the new millennium in style: maybe the nation is wealthy and optimistic enough that big parties seem apropos. Whatever the reason, come Dec. 31, there'll be an outpouring of music, dancing, laser shows and fireworks, along with time capsules enough to keep archaeologists busy until the next millennium.

title: Ms. Eidlin, Mr. McCarthy
description: Lisa Beth Eidlin, the daughter of Howard Eidlin of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Marlene Eidlin, was married yesterday to Matthew Evan McCarthy, a son of Diane and Richard McCarthy of Bass River, Mass. Rabbi Roger Ross officiated at Troutbeck, an inn in Amenia, N.Y. The Rev. Neil O'Connell, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Streetscapes/Charles B. J. Snyder; Architect Who Taught a Lesson in School Design
description: AFTER angering preservationists with its treatment of some older schools, the New York City School Construction Authority is planning to survey its buildings to find out just what it has. The survey will undoubtedly focus on Charles B. J. Snyder, architect for city schools from 1891 to 1922, whose many designs include Erasmus Hall High School in Brooklyn and Morris High School in the Bronx.

title: Congressional Notebook; Cow and False Alarms Close Session
description: There is always a touch of zaniness surrounding the rush by Congress to get out from under its workload on Capitol Hill, and this year was no exception.

title: MOVIES: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: It's a matter of taking the bitter with the sweet when it comes to choice movies on television this week.

title: Winter Dreams; Moscow
description: Living in Moscow, whenever I walked about the city, I would start from Red Square, and, building up a street map in my mind, reorient myself back there. But one snowy day, distracted by recollections of snow in my native New England, I suddenly realized that my mental map had disappeared and that I was lost.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-21-99: On Language; Trope-a-dope
description: 'Comfortable in his skin'' was identified by Melinda Henneberger of The New York Times as ''the favorite phrase of admirers of . . . former Senator Bill Bradley.'' It appeared in a Howard Fineman article in Newsweek in July: ''He came off as a relaxed public man comfortable in his own skin,'' and Eleanor Clift used it a month later on Fox TV: ''The fact that he's more comfortable in his own skin is what makes him appealing.''

title: Ivette Greenblatt, Andrew Friedman
description: Ivette Andrea Greenblatt, a daughter of Ruth and Martin Greenblatt of Abington, Pa., was married last evening to Andrew Michael Friedman, the son of Gloria and Marvin Friedman of Brooklyn. Rabbi Bernard Frank officiated at the Academy of Natural Sciences in Philadelphia.

title: A Jazzy 'Twelfth Night' Gets a Second Chance
description: CAN a musical that bombed on Broadway be recharged in regional theater or on television?

title: The Best Illustrated Children's Books 1999
description: The illustrations on these pages have been taken from the Book Review's choices of the 10 best illustrated children's books of 1999. Since 1952, the Book Review has annually asked a panel of judges to make a selection from among the several thousand children's books published each year. The judges this year were Henrietta Mays Smith, professor emerita at the School of Library and Information Science, University of South Florida, Tampa; Gregory Maguire, a critic and the author of ''Confessions of an Ugly Stepsister''; and Lane Smith, an artist whose books include ''The Stinky Cheese Man: And Other Fairly Stupid Tales'' and ''Squids Will Be Squids.'' As a matter of note, Petra Mathers has been a winner three times before and Marjorie Priceman once before.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-21-99: Salient Facts: Extreme Injuries; Ouch, Dude
description: WHAT'S BLACK AND BLUE (OR TEAL AND MANGO) AND GOES BUMP-BUMP-BUMP-SNAP?

title: Paying the Price For Avoiding Japan
description: Just a couple of years ago, life was easy for managers of foreign stock funds. If they wanted to beat a common benchmark -- the Morgan Stanley Capital International Europe, Australasia, Far East index, or EAFE -- all they had to do was underweight holdings in Japanese stocks.

title: Byrne Drops Senate Bid and Endorses Corzine
description: Stressing party unity and pragmatism, Tom Byrne, a Princeton businessman and son of a former governor, withdrew his bid yesterday for the Democratic nomination to the United States Senate from New Jersey. He threw his support behind a rival candidate, Jon S. Corzine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, ANNA
description: ROSNER-Anna. Age 101, on November 18th, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Leo. Loving mother of Mildred and June. Adored grandmother of Stacy, Jeffrey, Wendy, Amy and Marcy. Cherished greatgrandmother. Anna had a long fruitful life and she will be deeply missed by all.

title: Todd Ries and Stacy Jones
description: Stacy Lorie Jones, a daughter of Sally and Christopher H. Jones of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to Todd Gessner Ries, a son of Suzanne and Geoffrey K. Ries of Spring House, Pa. The Rev. Robert Holum, a Lutheran minister, officiated at Luther Place Memorial Church in Washington.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-21-99: Word & Image; Comehither.com
description: So how come my television screen and newspapers are filling up with come-ons for dot-coms? Besides cars and telephones, the ads on ''Ally McBeal'' are pushing eToys.com and petstore.com and drugstore.com. Dot-coms flash on my screen between murders and disasters on the 11 o'clock news. Ads in The Times shout Yahoo and Excite and eBay and E*Trade and ask me to think AltaVista every time I dream of Michelangelo's ceiling.

title: November 14-20; General Pays a Price For Adultery
description: In its most severe punishment to date for adultery, the Army stripped a general of his two stars and forced him into retirement as a colonel for having affairs with the wives of two subordinates. Maj. Gen. John H. Maher 3rd, who had been a vice director for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, was demoted following an administrative hearing in Georgia where the general was found guilty of conduct unbecoming an officer. The cost is high: with the demotion, General Maher's annual pension will be reduced by $18,000. ELIZABETH BECKER

title: A Web Site Aims At the Corporate Gift Market
description: A gift-giving Web site geared for the corporate market, www.camdens.com, made its debut in September. Featuring traditional gifts like pens ($50) and picture frames ($65-$500), as well as more modern items like handmade wooden computer keyboards ($400), monitors ($3,300) and wireless mice ($275), Camdens also plans to offer trips to spas, golf courses and the Egyptian pyramids.

title: BUSINESS; Point and Click: Interactive TV Is Poised for a Prime-Time Run
description: LIKE millions of other Americans, Tim Tainter likes to play along with the contestants on ''Jeopardy,'' the syndicated game show. Unlike most viewers, however, he uses his Microsoft WebTV remote control to click on multiple-choice answers that appear on his screen along with the live telecast.

title: Home Port Project Stalls, But Zoning May Hold a Key
description: A routine hearing by the City Council's Committee on Economic Development was winding down last Monday when the chairman, Jerome X. O'Donovan, remembered he had one last question for Mike Carey, the president of the city's Economic Development Corporation.

title: For a Survivor, An Empty Calculus
description: To the Editor:

title: Using Stone, Man and Nature Reshape the Landscape
description: ASK the owner of a new Greenwich mansion which is the best stone wall in Connecticut and the answer will probably be ''mine.''

title: Backtalk; Baseball (When All Else Fails)
description: At a tony Manhattan private school for boys last week, the headmaster, a Brit, confided that even after many years here he was still desperately struggling to understand baseball. Could he ask a rudimentary question? I nodded politely and tried to remember if the infield fly rule had been rescinded or if the strike zone had been relocated again.

title: Marbury's Attitude Rubs Some the Wrong Way
description: While the Nets ran through plays at their shoot-around before Friday night's game against Boston, Stephon Marbury pointed at Keith Van Horn and told the power forward to set a screen for him. Van Horn replied that the play did not call for a screen, but Marbury said to do it anyway because it would loosen up the offense.

title: Voters Draw Blanks On a Bush Pop Quiz
description: An update . . .

title: Funny Faces
description: Watch fanciers should expect to find some new faces in the crowd this fall. If you can't turn back time, at least you can turn it over with Cartier's Tank Basculante ($2,400 to $11,200), which sports a rectangular face that flips around to a solid gold or steel panel. Originally created in the 1920's to protect the watch crystals of polo players, the model has been reintroduced for the turn of the century; a special millennium Tank is engraved on the back with the dates 1999, 2000 and 2001.

title: Getting Inside the Head for a Portrait of Evil
description: FROM ''Next of Kin'' in 1984 through ''The Sweet Hereafter'' in 1997, Atom Egoyan has made impeccably controlled films, often on the theme of people's desire for control. So how did he feel during the shooting of his new movie, ''Felicia's Journey,'' when Satan seemed to turn up on screen in place of the expected Bob Hoskins?

title: Land, Wealth and Power Within Shinnecocks' Grasp; Tribe Debates Pursuit of Territorial Claim
description: WE grew up chasing trespassers off our land,'' said Margo Thunder Bird, a 47-year-old Shinnecock Indian who lived in Riverhead as a child but spent her summers at the Shinnecock reservation in Southampton. ''That's how we made our political goals as children. We would throw stones at them and tell the non-Indian people to get off our land. We would say, 'You can't be here. This is Indian land.' Our grandmother raised us. She applauded our efforts.''

title: The Clutter In the Car Stops Here
description: ON most days, Don Storholm, an unpretentious 60-year-old who wears a Mickey Mouse watch, does business out of his car. For 27 years, he has made a comfortable living estimating costs for construction projects in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area, using his mobile office as a base.

title: Hollywood Filmmakers Pass on the Year 2000 Peril
description: Just as the public has grown increasingly complacent about the Year 2000 computer problem, along comes ''Y2K,'' the movie. The made-for-television thriller, which will be shown on NBC on Sunday night, features just about every scary scenario envisioned by the Year 2000 doomsayers: blackouts, cash and food shortages, plane crashes and nuclear meltdowns, to name just a few.

title: Parents Blaming Parents
description: I have the utmost sympathy for the horrifying loss that the Shoels family suffered. And it is an added horror that the final words their son Isaiah heard were a racial slur. But does that alone make Isaiah's death more egregious than the deaths of the other victims? All of the victims' families suffered, and suffered equally, the death or maiming of a loved one and the shattering of hopes and dreams for their futures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRLICH, STANLEY L.
description: EHRLICH-Stanley L. Of Short Hills, NJ. On Friday, November 19, 1999. Husband of the late Phyllis Dettelbach Ehrlich. Survived by son, David Ehrlich and his wife Joanne, and grandson Alexander. Memorial service at Smith and Smith (Suburban), 415 Morris Avenue, Springfield, NJ on Sunday, November 28, at 1PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Overlook Hospital Foundation, PO Box 220, Summit, NJ 07902-0220.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Hockey Arena Raises Hopes of a Livelier Trenton
description: CITY officials are hoping that the 8,000-seat minor-league hockey arena opened in Trenton last month will move the state capital another step forward in its revitalization effort.

title: The Whats and Ifs Of the Electoral Votes
description: So if the polls are bouncing around, most voters aren't paying any attention and Election Day is still 50-odd weeks off, what's the score at this point, the real score, as in Electoral College votes, the only votes that count when all is said and done?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADY, MARGARET VIGGIANO
description: BRADY-Margaret Viggiano. On November 18, 1999. Beloved mother of Helen Walsh. Devoted grandmother of Joseph, Anna and Matthew Walsh. Retired detective of the NYC Police Department. Interment private.

title: Winter Dreams; Vermont
description: Instead of a January thaw last winter, the remote border country of Vermont's Northeast Kingdom was hit by a ''Canadian Thaw'' -- three feet of snow and a hell of a blow, in local parlance. One sunny morning a few days after the blizzard, I drove north 10 miles from my home in Irasburg to Lake Memphremagog, where I planned to spend the day ice fishing.

title: Nassau Patronage Jobs: A Hot Potato for Gulotta and the Democrats
description: NO sooner were the votes tallied in Nassau County's stunning election upsets this month than people were already angling for new patronage possibilities.

title: Glen Cove Still Suitor for Foxwoods Ferry
description: FIRST came the 1998 announcement that the operators of the Foxwoods resort in Connecticut planned a high-speed ferry service connecting the casino to Glen Cove, with a second, commuter-oriented route between Glen Cove and Manhattan. Then, this year, came word that the casino operators had gotten a better offer from the owner of waterfront property in nearby Glenwood Landing.

title: An Old Industrial City Turns to Entertainment
description: THE reproduction of a British Navy frigate from the Revolutionary War, H.M.S. Rose, was scheduled to return to Black Rock Harbor in Bridgeport for the winter on Nov. 10, but it arrived Nov. 1 instead. ''It's a sailing ship,'' said Kaye Williams, the owner of Captain's Cove Marina, which is H.M.S. Rose's home port. ''That's the kind of schedule it keeps.''

title: The Art of Museum Shopping; Deck-Osaurus Rex
description: Trim your tree with a T-Rex.

title: Remembering the Boys Who Tended the Mules on the Canal
description: The Mule Tenders Barracks Museum in Griggstown, a section of Franklin Township, sits at the midpoint of the 44-mile-long Delaware and Raritan Canal, which ran from Bordentown to New Brunswick when it was in operation from 1834 to 1932.

title: FIRST PERSON; On a Big Stage in a Cozy Bar
description: DAVID GRINSTEAD said I should call you,'' said the fact checker from Saveur magazine over the telephone. It was January 1997 and David had written an article about the last night of the Blue Bar at the Algonquin Hotel. I answered the man's questions, corroborating details in what I hoped was an even-sounding voice. ''Well,'' I thought to myself, ''The good news is, his career is going well.''

title: EVENING HOURS
description: Welcoming art and a book, and benefiting actors and restoration.

title: A Village Here, A Village There. But Why?; For Many in Mamaroneck, It Is Still the 'Place Where We Gather'
description: THERE has always seemed to be a certain nobility to this village. As a boy growing up here, that is what I thought. Possibly it was because legend had it that George Washington had slept in Mamaroneck. We knew the exact spot, in fact -- on the corner of the Post Road and Orienta Avenue where the old Washington Arms stood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOLPE, EMANUELE
description: VOLPE-Emanuele. Mass of Resurrection, Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 145 West 46 Street, NYC, Monday, Nov. 22, 1999 at 6 PM.

title: Egypt
description: At the Great Pyramids of Giza, Egypt intends to steal a beat on the sun. At midnight, a helicopter will lower a gold cap atop the Pyramid of Cheops, so laser light bounced off it bathes the plateau in a golden glow -- a first taste of the new dawn. It is a spectacle that its planners expect to be broadcast live to television viewers around the world.

title: L.I.R.R. to Modify Horn Levels on Diesels
description: After months of complaints about shrill and excessively loud horns on its 46 new diesel locomotives, the Long Island Rail Road will modify the horns to reduce noise.

title: The Worst of Times
description: Reflections on a Ravaged Century

title: Battered Grant Wins With Late Knockout
description: Michael Grant, a coddled young heavyweight with a burnished media image, earned his heavyweight stripes here tonight -- the hard way. After getting battered over nine rounds by a battle-hardened Andrew Golota, who knocked down Grant twice in the first round, Grant stunned Golota in the 10th round with a devastating right hand and followed that with a blistering combination that sent Golota reeling to the canvas and brought a quick end to the bout.

title: A Winning Merlot
description: Louis Caracciolo, an owner and the winemaker at Amalthea Cellars in Atco, Camden County, has long displayed a knack -- some might say a gift -- for red wines.

title: More Fired Workers Are Suing for Stock Options
description: WHEN Charles E. Knox was terminated from his job in middle management at Microsoft in 1995, he sued the company, accusing it of breaching his employment contract. He asked for not only the usual lost salary, but also the worth of his options. A court awarded him $650,000 but denied him the value of any options.

title: Watching What the Army Teaches
description: Bowing to criticism and pressure, the Army is finally moving to reform a training academy that should preferably be closed -- the long-notorious School of the Americas. Established in 1946 to befriend and tutor members of the Latin American military and train them in the virtues of democratic civilian control, over the decades it became an instrument of American cold-war policy, providing training for fighting and interrogating leftist guerrillas. The school became far better known for the dictators and thugs it graduated than for any good works done. The drug-dealing Gen. Manuel Noriega of Panama was an alumnus, as were the Guatemalan colonel linked to the killing of an American innkeeper in 1990, 19 of the 26 soldiers who murdered a group of Jesuit priests in El Salvador in 1989, and the late Roberto D'Aubuisson, who reputedly organized many of El Salvador's death squads.

title: Who Are We? Nuts and Bolts; No Sunbeams
description: WHAT is this thing called Connecticut?

title: Ideas & Trends; If a Poll Falls in the Forest and No One Hears It ...
description: THERE was lots of news on the campaign trail last week, from Governor George W. Bush's foreign policy debut to new polls in New Hampshire showing a tightening horse race in both parties. But is anyone paying attention, beyond the rapt little world of journalists, consultants and political groupies?

title: Results for Suffolk County's Fourth and Eighth Graders
description: Students in Suffolk County outperformed their counterparts across the state on state fourth and eighth grade tests released earlier this month, but lagged behind their more affluent counterparts in Nassau County.

title: Lopes's Path Blocked By the Usual Excuses
description: Why was Davey Lopes unable to secure a manager's job until now? Let him count the ways.

title: It Takes a Village To Make an Office. Ask Mother Merck.
description: IF you worked at the Merck & Company headquarters here, during a day at the office you could leave your car for an oil change, drop off your dry cleaning and pick up laundered shirts, order a birthday cake, buy a baby gift and wrapping and have the package sent, take care of banking and ask the travel service to set up your vacation. On the way out you could rent a video and stop at the bakery, picking up dinner and a fresh baguette to take home.

title: The World; Triumphant, The Left Asks What Else It Is
description: AS leaders of the center-left parties that govern much of the Western world gather in resplendent Renaissance palaces in Florence this weekend to ponder the course of the fuzzy but resonant political idea some of them call the ''third way,'' sharp differences are evident as to what social democracy in the post-cold-war world should be.

title: A Storied Vaudeville Theater Shuffles Off the Stage of History
description: The Jefferson Theater, a landmark of vaudeville history, has gone the way of vaudeville itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENOVESE, ALFRED M.
description: GENOVESE-Alfred M. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Alfred M. Genovese, associated with The Times from 1966 until retiring in 1981.

title: House Master
description: Rostenkowski

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: State Picks First Sites For Open-Space Plan
description: Repair and purchase of battlefields, city playgrounds and greenbelts are among the first $86.5 million in spending recommended for $1.6 billion in open space bond money approved by voters last November.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANSKY, SANFORD
description: DANSKY-Sanford. Loving husband of Rita. Adoring father of Julie and father-in-law of Craig Hazen. The most wonderful Pop-Pop in the world to his grandson Mick. Devoted brother of Ilene Lasker. Decorated WW II fighter pilot with the Flying Tigers. You're missed beyond words and will live in our hearts forever. Memorial service Sunday, 2:00 PM, Plaza Memorial, 91 St. at Amsterdam Ave.

title: Carla Stanmyre, John McDonald
description: Carla Elizabeth Stanmyre and John Thomas McDonald were married last evening at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York. The Rev. Daniel T. Davies performed the ceremony.

title: Condo to Let: Checking It Out
description: SALLY SWEET, who owns Wise Vacation Rentals in Killington, Vt., cleanly identifies the core of the issue. ''When 14 people rent a vacation condo,'' Ms. Sweet said, ''they pick one person to do the work, and that person wants to be a hero when they all arrive.''
