title: Pick-Me-Ups, Pick-You-Ups; Strolling and Seeing
description: For those who prefer a real-world escape, one of the most uplifting spots in Westchester is the Pepsico Sculture Garden. Some 45 works of art are displayed among 112 acres of garden at the corporate headquarters of Pepsico in Purchase. Artists include Rodin, Mir'o, Henry Moore, Louis Nevelson and Claes Olden brug.

title: A Trail That Doesn't Take a Mouse to Follow
description: WHAT I wanted was some bread. Not just any bread, but a suitable accompaniment for the tart but delectable slice of cheese I had sampled at Auray Cheese Shop in Larchmont.

title: A Violinist Still Full Of Ideas
description: IT happens even to world-famous musicians: reaching a milestone age, they ask themselves whether they have exhausted the limits of their ambition. Some never do.

title: Q & A
description: Bird-Watching in Rio

title: Man Against Nature, And Nature Is Winning
description: Man and nature are in a turf war.

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: HEALTH CARE ON THE ROAD

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS; Children of the Ink
description: A STRAW FOR TWO By Eric Sanvoisin. Translated by Georges Moroz. Illustrated by Martin Matje. 40 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $9.95. (Ages 8 and up)

title: Cafe That's Like a Living Room of Hipsters
description: THE local musicians started milling around the Common Sense Cafe about an hour before show time on a recent Saturday night.

title: Amy Olsen, Stephen Hess
description: Amy Foster Olsen, the daughter of Roberta and David A. Olsen of Lakeville, Conn., was married yesterday to Stephen Taylor Hess, a son of Mary and John J. Hess of Glen Ellyn, Ill. The Rev. Amy E. Richter performed the ceremony at St. Chrysostom's Episcopal Church in Chicago.

title: Professor Sees a Toy, Then Invents Game
description: DONALD GREEN remembers beating his father at chess when he was about 6 or 7.

title: Get Rodriguez
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Van Allen Belt's The Limit, It Seems
description: Space tourism will materialize faster than most people think, with short flights as soon as 2004 and extended visits possible within 20 years, British travel agents were told last week at a conference.

title: Mephisto Tennessee Waltz
description: THE LONG HOME

title: The Quieter Side of a Mighty Ancient Culture
description: WHAT does Camden have in common with New York and Boston? All three cities are currently offering opportunities to become better acquainted with the ancient people of the Nile. But unlike the operatic extravaganzas at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Manhattan and the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, ''Women of the Nile,'' at the Stedman Gallery on the Rutgers campus here, is a delicate whisper. The New York and Boston blockbusters primarily deal with powerful male rulers. In contrast, the exhibition in Camden highlights, as the catalog states, the ''long-lost voice of Egyptian women.''

title: Museums That Let the Senses Expand
description: BROOKLYN may have a show titled ''Sensation,'' but memorable sensations with more nuance may be experienced by a regular visitor to museums and galleries in Connecticut. From show to show, an exhibition space is usually changed in some way. Sometimes, though, the transformations are astonishing.

title: Two Choices for a Phantom Street: Store or Homes
description: Nearly every map of Brooklyn, from official city charts to the Hagstrom Atlas, treats 58th Street between Flatlands Avenue and Avenue J as a roadway just like any other. But the block is not like other streets. In fact, it is not a street at all, just a vacant lot.

title: Elliott M. Sanger, 77, a WQXR News Producer
description: Elliott M. Sanger Jr., a news producer for WQXR, the radio station owned by The New York Times, and a corporate relations executive for The New York Times Company, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 77.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANKS, ROBERT DOUGLAS
description: DANKS-Robert Douglas. Died November 18, in Palm Beach, FL, at the age of 97. Founding Partner of Ernst and Co., and former Governor of the New York Stock Exchange. Fomrer resident of Rye, NY. Beloved husband of the late Anne Danks. Survived by his wife Gil and daughter Evelyn Corbetta of Darien, CT. Devoted grandfather of Jane Yezzi, Maryann Cousins, Allison Radin, Robert and Richard Corbetta. Also survived by eight great-grandchildren. Family will receive friends Monday, November 22, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Post Rd., Rye. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10 AM, Resurrection Church, Rye. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

title: November 14-20; New Round in A.T.M. Wars
description: Banks won a victory in their effort to stamp out a spreading uprising against fees charged for use of automated teller machines. A federal judge in California, saying such regulation is the purview of the federal government, blocked San Francisco and Santa Monica from enforcing the nation's first two local laws banning such surcharges. But with the fees having touched a public nerve, the issue is not likely to die. For example, Peter Vallone, the New York City Council speaker, said he intended to press ahead to enact a similar ordinance. ANDREW POLLACK

title: More Pay Phones? No Thanks
description: While some New Yorkers clamor to have pay phones installed on sidewalks, others fight just as hard to keep the phones out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMERMAN, BERNARD
description: HAMMERMAN-Bernard. On November 19, 1999. Born July 15, 1923. Devoted son of the late Louis and Rose Hammerman. Loving husband of Joan. Father of Darcy (Allen), Brett (Diana) and Robert (Wendy). Adoring grandfather of Harley, Jeremy, Sloane and Maris. Precious brother of Ben (Lorelei), Goldie (Norman), David (Sarah) and the late Hyman (Florence). Caring uncle to his nephews and nieces and their children. Bernie was a purple heart veteran of World War II. At the end of 1945, with his brothers, he started the family business which proudly continues. With the passage of years, Bernie forms a multitude of friendships with reciprocal loyalties. He was generous of spirit and substance. He lived his life by the Golden Rule, with great pride in his heritage. He was respected and loved by all of his friends, employees and family. We are all truly bereaved and pray that we may find solace in his blessed memory. Services, Sunday, November 21, 12:45 PM, Riverside Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. The Hammerman Family

title: A Talent for Characters You Love and/or Hate
description: IT must be harder than hitting a double bank shot for an actor to play a moment in which his character is at once so repellent yet so lovable that the audience wants both to turn away and to offer the character a great big hug (or if not a hug, then the name of a good therapist).

title: Pay on Delivery
description: After being strapped down, drugged against my will and cut up (''Caesarean'' is an offensive euphemism) for no other reason than the doctor's impatience, I made damn sure to work with midwives the next times around and had two beautiful, four-hour birthings -- one in a hospital and the last at home surrounded by friends and family. And yes, it hurt. And yes, both experiences empowered me in so many ways that I couldn't begin to count them. And I say this 8, 13 and 17 years later.

title: Pay on Delivery
description: If Margaret Talbot is suggesting that women who enter the hospital with a clear birth plan and seek natural childbirth are often viewed, in her words, as ''control-freak parents,'' she is right. The medical profession has always been scared of patients who are well informed and speak up for what they want. Especially women.

title: New Obstacle Seen as Ulster Is Given Date Of Home Rule
description: Britain today put in motion plans to start up the new Northern Ireland government under the freshly revived Ulster peace agreement, but immediate progress was halted by a dispute between the rival Ulster Unionist and Sinn Fein parties.

title: At the Station: Much More Than Trains
description: HARDLY anyone likes to commute, but what if your train station had valet parking or especially smooth coffee at the concession stand? What if the station building was a historic landmark or if there were stunning river views from the platform? Would any of those features make a difference?

title: Maybe E-ZPass Will Help On Parkway, Starting Dec. 1
description: The Hillsdale and Paramus toll plazas on the Garden State Parkway will begin using the E-ZPass toll system, beginning Dec. 1. It will expand plaza by plaza north to south, and officials say all plazas will take E-ZPass by mid-2000.

title: A Rock Comedy Without Punch Lines
description: LAUGHTER is the immediate response to most of the songs on Beck's sixth album, ''Midnite Vultures'' -- so much so that it could be called a comedy record. But it's a comedy record in the sense that intelligent directors make comedy films: it's one big aesthetic disposition, rather than the series of bulletlike jokes on what are commonly called comedy records by the likes of Adam Sandler and Chris Rock. ''Midnite Vultures'' is funny without making actual jokes. (It's last track, ''Debra,'' is the only song with something resembling a narrative.) Beck has a pitch-perfect ear for pop-music convention, but ''Midnite Vultures'' presents a kaleidoscope of folly; it doesn't stand still long enough to make single punch lines.

title: Two Old Pals, Still Trying to Make It After All
description: THE night view stretches forever from the terrace of the 16th-floor duplex on Central Park West. Inside, it's the proverbial telephone booth. In the center of a room about 20 feet square, Mary Tyler Moore practices throwing her left hook while she, Valerie Harper and a film crew patiently work around one another, setting up for the next scene. Space is tight, but this is ridiculous. Is there room for the camera? Furniture is removed. Lose the couch.

title: A. Fanfani, Italy and U.N. Leader, Dies at 91
description: Amintore Fanfani, who was prime minister of Italy six times and President of the United Nations General Assembly in the 1960's, died today after a long illness. He was 91.

title: Close Encounter on Fifth Avenue
description: THE SETTING -- There were no U.F.O. sightings at a forum last Tuesday evening on alien abductions, but universes were definitely colliding.

title: Saving Comes First
description: To the Editor:

title: Staying Upbeat About Stocks
description: Optimism among financial advisers about United States stocks has risen for a fifth consecutive week, climbing to its highest point in more than three months, according to a survey by Investors Intelligence, a newsletter in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-21-99: The Ethicist; Bad Boys On the Bus
description: I board a bus in which three young men are engaged in loud and vulgar conversation. As their talk turns more violent, some passengers move away. The young men begin taunting other passengers with racial slurs. After a few more stops, they approach an elderly woman and demand her purse. She refuses. A few more insults and they leave the bus. The driver remains silent throughout. At what point are you compelled to intervene? Complicating matters, I am white, the young men are African-American and the slurs are directed at people of Asian descent. /J.C., San Francisco

title: Mixing a Cocktail of Disconnected Partygoers
description: IT was late last month, a week before the first preview of the Broadway revue ''Putting It Together,'' a collection of Stephen Sondheim songs, and Carol Burnett was still figuring out how to tug Ruthie Henshall's earrings off.

title: Proselytizers for a Culture That Sells Itself
description: ON a recent warm afternoon, a crowd of lively boys and girls make their way along West 89th Street in Manhattan to the homey headquarters of Ballet Hispanico. With their book bags heavy with dance gear, they jokingly try out ballet moves to the loud salsa pouring from an open window.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS; It's a Crumby Job
description: TOUGH COOKIE Written and illustrated by David Wisniewski. Unpaged. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard Books. $16. (Ages 6 and up)

title: Groton Area Is Rich In History and Nature
description: THE small cities of New London and Groton, in southeastern Connecticut, find themselves living in the shadows of two enormously popular Indian casinos.

title: Widowed Young, Grieving Long
description: PEOPLE look at me and think I'm functioning, but I'm not really here, I'm just a shell,'' said the woman. She is 50, a teacher who lives in Manhattan with her two teenage sons. Her half-life began, she said, when her husband of 25 years died more than a year ago.

title: VIEW; Hey, Yale, Can This Be My College Essay?
description: IT is a few weeks before my 17th birthday and I am in New Haven standing on Hill House Avenue in the shadow of the Yale admissions office. On this humid Friday morning in late July, the campus feels deserted, but I am not alone. Scores of cars filled with nervous Yale applicants and their grim-faced parents appear on the tree-lined street. Our group crowds the admissions office lawn. We stare at each other warily. Soon our tour guide joins us, introducing himself as Mike. ''I'm from San Francisco,'' Mike says. ''I love it here at Yale.''

title: Governor Nominates Two For Pinelands Commission
description: An environmentalist and a former utility company president have been nominated by Governor Whitman to fill two vacancies on the Pinelands Commission, which oversees more than a million acres of environmentally sensitive land in seven southern New Jersey counties. The governor nominated Sally Dudley, a former mayor of Harding Township who is executive director of the Association of New Jersey Environmental Commissions, and Jerrold L. Jacobs of Linwood, the former president of Atlantic Electric, now known as Conectiv. Mr. Jacobs was nominated to be chairman of the 15-member commission. The nominations must be approved by the Senate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANGER, ELLIOTT M. JR.
description: SANGER-Elliott M. Jr. On Friday, November 19, 1999, after a long illness, at age 77. Beloved husband of Joan B. Sanger. Adored father of Elizabeth Sanger and father-inlaw of Jeffrey Trachtenberg, devoted brother of Kenneth E. Loving son of Eleanor N. Also adored grandfather of Benjamin and Joshua Trachtenberg and devoted brother-in-law of Judith and Andrew Ball and Joan S. Sanger. Funeral services Monday, November 22, at 11 AM, Temple EmanuEl, 65th St. and 5th Ave. Family will receive friends Sunday, November 21, 3-5 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Mount Sinai Oncology Care Center, Columbia College, or a charity of your choice.

title: Rolex Goes Platinum
description: This season's hottest disappearing act is Rolex's Oyster Perpetual Yacht Master, in a combination of platinum and steel. Introduced at the annual watch fair in Basel, Switzerland, last spring, the new Rolex started arriving in stores last week, but is already sold out.

title: Over the Top at Victoria Falls
description: The Kololo called it Mosi-oa-Tunya, ''the smoke that thunders'' (literally, ''smoke does sound there''), after the pounding mist that rises high above the basaltic rim like tracts of grass set on fire. ''Scenes so lovely must have been gazed upon by angels in their flight,'' wrote a rarely stunned David Livingstone, rechristening Victoria Falls for his queen, in 1855. Still one of the natural wonders of the world, still ethereal, ''The Falls,'' as everybody calls the place now, has over the past century become, arguably, the adventure capital of an adrenaline-crazed world.

title: Pope Lectures German Bishops On Abortion
description: Showing impatience with the reluctance of Germany's Roman Catholic bishops to stop offering abortion counseling, Pope John Paul II told them today to hurry up and obey his teaching.

title: Bush Gives a Message About Dignity
description: This 30-second commercial, titled ''Pictures,'' is the sixth to be released by the Bush campaign and begins running today in New Hampshire, a state with an early primary.

title: Trade Pact With China: Hold the Applause
description: FOR more than 100 years, American business has been bewitched by the size and potential of China. The experience, of course, has been a rocky one. But the dreams live on.

title: Pictures, Not Art
description: To the Editor:

title: A Start on Soft Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Page 15 of the Connecticut section today with an article about the best Web sites in the state includes two incomplete Web addresses. The entries should read: w3.nai.net/lmerrell/pomfret.html and www.99main.com/jrothgeb/ctgenweb.htm

title: A Man Who Knows His Stuff Leads a Quest for Antiques
description: CHRIS JUSSEL knows his antiques.

title: The Name Is the Same
description: BAMBI

title: Hostility to Cold Callers Shows the City's Vibrancy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paris
description: The City of Light is becoming a city of lights for the end of the millennium. Paris always likes to show off on New Year's Eve, but this time around the Champs-Elysees is promising more than its usual -- pretty dazzling -- lights. And to cap the view down the avenue, a 185-foot-high Ferris wheel will illuminate the Place de la Concorde (and offer one of the best views in Paris).

title: The American Road Part I; Eccentric Monuments and Monumental Eccentricities in the Southwest
description: My family never took vacations. The many car trips I recall from childhood were simply a means to cart our family from one city to another, generally for a wedding or a bar mitzvah.

title: Crime
description: It's no use trying to read Ruth Rendell's mind. You can follow her logic, analyze her insights and puzzle out her plots. But she'll always astonish you, as she does in HARM DONE (Crown, $24), with the emotional depth of her psychological mysteries.

title: Not All the County's Stars Are Hung From the Sky
description: LEAVING the Hamptons crowd to the name droppers and the Milky Way to the heaven watchers, Westchester's residents can catch a glimpse of celestial bodies like Gywneth Paltrow, Lucie Arnaz, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., Tommy Mottola and Glenn Close in the diners and markets of Katonah and Bedford.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS; Serenade to a Beluga
description: A SYMPHONY OF WHALES By Steve Schuch. Illustrated by Peter Sylvada. Unpaged. San Diego: Harcourt Brace & Company. $16. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Parents Blaming Parents
description: Michael Shoels recalls how his son, Isaiah, raised the question ''What would you do if someone gunned down all your children?'' He is quoted as saying to Isaiah, ''Is there a reason you ask that?'' and describing his son's attitude as ''testy.''

title: On Their Own
description: BUD, NOT BUDDY

title: They Are the Very Best of Friends; A Bus, a Bow, the Beatles and a Buddy
description: TELL us about your best friends, we said. And you did.

title: Ageless Art
description: OLD age brings with it physical and mental insults and humiliation,'' says Morton Goldman, a participant in ''Art in Our Neighborhoods.'' ''Art and the doing of art allows for a momentary transcendence of these issues.'' The program, which has been supported by the Haym Salomon Foundation since 1996, aims to help older people communicate through group art activities that also reduce their isolation. Their work can be seen at the headquarters of Pfizer. Hundreds of people created art in 20 neighborhood programs and some 80 pieces were selected for the show, among them ''Vegetable Market'' (above), a glass painting by Lillian Lum.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Books in Brief
description: Bunnicula Strikes Again!

title: Hell With the Lid Off
description: VILLAGE OF A MILLION SPIRITS A Novel of the Treblinka Uprising. By Ian MacMillan. 257 pp. South Royalton, Vt: Steerforth Press. $24.

title: Our Towns; Where Laborers Are Handy but Shunned
description: DEPENDING on whom you talk to, Tony Hay is either the soul of a new suburban xenophobia or the last bulwark against Brewster as barrio.

title: Welcome Back
description: RAMONA'S WORLD

title: Backtalk; Khannouchi's All-American Performance
description: For the first time since Alberto Salazar ran 2 hours 8 minutes 13 seconds in the 1981 New York City Marathon, the world's best time in the men's marathon is once again held by an American. Khalid Khannouchi's 2:05:42 in this year's Chicago Marathon was not only a magnificent performance, it was also a home-grown achievement. Khannouchi may not be a citizen yet, but he is an American in every other respect.

title: Parents Blaming Parents
description: I tend to feel that holding parents to some basic legal standard of reasonable supervision is a good idea. At least it conveys some sense of the importance of the job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULMAN, MURRAY
description: SHULMAN-Murray. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Murray Shulman, associated with The Times from 1951 until retiring in 1992.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Suzanne Farrell's dance program at the New Victory Theater in Manhattan misstated the given name of the president of Kennedy Center, which is presenting the program. He is Lawrence J. Wilker, not James.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS; Verse-Case Scenarios
description: ONE HUNDRED YEARS OF POETRY FOR CHILDREN Edited by Michael Harrison and Christopher Stuart-Clark. Illustrated. 192 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $25. (All ages)

title: Counting Bodies In Kosovo
description: Where are the bodies in Kosovo?

title: Aloft Down Under
description: ''Wait for the roll . . . two, six . . . heave!'' I dug my toes into the teak deck and hauled mightily on the mizzen sheet, my watchmates grunting in unison on the line behind me. By inches we brought the boom amidships. It was gusting to 30 and we were preparing to bring the 180-foot, 16-sail STS (Sail Training Ship) Leeuwin around into the starboard tack. The helmsman trainee spun the wheel, and as all hands smartly manned the sheets and braces, the big barkentine responded. We were nine days out of Esperance bound for Albany, about 250 miles along the south coast of Western Australia. We felt comfortable and competent -- we had come a long way in a week.

title: Habitats/West 21st Street; For Twins and Husbands, The Building's the Same
description: AS children growing up in a tiny town in Rhode Island, Denise and Debra LaChance dressed exactly alike. Having identical twins was a badge of honor for their mother, and she didn't miss the opportunity to show them off. Fortunately, she had good taste; as high school seniors, they were voted best dressed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELCHER, FREDERIC G.
description: MELCHER-Frederic G. 53. Of Evanston, IL, passed away November 18, 1999. Beloved husband of Sue. Loving father of Carmen (Sean) Schipper and Laura Melcher. Devoted son of the late Dan and the late Peggy Melcher, and dearest stepson of Margaret Melcher. Dear brother-in-law of Bob Koehler (the late Barbara Grau). Cherished uncle of Alison Koehler and fond nephew of Nancy Diemand. For further information call 847-832-9600.

title: Giants' Defense Looks to Avenge Embarrassing Loss to Redskins
description: As the Giants prepared this past week to face Brad Johnson, the highly rated Washington Redskins quarterback whose passing destroyed them two months ago, defensive end Michael Strahan heard the suggestion -- on radio talk shows and elsewhere -- that the Giants had squandered their chance to obtain Johnson last winter because they were unwilling to trade Strahan.

title: Bugged
description: 'A functioning organization with no one in charge'' is a description of Alcoholics Anonymous. Perhaps the ants . . . no, of course not.

title: Clinton's Visit in Turkey May Help Speed Up Reform
description: No visitor in memory has left as positive and potentially far-reaching an impression on Turkey as President Clinton did this week.

title: November 14-20; A Notorious Drug Is Back
description: Thalidomide, the notorious sedative that maimed thousands of babies in the 1960's, may well be the wonder drug of the 1990's. It won government approval last year for treatment of leprosy, and has shown promise in AIDS. Now scientists at the University of Arkansas have announced a new use for it, as a treatment for multiple myeloma, a rare bone cancer. They tested thalidomide at the urging of a Manhattan lawyer whose husband was dying of myeloma. It didn't help him, but one-third of 84 patients who had failed to respond to other therapies improved, and two went into complete remission.

title: Lapland
description: Any Scandinavian bartender knows that aquavit won't freeze, but it can be made to flow more slowly. That's kind of what happens to time in Lapland along the Torne River, separating Kardis, Sweden, from Finland (and two time zones). On New Year's Eve, about 4,000 folks will dance on the frozen river to two orchestras, starting at 9 in Finland, with fireworks at midnight. Then they will do it again an hour later in Sweden. Contact the Swedish Travel and Tourism Council, (212) 885-9700.

title: Electoral Setbacks Force German Chancellor to Retreat From Lure of the Free Market
description: Having spoken out vigorously this summer in favor of the free market, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany arrived at a conference here today on the future of Social Democracy saying a leading German company should be protected against a hostile takeover bid from a British concern.

title: Amtrak and Hertz Expand Rental Sites
description: Amtrak and the Hertz Corporation are expanding efforts to help railroad passengers rent cars on arrival, just as air passengers can at the airport. Since May, Hertz has established a presence in 18 railroad stations, mostly in the West, though sometimes it is only a dedicated wall phone. At the end of October, the two organizations announced that they would put rail-drive links into 20 more depots.

title: Who Needs Philosophy?
description: Back when she was the star of her high-school drama club, the philosopher Martha Nussbaum wasn't interested in playing Emily in ''Our Town.'' Her favorite role was Robespierre -- in a five-act, French-language production she wrote herself. Decades later, she still speaks fondly of the meandering walks she would take around the affluent Philadelphia suburb of Bryn Mawr, dreaming of the sacrifices the Frenchman made to advance his ideals. ''I was fascinated by his dilemma of wanting liberty for everyone, but having to figure out what to do with individuals who won't go along with your plan,'' she recalled recently. ''I still think about it all the time.'' Nussbaum also remembered the fun she had playing Joan of Arc, entranced as she was by the question of ''how far to sacrifice friendship and personal loyalty to an abstract cause.'' Although Nussbaum eventually traded the stage for the academy, she still takes these early inspirations to heart. Synthesizing the passion of the revolutionary with the zeal of the self-sacrificing saint, she has become, at 52, the most prominent female philosopher in America.

title: Wrapped for the Cold

To guard against this season's cold there is something frothy: Dior tailored suit jackets with bubbly sweater knits that cuddle collars and cuffs (far left, center and bottom). In the same mood is Fendi's sweater-knit bag (top far left). A sheared mink sweater (above center) looks modern, and coats that expose a few inches of skirt are reappearing. A Prada version (left) is decorated with leather leaves. A threesome in black (below) achieve individuality with designer bags. For ladies who lunch, there are silver fox collars (top, second and third from left) and a mink-edged hooded taffeta anorak (top far right). Two women leave a farmers' market with wreaths for warmth.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Yo Ho Ho and a Case of Dynamite
description: Carl Schenck, a 1930's industrialist and a self-made millionaire, has an audacious plan: to cruise to the Arctic on a luxury yacht and bag the most exotic big game imaginable. For this fool's errand he's acquired the Lodestar, a 225-foot vessel of delicate construction, and laid in an arsenal that includes an elephant gun, a cannon-fired harpoon, 5,000 rounds of ammunition and a case of dynamite sticks. Among his crew is Will Boden, a former captain haunted by the loss of his own ship several years earlier. Boden, an Arctic veteran, knows Schenck's plan is daft but can't resist the adventure. When he warns Schenck that the Lodestar isn't designed for ice, Schenck reveals the purpose of the dynamite and the depth of his navete: ''We get caught in any ice,'' he proclaims, ''we'll blow our way out.'' Schenck's unflagging brio, modeled on his hero Teddy Roosevelt, carries him surprisingly far north and lands his passengers and crew in all sorts of trouble. In VOYAGE TO THE NORTH STAR (Carroll & Graf, $24), his first novel, Peter Nichols, who wrote about his own voyage across the Atlantic in a wooden boat in the memoir ''Sea Change,'' tells an engaging story in unadorned language about the nature of folly and the folly of challenging nature. Nichols allows his readers to see the passage up the East Coast, from New York Harbor to Baffin Island, through the eyes of a seasoned mariner, and takes particular delight in recording the details of the seagoing world in the days before global positioning satellites. Bruce Barcott

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Books in Brief; Ripe Emotions
description: Pears that stare. Belligerent tomatoes. Affectionate strawberries. A red pepper that looks shocked -- shocked! -- when it gets a surprise smooch from an orange pepper. Who'd have dreamed that produce could be so expressive, so charming, so lively and funny? Armed with an X-acto knife, kidney beans, a little beet juice and a basketful of produce, in HOW ARE YOU PEELING? Foods With Moods (Arthur A. Levine/Scholastic, $15.95; ages 5 and up), Saxton Freymann and Joost Elffers have created sweet and feisty little beings with feelings, passions, fears and an emotional range that is, well, organic, although not usually associated with products of the soil. To illustrate their charming rhymed text about recognizing and accepting feelings, the artists have deftly carved oranges with attitude, peppers that glare and leer, quizzical fruit, a sweet-faced onion soothing a bawling baby onion and -- my favorite -- a gaggle of friendly lemons just getting acquainted.

title: Foreign Affairs; Y2K Plus 5

The protesters might want to talk to the workers of Sri Lanka first, because what you find here, in this island state located off the southern tip of India, is a rather nuanced view of globalization -- an awareness that it is as much a vehicle for developing countries to escape poverty as it is a vehicle for them to be exploited.

Mrs. Connelly, a noted philanthropist, was the co-founder and Chairperson of the Connelly Foundation, W. Conshohocken, PA. Beloved wife of the late John F. Connelly, former Chairman and President of Crown Cork & Seal, Co., Philadelphia, PA. Loving mother of Josephine C. Mandeville, Villanova, PA, Emily C. Riley, Villanova, PA, John F. Her family will receive friends and relatives on Monday, November 22nd from 3 to 8 pm at the Cathedral. Interment Calvary Cemetery, W. Conshohocken, PA. If his centennial passes by relatively unnoticed, as I fear it might, the only explanation will be that there have already been so many centennial celebrations this year, beginning with Duke Ellington's and Ernest Hemingway's, that a predictable element of fatigue has set in.

The scholarship, covering the $235 cost of a half-year dance class, may also bring opportunities to perform at community events and on the center's show on Cablevision, said its artistic director, Elissa Machlin-Lockwood.

description: Joe Girardi, who played an integral role as the Yankees won three championships in the last four seasons, will be with another team next year, his agent said yesterday.

title: Lives; 'Nov. 22, 1963, the Day I Died'
description: Abbott is the name I was born with, Abbott Vaughn Meader, in Waterville, Me., the night of the biggest flood in New England's history. I grew up in children's homes, got thrown out of one of them, got through high school and went in the Army. When I came back I started doing stand-up comedy. I was doing a little political stand-up in the Village, and one night I threw in a line in Kennedy's voice and everybody fell down. So I started doing press conferences as Kennedy with the audience. A manager found me and got me to do the album.

title: Political Memo; Pataki Upstages a Rival Over Cleanup of Hudson
description: On Friday, Nov. 12, aides to Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer let reporters know that New York State was about to sue General Electric over the dumping of toxic waste in the Hudson River, a move long demanded by environmentalists. The news conference would be on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, JULIUS
description: COOK-Julius. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Julius Cook, associated with The Times from 1969 until retiring in 1995.

title: Long After Blackout, Merchants Are Feeling Overlooked and Underpaid
description: Mohammed Ali's dreams of prospering from the Bangladeshi-Indian grocery he bought in April began to sour in July, he said. That's when his business, on the Lower East Side, was struck by a blackout and weeks of ensuing electrical problems.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-21-99: The New Economy; Monopoly Money
description: Important news about Microsoft the other day -- and, no, I don't mean the verdict declaring it a monopolistic bully. With a bit less fanfare, the company announced that it would be offering users of its Office group of applications online access to the software, anytime, on demand. Between the lines, you might read portents of something bigger: Microsoft morphing from mere seller of software into a sort of global utility, hoping to receive from each of us a monthly check.

title: Karen Feldman, Ronald Roth
description: Karen Elizabeth Feldman and Ronald Michael Roth were married last evening at Carltun on the Park in East Meadow, N.Y. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas officiated.

title: Ideas & Trends: Silent Majorities; Polling's 'Dirty Secret': No Response
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON is such a devoted student of public opinion polls that his aides say he can recite, from memory, the American people's double-digit tastes on a wide array of issues. Besides using survey data to help shape some of the most important decisions of his presidency, Mr. Clinton has also consulted polls before deciding whether his family should go to the beach or the mountains on their summer vacations.

title: A Village Here, a Village There. But Why?; Upscale and Simple Lures of Larchmont: From Fine Wine and Coffee to a 29 cents Hairnet
description: DOWNTOWN Larchmont is a blend of sophistication and simplicity. Its 12 square blocks, lined with brick and stucco buildings, are part Madison Avenue, part 1950's suburbia. The shops are a mix of ultra-upscale and mom and pop utilitarian, and they can seduce even a nonshopper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASADESUS, GABY
description: CASADESUS-Gaby. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sadness the passing of its beloved friend and devoted Steinway Artist Gaby Casadesus, on November 12, 1999 in Paris at the age of 98. A native of Marseille, Mme. Casadesus was first taught by her mother and continued her studies at the Paris Conservatory under Marguerite Long and Louis Diemer. After a brilliant solo career in which she championed the music of such composers as Faure, Moszkowski, and Ravel, she married the renowned pianist and composer Robert Casadesus in 1921. Their collaboration resulted in one of the most celebrated piano duos in history. An acclaimed teacher, Mme. Casadesus' master classes at the Ravel Academy in St-Jean-de-Luz, the Mozarteum in Salzburg, and the Fontainebleau School were legendary. She was a co-founder of the Robert Casadesus International Piano Competition in 1975. Mme. Casadesus' discography, including a recent reissue of live performances from 1942 to 1948 by Dante Productions, will keep her legacy alive for future generations. To her daughter Therese, son Guy, and her entire family we extend our heartfelt condolences. She was an inspiration to us all, and her loss is deeply felt. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P., Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: Corrections

title: November 14-20; Congress Passes a Budget
description: Fifty days after the new fiscal year began, Congress completed work on a budget that totals about $610 billion. For the second consecutive year, the budget broke the spending limits that lawmakers had set for themselves. It includes $17 billion more for the military and $2.3 billion more for medical research than last year, even as it frees money to pay $351 million of $926 million in back dues to the United Nations and offers 41 of the world's poorest countries some relief from their debts. Republicans had sought the military and medical research funds, while President Clinton had sought the United Nations and debt relief money. Mr. Clinton also is getting most of the funds he sought for hiring primary school teachers and local police officers.

And so, a teenager's guide to Westchester is, in some ways, not a guide at all but an informal report on some unofficial teenage activities:

title: Style; The Blues Brothers
description: Question: What does a portly 74-year-old black man who favors satin tuxes, cuff links and cummerbunds have in common with a skinny 21-year-old blond boy who poses in Versace, does Gap ads and takes to the stage in silver shades and Adidas? Hint: They are both Southern gentlemen; their fans offer each standing ovations (one before he plays a note, the other after an ear-slamming display of virtuosity not seen since Hendrix picked guitar with his teeth). Bigger hint: Both of them love the blues even more than they love women. It was the blues that kept them in New York City during Hurricane Floyd -- more thunder and lightning happening onstage than outside the Beacon Theater.

title: November 14-20; A Civil Rights Hero Loses a Lawsuit
description: Rosa Parks was voted a medal last spring by Congress for having helped launch the civil rights movement by refusing to move to the back of a bus in Montgomery, Ala., in 1955. But when Outkast, a rap group, put her name on a song containing expletives and racial epithets, she sued in federal court here, contending that her name was being exploited for commercial gain. A judge ruled against her, finding that the First Amendment protected the group. KEITH BRADSHER

title: Fiji
description: lays claim to being the first place the millennium will dawn, because the 180th meridian -- the imaginary line exactly halfway around the globe from the imaginary one through Greenwich -- runs across three of its many islands: Udu Point, Rabi Island and Taveuni. And for those who buy into the purist theory that the 180th meridian, not the zigzagging, thoroughly politicized international date line, is where every day begins and ends, the event of the New Year may be a brilliant drawing of the meridian with pyrotechnics visible for miles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINS, HAROLD
description: ROBINS-Harold. On November 20, 1999, peacefully in the home that he loved. Adored husband of Cherry Balaban Robins. Cherished father of Anthony, Jessica and Donald, and loving father-in-law of Susan, Peter and Kayko. Proud grandfather of Nina, Lucy, Caitlin, Joseph, Niki and Michael. Devoted brother of the late Lillian Feinberg. Extraordinary and steadfast friend to all who were privileged to know him. The family will receive friends in their home on Friday, November 26, 1-5 PM.

title: Another Start-Up Delay For Ion Collider
description: Researchers at Brookhaven National Laboratory have announced a further delay in starting up the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider, the giant machine in which scientists hope to recreate conditions thought to have existed just after the birth of the universe. The collider was previously expected to be up and running in January. The delay until April is primarily due to problems in the alignment of sections of the collider's dual 2.4-mile circular rings, scientists say. If all goes as planned, beams of counter-rotating particles will race around the rings at nearly the speed of light, then crash together at high energies and extremely hot temperatures. Scientists believe that the resulting meltdown of protons and neutrons will mimic the Big Bang.

title: Parents Blaming Parents
description: People who don't have the love to forgive are the ones who fill their hearts with hate. Suing and isolating others during moments of loss is telling our children that money is the priority in life and finding someone to blame is the solution. Columbine was a tragedy because it has separated us instead of bringing us together.

title: The Dictionary of Dope
description: How to Stop Time

title: Winter Dreams; Austria
description: Stumbling off the overnight flight mussed and bleary-eyed, everything brightens -- with the prospect of something that is homey. That is the attraction of a winter place: The contrast of the clear cold air outside and the yellow-lighted warmth of a house inside. In the cozy comfort of, say, a castle hotel. Castles attempting to be small hotels (much better than hotels pretending to be castles) now abound in Europe. There is a special atmosphere of one I recall in Austria in winter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKEWELL, ANDERSON, THE REV.
description: BAKEWELL-Anderson, the Rev. Reverend Anderson Bakewell, a Jesuit priest, missionary, mountain climber and explorer died of cancer at his home in Santa Fe, New Mexico on October 13, 1999. He was 86. Fr. Bakewell was born in St. Louis, MO. He graduated from St. Louis University in 1937. In 1942, he entered the Society of Jesus, volunteering five years later for a mission to India. He worked with fellow Jesuits at the Haffkine Institute in Bombay, preparing antivenin for snake bites and studying cobras, krait and vipers. After ordination in Calcutta in 1951, he worked at a jungle mission in Bihar. Returning to the U.S. in 1955, he raised money to build a Jesuit retreat house in Faulkner, MD. Later he served as assistant pastor at Holy Trinity Church, Georgetown, where the Kennedys attended Mass. In 1967, he volunteered for a mission to Delta, Alaska where he had a 35,000 square mile parish, ministering to four churches and three pipeline camps, twice carrying out rescues at 70 degrees below zero. In 1978, he became chaplain of the Carmelite Monastery in Santa Fe. In 1939, Father Bakewell made the first ascent of Cristobal Colon, the highest peak in the Columbian coastal range. In 1941, he was in the first party to climb Mt. Wood, in the St. Elias Range, Yukon, then the highest unclimbed peak in North America. In 1950, he participated in the first attempt to climb Mt. Everest from the south. In 1965, as a member of the Explorers Club, he participated in the first nonstop, round-the-world flight across both poles. As a naturalist he collected reptiles, mammals and plants material for U.S. scientific institutions. He was also a trophyholding big game hunter. Funeral masses were held in Santa Fe and St. Louis. Burial was in St. Louis.

title: Barak, Addressing American Jews, Stresses Israel's Yearning for Peace
description: In his first address to a broad range of prominent American Jews last night, the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, embraced the search for peace with Israel's Arab neighbors, saying that if negotiations fail, ''it will not be for lack of commitment or perseverance on our part.''

title: Corrections

title: POSTINGS: Sidewalk Plaques for 8 Fashion Designers; A Walk of Fame On Seventh Ave.
description: The first thing he wanted to do when he visited his aunt in California as a starstruck teen-ager in the 1930's, Geoffrey Beene recalled last week, was to slip into the footprints and handprints of ''great, great actresses'' outside Grauman's Chinese Theater in Hollywood.

title: November 14-20; Movement Toward Peace In Northern Ireland
description: The politicians of Northern Ireland have never had problems talking. For five years they have been at it, in marathon negotiating sessions seeking a lasting peace plan. But this time the words were different -- conciliatory, accommodating and thought out -- where before they had always been obdurate, insulting and impulsive.

title: Connecticut's Corner of the Web
description: QUIRKS and all, Connecticut's presence on the World Wide Web is a bit like a leisurely bicycle ride though the emerald hills of Litchfield County: every turn brings an unexpected delight, or yet another endless byway under construction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VONDERMUHLL, ROSAMOND LOMBARD
description: VONDERMUHLL - Rosamond Lombard, 90, wife of George A. Vondermuhll, Jr., died peacefully Sunday, November 14, 1999, at Duncaster Retirement Community, Bloomfield, CT. Daughter of the late Percival Hall and Isabel (Fabyan) Lombard of Brookline and Pocasset, MA. Beloved and devoted wife, mother, sister, mother-in-law, and grandmother. A graduate of Winsor School and Radcliffe College, she served over 40 years with world program of Moral Re-Armament. Also survived by son and daugher-in-law Alfred and Laura (Camins) Vondermuhll & granddaughter Isabel, all of New York City & Litchfield, CT, grandson Nicholas of Allston, MA, and brother George F.F. Lombard of Weston, MA. Memorial Service to be announced. Memorial contributions to Duncaster Residents' Assistance Fund, 40 Loeffler Road, Bloomfield, CT 06002; Moral Re-Armament, Inc., 1156 Fifteenth St. NW, Washington, DC 20005; or Old St. Andrew's Church, 59 Tariffville Road, Bloomfield, CT. 06002.

description: To the Editor:

title: Some Old Wisdom for Young Stars in the N.B.A.
description: Terry Cummings was sitting by his locker recently, pondering what the National Basketball Association has become in his 17-year career. He has run the gamut, from rookie of the year to clubhouse sage. Now, at age 38, he is trying the role of N.B.A. ombudsman.

description: THE music business has pretty much gone down the path blazed by book sellers: large chain stores, offering the same selections, and too often staffed by employees who say ''whatever we have is out, help yourself.''

title: A Minority of One
description: As an idealistic undergraduate at the City University of New York, I volunteered to work in Herman Badillo's1973 mayoral campaign. So I was outraged to read in James Traub's article (Oct. 31) that ''Badillo doesn't regret a syllable'' of his bigoted remarks, in which, among other things, he referred to Hispanic immigrants as ''Incas and Mayas who are, you know, five feet tall with straight hair.''

title: Thanksgiving Cobblers That Are Easy as Pie but Lighter
description: ASSUMING the planning for Thanksgiving is already under way, imagine the holiday meal without pie. Well, not exactly. Consider Thanksgiving with a cobbler instead. And with good reason.

title: In Denver, Nostalgia in a New $50 Million Enclave
description: FOR more than a century, the Elitch Gardens Amusement Park here was a place where families gathered for summer entertainment, picnics or just a stroll. Now, as houses replace roller coasters on the old site, the developers' hope is that those traditions will continue.

title: The Battle Over A.T.M. Fees
description: Customers are expressing outrage at the surcharges banks impose on them for using automated teller machines owned by banks other than their own. The cities of Santa Monica and San Francisco recently banned these surcharges. The New York City Council is planning to do the same. But before customers get too riled up about paying fees for the privilege of reclaiming their own money, they need to recognize that businesses do, after all, have a right to charge for their services. More important, efforts to ban the surcharges are apt to backfire and cause bank customers more harm than good.

title: Parents Blaming Parents
description: I can't decide which is more disturbing: the fact of the high-school shootings or the way in which some people have reacted to them with lawsuits and finger-pointing (Lisa Belkin, Oct. 31). This ''there must be someone to blame'' mentality assumes a simple cause-and-effect relationship in parenting. In reality, people are wildly complex creatures.

title: Options In Replacing Wood Floor
description: ONE of the advantages of wood floors is that when they get scuffed, scratched or just plain sorry-looking, they can usually be restored to like-new condition by simply sanding off the surface and refinishing the newly exposed wood.

title: Parents Blaming Parents
description: Lisa Belkin searches for the causes of school shootings in failed parenting, in the secrets teenagers keep, in an increasingly complex world. The real cause stares us in the face: it is the epidemic, ceaseless cruelty that children are allowed to inflict upon other children in our public schools.

description: First of all, people can't quite believe that we three have been friends since first grade. Since first grade, and still good friends, 65 years later.

title: A Contract After A Death
description: Q. My husband and I signed a contract and paid a deposit to purchase an apartment in New York City. My husband then died, and I realized that the apartment would no longer be suitable for me alone. Because of my different needs and changed finances, I wanted to cancel the contract. At first the seller refused to return the deposit, but after much negotiation, the seller agreed to refund all but $5,000, which was presumably for damages. Is it legal for the seller to keep all or part of the deposit under such circumstances? . . . Arline Miller, Jamaica Estates, Queens.

Cohesion has been obliterated by war, physical and ideological, leaving scattered treasures on the indifferent streets. The thread, if one exists, is conflict -- Germany's, Europe's, the world's.

title: The American Road Part II; Through the Delta, Blues on My Mind
description: In July, when the temperature was spiking at 100 in Pittsburgh, my present home, an old undertow got hold of my feet and told me to travel the Blues Highway again, the part of it that I had traveled as a boy anyway, U.S. 61 from Memphis to New Orleans. These two cities were not my focus, but the Delta highway itself and the villages along the way, where I grew up listening to the blues in juke joints and on the falling-down porches of country stores. I wanted to find that music again, at its birthplace.

title: When Moses Put Dampers On Extending the Rails
description: Your article on Robert A. Caro and Robert Moses 25 years after ''The Power Broker'' [''The Father of Parks, and Traffic,'' Oct. 31] mentions that Moses barred rail access to Jones Beach. It gets worse: He was a trustee of Hofstra in the 1950's and left soon after the university refused to fire a professor who had developed a plan for such a rail spur. Almost at the end of his tenure as head of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, Moses also vetoed rail tracks on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. This would not only have created rail freight access to Long Island, which it now sorely lacks, but also (via the Hellgate Arch) the only rail freight connection across the Hudson to New England south of Castleton, near Albany.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Books in Brief; Heads of Joy
description: It's almost exactly a year since controversy about a white teacher's classroom use of a book called ''Nappy Hair'' in a public elementary school in Brooklyn forced her transfer. Now the esteemed and prolific African-American feminist writer Bell Hooks has upped the ante, so to speak, with her first children's book, HAPPY TO BE NAPPY (Jump at the Sun/Hyperion, $14.99; ages 4 to 8), a glorious praise-song for nappy hair, marvelously illustrated by Chris Raschka. Hooks has always been concerned with what she calls ''the politics of representation that systematically devalues blackness.'' From its opening line, ''Girlpie hair smells clean and sweet,'' to its very last image, ''Happy to Be Nappy'' is a richly colorful and jazzy debunking of such devaluation. The opening line is potent politically, because ''Girlpie hair'' scans both as an adjective and the noun it modifies and as what it's meant to be: ''the hair of Girlpie.'' There was an ancillary outcry against Carolivia Herron's ''Nappy Hair'' -- that her text was laced with ''ebonics.'' Perhaps ''Happy to Be Nappy'' is a kind of call and response to the call and response of ''Nappy Hair.'' The text appears in a childlike kind of curling cursive script. Raschka's colorful rectangular shapes form the myriad portraits of African-American girls and at times frame their heads with wondrous halos. An illustrator whose bold watercolor-and-charcoal illustrations brought such energy to his own books -- including ''Charlie Parker Played Be Bop'' and ''Yo! Yes?,'' a Caldecott Honor Book -- Raschka playfully twists and turns Girlpie's black hair everywhere: on her head, into her eyes and out in space.The girl's hair moves and swirls and flares. It's ''soft like cotton, flower petal billowy soft, full of frizz and fuzz.'' And Girlpie herself is all manner of African-American girl, from deep brown to orange-pink, shy, sophisticated, sassy and cool in both her look and her stance. When her patient, loving mother combs and brushes, twists and plaits Girlpie's hair, the girl is ready to fly. ''All kinks gone! All heads of joy!'' The term ''nappy,'' of course, can be a strong pejorative among African-Americans. But Hooks clearly relishes challenging that perception. It's wonderfully liberating to see a little girl take pride in her natural self. Kermit Frazier

title: Accountant Acts to Settle Insider Charge In Stock Case
description: An Arkansas business associate of Thomas F. McLarty 3rd, the former White House chief of staff, has agreed to pay more than $144,000 to settle charges of insider trading.

title: Parents Blaming Parents
description: 'Who else do we blame?'' For starters, how about a system that promotes pornography and gut-wrenching violence as daily entertainment and then tops it off with cheap guns for sale on every street corner? It is a miracle that any parent succeeds in the face of pervasive and systematic sabotage.

title: Colorado Canyon Area Is Newest National Park
description: The United States' 55th national park was created last month when President Clinton signed legislation creating Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park in southwest Colorado, about 250 miles from Denver. It is the first new national park since Death Valley and Joshua Tree were established in 1994.

title: New Crisis Frames Even Tougher Test of Indonesian Unity
description: It has become a hauntingly familiar drama in Indonesia: families huddling on a windswept pier or in a crowded bus station, fleeing a home that has become too dangerous as old grievances give rise to new and explosive separatist passions.

title: Adoption Agency Thwarted Father's Rights, Judge Says
description: Saying that an adoption agency had deceitfully thwarted a young father's rights, a judge in Brooklyn awarded a 20-year-old man custody of his infant son on Friday, and described their two-year separation as a ''human tragedy.''

title: Turn Left at Cloud 109
description: On a business trip this fall I had what is becoming the standard airline experience. Nine p.m., arrived at Detroit's main airport, then waited until 10 p.m. for the baggage to appear. Next night's flight out of Detroit was delayed two hours -- and eventually canceled, around midnight, followed by a stay at the airport hotel and a 6 a.m. departure. An air trip from one off-the-main-route location (Allentown, Pa.) to another (Hartford) took longer than it would have by car, because of hub-and-spoke routing through Philadelphia. Plus, there was the traveling person's toll of Dead Time: the hours lost in taxis to and from airports, in lines at the check-in counter and security gate, in the aisle of the plane itself, waiting for victors to emerge in the battles for space in the overhead racks. Need I mention mini-pretzels as meals?

title: Parcells Keeps Jets Cautiously Optimistic
description: The question tantalizes Bill Parcells: can the Jets do it? Can they recover from that disastrous 3-6 start and actually make something of this season?

title: Pay on Delivery
description: In a world where women are constantly proving their worth -- in the office, on the playing field, at home -- unmedicated childbirth need not be singled out as ''proof'' of one's strength. Lest anyone be misled, even with today's pain blockers, childbirth is a body-racking experience, and a woman's decision to block some or most of the pain should be left unjudged.

title: Putting Children on Trial as Adults
description: To the Editor:

title: Netherlands
description: Who knows what to make of all that end-of-the-world talk surrounding the year 2000?

title: Mr. B. on Broadway
description: To the Editor:

title: Winter Dreams; Tokyo
description: What I like most about wintertime in Tokyo is being indoors, away from nature's chilly work. Nothing beats the cozy comfort of a kotatsu -- a low-slung table and heating unit rolled into one. Old-fashioned renditions feature charcoal-generated heat; modern ones depend upon an infrared bulb to radiate warmth. Legs are tucked under a quilt that is sandwiched between frame and tabletop while the torso is kept toasty in a hanten jacket, a short, thickly padded, kimonolike garment that folks don in winter. This Japanese version of the couch potato is greatly enhanced by a companion set of toes with which to share the quilt and a large bowl of mikan tangerines set within easy reach.

title: IN PERSON; It All Comes Down to Sex
description: BEFORE the latest political triangulation involving Bill Clinton -- the one instigated by the feminist writer Naomi Wolf and Al Gore -- there was Lionel Tiger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFARB, FRIEDA (NEE OBERST)
description: GOLDFARB-Frieda (nee Oberst). Of Fort Lee, NJ, on November 4, 1999. Beloved wife of 65 years to the late Michael; devoted mother of Felice Toonkel and Sheila Martin; loving grandmother of Stacey, Adam, Erica, Jennifer, and the late Margot; and great-grandmother of Maxwell, Matthew, Caleb, and Eliza.

title: Parents Blaming Parents
description: It is ironic to see Geoffrey Fieger trying to pin responsibility for the Columbine murders on the killers' parents when he has made a career out of espousing individual responsibility for one's own actions.

title: A Painter in Two Cities; A Pair of Group Shows
description: Paul Jenkins

title: Where Teatime Has a Parisian Flair
description: THE world of the Parisian salon de the seems to exist in a universe parallel to that of the city's cafes and wine bars. But while the latter correspond to every visitor's image of France, tea parlors tend to evoke England. Forget preconceptions. Paris has scores of wonderful tearooms, and they are as much a part of the city's fabric as its cafes and bistros a vin.

title: Giving Parents a Helping Hand
description: Help with parenting is sprouting from an unexpected source: employers.

title: Mexico City
description: On a weekday night in a hard-luck neighborhood not far from Mexico City's main plaza, Paquita la del Barrio sings to her fans in a crowded restaurant. With perfect phrasing, she enunciates her lyrics as though they were declarations of universal truths. ''I deserve better than you,'' she sings as the audience roars its approval. ''I'm going to squash you like a bug.''

title: Ancient Towns By the Adriatic
description: IT is a fine morning, and breakfast is served outdoors, on a flagstone patio overgrown with vine. There are plump figs bursting with seed, cheese fermented in underground caves and fragrant, creamy honey from my hosts' beehives. My hosts are a Swiss journalist and his Italian wife, and their stone house near Loreto faces a deep ocher-and-green valley: a patchwork of wheat fields, olive groves and vineyards surrounded by misty hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, DONALD J.
description: ROSS-Donald J. Of Tucson, AZ passed away November 16, 1999 in Douglas County, CO. He was born in Brooklyn, NY, September 11, 1927. Don attended both Syracuse and Rutgers Universities before active duty in the Army in World War II. Upon his return he completed his studies at the University of Michigan, receiving his Bachelor's Degree in Business Administration in 1950. He was married June 11, 1949 to Margaret Anne Sanders of Rockville Centre, Long Island. Don began his business career as a Security Analyst with Chemical Bank and then Merrill Lynch. He then joined Blythe & Co. working in their corporate finance department. By 1966, he had moved to St. Louis, MO as Vice President of Corporate Finance for Goldman Sachs & Co. He retired in June, 1985 and moved to Perry Park, CO. Don is survived by his wife of fifty years, Margaret Anne Ross and six children, Donald Ross Jr., Patrick Ross, Meg Taylor, Jim Ross, Kathleen Skinner, Michael Ross and ten grandchildren. The Donald J. Ross family ask that contributions be made to Polycystic Kidney Research Foundation, 4901 Main St., Suite 200, Kansas City, MO 64112. 1-800-PKD-CURE.

title: Fran Katz, Robert Watson
description: Fran Gail Katz and Robert Louis Watson were married last evening at Congregation Beth El in Bethesda, Md. Rabbi Jonathan Z. Maltzman performed the ceremony.

title: November 14-20; Clinton at Quake Sites
description: Turkey, still reeling from the effects of two strong earthquakes in three months, gave a warm welcome to President Clinton when he arrived three days before a summit meeting in Istanbul of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe and spent the time touring the country.

title: Sharing Lives, Sharing Memories; A Son Takes a Wife; She Gets a New Friend for Life
description: I met my best friend while I was struggling up a dormitory stairwell carrying a refrigerator. Although burdened by her own load on this first day of our graduate school program, she offered me her help and the help of her strong boyfriend. From then on we've been best friends.

title: H. Clay Earles, 86, Speedway Owner, Dies
description: H. Clay Earles, who 53 years ago carved a hardscrabble racetrack out of the red clay of southern Virginia and then painstakingly turned it into a cash-spewing shrine to the cult of the stock car, died Tuesday at his home in Martinsville, Va. He was 86.

title: Shu-Ping Chan and Jana Mason
description: Jana Lynn Mason, the daughter of Rose Mason of Manassas, Va., and the late Lt. Col. Emil S. Mason, was married yesterday to Shu-Ping Chan, a son of Dr. Mary Chan and Dr. Daniel Chan of Westport, Conn. The Rev. Joseph A. Mindling performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Washington.

title: An Imperiled Muse Weaves Her Spell
description: Outside museums and galleries and fine-art publications, black-and-white photographs from the past don't often take center stage. An exception to that observation is ''Shooting the Past,'' a two-part Mobil Masterpiece Theatre drama being shown tonight and next Sunday night at 9 on PBS. Its extraordinary main character is a vast picture library housed in a splendid 19th-century mansion on the edge of London and tended by a small and intensely devoted staff.

title: In Eastern Europe, A New Generation Is Shifting Priorities
description: In the Vox Maris discotheque, Graziela Tache extended one leg even farther out from under her tiny slit skirt. ''You know what these boots cost?'' she asked. ''They were $250. You know what that waitress earns? Maybe $100 a month. There are two levels in society.''

title: U.S. Readies a Major Land-Protection Initiative
description: As one of its last major public land initiatives, the Clinton administration is preparing to designate as national monuments up to a dozen open areas in the West that federal officials say need protection from future commercial development and recreational overuse.

title: A Joy Ride With Ralph Nader
description: Most certainly, the Mercedes-Benz Gelaendewagen is ridiculously beautiful, outrageously well crafted and totally unnecessary (The Way We Live Now, by Jeffrey Goldberg, Oct. 31). I am not much into cars, except to have them take me from point A to point B. But ever since I watched three little old ladies climb out of a G-300 (the five-door, long-wheelbase model), their faces lit with happy smiles, their arms linked, their steps as light as if they were 17, I fell in love with the G-Wagen. Any car that can make you smile that way is worth its weight in gold. And with a curb weight of 5,115 pounds, that would be a lot of gold.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Philipsburg History

title: Alsace, Where German Gemtlichkeit Meets French Finesse
description: When the menu reads tarte l'oignon/zwiebelkchen, foie gras d'oie/ganseleber, choucroute/sauerkraut, raise a toast in a sunny blond vin/wein and celebrate being in Alsace. This beguiling province in eastern France, in the shadow of the hazy Vosges Mountains, is a stronghold of border cooking, the culinary blend that occurs where two countries meet, as France and Germany do here along the Rhine.

title: Bugged
description: In Douglas Foster's article on Deborah Gordon (Oct. 31), the biologist ponders ''the basic mystery about ant colonies . . . that there is no management.'' Apparently, unmanaged insect behavior was already a mystery to the writer of the biblical Proverb, 30:27: ''The locusts have no king, yet all of them march in rank.''

title: Cadets Can't Catch Cougars
description: Army Coach Bob Sutton stomped furiously onto the field, screaming at the referees, with 3 minutes 23 seconds left in the fourth quarter today. He had watched his team methodically dig itself a 20-0 hole against Houston and then score 14 points in 12 minutes, only to be denied an opportunity to take the lead when it was ruled that an onside kick had gone out of bounds untouched.

title: A Vote for Disney
description: To the Editor:

title: Everywhere
description: The last thing many New Yorkers may want to hear at 7 a.m. on Jan. 1 is an hour of nonstop drumming. But any millennial revelers on the East Coast who aren't already experiencing pounding in their heads by then can join with percussionists around the world in a synchronized effort to drum in the new year. The event was conceived by the All One Tribe Foundation in Taos, N.M., and anyone with a drum, a set of bongos -- even a pot and a spoon -- can participate.

title: Hostility to Cold Callers Shows the City's Vibrancy
description: To the Editor:

description: IT AIN'T NO SIN

description: COURTENAY-Adrian H., Jr. On November 20, 1999, at age 86. Beloved husband of the late Judith Clark Courtenay and Veronica Courtenay. Loving father of Adrian H. III, Mary Sokolove, Elizabeth Shaw and Priscilla La Rocca; nine grandchildren and 4 greatgrandchildren. Dear brother of the late Catherine Cheshire. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday, November 23, 2-5 and 7-9 PM with services Wednesday 9:30 AM.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 21, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Better Perks Resonate in Boom Times
description: HIS name may not be familiar to anyone but his own employees, but chances are you've heard about what Al Galdi has done: given new BMW's to any employee who has worked at his company for at least a year.

title: Meeting on Military Ties
description: A United States Defense Department official met with Chinese officials today in an effort to re-establish high-level military contacts abruptly suspended by Beijing after the NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade in May.

title: They Are the Very Best of Friends; Two Cousins Who Took on the World
description: TELL us about your best friends, we said. And you did.

title: November 14-20; History Stumbles Again
description: What's a one-sentence history of the American West in the late 1800's? The politically correct answer, of course, is that the white man came in and wrecked everything.

title: In Wild, Wild East, Smoke Jumpers Stalk Beetles
description: They usually make their living parachuting into wildernesses from Alaska to New Mexico, where they fight forest fires, or rather, corral them by chopping breaks through the trees. Yet for the last month, a small crew of smoke jumpers has been deployed to Queens to help in another battle.

title: A Runner's Thanks
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 26 about day spas misidentified a Manhasset spa where reservations were being taken two months in advance. A publicist for Elizabeth Arden called The Times on Nov. 12 to say the spa was operated by Estee Lauder, not Elizabeth Arden.

title: To the Ramparts For Riesling
description: When Willie Gluckstern wrestles with modesty, modesty loses. His opinions -- nay, convictions -- can be measured only on the Richter scale.

title: Spots Where Champions Call the Shots
description: THEY have guns or pool cues, darts or bows and arrows. And they will often travel -- either for competition or camaraderie.

title: INSIDE
description: Back and Forth on Ulster

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, FRANK
description: ROTH-Frank. 78, of Lakeville, CT, formerly of Roslyn, NY. Loving husband and best friend of Barbara for 50 years. Cherished father of Ellyn Mittman, Stuart Roth and Peter Roth, and father-in-law of Larry Mittman, Elizabeth Roth and Michelle Roth. Beloved grandfather of Wesley and Jordan Mittman. Dedicated to his family, who were his greatest source of pleasure and pride. Gifted musician and furniture designer. Former President of Congregation Beth David, Amenia, NY, and founder of The Connecticut Northwest Corner Jewish Community Group. He will live on in the hearts of his loved ones forever. Services 12 noon, Monday, at ''The Riverside,'' 180 West 76th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the University of Massachusetts Cancer Center in Worcester, MA 01613-9938.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: FIVE DAYS IN LONDON, MAY 1940

title: November 14-20; Air Crash Sets Off An Ambiguous Probe
description: An informal axiom among aviation investigators is that if you don't know the reason for a crash within the first three days, you are in for a long haul. But three weeks after Egyptair 990 plunged toward the water so fast that people inside were weightless, investigators cannot demonstrate why -- although some theorized from cockpit conversations that a reserve pilot may have intentionally set the plane on its plunge toward the sea. So the investigators laid out a plan that will take weeks or months to raise a substantial part of the Boeing 767 from more than 250 feet of water, twice as deep as Swissair 111 or TWA 800. The flight data recorder shows a plane that flew ''straight as an arrow,'' as one crash specialist put it, until it plunged, but the cockpit voice recorder is ambiguous.

title: A Watchful Eye On the Heavens, Inside or Out
description: BEFORE People magazine and Salon, there were stars, and star watchers. Not to mention planet, moon and sun watchers.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; A Unifying Art
description: Diego Rivera ''put his stamp on Mexico, the way Bernini placed his on Rome,'' Pete Hamill writes in DIEGO RIVERA (Abrams, $49.50), his fascinating book about the Mexican muralist. As Hamill points out, Rivera was a man of contradictions. He was a staunch Communist and president of the Workers and Farmers Bloc in Mexico, but he never hesitated to accept commissions from wealthy capitalists. And like his former mentor and sometime rival, Pablo Picasso, Rivera was both a lover and destroyer of the women in his life. He callously abandoned Angeline Beloff, his Russian common-law wife, along with his son Diego Jr., and was frequently unfaithful to his second wife, Lupe Marin. And, of course, there was his tempestuous relationship with Frida Kahlo, an artist whose own fame at times threatened to overshadow his. They married in 1929, and as Hamill points out, ''they would remain together -- in spite of sorrows, abortions, a miscarriage, mutual infidelities, treacheries, a divorce followed by remarriage -- until Frida's death in 1954.'' It seems that Rivera could be loyal only to his painting, and the work he produced, especially the during the 1920's and 30's, cemented his reputation as one of the great muralists of the 20th century. Hamill, who studied art in Mexico when he was a young man, writes authoritatively about Rivera's work and diverse styles. He also describes the pivotal role Rivera's art played in Mexico's development: ''In his art, he unified a people long fractured by history, language, racism, religious and political schism. He said in his art: you are all Mexico.'' Carolyn T. Hughes

title: Galaxy and United To Battle in Final
description: Three years ago, D.C. United and the Los Angeles Galaxy met in Foxboro, Mass., in the first Major League Soccer championship game. Playing in a downpour, United rallied from a two-goal deficit for a 3-2 overtime victory.

title: Pay on Delivery
description: I wholeheartedly agree with Talbot's response to natural childbirth advocates. In fact, I would go one step further and ask, What about women who cannot experience the ''empowering'' experience of childbirth? Are you going to tell me that women who adopt children are less morally or spiritually equipped to be mothers? Because that's what you are implying if you deem giving birth without drugs a singular moment. The challenge of being a mother is not enduring hardship at birth but enduring the hardship -- and joy -- that comes from being a parent. I fear that those who make such a production about the actual birth of a child are more concerned with themselves than with the child.

title: Clinton Tries To Subdue Greeks' Anger At America
description: President Clinton moved to defuse anti-American sentiment in Greece today by suggesting that Washington had erred in supporting the military junta that suppressed democracy here from 1967 to 1974.

title: Knicks Win, and Sprewell Gloats
description: The ranting collection of men in the front-row corner seats were boring their way under the thinning skin of Latrell Sprewell. At first, he could take the irritation, and tossed back the hostile vibes filling up the Arena in Oakland like a stiff shot of whiskey.

title: Even Cowboys Get the Blues
description: WALTER BENJAMIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVEY, SYLVAN
description: LEVEY-Sylvan. 78. Champion of the truth, seeker of the light. He will be greatly missed by his wife, Faye; his daughter, Jill; son in-law Cob; granddaughter, Maya Tilly; and by the scores of friends for whom he was mentor, counselor and incomparable friend. Services Sunday 3 PM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue.

title: M.T.A. Car Searches: Intrusion or Precaution?
description: A nattily dressed stockbroker swung his Mercedes-Benz sedan into the public parking garage, slowing down as two transportation police officers stepped forward to block the entrance. He rolled down the window and briskly rubbed his hands together in the early morning chill.

title: Borrowing the Blues
description: To the Editor:

title: Bradley Is in Full Control, and Some Friends Fret
description: As he was preparing a major poverty proposal earlier this fall, former Senator Bill Bradley huddled with a small group of top advisers to hash out final details. Several aides expressed concerns about one idea they thought might be overreaching and risky: a sweeping pledge to cut child poverty by half over the coming decade.

title: Pay on Delivery
description: Talbot never mentions that it is a slippery slope from the epidural to more serious intervention. She focuses on its role in reducing pain to the exclusion of its potential to harm the birth process. Simply put, a numb woman may not feel enough to ''push'' effectively.

title: Williams Starts to Retaliate Against Dirty Tactics
description: The education of New Orleans Saints running back Ricky Williams continues. The latest lesson: dirty play.

title: Suzanne Palitz And Joel Bauman
description: Dr. Suzanne L. Palitz, a clinical psychologist, and Dr. Joel S. Bauman, a geriatrician, were married last evening by Rabbi Albert Axelrad at the Fairmont Copley Plaza in Boston.

title: A Joyful Noise
description: Talk, Baby!

title: Overkill on Drug Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: I Liked a Pol
description: I first noticed the hole in political journalism during a brief and largely frustrating attempt to fill it. I landed in Washington in 1992, a few steps ahead of the Clintons, and expected the ground to be thick with accounts of life as it appeared to the incoming president. But most of what was written about Clinton, like most of what was written about other big-time politicians, was written from a strange distance. I say strange because the reporters appeared content with their bleacher seats.

title: BENEFITS
description: Aiding Cancer Research

title: Having Important (and Generous) Friends Helps
description: AT WNYC's office, on the 25th floor of the handsome old Municipal Building in Lower Manhattan, volunteers are hunched over the telephones in the rotunda, a drab space that belies its grand moniker, frantically responding to listeners pledging money. Even fortified with coffee and bagels, they look tired. Reporters in the news department, usually out chasing down stories, alternate with staff members like Mark Hilan, local host of ''Morning Edition,'' and Fred Child, musical and cultural director, to plead unashamedly for desperately needed support. These are the final hours of the station's recent fund-raising drive.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 31 of Arts & Leisure today about WNYC radio misstates the given names of a producer who is in Zimbabwe working on a documentary for the station. The producer is Gene Bryan Johnson, not Jane Bryant.

title: The Empty Rocking Chair
description: People are living longer, healthier lives, and what used to be called retirement, a time to sit and fish or crochet, is increasingly an opportunity to grow and explore. Howard Stone, 64, and his wife, Marika, 58, are busy themselves, helping others their age keep busy. Their Web site, www.2young2retire.com, tells stories of people 55 and older who have entered new fields. It has grown to include about 50 links with ideas for post-retirement. The Stones themselves are good examples. Mrs. Stone, formerly in business publishing, is now a yoga teacher, and Mr. Stone, also in that profession, is a professional coach to people who, like him, were interested in making a career transition. Among the site's links are some about coaching and mentoring schoolchildren; on serving as foster grandparents and learning computer skills; for the Peace Corps and Elderhostel, and for new employment possibilities like franchise ownerships.
