This month's true story is about Bob Kasey, a retired executive who started programs called Creative Grandparenting and Creative Mentoring.

title: Have a Heart, or Several
description: What next, a patent on the human heart? No, but a production line for kits so surgeons can build hearts, maybe. William Haseltine, the highflying chief executive of Human Genome Sciences, raised that possibility last week. His company, which aims to develop medical applications for human genes, has already helped produce a drug, now in testing, meant to generate new vessels when injected into the heart. In other words, a bypass without surgery.

title: Parents Blaming Parents
description: I was disgusted by the behavior of Michael and Vonda Shoels in the aftermath of their son's murder. Michael Shoels states that he and his wife are ''not vengeful people.'' He goes on to profess that the Harrises and the Klebolds ''taught those children hate'' and raised ''children who hate.''

title: Family Wine Tradition
description: THE commercial evidence notwithstanding, wine is not the only thing on Don Zacharia's mind. Take the elegant dinner in an upstairs dining room at Le Cirque 2000 in Manhattan in mid-October. The occasion, the 20th anniversary of Opus I, an upscale California Bordeaux-style blend, centered on a Zachys-Christie's mini-auction of 18 imperials -- 6-liter bottles -- and 18 double magnums embracing the 1979-96 vintages.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about inspirational places on Long Island misidentified the man shown on a Woodbury farm. He was Pete Meyer, who owns the farm; Adam Pascal is a friend who used to work there.

title: Steady Eye, a Steadier Hand With a Gun
description: THEY have guns and will travel -- quite often to a marksmanship competition that will end with them taking home a trophy. Here is a look at some of the best shots in Connecticut.

title: Bolstering Your Career, Off the Time Clock
description: Volunteering -- whether to help children, the elderly, the homeless or the hungry -- translates into improved performance on the job and, sometimes, better jobs.

title: Galileo's Universe
description: I traveled to Italy the first time as a tourist, the second time attached to the unglamorous end of a documentary film crew and the third, fourth, fifth and sixth times in search of the ghost of Galileo. At work these past five years on a book about the legendary father of modern science, and naturally infatuated with him, I moved through cities where he'd lived, half expecting to catch sight of his fur-lined jacket ducking into a doorway or rounding a corner just ahead of me on the Via Maggio.

title: Understatement, at $5 Billion
description: BACK in the late 1970's, when Warren A. Stephens was an M.B.A. student at Wake Forest University, he savored the prospect of making it on his own. But he was urged homeward to the family business by a favorite professor who admonished him to ignore any resentment from others over his lineage. No matter what he did, the professor said, ''You're not going to be able to prove anything to the people who want you to prove something.''

title: Amanda Bell, Peter Oltchick
description: Amanda Anne Bell, a daughter of Diana and Charles W. Bell of Easton, Conn., was married last evening to Peter Jay Oltchick, the son of Judith and Stuart Oltchick of Manhattan. Rabbi David Lincoln officiated at the Inn at Longshore in Westport, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, DIANE DAVENPORT
description: ALEXANDER-Diane Davenport. Died peacefully November 17, 1999, at Longboat Key, Florida; age 74. Formerly a resident of Westport, Connecticut. Beloved wife of Charles J. Alexander, Jr., loving mother of Lauren Helmetag of Brooklyn Heights, New York, Leslie Luhring of Brooklyn Heights, Charles J. Alexander III of North Miami, Florida, and Sara Jane Henderson, of Fairfield, Connecticut. Adored grandmother of Max Alexander Helmetag, Alexander Lawrence Luhring, Peter Charles Henderson and Kyle Alexander Henderson. Also survived by many cousins, all grandchildren of the late W. L. Smith and Anne Elizabeth Barlow Smith, of East Liverpool, Ohio. Dede was the daughter of the late Edmund and Sarah (''Sal'') Davenport of New Canaan, Connecticut. She was a graduate of Rosemary Hall School, and in 1948 received a degree of Bachelor of Fine Arts from Yale University. She was an accomplished, devoted artist; at an early age, her ''miniaturistic dexterity'' was acclaimed in a New Yorker review of young artists' work. She was listed in Who's Who in American Art, and was a member of the National Association of Women Artists, the Silvermine (CT) Guild of Artists and Longboat Key Art Center. Dede's blithe spirit, bright wit and thoughtful caring for her family and legion of friends will be missed, but remembered joyously, by all who knew her. A memorial service will be announced later.

title: French Diet Secret: If It Feels Good, Eat It
description: MAYBE it's insouciance. Maybe it's sang-froid. Or maybe it's that certain je ne sais quoi.

title: Island's Mayors, in Unity, Travel to Albany
description: ONE hundred miles from Albany, and barely into three boxes of Entenmann's doughnuts, a small contingent of Long Island mayors decided last week to push New York's largest municipal lobbying group to press the state to administer service awards for volunteer firefighters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FONG, SHEW T.
description: FONG-Shew T., age 72. Loving husband of Lai Wing. Father of Deputy Chief (NYPD) Dewey Fong. Passed away after a long illness on Nov. 18, 1999 in NYC. U.S. Army Veteran and wonderful father and grandfather. Will be greatly missed by family and friends. Viewing Monday, at Chinese Cheung Sang Funeral Home, 22 Mulberry Street, from 3-7 PM. Funeral on Tuesday at noon. Very Dear Friends of Family Howard Koeppel & Mark Hsiao

title: Sherry Li, Russell Levitt
description: Dr. Zhexiang Li, a daughter of Li Xiahui and Shen Shanyu of Shanghai, was married last evening to Russell David Levitt, the son of Vivian Levitt of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Melvin Levitt. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated at the Sheraton Suites in Weehawken, N.J.

title: Senate Inquiry In Keating Case Tested McCain
description: In late 1989, Senator John McCain went home to Arizona to fight for his political life.

title: When the World Is Times Square
description: MILLENNIUM madness is surfacing around the globe, with cities vying to organize New Year's Eve celebrations that are spectacular and meaningful, distinctly regional and globally aware. Some places don't mark time with a calendar dating from Jesus' birth, and others don't have the wealth for a big New Year's Eve bash. Nonetheless, from Tokyo to Rio, South Africa to the North Pole, there are thousands of long-planned millennium events, with last-minute inspirations being announced daily.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPARD, SUE
description: SHEPARD-Sue. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) express profound sorrow at the loss of Sue Shephard of Saint Louis, the generous, loving and supportive partner of her husband, Irving, ATS Chairman of the Board. He was a founding father of the ATS Saint Louis Chapter and continues to be a guiding local, national and international force. As Technion Guardians, the Shepards demonstrated the highest level of commitment for the Technion. In recognition of their exemplary devotion, they were awarded the Albert Einstein Award in 1983, the highest honor bestowed by the ATS. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Irving Shepard and the entire Shepard family. American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology Lawrence S. Jackier, President Melvyn H. Bloom, Exec Vice Pres Alvin A. Wolff, Jr., Saint Lewis Chapter President Marvin Wool, Saint Lewis Chapter Chair Fred Greenberg, West Central Region Director

title: In Crotona Park, Signs of New Season
description: ON a nice day, when golden light bathes the rolling, rocky terrain of Crotona Park, a lovely place to be is the summit of Indian Rock, viewing the little lake and the lofty elm, black cherry, sassafras and sweetgum trees. Indian Rock was named by local boys who mounted the small Bronx peak and imagined they were braves guarding their chief, Ranaqua, as he smoked the pipe of peace with Europeans who wanted the land.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Sugar, Sugar

title: BEST SELLERS: November 21, 1999
description: Weeks

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Books in Brief
description: I, CROCODILE

title: Correction
description: The New York Online column last Sunday, about a Web site produced by Channel 13 to accompany the television series ''New York: A Documentary Film,'' included erroneous references from the site, both to Henry Hudson's voyage to New York in 1609 and to the circumstances of his death. Hudson did not discover New York Harbor. Giovanni da Verrazano is considered the first European to have sailed into the harbor, in 1524. On Hudson's next voyage to the New World, his crew mutinied. He was cast adrift in a small boat in 1611 in what is now Hudson Bay in Canada, and never heard from again. He did not return to New York Harbor and drown.

title: Recorder Players Blow Their Own Horn
description: LIKE a medieval tapestry, the lilting choir of alto, soprano, tenor and bass voices weave, filling the auditorium. But on the round stage at Candlewood Middle School in Dix Hills, the musicians aren't singing in consort. They are all playing the same instrument.

title: A London Zoology of Lions, Lears and Lost Loves
description: YOU want to know what has most exhilarated the London critics this fall? No, it has not been the performance of Nigel Hawthorne (star of the stage and screen versions of ''The Madness of George III'') as the most celebrated of mentally challenged monarchs in Yukio Ninagawa's revival of Shakespeare's ''King Lear.'' No, I'm not talking of the new plays by Alan Ayckbourn and Mark Ravenhill that have recently hit the West End, or even of the Redgrave siblings, Vanessa and Corin, though both are excellent in Noel Coward's ''Song at Twilight'' at the Gielgud.

title: The Short and Long of Races for County Runners
description: NOW that the new marathon world record holder, Khalid Khannouchi, lives in Ossining, maybe Westchester will take to the streets again, becoming a hotbed for competitive running as it was in the past.

title: Tropical Treats, at the Corner Store
description: BEHIND the counter of a bodega at West 169th Street and Audubon Avenue in Washington Heights, Antonio Araujo rings up purchases, hands over packs of cigarettes and occasionally dispenses a single, unwrapped cookie or candy to a customer wanting a reminder of home.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Morningside Heights; 2 Parks Sandwich Town and Gown
description: RISING above the rugged hills overlooking the Hudson River, the soaring Gothic spires of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, at Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street, and the venerable modernist Riverside Church stand as sentinels over Morningside Heights, a neighborhood long known for serving the needs of the body, mind and spirit.

title: After Anatevka: Dark Look at a New Land
description: IT'S just like 'Fiddler,' '' the woman said, very loudly, into her cell phone. ''Very, very similar.''

title: They're the Very Best of Friends; Using a New Language To Write of Old Friends
description: TELL us about your best friends, we said. And you did.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDANIEL, SALLY
description: McDANIEL-Sally. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Sally McDaniel, associated with The Times from 1961 until retiring in 1994.

title: A Sophisticated Meal, Easy on the Wallet
description: IF appetizers are the apple of your eye, do I have a restaurant for you. It's called the California Cafe, but on weeknights, from 4 to 7, the bar and lounge area becomes appetizer heaven. That's when the price of every starter, including soups, salads and light entrees, is cut in half. Diners who enjoy the creativity, diversity, economy pr ordering two or three appetizers rather than conventional entree-centered meals will be delighted with the choices and fun available at this sleek Roosevelt Field Shopping Mall spot in Garden City (516-294-8686). Add a glass of any house wine for $3, and on Monday nights any bottle for half its regular price, and you have a varied and sophisticated feast for a virtual pittance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRLICH, STANLEY L.
description: EHRLICH-Stanley L. Of Short Hills, NJ. On Friday, November 19, 1999. Husband of the late Phyllis Dettelbach Ehrlich. Survived by son, David Ehrlich and his wife Joanne, and grandson Alexander. Memorial service at Smith and Smith (Suburban), 415 Morris Avenue, Springfield, NJ on Sunday, November 28, at 1PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Overlook Hospital Foundation, PO Box 220, Summit, NJ 07902-0220.

title: 2 Killed and 113 Injured in Pileup of 4 Buses
description: Four buses carrying hundreds of students back to Pennsylvania State University after a day in Manhattan collided in a chain-reaction pileup on a foggy Interstate highway in northeastern Pennsylvania early yesterday. Two people were killed and 113 were injured, 7 seriously, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANKS, ROBERT DOUGLAS
description: DANKS-Robert Douglas. Died November 18, in Palm Beach, FL, at the age of 97. Founding Partner of Ernst and Co., and former Governor of the New York Stock Exchange. Fomrer resident of Rye, NY. Beloved husband of the late Anne Danks. Survived by his wife Gil and daughter Evelyn Corbetta of Darien, CT. Devoted grandfather of Jane Yezzi, Maryann Cousins, Allison Radin, Robert and Richard Corbetta. Also survived by eight great-grandchildren. Family will receive friends Monday, November 22, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Post Rd., Rye. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10 AM, Resurrection Church, Rye. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

title: Internet Makes an Easy Target For Lobbyists and Lawmakers
description: When it comes to cyberspace, the mantra of politicians vying for the title of most e-friendly, Republicans and Democrats alike, has been ''Hands off and go slow.'' Yet lawmakers have already passed a laundry list of bills that leave the federal government's fingerprints all over the Internet, and more are in the pipeline.

title: McCain Sees No Proof of an Effort to Question His Stability
description: Senator John McCain of Arizona said today that he was not personally aware of any whispering campaign by fellow senators to suggest that his war experience in Vietnam had left him too emotionally unstable to be president.

title: What Teachers Know
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, DIANE DAVENPORT
description: ALEXANDER-Diane Davenport. Died peacefully November 17, 1999, at Longboat Key, Florida; age 74. Formerly a resident of Westport, Connecticut. Beloved wife of Charles J. Alexander, Jr., loving mother of Lauren Helmetag of Brooklyn Heights, New York, Leslie Luhring of Brooklyn Heights, Charles J. Alexander III of North Miami, Florida, and Sara Jane Henderson, of Fairfield, Connecticut. Adored grandmother of Max Alexander Helmetag, Alexander Lawrence Luhring, Peter Charles Henderson and Kyle Alexander Henderson. Also survived by many cousins, all grandchildren of the late W. L. Smith and Anne Elizabeth Barlow Smith, of East Liverpool, Ohio. Dede was the daughter of the late Edmund and Sarah (''Sal'') Davenport of New Canaan, Connecticut. She was a graduate of Rosemary Hall School, and in 1948 received a degree of Bachelor of Fine Arts from Yale University. She was an accomplished, devoted artist; at an early age, her ''miniaturistic dexterity'' was acclaimed in a New Yorker review of young artists' work. She was listed in Who's Who in American Art, and was a member of the National Association of Women Artists, the Silvermine (CT) Guild of Artists and Longboat Key Art Center. Dede's blithe spirit, bright wit and thoughtful caring for her family and legion of friends will be missed, but remembered joyously, by all who knew her. A memorial service will be announced later.

title: The Struggle for the Center
description: Now that Congress has adjourned, and the presidential campaign is heating up, it is worth noting some shifts in voter attitudes. These adjustments do not seem obvious to Republican Congressional leaders in Washington. They remain wedded to their anti-government approach of tax cuts above all. They are also at a low ebb in public confidence, according to a spate of recent polls. These surveys affirm the conventional wisdom that national elections are in the main a battle for control of the political center. But they also show that the center contains new combinations of voters whose loyalties are not firmly tied to either party.

title: Getting Better Teachers
description: I am not surprised by the recent news that New York City teachers score much lower than their suburban counterparts on the state's certification exams. In the 20 years I spent as an administrator in Community School District 19 in Brooklyn, the last four as superintendent, I saw the quality of the staff sink. As teachers retire and more are needed to reduce class sizes, the perennial problem of hiring qualified educators has become dire, especially in poor districts.

title: A More Open I.M.F.
description: Michel Camdessus, the self-assured but often criticized managing director of the International Monetary Fund, announced his retirement earlier this month and already a handful of European officials are busy choosing his successor. French, German and British officials regard the appointment as theirs to make despite the fact that managing directors make decisions that decide the fate of taxi drivers in Indonesia, small shop owners in Ecuador, taxpayers in Thailand and farmers throughout sub-Saharan Africa.

title: Accounts
description: Carfax Inc., Fairfax, Va., part of the R. L. Polk Co., to the Martin Agency, Richmond, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., to handle the first account of the used-car data company. Spending was estimated at $15 million to $20 million in the next 12 months.

title: Compressed Data; A Night on the Digital Edge Without Videos or Ice Cream
description: It seemed a simple enough way to spend a Saturday night in Manhattan: cross the new frontier in digital home delivery by ordering two videos and a pint of ice cream from Kozmo.com, the Web site that has reaped abundant publicity by promising to zip videos to your doorstep in under an hour.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: No Longer Tolerant of Official Misconduct, Brazilians Now Demand Accountability
description: Suspect that bankers may have illegally profited from Brazil's currency devaluation last January? Convene a congressional investigation to look into it. Worried about organized crime? Order a second legislative inquiry. Fearful of corruption in the judiciary? Get yet another committee to examine the issue.

title: Pragmatists Told to Beware 'Chemically Pure Capitalism' : Trans-Atlantic Visions of a Center-Left Future
description: FLORENCE  America, the practical, and Europe, the rather more theoretical, looked at the future and how to govern it on Sunday, and came out with characteristic answers for the management of economies and nations that seem less and less responsive to ideology.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Thursday about the recruiting frenzy for technical talent in Silicon Valley referred imprecisely to the immigration status of Canadian and Mexican workers. Visas are indeed required, though under the North American Free Trade Agreement, provisions are less restrictive for Canadians and Mexicans in some jobs than for other foreign workers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FULLER, FRANCES A.
description: FULLER-Frances A. 88 years. Dalton, PA. Died November 20, at home. Widow of Mortimer Bartine Fuller Jr., former President of International Salt Co., Clarks Summit, PA. Graduate Rosemary Hall, Greenwich, CT, and Smith College, Northampton, MA. Surviving: two daughters, Patricia Acker Fuller, Providence, RI, Frances Fuller Gunster, Dalton, PA; one son, Mortimer B. III, Rye, NY; eight grandchildren; seven great-grandchildren; several nieces and nephews. Funeral services Wednesday, November 24, 10 AM, at Church of the Epiphany, Glenburn, PA. Interment will be private. Friends may call at the family residence, Dalton, PA, Tuesday, 3-6 PM. Memorial contributions to the Friendship House, Scranton, PA; the Overlook Foundation, Dalton, PA; or Church of the Epiphany, Glenburn, PA. For information, contact Snowdon Funeral Homes, Scranton, PA.

title: Altered Foods: Future Can Wait
description: To the Editor:

title: Magicalmysterycat Takes Valley Stream
description: Magicalmysterycat, one of the leading juvenile fillies in racing until she started a four-race losing streak last summer, broke out of her slump at Aqueduct yesterday when she rallied in the home-stretch and won the Valley Stream Stakes at odds of 7-1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, FRANCES (NEE FRUHLINGER)
description: WILSON-Frances (nee Fruhlinger). On November 21, 1999. Of NYC. Loving wife of the late Abraham (Al). Dear sister of Dorothy Rosenstein. Devoted aunt and great-aunt. Services Monday, 12:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Chaos and Intolerance Prevailing In Kosovo Despite U.N.'s Efforts
description: Five months after NATO forces moved in to take absolute control of Kosovo, there is little electricity and an inconstant water supply, the streets are full of garbage, traffic is in chaos without working stoplights or police direction, few cars have license plates, and no one has new identity papers.

title: Masters Add to Their Honors At the Fall Nationals in Boston
description: The world's biggest collection of master points grew here last night after the opening event of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall National Championships. Paul Soloway of Mill Creek, Wash., who has more than 52,000 points and has been winning titles at every level for more than 30 years, snatched a victory in the Life Master Open Pairs, playing with Steve Catlett of Richmond, Va. Lew and Joanna Stansby of Castro Valley, Calif., the defending champions, were overtaken in the final round and placed second.

title: An Extravagant Station
description: To the Editor:

title: Boulez in His New Role: Relaxed, Jovial and Busy
description: Pierre Boulez's first stint in the Composer's Chair at Carnegie Hall last week was brief but busy. Inside four days he spent several hours talking in public, rehearsed a group of young professionals for an all-Schoenberg program at Weill Recital Hall and presented a concert with the Ensemble Intercontemporain in the main auditorium. Those who went to everything, including about 80 young conductors, players and composers chosen to attend the Schoenberg preparations, had a blast of the Boulezian spirit, which, like sharp winter air in sunlight, is exciting and challenging and lets you see clearly. As for Mr. Boulez himself, he seemed happy, cordial and relaxed.

title: Faubion Bowers, 82, Defender Of Kabuki in Occupied Japan
description: Faubion Bowers, an American linguist, critic and writer on the arts who helped preserve Kabuki, the popular drama of Japan, when occupation authorities sought to ban it as a relic of a feudal society after World War II, died on Tuesday at his Manhattan home. He was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NITKA, ESTELLE
description: NITKA-Estelle. Wife of the late Arthur. Beloved mother of Roberta, Larry, Cheryl and Stephanie. Mother-in-law to Carol Nitka and Mark Reeder. Beloved sister of Mildred Fischel and Arthur (Sonny) Brenner. Beloved grandmother to Rachel, Sarah, Alex and Lucy.

title: Wielding the Kennedy Name for the Good of His Party
description: EVERY once in a while, Representative Patrick J. Kennedy says, he shows up to address some Democratic fund-raising event out in the country and the people awaiting him smile politely and ask, ''When is the congressman getting here?''

title: Op-Art
Political Privilege
description: To the Editor:

title: Pointing a Gun at Nature
description: To the Editor:

title: Victim of an Earlier Random Assault Is Recovering
description: His jaw is no longer wired shut and his shattered fingers are beginning to move again, but Kent Gasser's face still bears the signs of a merciless beating he survived six weeks ago in Riverside Park, when a stranger bashed his head with a rock in the middle of the day.

title: Israel's Leader Highly Praises Hillary Clinton
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel offered an unprompted defense of Hillary Rodham Clinton yesterday, telling a group of American Jewish leaders in New York that her recent trip to the Middle East had been ''highly successful'' and had advanced the peace process.

title: Gates Foundation Gives Unicef $26 Million to Combat Tetanus
description: An American support group for Unicef, the United Nations children's fund, announced yesterday that it has received its largest donation ever, a grant of $26 million from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation earmarked for the elimination of tetanus among babies and their mothers in the poorest nations.

title: Internet Companies Agree to Merger
description: Two Internet companies that are minority owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies have agreed to a deal.

title: Jets Catch Bills With Their Guard Down
description: It's too soon to tell whether the Jets' 17-7 victory over the Buffalo Bills today will have any significance, but the Jets continue to surprise everyone but themselves.

title: Suicide Cult's Possessions Auctioned Off
description: Many of the items on the block were ordinary enough -- a plastic laundry hamper, card tables, camping gear, clothes, tools, cookbooks, a sewing machine. Only a few -- a voluminous collection of books about U.F.O.'s, 20 metal-frame bunk beds, a pair of black Nike sneakers -- offered a hint of their macabre origins.

title: MEDIA: Cue the Music, Roll the Mayhem; Wrestling, Once Ad-Libbed, Is Now as Carefully Scripted As a Top-Rated Soap Opera
description: On a recent Monday, 11,000 fans gathered in Conseco Fieldhouse here to watch World Championship Wrestling's ''Monday Nitro,'' a live wrestling match with more plot twists than an Italian opera. Behind a silver curtain near the ring, the scriptwriters, Vince Russo and Ed Ferrara, stood with earphones clamped to their heads, staring into television monitors, following the action as 3.5 million people watched on Turner Network Television, a unit of Time Warner Inc.

title: Daigle Stars in Ranger Debut
description: Alexandre Daigle made the most of his return to the National Hockey League, earning at least one more game by assisting on two goals in his Rangers debut Saturday night.

title: Thoughtful Songs That Speak Of Passion and Righteousness
description: In the search for love, truth and justice, a good vamp never hurts. That's the modus operandi of Me'shell Ndegeocello, the singer, songwriter and band leader who carried her audience from rapt silence to joyful shouts at the Bowery Ballroom on Wednesday night.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the At the Movies column of Weekend on Nov. 12 about Ang Lee's ''Ride With the Devil,'' which is to open in Los Angeles and New York on Wednesday, misstated the title of the novel on which the film is based. It is ''Woe to Live On,'' not ''Ride With the Devil.''

title: Hear, Hear, Please! 'Question Time' in Japan
description: The prime minister is at the lectern, struggling to field a series of increasingly challenging questions from the leader of the opposition. Jeers are rising in crescendo from the Parliament floor, and the few spectators allowed in are on the edge of their seats, fairly straining for a view.

title: Monday Morning Quarterback
description: DO THEY EAT LIKE THEY BLOCK?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINKOFF, EDITH
description: MINKOFF-Edith. Died in her sleep on November 20. She was a beloved mother, grandmother, sister, aunt and friend, a longtime volunteer Braille writer, and a former Clerk of the Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. She was a dynamic human being. We all loved her. Roni Norwin

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GEORGES KAPLAN
description: GEORGES KAPLAN Toujours dans nos coeurs. Ta Famille

title: It's No Contest in M.L.S. As United Takes 3rd Title
description: Two defensive blunders by the Los Angeles Galaxy were all D.C. United needed today to capture its third title in the four years of Major League Soccer with a 2-0 victory before 44,910 at Foxboro Stadium.

title: More Teenagers Disapprove Of Drug Use, Survey Finds
description: Teenage approval of marijuana and other illegal drugs has started declining, with fewer adolescents saying they consider drug use to be ''cool,'' according to a national study being released today.

title: A Homeless Man Challenges New York City Crackdowns
description: Even before New York's police commissioner pledged last week to arrest homeless people who persist in sleeping on sidewalks, a homeless Army veteran who has improvised a bed on the city's streets for a decade was quietly trying to stop him through the courts.

title: Exceptions to the Balanchine Rule
description: ''Tzigane'' and ''Meditation'' are the two ballets by which George Balanchine should not be judged. The first looks like a Cubist nightclub number on Gypsy motifs, and the second offers an unabashedly sentimental image of a man recalling his lost love.

title: Altered Foods: Future Can Wait
description: To the Editor:

title: Jordan Frees Four Jailed Hamas Leaders and Expels Them
description: Ending a three-month standoff, King Abdullah of Jordan freed four imprisoned leaders of the militant Palestinian movement Hamas today and hours later placed them on a private jet bound for the Persian Gulf state of Qatar, Jordanian officials said.

title: Holiday Target For Music Sales Over Internet Won't Be Met
description: After scrambling to adopt a technical standard for sales of music online, record companies and hardware makers last summer said they had paved the way for Christmas sales of portable digital players. But the holidays are ringing in a reality: neither the tunes nor the players will be in place to make this the first big ''digital music Christmas.''

title: Sports of The Times; Lucas Is in Charge Of a Reborn Dream
description: THERE is a large opening at the west end of Giants Stadium. On game days, the area just inside the opening is an intersection of hustle and bustle as players scramble to get on buses, greet family and friends and begin the process of digesting a tough loss or a heady victory.

title: Davis Leaves His Mark on the Game
description: As today's grueling game ground to a conclusion with a 23-13 Redskins victory over the Giants, Washington running back Stephen Davis wore a uniform that displayed colors different from those worn by his teammates. In addition to the team scheme of white, gold and burgundy, Davis wore the green of the grass and the brown of the dirt. He acquired them by carrying the football 33 times for 183 yards, the most yardage in a game this season in the National Football League, and the most in Davis's four-year professional career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFEDER, SAMUEL
description: GOLDFEDER - Samuel. Died peacefully at 85 in Ft. Lauderdale. A sweet and caring man who deeply loved his family. Survived by Rose, wife of 59 years; children Edward (Phyllis) and Jerry (Alice Yaker); and grandchildren Michelle, Lisa, Peter (Larissa) and Carly; and sister Laura. Shiva at Jerry and Alice's Monday and Tuesday 7-10 PM, Tuesday and Wednesday 12-4 PM. Everyone who knew him loved him.

title: No Rescuer but No Capitulation, Mannesmann Chief Says
description: As he tries to fend off the biggest hostile takeover attempt in history, the chief executive of Mannesmann A.G. insisted today that he was not looking for a rescue by either a ''white knight'' investor or by German political leaders.

title: Russian, as Moor of Venice, Enters Tough Competition
description: For more than 20 years the role of Verdi's Otello, one of the most dramatically and vocally challenging in the repertory of Italian opera, has essentially been owned by Placido Domingo. So the appearance of any new aspirant is news.

title: Side by Side, a Veiled Spirit And a Heart Upon the Sleeve
description: For the years she ruled as the queen of television variety shows, from 1967 to 1978, Carol Burnett was a warm spot in the seas of medium cool. At a moment when comedy kept turning darker and angrier, Ms. Burnett offered brilliant clowning without bile, satire without a sneer. Few contemporary comedians have commanded such undiluted good will, and even today this actress can't appear on a stage or screen without inspiring an instant flood of affection.

title: Citywide Sweep Leads to 23 Arrests of the Homeless
description: Acting on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's declaration that a civilized city should not tolerate people sleeping on its streets, police officers arrested 23 homeless people over the weekend, all for disorderly conduct, and referred 127 others to shelters after sweeping through 850 locations across the city that are known as havens for the homeless, city officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHIZNER, RICHARD
description: CHIZNER-Richard. The Board of Governors of Inwood Country Club record with sorrow the passing of our Vice President, Richard Chizner. We extend heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Judith, his adoring children and grandchildren. We will miss you. The Board of Governors of Inwood Country Club

title: Neighbors Give Central Park a Wealthy Glow
description: By passing the hat among its neighbors, who happen to be America's most densely packed bunch of rich people, Central Park has harvested the largest haul of private dollars ever raised for a public park.

title: CUNY Plan to Bar Remedial Students From 4-Year Programs Faces a Final Test
description: Eighteen months after the City University of New York decided to remove ill-prepared students from its senior colleges, the policy faces its last hurdle today as the New York State Regents decide whether it is consistent with the university's mission.

title: Right to Pray
description: To the Editor:

title: Media Talk; Executive Editor Is Quitting Talk Magazine
description: Editors are leaving Talk magazine and its guiding light, Tina Brown. First it was the managing editor, then it was a features editor, and now it is David Kuhn, Ms. Brown's longtime deputy, who followed her from Vanity Fair to The New Yorker and who has spent almost a dozen years altogether under her editorial spell.

title: Steelers Too Weak To Topple The Titans
description: There were 3 minutes 15 seconds left, the Pittsburgh Steelers had the ball at their 9-yard line and trailed the Tennessee Titans by 16-10 at Adelphia Stadium today. Pittsburgh, with no timeouts remaining, was a 91-yard drive away from 7 points to win it.

title: Bowden Drives a Bus With One Stop to Go
description: He sat on a bench in the front of the locker room looking every bit of his 70 years. Sweat trailed down the side of Bobby Bowden's face. Half-dressed athletes 50 years younger talked to the television cameras, baby-faced trainers gathered up soaked uniforms from the floor while men and women toting notebooks stepped around him.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Tired of Losing, Defense Angrily Points Fingers
description: This is becoming the same old sad, miserable story for the Giants. It keeps repeating itself, like a bad dream, or Bill Murray's tripping out in ''Groundhog Day.'' The Giants' offense is so bad, it was practically shut down by the worst defense in the National Football League. The Giants' offense is so bad that quarterback Kent Graham was on the sideline late in the second quarter, taking smelling salts, his head woozy from yet another concussion after enduring a half-dozen nasty shots from the Washington Redskins' terrible defensive line.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: At Vassar, a Lesson in Impermanence
description: Amid battered picnic tables and grimy barbecue stands, nine Tibetan monks stood in a park on a rainy night and cast millions of grains of consecrated sand into the Hudson River.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIMARCO, MERK
description: DiMARCO-Merk. Of Huntington, retired insurance broker. Husband of Dorothy, father of Stephen, Suzanne Bense, and Valerie McGuire. Reposing Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Avenue, Huntington. Mass Tuesday, 9:45 AM, St. Patrick's Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, JEROME
description: ZIMMERMAN-Jerome. Beloved husband of Renee. Devoted father of Leslie Daspin and Kenneth Zimmerman. Dear father-in-law of Richard Daspin and Arlene Zimmerman. Adored grandfather of Scott, Jonathan, Matthew, Nicole, Zachary and Ryan. Great grandfather of Lekse Daspin. Services Monday, November 22, 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street. Contributions to the Foundation Fighting Blindness will be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLIFFORD, JOHN A.
description: CLIFFORD-John A. On November 20, 1999. Beloved husband of Noel. Loving father of Joan. Dear brother of Sister Mary Olivia, R.S.M. Funeral from Francis X. Hatton Funeral Home, Inc, 36-46 Bell Blvd, Bayside, on Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial at Sacred Heart R.C. Church, at 9:45 AM. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. Visiting 2-5, 7-9 PM, on Monday.

title: Town With Fabled Past Facing Uncertain Future
description: When a group of newly freed slaves here wanted to form a community of their own just after the Civil War, they had to take whatever land they could get. In 1865, that was a snake-infested, mosquito-ridden swamp in a flood plain along the southern side of the Tar River in eastern North Carolina. It was land that the white people in nearby Tarboro, on the northern side of the river, did not want.

title: An Odyssey That Started With 'Ulysses'
description: At the age of 18, after my freshman year in college, I worked as a mailman. This was merely a summer job. My life's calling, I had decided, was to be a novelist, and late at night I was already toiling on my first novel.

title: A Veteran Director, Delighting in Opposites
description: There are odd juxtapositions in the career of any filmmaker, particularly one who has been at it as long and prolifically as Michael Apted. But it's hard to imagine an alignment odder than the one that has encompassed Mr. Apted in the last few days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, SOLOMON
description: FELDMAN-Solomon. On November 19, 1999. Beloved husband of Edith. Devoted father of Penny and David Graubard, and Mark and Dede Feldman. Cherished grandfather of Kerry and Stephan Shelanski, Andrew and Samantha Kronfeld, Abigail Feldman, Peter and Marly Graubard and Jordan Graubard. Loving great-grandfather of Liliana, Daniel, Annabel, Jack and Harrison. Services Tuesday, 12 noon, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: When a Parent Becomes the Child
description: I REMAIN IN DARKNESS

title: Patents; Helping drug makers fit the medication to a patient's genetic makeup.
description: HY is it that one type of antidepressant can lift one patient's spirits while the same medication leaves his neighbor jittery and sleepless? Or that a certain asthma drug might instantly open up one child's breathing passageways, while bringing no relief to the next wheezing patient who walks into the pediatrician's office?

title: Vive La Difference (Electronic)
description: Jonathan Harvey, who was featured last Monday at the first of two Miller Theater concerts devoted to composers connected with the Paris electronic music institution Ircam, has noted what he calls an increasing ''femaleness'' in his work, as electronic and live sounds mix to create music that is embracing and enfolding, rich and warm in sound and, however fast the detail, unhurried in essence. Keeping the metaphor, the works of his colleagues Tristan Murail and Magnus Lindberg, performed in the second concert, on Thursday, would have to be described as female and male respectively.

title: Ninepins Holds Off Muscle Car to Win
description: Ninepins took the lead over the 17th of 19 jumps and then fought back a strong challenge from the runner-up, Muscle Car, to win the $100,000 Marion duPont Scott Colonial Cup Steeplechase on Saturday at Springdale Race Course in Camden, S.C.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLEICH, DOROTHY REMAN
description: BLEICH-Dorothy Reman. On November 21, 1999, died peacefully in her sleep after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Martin. Devoted mother of David and Laura, Eric and June, Gay and Gene Kassan. Adored grandmother of Brian, Kate, Amanda, Alexander, Michael Kassan and Elisabeth Kassan. Dear sister of Sylvia Gurchin. Services Monday, 2 PM, graveside, at Wellwood Cemetery. For information contact Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Forest Hills, NY, (718) 263-7600.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FELDMAN, HENRY, KISLEV
description: FELDMAN-Henry, Kislev 19-1994 Beloved. Still missed-still loved. Toujours dans nos coeurs Your wife Helen and son Leonard

title: Woman Fatally Stabs Another at a Bowling Alley in Queens, the Police Say
description: An 18-year-old teacher's assistant enjoying an evening with friends at a Queens bowling alley was killed early yesterday by a young woman who had been harassing her for about 45 minutes before the attack, the police and the victim's family said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLAVIN, JOHN I.
description: SLAVIN-John I. On Saturday, November 20, 1999. Of West Orange. Beloved husband of Florence (nee Lieb). Devoted father of Judy May and Emily Grotta. Cherished grandfather of Joanna May, Jesse May, Jacob Grotta and Amy Grotta. Graveside services were held at Temple B'nai Jeshrun Cemetery, Hillside, NJ, on Sunday, November 21, 1999, at 3:30 PM. For information, Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, NJ.

title: William Nickerson, 91, Writer Of Popular Investment Books
description: William E. Nickerson, who made millions of dollars from real estate investments and millions more writing books telling others how to do the same thing, died on Oct. 19 at his home in Capitola, Calif. He was 91.

title: Bush Explains His Opposition to Abortion
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas today made clear his strong opposition to most abortions and implied that while he would not, if elected president, make that viewpoint the principal consideration in appointing Supreme Court justices, he might not dismiss it, either.

title: Quentin Crisp, Writer and Actor on Gay Themes, Dies at 90
description: Quentin Crisp, the British-born writer, raconteur and actor who found fame at 59 when he published ''The Naked Civil Servant,'' an account of his openly homosexual life in London, and who found happiness when he moved to New York at 72, died yesterday in Manchester, England. He was 90.

title: A Battle for Farmers
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Schedules Bill and Note Sales
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and a two-year note being auctioned tomorrow.

title: Excite@Home to Separate Cable and Content Divisions
description: Under pressure from investors to clarify its business strategy, Excite@Home has decided to draw a distinction between its Internet access business and its media-content business by creating a separate tracking stock for the media assets, the company said today.

title: In America; The Softer Side of Steinbrenner
description: Psst. The Yankees aren't going anywhere. Not to New Jersey. Not to the West Side. A glittering new 21st-century stadium will blossom in the Bronx, where the greatest tradition in all of sports will continue. Bet on it.

title: Giants Fumble Their Chance at First Place
description: Where there was a late drive, there was also a late fumble. Where there was a late stop, there was also a late penalty. Where there were defensive heroics, there were also gaping holes. Where the offense looked rejuvenated under a new leader, it also scored just one touchdown against the worst defense in the National Football League.

title: Jewish G.O.P. Group Unveils Ad Assailing First Lady on Mideast
description: A group of Jewish Republicans has produced a television commercial attacking Hillary Rodham Clinton for remaining silent at an event two weeks ago where the wife of Yasir Arafat accused Israel of poisoning Palestinian women and children with toxic gases.

title: A Labor Shortage?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PRICE, BARRY
description: PRICE-Barry. A beautiful boy away from us 24 years. You're always in our hearts. Love & kisses, Mommy, Daddy, Jodi, Blair, Mar

title: Nets Hit the Road, but 1-9 Is Not a Highway
description: Less than 24 hours after suffering a humiliating loss to a Philadelphia 76ers squad led by John Calipari, their former coach, the Nets flew west yesterday as a team in almost total disarray.

title: Agencies Named By 3 Advertisers
description: Three advertisers are naming agencies.

title: INSIDE
description: Drug Suspect Extradited

title: Excerpts From Bush's Comments on Abortion
description: Following are excerpts from comments on abortion by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas in an interview by Tim Russert on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press.'' They were transcribed by the Federal Document Clearinghouse.

title: Why to Reject an Ad
description: To the Editor:

title: Point-and-click with a personal touch: Internet company offers customized computer cursors.
description: A SMALL Internet company is hoping that the adage about tall oaks growing from little acorns also applies to cyberspace, as it seeks big results from turning perhaps the tiniest place on a computer screen into advertising.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VANDERBILT, ALFRED GWYNNE
description: VANDERBILT-Alfred Gwynne. A memorial service for friends, family and horsemen will be held Monday, December 6, 1999 at 10:30 AM, Aqueduct Race Track, Equestris Dining Room. For information, 718-641-4700 ext 3433.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOONVES, SOL
description: MOONVES-Sol. Age 82, of Margate, FL, formerly of Long Island. Devoted husband of the late Leah and brother of Herman and Josie. Beloved father of Joy (and the late Alan) Buchfirer, Marcia (and Gene) Cooper, Marlene (and George) Stephanides, Fred, Chip and the late Paul (and Denyse), and adored grandfather of Julie, Stacy, Heather, Kim, Ashley, Zachary and Jackie, and cherished uncle.

title: One Final Goal for Gretzky, and It's a Beauty
description: When it comes to Wayne Gretzky, there is always room for another honor. On Monday night here, not far from his hometown of Brantford, Ontario, Gretzky will be accorded the greatest honor: enshrinement in the Hockey Hall of Fame.

title: Crime Rate in New York City Fell 8 Percent in Early '99, F.B.I. Says
description: Despite an uptick in the homicide rate, New York City's overall crime rate fell by 8 percent during the first six months of the year, compared with the same period last year, according to preliminary figures released yesterday by the F.B.I.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Clinton, a Renaissance Guy, Paints the Globe Bright
description: It was a long wait, particularly long because the bathrooms were placed off limits for security reasons, long enough even for the Champagne and the caviar canapes to run out, but when President Clinton arrived he quickly wowed a glittering audience with visions of a juster world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSELL, VIVIAN
description: RUSSELL-Vivian. Beloved mother of Lucian Russell & Robin Russell, and grandmother of Matthew Russell, died on 16 November, 1999, in Hyattsville, MD. A memorial service is in the planning stage. For information call 212-243-9937.

title: When Interns Meet Managed Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about shopping robots that offer online price comparisons, referred incorrectly to Bottomdollar.com. Internet merchants can pay the company for advertisements on its site only; they cannot pay to have their products put at the top of lists of search results.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Those are the streets I played in, the trees I climbed. You take the town and move it anywhere else, then you've severed me from my actual roots.''

title: Equity Offerings Set for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMERMAN, BERNARD
description: HAMMERMAN-Bernard. On November 19, 1999. Born July 15, 1923. Devoted son of the late Louis and Rose Hammerman. Loving husband of Joan; father of Darcy (Allen), Brett (Dana) and Robert (Wendy). Adoring grandfather of Harley, Jeremy, Sloane and Maris. Precious brother of Ben (Lorelei), Goldie (Norman), David (Sarah) and the late Hyman (Florence). Caring uncle to his nephews and nieces and their children. Bernie was a purple heart veteran of World War II. At the end of 1945, with his brothers, he started the family business which proudly continues. With the passage of years, Bernie formed a multitude of friendships with reciprocal loyalties. He was generous of spirit and substance. He lived his life by the Golden Rule, with great pride in his heritage. He was respected and loved by all of his friends, employees and family. We are all truly bereaved and pray that we may find solace in his blessed memory. Family will be sitting shiva at the Hammerman residence, 980 5th Avenue, New York City. The Hammerman Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDMAN, JUDITH
description: SEIDMAN-Judith. On November 21, in her 88th year. Deeply beloved wife for 63 treasured years of her lifelong friend Lloyd. Incomparable mother of Elinor Berlin and David, and to their spouses Robert Berlin and Ruth Greenstein. Devoted grandmother of Daniel, Michael and Joanna Berlin. Her inspiration remains with countless friends, relatives and students, here and abroad. A memorial service will be announced.

title: When Interns Meet Managed Care
description: To the Editor:

title: E-Commerce Report; Seller beware: A new kind of software tool makes it easier for Internet surfers to track down the lowest on-line prices.
description: E-COMMERCE companies have enough to worry about when it comes to competitive pricing, as Internet shoppers can visit price-comparison sites like mySimon and DealTime.com to search for savings.

title: Once Again, Davenport Dominates Hingis
description: Public floggings may be illegal, but Lindsay Davenport inflicted one on top-ranked Martina Hingis yesterday at Madison Square Garden. Davenport wielded her racket like a weapon in a shockingly one-sided 6-4, 6-2 victory in the final of the Chase Championships, and Hingis, who usually thinks her way out of intimidating situations, never came close to escaping this one.

title: Doug Sahm, Musical Voice of Texas, Dies at 58
description: Doug Sahm, a patriarch of Texas rock and country music, was found dead on Thursday in Taos, N.M., The Associated Press reported. He was 58 and lived in Austin.

title: Czechs Line Up to Remember Iron Curtain's Bad Old Days at Cardboard 'Museum'
description: Ten years after the Velvet Revolution, which quickly ended 40 years of totalitarian rule here, Prague residents found themselves this weekend back in grim Communist reality, complete with interminable lines in shops, abusive police officers, arrogant bureaucrats and brainwashing propaganda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BINEN, SEYMOUR
description: BINEN-Seymour. Beloved husband of Fay (Gordon). Devoted father of Dr. Lenore Binen and Lloyd Binen, and stepfather of Ira and David Gordon. Cherished grandfather of nine. Great-grandpa of Leah. Services Monday, 1:30 PM, at ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Altered Foods: Future Can Wait
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASCHER, GERARD
description: ASCHER-Gerard. On November 21, 1999, at age 82. Beloved husband of Bertha, devoted father of Enid and loving brother of Doris Alenier. Service 11 AM, Tuesday, November 23, at Menorah Gardens, 9321 Memorial Park Road, West Palm Beach, FL.

title: Olivetti's Chief Drops Asset Plan
description: Olivetti S.p.A. and Tecnost S.p.A., the unit through which Olivetti bought Telecom Italia, said today that they had abandoned plans to strip Italy's largest telecommunications company of its profitable mobile phone unit.

title: He Plays His Role To Perfection
description: The profanity tumbled from his mouth unfailingly, until the final horn blared and his team had won. Some of it was tossed in the direction of belligerent courtside fans, some at the players assigned to guard him.

title: Japanese Hospitality
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite Agreement, Snags Remain for Digital TV
description: The cable television and consumer electronics industries say they have finally solved a problem that has lingered for more than 18 months as a serious impediment to digital TV.

title: Essay; A Lightweight He's Not
description: The political news of the week is that George W. Bush can comport himself confidently under sustained, serious questioning.

title: Microsoft Faces A Class Action On 'Monopoly'
description: Lawyers say they will file a class-action suit against Microsoft today on behalf of millions of Californians, in the first of what could become a flood of major lawsuits springing from the Justice Department's antitrust action against the company.

title: So Far, It Just Keeps On Ending and Ending and . . .
description: The cracked-looking fellow in a sandwich board that announces, ''The End Is Nigh!,'' has served cartoonists down the decades, but for believers over many centuries the message has been no joke. With the millennium upon us and a million pilgrims expected in Jerusalem, once again expectations of Armageddon are stirring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, FRANK
description: ROTH-Frank. 78, of Lakeville, CT, formerly of Roslyn, NY. Loving husband and best friend of Barbara for 50 years. Cherished father of Ellyn Mittman, Stuart Roth and Peter Roth, and father-in-law of Larry Mittman, Elizabeth Roth and Michelle Roth. Beloved grandfather of Wesley and Jordan Mittman. Dedicated to his family, who were his greatest source of pleasure and pride. Gifted musician and furniture designer. Former President of Congregation Beth David, Amenia, NY, and founder of The Connecticut Northwest Corner Jewish Community Group. He will live on in the hearts of his loved ones forever. Services 12 noon, Monday, at ''The Riverside,'' 180 West 76th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the University of Massachusetts Cancer Center in Worcester, MA 01613-9938.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FADER, JUTTA
description: FADER-Jutta. The staff of the Kings County District Attorney's Office mourns with deep sorrow the untimely passing of Jutta Fader, beloved wife of David Fader, Executive Director of Fiscal and Human Resouces. In addition to her husband, Jutta is survived by her mother, Herta Schliewert, her sister, Barbara, and partner, Ulla Scholtes. David's friends and colleagues send their heartfelt condolences to him and the entire family. We know she will be truly missed. Charles J. Hynes, District Attorney and staff of the District Attorney's Office

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NULTY, MARILYN E.
description: NULTY-Marilyn E. Of Boca Raton, FL, and Oceanside, NY, on November 19, 1999. Beloved wife of John W. Loving mother of Susan L. Sempier (Burt J.) and James J. (Lisa J.). Devoted grandmother of Lisa R., John W. and Burt P. Sempier. Sister of the late Barbara Peterson. Reposing at the Towers Funeral Home, Inc., Long Beach and Foxhurst Rds, Oceanside, NY, Monday and Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass St. Christopher's R.C. Church, Baldwin, NY, Wednesday, 9:45 AM. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Contributions to Hospice by the Sea, Boca Raton, FL 33486, would be appreciated.

title: Protesting War School for Foreigners
description: In a small classroom inside a pink building on this historic Army post, Maj. Pablo Friedrich is learning the art of war.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Class-Action Suit Based On Microsoft Antitrust Case

title: Punishment on Display
description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER LONG DELAY, U.S. PLANS TO ISSUE ERGONOMIC RULES
description: The Clinton administration is about to propose new workplace rules that officials said would protect millions of workers from repetitive-stress injuries, one of the major sources of physical pain and disability in offices and factories across the country.

title: So There! Sprewell Energizes Knicks
description: The Knicks discovered a little something about anger management Saturday night as they watched Latrell Sprewell, their scowling, tireless teammate, bound onto the floor of the Arena in Oakland as if channeling the Tasmanian Devil.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce; After a year on the credibility trail, a columnist finds that the Internet industry is still dangerously self-indulgent.
description: FINALLY, the Internet's growing lack of credibility among consumers is becoming a cause celebre.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANGER, ELLIOTT M. JR.
description: SANGER-Elliott M. Jr. On Friday, November 19, 1999, after a long illness, at age 77. Beloved husband of Joan B. Sanger. Adored father of Elizabeth Sanger and father-inlaw of Jeffrey Trachtenberg, devoted brother of Kenneth E. Loving son of Eleanor N. Also adored grandfather of Benjamin and Joshua Trachtenberg and devoted brother-in-law of Judith and Andrew Ball and Joan S. Sanger. Funeral services Monday, November 22, at 11 AM, Temple EmanuEl, 65th St. and 5th Ave. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Mount Sinai Oncology Care Center, Columbia College, or a charity of your choice.

title: Impeding Fair Access to Organs
description: Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, and House Speaker Dennis Hastert have engineered another delay of important reforms to the nation's system for distributing donated human organs for transplants. The delay would prevent new regulations from going into effect until next year, giving opponents of the reform more opportunity to organize efforts that could postpone the new rules indefinitely.

title: John D. Le Vien, 81, Documentary Filmmaker
description: John D. Le Vien, a documentary film producer nominated for two Oscars, died on Nov. 9 at a hospital in London, where he had lived for the last 30 years. He was 81.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Giving section on Wednesday about the blurring of lines between nonprofit and commercial enterprises misstated the surname of the president of the Alliance for Families and Children, a charity that also has a commercial division. He is Peter Goldberg, not Goldmark.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Nov. 13 about the NBC film ''Mary, Mother of Jesus'' rendered a quotation from Cecil B. DeMille's film ''The Ten Commandments'' incorrectly and misattributed it. The line was ''Oh, Moses, Moses, you stubborn, splendid, adorable fool'' -- not ''Moses, you beautiful fool.'' It was spoken by Anne Baxter, not Nina Foch.

title: The Big City; A Test to See If You Can Do Big City Math
description: PUBLIC school officials are alarmed that three-quarters of New York City's eighth graders failed the statewide math test, but maybe the problem lies in the test. Instead of pestering students about square roots and parallelograms, why not pose math problems that they actually face in New York?

title: Media Talk; An Insider Is Named to Head St. Martin's
description: Still recovering from the recall of its George W. Bush biography, St. Martin's Press last week chose a longtime editor of its literary list to replace the departed editor in chief, who fled abruptly saying he was disgusted with the book.

title: Bledsoe Manhandled by the Dolphins
description: Nobody had to alert the Miami Dolphins' defense today to the perils of facing a quarterback like the New England Patriots' Drew Bledsoe.

title: Media Talk; Judge Dismisses Bias Lawsuit Against CNN
description: Four years ago, CNN hired a veteran journalist, Art Browne, as a senior editor in its New York office. What made the move somewhat unusual for CNN was that Mr. Browne was 59 at the time, had been unemployed for four years and suffered from a neurological condition called essential tremor disorder, which caused his voice, hands and head to shake.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEAGY, ANN ELIZABETH
description: KEAGY-Ann Elizabeth. Died November 19 at Waveny Care Center, New Canaan, CT after a prolonged illness from Alzheimers. For 35 years, she headed the Fashion Design Department of the Parsons School of Design. Survivors are her husband, J. Rodman Keagy, daughter, Wendy Ann Keagy, both of New Canaan, and brother, George W. Hlavaty, of Mesa, AZ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GABRIEL, RUTH (SOBEL)
description: GABRIEL-Ruth (Sobel). Dearly beloved wife of the late Fred, devoted mother of Drs. Hugh Paul, Dolores and Nat, loving aunt of Pamela, Sam, Louise and Robert Wilder, and great-aunt. Funeral services Monday, 1:15 PM, ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Colombia Extradites Drug Suspect to U.S.
description: A Colombian accused of running a major heroin smuggling ring was bundled aboard an American government plane in Colombia today and flown to the United States. It is the first time in nearly a decade that Colombia has turned over one of its own citizens to stand trial in this country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARHANSOFF, MARTIN T.
description: DARHANSOFF-Martin T. Died at New York Presbyterian Hospital on November 19, 1999, at age 66. Beloved husband of Leslie; devoted and loving father of Jeremy; dear brother of Margo; and uncle of Heather and Brad. Wonderful friend and supporter to many who depended upon his professional advice and personal loyalty. Your humor, patience and gentleness will be missed each and every day. Funeral at Plaza Funeral Home, Amsterdam and 91st, Monday, November 22, 10:30 AM.

title: Critic's Notebook; Between the Lines, Revealing Glimpses Of Five Candidates
description: Although America doesn't have a lot of writers-turned-politicians like Vaclav Havel or even politician-writer hyphenates like Churchill or Disraeli, it's the rare candidate today who hasn't chosen to promote himself by promoting a book.

title: Final Grades Are Ready on Year 2000 Readiness
description: The federal government is going to get a respectable report card, with plenty of A's, when the House subcommittee tracking Year 2000 preparations issues what it calls its final grades today.

title: Two Plays on Defense Turn the Tide
description: It was the kind of sideline conversation that defensive players have all the time. In the first quarter against Buffalo at Giants Stadium this afternoon, the Jets' second-year defensive end Eric Ogbogu was telling the rookie defensive tackle Jason Wiltz that they each needed to make a spectacular play to help the team win and avoid becoming afterthoughts in Coach Bill Parcells's plans.

title: Concussion For Graham
description: Although Giants Coach Jim Fassel would not name his starting quarterback for the Giants' next game against Arizona, it is unlikely he will return to Kent Graham, who left yesterday's 23-13 loss to the Washington Redskins midway through the second quarter with a concussion. Graham said he sustained the concussion in the first quarter, though he was not sure on which play.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAILEANU, EUFROSINA
description: RAILEANU-Eufrosina. Dear Zina: loving, vibrant, gifted friend. We'll miss you. Lois Brenner and Bob Stein

title: Following Coke, Pepsi Will Raise Prices
description: Following the trend set by Coca-Cola earlier this month, PepsiCo plans to raise the price it charges its bottlers for concentrate by nearly 7 percent next year.

title: Final Sabbath for a Spiritual Hub; A Synagogue That Embodied an Earlier Bronx Is Closed
description: The sign, printed in pencil and taped to the front door of the Mosholu Jewish Center in the north Bronx, said ''Sale.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Friday about Dr. Daniel Nathans, a Nobel Prize-winning geneticist, referred imprecisely to the technique he pioneered to analyze DNA. He used chemical scalpels, not actual blades.

title: China Takes a Giant Leap Closer to Manned Spaceflight
description: China announced its first successful launching and recovery of an unmanned spacecraft today, an important step toward the goal of putting its own explorers in space.

title: Compressed Data; Survey Finds Resistance To E-Shopping for Clothing
description: Merchants with high hopes for peddling cashmere and embroidered denim jeans on the Web this season and into the future may be in for a shock. Nearly half the Internet users in a recent survey said they never planned to buy clothing online, according to NPD, a market-research company based in Port Washington, N.Y.

title: In Occupied Chechnya, Order Without Allegiance
description: As the Russian Army closes in on Chechnya's besieged capital, Grozny, it is using a fresh strategy: promising Chechens that their bedraggled towns will be spared a relentless bombardment if they surrender, then attempting to secure loyalty by restoring services like gas and electricity.

title: Maryland Soars To Its Third Title
description: Maryland's Keli Smith picked a good day for her dream to come true.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, MARTHA GOODSTEIN
description: JACOBSON-Martha Goodstein. Age 84, of Hickory, NC. Died November 20, 1999. Beloved wife of Archie Kirschman and Ben Jacobson; cherished mother of Barry J. Jacobson and Pauline K. Lavitt; devoted grandmother of Ari, Adam, Brette, Spiro and Stefano Jacobson and Howard and Arthur Lavitt; adored great-grandmother to Brent, Jacqueline and Austin Lavitt. A true woman of valor with enormous kindness and compassion. She will be missed sorely by her loving family and friends. Make God grant her a seat at his table. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, 9:30 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEICHNER, SOLOMON
description: ZEICHNER-Solomon. On November 20, 1999. Husband of Helen. Father of Carl, Martin and Jane. A NYC school Principal at P.S. 2 and Roosevelt Island P.S./I.S. 217. President of the Benjamin Franklin Reformed Democratic Club of the Bronx. Memorial at 1 PM, November 22, at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave, Yonkers, NY. In lieu of flowers, please plant a tree in Israel with the Jewish National Fund or contribute to the American Cancer Society.
