description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRANKLIN, LEONARD
description: FRANKLIN-Leonard. Lovingly remembered every day, but especially today, your 85th birthday. Hannah and Alan

title: Johnson Pass Just Misses
description: There have been moments in receiver Keyshawn Johnson's career with the Jets when he laments the fact that he has had six quarterbacks in his three and a half seasons. Yesterday he took matters into his own hands -- he threw his first pass.

title: FOOTLIGHT
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLINE, BEBE ARON
description: KLINE-Bebe Aron, 88, on November 18th, 1999, Kislev 9, 5760. Beloved, loyal and generous mother of Karen M. and Kenneth S., wife of Samuel, optimistic and funny grandmother of Daniel H. and Rachel S., adoring sister of George and Charles Aron, devoted aunt. Graduate St. John's Law School 1932, Matron of the Eastern Star. One of the first women admitted to practice before the Supreme Court of the United States. Poet. ''La famille c'est toute.'' She will be deeply missed and always loved.

title: Serge Lang, 79, Expert on World Cup Skiing
description: Serge Lang, a French sportswriter who helped create skiing's biggest and most successful tour, the World Cup, died Sunday in Sternenberg, in the Alsace region of France. He was 79.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOVINGER, MILTON
description: LOVINGER-Milton. Died Saturday in FL. Service: Noon today, Gutterman's Funeral Home, Rockville Centre, NY. Donations to Hospice By The Sea, Boca Raton, FL. 33486

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Sunday about a campaign by the N.A.A.C.P. to reduce the influence of College Board scores in admissions misidentified the board's headquarters location. It is New York; the Educational Testing Service, which helps prepare the questions for the board, has an office in Ewing, N.J., and is based in Princeton.

title: Woman Confesses to Killing in Bowling Alley, Authorities Say
description: A Queens woman confessed Sunday to fatally stabbing an 18-year-old teacher's assistant in a bowling alley, telling detectives she was motivated by an altercation with the victim that took place years earlier, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Seeking Common Ground in the Debate on the Homeless
description: In the week since Nicole Barrett was hit with a brick in a random attack, apparently by a homeless man, the crucial players on the city stage have responded to the intense focus on the mentally ill homeless by relying on what would seem to be a long-rehearsed script, taking predictable positions as they appeal to their usual constituents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANAUER, PRISCILLA (NEE ALTSHUL)
description: HANAUER-Priscilla (nee Altshul). November 19, 1999, in Minneapolis, MN. Beloved wife of the late Leonard Hanauer. Beloved mother of Vicki Hanauer & Patti Baskin. Loving sister of Claire Carmen. Cherished grandmother of six and adored great-grandmother of four. Interment Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, New Jersey, Tuesday, November 23rd. at 1 PM.

title: Spurs for Bush In Foreign Policy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Stripping Away the Myths And Fleshing Out the Life
description: REMBRANDT'S EYES

title: Abroad at Home; Janet Reno's Test
description: Janet Reno has been an admirably independent attorney general. Where her record is to be faulted is on civil liberties. Whether through inexperience or insensitivity, she did not raise her voice against harsh provisions of the 1996 Immigration Act and other legislation.

title: SBC Makes Deal to Transfer Internet Customers to Prodigy
description: SBC Communications Inc., the regional telephone giant, said yesterday that it would transfer all of its residential Internet customers to the Prodigy Communications Corporation, the online service that has long been overshadowed by America Online, in return for a 43 percent stake in Prodigy.

title: Public Interests; Pre-2K Thanksgiving
description: This is going to be our pre-millennial Thanksgiving, and we have lots to celebrate.

title: Denouncing U.N., Iraq Cuts Oil Sales Used to Buy Food
description: Iraq today unexpectedly began to cut off the oil it is allowed to export in exchange for food and other basic supplies, after the Security Council extended the program for only two weeks.

title: A Therapy Gains Ground In Hospitals: Meditation
description: As her meditation session drew to a close, Mary Bryant found it difficult to get up from her chair. Not only was it hard to break the calming spell cast by her instructor, but Ms. Bryant was still stiff from running the New York City Marathon and pushing, for the whole 26 miles, a flower-strewed wheelchair dedicated to a late friend and fellow breast cancer patient.

title: For the French, Food Isn't Everything
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Record in Greece
description: To the Editor:

title: Could Nicotine Make a Play at the Plate?
description: The roar of the crowd, the crack of the bat -- and that unpleasant little squirt of tobacco juice many batters like to let loose just before they step into the box. It just wouldn't be baseball without them.

title: Fast-Spinning Steps That Reveal a Vivid Imagination
description: There is magic growing in the old American Banknote Building on Barretto Street in the South Bronx. A former warehouse, it is now the home of the Arthur Aviles Typical Theater, which danced there on Saturday night in a funky, welcoming performance space filled with possibilities. Rehearsal and artists' studios are also being carved out of the building, donated by Gail and Max Blauner and developed by Mr. Aviles and the Point, a nearby arts and community center.

title: 3-2-1, Call Cape Canaveral
description: Bureaucrats aren't particularly known for a sense of humor or of history. So it was something of a shock when the North American Numbering Plan Administration, the agency that assigns area codes, came up with a clever new one for Brevard County in Florida.

title: Mr. Barak's Summons to Peace
description: Addressing an audience of American Jewish leaders the other night, Ehud Barak chose the ancient words of Ecclesiastes, ''there is a time for war and a time for peace.'' It was a particularly apt quotation. As a former general and a former foreign minister under Shimon Peres, Mr. Barak has seen his share of warmaking and peacemaking. Now, as Israel's prime minister, he well knows that the next few months offer a rare and perhaps fleeting opportunity for clinching a Middle East peace agreement.

title: Vintage Genetics Turns Out to Be Ordinaire
description: It's the New World's Vatican of viticulture, the oracle of grape-growing, the arbiter of winery practice. The University of California's department of viticulture and enology here trains most of California's winemakers and provides root stock for much of the New World.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the news coverage of a random attack by a man with a brick in Manhattan on Nov. 16, which left a woman severely injured, misspelled the surname of the editor of The American Journalism Review, who said he saw nothing unethical about The Daily News's decision to run a front-page headline for an editorial. He is Rem Rieder, not Reider.

title: Challenging Marauders' Spread, Navy Recovers a Hijacked Ship: India and China Set Sights on Piracy
description: SINGAPORE  India and China are taking tough action to crack down on one of the greatest menaces facing commercial shipping companies operating in Southeast Asia  armed gangs of pirates who hijack vessels and their crews.

title: U.S. Gasoline Price Up
description: The retail price of gasoline in the United States rose to its highest in three and a half years, $1.269 a gallon, in the week ended today, a government survey showed, as crude oil surged to its highest price in almost nine years. The average pump price for regular self-service gasoline rose 1.8 cents, as prices increased in all parts of the country except the Rocky Mountains, according to an Energy Department survey of 800 filling stations. That was the highest since the week ended June 3, 1996.

title: Gretzky Joins Great Ones Of the Past
description: It will be up to future generations to decide whether the Great One really was the greatest hockey player of all time.

title: Utility Consulting Company Ousts Chief
description: Navigant Consulting Inc. ousted its chief executive, Robert Maher, today and said it was reviewing $17 million in loans the company made to him and other officers. The company's shares fell $12.375 each, to $13.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEAGY, ANN LAVATY
description: KEAGY-Ann Lavaty. Parsons School of Design, a division of New School University, mourns the loss of Ann Lavaty Keagy, who chaired the Department of Fashion Design from 1953 until 1982 when she retired. For three decades Mrs. Keagy educated two generations of the best & brightest on Seventh Avenue, including Donna Karan, Louis Dell'Olio, Jeffrey Banks and Zack Carr. While at Parsons Mrs. Keagy initiated the legendary Designer Critic program, which remains today as a lasting legacy. Marie Essex, Chair, and the Faculty of the Department of Fashion Design

title: Help Indigenous Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Wrong Cure for Homelessness
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN NORDEN, ELIZABETH
description: VAN NORDEN-Elizabeth, Wife of the late Duncan Van Norden, passed away on Sunday, November 21, 1999. She was 87 years old. Born in New York City to Elizabeth and Stanley M. Rumbough, Mrs. Van Norden was a resident of New York before moving to Palm Beach. She served as a director of the New York City Mission Society and was a member of The Garden Club of Palm Beach, the Society of Four Arts and The Colonial Dames of America. Mrs. Van Norden was involved in Planned Parenthood as well as other philanthropic organizations. She is survived by two daughters, Elizabeth Harris Taylor of California and Marcia Cowles Dean of Missouri; a brother, Stanley M. Rumbough, Jr. of Palm Beach; six grandchildren and six great grandchildren. A private memorial service followed by interment will be held at Bethesda-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church, Palm Beach. Memorial donations may be made to the Peggy Adams Animal Rescue League of the Palm Beaches, 3200 N. Military Trail, West Palm Beach, Fl, 33409. Information: Quattlebaum - Holleman - Burse Funeral Home, 1201 South Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL.

title: Kearse's Success Is Hardly Accidental
description: Everything at shiny Adelphia Stadium is new, especially the Tennessee Titans and their delirious fans. More than 66,000 gathered here on Sunday to see the Titans tackle Pittsburgh, and one of their most enjoyable moments was when the song ''Le Freak'' blared across the stadium. Children danced in the aisles. Their parents offered a move, too. Blue and white posters were waved celebrating ''The Freak,'' Titans defensive end Jevon Kearse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CATTS, MAYE V.
description: CATTS-Maye V. Of New York and Florida, died November 20, 1999. Survived by her loving daughter Roberta Mallow; grandchildren Deborah (Brian) and Peter (Miranda), and great-grandchildren Dean and David. Private services at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUCHAN, IRA
description: DUCHAN-Ira. Beloved husband of Charlotte. Loving father of Joan, Linda, Brian and Bill. Proud grandfather of five. Devoted brother of Irving and the late Simon. Services Tuesday, 12 noon, at ''Sinai Chapels'', Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: MEXICAN TRADE DEFICIT GROWS
description: Mexico's trade deficit widened in October as a growing economy drew more imports. Mexico had a trade shortfall of $654 million, above economists' forecasts of $400 million, and higher than September's revised deficit of $321 million. The October number is much less than the trade deficit of $798 million for October of last year. Government figures show the economy is expanding faster than expected in the second half of the year, with growth expected to reach at least 3.5 percent.

title: Deaths of Lobsters in Long Island Sound Tied to Tiny Parasite
description: The mysterious deaths of hundreds of thousands of lobsters in Long Island Sound this fall may have been caused by a tiny parasite that is deadly to crustaceans but not a threat to people, marine scientists in New York and Connecticut said today.

title: A Doctor's Helplessness
description: To the Editor:

title: Newest Superfruit: The Pomegranate
description: Make way for the latest entrant to the pantheon of fruits and vegetables that may fight disease: the pomegranate.

title: In Kung Fu, Only the Muscles Scream
description: Kung fu is the martial art with the silliest song -- Carl Douglas's ''Kung Fu Fighting'' of 1974 -- and most revered practitioner: Bruce Lee, whose fans became even more cultlike after he died of a brain edema in 1973 at the age of 32.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRLICH, STANLEY L.
description: EHRLICH-Stanley L. Of Short Hills, NJ. On Friday, November 19, 1999. Husband of the late Phyllis Dettelbach Ehrlich. Survived by son, David Ehrlich and his wife Joanne, and grandson Alexander. Memorial service at Smith and Smith (Suburban), 415 Morris Avenue, Springfield, NJ on Sunday, November 28, at 1PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Overlook Hospital Foundation, PO Box 220, Summit, NJ 07902-0220.

title: Q & A
description: Sex and the Single Fossil

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOCK, ADOLPH
description: BOCK-Adolph. The Young Israel of Forest Hills mounrs the passing of its memeber, Adolph Bock. May the Almighty console the family together with all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Who's That Big Guy Out There Working With the Knicks?
description: The familiar hulking figure on the far end of the court was wearing his black knee pads, three layers of T-shirts soaked to his skin and the same old grumpy disposition.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Talks to Avert Bankruptcy At German Company Fail

title: Corrections
description: A list of credits in the Arts & Ideas pages on Nov. 6 with a television review of the musical ''Annie'' on ABC on Nov. 7 misidentified the lyricist. He is Martin Charnin; Charles Strouse wrote only the music.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: ELUSYS THERAPEUTICS, Pine Brook, N.J., named Stephen G. Sudovar to the new post of president and chief executive. He had been president at Roche Laboratories.

title: Another Art Battle, as Detroit Museum Closes an Exhibit Early
description: Visitors to the Detroit Institute of Arts, the grande dame of museums here, could visit a room in the modern gallery to see a toy Jesus wearing a condom, a pile of human excrement and a brazil nut labeled with a racial epithet. For two days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REMO, JOHN G.
description: REMO-John G. Of Bronxville, NY on November 17, 1999. Beloved husband of Mary. Dear father of Ernest B., John L. and Robert A. Loving grandfather of Catherine, John C., Allison M., Christopher S., Alexander G. and Marissa N. Memorial mass at St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Saturday, November 27 at 10A.M. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COURTNEY, CHRISTINA (NEE O'NEILL)
description: COURTNEY - Christina (nee O'Neill). Fortified with the Sacraments of Holy Mother Church. Born in Tullamore, County Offaly, Ireland on January 1, 1904. She passed away peacefully November 20, 1999 at her daughter's home in Chesterfield, Missouri. Beloved wife of the late William Joseph Courtney. Cherished mother of William (Marie) Courtney, John Courtney, Mary (O.G.) Reichardt and Bernadette Courtney. Dearest grandmother of Christine, William (Joann) & Peter Courtney. Great grandmother of Kathryn, and friend of many. Funeral mass will be held on Wednesday at 10AM at Queen of Peace Catholic Church, 141-36 77th Ave, Flushing, New York. Interment immediately following at Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery 172-00 Booth Memorial Avenue Flushing, New York. Visitation Tuesday 4-8 PM at Quinn-Fogarty Funeral Home, 162-14 Sanford Avenue, Flushing, New York. Masses or contributions to charity of one's choice.

title: Nigeria Leader Amazes Many With Strong Anti-Graft Drive
description: After Friday prayers, townsfolk say, Maryam Abacha, the widow of the dictator who ruled and looted this country for five years, has begun opening the gates of the family compound to the city's poor, who fill her courtyard to receive free bags of rice, millet and sorghum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROFT, EDITH
description: CROFT-Edith. November 20, 1999. Survived by her only child, Rhoda Croft, of 1 High Service Avenue, North Providence, R.I. 02911.

title: New Theater: Your Name Here; Donors Help the Roundabout Transform Its Space
description: The V.I.P. lounge is spoken for at $500,000, as is the box office at $250,000. But the penthouse lobby is still up for grabs at $1.5 million, along with the orchestra pit ($350,000) and four restrooms ($75,000 each).

title: F.C.C. Acts to Assist Blind TV Audience
description: The Federal Communications Commission has proposed that broadcasters be required to adopt technology allowing the blind to follow the action on television by listening to a narrator describe it.

title: Chicken Soup From Barak: It Can't Hurt
description: IF you want to open a kosher shop or restaurant, you have to get a rabbinical seal of approval, known in Hebrew as a hechsher. Sometimes, a temporal version of a hechsher is needed in the world of New York politics, and that is exactly what Hillary Rodham Clinton got over the weekend from the visiting Israeli Prime Minister, Ehud Barak.

title: Huge German Builder Nears Bankruptcy
description: Philipp Holzmann A.G., the biggest construction company in Germany, appeared headed toward bankruptcy today after late-night talks brokered by Chancellor Gerhard Schroder failed to reach a compromise among banks trying to arrange a $2.6 billion bailout.

title: Volpe Deserves Life in Prison, Prosecutor Says
description: A federal prosecutor held yesterday that the police officer who tortured Abner Louima deserved no mercy and should be sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

title: Stress of War May Lead to Heart Disease
description: The war never seems to end for some combat veterans.

title: Spurs for Bush In Foreign Policy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMERMAN, BERNARD
description: HAMMERMAN-Bernard. To my dear friend Joanie and her loving family, I extend my heartfelt condolences on the profound loss of her husband, a devoted father, father-in-law, grandfather and brother. Bernie was a lifelong friend, and his passing leaves a tremendous void in the lives of all of us who know and love him. Renee Jacobson

title: Parcells Praises Lucas But Expects Much More
description: This is Bill Parcells's endorsement of Ray Lucas:

title: Throat Gesture Faces Ban By N.F.L.
description: The National Football League has become increasingly angry with its players who make throat-slashing gestures after scoring a touchdown or making a big play. Now, league executives, embarrassed by Jets wide receiver Keyshawn Johnson's display on ''Monday Night Football'' last week, are taking steps to ban the gesture.

title: EgyptAir Inquiry Continues To Focus on Crew Member
description: After a week of carefully examining the cockpit voice recorder and other evidence from EgyptAir Flight 990, Federal investigators remain focused on the actions of a reserve pilot who they believe may have deliberately crashed the passenger jet into the Atlantic Ocean, government officials said today.

title: A Gucci Insider to Lead Saint Laurent
description: When it was announced last week that Gucci had finally closed its deal to buy Yves Saint Laurent for about $700 million in cash, there was a flurry of phone calls from journalists in Europe and elsewhere to Gucci's chief press officer, Lisa Schiek, in New York. They wanted to know one thing: Who was Mark Lee?

title: Frank E. Taylor, 83, Book Publisher, Editor and Film Producer
description: Frank E. Taylor, a longtime book publisher who was editor in chief and general manager of the McGraw Hill Book Company's trade-book division and publisher of Avon Books for the Hearst Corporation, died on Nov. 16 at his home in Key West, Fla. He was 83.

title: Excerpts From Text of Bradley's Speech
description: Following are excerpts from prepared remarks by former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey for a speech yesterday at New Hampshire College in Manchester.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIOTT, THOMAS JOSEPH
description: ELLIOTT-Thomas Joseph. World War I Army Veteran and Bronze Star recipient. Retired Police Office NYPD and retired Lieutenant, Federal Protective Service. On Saturday, November 20th, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Kathleen Cronin Elliott. Dear father of Peggy Frayne, Thomas, Vincent, Christopher and Maurice. Loving grandfather Meaghan and T.J. Frayne, Thomas, Andrew and John Elliott. Dear brother of John Elliott, Mary Farmer, Betty Mescall and the late Brother James, F.S.C., and Edward Ryan Elliott. Funeral from Schuyler Hill Funeral Home, 3535 East Tremont Ave., Bronx, Wednesday, 10:30AM. Mass of Christian Burial Saint Frances deChantal, 11AM. Interment Saint Raymond's Cemetery. Visiting Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9:30PM.

title: What Girls Shouldn't Know
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORIN, LILLIAN (LEE)
description: DORIN-Lillian (Lee). On November 21, 1999. Beloved wife of Abraham (Al). Adored and adoring mother of Amy Dorin and Jeanne Dorin McDowell. Wonderful grandma of Julia Dorin McDowell. Cherished sister/sister-in-law of Minna, Elliott and Philip & Estelle Horowitz, Miriam Reisman and Alma & the late Irving Dorin. Dear aunt of many nieces and nephews whom she loved very much. She was the most compassionate, spirited, courageous woman, whose lovingkindness affected the lives of all who knew her.

title: Military Is Said to Prevent East Timor Refugees' Return
description: Intimidation by militias linked to the Indonesian military is preventing tens of thousands of East Timorese refugees from returning home from camps in West Timor, a senior American diplomat said today on a tour of the region.

title: Business and Labor Differ On Ergonomic Proposals
description: Proposed federal rules aimed at preventing on-the-job injuries from repetitive motion touched off a debate today over how such injuries occur, what they cost American businesses and what can be done to avoid them.

title: Metro Business; Water Utility Sale
description: Thames Water of London, the world's third-largest water company, said yesterday that it would buy a New Jersey utility, the E'town Corporation, for $948.1 million in cash and assumed debt.

title: Israeli Army Ousting Officer for Intolerance
description: The topic for the day in one Israeli Army classroom was the status of women in Judaism. Sixty soldiers sat awaiting the lecture, part of an education series where attendance is mandatory.

title: Brick Attack Victim Improves, Family Says
description: After a week of drifting in and out of consciousness in an intensive care unit, Nicole Barrett, the woman who was struck in the head with a brick in Midtown, has begun to speak and ask about what happened to her, her family said yesterday.

title: Wieden & Kennedy wins the gold, as Nike gives it the consolidated United States account.
description: THE agency that created the signature theme ''Just do it'' for Nike Inc. has done it again, regaining its status as the sole agency for the Nike brand in this country.

title: VALEO TO SELL LUK
description: Europe's No. 2 car-parts maker, Valeo S.A., will sell its stake in the German clutch maker LuK to the investment company INA Holding-Schaeffler Group, wiping out its debt and helping to finance future acquisitions. Valeo, a French company, will sell the 50 percent stake for 1.21 billion euros ($1.25 billion), giving it a capital gain after tax of 641 million euros. Valeo has been buying stakes in Japanese parts makers to exploit investment opportunities opened up by the reorganization of the Nissan Motor Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAILEANU, EUFROSINA
description: RAILEANU-Eufrosina. New York City Opera deeply mourns the passing of Eufrosina Raileanu, the principal violist in our orchestra since 1988. She was a greatly gifted musician who brought joy to her music making while continually striving for perfection. The courage and grace with which she fought her illness has been an inspiration to all of us. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family and her many friends. Paul Kellogg, General Director

title: Republican Governors, Wanting One of Their Own, Decided Early on Bush
description: More than one Republican governor looked at making a presidential run this year, and there was a touch of envy directed at the one who ultimately did. When Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin decided against a campaign, he observed that his Texas counterpart had a more famous name and more money, was better-looking and came from a much bigger state.

title: Sports of The Times; Can Marbury Save Himself And 'Game?'
description: WHAT has happened to the kid with the sparkle in his eyes and the quick, engaging smile? Where is the 14-year-old Coney Island prodigy who sat on the floor outside the Lincoln High School gymnasium eight years ago and told a reporter that his life's calling was so obvious to anyone who watched him play?

title: WHITBREAD TO BUY SWALLOW
description: As Britain's hotel chains look to cut costs through consolidation, Whitbread P.L.C. agreed to pay $935.9 million for Swallow Group P.L.C. and will bring most of Swallow's 38 hotels into its chain of Marriott-franchised establishments. Whitbread will offer 390 pence, or $6.32, for each Swallow share. It will also pay a second interim dividend of 8 pence, or 12.96 cents. Whitbread hopes to compete in the four-star market with Hilton Group.

title: Brilliance or Eye Problems?
description: To the Editor:

title: Prosecutor Seeks Takeover of Boxing Group
description: In the first attempt by federal law enforcement officials to take over a private sports organization, the United States Attorney's office asked a federal judge today to appoint a monitor to run the International Boxing Federation, whose leaders were indicted early this month on racketeering and bribery charges.

title: Hair Salon Was Overly Creative, U.S. Says
description: There's no law against lying about your hair color, and Jacques Dessange Inc. has always been willing to oblige brunettes wanting to be blond, or vice versa, at its chic hair salons.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The yen rose against the dollar after a report signaled Japan's economy probably expanded in the July-September quarter. In New York, the dollar settled at 104.83 yen, down from 106.08 on Friday.

title: Executives Are Shifted At 3 Agencies
description: Executives at three agencies are taking new roles.

title: Brilliance or Eye Problems?
description: To the Editor:

title: Central Park for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, ANNABELLE
description: WIENER-Annabelle, Deputy Secretary General, World Federation of the United Nations Association, age 78, died after a short illness on November 20. She is survived by her three children, five grandchildren and two great grandchildren. A memorial will be held November 23, U.N. Chapel, 44 ST. & 1 Ave. at 3pm. Contributions American Heart Association.

title: Public Relations Units Merging
description: The Omnicom Group said yesterday that it would merge one of its public relations agencies, Copithorne & Bellows Public Relations in San Francisco, with the Porter Novelli International unit of Porter Novelli, a public relations agency in New York, to create the Porter Novelli Convergence Group, specializing in technology clients.

title: A Rhythm Propelled By a High-Flying Line
description: In helping jazz compositions get over the line into the realm of art music, jazz musicians these days are apt to use the long line. It's a tool that's as useful as the short riff, but achieves the opposite effect; instead of tying down the music's center of gravity, the long line can float far out like a kite connected to the tune's putative rhythm and key. Motoring right through expected breaks at bar divisions, it gives a feeling of perpetual motion; it can define tempo and warp it, become a sort of mantra or fade into the background to become just a murmuring color.

title: UConn's Depth and Defense Handcuff UMass
description: When the ''U Game'' between Connecticut and Massachusetts was resumed three seasons ago after a five-year hiatus, it seemed an ideal matchup, since both schools, 75 miles apart, had reached the upper echelon of college basketball and had a rivalry that dated to 1905. Not only that but UMass, led by Marcus Camby, had reached the Final Four in the 1995-96 season and UConn had won 30 of 32 games and made it as far as the final eight of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YANNUZZI, JOSEPHINE J. (NEE PALUMBO)
description: YANNUZZI-Josephine J. (nee Palumbo) on Sunday, November 21, 1999, of Manhattan. Wife of the late Geraldo Yannuzzi, mother of Lawrence Yannuzzi, MD, & Louise Saliceti. Sister of John Palumbo, the late Philomena Margotta, Anthony, and Carmen Palumbo. Also survived by five grandchildren, and two great grandchildren. Funeral from the Galante Funeral Home, 2800 Morris Avenue, Union, NJ, on Wednesday at 8:30 AM. Funeral Mass at St. Rose of Lima Church, Short Hills, NJ at 10 AM. Interment Glendale Cemetery, Bloomfield, NJ. Visitation Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to the Macula Foundation Inc., 519 East 72nd Street, New York, New York 10021 in her Memory.

title: Physicists Invading Geologists' Turf
description: Dr. William Dietrich has walked, driven and flown over more natural landscapes than he can remember. As a veteran geomorphologist, he has studied how everything from the plop of a raindrop to mighty landslides and geologic uplift have shaped the face of the planet.

title: DIGITAL INSIGHT AGREES TO PURCHASE NFRONT
description: The Digital Insight Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire NFront Inc., another provider of Internet banking software to community banks, for about $439 million in stock. Digital Insight will swap 0.579 share for each share of NFront. Shares of Digital Insight, of Calabasas, Calif., tumbled $9.75 each, to $40.375, in Nasdaq trading, where shares of NFront rose $2.5625, to $21.3125. Digital Insight, which reported revenue of $11.8 million for the quarter that ended on Sept. 30, said that after the merger it would have about 645 financial institutions as clients. NFront, based in Atlanta, reported revenue of about $5 million for the fiscal year that ended on June 30.

title: Alvin Coox, 75, Historian Of Russia-Japan Fight, Dies
description: Dr. Alvin D. Coox, a former professor of Asian studies at San Diego State University who called attention to the importance of an obscure but critical military campaign in World War II, died on Nov. 4 in a hospice in San Diego. He was 75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PISANO, ANTHONY M.
description: PISANO-Anthony M. On November 21 at the Stamford Hospital. Beloved son of Rose Pisano, husband of Meryl Pisano, father of Ariana and brother of Joseph. For further information call the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home at 203-327-1313.

title: N.B.A. Investigating Sprewell
description: After shouting obscenities to his hecklers at the Arena in Oakland, Calif., on Saturday and exhibiting questionable behavior with his on-court antics, Latrell Sprewell might face disciplinary action from the league.

title: Boxer Still on Critical List
description: Stephan Johnson, who was knocked out in the 10th round of a bout against Paul Vaden at Trump Taj Mahal in Atlantic City on Saturday night, remained in critical condition yesterday at the Atlantic City Medical Center in a medically induced coma with swelling in his brain. He underwent surgery Sunday to relieve pressure on his brain.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Women's Event Books Odd Couple

title: Westchester Catholics Assail Bill That Would Protect Gays
description: A proposal to create a Human Rights Commission in Westchester County has come under criticism from Roman Catholic groups because the panel would protect gay people from discrimination.

title: Little Library On the Offensive
description: The Laura Ingalls Wilder Library was named after the favorite daughter of Mansfield, Mo., who wore her best velvet dress to the dedication ceremony in 1951. But today the little library, about a half-block from the town square, looks forlorn. The roof leaks. Foam insulation is taped to the windows of the concrete building to keep out the frost. Library employees shiver in their coats through the icy Ozark winters.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLOOM, BERNARD D., D.D.S.
description: BLOOM-Bernard D., D.D.S. April 11, 1922-November 23, 1992. Seven years ago today. Alive in our hearts always. Jac

title: Stari Trg Journal; A Battered Kosovo Village the West Forgot to Help
description: Bairam Bala stood on the concrete foundations of what was once his house, surrounded by ragged edges of shelled and collapsed walls, near the burned and rusted remnants of his belongings gathered neatly in a pile, for some Westerner, who will never come, to inventory and make good his losses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZORSKI, MARGARET
description: ZORSKI-Margaret. On November 22, at age 77. Beloved mother of Jack, Suzanne, Kevin and Peggy. Services Saturday, 11:30 AM, at St. Patricks Church, Glen Cove, NY.

title: Lessons From Ancient Heat Surge
description: What happens when great amounts of heat-trapping greenhouse gases are injected into the atmosphere in a relatively short span of earth history, as is happening today as a result of the burning of coal, oil and natural gas?

title: Pfizer and Celera in Deal
description: Pfizer will buy genetic information from the Celera Genomics Group, a gene-mapping company that is a unit of the PE Corporation, and collaborate on research under a five-year agreement. Pfizer will gain access to Celera's genetic databases until 2005. The databases include three billion base pairs of human DNA, or about 75 percent of all human genetic information. Celera and Pfizer will also collaborate to discover gene-based therapies. The terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, SELMA
description: HOROWITZ-Selma. On November 21, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Mortimer. Daughter of the late David and Fanny Drechsler. Sister of the late Bernard. Mother of Bobbi Horowitz and the late Sue Hank. Grandmother to David Slone. She was a team golfer, bridge player and always a kid from Brooklyn at heart. Service Tuesday 11:30AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page headline on Saturday about the Senate's approval of five spending bills misstated the estimated cost of the package. It was $386 billion, not $610 billion.

title: Too Many Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAN TO EXCLUDE REMEDIAL STUDENTS APPROVED AT CUNY
description: The New York State Regents yesterday cleared the way for the City University of New York to begin to exclude students from its bachelor's degree programs who cannot demonstrate that they are ready to begin college-level work in both mathematics and English.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORD, J. COUPER
description: LORD-J. Couper. The Trustees of St. Andrew's Dune Church mourn the departure of one of our greatest leaders, the third longest-serving Trustee in the 121 years since our founding, the longest serving Trustee officer and the longest serving President of the Trustees. Coupie served with 36 of these 70 men and women who have been Trustees since 1879; He lead the Dune Church into its second century of service to the Southampton community. He will be missed by the Southampton community and the thousands who have worshiped with him each summer at the Dune Church. We thank God for the gift of his leadership, for the honor of serving with him and for the peace that finally is his. The Trustees of St. Andrew's Dune Church, Southampton, New York

title: Foreign Exchange With a Well-Kept Secret
description: Anyone who assumes that jazz works on a Darwinian principle -- that the best talents will win out, and consequently be heard and studied -- would have been surprised by the set Misha Mengelberg played with the trumpeter Dave Douglas's quartet on Wednesday night at Makor.

description: WAXGISER-Esther. On November 21, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Morris Waxgiser. Devoted mother of Marilyn Segal and Lynn Fox. Cherished grandmother of Mark, Steven, John, Peter, Lauren and Jeffrey. Loving great grandmother of Max, Evan and Julia. description: ''He was the man juxtaposed by the events of history to play this role right now. And so he's governing fearlessly, almost as if he has a death wish. Why? He's 61 years old. He's been president, he's been jailed. He has money. He has achieved everything. This is what's left.''

title: The Corpse Is Gone; Enter Quietly the Cleaners
description: Once cadavers and evidence are removed from a typical crime scene, the police and paramedics drive away, leaving a traumatized family and an opportunity for a delicate enterprise now quietly evident across the land.

title: Stone Thrown at Car Window on Upper West Side Proves to Be a False Lead
description: It was just a stone thrown at a parked car, an act of vandalism not much different from countless others. But with the search for the man who bashed a young woman with a similar paving stone in Midtown almost a week old, any promising lead can bring out scores of investigators.

description: JACOBSON-Martha. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to our dear friend and partner, Barry Jacobson, his sister Pauline Lavitt and their families on the loss of their beloved mother, Martha. She was a sweet, warm and compassionate woman who will be missed by everyone who knew her. Larry and Denise Wohl

title: Group Sends Book on Gay Tolerance to Schools
description: In a move likely to fuel debate over how secondary schools should handle the issue of homosexuality, a coalition of medical, mental health, educational and religious organizations announced yesterday that it would send the nation's school superintendents a booklet informing them that there is ''no support among health and mental health professional organizations'' for the idea that homosexuality is abnormal or mentally unhealthy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUBBARD, KATHRYN (NEE BROWN)
description: HUBBARD-Kathryn (nee Brown). 88, on November 19, 1999, of Washington, CT. Wife of the late W. Prescott Hubbard. Mother of Ethan, John and George Hubbard, Cynthia H. Bluh and Natalie H. Dyer. Grandmother of 14; great grandmother of 4. Memorial services Saturday, November 27, 1999 in the First Congregational Church of Washington, CT. at 11:00 AM.

title: Bradley, in Attack on Gore, Revives Finance Questions
description: In blunt criticism that echoed Republican attacks against the fund-raising practices of the 1996 Clinton-Gore campaign, former Senator Bill Bradley said today that Vice President Al Gore had little interest in changing the campaign finance system because it protected incumbents.

title: Acrobatics and Lyricism For the Spirit of Asia
description: Rika Oriental Ballet

title: Nissan Motor Reports 6-Month Loss of More Than $3 Billion
description: Addressing unrecognized liabilities that had been festering for years, the Nissan Motor Company reported a loss of more than $3 billion today for the first six months of its fiscal year and said that it expected an annual loss of more than $5.5 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVIN, THOMAS V.
description: LAVIN-Thomas V. On Saturday, November 20th, 1999. Beloved husband of Agnes Elizabeth for 59 years and father of Thomas, William, Gregory, Mary, Patricia, Peter, John, Michael and Mark. Grandfather of 26 children and great-grandfather of one. Brother of Gerard A. Lavin. Service was held at Denis O'Connor Funeral Home. Mass of the Ressurection at St. Francis de Sales Church, 12916 Rockaway Beach Blvd., Belle Harbor on November 23, 9:45 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORLANDO, CARL
description: ORLANDO-Carl. Age 84. An inventor with some twenty patents. He lived in Italy, New York, and New Jersey, graduated from Columbia and Rochester Universities. He was a Navy Veteran of WWII. He was the creator of a non-invasive heart and breathing monitor. He was Chairman and founder of SensoTech Industries, Eatontown, New Jersey. As Chief of Photo Optics at Fort Monmouth Army Electronics Command Unit. He helped patent for drone planes, night vision, a moving target indicator, image stabilization, a onestep photographic technique, a photographic high speed shutter, a military tactical image interpretation facility and holographic production and reconstruction, a founding member of the Society of Photographic Scientists and Engineers, and a member of the Society of Imaging Science and Technology. He is listed in ''Marquis Who's Who in Science and Engineering'' for 1994-1996, also ''Medicine and Health Care'' 1997-1998. He was elected to the Monmouth Regional High School Board of Education and he served his local Catholic parish. His love will endure in the hearts of his beloved wife Ann, five daughters, fourteen grandchildren and six great grandchildren. He treated everyone he met with respect and dignity, understood the unique qualities of the individuals whose lives he touched and gave his unconditional love to all.

title: POTOMAC ELECTRIC ACQUIRES DUTCH GAS DISTRIBUTORS
description: The Potomac Electric Power Company bought 17 natural gas distribution networks from four local governments in the Netherlands for $525 million in cash, its second investment in the Dutch gas market in four months. Potomac, a Washington-based utility with 700,000 electricity customers, acquired 21 Dutch gas networks for $724 million in August. Both purchases will add to earnings this year, the company said. Potomac and other United States utilities have expanded into Europe to find new sources of revenue as they lose their monopolies over power sales at home.

title: Albany Is Near Deal on Using Tobacco Share
description: Just as the states are about to take in a torrent of money from their settlement with tobacco companies, New York's lawmakers are moving toward a consensus that most if not all of the state's share should be spent on health.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Davenport and Hingis: Too Much
description: The women's tennis season is over, and here's one last parting shot.

title: Taking Vitamin E, for Better or for Worse
description: Vitamin E supplements are among the most popular over-the-counter remedies, taken in the belief that they may help with everything from dry skin to the effects of aging. But not all vitamin E is created equal. A new study raises questions about how useful the vitamin can be in helping people with crippling arthritis of the knee and also offers evidence that some forms of it may actually worsen osteoarthritis.

title: Marbury Keeps His Cool In Responding to Critics
description: Stephon Marbury will continue to play his game and do whatever it takes to right the Nets from their 1-9 start, but two days after several teammates lashed out at Marbury, he struck back at his detractors.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHEY, DENNIS R.
description: RICHEY-Dennis R., 46, of West Hartford, CT, died suddenly at his home on November 20. He was the beloved husband of Nancy Maggard and is survived by his four children, William Drake, Elizabeth Grace, Anne Stoddard, John Rutherford, and his cousin, Audrey Peckner of West Palm Beach, Florida. Dennis was a Vice President and member of the Board of Directors of General RENew England Asset Management. Among his many charitable activities were his membership at St. John's Church, where he was a member of the Vestry and the Outreach Committee. Recently, he had devoted time to the Hartford Area Habitat for Humanity. Mr. Richey was also a member of the Board of Trustees and Treasurer of the Renbrook School. Previously, he had focused on the Bethany Christian Services of New England, serving as the Chairman of the Board of this adoption agency. He graduated from St. Lawrence University with a bachelors, and NYU with an MBA. Donations, in his memory, may be made to the Hartford Area Habitat for Humanity, Parkville Project, 780C Windsor Street, P.O. Box 1933, Hartford, Connecticut 06144.

title: INSIDE
description: Domestic Abuse, by Women

title: Savoring the Phases of Boulez's Art
description: Dividing musical lives into thirds has become such a habit since we first did it to Beethoven's that the idea descends unbidden on any retrospective of a composer's career. The process may also apply to Pierre Boulez, who on Sunday afternoon was concluding a week of workshops and concerts at Carnegie Hall.

title: Madison Square Mystery: Who Will Lead Rangers?
description: John Muckler was absent from Ranger practice yesterday, which could be an omen. The coach was in Toronto for Wayne Gretzky's Hall of Fame induction and Muckler's next move remains the subject of intense speculation. Will he be dismissed for a record of 6-12-3 in the first quarter of the 1999-2000 season?

title: Flashback, Courtesy Of the G.O.P.
description: The further Al Gore tries to distance himself from Bill Clinton, the closer the Republicans want to link him. That is why the Republican National Committee is putting up a billboard that shows the president and vice president in a bear hug.

title: Eufrosina Raileanu, 39, City Opera Violist
description: Eufrosina Raileanu, the principal violist of the New York City Opera Orchestra and a busy freelance player who worked with several chamber groups, died on Saturday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 39 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GONZALEZ, LOUIS, JR. (CLYDE CORDEY)
description: GONZALEZ-Louis, Jr. (Clyde Cordey). On November 21, 1999 at age 62. Survived by his life partner Patrick Lannon, sisters Gloria Gonzalez and Sally Marfisi, beloved niece Jeanine Pagan, and his family of friends, who will miss him dearly.

title: BOLIVIAN GAS UNIT IS SOLD
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation, based in San Antonio, agreed to sell its Bolivian natural gas exploration unit to BG P.L.C., a British gas company, for $100 million to focus on refining oil and selling fuel. The sale of Tesoro Bolivia Petroleum Company represents Tesoro's exit from petroleum exploration. Tesoro Bolivia extracts about 19.1 million cubic feet of gas a day and has reserves of about 2.25 trillion cubic feet. BG said the acquisition would complement its other gas assets in Latin America, which include Comgas, Brazil's largest gas distribution company, and stakes in pipelines linking Argentina, Uruguay, Brazil and Bolivia.

title: The Teamster Case
description: In winning a conviction last week against the former political director of the Teamsters union for his role in an illegal campaign finance scheme, the U.S. attorney in Manhattan, Mary Jo White, provided an example of vigorous law enforcement -- and a sharp contrast to Attorney General Janet Reno's desultory pursuit of campaign finance abuses by President Clinton's 1996 campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, RONNA & SETH
description: ROBERTS-Ronna & Seth. Loving parents of Adam and Ethan. Seth is survived by his brother Ross, Ronna is survived by her mother Sylvia Glick Fidler and by her brothers Elliot and Lewis Fidler. Services Wednesday, November 24, at 10AM at I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead, N.Y.

description: Garth Fagan Dance

title: Tiffany's Owns the Building Once Again
description: Fifteen years after Tiffany & Company sold its flagship store on Fifth Avenue, the jewelry maker has repurchased the property, which was the setting for Truman Capote's novel ''Breakfast at Tiffany's.''

title: Tracking Ground Water's Unwelcome Guests
description: Industrial solvents and related chemicals are present in the ground water used to provide drinking water for 35 million to 50 million Americans, according to the United States Geological Survey, which is about to publish the first national report card on the presence of these chemicals.

title: Regulators See Need for Rules of the Road for Online Trading Firms
description: Online brokerage firms are the hot rods of Wall Street, providing fast and cheap access to stock market investors every trading day. Now, securities regulators want these firms to install seat belts.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review yesterday about the Stephen Sondheim revue ''Putting It Together,'' at the Barrymore, misstated the title of a song, sung by Bronson Pinchot, from ''A Little Night Music,'' another Sondheim show. The song is ''Bang!,'' not ''War.''

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: A Solid Remedial Plan for CUNY
description: The New York State Board of Regents set the right tone yesterday when it modified the City University of New York's new remediation plan before approving it. The plan ratified yesterday was more reasonable by far than the draconian measure produced by the CUNY trustees last year, which would have shut out 60 percent of all entering students from CUNY's four-year colleges.

title: Telecom Italia Shares Rise After Spinoff Plan Is Abandoned
description: Shares in Telecom Italia S.p.A. and the companies that acquired it last spring climbed today after a decision to abandon a plan to strip the company, Italy's biggest phone provider, of its profitable cellular phone unit.

title: Barren Island Has Fertile Soil for Epic and Author
description: When it was suggested to Wayne Johnston that his new book, ''The Colony of Unrequited Dreams,'' might be the Great Newfoundland Novel, a smile crossed the author's face. ''Is that an oxymoron?'' he wondered during a recent interview in New York. For this 41-year-old Canadian, his birthplace -- a former British colony and since 1949 a province of Canada -- ''may not be big, but the struggle is heroic.''

title: EFFICIENT NETWORKS BUYING CABLETRON SUBSIDIARY
description: Efficient Networks Inc., which makes modems for high-speed Internet access over phone lines, agreed to buy a complementary equipment business from Cabletron Systems Inc. for $860.6 million in stock. Efficient will pay 13.5 million shares for Cabletron's FlowPoint subsidiary, which makes routers that speed information on computer networks. The agreement makes Cabletron, based in Rochester, N.H., the largest shareholder of Efficient, with a 24 percent stake. Cabletron's shares rose $1 each, to $24. Efficient, based in Dallas, first sold shares to the public on July 15 at $15 each. Yesterday they jumped 23 percent, rising $15.50, to $79.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Dynasty In Making For United
description: MAJOR LEAGUE SOCCER

title: The Giants' Season Is in Collins's Hands
description: In the nine months since Kerry Collins signed with the Giants, there have been few days when Giants Coach Jim Fassel has not been asked about his crowded and awkward quarterback situation.

title: League Strikes Television Deals
description: The Arena Football League, the high-scoring downsized version of traditional football, which helped the St. Louis Rams quarterback Kurt Warner learn to make quick decisions, announced three-year television deals yesterday with TNN, ESPN, ESPN2 and ABC worth $25 million in cash and promotional value.

title: Lloyd's Wins U.S. Judgment
description: A New York court ruled last week that Lloyd's of London, the British insurance market, was entitled to collect $769,000 from two of its investors.

title: A War of Words in Battle for Mannesmann
description: Chris Gent, chief executive of Vodafone Airtouch, flew to Frankfurt today to promote his company's $127.7 billion hostile bid for Mannesmann, the German conglomerate, and to tell skeptical workers that there would be no job cuts if the takeover succeeded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLIFKA, MARTIN
description: SLIFKA-Martin, passed away on Sunday, November 21, 1999, age 94, peacefully at his home in Palm Beach, Florida. Dearest, most beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Robert and Rhoda Slifka, Joan Slifka, and Richard Slifka. Loving grandfather of Hy Goldburg, Nancy Goldburg, Linda and Bob Swysgood, Laura and Barry Goldstein, Gail and Sharon Slifka and the late Howard Slifka. Great grandfather of Riley, Brandy, Caela and Jordan. His first wife Mildred Rosenberg died in 1979. Also, much loved step-father of Amanda and Barry Glekin, Mark Masson and Melanie and Robert Stoutzker. Step-great grandfather of Charlotte and Freddie. Funeral services will be held at LevittWeinstein Memorial Chapel 5411 Okeechobee Blvd., West Palm Beach, FL on Tuesday, November 23 at 11:00 AM. Interment to follow at Royal Palm Memorial Gardens.

title: Rwanda Refuses to Grant a Visa for U.N. Tribunal's Prosecutor
description: Rwandan officials, angered that charges against a top genocide suspect have been dropped, have refused to grant a visa to the prosecutor of the United Nations tribunal investigating the massacres of at least 500,000 people in Rwanda in 1994.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, EDWARD ''NIK'' JAMES
description: WILLIAMS-Edward ''NIK'' James. November 17, 1999, at age 50. Leader and innovator in the global art movement. In his most recent endeavor, he conceived of and was leading the development of the Beecher Center for Art and Technology at the Butler Museum in Youngstown, Ohio. He is survived by his brother, Richard R. Williams, two nieces, Sarah and Jennifer, a nephew, Seth, and life partner Arleen Schloss AKA A. Renegade. Interment private.

title: Man Gets 22 Months In Immigrant Smuggling
description: A Korean whose ship shuttled scores of illegal Chinese immigrants to the United States and the Bahamas was sentenced yesterday to 22 months in prison for organizing the trips from South America.

title: SINGAPORE CONCERN IS BUYING DII GROUP
description: A Singapore company, Flextronics International, Ltd. agreed yesterday to acquire the Dii Group for $2.4 billion in stock in a deal that unites two providers of contract electronics manufacturing. Based on the Flextronics closing price on Friday, the transaction values each Dii Group share at $65.41. Dii Group, based in Niwot, Colo., reported revenue of $893 million for the nine months ended Sept. 30. Flextronics had revenue of $1.48 billion in the six months ended Sept. 24. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Dii rose $7.9375 each, to $59.75. Shares of Flextronics fell $2.875 each, to $78.375, on the Nasdaq. Dii and Flextronics assemble computer, electronic and telecommunications equipment for larger companies.

title: Luongo Called Up As Backup Goalie
description: The Islanders recalled goalie Roberto Luongo from Lowell of the American Hockey League yesterday to fill in for Wade Flaherty, the backup goaltender, who will be out one week with a right shoulder strain sustained in practice.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: JDS UNIPHASE CORP., San Jose, Calif., the world's leading maker of parts for fiber optic equipment in phone networks, said it planned to buy SIFAM Ltd. of Britain for $97.2 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AWERDICK, JOHN H.
description: AWERDICK-John H. The law firm of Hall Dickler Kent Friedman & Wood mourns with deep sorrow the passing of our partner and friend, John H. Awerdick. We will miss, but always remember joyously, John's dynamic personality, team spirit, and the friendship he extended to us all. We offer heart felt condolences to his wife Sue, their two children, and the entire family.

title: Howard Ferguson, 91, Composer Who Compiled Musical Texts
description: Howard Ferguson, a British musician internationally known for his editions of early keyboard music and of Schubert's complete piano works, died on Nov. 1 at his home in Cambridge, England. He was 91.

title: Ways to Tame Menopausal Hot Flashes, Without Estrogen
description: Hot flashes are a staple of menopause jokes, but there is nothing funny about them, and certainly nothing imaginary. They are experienced by at least 75 percent of American women at some point in menopause, including just before and just after. (They can also be brought on by the popular breast cancer drug tamoxifen and by the bone-building drug raloxifene.) They can vary from occasionally annoying to life-disrupting, and they can last for as little as a few days or as long as 10 years or more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSER, WILLIAM M. SR.
description: MOSER-William M. Sr., CPA. Of Great Neck, NY. On November 21, 1999. Oldest active member, former Treasurer, and Police Unit Captain of Co. No. 4, ManhassetLakeville Fire Department. Husband for 64 years of Ada Moser. Father of Bill Moser Jr., and wife Kathy, of Steamboat Springs, CO, and Sharonjean Moser Leeds and husband Dr. Richard Leeds of San Francisco, CA. Visiting in the Doyle B. Shaffer, Inc., Funeral Home, Little Neck Parkway & Northern Boulevard, Little Neck, Tuesday 79PM. Fire Department services Tuesday, 8PM. Religious services, Tuesday, 8:30PM. Internment private. In lieu of flowers, donations to: The Manhasset-Lakeville Fire Department, Company No. 4, would be appreciated.

title: BANK PROFITS IMPROVE
description: Japan's biggest banks, including Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd. and Sanwa Bank Ltd., reported improved profits for the six months that ended Sept. 30 and used stock profits to write off bad loans. Rounding out the half-year results for the nine city banks -- the biggest nationwide banks -- Tokyo-Mitsubishi reported net parent income of 62.9 billion yen for the half-year, up from 42.8 billion yen a year earlier. Sanwa, the nation's fourth-largest lender, reported profit of 32.1 billion yen ($303 million), up 9.9 percent.

title: Drive to Push Seat Belt Use By Children
description: Police officers nationwide will be stepping up enforcement of the laws on seat belts for children during this Thanksgiving week, Department of Transportation officials said today.

title: An Update On Fado, But True To the Heart
description: Basic black and an air of tragic dignity are essentials for fado, the songs that are one of Portugal's most prized traditions. Misia, the Portuguese singer who performed on Friday night at Town Hall in a World Music Institute concert, defied the convention when she entered in a long white cloak with a shawl covering her hair, looking pristinely penitential.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAFFNEY, HENRY EDWARD
description: GAFFNEY-Henry Edward. On November 19. Devoted husband of Mary. Beloved father of Mary, Henry, Catherine, Christopher and Edward. Loving father-in-law of Joseph, Lisa, Anne and Pam. Also survived by 11 grandchildren. A funeral mass will be celebrated November 26 at 1:30 PM at St. Francis Xavier Church, 46 West 16 Street, New York City 10011. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to ''Xavier Welcome Table'', care of St. Francis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINER, JACK P.
description: MINER-Jack P. On Monday, November 22, 1999. 90 years young. Beloved husband of 62 years of Rose. Devoted father of Phyllis & Harvey Granat & Carla & Martin P. Miner. Adored grandfather of Steven and Stacey Granat, Cheryl & Eugene Segall, Cary and Evelyn Granat, Colin Miner and David and Jennifer Miner. Loving ''Papa Jack'' to his seven great grandchildren. Cherished brother of Frances Fenster and beloved ''Uncle Jack''. He was the patriarch of a large & loving family and set an example of living life with love, compassion, strength and dignity touching all who knew him with wisdom and joy of life. He was uniquely inter-generational. Services Tuesday, November 23rd, 1PM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers or baskets, it would be appreciated if contributions are made in his memory to either NYU Palliative Care Program, C/O Dr. James Wernz, 160 East 32 St, NY NY or to The Inn Foundation, c/o Beth Israel North, Neurosurgery, C/O Dr. Fred Epstein, 170 East End Avenue, NY, NY. 10128

title: Uncovered Short Sales Rise 1.8% on New York Exchange
description: Open positions of short sales on the New York Stock Exchange edged up 1.8 percent in the most recent monthly period, the exchange said last week.

title: A Grateful Clinton Offers Encouragement to Bulgaria
description: President Clinton thanked Bulgaria today for supporting the NATO campaign against Slobodan Milosevic in nearby Yugoslavia and urged the struggling nation to stay the course of economic reform.

description: FRANKFURT  Philipp Holzmann AG, a construction giant that symbolized Germany's postwar reconstruction, faced the prospect of insolvency Monday, leaving the fate of 60,000 workers hanging in the balance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, BEATRICE R. (FISHMAN)
description: LEWIS-Beatrice R. (Fishman), 82, of Monroe Twp., NJ, formerly of Brooklyn on November 22, 1999. Mrs. Lewis loved being a Legal Secretary at Donovan, Leisure, Newton and Irvine until May 1986. She loved New York, the theatre, her family and Loehmans. Mrs. Lewis was a member of the National Council of Jewish Women and B'Nai Brith. She is survived by her husband of 59 years: Irving; her sons and daughters-in-law; Jonathan and Melanie Lewis of Wilmington, DE, and Michael and Arlene Lewis of Mt. Laurel, NJ; her brother: Philip Mann of White Plains, NY and four grandchildren: Joshua, Helen, Adam and Sara. Service 12:00 Noon Wedesday, Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, Cranbury Rd. at Evergreen Boulevard, East Brunswick, New Jersey.

title: InfoSpace.com Acquisition
description: A provider of maps and directories to Web sites, InfoSpace.com Inc., agreed today to buy closely held eComLive.com Inc. for about $33.5 million in stock to add real-time services like video conferences. InfoSpace.com will exchange 355,618 shares of its common shares for all of eComLive.com's shares and options. EComLive.com, based in Fremont, Calif., offers Internet-based services including multimedia broadcasting.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about La Noue Davenport, an expert in early music and period instruments, misstated a surviving son's given name. The son is Dylan, not Chester.

title: Yankees Offer Rhodes 4 Years
description: The Yankees have offered Arthur Rhodes a four-year, $10 million contract and are one of three teams the left-handed reliever is still considering, his agent, Dan Horwits, said yesterday.

title: Technology Issues Continue to Help Nasdaq Index Climb
description: Technology stocks continued their rapid ascent yesterday, carrying the Nasdaq composite index to its 14th record in the last 17 sessions. Gains in Internet stocks and big companies like Microsoft and Intel helped to fuel the advance.

title: GARDEN RIDGE CORP. WILL BE TAKEN PRIVATE
description: The Garden Ridge Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to be taken private for $11.50 a share in a deal that values the company, a floral and housewares retailer, at $185 million. The buyout is being led by GRDG Holdings L.L.C., which is majority-owned by two investment funds advised by Three Cities Research Inc., a private equity firm based in New York. Garden Ridge, based in Houston, has 33 stores in 12 states and had sales of $176 million in the six months ended Aug. 1. GRDG currently owns 30.9 percent of Garden Ridge.

title: TELEMONDE AGREES TO BUY GLOBAL COMMUNICATIONS
description: Telemonde Inc., an Internet voice- and data-services provider, agreed yesterday to buy Global Communications Holdings Ltd. of Britain for $160 million in cash, notes and stock to add electronic-commerce services. Global Communications, which is closely held, processes transactions for more than 2,000 online merchants -- or more than half of the existing e-commerce sites in Britain -- through its Netbanx unit. Telemonde will use Global Communications' business to expand its own prepaid calling cards, voice-mail and fax mail services. The acquisition is Telemonde's biggest and is part of the New York-based company's plan to buy companies that run Internet-based businesses in less-developed countries. Global Communications, based in Cambridge, England, operates in 20 countries.

title: A Virtual Oasis For Morocco Stocks; Trading Going on Here? Shocking!
description: The trading floor of the Casablanca Stock Exchange, with just 30 traders working in little computer cubicles, is as quiet as a church. And it is about to get even quieter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EKSTEIN, GUSSIE
description: EKSTEIN-Gussie. Of Morristown, formerly of Brooklyn, on Sunday, November 21, 1999. Wife of the late Robert Ekstein. Mother of Cecelia deLaRosa of Parsippany, NJ. Sister of Philip Strum of Delray Beach, FL and Edward Strum of NY, NY. Also survived by two granddaughters. Funeral services private. Please omit flowers, but those who wish to make a contribution may do so to the Morristown Memorial Hospital, 100 Madison Ave., Morristown, NJ 07960

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, SOL
description: FELDMAN-Sol. The Officers, Board of Directors, and Members of Engineers Country Club mourn the passing of their beloved member. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the Feldman family.

title: Drivers' Test Scheme Reveals Secret Decoder Watchbands
description: At Princeton, there is a strict honor code that tries to prevent cheating. At West Point, a cadet found to have cheated on tests can face immediate expulsion.

title: Need for Counseling Unmet In Boy Who Became a Killer
description: Nathaniel Abraham, the youngest American charged and convicted of murder as an adult, received no special counseling or other assistance despite warning signs years before he fatally shot a man at age 11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELLER, ELAINE
description: FELLER-Elaine, age 69, retired educator; resident of Belle Harbor, NY, on November 22nd. Beloved wife of Irving for 43 years; cherished mother of Michael, Robyn, Alyssa and Paul; loving grandmother of Danielle, Zachary and Sam. Her boundless love and courage will remain an inspiration to all who loved her. Service Gutterman's, Woodbury, LI, today, 10am.

title: DIAMONDS RETURN TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: The world's largest diamond producer, De Beers, is repatriating about $100 million worth of large South African-mined diamonds stockpiled in London. ''De Beers is in the process of bringing back large stones in the stockpile at the request of the Diamond Board'' of South Africa, a De Beers spokeswoman, Tracey Peterson, said. About $700 million worth of regular-sized diamonds will remain in London. The board's demand that the diamonds be returned was part of a dispute that delayed the export of De Beers's consignments twice this year.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALTER, ELY
description: BALTER-Ely. Dietitian, French W.W. II Veteran. Beloved father, grandfather & greatgrandfather. Died at age 94, November 21, 1999.

title: Front Row
description: BBC Documentary Looks at Agencies

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEDS, STEVEN
description: LEEDS-Steven. Temple Israel, Lawrence mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends deepest sympathy to his bereaved family. Brooks R. Susman, Rabbi Alan J. Hartstein, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, ROBERT A., M.D.
description: BERMAN-Robert A., M.D., on November 21, 1999. Beloved husband of Jan. Loving and loved father of Jonathan (Lynda), Virginia (Jack) Glasser, Maria (Richard) Koby, Stephen, Amy (Tony) Martez. Cherished grandfather of six. For information call Boulevard West Funeral Home, Hewlett, LI.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: Crude oil prices surged 3.6 percent, to $27 a barrel, the highest since the Persian Gulf war, after reports that Iraq halted oil shipments and rejected a United Nations plan to extend an export agreement for two weeks.

title: An Inmate, 18, Hangs Herself In a Rikers Cell
description: An 18-year-old inmate at Rikers Island awaiting trial on drug charges hanged herself in her cell yesterday afternoon, the city Correction Department said.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Chicago Faces The Future, Reluctantly
description: After more than 150 years at the top, the Chicago Board of Trade can no longer call itself the world's largest futures and options exchange.

title: Survey Finds Race-Relations Gap In Armed Services, Despite Gains
description: Despite a decades-long effort to promote equal opportunity and good race relations in the armed forces, the Pentagon has found that wide gaps remain between how whites and minority uniformed personnel perceive how they are treated.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: A Pesticide Filter

title: Weight, Longings And Other Realities
description: RoseAnne Spradlin

title: KOREAN G.D.P. SOARS
description: Encouraged by the rapid recovery of investments in factories and a surge in exports, South Korea's real gross domestic product shot up 12.3 percent in the third quarter of this year from a year earlier, the Bank of Korea, the nation's central bank, said. In the first nine months of the year, the nation's G.D.P. surged 9 percent from a year earlier, in contrast to a 6 percent contraction in the corresponding period of last year. The third-quarter growth rate was the highest since the first quarter of 1988, when the nation's G.D.P. skyrocketed 15.9 percent.

title: Treating the Whole Person
description: To the Editor:

title: In New Jersey, Judges Make Their Case For a Raise
description: State judges need a raise, the chief justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court told a special legislative panel today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SORMANI, LEO L.
description: SORMANI-Leo L. Beloved husband of Mary Santini Sormani. Loving father of Delores Patrissi, Robert Santini and Adele Santini. Reposing at Farenga Bros. Funeral Home, 920 Allerton Ave., Bronx, until 9 AM, Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday, at 10 AM, at Holy Rosary Church.

title: Spouse Abuse Crackdown, Surprisingly, Nets Many Women
description: Defenders of battered women long struggled to persuade authorities to crack down on brutal men who reigned by the fist at home. But those crackdowns have produced an unexpected consequence: in some places, one-quarter or more of arrests for domestic assault are not of men but of women.

title: L.I. Highway Worker Sues Town, Citing Bias
description: A former Smithtown highway worker who says he was subjected to racial slurs by fellow town employees filed a discrimination lawsuit against the town today.

title: Red Storm's Recruiting Makes N.B.A. a Rival
description: Mike Jarvis was sitting in his office speculating on what may be the best recruiting class in the nation, and as he discussed the possibility that the best of the group might never set foot on the floor at Alumni Hall, he was smiling. It might seem an odd response from a man facing that sad truth, but Jarvis could smile because St. John's has landed a group more than one man deep.

title: Metro Business; At Rainbow Room, Added Accessibility
description: The Rainbow Room, the venerable and expensive restaurant on the 64th floor of Rockefeller Center, has agreed to renovate rather than fight a government lawsuit that says it is inaccessible to wheelchairs and unsafe for hearing-impaired diners.

title: 'The Scarlet Letter,' Alive And Bitter in the Inner City
description: Artists talk with one another across the centuries; they talk about their obsessions, their ancestors, the particulars of their time and place and about whatever can go beyond the particular to take on a new life.

title: SWEDISH INTERNET CONSULTANT BUYING AMERICAN RIVAL
description: Icon Medialab International, an unprofitable Swedish Internet consulting company, agreed yesterday to buy an American rival, Nicholson NY, for as much as $76 million in stock, part of its plan to seek a listing on the Nasdaq stock market. Icon, based in Stockholm, will pay with 817,500 shares and may issue another 80,000 should Nicholson reach unspecified sales and profitability goals next year. Nicholson, based in New York, is a closely held company with 100 employees. It expects sales this year of $10.5 million.

title: In Trash Fight, Aiming Pebbles at Goliath
description: What to make of this mayor who started the garbage war against New York City?

title: Real Trouble in a Shtetl: Love, Sacred and Profane
description: In the turn-of-the-century shtetl that is the setting for the Folksbiene Yiddish Theater's new production of ''A Klezmer's Tale: Yoshke Muzikant,'' there's trouble.

title: GOTO.COM, INTERNET SEARCH SERVICE, BUYING CADABRA
description: GoTo.com Inc., an Internet search service, said yesterday that it would acquire Cadabra Inc., which provides comparison-shopping services, for $250 million in cash and stock to expand its electronic-commerce offerings. GoTo.com will pay $8 million in cash and $242 million in stock for closely held Cadabra. GoTo.com offers to help guide Internet users to products, prices and other features so it can match up merchants and advertisers with its Web site visitors. The company, based in Pasadena, Calif., offers an Internet search service where merchants pay for listings. Cadabra is based in San Mateo, Calif. GoTo.com's shares fell $2.625, to $105.625.

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption yesterday about the Major League Soccer championship between D.C. United and the Los Angeles Galaxy misidentified the Galaxy player shown pressuring the goalie. He was Carlos Hermosillo, not Danny Pena.

title: For Latest on AIDS Therapy, Click Here
description: For people who have AIDS, or the infection that causes it, information can be the most important weapon of all.

title: Lesbians Find Cancer Support Without Excuses
description: What happens to a couple when one partner suddenly becomes ill and dependent? How will a lover react to a scarred or missing breast, a bald head, a woman who wakes up crying in the middle of the night, wondering how much time she has left?

title: A Microsoft Suit With a Sure Winner
description: It had to happen: America's most successful industry, high technology, is under sustained assault from America's second-most successful industry, litigation.

title: Presbyterian Court Denies Two Efforts Against Gays
description: A regional court of the Presbyterian Church dealt a setback today to efforts by conservatives trying to categorically ban gay marriages and the ordination of gays.

title: Positions Filled By Lowe Lintas
description: Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide in New York, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has made additional appointments at the agency, formed recently by the merger of Ammirati Puris Lintas and Lowe & Partners Worldwide.

title: The State of the Planet, in Verse and in Adversity
description: To commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, Columbia University held a two-day conference last week called ''The State of the Planet.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECK, JACK
description: BECK-Jack. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted member Jack Beck, beloved husband of Charlotte, father of Steven Beck and Alice Bannett, Renee and Allen Silverstein, grandfather of Day School students Elizabeth and Jessica and Emily. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, Pres. Jerry Forst, Vice Pres. Jack Rosen, Vice Pres.

title: In a Nonstop Economy, Truckers Keep Rolling
description: Terry Wheat cherishes his new International Eagle 18-wheeler loaded with Budweiser beer, soon to be loaded with whatever the dispatcher assigns him next. ''My truck is built strictly for comfort,'' he said. ''My seats swivel and kick back.'' Behind the seats is his sleeper, with double decker beds, a television, a VCR, a refrigerator and his Nintendo games.

title: A New 'Tristan' To Rival Memories
description: ''Tristan und Isolde'' has been a passive presence in the big opera houses of the world, like an imposing building left vacant for lack of prime tenants. For years we have had the orchestras, the conductors, the directors and the means to bring Wagner's immense, hypnotic and deeply disturbing opera to life. What we have not had is people to sing it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUBBARD, KATHRYN (NEE BROWN)
description: HUBBARD-Kathryn (nee Brown). 88, on November 19, 1999, of Washington, CT. Wife of the late W. Prescott Hubbard. Mother of Ethan, John and George Hubbard, Cynthia H. Bluh and Natalie H. Dyer. Grandmother of 14; great grandmother of 4. Memorial services Saturday, November 27, 1999 in the First Congregational Church of Washington, CT. at 11:00 AM.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Spawning Like Salmon

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 17 about a meeting of the top national fund-raisers for Gov. George W. Bush of Texas misstated the given name of the state senator who is the Republican Party chairman in Manhattan. He is Roy M. Goodman, not Ray.

title: China Crawls Into Space
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Road With Mom the Sexpot
description: Watching the British actress Janet McTeer's astoundingly vital portrayal of a sexy free-spirited Southern gal in Gavin O'Connor's film ''Tumbleweeds,'' you have the thrilling awareness of an actor melting so deeply into a role that what is on the screen is not a performance at all but a kind of spontaneous alchemy. Ms. McTeer's character, Mary Jo Walker, belongs to a breed of vibrant, earthy woman that movies love to portray but have hardly ever got exactly right.

title: More African Women Have AIDS Than Men
description: AIDS has long been considered primarily a men's disease. But yesterday the United Nations reported for the first time that more women than men were infected with the AIDS virus in Africa, the site of a vast majority of such infections in the world.

title: Jets to Call on Defense In Rematch With Colts
description: They lost to the Patriots and Drew Bledsoe in the first game of the season, and then bowed the following week to Doug Flutie and the Bills. The Jets also fell victim to the Colts and Peyton Manning the first time they met this season. An 0-3 record against three of the elite teams, and quarterbacks.

title: A Master Work, but Easy to Browse
description: IN the nearly 20 years Alan Davidson took to compile the Oxford Companion to Food (Oxford University Press, $60), anticipation ran high. He had written encyclopedic works on topics like fish and fruit and edited a scholarly series of pamphlets called Petits Propos Culinaires, but this was to be a collective work, with contributions from some of the best minds in the academic world of food.

title: Jury Awards $79 Million in Suit Over Injury to Child's Brain
description: A Manhattan jury has awarded $79 million to a family whose son was left with severe brain damage nine years ago after a procedure at New York-Presbyterian Hospital. The judgment was one of the largest ever against a New York City hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOHUE, ALBERT F.
