description: DONOHUE-Albert F. Of Bronxville, NY, on November 22, 1999. Husband of the late Barbara Braun Donohue. Father of Thomas, Mary Allen, John and the late James Donohue. Grandfather of 13. Interment St. Mary's Cemetery, Cortland, NY, on Saturday, November 27, at 11:30 AM. Memorial mass at a later date.

title: Albanians in Kosovo Grateful U.S. Army Is There
description: Braving the first snow of the year, hundreds of Kosovo Albanians packed the main street here today to try to glimpse President Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STUPAK, MAX
description: STUPAK-Max. On November 22, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Mollie; loving father of Herbert and Anna, Elliot and Susan. Adoring grandfather of nine and greatgrandfather of five. He will be deeply missed. Service Wednesday 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Rowan Transfers Sparkle
description: SMALL COLLEGE REPORT

title: MALAYSIA TO REJOIN INDEX
description: A Geneva-based index compiler, Morgan Stanley Capital International Inc., said that it would fully reinstate Malaysian stocks into its widely followed portfolio indexes on May 31 and that it would increase Taiwan stocks over the course of a year. The firm will readmit Malaysian stocks into its Emerging Markets Free and All Country Free portfolio indexes all at once. Morgan Stanley Capital International first announced in August it would restore Malaysia and count Taiwan stocks at full weight starting in February. Then, it delayed the changes until May 31 because of concern about possible computer problems related to the leap year in 2000. (Bloomberg News)

title: A Time Traveler Returns, Still Restless
description: Michael Crichton may be derided by ''serious'' novelists, ''serious'' scientists and ''serious'' book reviewers for his popular techno-thrillers, the latest called ''Timeline,'' a story of quantum technology, time travel and 14th-century France.

title: HILLENBRAND REDUCING STAFF IN ITS HEALTH CARE UNIT
description: The holding company Hillenbrand Industries Inc. said yesterday that its Hill-Rom Company health care unit would cut about 350 positions, or 5 percent, over nine months. The reduction will primarily eliminate administrative positions, Hillenbrand said. The unit employs approximately 6,600 people worldwide, with about 2,000 in the Batesville, Ind., area, where it is based. As a result of the work force reduction and other charges, Hillenbrand expects to take a fourth-quarter charge of $30 million to $35 million. On the New York Stock Exchange, Hillenbrand's shares fell $3.8125 each, to $32.

title: Jeraldyne Blunden, 58, Founder Of Dayton Modern Dance Troupe
description: Jeraldyne Blunden, the founder and artistic director of the Dayton Contemporary Dance Company, died on Monday at the Franciscan Medical Center in Dayton, Ohio. She was 58 and lived in Dayton.

title: News Corp. Weighs Investing in Health Site
description: The News Corporation is in talks to invest cash and other assets in the Healtheon/WebMD Corporation for a large minority stake in the Internet health-information company, its chairman and chief executive, Rupert Murdoch, said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a note in Science Times yesterday identifying the writer of a letter about a new technique for recording music misstated his area of expertise. The writer, Benjamin Bederson, is an emeritus professor of physics, not history, at New York University.

title: Mrs. Clinton to Be Official New Yorker
description: In a matter of weeks, Bill and Hillary Clinton will become the ultimate commuter couple.

title: Germany Fails in Effort To Keep Builder Afloat
description: FRANKFURT  The German construction company Philipp Holzmann AG filed for insolvency Tuesday after last-minute intervention by Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder failed to convince banks to support a 4.3 billion Deutsche mark bailout.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONATO, ANNETTE BURROWS
description: DONATO-Annette Burrows. Died November 23, 1999. Loving mother of Vincent, loving sister of Marion Wade & Dr. Benjamin Burrows. Loving aunt of Jan Burrows, Steven Burrows, Lynn Evans, Susan Theobold & Donald Wade. Private services will be held on Friday.

title: Triangle Shirtwaist Fire
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Tragedy And College Rites
description: To the Editor:

title: Opponents of a Change in CUNY Admissions Policy Helped Pass a Compromise Plan
description: Behind the State Board of Regents' historic 9-6 vote on Monday to allow the City University of New York's senior colleges to sharply limit admissions was a loose group of current and former CUNY officials and their allies whose support for a compromise made it more palatable for wavering Regents to cast an affirmative vote.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PIONEER NATURAL RESOURCES CO., Irving, Tex., an oil and natural gas exploration company, said it bought fields in Argentina for about $40 million, increasing its production in the country by 15 percent.

title: Immigrant Laborers Say They Knew of Job Risks
description: Lauriano Avilez said that he and other immigrant workers who poured concrete and put up the cinder block walls at a construction site that collapsed yesterday in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, knew toiling inside the structure had its risks.

title: A 'Gadget Guy' Comes Home
description: I'm basically trained as a techie. I left M.I.T. as an electrical engineer and the Sloane School with a systems background. Coming to Reebok was going from electronics and high-tech digital convergence to footwear and apparel. But I've always been a gadget guy, and I've managed to find technology in any business I've been in.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWIKELBERG, MATYS
description: ZWIKELBERG-Matys. On Nov. 22, 1999. Cantor, beloved father, grandfather and brother. Survived the Holocaust. Services at 1 PM Wednesday, at Parkside Chapel, Flatbush, Brooklyn. We will always remember him singing.

title: 1,000 Rally for Korean-American Merchants Who Fear Backlash of Bias in Palisades Park
description: Waving American flags and chanting ''We want change,'' and ''End racism now,'' about 1,000 Korean-Americans rallied outside Town Hall today in support of Korean-American merchants who complained of unfair treatment by local officials.

title: Thick and Thin of Soup
description: MY grandmother sometimes began Thanksgiving by serving a soup thick with mushrooms, meat and barley that was too filling. But a lighter soup made with mushrooms, one that stimulates the appetite, is always a good idea. And a soup that can go either light or rich is the best idea of all.

title: Police Charge High-Tech Sleight of Hand
description: A Bloomingdale's employee was arrested Monday evening and charged with using a hand-held computer to steal a customer's credit card number, the police said yesterday.

title: Wallace Persons, 90, Executive; Led Growth of Emerson Electric
description: Wallace R. Persons, who in nearly 20 years as chief executive, expanded the Emerson Electric Company from a small regional appliance maker into a diversified industrial manufacturer, died on Sunday in St. Louis, the company said. He was 90.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Some Leaders Resist Call To Attend Trade Meeting

title: COOPER TIRE AND RUBBER AGREES TO BUY SIEBE AUTOMOTIVE
description: The Cooper Tire and Rubber Company, the world's No. 7 tire maker, agreed yesterday to buy, for $245 million, a unit of Invensys P.L.C. that makes brake and fuel lines. The Siebe Automotive unit had sales of about $400 million in the year that ended on Sept. 30, with about 53 percent in North America and 37 percent in Europe. Siebe, based in Southfield, Mich., has about 4,000 workers in 16 locations. Cooper, based in Findlay, Ohio, is trying to broaden its appeal to automakers as a worldwide supplier. Invensys, based in London, was formed in February when Siebe P.L.C. and BTR P.L.C. merged.

title: Animated Sequel Finds New Level Of Imagination
description: ''Toy Story 2'' can be enjoyed -- enormously -- without wondering exactly why the Pixar animation looks even better than it did the first time. Among the many talents of the director, John Lasseter, and his huge crew of computer-animation pioneers is a gift for making their work look easy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, HARRY
description: SCHWARTZ-Harry, 99, of Hollywood, Florida, formerly of NYC. Passed away November 22, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Lillian. Loving father of Arnold and Eileen Schwartz and Ruth and David Schwab. Loving and much loved Grandpa Harry to his five grandchildren, their spouses, and his twelve great-grandchildren. Harry was raised at the Brooklyn Hebrew Orphan Asylum. He became the youngest CPA in NY and founded his own firm, and later became an Advisory Partner at the firm which is now Deloitte & Touche. Levitt Weinstein Funeral Home, (800-343-5400).

title: Is Sprawl Strangling Atlanta?
description: To the Editor:

title: Measure of Good Will Toward Muslims Backfires in House
description: The resolution seemed innocuous enough.

title: Sound Truck Newest Weapon To Combat Holiday Gridlock
description: As city drivers veered out of intersections, muzzled their horns and cowered before car-boot-bearing traffic agents yesterday, the Mayor unleashed a new weapon against holiday gridlock -- a noisy sound truck spewing threats.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You cannot forget the injustice that was done to you. No one can force you to forgive what was done to you. But you must try.''

title: Liberties; And She's Off!
description: We knew she was running when she showed up in earth tones.

title: Moving to Ease Doubts, First Lady Says She Will Enter Senate Race
description: Seeking to dispel a cloud of doubt that has shadowed her emerging campaign for public office, Hillary Rodham Clinton flew to New York yesterday to declare that she was in the race for the United States Senate to stay. She said she would move into her new house in Chappaqua, N.Y., as soon as the Secret Service said she could, and begin campaigning ''as vigorously as possible.''

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Higher Education Pays

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Fish Roast to Go

title: N.B.A. Presses Sprewell On Behavior in Oakland
description: A groggy Latrell Sprewell picked up his ringing telephone this morning and heard the voice of a league security officer. Suddenly, his fog cleared from the jolt of questioning he was under regarding his conduct last Saturday night at the Arena in Oakland.

title: Blessed Are the Needy, for Iris Is on the Job
description: TEN years ago on Thanksgiving, Iris Arce, a $28,000-a-year payroll underling for New York Telephone, had been on strike for four months. She was living in a small one-bedroom Brooklyn apartment with her 17-year-old daughter and her grandchild, her daughter's 3-year-old son.

title: Head to Head In Mexico: D.E.A. Agents And Suspects
description: Two American drug-enforcement agents who had been driving around a Mexican border city with an informer were chased, surrounded and nearly killed two weeks ago by a posse of suspected drug traffickers and their heavily armed bodyguards, United States and Mexican officials said yesterday.

title: KeyCorp Plans to Lay Off 3,000 Employees
description: KeyCorp, the Cleveland financial company that in five years has grown from a regional bank into a broader financial services concern with home equity, investment banking and credit card operations from Maine to Alaska, said yesterday that it would lay off 3,000 employees to cut costs.

title: With Joe Camel put out to pasture, tobacco makers like R.J.R. try a more direct approach.
description: WITH Joe Camel gone, at the federal government's insistence, to that palm-studded marketing oasis in the sky, R. J. Reynolds Tobacco is turning to the magazine industry to give its biggest nondiscount brand a boost.

title: Our Towns; Keeping Nature In Its Place
description: MARK JOHNSON is what people used to call a dogcatcher. But as the suburbs sprawled into former farms and forests, animal control officers like Mr. Johnson found themselves not just rescuing cats from elm trees and dogs from highways, but negotiating between people and the rest of the wild kingdom. It's an increasingly complicated relationship.

title: VIBRANT FRENCH ECONOMY
description: Consumer spending in France grew at an unexpectedly fast rate in October, providing further evidence that Europe's second-largest economy is also its fastest growing. The national statistics office said spending for manufactured goods was 2.3 percent higher than in September. The report excluded spending for services, which account for 40 percent of total consumer spending, suggesting that overall growth was even higher. The French government expects the economy to grow 2.3 percent this year and 3 percent next year, compared with expected growth of 1.4 percent this year and 2.7 percent next year in Germany, the biggest European economy. John Tagliabue

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATANSON, ARTHUR
description: NATANSON-Arthur. Died suddenly in FL on November 21, 1999. Beloved husband of Wanda. Father of Carol McPartlan, Diane Alan and Susan Duncan. Grandfather to Nicholas, Alexa, Ryan and Paul. Owner of Detra Watch Case Co., N Y. WWII Army Veteran. Memorial contributions to Tourette Syndrome Association, Bayside, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a billboard planned by the Republican National Committee for display across the street from Al Gore's campaign headquarters in Nashville referred incompletely to the image. The photograph, issued by the committee, was an artist's rendering of what the billboard will look like when it is erected, in the next two weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AWERDICK, JOHN HOLMES
description: AWERDICK-John Holmes. Of Verona, New Jersey on November 21, 1999. (Attorney, a partner with the firm of Hall, Dickler, Kent, Friedman & Wood, L.L.P., NY). Beloved husband of Susan (nee McIntosh). Devoted father of Jason Alexander of Arlington, VA and Megan Elizabeth of Verona, NJ. A memorial service will be held Sunday, November 28, 1999 at 3 PM in the Union Congregational Church, Upper Montclair, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations to Music Therapy C/O Mr. Robert Wilkins, Director of Development, Memorial Sloan-Kettering (MSKCC), 1275 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021 or to Union Congregational Church, 176 Cooper Avenue, Upper Montclair, NJ 07043 would be appreciated. For information Dancy Funeral Home, Caldwell, New Jersey.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: If the Art Fits, Some Will Wear It

title: Is Sprawl Strangling Atlanta?
description: To the Editor:

title: N.I.T. Teams Hope a Rough Trip Is Worthwhile
description: The Notre Dame basketball players were looking forward to attending ''Smokey Joe's Cafe'' on Broadway last night on the eve of the Preseason National Invitation Tournament semifinals. But they had to forgo that outing and practice instead at night because the 2-year-old son of their rookie coach broke his leg at the airport and delayed the coach's trip from South Bend, Ind. The boy, Tucker Doherty, tripped over a rope barrier on Monday night and had to be immobilized in a body cast after fracturing a big bone in his upper leg. So the team traveled to New York without Coach Matt Doherty, who planned to arrive yesterday afternoon.

title: Is Sprawl Strangling Atlanta?
description: To the Editor:

title: Forget Millions, He Just Wants Quiet; New Yorker Endures Contestants Who Can't Even Dial Correctly
description: If, perhaps, you dreamed of riches and wanted to try your luck on the smash-hit quiz show ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire,'' all you had to do was dial the simple toll-free number 1-877-258-5808.

title: Attention to Scores Comes at a Price
description: THERE is a national consensus that students need more competency in reading, math, science and history. But Americans also want schools to teach citizenship, healthful lifestyles and creativity. When people rely mostly on test scores to assess school quality, do they unwittingly sacrifice these other goals?

title: Political Briefing; Polls and Politicos See California Long Shot
description: When Representative Tom Campbell, a Republican from California's 15th Congressional District, announced last Friday that he was jumping into the race to unseat Senator Dianne Feinstein, a liberal Democrat, he declared the task ''do-able.'' Most political experts think otherwise.

title: Text of House Resolution Showing Deleted Sections
description: Following is the original text of a bipartisan Congressional resolution encouraging tolerance toward Muslims. The paragraphs in italics were deleted by House Republicans last week; wording changes were made in other paragraphs but are not reflected here. A copy of the original resolution and last week's revisions were provided to The New York Times by the Arab American Institute of Washington, which helped draft the original measure.

title: Gates Vaccine Gift
description: The chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, William H. Gates, and his wife, Melinda, will donate $750 million to help provide vaccinations against deadly diseases for children in developing countries.

title: OFFERING SEEN FOR FENDI
description: Patrizio Bertelli, the chief executive of Prada, which jointly bought 51 percent of a fashion rival, Fendi S.p.A., with LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A. last month, said the companies could take Fendi public in two to three years. Merger activity in the fashion industry is increasing as companies seek cost savings by sharing purchases of raw materials and combining buying systems. Prada and LVMH took control of Fendi with the aim of developing it as a global brand. Prada and LVMH expect to open about 10 Fendi stores a year and to increase the number of products.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CANNON, VICTOR, JR.
description: CANNON-Victor, Jr.-David misses your conversations at midnight and I see you in all that I have. Ellen and David

title: Seattle Round Might Not Get Out of the Starting Blocks, EU Aide Warns : WTO Dispute Stymies Agenda for Talks
description: GENEVA  With a week to go before it kicks off its major summit meeting, the World Trade Organization failed Tuesday to agree on a draft agenda to submit to the world leaders expected in Seattle on Nov. 30.

title: Australia Beats U.S. In the Semifinals
description: Australia reached the final of the FIFA Under-17 Championship tournament with a victory, advancing on penalty kicks after finishing regulation time tied at 2-2. Australia held the advantage, 7-6, in penalty kicks.

title: Massachusetts Sets Low Bar For Passing Graduation Test
description: The Massachusetts Board of Education voted today to set a low passing mark for new tests that students must take to graduate from high school.

title: Looking Beyond the Myth-Making Easel of Mr. Thanksgiving
description: There's a scene in Steven Spielberg's 1987 movie ''Empire of the Sun'' in which a British mother and father gaze down serenely at their handsome young son, peaceful, safe and secure in bed. It could almost be a Norman Rockwell painting. And that was no accident, says Mr. Spielberg in ''Norman Rockwell: Painting America,'' a 90-minute ''American Masters'' documentary that has its premiere on PBS tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONSTANDT, GEORGE
description: KONSTANDT-George. November 23, 1999. We are all the lesser for the loss of an extraordinary man. Survived by his wife & life partner Theo, children Sari, David, Mark, Lisa and Ken, brothers and sister Andy, Cheryl and Larry, granddaughters Addison and Daryl, and his parents Ann and Felix. Peace and love.

title: INVESTMENT FIRM ACQUIRED
description: A Belgian investment company, GIMV, offered to buy the Dutch venture-capital company Alpinvest Holding for 745 million euros ($769 million) as it builds up its European activities. The shares of Alpinvest, based in Naarden, soared after GIMV said it would pay 20.87 euros a share. GIMV is expanding its investment portfolio to reduce its dependence on the Belgian economy. About 16 percent of the Antwerp-based company's book value is invested outside Belgium, and it aims to bring that up to 25 percent in the coming years.

title: Starting With a Bang, And a Point
description: The pianist Mitsuko Uchida purposely played the works by Chopin, Webern and Mozart that formed the first half of her recital at Carnegie Hall on Monday night in the opposite order from what convention would have dictated. The ordering was musically fascinating and just one indicator of the intelligence this fine pianist has always brought to her work.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Defiant Muslims Begin Building Nazareth Mosque
description: Thousands of jubilant Muslims chanted prayers to Allah, threw fists into the air and set off firecrackers today as they defiantly laid the marble cornerstone of a mosque in the shadow of the Basilica of the Annunciation.

title: The Economy Doesn't Need the Third Way
description: At his meeting with other progressive political leaders in Florence, Italy, President Clinton said some things that were admirable -- he called for debt relief for poor nations and ratification of the Child Labor Convention -- and a few others that sounded a little far-fetched, as when he celebrated the ''little genomic maps'' that he said would soon be sent home with new babies.

title: CLINTON IS STYMIED ON TRADE MEETING
description: Presi dent Clinton has quietly tried and failed -- to persuade leaders of major countries to attend a huge trade conference in Seattle next week in order to break political deadlocks over workers' rights, agricultural subsidies and America's self-proclaimed authority to block low-cost imports.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, ANNA
description: ROSNER-Anna. The Officers, Trustees, Clergy and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Geoffrey J. Colvin, Ch. of the Bd. Paul S. Schreiber, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GONZALEZ, LOUIS, JR. (CLYDE CORDEY)
description: GONZALEZ-Louis, Jr. (Clyde Cordey). On November 21, 1999 at age 62. Survived by his life partner Patrick Lannon, sisters Gloria Gonzalez and Sally Marfisi, beloved niece Jeanine Pagan, and his family of friends, who will miss him dearly.

title: LYCOS IN AGREEMENT TO BUY INTERNET GAMES COMPANY
description: Lycos Inc., an Internet portal company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Gamesville.com, a Boston-based Internet games company, for $207 million in stock. Gamesville.com's Web site specializes in ''massively multiplayer'' real-time games including Bingo Zone, Quick-Draw Poker and PopQuiz. The company says that its Web site has 2.2 million registered users, and that the total is growing by 10,000 a day. Lycos, based in Waltham, Mass., said it plans to integrate Gamesville into its network of sites, increasing its reach to 47 percent of the monthly Web audience from 45.8 percent currently.Lycos's World Wide Web network includes the Tripod, HotBot, Angelfire and MailCity sites. The company's stock rose $3.75 yesterday, to $59.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Concerns Raised Over Encryption Report
description: As the Clinton administration began circulating its long-awaited plan yesterday for easing export controls on encryption technology, industry representatives and privacy groups said the proposal fell short of promises made by the White House two months ago.

title: Guilt and Giving
description: To the Editor:

title: Plaintiffs' Rift Disturbs Microsoft Judge
description: The trial judge for the Microsoft antitrust case said he appointed an outside mediator partly because of ''disturbing reports'' that the Justice Department and the 19 states suing the software maker were split on the issue of what sanctions to seek against the company.

title: Sports of The Times; Now Fassel Must Ease The Reins
description: IT was early in the second quarter Sunday and the Giants safety Percy Ellsworth was returning an intercepted pass. His teammate, the 305-pound tackle Keith Hamilton, peeled back, lining up the Washington Redskins' Mike Sellers for a block delivered with such force Sellers was soon airborne.

title: Equipment Error Cuts Phone Service in New Jersey
description: A Bell Atlantic equipment failure cut regular and emergency telephone service to tens of thousands of New Jersey customers yesterday, and company officials were unable to say when service would be fully restored. After the disruption started, 20 communities were switched to a backup system for 911 service.

title: On the Eve of the Feast
description: HERE are some common questions about Thanksgiving dinner and a few last-minute tricks to get the cook through the day.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Landmark House Becomes an 18th-Century-Furniture Gallery
description: The two-story brick house at 311 East 58th Street, just 50 feet west of an approach to the Queensboro Bridge, is a true antique. A New York City landmark, the house, nestled as if in a time warp amid the neighboring high-rises, was built in the 1850's and is considered a splendid example of the simple dwellings that once dotted Midtown. So it seems appropriate that the house, a private residence for more than 140 years, is soon to be converted to a gallery selling antique furniture.

title: Flavio da Costa, 93, Brazil's Soccer Coach in 1950's
description: Flavio Rodriguez da Costa, the Brazilian soccer coach whose 23-year professional career was overshadowed by his national team's loss to underdog Uruguay in the 1950 World Cup final, died on Monday at a hospital in Rio de Janeiro. He was 93.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COYLE, ANN
description: COYLE-Ann. Of the Bronx. Died Tuesday, November 23, 1999. Beloved daughter of the late Sarah & James Coyle. Dear sister of the late Mary, Sarah, James & Martin. Mass Friday, November 26, 9AM, Providence Rest Chapel, 3304 Waterbury Ave, Bronx, NY. Interment to follow 10:30AM, St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, Queens.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GARRETSON, MATILDA BLOOM
description: GARRETSON-Matilda Bloom. Remembered with love.

title: Mannesmann Shores Up Its Defenses
description: Mannesmann stepped up its defense against Vodafone AirTouch today, accelerating a plan to spin off its older industrial holdings and securing the support of its biggest shareholder.

title: Stony Brook's Welcome Is a Bit Overwhelming
description: Hundreds of Stony Brook alumni gathered around Nick Macarchuk in a reception room tonight before Stony Brook played its first home game as a Division I team, against St. John's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEUMAN, ELEANOR (BILSKY)
description: HEUMAN-Eleanor (Bilsky). Age 80. On November 23, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Loving mother of Harilyn, Ellen & Wendy. Caring mother-in-law of Ronny and Tom. Adored grandmother of Spencer, Drew, Katie and Adam. Funeral service Wednesday, November 24, 10:45AM, ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Drag Queen Rescues a Disabled Cop
description: Joel Schumacher's garish, message-laden comedy, ''Flawless,'' is so awful it just might put an end to Hollywood's hypocritical infatuation with men in drag as symbols of its own supposedly liberated sexual attitudes. If so, that would be an unintended benefit.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Immediate Takeover Of I.B.F. Is Denied
description: A federal judge today turned down a request by federal prosecutors to remove control of the International Boxing Federation from its indicted leaders immediately, but he said he would hear additional arguments in the case on Monday.

title: Stores at the Mall Try To Reclaim Christmas; Retailers Face E-Commerce Challenge
description: As Internet retailers crow that the country is about to have another e-Christmas, brick-and-mortar stores are striking back.

title: Failures of Peace in Kosovo
description: President Clinton went to Kosovo yesterday primarily to pay a pre-Thanksgiving call on American troops and encourage ethnic reconciliation. His pleas for forgiveness toward the Serbs drew a predictably chilly reception. But his visit will be valuable if it draws broader attention to the serious problems bedeviling international rebuilding efforts in Kosovo. Last spring NATO used its military power to uphold humanitarian principle and allow hundreds of thousands of brutally uprooted ethnic Albanians to return to their homes. That precious victory must not now be allowed to degenerate into an unstable, unworkable peace.

title: Treasury Prices Hold Steady As Inflation Concerns Grow
description: Reacting to investor fears that the economy will continue to race and that the Federal Reserve will be forced to respond by raising short-term interest rates again, bond prices fell slightly yesterday, leaving yields at their highest level in a month.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article in some editions on Sunday about the ATP Tour's year-end championship misidentified the tennis organization that Philippe Chatrier served as president in 1990, when the championship began. It was the International Tennis Federation, not the Association of Tennis Professionals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIMSATT, MARGARET ELIZABETH HECHT
description: WIMSATT-Margaret Elizabeth Hecht died November 22, 1999. She was born in Chicago, IL, February 26, 1919, to the late Frank Abner and Margaret Lipps Hecht. She is survived by her son, James Velvet Wimsatt, and her daughter-in-law, Nancy Lee Abbey, of Hamden, CT. She was predeceased by her son, Alexander Wimsatt, a student, and her husband, William Kurtz Wimsatt Jr., Sterling Professor of English at Yale University. She was a graduate of the University of Chicago and Yale. She was a poet, reviewer, essayist and a teacher of English composition at the University of New Mexico and Yale. She was a resident of New Haven, CT. from 1941-1997. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be sent to the South Central CT Chapter of the Alzheimer's Association, 2911 Dixwell Avenue, Hamden, CT. 06518. For information: The Hawley Lincoln Memorial, 493 Whitney Avenue, New Haven, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, RAYMOND LEE
description: KAUFMAN-Raymond Lee. Loving father and grandfather, passed away on November 22, 1999 in Santa Monica, CA. He was 70 years old. He will be remembered for his style, compassion and sparkling humor. Ray is survived by his daughter Ilene and husband David and grandson Gabriel, son John, daughter Nancy and son-inlaw Jeffrey, brother Lewis, sister Carol, and brother-in-law Bob, and the many cousins who loved him. Services will be held Wednesday, November 24, 11 AM, at Hillside Memorial Park, Los Angeles, CA. Contributions may be made to the Cedar-Sinai Medical Center, Parkinson's Research.

title: INSIDE
description: Israeli Mosque Conflict

title: Russia to Cut Its Military Forces in Georgia
description: In a move that will blunt Russia's influence in the Caucasus, Russia has agreed to slash its military forces in Georgia.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about Iraq's move to cut off the oil it is allowed to export in exchange for food and other basic supplies misstated the reason United Nations sanctions were imposed on Iraq. They were imposed, in 1990, because of Iraq's invasion and occupation of Kuwait. The reason was not the Iraqi government's failure to demonstrate that it has eliminated production of weapons of mass destruction; that is a reason they have not been lifted.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Intentions
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton did the smart thing, and not a moment too soon. ''The answer is yes,'' she said at a campaign appearance yesterday. ''I intend to run.'' Actually she should probably have avoided the word ''intend,'' since her spinners had to explain that the word was not meant as an escape hatch from her expected Senate race against New York City's mayor, Rudolph Giuliani. But the main message got through. After a series of gaffes, the first lady is committed, at least unofficially, to running in one of the nation's most unforgiving political environments for a rookie candidate. The early reviews have been rough because both friends and enemies expected, probably unrealistically, for her to be as effective in the spotlight as she was behind the scenes.

title: Political Briefing; Twin Cities Churches Take On the Governor
description: Remember when Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota declared a couple of months back that religion was nothing but a ''crutch for weak-minded people''?

title: Justice for Juveniles
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Schools Seek to Stick to Their Own Standards
description: At Nightingale-Bamford, a private school for girls on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, the chemistry labs rival those of a small college -- well equipped and spanking new. The school's computer classes have as many terminals as students; its auditorium would put many Off Broadway theaters to shame.

title: Metro Business; New York Dispute Ends for 2 Railroads
description: CSX Transportation Inc. and Canadian Pacific Railway Company, two of North America's largest railroads, ended a dispute over the services Canadian Pacific can sell to rail customers in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, NETTIE (NEE FISHKIND)
description: ROSEN-Nettie (nee Fishkind). Of Fort Lee, NJ, beloved wife of the late Sol Glick and the late Paul Rosen, devoted mother of the late Ira Glick. Services today 11 AM, Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, N.J.

title: Business Travel; Those traveling during the Thanksgiving holiday period had better brace for some heavy crowds.
description: WHEN both the AAA and the Air Transport Association predict a record number of travelers over the Thanksgiving holiday, you can pretty well count on crowded highways and skyways. AAA (formerly the American Automobile Association) is predicting a record 28 million vehicles on the roads during the holiday period, while the transport association is predicting almost 20 million airline passengers between last Friday and next Monday.

title: For Beaujolais Nouveau's Just the Start
description: The Beaujolais nouveau has arrived, but did anyone notice?

title: Shea Plans Turnaround With Time Running Out
description: Terry Shea gathered a contingent of news media at Rutgers to close out the dismal 1999 season, and before he could be asked how he would improve his 1-10 team's fortunes, Shea submitted his own plans.

title: Kings Prove Dazzling, And More, Against Nets
description: There would be no therapeutic victory to restore the Nets to wholeness, no strong, unified performance to serve as a balm for a team as sore as a fresh wound. The cross-country plane ride and public airing of their locker-room grievances did nothing to heal what ails the Nets. They left Sacramento as they entered it tonight: wounded, fractured and with one victory to their name.

title: STRONGER BOMBARDIER EARNINGS
description: Increased demand for medium-size aircraft contributed to a 33 percent gain in third-quarter earnings at Bombardier Inc., a Montreal-based aerospace company. Bombardier, which also makes passenger trains and recreational vehicles, earned 167 million Canadian dollars, or $113.6 billion, on a 21 percent increase in revenue to 3.2 billion dollars, or $2.2 billion. Bombardier said its order backlog as of Oct. 31 totaled 26.7 billion dollars, or $18.2 billion, 25 percent more than a year earlier. Timothy Pritchard

title: The Chef
description: AS a kid, I always loved my mother's pineapple upside-down cake. But as a chef, I knew it needed a drastic makeover to take it into the next century. Losing the maraschino cherry was a no-brainer. Getting rid of the cake's clunkiness was trickier.

title: Van Horn Is Looking to Find His Range
description: It is not a good sign when an All-Star-caliber forward is encouraged by 44 percent shooting. Instead, it's a case of lowered expectations and drooping confidence. When Keith Van Horn, the Nets' talented power forward, speaks favorably of his play over the three games before tonight's game, in which he averaged 22 points and 11.7 rebounds but made only 21 of 47 shots (44.7 percent), it is time for concern.

title: Nike to Sell Custom-Design Shoes on Web
description: Nike Inc., the world's largest athletic shoemaker, said this week that it would sell custom-designed men's and women's shoes to American customers over the Internet.

title: When to Hold, When to Fold (a k a Retire)
description: Seven days a week, for 9 or 10 hours each day, Merritt W. Huntington is on the job, negotiating deals and supervising a small staff. But he is no striving young investment banker or 20-something consultant on the make. He is a 73-year-old orchid grower.

title: Out in the Cold?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Mets or Mariners? Olerud Is Still Deciding
description: General Manager Steve Phillips of the Mets said yesterday that he does not expect progress to be made on talks with first baseman John Olerud this week, when the baseball world slows to a crawl during the extended Thanksgiving weekend. Although Phillips would not confirm it, it is believed that the Mets are either close to making an offer or have already made one and that the Mariners -- the other leading contender for Olerud -- are also close to making an offer, if they haven't done so already.

title: Gore Condemns Attack
description: Vice President Al Gore today accused Bill Bradley of leveling an improper personal attack in criticizing his fund-raising practices in the 1996 campaign.

title: Gladys Yang Is Dead at 80; Translated Chinese Classics
description: Gladys Yang, a British translator who spent most of her life in China, translating and promoting Chinese literature for foreign readers, died Thursday in Beijing, the official New China News Agency reported. She was 80.

title: Holiday Tomorrow; Thanksgiving
description: NEW YORK

title: COLE TO CLOSE OPTICAL DEPARTMENTS IN WARD STORES
description: The Cole National Corporation, a retailer of eyeglasses and lenses, said yesterday that it would close its 150 optical departments in Montgomery Ward stores to focus on businesses like Pearle Vision and Sears Optical stores. Cole said it would take a fourth-quarter pretax charge of $2 million to $2.5 million for the Wards closings. Cole, which had sales of $1.07 billion last year, operates optical departments for big retailers and stores under the Pearle name. The company warned that expenses would rise for initiatives, including franchisee support and advertising for the Pearle chain, before sales improved significantly. It also said fourth-quarter earnings might be hurt by manufacturing and distribution problems for a new system at Pearle stores.

title: Rear Adm. Walter C. Ford, 95, Destroyer Commander in Combat
description: Rear Adm. Walter Chilcott Ford, a destroyer commander in World War II and the executive director of the newborn Central Intelligence Agency in the later 1940's, died on Saturday at the Mariner Health facility in Bethesda, Md. He lived in Annapolis and would have turned 96 this week.

title: Giants' West Suspended
description: Lyle West, the Giants' sixth-round draft choice this year out of San Jose State who plays almost exclusively on special teams, was suspended for four games yesterday for violating the National Football League's policy on anabolic steroids and related substances.

title: Corruption Is the No. 1 Contender
description: So the federal government has discovered that boxing is corrupt and is set to appoint a former United States attorney to monitor the International Boxing Federation. O.K., new Mr. Boxing Czar, who should be the No. 4 ranked flyweight: Jose Bonilla of Venezuela or Chatchai Dutchboygym of Thailand? No fair peeking at Fight Game magazine, either.

title: Y2Kings Are a Team For the Millennium
description: Fresh off his ''Good Old Boys'' commercial with Randy Moss for Nike, Jason Williams recently filmed a spot for the National Basketball Association. With the voice of the Sacramento Kings point guard narrating highlights of Bob Cousy, Pete Maravich and Magic Johnson, he looks into the camera and proclaims, ''It's our turn now.''

title: German Bishops to Halt Abortion Certificates
description: Germany's Roman Catholic bishops bowed today to insistent demands from Pope John Paul II that they stop issuing certificates that open the way for women to have abortions.

title: Far From Gettysburg, A Heartland Torn Apart
description: As intensively as Hollywood has strip-mined the Civil War in search of box-office gold, that anguished era has never looked or sounded in a movie quite the way it does in Ang Lee's chilly epic, ''Ride With the Devil.'' This visually arresting but dramatically flat portrait of a group of pro-Southern bushwhackers waging guerrilla war against Union forces and sympathizers in the fields, farms and backwoods roads along the Kansas-Missouri border veers about as far from the high-romantic flourishes of ''Gone With the Wind'' as a movie can go.

title: U.N. Officials Say Iraq Is Completing the Shutdown of Oil Exports
description: Iraq continued to close down its oil export operations today by loading the last tanker waiting at the Persian Gulf port of Mina al-Bakr, United Nations officials said. Experts said the loading would be completed overnight tonight.

title: Like Her Dad, She Knows Her Beethoven
description: It has been heartening to watch Pamela Frank develop as a violinist. When she played her New York debut recital in 1990, she was 22 and just completing her studies at the Curtis Institute in Philadelphia. But she had already been awarded an Avery Fisher Career Grant -- this year she won the more prestigious Avery Fisher Prize -- and her performances were mature, graceful and technically firm. Since then she has been heard regularly as a recitalist, concerto soloist and chamber music player and has made a handful of recordings. And in that time her sound has grown more kaleidoscopic and her interpretations have become richer in character.

title: Satan Is Planning Millennial Mischief
description: In ''End of Days,'' Arnold Schwarzenegger assumes the cruciform position in a church as he modestly tackles the role of Jericho Cane, someone who could keep mankind free of Satan for the next thousand years. ''This is as pro-religious a movie as you can make,'' the film's director, Peter Hyams, recently told Variety. ''This is about the biggest action star of the past 20 years putting the gun down and saying the only thing that works is faith.'' What that statement overlooks is that it takes two ridiculous blood-soaked hours for Mr. Schwarzenegger to part company with his weapon.

title: Plenty of Fat to Trim, State Tells Jersey City
description: Two months after Mayor Bret Schundler threatened to lay off most of his civilian employees unless he got an extra $27.5 million in aid, the state responded yesterday by offering $16 million in aid and recommending $6.5 million in cuts.

title: America Online Deal With Intuit
description: America Online Inc., the top Internet service provider, and Intuit Inc., the maker of the popular Quicken financial software, said yesterday that they would provide an online bill-paying service to AOL's more than 19 million subscribers.

title: Metropolitan Life Sets Plan for Issuing Stock to Policyholders
description: Metropolitan Life, one of the nation's largest life insurers, intends to file a formal plan with New York State regulators today for a reorganization in which it will issue shares next spring. The stock would instantly become the most widely held in the United States.

title: Calendar
description: Calling all Chocaholics

title: Pear Cider to Make Charlemagne Blush
description: SPARKLING apple cider is ubiquitous, but now there's poire. Uncork a bottle of this French import, and you can fill glasses with a golden, gently sparkling cider infused with the delicately musky aroma of pears. Its subdued ripeness is balanced by a refreshing tartness.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARTER, DAVID
description: CARTER-David. My beloved father, six years in heaven, joined this August by my cherished mother Pauline. Each year the memories grow fonder and my love deepens. The photos and videotapes help bridge the gap, but nothing can fill the void of not having either of you to call up and schmooze with. So pardon me for not knowing which way to face when I address the heavens in search of your love and advice. Unending love & devotion, Donny.

title: Conservatism's Failures
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Killed and 2 Hurt in Crash Of Helicopter on Long Island
description: Two people were killed and two men were critically injured last night when an Army National Guard helicopter crashed as it tried to land in the fog at Long Island-MacArthur Airport in Suffolk County, the authorities said.

title: The Chestnut Comes Out of Its Shell
description: CHESTNUTS are challenging. Unlike walnuts, pecans and hazelnuts, these big, meaty nuts have to be wrestled into submission. Each one has to be scored with a sharp paring knife, roasted until the skin loosens and then painstakingly peeled. It's no wonder they look most appealing on a street vendor's cart, warm and ready to eat.

title: For Daigle, One Game Has to Be Just the Start
description: No one questions whether Alexandre Daigle has any skills left. Almost everyone in hockey questions his passion for the game. Daigle therefore has plenty to prove here on Wednesday night when the Rangers face the Lightning.

title: Construction Worker Dies in Brooklyn Building Collapse
description: A building under construction in Brooklyn collapsed yesterday, plunging a dozen immigrant workers down four stories in a cascade of wet concrete, killing one and badly injuring the others.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  IGNATOW, ARCHIE
description: IGNATOW-Archie. We think of you always and miss you so much. Remembered with love. Gene, children and grandchildre

title: Vallone Seeks to Ease Rules On Gatherings at City Hall
description: The City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, introduced legislation yesterday to ease Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's restrictions on access to the steps of City Hall for news conferences and demonstrations.

title: Goldman, Sachs Discussing Electronic Options Market
description: The Chicago Stock Exchange and Goldman, Sachs & Company said today that they were in talks to form an electronic options market that would compete with the four major stock options exchanges.

title: The Knicks' Comeback Falls Short by a 3-Pointer
description: The Knicks hauled their frontline of spare parts onto the showroom floor of the Staples Center tonight and were faced with the forgotten team off the back lot of Hollywood, the Clippers.

title: John B. Brooks, Jazz Arranger, Composer and Songwriter, 82
description: John Benson Brooks, a jazz composer, arranger and songwriter, died on Nov. 13 at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: Charges of Shoddy Practices Taint Gifts of Plastic Surgery
description: For most of its 17 years, Operation Smile seemed to be a model charity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, SEYMOUR ''CY''
description: KAPLAN-Seymour ''Cy'', 79, television syndication executive, on Oct. 23, 1999. He is survived by his daughter Jane (Matt) and grandchildren Jonathan and Emily.

title: Foreign Investors Win Court Order in Russian Oil Case
description: A prominent foreign investment group won a Siberian court order today to temporarily halt the sale of one of Russia's largest oil producers. It was the latest maneuver in a struggle widely viewed as a test of Russia's respect for the rights of foreign investors.

title: Needle Use Sets Off H.I.V. Explosion in Russia
description: Needle sharing among intravenous drug users has set off an explosive increase in H.I.V. infections, with the number of new cases reported in Moscow so far this year more than four times greater than in all of 1998, the World Health Organization said today.

title: A Dutiful Son's Errand in the Big Easy
description: PELIKAN

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Central Intelligence Agency documents from the end of the cold war misstated the month when the Soviet Union formally dissolved. It was December 1991, not August.

title: Text and Music Evoking Emotions, Spiritual and Mundane
description: One hardly wants to disparage the orchestral, chamber and recital components of Lincoln Center's Great Performers schedule, but over the last 10 years it has been the vocal component of the series that has yielded the most consistently memorable performances, or in more immediate terms, the ones that linger in a listener's ears and thoughts long after the final bow.

title: ASIAN BANK PACT
description: The central banks of Malaysia and China agreed to let each other's banks set up branches in their countries, in a move that will partly liberalize their financial services industries. The pact was signed after China's premier, Zhu Rongji, met the Malaysian prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, in Kuala Lumpur. It will pave the way for the Bank of China to open a branch in Malaysia. Malaysia's banks will be allowed to convert their representative offices in China into full-fledged branches. The pact comes after years of talks between the two nations to set up financial institutions in each other's territories.

title: Rapes of 8 Schoolgirls Puts Detroit on Edge
description: Crime has been walking children to and from school here, and this city is enlisting an army of volunteers to fight back.

title: Gore to Meet Kazakh Leader After MIG Case
description: Vice President Al Gore plans to meet with the leader of Kazakhstan next month, despite that country's sale of Soviet-built weapons to North Korea, administration officials said this week.

title: Two Major Bridge Titles Won in Boston
description: World-class players won two major titles here on Monday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall National Championships.

title: Political Briefing; Ballot for Open Seat Has One Empty Slot
description: And what of the coming election in the 15th Congressional District now that Representative Campbell is leaving?

title: Gene Levitt, 79, a TV Writer; Created 70's Hit 'Fantasy Island'
description: Gene Levitt, a television writer, director and producer who created ''Fantasy Island,'' a popular show in the late 1970's, died on Nov. 15 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 79.

title: VENEZUELA CHANGES PLAN
description: Venezuela abandoned a plan to invest $200 million to expand production at the idled Cienfuegos oil refinery in Cuba, citing high costs. Venezuela will instead seek a venture with Cuba's state oil company, Cupel, to bring Cienfuegos back on line, refining 70,000 barrels a day. The country plans to pump its own crude to Cuba and sidestep a United States trade embargo against Cuba, which has had oil shortages since the early 1990's, an official said.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE FALLS. Coffee fell more than 2 percent on expectations that more rain in Brazil will stem drought damage to the world's biggest crop. In New York, coffee for March delivery fell 2.65 cents, or 2.3 percent, to $1.1205 a pound.

title: The Surface Seems Chilly, But It Is Definitely Love
description: ''Last Train to Nibroc'' was first presented at the 78th Street Theater Lab in Manhattan last winter. Here are excerpts from D. J. R. Bruckner's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 5. The play opened on Sunday at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater, 432 West 42nd Street, Clinton.

title: The Pastry Chef's Rich Little Secret
description: IT'S a simple almond cake, leavened by egg whites, moistened with browned butter and baked into a small mold. But such simplicity is deceiving: the classic French pastry called the financier is exquisitely refined. It is springy, sweet and nutty with an exterior that's as crisp as an eggshell.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Case of a Texas Firm Raises Questions About Regulation
description: WHAT happens when a brokerage firm's auditor discovers that some of the firm's assets have been used to support another company and that as a result the firm has run out of capital? At a brokerage firm in Texas, the alarm bells sounded. The company quickly came up with additional capital and the National Association of Securities Dealers began an investigation. The firm's chief financial officer was fined and suspended from her job for 10 days.

title: Texas Tragedy And College Rites
description: To the Editor:

title: CLINTON, SALUTING KOSOVO ALBANIANS, URGES FORGIVENESS
description: They waved tiny American flags, they chanted his name in an excited frenzy, they met his every word with thunderous applause -- at least until President Clinton urged the Kosovo Albanians to try to forgive the Serbs. Then they fell silent.

title: Plan for Tobacco Fund
description: To the Editor:

title: Revisionism on Kosovo?
description: To the Editor:

title: Tracking Stocks Show Signs Of Respectability at Age 15
description: Once dismissed as gimmickry, tracking stocks have become an almost thoroughly mainstream way for big companies to highlight the performance of their far-flung units.

title: Medicare Cuts Jolt New York Hospitals That Train Doctors
description: Teaching hospitals in New York said today that they would lose tens of millions of dollars in federal Medicare money under a budget bill that was passed by Congress last week and is soon to be signed by President Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLUTZKY, RHODA (NEE WEGENSTEIN)
description: SLUTZKY-Rhoda (nee Wegenstein), age 93, of Brooklyn. Beloved wife of 71 years to Samuel. Loving mother of Michael & Carol Slutzky. Devoted grandmother to Steven and Jill, Mark & Debbie, Debra and Ian Hendler, and Stuart and Susan. She loved & was loved by friends and family and will truly be missed. Funeral service to be held at 11 AM, on Wednesday, November 24, at the John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 1st Avenue at 70th Street.

title: Bishops and Universities
description: To the Editor:

title: National News Briefs; Maker of Zinc Lozenge Agrees to Drop Claims
description: The maker of popular over-the-counter zinc lozenges and a national home shopping network have agreed to stop making claims that the lozenges can prevent colds and alleviate allergy symptoms, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: Olympic-Caliber Performance
description: For the last three weeks ABC's game show ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' has so dominated television that competitors have taken to writing off this month as an aberration, something unlike anything they have ever seen before.

title: Holzmann of Germany Seeks Court Help to Save Company
description: Philipp Holzmann A.G. asked a Frankfurt court today to help run its business after Deutsche Bank and other creditors failed for a third time to agree on a rescue plan to keep the 150-year-old builder going.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STIRTON, DR. THOMAS, III.
description: STIRTON-Dr. Thomas, III. Of Staten Island, on November 22, 1999. Beloved husband of Dolores. Loving father of Carol Anne StirtonBroad, Catherine and Thomas Stirton IV. Dear brother of Virginia Wadleigh. Cherised grandfather of Thomas Stirton, V. Funeral Service Harmon Home for Funerals, 571 Forest Ave., Staten Island, NY Saturday 10:30am. Interment Moravian Cemetery. Friends will be received Friday 2-4 & 7-9pm.

title: AMCOL SELLING ABSORBENT PLASTICS BUSINESS TO BASF
description: The Amcol International Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its absorbent plastics unit to the German chemical giant BASF for about $657 million in cash. The business being sold, called Chemdal, makes water-absorbing polymers used in disposable diapers and other personal-care items. With the sale of the Chemdal business, which accounts for 42 percent of its total sales, Amcol will focus on its specialty minerals business. Shareholders of Amcol, which is based in Arlington Heights, Ill., will get a cash payment of about $14 to $14.50 a share from the sale. Amcol shares rose 27 percent, gaining $3.75 each, to $17.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: An Unconventional Spot in the East Village? How Strange
description: PRUNE is the name. Has a nice ring to it, no?

title: AT&T Considers Breaking Out Cellular Business as New Stock
description: Top executives at AT&T are planning to create a separately traded tracking stock for the company's fast-growing cellular unit and to invest billions to deliver high-speed Internet access and local phone service to millions of American homes using wireless technology.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: An Extra Bank Fee
description: To the Editor:

title: LONDON SUBWAY CONTRACT
description: The company that operates London's subway system, London Underground Ltd., awarded a $1.94 billion contract to build a new communications network to Motorola Inc., Racal Electronics P.L.C. and the Fluor Corporation. The consortium, called CityLink Telecommunications Ltd., has pledged to invest $568 million to upgrade the telecommunication capabilities of the subway system, which is being overhauled, and maintain it for 20 years. The project is part of the British government's plan to partly privatize London's subway system.

title: When the Whistle-Blower Has to Make a Choice
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: SAINSBURY'S PROFIT DROPS
description: Britain's intense supermarket war began to show its effect as J. Sainsbury P.L.C., Britain's second-largest food retailer, said its first-half profit dropped 29 percent. J. Sainsbury has been trying to fight off competition from Asda Group, which Wal-Mart bought in June, and Tesco, Britain's largest food retailer. The supermarkets have been aggressively cutting their prices. Pretax profit after reorganization costs of 55 million [pounds] fell to 297 million [pounds] from 421 million [pounds] a year ago. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Definition of Abortion Is Found to Vary Abroad
description: The recipient of the largest amount of American birth control aid is Bangladesh, a Muslim country that languishes among the world's sickest, poorest and most populous. Despite a decision by Congress last week to limit federal spending on groups that promote abortion rights abroad, the way the United States' contribution is spent in Bangladesh depends much more on local laws and practices than on anything done half a world away on Capitol Hill.

title: Edible Gifts, a Click or a Call Away
description: WHAT started as a trickle of mail-order food sources on the Internet last year has turned into a torrent, making it difficult to sort out the delicious from the dreary.

title: And Now, a Balloon From Our Sponsor
description: Everyone who goes to the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade knows there is a price to be paid: getting up at dawn to grab a curb-side spot, getting squashed by hordes of out-of-towners, getting home too late to put the turkey in the oven.

title: The Betraying Handshake
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley used a vivid metaphor to describe Washington's continual failure to free American elections from the influence of special-interest money. Speaking in New Hampshire on Monday, he recalled the moment in 1995 when President Clinton and Newt Gingrich, then Speaker of the House, shook hands in public on a promise to pass campaign finance legislation. Nothing happened, Mr. Bradley said, because Democrats, Republicans and their big contributors had long ago made a ''secret handshake'' on ''a deal between politicians and business to keep things as usual.''

title: Tables Are Waiting On the Internet
description: A HIGH-STAKES movement is taking shape in the New York restaurant world.

title: Ex-Official Gets 2 Years In Parole Case
description: A former state parole commissioner was sentenced to two years in prison yesterday for lying to a federal grand jury investigating allegations that Gov. George E. Pataki's campaign aides promised early paroles in exchange for contributions.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO SLIDES. The dollar rose against the single European currency as traders exchanged euros for dollars and converted them into yen. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0273, down from $1.0314 on Monday.

title: New Law in Texas Preserves Racial Mix in State's Colleges
description: It was the demise of affirmative action that got Daniel Garza, the son of an immigrant construction worker, into one of the best public universities in the nation.

title: Quarterly Results Are Weak at Deere
description: Deere & Company, the maker of agricultural equipment, said today that its fourth-quarter operating profit fell 94 percent, stung by low crop prices that kept farmers from buying tractors and combines.

title: Vidin Journal; They'll Give the King Anything, Except a Crown
description: The former king of Bulgaria had prepared his speech and put his passport into his pocket. He was anxious not to give offense -- and so it was all the more painful to Simeon II that on a recent visit to the land of his birth he was more than five hours late.

title: Greenfield Opening An Internet Unit
description: The Greenfield Consulting Group in Westport, Conn., is starting Digital Idea, an Internet research consulting company.

title: Gore's Finance Record
description: To the Editor:

title: Earthquake Helped to Lower October Durable Goods Orders
description: Supply disruptions for computer and electronics makers after an earthquake in Taiwan led to a drop in orders for durable goods in October, government figures showed today. Demand for most other items increased.

title: Westchester Debates Proposal To Investigate Bias Against Gays
description: Hundreds of Westchester residents turned out today for a public hearing on a proposal to create a county human rights commission, a plan that has raised objections from some religious leaders because it would investigate complaints of discrimination against gays.

title: Sleeping With the Competition
description: I realized I would never marry my college boyfriend the day that he was chosen for a summer internship at The Washington Post and I wasn't. He did nothing so boorish as gloat; in fact, he barely dared to celebrate. But I ended things anyway. Perhaps I'm revealing more about my ego than is wise in a national publication, but I knew even then that I was too competitive to go through life with someone who did the same work as I.

title: Foreign Affairs; Lead or Get Out of The Way
description: Scene #1: A few days after the coup in Pakistan, the coup leader, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, held a news conference that surely was a historical first. The Pakistani general said he had had to mount the coup in order to pull Pakistan out of its morass of corruption, and to prove that he was up to this task the general offered to disclose his tax returns. Think about that. When in the history of coups has a general sought to win legitimacy by offering to disclose his tax returns? He didn't vow to retake Kashmir or to nuke New Delhi. He vowed to prove that he had played straight with the Pakistani I.R.S.

title: UBS EARNINGS RISE
description: One of the world's largest banks, UBS of Switzerland, earned $3.3 billion in the first nine months of the year, nearly double the results of a year earlier, when UBS was hurt by its exposure to the problems of Long-Term Capital Management, a United States investment fund. The bank's earnings also were helped this year by its investment banking unit, Warburg Dillon Read, which earned $1.34 billion, compared with a loss of $794 million in the first nine months of 1998. Elizabeth Olson

title: On the Danube, A Quiet Revolution
description: BACK in the early 1980's, I made a trip to Vienna to cover a conference on arms control. I've forgotten the conference, but I do remember ''The Marriage of Figaro'' one night at the Staatsoper. I remember, too, how the aroma of chocolate filled the Sacher Hotel each morning, from all those Sacher tortes baking downstairs.

title: Political Briefing; Don't Stop the Train; He's Not Getting Off
description: It has been three weeks, and still the folks in Mississippi don't know who will be their next governor.

title: Orchestra Strike Forces City Ballet to Cancel Opening
description: The New York City Ballet canceled the opening-night performance of its fall season at the New York State Theater last night when its 70-member orchestra went on strike.

title: The A.T.M. Fees We Should Be Thankful For
description: The cities of San Francisco and Santa Monica, Calif., have banned the surcharges that banks apply when noncustomers use their automated teller machines. Similar bans are under consideration in other cities, including New York. But even though the laws are coming in response to consumer complaints, consumers -- along with small banks -- are likely to be hurt by them.

title: London Awards Are Announced
description: Five agencies have taken top honors at the 14th annual London International Advertising Awards ceremony.

title: White Teenagers Charged in Killing That Is Called Racial
description: Two white teenagers were charged with murder today in what prosecutors say was the racially motivated random shooting of a black teenager.

title: New Agency Hired For Kia Account
description: Kia Motors America in Irvine, Calif., said yesterday that it had awarded its account to David & Goliath, a new agency in Los Angeles. Billings were estimated at $75 million to $80 million. Goldberg Moser O'Neill in San Francisco, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, handled the account for more than six years before being dismissed last week.

title: Nassau Republicans Consider Hurried Repeal of Tax on Land Sales
description: In a move that threatens to undermine their own plan to repair Nassau County's battered budget, Republican lawmakers are considering an 11th-hour repeal of the unpopular real estate transfer tax they enacted this summer to help close Nassau County's yawning deficit, officials here said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARRIAN, MURRAY
description: ARRIAN-Murray. Died November 21, 1999 in West Palm Beach, Fla. at age 78. Formerly of NYC. Beloved husband of Claire for 56 years, devoted father of Barbara and Shelley and father-in-law to Mark Gelblat and Howard Fleit. Adoring grandfather to Dana and Kenneth Burton, Halayne Gelblat, Rachel and David Fleit, uncle to Regina Hazen. Wonderful friend to many. His smile will be greatly missed. He will be remembered as a kind and gentle man.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BALCOFF, FANNY
description: BALCOFF-Fanny. Grandma Fanny: Your good and gracious deeds, your caring and giving will be remembered, Always. The special meaning of your life remains inscribed forever in our hearts and minds, and lives on within us. Remembering you today and every day. Bill, Robin and Sarah Faye Pollack

title: A Reincarnated Dove, Smaller but Genuine
description: SOME old restaurants fade away. Others disappear in a flash. Sign of the Dove, for years one of Manhattan's most beloved dining spots, left in a cloud of dust last year, pulverized by the wrecking ball to make way for a high-rise. The hole it left in the landscape was more than physical.

title: On the Fast Track, Those in Charge Must Change
description: You're dialing the phone when your controller sticks his head in the door and asks if you have a minute. Do you hang up and ask him what the problem is?

title: Police Officer Injured on Duty in the Bronx
description: An undercover police officer who was shot at on a Bronx street last night suffered minor injuries, the police said.

title: Accounts
description: Vstream, Boulder, Colo., a Web-based business communications company, to the Greco Ethridge Group, Boston, to handle its first account. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Ferguson Suspended 4 Games for Steroids
description: Just when the Jets' defense appeared to be getting healthy, the team lost nose tackle Jason Ferguson for four games today when he was suspended by the National Football League for testing positive for steroids.

title: Editor Explores Unintended, and Negative, Side of Technology
description: STEPHEN L. TALBOTT, a former software programmer and technical writer, has always been wary of computers and their effect on the human psyche. Even as he made a living editing books on computer programming, he wondered aloud whether the machines were making people's lives worse, not better.

title: 4 at Junior High Charged In Sexual Abuse of Girls
description: Four boys, ages 11 and 12, have been arrested on sexual abuse charges after two 12-year-old girls at a Brooklyn junior high school accused them of sexual attacks, the authorities said.

title: Whitney Biennial May Include Digital Artworks
description: In what may come to be viewed as a milestone for digital artists, the Whitney Museum of American Art is preparing to include Internet-based artworks in its biennial survey of American art next spring, say to artists and others familiar with plans for the exhibit.

title: Essay; G-8 Minus One
description: The Yeltsin ''family'' and its new K.G.B. front man, Vladimir Putin, came up with a plan to regain popularity in the coming elections: Use foreign funds to build up the army and -- under the pretext of anti-terrorism -- exterminate the militant Chechens.

title: DELAY IN DAEWOO RESTRUCTURING
description: Lee Hun Jai, chairman of South Korea's Financial Supervisory Commission, which is overseeing the restructuring of the Daewoo Group, said debt-workout plans for Daewoo affiliates due this week may not be completed for one or two weeks. Daewoo has been flirting with bankruptcy since July, and the government said earlier this month that its debts total at least $74 billion.

title: Reaching Out for Help, or to Help
description: WHEN Bonnie Frascatore was confined to bed for seven months during a high-risk pregnancy, the high point of each day came when she switched on her computer. Every day, she received e-mail from a woman who had experienced a pregnancy just as difficult.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about ''living wage'' ordinances, which raise pay for low-wage workers and grant them benefits, misstated the name of an organization involved in the movement. It is the Industrial Areas Foundation, not the Independent Areas Foundation.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COLUMBIA ENERGY GROUP, Herndon, Va. a natural gas company, said it would sell its energy-trading business to Enron Corp., Houston, the world's largest marketer of power and natural gas, for an undisclosed price.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Chinese immigrants who give massages in New York City parks and streets referred imprecisely to the original home of one immigrant, Jack Feng. It is Shenyang -- a city in Liaoning Province, not a province itself.

title: Why Doesn't Windows CE Get Any Respect?; When It Comes to Personal Organizers, Microsoft's Minisystem Does Not Rule the Market
description: YOU wouldn't expect to find a better spokesman for the Philips Nino than Blake Patterson. If you visit the Philips Electronics Web site, you see a prominent link to a site built by Mr. Patterson, a 27-year-old Web designer from Alexandria, Va. Philips points to Mr. Patterson as a dedicated user of the Nino, the company's palm-size computer. Predictably, Mr. Patterson's site is a veritable shrine to the Nino.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a front-page article about Operation Smile, the charity that performs reconstructive surgery in developing countries, suggested a reason erroneously for Charles B. Wang's decision to retract his pledge of $10 million. Mr. Wang, chief executive of Computer Associates, declined to comment to The Times on his reasons for diverting the money to another charity. There was no indication of a problem with accounting for the funds.

title: Bernard Klatzko, 73, Jazz Record Producer
description: Bernard Klatzko, a researcher, author and record producer specializing in acoustic blues and early jazz, died on Nov. 15 at North Shore Hospital in Glen Cove, N.Y. He was 73.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''In truth, there were times when I said to myself: 'I am going to watch this man die out here.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARMINGTON, NEWTON D., M.D.
description: WARMINGTON-Newton D., M.D.. The Administration, Faculty, Staff, & Students of the State University of New York Downstate Medical Center mourn the passing of Newton D. Warmington, M.D., Clinical Assistant Professor of Urology. Dr. Warmington was a 1989 graduate of the College of Medicine. We are profoundly saddened by his untimely passing & extend our deepest sympathies to his family, friends, and colleagues. John C. LaRosa, M.D., President Eugene B. Feigelson, M.D., Dean of the College of Medicine

title: Uncovered Short Sales Increase 1.4% on Nasdaq
description: Even as the Nasdaq composite index has climbed, the number of open positions of short sales on the market edged up 1.4 percent, the National Association of Securities Dealers, which operates the market, said yesterday.

title: The Big City; Bumper Crop Of Bedrooms And Closets
description: ''IT'S a real blessing,'' Kathryn Sanders said more than once as she conducted the tour of her new home. For 16 years, Ms. Sanders, a special-education teacher at a public school in Chelsea, had been living in a vintage Lower East Side tenement that looked nothing like this place.

title: Money Manager Promotes Four Executives
description: Franklin Resources Inc., the biggest publicly traded money management company by market value, said this week that it had promoted four executives to a new office of the president, paving the way for succession.

title: Dr. Dad Gives Thanks for Impossible Families
description: ON a Saturday morning here, there is only one possible place to be, at least for parents with children under 10. Dr. Edward M. Hallowell is at a soccer game. His son Jack, 7, is playing for the Maroon team; his wife, Sue Hallowell, is team manager. And because this is Cambridge, ground zero for self-conscious parenting, every soccer team has been taught to chant, ''One, two, three, four -- We don't care about the score!''

title: Judge in Seattle Bans Man From a Newsgroup
description: A county judge in Seattle has raised eyebrows among civil liberties groups by applying anti-harassment law to the realm of cyberspace. Last week, as part of a restraining order, the judge barred a man from posting messages to a public newsgroup.

title: Shot Grazes Officer After Bouncing Off Cell Phone
description: A plainclothes police officer who was shot at late Tuesday night during an undercover drug operation in the Bronx escaped serious injury when a bullet ricocheted off his cellular telephone and grazed his stomach, officials said yesterday.

title: Passion Is One More Casualty for the Knicks
description: A team that ended up being loathed by parts of middle America last season for its brazen arrogance and outlaw roster has emerged this season with an identity as indistinguishable as a blade of grass.

title: Czechs Remove a Wall Built to Isolate Gypsies
description: A wall put up six weeks ago to separate Gypsies from their Czech neighbors in a town in northern Bohemia was torn down today, to the relief of an embarrassed Czech government and foreigners who had suggested that racism might thwart the country's bid to join the European Union.

title: Fearless Vision Brings an Artist Home
description: WE grow accustomed to the Dark --/When Light is put away,'' wrote Emily Dickinson, one of John Dugdale's favorite poets.

title: Moving to the Top Of the Stocking; The Year's Hot Toy? Anything Pokemon
description: Adriana Reyneri and her two young sons, Jake and Luke, were exploring F.A.O. Schwarz in Manhattan yesterday when they stopped in front of a display for ''Toy Story 2,'' the sequel to the 1995 animated hit movie.

title: China Deal Adds a Sour Note to Gore's Sweet Labor Tune
description: The Clinton administration's trade agreement with China, hailed by President Clinton as one of his greatest foreign policy achievements, is complicating Vice President Al Gore's efforts to energize labor behind his presidential campaign.

title: WESTPOINT STEVENS HIRES MERRILL LYNCH AS AN ADVISER
description: WestPoint Stevens Inc., the largest United States maker of home furnishings like bedding and towels, said yesterday that it had hired Merrill Lynch & Company to advise it on options, including a sale or merger. The company said it had not received an offer and was not in any talks. WestPoint Stevens shares have lost about half of their value in the last six months. They are down 42 percent this year and have a market value of about $978 million. WestPoint Stevens also said it suspended an offer to buy back as many as three million, or 6 percent, of its shares. The buyback program began on Oct. 29 and was supposed to have ended on Tuesday, the company said.

title: Mary Bergman, Actress, 38; Did Voice-Overs On 'South Park'
description: Mary Kay Bergman, whose many voices were heard on ''South Park'' and in other animated television shows and films, died on Nov. 11 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 38.

title: Whirlwind of Facial Surgery By Foreigners Upsets China
description: ''I am the father of Patient 088, and I'd like to express my gratitude but also say I am very dissatisfied,'' Zhao Kang wrote in a letter to the Plastic Surgery Hospital in Beijing, in the shaky characters of a man with little education. Instead of fixing his son's disfiguring cleft lip, as he had wanted, surgeons fixed the son's cleft palate, which the father said had not affected his speech.

title: Safir Defends Effort to Clear City Streets At Night
description: As the police arrested more homeless people trying to sleep on city streets yesterday, Police Commissioner Howard Safir defended the Giuliani administration's effort against criticism from City Council members. Mr. Safir said the police would use all legal means to keep people from sleeping on the streets.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: EgyptAir Pilot, From Privileged Background to a Terrible Prominence
description: Back in Kafr al-Dabusi, a farming community set against the lush fields and irrigation canals of the Nile delta, the villagers still remember the dashing young airman who would circle in his small plane, scaring the pigeons from their roosts and sending the women trilling in wonder.

title: Act of Charity Reclaims a Life From the Streets
description: Vincent Jones cannot forget the first time he saw the homeless man, so skinny he was ''holding up his pants with one hand and holding onto the wall with the other.''

title: Awed by Computer Music
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STUPAK, MAX
