description: STUPAK-Max. West Side Jewish Center (34th St.) mourns the passing of our devoted life member Max Stupak, a dedicated, generous and cherished member and friend who will be missed beyond words. Our most heartfelt condolences to his beloved family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, DAVID
description: LEVINE-David. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, David Levine. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Betty, and their family. Morton West, President Daniel Amster, Secretary

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Quick Talker, Unlike Grandfather

title: Taking Care (Use Plastic) on Foreign Sites
description: HERE are a few things I know about the raw-milk camembert cheese that a French company called Fromages .com sells online. First, milk is ladled carefully into vats. Then it matures into creamy yellow rounds that get coddled, like newborns in a hospital nursery, until at the age of 21 days they reach the peak of taste.

title: Privacy Concerns
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rocket Is Reclaiming His Birthright
description: It was a joyous mood recently in the Dallas locker room because the Cowboys had once again toppled the rival Washington Redskins. It was also a regal room because Nelson Mandela, the South African social and political icon, and Prince Bandar of Saudi Arabia were in the Cowboys' midst.

title: Guard at Empire State Building Accused of Sexual Abuse of Boy
description: A security guard at the Empire State Building was arrested last night after a 14-year-old boy from Georgia told the authorities that the guard had sexually abused him in a stairwell, the police said.

title: How to Talk To a Computer
description: Q. Is speech recognition software another alternative to the mouse? How powerful a computer do you need for it?

title: U.S. Missile Shield Will Set Off a New Arms Race, China Warns
description: China's chief of arms control issued a new warning today that American plans for a national missile defense system, even if intended to stop attacks from countries like North Korea and Iraq, would set off a global arms race and cause more countries to develop nuclear weapons.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO SLIDES. The euro fell on doubts that the speed of euro-zone growth can lift the currency after a report showed United States growth outpacing Germany's. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0193, down from $1.0273.

title: An Offer for PennCorp
description: The National Bancshares Corporation of Texas and its subsidiary offered to buy the PennCorp Financial Group for $1 a share in cash yesterday -- 78 percent more than the insurer's shares were worth on Tuesday. The company made its offer in a letter to David Smith, the chairman of PennCorp, which is based in Dallas. National Bancshares and its NBT of Delaware unit already hold a 4.3 percent PennCorp stake. They would pay $27.9 million for the shares they do not own.

title: Novices Offer Up Dreams on Game Demos
description: EVERY year, a congregation of programmers, animators and designers assembles in San Jose, Calif., for the Game Developers Conference, a techie jamboree dedicated to the art and science of video games. In the spirit of innovation, last year the conference featured a festival for independently developed games, along the lines of Sundance or the South by Southwest conference in Austin, Tex. The winners are announced in March, but collecting and culling the entries takes the better part of a year.

title: Safety of Common AIDS Drug Questioned in South Africa
description: Stirring a furor among doctors and researchers who treat patients infected with the virus that causes AIDS, government officials here have been questioning the safety of the standard anti-AIDS drug AZT, saying they suspect it may be too dangerous to justify its use.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: ECONOMY PROVING IT'S MORE ROBUST THAN ANTICIPATED
description: The long-running expansion of the American economy rolled into autumn with even more momentum than had been thought, and is poised to set a record for longevity with the arrival of the year 2000.

title: First Ladies, Unbound
description: ''So the answer is yes.'' Thus Hillary Rodham Clinton committed herself to seeking the Senate seat in New York. The next question we should ask is: Should we continue to pay for her services as first lady?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about an agreement to build a pipeline across Turkey to carry oil from the Caspian Sea region included one country erroneously among the signers and omitted one. Along with the United States, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and Turkey, the list includes Georgia but not Turkmenistan.

title: Along the Road to Victory In an 'Unmakable' Contract
description: Victories by a woman in major team play are very rare indeed, but Rita Shugart of Pebble Beach, Calif., achieved her second within a year here Monday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall National Championships.

title: An Excite@Home Deal With Compaq
description: Excite@Home said today that consumers would be able to sign up for its @Home high-speed Internet service through the Compaq Computer Corporation, a maker of personal computers.

title: MEXICO-EUROPE TRADE DEAL
description: Mexico and the European Union finished negotiations on a free trade agreement, the broadest pact the European bloc has negotiated and its first with a Latin American nation. It ends barriers to 95 percent of the goods traded between the two and includes rules on intellectual property and dispute resolutions. Mexico agreed to cut tariffs on European industrial products to as little as 4 percent by 2003. President Ernesto Zedillo said the pact would ''provide new balance'' for Mexico, which sent 88 percent of its exports last year to the United States. The pact faces votes in the Mexican Senate and the European Parliament.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Nov. 10 about prospective remedies being sought by the plaintiffs in the Microsoft antitrust trial omitted a first name and title in some editions for the government official who said he thought Microsoft could live within the law without being broken up. He is Bill Lockyer, the attorney general of California.

title: Race and Gender in the Military
description: Harry Truman's 1948 executive order integrating the armed forces created a black management class and got blacks and whites to live and work together on relatively peaceful terms long before the society as a whole was ready to tackle this issue. The military is still well ahead of the private sector when it comes to incorporating women and minorities into management positions. But a pair of surveys released by the Pentagon this week revealed that, though progress continues, racial friction is still a pressing problem and prejudices based on race and gender remain a serious obstacle to full integration of the officer corps.

title: A Report Card on Drunken Driving
description: Thanksgiving weekend is a dangerous time to be on the road. Experts estimate that roughly half of all traffic fatalities in the next few days -- about 250 deaths and 13,000 injuries -- will be attributable to drunken drivers. That is a much higher death rate from drunken driving than for other weekends of the year. Still, the overall annual numbers for alcohol-related deaths have declined in recent years, because of grass-roots education efforts by groups like Mothers Against Drunk Driving and tougher laws against drunken driving in most parts of the nation. In 1998, alcohol-related driving deaths reached a record low of 15,935, down from about 28,000 in 1980.

title: Crossover, Minimalism And Dreams for Strings
description: The Kremerata Baltica chamber orchestra has been a hot ensemble since the violinist Gidon Kremer started it in 1996. It is, in part, a showcase for young musicians from the Baltic countries (Mr. Kremer is from Latvia), and by no means secondarily, a vehicle for Mr. Kremer's explorations in unusual corners of the repertory. For its current visit, the Kremerata is traveling light: the ensemble that performed at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening was a string trio, with Mr. Kremer, Ula Ulijona, a violist from Lithuania, and Marta Sudraba, a cellist from Latvia.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil gained almost 2 percent after an industry report showed that United States inventories fell for a second consecutive week. In New York, crude oil for January delivery rose 43 cents, to $26.87 a barrel.

title: GUNMAKERS CURB EXPORTS
description: Bowing to political pressure to stop illegal gun sales, Brazil's two largest gun manufacturers, Forjas Taurus S.A. and Companhia Brasileira de Cartuchos, suspended sales to neighboring Paraguay. Recent high-profile multiple killings with illegally obtained handguns have drawn attention to gun smuggling from Paraguay, a nation considered a springboard for much of the contraband and pirated goods sold in Brazil. But it is not clear whether handguns made in Brazil and obtained illegally in the country are necessarily funneled through Paraguay.

title: Judge Kaye's Court Reforms
description: In her six years as New York's chief judge, Judith Kaye has been proved a dedicated and effective reformer of the state's sprawling court system. Each of her hard-won changes has had a positive impact -- whether it be the repeal of automatic exemptions from jury service that let many citizens escape their civic duty, various physical improvements in court facilities, or innovations like the creation of specialized courts to better handle domestic violence and nonviolent drug cases. All this has justly earned Judge Kaye national recognition.

title: Catbird Seat on Great European Phone Deal Is in Hong Kong
description: As Mannesmann of Germany and the British company Vodafone Airtouch roll out the heavy artillery for their bitter takeover battle, there is already one undisputed victor: a Hong Kong tycoon who is watching Europe's great corporate war from the penthouse of a skyscraper half a world away.

title: Conservative Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: After Collapse, Past Violations Cited at Projects
description: A day after an accident killed a worker at a Brooklyn building site, local and federal investigators said yesterday that the contractor had a history of safety problems and violations at its projects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ERWIN L.
description: COHEN-Erwin L.., passed away on November 24, 1999. Beloved husband of Harriet (nee Baum) Adored father of Linda and Ted, brother of Margery Ehrlich and the late Arlene Brodsky. Shiva to be observed at home.

title: In America; The Courage To Learn
description: The education of young girls was supposed to have ceased when the Taliban took power in Afghanistan a few years ago. It was outlawed. The stifling cloak of ignorance was to have been thrown like a burqa over the country's females.

title: Left Holding the Scanner
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire in Meatpacking District Destroys Art
description: A fire spread through a group of artists' lofts and art galleries in the meatpacking district yesterday morning, destroying 30 years of one painter's work but sparing a Robert Motherwell canvas that had been hung in a gallery just the night before.

title: Economic Stimulus in Japan: Priming a Gold-Plated Pump
description: In its ceaseless effort to prod its maddeningly lifeless economy into action, Japan has spent more than $1 trillion, much of it on bridges, tunnels, airports, concert halls and pavement aimed at propping up the economy and satisfying political promises.

title: Holocaust Insurance Settlement Reported
description: In the first settlement of litigation over unpaid Holocaust-era life insurance policies, the Italian insurer Assicurazioni Generali has agreed to pay the descendants of one Nazi victim $1.25 million to resolve a single case, according to people knowledgeable about the deal.

title: BIRMINGHAM STEEL, UNDER PRESSURE, EXPLORES SALE
description: The Birmingham Steel Corporation, which has been under shareholder pressure to install new management, said yesterday that it had hired an adviser to explore a sale of the company and was seeking a meeting with the group of discontented investors. Ther financial adviser, Credit Suisse First Boston, will examine Birmingham Steel's strategic options, including the possible sale of the entire company. It has already received some interest from potential buyers, the company said. The company's shares fell 6.25 cents today, to $7.125, giving it a current stock market value of more than $210 million.

title: Mexico Grounds Entire Fleet Of Airline Involved in Crash
description: Citing safety concerns about aircraft operated by Mexico's third-largest airline, known as Taesa, aviation authorities have ordered the airline to ground its fleet and suspend operations.

title: The Rough and Tumble of Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: German Company Settles Medicare Case
description: Fresenius Medical Care A.G., the world's biggest provider of dialysis services, said this week that it had agreed to pay $485 million to settle United States government claims of overcharging Medicare.

title: Colorado Fuels U.S. Debate Over Use of Behavioral Drugs
description: A resolution recently passed by the Colorado Board of Education to discourage teachers from recommending behavioral drugs like Ritalin and Luvox has intensified a national debate over the growing use of prescription drugs for children.

title: Examine Above the Elbow
description: To The Editor:

title: With President Gravely Ill, Croats Face Succession Issue
description: With Croatia's dominant political figure, President Franjo Tudjman, apparently on the brink of death, Parliament passed a constitutional amendment today that would allow the country to be governed in the meantime, with some of his duties passed on to the speaker of the Parliament.

title: France Again Rejects Coke Orangina Bid
description: After a two-year struggle with French regulators, the Coca-Cola Company was rejected yesterday for a second time in its bid to buy the Orangina soft drink brand from Pernod Ricard S.A., and a spokesman for Coca-Cola said the company regarded the decision as final.

title: At 24, a Gold Medalist Possesses 22 Prizes, and Dazzle
description: The New York debut recital that Antonio Pompa-Baldi gave on Monday evening at Alice Tully Hall was part of his winnings as the gold medalist of the most recent Cleveland International Piano Competition. Mr. Pompa-Baldi, who is from Foggia, Italy, gave his recital a theme that was both nationalistic and global. Only one Italian composer, Marcello Abbado, was represented directly; two others, Corelli and Paganini, were heard by way of the variation sets composed by Rachmaninoff and Brahms. And the remaining works, Debussy's ''Suite Bergamasque'' and Poulenc's ''Suite Napoli,'' looked at Italy through French eyes.

title: Plan to Monitor Hartford Police Is Hailed
description: Longtime critics of the local police are hailing a plan to hire a civilian monitor and resurrect a moribund police review board to investigate all police shootings.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAME

title: City's Emergency Director Is Said to Accept a New Job
description: Jerome M. Hauer, the director of the Mayor's Office of Emergency Management, will step down early next year to take a job in the private sector, government officials and others with knowledge of the job offer said yesterday.

title: Privacy Concerns
description: To the Editor:

title: Outspoken Chief Economist Leaving World Bank
description: Joseph E. Stiglitz said today that he would resign as the World Bank's chief economist after using the position for nearly three years to raise pointed questions about the effectiveness of conventional approaches to helping poor countries.

title: Nasdaq Rises to Another Record, Led by Computer Issues
description: Stocks rose, led by computer-related shares like Cisco Systems, as investors scurried to keep up with the Nasdaq composite index, which is on track for its best year ever.

title: Lighting Up The Holiday: On Chaser, On Dimmer, On Twinkler And Flasher
description: THE city of Taylor, Tex., started its holiday lighting display five years ago. More than 130,000 lights later, downtown Taylor is ablaze beginning on Thanksgiving weekend with brightly lighted Christmas trees, characters from nursery rhymes, a wagon train, teepees, a 20-foot sailing ship, a Santa Claus with his sleigh and eight reindeer, the Taj Mahal and a rocket ship that commemorates John Glenn's return to space.

title: Gambling to Win or Lose, but Mostly Just to Play
Paid Notice: Deaths  FLUSS, YESHAYA
description: FLUSS-Yeshaya. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends condolences to Hersch Fluss on the loss of his brother. May the family be conforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Detroit Grabs First Place
description: RED WINGS 4, BLUES 2

title: Op-Art; Meatless Turkey Alternatives
Boy Scouts Start Drive For Funds In Detroit
description: In this city of more than a million people, there are just 20,000 boy scouts. But there is an unusual, $17 million effort afoot to increase that number.

title: NORTHEAST OPTIC FORMS NETWORK WITH PECO AND CON ED
description: NorthEast Optic Network Inc. said yesterday that Consolidated Edison Inc. and the PECO Energy Company had agreed to help it expand its fiber optic network in their service areas in exchange for equity stakes in the company. NorthEast's network now runs from Portland, Me., to New York City, and the company is aiming to extend its reach to Washington. The news sent NorthEast shares up $10.875, to $72. Con Ed will eventually get a 10.75 percent stake in NorthEast, which is based in Westborough, Mass., while PECO will get a 9.25 percent stake. Those stakes are valued at about $230 million together, based on today's closing price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACKIE, HELGA JOLES
description: MACKIE-Helga Joles. Died on November 23, 1999, in NYC. Born in Vienna, she arrived in this country at age 11 during W.W. II. Beloved wife of Vernon & mother of Joshua. Her memory will live in the hearts of all whose lives she has touched. Funeral Service on Friday, November 26, 10AM Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street.

title: Hold a Stem, Catch the Eye
description: Venetian glass vases -- shaped like eggs, gourds or pears -- have such appealingly voluptuous shapes they can stand alone, like glass sculptures. Or they can do their work as vessels and hold tulips, peonies and lilies.

title: No Shortage of Experts
description: To the Editor:

title: In Taking a Seat, Relief Pilot Added to Investigators' Suspicion
description: Investigators were drawn to Gamil al-Batouti, the relief pilot they suspect of crashing EgyptAir Flight 990, not just because of the reference to God that he made shortly before the plane began its fatal dive, but also because of the abrupt way he took the co-pilot's seat a few minutes earlier, government officials said today.

title: Stanley Frankel, 80, Writer and Corporate Officer
description: Stanley Frankel, a journalist, corporate executive and speechwriter for Democratic presidential candidates, including Adlai E. Stevenson, Robert F. Kennedy, Hubert H. Humphrey, George McGovern and Walter F. Mondale, died on Nov. 12 in a New York City hospital. He was 80.

title: A Mosque in Nazareth
description: To the Editor:

title: Bulgaria's 'Democracy'
description: To the Editor:

title: Online Company Settles Federal Charges
description: Alibris Inc. has paid $250,000 to settle federal charges that its predecessor company intercepted and stored e-mail sent between customers and Amazon.com Inc., the Justice Department said this week.

title: Israel Eases Secrecy Over Nuclear Whistle-Blower's Trial
description: The Israeli government today allowed a newspaper to publish censored excerpts from the classified transcript of a treason trial of 12 years ago. They provided the first glimpse ever into the courtroom where Mordechai Vanunu was convicted for blowing the whistle on Israel's secret nuclear program.

title: Geese in Suburbia
description: To the Editor:

title: The Last Course Throws Off Light
description: At the Japanese restaurant Omen in SoHo, diners can get more than sushi. The owner, Mikio Shinagawa, also sells a selection of plates and the Uchu lamp, above. The rice paper lamp, inspired by Isamu Noguchi's paper lamps, was designed by Yukio Kitagawa in 1992. Since then, Mr. Shinagawa has ordered the lamp from Japan occasionally for friends and customers. This month, he ordered 30. Uchu (which means Cosmos) is 24 inches in diameter and has a six-foot cord; it's $300 at Omen, 113 Thompson Street (Prince Street); (212) 925-8923.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, SELMA
description: HOROWITZ-Selma. The Board of Governors and members of Fenway Golf Club record with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime former member, Selma Horowitz, and extend our sincere condolences to the members of her family. Jeffrey Citron, President Marvin Leffler, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUMPOWSKY, MARCIA F.
description: TUMPOWSKY-Marcia F.. Beloved wife of Roy. Loving mother of Paul & Ronald. A devoted mother and teacher. She'll be missed by her family, friends and students. Funeral service to be held 10AM Friday, November 26 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: CALENDAR
description: A California Architect

title: EBay Is Told That It Sells Nazi Items
description: The online auction service eBay Inc. has come under fire previously for letting people bid on pornography and firearms. Yesterday, it encountered more problems when a group that monitors anti-Semitism complained about the sale of Nazi memorabilia.

title: Cajun Country's Very Salty Dog
description: It was not the ideal setting for a rock concert, but then again, this was southern Louisiana, the capital of cultural mix and match.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Transit Union Leader Sets Pay Demand
description: With a strike deadline set for Dec. 15, the president of New York City's transit workers' union complained yesterday of little progress in contract talks and said he wanted more than the 11 percent raise over three years received by the region's railroad workers.

title: John G. Stewart Book Executive, 80
description: John G. Stewart, former manager of The New York Times Book Division, died on Tuesday at his home in Rumson, N.J. He was 80. He had a brief illness, his wife, Linda, said.

title: Where East Meets West: At the Front Door
description: Never judge a house by its exterior. In Hunter, N.Y., near the ski slopes, stands a house that is anonymous 1960's-style American clapboard on the outside and Japanese-style maple and oak on the inside. ''We wanted a tranquil retreat,'' said Vivia Horn, president of her own advertising agency in Manhattan, who designed the spare ski lodge with her husband, Steven Horn, a lawyer. (They have since divorced, but both still use the 2,500-square-foot house.)

title: New Yorkers Give, for a Park That Shines
description: To the Editor:

title: Armstead Softens Criticism
description: Linebacker Jessie Armstead, critical of the Giants' offense after their loss at Washington last weekend, said today that he is no longer going to answer questions about the team's offensive effort.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALIMIR, FELIX
description: GALIMIR-Felix. November 10, 1999. So few people possess the talent and the intelligence to be revealed to others. Through your great gift of music, you are one. Thank you for being so generous with that very personal wisdom, Dear Felix, and for lacing it so often with good humor. We have been honored by the opportunity to share your legacy. The Artists, Board of Directors, and Patrons of New York Philomusica

title: Plaid Feels Great Against the Skin
description: Most stores are happy to wrap presents for the holidays. This month, Burberry covered all six stories of its facade in its signature pattern. ''We blew up the plaid 70 times larger,'' said Diane Gatterdam, national vice president for store design. It was printed on vinyl with an adhesive back by C2 Media, a graphics printing company in Manhattan. On Nov. 11, when workers installed the vinyl, it was 40 degrees. To raise the temperature to the 55 degrees required for the adhesive to work, they used hair dryers, Ms. Gatterdam said. Burberry is at 9 East 57 Street.

title: Huskies Rally and Hold Off Kentucky Surge
description: Trailing by 4 points at the half and by 2 with 4 minutes 45 seconds left in the game, the University of Connecticut's No. 1 ranking appeared seriously imperiled by unheralded Kentucky tonight in the opening round of the Coaches vs. Cancer Challenge at the Hartford Civic Center.

title: GRANADA PROFIT RISES
description: Britain's largest hotel operator, Granada Group P.L.C., which also owns a third of the British television network ITV, said that implied second-half profit rose 12 percent on increased advertising from shows like ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' and sales of TV programs. Income before one-time items rose to $:382 million, or $616.8 million, in the six months through September, from $:340 million a year earlier. Total sales rose 6 percent, to $:4.08 billion. Granada said it was seeking acquisitions that could lead to splitting itself into media and hospitality divisions.

title: Origami Sites Show How to Fold Them
description: IN the world of origami, all links lead to Joseph Wu.

title: Straight and Narrow, With a Wiggle or Two
description: WHEN I work on a shop, I try not to think like a furniture designer,'' said Dakota Jackson, who is best known for his chairs.

title: New Jersey Turnpike Accelerates Toll Increase
description: The first toll increase on the New Jersey Turnpike since 1991 will begin on May 22, seven months sooner than originally announced, the agency said yesterday.

title: France Takes Steps to End Feud With Britain Over Beef Imports
description: The feud between the French and British over France's refusal to import British beef seemed to inch toward a finish today as the French acknowledged that they had taken a set of recommendations to their national food safety agency to get approval for lifting the import ban.

title: Crowds Take to Roads and the Sky to Sit at Thanksgiving Tables
description: A record number of travelers jammed airports and highways across the nation yesterday to celebrate Thanksgiving with family and friends. Despite the crowds, the day went off with no more than the usual frustrations.

title: 'The Smallest One Was Madeline'; A New Focus on the Creator of a Classic
description: Madeline must be the only famous French orphan born in a tavern near Gramercy Park. It was there, 60 years ago, that Ludwig Bemelmans, her creator, jotted on the back of a menu the famous phrases, ''In an old house in Paris that was covered with vines lived 12 little girls in two straight lines.''

title: Asea Insider Trading Case Is Settled
description: A former executive at ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd. and a friend have agreed to pay more than $400,000 to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges concerning insider trading on the company's purchase of Elsag Bailey Process Automation N.V.

title: Fairy-Tale Settings for Snug Bugs
description: GOOD NIGHT to ordinary children's beds. Themes are everywhere, from headboard to finial (or in one case at least, stem to stern). Designers are going to remarkable lengths to cater to the dreams of aspiring astronomers and would-be Eloises. Many of the twin beds shown here can be customized in bold and delectable colors: some makers offer as many as 40 to choose from. But remember -- whatever the theme or color, you still provide the room service.

title: A Young Man Who Traveled Far on Hopes of a Better Life
description: Like thousands of young men before him, Eduardo Daniel said goodbye to his hometown -- this one in the poor and arid state of Puebla in southern Mexico -- and, with a satchel of clothes, went north for a new life in New York.

title: EUROPE WINS STEEL RULING
description: The European Union won a World Trade Organization ruling that the United States violated global trading rules by imposing countervailing duties on British steel imports. A European Union spokesman said the finding upheld European assertions that the United States was wrong to impose duties on leaded bars and hot-rolled lead made by a state-owned steel concern. United States officials may appeal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEILLER, HERMAN EMIL
description: WEILLER-Herman Emil. Of Larchmont, NY on November 23, 1999. Mr. Weiller is survived by two daughters, Cathy Buchalter and Ruth Weiller. He is also survived by two sons-in-law, Terry Buchalter and Randall Clare, two grandchildren Dana and Jonathan Buchalter, and his companion of eighteen years, Jeanne Weisgrau. His wife Marie Schorr Weiller died in 1980. Funeral service Friday, November 26, 1999, 12:30 P.M. at Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue (exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry, New York. Memorials to Hospice of Westchester appreciated.

title: Storing Your Life in a Virtual Desktop; Web-Based Storage and Software Reinvents an Old Idea, the Network Computer
description: COLIN S. BRADY is one of those executives whose office is a computer screen, whether it is the one on his home computer, his work computer or his laptop. So last July, when both his laptop and his home computer crashed irreparably within a four-day period, it was as if two-thirds of his office had been destroyed.

title: Putting a Multimedia Spin On the Ordinary Business Card
description: At the Comdex computer show in Las Vegas last week, one of the hot items was business cards. Not ordinary cards, but CD-ROM's cut to the size of business cards.

title: ING'S PROFIT TRIPLES
description: The leading Dutch financial-services company, ING Groep N.V., indicated that its third-quarter profit more than tripled as its investment-banking unit recovered from last year's rout in financial markets. Profit from operations rose to 796 million euros, or $814 million, from 254 million euros last year.

title: Metal Goes Classical, With Growls And Screams
description: Classical-music popularizers typically cite the riot that greeted the opening of Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring'' as proof that symphonic works have, at least once this century, been wild enough to raise mayhem. But when was the last time an orchestral prelude was greeted by screams so deafening that they drowned out not only the struggling flutes, but the mighty tuba? And in what hall have critics dodged half-eaten pizza slices lobbed by overstimulated fans?

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: Crew's Maneuvers
description: For weeks, in the midst of tumult over dismal test scores, tougher standards and plans to hold back thousands of children who fail to meet them, Rudy Crew, the New York City schools chancellor, and Rudolph W. Giuliani, the mayor, have conducted a delicate dance over whether Dr. Crew will stay or go.

title: Insurer Unit Set to Acquire Investing Firm
description: The brokerage unit of the Prudential Insurance Company of America is in the final stages of negotiations to buy Volpe Brown Whelan & Company, one of the last independent investment banks on the West Coast, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, GRACE
description: GALLAGHER - Grace. The Trustees, physicians and staff of the hospitals of Mount Sinai NYU Health note with profound sadness the passing of Grace Gallagher, beloved wife of our esteemed colleage, Jack Gallagher, Chief Executive Officer of North ShoreLong Island Jewish Health System, our strategic partner in advancing the quality of healthcare services. We extend our deepest sympathy to him, to their children and to the entire family. Stephen M. Peck, Chairman John W. Rowe, MD, President and Chief Executive Officer Barry R. Freedman, Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer Theresa A. Bischoff, Executive Vice President

title: First Talks Are Scheduled by Mediator in Microsoft Case
description: The government and Microsoft have been summoned to Chicago on Tuesday for their first round of settlement talks under Richard A. Posner, the federal appeals court judge who has been selected as a mediator, according to a person close to the antitrust case.

title: SCIENTIFIC GAMES SEEKS HELP TO RAISE ITS SHARE PRICE
description: The Scientific Games Holdings Corporation, an operator of networks to run lotteries, said yesterday that it had hired Salomon Smith Barney to help it explore strategic opportunities to bolster its share price. Shares of Scientific Games rose $2.125, to $16.625. At that price its stock is worth almost $200 million. The company, based in the Atlanta suburb of Alpharetta, Ga., provides lottery systems and products like lottery tickets in 28 states and 54 countries. Its shares have fallen 16 percent in the last year, along with other lottery operators like the Gtech Holdings Corporation, amid slow growth of the international lottery business.

title: Making a Blissful Life From Overfeeding
description: MICHAEL A. GINOR, majority owner of Hudson Valley Foie Gras, can remember the first moment he tasted that fattened liver that was to become his love and his livelihood. He was a college student in Israel, some 15 years ago; he and his girlfriend, Laurie -- now his wife, -- were being treated to dinner at a restaurant chosen by his father, a wealthy businessman of normally dreadful culinary taste.

title: When a Gizmo Can Invent a Gizmo
description: IF Dr. Frankenstein's monster had published a best seller, who would have gotten the rights to that intellectual property?

title: Trip Worth It for Two Teams of Wildcats
description: The championship game of the Preseason National Invitation Tournament will be an all-Wildcat affair matching two recent N.C.A.A. tournament champions. Kentucky guaranteed that last night by surviving Maryland, 61-58, after squandering a 16-point lead in the second game of a semifinal doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.

title: For Injured Children, The Images of Life
description: In 1993, Kenro Izu, a New York photographer, went to Angkor Wat in Cambodia. When he saw how many children had lost limbs to land-mine explosions and thought about all the times he had used settings in countries like Cambodia, he decided he wanted to help. In 1995, he founded Friends Without a Border to raise funds -- $45,000 so far -- for a children's hospital, which opened in February. A benefit auction for the hospital on Wednesday at Swann Galleries will offer 120 photographs, including, above, one by Imogen Cunningham; below, by Jerry N. Uellsman; and bottom, by Hiroshi Sugimoto. Previews Tuesday and Wednesday; $20 for reception and auction; 104 East 25th Street; (212) 254-4710.

title: Reinventing the Day
description: There is no precise form of words for giving thanks today. The number of place-settings depends on the weather, on long-distance travel plans and last-minute arrivals. The menu is only partly foreordained by custom. Once, the turkey was stuffed with cornbread instead of chestnuts, and now the idea of cornbread stuffing seems almost venerable. As the years pass, the dinner hour drifts from early afternoon to early evening and back again. The setting shifts from house to house as the family grows older, younger, more scattered. It is even hard to say just who is indispensable at this feast, for memory has a way of bringing everyone -- living and dead, present and absent -- into company at the table.

title: Nets Are Feeling Better After Dose of Warriors
description: The Nets ran into the perfect pick-me-up tonight at the Arena in Oakland. Instead of meeting a group of high-flying, fancy-passing, sweet-shooting gamers, they faced the Golden State Warriors, a West Coast crew that is as injured as it is hapless. It was just what a loser of seven straight games needed.

title: L.I. Republicans Repeal Tax That Cost Election
description: Republican lawmakers in Nassau County voted this evening to repeal the unpopular real estate transfer tax that they enacted over the summer, even as they acknowledged that they had yet to figure out where they would find the more than $50 million that the tax was expected to bring in.

title: Yacht Modems Let Fans Keep Track of Races Online
description: ARMCHAIR sailors will be able to follow the America's Cup yachting race from both their television sets and their computers, thanks to a new system that receives data from wireless modems aboard the yachts.

title: One-Man Bridge From U.S. to Britain
description: Alistair Cooke was about to tuck into his lobster bisque at the Carlyle the other day when a stranger stopped at the table and said: ''You look familiar. Do I know you?''

title: Lee Shaw, 86, Lawyer, Dies; Helped Develop Labor Law
description: Lee C. Shaw, who helped draw much of the road map for modern labor law and then used it to help corporations negotiate with unions, died of a heart attack on Nov. 15 at his home in San Diego. He was 86.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WITHERS, ROSAMOND F. E.
description: WITHERS-Rosamond F. E.., M.D. Quintessential consort, incomparable friend; I will keep you with me forever. Donal

title: Investigation Begins Into Why Army Helicopter Crashed at L.I. Airport
description: The twisted wreckage of an Army National Guard helicopter in which two people were killed and two others were critically injured late Tuesday lay strewn along the end of a runway at Long Island MacArthur Airport today as federal and local officials tried to determine the cause of the crash.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Gore, Running in Iowa, Runs Hard From Clinton
description: As Vice President Al Gore tries to sell himself as his own man, unencumbered by President Clinton and his scandals, it is hardly a surprise that he plays down his ties to the politician he hopes to succeed.

title: Thanks for Nothing: Leetch Breaks His Right Arm
description: Even when they win, the Rangers lose.

title: NICKEL DISPUTE WORSENS
description: A Toronto-based mining company, Inco Ltd., which fills more than a quarter of global demand for nickel, said that problems beyond its control had forced it to renege on some contracts. The company said a 10-week lockout at its mine, smelter and refining complex at Thompson, Manitoba, had halted deliveries of nickel grades that had recently accounted for 15 percent of its total shipments. The Thompson complex alone supplies 4.5 percent of the world demand for nickel. No talks were scheduled between Inco and the United Steelworkers to produce a contract that would end the lockout.

title: MEAD SELLS ITS 50% STAKE IN NORTHWOOD TO CANFOR
description: The Mead Corporation said yesterday that it had sold its 50 percent stake in the pulp maker Northwood Inc. to the Canfor Corporation for $216.3 million in cash and securities. Mead, the No. 1 maker of school notebooks, wants to focus on specialty paper and packaging. Mead received $163.5 million in cash and $52.8 million in convertible debentures. The company, which makes Trapper notebook organizers, will record a fourth-quarter gain of 43 cents a share from the sale and said it planned to invest the proceeds in its growth businesses.

title: Superhighway Encounters
description: To the Editor:

title: Trinidad-Reid Bout Is Postponed
description: The bout between Felix Trinidad and David Reid, the World Boxing Association superwelterweight champion, has been postponed because the World Boxing Council has mandated that Trinidad defend the welterweight championship against the No. 1 contender Derrell Coley within 90 days or vacate the title.

title: Could That Be a Human Voice Coming Out of the Computer?
description: Text-to-speech technology has been around for nearly 20 years as a way for the blind to use computers. What has been elusive has been the ability to make the computer voice sound human rather than tinny and robotic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'ALBINI, CLARA
description: D'ALBINI-Clara., 95, died on October 31, 1999. Mourned by her daughter and son-in-law, Gabrielle and Gabe Katona, by cherished relatives of her beloved husband the late Louis, and by her many friends and fellow travelers.

title: West's Role in Chechnya
description: To the Editor:

title: Boston Journal; From a Place for Welfare to One for Fostering Pride
description: In cities, buildings are constructed and gutted and torn down and rebuilt all the time. Rarely does a single structure come to embody for one group of people both a moment of indignity and defeat, and one of pride and possibility.

title: GOODYEAR TO CLOSE ITALIAN FACTORY AND CUT 500 JOBS
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company is closing its only tire factory in Italy. The shutdown of the plant, in the southern Italian town of Cisterna di Latina, will mean the elimination of 500 jobs. It follows nearly a year of steady reductions in the size of the plant's work force. At the start of 1999, the plant employed an estimated 900 people and produced 17,000 tires a day. Goodyear is in the midst of a worldwide effort to streamline its far-flung manufacturing operations.

title: UNILEVER TO BUY AMORA MAILLE
description: The British-Dutch consumer products giant Unilever agreed to acquire France's leading maker of condiments, Amora Maille, for $745 million. Unilever will buy the company from Paribas Affaires Industrielles LBO Fund, a division of the French investment bank Paribas S.A., and a group of other investors. Amora Maille makes Amora brand mustard, ketchup, bouillon, salad dressing and seasonings, as well as a Maille line of mustard, sauces, olive oil and vinegar. The Dijon-based company employs 1,000 people and is expected to post sales this year of $360 million.

title: That Fickle Lover In Design Affairs
description: SOME houses are built around a view, some around a hearth, some around the kitchen. But rare is the home predicated on celestial events. In architectural history, the buildings that channel sunlight are usually religious structures that materialize light, as though the finger of God were making a divine point by marking space at a designated time.

title: Your Poll, My Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Charles Schaefer Jr. Dies at 85; Businessman and Philanthropist
description: Charles V. Schaefer Jr., a New Jersey businessman who became a major benefactor of Stevens Institute of Technology and chairman of its board, died on Nov. 18 at the North Ridge Medical Center in Oakland Park, Fla. He was 85 and lived in Saddle River, N.J.

title: INSIDE
description: Questions Over Dialysis

title: C.I.A. Counters Critics of Its Cold War Work
description: After enduring a decade of second-guessing over whether it failed to detect Communism's impending demise, the Central Intelligence Agency is still a bit defensive about its performance in the waning years of the cold war.

title: You Can Get Anything You Want; Pay a Visit to Arlo's Home Page
description: One of the more memorable events in the history of Thanksgiving occurred in Stockbridge, Mass., on Nov. 25, 1965, when Arlo Guthrie dumped trash where he wasn't supposed to (the town dump having been closed for the holiday). Mr. Guthrie was arrested the next day for littering, and the arrest and its ramifications were immortalized in Mr. Guthrie's 18-minute song, ''Alice's Restaurant Massacree.''

title: Another Site for Donations
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: The Rough and Tumble of Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; With Thanks For Heart And Home
description: A YEAR ago, he had two young children to preoccupy his thoughts and his wife to assist him in keeping his faith. Thanksgiving was spent quietly, pensively, in his Jersey City apartment, supposedly a convenient ride to where he was receiving treatment for the cancer that so rudely had rerouted his life.

title: The Joy of 'Millionaire'
description: To the Editor:

title: Seating to Flatter the Complexion
description: At RX, a restaurant that is to open in February at the Dylan Hotel, banquettes will be framed in amber glass and upholstered in dark green suede, and chairs will be covered in blue and violet silk. A golden tapestry woven of silk and glass beads will hang from the 26-foot ceiling to the left of the fireplace.

title: Wafting Through the 1930's on Piano Notes
description: Unlike commercial concert presenters, conservatories, with their pools of student performers who don't have to be paid, can afford to offer truly adventuresome concerts. But few conservatories would attempt a project as bold and fascinating as Piano Century, the 11-concert survey of 20th-century piano music being offered by the Juilliard School, which runs through April 25.

title: Superhighway Encounters
description: To the Editor:

title: MetroStars Draft DaSilva
description: In their first roster move since the end of a forgettable season, the MetroStars yesterday chose Nino DaSilva, a 20-year-old midfielder, with the first overall selection in the Major League Soccer waiver draft.

title: A Holiday That Plays to Our Strengths
description: Addressing his Philadelphia congregation in 1808, a freed slave and African Episcopal minister named Absalom Jones proposed a day of national thanksgiving: January 1, the date when the importing of slaves into the United States was outlawed. He imagined the holiday as an American answer to the Jewish duty of remembrance, the divine command to recall a history of bondage and deliverance.

title: Revolutionary With a String of Pearls
description: FRANCES WILSON PEABODY is 96, a Mayflower descendant and a lifelong Republican -- almost. She had to stop, she says, because ''I can't very well be a Republican with all the homosexuals in our family.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELEM, SAMUEL A.
description: ELEM-Samuel A.. Age 88, of N. Miami Beach, FL., on November 20, 1999 after a brief illness. He was a master jeweler and the owner of Bertel Jewelers of NYC. He leaves his wife of 38 years, Esther Kaplan Elem; his daughter, Cathy Hollis and husband Glenn; and a sister, Ethel Liebowitz. He is also survived by two stepsons, Alan Kaplan and wife Eva and Edward Kaplan and wife Madelon, as well as six loving grandchildren. He will be dearly missed.

title: PC's Are Adopting New Shapes, One Just a Bit Too Familiar
description: After Apple's iMac broke the ''any color as long as it's beige'' and ''any shape as long as it's a box'' molds, personal computer makers have been showing off odd-shaped and colorful computers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLANDER, BIRDY
description: FRIEDLANDER-Birdy. On November 24th at the age of 91. Loving mother of Myra and Allen. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Services Friday 10:30AM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Murdoch Ally Says He Erred On NBC Sale
description: A suggestion by Rupert Murdoch that NBC had been offered for sale to Time Warner was ''a bit of a mistake,'' an executive close to Mr. Murdoch said yesterday. The executive also sought to counter any criticism that with his remarks Mr. Murdoch, the chairman of the News Corporation, had been seeking to affect the Time Warner stock price.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Revised Growth Estimate Shows Economy in Top Gear

title: Thanksgiving
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUIZEND, HENRI
description: DUIZEND-Henri. The Conservative Synagogue of Jamaica Estates mourns the demise, in Israel, of Henri Duizend, our first president. He was a driving force in the creation of our synagogue. To Lies we extend our sincerest condolence.

title: Nitzana Journal; A Limitless Dream for the Desert of Tomorrow
description: Standing at the edge of the Negev, overlooking a border crossing into Egypt, Lova Eliav swept a hand across the expanse and summoned up his vision of a new Israeli city in the sand.

title: Unschooled on Forks
description: To the Editor:

title: Residents and Civic Leaders in Milford Meet to Confront Reports of Bigotry
description: In church and in City Hall, leaders and residents of this middle-class shoreline suburb halfway between New Haven and Bridgeport have been gathering over the last two weeks to discuss what has become a too-familiar concern in southern Connecticut: reports of bigotry in their community.

title: Rate Worry Erodes Prices Of Treasuries
description: Treasury yields rose to four-week highs after the government raised its estimate of third-quarter growth, fueling concern that the Federal Reserve will need to raise interest rates to keep inflation in check.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Broadway Battle

title: Superhighway Encounters
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Bell Atlantic May Be Sued
description: Bell Atlantic may be sued for denying benefits to employees of a spinoff company, a federal judge has ruled.

title: After the Drama, a Shanghai 'Peony'? Yes, With Changes
description: One of the few predictable postscripts to last year's drama over the blocking of a production of ''The Peony Pavilion'' from a New York performance was that cultural officials here would come up with their own version of the classic Chinese opera. The Communist Party-approved ''Pavilion'' was recently performed in a run-down auditorium here. It won few plaudits outside the official press, and even in a relatively modest-size performance hall plenty of seats remained empty.

title: N.F.L. Matchups
description: CHICAGO (5-6) AT DETROIT (6-4)

title: Ikon Settles Suits For $111 Million
description: Ikon Office Solutions Inc. has agreed to pay $111 million to settle securities fraud lawsuits contending that the company, the second-largest supplier of copiers in the United States, misled investors about internal problems that led to major financial losses last year.

title: For the Keepers of the Confederate Heritage, a Taste or Two of Appomattox
description: It may not be as bad as the winter of 1865, but this year has not been kind to the Sons of Confederate Veterans and their desperate defense of their ancestors' most beloved emblems.

title: Musical Quarterbacks Amuses Cards' Brown
description: Dave Brown has watched with interest as his former team has changed quarterbacks in each of the last two seasons.

title: Treatment of Kidney Failure Is Flawed, 2 Studies Suggest
description: Two studies being published today suggest that flaws in the treatment of kidney failure may endanger thousands of Americans. Both concern dialysis, the treatment given several times a week to cleanse the blood of waste products that build up when the kidneys do not work.

title: Serbia Holds Up Fuel Sent to Help Opposition
description: Serbian customs officials have held up the European Union's first effort to donate heating fuel to Serbian towns controlled by the political opposition, impounding the 14 fuel trucks overnight at this border town.

title: A Disabled Mother Gains New Independence
description: Maria Frias, a single mother of three, considers herself lucky this Thanksgiving to be able to get out of the house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEPASQUALE, JOHN A.
description: DEPASQUALE-John A.., M.D. of Wethersfield, CT., and Pompano Beach, FL died peacefully in his sleep on November 23rd due to cumulative effects from a past stroke. Dr. DePasquale earned his Doctor of Medicine degree in 1936 from the University of Pennsylvania Medical School. He was an outstanding diagnostician and trauma emergency practitioner with a bedside manner befitting the highest standards of his profession. He graduated with Honors from Catholic University, BS '32. He received a Boxing Medal for his undefeated college boxing career and in 1994 was elected to the Athletic Hall of Fame. A WWII hero at Guadalcanal, in 1946 for his ''courage and devotion beyond the call of duty,'' Lieutenant Colonel DePasquale was awarded the Silver Oak Leaf and the Purple Heart for his daring and skill while performing operations in the open field under heavy gunfire during enemy assaults. Born in Newark, New Jersey March 7, he is survived by his wife, Mary, his daughter, Mary-Jean A. DePasquale of Wethersfield, his son & daughterin-law John A. and Elizabeth A. DePasquale of Matinecock, NY and two grandchildren, Alexa Ann and John A. DePasquale III.

title: In Spotlight, Texas Band Juggles Thrill and Fear
description: Among the hundreds of performers in the crowded Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, the Trinity Valley Community College marching band and dance team would probably not have drawn an extraordinary amount of attention, except perhaps in its hometown of Athens, Tex.

title: To Weave A Refuge Out of Disaster
description: Toshiko Mori, a Manhattan architect, has found a way for victims of earthquakes, famines and wars to make their own temporary shelters by weaving together scraps of fabric. Ms. Mori asked Patagonia, the outdoor clothing concern, and others to donate remnants of polyester fleece and breathable waterproof polyester. Then she wove a 3-by-6-foot hammock, right, with an attached blanket. It took two hours. Two more hours produced a ''shingled'' waterproof wall, shown with Ms. Mori, above. Combine four sloping walls with a few hammocks, and there's a home.

title: For People Shopping Online, Survey Strikes Cautionary Note
description: If you believe all the television commercials, online shopping will be an effortless and satisfying experience this holiday season. But a couple of recent reports suggest that dealing with Web-based stores can be anything but.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 8 of House & Home today about Dr. Edward M. Hallowell, a psychiatrist and author, refers incorrectly to the city where he grew up. It is Charleston, S.C., not in North Carolina.

title: Metro Business; Brooklyn Lawyer Is Charged in Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission brought fraud charges against a Brooklyn lawyer and his investment advisory firm on Tuesday, alleging that they raised more than $1.2 million selling investments in a phony bank in a nonexistent country.

title: Unpolished, Untucked, Unkempt, Unleashed
description: Thirty years into its career, NRBQ makes being unpolished a way of life. Its 30th-anniversary show, on Sunday night at the Bowery Ballroom, started with Terry Adams lunging at the piano to jab a handful of notes. Slack-jawed, with his shirt untucked and his long hair mussed, he started pounding a left-hand boogie as the rest of the band reached for its instruments, then began bawling, ''Go tell ma/go tell pa/the mule is in the corn.'' It was one more night of romping, unkempt rock, upholding a tradition of anarchy-laced good times that NRBQ claimed from the start.

title: The Money in the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Born To Be Wired
description: WHEN Apple introduced the iBook several months ago as the portable version of its popular iMac desktop computer, one of its more intriguing features was a built-in radio antenna that in theory enabled the iBook to connect to the Internet and share files with other Macintosh computers without wires.

title: Nigeria's Culture Of Corruption
description: To the Editor:

title: FINDEX SEEKS BUYOUT OFFERS FOR AT LEAST $16 A SHARE
description: FindEx.com Inc., an Internet provider of religious products and financial information said yesterday that it was seeking buyers willing to pay at least $16 a share. Joe Szczepaniak, the president, chief executive and the only member of the company's board, said in an interview that there were 9.1 million shares outstanding, which would value the company at more than $145 million if it received $16 a share. The Omaha-based company, which has not released any financial reports, said last week that it had offers of at least $10 a share from unnamed companies. After reviewing operations, FindEx.com said it would reopen the bidding at $16 a share to ''protect shareholder value.'' The shares closed yesterday at $10, down 50 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DURELL, HELEN
description: DURELL-Helen. On November 23, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Jack, Robert and Marjorie. Adoring grandmother of Stewart, Seth and Jared. She will be deeply missed by her family and friends. Graveside service Friday, 1PM at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Sprewell Is Fined $10,000 By N.B.A.
description: The National Basketball Association all but ordered Latrell Sprewell to wash his mouth out with soap by fining him $10,000 yesterday for directing profanity toward fans during his emotional return to Golden State in Oakland on Saturday.

title: The Rough and Tumble of Politics; McCain, Wronged
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A caption in Circuits last Thursday with an article about portable music and multimedia players misidentified a model of the Sony Glasstron, a device that looks like sunglasses and is used to view entertainment or game videos. The player shown was the PLM-A35, which costs $599, not the PLM-S700 PC, which is $2,599.

title: GARDEN Q & A
description: Fruits and Nuts

title: The Great Green Way
description: As Underdog and friends float and bob down Broadway today, they will find spruced-up parks, squares and traffic islands along the way. From Battery Park on up, a series of recent and impending renovation projects are flourishing along New York's most historic thoroughfare.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROAD, ROSE JEROMER
description: BROAD-Rose Jeromer. Dearest mother, 20 years of missing your warmth, beauty and wisdom. Lovingly remembered every day. Justine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEILLER, HERMAN
description: WEILLER-Herman. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Amiel Wohl, Rabbi

title: AMERICAN INDUSTRIAL HIRES ADVISERS TO STUDY STRATEGIES
description: American Industrial Properties, a real estate investment trust, said yesterday that it had hired Salomon Smith Barney Inc. and Prudential Securities Inc. as financial advisers to assist it in evaluating strategic alternatives. Citing the changing dynamics of the REIT market, American Industrial said alternatives included a merger, the shedding of some assets or a sale of the company. It said it would also consider continuing its growth strategy. American Industrial's shares rose 18.75 cents, to $11.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. At that price, its stock is more more than $250 million.

title: I.O.C. Offers 50 Guidelines For Its Cleanup Campaign
description: With less than a month before a crucial meeting of its members, the International Olympic Committee yesterday released 50 recommendations that will form the centerpiece of the beleaguered Swiss-based organization's reform campaign.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Sima Nan, a man in China who tries to debunk claims of supernatural powers, misspelled the surname of an American magician with whom he recently performed. The American is James Randi, not Randy.

title: A Young Man in Search Of His Sexual Identity
description: The first scene of ''2 by 4'' is about black leather pants. The second is about sexual orientation. Johnny Maher's girlfriend asks him, ''Do you like men?'' He shrugs and answers, ''Try anything once, you know.'' Or twice. Or more.

title: Today's Sections
description: Because of holiday production requirements, Section A is printed in two parts today. National news begins on Page A29.

title: She's Flinty And He's Stubborn? Perfect
description: ''One Special Night,'' the film that reunites Julie Andrews and James Garner, lives up to its title. These dependable performers can still generate enough sparks to warm two hours on Sunday night.

title: 'More Stuffing' Is Mayor's Cry of the Day, and It Works
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, whose frequent refrain is that the highest form of compassion is to help people work to help themselves, briefly shed his tough-love armor yesterday and donned an apron to help pack up Thanksgiving meals for homebound AIDS patients.

title: Feminists Play the Victim Game
description: An increasing number of women are being arrested for domestic assaults, and the response to this news shows just how pervasive sexist attitudes still are in our culture. But this time the sexism is coming from feminists and their allies, who insist that most women arrested must have acted in self-defense. This sentimental insistence on female innocence does no service to women, who should be treated as human beings with a capacity for aggression and held equally accountable for their actions.

title: Kosovar Refugees Thankful for Family and Life in America
description: The sprawling Kosovar Albanian clan of Erbelis and Devas celebrated their first Thanksgiving together yesterday. The hostess, Lili Erbeli, raised her glass of merlot in a toast to the three dozen cousins squeezed around her dining room table, three generations of Albanian-Americans with three generations of their refugee kin. ''Happy Thanksgiving everybody,'' she said. ''Welcome to my house.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nations Begin to Restrict Their Plants and Wildlife

title: BOXING: The Nightmare of the Ring; Boxer Who Yearned for a Title Winds Up in a Coma
description: When the promoter called in September to offer him a chance to fight in Atlantic City, Stephan Johnson knew it would probably be his last chance to become a contender for a world title fight and the big payday that had eluded him his entire career.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''For most Americans, Congress not doing a lot is not a bad thing. It's a lot better not to make big mistakes.''

title: Some Fear A Shortage Of Water
description: If there's been one constant to life in New York City, it's that water from upstate reservoirs will always flow from the tap. But now, with the millennium approaching, a few New Yorkers are not so sure, and they've started stocking up -- just in case.

title: Germany's Consensus Economy at Risk of Unraveling
description: Chancellor Gerhard Schroder could scarcely conceal a triumphant grin as he announced a $2.2 billion bailout of Germany's biggest construction company on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DURELL, HELEN
description: DURELL-Helen. On November 23, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Jack, Robert and Marjorie. Adoring grandmother of Stewart, Seth and Jared. She will be deeply missed by her family and friends. Graveside service Friday, 1PM at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Inventive Garments Designed to Go With the Flow
description: The clothing designer Issey Miyake is some kind of artist, although which kind is not always clear.

title: Infection Kills Day Care Worker
description: Three days after a day care center worker in Union City, N.J., died of meningitis, health officials will offer free antibiotics today to her co-workers and families of children in the day care program, the police said.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Feast Time For Filmmakers

title: The Future of Books Is on the Screen
description: To the Editor:

title: All-Around Maverick Comes Back Into Focus
description: If not the most accomplished man in England of his time, Edward William Godwin (1833-1886) came close. An architect, antiquarian, designer of furniture and textiles, interior decorator, set and costume designer, journalist, critic, collector, bon vivant, high-caste Bohemian and womanizer, this dazzling polymath was also a close friend of Oscar Wilde, a collaborator with Whistler and the father -- by the actress Ellen Terry -- of Edward Gordon Craig (1872-1966), the theatrical designer and theorist.

title: SFX Entertainment Acquires SME Power
description: SFX Entertainment in New York has acquired SME Power Branding in New York, a sports branding identity company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, WALTER
description: SILVERMAN-Walter, on November 23, 1999. Formerly of Rockville Centre, Long Island. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. A life well-lived and much cherished.

title: Civilian Police Force Brings New Problems in Haiti
description: Renan Etienne keeps his military academy diploma hanging in his office, although it is an odd decorative touch. He is the Port-au-Prince commander for the Haitian National Police, the civilian force that replaced the brutal and corrupt Haitian Army.

title: An Economy of Art for the Fortune Set
description: Walker Evans's photographs began appearing in Fortune a few years before an assignment from that magazine led to some of the most haunting images of the Great Depression. For an article on the American Communist Party in its September 1934 issue, Evans took pictures of party members camping near Beacon, N.Y., looking and behaving like relaxing petit bourgeois Americans anywhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREW, DR. GERALD M.
description: DREW-Dr. Gerald M. On Nov. 24, 1999. Beloved husband to Selma, loving father to David and Jenny. Esteemed colleague, mentor and loyal friend. Dr. Drew, University of Michigan Dental School, 1948, practiced fifty years with outstanding expertise and unequalled passion. He was a retired U.S. Navy Lt. Commander, a Board Certified Endodontist, Professor at Columbia and FDU, & Director of PG Endo at NYU. His legacy of generosity, love, compassion, humor and friendship will live on in all of us. Services today, November 26, 1 PM, Garlick Funeral, Monticello

title: The Future of Books Is on the Screen
description: To the Editor:

title: Keep Trucking Safe
description: To the Editor:

title: Sehorn Still Searching for Himself
description: On videotape, Jason Sehorn has watched the Giants' No. 31 play this season, watched him be beaten to the football by opposing receivers, watched him chase receivers from behind, watched him, out of control, barge into a receiver -- a yellow flag soon flying into the frame.

title: Holik Is Suspended, And Devils Pay the Price
description: COYOTES 4, DEVILS 2

title: Reading Al Gore
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHART, MIMI
description: REICHART-Mimi. 21 years you left me, but I still love you and I miss you. November 26, 1999. Lloy

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Croatia Moves to Declare President Temporarily Incapacitated
description: The Croatian government, meeting today in emergency session, asked the Constitutional Court to declare the ailing President, Franjo Tudjman, temporarily incapable of carrying out his duties.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: ASIA

title: Prayer and School Football
description: The Supreme Court has agreed to decide whether a Texas school district violated the Constitution by letting students lead others in prayer over the public address system before high school football games. The practice plainly breaches the First Amendment's wall of separation between church and state, and the justices should not hesitate to say so.

title: A Missile Shield Could Backfire
description: The presidential campaign may be heating up, but Republicans and Democrats are sounding remarkably alike on at least one important issue. Candidates on both sides want to build a national defense against missile attack.

title: Talisman Energy Criticized Over Its Holdings in Sudan
description: Jim Buckee would like Talisman Energy Inc. of Calgary, Alberta, to be known as a true Canadian success story, a company that has increased oil and gas production by 30 percent a year since the mid-1990's by reaching beyond its prairie base to develop wells in the North Sea, Indonesia and Sudan.

title: Yeltsin Delays Accord With Belarus, and Aides Cite Bronchitis
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin put off plans today to sign a unification treaty with Belarus, a political and diplomatic extravaganza that had been scheduled for Friday, after falling ill with what aides said was viral bronchitis.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Abortion Seen As Pivotal Issue In Senate Race
description: Abortion has emerged as a pivotal issue in the United States Senate race in New York, even though the two presumed candidates, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Hillary Rodham Clinton, have identical positions.

title: Rainbow Room Access
description: To the Editor:

title: Teachers in Chicago Schools Follow Script From Day 001
description: It was the 53rd day of the school year at Joyce Kilmer Elementary, a fact that was hardly lost on Christine Jabbari.

title: Former Drug Chief Says U.S. Brushed Aside Mexico's Role
description: During the five years that Thomas A. Constantine spent as the nation's top drug-enforcement official, he never sat down with President Clinton to discuss drug policy. He was never called to brief the president on a major enforcement issue. The phone never rang for a chat.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: David Baskin

title: Cage Couples Spry Play With Calming Influence
description: On Tuesday, Michael Cage loaded his weary, 37-year-old body onto a commercial flight in New Jersey and flew six hours to meet the Nets in Oakland. The 15-year veteran knew he would be activated from the injured list, but he had no intention of playing in the next night's game against the Golden State Warriors.

title: Radiation Ripples From Big Bang Illuminate Geometry of Universe
description: Like the great navigators who first sailed around the world, establishing its size and the curvature of its surface, astronomers have made new observations that show with startling directness the large-scale geometry of the universe and the total amount of matter and energy that it contains.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Desk Job by Day, Singing at Night

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Mirit Cohen

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: A Setback For Sondheim

title: BASF Says It May Sell or Exchange Its Pharmaceuticals Unit
description: BASF A.G., Europe's largest chemicals maker, said today that it was in talks with rival drug makers as it considered whether to sell its pharmaceuticals unit or exchange it for another company's pesticide division.

title: So Who Rhymed Bianca With Sanka?
description: Joan Kibric was crying, and so was Ethel Watt. Heck, even Herb Fields, tall, handsome Herb Fields, the sole remaining ''boy singer,'' was crying, weeping so hard he had to leave his seat.

title: A Southern Legacy and a New Spirit
description: You can't say it about many cities, but you can say it about this one: One man changed its destiny.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Nov. 12 about Biagio DiLieto, a former mayor of New Haven, included an erroneous educational reference from Who's Who in American Politics. He did not graduate from Yale Law School and did not have a law degree.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: John Wesley

title: Biggest Test for Mahathir May Come in Malay Backyard
description: ALOR SETAR, Malaysia  Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad's toughest fight in the general election Monday will most likely be here in his own backyard, where an Islamic opposition party has hundreds of thousands of supporters and where past elections have been decided by as few as 11 votes.

title: An 'Audition' For Coppola
description: Francis Ford Coppola says he hopes the DVD of his film ''Apocalypse Now,'' released this week by Paramount, makes a good impression. Not that the director feels in need of critical stroking, but he hopes the production work on the disc catches attention because it was performed by the DVD laboratory he has started at American Zoetrope, his film company in San Francisco.

title: Stars in the Off Broadway Galaxy
description: ACTING awards may be self-indulgent and ever so tacky. But as long as we're stuck with them, why shouldn't there be a high-powered set of them for Off Broadway? Within the theater industry, the Obies, administered by The Village Voice, have considerable prestige, and the Drama Desks, parceled out to actors and productions on Broadway and off, certainly merit mention in Playbill bios.

title: CONGRESS LEAVES BUSINESS LOBBIES ALMOST ALL SMILES
description: Democrats call it the do-nothing Congress, one that failed to come to grips with issues like gun control, campaign finance and Medicare coverage of prescription drugs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLSTEIN, EVA
description: PERLSTEIN-Eva. On November 20, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Mother of Howard and Helen. Grandmother of Michelle, Amy, Jason and Riva. Mother-inlaw of Vicki, and sister of Albert & the late Jesse. Memorial service was held on November 24, 1999, Palm Beach Gardens, FL.

title: A Shot-Blocking Tree Takes the Garden Court
description: Loren Woods was one tall tree at a college called Wake Forest. From the bottoms of his feet to the top of his head he measures 7 feet 1 inch, and he gets even loftier when he leaps and waves his long limbs to block shots or intimidate opponents. But Woods was not happy in two seasons at Wake Forest, and he was willing to miss a year of competition to leave for another school.

title: For Serenity
description: As is well known, the holiday season, which should raise the spirits, is often a trying time. So if you find yourself longing for a serene setting in which to reflect, here are a dozen places that may restore the spirit while they please the palate. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: To Train Caring Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Some Ghosts Worth Reviving

title: She's a Can't-Help-It Kind of Person
description: The characters in ''The Absolution of Willie Mae'' talk about money a lot. Willie Mae's man, Bubba, has married a rich white woman who has $11 million. Willie Mae's sister Minerva is married to a guy who makes $150,000 or so, which is why she stays with him. Bubba uses an immorally gained $265,000 to start a taxicab business (his wife's millions, apparently, aren't good enough for him). Somebody is mysteriously putting an extra $100 a month in Willie Mae's bank account. Now if only somebody would take a little of that and buy her a new sofa. Gmerice Carter's set makes good use of space, but the title character's house is a dump.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREITSTONE, JOSEPH
description: BREITSTONE-Joseph. Beloved husband of Frances. Loving father of Debra Mahoney, Peter and Dianne Breitstone, Stephen & Jill Breitstone. Adored grandfather of Anjali, J.B., Jason and Lauren. Services at ''Boulevard Riverside Chapels'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, today at 12:30 PM.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'The World of Donald Evans'

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: A Midsummer Night's Dream

title: Corrections
description: An article in the arts pages yesterday about the broadcaster and author Alistair Cooke misstated the year of his birth. It was 1908, not 1980.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENE, RICKY
description: LEVENE-Ricky. So dearly loved, so deeply missed, so much too soon. Our constant love. Mom and Your Family

title: Strange Can't Begin to Describe It; Fulani and Buchanan See an Upside to Political Marriage
description: One day soon, if all goes as planned, a woman who has campaigned time and again in Harlem for political office will do so again. But this time, Lenora Fulani, two-time presidential candidate, former standard-bearer of the now-defunct New Alliance Party, and perpetual thorn in the Democratic Party's side, will have company.

title: Blair and Chirac Want Europe to Have Rapid Reaction Capability : EU Force No Threat To NATO, Allies Say
description: LONDON  Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and President Jacques Chirac of France called Thursday for the creation of a European crisis intervention force, a historic step that they insisted would strengthen Europe's military capability and complement, rather than compete with, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Body of Woman, 74, Is Discovered on S.I.
description: The bound and gagged body of a 74-year-old woman was discovered in her bed on Staten Island yesterday after a friend went to her home to bring her Thanksgiving dinner and alerted the police, the authorities said.

title: Europeans Envisioning Strike Force Without U.S.
description: European leaders are now aiming to create within three years a rapid intervention force that could field 50,000 soldiers and 300 to 500 aircraft for up to a year in a future conflict like the one in Kosovo earlier this year.

title: Accounts
description: Blackshopping.com, San Francisco, owned by Netnoir Inc., to Prime Access, New York, as the first agency for the retail Web site aimed at black consumers. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERNOWSKI, MARY
description: CHERNOWSKI-Mary. On November 23, 1999. Beloved mother of Joseph F. Loving sister of Ann Woltcheck. Cherished grandmother of Tracie and Jennifer. Dear aunt of Ann and Joseph. Religious service at The Kodis Funeral Home, 63-06 Flushing Avenue, Maspeth, Friday, 8:00 PM. Funeral Saturday, 10:30 AM. Interment in Mount Olivet Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, DAVID
description: LEVINE-David. We shall miss you dear friend. Our close relationship throughout the years has given us much pleasure and many memories which we shall always treasure. You were the perfect example of a true friend. Terry and Seymour

title: The Walleye War; A Trade Dispute Roils the U.S.-Canadian Border
description: Just beyond Wolf Island, Donna Hanson was closing her fishing camp for the season, locking up tourist cabins before the ice reached across Lake of the Woods. With the ice, 14,652 islands turn into one vast winter wilderness empty but for wandering deer, moose and bears.

title: John McCain in the Crucible
description: I am not surprised by reports that Senator John McCain's political enemies have been spreading rumors that his famous temper is a sign of a broader ''instability'' caused by his imprisonment in Vietnam.

title: Military Survey Unfair
description: To the Editor:

title: After a Murder Trial, Amarillo Asks, 'Is This a Tolerant Place?'
description: While there are all sorts of teenage cliques in this Texas Panhandle city, it is the punks and the preps who have always collided.
