None of the insults ever escalated beyond fistfights, though, until one of the punks, Brian Deneke, was run over in a street brawl, killed by a prep in a Cadillac.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORD, MARY ELIOT
description: FORD-Mary Eliot. November 20, 1999. Teacher, scholar, loving wife of Joseph. Mother of John & Sara. Memorial service on December 4th, 3 PM, Saint Anne's Church, Bridgehampton, NY. Contributions to the Alzheimer's Association would be appreciated.

title: Metro Business; Alcoa Will Renew New York Presence
description: Alcoa has agreed to lease 51,000 square feet at the Lever House in Midtown Manhattan, giving the aluminum producer its first presence in New York City since the 1980's.

title: Police Dept. Taking a Harder Line on Misconduct
description: The New York City Police Department, long criticized as too lenient in punishing officers accused of misconduct, has toughened its internal discipline system, prosecuting and convicting more officers in departmental trials, department statistics show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANKIN, DAVID S.
description: MANKIN-David S. His promise, strength and courage will be remembered with pride and love. The face we no longer see with our eyes never leaves our hearts. Our hearts are with your soul. Your loving family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIRINSKY, KATHRYN ANN
description: ZIRINSKY-Kathryn Ann, 44, on November 24, 1999, after a courageous battle with colon cancer. Devoted wife of Robert. Adored Mom and best friend of Ralph, Elissa and Harry. Beloved daughter of Phyllis and Thomas Sinatra. Dear sister of Nina, Frank and Carla. A memorial service will be held next week, details to follow. No flowers or baskets, please. We request that all donations in memory of Kathryn be sent to the James F. Holland, M.D. Research Fund, Mount Sinai Medical Center-Development Office, 1 Gustave L. Levy Pl., N.Y., NY 10029.

title: The Terrors of Toyland: Collectors
description: Toy Story 2

title: Stung, House G.O.P. Seeks More Business Cash
description: Alarmed and embarrassed by the recent financial success of House Democrats, top fund-raisers for House Republicans issued an urgent appeal this week to business interests to increase their giving to Republican candidates and committees.

title: Ferguson's Suspension Sends the Jets Scrambling Again
description: The Jets began scrambling today to change part of their game plan, their defensive alignments and their special teams personnel in the wake of the suspension of nose tackle Jason Ferguson.

title: Years After Davidian Cult Fire, Legal Battles Gather Force
description: Six years after David Koresh's strange ministry of God and guns ended in flames at the Branch Davidians' compound near Waco, more questions than answers continue to rise out of the ashes.

title: Schroeder's Bailout of Holzmann Earns Little Praise From Skeptical Markets : Reform vs. Reality In Berlin and Tokyo
description: Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder's role in the bailout of a major German construction company gives him a populist victory of uncertain duration. But, more significantly, his gesture sustains a crisis of disbelief in the German economy that affects confidence everywhere else in Europe.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Team Prepares for Life Without Leetch
description: The Rangers have two choices now that they will be without their captain, Brian Leetch, for at least a month. They can crumble while they wait for his broken right arm to heal. Or some of their underproducing, well-paid veterans can try to turn the team around before Leetch returns.

title: Public Interests; Hillary's Rootlessness
description: New Yorkers regard themselves as the most interesting topic in the universe. Therefore, we were gratified to learn that the much-discussed U.S. Senate campaign here is actually going to be all about us, us, us.

title: Residential Real Estate; Low-Income Bronx Apartments Near Completion
description: Occupancy will begin in January at an apartment complex taking shape in the shadow of Yankee Stadium. The two buildings, with 252 apartments, represent one of the largest low-income rental housing projects erected in the South Bronx in recent years.

title: Playing Hard to Get for Car Thieves
description: AUTO theft is on the decline. Chalk it up to a booming economy, to a drop in overall crime rates, to improved security devices -- or to all three factors -- but the numbers are stark.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Gunter Brus

title: An Oasis of Peace in Somalia Seeks Freedom
description: It has been nearly nine years since the people of northwest Somalia gathered here to declare themselves separate from the chaos of the rest of their country. They created a government. They rebuilt their villages and businesses. A young veterinarian named Mohammed Nur Arale saw enough peace recently to invest in a luxury unknown in this town since 1988: a gas station with a pump that actually works.

title: A Flood of War Refugees From Angola Strains Namibia
description: With fighting by rebels and government forces intensifying along the southern edge of Angola, thousands living in the area, long an Angolan rebel stronghold, have fled across the river border in the last nine days and taken refuge outside the police station in this rural village.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 14.

description: Basilica Restored, but . . .

description: FOR CHILDREN

description: To the Editor:

title: Finding the Sweatshops
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain Won't Move to Block Attempt to Take Over NatWest
description: Britain said today that it would not block the Bank of Scotland's 22 billion [pounds] ($36 billion) hostile bid for National Westminster Bank on competition grounds, leaving it up to shareholders to decide whether Britain's third-largest bank will be taken over.

title: A New Fair And a New View On 'Boundaries'
description: You don't have to wait until the millennium for the 20th century to be reinvented. It's happening tomorrow. The International 20th-Century Arts Fair, which is at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue at 67th Street tomorrow through Wednesday, may be the first ''antiques'' fair with contemporary works of art and design. ''It's a psychological thing,'' said Brian Haughton, an organizer of the fair. ''As we go over the cusp of the next millennium, people suddenly see what was made in this century as antique.''

title: Atlanta's Traffic Jams
description: To the Editor:

title: Chilly, Wet Parade Rolls As Crowds Try to See It
description: At 6:30 yesterday morning, a Macy's official told her associates the news: the bad-weather front that was supposed to pass through had stalled. There would be sprinkles, downpours and only brief moments of no precipitation. The air for the 73rd Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade would feel frigid, despite temperatures in the mid-40's.

title: INSIDE ART
description: A New Auction For Old Masters

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBNER, FLORENCE VERONICA
description: DUBNER-Florence Veronica. A woman of singular conviction, a mother (and grandmother and great-grandmother) of singular devotion. Survived and mourned by a great many friends and a large, loving family, especially her children: Joseph, Mona, Marthe, Ann, Peter, David, Elizabeth and Stephen. Donations to: Caring Community Hospice (4281 North. Homer Avenue, Cortland, NY 13045) and Family Connections (156 Port Watson Street, Cortland, New York 13045).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROWLEY, BARBARA SHIELDS
description: CROWLEY-Barbara Shields. We miss you so and love you always. Roses, Susan and Shaun

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-26

title: The Microsoft Referee
description: Neither Microsoft nor the Justice Department appears ready to negotiate an out-of-court settlement of the government's antitrust charges. But Thomas Penfield Jackson, the trial judge whose initial ruling three weeks ago labeled Microsoft a bullying monopolist, wants a quick settlement anyway. Last week he made an artful move to get one, appointing one of the country's leading antitrust experts, Richard Posner, a federal appeals court judge, to serve as mediator for renewed settlement talks. Judge Posner has a rare qualification. He strikes fear in the hearts of both sides of this epic battle -- enough fear, perhaps, to compel them to compromise.

title: Three Women Mugged in Central Park Incidents
description: Women were mugged in Central Park yesterday and Wednesday, the police said last night, and in an unrelated attack at Rockefeller Center, a woman was sexually abused near the skating rink Wednesday night, the police said.

title: Louisiana Tech Pines for a Bowl
description: Here's a personal ad worth circling:

title: Political Memo; Clinton's 2 Star Students Remember Their Lessons, but Shun School Ties
description: The two most famous students of the Bill Clinton political school -- Hillary Rodham Clinton and Al Gore -- have finally graduated. But now that they are out on their own, they seem to be sticking to the same textbook.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Frank Stella

title: PATENTING LIFE: A special report.; Biological Products Raise Genetic Ownership Issues
description: For generations, tribes in the Amazon rain forest have used secretions from the skin of a frog to make poison blow darts. Now Abbott Laboratories is developing a painkiller modeled on the active chemical in the frog secretion that seems as effective as morphine but without damaging side effects.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Sarah Morris

title: Quake-Hit Assisi Basilica Restored, but the People Aren't
description: When a powerful earthquake ravaged the vaulted ceiling of the Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi two years ago, the damage to priceless 13th- and 14th-century frescos was so devastating that it overshadowed the loss of 11 lives and many thousands of homes.

title: Ernest Signorelli, 75, Republican Who Fought for Surrogate's Post
description: Ernest Leonard Signorelli, a maverick Republican who served Suffolk County as a judge for 35 years before retiring as its surrogate in 1995, died on Saturday at a nursing home in Center Moriches, N.Y. He was 75 and most recently lived in Manorville, N.Y., and St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: John Roloff

title: Corrections
description: A Reporter's Notebook article on Nov. 18 about President Clinton's visit to Turkey misstated the year the Hagia Sofia church in Istanbul, now a museum, was built. It was A.D. 532-537; A.D. 360 was the year a church was first built on the site.

title: A Passion for Doing Right That Went Horribly Wrong
description: If you were gay in the late 1970's and happened to live in San Francisco, the city (or at least the Castro) probably felt a lot like Camelot. Only nine years after Stonewall, the Greenwich Village uprising that gave birth to the gay rights movement, shame had turned into pride and lurking into strutting. Laws were being changed, as were attitudes, and you were at the center of it all. That's beautifully clear in the scene of an exuberant gay parade in ''Execution of Justice,'' with Harvey Milk campaigning in a convertible on a sunny day, accompanied by the sounds of the Village People singing ''Y.M.C.A.''

title: Australia Turns to X-Rays To Penetrate Smugglers' Lies
description: After decades of trying to seal its 22,000-mile coastline against Asian boat people, Australia is planning to add X-rays to its defenses against a new wave of people-smuggling, this time from the Middle East.

title: After Collapse, A Transfer Draws Inquiry
description: Investigators looking into the collapse of a building at a Brooklyn construction site on Tuesday, in which a worker died, are examining whether city officials overlooked problems at other projects by the same contractor after he complained to the Giuliani administration about building inspections, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDMAN, JUDITH
description: SEIDMAN-Judith, 87, on November 21. Beloved wife of Lloyd; mother of Elinor Berlin and David. Memorial service Sunday, November 28, 11 AM, Barnard Hall (Barnard College), Broadway and 116th, 3rd Floor, Sulzberger Parlor.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS WEEK 12
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: 2 Advertisers Change Agencies
description: Two big advertisers are changing agencies.

title: Security and Free Trade Pacts Under Discussion : Wary of Rivals, East Asia Weighs Closer Integration
description: MANILA  Wary of being marginalized as Europe and North America form powerful trading and negotiating blocs, East Asian countries are considering significant moves toward closer integration, including a giant free trade zone for the region, officials said Thursday.

title: A Battery That Dies on Demand
description: CAR won't start? If a thief is trying to drive it away, that's not a bad thing. A new battery from Sears, the DieHard Security, includes a built-in immobolizer. The company says it provides an extra measure of theft protection by allowing a driver to shut down the electrical system of a car when it is parked.

title: Real Risks of PCB's
description: To the Editor:

title: Fifteen questions about Madison Avenue that could change your life (or maybe not).
description: TYPICALLY around holidays, this column presents a feature known as ''20 Questions,'' examining the foibles of advertising, marketing and the media. But rather than 20 questions, the focus these days has been on 15 questions, as in the number of queries contestants must answer correctly to win the grand prize on the phenomenally successful ABC game show, ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire.''

title: For the Ears Of Adults
description: It takes Randy Newman just 2 minutes 43 seconds to deliver ''The World Isn't Fair,'' the year's most searching song about the state of the Union on the edge of the millennium, from his recent album, ''Bad Love.'' Carrying on a one-sided conversation with Karl Marx, the singer, in his most insinuating pseudo-New Orleans drawl, regales the dead philosopher with a personal anecdote about attending a private-school orientation at which the trophy wives and mothers were as beautiful as princesses, and their husbands (including himself) looked like frogs.

title: Johnson Says He'll Be Out For 2 Weeks
description: When Larry Johnson sat down for a cup of coffee this morning, the pain in his back shot down into his legs. And after he sat out another Knicks practice today, Johnson indicated that the pain of performing that simple task could mean that his return to the court is still a ways off.

title: Young Artists Liven Up 3 Broadway Newsstands
description: Is there art on Broadway? A newsstand on the southwest corner of Broadway and 44th Street is proof that there is.

title: The Old Coach Sees the Old Cowboys
description: Jimmy Johnson looked up and through the Texas Stadium roof. Yes, the hole was still there. He looked left and right saw 64,328 fans who had come to watch him stroll these sidelines once again and to view his new team, the Miami Dolphins. He looked across the field and recognized the blue and white uniforms, the blue star, the Dallas Cowboys. The team he had coached for five seasons.

title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: JOHN LEWIS: ''Evolution'' (Atlantic). There are some statements that can't be made in youth, and ''Evolution,'' the new solo piano album from John Lewis, the former Modern Jazz Quartet pianist, is one of them. ''Evolution,'' programmed with jazz standards and some of Mr. Lewis's compositions, captures the burned-off essence of his style -- which is full of straightforward elements, major harmonies and two-note chords -- in a context of shifting rhythm. The album was recorded in a concert hall without an audience, a production technique that favors his light touch and his even legato. It's a good album for the stillness of winter.

title: Nigeria's Clean Broom
description: Nigeria is Africa's most populous country, and potentially one of its most prosperous. But for decades, a deeply rooted culture of corruption has undermined Nigeria's economy, impoverished its people and tarnished its international reputation. It has also helped make Nigeria one of the world's leading centers of drug smuggling, including much of the narcotics that reach the United States.

title: Turkish Court Upholds Death Sentence for Kurdish Rebel Leader
description: A Turkish appeals court today upheld the death sentence given to the imprisoned Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan, but whether the sentence will be carried out remained highly uncertain.

title: George A. Stinson, 84, Dies; Lawyer and Steel C.E.O.
description: George Arthur Stinson, who managed two highly successful careers as a tax lawyer on Wall Street and as a steel magnate in Pittsburgh, died on Nov. 19 at his home in Tryon, N.C., where he had retired in 1983. He was 84.

title: Sports of The Times; Marshall Gets Little Consideration
description: OF COURSE it would seem unfair, unkind and rather rotten, too. Here is Marshall University, that doughty college located in Huntington, in the Appalachian foothills of West Virginia, whose Thundering Herd football team is undefeated, at 10-0. It is one of only three Division I-A teams to be unbeaten, and yet it is given the back of the pollsters' hand, 11th in two of the most important polls, 12th in the other.

title: After Open Enrollment: CUNY's New World
description: To the Editor:

title: The S.E.C. Tries to Make Companies Take Smaller Baths
description: HERE was a time when the accounting police worried about companies that tried to avoid reporting losses. Now the cops are trying to keep companies from taking excessive write-downs.

title: Mentally Ill And Adrift On the Street
description: BREATHES the New Yorker whose thoughts and prayers are not with Nicole Barrett this holiday season?

title: Morgan Stanley Sets Price on Japanese Debt
description: The Tokyo office of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter priced the first set of bonds linked to nonperforming Japanese real estate loans today, paving the way for what may be a flood of deals aimed at clearing away the mountain of bad debt on the balance sheets of Japanese banks and financial institutions.

title: After Open Enrollment: CUNY's New World
description: To the Editor:

title: After a Two-Week Slide, Lions Find a Way to Win
description: The Detroit Lions had spent the last two weeks trying to reclaim their mojo. It was lost somewhere in the Arizona desert when Coach Bobby Ross made one of those inexplicable calls, going for a 2-point conversion against the Cardinals when he should have kicked the extra point. That loss was followed by a loss to Green Bay last week in which safety Mark Carrier illegally used his head as a weapon, leading to his suspension for today's game.

title: Satellite TV Is Poised for New Growth
description: With the holiday race for the consumer's dollar already under way, the satellite television industry is still poised anxiously at the gate. The starting gun for a marketing push that could put its pizza-size dishes under hundreds of thousands of Christmas trees this year sits on President Clinton's desk.

title: Utility Ousts 5 in Chicago After Failures Last Summer
description: Trying to restore confidence after a series of embarrassing power failures here last summer, Commonwealth Edison asked for the resignations of five more executives and middle managers this week.

title: Bulldogs Win It On Late Field Goal
description: MISSISSIPPI STATE 23 MISSISSIPPI 20

title: Yielding to Social Sham: The Sin in Ibsen's Creed
description: ''Ghosts'' has this going for it: anyone who has absorbed it never again has to wonder what Ibsen means. This is the heart of the religion, delivered in a two-hour sermon of Stygian darkness. And the production at the Century Center for the Performing Arts, part of a series presenting all of Ibsen, aims at purity. J. C. Compton, founder of the center, directs, and she has enlisted as dramaturge the president of the Ibsen Society of America, Joan Templeton.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend, including special performances for the Thanksgiving holiday. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Philadelphia Journal; Jobs for the Troubled And a Second Chance
description: Gary Ackerman was making sandwiches at the Back Home Cafe with his usual devotion. He neatly stacked thick slices of fresh roast beef, ham and turkey between rolls lined with lettuce, and spooned up mounds of tuna salad made with broccoli and toasted almonds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUMPOWSKY, MARCIA F.
description: TUMPOWSKY-Marcia F. Beloved wife of Roy. Loving mother of Paul & Ronald. A devoted mother and teacher. She'll be missed by her family, friends and students. Funeral service to be held 10AM Friday, November 26 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Injury Forces Retirement of the Speed King Artax
description: On the morning he was scheduled to enter tomorrow's Cigar Mile for a final shot at winning the title Horse of the Year, the sprinter Artax was suddenly retired yesterday after he was found to have torn the suspensory ligament in his left foreleg.

title: After Open Enrollment: CUNY's New World
description: To the Editor:

title: A Taste of Velazquez Proves a Banquet
description: ON the principle that there are no small shows, only small artists, the six paintings brought together for ''Velazquez in New York Museums'' at the Frick Collection add up to a very big show indeed.

title: Over 250 Are Lost After Chinese Ferry Burns in Stormy Sea
description: At least 118 people are dead and 172 are missing after a ferry burned and broke apart in frigid, raging seas off China's northeastern coast on Wednesday night.

title: Canadian Index at Record High On Surging Technology Shares
description: Canada's benchmark stock index rose to a record yesterday, its first in more than a year and a half, powered by a monthlong surge in technology stocks.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; Medical Sleuths Stalk One of History's Great Killers
description: FLUThe Story of the Great Influenza Pandemic of 1918 and the Search for the Virus That Caused ItBy Gina KolataIllustrated. 330 pages. Farrar, Straus and Giroux. $25.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Otto Fried

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, SIDNEY
description: GROSS-Sidney. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and friend. We give thanks for the love and goodness you left us. You are in our hearts and memories always. Vividly alive to us, no matter the years that pass.

title: Patrolling the Beat at the Union Office Now
description: THE plexiglass shield was over there, and this is the famous locked door,'' said Police Officer Patrick J. Lynch, pointing. The new president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association turned the brass handle of the door lock that used to bar uniformed officers from their union leaders, who were ensconced in a luxe Manhattan office suite at 40 Fulton Street with breathtaking river views.

title: Fassel's Mother Dies, and Giants Rally Around Coach
description: Dorothy Fassel, the 76-year-old mother of Giants Coach Jim Fassel, died Wednesday night at her home in Scottsdale, Ariz. She had been in declining health for several months, a condition originally brought on by kidney problems.

title: Tokyo Journal; Be Tall and Chic as You Wobble to the Orthopedist
description: A few weeks ago, Tomomi Okawa, a 25-year-old office clerk, was driving home from shopping when she crashed into a concrete pole, killing a friend who was riding in the passenger seat.

title: British M.B.A. Courses Shake Up Old School
description: Li Lingping from Beijing and Cory Elysa Cohen from New York could hardly represent more disparate societies. Where Ms. Li, 31, lists ballroom dancing and discussion groups as leisure time activities, Ms. Cohen, 24, prefers kick-boxing and sports cars.

title: Bus Driver Killed in Crash With Fire Truck in Brooklyn
description: A Fire Department ladder truck racing through the rain to a fire at a Brooklyn house ran a red light and collided with a city bus yesterday, killing the bus driver and injuring nine passengers and firefighters, police and fire officials said.

title: An Old Town Grows
description: To the Editor:

title: Xavier Defeats Old Rival
description: Xavier beat Fordham Prep, 37-16, yesterday in the 76th meeting of New York's oldest Thanksgiving Day football rivals.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: When they make the movie, the title will be ''A Cheese Cart Grows in Brooklyn.'' In a former life, Crisci's dished out pasta and red sauce to a neighborhood crowd in Southside. The name remains the same, and an oval neon sign still hangs out front, but everything else has changed. The new Crisci's is aiming high, with Manhattan ambitions and Manhattan prices, most visibly in the $75 tasting menu.

title: California Gasoline Prices Are a Focus for Regulators
description: Californians paid an average of about 26 cents more for a gallon of gasoline than other Americans in the first eight months of this year, according to a report released this week by the state's attorney general. And those high prices have become a focal point as federal and most state regulators prepare to approve the merger of Exxon and Mobil and continue to debate the acquisition of the Atlantic Richfield Company by BP Amoco.

title: Delta Backs Off Air Fare Increase
description: Delta Air Lines Inc., the third-largest American airline, dropped its 3 percent increase for leisure and business fares today, raising the possibility that three rivals also might have to roll back the higher prices, an Internet site that tracks fares said.

title: BEASLEY BROADCAST IS PLANNING PUBLIC OFFERING
description: Beasley Broadcast Group Inc., a family-run company in Naples, Fla., that owns and operates radio stations, will seek to raise as much as $150 million through an initial public offering, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. After completing pending acquisitions in Atlanta and Augusta, Ga., Beasley will own and operate 32 stations, including 21 FM and 11 AM, in seven markets in the eastern United States. Nine of the stations are in three of the nation's top 12 radio markets: Atlanta, Philadelphia and Miami.

title: Talk of Court Move From Hartford Draws Complaints of Favoritism
description: Good things have been happening lately in Waterbury, population 108,000, the hometown of Gov. John G. Rowland and the place he often calls ''the center of the universe.''

title: Racing Is Canceled After Two Races
description: A week of wet weather forced Aqueduct to cancel its racing program after the second race yesterday when the jockeys complained that the track was uneven and officials agreed that it was too dangerous to continue.

title: A Quick Trip to a Bank Machine Becomes a Night of Incarceration
description: As automated teller machine vestibules go, the one at the Commerce Bank on Royal Road here is awfully nice, measuring a spacious 14 feet by 16 feet, with gleaming black tiles surrounding a rectangle of carpet and a view onto a colonnaded porch.

title: World Briefing
description: THE AMERICAS

title: Microsoft on the Defense, Again
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINA SIGNS PACT WITH CANADA
description: China signed a new trade agreement with Canada that is much like the pact reached last month between China and the United States. Tariffs on Canadian imports will be lowered to an average of 5.2 percent from 12.5 percent over the next two and a half years. The agreement, signed in Toronto, also widens the range of products and services that can be sold in China and permits Canadian companies to make direct investments in areas like telecommunications and financial services. Similar agreements are being negotiated with other countries to ensure China's entry into the World Trade Organization. China is Canada's fourth-largest trading partner and last year bought $1.7 billion worth of Canadian goods, mainly agricultural commodities and potash.

title: EXXON AND MOBIL EXPECTED TO GET MERGER APPROVAL
description: After a year of review, antitrust officials at the Federal Trade Commission have notified the states that next week they intend to recommend the approval of Exxon's $81 billion acquisition of Mobil, state officials said today. The move came after the companies agreed to the largest divestiture in the commission's history.

title: 3 Die as Plane Plows Into Newark Neighborhood
description: A private plane carrying a Maryland family home after Thanksgiving in New York crashed in Newark yesterday, killing all three on board and injuring 25 others as it plowed along a street, struck buildings and cars and broke into flaming debris that set off fires, explosions and chaos in a neighborhood.

title: SHARES OF ENLIGHTEN SOFTWARE HAVE SURGED THIS MONTH
description: Enlighten Software Solutions Inc., a maker of software to manage networks of computers on various operating systems, almost tripled after it began selling a Linux-compatible product last week. Enlighten shares rose $8.75 yesterday, to $12.75, as 6.1 million shares changed hands in a half-day session, about 45 times the three-month average. The stock was at $3.125 on Nov. 15, a day before the company announced the system-management program for Linux, the operating system that competes with the Microsoft Windows. Enlighten's software creates a graphical tool bar that allows a user to manage computers on a network, even if they are running on different operating systems.

title: Doctors' Life Experience
description: To the Editor:

title: A Deft Maestro Who Got Ulster To Harmonize
description: The grim, unyielding men from the remote poles of Ulster politics were still getting adjusted to being seated side by side around a dining room table when their host hit them with another novelty.

title: Sports of The Times; Violence During Play, Not After It
description: EARLIER this week the National Football League, which oversees the most violent sport in America, placed throat slashing on its list of banned gestures. So players can't shimmy, can't rip their helmets off and can't otherwise indulge in extended celebrations.

title: Study Details Sacrifices In Caring for Elderly Kin
description: A small study that surveyed the economic cost to individuals who provide informal care for elderly relatives has found that working caregivers sacrifice substantial wages and benefits by passing up promotions, training and transfers, and taking extended time off from their jobs to fulfill their family responsibilities.

title: Patten Gets Expanded Role In the Giants' New Air Show
description: It is not just the quarterback who will be new for the Giants on Sunday against the Arizona Cardinals. The receiving corps will have a new look, too.

title: On Ground, Close Calls And a Scene of Carnage
description: In a flash, a Friday morning's routine became a terror of fire, whizzing pieces of airplane, flying shards of glass, falling chunks of ceiling plaster and dangling electrical wires shooting sparks.

title: Euro Declines to Record Lows Against Dollar, Pound and Yen
description: Defying predictions of accelerated growth in Europe, Europe's single currency sank to record lows today against the American dollar, the British pound and the Japanese yen.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SUSSMAN, JACK R.
description: SUSSMAN-Jack R.. Today is your birthday, always remembered with love. Bette S

title: Hope Fades For the 280 Lost on Ferry Off China Port
description: Rescue workers said today that it was unlikely that they would find any more survivors from a ferry carrying more than 300 people that burned and sank Wednesday night in rough, icy waters near Yantai, in the northeast.

title: Barkley Is Getting A Harsh Reminder
description: Before the Scottie-Charles reunion last night, it was Sir Charles versus the Admiral, circa 1993, on NBA.com TV in the Houston Rockets' locker room.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLMAN, SALLY (NEE REBHUN)
description: COLMAN-Sally (nee Rebhun). On Nov. 24, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Lewis B. Dearest mother of Judith, Naomi and George. Blessed grandmother and great grandmother. Service on Sunday, November 28, 12PM at I.J. Morris, Hempstead, NY. (516-486-2500).

title: ELCOM SHARES INCREASE 88% AFTER DEAL WITH VISA
description: Shares of Elcom International Inc. jumped 88 percent yesterday after the business software maker teamed with Visa International Inc., the credit card association, to offer online-commerce software. Elcom soared $7 15/16 to $15 15/16, in trading of 11.8 million shares, making it the sixth-most active United States stock. That was the highest close in nearly four years. Elcom's software that lets companies procure supplies through the Internet will be combined with Visa's system for commercial electronic payments and data delivery to automate the traditional paper-based purchasing process.

title: A Woman Is Found in Flames On a No. 2 Train in the Bronx
description: A New York transit worker and several passengers frantically doused flames on the clothing of a woman on a southbound No. 2 train in the Bronx early yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Bugs? Sheep's Lungs? If That's What You Eat, That's Who You Are
description: Food: A Culinary History

title: Busy Season Begins for Merchants
description: Ed and Kathy Blasco kicked off their holiday shopping today the same way they have for the last 15 years: they headed for the Country Club Plaza in Kansas City. The Blascos were set to enjoy the balmy weather and the Christmas songs being played by a live band, but they did not plan to make many purchases.

title: Borrowing From All Over And Making It Mexican
description: The son jarocho is a Mexican traditional style driven by frenetic strumming and a foot-stamping beat. It doesn't usually generate a mosh pit unless it's played by Cafe Tacuba, the band from Mexico City that performed at Irving Plaza on Monday night.

title: Wiltz's Task: Keep Pressure On Manning
description: Jason Wiltz, a rookie defensive lineman, was watching television Wednesday night when he learned that his Jets career was about to take a major turn.

title: Calvin Dodd MacCracken, 79, Inventor Who Held 80 Patents
description: Calvin Dodd MacCracken, an inventor and founder of his own creative engineering firm in Englewood, N.J., died Nov. 10 at Kendall at Hanover, a retirement community in New Hampshire. A former resident of Englewood, he was 79 and lived in Hanover and West Cornwall, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, RITA
description: SNYDER-Rita. Of Forest Hills Gardens, NY. Beloved wife of Walter for 63 years. Loving mother of Abyna Zimmerman & mother-inlaw of Mel Zimmerman. Devoted grandmother of Matthew. Loving sister of Anne Wolfe, Gerard Wolfe and Abyna Jaffe. Cherished aunt to many nieces and nephews. Reposing at Fox Funeral Home, Inc. corner Ascan Ave. and Metropolitan Ave, Forest Hills, Sunday 25 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Monday, November 29, at 10:15 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Rules of the Crossword Pantheon
description: To my chagrin, I've concluded that my prospects for achieving immortality are remote: My name does not fit easily into crossword puzzles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCONNELL, JAMES F.
description: McCONNELL-James F.. Of Huntington Station, NY, died suddenly on November 24, 1999. Recently retired from Flushing Savings Bank. Beloved husband of Joanne. Loving father of Mary Jo McCoy and Veronica Polk. Dear son of Veronica and the late James A. Caring brother of Edward, Therese McConeghy and the late Veronica. Cherished grandfather of Megan. Visitation 2-5 and 6-9 PM Sunday at the A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, Inc., 1380 New York Avenue, Huntington Station. Mass of Christian burial at 9:45 AM Monday at St. Elizabeth R.C. Church, 175 Wolf Hill Road, Melville, NY. Donations may be made to Our Lady of Sorrows Grammar School, C/O Flushing Savings Bank, 144-51 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, New York 11354.

title: Copland as a Stylistic Explorer Veering Off the Map
description: The Completely Copland festival at the New York Philharmonic began on Wednesday night with the seldom-heard Symphonic Ode, a brassy, restless blast of a piece that served as a rebuke to those who think of Copland as a composer of wistfully tonal, accessible Americana.

title: INSIDE
description: A Basilica's Rebirth

title: Early Version Of 'Gatsby' Gets a Chance Of Its Own
description: To Prof. James L. W. West III, '' 'Ulysses' is the great novel that no one has ever read, and 'The Great Gatsby' is the great novel that everyone has.''

title: Osgood Journal; A Couple's Million Thanks, Times 23
description: In an age of multibillion-dollar buyouts and nine-digit lottery jackpots, $23 million might not seem like a fortune anymore. But to this one-stoplight southern Indiana town, whose annual operating budget hovers around $300,000, it's enough to make a huge difference.

title: At National Championships, Winning a Unique Double
description: A unique double was achieved here Thursday night by Jill Meyers of Santa Monica, Calif., at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall National Championships. She won the Blue Ribbon Pairs title with John Mohan of St. Croix, V.I., becoming only the second woman to win that title in its 37-year history. And earlier in the week she won the Women's Board-a-Match Teams.

title: COLD WAR WITHOUT END
description: Long after Communism has faded, the battle over moles and spies and smears goes on, but in a different arena: the personal instead of the political. A report by Jacob Weisberg in The Times Magazine.

title: When a Quake Strengthens a Basilica
description: Seconds after the devastating earthquake of September 1997 rocked large parts of central Italy, the Rev. Vincenzo Fortunato surveyed the nave of the upper church of the Basilica of St. Francis in Assisi. The ground around him was strewn with large chunks of its vaulted ceiling and its frescoes attributed to Giotto and Cimabue. ''I was afraid the entire ceiling had collapsed, there was so much dust everywhere,'' he recalled. ''I thought things were a lot worse, that it was all over.''

title: Sega Announces Overhaul As Losses Exceed Forecast
description: Sega Enterprises, the beleaguered video game company, committed itself today to a radical reorientation of its business aimed at harnessing the power of the Internet. Sega also said its losses in the first half of the fiscal year were larger than had been expected.

title: Arizona's 'Cats Prove Too Tough for Kentucky's
description: In an off-Broadway production of ''Cats'' last night, the Wildcats of Arizona defeated the Wildcats of Kentucky, 63-51, in the championship game of the Preseason National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden. Assuming the starring roles for eighth-ranked Arizona were the two newest members of the cast, Gilbert Arenas and Jason Gardner. The venue was appropriate for their surnames. The people who run it call the Garden the ''world's most famous arena.''

title: Spending the Tobacco Money
description: Sometime next month, the State of New York should be getting its first installment of a $25 billion legal settlement from the tobacco industry. After passing along almost half of the money to local governments, the State Legislature must decide how to use the rest. Since the payments amount to compensation for the sickness and health costs caused by tobacco products, this windfall should be used to combat smoking and to improve the health care of New Yorkers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KILBERG, BETTY JUNE
description: KILBERG-Betty June. On Nov. 25, 1999. Beloved mother of Charlene, Mel and Aaron. Dear sister of Kenny and Luke. Survived by six grandchildren. Family to receive friends at Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 61-40 Woodhaven Blvd, Rego Park, Sunday from 3-6 PM. Religious service, Monday, 11 AM, followed by interment at Mount Ararat Cemetery.

title: Strike by Musicians Forces 'Nutcracker' To Dance to a Tape
description: The Christmas season began yesterday not on a sour note exactly, but on a recorded one, when labor negotiations between the New York City Ballet and the musicians who play in its orchestra hit a snag last night just before the curtain went up on the first holiday performance of ''The Nutcracker.'' The result was that the strike declared by the musicians on Tuesday continued and ''The Nutcracker'' had to be performed to taped music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOVACS, JOHN J.
description: KOVACS-John J.. Of Amston, CT, died peacefully on Wednesday, November 24, at age 91, at the Marlborough Health Care Center, Marlborough, CT. He was born in Spuyten Duyvil in the Bronx, NY and was formerly of Point Pleasant Beach, NJ. His funeral service will be Tuesday at 11:30AM at St. Francis of Assisi Chapel at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. His family will receive friends at the Potter Funeral Home, 456 Jackson St. (Rte 195), Willimantic on Monday from 6:00 to 8:00PM. Contributions to a charity of the donor's choice.

title: Dispute Over a Mosque
description: To the Editor:

title: Early Version of 'Gatsby' Gets a Chance of it's Own; She Loves Him, She Loves Him Not
description: Here, in the order in which they were composed, are three versions of the passage in The Great Gatsby in which Jay Gatsby makes his famous remark about Daisy's voice. The narrator, Nick Carraway, and Tom Buchanan, Daisy's husband, are standing with Gatsby in the driveway outside the Buchanans' house in East Egg as the characters gather their belongings for a drive into Manhattan. JAMES L. W. WEST III

title: Political Memo; Levity the Soul Of Bush, a Puck Among the Pols
description: As George W. Bush loped through the headquarters of the Timberland Company here, he might have been any candidate in the hunt for votes, any pol on the path toward the presidency. He tirelessly shook hands, dutifully took questions and let a multitude of promises bloom.

title: WORLDWIDE SPORTS AGREES TO PURCHASE OF BOLLE
description: Worldwide Sports and Recreation Inc., a closely held maker of binoculars and telescopes based in Kansas City, Kan., agreed to buy Bolle Inc. for $85 million in cash and debt, adding sunglasses and ski goggles to its product lineup. The cash part of the offer totals about $37.2 million, or $5.25 a share, 14 percent more than Bolle's closing price Wednesday and 62 percent more than its price two weeks ago when the bid was first disclosed. Bolle, based in Rye, N.Y., sells eyewear designed for athletes under its own and other names that is priced as high as $180.

title: A Flawed Drug Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyers for Homeless Seeking To Block New Rules on Shelters
description: The Legal Aid Society is asking court officials for ''emergency intervention'' next week to stop the city from beginning to enforce state regulations that make work a condition of shelter and threatening foster care placement for children from families that are expelled.

title: A Landlord's Lament
description: I was sitting in a small apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. An engineer, a man I had known for all of 90 seconds, faced me on a sofa, telling me the story of his life. His marriage, he said, was breaking up. That's why he needed me to rent him this apartment.

title: Tiny Maker of Modem Part Has Wild Surge in Its Stock
description: The Ariel Corporation, a technology company that was forced only last month to renegotiate its debts, rose more than ninefold this week after it announced that it would begin selling a product to compete with offerings from the much larger Cisco Systems and Lucent Technologies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRENFELD, IRVING., DR.
description: EHRENFELD-Irving., Dr.. Husband of Anne. Father of Ellen E. Mintzer and Howard Ehrenfeld. Brother of Mathilda Budner. Grandfather of Mara E. Mintzer. Father-in-law of Barry Mintzer. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mount Vernon, NY, Sunday at 1:30 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CAPUTO, THOMAS
description: CAPUTO-Thomas. Gone one year. You are in our hearts forever. Kuntzman Family

title: 5 Powers at U.N. Still Split on Iraq Arms Inspection
description: Envoys of the five major powers at the United Nations ended several weeks of talks yesterday without agreeing on how to restart arms inspections in Iraq, diplomats said.

title: In a Mismatch, Connecticut Dominates Old Dominion
description: Having struggled to beat an unheralded Kentucky team on Wednesday, the top-ranked University of Connecticut women's basketball team appeared to face a far more daunting task when it met 14th-ranked Old Dominion today in the final of the Coaches vs. Cancer Challenge at the Hartford Civic Center.

title: Microsoft on the Defense, Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft on the Defense, Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The listing of lottery numbers yesterday misstated the results of the Connecticut Play 4 and the Connecticut Cash 5 in some copies. The numbers for the Play 4 were 9210; for the Cash 5 they were 5, 13, 19, 27 and 31.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAKE, MURRAY
description: DRAKE-Murray. Survived by beloved wife of 56 years, Ruth; loving father of Robert and Neil and daughter-in-law Paula Drake; cherished grandson Adam; brothers Sidney (Barbara), Stanley (Arlene). Funeral will be held Sunday, 10AM, Riverside Chapel, Great Neck, NY. Burial New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, N.Y.

title: Op-Art
BRAZILIAN JOBLESSNESS RISES
description: Brazil's unemployment rate increased unexpectedly in October to 8.2 percent from 8 percent a month earlier. The data collected in Brazil's six largest cities suggest that the central bank's strategy of halting a gradual decline in interest rates is stifling an incipient economic recovery. The country's unemployment problems have been compounded by difficulties in the auto industry, which depends on lower interest rates to finance consumer car sales. Simon Romero

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHMAN, DORIS
description: FISCHMAN-Doris., age 99, died on November 23rd. Wife of Irving Fischman. Mother of Naomi, Ethel, and Harlow (Ken). Grandmother, great-grandmother and great-great-grandmother. An extraordinary woman. You were the guiding star around which our universes spun. Burial Sunday, November 28, 11:00 AM, Mount Eden Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: RED HAT STOCK CLIMBS ON GROWING DEMAND FOR LINUX
description: Red Hat Inc., developer of a free computer operating system that competes with Microsoft Corporation's Windows, surged 26 percent on enthusiasm for the increasing use of its Linux software. Shares surged $44.5625, to $213.505. The stock rose 18 percent Wednesday. It has increased more than fifteenfold since Red Hat sold shares to the public in August, giving it a market value of $14.7 billion. Red Hat sells a commercial version of Linux, which runs powerful corporate computers, and charges for additional services and technical support. Shares of the company, based in Durham, N.C., have doubled since Nov. 8 after a judge declared Microsoft a monopoly.

title: 45 Arrested in a Protest Against Capitalism
description: Four days before the World Trade Organization is to convene in Seattle to lay the groundwork for a global round of trade negotiations, about 400 young anti-capitalists held a roving protest in Manhattan yesterday afternoon that blocked traffic and resulted in 45 arrests.

title: Is Medical Charity Exportable?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hong Kong Bounces Back, But Faces New Challenges
description: In a report that made the Asian crisis seem like a distant memory, Hong Kong said today that its economy grew 4.5 percent in the third quarter of this year. The government also upgraded its forecast of growth for the full year to 1.8 percent from 0.5 percent.

title: Homeless Man Is Accused of Killing S.I. Woman
description: A homeless man who said he had found an elderly friend dead in her Staten Island home when he brought her a Thanksgiving meal on Thursday was charged yesterday with murder, the police said.

title: Personal Incomes in October Had Largest Rise Since 1994
description: Personal incomes in October rose at the fastest pace in five and a half years, bolstering consumer spending and paving the way for what may be the strongest holiday shopping season this decade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'DONNELL, FRANK X., JR.
description: O'DONNELL-Frank X., Jr.. died in his ninetieth year on Monday, November 22, 1999 at home in Atlanta, GA. Beloved husband of the late Margaret Myers O'Donnell, father of Frank X. O'Donnell III of Atlanta and Carolyn O'Donnell Consor of New York City, he is also survived by seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Born in New York City on January 15, 1910 to the late Frank X. and Helen Gallagher O'Donnell, Mr. O'Donnell was raised in New York, graduated from Fordham University (1933) and Fordham Law School (1936) where he served on the Law Review. He had been a partner at the New York law firm of Burke and Burke, which he joined in the 1940s and retired from in 1976. When first married in 1936, he and Mrs. O'Donnell lived in New York City, moved to Larchmont, NY in 1942, retired to Albuquerque, NM in 1976, and finally moved to Atlanta, in 1995. He and his wife had been avid sailors at the Larchmont Yacht Club from 1949 until thier move to Albuquerque. Mr. O'Donnell was very active in the Community Chest and politics in Westchester and subsequently in Alubquerque, where he served as president of the Albuquerque chapter of the Service Core of Retired Executives (SCORE). A private funeral service was held on Friday, November 26th at the Church of St. Thomas More in Decatur, GA. In lieu of flowers, donations be made in his memory to Fordham University, Development Office, 30 W. 60th St, New York, NY 10023.

title: Critic of War in Vietnam Is Now Praising Johnson
description: Thirty-six years ago this week, John F. Kennedy was killed by a sniper's bullet in Dallas, and Lyndon B. Johnson succeeded at once to the presidency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENNON, KATHERINE M.
description: LENNON-Katherine M.. Age 87, died November 25, 1999 in Albany, NY. Lifelong resident of NYC, she was the daughter of the late Martin and Mary O'Dea Lennon, and sister of the late Roger T. Lennon. Miss Lennon was employed for more than 30 years at Coats and Clark Mfg. Co. as secretary to the president. She was a lifelong communicant of Saint Brendan's Parish in the Bronx, and the first woman to be elected to its Board of Trustees. Aunt of Roger Lennon of Warwick, NY, Brendan Lennon of Briarcliff Manor, Peter Lennon of Fishkill, Terence Lennon of Briarcliff Manor, Michael Lennon of Ossining, Kevin Lennon of Ossining, Alice Brett of Stratford, CT and Eleanor Peterson of Latham, NY. Also survived by several grandnieces, grandnephews and cousins. Funeral services from the McKeon Funeral Home, 3129 Perry Ave., (at 204 St.), Bronx. Friends may call Sunday from 2:00-5:00 PM and Monday morning from 9:30 with a Mass of Crhistian Burial 10:00 AM at the Church of Saint Brendan. Interment is in Calvary Cemetery, Queens, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACHLES, EDITH
description: MACHLES-Edith., 99. Beloved mother of Gail (Henry) Abrams & Myrna (Andre) Block. Devoted wife of the late Morris. Grandmother of 5 & great-grandmother of seven. Services at 12 PM on Sunday, November 28, 1999 at the Westchester Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Federal Budgets, Both Ways
description: With tempers still sore from their recent federal budget battles, Congress and the White House are quietly preparing for the next fight. Both Republicans and Democrats are offering a split personality to voters, proclaiming a love for fiscal discipline and also for calculated spending increases in defense, education, health programs and financing for research. The latest economic projections suggest that both parties will be able to continue avoiding hard choices. If the year finishes up in robust economic health, federal revenues ought to be plentiful enough for Congress and the White House to save some money and pay for targeted programs at the same time. The election may also prove that voters like having it both ways.

title: Scottish Bank Raises Offer For NatWest
description: Hoping to deter a rival offer, the Bank of Scotland increased its hostile bid for National Westminster Bank to $41.3 billion today as it tries to acquire an institution twice its size to create Britain's second-largest bank.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALFUS, MAURICE
description: ALFUS-Maurice. Beloved father of Phillip, cherished brother to Helen & uncle to Jacques and Liane. An admired colleague to those at the DBC and respected member of Honors. A life well lived, a fighter who always had time to listen. Funeral services to be held at Riverside Memorial, 10:45 A.M., Sunday, November 28, 1999.

title: INTERNET ACCESS EXPANDED
description: In a move that advances the plans of companies like the Microsoft Corporation and Organizacaoes Globo, Brazil's government will allow pay-television providers to provide Internet access. The authorization is likely to shake up Brazil's fast-growing Internet industry. Microsoft was one of the first foreign companies to make a commitment in Brazil's high-speed Internet market by investing $126 million in a subsidiary of Globo.

title: An Approval for a Coronary Drug Device
description: Biocompatibles International P.L.C., a medical products maker, said today that the European Union had approved its coated cardiac device intended to deliver drugs directly into coronary arteries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, CHARLES ''CHARLIE'' A.
description: MARTIN-Charles ''Charlie'' A.., 87, of Pompano Beach, FLorida. Died November 24, 1999. Married to Regina ''Bobs'' Ullman Martin. Also survived by a son, Tom Martin; daughters Jennifer Ward and Jackie Martin; a sister, Betty Cohen; and three grandchildren. A graveside ceremony will be held at 1 PM Sunday, November 28, 1999 at the Krumville Cemetery, Krumville, NY. For more information, contact the Copeland Funeral Home, (914-255-1212).

title: How Medicine Became Just Another Product
description: Once again, we are reminded that teaching hospitals are in trouble. In the bill that President Clinton is likely to sign, the formula for financing graduate medical education has been challenged.

title: Zero Day Near, New York Asks, 'What If?'
description: Last month, after searching and testing hundreds of computer systems and countless electronic devices in New York City's vast inventory of technology, city officials took one of the final steps in a four-year, $300 million effort to prevent any turmoil stemming from the Year 2000 computer problem.

title: The Diversity Project in Texas
description: The federal court decision that struck down raced-based admissions at the University of Texas in 1996 was promptly decried as a barrier that would not only exclude black and Hispanic students from university life but also diminish their professional prospects and their role in the next generation of Texas state leadership. But three years after affirmative action was decreed dead, the flagship university at Austin is admitting as many minority students as it did under affirmative action -- thanks to a state law guaranteeing college admission to all students who graduate in the top 10 percent of any public high school.

title: A Tax Revolt Grows in New Hampshire
description: Nona Philbrick, an 85-year-old retired schoolteacher, could not bring herself at first to open the local tax bill that was in her roadside mailbox this morning.

title: Bishop George Papaioannou, 66; Achieved Rank Despite Marriage
description: Bishop George Papaioannou of New Jersey, who became the first married priest to be elevated to the rank of bishop in the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America, died on Monday at a hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 66.

title: High Tech and Layoffs
description: To the Editor:

title: Malaysia Autocrat May Win Now but Lose Later
description: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad is all but certain to win a parliamentary election next week, but already, to many people here, he seems like a relic of the past.

title: Is Medical Charity Exportable?
description: To the Editor:

title: PHONE COMPANY PROFIT FALLS
description: Singapore Telecommunications Ltd., Asia's No. 5 phone company, posted its first profit decline since it went public in 1993, hurt by big reductions in its international rates to prepare for competition. Profit, before a gain, for the six months ended in September fell 3.1 percent, to 966.2 million Singapore dollars ($578.6 million), or 6.34 cents a share, from 997.6 million dollars, or 6.54 cents a share, a year earlier. The decline in earnings mirrors the problems of other phone companies in Asia, where markets are being opened to more competition. Cable and Wireless HKT of Hong Kong, Asia's No. 4 phone company, posted its first loss earlier this month as it faced new rivals in international calling.

title: Easing a Woman's Fear
description: This is a 60-second commercial that former Senator Bill Bradley, who is running for the Democratic presidential nomination, began showing in Iowa, New Hampshire and the Boston area this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, RHODA
description: WEINER-Rhoda. The Central Synagogue Community extends its condolences to Rabbi Tom Weiner, former Associate Rabbi of Central Synagogue, and to the rest of the Weiner family, on the death of their beloved Rhoda Weiner. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Peter Rubinstein, Rabbi Joshua Davidson, Rabbi Sarah Reines, Rabbi Jordan Franzel, Cantor Richard Bottan, Cantor Emeritus Samuel Wasserman, President

title: AIR METHODS SET TO BUY AREA RESCUE CONSORTIUM
description: The Air Methods Corporation, a provider of emergency air medical-transportation services, said it planned to buy the nonprofit Area Rescue Consortium of Hospitals to expand into Missouri. Area Rescue, which is closely held, has five twin-engine helicopters that provide air medical services to hospitals in the St. Louis area. Air Methods' Mercy Air Service division has 44 helicopters and six fixed-wing aircraft serving hospitals in 15 states. Air Methods, based in Denver, expects to agree on financial terms by Jan. 15 and complete the deal by March 1.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When I go home and put on 'La Boheme,' I know Rodolfo's going to sing the same words every time, and it gets me prepared to come back to Belfast because the one thing I know is that I'm going to have to sit here and listen to you guys saying the same thing over and over again every time. ''

title: Reliance Group Names New No. 2 Official
description: Reliance Group Holdings Inc., an insurance holding company facing multiple woes, said this week that it had named a turnaround specialist, Robert S. Miller, as its president and second in command.

title: Overmatched Again: Nets Lose to the Lakers
description: Last May, the Nets offered Phil Jackson a multiyear contract worth more than $7 million a season, but for $1 million less he got Shaquille O'Neal, Kobe Bryant, Glen Rice and a legitimate chance to win a seventh National Basketball Association championship.

title: BANK MERGER IN INDIA
description: HDFC Bank, a commercial lender, said it would buy Times Bank for about 2.2 billion rupees ($50.5 million) in the first-ever takeover among nongovernment banks in India. HDFC Bank, an arm of the Housing Development Finance Corporation, India's largest home mortgage lender, said it would swap one share for every 5.75 shares of Times Bank. It said the takeover -- which will give it 200,000 new customers, 38 additional branches, and the ability to cut operating costs -- will speed HDFC Bank's expansion into consumer banking. Chase Capital, an arm of the Chase Manhattan Bank of the United States, owns about 15 percent of HDFC Bank. Times Bank sold 3.5 billion rupees worth of shares in its initial public offering in June. Bennett, Coleman & Company, one of India's leading newspaper publishing groups, owns about a 76 percent share of the bank.

title: A Post-Thanksgiving Crush of Travelers
description: It is that time of year again. Along with leftover turkey and overflowing shopping bags comes that other sign of the holiday season -- traffic, lots and lots of it.

title: With Leader Incapacitated, Croatia Power Is Transferred
description: Croatia's Constitutional Court declared today that President Franjo Tudjman, on his deathbed in a suburban hospital, was temporarily incapacitated, a decision that transfers his powers for now to the speaker of Parliament.

title: Rwanda Tribunal Delays Suspect's Release
description: A judicial appeals panel agreed today to a one-week stay of its decision to release a leading suspect in the 1994 genocide in Rwanda, in which half a million or more ethnic Tutsi died.

title: Camby on Sideline, With an Assist From Ewing
description: The pressure to play in pain is accumulating over Marcus Camby, with every thinly veiled nudge by his coach, with every loss by the Knicks, with every test that indicates his knee injury is nothing more than tendinitis.

title: Hokies Complete Their Circuit With No Glitches
description: They did their part by capping a perfect regular season with a 38-14 victory today over Boston College, capturing their third Big East championship. But here were the Virginia Tech players and their coaches, frozen in place at midfield, watching the green lights on small scoreboard narrate in code the final seconds of a football game half the country away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENWALD, STEPHEN
description: GREENWALD-Stephen. On November 25, 1999. Survived and deeply mourned by his wife Lita, his sister Rita Klein, numerous nieces and nephews and a multitude of friends. Services 12 noon Sunday, November 28th, East 55th Conservative Synagogue, 308 East 55 Street. In lieu of flowers contribution to The Mariom Foundation, c/o Greenwald, 785 Park Ave, New York, NY 10021 would be greatly appreciated. ''The elements so mixed in him that Nature might stand up and say to the world, this was a man!''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Holiday Shopping Season Begins in Malls and on Web

title: Is There a Doctor in the Cruiser?; Police Recruits Learn Lessons in Labor and Delivery
description: They were young, earnest and itching for action, but most of the 90 recruits who gathered in the Police Academy gym last week did not have even a passing acquaintance with the boiling of water, the clamping of umbilical cords or the other skills of midwifery.

title: The Rangers' Long Season Is Feeling Longer and Longer
description: If you threw out the second period tonight, the Rangers played a competitive game. But that's like saying, discount the first two months of the season and the Rangers have the makings of a good team.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SOVEREIGN SPECIALTY CHEMICALS L.P., a closely held maker of adhesives, sealants and coatings, agreed to sell 75 percent of its stake in Sovereign Specialty Chemicals Inc. for an undisclosed price. The buyer is a group led by AEA Investors Inc., New York, which was founded by families that included the Rockefellers, Mellons and Harrimans.

title: A Wry Touch With a Song Added to the Same in Tap
description: Jazz Tap Ensemble's ''Song and Dance,'' presented on Wednesday at the Joyce Theater, is a treat. An adroit blend of dance and music numbers, the show is full of subtle, witty tapping. And it boasts two guest vocalists who help set the evening's genial tone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDEROFF, FRED, DR.
description: BENDEROFF-Fred, Dr.. Beloved husband of Ann Benderoff. Dear father of Gayle Benderoff, (Sy) Israel, Paula (Dr. Howard) Donsky, Ilene (Dr. Bruce) Kovan, Dr. Bruce (Carol) Benderoff & Brian Benderoff. Loving grandfather of Laura & Julia Israel, Rebecca, Samuel and Heather Donsky, Elizabeth, Katharine, Rachel, Sarah and Jane Kovan, Lauren and Emily Benderoff and the late Jonathan Scott Kovan brother of the late Lawrence Benderoff, brother-inlaw of Beverly Benderoff, son of the late William Benderoff and the late Ida Benderoff. For information call The Ira Kaufman Chapel, 248-569-0020. Serivces & interment to be held in Detroit, Sunday.

title: 500 PEOPLE TO BE ADDED TO SALES WORK FORCE IN 2000
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would add 500 people to its software sales force next year to step up pressure on rivals like th Oracle Corporation. I.B.M.'s software sales group will reach 7,000 worldwide with the new hiring, said Steve Mills, general manager of I.B.M.'s Software Solutions. The company employs more than 22,000 in its software unit. The company is trying to catch up with Oracle, the biggest maker of software that stores large libraries of information, and Computer Associates International Inc., whose programs manage networks. The hiring initiative comes after I.B.M. said on Monday that it was cutting more than 100 software employees, the third round of job reductions at the company in six weeks. Most of the laid-off software employees worked in marketing and sales. The company, based in Armonk, N.Y., is continually reshuffling its work force to focus on areas of sales growth, like databases, Mr. Mills said.

title: Son Is Arrested in the Killings of His Parents, Both Lawyers
description: The elder son of a Long Island husband-and-wife legal team whose bodies were found burned last week after a fire at their upstate vacation home was arrested today and charged with killing them.

title: PARK PLACE IS NEAR AN ATLANTIC CITY CASINO DEAL
description: The Park Place Entertainment Corporation, the world's largest casino company, said that it would offer to take an 80 percent stake in the bankrupt Sands hotel and casino in Atlantic City, through a reorganization plan it will submit in partnership with Merrill Lynch Asset Management. Under the plan, Park Place would make a $30 million investment in the Sands. Park Place would aid its earnings per share within a year by combining functions like purchasing and marketing at the Sands with its other Atlantic City properties, said Scott LaPorta, the company's chief financial officer.

title: Reaching in Two Directions
description: This 30-second commercial, ''The American Project,'' is one of two that the Republican presidential campaign of Gary L. Bauer will begin showing today in Iowa, which has a caucus in late January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLON, BERTHA
description: DILLON-Bertha. Beloved wife of the late Henry Jack Dillon. Loving mother of Myrna and Leonard Arnold and Robert and Roberta Dillon. Cherished grandmother of Kenneth and Cara, Deborah and Chuck, Jonathan and Sharon, Andrew, Benjamin and Sarah. Greatgrandmother of Jeffrey, Brooke, Hallie and Steven. Dear sister of Eleanor Lefkowitz. Graveside services at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI Sunday at 11AM.

title: Long Road in Nigeria
description: To the Editor:

title: Russia to Hunt Chechen Rebels in Mountains
description: After pummeling Chechnya's capital in an all-night fusillade, Russian military commanders said today that their troops would begin pursuing guerrilla forces directly into their mountain hideouts.

title: Japan Endorses Standby Fund To Stabilize Southeast Asia
description: MANILA  Southeast Asian countries and Japan have taken the first step toward the creation of a standby fund to help prevent a recurrence of the financial crisis that engulfed the region in 1997, Philippine officials said Friday.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the News Watch column of Circuits on Nov. 18 misstated the name and Web address of a site that stores medical records online. It is MedicalRecord.com (www.medicalrecord.com), not MedicalRecords.com.

title: Selfless in Sofia
description: To the Editor:

title: Louis Menk, Railroad Executive, Dies at 81
description: Louis Wilson Menk, a railroad entrepreneur who wove three medium-size companies into the much larger Burlington Northern, then went to the rescue of a faltering industrial giant, International Harvester, died Tuesday at his home in Carefree, Ariz., a suburb of Phoenix. He was 81.

title: BRITISH MEDIA MERGER
description: Two British media companies, Carlton Communications and United News and Media, announced that they would merge in a deal valued at 4 billion [pounds] ($6.5 billion). The merger, a straight stock swap, would make the combined company the largest commercial television concern in Britain. Analysts said the planned merger would face tough regulatory hurdles because it is illegal for one company to control more than 25 percent of Britain's television advertising revenue and more than 15 percent of Britain's television audience. The companies said they might sell assets to appease regulators.

title: Community Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: Executives' Buying of Stocks Climbs
description: Executives at United States companies from real estate investment trusts like the Host Marriott Corporation to retailers including AutoZone Inc. are buying shares in their companies at the strongest pace in 11 months, even as the stock market approaches record highs.

title: NBC SET TO TAKE STAKE IN THE EGREETINGS NETWORK
description: The NBC unit of the General Electric Company is taking an equity stake in Egreetings Network Inc., an Internet provider of gifts and free greeting cards, to promote NBC shows on free online postcards. Terms were not disclosed. Egreetings will use shows like ''The Tonight Show'' and ''Providence,'' as themes for its free postcards and animations. It will promote the cards on its Web site and through e-mail to its 8 million users. On Oct. 14, San Francisco-based Egreetings filed to sell $75 million in stock to the public.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLOWITZ, PAULA
description: BERLOWITZ-Paula. Age 94, passed away peacefully Sunday, November 21, at her home in Coney Island. She is survived by her brother Philip and numerous nephews and nieces. We mourn her loss and cherish her indomitable zest for life. Friends and Family of Paula Berlowitz

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGELMOHR, JACK H.
description: ENGELMOHR-Jack H.., 83, of Upper Nyack, NY, on November 25, 1999. Former CEO of White Plains Hospital. Survived by beloved wife Dorothy, son Jack and daughter Carol. Visitation 2-4 PM at Hannemann Funeral Home, 88 South Broadway, Nyack, November 30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, GRACE S.
description: GALLAGHER-Grace S.. The Board, Members and Staff of Greater New York Hospital Association express our condolences to our esteemed colleague, Jack Gallagher, Chief Executive Officer of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Healthcare System, on the passing of his beloved wife, Grace. We extend our deepest sympathy to Jack, his children, and the entire Gallagher family. Mark J. Mundy, Chairman Kenneth A. Raske, President Greater N.Y. Hospital Association

title: State Subsidies to Hospitals Face Renewal Deadline, Spurring Policy Debate
description: New York hospitals are being suffocated, according to one viewpoint, by the government and by insurance companies that place profits perilously above patients' needs. Or, from another vantage point, the hospitals are hopelessly inefficient spendthrifts whose practices have not kept pace with cost-cutting trends in health care.

title: Kurds Sense a Shift Toward Peace After 15-Year War
description: Sitting at his sewing machine by a ground-floor window, a tailor named Ahmet Tuzun senses something he never expected.

title: A Day When a Victory Is Fleeting
description: The 106th meeting between the Texas and Texas A&M football teams was unlike any other, a mixture of Texas orange and maroon, of ribbons and triumphant tributes. This afternoon here at Kyle Field, there was deafening cheering. There was also solemn silence.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about an undercover drug operation in the Bronx, in which one officer was grazed by a bullet and another was struck in the head with a pistol, included erroneous identifications of the officers in some copies. The identities of those two officers were not released by the police because they work under cover. The officers mentioned in the article, Sgt. Robert Delaney and Officer Wilbert Morales, were part of the undercover team but were in uniform.

title: Beliefs; A plan to preserve church ties leaves Catholic educators with more questions than answers.
description: ''A leap in the dark'' is what one well-informed church official called Roman Catholic bishops' approval on Nov. 17 of a document intended to maintain the Catholic identity of Catholic colleges and universities. Very few people question the legitimacy of the bishops' goal, which is widely shared by Catholic educators. What was controversial was the wisdom of the proposed means, which have been widely opposed by many of the same educators.

title: Rep. Sanders Won't Leave House Seat, Democrats Say
description: Ending a fierce tug-of-war between House and Senate Democrats, Representative Bernard Sanders of Vermont plans to announce on Monday that he will seek re-election and forgo a race for the Senate in 2000, Democratic Congressional officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIRINSKY, KATHRYN ANN
description: ZIRINSKY-Kathryn Ann., 44, on November 24, 1999, after a courageous battle with colon cancer. Devoted wife of Robert. Adored Mom and best friend of Ralph, Elissa and Harry. Beloved daughter of Phyllis and Thomas Sinatra. Dear sister of Nina, Frank and Carla. Cherished daughter-in-law of Ruth. A memorial service will be held next week, details to follow. No flowers or baskets, please. We request that all donations in memory of Kathryn be sent to the James F. Holland, M.D. Research Fund, Mount Sinai Medical Center-Development Office, 1 Gustave L. Levy Pl., N.Y., NY 10029.

title: Mentally Ill Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Universe's Mysteries
description: To the Editor:

title: Free Trade, Up To a Point
description: It's usually smart to be wary of the hard sell. And the hard sell is what we will hear coming from Seattle next week, as the World Trade Organization meets there. The Clinton administration has been pushing for China's entry into the trade group, optimistically predicting immediate gains for American businesses. Markets will be opened, tariffs will be reduced and regulations will be loosened, we're told. W.T.O. membership, the administration claims, would transform China because its regulations, on trade and other matters, would become public and subject to foreign scrutiny.

title: Microsoft on the Defense, Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Creative Turmoil At Arista; Founder and Chief Resists a Successor
description: At age 66 -- or a whispered 67 -- Clive Davis is a music man who usually plays it by ear, sensing hits and nurturing artists spanning from Janis Joplin and Barry Manilow to Whitney Houston and Sarah McLachlan.

title: Ex-Football Player Sues Nasdaq Official Over a Career Dispute
description: A former New York Giants football star is contending in a lawsuit that Frank G. Zarb, the chairman of the organization that runs the Nasdaq stock market, cut short his career in the insurance industry by deceiving him about a $1.23 billion corporate buyout. The case is scheduled for trial on Monday in the Superior Court of New Jersey in Newark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATKIN, REGINA SHOOLMAN
description: SLATKIN-Regina Shoolman. Of NYC, Essex, NY, Palm Beach, FL. formerly of Montreal on Nov. 25, 1999. Born January 16, 1907. Loving wife of the late Charles E. Slatkin, devoted mother of Carole and Laura. Also survived by her dear Rose Slatkin, David & Charles Schulman, Gus Slatkin; and by many loyal friends. More deeply loved than words can express.

title: Montevideo Journal; Ex-Guerrilla Takes Struggle to the Campaign Trail
description: While driving to his congressional office the other morning, Senator-elect Jose Mujica took a trip down memory lane to the days when he was imprisoned for his guerrilla activities by the military dictatorship that ruled here in the 1970's and 80's.

title: New Insight Into Everest Mystery; Finding Mallory Elicits A Flurry of Theories
description: Putting yourself in the boots of a dead stranger to deduce what he thought and did in his final hours is a detective's technique. But when the death occurred more than 75 years ago in one of the most remote points of the earth, the task seems nigh impossible.

title: Managed Care's Future
description: The recent decision by UnitedHealth Group, a big managed care company, to let doctors treat patients without interference might mark the death of one reviled tactic of managed care. No longer will United have to approve, in advance, procedures that doctors have recommended to their patients. Doctors resented the need for such clearance as an intolerable interference by unqualified outsiders, and patients resented any denials as cost-saving by the insurance company at the expense of their health. To United's surprise, the advance approvals were not even saving any money, so it ended the practice.

title: For Racist Slights, the Meter Is Still Running
description: NOW that the holiday season has officially begun, the city's social meters are clicking wildly. A cast of characters ranging from doormen to store clerks are busy flexing their prerogative of exclusion, separating those with means from the climbers, the insiders from the interlopers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOUIE, LORRAINE
description: LOUIE-Lorraine. November 20, 1999 in New York. Beloved wife of Daniel Pelavin. Loving mother of Anna and Molly Pelavin.

title: Erica Heller, Ronald van den Boogaard
description: SOME New Yorkers belong in their neighborhoods as cactus belongs in the desert: they couldn't live anywhere else. A few blocks north or a few blocks south and they would wither.

title: Not Enough Substitute Teachers To Go Around
description: WHEN Janet Lindner shows up for work on any given morning at Croton High School, she always carries a briefcase with the basic tools of her trade: scissors, Post-Its, Scotch tape, a stapler, pens and paper. After that, it is her more than 25 years' experience as a full-time substitute teacher that helps her maintain her equilibrium, whether she is asked to lead a chemistry experiment, supervise a French test or teach physics.

title: Baron's Internet Play
