description: Baron Capital of New York, which currently offers a trim lineup of just three mutual funds, apparently is bullish enough on the growth prospects for the Web to become the latest money management firm to start an Internet fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, ROBERT G.
description: GORDON-Robert G.. Died November 17 in Hamilton, NY, a few days short of his seventieth birthday. After retiring as a member of the English faculty of Montclair State College in 1991, he moved to Hamilton to live near his alma mater, Colgate University. Earlier he had taught at the Englewood School and White Plains H.S. A student of British art, he donated his extensive collection of works on paper to the Picker Art Gallery at Colgate. Bob was a frequent contributor of fiction, articles, poetry and verse to publications here and abroad, including the New York Times and Wall Street Journal. His monograph on the friendship of John Butler Yeats and John Sloan was published in Dublin. There are no survivors, other than a legion of friends and former students who cherished his wit and erudition. Contributions in Bob's memory may be made to the Gordon Scholarship Fund at Colgate. For further information, Burgess Funeral Home, (315-824-2417).

title: Learning the Price of Lunch
description: THE first time it happened, my 12-year-old daughter, Marian, hid the bill in her room. It scared her, and I think she hoped it would just go away. The second time, she left the bill in resignation on the dining room table, where I couldn't miss it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALFUS, MAURICE
description: ALFUS-Maurice. Beloved father of Phillip, cherished brother to Helen & uncle to Jacques and Liane. An admired colleague to those at the DBC and respected member of Honors. A life well lived, a fighter who always had time to listen. Funeral services to be held at Riverside Memorial, 10:45 A.M., Sunday, November 28, 1999.

title: Jennifer Spear, Hunter Norton
description: Jennifer Sharon Spear, a daughter of Linda and Jay Spear of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., is to be married today to Hunter Norell Norton, a son of Barbara and Robert Norton of Trumbull, Conn. Rabbi William Dreskin is to officiate at Tarrytown House in Irvington, N.Y.

title: The Jets' Best Hope Is to Remain in Control
description: The last time the Jets faced Indianapolis, their season seemed all but ended as the final seconds ticked away.

title: Food; A Clam Dunk
description: On the scale that runs from soup to stew, chowder is dead center, thick and hearty, each ingredient still apparent. But the flavor of the whole is richer and more profound than its individual parts. Chowder is edible democracy.

title: Desolation Row
description: THE HUNGRY YEARS

title: Ideas & Trends; She's Not the First Lady to Escape the White House
description: THE White House, with 132 rooms of grandeur and its aura of power, has often seemed confining to the wives of the men who lived there. Hillary Rodham Clinton, seeking power that she did not have to exercise through her husband, announced last week that she was moving to an 11-room house in Chappaqua.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Mistler's Exit

title: No Stage, No Actors, But It's Theater (and Art)
description: NEW YORK: You walk past a catalog-filled vitrine into a room with somber red walls, dark wainscoting and heavy benches. All around are paintings of happy peasants and plentiful harvests, along with a disconcerting scene of a man spying on a picnic from behind a 1940's car. The style is Cezanne plus Socialist Realism. Water drips from the ceiling into scattered buckets and tarpaulins. You feel as if you had strayed into a derelict Eastern European museum -- and, a block from Broadway, you have.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2000 Toyota Echo; An Odd Lesson in College Economics
description: AFTER pulling me over at 1:30 a.m. on a recent Thursday, Trooper Antone Wilson of the Massachusetts State Police offered an enthusiastic, Bostonian ''How ah yah?'' followed by a more pointed question: ''Is this car gas or electric?''

title: Integration Anxiety
description: Our children attended five different Montclair schools beginning in 1972. They were bused to a school twice as far away as the neighborhood facility in order for schools to achieve racial balance. My husband and I worked for, and approved of, this effort. We, too, had chosen Montclair because we wanted to live in a diverse community. When our kids invited friends over to play, we never knew what color they were going to be. Our kids never thought to mention it.

title: Our Towns; Evangelism Hits the Road To Find Flock
description: HAS James Chavez, an earnest Jehovah's Witness, lost his way?

title: Can Props Have a Life Outside the Theater?
description: CAN dramas that have been stripped of their actors and actions, stripped of everything but their props, costumes and sets, still be dramatic? Or, for that matter, can they be art? The exhibition ''Playing with Fire,'' a survey of the artifacts of Julie Taymor's 25-year career as a director and designer of operas, musicals, movies and plays, is a perfect test case.

title: For Plan to Shrink Tower, a Chorus of Cheers From the Neighbors
description: A City Council committee voted last Tuesday to rezone a plot of land situated near John Jay Park to accommodate only low-rise residential buildings.

title: MOVIES: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: Fascism, bigotry and sheer inhumanity -- some of it packaged in the normally sunny colors of animation -- provide the dramatic substructure for a rich array of films on television this week. And oddly enough, the comic relief comes from a lighthearted look at the American presidency.

title: Badgers Slighted
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Parents Blaming Parents
description: ''Forgiveness doesn't mean there aren't consequences'' (Lisa Belkin, Oct. 31). This lament from a Columbine parent whose son was injured during the shootings last spring is heart-wrenching in its irony. What will it take for us to finally recognize that the killers in this incident acted on exactly the same sentiments that conflate retribution with justice? Before we start pointing fingers at individual parents and authorities, we have to recognize a broader truth: what happened at Columbine was not the fault of guns, bad parenting, video games or lackadaisical police work; it was the product of a culture that cannot make up its mind between rugged, self-righteous individualism and the mutual cooperation necessary for a stable society.

title: One Degree of Separation
description: This week's career advice: To become a Pulitzer Prize-winning editorial cartoonist, judging from the careers of Jeff MacNelly of the Chicago Tribune and Doug Marlette, left, of Newsday, follow these easy steps:

title: The Theater Is Not Dead. It's Into the Second Stage.; First, Broadway Chased Plays to the Suburbs in the 50's. Now, Dircetors Are Experimenting in Even Smaller Spaces.
description: THERE are no small parts,'' Sir Laurence Olivier famously said. ''Only small actors.''

title: Correspondence/The Royal Mail; Britons Have Always Gone Postal -- With Social Niceties
description: BEFORE I moved to London, I took a deep breath and read ''Clarissa,'' Samuel Richardson's classic 18th-century novel about the seduction and ruin of a virtuous young girl. From an anthropological point of view, what is interesting about ''Clarissa'' is not only that it is more than one million words long and that reading it demands a peculiarly British form of stoicism, but also that it is an epistolary novel -- that is, it is written entirely in the form of letters between its characters.

title: Instruments Examined in Newark Air Crash
description: Investigators focused on a pair of tiny gyroscopes yesterday as possible factors in the crash of a private plane in Newark that killed three members of a Maryland family and injured 25 people on the ground as it plunged down a street, broke apart, struck buildings and cars and set off fires and explosions.

title: Islanders Start Quickly But Fade at the Wire
description: For Islanders goaltender Felix Potvin, the decisive point in tonight's 4-3 loss to the Washington Capitals was not the pair of third-period goals by Peter Bondra.

title: A Linguistic Big Bang
description: Lawrence Osborne (Oct. 24) recognizes that ''only someone with the conscience of a Josef Mengele'' would perform an experiment to see whether, if children grow up isolated on an island, they would develop a language. But he is dismayingly uncritical of the conscience of Judy Kegl, a linguist who has chosen not to teach ''a more established sign system like American sign language'' to deaf children at her experimental school in Nicaragua: ''To preserve what Nicaragua's deaf have created, Kegl does not want to encourage the adoption of other idioms -- even if that leaves the students unable to communicate with other deaf communities.''

title: Soaking Up All That Padua Has to Offer
description: Correction Appended

title: Footnotes
description: 1. ''Dreaming Southern'' was published by Dutton earlier this year. While certain aspects of the story parallel Linda Bruckheimer's own life, the colorful character of the mother, Lila Mae Wooten, bears no resemblance to her mother. ''I had to explain that to her, too,'' says Bruckheimer, who is at work on a sequel, tentatively titled ''Memories of Honeysuckle Way.''

title: Small Bookshops in Peril? On One Avenue, They Sprout
description: While independent booksellers around the nation are closing in the face of competition from big corporate retailers and giant Internet discounters, small bookshops are returning to one Brooklyn neighborhood.

title: A Filmmaker Now Known for Two Families
description: RORY KENNEDY'S glowing face and great smile stand out in the family photograph. Next to her is the matriarch, who has 13 children and grandchildren galore. Most live near her and all return regularly en masse for holidays and other family gatherings. There are the young men, some of whom have had problems with drinking, drugs or romance. The mentally retarded sister is not there; she lives elsewhere. Not long ago, one of the sons was arrested and jailed. The whole family united to support him but couldn't come up with the $2,500 bail.

title: Habitats/37th Street Between Ninth and 10th Avenues; A Longtime Resident Keeps on Expanding
description: TIMOTHY WHITE'S family has some history on the street where he lives. Not the kind most families like to talk about, but history nonetheless.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CATTS, MAYE V.
description: CATTS-Maye V.. Of New York and Florida, died November 20, 1999. Survived by her loving daughter Roberta Mallow; grandchildren Deborah (Brian) and Peter (Miranda), and great-grandchildren Dean and David. Private services at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: POSTINGS: $11.5 Million for Six Floors; Pratt Buys 14th St. Space
description: Pratt Institute, the Brooklyn-based art and design college, has purchased the upper six floors of a seven-story building on West 14th Street as a permanent home for its Manhattan operations.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: SOMEWHERE IN A DESERT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAKE, MURRAY
description: DRAKE-Murray. Survived by beloved wife of 56 years, Ruth; loving father of Robert and Neil and daughter-in-law Paula Drake; cherished grandson Adam; brothers Sidney (Barbara), Stanley (Arlene). Funeral will be held Sunday, 10AM, Riverside Chapel, Great Neck, NY. Burial New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, N.Y.

title: The View From/Ledyard; The Flag Shows Up In American Indian Art
description: AFTER the American Indian sun dance ceremony was prohibited by the federal government in the 1880's, some bands of Lakota Indians would gather in large groups during the summer to sing, celebrate and dance around a pole much like the one they had used in their traditional ritual of Thanksgiving. On top of it, they flew the American flag, which also decorated the clothing of warriors and children. It was, at least from the outside, a Fourth of July celebration, and the military was less likely to break up what appeared to be a patriotic fete.

title: Melding Top Tier With the Down to Earth
description: TWO Huntington restaurant dynasties from opposite ends of the culinary spectrum have joined to open Sal D's (631-549-0643) at 208 Wall Street in the Southdown Shopping Center. Sal is Sal Meringolo, one of the owners of J & J Southside, a popular old-line neighborhood Southern Italian tavern and restaurant on Route 110 and D's refers to Dean Philippis, whose family owns the sophisticated Mazzi on the Jericho Turnpike and the upscale Piccolo's across the street from Sal D's (a third owner, Frank Algieri, was a cook at J & J's).

title: Big Board Ready to Open the E-Gates
description: RICHARD A. GRASSO, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, says he has convinced the members of his 207-year-old institution that the best way to cope with the change rocking Wall Street is to create it.

title: Shame on Sprewell
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Webber Enjoys Reign As King Among Kings
description: Lawrence Funderburke remembers a conversation between him and Chris Webber in May 1998, days after Webber was dealt to Sacramento from Washington. Funderburke, one of just a few players still on the Kings' roster from two seasons ago, recalled trying to assuage Webber's worst fears about playing for a perennial lottery team.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-28-99: Expert Opinion; Parents Just Don't Understand
description: The Experts

title: Mexican Arts, Crafts and Clothing
description: La Sirena, a Mexican arts, crafts and clothing store, reopened at 27 East Third Street, between Bowery and Second Avenue, on Nov. 20 after closing its 107 Avenue B location eight months ago.

title: When Children Kill
description: To the Editor:

title: A Woman Is Slashed in a Subway Robbery
description: A 62-year-old woman was slashed on the face with a knife yesterday during a robbery on a Manhattan subway platform, the police said.

title: A Space Station? Big Deal!
description: Fifty years ago, the rocket scientist Wernher von Braun and several of his colleagues charted a course for space exploration that envisioned using winged shuttles to construct a space station in Earth's orbit, from which astronauts would venture forth to establish a Moon base and, ultimately, a colony on Mars. Vividly illustrated by the space artist Chesley Bonestell -- first in Collier's magazine and then in various books and films -- the von Braun plan imprinted itself on Americans as the way to space.

title: The World; A Middle East Choice: Peace or Democracy
description: IN the last several months, even as a final peace between Israel and the Palestinians has come to seem more plausible, a new element of uncertainty has been creeping into the Middle East. The static pantheon of Arab leaders is beginning to crumble, and generational change has started to sweep through the region as aging and entrenched leaders give way to sons or designate heirs. So these are anxious times, as iron men begin to fade and courtiers plot their futures. Within five years, say experts on the region, the current lineup of Arab leaders is likely to be totally transformed.

title: For U.S., Bradley Favors An Internationalist Path
description: In his first major campaign event on foreign policy, former Senator Bill Bradley will use a meeting with students this Monday to cast himself as a committed internationalist who believes that America's vital interests abroad can best be advanced through the free flow of goods, capital and ideas across national boundaries, his aides said.

title: The Neediest Cases
description: The end of the century, now so near, inevitably brings thoughts of this century's beginning. We are used to the orderly chaos of New York's streets, their feel of almost limitless energy and opportunity. In the New York of 1900, the same energy would have been evident, but with it a sense of underlying social disunion, chaos of a very human kind. It was a place, as Theodore Dreiser wrote, where the strong ''were so very strong, and the weak so very, very weak -- and so very, very many.''

title: Andes Race Is Not for Faint of Heart
description: While the rest of us lazily reached for the remote this weekend, 200 supertoned athletes from 31 nations continued preparations to paddle, ride horseback, climb, rappel, schlep, scratch and claw their way through the Andes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCH, FRIEDA K.
description: DEUTSCH-Frieda K.. On November 26, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Morrey; loving mother of the late Ira; cherished grandmother of Jesse and Elena Deutsch; greatgrandmother of Hannah and Aaron. Services Sunday 9:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Assault On Good News
description: Three years ago, Sullivan declared that the AIDS plague was no more. ''It's over,'' he wrote, as 30 million people continued to suffer from infection.

title: The Nation: Negative Spin; Their Biggest Campaign May Be Against Type-Casting
description: FOR weeks, the story line on Senator John McCain of Arizona has been that he has a big, bad temper. But here's a news flash: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has one, too. Even Mr. Bush does not dispute a description by the writer Richard Ben Cramer that he is the ''Roman Candle'' of the Bush family.

title: Chess, Sure. But Rifles? In Great Neck?
description: THE second season of Great Neck South High School's participation in interscholastic riflery is scheduled to begin on Dec. 18, and the number of students trying to make the team has soared. Some local residents find this so appalling that they have mounted a community effort to ban the sport.

title: POSTINGS: 98 Subsidized Apartments for Those 62 and Over; Touch of Art Deco in the Bronx
description: A 98-unit rental building for people 62 and over in the West Farms section of the Bronx, which is to accept its first tenants Wednesday, has been designed to show that subsidized housing can be attractive and compatible with its surroundings.

title: A Timeless Moment Grounded in Impermanence
description: THIS,'' said William Carden, the director, ''is theatrical tough love.'' The audience in the cavernous Majestic Theater roared its approval.

title: And Once You've Got To Carnegie?
description: AS a lively concert season unfolds in New York, with major institutions giving belated cram courses in the music of this century and bracing for a Bach year, it is easy to forget for a moment the dreary, predictable seasons of a year or two ago. It is also tempting to assume that under the burbling surface, all is well.

title: Youth Is Served
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: How Green Is the Desert
description: WHEN you wander through the oasis at Tozeur in western Tunisia, it's hard not to fantasize about Eden. In neat groves, thousands of slender palm trees tower. Their gray-green fronds and honeycomb date clusters shield a dazzling, climate-defying garden of fruits and vegetables from the desert sun. Mottled sunlight descends through citrus, pomegranate and peach trees, many wound with grapevines. Banana and olive trees shade low-growing tomatoes and hot peppers; what appear as weeds are actually heads of lettuce, fringed carrot tops and parsley that will be chopped into garnish for couscous. Barley and tobacco and pale pink rose bushes sprout seemingly at random.

title: Haggle City
description: OH, no! What had I taught these girls? What would their mothers say? Worried, I waved goodbye to the four 12-year-olds as they boarded the plane at La Guardia, headed back to Davenport, Iowa. They'd been my guests for a long weekend in New York City. Sara, my friend's daughter, had stayed with me before, and had told me about her three best girlfriends, who I knew wouldn't otherwise have the opportunity to visit Manhattan. So I invited them all.

title: Through a Lens, the Body's Many Guises Multiply
description: IN strictly physical terms, the evolution of the human body may be slow, yet our perception of the body has been undergoing rapid change throughout this century, thanks to photography. More democratic, accessible, unforgiving and narcissistic than painting or drawing, it has shaped how we look at each other -- and ourselves. It has also redefined our notion of the body in everything from entertainment, sports and fashion to wars, famine and medicine.

title: Remember Education's Consumers; Good Teachers Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The What's Doing column on Oct. 17, about Paris, misstated the address of the restaurant Les Allobroges. A letter dated Nov. 16 to the author from the owner, Olivier Pateyron, points out that it is 20, rue des Grands-Champs, not 71.

title: Ensor, Once Unloved, Gets a Retrospective
description: The Belgian painter James Ensor (1860-1949) may have been the ultimate misunderstood artist. Disliked by the critics and rebuffed by his peers early in his career, Ensor attempted to sell the entire contents of his art studio in 1893 for a mere 8,500 Belgian francs, then the equivalent of around $300 -- and failed.

title: Walls Stop Talking: Political Murals Are Vanishing
description: While taking the D train into Brooklyn one day last year, Arlan Huang was shocked by what he didn't see.

title: Q&A/Dr. Nancy L. Close; Tips on Locating Quality Child Care
description: CONNECTICUT, according to Nancy L. Close, Ph.D., has some of the most stringent licensing requirements for child care. Because of this, there is a chronic shortage of excellent providers in the state. Dr. Close, the associate director for Yale's early childhood education program and an assistant clinical professor at both the Yale Child Study Center and in the psychology department, advises parents on how to choose quality day care for young children.

title: When New Architecture and New Age Met
description: THE French-Canadian theater director Robert Lepage, known for his provocative and unorthodox productions, has come up with another uncommon story: an encounter between two remarkable men -- the great architect Frank Lloyd Wright and the Greek-Armenian philosopher and spiritual teacher Georgi I. Gurdjieff.

title: A Brand-New Director Takes On an Age-Old Taboo
description: SPORTING several days' stubble, a forearm tattoo and camouflage fatigues, Tim Roth sits at a table in a sleek SoHo hotel looking oddly battle-ready. ''I'm prepared for anything,'' he says after a sip of bottled water. ''I'm bulletproof.''

title: Amazon's Risky Christmas
description: MAZON.COM has ordered 181 acres of holiday wrapping paper and 2,494 miles of red satin ribbon -- just in case. It has stocked its shelves with 10,000 copies of the Pack the Pig game and a few extra table saws. And it has built four new automated warehouses that give it the capacity to pack, wrap and ship nearly a million boxes a day.

title: Flower Power, Unwilted by Time
description: Granny's afghan takes a trip off the bed as a fashion statement for a new generation that enjoys a cozy wrap and is ready to shed the all-black style that has gripped the 1990's. These colorful crocheted designs, with fringed or lacy borders, were first worn as clothing by flower children rebelling against designer dictates; they were also the opening shot of do-your-own-thing style. Today, the afghan is popular as a poncho, an alternative to the outdoor sweater. It is also worn as a skirt, a long scarf, even as a tote bag.

title: Brookhaven Reactor Loss Was a Plus for All
description: Early this decade, when the news broke that B.N.L. may have been releasing radioactive waste into the Peconic River for some time, two Riverhead fishermen had a good laugh about the initial clamor for testing of the river.

title: How to Become a Star, Or at Least Impersonate One
description: SHE shook her hips just like Tina Turner. She sang in a seductively rough and raspy voice, too. All the physical details were in place: the larger-than-life hair, the confident smile, the short dress. Even her legs were appropriately muscular and toned.

title: Providing Heat in an Apartment
description: Q I live in a small rent-controlled apartment. Its only sources of heat are a small radiator and two vertical steam pipes, one in the kitchen and the other in the bathroom. The riser in the bathroom is equipped with a steam valve near the ceiling that noisily spews dirty, rusty water and a foul-smelling gas that floods the bathroom and makes me sick. Management's response to my complaints have been to change the valve -- which produces no result -- or to remove it -- which deprives me of heat. Am I not entitled to enough heat, including in the bathroom, and to clean healthy air? . . . Anne-Marie Kunzler, Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAGE, ROSALEEN P. (NEE MURRAY)
description: SAGE-Rosaleen P. (nee Murray). On November 26, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Donald D. Loving mother of Rosemarie Sullivan, Daniel, Bernadette Staunton, Maureen Shillet, Eileen Robinson, Kathleen, Monica, Margaret O'Brien, Josephine McCaffrey and Patrick. Beloved sister of Msgr. James Murray, May Houlihan, John Murray, Sr. Mary Rose Murray, S.U. and Patrick Murray. Cherished grandmother of 17. Reposing David J. Hodder and Son Funeral Home, 899 McLean Ave, Yonkers. Visiting hours Sunday and Monday, 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 11:15 AM, St. Barnabas Church. Interment St. Raymond Cemetery. In lieu of flowers kindly make contributions to St. Patrick Home Development Fund, 66 Van Cortlandt Park South, Bronx, NY 10467; 718519-2800.

title: For Serious Writers And Their Readers, An Oasis on the Air
description: WHEN Ana Castillo, an award-winning Mexican-American writer, appeared on a weekly public radio show called ''Bookworm,'' the host did something strange. He had read her entire body of work and he asked intelligent questions. For 30 minutes, Ms. Castillo held forth on matters like the parallels and dissimilarities between her novels and her poetry, the proper use of irony in romantic and passionate passages and the influence of both the telenovela and 16th-century Spanish literature on her work. Only a close critical listening would have revealed the bottom-line reason for her visit: to plug her new novel, ''Peel My Love Like an Onion.''

title: November 21-27; Domestic Abuse by Women
description: Accepted wisdom among sociologists who study domestic abuse holds that 95 percent of batterers are men. But in certain spots, from Concord, N.H. to Boulder County, Colo., 25 percent or more of recent arrests for domestic assault have been of women.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Einstein's Daughter

title: Crichton's Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Virginia Tech Figures 11-0 Computes to the Sugar Bowl
description: Frank Beamer is a muddy tennis shoes kind of guy. His coaching cap is of the truck driver variety -- billed, with logo, pulled down over his eyes. But the Virginia Tech coach didn't waste much time on Friday in trading in his school's hat for the 1999 Big East champion's crown.

title: Undertaker Feels the Ebb Tide of a Sinking Crime Rate
description: It was very quiet one recent week at La Paz Funeral Home in Mott Haven. Just a single case, an old person who passed away from natural causes.

title: OPINION; The Real Test: Teaching Writing
description: THE school-by-school results of the fourth- and eighth-grade New York State standards assessments in math and language arts are public, and within a few weeks the individual reports will make their way to the homes of thousands of anxious children and parents. Already the cacophony has begun.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Henry of Atlantic City

title: Born of Earth, in More Ways Than One
description: IT'S watched day and night,'' Peter Callas says. ''My assistants and I work eight-hour shifts, but we have some creature comforts, like a phone and a television.''

title: Style; You Can Go Home Again
description: In Linda Bruckheimer's debut novel, ''Dreaming Southern,'' Becky Jean Wooten -- who spent her early adulthood in Los Angeles forgetting her Kentucky upbringing -- undergoes a conversion. She investigates her ancestors and urges her family to see the American countryside before it disappears. ''The country is being overrun by minimalls and skyscrapers!'' she warns.

title: Navigating the Bureaucracy After an Accident
description: Scott MacDonough does not remember being hit. All he remembers is the car's headlights coming closer, and a last-minute instinct to protect his dog, Alexis.

title: Q & A
description: Japan's Gardens

title: An Entrepreneurial Spirit In a Health Network Guide
description: TWO days after non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, a form of cancer, was diagnosed in her, Julie Lerner asked a doctor whether she could still have children. According to Ms. Lerner, his terse, unemotional reply was: ''Why are you worried about that? You might not live.''

title: PRIVATE SECTOR; Steady Hand for a Stormy Rescue
description: GETTING advice for turning around the Rite Aid Corporation was a top priority for its new chairman, Leonard I. Green, when he recently called Kenneth Moelis, chief of corporate finance at Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette. But so was talking about how Mr. Moelis's three children spent most of a Los Angeles Lakers game at the Staples Center watching TV in Mr. Green's box.

title: For Harlem, More to a Boom Than Shopping Centers
description: IT was no ordinary night on 122nd Street. The crowd of about 100 people pressed into the carved cherrywood corners of Martha Chandler Dolly's historic brownstone, turned out in an assortment of little black dresses, tiny spectacles and wildly coifed dreadlocks.

title: Talk-Show Confessions With a Priest for a Host
description: Standing before an audience of some 100 people in a half-moon-shaped television studio here, the Rev. Alberto Cutie bowed his head and asked God ''to illuminate us.''

title: Jet Comes Off the Bench And Unto the Breach
description: FOR the first time in his year and a half with the New York Jets, Eric Ogbogu of Tarrytown can count on one thing when his team visits Indianapolis today in a game pivotal to the team's season.

title: Open Wide the Doors: Memories of a Mentor
description: IT'S hard to believe that Judith Jamison is already celebrating her 10th anniversary as artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. Next month, she will receive a Kennedy Center Honor for her contribution to 20th-century dance. At the same time, working within the Ailey tradition, Ms. Jamison has envisioned the direction the company will take in the 21st century.

title: Replacing Hardware From Times Past
description: DOORKNOBS, window catches, locks, escutcheon plates, drawer pulls and hinges are called architectural hardware to distinguish them from other types of hardware like tools, nails and computers. Replacing contemporary architectural hardware is relatively easy because most large home centers stock of variety of common styles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARBER, FRANCES
description: GARBER-Frances. Beloved wife of the late Allan Lee Garber. Loving mother of Mitchell and Janice, Donald and Betsy, Nancy and Jeffrey Hollander. Adored grandmother of Andrew and Matthew, Madeline and David, Jacob and Samantha. Services at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, on Sunday, November 28, at 1 PM, followed by interment at Beth Moses Cemetery. Shiva will be held at the home of Nancy Hollander, 1962 Helen Court, Merrick, from Sunday evening through Friday afternoon, December 3. Contribbutions to cancer research will be appreciated.

title: New Zealand Wary of Its Easy Path
description: Nearing the midway point of an uncertain and feisty America's Cup competition that has already seen its share of raised tempers and fallen expectations, only one particular is etched in stone. When the 30th cup match begins in February, one of the two contending teams will be sailing a sleek, black yacht flying the banner of the cup's current defender, Team New Zealand.

title: Fez Reveals Morocco's Soul
description: BEHOLD the city of Fez as it looked in the year 1000.

title: National Geographic Puts Atlas Online
description: With its newly published seventh edition of the Atlas of the World, the National Geographic Society not only puts the whole world in your hands but also allows you to keep up with it.

title: Mount Vernon to Mourn Washington Again
description: On Dec. 18, on the 200th anniversary of George Washington's funeral, visitors to Mount Vernon will see a re-creation of the services, the last of many events commemorating the bicentennial of Washington's death at Mount Vernon on Dec. 14, 1799. More than 250 people, including descendants of original mourners, will dress in 18th-century mourning attire for the re-enactment.

title: Court Silences Iran Reformist With Jail Term
description: Iran's most powerful religious court yesterday imposed a five-year jail term and a five-year banishment from political activity on a Muslim cleric, Abdullah Nouri, who is a close ally of Iran's reformist president and has won wide popular support with demands for an end to authoritarian rule by the religious hierarchy.

title: Area Codes Irking You? Then Fax Me Or Beep Me
description: TODAY'S Amazing Mathematical Exercise:

title: Some Transitions Of the Tumultuous Kind
description: Last Monday, the terminal at the new Northwest Arkansas Regional Airport near Fayetteville was formally named for Alice Walton, the only daughter of the late Sam Walton. She had been a prime backer of the airport, and her investment firm, the Llama Company, underwrote the $80 million in bonds that financed it. When President Clinton flew in a year ago to dedicate the airport, he singled her out for credit. Passenger boardings there continue to rise.

title: Collins Is Hoping To Rewrite History
description: On Sunday afternoons growing up in the hardscrabble railroad town of Lebanon, Pa., the pro football Kerry Collins watched on television was almost always hearty and brawny football.

title: Holiday Shopping With a Purpose
description: IF you want to combine holiday shopping with helping a good cause, head to here today. Throughout the five-block-long downtown area from noon to 5 p.m. there will be Christmas music, visits from Santa Claus and festively decorated stores, which will be donating 10 percent of their sales to the new Rye Merchants Association Scholarship Fund.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Nov. 14 supplement for ''Stuart Little'' referred incorrectly to the title character. It is a digital mouse, not an animatronic one.

title: Chechen Rebels Counterattack East of Besieged Capital
description: As Russian artillery continued a savage pounding of Chechnya's capital, largely reducing to rubble the remainder of a city of 250,000, Chechen militants said they had staged their first major counterattack and retaken most of a town in a hilly region 20 miles to the east.

title: In Land of the Car, All Take the Wheel, Few Deign to Park
description: Los Angeles A to Z, an encyclopedia of this city's history and folkways published by the University of California Press, lists ''automobile'' as ''a feature of the regional culture so dominant as to defy brief description,'' and that seems a safe understatement. Here in the region that perfected drive-through banking, drive-in restaurants and drive-by shootings, people do almost everything with their cars.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Ralph Walks, Theory Talks
description: The academic novel has achieved a certain cachet in recent years, and if trying to outdo last year's offerings has become something of a contest, Percival Everett's GLYPH (Graywolf, $22.95) is a likely winner. Told from the viewpoint of a hypercritical infant named Ralph, the child of a hostile literary theorist whom he nicknames Inflato and a vaguely maternal painter he calls Mo, the novel is both a treatise and a romp. His genius evident only through his scribbled notes (he is mute by choice), Ralph is kidnapped, first by a grim psychiatrist, then re-kidnapped by a host of others, including the United States Army and a Mexican prison guard in what Roland Barthes, who also appears here, might call the abduction of the text. Along the way there are sendups of everything from semiotics to military intelligence, deconstruction and cognitive psychology. Everett, whose previous work includes novels, short stories and children's literature, has always gone in unexpected directions, and here his omnivorous intelligence and wordplay match Ralph's imperiled intellect perfectly. To quote Ralph: ''Choosing not to engage in speech had its drawbacks, among them an inability to summon help from the next room.'' If the novel has a shortcoming, it's not the glorious excess (there are footnotes on almost every page), but that you probably had to have been in the academy in the 1970's and '80s to appreciate the infatuation with literary ''big theory.'' Still, it's hard to fault a novel that features a mock dialogue between Socrates and James Baldwin. Exegesis, anyone? David Galef

title: The Assault On Good News
description: Andrew Sullivan cites falling poverty and joblessness rates as evidence that the poor in America never had it so good (Counter Culture, Nov. 7). But these indicators mask ugly realities. For the past decade, we have kept the household income threshold that officially denotes poverty at an absurdly low level; in addition, the proliferation of low-wage jobs has shattered the traditional link between finding full-time work and escaping poverty. Government and private economists agree that the bottom 40 percent of United States households are worse off now than they were 20 years ago. This is not an invention of the political left, and it should be discussed and debated in the coming presidential election campaign -- Sullivan's swipes at Bill Bradley notwithstanding.

title: Chewing Scenery
description: A Life on

title: Off the Hook On Phone Stocks
description: Brokers at Merrill Lynch don't have to hold their phone pitches after all.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Metro-North train stations in Westchester referred incorrectly to the Mamaroneck stop. There is indeed a station house. Built in 1888, it is on the west side of the tracks, with a ticket office and a coffee vendor.

title: Rutgers Estimates Its Value To the State, In Dollars
description: Rutgers University contributes $2.19 billion to the state economy in salaries, taxes and other expenditures each year, according to a study conducted by the university.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM -- CITYPEOPLE; Young Chef at Hale House Returns Love With Cooking
description: Albert Saxon stepped into the meeting room at Hale House clad in his pristine white chef's outfit minus the hat. He was still getting used to the uniform, and the hat was too much too soon, he said. But he was glad to be back at Hale House, the nursery for children of drug-addicted mothers where his own life began.

title: Ms. Feigenbaum And Mr. Turnof
description: Stacy Lynn Feigenbaum, a daughter of Sheila and Maurice Feigenbaum of Edison, N.J., is to be married today to Aaron Jay Turnof, the son of Harriet and Jack Turnof of Wayne, N.J. Rabbi Michel Gurkov is to officiate at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J.

title: TENNIS; Agassi and Sampras Earn ATP Showdown by Winning in Straight Sets
description: Andre Agassi and Pete Sampras won their semifinal matches today at the ATP World Championship to set up a Sunday final pitting the year's best player against the undisputed player of the decade.

title: Virginia Tech Is Undeserving
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: In Full Bloom
description: DREAMING BY THE BOOK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENWALD, STEPHEN
description: GREENWALD-Stephen. On November 25, 1999. Survived and deeply mourned by his wife Lita, his sister Rita Klein, numerous nieces and nephews and a multitude of friends. Services 12 noon Sunday, November 28th, East 55th Conservative Synagogue, 308 East 55 Street. In lieu of flowers contribution to The Mariom Foundation, c/o Greenwald, 785 Park Ave, New York, NY 10021 would be greatly appreciated. ''The elements so mixed in him that Nature might stand up and say to the world, this was a man!''

title: One Way to Meet a Gambit Is to Offer Another Gambit
description: There is no set blueprint for tournaments. Indeed, the rise of open Swiss-system events means that tournament sponsors and organizers have a virtually unlimited choice of formats.

title: Skating on Thick Ice
description: Susanna Rahkamo and Petri Kokko, skating partners who became a married couple, had a vision, a crystalline fantasy interrupted only by the sound of blades skimming across a plane of ice and temperatures some 20 harrowing degrees below zero. They wanted to take skating back to its origins in the outdoors of their native Finland.

title: Condominium Conversions Are Gaining in Chicago
description: ALMOST seven years after he moved into a two-bedroom rental on the top floor of a downtown high-rise here, Kenneth Green finally got what he was hoping for -- a conversion notice.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOROWITZ, SARAH GAYER
description: HOROWITZ-Sarah Gayer. November 28, 1967. I miss you, Mommy.

title: Walking Wapping's Streets
description: Your Molly has never been false, she declares,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, MARGARET MORRILL
description: WILLIAMS-Margaret Morrill., 77, died on November 21, 1999 at the Hilton Head Medical Center and Clinics, Hilton Head Island, SC. A life long resident of Bronxville until 1981, she was active in a variety of social, civic and charitable organizations, including Planned Parenthood of Westchester, the Vestry and Altar Guild of Christ Church in Bronxville, Musical Therapy (precursor to The Song Pipers), the Junior League of Bronxville and the Westchester Cotillion Committee. Survived by her five children: Centes C. Williams of Bronxville, NY, William L. Williams, Jr. of Brentwood, TN, David M. Williams of New York City, Margaret W. Loftus of Scarsdale, NY, Abbe W. Winn of Atlanta; six grandchildren; her sister Centes M. Papes of Mt. Kisco, NY and her brother David C. Morrill of Tuscon, AZ. She was preceded in death by her husband William L. Williams. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church, Bronxville, NY on Saturday, December 11, 2PM. Memorial contributions to Planned Parenthood HudsonPeconic, 11 Skyline Drive, Hawthorne, New York 10532 or Christ Church, 17 Sagamore Road, Bronxville, New York 10708.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the special Holiday Films supplement on Nov. 14 for the movie based on Pushkin's 1833 verse novel misstated its title. It is ''Onegin,'' not ''Eugene Onegin.''

title: Streetscapes/Manhattan Avenue Between 104th and 106th Streets; 1880's Brick Row Houses With a Bostonian Air
description: THE picturesque pocket of Victorian row houses on Manhattan Avenue from 104th to 106th Streets, which date from the time the thoroughfare got its name, has a calm Bostonian air that makes it seem a bit removed from city life.

title: Brookhaven Reactor Loss Was a Plus for All
description: Don Garber's essay [''The Loss in Brookhaven's Reactor,'' Nov. 21] would lead you to believe that without Brookhaven National Laboratory's High Flux Beam Reactor, certain aspects of science will come to a standstill. Mr. Garber also would have you believe that no community input was involved in the decision to close it forever, and that opposition to the reactor was some sort of left-wing conspiracy.

title: Brother's Keeper
description: As a doctor who works at several prisons, I was appalled at your Ethicist's (Nov. 7) answer to C.F., whose brother is in prison. Unless New York is very different from my state, both the inmates and the prison officials would be aware of this man's H.I.V. status. Testing is routine in most state prisons. Those who test positive are treated, and certain precautions are taken. Since other inmates are aware of which medications are used and what the precautions mean, it would be difficult to keep H.I.V. status secret.

title: November 21-27; U.S. Economy Steams Ahead
description: The government's latest snapshot of the nation's $8.9 trillion economy revealed even more momentum than had been thought.

title: Science Fiction
description: Frank Herbert, a newspaperman by trade, died in 1986. He is best known for the series of novels that began in 1965 with ''Dune.'' Set on a desert planet that holds the key to humanity's destiny, this book and its five sequels stand as one of science fiction's grandest feats of informed imagination. The ecology of Dune, with its Bedouin-like Fremen and the mammoth sandworms that dominate its food chain, was worked out to a degree never before seen in the genre; ''Dune'' was cited as a learning tool in the first ''Whole Earth Catalog,'' a book that introduced an entire generation to the concept of our planet as a dynamically adaptable yet ultimately fragile environment.

title: Commercial Property; High-Tech Growth Filling Financial District Offices
description: JOSEPH MOINIAN stood at the corner of John and Gold Streets recently and recalled what it was like in this downtown office district in the middle of the decade. ''Eighty John Street was fully vacant, 90 John Street was 68 percent vacant, 99 John Street was about to become fully vacant and 90 William Street was 60 percent vacant,'' he said. ''It was a ghost town.''

title: Foreign Affairs; EgyptAir 990
description: When EgyptAir Flight 990 went down I thought of writing a column about the passenger list. I was struck by how many Americans, and particularly American Jews, were on the flight, sitting alongside 33 elite Egyptian Army officers who had been training in the U.S., as well as a host of other nationalities. I thought back to the first time I visited Cairo in 1972, when Egypt didn't even have diplomatic relations with the U.S., let alone American or Jewish tourists. We forget, but for Americans, going to Egypt back then was almost like visiting North Korea. So it seemed to me this tragedy underscored how far Egyptian-American and Egyptian-Israeli relations had actually come since those dark days. While this was no balm for the victims' families, one hoped their common grief might bind their countries even more.

title: A Rousing Week of Records Overseas
description: Investors in France, the Netherlands, Britain and Spain last week were like fans shouting ole at a bullfight, as they lifted stock markets in those countries to new highs.

title: Comparing Places
description: To the Editor: I was flabbergasted to read W. D. Wetherell's statement that he has never been to San Francisco (''The World Comparatively Speaking,'' Oct. 17). Then he mentions a place like Tottenham in London, which is not as well known all over the world as San Francisco. Instead of one more river, I suggest he take in one more city like San Francisco.

title: Even Those Who Have Found Success Go Back to School
description: THEY have managed high-power offices, raised families, succeeded as freelance artists, come out on the plus side of serious personal crises. They have done things that clearly require skill and grit. Yet the thought of attending classes, writing papers and getting a college degree scares them.

title: Live, Loud and Ready to Go on Tour: All I Need is the Amp
description: LOTS of bars and restaurants on Long Island have signs advertising ''live music.'' These signs should be larger. They can easily be missed by careless or shortsighted patrons. More than once I've found myself sitting down for a quiet drink or dinner when, without warning or apology, a group of young people dressed in black starts setting up multiple microphones and gigantic loudspeakers on a tiny stage.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Church Fair in Bedford

title: Little Things Mean a Lot
description: It's the country's largest exporter, sells more high technology to NASA and the Department of Defense than anyone else and is famous for the complex feats of design and analysis that its engineers perform on computer work stations. But when it comes to cutting costs in a tough competitive environment, Boeing has its eyes fixed on . . . pencils.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, GRACE S.
description: GALLAGHER-Grace S.. The Board, Members and Staff of Greater New York Hospital Association express our condolences to our esteemed colleague, Jack Gallagher, Chief Executive Officer of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Healthcare System, on the passing of his beloved wife, Grace. We extend our deepest sympathy to Jack, his children, and the entire Gallagher family. Mark J. Mundy, Chairman Kenneth A. Raske, President Greater N.Y. Hospital Association

title: Corrections
description: The Frugal Traveler column on Nov. 14, about a weekend in the Boston area, referred incorrectly to its geography and to the availability of transportation to and from the Charlestown Navy Yard. The Charlestown neighborhood, where the Constitution is anchored at the Navy Yard, is on the Inner Harbor, not the Charles River. For the return to downtown Boston from the yard, the No. 93 bus stops outside Gate 4; there is also a ferry, which the author took.

title: November 21-27; Iraq Cuts Oil Sales
description: Iraq cut off the oil it is allowed to export in exchange for food, medicine and other supplies, protesting a two-week stop-gap extension of the United Nations program, which is normally rolled over for six months.

title: Menacing Mice
description: To the Editor: Barbara Strauch's article ''Camping on an Isle of Menacing Mice'' (Oct. 31) reminded me of my trip to Channel Islands National Park last summer.

title: Plant Officer Sentenced
description: A sewage plant superintendent who was blamed for the discharging of more than 120 million gallons of unchlorinated sewage into the Hudson River and pleaded guilty to a violation of state environmental law has been sentenced to 200 hours of community service aboard the sloop Clearwater.

title: Liberties; Trump Shrugged
description: Greed is good, again.

title: The Last Tribal Battle
description: I found it revealing that Diana Jean Schemo's (Oct. 31) account of the Korubu Indians (in which she ponders possible outcomes from the tribe's contact with the ''civilized'' world) ran in the same issue as Lisa Belkin's exploration of the aftermath of Columbine High. Schemo writes: ''In September, a Korubu couple saw an anaconda pull one of their children, a 3-year-old girl, underwater. She never surfaced. Should such a life of hardship be preserved?'' Throughout the article, the author refers to the ''inferior evolution'' of this tribe, compared with ''civilized'' society. Yet the juxtaposition of the two articles serves as a grim reminder that, despite all our technological development, we have ''evolved'' from a society that fears for our children to one that fears our children. Progress, indeed.

title: M.B.A. Boom Fades as Candidates Seek Instead the Rewards of the Internet

After college, he joined a consulting firm, where he advised blue-chip companies like AT&T, General Motors and I.B.M. He then applied to a few business schools, gained admission to Stanford, the most selective of them all, and prepared to enroll this fall.

The former restaurant at the Roslyn Claremont Hotel had food that centered around Tuscany and decor that evoked a garden with white lattices, peach-sponged walls, flowers, cascading greenery and a three-story atrium ceiling.

And it has grown from 1958, when it was called the Christmas Antiques Bazaar and the State Armory in downtown Greenwich was host to 40 dealers. This season, almost 50 dealers are gathering at the Civic Center in Old Greenwich.

It trims the structure that holds the disco ball. And it illuminates 20 street signs, like the one for Fusco's Paint Store, where Tony Manero, the lead character, works.

title: Croatia Looks Wistfully to Europe as Leader Nears Death
description: The imminent death of Croatia's founder and president, Franjo Tudjman, no matter who succeeds him, will take much of the personal animosity and heat out of the country's strained relationships with Washington and the European Union, turning at least a part of the Balkans more firmly westward, senior Croatian officials and Western diplomats say.

title: Integration Anxiety
description: As a resident of Montclair, N.J., with three children in the public schools (one of them at the Renaissance School), I was interested to read Lise Funderburg's good article (Nov. 7) about the difficulties of maintaining a racially and economically diverse community. But she missed one critical point: New Jersey does not give any of its handful of integrated school districts aid to support integration, despite the significantly greater costs associated with integrated schools. (For example, Montclair spends $2.5 million on busing alone.) Although the governor and legislators espouse the values of integration and diversity, state aid to Montclair's public schools has declined.

title: A Turbulent Trade Meeting
description: Officials from the 135 member countries of the World Trade Organization will meet in Seattle starting Tuesday, not to solve the world's trade disputes but merely to set an agenda for the next round of negotiations. Even that will not be easy. Rich countries are squabbling with poor countries. Thousands of street demonstrators are expected to denounce the organization for trampling on the rights of third-world workers, the sovereignty of individual countries and the environment.

title: A Holbrook Mountain Rises and Spirits Fall

''Everybody makes jokes that it looks like we're in Colorado,'' she said. ''But when you see the trucks up there working, you know what it is. It's a dump. We're living in the midst of an industrial site. I'm embarrassed to have my friends come over.''

Residents of Connecticut will be celebrating with gusto as well, despite reports of champagne shortages and the rising price of filet mignon. Doctors, they were told, would no longer be forced to seek approval for treatments. Instead, the emphasis would be on meeting patients' medical needs effectively.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-28-99: The Ethicist; The Office Spy

The assistant had no information that anyone was helping her -- until the fax machine spit out a document from an executive at another company analyzing one of the studio's scripts. Should she have made a copy of this document? If so, what should she do with it? Should she really be a snitch?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, JANET LAIB
description: GOTTLIEB-Janet Laib. A fashion writer and publicist, died Friday, November 26 from cancer. She was 73. Mrs. Gottlieb left college and moved to New York after publishing her first freelance article, ''Must College Girls Wear Diapers?'' about the coddling of co-eds. Though intending a life on the stage, she instead found a career in magazine publishing and freelance writing. She worked at Seventeen and the Tobe Fashion Report, and her byline appeared in Vogue, Ladies Home Journal, The New York Times and other publications. She formed Janet Laib Public Relations, with a small stable of clients including Xerox, Hathaway Shirts and William Greenberg Jr. Desserts. In 1981, she became president of Edward Gottlieb Inc., a communications firm, and subsequently married her partner, Mr. Gottlieb. They worked on communications strategies for merger and acquisitions and crisis management for clients including Volkswagen US, Bear Stearns and Fleet Bank. Mrs. Gottlieb kept her passion for theater, and was one of the first backers of the play ''Wit.'' She belonged to The Fashion Group, the Overseas Press Club and The Financial Women's Association, as well as the Public Relations Society of America, the American Society of Journalists and Authors, and the Players Club. Born in Detroit, she attended the George School in Bucks County, PA and the University of Michigan, receiving her B.A. from the New School for Social Research in New York. She leaves a daughter, Margo Amgott. Her husband predeceased her. Burial is private. A memorial service will be held at 4 PM, Saturday, December 11 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Contributions may be made to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, Development Office, 107 E. 70 St., NY, NY 10021 or to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Development Office, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLIGAN, THOMAS CLAVIN, SR
description: GALLIGAN-Thomas Clavin, Sr. Age 91. Former Associate General Counsel of Colgate Palmolive. Died on November 24, 1999 at Blount Memorial Hospital, Maryville, TN. Orphaned at 9, Galligan moved to Montclair, NJ at 13 and graduated from Montclair H.S. in 1925. With the assistance of his Aunt Sara Clavin, he put himself through Rutgers University from which he received his B.A. in 1929 and then Cornell Law School from which he received his LL.B. in 1932. The next year he joined the Law Department of Colgate Palmolive where he worked for the next 52 years, the longest service any lawyer has ever provided to Colgate. Specializing in labor and employment law and advertising law he was devoted to following both the letter and spirit of the law. He was a member of the bar in both New York and New Jersey. Galligan was a loyal alumnus of both Rutgers and Cornell. He was the author of the Class Notes of the class of 1929 in the Rutgers Alumni Magazine for many years and wrote a biography of the class for its 50th reunion in 1979. Galligan regularly assisted both schools in their fund raising efforts. He endowed the Sara Clavin Scholarship at Rutgers and the Galligan Faculty Development Fund at Seattle University School of Law. He lived in Montclair from 1921 to 1998 where he moved to Louisiana and then Tennessee in order to be closer to his family. In Montclair, he attended Immaculate Conception Church and was a member of the Knights of Columbus. He was preceded in death by his wife Elizabeth, his brother Raymond Galligan and his sister Sara Galligan, all formerly of Montclair. He is survived by his son Thomas C. Galligan, Jr., Dean and Professor of Law at the University of Tennessee College of Law; his daughter-in-law Susan Galligan and his grandchildren Patrick 14, Sarah 12, Aisling 10 and Jennifer 7 of Knoxville, TN. The body was cremated and a memorial service will be conducted on December 11th at 9:30 AM at Immaculate Conception Church in Montclair, New Jersey. For more information call Smith Mortuary, Maryville, TN, (865-983-1000).

Leading the program, directed by Leit Bjaland, is Ravel's ''Alborado del Gracioso,'' variously described by Mr. Bjaland as ''a post-impressionistic vision of romance'' and ''a brilliant work filled with sun-drenched brights and enameled colors.'' Next comes Saint-Saens's Violin Concerto No. 3, with Benny Kim. Finally, there are excerpts from Berlioz's ''Romeo and Juliet.''

title: Welcome to Paradise
description: From dot.com executive suites to fast-food service counters, the worker is king. Employers have to roll out the red carpet for potential hires, and multiply the incentives for workers to stay. Competitive pay is only a start. Employers have been known to troll the competition's after-hours hangouts, or to turn their cafeterias into four-star restaurants. What are the most creative ways you have found to hire and keep employees? Or the best blandishments you have been offered? Send your stories to On the Job, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by e-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARTER, DAVID
description: CARTER-David. My beloved father, six years in heaven, joined this August by my cherished mother Pauline. Each year the memories grow fonder and my love deepens. The photos and videotapes help bridge the gap, but nothing can fill the void of not having either of you to call up and schmooze with. So pardon me for not knowing which way to face when I address the heavens in search of your love and advice. Unending love & devotion, Donny.

Survived by her sons Dr. Matthew Fine (Isabell) and Henry Fine (Amy), brother Bert Gerzog (Natalie), three grandchildren, and long time friend Irwin Blocker. title: Giving Voice to 'Gatsby'
description: In the spring of 1996, Andre Previn, the former conductor of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, and his friend and sometime colleague, the composer John Harbison, were both working on operas. Previn was finishing up the score for Philip Littell's adaptation of Tennessee Williams's ''Streetcar Named Desire''; Harbison was polishing the music for his own libretto of F. Scott Fitzgerald's ''Great Gatsby.'' Struggling to adapt the ancient conventions of opera to a 20th-century aesthetic -- and to an audience more used to television and the movies than to a form of sung drama in which the action is periodically interrupted for still more singing -- the two composers occasionally became a little ''manic,'' Harbison recalled recently. To let off steam, they used to call each other up.

title: An Art Project Built on Words and Intended to Catapult the Imagination
description: THE adult notion of public art took form here recently when a 7-foot sculpture, largely designed by students, was unveiled in front of the Edgewood Elementary School. Rooted to the landscape near a gracefully arching tree, the four-paneled work is meant to represent the lasting value of a caring school community.

description: CLERK is a magic word,'' Bob Greene told his students at Hofstra University. ''All the records are there for you to see. Anyone, a landscaper, contractor or whoever, has to file applications with the town clerk.''

For the graceful raptor flew in closer from the horizon fringe where it had first been spotted and teased the gathering near the beachfront by pausing directly overhead, like a dancer on the wind.

More often, though, they are allowed to tiptoe in -- but just so far. That, frequently, is the battleground -- defining exactly how many steps they can take inside.

title: Danielle Corigliano and Jon Thorson
description: Danielle Corigliano and Dr. Jon Scott Thorson were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. Bernard L. Keitz performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer.

title: Pay on Delivery
description: I appreciated Margaret Talbot's elegant testimonial to the value of epidural analgesia in childbirth (The Way We Live Now, Oct. 31). Nowhere else in the practice of modern medicine do we find it acceptable for a patient to experience pain when a safe alternative is so readily available. The provision of relief from labor pain has been a controversial subject for centuries. Yet it continues to amaze me that women in labor -- even now, in this decade of patient advocacy and patient choice -- are still actively dissuaded from utilizing pain relief. It is my hope that the press can build on the wealth of published medical research, which demonstrates that epidural pain relief in labor is safe (for infant and mother).

title: On Reading History Between the Lines of Faces
description: IT seems that no two 20th centuries are alike. Most of the planet lived through the same amazing technological changes and the same two world wars, and in this media era the vast majority saw the same or similar visual reports of major events; nonetheless, every nation has a distinct version of history and a distinct way of looking at the past. Even within one country, people see and experience the time largely the way they choose to; it may be that each one of us has a personal version of national history and another of international history as well.

title: Tower Plan Hits Snag
description: A plan to allow a cellular phone tower to be placed on Ossining High School by Sprint PCS has run into opposition by some community members. Although the contract was approved by the Ossining Board of Education in September last year, ongoing community opposition -- based mostly on potential health risks but also on concern about the commercialization of school property -- led the board to announce at a meeting earlier this month that it would seek to renegotiate the contract with Sprint.

description: Whether they are at home in the Garden, or on the road, the Rangers continue to confront the same question again and again: how can a team this well-paid be so bad?

A member of the New York Board of Trade, was active in the ''Made in America'' campaign. A graduate of Syracuse, flag officer of the Stamford Yacht Club and the Corinthian Club. Wasn't Ronald Reagan responsible for all that?

title: ON POLITICS; Two Votes on Development Provide Lawmakers an Out

title: Holidays With the Ballantines
description: Picture Christmas Eve, 1891. John and Jeannette Ballantine, of the Ballantine brewery family, have prepared their Newark mansion to receive family and friends. That setting has been recreated at the Ballantine House by the Newark Museum for an exhibition through Jan. 2.

title: Bookend; Lincoln as We Know Him
description: The people who have changed our human world for the better are not commonly easy to like or know. Lincoln was no exception: loose-jointed, slackly attired, gigantic and homely, as the descriptions have him; a man who was sometimes capable of putting others at ease but never himself. We can think we know him -- there are so many facts. But do they bring him closer? Hardly a season passes without a new book about Lincoln the man. This autumn has seen the publication of two: ''Lincoln on Lincoln,'' selected and edited by Paul M. Zall (University Press of Kentucky), an anthology mainly culled from speeches and letters, and ''Lincoln as I Knew Him: Gossip, Tributes, and Revelations From His Best Friends and Worst Enemies,'' edited by Harold Holzer (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill). The winter will bring an agreeable study in a newer genre, ''Lincoln: A Foreigner's Quest'' (Simon & Schuster), a snapshot biography and amateur tour of Lincoln's career by the English travel writer Jan Morris. Together these books might be supposed to convey the inner and the outer Lincoln. Perhaps the best compliment one can pay to their truthfulness is to say that they leave the mystery untouched.

description: Under Linda Bruckheimer's direction, rural Bloomfield (pop. 1,100) is getting the full Hollywood treatment.

But this month Mr. Hayun's MC Furniture and 15 other businesses in the three-building complex, employing a total of 250 people, will have to find new homes or close for good.

description: LESLIE GLASS wants to know your name, your town, your quirks and the type of lethal weapon you'd carry. She needs your nickname -- provided it's not Scarface. Tell her about the most precious thing in your life, and your biggest fear. And let her know whether you'd like to be the victim, perpetrator, suspect or law enforcer in her next book.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIP, BARBARA ALICE BOYLE
description: KIP-Barbara Alice Boyle. died on Friday, November 19, 1999 at her home in Millwood, New York from cancer of the lung. She was born in New York City on February 25, 1927, a daughter of the late William P. and Jane Boyle. She was a lifelong resident of Briarcliff Manor, Ossining and Millwood, N.Y. area. Barbara graduated from the Briarcliff Manor High School. She attended the College of Wooster in Wooster, Ohio and graduated from George Washington University in Washington, D.C., in 1949. In 1950 she married Ruloff F. Kip, Jr. of Montclair, N.J., at All Saints Church in Briarcliff Manor. During her life, Barbara was active in many ways as a volunteer. She was, for forty years, a Red Cross Grey Lady at the Veterans Hospital in Montrose, N.Y., and she was a volunteer ombudsman for the Long Term Care Office of the State of New York. She was also a volunteer driver for many years of the American Cancer Society. She was active in local programs at her parish, Saint Pauls on-theHill Episcopal Church in Ossining, N.Y. and she served on numerous committees and commissions of the Episcopal Diocese of New York. She was a 50-year member of the Patrons of Husbandry (also known as the Grange). She is survived by her husband, Ruloff F. Kip Jr; a son, Phelps C. Kip Jr., and his wife, Krista; a son, Nicholas H. Kip and his wife Lucinda; three daughters, Carlotta B. Kip, Stephanie J. Kip and Katrinka T. Kip; two grandchildren, Alexander and Elizabeth Kip, born of Nicholas and Lucinda Kip; two brothers, William P. Boyle, Jr. and Barrie Boyle; and a niece Tracy Wilkes, her husband Paul Wilkes and several other nieces and nephews. She was predeceased by her sister, Virginia Boyle Wisser, and she is expected to be survived by the yet unborn daughter, Hanna Kip, of Phelps and Krista Kip. Services further will be at St. Paul's on-the-Hill Episcopal Church, at 40 Ganung Drive, Ossining, New York, 10562, at 11 AM on December 4, 1999. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations in her memory either to The Bosler Humane Society (a home for abandoned animals), P.O. Box 12, Baldwinville, Mass., 01436, or to Phelps Hospice Phelps Memorial Hospital Center, 701 N. Broadway, Sleepy Hollow, N.Y., 10592-1096.

title: Ads and Billboards Urge Drivers to Act Friendly
description: In an effort to combat road rage, the state Division of Highway Traffic Safety last week began a campaign urging the public to ''Drive Friendly.''

title: Having A Fit Over Carry-ons
description: HERE are some of the things that airline flight attendants have watched passengers lug on board: Mariachi hats, potted palms, boogie boards, shopping bags brimming with canned hams, a live duck in a cage, cases of wine, covered-dish casseroles, multi-tiered wedding cakes, a three-foot-tall religious statue for lawn display, an automobile transmission and a freshly severed buck's head with its antlers poking out of a trash bag.

title: A Madcap Day in Marrakesh
description: COME with me to ze casbah,'' Aunt Ettie said, curling her finger. I was 8 and she was the family traveler, the one who kept her bags permanently packed in case Cunard had a discount berth at the last minute.

title: Spanish Wines Answer Every Culinary Matchup
description: YEARS ago when I updated my sound system, one thing I insisted on was a turntable. All those albums were never going to appear on CD and I was not ready to give up my musical memories. One record from 1964 in the collection is Bob Dylan's ''Times They Are A-Changin' .'' One cut in particular resonates over the decades, ''Boots of Spanish Leather.'' All those years ago I found it sophomorically moving in its appreciation of loss, but then again, I was a sophomore.

title: Keith Jarrett Meditates on Mortality
description: KEITH JARRETT'S new solo album, ''The Melody at Night, With You,'' begs a listener to think about the relationship between music and mortality. Mr. Jarrett, the Proust of jazz, had chronic fatigue syndrome recently, and for a while the Internet was bubbling with rumors of his imminent demise that gained credence after he canceled several concerts. The album is dedicated to his wife, Rose Anne, and if one reads the song titles -- ''I Got It Bad and That Ain't Good,'' ''Somebody to Watch Over Me,'' ''Don't Ever Leave Me'' -- it can be surmised that she has been an integral part of making Mr. Jarrett healthy again.

title: A Personal Message That Is Larger Than Life
description: On a billboard at 14th Street and First Avenue, John Greeley has placed an ad seeking an ''attractive, intelligent woman, 23-35,'' to make his life complete.

title: Integration Anxiety
description: Your article on Montclair's efforts to achieve racial balance was troubling on several levels. Perhaps most disturbing was the classroom discussion with a young black male who seemed to have been led to the conclusion that he was discriminated against by being denied entry to a local store. There appeared to be no follow-up questioning of the white males in the classroom to determine if they had experienced similar difficulties. Also, there seemed to be no attempt by your writer to contact the store owner to inquire about his policy of excluding juveniles. Could it be because of prior experiences with shoplifting that cut across racial lines?

title: Johnson Put on Injured List

title: Cold War Without End
description: Wandering around Herb Romerstein's house, but not knowing Herb Romerstein, you might think you had happened upon the lair of America's last surviving Stalinist. On the walls hang tattered posters for Popular Front rallies and Communist candidates. Knickknack cases display K.G.B. medals and yellowing photos of Bolshevik heroes. In the basement is the ''Felix Dzerzhinsky Memorial Library,'' named for the founder of Lenin's secret police. Crammed into every corner are books, transcripts, pamphlets and files that constitute a vast archive on American Communism. Completing the picture, a snow-white spitz guards the trove.

title: Ulster Unionists Open Way to Govern With Sinn Fein
description: Opening the way for a new power-sharing arrangement in Northern Ireland, the Ulster Unionist Party today approved the entry of its leaders into government with its sworn rivals from Sinn Fein, the political ally of the Irish Republican Army.

title: Discovering The Land Left Behind
description: I HAD never seen most of my country, Argentina. During my 19 years in Buenos Aires, my parents and I seldom traveled outside the capital. Vacations were an unaffordable luxury. Now I can afford to see what I had read about in school, what I had known only as dots on a map or pictures in a textbook.

title: A Tired Theme
description: To the Editor:

title: Laborers Wanted, but Not Living Next Door
description: Down a slate path, behind a row of hedges and white vinyl-sided walls, Roberto Tobar Galvez, 24, shares a small ranch house here with more than a dozen other day laborers from the state of Hidalgo in central Mexico. Each morning they gather on street corners in the hopes of being hired for construction and gardening jobs that can pay $80 to $100 a day.

title: Syracuse, Humbled, Still Expects a Bowl
description: The Syracuse Orangemen, despite reeling from four losses in their last five games, remain adamant about the value of participating in a bowl game this season.

title: Models, Defiantly Gray, Give Aging a Sexy New Look
description: FLIPPING through Banana Republic's new winter and holiday catalogs, shoppers are confronted with page after page of flawless young beauties showing off the chain's stylish, modern clothes.

title: Cultural Turbulence Reflected In Exhibition of Still Lifes
description: STILL LIFE paintings are often regarded as complacent and predictable. But the issues that are brought to the table, so to speak, do not always stay still. Rather than merely showing off how good the artist is at rendering objects realistically, a still life can be as charged -- politically, religiously and erotically -- as any other genre of painting. And because a still life has a veneer of order and propriety, deviations from that are often extremely potent.

title: A Wright House
description: To the Editor: In her article ''Rediscovering a Colorful College Town'' (Oct. 31) Brenda Fowler wondered if students ever occupied Frank Lloyd Wright's house at 22 North Butler Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEWART, JOHN G.
description: STEWART-John G.. Age 80, died after a brief illness, on November 23, at his home in Rumson, New Jersey. He is survived by his wife Linda; his sister, Jane Heckman of Lombard, IL; a son Mark Stewart of Monmouth Hills, NJ; a daughter Jennifer Stewart of Studio City, CA; three stepchildren and twelve grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at All Saints Church, Navesink, NJ, November 30 at 2:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that memorial contributions be made to the Alzheimer's Association, Central NJ Chapter, 12 Roszel Road, Suite C201, Princeton, NJ 08540-6234.

title: Lives; One Last Chance
description: I got addicted to gambling after winning an ''Omaha Hi-Lo'' poker tournament in Santa Fe toward the end of the summer of 1997. I'd spent the season learning the game -- mostly from Jack, a retired sailor who divided his time between the poker and craps tables. I had a history of overindulging in every new pleasure, but Jack was the kind of gambler who'd take a modest profit and walk away -- if only to another table. He didn't push his luck, but he seemed sure that as long as he played well, it would never really run out. Gambling was something he took seriously. It was his hobby, his intellectual pursuit, his distinguishing skill. He told this joke: There was a guy who used most of his money for women, booze and gambling; the rest of it he just frittered away.

title: Venice
description: To the Editor: As a resident of Venice many years ago, I know there are wonderful hidden corners with modestly priced restaurants, shops, even hotels, as described by Daisann McLane ''The Siren Charm of Venice,'' (Oct. 31). Unfortunately, most tourists do not seek them out.

title: Corrections
