title: Satisfying a Basic Drive: I Am, Therefore I Shop
description: IN an era when advice spills forth on every subject, I occasionally do the unthinkable when it comes to shopping: I go by instinct.

title: Turkey Faces A Quandary On Rebellions By Its Friends
description: The war raging in Chechnya has exposed one of Turkey's most delicate diplomatic problems.

title: Broadcast of Man's Death Rekindles a Debate in Los Angeles
description: The year after a suicide broadcast on live television prompted soul-searching and public apologies from news directors, five Southern California stations showed a car chase on Friday that ended with the man being shot to death by police officers.

title: A Small, Gentle World
description: Working in South Jersey for 36 years, Paul Stankard has been creating intimately sized glass sculptures of extraordinary beauty. As an internationally acclaimed artist in the contemporary glass movement, Mr. Stankard uses a torch flame to melt and manipulate glass rods into subjects of remarkable detail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEUER, LUCY
description: FEUER-Lucy. On Thursday November 25, 1999 of Tamarac, Florida. Beloved wife of the late Otto Feuer; loving mother of Michael Feuer (Regine); loving mother to Peter Feuer (Adrienne) and Doris Brown; beloved grandma to Elise, Sherri, Lindsay, Ashley, Sarah ''Butterfly'' and Jonathan ''Muldoony''; devoted companion to Henry Lebensold. Another leg in the journey. Funeral service will be held at Temple Micah, 2829 Wisconsin Avenue NW, Washington, D.C. 20007, Sunday November 28, 1999 at 1 PM. Interment Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Adelphi, MD. Shiva will be observed at the residence of Michael Feuer. For further info, contact Tacoma Funeral Home, Washington, DC.

title: Sharpton Assails Crackdown on Homeless
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton yesterday denounced Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's recent crackdown on homeless people and called on New Yorkers to monitor and report police efforts to sweep the homeless off the streets. Mr. Sharpton said he planned to hold an all-night ''tent city'' vigil for the homeless at City Hall Park on Dec. 5.

title: Package Trip Vs. a la Carte
description: A FREQUENT question to this department is how travel packages can be offered at prices lower, sometimes, than even the cheapest air fare to the place involved. Are the hotels terrible? Is the flight aboard Aero Mysterioso? How do packages work?

title: Artistry and Social Compassion in Counterpoint
description: ANOTHER opening, another show: surely there are more humane ways than this to think about earthquakes. But unless you have the misfortune to be struck by one, a seismologic event usually arrives packaged as prime-time entertainment, with unctuous news anchors or made-for-TV actors reciting their lines over numbing boom-de-boom soundtracks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTOCK, DAVID
description: WEINSTOCK-David. Young Israel of Forest Hills mourns the passing of its member, David Weinstock. May the Almighty console the family together with all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Looking Closely At Domestic Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Insurance Coverage For a Co-op
description: HOMEOWNERS are often admonished to make sure that the hazard and liability insurance on their homes is up to date and that it provides all the needed coverage. Co-op shareholders are likewise advised -- usually by boards of directors or the building's lawyers -- to obtain insurance for the furniture and fixtures within their apartments, because the coverage provided by the building's hazard policy essentially stops at a tenant-shareholder's door.

title: From Russia, With Dark Humor, Like the Old Days
description: AT last year's New York Film Festival, the director Aleksei Guerman, a bear of a man with a disarming wit and a typically Russian sense of irony, introduced his latest work, ''Khroustaliov, My Car!'' to the press. It was the first time in his 40-year career, he said, that he had completed a film that had not been immediately shelved by the authorities. His previous work, ''My Friend Ivan Lapshin,'' spent four years in limbo before its release in 1985, when it became a celebrated film of the perestroika era. ''After every film I made, I was fired from my job,'' he said.

title: A Luxury Pharmacy May Soon Sell One Less Product
description: Standing in a street cloaked in afternoon mist, two office workers gazed at the gold jewelry gleaming in the pharmacy window.

title: Pataki Seeks a Trade-Off With Democrats to Cut Medicaid
description: In secret negotiations, Gov. George E. Pataki is pushing his Democratic rivals in the Legislature to cut Medicaid spending steeply as part of a deal to preserve a program that pays hospitals billions of dollars to treat uninsured patients and train doctors, according to people involved in the talks.

title: Genuine Plea or Cunning Ploy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Victim Might Fail to Recall Brick Attack
description: Twelve days after she was struck in the head by a brick, Nicole Barrett is talking more with her family and friends but has never mentioned the attack by a stranger on a Midtown street, her brother said yesterday.

title: Dizzy Climate or Not, Works That Intrigue
description: THE Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield could have had an easy time of ''Best of the Season,'' a show that aims to bring some the most important contemporary work shown in New York galleries to Connecticut. The show might have been confined to more or less conventional painting and sculpture, but it would then neglect the fact that the current art world climate is especially dizzying. The organizer, Harry Philbrick, who is also the Aldrich's director, imported some very complex, technically ambitious works, as well as pieces that are easily moved and mounted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VON GRONICKA, ANDRE
description: VON GRONICKA-Andre. Of Philadelphia, PA on November 23, 1999. Predeceased by his wife Hilde (nee Stock) von Gronicka (1997). Father of Andrea Rudner and Ingrid O'Riordan. title: Venice
description: To the Editor: In 1959, newly married, my wife and I had a wonderful time in Venice, but I rejected the calls of several gondoliers (''Gondola, sir?'') because we were on a tight budget. For years afterward my wife reminded me of this by repeating the words ''Gondola, sir?''

title: Soup Comes to the Rescue as a First Course Idea
description: A FRIEND called recently to see if I could offer any suggestions for easy first courses. In the summer, it is not difficult to come up with ideas. But come fall and winter, one of the simplest dishes to serve when you are having a dinner party is soup, since it only improves when it is made in advance.

title: Carry-On Weight
description: To the Editor: On Oct. 30, I checked in on British Airways Flight 4517 from Gatwick to Tampa, Fla. This was my first flight on B.A. in some time; my outbound flight had been on another carrier.

title: Sufia Kamal, Poet and Advocate, Dies at 88
description: Sufia Kamal, a Bangladeshi poet, political activist and feminist, died at age 88 on Nov. 20 and was buried four days later with full state honors, the first woman to receive that recognition from Bangladesh.

title: Early Sex Abuse Hinders Many Women on Welfare
description: Caseworkers rarely ask and clients rarely tell, but growing evidence suggests that disproportionately large numbers of women on welfare were sexually abused as children, a finding that offers new insight into many of the so-called hard cases that are an increasing focus of the national effort to overhaul the welfare system.

title: Warnings Issued on Safety Of Some Holiday Toys
description: The state Department of Consumer Affairs and New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, a consumer and government watchdog agency, last week issued a warning to parents to avoid buying small toy balls and plastic toys made with toxic chemicals. One warning was about toy balls smaller than 1.75 inches in diameter and any toy with small removable parts; the danger is that that a child will choke on the ball or pieces, said Gerald Flanagan, a consumer advocate with the public-interest group. In 1998, 14 children in the United States died from toy-related accidents, mostly from choking, he said.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-28-99: On Language; Bread 'N' Butter
description: I am not in the least superstitious, but I know enough not to open an umbrella indoors, leave shoes on a table or a hat on a bed, touch somebody with a broom or rock an empty rocking chair. When any of these sure-fire invitations to misfortune occur, I -- like anyone who hears a sneeze -- say, ''Bless you!'' The latest medieval research tells us that this phrase -- in German, Gesundheit, ''a state of good health'' -- keeps the Devil from possessing your soul.

Devoted mother of Debra Samuelson of NYC and Cynthia Samuelson and her husband, Jonathan Samen of Lexington, MA. Dear grandmother of Joel, Hayley and Maggie. Services at the Rye Community Synagogue, 200 Forest Ave., Rye, NY on Monday, November 29, at 12 Noon. Memorial observance at her late residence until Friday, sundown. Remembrances to Women's American O.R.T., 315 Park Avenue South, NYC 10010.

title: For Whom the Toll Swells
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority has unveiled a plan for two toll increases. The first increase would take place when the E-ZPass system is installed or Jan. 1, 2001, whichever comes first, and the second on Jan. 1, 2003. It would give drivers who use the E-ZPass system a smaller increase than those who pay cash. Governor Whitman has the final say over the increases, which will be the first since 1991.

title: Idea in Chicago Is All Work With Some Play
description: There is an experiment of sorts taking place in Chicago, and if it is successful it could be a blueprint for how National Football League head coaches approach the game in the future. Bears Coach Dick Jauron is the one playing chemist, and so far he has been able to accomplish something few N.F.L. head coaches ever have: working hard while simultaneously allowing himself, his staff members and his players time for their personal lives.

title: A Survivor in the Wired Universe
description: LIZA MINNELLI, who is making a comeback of sorts, will be playing the Palace Theater in Manhattan the same week that savvier survivors will play that wall-less, electronic palace, Cable. There are documentaries floating around about the heavy metal band Metallica, still on top despite the death of one star in a freak accident and the near immolation of another in a flash of fire on stage. And then Vince McMahon, creator of the current wrestling boom and chairman of the World Wrestling Federation, has been making the rounds. He has apparently come out on top, over that telecommunications Goliath Ted Turner, by proving that wrestling will keep all the 11-year-old boys in America mesmerized so long as it gets grosser and grosser.

description: On a recent morning, Judy Wessler, who runs a nonprofit watchdog group, visited five children's health clinics situated in housing projects in the South Bronx. But she did not have much luck getting in.

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS; A Museum of His Own
description: Some people would say Ed Shirak Jr. of Hoboken is a little obsessed with Frank Sinatra. Mr. Shirak, 54, wrote a biography of Sinatra titled ''Our Way,'' self-published in 1995; photographs of the Chairman of the Board adorn his shop, Lepore's Homemade Chocolates on Garden Street. His most notable tribute is a museum that he plans to open to the public on Dec. 12 -- Sinatra's birthday -- next door to the site of the singer's birthplace. (Information: 800-266-1035.)

title: Budget Time and the Listening's Not Easy
description: IT is budget time for Westchester County, and the rhetoric is emotionally charged: one group decries what County Executive Andrew J. Spano has or has not included in the budget, another says he has lied to the public. And still others beg passionately for their cause.

title: Shopping for the Pots-and-Pans Rattler on Your List
description: CATHY McCAULEY wandered through her shop, past an aisle filled with gaily colored dishes, cups and pitchers, and suddenly stopped short. Up on a shelf, just above eye level, was an empty space. She grabbed a plate from another spot and expertly slid it past the displays of tableware to a more suitable location. ''Can't have an empty space in retail,'' she said with a laugh. ''We've become masters of squooshing.''

title: Works of Still Life That Can Be Uneasy
description: STILL LIFE paintings are often regarded as complacent and predictable. But the issues that are brought to the table, so to speak, do not always stay still. Rather than merely showing off how good the artist is at rendering objects realistically, a still life can be as charged -- politically, religiously and erotically -- as any other genre of painting. And because a still life has a veneer of order and propriety, deviations from that are often extremely potent.

He is buried with his men on Morris Island in South Carolina, where they died in battle; there is a monument to him in Moravian Cemetery on Staten Island.
