title: Russia Copies NATO in War to Win Minds
description: Mikhail V. Margelov has had his share of challenging assignments: assisting the K.G.B., working for the government press agency Tass, and then, in 1996, helping to produce the ads for President Boris N. Yeltsin's come-from-behind campaign. His new job tops them all: selling Russia's war in Chechnya to the public.

title: New Brunswick, Meet New Haven
description: DAVID SAINT and Doug Hughes don't just believe that regional theaters should work together; they are making it happen with two new plays: ''Down the Garden Paths,'' by Anne Meara, and ''Syncopation,'' by Allan Knee.

title: A Serialist Who Adheres To Tonality
description: GENERATIONS of music students have gained admission to 20th-century music theory through the imposing but welcoming portal of George Perle's book ''Serial Composition and Atonality.'' Published in 1961, it is in its sixth edition and was recently translated into Chinese. But a lot of its readers may not have known that Mr. Perle is himself a fine composer, or that paradoxically, his creative work stands distinctly aside from many of the practices detailed in his book. From a study of Berg's work, in particular, he developed a system within which a sense similar to that of key is maintained even though all 12 notes are in play, a system he called ''12-tone tonality.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; In Nobody's Shadow
description: What would Lee Krasner -- a famously blunt, plain-spoken woman impatient with all forms of pretension -- have made of the trendy critical jargon that Robert Hobbs, an art history professor at Virginia Commonwealth University, employs in his book on her work? Krasner, a respected Abstract Expressionist painter as well as a formidable ''art widow'' (she survived her husband, Jackson Pollock, by almost 30 years and dedicated much of her energy to championing his work), might have snorted to read that her approach has ''affinities with . . . structuralist and poststructuralist linguistic theory,'' that her ''ostensible subjects are predicated on contingency'' and that her ''artistically constructed self remains provisional'' -- the last sounding suspiciously like a fancy way of saying that she never really developed a style of her own. This question of originality (or lack thereof), frequently raised in discussions of her career, is one she herself once addressed by insisting that the paintings she produced right after Pollock's death were not mere imitations of his, as some critics claimed, but deliberate acts of homage. Though she may not have been a major innovator, and one can wish her work did not so often evoke that of other artists, the paintings reproduced in LEE KRASNER (Independent Curators International/Abrams, $49.50) are testimony to a long, fiercely intelligent engagement with many of the great art-historical figures, problems and issues of her time. And even in the paintings clearly influenced by Pollock, her colors are both lusher and more rhapsodic than his ever were; perhaps nobody ever made such brilliant use of deep pink. Without recourse to labored intellectualizing, B. S. Friedman, a friend and early biographer of Pollock, simply portrays Krasner in all her prickly glory in his introduction to this book. Evelyn Toynton

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Energy-Efficient, Ecology-Sensitive Housing
description: THE 128-apartment development in Newark -- involving both the conversion of a 19th century factory into 62 units and the construction of a 66-unit apartment building on the nearby site of a factory that is to be demolished -- appears to be much like other low- and moderate-income rental housing projects in New Jersey.

title: The Next Big Dialectic
description: I've always been skeptical of people who predict the future professionally, of the Alvin Tofflers and John Naisbitts as well as the Jeane Dixons and Pat Robertsons. For one thing, it's pretty much impossible to make confident predictions without sounding portentous and creepy. And purporting to describe the warp and woof of life 100 years from now is an extreme folly. On the other hand, the time frame insures that no one will be able to tell me I was wrong if, in 2100, it turns out I was wrong.

title: A Movement To Muffle News Choppers
description: For years, noise generated by sightseeing helicopters vexed many Manhattan residents, who complained so loudly that the city began restricting tourist flights to more remote airspaces. But there are no such restrictions for news helicopters. Now some people want to regulate those as well, saying they hover at low altitudes for long periods of time, their enormous blades whirring in the sky.

title: The Real Challenge Is Inward
description: To the Editor:

title: Los Angeles Journal; Hollywood's Indulgent Alternative to Health Food
description: Consider the chili cheese dog, the trademark indulgence at Pink's hot dog stand in Hollywood: dripping with sweet, smooth chili, wrapped in a slice of American cheese and a soft bun, of considerable heft and not a little messy, it seems an unlikely culinary obsession in a city thought preoccupied about healthy eating.

title: The Way We Live Now: 11-28-99; Safety in Numbers
description: It seems almost funny to remember that as recently as the 1980's, hardly anyone outside the financial industry had any real interest in forecasting stock prices. An exception was one of my colleagues, a professor who actively managed his own portfolio long before the advent of Internet trading. His crowning achievement was predicting the October 1987 crash with far greater accuracy than almost all the experts. In the weeks following the crash, many stepped forward claiming to have seen it coming, but almost alone among them, my colleague had taken a major chunk of his money out of the market just weeks before it happened. In the risk-averse world of tenured academics, this gutsy move earned him instant superstar status.

title: Writer and Artist, All in One Package
description: YES, it really is that Edward Lear: the author of nonsense rhymes like ''The Owl and the Pussycat.'' Lear might have been surprised to learn that he would be remembered more for his writing than for his art. But as an artist, he would have been shocked that the oil paintings he regularly exhibited at the Royal Academy in London are forgotten, while his watercolors, among them the views of Greece now at the Princeton University Art Museum, live on.

title: IN MY...BRIEFCASE: PETER W. MAY
description: AS president and chief operating officer of the Triarc Companies, Peter W. May, 56, combines the old and the new in his briefcase. It's a reflection of his company, which makes and markets longtime soft-drink brands like Royal Crown Cola and new-age ones like Snapple under one corporate umbrella.

title: November 21-27; Fevered Pitch: Coping With the Jerusalem Syndrome
description: It even has its own name: Jerusalem Syndrome. The symptoms: donning a white hotel bed sheet and preaching sermons in the street, or any other manifestation that suggests sufferers believe they are figures from the Bible. Psychiatrists in Israel expect the number of diagnosed cases to surge over the next month as millennium pilgrims descend on the city, which is sacred to Christians, Jews and Muslims.

title: Raising an Old Question About Race, and Ignoring the Real Issue
description: In the late 80's, wired from having attended Knicks games, Tom Brokaw would buttonhole colleagues at NBC News, an Ancient Mariner with a burning modern question: Why were African-Americans dominating basketball? He would not take environment for an answer, and he eventually brushed aside both the cautious and the righteous who warned him that even asking the question could be construed as racist.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: KT Sullivan, Stephen Downey
description: Kathleen Sullivan and Stephen Miner Downey were married yesterday by the Rev. Aldo J. Tos at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Trying to Figure Out What Space to Save
description: MOST people get interested in land use at the moment that, say, Wal-Mart announces plans to build across the street. But Judy Jengo is the sort of person who started going to her borough planning board meetings -- after a day at work on environmental issues -- for fun.

title: Peekskill Spot Offers Fare for the Few
description: IN these days of economic hubris, the Zephses Victoria at the stove and her brother Michael managing out front -- can offer a lesson in humility to other small family concerns. For almost 10 years this team has consistently pleased customers by following a simple, yet elegant plan of nonexpansion. Too many small gems compromise success by overreaching, but this restaurant has clearly decided to delight the discerning few.

title: Transfixed by New York; Whether as Dream or Nightmare, the City Looms Uncommonly Large in the Minds of Dominicans, New York's Largest Immigrant Group
description: HE who dies without seeing New York dies blind,'' goes the Dominican saying, and countless citizens in this Caribbean nation of eight million have heeded those words. Although the Dominican Republic is only the 85th most populous country in the world, it has been the No. 1 source of legal immigrants to New York City for 23 of the last 25 years, sending an estimated 345,000 people in that period.

title: The Biotech Death of Jesse Gelsinger
description: The jagged peak of Mount Wrightson towers 9,450 feet above Tucson, overlooking a deep gorge where the prickly pear cactus that dots the desert floor gives way to a lush forest of ponderosa pine. It is said that this is as close to heaven as you can get in southern Arizona. Jesse Gelsinger loved this place. So it was here, on a clear Sunday afternoon in early November, that Paul Gelsinger laid his 18-year-old son to rest, seven weeks after a gene-therapy experiment cost him his life.

title: Small Worlds On the East Side
description: CELLO *** [Rating: Three Stars]

title: The Nation: Biting Back; Some Lawyers Try to Make Nice
description: SOON after EgyptAir Flight 990 plunged into the Atlantic Ocean, the personal-injury lawyers at R. Jack Clapp and Associates marshaled their resources and mobilized their forces.

title: Just Imagine ...
description: Over this past century, business has given us the car, the radio, the television, the personal computer, the jet, the trash compactor and shampoo combined with conditioner. Imagine that you could ask for one equally huge innovation in the coming century, to improve your own lot or that of all mankind. What would you ask for? Send your ideas to Outlook 2000, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by e-mail to Outlook-2000@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Soccer Doesn't Need to Be Major League
description: Saturday mornings in the fall, I like to take the No. 1 train up to 218th Street and, believe it or not, find the best sports buy in all of New York. There, for $3, I can sit in the aluminum bleachers at Baker Field and watch the Columbia University men's soccer team in action.

title: Q&A/Dr. Amy E. Newburger; How to Keep Looking Good at Any Age
description: WHEN she was 32, Dr. Amy E. Newburger had a skin cancer, something the dermatologist thought would never happen to her. When she was about 45, she realized that she was aging and wondered if her professional effectiveness would be diminished by looking old.

title: Integration Anxiety
description: Your article seems to suggest that any integration effort that fails to eradicate even a minuscule statistical difference between the races in Montclair, N.J., would be a failure. You should try to eliminate the sort of hyperbole found in the description of Montclair as a town that ''can't break free of segregationist, prejudiced patterns.'' To describe a suburb of New York City as if it were the Mississippi Delta circa 1955 is simply irresponsible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREMBERG, IRVING A.
description: KREMBERG-Irving A.. of Island Park, N.Y. on November 25, 1999. Beloved husband of Lois, pre-deceased by daughter Michele. Also survived by son Alan, son-in-law Matt Dougherty and grandchildren Molly and Patrick. Memorial services will be held Wednesday, December 1, at 2PM at Little Neck Jewish Center, 4910 Little Neck Parkway, Little Neck, NY.

title: Air Carrier to County
description: Atlas Air, the third largest air cargo carrier in the United States, will lease 120,000 square feet of space at Texaco's Corporate Center at 2000 Westchester Avenue in Harrison beginning in the spring.

title: Bringing That Holiday Pie in the Sky Down to Earth
description: THE SETTING -- With Thanksgiving little more than a guilty gastronomical memory, many may cringe at the mere mention of food.

title: Inspiration or Computation?
description: No. 1: ''Tom left the sterile halls of the monolithic corporation feeling relieved. He had won another battle. He had sold his third manuscript.'' No. 2: ''Dave Striver loved the university -- at least most of the time. Every now and then, without warning, a wave of . . . well, it was true: a wave of hatred rose up and flowed like molten blood through every cell in his body.'' One of these openings to a short story was written by a human being, and the other by a computer. A couple of months ago, Dan Hurley, who lives in Montclair and is known as the 60-Second Novelist for the instant stories he writes (for a fee) for passersby, posted these two 500-word stories and three others on his Web site, www.instantnovelist.com. He asked visitors to vote on which one they thought was written by a software writing program called Brutus.1. He posted the results last week: only 25 percent of the 2,000 voters picked out the computer-generated story, No. 2 here. Question is, what will the dust jacket photo look like? CARL SOMMERS

title: Teachers Could Earn More If They Were Baby Sitters
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER; Music-Theater Defined: It's . . . Well . . . Um . . .
description: HOW far Off Broadway is Off Off? Antwerp? Amsterdam? Copenhagen? Toronto? Montreal? And what of the differences among opera, musicals and music-theater? Are there any? And if so, what are they exactly?

title: Ladybugs Find a House Can Also Be a Home
description: LADYBUGS are spending their winters with more and more Connecticut homeowners. The ladybugs, technically known as multicolored Asian lady beetles, have home owners all over the state wondering how to get rid of them or, conversely, how to keep them alive in the house. Kenneth Welch, an entomologist at the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station in New Haven, said he is getting both questions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRUSHALMI, ETHEL
description: IRUSHALMI-Ethel. Devoted wife of the late Irwin. Beloved mother of Jack and Russell. Cherished grandmother of Dylan. Dear sister of Stephen Tanney. Services Monday, 12 noon, at ''Sinai Chapel,'' 162-05 Horace Haring Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: War School's Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: Hospital Puzzle: The Freeloading Antennas
description: OVER the years, a forest of antennas has sprouted atop the Nassau County Medical Center here, turning it into a veritable broadcasting tower. Its dozens of aerials come in all shapes and sizes: pole antennas, dish receivers and even what appear to be big electronic drums.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEUCHS, FREDERICK LUDWIG
description: LEUCHS-Frederick Ludwig., 73, master stained glass artist of Stockbridge, Massachusetts, and St. Petersburg, FL, formerly of NYC, died Oct. 3. His work is found in Carnegie Hall, The Cloisters, Riverside Church, St. John the Divine, Church of the Heavenly Rest, St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue Synagogue, and Picasso House, all in NYC; as well as the Library of Congress, West Point, GW Masonic National Memorial, and the National Shrine of the Divine Mercy. He did private work for President and Mrs. Kennedy and Nelson Rockefeller. He was Artist in Residence at Eckerd College, FL. He served in World War II And the Korean Conflict. He leaves his wife, the former Marie Bidwell; five daughters: Paula Moats of Atlanta; Catherine Bohrman of Greenwich, CT; Adele Odegaard of Chicago; Mary Anne Leuchs-de-la Rosa of Houston; and Ellen Leuchs of Hadley, MA; two sisters, Anne Marie Makuc and Elisabeth Marie Tucker; and six grandchildren.

title: Pinot Noir, Made to Order
description: Playing impresario, enterprising niche importers often commission wines, sometimes choosing materials and styles. Retailers rarely do. When the Burgundy Wine Company, a Greenwich Village shop that specializes in pinot noir, engaged an influential California winemaker to produce one, the result was fascinating.

title: On Screen, Over Lunch, Ever the Distant Hero
description: HE looks devastated. But then Ralph Fiennes always looks as if he is caught between deep melancholy and outright despair. It must be something about the roles he takes, or the way his mouth turns down at the corners, because his demeanor, while not exactly jaunty, is certainly sporting. Told that a mix-up at the restaurant in his Manhattan hotel, The Four Seasons, means he'll have to wait a good half-hour at the bar before a table becomes available in the dining room, he says mildly: ''You mean they are not going to clear the restaurant? Oh dear, what is the world coming to?''

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about living in Morningside Heights misspelled the surname of a Riverside Drive resident who began hunting for a larger apartment last summer, and omitted the surname of her husband. She is Erica Lansner, not Lasner. Her husband is Eugene Villalobos.

title: Sidewalk Bicyclists Can Be Controlled
description: To the Editor:

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Matt E. Silver and Perry Farrell; Ecology Can Be Fun
description: MATT E. SILVER, the rave music producer, anxiously paced the bar at Wetlands on Tuesday night, waiting for his friend, the alternative rock star Perry Farrell, to speak. ''Perry looks like a little boy up there,'' Mr. Silver said.

title: A Quick Bet, Perhaps, for the Sage of Omaha
description: WARREN E. BUFFETT, the chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, is known for his concentrated bets on big brand- name companies with solid franchises. So why has Mr. Buffett, the sage of Omaha, put his own money in a lackluster closed-end fund by the name of Baker, Fentress & Company, founded over 100 years ago, which is in liquidation?

title: Giving Thanks In Miami For Absent Puritans
description: For party pilgrims, this billion-dollar sandbar is Plymouth Rock.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, HARRIET G.
description: COHEN-Harriet G.. 11/3/83. In cherished and loving memory, dearly beloved mother, grandmother, sister and sister-in-law. Sadly missed. Always in our hearts. Richard J. Lindsey Heather & Ashley Brooke Sisters Estelle and Beula and Sister-In-Law Lucille

title: Applauding the Life of the Party
description: The Committee to Protect Journalists held its annual dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria last Tuesday, raising more than $1 million and handing out awards to five who had been beaten, jailed, or threatened for their lives. Norman Pearlstine, editor in chief of Time Inc. and a former editor of The Wall Street Journal, served as dinner chairman.

title: Summing Up John Adams at Midcareer
description: WHEN John Adams cruised onto listeners' radar screens in 1980, with his ''Shaker Loops'' and ''Phrygian Gates'' (both composed in 1977), on an LP from the small, now defunct label 1750 Arch, three things were immediately apparent.

title: Metro Matters; In Prosperity, Nagging Pangs Of Uneasiness
description: Consider this a letter to a friend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, BERNARD
description: ROBBINS-Bernard. On November 28, 1999, at age 86, after a brief illness. A violinist whose career included the Stradivarius String Quartet, the NBC String Quartet, the Stuyvesant String Quartet, the NBC Symphony Orchestra with Toscanini and the New York Philharmonic Orchestra. He was born in New York City to Russian immigrants. He entered City College at age 15 and graduated from Columbia University at age 19 with a Master's Degree in Mathematics. Concurrently, he attended and graduated from the Juilliard School of Music. Beloved husband of Libby. He is also survived by three daughters, Sheila Reid of Worcester, MA, Ellen Robbins of New York City, and Julie Mainieri of Larchmont, NY; and four grandchildren and three greatgranchildren.

title: Leading Ladies
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Should Schools Play Doctor?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fading Soviet Nostalgia Across Eastern Germany
description: During the cold war, the Soviet Union kept hundreds of thousands of troops in East Germany, on alert for the war with the West that never came. When the Soviet Army left after the Berlin Wall fell and Germany unified, many of its barracks were put to other uses. Others are simply decaying, symbols of a Communist empire on which the sun suddenly set. The Soviet soldiers and families who lived here apparently never thought of leaving: they painted murals glorifying their military, erected elaborate memorials to the prowess of Soviet airborne units, gave birth in now abandoned hospitals and buried their loved ones in now untended tombs.

title: Market Place; Waiting for 2000, wondering if the economy will keep surging and watching for Fed signals.
description: WITH about a month left in the millennium, the three major stock indexes are poised to record annual returns of more than 10 percent each for the fifth year in a row -- an unprecedented streak.

title: Shareholders Want Change at RMS Titanic
description: An investment group that includes officials from SFX Entertainment plans to oust the management of RMS Titanic as part of an effort to get higher returns from the famous shipwreck's artifacts.

title: Trojan War Victims Lie on Normandy Beaches
description: War is hideous glory in Homer, elevating combatants to achievements that astound them, terrifying them with death and abandonment among the shades below and debasing them with runaway lusts. And the performance of ''The Iliad: Book I'' by the Aquila Theater Company, the first mixed British-American company approved by Actors Equity, at Lincoln Center draws an audience so deep inside the great poem that one seems to experience what Homer's heros did.

title: E-Commerce Report; Nightmares Before Christmas
description: FOR many Internet retailers, success this holiday shopping season rests on the shoulders of the customer service team or the technical support staff -- whose job it is to keep a Web site from crashing. But for executives of Bluefly.com, a discount apparel merchant, success rides on the back of a Himalayan mountain goat -- the source of Pashmina.

title: INSIDE
description: Palestinians Arrest Critics

title: CUNY Misuses Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stock Market's Success May Hinder Future Rally

title: Johnsson Thrives With the Rangers
description: Just 23 games into his National Hockey League career, the Rangers' Kim Johnsson does not know enough about the league to identify its different levels of talent.

title: Vodafone's Chief Executive Has an Empire on Which the Sun Never Sets
description: To a backdrop of glittery chandeliers and somber marble pillars in a financial-district conference room, Christopher Gent, the smooth-talking chief executive of the world's biggest mobile phone company, was outlining his designs on German rival Mannesmann the other day when, unusually, he seemed to stumble over a word.

title: Sacrificing the Drug War
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRETT, JOHN J.
description: BARRETT-John J. Age 95, died November 26, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Josephine. Brother of Oscar, uncle of Audrey, Pamela and Cassin, loving greatuncle and great-great-uncle. Counsel to the firm of Kirkpatrick and Lockhart, and Founding Partner of the former Barrett, Smith, Schapiro, Simon and Armstrong firm. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated, Wednesday at 10 AM, St. Monica's Church, 413 East 79th Street at 1st Avenue. Visitation Monday 7-9, and Tuesday 3-5 and 7-9, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICKETT, GWENDOLYN W.
description: PICKETT-Gwendolyn W. On November 26, 1999 at age 90. Beloved wife of the late Charles; loving sister of the late Leonard Whitcup; dear aunt of Andrea Leskes, Vivian Leskes, Daniel Doscher and William Doscher; and sister in-law of Sally Whitcup, Florence Elliott and Elizabeth Doscher. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Monday November 29, 1 PM. Interment Temple Israel Cemetery.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Giants' and Jets' Days Are Getting Colder and Shorter; After a Loss, Parcells Goes Back to the Drawing Board
description: The tantalizing hope that the Jets could salvage their season all but disappeared today.

title: Companies Expected to Offer Equity Shares for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, RUTH (NEE GLASS)
description: BLUM-Ruth (nee Glass). On Saturday, November 27, in Baltimore, formerly of New York and Miami Beach, in her 95th year. Beloved wife of the late Michael H. (Mickey) Blum. Devoted mother of David Blum. Dear mother and mother-in-law of Fran and Jim Goodman and Harlyne Kohlberg Blum. Loving and much loved grandmother of Allison Goodman and Dan Brice, Leslie and Matt Allen, Daniel Goodman and Andy Blum. Dear Great-Grandma Ruthie of Rachael and Emily Allen and Nathaniel Goodman Brice. Predeceased by all her siblings. Also survived by many loving nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews. Graveside services at Mount Ararat, Farmingdale, LI, NY, on Monday, November 29, at 2 PM. Please omit flowers. For information, Sol Levinson & Bros., Inc., 1-800-338-1701.

title: House Fire Kills Restaurateur And His Wife; and Injures 8
description: A popular New Jersey restaurant owner and his wife were killed by a fire that rapidly engulfed their home here over the weekend.

title: China Tells Southeast Asia It Will 'Never Seek Hegemony' Over Islands : Beijing Tries to Cool Spratlys Dispute
description: MANILA  China has indicated that it wants to avoid further conflict with Southeast Asian countries over the Spratly Islands dispute in the South China Sea even though it opposes their plan for a code of conduct in the area, Southeast Asian officials said Sunday.

title: Lazard and Daiwa Expand Japan Link
description: Lazard Brothers & Company in London and Daiwa Securities SB Capital Markets said yesterday that they had expanded their relationship.

title: Russia Promises Escape Route for Civilians to Flee Grozny
description: In a fresh sign that the Russian military plans to bombard Grozny, the Chechen capital, into submission, the government said today that it would open a safe passage for desperate civilians to flee.

title: Royal Bank of Scotland Weighs Bid for National Westminster
description: The Royal Bank of Scotland Group is expected to make a $41.71 billion hostile bid for National Westminster Bank as early as Monday, executives who have been informed about the plan said here tonight.

title: In Westchester, Gay Rights on Hold
description: To the Editor:

title: Tension and Flip-Flops in a Fishbowl
description: The encounters among four men and three women of the Betontanc dance and theater company from Slovenia are highly punishing. In ''Secret Sunshine Schedule,'' a piece that is impressively startling in its imagery and execution, the performers are enclosed but not necessarily trapped within four plexiglass walls. Repeatedly they slam themselves or one another against these transparent surfaces and the floor, or communicate through carefully timed sequences of back flips, dives and falls.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I loved being a commander, but I found myself saying I would be a better commander if I wasn't a parent and a better parent if I wasn't a commander.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEYES, FENTON
description: KEYES-Fenton. Age 84, educator and author, of Pennswood Village, Newtown, PA, on November 27, 1999, after a brief illness. He is survived by Elizabeth Dix Keyes, his wife of 55 years; his son Charles Fenton Keyes of Washington, DC; his daughter, Janet Keyes O'Connell of Larchmont, NY; and four grandchildren. Private burial at the Moravian Cemetery, Staten Island. His family would be grateful for contributions to Yale University Class of '37.

title: Ashley Montagu, 94, Anthropologist and Popular Author
description: Ashley Montagu, the London-born anthropologist and popular author whose energy, erudition and showmanship brought genetics, paleontology and other topics in the life sciences to a wide American audience, died on Friday in Princeton, N.J. He was 94.

title: Compressed Data; Internet Law Expert Returns to Antitrust Case
description: He's back.

title: Compressed Data: Y2K Pulse; Learning to Live With Year 2000 Concerns
description: Managers and technical experts working on Year 2000 computing projects are becoming increasingly optimistic -- despite delays and program weaknesses that ought to worry them -- according to an informal coalition of Year 2000 analysts who have polled such professionals in June, September and again this month.

title: Monuments for Posterity
description: For someone who paid no attention to environmental issues during his first year in office, Bill Clinton may wind up with an impressive legacy as a preservationist. In addition to his earlier programs to restore the Everglades and to protect Yellowstone, the forests of the Pacific Northwest and the redwoods in California, the president recently set in motion a plan that would, in effect, create 40 million acres of new wilderness by blocking road building in much of the national forests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CITRIN, PHILIP
description: CITRIN-Philip. Age 86, of West Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Glen Cove, NY, on November 27, 1999. Excellent husband to his beloved wife, Evelyn. Devoted father to Barbara and Jack Gattuso, Ava and Michael Dvoretz, Niles and Nancy Citrin. Adored Pop Pop of Suzanne, Brian, Steven, Todd, Jodi, Elise and Mark. Loving greatgrandfather of Matthew, Rachel and Jordyn. He was a member of the Masons and Knights of Pythias. His greatest joys in life were the times spent with his family. He loved his relatives and many friends who along with his family will miss him dearly. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Grief for Immigrant Who Lived and Died for Work
description: In his two years in New York, Eduardo Daniel did little other than work, his friends and relatives say.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAWSON, TRUDY W.
description: DAWSON-Trudy W. On November 26, 1999, at age 53. Associate Director of Marketing and Booking at Lincoln Center. Beloved mother of Jason and Josh Dawson. Loving grandmother of Haley and Paige Dawson. Interment private. A memorial service to be announced.

title: Standoff With Police Follows Fatal Shooting at Queens Club
description: A man fatally shot a woman in a Queens pool hall yesterday morning and then held the police at bay for nearly two hours by pointing his gun to his head while standing over the woman's body, the police said.

title: Goalie Of Future Lifts Isles In Present
description: The Islanders got a glimpse of the future tonight.

title: Basque Rebels in Spain Ending Cease-Fire After 14 Months
description: The Basque separatist group E.T.A. announced today that it would end a 14-month-old cease-fire and warned that armed attacks could resume as early as Friday in its long struggle for an independent homeland.

title: A Way to Help Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: The Super Bowl is attracting a crowd of new competitors.
description: IF Beethoven were commissioned to rewrite his Fifth Symphony for Super Bowl XXXIV, he would undoubtedly begin this way: ''Dot, dot, dot, com. Dot, dot, dot, com.''

title: U.S. WEIGHS USING FOOD AS SUPPORT FOR SUDAN REBELS
description: President Clinton is about to sign a bill permitting the administration to pursue a contentious strategy against the Islamic government in Sudan by giving food assistance directly to rebels who have been fighting the authorities in Khartoum for 16 years.

title: Recalling the Co-Founder of Camelot
description: Lest the title of tonight's PBS documentary, ''Jackie: Behind the Myth,'' leads you to fear you are in for two hours of digging the dirt, be reassured. This collection of encomiums couldn't be more respectable and less revealing if it was produced by a Jacqueline Kennedy fan club, which in a way it is. Relatives, friends and hangers-on in Camelot (Pierre Salinger, John Kenneth Galbraith and others) compete or conspire in affectionate reminiscences about their friend's life and accomplishments, such as they were.

title: A Carnival of Derision to Greet the Princes of Global Trade
description: There will be hundreds of protesters in sea-turtle costumes and stilt walkers dressed as monarch butterflies. Thousands of people will tie up the downtown area during a giant demonstration, and protesters will chain themselves to buildings or scale walls to unfurl banners denouncing the target of their ire: the World Trade Organization.

title: Test-Score Obsession Destroys Zeal for Learning
description: To the Editor:

title: Idaho Christians Rally Round a Cross on a Hill
description: For 43 years, a 60-foot white cross has stood like a Christian beacon on the eastern skyline of this city.

title: Cisco to Offer More Details On Wireless Technology
description: A new wireless technology is about to join the contest to provide high-speed Internet connections to homes and businesses.

title: Gifts for Celebrating the Century or Just Relaxing
description: Well, they finally did it. The publisher Benedikt Taschen has issued a book called ''Sumo,'' a collection of photographs by Helmut Newton, edited by his wife, June Newton. Which may sound innocent enough. But here's the thing: it's 465 pages long, measures 20 by 28 by 4 inches, weighs 66 pounds and comes with its own chromed stainless-steel folding table designed by Philippe Starck. So the dream of Seinfeld's Kramer of a coffee-table book that is actually a coffee table has been all but realized.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Web Sites and Recording Labels at Impasse on Fees
description: A growing number of Web sites are offering customized music programming -- song sets created in response to the personal tastes of listeners. What the listeners are not hearing is a behind-the-scenes dispute between the sites and major record labels, in which tens of millions of dollars may be at stake.

title: TENNIS; Sampras Shows Agassi Who's Ultimately No. 1
description: Pete Sampras wondered aloud whether his tender back could withstand a five-set match against Andre Agassi in the final of the ATP Tour World Championship today. Fortunately for Sampras, he never had to find out. Sampras routed Agassi, 6-1, 7-5, 6-4, to win the season-ending tournament for the fifth time.

title: Now, Brought to You by Coke (or Pepsi): Your City Hall
description: Beachgoers who become thirsty while strolling on this surfing town's pier had better like Coke. Every vending machine on and around the pier offers only Coca-Cola beverages.

title: Collision With Stolen Car Kills 1 and Injures 4
description: A man was killed and four other people were injured last night when thieves driving a stolen BMW crashed into another car, the police said. The thieves were then picked up by the driver of a second stolen car, who drove away. A 17-year-old passenger in the stolen BMW was later arrested, the police said.

title: Sports of The Times; Giants Are Getting What They Paid For
description: LATE yesterday afternoon Wellington Mara stood in a Giants locker room soaked in gloom and disappointment after a 34-24 thrashing by the Arizona Cardinals. The loss sank the Giants to 5-6. But for playing in a miserable division, the loss would have ended the Giants' playoff hopes.

title: 7 Palestinians Arrested For Criticism Of Arafat
description: The Palestinian Authority arrested seven prominent Palestinians today after they signed a statement accusing Yasir Arafat's administration of ''tyranny and corruption.''

title: Those Toys Are Leaders In Box-Office Stampede
description: The movie box-office total for the five-day Thanksgiving weekend, paced by an astonishing $80.8 million opening for ''Toy Story 2,'' might not have reached to infinity, much less beyond, but it was plenty strong enough to shatter several records and confirm Thanksgiving's position as an increasingly important time to release new films.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Editorial Observer; Better Ways to Measure Poverty
description: Poverty remains, at 13 percent of the population, more prevalent today than it was during the 1970's despite substantial economic growth and antipoverty spending over the past 30 years. In New York City, poverty remains stuck at nearly twice the national average and only barely below levels that prevailed during the recession of the early 1990's.

title: SOVEREIGN ISLANDS -- A Question of Regulation; Alaskans Choose Sides in Battle Over Cruise Ships
description: The cruise ship industry, once embraced as a savior for Alaska's lagging economy, has worn out its welcome in some quarters.

title: Accounts
description: * MGH Advertising, Baltimore, was awarded the new accounts of three Web-based companies with combined billings estimated at $10 million: Assetrade.com, St. Louis, an asset management service aimed at industrial companies; Ehats.com, Hanover, Pa., which will sell headwear; and RegistrationVillage.com, Columbia, Md., which will provide a product recall alert service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAGE, ROSALEEN P. (NEE MURRAY)
description: SAGE-Rosaleen P. (nee Murray). On November 26, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Donald D. Loving mother of Rosemarie Sullivan, Daniel, Bernadette Staunton, Maureen Shillet, Eileen Robinson, Kathleen, Monica, Margaret O'Brien, Josephine McCaffrey and Patrick. Beloved sister of Msgr. James Murray, May Houlihan, John Murray, Sr. Mary Rose Murray, S.U. and Patrick Murray. Cherished grandmother of 17. Reposing David J. Hodder and Son Funeral Home, 899 McLean Ave, Yonkers. Visiting hours Sunday and Monday, 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 11:15 AM, St. Barnabas Church. Interment St. Raymond Cemetery. In lieu of flowers kindly make contributions to St. Patrick Home Development Fund, 66 Van Cortlandt Park South, Bronx, NY 10467; 718519-2800.

title: Ruling Party Wins Election For President In Uruguay
description: The candidate of the governing Colorado Party won the Uruguayan presidency on his fifth try today by beating back a strong challenge from a leftist coalition that included Socialists, Communists and former guerrillas.

title: Blacksburg Journal; 'Hokie-Mania' Helps Raise Virginia Tech's Profile
description: Hordes of ecstatic football fans poured into this university town over the holiday weekend, but perhaps none gave more meaning to the spectacle than little Patrick Sullivan.

title: Internet Equipment Maker Planning to Make a $4.3 Billion Acquisition
description: Redback Networks, a maker of equipment to help Internet service providers transmit data more easily, is acquiring Siara Systems for about $4.3 billion in stock, company executives said yesterday.

title: In Westchester, Gay Rights on Hold
description: To the Editor:

title: The Defense Did Its Share
description: The Jets' defense held Edgerrin James, the conference's leading rusher, to 74 yards on 24 carries; it held Peyton Manning, the conference's leading passer, to a season low of 198 yards on 23 of 31, and it held the dangerous receiver Marvin Harrison to fewer than 12 yards a catch.

title: A Pilot's Motivations
description: To the Editor:

title: Belle Cherie Breezes To Another Victory
description: The Top Flight Handicap, which was postponed on Friday when a week of wet weather forced Aqueduct to cancel seven races, became a personal triumph yesterday for Belle Cherie, who won by 7i lengths.

title: More Traffic in the Double-Stroller Lane; Twin Births Surge, and the Parents Face Special, and Costly, Challenges
description: Jonathan Alexander was sitting comfortably in his stroller, ready to roll. His twin sister, Rachel, was screaming. She did not want to wear a jacket. She did not want to take a walk. She did not want to do much of anything, it seemed, but arch her back and wail in protest. Suddenly, as if in sympathy, Jonathan joined her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, ROSEMARY
description: MARKS-Rosemary. On November 27, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Robert. Loving mother of Herbert, Jan and Suzanne. Adoring grandmother and great-grandmother. Dearest companion of George Court. Services 12:45 PM, Monday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFIN, KATHERYN RENATE
description: JAFFIN-Katheryn Renate. On November 27. Adoring mother of Madeleine R. Kania. Devoted grandmother of Jennifer Ann and Laura Jean Kania. Proud motherin-law of Robert J. Kania. Devoted wife of 52 years to the late Theodore S. Jaffin. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Wednesday, December 1, 11:30 AM. Interment Ferncliff Cemetery, Ardsley, NY.

title: Shaping The Future In Seattle
description: This week, representatives from more than 130 countries will gather here for a meeting that will help set the global economic agenda for years to come. The greater the success of this meeting at establishing fair and predictable conditions for expanded world trade, the better the future prospects not only for our own economy but for global prosperity.

title: Merged Agency Names New Officials
description: Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has announced additional personnel changes for the British and European offices of the agency, formed recently by the merger of Ammirati Puris Lintas and Lowe & Partners Worldwide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, MARGARET MORRILL
description: WILLIAMS-Margaret Morrill, 77, died on November 21, 1999 at the Hilton Head Medical Center and Clinics, Hilton Head Island, SC. A life long resident of Bronxville until 1981, she was active in a variety of social, civic and charitable organizations, including Planned Parenthood of Westchester, the Vestry and Altar Guild of Christ Church in Bronxville, Musical Therapy (precursor to The Song Pipers), the Junior League of Bronxville and the Westchester Cotillion Committee. Survived by her five children: Centes C. Williams of Bronxville, NY, William L. Williams, Jr. of Brentwood, TN, David M. Williams of New York City, Margaret W. Loftus of Scarsdale, NY, Abbe W. Winn of Atlanta; six grandchildren; her sister Centes M. Papes of Mt. Kisco, NY and her brother David C. Morrill of Tuscon, AZ. She was preceded in death by her husband William L. Williams. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church, Bronxville, NY on Saturday, December 11, 2PM. Memorial contributions to Planned Parenthood HudsonPeconic, 11 Skyline Drive, Hawthorne, New York 10532 or Christ Church, 17 Sagamore Road, Bronxville, New York 10708.

title: Giuliani's Mother Stable After Being Hospitalized
description: The mother of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has been admitted to Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan, where she is in stable condition, a hospital spokesman said yesterday.

title: Congress's Big Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: In Relief, Plummer Sparks the Cardinals
description: When the arm of a Giants blitzer hit the throat of Arizona quarterback Dave Brown in the second quarter, Brown went to the sideline and said to Jake Plummer: ''Jake! Jake! Get ready! I can't talk!'' At least this was the recollection of Frank Sanders, a Cardinals wide receiver, who overhead the conversation and repeated it after today's game in a raspy voice that imitated Brown's.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAXIM, LESLIE M.
description: MAXIM-Leslie M. November 29, 1917-June 23, 1996. A Man for All Seasons. Lived life to the fullest. Lovingly remembered. Pete

title: Germany's East Is Still Haunted By Big Brother
description: Rudiger Hinze took a scrap of paper from his eyeglass case and read four names: Jager, Kopp, Schulze and Schreiber. ''Those are the code names,'' he said, ''of the people in this village who spied on me for years.''

title: Bills Keep the Punchless Patriots in November Free Fall
description: A month ago the Patriots were one of the teams to beat in the American Football Conference East. They raced out to a 6-2 record and were riding high on a wave of confidence they felt would carry them into the playoffs.

title: Big Plans for New Jersey's Schools, but Where's the Money?
description: As the legislative session draws to a close here, lawmakers are hammering out plans for one of America's most ambitious statewide school construction and renovation efforts, a something-for-everyone financing program that could wind up costing as much as $11 billion -- nearly what Congress was considering spending to rebuild schools across the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANSICKLE, EDWARD ARLINGTON
description: VANSICKLE-Edward Arlington, age 75. Died November 21, 1999 in Burlington, VT. Renowned actor/ opera singer. A Requiem Mass will be held on Wednesday, December 1, 1999 at 11 AM at Church of the Blessed Sacrament, 152 West 71st Street, New York City. Interment following in GreenWood Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Phoenix Rises at Covent Garden; After Years of Soap Opera, Time for a Happier Libretto
description: It makes for a dull ending to a long-running soap opera that once entertained with spats, insults, scandals, brinkmanship and frequent warnings of imminent disaster. But after four years of unremitting melodrama, the Royal Opera House at Covent Garden has now completed a $360 million redevelopment and will reopen on schedule on Dec. 1 with a gala of song and dance attended by Queen Elizabeth.

title: Grey Advertising Promotes 3 Executives
description: Grey Advertising in New York is making promotions in its creative department. Three executive vice presidents and senior creative directors -- Richard Mahan, 46; Mark Schwatka, 49; and Dave Tutin, 47 -- were promoted to executive creative directors. They join Bob Skollar, 49, executive vice president, who had been the sole executive creative director for the last four years. Also, Rob Baiocco, 35, senior vice president and group creative director, was promoted to executive vice president and senior creative director.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POWER, LORETTA, SR. (SR. DANIEL MARIE, O.S.U.)
description: POWER-Loretta, Sr. (Sr. Daniel Marie, O.S.U.) on November 27, 1999. Former Principal of St. Jerome's School and Our Lady of Mercy School in the Bronx, and Blessed Sacrament School in New Rochelle, NY. Reposing at Bedford Park Convent, Marion Ave and 200th St, Bronx, Monday, 2-5 PM and 6-8 PM. Mass of the Resurrection at Convent Chapel, Tuesday, 10 AM. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery.

title: Knicks Are Waiting for the Nod From on High
description: Long after the Knicks' starters had filed out of the gym, there were still sneakers screeching and a veteran growling behind the doors for an extra 45 minutes today.

title: Cardinal O'Connor Falls at End of Mass
description: Cardinal John O'Connor, apparently weakened from the aftereffects of radiation therapy for a brain tumor, stumbled as he left his chair at the end of Sunday Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral, but did not injure himself or consult a doctor, his spokesman said. It was the second time he had fallen during a Mass since Nov. 14, when a shepherd's staff buckled as he leaned on it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, ROSEMARY K.
description: MARKS-Rosemary K. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: TV for the Blind
description: To the Editor:

title: Advancing Toward to the Millennium in Good Company
description: Voices and bodies, as tuned and trained, as quick to respond to commands as any piece of glittering technology, and alive to impulse, too: this is what gives one hope for a millennium theater we may bask, even glory, in.

title: Gay Republican Cleaves to the Party Despite a Bush Snub
description: AS an outspokenly gay Republican, Richard Tafel is accustomed to critiques from the left and the right. He recently wrote a book, ''Party Crasher: A Gay Republican Challenges Politics as Usual,'' that essentially tries to defend his place on the political map -- or, as he puts it somewhat more grandly, to answer the question: ''How did a nice guy like me find myself in the crossfire of American politics?''

title: Rough Day For Sparks
description: The Giants' left cornerback, Phillippi Sparks, had a nightmarish day against Arizona wide receiver Rob Moore in yesterday's 34-24 loss to the Cardinals at Giants Stadium. Moore, who had 7 catches for 102 yards, wrestled the ball away from Sparks in the end zone for a touchdown and beat him for a 44-yard sideline bomb that set up another score.

title: The New Face of Northern Ireland
description: Northern Ireland's revived peace agreement passed its most critical test yet Saturday, when the province's main Protestant party agreed to participate in a new local government that will also include political representatives of the Irish Republican Army. The vote by the Ulster Unionist Party was a triumph for its politically courageous leader, David Trimble, whose willingness to move beyond old orthodoxies has made a vital contribution to peace. Overcoming fierce internal opposition, Mr. Trimble persuaded his party to end its nearly 17-month boycott of the new government, even though the I.R.A. has not yet begun turning over its illegal arsenal of bombs and guns.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Albany's Tobacco Share
description: To the Editor:

title: Strict Shelter Rules Force Many Families Out
description: One night the Long Island family slept in a church. For two weeks, the superintendent of an apartment building put them up in his storage space, shifting Sheetrock and plywood to make room for all eight: husband, wife and six children, ages 5 to 13. Later, a widow who shared the family's Pentecostal faith let them bed down on a comforter spread across her linoleum floor.

title: An 18-Year-Old Amateur Triumphs
description: Aaron Baddeley became the youngest champion in the 95-year history of the Australian Open and the first amateur winner in 39 years.

title: Essay; Jeremiah Speaks
description: In changing around the clothes in my closet to get ready for winter, I made a dismaying discovery: I have 38 shirts.

title: Hargeisa Journal; A Woman of Firsts and Her Latest Feat: A Hospital
description: ''I'm a crazy old woman,'' Edna Adan Ismail said only a minute or two after introducing herself. ''You might as well know that from the start.''

title: 2 Executives Leaving TBWA/Chiat/Day
description: Two top creative executives at two offices of TBWA/Chiat/Day are leaving the agency.

title: People
description: * Greg Davis was named to the new post of senior vice president and business development director at Hampel/Stefanides, New York, part of the Envoy Communications Group. He had been business development director at Berlin Cameron & Partners, New York.

title: Treasury Schedules Sales of Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three-and six-month bills and an auction tomorrow of a 43-day cash-management bill.

title: Farrell Stages Two Balanchine Works
description: New casts in George Balanchine's ''Tzigane'' and ''Meditation'' failed to overcome the meagerness of the two pas de deux and their looming anecdotal history on Saturday night in ''Suzanne Farrell Stages the Masters of 20th-Century Ballet'' at the New Victory Theater.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENTHAL, LYNN
description: ROSENTHAL-Lynn. You are missed. Rest in Peace

title: Motherhood Deters Women From Army's Highest Ranks
description: In the small world of women who are senior officers, Lois Beard was considered a prime candidate to become the Army's first General Mom.

title: Op-Art
Polls and Pundits Hold Answers
description: In six days the computers will make it official: top-ranked and 11-0 Florida State versus No. 2 and 11-0 Virginia Tech for the national championship in the Sugar Bowl. In 12 days, Heisman voters will do the same: Ron Dayne of Wisconsin will win the trophy as the best college football player of 1999.

title: Foolish Errors Make for Lost Weekend
description: The weekend held such promise for Bill Parcells, before it eventually crumbled into a devastating loss to Indianapolis, which all but eliminated the Jets from the playoff race. The head coach lambasted his team afterward, scolding players by name for blowing opportunities. And their season, too. It wasn't supposed to be this way.

title: Sjoland Wins By One Shot
description: Patrik Sjoland of Sweden shot a two-over-par 72 yesterday and won the Hong Kong Open by one stroke over the Welshman Ian Woosnam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, C. WINSTON
description: FITZGERALD-C. Winston. Age 77, on November 26, after a long illness. A native of Lynchburg, VA, Winston in the 50's was Alexander Greiner's assistant as Artist Liaison for Steinway & Sons. For S. Hurok, he served as manager for Marian Anderson's farewell tour and for Sviatoslav Richter's last U.S. tour. He joined the staff of the New York Philharmonic, where he remained until his retirement. Survived by his longtime friend, Hilton Bailey, Winston will be missed by many.

title: Despite a Dash of HBO Fame, the Lure Is Still the Stage
description: Cynthia Nixon is only 33, but she has been called a perennial of the New York theater. It's all right with her, she says, especially the New York part.

title: All in the Family  Disney's Miramax film unit is a publishing partner in Talk, a magazine that devotes a remarkable portion of its film-industry coverage to movies by Disney or Miramax -- as the chart on Page C19 delineates.
Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, RICHARD E. (DICK)
description: MILLER-Richard E. (Dick). On November 28, 1999. Former Art Director for Sports Illustrated. Combat veteran of the Korean War. He is survived by his loving companion Thomas Maguire and mourned by his many friends. Reposing Redden's Funeral Home, 325 West 14th St, NYC, Tuesday, 25 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service at 8 PM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: World Trade Group Inspires Protesters
description: In what is shaping up as one of the biggest protest efforts in years, people from more than 500 organizations have poured into Seattle. They accuse the World Trade Organization, the 135-nation, Geneva-based group that is holding its ministerial meeting in the city this week, of favoring free trade at the expense of the environment, consumer safety and workers' rights.

title: Hanson Seeks to Buy Australian Concern
description: Hanson, the British building-materials producer, said today that it had offered to buy Pioneer International for 1.56 billion [pounds] ($2.50 billion), to strengthen its position in the global market.

title: Europeans Are Closing In On a U.S. Tournament's Title
description: Europeans seem poised to capture the major title at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here today as the tournament concluded. Leading 10 teams into the final two sessions of the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams were the defending champions: Rita Shugart of Pebble Beach, Calif., Geir Helgemo of Norway, Tony Forrester and Andrew Robson, both of Britain. Their closest pursuers are Norberto Bocchi, Giorgio Duboin, Dano DeFalco and Guido Ferraro of Italy, as well as players from Poland, France and Britain who were in contention together with another Italian pair.

title: Seeing Enemies Everywhere, Serbia Begins a Legal Offensive
description: In recent weeks, Serbia has become enveloped in a frenzy of arrests and trials that fill the television news programs and newspapers, enhancing the siege atmosphere in an isolated state.

title: With Victory in Their Hands, The Devils End Up Defeated
description: Patrick Marleau scored with 5.6 seconds to play in overtime to lift the San Jose Sharks to a 4-3 victory over the Devils tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, JOAN
description: GOLDSTEIN-Joan. November 26, 1999. Most loved wife of Alvin Goldstein, mother to Janis, Howard, Neva and Doug, devoted grandmother to Daniel, Robert, Rebecca, Corey and Jesse, and sister to Marcia. Her fierce love and commitment to her family and friends will be most sorrowfully missed in the present, but held fast to forever more in all of our hearts. Services held at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, interment at Mount Moriah Cemetery in Fairview, NJ. Her family respectfully requests that donations in Joan's name be presented to any of the numerous viable cancer help or research organizations or charities of their choice.

title: Bush's Abortion Stance
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOMBERG, ALLAN ELLIA, DR.
description: BLOOMBERG-Allan Ellia, Dr. Beloved husband of Sue and Georgene. Wonderful father of Jon, Paul and Seth. Proud grandfather of Sam. Cherished father-in-law of Maeda and Nilda. Highly respected physician. Deep in our hearts there is life everlasting and love without end. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, November 30, at 4:30 PM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street at Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRENKEL, BEVERLY V.
description: FRENKEL-Beverly V. On November 22, 1999. We deeply regret the passing of Beverly Frenkel, devoted wife and mother of Judge Herbert and Charles Frenkel and sister of Ruth Zeichner.

title: 'Nutcracker' Whirls On, With Taped Tchaikovsky
description: ''The Nutcracker'' opened on Friday night at the New York State Theater with the New York City Ballet's bright performance of George Balanchine's version of the choreographic fairy tale, which has become a holiday tradition. This year, however, there was a break in tradition. The New York City Ballet Orchestra was on strike, and Tchaikovsky's score was heard on tape for the first time since the production's premiere in 1954.

title: Will He or Won't He? The Giuliani Chorus
description: Armed with Hillary Rodham Clinton's announcement last week that she is committed to running for the United States Senate in New York next year, commentators on Sunday morning television news programs and advisers to the first lady sought to turn up the pressure yesterday on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to formally declare his candidacy.

title: Nets End Their Road Trip Looking More and More Lost
description: The near nightly experience of being run off the court has become so upsetting that Stephon Marbury has resorted to looking at the big picture. Not the National Basketball Association's 82-game regular season, but life.

title: Media Talk; Newspapers Criticize Circulation Auditor
description: Pop quiz on the A B C's of the Audit Bureau of Circulations. Which of the following counts as paid circulation, by the bureau's rules?

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Giants' and Jets' Days Are Getting Colder and Shorter; A Team Without a Clue For What's Gone Wrong
description: Jim Fassel, the Giants' coach, said he was disappointed and accepted blame. Michael Strahan, the defensive end, said he was shocked. Kerry Collins, the new quarterback, said he was discouraged and encouraged. Jessie Armstead, the talkative linebacker, spoke loudly with his absence, leaving Giants Stadium without comment. Sam Garnes, the strong safety, said what he saw was ''totally ridiculous.''

title: TECHNOLOGY; Internet Labels Lose Meaning in Rush for Popular Addresses
description: It used to be that you could tell a lot about a Web site just by looking at the letters after the ''dot'' in its address. But as competition for prime Internet addresses intensifies, the most popular dot suffixes for domain names -- .com, .net and .org -- are losing the meanings they once had.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNORS, DONALD F.
description: CONNORS-Donald F. Professor Emeritus at Fordham University, died at his home on Saturday, November 27, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Helen Newman Connors. He is survived by five sons, Dr. Donald F. Jr., Thomas, Michael, Edward and Christopher; two daughters, Harriette DeLuca and Helen Bates. He is survived by 20 grandchildren and 26 greatgrandchildren. Calling hours are Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9, at Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Ave, Scarsdale, NY. Funeral Wednesday at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, in Scarsdale, at 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, RITA
description: KAUFMAN-Rita. The Ramaz School family mourns the passing of its devoted alumni parent and grandparent and longtime benefactor, the beloved mother of our cherished alumni and supporters, the late Judy Hurwich, Gerald S. Kaufman, Belda Lindenbaum and Carol Newman. The Kaufman Auditorium in our Upper School, together with her many expressions of love for the children of Ramaz and the School itself will render her memory eternal in our midst. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, Principal David N. Kahn Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOTTI, LOUIS B. JR.
description: DOTTI-Louis B. Jr. Of New Canaan, CT, on November 27, 1999. Formerly Executive Vice Presidnet of Institutional Investor and Board Member of the National Kidney Cancer Foundation. Father of Nicholas Dotti. Memorial service Saturday, December 4, at 2:30 PM, in the First Presbyterian Church, Oenoke Ridge Road, New Canaan, CT. Memorial contributions to the Kidney Cancer Foundation, New York Chapter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, CHARLES W.
description: ALEXANDER-Charles W. Suddenly on November 27, 1999. Loving husband and best friend of Rhoda Landau Alexander. Beloved father of Michael, Jimmy, JoAnn and Richard. Cherished brother of Ira. Devoted grandfather to Jessica, Jacob, Jack, Max, Luke and Noah. Admired fatherin-law of Jane, Kim, Cindy and Patrick (Rodgers). Charlie devoted his talent and time in retirement as a volunteer arbitrator to the Education and Assistance Corporation. Dad, your love, humor, charm, loyalty, guidance and strength will live within us every day and always. Memorial services were held on November 28, 1999, at Gutterman's Inc, Rockville Centre, NY.

title: Patents; Just the thing for the holiday rush: a shopping bag that can be worn like a backpack.
description: AS the holidays approach, shopping for gifts and festive meals becomes a major undertaking for many people. Just about everyone knows what it is like to leave a store laden with shopping bags, and since few do their holiday shopping with a backpack, a wheeled cart or a valet, the plastic handles on those bags often end up creating new indentations in fingers.

title: Media Talk; Less Enthusiasm For Networks' Music Projects
description: It was only a year ago that network movie executives were speaking optimistically about commissioning music-based television mini-series to cash in on the sales of related compact discs. The biggest television event last November, an NBC mini-series on the Temptations, helped create momentum for the music-based idea by generating big ratings and big sales for a CD, sold through an ''800'' telephone number. The momentum increased in February when a second NBC music-oriented movie, ''The 60's,'' was such a hit that its CD became the best-selling movie soundtrack on the Billboard chart.

title: Media; Challenge Facing Talk: Regenerate the Buzz
description: After four issues, Tina Brown's Talk magazine is no longer the talk of the town. After the burst of attention that accompanied the first issue -- which featured an arguably revealing profile of the First Lady -- the magazine has hardly stirred a whisper.

title: TWO STATES RETAIN ROLES IN SHAPING PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: The presidential primary season this week enters a frantic two-month sprint to the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary as the contenders deliver their pitches in a blast of speeches, debates and costly television commercials.

title: Compressed Data; A Schwab Manager Reviews 'Y2K: The Movie'
description: You had to be generously willing to suspend disbelief to accept the plot of ''Y2K: The Movie,'' the recent NBC thriller in which computing's millennium bug leads to industrial apocalypse and sets off a nuclear meltdown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, JANET LAIB
description: GOTTLIEB-Janet Laib. A fashion writer and publicist, died Friday, November 26 from cancer. She was 73. Mrs. Gottlieb left college and moved to New York after publishing her first freelance article, ''Must College Girls Wear Diapers?'' about the coddling of co-eds. Though intending a life on the stage, she instead found a career in magazine publishing and freelance writing. She worked at Seventeen and the Tobe Fashion Report, and her byline appeared in Vogue, Ladies Home Journal, The New York Times and other publications. She formed Janet Laib Public Relations, with a small stable of clients including Xerox, Hathaway Shirts and William Greenberg Jr. Desserts. In 1981, she became president of Edward Gottlieb Inc., a communications firm, and subsequently married her partner, Mr. Gottlieb. They worked on communications strategies for merger and acquisitions and crisis management for clients including Volkswagen US, Bear Stearns and Fleet Bank. Mrs. Gottlieb kept her passion for theater, and was one of the first backers of the play ''Wit.'' She belonged to The Fashion Group, the Overseas Press Club and The Financial Women's Association, as well as the Public Relations Society of America, the American Society of Journalists and Authors, and the Players Club. Born in Detroit, she attended the George School in Bucks County, PA and the University of Michigan, receiving her B.A. from the New School for Social Research in New York. She leaves a daughter, Margo Amgott. Her husband predeceased her. Burial is private. A memorial service will be held at 4 PM, Saturday, December 11 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Contributions may be made to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York, Development Office, 107 E. 70 St., NY, NY 10021 or to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Development Office, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021.

title: In America; Bullying the Homeless
description: Away from the parade, hunched in doorways or curled up in boxes soggy from the steady rain, the street people passed the Thanksgiving holiday.

title: Stephen Greene, 82, Painter With Distinctive Abstract Style
description: Stephen Greene, an abstract painter who whose sensuous brushwork and half-buried symbols synthesized elements of several postwar movements into a distinctive style, died on Nov. 18 at his home in Valley Cottage, N.Y., where he had lived for more than 40 years. He was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACJANNET, CHARLOTTE BLENSDORF
description: MacJANNET-Charlotte Blensdorf. Died November 25, in Geneva, Switzerland, age 98. As a musician, educator, camp director and conference organizer, she spent the 20th century promoting international peace and good will throughout Europe and America. With her late husband, Donald, she operated the MacJannet School and Camps in France, then transformed a ruined 11th century priory in Talloires, France, into the present European campus of Tufts University. Her idealism, energy and indefatigable optimism will forever inspire all who knew her. Friends who wish to carry on her work may send donations in her name care of The MacJannet Foundation, 200 Linden Street, Wellesley, MA 02482.
