description: To the Editor:

title: Hsing-Hsing the Panda, A Gift From Mao, Dies
description: Hsing-Hsing, the National Zoo's giant panda who for more than a quarter-century served as diplomat, research subject and sweet-natured delight to millions, died this morning. Zookeepers gave the panda a lethal injection after deciding that irreversible kidney disease had made his life too painful to endure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARBER, SAMUEL
description: FARBER-Samuel. On November 27, 1999, age 94. Longtime resident of Brooklyn, recently of Boynton Beach, FL, and Southbury, CT. Beloved husband of Marjorie. Loving father of Elizabeth Bernhardt and Anne Farber, and father-in-law of William Bernhardt and Richard Kaiser. Cherished grandfather of Rachel, Emily, Doris, Sophie, Deborah and Sam. Services at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Wednesday, December 1, at 10:45 AM. Visiting hours Tuesday, 6-9 PM.

title: Santa Clara Advances
description: WOMEN'S DIVISION I

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALZIEL, EDYTHE
description: DALZIEL-Edythe. November 28, 1999. In Pinehurst, NC. Memorial service Gloria Dei Church, New Hyde Park, December 1, 11 AM.

title: Whos Going to Solve the China Question?
description: A man cycles past a coal powered electricity plant in Fuxin, China. Issues about the countrys responsibility to help curb global warming must be weighed against concerns about economic development. Greg Baker/AP

title: 26.4 Billion Offer Pits 2 Scottish Banks For Britain's No. 3 : Royal Bank Tops Rival's Bid to Buy NatWest
description: LONDON  The battle for control of National Westminster Bank PLC intensified Monday as Royal Bank of Scotland PLC offered 26.4 billion to acquire Britain's third-largest bank, exceeding a rival offer from Bank of Scotland PLC.

title: INSIDE
description: Review of Boycott Laws

title: Sports of The Times; The Only Playoff Team On Campus
description: THE only playoff coach at Hofstra University yesterday couldn't say enough about his football team. How it had not given up when it was 10 points behind last weekend, how it refused to surrender to tragedy a month ago or earlier this season when its star running back went down for the year.

title: EUROPEAN RETAILING DEAL
description: Britain's No. 1 appliance retailer, Dixons Group, agreed to pay 160 Norwegian kroner a share in cash for Elkjop of Norway to become Europe's biggest electric-goods company. Dixons's offer is for the 41 percent of Elkjop, the top Scandinavian electrical retailer, that it does not already own, and values the company at $712 million. Dixons operates in Ireland, Belgium, Luxembourg, Germany and France.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOOB, JULIA ASHLEY (NEE SHANET)
description: KOOB-Julia Ashley (Nee Shanet). At age 85. As Julia Ashley she taught English at Woodrow Wilson Vocational High School, Erasmus High School, High School of Art and Design. A bright and warm loving person. She touched the minds and hearts of all who knew her. She was the wife of Harry, the mother of Priscilla and Joseph Erardi, Kathleen and Andrew Wittenborn. The sister of Howard and Bernice Shanet, the aunt of Laurence Shanet, the grandmother of Vincent & Deborah Erardi, Harry and Melissa Erardi, the great-grandmother of Branden and Joey Erardi. in lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate that donations be sent to The Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Medical Center, 1st Avenue at 16th Street, New York, New York 10003.

title: Mind and Body
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARREN, WILLIAM S.
description: WARREN-William S. On behalf of the trustees and staff of the American Federation of Arts, we send our heartfelt condolences to our beloved trustee Nani Warren for the tragic death of her son, William S. Warren, and her grandchildren Jack, Will and Rob. Robert Meltzer, Chairman Jan Mayer, President Serena Rattazzi, Director

title: Whistleblower Act Is in Peril After Court Widens an Issue
description: Finding itself with a far-reaching constitutional challenge to the federal whistleblower law suddenly on its hands, the Supreme Court appeared uncertain today about how to proceed through a jurisdictional thicket of its own making.

title: In London, The Last 'Sensation' Gives Way To the Next
description: When you ask regulars of the London art scene what they think of the furor caused in New York City by ''Sensation,'' the exhibition of work by young British artists (or Y.B.A.'s) at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, you get a range of reactions.

title: GROUP ASKING U.S. FOR NEW VIGILANCE IN PATIENT SAFETY
description: Citing evidence that medical errors cause tens of thousands of deaths each year, the National Academy of Sciences called today for a new federal agency to protect patients and said Congress should require all health care providers to report mistakes that cause serious injury or death.

title: Colombey-les-deux-Eglises Journal; Still Holding Court, the Mythic Gaullist Who Was
description: Coming here is a ritual of French politics. Even some of the country's highest office holders come to this small village, three hours from Paris by car, every year on the anniversary of Charles de Gaulle's death.

title: The Reality of the Fantasy in the Harry Potter Stories
description: It was a quarter of a century ago that Bruno Bettelheim, the child psychologist, accounted for what may be the most impressive and otherwise mysterious publishing phenomenon of the season: the fact that the Harry Potter mysteries by the previously unknown J. K. Rowling are turning out to be among the best-selling books in history.

title: The Future of Elian Gonzalez
description: In the Florida Straits, where so many Cubans have lost their lives trying to make their way across the last cold-war barrier to the United States, another small, overloaded boat has sunk, apparently drowning a young woman and casting her 5-year-old son adrift. For two days after the 17-foot boat went down, Elian Gonzalez clung to an inner tube before fishermen on Thanksgiving morning found him and two adults who had survived. His pluck kept him alive, and brought him to the country his mother and stepfather may have died trying to reach. Their bodies have not been found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, BERNARD
description: ROBBINS-Bernard. The Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York, Inc., notes with sadness the death of Bernard Robbins, a valued member of the Orchestra's violin section from 1955 to 1983. In addition to his long tenure at the Philharmonic, Mr. Robbins performed with the NBC Symphony under Toscanini and with the Stradivarius String Quartet, the NBC String Quartet and the Canadian Quartet. His legacy of high standards and deep regard for his colleagues will long enrich our lives. We extend our sincere condolences to his family, including his wife, Libby, and their children. Kurt Masur, Music Director Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Deborah Borda, Exec. Director

title: Gold Retreats as Britain Sells 25 Tons Below Market Price
description: Gold futures dropped almost 3 percent yesterday, their biggest decline in four weeks, after the Bank of England sold about 25 metric tons of bullion below the market price.

title: Can Doctors Curb Medical Costs?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pipeline Company Expects Losses From Unauthorized Trades
description: Plains All American Pipeline L.P. said today that unauthorized crude oil trading by an employee was expected to cause $160 million in losses and was forcing the company to renegotiate credit agreements.

title: A Namibian Independence Hero Faces New Challenge at the Polls
description: A decade after leading Namibia to independence, President Sam Nujoma's party faces the first bona fide challenge to its political leadership this week when voters elect a president and new Parliament.

title: Dow Off 40.99 on Worries About Fast Pace of Economy
description: Worries that the economy is showing few signs of slowing despite the efforts of the Federal Reserve swept through the bond market yesterday, pushing interest rates sharply higher. Stock prices, which have been on a torrid run, fell in sympathy.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture in the Arts section yesterday with a review of the Aquila Theater Company's performance of ''The Iliad: Book I,'' at Lincoln Center, was published in error. It showed the troupe's version of ''King Lear.'' (A second picture, with the continuation of the article, indeed showed ''The Iliad.'')

title: VITAL SIGNS: Rx MONEY; A Lower Risk and a Much Higher Cost
description: Celebrex and Vioxx are two of the hottest drugs on the market, in large part because of their potential for reducing pain and inflammation without the risk of gastric harm associated with medicines like ibuprofen, naproxen or aspirin. But a pair of new studies has led The Journal of the American Medical Association to conclude that while those risks are indeed lowered, they are not lowered enough to justify the extra cost of prescribing them for most people.

title: Excerpts From Speech on Foreign Policy
description: Following are excerpts from the prepared text of Bill Bradley's speech on foreign policy today at Tufts University:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUNKER, EDMUND CASON
description: BUNKER-Edmund Cason, 84, died November 28, after a long illness. Mr. Bunker was a pioneer in the field of Broadcasting, serving as Vice-president of Station Relations, Sales and The Corporation of CBS Inc., President of Radio Advertising Bureau, Director of Broadcasting for Foote, Cone and Belding, Vice-President of the Inter public Group of Companies, Inc. He leaves his wife, Katherine, two daughters and two granddaughters.

title: JAPANESE CHIP VENTURE
description: Japan's largest chip maker, the NEC Corporation, and the nation's third largest, Hitachi Ltd., agreed to form a joint venture to cut costs and accelerate the process of developing future generations of computer memory chips. The venture, NEC-Hitachi Memory Inc., will start by year-end with the aim of developing 256-megabit and 512-megabit dynamic random-access memory chips, devices that will succeed the 64-megabit D-RAM's most commonly used as main memory in PC's. NEC and Hitachi plan to sell D-RAM chips based on the venture's technology by the end of March 2002.

title: The Confederate Flag
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: 6-Eyed Creature To Watch Sky On Famed Peak
description: Since the early years of the 20th century, Mount Wilson, a peak north of Los Angeles, has been a center of astronomy.

title: Accounts
description: * Ticketmaster Online-CitySearch, Pasadena, Calif., owned by USA Networks, to Mediacom, New York, part of Grey Advertising, to handle its first national media account. Billings were estimated at $10 million. Creative duties are handled by a Mediacom sibling, J. Brown/LMC Group, Stamford, Conn.

title: Man Killed and 2 Others Shot in Brooklyn
description: Two men in Brooklyn shot and killed a grocery store employee last night, seriously wounded two other men and then carjacked a getaway car, the police said.

title: Body Found in Duffel Was Kidnapping Victim
description: A man who was shot to death, stuffed into a duffel bag and dumped in Westchester County was the victim of a ransom plot, court papers say.

title: Bush Offers Giuliani Help On the Right
description: On his first political trip since Hillary Rodham Clinton announced her intention to run for the United States Senate, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani basked today in the praise of a political benefactor, Gov. George W. Bush.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Home Resales Slid 6.6% in October, the Fourth Month of Decline
description: Sales of existing homes fell in October to their lowest level in almost two years, an industry survey showed today, signaling that one of the forces behind the near-record United States expansion has started to cool.

title: Judge Dismisses Libel Suit by Former Medical Examiner Against The Times
description: A State Supreme Court judge has dismissed a longstanding libel suit against The New York Times by Dr. Elliot M. Gross, a former New York City chief medical examiner, who said he was defamed in a series of articles in 1985 and 1986 that quoted pathologists and others who accused him of misconduct and producing inaccurate or misleading autopsy reports.

title: Lawyer Says Federal Tapes Will Backfire
description: A lawyer for John Powell, the former leader of the Suffolk County Republican Party who is being tried on charges of conspiracy and extortion, said during closing arguments today that the government's secretly recorded evidence would backfire, exonerating Mr. Powell.

title: Link Up and Cash In
description: Proponents of campaign finance ''reform'' have pushed for years for full public financing of candidates. This is the only way, the true believers insist, that the public interest can be served and the special interests constrained. Well, consider public financing's latest gift to politics: the unholy alliance of Patrick Buchanan and Lenora Fulani. Those two politicians, who have garnered almost no public support of late, may well be given a prominent platform next year, at taxpayer expense.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Danger: Road Dust

title: HIDDEN INTEREST -- A special report.; When Physicians Double as Entrepreneurs
description: Thousands of heart specialists watched on closed-circuit television monitors at the Washington Convention Center as a tiny device was implanted in a patient's coronary artery. The doctors heard the voice of Dr. Martin Leon, a prominent cardiologist who was describing the operation taking place in a hospital many miles away.

title: No Improper Influence Seen on Part of Builder in Fatal Collapse
description: The Brooklyn district attorney's office has determined that the contractor involved in the fatal collapse of a building last week did not have a direct role in the ouster of the borough's buildings commissioner this year, a law enforcement official said yesterday.

title: NEW CANADA EXCHANGE
description: Stock trading began on the new Canadian Venture Exchange, which combines issues previously listed on the Vancouver, Alberta and Winnipeg stock exchanges, as well as Toronto's over-the-counter Canadian Dealing Network. Known as CDNX, the new exchange has about 2,600 listings, mostly from Vancouver and Alberta -- and 55 percent of them are junior mining and oil companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, THOMAS L.
description: JACOBS-Thomas L. Suddenly on 11/27/99. Beloved husband of Ann Harris-Jacobs and devoted father of Lauren. Retired Deputy Commissioner of Corrections; former Commissioner of Probation; Adjunct Professor at John Jay College. He will be missed by all who knew him. Visiting hours 2-4 p.m. and 6-8:30 P.M., Wednesday, December 1, Benta's Funeral Home, 630 St. Nicholas Ave (141 St), NYC. Mass of Christian burial Thursday, December 2, 7:30 P.M. Church of St. Francis Xavier, 46 W. 16th St. between 5th and 6th Avenues. In lieu of flowers the family would appreciate contributions to St. Aloysius Scholarship Fund, 223 W. 132 St, NYC 10027 or Capital Campaign Church of St. Francis Xavier, 55 W. 15 St., NYC 10011.

title: Isles' Goalie Gets Off To Fast Start
description: After it was over, and the reality of what he had accomplished in his National Hockey League debut began to sink in, goaltender Roberto Luongo stopped in the hallway of the Fleet Center Sunday night and did what any 20-year-old budding star would do in the same situation. He turned on his cell phone and called his parents in Montreal to tell them the good news.

title: CK WITCO SELLING EUROPEAN INDUSTRIAL DYE OPERATIONS
description: The CK Witco Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its European industrial dyes business to Yorkshire Group of Britain for $86 million in cash and stock. The sale also includes CK Witco's worldwide textile colors business. CK Witco, based in Stamford, Conn., is a specialty chemicals producer with annual revenue of $3.3 billion. Yorkshire, headquartered in Leeds, England, makes dyes. It had revenue of $94 million in 1998. The operations being sold generate annual revenue of $150 million. CK Witco was created in September through the merger of Crompton & Knowles and Witco.

title: In Policy Talk, Bradley Urges More Trade and Less Force
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley sketched out a vision for foreign policy today, declaring that he would try to resolve global conflicts with trade and diplomacy instead of force, reduce the threat of a new arms race and set clearer limits on American military intervention in the world's many ethnic wars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SABER, CHARLES
description: SABER-Charles, 77. Of Saber's Hardware. Died Monday after a long illness. Services are at United Hebrew Community, 201 E. Broadway, at 11:45 on November 30.

title: A Furious Strahan Ends His Silence
description: In the locker room after Sunday's devastating loss to the Arizona Cardinals, Giants defensive end Michael Strahan had little to say.

title: Fix Speech Problems Early, Experts Now Urge
description: Legend has it that Albert Einstein did not say much as a toddler, making his mother and father worry that he might never be very bright. His supposed failure to master language early has reassured parents of late talkers ever since.

title: After the Storm, an Ecological Bomb
description: In September, the one-two punch of Hurricanes Dennis and Floyd dropped some three feet of rain on the eastern third of North Carolina, turning the region into a putrescent hell of polluted flood waters, decomposing chickens and hogs, rotting farm fields and ruined neighborhoods. Never before in the recorded history of the region, experts say, had there been such a big and disastrous flood.

title: Boeing's Unapproved Designs Lead to Federal Safety Review
description: The Federal Aviation Administration will conduct a special three-month safety audit of Boeing's factories, after learning that the company built hundreds of airplanes that did not meet approved designs, the agency said today.

title: BP Amoco's Loss Considered Business as Usual in Russia
description: A court-ordered sale of an oil company last week that effectively made most of BP Amoco's half-billion-dollar investment in Russia worthless has ignited new cries of outrage among foreign investors. But it is not expected to have grave consequences for Russia.

title: With Hemingway as Friend, Who Needed Enemies?
description: HEMINGWAY VS. FITZGERALD

title: Besides Singing, There's Something to Look At
description: Tracey Thorn is a modest star, drawing attention to herself with delicate insistence. Her voice has become a fundamental presence in British pop since the 1980's as she and her partner, the multi-instrumentalist Ben Watt, have explored variations on soul in the group Everything but the Girl. In the past few years, EBTG (as the duo is known) has used dance-oriented electronic music to transcend cult status. This has challenged the reserved Ms. Thorn, creating a subtle conflict that rewards both the singer and the genre she now inhabits.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Nov. 19 about the agreement to build an oil pipeline from the Caspian Sea region to the Mediterranean misidentified a leader toasting the deal. He was President Nursultan Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan, not President Imamali Rahmanov of Tajikistan.

title: A Plane Crash Jarringly Reverberates on a Quiet Block in Newark
description: Robbie Hutchins has lived most of her 34 years at 25 Kent Street, in the middle of a tiny, quiet block, just off one of the city's busiest avenues. Before last Friday, she said, her memories were of a safe oasis of close-knit families, where parents on concrete stoops watched one another's children skip rope and play kickball in the shadow of an abandoned factory. These were the happy days of childhood, both hers and that of her daughter, Kawana.

title: A Trap for Russia
description: The Western debate over Russia's assault on Chechnya has been largely polarized, with Russophobes crying genocide and Islamophobes warning about Muslim terrorists. But the attitudes of Chechen refugees whose lives have been upended by the war are far more nuanced, and may yield some insight into achieving a lasting peace.

title: Judge Limits Expenditures by the I.B.F.
description: A federal judge, acting on part of a request by federal prosecutors that the court take sweeping control of the International Boxing Federation, issued an order today barring its indicted leadership from making any individual expenditures in excess of $5,000 without court permission.

title: Truck Safety in Transition
description: Just before adjourning, Congress approved a measure creating a separate new agency within the Transportation Department to address the pressing issue of truck safety. Last year 5,374 people died in truck accidents, an average of more than 100 per week. The new agency is needed because the organization long responsible for policing truck safety, the Federal Highway Administration's Office of Motor Carriers, is too complacent and too cozy with the trucking industry.

title: Maybe A Settlement, Never Closure
description: IT isn't as if Eugene and Serena Neumann spend their days dwelling on how fate and the Nazis robbed them of their youth, condemning them to years of slave labor and places like Auschwitz, that synonym for barbarity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINE, PHILIP, MD
description: FINE-Philip, MD, of Marlboro, NJ, formerly of Woodmere, LI. Beloved husband of the late Constance, adored father of Cynthia (Dr. Stuart) Green, Barbara (Donald) Weber, and Mitchell (Tsivia) Fine. Cherished grandfather of 14 and great-grandfather of two. Major in Medical Corps of General Patton's Sixth Armored Division from 1942-1945. Recipient of Bronze Star, Purple Heart, and Conspicuous Service Cross Medals. Retired from General Practice in Cambria Heights and Valley Stream after 35 years. Irreplaceable to all who knew and loved him. Information: Bloomfield-Cooper Chapel 732-446-4242.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLEY, AUGUSTUS MAVERICK ''GUS''
description: KELLEY - Augustus Maverick ''Gus'', age 85. Of Birchard Avenue, Little Compton, Rhode Island. Former husband of Eva Kelley. Stepfather of Pavel, Andrei and Dr. Anne Joseph. Brother of Nicholas Kelley, Jr. and the late Judge Florence M. Kelley, brother-in-law of Margaret M. Kelley and David Worgan. Uncle of Nicholas M., Susan M. and Deborah M. Kelley. A service of Thanksgiving in trubute will be held Saturday December 4, 1999 at 11AM in the Friends Quaker Meeting House, Main Road, Westport, Mass. Relatives and friends invited. For more information contact the 'Cherry Place' Home of Waring-SullivanAshton-Coughlin-Driscoll, 178 Winter Street, Fall River, Mass.

title: The Future of Trade, According to Gates
description: To the Editor:

title: A Passion for Compassion for the Homeless
description: MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI dispensed some free psychotherapy last week, this time for those who disagree with his homeless policies. ''To me, it's a psychological problem that some people in the city have had in the past in dealing with their own guilt,'' he said at a news conference at Bellevue Hospital Center.

title: Iran Jails a Critic
description: Abdollah Nouri, one of Iran's most popular and courageous political reformers, has been unjustly sentenced to five years in prison and banned from running for office until 2004. His alleged crime consisted of publishing newspaper articles critical of official Iranian policies. That such a harsh sentence could be imposed for exercising basic journalistic freedoms is a measure of how fearful and out of touch Iran's ruling conservative clerics have become in the face of popular demands for greater democracy and individual liberty.

title: A China Dissident's Ordeal: Back to the Mental Hospital
description: A Chinese political dissident who was held for more than seven years in a psychiatric hospital after he unfurled a protest banner in Tiananmen Square in 1992 has been reincarcerated, prompting human rights advocates to call for a United Nations investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLINSMAN, WILLIAM J.
description: GLINSMAN-William J. On November 27, 1999. Beloved husband of Margaret M. (nee Van Hasselt) Glinsman. Brother of Geraldine Casey. Former Director of N.Y. State Mediation Board, former President of Local 211, I.U.O.E., Labor Arbitrator for many industries. Reposing at Schuyler Hill Funeral Home, 3535 East Tremont Ave., Bronx until Wednesday at 9:30 AM. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Frances de Chantal Church, 10 am. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting 2-5 and 7-9:30 pm

title: Trade Talks Start in Seattle Despite a Few Disruptions
description: A week of talks aimed at expanding global trade got off to something well short of a smooth start here today. The disruptions included a brief bomb scare, the smashing of a window in protests at a McDonald's restaurant and a takeover of a vacant three-story building by a self-described group of anarchists.

title: Regina Slatkin, a Specialist in Art, Dies at 92
description: Regina Shoolman Slatkin, a dealer in old master drawings and a writer and specialist on the 18th-century French painter Francois Boucher, died on Thursday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 92 and had homes in Manhattan, Essex, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Hillary Clinton Takes a Step Into Queens Politics
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton waded into local Democratic Party politics last night by attending a fund-raising reception for Congressman Joseph Crowley, who represents Queens and a section of the Bronx.

title: Giants Lose Way for Season
description: Charles Way, the Giants' fullback, will miss the rest of the regular season because of a torn meniscus in his right knee, according to two people who requested anonymity. Way, who has been bothered by pain and swelling in the knee for several weeks, started last Sunday's game against the Arizona Cardinals but did not play after the second quarter. He was limping badly in the team's locker room after the game.

title: After Trying the Virtuoso Life, A Designer Stoops to Success
description: When Wynn Smith begins designing a new collection, he approaches the matter the way he would sit down to write a short story. First, he manufactures a character, then conjures for her the kind of detailed biography that could serve as a model to creative-writing students in many an M.F.A. program.

title: U.S. Frees Man Jailed 3 Years On Secret Data
description: Attorney General Janet Reno declined to block the release last night of an Egyptian man who had been held for three and a half years in a New York jail on secret evidence that the F.B.I. had said linked him to terrorists in the United States and Egypt.

title: 'Nutcracker' on Tape
description: To the Editor:

title: Can Doctors Curb Medical Costs?
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors' Unsolved Mysteries: When Fevers Have No Known Cause
description: The fever took up residence in the young man like a squatter who had started to break things. In the beginning it seemed benign enough. It started one morning as a temperature of 101. That was all: no cough, no diarrhea, no skin rash, nothing. Doctors thought it was probably a run-of-the-mill viral infection that would go away on its own. But it didn't. Soon, the nosebleeds and abdominal pain started.

title: Robert Bingham, A Publishing Scion And an Author, 33
description: Robert Bingham, the author of a collection of short stories and a member of the prominent Kentucky newspaper publishing family, died Sunday at his home in TriBeCa in Manhattan. He was 33.

title: Both Sides Join to Pick New Cabinet For Ulster
description: Leaders from pro-British Protestant and pro-Irish Catholic parties took a major step tonight in moving their age-old conflict into the political arena, selecting the members of the cabinet that will run the new power-sharing Northern Ireland Assembly.

title: Deutsch Gets A Domino's Account
description: Domino's Pizza Inc. has awarded the national creative part of its account, with billings estimated at $100 million to $120 million, to Deutsch Inc. in New York.

title: 3M BUYS POLAROID'S ANTI-GLARE SCREEN BUSINESS
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said yesterday that it had bought the Polaroid Corporation's anti-glare computer-filter business, adding to 3M's No. 1 position in the world market for anti-glare screens. Terms were not disclosed. Polaroid, the world's biggest instant photography company, also will sell computer-filter parts to 3M and allow 3M to use the Polaroid name for marketing. The sale is part of Polaroid's effort to increase its share price by selling some businesses that are not directly related to the main business of instant photography. Polaroid shares rose 6.25 cents, to $19.375, in New York Stock Exchange trading, while 3M, based in St. Paul, fell 56.25 cents, to $94.9375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARBER, SAMUEL
description: FARBER-Samuel. On November 27, 1999, age 94. Longtime resident of Brooklyn, recently of Boynton Beach, FL, and Southbury, CT. Beloved husband of Marjorie. Loving father of Elizabeth Bernhardt and Anne Farber, and father-in-law of William Bernhardt and Richard Kaiser. Cherished grandfather of Rachel, Emily, Doris, Sophie, Deborah and Sam. Services at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Wednesday, December 1, at 10:45 AM. Visiting hours Tuesday, 6-9 PM.

title: Golf Club Faces Steep Penalties in Sex-Bias Case
description: The Massachusetts attorney general's office has asked a state judge to appoint a monitor to take over a private country club, after a jury in Boston found that the club had systematically discriminated against a group of female golfers and awarded them $1.9 million in damages.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a possible move of Connecticut's Appellate Court out of Hartford misidentified the court that Justice Francis M. McDonald said had a backlog of 200 murder cases and 22,000 civil cases. It is the Superior Court system, not the Appellate Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESLIE, BETHEL
description: LESLIE-Bethel. Died Sunday at home. Visitation on Wednesday, December 1, 5-8PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Memorial service Thursday, December 2, 1:30PM, at the Chapel of St. Bartholomew Church, 109 E. 50th St. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The Actor's Fund.

title: Helping Turn Individualists Into Willing Collaborators
description: Joel Frahm, one of the young band leaders often heard in New York's small jazz clubs, sounds supremely comfortable playing the tenor saxophone. He has enough physical force to produce a full, mellow sound at a rapid tempo, and sometimes he naturally recalls Sonny Rollins's playing from the late 1950's.

title: COX BROADCASTING TO BUY SAN FRANCISCO TV STATION
description: Cox Broadcasting Inc., an affiliate of the No. 5 United States cable television operator Cox Communications Inc., agreed yesterday to buy the independent station KICU-TV, which broadcasts in the San Francisco Bay area. Terms of the agreement with the closely held KICU Inc. were not disclosed. KICU, Channel 36, will be Cox's second station in San Francisco, the fifth-largest television market in the United States, along with KTVU-TV, a Fox affiliate. Shares of Cox Communications, based in Atlanta, fell 56.25 cents, to $47.375.

title: A Royal Bank Counteroffer For NatWest
description: The Royal Bank of Scotland announced a $42.5 billion hostile bid today for National Westminster Bank, Britain's third largest, touching off a potentially bruising bidding war.

title: Campaigns are taking to the streets to raise awareness of companies' products and services.
description: THE battle among advertisers for eyeballs is not limited to the Internet. There is still warfare being waged street by street as more marketers -- including dozens of dot-coms -- turn to outdoor advertising to increase awareness of their products and services.

title: Front Row
description: A Writer's Bazaar

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAWSON, TRUDY
description: DAWSON-Trudy. The Board of Directors, Artists and Staff of The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center mourn the loss of our beloved colleague and friend Trudy Dawson, Associate Director of Marketing and Booking at Lincoln Center. Trudy was an invaluable partner to the Chamber Music Society; her professional and friendly manner made working with her a pleasure. She was an asset to Lincoln Center and will be missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family, friends and colleagues. Donaldson C. Pillsbury, Chairman Peter Frelinghuysen, President David Shifrin, Artistic Director Jacqueline M. Taylor, Exec. Dir.

title: Q & A
description: The Species Census

title: Water Recedes, but Tensions Rise; Cleanup Strains Bonds Between Tenant and Landlord
description: When Bettina DeCaumette and her mother wanted to start an antiques business almost eight years ago, they found an empty storefront on Hamilton Street, in this throwback of a town with its weathered brick buildings and locally owned stores. They were told that the owner of the building was a man named Phil Neri, who also operated the Brook Theater a few doors down, with its grand lobby lined in silk brocade and black-and-white photographs of stars from the 40's and 50's.

title: Giuliani Is Consistent
description: To the Editor:

title: College and Diversity
description: To the Editor:

title: It's The Big Game: ESPN v. Baseball
description: There is hot stove league news more riveting than questions about the Mets' ability to keep John Olerud or the Yankees' desire to re-sign David Cone.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''These stunningly high rates of medical errors -- resulting in deaths, permanent disability and unnecessary suffering -- are simply unacceptable in a medical system that promises first to 'do no harm.' ''

title: Justices to Decide Foreign Policy Question in Massachusetts Boycott of Myanmar
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Massachusetts intruded too far into the realm of foreign policy when it adopted a law requiring state agencies to boycott companies that do business in Myanmar.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CITRIN, PHILIP
description: CITRIN-Philip. Age 86, of West Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Glen Cove, NY, on November 27, 1999. Excellent husband to his beloved wife, Evelyn. Devoted father to Barbara and Jack Gattuso, Ava and Michael Dvoretz, Niles and Nancy Citrin. Adored Pop Pop of Suzanne, Brian, Steven, Todd, Jodi, Elise and Mark. Loving greatgrandfather of Matthew, Rachel and Jordyn. He was a member of the Masons and Knights of Pythias. His greatest joys in life were the times spent with his family. He loved his relatives and many friends who along with his family will miss him dearly. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Left-Handed Dexterity
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets' Tape Doesn't Lie: Many Targets to Blame
description: The tape ran, stopping and starting again, over and over, for an hour and a half. The Nets watched the first half of their humiliating 129-90 loss at Phoenix in excruciating detail, then met as a team with their coaches before taking the floor at the Champion Center for a long practice.

title: Climate and Capitalism
description: To the Editor:

title: Warner-Lambert Sues Pfizer Over Drug
description: The Warner-Lambert Company sued Pfizer Inc. as expected yesterday in an attempt to end the marketing agreement between the two companies to sell Lipitor, an enormously successful cholesterol-reducing drug.

title: Ending Tenure for Principals
description: The Giuliani administration and the principals' union must not let their negotiations on ending tenure for principals break down over a less vital issue concerning assistant principals. New York City believes that any plan to end tenure should also apply to assistant principals. The union, which represents 2,500 assistant principals in addition to 1,100 principals, argues that assistant principals were not on the agenda, and in any case that the functions and responsibilities of assistant principals are very different from those of principals.

title: INVESTIGATORS DIG FOR MASS GRAVES AT MEXICO BORDER
description: Mexican authorities, backed by F.B.I. investigators, began yesterday to excavate sites near the Texas border that they believe may hold the bodies of scores of Mexicans and Americans who disappeared in the last several years and who are thought to have been killed by drug traffickers.

title: Choreographic Tales of Ambition, Guilt, Struggle and Survival
description: The Mary Anthony Dance Theater looked to the past while living in the present on Sunday afternoon at the Theater of Riverside Church.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Investor in Japan Files U.S. Suit
description: The Amada Company, Japan's largest manufacturer of metalworking machinery, has filed a lawsuit against the Republic New York Corporation and two officers, accusing them of fraudulently inducing the firm to buy securities, which are now worthless, from Martin Armstrong, an investment adviser.

title: ENDO PHARMACEUTICALS AGREES TO ACQUIRE ALGOS
description: Endo Pharmaceuticals Holdings, a closely held drug maker in which the New York investment firm Kelso & Company owns a majority stake, agreed to buy the Algos Pharmaceutical Corporation to gain new painkillers. The value of the transaction was not immediately disclosed. Algos shareholders will own about 20 percent of the combined company after the acquisition; Kelso & Company will own the majority of the shares. Algos shareholders will also receive warrants which they can exercise to buy more Endo shares if Algos's lead product, the painkiller MorphiDex, receives United States approval by the end of 2001. The shares of Algos, based in Neptune, N.J., fell $2.75 each, to $12.25, on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, ROLAND E.
description: PETERS-Roland E. At 82, loving husband of Gertrude. Adored and cherished father of Jody. Dear brother of the late Mark & Eileen. Uncle and ''father'' to Caroline and Maddy. Great-uncle of Stephen, Stacey and Douglas. Memorial services will be private.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Medical Device Research Mixes With Profit Motive

title: Is the Environment in Deep Water?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Comatose Fighter's Condition Worsens
description: The condition of a Queens boxer who fell into a coma after being knocked out in a middleweight bout in Atlantic City worsened yesterday when fluid began to fill his lungs, his trainer said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREEN, ALFRED J.
description: GREEN-Alfred J. Gone 10 years, in our hearts forever. Your Loving Famil

title: Media Edge Favored by Combe
description: Combe Inc. in White Plains, which makes health and beauty aids and over-the-counter drugs, has awarded media duties that had been handled in-house to Media Edge in New York, the media arm of Young & Rubicam Inc. Competitive Media Reporting, a unit of VNU N.V., put spending last year at $80 million.

title: Respect for Muslims
description: To the Editor:

title: Watching China's Big Board; Beijing Backs Trade Pact but Investors Remain Wary
description: In a dark, cavernous room literally tucked under the seats of the Beijing Workers' Stadium, hundreds of Chinese spend long hours sitting on coarse wooden benches squinting to see red and green numbers march down an electronic display screen half as long as a football field.

title: Mets Still Hope to Keep Olerud
description: The Mets had several discussions with John Olerud's agent, Joe McIntosh, over Thanksgiving weekend, but General Manager Steve Phillips said he still did not know when the free-agent first baseman would decide whether to return to the Mets or sign with the Seattle Mariners, near where he and his wife grew up and have a home.

title: Interns' Right To Unionize At Hospitals Is Expanded
description: The National Labor Relations Board ruled yesterday that interns and residents at privately owned hospitals had the right to form unions under federal law.

title: Dalembert Victorious In Debut
description: SETON HALL 79ST. PETER'S 65

title: ALTAVISTA IS BUYING RAGING BULL, FINANCIAL WEB SITE
description: The AltaVista Company, an Internet search service that is controlled by CMGI Inc., will buy the closely held financial Web site Raging Bull, adding 1.7 million users to AltaVista and making it the ninth most visited Web site. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed. Raging Bull, based in Andover, Mass., has received financing from CMGI, a venture capital company. CMGI bought a majority stake in AltaVista, based in Palo Alto, Calif., in August and plans to sell shares in the company to the public next year. Shares of CMGI, also based in Andover, rose $14.875 each, to $161.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: MOVEMENT IN CANADIAN AIRLINE DEAL
description: The directors of the Canadian Airlines Corporation said a $63 million offer by Air Canada was fair. But the board did not recommend acceptance or rejection of the bid to shareholders because it said some of Air Canada's takeover terms would not be met and because Canadian Airlines was still seeking alternative investors. Air Canada has been pressing its offer to buy Canadian Airlines since the collapse on Nov. 6 of an unsolicited proposal by the Onex Corporation to buy both airlines and merge them.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Courtroom Drama, Set to Music

title: Holocaust Survivors Urge Quick Payments in Swiss Settlement and Assail Legal Fees
description: Holocaust survivors and their relatives from around the world implored a federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday to quickly distribute the proceeds of a $1.25 billion settlement between Swiss banks and Holocaust survivors and to block lawyers from collecting what the survivors called exorbitant fees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENYON, HARRIETT HARDY
description: KENYON-Harriett Hardy. Of Asheville, NC, wife of the late W. Houston Kenyon of New York, died on November 13, 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENZER, RUTH L.
description: MENZER-Ruth L. Beloved wife of the late Jesse. Adored mother of Susan Levin and Dr. Lawrence Menzer. Cherished grandmother of Wendy and Zachary Menzer and Jonathan Levin. Services Tuesday, 12 Noon at RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: Cuban Government Enters Fight for Boy
description: The father of a 5-year-old Cuban boy who drifted in the Atlantic Ocean for two days on an inner tube before he was rescued on Thanksgiving Day has enlisted the aid of the Cuban government in seeking his child's custody.

title: Yesterday's Precocious Puberty Is Norm Today
description: A friend who runs the child care program at a Brooklyn high school reports that one of the newly enrolled mothers, a freshman, is 13. Her baby's father is 14. While children having children is not a new phenomenon, the ever-dropping age of puberty is.

title: Ogilvy Awarded Brill Account
description: Brill's Content magazine in New York, owned by Brill Media Ventures, has awarded advertising and redesign duties to units of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York, part of the WPP Group. Billings have not been determined.

title: Defending Champs Retain Their Title In Bridge Tourney
description: The defending champions swept to victory in the final event of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall National Championships here on Sunday night. Rita Shugart of Pebble Beach, Calif.; Andrew Robson and Tony Forrester, both of Britain; and Geir Helgemo of Norway, won the prestigious Reisinger Board-a-Match team championship by one of the highest margins in the history of the game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUTNER, MILDRED
description: KUTNER-Mildred. 82, formerly of Brooklyn, passed away November 29 in FL. Survived by two children; Anne (Michael) Greenstein and Mark (Gail) Kutner. Cherished grandchildren; Meredith, Melissa, Dale, Mallory, and Seth. Brother Leonard Sragow and sister Beatrice Mayrick. Services on December 1, Wednesday 9:30 a.m., Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY and burial following at New Montefiore. In lieu of flowers donations to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: Forget Next Week, the Jets Can Focus on Next Year
description: It was a long time coming, and there were moments it seemed the implausible would happen, but the Jets conceded today that their playoff hopes were no longer even a glimmer.

title: Interns and Residents Allowed to Unionize
description: Concluding that interns and residents at privately owned hospitals are employees, the National Labor Relations Board ruled that they had the right to form unions under federal law.

title: VITAL SIGNS: THERAPIES; Sweating Away Pain of Juvenile Arthritis
description: Juvenile arthritis often relegates its sufferers to the sidelines. But a University of Buffalo study of weight training has found that a carefully designed exercise program significantly reduces pain and increases ability to function.

title: John Barrett, 95, Urban League Chairman
description: John J. Barrett, a Manhattan lawyer and former chairman of the New York Urban League, died on Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 95 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about the Windows CE operating system misspelled the name of a pocket-size personal organizer made by Casio Inc. that uses the system. It is the Cassiopeia, not Casiopeia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENEFICK, WILLIAM J.
description: KENEFICK-William J. Age 74 of Vershire, VT, formerly of NY died November 28, 1999 in Lebanon, NH. Born February 28, 1925 in Brooklyn, son of George and Irene (McLaughlin) Kenefick. Educated in NY schools including Queens College and Columbia University. Veteran of W.W. II. Retired from Sikorsky Aircraft, Stratford, CT. in 1991. Moved to VT. permanently in 1994. He was an expert class amateur radio operator call letters AD1I. Survived by beloved wife Marie (Doran) Kenefick, Vershire, Vt, two sons, James F., Reston, VA, Robert W., Portsmouth, NH, daughter Patricia Ann, Aliso Viejo, CA, and a sister Irene Kenefick, Waterbury Ctr VT. A funeral mass will be held December 3, 11:00 am, St. Anthony's Catholic Church, Bethel, VT. Calling hours Thursday December 2, 7-9 PM. Day Funeral Home Randolph, VT. Donations to American Cancer Society 13 Loomis St., Montpelier, VT 05602.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, RITA
description: KAUFMAN-Rita. The Kaufman, Lindenbaum, Newman, and Hurwich families mourn the passing of Rita Kaufman. Loving wife of the late Benjamin Kaufman. Cherished mother of the late Judith (and Baruch Hurwich), Gerald (and Carol Kaufman), Belda (and Marcel Lindenbaum) and Carol (and Melvin Newman). Beloved Nana to seventeen grandchildren, twenty five great-grandchildren and hundreds who were lucky enough to know her. Nana was the matriarch of a close and loving family. Larger than life, she made a lasting impression on everyone she met. She embodied the Jewish values of love of family, hospitality toward guests, learning and charity, and she passed these values on to her children and grandchildren. She is also survived by sister & brothers Hilda Riback, Harry Skydell, Adrian Skydell, Irving Skydell and Anita Chanowitz. She cared for us all, we will miss her. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, November 30 at 12:15 P.M. at Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, 125 E. 85 Street, NY, NY.

title: No More Giveaway Computers. Free-PC to Be Bought by eMachines.
description: As it turns out, there is no such thing as a free PC.

title: More Vie for Slots on the Senior Varsity
description: After not having touched a basketball for nearly half a century, 63-year-old Aldona Siuta of Avon, Conn., decided last year that it was time to fulfill her hoop dreams: she laced up a pair of high tops and threw herself into a twice-weekly women's over-50 pick-up game she had read about in her local paper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFIN, KATHRYN RENATE
description: JAFFIN-Kathryn Renate. On November 27. Adoring mother of Madeleine R. Kania. Devoted grandmother of Jennifer Ann and Laura Jean Kania. Proud motherin-law of Robert J. Kania. Devoted wife of 52 years to the late Theodore S. Jaffin. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Wednesday, December 1, 11:30 AM. Interment Ferncliff Cemetery, Ardsley, NY.

title: Va. Tech Appears A Sugar Bowl Lock
description: B.C.S.

title: A Night of Fisticuffs, Not High Kicks
description: The chocolate-dipped strawberries were large and luscious. The Champagne was perfectly chilled. The string quartet was melodiously soothing. Boxing was the only thing that seemed out of place at Radio City Music Hall yesterday.

title: CHESAPEAKE IS ACQUIRING 14.9% STAKE IN SHOREWOOD
description: The Chesapeake Corporation, the biggest North American maker of point-of-purchase displays, said yesterday that it had acquired a 14.9 percent stake in the Shorewood Packaging Corporation for $70.7 million, part of its effort to acquire Shorewood through a $740 million hostile takeover. Chesapeake said it planned to buy about 4.1 million Shorewood shares from Ariel Capital Management Inc. for $17.25 a share. Shorewood manufactures boxes for hair-care products, videos and drugs. The takeover battle began on Nov. 18, when both companies rejected each other's acquisition offers. The shares of Chesapeake, based in Richmond, Va., fell 25 cents, to $32.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. Shorewood rose $1.625, to $15.75.

title: With Ward On Target, Lights Out For Dallas
description: Soon after the start of the third quarter last night, Charlie Ward realized he was free and clear from any defenders. Dallas Coach Don Nelson was daring him to bury his depleted team -- ''Most teams do,'' Ward said -- and the Knicks' point guard measured his footing behind the 3-point arc and fired. And fired. And fired.

title: When Ravel Hears a Waltz, It's Schubert's
description: Typically, only pianists with formidable techniques win prizes at international piano competitions. But when it comes to rewarding fine musicianship, these controversial events have been far less reliable.

title: Review of Police Lab Faults Chemists, Hindering Accreditation
description: A team from a national group that accredits law enforcement laboratories found that six chemists in the New York Police Department's crime laboratory gave inadequate answers when asked about the procedures for identifying illegal drugs, officials from the department said yesterday.

title: Mattress Store Experiments With Non-Blowout Sale
description: From The Onion:

title: CANADIAN TELECOMMUNICATIONS DEAL
description: Canada's largest competitive provider of long-distance and local telephone services, AT&T Canada Inc., agreed to acquire TigerTel Inc., the Canadian telecommunications subsidiary of Applied Digital Solutions Inc., for $47 million. Toronto-based AT&T Canada had revenue of $354 million in the nine months ended Sept. 30. TigerTel, based in Toronto, had revenue of $24 million in the nine months ended Sept. 30. Applied Digital, a Palm Beach, Fla., provider of Internet telecommunications services to businesses, owns 65 percent of TigerTel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLLNER, EDWARD H.
description: WOLLNER-Edward H. Of New York, Florida and, most recently, Washington, D.C. Died peacefully November 28, 1999 after 92 wonderful years of life. He had retired in 1988 after 60 years in the advertising & printing industries. He was the beloved husband of Harriet S. Wollner (deceased), devoted father of Linda (David) Cashdan of Washington, D.C. and Donald (Martha) Wollner of Brooklyn, N.Y. and adoring grandfather of Melanie Cashdan, Richard Cashdan and Preston Wollner.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, ANNE
description: BLUM-Anne. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue records with sorrow the passing of the mother of our esteemed member Dr. Gerald Blum and extends to him and the family our heartfelt condolences.

title: The Future of Trade, According to Gates
description: To the Editor:

title: Bethel Leslie, 70, an Actress In Theater, Television and Films
description: Bethel Leslie, a lifelong presence onstage and on television whose final Broadway performance earned her a Tony nomination, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 70.

title: New Book Challenges Theories of AIDS Origins
description: Is AIDS a disaster inadvertently brought on by humans in the early testing of a polio vaccine in Africa in the 1950's?

title: Use Helmets, Surgeons Tell Young Sledders
description: Zooming out of control down a long snowy slope on a sled or saucer is part of what makes winter winter. But it can also lead to severe, even lifelong, injuries.

title: Yeltsin Hospitalized; Pneumonia Is Suspected
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin was hospitalized today for the second time in less than two months after doctors detected what might be pneumonia during a checkup, his press secretary said.

title: Russian Army Says Chechen Resistance Is Growing Stiffer
description: After two months of steady advances into Chechnya's heartland, the Russian military said today that it is beginning to encounter serious resistance from Islamic militants, and that the fighting is likely to intensify in the next few weeks.

title: Hearing From Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, , MAE
description: ROSNER--Mae. On November 29, 1999. Predeceased by her siblings Rose Amster, Harry and Moe. Dear aunt of Joyce Mace, Richard Amster and David Rosner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STADLEN, CAL A.
description: STADLEN-Cal A. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and brother. 1915-1999. Rest in peace from your long travail.

title: Troubadour Updated, Edged With Melancholy
description: ''I've always had this passion, really, for exotic dancers and the sensual, sexual magic they make,'' murmured Marc Almond on Sunday at the Bowery Ballroom. Ready as always to spread a little passion, he then invited a highly toned, scantily clad stud introduced as Ivan to play muse during ''Lonely Go-Go Dancer,'' from the new album, ''Open All Night'' (Instinct/Blue Star).

title: George Magazine Names Editor to Replace Kennedy
description: Undaunted by the prospect and challenges of stepping into a role established by John F. Kennedy Jr., Frank Lalli, a former managing editor of Money magazine, has agreed to take over as editor in chief of George magazine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRETT, JOHN J.
description: BARRETT-John J. Age 95, died November 26, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Josephine. Brother of Oscar, uncle of Audrey, Pamela and Cassin, loving greatuncle and great-great-uncle. Counsel to the firm of Kirkpatrick and Lockhart, and a Founding Partner of the former Barrett, Smith, Schapiro, Simon and Armstrong firm. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated, Wednesday at 10 AM, St. Monica's Church, 413 East 79th Street at 1st Avenue. Visitation Monday 7-9, and Tuesday 3-5 and 7-9, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The New York Urban League, 204 W. 136th St, New York, N.Y. 10030.

title: Far From Bel Canto Flights of Fancy
description: Vesselina Kasarova gave her first recital in the United States on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, but she is not unknown here. In recent seasons this Bulgarian mezzo-soprano has appeared in starring roles with the Opera Orchestra of New York, and she has made a handful of recordings for RCA. These were enough to guarantee a sold-out house for her recital, part of Lincoln Center's Great Performers series. Her program was devoted to Schubert, Brahms and Schumann, a change from the bel canto flights of ''I Capuleti e i Montecchi,'' the Bellini opera she sang in New York recently.

title: Sorting Out Contenders In Tourneys
description: N.C.A.A.

title: Robotic Adventurer Aims for Mars' South Pole
description: Less than a century after explorers made their first heroic assault on the poles of Earth, an American spacecraft is racing toward Mars and the first landing in the polar region of another planet.

title: Can Doctors Curb Medical Costs?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Surge in Carry-Ons
description: To the Editor:

title: Scuttled by Its Wary Publisher, Bush Biography Finds New One
description: Soft Skull Press, an irreverent micro-publisher that got its start in a Kinko's copy store, is reviving a disputed biography of George W. Bush that was recalled last month amid revelations that the author had a criminal record.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; In the Seesaw of Currencies, the Dollar Stands Tall in the Middle
description: ONE constant of financial markets is that they regularly defy expectations. It means that losers can be winners, analysts are caught off guard and explanations of what is occurring must sometimes be given with a shrug of the shoulders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNCH, LUKE DANIEL, SR.
description: LYNCH-Luke Daniel, Sr. Died peacefully after a long illness on November 27, 1999 in Naples, Fla. Beloved husband of Marjorie for 55 years. Devoted father of Luke Jr. (Nancy), Dorsey (Joyce), and Dan (Cornelia) Lynch and Carol Manire (Michael). Big Chief to 11 grandchildren. Brother of James. Mr. Lynch was born in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn on August 2, 1921. He graduated from Regis High School in N.Y.C. (1939), attended Fordham University and graduated in 1944 from the U.S. Naval Academy (Class of 1945). While at the Naval Academy, he was class vice-president, played varsity basketball and baseball, was a company commander and a five-striper. He served in the Pacific Theater on the U.S.S. Alabama, which participated in the Japanese surrender at Tokyo Bay. After the war, he graduated from Columbia Law School (1949), and went on to a career specializing in insurance and reinsurance law. Mr. Lynch was a former senior partner of Mendes & Mount as well as LeBouef, Lamb & Leiby, where he represented Lloyds of London. At the time of his death, Mr. Lynch was a senior partner of the law firm of D'Amato & Lynch in N.Y.C. and a Director of Queens County Savings Bank. He was a former president of the Cherry Valley Club in Garden City, NY. The family will receive visitors Thursday, December 2, from 7-9, at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Ave, Garden City. A memorial service will be held on Friday, December 3 at 11AM, St. Joseph's Church, Fifth Street and Franklin Ave, Garden City. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the U.S. Naval Academy Alumni Association-Class of 1945 Fund, U.S. Naval Academy, Annapolis, MD.

title: 14 Across: Fame
description: To the Editor:

title: CONTINENTAL AIRLINES INCREASING STOCK REPURCHASE
description: Continental Airlines Inc., the fifth-largest United States airline, said yesterday that it would increase its stock repurchase by $400 million, to $1.2 billion, because of its gain from the sale of a stake in the Amadeus reservations system. The airline also said it would take a $50 million fourth-quarter charge to retire some planes early and reduce growth in hopes of buoying average air fares. Continental's shares declined 62.5 cents yesterday, to $36.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Coke Promotion Is Halted
description: Coca-Cola said today that it would end a promotion in Belgium after a court ruled the company had abused its position as that nation's largest maker of soft drinks.

title: COLUMBIA/HCA REPURCHASING $1 BILLION IN STOCK
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, the hospital operator, said yesterday that it would repurchase up to $1 billion of its shares as it worked to settle federal fraud charges that have held down its stock price. Columbia/HCA has repurchased about $3 billion of its shares since 1997, when federal agents raided its operation in El Paso, Tex., at the beginning of an investigation into allegations of fraudulent billing of Medicare and other government health programs. Shares of Columbia/HCA fell 25 cents yesterday, to $26.50. Companies repurchase shares when they believe they are undervalued.

title: Apartheid's Legacy Leaves Poorest Adrift
description: The city councilman strode through the black section of town on a recent day and proudly pointed out the progress.

title: Navy Petty Officer Is Accused Of Giving Russia Information
description: A Navy code expert has been charged with passing secrets to Russia five years ago, military officials said tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LLOYD, JONES, DONALD J.
description: LLOYD-JONES-Donald J., Dr. The American Geographical Society notes with profound sorrow the death on November 29, 1999 of its president, Dr. Donald J. LloydJones. His remarkable leadership, judgement, vision, devotion, and generosity will be deeply missed. In particular, the dynamic guidance he provided to the Society as its treasurer in the 1970s and as its president in the 1990s will long benefit the Society and all it serves. The memorial service will be held at 2:00 pm on Friday, December 3 at St. Joseph of Arimathea Church, 2172 Saw Mill River Road, Elmsford, New York 10607 (914) 592-7163. The family has requested that, in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to the church or to the American Geographical Society, 120 Wall Street, Suite 100, New York, New York 10005. Richard H. Nolte Chairman Emeritus John E. Gould Chairman William P. Doyle Executive Vice President Mary Lynne Bird Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORETZKY, GERTRUDE
description: KORETZKY-Gertrude, 83. Of New York City. On November 28, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Boris Koretzky. Services to be announced at a later date.

title: Pondering Next Rung on the Evolutionary Ladder
description: If evolution is still unfolding, and most scientists believe it is, just how complex an organism could the evolutionary process create, before hitting some fundamental limit?

title: A Romance With a Rain Forest and Its Elusive Miracles
description: It has the makings of a good story and Dr. Mark J. Plotkin clearly relishes the beginning. If only it had a happy ending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, IRVING
description: SILVERMAN-Irving, passed away on November 24, 1999 in Deerfield Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Claire. Adored father of Lew and Betty. Brother of Claire Israel and the late Lillian Kwartler. Cherished grandfather of Caryn and Steven.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: News Analysis; The Strike At Ballet Doesn't Turn On Money
description: The French composer Darius Milhaud was asked by a cousin if all the instruments he wrote into a symphonic score should be played together. ''Preferably,'' he replied.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOMBERG, ALLAN E., MD.
description: BLOOMBERG-Allan E., MD. The Montefiore Staff and Alumni Association records with sorrow the loss of our esteemed past president and longstanding member of its Executive Committee. He will be remembered as an innovative and accomplished surgeon and a true gentleman. Our sincere condolences to his family. Jacqueline A. Bello, MD President Margaret Pinsker Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SISKIND, MOLLY
description: SISKIND-Molly. On November 28, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Theodore. Loving mother of Marion Liebowitz, mother-in-law of Dr. Martin Liebowitz. Cherished grandmother to Jonathan, David, Amy & great grandmother to Anna, Jordan, Kara, Andrea, Jennifer and Tamara. Services Wednesday 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: VITAL SIGNS: BEHAVIOR; When Guns Spell Danger for the Owner
description: People who buy handguns are more likely to kill themselves than people who do not, even up to six years after the purchase, and women who buy guns are doubling their risk of becoming murder victims, concluded a study published Nov. 18 in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Guster's Stand: Success Through True Believers
description: Guster, the trio that sold out the Hammerstein Ballroom on Saturday night, plays tuneful, wistful songs that recall hits by bands like Semi sonic and the Goo Goo Dolls. The group records for the major label Sire, and may still find fame through soundtracks and radio play, like those groups. Its latest album, ''Lost and Gone Forever,'' was produced by Steve Lillywhite, who has helped shape the modern rock roster, from U2 to the Dave Matthews Band. When Mr. Lillywhite emerged to play some peppy bass lines, Guster's lead singer, Ryan Miller, quickly quoted U2's smash ''Sunday Bloody Sunday.'' It was a hopeful gesture.

title: Approval Expected For Yankee Nets
description: The YankeeNets merger is expected to be approved by baseball owners today at their meeting in Dallas, according to an official of the basketball team, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified.

title: After Outburst, Parcells Tells Johnson: Hush
description: Bill Parcells, who can lash out with the best of them, gave a more or less friendly warning to the voluble Keyshawn Johnson today. Watch your words, the coach told Johnson, the Jets' standout receiver.

title: Picking a New Coach is Old Hat for MetroStars
description: The following should sound familiar: The MetroStars have a new coach, their sixth in four years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPERMAN, EUGENE
description: COOPERMAN-Eugene. Age 77. Died November 26, 1999 of cancer of the esophagus & stomach after a long and painful illness. Resident of Westport, CT., and New York City. Devoted husband of Frances. Proud father of Roberta Penziner and Debbie Quigg. Beloved grandfather of Alyssa, Mara, Jodi, Denise and Tina.

title: Clinton Signs Final Budget Bill and Turns to Next Year
description: Nearly two months after the start of the government's fiscal year, President Clinton signed the last piece of the federal budget into law today, saying the agreement that he worked out with the Republican-led Congress had been worth the weeks of tortured negotiations.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CULVER HOLDINGS P.L.C., Cardiff, Wales, said its subsidiary, WorldTravel Direct, had acquired the travel company Powerflyer.com Inc., San Jose, Calif., to expand its Internet-based travel business.

title: Alarm Over AZT
description: To the Editor:

title: Alain Peyrefitte, 74, French Conservative Writer
description: Alain Peyrefitte, a French journalist, best-selling author, former cabinet minister and confidant of de Gaulle, died on Saturday in Paris. He was 74.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUDENBERGER, HERBERT J.
description: FREUDENBERGER-Herbert J. The Frankfurt born psychoanalyst and renowned author who coined the word ''burnout'' in the 1970's and gave a prescription for ''burnout'', died on Monday in New York City. He was 73. The author of more than 35 books and articles was awarded in September of 1999 in Boston by the American Psychological Association The Gold Medal Award, recognizing his outstanding achievements in the field of psychotherapy. Dr. Freudenberger wrote many books including the seminal work in ''Burnout''. Dr. Freudenberger has been cited and appeared on many news and TV programs. He was often cited in numerous national publications. He was a private practitioner and group therapist in Manhattan for more than 40 years. He sat on numerous Washington lobby groups and was one of the founding members of the National Association of Practitioners, and a critical board member of many divisions of the APA. Dr. Freudenberger is survived by his beloved wife Arlene; and his three much loved children, Lisa Freudenberger Roth and her husband Theodore, Marc Freud and his wife Nikki and Lori Freudenberger. The funeral will be held Wednesday at the Sinai/Free Synagogue of Westchester, Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Can Doctors Curb Medical Costs?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sacrifices for Needy Kin
description: To the Editor:

title: VITAL SIGNS: PATTERNS; On the Trail of a Gene for Stuttering
description: A study comparing identical and fraternal twins in Australia found evidence that stuttering and its severity may have a genetic basis.

title: Russia Discloses Details of Its Former Chemical Arms Program
description: Not long after Congress cut American assistance to Russian programs aimed at destroying chemical weapons stockpiles, Russia has disclosed new details about its former chemical weapons program.

title: Freedom Begins With Elation and Prayer
description: One of the first things that Nasser K. Ahmed did in his first hour of freedom last night was to pray for five minutes at the Al-Bader mosque, about a half-block from his apartment in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn.

title: Abroad at Home; George W.'s Answer
description: A small incident may give us crucial insight into the character of a presidential candidate. That happened last week when George W. Bush appeared on the NBC television program ''Meet the Press.''

title: What Do Physicists Fret About? Nothing
description: Like the sorcerer's apprentice, who could not banish the spirits that his spells had conjured up, astronomers around the world have been trying, with increasing desperation, to disprove an astonishing discovery announced early last year: distant galaxies are being swept apart, ever faster, by a tide formed of apparently empty space.

title: 3 Airlines Reverse Course on Raising Fares, for Now
description: A 3 percent rise in air fares last week was quietly rolled back when American Airlines, Continental Airlines and United Airlines threw in the towel -- American on Sunday, Continental and United yesterday. But analysts say that sooner or later, probably sooner, the airlines will try to raise fares again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERKEL, EVA
description: MERKEL-Eva. On November 28, age 68, from complications after heart surgery. Beloved wife of Herbert Salten and the late Edgar Merkel, daughter of Marianne Forgan and the late Ernest Forgan, mother of Stephen Marcus Merkel and Dr. Peter Alexander Merkel, mother-in-law of Robin Shanus and Dr. Laura Dember, stepmother of Miriam Kotsonis and stepmother-in-law of John Kotsonis, grandmother of David Edgar Merkel, David Kotsonis and Rebecca Kotsonis, cousin, sisterin-law, aunt, great aunt and devoted teacher, principally at Greenburgh Central 7. Funeral Wednesday 10:00 AM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, New York, 914-664-6800. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services.

title: Q & A: N.F.L. Playoffs With Judy Battista
description: The Giants, looking to repeat as Super Bowl champions, will take the field against the Eagles for the third time this season when the two teams meet in the N.F.C. divisional playoff game at Giants Stadium on Sunday. This is probably not the team the Giants wanted to see to start their playoff run, writes Judy Battista, who covers the N.F.L. for The Times.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the decline in the euro, and a contents entry on Page A1, misstated the currency's closing price in some editions. In New York on Friday, the euro settled at $1.0156, not $1.1056.

title: Mannesmann's Chief Sees A Future Without Vodafone
description: Fighting the largest hostile-takeover attempt ever made, Klaus Esser, chief executive of Mannesmann of Germany, began a long-awaited defense today against the wireless giant Vodafone AirTouch, arguing that the $127.7 billion bid was too low and forecasting that his own company would enjoy booming growth for years -- alone.

title: Stanton Stays; Cone's Status Is Still in Limbo
description: The Yankees formally announced yesterday that Mike Stanton would return as their left-handed setup man -- for three years at a salary of $7.35 million -- a signing that had been expected for almost three weeks. Stanton did not want to leave the World Series champions and the Yankees did not want to lose Stanton and then have to search for a reliable lefty reliever.

title: G.E. MAKES DEAL TO BUY MECON, A SOFTWARE MAKER
description: The General Electric Company, the biggest medical-imaging equipment maker, agreed to buy Mecon Inc. for about $81.2 million in stock to acquire software that lets hospitals compare prices for supplies over the Internet. G.E. will pay $11.25 in stock for each Mecon share. GE Medical Systems, based in Milwaukee, is adding to the range of services that it sells through the Internet Mecon's software helps hospitals manage costs more efficiently. Mecon granted G.E. an option to acquire newly issued shares, representing 19.9 percent of those outstanding. Shares of Mecon, based in San Ramon, Calif., rose $1.375 each, to $10.75. General Electric fell $2.50, to $133.125.

title: Public Interests; Long Shots Anonymous
description: This Thursday, George W. Bush is going to emerge from his burrow and take part in a debate with the other Republican presidential candidates in New Hampshire. Unless, of course, he sees his shadow. In that case we will have six more weeks of autumn, during which the governor of Texas will have to stay home and squire his wife to more awards ceremonies.

title: New Reform Party Does Poorly in Malaysian Election
description: Malaysia's fledgling reform movement made few inroads on Monday in a parliamentary election that returned Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad to power after a campaign that stressed stability and economic well-being.

title: New York State Earns Top Dollar From Collect Calls by Its Inmates
description: Ruth Smith said a telephone call from prison had been a way for her cousin to speak to his dying mother. For Tulen Rivera, the calls from prison are an opportunity for her three boys to speak with their father. For Ruby Jackson, speaking by phone with her imprisoned husband is a chance to talk without having to spend eight hours on an overnight bus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIRINSKY, KATHRYN ANN
description: ZIRINSKY-Kathryn Ann, 44, on November 24, 1999, after a courageous battle with colon cancer. Devoted wife of Robert. Adored Mom and best friend of Ralph, Elissa and Harry. Beloved daughter of Phyllis and Thomas Sinatra. Dear sister of Nina, Frank and Carla. Cherished daughter-in-law of Ruth. Memorial service 4pm Wednesday December 1, 1999 at the Hewitt Elementary School, corner DeMott and Hempstead Avenues, Rockville Centre. Receiving at our home Tuesday evening and after the memorial service. No flowers or baskets, please. We request that all donations in memory of Kathryn be sent to the James F. Holland, M.D. Research Fund, Mount Sinai Medical Center-Development Office, 1 Gustave L. Levy Pl., N.Y., NY 10029.

title: VITAL SIGNS: SIDE EFFECTS; Hold the Phone, Save the Brain
description: Cradling the phone between the neck and shoulder is certainly not good for the neck. But for one French psychiatrist it was bad for his brain, too.

title: Unions Find the Holidays A Time to Ask and Receive
description: Many are the signs of the holidays: the lines at Macy's, the traffic in Midtown, the Christmas tree vendors taking up stations on the street. And now comes another: the threat of labor strife.

title: For Oil Workers, Merger Is Just Another Word for More Layoffs
description: BEAUMONT, Tex., Nov. 29 -- They have been downsized, cut back and re-engineered. So when the 900 or so remaining blue-collar workers here at Mobil's largest domestic refinery, out of about 1,500 a decade ago, heard last week that their company was discussing a possible merger with Exxon, it was like a siren warning them that an already suspect valve might be about to blow.
